headline: Alabama Democrat Toes the G.O.P. Line
text: ANDALUSIA, Ala.  Among the men who gather every morning at 6 o’clock at the Church’s Chicken here on Three Notch Street, there is general agreement that the Obama administration is doing a very bad job of running the country. And the stakes are as high, as one coffee drinker put it, as the survival of the country’s culture, economy and way of life.

headline: Danish Police Start Inquiry in Cartoonist Attack
text: OSLO  The Danish police have ransacked three apartments in an attempt to determine whether a 28-year-old immigrant from Somalia acted on his own initiative on Friday when he was suspected of trying to kill a newspaper cartoonist whose 2005 drawing of the Prophet Muhammad set off pitched riots among offended Muslims in the Middle East and elsewhere.

headline: Another Chance to Dine With André
text: Good dinner companions are hard to find, especially in this era of distracted iPhone-texters and constant tweeters. Take a break from the digital age and head to the Walter Reade Theater tonight for a screening of “My Dinner With Andreé,” part of a series devoted to the French director Louis Malle. This 1981 film stars Wallace Shawn (he co-wrote it with André Gregory), as Wally, a playwright in an oversize raincoat who takes acting jobs when he can get them to make ends meet. In his original review for The Times, Vincent Canby wrote, “ ‘My Dinner With Andre’ is just that, nearly two hours of talk about theater, art, life, electric blankets and Western Civilization, over dinner.” Bon appétit.

headline: Iranian Filmmakers Keep Focus on the Turmoil
text: CAIRO  Iran’s government cannot silence the filmmakers.

headline: Nuance Communications Buys SpinVox, Which Converts Voice Mail to Text
text: SpinVox, a former high-flying British start-up that developed a system for converting telephone voice-mail messages to text, has been sold to an American software provider for less than a quarter of the valuation it once commanded.

headline: Out of the Mouth of Ryan, a Soundtrack of the Jets’ Ups and Downs
text: In his first season as the Jets’ coach, Rex Ryan talked. And talked. And talked some more.

headline: Billionaire’s Ex-Wife Hires New Lawyer in Civil Suit
text: Patricia Cohen, the ex-wife of the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen, has a new lawyer representing her in the civil racketeering lawsuit she filed against Mr. Cohen.

headline: Trivial Pursuit
text: Start the New Year off right by exercising your brain as well as your body. Tonight, Le Poisson Rouge is hosting the Big Quiz Thing, a live trivia event that has been running since 2002. Beginning at 7:30, the quizmaster Noah Tarnow will be on hand to present questions onstage and on a video screen while groups of contestants collaborate to produce answers and vie for a chance to win $250. We suggest studying up ahead of time for a special round of “Rebus in Peace,” which requires contestants to guess the names of celebrities who have died in the past year based on clever clues. Why let that People magazine subscription go to waste?

headline: Doing the Wamble Twang
text: “Doug Wamble specializes in a rustic Southern sound, from the bluesy cry of his vocals to the quavering twang of his acoustic guitar,” writes Nate Chinen. “He’s a magnetic performer even by himself; in a working band like the one he leads here, with Rich Hinman on pedal-steel guitar and Jeff Hanley on bass, he can be gripping.” Mr. Wamble, who hails from Tennessee, will be at Bar Next Door on Macdougal Street tonight beginning at 8:30 p.m., with another show at 10:30.

headline: Limbaugh to Resume Radio Show on Wednesday
text: Rush Limbaugh will return to his talk show on Wednesday, two days later than planned, after a two-day stay at a hospital in Hawaii.

headline: Knicks Take Out Pacers, and Suspense, Early
text: There were 3 minutes 26 seconds left in the first quarter Sunday night, the Knicks up by 15 over the Indiana Pacers. Suddenly, the decibel level started to rise at Madison Square Garden. Some fans even stood and clapped. Al Harrington and Nate Robinson were reporting in, and the summer-warm welcome was not for Harrington.

headline: Inside the Classroom
text: Teach for America is nearing its 20th anniversary and has 17,000 alumni who committed two years of their lives to teaching in some of the nation’s most troubled schools. One person currently in the program is David Donaldson, who teaches English at a charter school in Baltimore.

headline: Seymour Wittek Dies at 88; World War II Hero at Home
text: Seymour Wittek, a former Coast Guardsman who helped battle a fire that threatened to devastate New York Harbor during World War II, and six decades later gained the recognition he coveted for his unit’s heroism, died Wednesday at a hospital in the Bronx. Mr. Wittek, who lived in Ossining, N.Y., was 88.

headline: Media Equation: And a Tablet Will Lead Them …
text: In today’s Media Equation, David Carr writes:

headline: Through Ups and Downs of Illness, Creativity Endures
text: Janet Dennard can still hear the hum of her sewing machine. Late at night, the memory of it lulls her back to sleep.

headline: At a Botanica, New Year Means Renewal, and Jinx Removal
text: Cecilia Oliver was having a problem with her lover and needed some help. “He’s being resistant,” she explained. “I want where he’s submissive to me at all times.”

headline: Suffolk County Executive Weighing Primary Challenge to Paterson
text: The first politician to announce a possible primary challenge to Gov. David A. Paterson is a well-financed, conservative Democrat  and his last name is not Cuomo.

headline: Authority Seeks Bids for Partner on Tower
text: The central tower at ground zero, designed to rise to 105 stories, has been characterized by some as a symbol of New York’s resilience, and reviled by others as a white elephant. Now it will pick up a new label: for sale.

headline: Union’s Money Fueled Lavish Lifestyle, Prosecutors Say
text: In her working hours, Melissa G. King administered benefit funds for the sandhogs’ union, associating with the muscled and plain-spoken men who blast through earth and darkness to build tunnels beneath the city.

headline: Muslim Deli Owners Must Choose Koran or Customers
text: Most of Khairul Kabir’s customers at the Madison Deli and Grocery in East Harlem do not realize that his jovial smile masks a lingering sense of shame.

headline: Parolee Held in Boy’s Killing Was Mentally Ill, Mother Says
text: The man accused of fatally stabbing a 9-year-old boy in an Upper Manhattan apartment over the weekend has suffered from schizophrenia for many years and was paroled from prison in May after serving five years for assault, according to family members and the police.

headline: Deborah Howell, One of the First Women to Lead a Big U.S. Paper, Dies at 68
text: Deborah Howell, one of the first women to become the top editor of a large American newspaper, died Friday in New Zealand, where she was struck by a car while on foot. She was 68 years old and lived in Washington.

headline: Neediest | Looking Ahead
text: Janet Dennard, who has struggled with bipolar disorder and a frayed relationship with her daughter, channels her creative energy into sewing.

headline: Next Up on Cable TV, Higher Bill for Consumers
text: The performances on “American Idol” may be erratic and the plot twists on “Lost” may be unpredictable, but one facet of television is certain: the costs just keep going up.

headline: The Smartphone Makes and Breaks
text: What will the mobile phone devour next? It swallowed up the personal digital assistant, the gadget that defined the beginning of the last decade, and is eating through the landline telephone, digital camera, MP3 player and even the wristwatch. The creative destruction has just begun.

headline: Yes, It Was Torture, and Illegal
text: Bush administration officials came up with all kinds of ridiculously offensive rationalizations for torturing prisoners. It’s not torture if you don’t mean it to be. It’s not torture if you don’t nearly kill the victim. It’s not torture if the president says it’s not torture.

headline: Where the Action Is on Climate
text: Even as many members of Congress resist as too hard or too costly the steps necessary to address global warming, American cities and states  the largest of which have carbon footprints bigger than those of most nations  have quietly been making serious commitments to curb emissions. Instead of finding reasons to do nothing, Congress should build on these actions to fashion a national response to climate change.

headline: Prisons and Budgets
text: The United States, which has less than 5 percent of the world’s population, has about one-quarter of its prisoners. But the relentless rise in the nation’s prison population has suddenly slowed as many states discover that it is simply too expensive to overincarcerate.

headline: Really Big Money Politics
text: The nation’s hard times are proving to be boom times for the lobbying industry in Washington. Lobbyists are expected to easily break their record of $3.3 billion in annual business, raising an inevitable question: How much more in special-interest donations will be bagged by lawmakers as they are furiously lobbied on everything from health care reform to economic regulation?

headline: That 1937 Feeling
text: Here’s what’s coming in economic news: The next employment report could show the economy adding jobs for the first time in two years. The next G.D.P. report is likely to show solid growth in late 2009. There will be lots of bullish commentary  and the calls we’re already hearing for an end to stimulus, for reversing the steps the government and the Federal Reserve took to prop up the economy, will grow even louder.

headline: Decline Is Relative
text: Here in the United States, we spent New Year’s weekend bidding good riddance to the awful, awful aughties  a miserable decade of bubbles and busts, rising health care bills and soaring deficits, domestic terror attacks and overseas quagmires.

headline: 4 Afghan War Veterans Look Back, and Ahead
text: WASHINGTON  One of them, an Army Ranger who served three tours in Afghanistan, led a team into a treacherous mountain ravine to recover the remains of 16 American commandos shot down in a helicopter crash. He still remembers how only their boots had been taken off their bodies by the Taliban.

headline: Jan. 3: Vikings Beat Giants
text: The Vikings rolled up 487 yards of offense in routing the Giants, 44-7.

headline: NBC to Bulk Up Olympic Coverage
text: NBC will augment its multi-network event coverage of next month’s Winter Olympics in Vancouver with news and studio programming on Universal Sports.

headline: Criticized as Too Sedate, Public Advocate’s Office Intends to Get Louder
text: In a challenge to the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the city’s new public advocate, Bill de Blasio, will unveil a plan on Monday to train aggrieved residents to organize petition drives, demonstrations and civic actions against City Hall.

headline: Warm Feelings at Least as Fans Bid Farewell
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets and the Giants want the N.F.L. to stage a Super Bowl outdoors in the Meadowlands in February 2014 at the new stadium they will share beginning next season.

text: Charles Johnson, left, of Little Green Footballs and Conn Carroll of The Heritage Foundation debate extremism on the right.

headline: Trying to Add Portability to Movie Files
text: It is easy to take a DVD to a friend’s house and watch it on his TV. But things are more complicated when digital video downloads are involved. A movie file bought from Blockbuster.com will not work on a Sony HDTV, for example, and videos from iTunes work only on devices with Apple software.

headline: Word of the Day | provocative
text: provocative •\prə-ˈvä-kə-tiv\• adjective

headline: Jets Rout Bengals and Clinch Playoff Berth
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On Sunday night, in the bitter cold, the Jets played in the final N.F.L. game of the regular season. They most likely played in the final N.F.L. game at Giants Stadium. But they did not play in the final game of their season, a notion that seemed impossible even to their coach three games ago.

headline: Gay in Uganda, and Feeling Hunted
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  Isolation, insults, threats and violence: this is what Uganda’s mostly closeted gay community has dealt with for years.

headline: Iraqracy
text: BAGHDAD – The old year ended here with mortar shells falling on the heavily fortified Green Zone and with the sounds of scattered gunfire, another reminder of how horrible that past decade had been. The New Year began with an assurance and a continuing mystery.

headline: Bernanke Blames Weak Rules for Crisis
text: Regulatory failure, not low interest rates, was responsible for the housing bubble and subsequent financial crisis of the last decade, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in a speech on Sunday, Catherine Rampell writes in The New York Times.

headline: Brad Smith Adds Unpredictability to Jets’ Conservative Game Plan
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Technically, the Jets’ Brad Smith is a wide receiver, listed as second on the depth chart behind Braylon Edwards.

headline: Jets Win and They're In
text: With a 37-0 victory over the Bengals, the Jets clinched a postseason berth in their regular-season finale.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Consider Easing Informant’s Term
text: The Justice Department is weighing whether to ask a federal judge to reduce the jail sentence of a former UBS banker who was a main figure in a wide-ranging tax evasion case against wealthy American clients, a person briefed on the matter said, Lynnley Browning writes in The New York Times.

headline: Living With Less and Liking It
text: WHOM do you know whose priorities have shifted from buying products to doing activities with friends and loved ones as a result of the recession?

headline: Yemen Says It Killed Militants as Three More Embassies Shut
text: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni government forces killed two suspected militants with Al Qaeda on Monday and wounded others in a firefight 25 miles north of this capital city, Yemeni officials said, tying the militants to the continuing threats directed against the United States and British Embassies here.

headline: South Korea Renews Offer of Liaison Offices
text: SEOUL, South Korea  President Lee Myung-bak renewed a proposal Monday that South and North Korea open liaison offices in each other’s capitals to facilitate dialogue.

headline: An Investment Chief at Third Avenue Is Said to Step Down
text: Martin J. Whitman, Veteran value investor, will relinquish his role as Third Avenue Management‘s co-chief investment officer, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Leader of Junta Confirms Myanmar Is Planning 2010 Elections
text: HONG KONG  The head of the military junta in Myanmar confirmed Monday that it was planning to hold national elections this year.

headline: Has the Financial Center Crown Lost Its Luster?
text: Three years ago, New York authorities worried that London might steal their city’s crown as the world’s financial capital. That distinction now looks much less desirable, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: Obama’s War Over Terror
text: The evening before he was sworn into office, Barack Obama stepped out of Blair House, the government residence where he was staying across from the White House, and climbed into an armored limousine for the ride to a bipartisan dinner. Joining him in the back seat were John Brennan, his new counterterrorism adviser, and two foreign-policy advisers, Denis McDonough and Mark Lippert. The three men with the president-elect were out of breath, having rushed more than a mile from transition headquarters on foot after failing to find a taxi in Washington’s preinaugural madness. As the motorcade moved out, they updated Obama on gathering evidence of a major terrorist plot to attack his inauguration. After a weekend of round-the-clock analysis, the nation’s intelligence agencies were concerned that the threat was real, the men told him. A group of Somali extremists was reported to be coming across the border from Canada to detonate explosives as the new president took the oath of office. With more than a million onlookers viewing the ceremony from the National Mall and hundreds of millions more watching on television around the world, what could be a more devastating target?

headline: Bain in $124 Million Deal for India’s Himadri
text: Bain Capital, the American buyout shop, is paying $54.4 million for a 15.6 percent stake in Indian chemical manufacturer Himadri Chemicals.

headline: What the Past Can’t Tell Investors
text: A stock that builds momentum in one year often carries it over into the next. Might that momentum effect work for the overall stock market?

headline: Citi’s Creator, Alone With His Regrets
text: “This is my final annual meeting as chairman,” says Sandy Weill, standing near the window of his office, peering at a grainy photograph of him and his wife on stage at Carnegie Hall more than three years ago. They are smiling broadly, and behind them is a packed house of cheering Citigroup shareholders. A huge banner dangling from the balcony reads “Thank You Sandy.”

headline: SpinVox, a Voice-to-Text Converter, Is Bought
text: SpinVox, a former high-flying British start-up that developed a system for converting telephone voice-mail messages to text, has been sold to an American software provider for less than a quarter of the valuation it once commanded, The New York Times’s Eric Pfanner reports.

headline: GMAC Gets $3.8 Billion More in Aid
text: The Treasury Department said on Wednesday that it would give $3.8 billion more to GMAC Financial Services and become the auto lender’s majority owner because GMAC had been unable to raise sufficient capital on its own.

headline: 4 Americans and Briton Killed in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  As a new year began in the war in Afghanistan, coalition casualties continued to mount with four American service members and a British soldier killed over the weekend, according to official announcements Monday.

headline: Kraft to Sweeten Cadbury Bid, Report Says
text: Kraft Foods is preparing to sweeten its hostile £10 billion takeover bid for British confectioner Cadbury, The Sunday Times of London reported.

headline: Ferrero Said to Discuss Cadbury Bids With P.E. Shops
text: Ferrero, the Italian confectioner, has met with private equity firms, as well as Hershey, to discuss a possible bid for Britain’s Cadbury, Il Sole 24 Ore reported.

headline: Co-Vocabularyear
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the words that helped define their 2009 – for good and ill.

headline: JAL Said to Favor Delta Offer
text: The president of Japan Airlines said he is against a bankruptcy proceeding under a state restructuring plan and has no plans to completely withdraw the carrier from overseas flights, The Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported.

headline: Novartis to Buy Majority of Alcon From Nestlé
text: Novartis, the giant Swiss drugmaker, said Monday that it would take control of the eye-care company Alcon by buying Nestlé‘s majority stake for $28.1 billion, raising its own stake to 77 percent, and said it would like to acquire the rest.

headline: Watson Wyatt Sews Up $4 Billion Merger With Towers
text: Watson Wyatt Worldwide, the human resources consulting company, completed its merger with rival Towers Perrin Forster & Crosby to form a combined company called Towers Watson that will make its trading debut in the United States on Monday.

headline: What Do You Think of the Response to the Foiled Terror Attack?
text: Since the Christmas day terror attempt, airport security has been tightened and questions have been raised about why the U.S. government didn’t “connect the dots” beforehand. What was your reaction to this news story and its aftermath?

headline: Tokyo Exchange Starts High-Speed Trading System
text: The Tokyo Stock Exchange will start a new high-speed trading system Monday, scrapping an antiquated, glitch-prone platform for one that is intended to compete with its major global rivals.

headline: Rusal I.P.O. Said to Value Shares Cheaper Than Rival
text: United Rusal‘s upcoming initial public offering in Hong Kong could value the world’s largest aluminum producer 16 percent lower than its biggest Chinese competitor, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: R.B.S. Says Pakistan Deal Fell Through
text: Royal Bank of Scotland said a deal to sell its Pakistani business had lapsed after failing to get regulatory approval, confirming a statement earlier this month from MCB Bank, the unit’s would-be buyer.

headline: The First Speed Read for 2010
text: Highlights from today’s media coverage in The New York Times:

headline: For the Holiday Season, Paris on Ice
text: Every year during the holiday season (and beyond) a rink appears on the esplanade in front of the majestic splendor of Hôtel de Ville, Paris’s City Hall, set between a pair of brightly-lit old-fashioned carousels.

headline: Tippling Point | Natural Wine Bars
text: Kathryn O’Mara, who last year opened London’s first natural wine bar, Artisan & Vine (126 St. John’s Hill; 44-207-228-4997), grew up drinking wine and works in the wine industry — and yet she had never really liked drinking wine by itself. “It tasted funny,” she recalled. “Like you had to get something plasticky out of your mouth.” But after O’Mara tried natural wine — that is, wine that hasn’t been doctored with additives or modern processes of vinification — she had an epiphany. “It’s a unique fruit-based beverage,” she said with a laugh. The shop, in a gorgeous Georgian-era pub in Battersea, sells such bottles as the “hypernatural” Sicilian vintages from Frank Cornelissen, who uses grapes indigenous to Mount Etna. “I wouldn’t expect everyone to be as carried away as I was,” O’Mara said. “But we have a lot of regulars now who say that they have difficulty going back to ordinary wines. A lot of them say they feel the difference and seek out these natural wines now.”

headline: Giants Open Thread: What Needs to Be Done?
text: Ernie Palladino has been a Giants beat writer since 1989 and is the only fully credentialed independent blogger covering them. He writes about the team at erniepalladinosgiantsbeat.blogspot.com.

headline: U.S. Decline: Do the Numbers Add Up?
text: Today’s idea: America’s vital statistics don’t add up to long-term decline, a scholar says. In the future, it will have far fewer retirees per capita than other advanced nations while enjoying military prowess and vast resources of energy, agriculture, labor and innovation.

headline: Cheerynomics vs. Gloomynomics
text: An economist catalogs the tribes of the economics profession based on their optimism.

headline: Hedge Funds Finish 2009 With a Bang
text: For the global hedge fund industry, 2009 marked one of best years of performance in close to a decade, The Financial Times reported, citing industry data.

headline: Equal Taxes for Private Equity?
text: Hedge fund managers and private equity partners are merely beating the system when they pay lower tax rates than their own secretaries and janitors, The Boston Globe says in an editorial.

headline: Jets Open Thread: The Beauty of Low Expectations
text: I was lucky enough to be at the Meadowlands last night for the last ride of a roller coaster of a regular season.

headline: Delta and Northwest Can Work as Single Carrier
text: Delta Air Lines has received government permission to operate as a single carrier with its Northwest Airlines subsidiary, a Delta executive said Thursday.

headline: Stocks Start Year Mixed in Asia, but Up in Europe
text: Global stocks started 2010 on a mostly positive note, rising modestly in Europe after a mixed session in Asia. Wall Street was primed to rise at the start of trading, The New York Times’s David Jolly reported.

headline: Flights Out of Newark Airport Halted for Possible Security Breach
text: Flights out of one terminal at Newark Liberty International Airport were temporarily halted Sunday night as officials investigated a possible security breach. Read the full story.

headline: Sampler: Cliff Crumbles, Owl Eviction, and Mr. April and His Crew
text: Intellectual Heft Goes to Sacramento | Beginning on Monday, 10 scientists and engineers will work with state lawmakers and legislative committees on issues like energy and water as part of a program to bring expertise to Sacramento. The $7 million cost is being picked up by foundations. Each fellow will receive a $45,000 stipend for a one-year term from the California Council on Science and Technology, which oversees the program and has a list of fellows and their assignments. [The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: Layoffs in Long Island City, but Growth, Too
text: While Mary Ceruti recognizes that the recession has cast some shadows on Long Island City, Queens, she says the area is still better off than it was eight years ago. Ms. Ceruti, executive director of a nonprofit gallery called the SculptureCenter and a resident who lives there with her husband and 3-year-old daughter, can point to plenty of abandoned development sites and unemployed neighbors. But she is also grateful for the restaurants and boutiques that have cropped up with the opening of so many new condos.

headline: What’s a Bailed-Out Banker Really Worth?
text: Last August, as midnight approached on a Friday, two Treasury Department staff members sat in a cramped basement office in the Treasury Building next to the White House and watched as their e-mail in-boxes filled up. The aides worked for Kenneth Feinberg, the government’s special master for executive compensation, and they were awaiting submissions from companies that had received (and not yet paid back) billions in what federal regulations call “exceptional assistance” from the government’s Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP.

text: Say goodbye to the voting booth with its quaint little curtain. Say goodbye to pulling the lever for your candidate. And say hello to filling in SAT-style ovals on Election Day.

text: Wall Street ushered in 2010 on Monday with its biggest stock market rally in nearly two months, as signs that manufacturing was strengthening around the world fed hopes that the economy would recover this year.

headline: After Balmy Hawaii, Chilly Washington
text: HONOLULU  As Air Force One lifted off late Sunday night, President Obama and his family left behind a balmy 77-degree Hawaiian evening. Bearing east, the plane headed toward Washington, where the temperature was a brisk 23 degrees.

text: President Obama is set to return to the White House shortly before noon, following an 11-day trip to Hawaii. He has no public events listed on his schedule for the rest of the day, but his advisers are bustling through the West Wing to prepare for his arrival – and an even busier year than they anticipated before the holiday break began.

headline: Bernanke in Atlanta
text: Ben Bernanke gave a somewhat odd speech at the American Economic Association meetings. Not a bad speech, and certainly not stupid. But defensive, I think, in the wrong way.

text: Welcome to 2010, a brave new world where film is made of ones and zeros, you can watch them on your phone and yet – wait for it – people are still flocking to the movie theaters. (You and your friends can only play Rock Band for so long.)

text: Cambodia opened its first biomass “charbriquette” factory in Phnom Penh last month, an enterprise that will produce fuel for stoves from waste biomass material.

text: This week, Eric Schofield, the manager at Bicycle Habitat on Lafayette Street in Manhattan, will be responding to readers’ questions about bicycle maintenance and repair.

headline: Eight Steps to a Better Year in 2010
text: It’s time to dust ourselves off and get back on the horse. It is a new year with new opportunities — and some old problems. I am not an economist, so perhaps I shouldn’t make any predictions about the economy.

headline: Credit Suisse Accused of Defrauding Resort Investors
text: Investors at four high-end resorts have filed a class-action lawsuit against Credit Suisse and the real estate services company Cushman & Wakefield, contending that they conspired to inflate the value of the properties so they could take them over, Jim Robbins writes in The New York Times.

headline: Blagojevich Will Appear on ‘Celebrity Apprentice’
text: Rod R. Blagojevich, the disgraced former governor of Illinois, may never hold an elected office again, but he has at least fulfilled his ancillary goal of getting booked on a reality show. Mr. Blagojevich, who was removed from office last January by the Illinois State Senate after his indictment on federal corruption charges, will be one of 14 contestants competing for the favor of Donald J. Trump on “The Celebrity Apprentice,” The Associated Press reported. Mr. Blagojevich, who was arrested and charged in December 2008 with conspiring to profit from his authority to appoint a successor for Barack Obama in the United States Senate, was denied in his previous attempt to become a reality television star. In April, a judge rejected his request for permission to travel to Costa Rica for the NBC series “I’m a Celebrity … Get Me Out of Here!”, while he awaits his federal trial. (The judge said at the time that Mr. Blagojevich did not appreciate “the position he finds himself in.”) Mr. Blagojevich’s rivals on “The Celebrity Apprentice,” which is taped in New York and makes its debut March 14 on NBC, include Darryl Strawberry, Cyndi Lauper and Sharon Osbourne.

headline: Intimitations of Decline
text: My column today discusses the possibility of American decline, and how we might avert it. It doesn’t venture any bold predictions about the likelihood of our decline, however. For that, I recommend consulting Joel Kotkin (representing the optimists) and Patrick Deneen (speaking for the deep, deep pessimists).

headline: Motorsports Links: Death in Dakar Rally
text: Motorsports news from around the Web…

headline: Monday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Table 8 Closing, Will Reopen Under Scott Conant
text: As several blogs have speculated, the chef Scott Conant is indeed taking over Table 8, the restaurant in the Cooper Square Hotel, which is closing today for renovations. Although hotel officials had suggested that the name might remain, the restaurant will have a new name and a fresh design by the time it reopens “in the coming weeks,” said a spokeswoman for the restaurant. Mr. Conant is the chef and an owner of Scarpetta on West 14th Street.

headline: Showcase: Disposed Of
text: Japan’s economic boom once kept the men in the Kamagasaki district of Osaka busy working on buildings and highways. Now they pass the time waiting in free-meal lines and collecting cans.

headline: Kenya Seeks to Deport Muslim Cleric to Jamaica
text: LONDON  The Kenyan authorities were reported on Monday to be planning to deport a Jamaican-born Muslim cleric, Abdullah el-Faisal, who may have helped inspire the Nigerian man accused of trying to bomb an American airliner headed to Detroit on Christmas Day.

headline: Pioneering Greenhouse Analyst Appraised
text: Global warming has of late felt like a new issue, but it’s useful once in a while to review the generations-long line of analysis that points to substantial climatic and environmental consequences from rising emissions of greenhouse gases. The basic idea, of course, goes back more than a century, but the real number crunching started in the 1950s, and even drew the attention of the filmmaker Frank Capra, who produced a series of television programs on science (in the post-Sputnik days when science was a high priority), that included “The Unchained Goddess,” a remarkable 1958 film on weather and climate. It contained a section on greenhouse-driven warming:

headline: Total Joins Chesapeake in Gas Joint Venture
text: The French oil giant Total said Monday that it was acquiring a 25 percent stake in tens of thousands of acres of natural gas fields in Texas controlled by Chesapeake Energy in a joint venture deal valued at $2.25 billion.

headline: Divergent Views on Signs of Life in the Economy
text: Signs of revival on the factory floor emerged in the United States and Asia on Monday, fueling exultant buying on Wall Street and reinforcing a sense that genuine economic recovery was unfolding.

headline: A New Look at High School Students’ Ambitions
text: The goal of going to college holds broad appeal, regardless of a family’s income level, a new survey suggests. And that is true even of students who lack confidence in their own academic preparation.

headline: For Law Firm’s New Chief, Challenges Abound
text: At five-foot-two, H. Rodgin Cohen may not be the tallest lawyer in the room. But his stepping down on Jan. 1 as chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell has left his successor, Joseph C. Shenker, with some big shoes to fill.

headline: Secrets Kept Last Week May Lead to Victories This Week
text: Ken Whisenhunt folded up his Arizona Cardinals play card and essentially tucked it in his pocket Sunday. Marvin Lewis rested the Bengals’ top running back and three defensive starters. The Philadelphia Eagles played a startlingly passive defensive style.

headline: A Brief Conversation About Last Night’s ‘Iron Chef’
text: Ms. Severson barely had her scarf off this morning before she was ranting about last night’s “Iron Chef America.” Mr. Sifton, a little scared by the emotion, suggested moving the conversation to the more impersonal if more easily shared medium of electronic chat. Their conversation follows, for the edification of those interested in such matters and for those who subscribe to Cablevision, which because of a contract dispute, did not broadcastthe event.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs Q. and A. With Judy Battista
text: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answered questions from readers on Monday (in the comment section below). With the playoffs approaching, Judy looks at the rematches that will take place this weekend; three of the four games feature the same matchup as this past Sunday. The Jets and Bengals, Packers and Cardinals, and Cowboys and Eagles square off again. In Monday’s Times, Judy took an early look at this weekend’s games, A.F.C. and N.F.C.

headline: Judge Refuses to Delay Prison for UBS Informant
text: A federal judge refused on Monday to delay the prison reporting date for a former Swiss banker-turned-informant who helped start a huge tax evasion investigation.

headline: Wake Up, Mr. West: Kanye Says He’s Back in the Studio
text: True to his word, Kanye West let Taylor Swift — and all of 2009 — finish before announcing he was back at work on a new record. After a surprise appearance at a Kid Cudi show in Los Angeles just before Christmas (at which Mr. West rapped about begging “fashion houses to hire me”), Mr. West further baffled fans with a post on his personal blog in which he compared himself with Kobe Bryant, Maya Angelou, Gil Scott-Heron and Nina Simone, The Guardian reported. In the all-caps post at kanyeuniversecity.com, Mr. West thanked his listeners for “their constant love and support over these past 6 years,” and he said he was working in a studio making new music. He offered few details about his latest effort, saying that he was working “with the same dedication that Kobe has on the court,” and that his responsibility, like other modern-day poets and artists, is “to accurately represent what is happening now, so when the powers that be try to rewrite history you can always look at our works and find truth and sincerity.” Mr. West has generally kept a low profile since a September incident in which he interrupted an acceptance speech by Ms. Swift at the MTV Video Music Awards.

headline: Group Gives Up Death Penalty Work
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Europe Seems Set to Approve Kraft’s Cadbury Bid
text: Kraft Foods appears likely to win conditional regulatory approval from the European Union this week for its hostile $16 billion takeover bid for the candy maker Cadbury, Reuters reports, citing an unidentified person familiar with the situation.

headline: Security Scare at Newark Airport
text: Flights out of one terminal at Newark Liberty International Airport were temporarily halted as officials investigated a possible security breach.

headline: What Happened on ‘Iron Chef’
text: It was billed by the Food Network as “The Greatest Night in Culinary History.” Mario Batali and Bobby Flay, the celebrity Iron Chefs, traveled to the White House with Emeril Lagasse, the New Orleans restaurateur whom the network calls a “Super Chef,” to meet up with the White House executive chef, Cristeta Comerford, to receive instructions for an epic “Iron Chef” smackdown: Mr. Batali and Mr. Lagasse versus Mr. Flay and Ms. Comerford, on the network from 8 to 10 p.m. on Sunday.

headline: Judge Refuses to Delay Prison for UBS Informant
text: A federal judge refused on Monday to delay the prison reporting date for a former Swiss banker who became an informant and helped start a huge tax evasion investigation.

headline: Hot Topic: Lighting Up in ‘Avatar’
text: As Michael Cieply reported in The New York Times on Monday, “some of those who oppose smoking in movies have just seen the future, and they are not happy about it.”

headline: Merz to Buy BioForm Medical for $253 Million
text: The Merz Pharma Group of Germany said Monday that it would buy BioForm Medical for $253 million in cash, expanding its aesthetic medicine business.

headline: Dissident Chinese Writer Appeals Sentence
text: BEIJING  Liu Xiaobo, the Beijing writer who was given an 11-year prison sentence on subversion charges on Dec. 25 after urging Chinese leaders to embrace democratic reforms, has appealed his conviction to the Beijing Supreme People’s Court, one of his lawyers said Tuesday.

headline: Travel Deals: JetBlue Flights Starting at $29
text: In celebration of the New Year, JetBlue is offering a Shake Up the New Year Sale with one-way tickets starting at $29. The sale ends Jan. 13 and is good for travel through March 24.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Kovalev’s Four Goals Sink Flyers
text: Four games on Sunday, highlighted by Alex Kovalev’s rare mortarboard trick — that’s four goals, named after the hat with four sides — that carried resilient Ottawa past the Flyers, who seemed to have a hangover from New Year’s Day. Home teams listed first:

headline: Levin Is Sorry for Creating AOL Time Warner
text: Jerry Levin, the former Time Warner chief who helped orchestrate the disastrous merger with AOL shares that resulted in the loss of billions of dollars for shareholders, offered a mea culpa Monday during an appearance on CNBC.

headline: The Story and the Backstory at the Fiesta Bowl
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz. — Have you ever seen a sports book that sells itself as more than a sports book? It’s not just the book about –- generic example here –- the Red Sox’ and Yankees’ one-game playoff in 1978. It’s about how that one game epitomized the tension of the rivalry, the essence of a baseball era and helped Americans adjust to life in the post-Vietnam era. Exaggerating a bit here, but you get the idea. The game itself isn’t really that important.

headline: If Everyone Is in an Honor Society, Has the Honor Been Cheapened?
text: I wanted to make sure that those of you catching up on your newspaper reading after the holidays saw an article by my colleague Winnie Hu on the proliferation of high school honor societies. As you’ll see below, we’re hoping this article will jump-start a comment thread on the issue on The Choice.

headline: Meet Mr. Gaga | The Stylist Nicola Formichetti
text: Whether or not you know him by name, you’ll recognize the stylist Nicola Formichetti by his aggressively modern looks (Lady Gaga‘s metal orb, anyone?). When it comes to his personal style, Formichetti attributes his unrestricted creativity to his multicultural upbringing, which was shared between Italy and Japan. Now 32, he lives in New York, London and Tokyo, and keeps himself busy working as the creative director of the London magazine Dazed and Confused, the fashion director of Vogue Hommes Japan and as a stylist for advertising campaigns for Uniqlo, Dolce & Gabbana and Alexander McQueen, to name just a few. Before kicking off Lady Gaga’s “Monster Ball” tour in Montreal, T caught up with Formichetti to ask him about his career, inspirations and what it’s like to work with Gaga.

headline: What to Watch Monday: Love and the End of the World
text: Over on the History Channel they’re bringing in the new year on a cheery note: It’s “Armageddon Week,” and Monday night at 8 the real Doctor of Doom, Michel de Nostradamus, gets center stage with a two-hour program called “Nostradamus: 2012.” These days it seems as if Nostradamus is credited with predicting everything from the world wars to your latest head cold. This program, History’s Web site says, will look at “the parallels between the nightmarish daily headlines and the 2012 prophecies from Nostradamus and others.”

headline: The Morning Skate: Will the Thrashers Trade Kovalchuk?
text: In their always interesting — and sometimes baffling — annual rankings of the 100 most powerful and influential people in the game, The Hockey News ranked the Thrashers’ star Ilya Kovalchuk at 71. Strange, since it recognizes that his status as a pending unrestricted free agent renders him überinfluential.

headline: Are the Oscars Ready for Another Sassy Southerner?
text: Though some bloggers are already lamenting that there is no drama left in the awards season, the Bagger can still find some stuff to get excited about, and that’s not even including the fan fiction version of the potentially in-the-works Goonies musical.

headline: Chaos and Inquiry Follow Security Breach at Newark Airport
text: A security officer failed to react when a man went through the wrong door at Newark Liberty International Airport on Sunday afternoon, the authorities said on Monday. When a passenger reported the breach, it set off seven hours of chaos, starting with the evacuation of the airport’s busiest terminal on one of the busiest travel days of the year.

headline: School Closed Today. Just Kidding.
text: Students at Brooklyn Technical High School thought they were in for a bonus New Year’s vacation when they got an e-mail message on Sunday, purportedly from an assistant principal, that the school would be closed until further notice.

headline: Bank of America’s Chief Seeks to Rebuild Trust
text: Bank of America‘s new chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, said Monday that the recession was fading and that the bank had finished making its biggest acquisitions, allowing him to focus on rebuilding relationships with customers.

headline: A Bizarre Finale
text: Normally, we would be riveted by the finally here N.F.L. playoffs. We’d be parsing matchups and deconstructing the favorites, double-checking the schedule and setting TiVo, then double-checking that. But with such a weird season spinning to a pitch perfect bizarro-world finish, nothing makes sense. Well, nothing other than the Redskins finally firing Jim Zorn, eight weeks after metaphorically decapitating him and interviewing possible successors while he wandered around looking for his head.

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this column incorrectly identified the elected official from South Carolina who assaulted a senator with a cane in 1856. He was a member of the House of Representatives, not a fellow senator.

headline: Is It Live, or Is It iTunes? Apple Store as Recital Space
text: People passing by the new Apple Store on Broadway and 67th Street on Sunday evening noticed something unusual happening inside the spacious salesroom: a pianist playing a grand piano on a makeshift concert platform right next to the towering window wall.

headline: Should a Quadriplegic Mom Have Custody?
text: Kaney O’Neill and David Trais will be in a Chicago courtroom this week, arguing over their five-month-old son, Aiden. Trais says that O’Neill is unfit to have custody of the boy because she is a quadriplegic, having lost all use of her legs and some use of her arms in a fall off a balcony a decade ago.

headline: The Stock of the Decade: Think Energy
text: While some stock market commentators are declaring the ’00s the lost decade for stock investments, that certainly wouldn’t have been the case if you had invested in energy sector stocks.

headline: Bay Passes Physical With Mets
text: Outfielder Jason Bay passed his physical with the Mets on Monday and will be introduced at a news conference at 11 a.m. Tuesday at Citi Field. Any concerns the Mets may have had about the long-term condition of his shoulders were apparently satisfied.

headline: For the Moment | Michele Caniato
text: Michele Caniato is the president of Culture and Commerce, a design management consultancy, and of Material Connexion, a materials consultancy and library; both companies are based in New York.

headline: Spoleto Festival USA Unveils 2010 Season
text: Updated | 2:35 p.m.  One of America’s oldest theaters will show off its newly finished facelift when the Spoleto Festival USA begins its 2010 season in May. Organizers of that classical music and theater festival in Charleston, S.C., said in a news release that it would feature the reopening of the Dock Street Theater, a performance space whose namesake was first opened in 1736 and says it was the first building designed as a theater in America. After a three-year renovation, the theater will reopen during the festival with a production of “Flora, an Opera,” a British ballad opera that was performed at the theater in the early 1700s. The Spoleto Festival USA, which was spun off from the Festival dei Due Mondi in Spoleto, Italy, will also feature productions of Noël Coward’s “Present Laughter,” presented by Dublin’s Gate Theater; “Giselle,” danced by Nina Ananiashvili and the National Ballet of Georgia; and “Dance,” a work by Lucinda Childs that includes an original score by Philip Glass; and a short film by the artist Sol LeWitt. The festival runs from May 28 through June 13.

headline: Pink Tea Cup to Reopen
text: The Pink Tea Cup, the Greenwich Village soul food restaurant that closed Sunday night after 55 years in business, will soon reopen nearby with its same staff, said Lawrence Page, who said he bought the name from the restaurant’s owner, Lisa Ford, for $400,000.

headline: VW’s Green Theme at Autostadt
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section I write about auto museums in Germany dedicated to preserving the heritage and history of Porsche, BMW, Audi and Mercedes-Benz (“Touring the Temples of German Automaking”). The trip did not include a visit to Volkswagen’s Autostadt because I had been there before, and a detour to Wolfsburg — some 250 miles north of Stuttgart — would have added considerable time to the tour.

headline: Readers Examine the Wherefores of Whining
text: When Thelma Karro, a retired librarian who is closing in on 80, gets together with her friends, questions of mere politeness or real concern are often met with a litany of woes. So to avoid lengthy — and unnecessary — back stories, she holds back on asking others, “How are you?”

headline: Chinatown Brasserie’s Chef to Open a Restaurant in the Village
text: With the Chinatown Brasserie space soon to become less Chinese, its chef, Joe Ng, will be opening an American-Asian spot in the West Village with the Chinese food expert and restaurant consultant Ed Schoenfeld.

headline: 'Once and For All'
text: A scene from "Once and For All We're Gonna Tell You Who We Are So Shut Up and Listen," part of the Under the Radar Festival. (Video courtesy of the New Victory Theater)

headline: Giants’ Season the Day After: Embarrassment
text: It is one thing to miss the playoffs. It is quite another to close out the season the way the Giants did on Sunday night.

headline: Economy Is Down, but Dubai Tower Tops All
text: For all the towers that give shape to Dubai’s skyline, the city-state still hails the addition of each new one as a reaffirmation of its reach-for-the-skies spirit.

headline: Economy Is Down, but Dubai Tower Tops All
text: Even in the midst of a devastating real estate crash, Dubai pulled out all the stops Monday to celebrate the opening of the world’s tallest building: a rocket-shaped edifice that soars 828 meters, or 2,717 feet, with views that can reach 100-kilometers, or 60-miles.

headline: The Year of Darwin
text: Steven Shapin has a wonderful essay in the London Review of Books looking at the remarkable outpouring that accompanied Charles Darwin’s bicentennial last year — the exhibitions and live readings and “one-man musicals,” the books and essays and scientific pilgrimages, the postage stamps and Facebook groups and “Darwin is my Homeboy” T-shirts. He writes:

headline: Aging: Abdominal Surgery Risk May Rise With Age
text: Common abdominal surgery like removal of the uterus or the gallbladder may pose a greater risk to older patients than generally reported. A new study finds that 5 percent of those 65 and older died within 90 days of surgery and that 17 percent developed complications.

headline: Corporate Tax Returns Face Heavier Scrutiny
text: While the recession may be ending across much of the world, its effect on revenue collectors and corporate tax returns will last much longer.

headline: Now Sipping | Stumptown Mocha
text: City Bakery’s 18th annual Hot Chocolate Month is around the corner, but don’t postpone crazy joy. Have a mocha at Stumptown and proceed directly to the next level.

headline: Two Killed in Las Vegas Courthouse
text: LAS VEGAS  A man clad in black opened fire in the federal courthouse lobby here on Monday, killing a security officer and wounding a deputy United States marshal before he was fatally shot by federal officers as he fled.

headline: Standoff Builds Over Afghan Cabinet
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The tug of war under way between President Hamid Karzai and Parliament over his cabinet picks entered a new phase Monday when the president ordered lawmakers to delay their long-planned winter holiday so he could offer them a new list of nominees.

headline: Regimens: Questioning Benefit of Diabetes Test Strips
text: People with Type 2 diabetes are often advised to use blood-glucose test strips to monitor their blood sugar levels, but a Canadian analysis has found that routine self-monitoring is not cost-effective for many patients: the strips can cost almost a dollar each, and they prevent comparatively few complications of diabetes.

headline: Chafee Announces Bid for R.I. Governor’s Seat
text: Lincoln Chafee, the former Republican senator from Rhode Island who lost his seat to a Democrat in 2006, announced Monday that he would run for governor there as an independent.

headline: S.F. Sea Lions May Have Gone South. Or North.
text: Update | 3:04 p.m. Some sea lions have returned to their old home, K-Dock at Pier 39. Their return home has pleased the staff at the company that runs the outdoor marketplace and attraction at Fisherman’s Wharf. “I’m so happy,” said Sue Muzzin, director of public relations at Pier 39.

headline: Final Words on Last Night’s ‘Iron Chef’
text: As comments trickle in responding to our correspondents’ reactions to the Sunday night edition of “Iron Chef America,” Kim Severson and Sam Sifton bring an end to their discussion about the contest, which saw the team of Mario Batali and Emeril Lagasse fall prey to that of Bobby Flay and the White House executive chef, Cristeta Comerford, in a kitchen battle that had them using vegetables harvested from the White House garden.

headline: Study Says Women With Mate Get Heavier
text: It is widely known that women tend to gain weight after giving birth, but now a large study has found evidence that even among childless women, those who live with a mate put on more pounds than those who live without one.

headline: After Holiday Gluttony, a Perfect Time for Entree Salads
text: If the holiday season was one feast after another for you, you may have resolved to eat nothing but salads in January. This can be a diet to look forward to, as there are plenty of ways to make salads interesting and satisfying.

headline: Football Culture Keeps Some in the Dark
text: The old football mentality  play through pain or get out of the way  can be dangerous, particularly in the murky area of brain injury.

headline: One on One: Jack Dorsey of Twitter and Square
text: I recently sat down for coffee with Jack Dorsey to discuss Twitter, the location-based service Foursquare and his latest venture Square, an on-the-go credit card payment platform. Mr. Dorsey is the co-founder and chairman of Twitter, an angel investor in Foursquare and chief executive of Square.

headline: Major Issues: Writing Text-Supported Arguments About the Purpose of College
text: Overview | What is the purpose of a college education? In this lesson, students examine the controversy over restructuring university curriculum to focus more on job-related skill development and less on traditional liberal arts learning. They then develop and practice the skill of supporting an argument with textual evidence by crafting a letter that argues for or against restructuring university curriculum.

headline: A Third Party Crasher Is Reported
text: The Salahis, it turns out, apparently were not the only ones who arrived uninvited to President Obama’s first state dinner at the White House.

headline: Camus’s Death and a Rare French Sports Car
text: Monday marks the 50th anniversary of the death of Albert Camus, the existentialist philosopher and novelist — and of the brief moment of notoriety Camus’s death brought to the car in which he died, a Facel Vega.

headline: A Placard Makes Parking a Breeze
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Spiced Red Lentil Dal
text: Mark Bittman makes spiced red lentil dal, a simple vegetarian dish from India.

headline: Judge Excludes Media Reports in Bank of America Case
text: The federal judge overseeing the government’s civil lawsuit against Bank of America over its Merrill Lynch deal ruled Monday that media reports about the merger could not be used as supporting evidence.

headline: From Davis and White to India, With Love
text: American ice dancers Meryl Davis and Charlie White thought their Indian-themed original dance program could be popular.

headline: Newark Airport Delays Cause Ripple Effect
text: Officials were trying to determine on Monday how a man who walked through the wrong door on Sunday turned a busy airport terminal into a human traffic jam. Read the full story.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Julian Louie, Designer
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Agency Won’t Be on Reality TV Series
text: A reality series in the works at MTV may be big, but it won’t be Huge.

headline: Event Planners Try to Dodge Slide of Dollar
text: Although it has ticked up a bit recently, the United States dollar did not have a particularly good 2009. Nor was its value against competing currencies like the euro and Japanese yen easy to predict.

headline: Elevating Simple Legumes, Just Enough
text: IF the word “dal” conjures up images of a simple dish of well-flavored lentils, the kind of thing you might see at an Indian lunch buffet, that’s not inaccurate. But it is incomplete, because dal is a generic term for bean dishes, and for the beans and lentils used to make them.

headline: Tips for Cutting Your Cable Bill
text: A new deal, covered in this New York Times article, between News Corporation and Time Warner Cable doesn’t just mean Time Warner will have to pay subscriber fees for the Fox Broadcasting network.

headline: Spiced Red Lentil Dal
text: 2 tablespoons peanut oil

headline: The Best Vegetable You’ve Never Tried
text: FOR weeks, Bill Maxwell of Maxwell Farms in Changewater, N.J., put the rutabaga bug in my ear every Saturday morning at the farmers’ market.

headline: Tharp’s Sinatra Show Is Broadway Bound
text: It’s been nearly 35 years since Frank Sinatra played the Great White Way, but Ol’ Blue Eyes is back: the singer’s music and voice will return to Broadway in a Twyla Tharp musical that its producers said on Monday will transfer to the Marquis Theater later this year. The musical, which is conceived, choreographed and directed by Ms. Tharp, was previously titled “Come Fly With Me” when it was presented at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta last fall, but will be called “Come Fly Away” for its Broadway run. (The show’s press representatives did not immediately offer an explanation for the name change, you dig?) Casting for “Come Fly Away” was not announced; it is to begin previews at the Marquis on March 1 and open on March 25. Mr. Sinatra’s only previous Broadway credit, according to ibdb.com, was a 1975 concert performed at the Uris Theater with Ella Fitzgerald and Count Basie. Ms. Tharp (“Movin’ Out”) has previously used Mr. Sinatra’s music in her dance pieces “Once More Frank,” “Nine Sinatra Songs” and “Sinatra Suite.”

headline: When Doctors Are Sued (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Managing Manure (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: What I Learned
text: I’m happy with the results of this year-long project. Though the work goes on — if it is fair to call it work — it has been more like play.

headline: Of Grief and Bereavement (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Options for Bone Loss, but No Magic Pill
text: A reader recently complained that her elderly mother had faithfully taken the medication prescribed to protect her osteoporotic bones from fracture but still broke her hip as she walked from her bedroom to the bathroom one morning. The older woman recalled that she had felt her hip give way and then fell, not the other way around.

headline: Contact Lens, 1930
text: Contact lenses had a long history before they were mentioned in The New York Times.

headline: Treating Patients When Language Is Only One of the Barriers
text: A defective heart, a child detained by border guards — Julia Barquero had already had her struggles. But now her physician at Bellevue Hospital Center, Dr. Danielle Ofri, was trying to explain to Ms. Barquero that she could not receive a heart transplant because she was an illegal immigrant.

headline: Microbes: Fighting Mosquito-Transmitted Viruses With Bacteria That Infect Many Insects
text: A type of bacteria that infects many insects may make mosquitoes more resistant to viruses that can be dangerous to humans, researchers have found.

headline: A Love Affair With Panthers, for the Moment
text: NAPLES, Fla.

headline: Suppressing Tinnitus With Music Therapy
text: Subjective tinnitus, the ringing or other noise that often accompanies noise-related hearing loss, is a tough problem to treat. But researchers in Germany have come up with a novel approach, a kind of music therapy in which the music is custom-tailored to the person with tinnitus.

headline: Much-Maligned Mother of Many Beloved Wines
text: About a decade ago, researchers had some startling news for wine lovers. Some of their beloved grape varieties, including chardonnay and gamay noir, were the offspring of a third-rate parent, gouais blanc. In fact, the research showed that at least a dozen varieties were a result of crosses, a long time ago, between pinot noir and gouais blanc, which had such a bad reputation that its cultivation was at times outlawed.

headline: White Lizards Evolve in New Mexico Dunes
text: The White Sands of New Mexico are a good place to study evolution in progress. One reason is that the terrain, gypsum dunes white as a sheet of paper, is so different from the surrounding area. Another is that the dunes formed only about 6,000 years ago.

headline: Congress Examines N.F.L. Concussions
text: DETROIT  Dr. Ira Casson, a symbol of the N.F.L.’s reluctance to recognize mounting evidence linking professional football and dementia before his resignation as co-chairman of a league committee on brain injuries, continued to deny the existence of any such relationship while testifying before a House Judiciary Committee hearing Monday.

headline: In California, a Scrub Oak Is an Old Pro at Cloning
text: In Southern California, a place where most everything is new, botanists have discovered something very old: a scrub oak that has been cloning itself for at least 13,000 years.

headline: The Perfect Marriage: Leek and Potato
text: Leek and potato soup. One of the classics, and a great favorite, hot or (as vichyssoise) cold.

headline: Using a Virus’s Knack for Mutating to Wipe It Out
text: Evolution is a virus’s secret weapon. The virus can rapidly slip on new disguises to evade our immune systems, and it can become resistant to antiviral drugs.

headline: A City Ballet Star’s Reinventions
text: When Peter Boal retired from New York City Ballet in 2005, he left a gap at the dance barre. As it happens, there just aren’t enough well-proportioned, innately elegant men with scrupulous line and demeanor to go around.

headline: Temperature and Exercise
text: Q. Does a person tend to burn more fat exercising outdoors in colder weather or in hotter weather? I am leaning to the colder weather side, since the body has to work harder to keep the body temperature near normal.

headline: Where Did the Time Go? Do Not Ask the Brain
text: That most alarming New Year’s morning question  “Uh-oh, what did I do last night?”  can seem benign compared with those that may come later, like “Uh, what exactly did I do with the last year?”

headline: Continental Chief Puts Pay On the Line
text: From Micheline Maynard, a DealBook colleague

headline: George Lakoff Tries to Reframe Sacramento’s Conversation
text: George Lakoff is known for, among other things, writing books about how the outcome of political debates and campaigns often depends on how the conversation has been framed, who controls the metaphors used. He has spoken to lawmakers in Washington and Sacramento and analyzed conservative spin and why liberals have failed in some of their efforts.

headline: Secret Service Investigates Obama Effigy in Carter’s Hometown
text: According to a report from a television station in Georgia, President Barack Obama may have been hanged in effigy in the hometown of former President Jimmy Carter on Saturday. Plains, Ga. is best-known as the home of Mr. Carter and the effigy was found hanging above a billboard celebrating the former president on Main Street.

headline: Medical Care That Transcends Words
text: In the chilly bureaucratic confines of the social services office where I worked before college, few people had it in them to waste energy on politeness. Poverty and dependence tended to take a toll on good manners.

headline: Man, 25, Arrested on Rape Charges for Second Time
text: A 25-year-old Upper Manhattan man was arrested on Sunday on rape charges, just a little more than two months after prosecutors dropped similar charges against him, according to the police.

headline: Hazards: With This Spider, Wear Safety Goggles
text: When a 29-year-old man went to an eye clinic in Britain complaining of a very sore, watery, bright-red eye, doctors at first suspected a virus.

headline: A Guide to the Cosmos, in Words and Images
text: In the universe there is always room for another surprise. Or two. Or a trillion.

headline: New Envoy’s Old Advice for Children: Read More
text: BARRE, Vt.  Katherine Paterson, the children’s novelist who will be appointed the national ambassador for young people’s literature on Tuesday, often assures aspiring writers that she showed little apparent talent as a child.

headline: In a Hall of Glass, Performing for an Audience of Shoppers
text: People passing by the new Apple Store at Broadway and 67th Street on Sunday evening noticed something unusual happening inside the spacious salesroom: a pianist playing a grand piano on a makeshift concert platform right next to the towering window wall.

headline: The Claim: Diabetes Can Lead to ‘Frozen Shoulder’
text: THE FACTS Shoulder problems are not what come to mind when most people think of diabetes.

headline: For F.D.R. Sleuths, New Focus on an Odd Spot
text: When President Franklin D. Roosevelt died unexpectedly on April 12, 1945, in Warm Springs, Ga., the White House lost no time announcing a cause of death.

headline: Travel Apps 2.0
text: Augmented reality — the hot new thing in smartphone technology — is starting to trickle into travel apps.

headline: Lenny Kravitz Says He Did Not Leak Michael Jackson Video
text: Two days after part of an unreleased song featuring Michael Jackson was leaked onto the Internet, Lenny Kravitz has announced, via a video posted to Twitter, that he had recorded it with Mr. Jackson and that the leak was unauthorized.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Jan. 4
text: On Dec. 17, Pictures of the Day published an unusual four-slide series by Scott Olson of Getty Images on the evacuation of an Afghan boy, rigid with tetanus, to an American field hospital in Helmand Province. A number of readers asked what happened to the child. On Monday morning, Lens received a note from Lt. j.g. Nichole Benson, who wrote: “I am a U.S. Navy Nurse at the Role 3 Hospital who took care of the young boy for the past three weeks and I am pleased to say that he went home with his father today. His father was very happy for the care they both received.”

headline: BlogTalk: New Year, Same Battles
text: A new year dawns in Washington, and the critics, pundits and bloggers are already putting in their two-cents’ worth on the issues that will be taken up by pols returning from vacation. The big topics today include health care, of course, terrorism and the soul of the Republican Party.

headline: Readers’ Photos: Curating a Decade
text: When Times editors began brainstorming about ways to mark the end of the decade, it didn’t take us long to settle on a course of action: get readers involved.

headline: Bush’s Supermajorities
text: Last week, discussing the filibuster, I wrote that “the Bush tax cuts, No Child Left Behind, and Medicare Part D all passed with Senate supermajorities.” I should have written that the Senate versions of those bills passed with supermajorities (that is, filibuster-proof majorities). The initial Senate vote on the 2001 Bush tax cuts, after some horse-trading with Democrats, was 65-35; the vote on the bill that came back from conference, however, was 58-33. The Senate version of Medicare Part D passed 76-21, but the final version passed 54-44. (Neither bill was filibustered, obviously: The 2001 tax cuts were passed using reconciliation, and in the cloture vote for Medicare Part D, 70 Senators voted yea.)

headline: Critics' Picks: 'M'
text: A. O. Scott reviews Fritz Lang's "M," about a serial killer and the city he terrorizes.

headline: Packing Tetrahedrons, and Closing In on a Perfect Fit
text: More than 2,300 years ago, Aristotle was wrong.

headline: Excerpt: 'Chuck'
text: In the new season of the NBC action comedy, its nerdy hero becomes a more competent spy.

headline: Census Working Overtime With Advertising
text: The first year of a new decade brings, for Americans, the decennial census. The census for 2010 will be the subject of what is being called the most elaborate advertising and marketing effort to date from the Commerce Department.

headline: Cleveland Orchestra Wrangles Over Proposed Salary Cuts
text: Under a cloud of labor strife, the Cleveland Orchestra planned to begin rehearsals on Tuesday. The players’ contract with management expired on Aug. 30, but both sides agreed to an extension during negotiations for a new contract. The players’ union, however, “formally terminated the extension agreement,” giving them the right to strike, the orchestra management said. “We’re operating without a contract,” said Gary Hanson, the orchestra’s executive director. “That situation represents an unspecified threat to the entire concert schedule.”

headline: Inside, Outside, All Around the Aesthetics
text: Folk, outsider and other self-taught artists are popularly viewed as exotics, and not without reason. They tend to produce weird, wacky and eccentric objects, and many of them seem to operate on a mental frequency to which few conventional people have access.

headline: Pulling Out All the Stops to Rescue a TV Hero
text: BURBANK, Calif.  Remember when “Chuck” was a show about a helpless newcomer maneuvering ineptly through a world of espionage and danger? Cherish those memories.

headline: Attacker in Afghanistan Was a Double Agent
text: This article is by Richard A. Oppel Jr., Mark Mazzetti and Souad Mekhennet.

headline: Frank Words About ‘Chuck’ From Josh Schwartz
text: Back in April, we had either the good fortune or poor timing to speak with Josh Schwartz, the co-creator of “Chuck,” at a time when he still wasn’t sure if that cult NBC series, about a computer nerd with a spy database in his brain, was going to be renewed for a third season.

headline: What They’re Saying About the Debacle in Denver
text: For political battles, it’s tough to beat the Broncos, who seemed to implode amid the the infighting.

headline: Giants Make a Change, Still Stinging From Failure
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The dismissal of Bill Sheridan as the Giants’ defensive coordinator Monday ended an unusual day of public soul-searching for the franchise.

headline: A New Sort of Culture War
text: As “Avatar” continues to dominate the box office, earning more than $1 billion globally in just a few weeks, more critics are weighing in on What It All Means, culturally. The public health perspective aside, the film represents, as the Bagger has noted, the future of movies: a synthetic high-tech saga, worthy of forking over a few extra bucks at the ticket machine. Its likely competitor in the best picture race, Jason Reitman’s “Up in the Air,” meanwhile, feels of-the-moment, handcrafted and indie – even though it stars the world’s slickest movie star in George Clooney, and comes from a writer-director who is himself a product of Hollywood. Their likely matchup has, as Owen Gleiberman put it in Entertainment Weekly, a “King Kong vs. Godzilla culture-war vibe,” or, as the Bagger likes to think of it, Autotune Kanye vs. Li’l Country Star Taylor.

headline: Day One Joys
text: The stock market is up today. The S.&P. 500 ended the day with a gain of 1.6 percent.

headline: College Report: A Full Denver Cup
text: The holiday season may be over, but college hockey’s schedule was full of holiday tournaments this weekend before conference play dominates the second-half race to the finish. While most of the tournaments feature a grab-bag of quality teams and subpar competition, the Denver Cup has traditionally served as a great appetizer for the stretch run. Last season, Boston University took the Cup on its way to a national championship.

headline: Skiff and Sprint to Unveil a Reading Device
text: Sprint and a start-up company called Skiff said on Monday that they would preview the first Skiff Reader in Las Vegas this week at the Consumer Electronics Show.

headline: Britain Informed U.S. About Nigerian, Official Says
text: LONDON  As officials on both sides of the Atlantic review intelligence lapses in the case of the 23-year-old Nigerian accused of attempting to bomb a Detroit-bound airliner on Christmas Day, a government spokesman said Monday that Britain had passed information about the suspect to American authorities before the bombing attempt.

headline: Adu and Altidore Out-Tweet the British Press
text: Soccer players are now scooping the voracious media that cover them. While January is traditionally the time of rampant speculation in tabloids and on Web sites about which player will move where, a couple of American forwards are tweeting themselves to the forefront of the transfer market speculation.

headline: Fiesta Bowl: No. 6 Boise State (13-0) vs. No. 4 Texas Christian (12-0)
text: In its infinite wisdom, the B.C.S. opted to match Boise State and T.C.U. against each other rather than give each the chance at unseating one of college football’s big boys. After watching the Sugar Bowl, who wouldn’t have loved to see T.C.U. take on the Gators? Or see Cincinnati head out to Tempe to play Boise State in this Fiesta Bowl? Alas, that time has passed. What remains is a rematch of last season’s Poinsettia Bowl, which saw the Horned Frogs outlast the Broncos by a single point. These top teams deserved better, as each could have used a win over a B.C.S. conference opponent to vault into next season’s preseason top five.

headline: New Health Rule: Quit Worrying About Your Health
text: Have you had your five to nine servings of vegetables today? Exercised for an hour? Cut back on saturated fat and gotten eight hours of sleep?

headline: Music Therapy to Treat Tinnitus
text: German researchers have come up with a form of music therapy that may help quiet the noise of tinnitus, a constant ringing or other sound in the ear. Tinnitus can occur after a noise-related hearing loss and is a particularly frustrating and difficult problem to treat.

headline: After Planning the Party of the Year, the First Workday of 2010
text: From deep inside a cubicle on the first official workday of 2010 for the hats-and-noisemakers crowd, a question came to mind: How did the people who worked while the rest of the city partied on New Year’s Eve spend their Monday? Were they still slaving away, if you can use that word about people who orchestrate ball drops in Times Square and mastermind fireworks displays in Central Park?

headline: Arenas Admits to Judgment Error in Gun Incident
text: Gilbert Arenas, the embattled Washington Wizards star, met with federal prosecutors on Monday and afterward issued a statement apologizing for his role in a handgun-related incident in the Wizards’ locker room.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Who’s Your Daddy?
text: It’s generally a life-changing event when people come out of the closet. For Samurai Shoppers though, going into the closet is equally momentous. You may possess a flawless fashion sense, but mistakes do happen: sweaters stretch, bodies shrink, trends outstay their welcome. A true Samurai probes her closet ruthlessly, banishing yesterday’s news and all traces of impulse purchases. Even I have fallen victim to acolytes of Dracula.

headline: Iran Professors Ask for End to Violence
text: Risking expulsion and possible arrest, 88 professors at Tehran University signed a letter on Monday calling on Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the country’s supreme religious leader, to end the use of violence against protesters, saying it was a sign of the government’s weakness.

headline: In Galleon Cases, Timing Could Be Everything
text: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Cold Arctic Pressure Pattern Nearly Off Chart
text: Forecasters say cold and snow are largely the result of a rare pressure pattern in and around the Arctic.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Heidi Mount, Model
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Eating and Gaining Together
text: Many people gain weight as they age, but a large Australian study shows that women with partners gain more weight than women who are single.

headline: Spoleto Festival Usa Unveils 2010 Season
text: One of America’s oldest theaters will show off its newly finished facelift when the Spoleto Festival USA begins its 2010 season in May. Organizers of that classical music and theater festival in Charleston, S.C., said in a news release that it would feature the reopening of the Dock Street Theater, whose namesake was first opened in 1736 and was among the first buildings in the country to be used solely for theatrical performances. After a three-year renovation, the theater will reopen with a production of “Flora, an Opera,” a British ballad opera that was performed at the theater in the early 1700s. The Spoleto Festival USA, which was spun off from the Festival dei Due Mondi in Spoleto, Italy, will also feature productions of Noël Coward’s “Present Laughter,” presented by Dublin’s Gate Theater; “Giselle,” danced by Nina Ananiashvili and the National Ballet of Georgia; “Dance,” a work by Lucinda Childs that includes an original score by Philip Glass; and a short film by the artist Sol LeWitt. The festival runs from May 28 through June 13.

headline: Late Midlife Crisis, Prompted by a Violent Encounter
text: Over the years, in a succession of funny-sad-usually entertaining novels, Anne Tyler has created a male character instantly recognizable as a distinct species despite individual variations: a lost soul or self-proclaimed loser who realizes that his life is stalled and who sinks into a low-grade depression  a sad-sack sort of fellow, basically well meaning but detached and more than a little passive.

headline: C.I.A. Is Sharing Data With Climate Scientists
text: The nation’s top scientists and spies are collaborating on an effort to use the federal government’s intelligence assets  including spy satellites and other classified sensors  to assess the hidden complexities of environmental change. They seek insights from natural phenomena like clouds and glaciers, deserts and tropical forests.

headline: Kanye West Says He’s Back in the Studio
text: True to his word, Kanye West (below right) let Taylor Swift  and all of 2009  finish before announcing he was back at work on a new record. After a surprise appearance at a Kid Cudi show in Los Angeles just before Christmas (at which Mr. West rapped about begging “fashion houses to hire me”), he further baffled fans with a post on his personal blog in which he compared himself to Kobe Bryant, Maya Angelou, Gil Scott-Heron and Nina Simone, The Guardian reported. In the all-caps post at kanyeuniversecity.com, Mr. West thanked his listeners for “their constant love and support over these past six years,” and he said he was working in a studio making new music. He offered few details about his latest effort, saying that he was working “with the same dedication that Kobe has on the court” and that his responsibility, like other modern-day poets and artists, is “to accurately represent what is happening now, so when the powers that be try to rewrite history, you can always look at our works and find truth and sincerity.” Mr. West has generally kept a low profile since a September incident in which he interrupted an acceptance speech by Ms. Swift at the MTV Video Music Awards.

headline: 14 Queens Libraries to Close on Weekends
text: The Queens Library announced on Monday that beginning next month, 14 library branches in Queens will no longer serve customers on the weekends.

headline: Tharp’s Sinatra Show Is Bound for Broadway
text: It has been nearly 35 years since Frank Sinatra played the Great White Way, but Ol’ Blue Eyes is back: his voice will return to Broadway in a Twyla Tharp musical that its producers said on Monday would transfer to the Marquis Theater later this year.
