The musical, conceived, choreographed and directed by Ms. Tharp, was titled “Come Fly With Me” when it was presented at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta last fall (above, with Keith Roberts and Karine Plantadit) but will be called “Come Fly Away” for its Broadway run. (The show’s press representatives did not immediately offer an explanation for the name change, you dig?) It is to begin previews at the Marquis on March 1 and open on March 25. Casting was not announced. Mr. Sinatra’s previous Broadway credit, according to ibdb.com, was a 1975 concert at the Uris Theater with Ella Fitzgerald and Count Basie. Ms. Tharp (“Movin’ Out”) has used Mr. Sinatra’s music in her dance pieces “Once More Frank,” “Nine Sinatra Songs” and “Sinatra Suite.”

headline: Cleveland Orchestra Without Contract
text: Under a cloud of labor strife, the Cleveland Orchestra planned to begin rehearsals on Tuesday. The players’ contract with management expired on Aug. 30, but both sides agreed to an extension during negotiations. The players’ union, however, “formally terminated the extension agreement,” giving them the right to strike, the orchestra management said. “We’re operating without a contract,” said Gary Hanson, the orchestra’s executive director. “That situation represents an unspecified threat to the entire concert schedule.” The orchestra management is seeking cuts in salaries and benefits, said Leonard Di Cosimo, president of Local 4 of the American Federation of Musicians in Cleveland. A negotiating session is scheduled for Wednesday, a day before the year’s first concert.

headline: ‘Celebrity Apprentice’ Books Rod Blagojevich
text: Rod R. Blagojevich, the disgraced former governor of Illinois, may never hold an elected office again, but he has at least fulfilled his ancillary goal of getting booked on a reality show. Mr. Blagojevich, who was removed from office last January by the Illinois State Senate after his indictment on federal corruption charges, will be one of 14 contestants competing for the favor of Donald J. Trump on “The Celebrity Apprentice,” The Associated Press reported. Mr. Blagojevich, who was arrested and charged in December 2008 with conspiring to profit from his authority to appoint a successor for Barack Obama in the United States Senate, was denied in his previous attempt to become a reality television star. In April a judge rejected his request for permission to travel to Costa Rica for the NBC series “I’m a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here!” while he awaits his federal trial. (The judge said at the time that Mr. Blagojevich did not appreciate “the position he finds himself in.”) Mr. Blagojevich’s rivals on “The Celebrity Apprentice,” which is taped in New York and makes its debut on March 14 on NBC, include Darryl Strawberry, Cyndi Lauper and Sharon Osbourne.

headline: One Monteverdi Work and 400 Years of Debate
text: The classical music world, besotted with anniversaries and now deep into the Romantic age, will celebrate the bicentenaries of Schumann and Chopin this year. In addition the early-music contingent, appropriately, will hark back another two centuries, to a landmark work whose informal name all but announces the anniversary, Monteverdi’s 1610 Vespers.

headline: Democrats Likely to Dispense With Conference Committee
text: House Democratic leaders will meet on Tuesday to begin discussing plans to merge their version of major health care legislation with the bill adopted by the Senate on Christmas Eve. But leadership aides in both chambers say there are no plans for a formal conference committee to reconcile the two measures.

headline: A Toxic Workplace, With Ill-Tempered Clients
text: There are more than 700 reasons not to visit Australia, Donald Schultz tells us, in a backhanded sort of way, in the opening episode of “Wild Recon” on Tuesday night on Animal Planet.

headline: Dances With Smurfs
text: For all its box office love, “Avatar” has also been hailed as “Dances with Smurfs” (cf. “South Park”). The pop culture fiends at MTV draw some parallels between James Cameron’s 3D epic and Kevin Costner’s Oscar-winning “Dances With Wolves,” as well as the sci-fi reaches of David Lynch’s “Dune” and the don’t-exploit-us sensitivity of Disney’s “Pocohantas.”

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘M’
text: This week, A. O. Scott looks back at Fritz Lang’s 1931 film “M,” about a serial killer stalking the streets of Berlin. Peter Lorre gives what Mr. Scott calls an “unnervingly persuasive performance” as the killer.

headline: Box Offices Ring in Broadway’s New Year
text: It was a Happy New Year at most Broadway box offices last week, with “Wicked,” “The Lion King” and “The Phantom of the Opera” setting records even after long runs on the boards, while other shows were winding down their runs on financial high notes.

headline: New Health Rule: Quit Worrying About Your Health
text: Have you had your five to nine servings of vegetables today? Exercised for an hour? Cut back on saturated fat and gotten eight hours of sleep?

headline: Morgan Freeman Becomes ‘CBS Evening News’ Announcer
text: CBS News is retiring Walter Cronkite’s voice, nearly six months after the esteemed anchorman died. Beginning Monday, the actor Morgan Freeman will read the introduction to the “CBS Evening News.”

headline: Intense Screenings for 14 Nations
text: There was harsh reaction from around the world to plans by the U.S. to conduct more thorough screenings of passengers arriving here from 14 countries.

headline: Even in G.O.P., Lazio’s Bid for Governor Is Hard Sell
text: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y.  Rick A. Lazio is on a tear: ripping into corruption and cowardice in Albany, blasting state leaders’ addiction to spending and taxes, warning that New York is on the verge of losing a generation of job seekers to economic decline.

headline: Mara Fumes; Sheridan Is Dismissed
text: The Giants’ president, John Mara, was scathing in his assessment of his team earlier today. A few hours later, the defensive coordinator Bill Sheridan was dismissed. Here’s a transcript of Mara’s discussion with reporters, via Giants.com:

headline: Visa Reigns With Silent Tax
text: The growing use of debit cards has meant big profits for Visa, and there are concerns that the company's market power has led to unnecessarily high fees to merchants.

headline: Coaxing an Antique Press to ‘Kiss the Page’
text: Stop the presses. That’s what Robert Warner, 53, does every time he takes his foot off the treadle at one of the antique letterpresses at Bowne and Company Stationers at the South Street Seaport Museum. Bowne, founded in 1775 and claiming to be the oldest company in the city still operating under the same name, opened the museum print shop to celebrate its bicentennial. Twenty years later, Mr. Warner, an eyeglasses-maker and artist, wandered in to volunteer. Now he is the master printer there in a former cast iron stove factory from 1835, turning out stationery, social announcements and commemorative items to raise money for the museum and teaching the digital generation of schoolchildren an ancient craft.

headline: British Prime Minister ‘Appalled’ by Protest Plan
text: LONDON  A radical Islamic group planning a protest march through the streets of a town that has achieved iconic status in Britain for honoring the passing hearses of British soldiers killed in Afghanistan ran into a stiff rebuff from the British government on Monday.

headline: Take Off Your Shoes, and Is the Parrot Loaded?
text: “DOES he bite?” the screener at the checkpoint asked warily.

headline: Shopping With Alexandra Champalimaud
text: A few carefully selected items is often all it takes to warm up even the most sparsely furnished room.

headline: Ex-Senator Runs for Governor in Rhode Island as Independent
text: BOSTON  Lincoln D. Chafee, the former Republican senator from Rhode Island who lost his seat to a Democrat in 2006 despite his family’s longtime presence in state politics, announced Monday that he would run for governor there as an independent.

headline: Where to Buy Warmth
text: CREATING a feeling of warmth at home is essential this time of year — especially in minimalist interiors, which can sometimes feel cold. And adding a few carefully selected items is often all it takes to warm up even the most sparsely furnished rooms.

headline: My Favorite 14 Apps of 2009
text: Looking back on the several hundred apps I have evaluated since the start of Gadgetwise, I thought a “Best Of” list would an appropriate way to kick off the new year. But how do I determine what’s best? Apps that are highest rated? Apps with highest number of downloads? Apps that I personally use most? No method seems really perfect, but what I settled on were the apps that I was most likely to show people when they asked “What do I need with a smartphone?”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,362 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: The N.F.L. Season’s Leaders for 2009
text: The final N.F.L. leaders in some prominent categories:

headline: Samsung Introduces Hybrid D.S.L.R. Camera
text: Samsung has announced, with limited details, its first interchangeable lens camera. The Samsung NX10 will be displayed at the upcoming CES Show in Las Vegas, so we’ll get more details later in the week.

headline: Rising Price of Faith in France’s Shrinking Parishes
text: GESTÉ, France  The soaring steeple, airy flying buttresses and steep slate roof of the 19th-century parish church that dominates this town in western France is  like many other village churches in France  scheduled for demolition, a victim of its size, its condition and, ultimately, municipal budget concerns.

headline: Week 17 Quick Hits: A Playoff Format Flaw
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names New Top Financial Bankers
text: Morgan Stanley named new heads of its financial institutions group last week, the latest reshuffling of its bankers in the wake of changes imposed by its new chief executive, James P. Gorman.

headline: A Snowboarder’s Dream and a Family’s Anguish
text: Over breakfast in Copper Mountain, Colo., on Dec. 13, snowboarder Kevin Pearce talked about the wicked crash in the halfpipe that shattered his ankle in June. It kept him off his snowboard until November.

headline: Will Profiling Make a Difference?
text: Updated, Jan. 5, 1:10 p.m. |  Philip Baum, a London-based aviation security expert, argues that profiling based on an analysis of the appearance, behavior, itinerary and passport of a passenger can be effective.

headline: Third Uninvited Guest at State Dinner
text: WASHINGTON  The saga of President Obama’s first state dinner continues.

headline: Attempt to Break New Irish Blasphemy Law
text: Last Friday morning in Ireland, about 30 minutes after a new law took effect with the new year that makes blasphemy a crime punishable by a fine of up to $35,000, a group of Irish atheists invited the government to prosecute them by publishing 25 blasphemous statements on an Irish Web site.

headline: Pitching a Product, Without Showing It
text: SPECIAL K, the 54-year-old Kellogg brand, has in recent years aimed at women with its “Special K Challenge,” which recommends replacing two meals daily with cereal and curtailing snacking to lose up to six pounds in two weeks. The popularity of the plan led the brand to expand to nine flavors and develop noncereal products like frozen waffles, protein bars, crackers, shakes and powdered drink mixes that can be substituted for cereal at mealtimes or eaten as the two daily snacks the plan permits.

headline: Neediest | Going Back to School
text: Out of work and behind on rent, Denise Wintz got help from the Neediest Cases Fund to get caught up, and went back to school to pursue a new career.

headline: Demonstrating Resourcefulness in the Face of Career Challenges
text: Have a problem? Denise Wintz has a Web site for you. Or a book. Or a motivational seminar.

headline: Abbott Says Plushenko is ‘Just Another Competitor’
text: Jeremy Abbott, the 2009 United States national figure skating champion, isn’t intimidated by the Russian skater Yevgeny Plushenko.

headline: How Visa, Using Card Fees, Dominates a Market
text: Every day, millions of Americans stand at store checkout counters and make a seemingly random decision: after swiping their debit card, they choose whether to punch in a code, or to sign their name.

headline: Tax Enforcers Intensify Focus on Multinationals
text: While the recession may be ending across much of the world, its effect on revenue collectors and corporate tax returns will last much longer.

headline: As Zorn Exits, Redskins Talk to Shanahan
text: Finally, two years after he was the surprise hire and after a season in which he was stripped of everything but the headset he wore on the sideline, Jim Zorn was fired by the Washington Redskins early Monday morning.

headline: Deciphering Hall Ballot Without Superstar
text: There is no higher level for a baseball player than to be a Hall of Famer, and no ranking or seeding among the chosen few. The plaque for Johnny Evers is the same size as the one for Johnny Bench, no distinguishing between obscure and obvious.

headline: Washington Post Discontinues Chess Column
text: The Washington Post has ended its chess column written by Lubomir Kavalek. The final column, which was published Jan. 4, noted that Kavalek covered chess for the newspaper for 23 years. Kavalek said in a telephone interview that the column began in 1995 and that before that he had written about chess events, beginning with the 1986 world championship match between Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov.

headline: Credit Suisse Is Accused of Defrauding Investors in 4 Resorts
text: HELENA, Mont.  Investors at four high-end resorts have filed a class-action lawsuit against Credit Suisse and the real estate services company Cushman & Wakefield, contending that they conspired to inflate the value of the properties so they could take them over.

headline: In Yemen, U.S. Faces Leader Who Puts Family First
text: SANA, Yemen  The United States is quickly ramping up its aid to Yemen, which Washington sees as a revived new front against Al Qaeda. But one of the most delicate tasks will be managing the relationship with the president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, who has filled his government with numerous members of his family and who wants to ensure that his son Ahmed succeeds him, Yemeni officials, analysts and Western diplomats say.

headline: In Russia, a Bankrupt Town Keeps Humming
text: BARANCHINSKY, Russia  For a few weeks this winter, this town wobbled on the edge of nonexistence.

headline: Court Upholds Conviction in 9/11 Case
text: A federal appeals court on Monday upheld the conviction of the only person who has been tried in a United States court on charges of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Roberto Alomar Awaits the Hall’s Call
text: When he passes a career milestone, Ken Griffey Jr. often says that he never dreamed about it. All he ever wanted, Griffey will say, was to be as good as his father.

headline: Novartis to Pay $28 Billion for a Majority Stake in Alcon
text: Novartis, the large Swiss drug maker, said Monday that it would take control of the eye care company Alcon by buying a majority stake from Nestlé for $28.1 billion. The move would raise its stake in Alcon to 77 percent, and Novartis said it was interested in acquiring the rest of the shares.

headline: The Resurgence of the Hazaras
text: For most of Afghanistan’s history the Hazara were typically servants, cleaners, porters and little else, an ethnic Shiite minority sidelined for generations.

headline: Oil Feud Reflects Growing Rift Between Russia and Belarus, Once Close Allies
text: MOSCOW  The oil price dispute that erupted over the weekend between Russia and Belarus has been depicted as a threat to European energy supplies  a development that has become something of an annual cold weather ritual. The greater threat, however, seems to be to relations between the two countries, often thought of as the closest of allies.

headline: Odds Against Gay Marriage Grow With Setback in Trenton
text: With just two weeks before New Jersey changes governors, gay-rights advocates are facing lengthening odds  and they have been long for some time now  of winning approval of a law that would grant legal recognition to same-sex marriages in the state.

headline: Dubai Opens a Tower to Beat All
text: Burdened by debt and a devastating real estate crash, Dubai is doing what it does best: doubling down.

headline: Outside the Box
text: Wonder Bread plastic bags sliced and weaved into a rug; buttons nailed and wired to a branch; weathered tree trunks transformed into comical demons. All of these unusual creations are part of “Toward Abstraction,” a “thought-provoking exhibition” at the American Folk Art Museum, writes Ken Johnson. The show is an example of the trend in mainstreaming self-taught art, and Brooke Davis Anderson, the museum’s curator of contemporary art, has selected from the permanent collection some 60 works in which formal, material and procedural elements are “asserted with particular vigor.” Go to see the imaginative designs of those who work “outside the professional art box.” Get inspired.

headline: Spring Ahead
text: Grab an early start on spring fashion today courtesy of the Japanese master craftsman Issey Miyake. The designer’s TriBeCa flagship has temporarily set up shop uptown with a pop-up store at 807 Madison Avenue, at 68th Street. You have until Jan. 30 to scout out new items for spring/summer 2010 for both men and women as well as pieces from the Cauliflower, Pleats Please and HaaT lines.

headline: The Return of Peter Boal
text: Balletomanes should rejoice tonight when  Pacific Northwest Ballet makes its long overdue New York debut under Peter Boal’s direction at the Joyce Theater. When Mr. Boal retired from New York City Ballet in 2005 “he left a gaping hole,” writes Gia Kourlas. “As it happens, there just aren’t enough well-proportioned, innately elegant men with scrupulous line and demeanor to go around.” This week Mr. Boal returns to the city not as a dancer but as the artistic director of the Seattle-based company. He has brought 21 dancers to present a program of repertory works, including two that were created for the company: Twyla Tharp’s “Opus 111” and Benjamin Millepied’s “3 Movements.”

headline: New Air Security Checks From 14 Nations to U.S. Draw Criticism
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration’s decision to mandate extra scrutiny  including full-body pat downs  for people flying into the United States from 14 mostly Muslim countries provoked criticism from foreign officials and skepticism from some security experts that the measures would be effective.

headline: With Death and Taxes, Timing Is All
text: My wife and I decided that our wills needed an update. The old documents were written so long ago that “cellphone” was a fairly new word suggesting prison slang for convicts calling home.

headline: When a Citizen Feels Impelled to Help
text: Just over a year ago, Laura van Straaten, a 41-year-old multimedia executive who had recently joined the ranks of the underemployed, stopped on a slushy street corner on West End Avenue to watch someone administering CPR to an older man who had collapsed. She saw how hard the man giving CPR was working, the sweat that slicked his face in the December cold as he pressed on the stranger’s chest, pushing him farther down into a small pile of snow with every compression. And she felt some chagrin that neither she nor the other bystanders could help the man who was struggling to keep that failing heart pumping.

headline: Big Plans for Old Sugar Refinery Face Review
text: In 2004, the Domino Sugar refinery that occupied five blocks along the Brooklyn waterfront in Williamsburg for more than 150 years shut down, joining the neighboring brick factories as remnants of the area’s industrial past.

headline: The Tea Party Teens
text: The United States opens this decade in a sour mood. First, Americans are anxious about the future. Sixty-one percent of Americans believe the country is in decline, according to the latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal survey. Only 27 percent feel confident that their children’s generation will be better off than they are.

headline: Google Moves to Keep Its Lead as Web Goes Mobile
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google unveiled a rival to Apple’s iPhone on Tuesday, part of its careful plan to try to do what few other technology companies have done before: retain its leadership as computing shifts from one generation to the next.

headline: True Economic Barometer? How About Bowling
text: As New York struggles to resurrect its economy, it needs powerful new engines of growth. Wall Street may look sturdier, but it will never be the old Wall Street again, when $10 routinely became $1 million during your lunch break. Another eruption in real estate prices? Dubious. The new sports stadiums? Not going to get us there.

headline: Man Accused of Second Rape on Same Manhattan Rooftop
text: A 25-year-old Upper Manhattan man was arrested Sunday on charges that he raped a woman on a rooftop on New Year’s Day  the same place where he was accused of raping a teenager three months ago.

headline: Mayor Sticking by Tourism Projections Despite Dropoff in 2009
text: With the number of visitors to New York City declining by almost 2 million last year, it might be reasonable to expect that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would offer a less than rosy view of the decline, or at least express some concern that a continued slump might be in store in 2010.
Stanley Fish is away this week.

headline: An Uneasy Feeling
text: I’m starting the new year with the sinking feeling that important opportunities are slipping from the nation’s grasp. Our collective consciousness tends to obsess indiscriminately over one or two issues  the would-be bomber on the flight into Detroit, the Tiger Woods saga  while enormous problems that should be engaged get short shrift.

headline: For Cape Cod Wind Farm, New Hurdle Is Spiritual
text: BOSTON  In a new setback for a controversial wind farm proposed off Cape Cod, the National Park Service announced Monday that Nantucket Sound was eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places, guaranteeing further delays for the project.

headline: With Physical Behind Him, Bay Joins Mets
text: The slugging left fielder Jason Bay officially joined the Mets on Monday when he passed his physical, the only thing delaying completion of his four-year, $66 million contract. Bay was introduced Tuesday at a news conference at Citi Field .

headline: A Team That Wins, but Can’t Win Respect
text: I am an invisible man. No, I am not a spook like those who haunted Edgar Allan Poe; nor am I one of your Hollywood-movie ectoplasms. I am a man of substance, of flesh and bone, fiber and liquids  and I might even be said to possess a mind. I am invisible, understand, simply because people refuse to see me.

headline: Lawmakers Grill Doctor for His Views on Concussions
text: DETROIT  Although the most theatrical moments of a House Judiciary Committee hearing on football brain injuries on Monday involved the grilling of a former N.F.L. doctor, most of the testimony centered on the application of recently strengthened professional rules to amateur levels, from youth leagues to college programs.

headline: Wizards’ Arenas Says Unloaded Guns Were a Misguided Joke
text: Gilbert Arenas, the embattled Washington Wizards star, apologized on Monday for what he called a misguided joke involving unloaded handguns, but he insisted that he never threatened anyone during a locker-room incident Dec. 21.

headline: When the Pilot Pulls Out the Flashlight
text: I DON’T enjoy flying as I used to. But who does?

headline: It Was All Started By a Mouse (Part 2)
text: (This is the second part of a two-part article. Click here for the first part.)

headline: Texas’s Kindle Raises Hopes and Questions
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  A couple of weeks after Texas won the 2005 national championship, Sergio Kindle arrived on the Longhorns’ campus. It was an eye-opening experience for Kindle, then an 18-year-old from inner-city Dallas.

headline: This Year’s Housing Crisis
text: The financial crisis and Great Recession have their roots in the housing bust. When it comes, a lasting recovery will be evident in a housing rebound. Unfortunately, housing appears to be weakening anew.

headline: Does Visa Play Fair?
text: We just published an article by Andrew Martin that explains how Visa has become the dominant payment network for credit and debit cards. Among other things, the article reports that Visa makes more than twice as much money on a transaction if a consumer signs a debit receipt rather than punching in a four-digit PIN. Mr. Martin also writes:

headline: Not Quite Making a Name for Himself at T.C.U.
text: Texas Christian quarterback Andy Dalton only had a couple of options when it came to playing college football.

headline: Pent-Up Anger
text: If what I do prove well, it won’t advance.They’ll say it’s stolen, or else it was by chance. — Anne Bradstreet

headline: Health Spending Rises in 2008, but at Slower Rate
text: Health spending grew in 2008 at the slowest pace in 48 years as the recession throttled back the explosive growth of health costs, the federal government reported Monday.

headline: Union To Put ‘Horrible’ Newsday Deal To Vote
text: A proposed contract reached between Newsday and its largest union would cut salaries by 10 percent, extend the workweek and eliminate one week of paid vacation per year, among other concessions, employees were told on Monday.

headline: What’s Acceptable for Bank Returns?
text: What is an acceptable return on equity for a bank? That question is likely to dominate the debate among executives, investors and regulators in the 2010.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the playwright and actor Sam Shepard was published in error. His arrest on charges of speeding and driving under the influence of alcohol occurred a year ago, not early Saturday morning. The Times regrets the error.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture with the Saturday Profile about Choi Sung-yong, the leader of Abductees’ Family Union who works to bring home South Koreans believed to have been kidnapped by North Korea, was published in error. The picture showed Choi Wook-il, a man who was smuggled out of the North by the Abductees’ Family Union; it was not of Choi Sung-yong.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Tuesday about travelers’ confusion over new security rules at airports misspelled the surname of a college student bound for Pittsburgh, who passed through security in Philadelphia. She is Current D’Ignazio, not D’Ignazil.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about accusations that an administrator for the union that represents workers who build tunnels embezzled money to pay for a lavish lifestyle misspelled the name of the school in the Bronx where she sent her children. It is Fieldston, not Fieldstone.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture credit last Tuesday with an article about the discovery of a two photographs believed to be of the first immigrant to set foot on Ellis Island when it opened in 1892 misstated her married name. She was Annie Moore Schayer, not Shulman.

headline: E-Mail Hoax Raises Hopes of a Day Off
text: For one glorious hour Sunday night, it looked as though Brooklyn Technical High School’s 4,900 students would not have to drag themselves out of bed at 7 a.m. for the first day of school after the long winter break. An e-mail message, purportedly from a school administrator, was sent to student government leaders saying that a construction accident had forced the building to close.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Paterson Seeks Overhaul to Combat Corruption
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson on Wednesday will unveil a set of sweeping proposals to rein in political corruption in state government, including vastly expanded ethics oversight, term limits for all state officeholders and a system of public campaign financing modeled on New York City’s, administration officials said on Monday.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Monday listing the National Football League’s final leaders in seven categories included, in some editions, outdated statistics for three players, one each in touchdowns, tackles and interceptions; in some copies, it also omitted two quarterbacks from the passing yards list. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/sports.

headline: Sales Spur Optimism in Manhattan Real Estate
text: The 2009 Manhattan real estate market ended on a better note than it began, according to fourth-quarter reports that were to be released Tuesday by the city’s largest brokerages.

headline: Higgins’s Goal Lifts Rangers at Garden
text: The Eastern Conference is so mediocre that the Rangers are in seventh place after beating the Boston Bruins, 3-2, on Monday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Jets’ Ryan Is Planning on Four More Games
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Less than 17 hours after the Jets’ most dominating and important victory of the season, Coach Rex Ryan stepped purposefully onto a platform Monday, grasped the sides of a lectern and said they had merely earned the right to keep playing football.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Dec. 22 about new frequent-flier tiers and other perks being provided by some airlines misstated the number of miles needed to achieve Continental Airlines’ new top category of Presidential Platinum. It is 100,000 miles, not 125,000.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the Pacific Investment Management Company’s hiring of Neel T. Kashkari, who ran the Troubled Asset Relief Program in the Bush administration, misstated the location of the cabin in which he decompressed after leaving that job a few months after the Obama administration took office. It was near Lake Tahoe in northeast  not northwest  California.

headline: Corrections
text: A brief report in the Gadgetwise column on Thursday about the Mattel Mindflex game misstated the number of batteries required. It is seven (four C batteries and three AAA batteries), not eight.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about new stamps the United States Postal Service will issue this year misidentified the image on a stamp portraying Katharine Hepburn that is to be issued on May 12. The image is from her movie “Woman of the Year,” not from the play “West Side Waltz.” (The margins on sheets of the stamps depict her in “West Side Waltz.”)

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Dec. 24 about the replacement of a scheduled production of “Speed-the-Plow” at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles with a revival of “The Subject Was Roses” erroneously attributed a distinction to Neil Pepe, who directed the 2008-9 revival of “Speed-the-Plow” on Broadway and will direct “The Subject Was Roses.” Mr. Pepe was not nominated for a Tony Award for his direction of “Speed-the-Plow.”

headline: Corrections
text: THE ARTS

headline: Curtis Allina Dies at 87; He Put the Heads on Pez
text: Curtis Allina, a candy company executive who presided over a powerful innovation in marketing that was less about the candy itself than it was about the container it came in  and who in unintended consequence created a universe of enraptured collectors  died Dec. 15 at his home in Olympia, Wash. Mr. Allina, who helped bring the world the modern Pez dispenser, was 87.

headline: Hate Begets Hate
text: Uganda’s government, which has a shameful record of discrimination against gay men and lesbians, is now considering legislation that would impose the death sentence for homosexual behavior. The United States and others need to make clear to the Ugandan government that such barbarism is intolerable and will make it an international pariah.

headline: Tasers and Liability
text: A federal appeals court in California has sent a strong warning to law enforcement officials that should make them rethink the all-too-common use of Tasers. It ruled last week that a police officer can be held liable for delivering a high-level electric shock to an unarmed person who poses no immediate threat.

headline: MoMA and the Coming Flood
text: The Tim Burton exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art was sold out, which is not serious deprivation at a museum that also offers Cézanne’s apples and Matisse’s goldfish. But what could disappointed fans of the dark vision of Edward Scissorhands or Gothic Batman turn to?

headline: To Stop a Terrorist: No Lack of Ideas
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preventing Attacks: Do We Expect Too Much?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Model for Prison Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: What’s Our Line?
text: Washington

headline: Casey Johnson, Daughter of Jets Owner, Dies at 30
text: The Jets announced Monday that Casey Johnson, a daughter of the team’s owner, Woody Johnson, had died in Los Angeles. The cause of the death was undetermined. Ms. Johnson was 30.

headline: A Venture Integrating Skype Into the Family Room
text: SAN FRANCISCO  There will soon be something new to watch on the living room TV: your relatives and friends in different parts of the world.

headline: Home and Away Opponents for 2010 N.F.L. Season
text: As the playoff teams look forward to what lies ahead, the rest of the league is already focused on next season. While the dates and game times have yet to be determined, the home and away opponents for 2010 are set.

headline: The Surge Is Over. The Americans Are Going. I’m Leaving Iraq.
text: BAGHDAD–This month I received the long-awaited phone call from the International Organization for Migration telling me that they had put me on their schedule to leave Iraq within the next few weeks.

headline: Word of the Day | culmination
text: culmination •\ˌkəl-mə-ˈna-shən\• noun

headline: Boise State Cracks Open Close Game With Surprise Encore of Trickery
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Any casual college football fan who stumbled upon Boise State in the magical Fiesta Bowl three years ago knows that the Broncos can conjure up the most creative of happy endings.

headline: Saving the Economy, One Strike at a Time
text: Within the past several years, a spate of upscale bowling alleys have come to New York, with features such as V.I.P. lounges, clubs and dress codes.

headline: Rex Ryan, Quipster, and Now Playoff Coach
text: Rex Ryan could charge admission to his news conferences, which are part football briefings and part monologues. Recommended reading: Greg Bishop’s article on “Rex’s Greatest Hits.”

headline: Ihor Sevcenko, Byzantine and Slavic Scholar, Dies at 87
text: Ihor Sevcenko, a leading scholar of Byzantine and Slavic history and literature who as a young man persuaded George Orwell to collaborate with him on a Ukrainian translation of “Animal Farm” for distribution to refugees, died at his home in Cambridge, Mass., on Dec. 26. He was 87.

headline: Tour de Fence
text: WHO is Danny MacAskill?

headline: News Quiz | January 5, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Bergeron Hurt as Bruins Fall to Rangers
text: Only two games on Monday, and Olympians figured in both of them. Home teams listed first:

headline: Kraft Offers Cadbury More Cash and Sells Unit to Nestlé
text: Kraft said Tuesday that it would offer more cash in its $16 billion hostile takeover bid for the British chocolate maker Cadbury, using the proceeds from a $3.7 billion sale of its North American pizza unit to Nestlé.

headline: Percy Delivers Boise’s Most Confounding Trick Play
text: Boise State’s J.C. Percy was No. 48 in your Fiesta Bowl program, but you’re forgiven if you missed him. Sure, he played in the No. 6 Broncos’ hard-fought 17-10 victory over No. 3 Texas Christian.

headline: Talbots Amends Credit Facility Ahead of Deal
text: Talbots, the clothing retailer, said Monday it had amended its secured revolving loan agreement with shareholder Aeon to repay all of its outstanding third-party bank debt.

headline: What’s Acceptable for Bank Returns?
text: What is an acceptable return on equity for a bank? That question is likely to dominate the debate among executives, investors and regulators in 2010, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: Backer Settles Suit Over Crime Drama
text: The legal wrangling over the troubled crime drama “Black Water Transit” has taken another turn, with the film’s backer quietly settling a $3.1 million lawsuit brought by a producer on the eve of trial, Reuters reported.

headline: Sumitomo Mitsui Said to Consider $8.7 Billion Share Sale
text: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Japan’s second-largest bank by market value, may announce plans this week to raise about 800 billion yen ($8.7 billion) in a share sale, two people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: Class Time + Substitute = Waste?
text: According to a recent Op-Ed, more than 5% of teachers are absent on any given day, which means that by the time you finish high school, you have had substitutes for nearly a year of your schooling. And few substitutes are trained in either teaching or the curriculum they have to cover. What experiences have you had with substitutes?

headline: Third Avenue Confirms Whitman’s Role Change
text: Third Avenue Management confirmed Monday that Martin J. Whitman will relinquish his role as the firm’s co-chief investment officer.

headline: International Aluminum Files For Chapter 11
text: International Aluminum Corporation, an American producer of aluminum and vinyl building products, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection late on Monday, hurt by a downturn in residential and commercial construction.

headline: Bond Market Perks Up After Weak Finish in ’09
text: Long-term borrowing costs mostly fell Monday as investors put more money into the Treasury market following a weak end to 2009.

headline: Welcome Home, Wives
text: Whether or not you’re willing to admit that you missed “Desperate Housewives,” ABC was grateful for the women of Wisteria Lane, as a new episode of that prime-time soap opera helped the network place second on Sunday night. NBC was first with “Sunday Night Football”; although Nielsen’s final audience figures were not immediately available, the preliminary overnight estimates for the New York Jets-Cincinnati Bengals game were higher than any other broadcast for the night but slightly lower than last week’s game, which averaged 19 million viewers. “Desperate Housewives” drew 15.2 million viewers for the night, and ABC was also lifted by new episodes of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (11 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” (10.9 million). CBS was third with “60 Minutes” (14.9 million), followed by reruns of “NCIS” and “Cold Case.” Fox was fourth with its animated comedy lineup, including “The Simpsons” (8.7 million) and “Family Guy” (8.1 million).

headline: MF Global Moves Corporate Home to Delaware
text: MF Global, the futures and options broker, said Monday it has changed its corporate domicile to Delaware from Bermuda.

headline: China May Allow Futures Contracts in March
text: China’s securities regulator may introduce futures contracts on the country’s stock indexes as early as March, an official with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: Japan Airlines Shares Jump as More Aid Is Sought
text: Japan Airlines shares jumped more than 30 percent Monday as the government looked to secure funds to prevent the carrier from running out of cash as it awaited a possible bailout.

headline: Not Guilty Plea in Philippines Massacre
text: MANILA  A mayor in the southern Philippines accused in the November massacre of dozens of people  the worst act of political violence in the country’s history  pleaded not guilty to 41 charges of murder at the opening of his trial on Tuesday.

headline: Messting
text: Text messages that could mess up your life.

headline: Biogen Chief and Icahn Adversary to Retire
text: Carl C. Icahn may be pleased to learn that one of his adversaries, James C. Mullen, the chief executive of Biogen Idec, is retiring as president and chief executive of the company as of June 8.

headline: Manufacturing Data Helps Invigorate Wall Street
text: Wall Street ushered in 2010 on Monday with its biggest stock market rally in nearly two months, as signs that manufacturing was strengthening around the world fed hopes that the economy would recover this year.

headline: Dodging the Dollar at Overseas Meetings
text: Although it has ticked up a bit recently, the United States dollar did not have a particularly good 2009. Nor was its value against competing currencies like the euro and Japanese yen easy to predict.

headline: Tax Enforcers Intensify Focus on Multinationals
text: While the recession may be ending across much of the world, its effect on revenue collectors and corporate tax returns will last much longer.

headline: TV Venture Gives Skype a Boost
text: There will soon be something new to watch on the living room TV: your relatives and friends in different parts of the world.

headline: Premier Takes 50 Percent Stake in North Sea Block
text: Premier Oil said it would take a 50 percent interest and assume operatorship of Block 22/19c in the Central North Sea after reaching an agreement with Serica Energy, Reuters reported.

headline: BofA Chief Disagrees With Calls for Bank Breakups
text: The chief executive of Bank of America, Brian Moynihan, said the financial industry needed to embrace a looming regulatory overhaul instead of fight it, but added that breaking up the biggest United States banks would be a mistake.

headline: Alcon Directors Criticize Novartis Tactics
text: An independent committee of directors of Alcon is disappointed with a takeover bid from Novartis, saying Novartis, the Swiss drug maker, is trying to circumvent protections for minority shareholders.

headline: S.E.C. Names Head of Inspections Office
text: A partner in PricewaterhouseCoopers, the big accounting firm, has been named to head a crucial division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which was blamed for contributing to the breakdown that allowed Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar fraud to go undetected for 16 years, The Associated Press reported.

headline: India Tightens Tourist Visa Rules
text: The Indian government recently announced that foreigners holding tourist visas, including ones with multiple entries, are now banned from re-entering the country within two months of their departure.

headline: Securities Suits Decline as Credit Crisis Fades
text: Securities-fraud class-action lawsuits fell 24 percent in 2009 as litigation related to the credit crisis, and especially subprime mortgage losses, began to dry up, according to a study, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Boyd Holbrook, Artist/Actor/Filmmaker
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: With Canadian Oil Merger, Prices Heat Up
text: PetroBakken Energy said Monday that it had paid $262 million to buy Berens Energy, a company that has drilled just three wells on its oil lands, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: How Safe Is a World Without the Bomb?
text: Today’s idea: Why should we expect a world without nuclear weapons to be safer than one with them? It’s time to think through the “hair-trigger” scenarios that nuclear abolition could bring about, says a Nobel-winning academic.

headline: Bank Lobbying Abetted Mortgage Mess, I.M.F. Says
text: Large United States banks that lobbied heavily were more likely to practice risky lending, and see their shares perform relatively poorly, the International Monetary Fund said in a study.

headline: Threats Lead Food Agency to Curtail Aid in Somalia
text: UNITED NATIONS  After weeks of receiving threats and demands that it dismiss many female employees and pay a “security fee” to an Islamic extremist group, the United Nations World Food Program announced Tuesday that it was suspending food deliveries to one million people in southern Somalia indefinitely.

headline: One on One: Jack Dorsey of Twitter and Square
text: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

headline: I.P.O. Market Remained Dreary in 2009
text: As I wrote in an article in Monday’s paper, venture capitalists are beginning to see signs of life in Silicon Valley.

headline: Aviva Buys U.S. Asset Manager
text: Aviva said it had bought a fund manager in the United States for an undisclosed sum, in an effort to win more investment management business from institutional investors there, Reuters reported.

headline: Rexchip Weighs I.P.O. in Taiwan
text: Rexchip Electronics, a memory-chip joint venture between Japan’s Elpida Memory and Taiwan’s Powerchip Semiconductor, is weighing an initial public offering in Taiwan this year, Dow Jones reported.

headline: Goldman Reviews London Operations, Report Says
text: A report Monday that Goldman Sachs is considering moving some of its key departments in London overseas has sparked the city’s mayor to call for a re-think on the U.K. government’s plans to implement a bonus tax.

headline: Are Bonuses Giving Manhattan Real Estate a Lift?
text: Is the return of the Wall Street bonus helping spur a comeback for Manhattan real estate prices? The suggestion by CNN Money, on the back of fourth-quarter figures that show that the 2009 Manhattan real estate market ended on a better note than it began.

headline: S.E.C. Plans Hedge Fund Sweeps
text: Some hedge funds may find themselves in tight spot in 2010 — not because of the markets, but because of one regulator who is setting his sights on wrongdoing in the industry.

headline: Enthusiasts to Descend on Detroit to Save Saab
text: “Sell Saab!” That’s the message of a group of Saab owners and enthusiasts who will gather, with their vehicles, at General Motors’ Renaissance Center headquarters in Detroit today for a last-ditch appeal to preserve the embattled brand.

headline: Sampler: New Shuttle, New Bookstores, a New Way to Sign Petitions
text: Oakland Mayor Dellums Takes a Different Route | Oakland’s Mayor Ron Dellums was not among the Californian mayors who signed a letter asking state leaders to move quickly in order to qualify for federal education financing. His advisers said Mayor Dellums respectfully declined, instead seeking specific support of amendments to the “Race to the Top” legislation such as a push for a diverse teaching corps. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The Sacramento Bee]

headline: Looking for Stability, Not Increases, in House Prices
text: Don’t expect housing prices to return to their boom levels for years, if not decades, an economist writes.

headline: Cold, Hard Fact: Packers Rule as Defensive Hogs
text: Looking for an edge as you prepare to dive into your playoff office pools — or into the New York Times N.F.L. Playoff Challenge?

headline: The Early Word: Back to the Table
text: Lawmakers pick up on Tuesday where they left off with terrorism and health care.

headline: Japan’s Finance Minister Considers Quitting
text: TOKYO  Japan’s new government braced for another setback Tuesday after reports that its ailing 77-year-old finance minister was pressing to resign, although it appeared that the prime minister might try to persuade him to remain in his job. The news comes at a difficult time  when the government, already weakened by a series of policy blunders and scandals, is attempting the delicate task of stimulating an economy already burdened with enormous debt.

headline: Today in Business Travel
text: Take Off Your Shoes, and Is the Parrot Loaded?After the failed bombing of an airliner, even a winged pet is subject to scrutiny at the airport security checkpoint.

headline: Looking at Tourist Numbers, Positively
text: With the number of visitors to New York City declining by almost two million last year, it might be reasonable to expect that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would offer a less than rosy view of the decline, or at least express some concern that a continued slump might be in store in 2010.

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Tuesday morning.

headline: City Is Denied a Trademark on a Backup Name for Tavern
text: In comparison to the name Tavern on the Green, it seems that the designation Tavern in the Park misses more than just a certain je ne sais quoi.

headline: Berkshire Rejects Key Part of Kraft’s Cadbury Bid
text: Berkshire Hathaway, the giant conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett and Kraft‘s largest shareholder, said on Tuesday that it had rejected the American food giant’s proposal to issue new shares to back up its $16 billion bid for Cadbury.

headline: Discovery, Imax and Sony Form 3-D Television Channel
text: Updated throughout | 12:18 p.m.  Discovery, Imax and Sony confirmed on Tuesday that they are forming a joint venture for a 3-D television channel.

headline: Hackers Attack Ahmadinejad’s Web site
text: Updated | 10:10 a.m. On Monday night in San Francisco an information technology consultant named Austin Heap reported on his blog that the official Web site of Iran’s president, Ahmadinejad.ir, had been attacked by hackers.

headline: Och-Ziff Posts Gains in 2009
text: Och-Ziff Capital Management, the publicly traded hedge fund manager run by Daniel Och, said its flagship OZ Master Fund rose 1.1 percent in December to end the year up 23 percent.

headline: Off-Key Bylaws and Other Kafkaesque Oscar Tidbits
text: Like any institution, particularly one whose members can fondly remember the Eisenhower administration, the Academy is a stickler for rules. As Steve Pond reports at The Wrap, the music division, in particular, has byzantine bylaws about eligibility:

headline: Apple Buys Quattro, a Mobile Ad Company
text: Update | 11:24 a.m.  Adding confirmation of deal.

headline: Jayson Williams Charged With D.W.I. After Accident
text: Updated, 5:55 p.m. | Jayson Williams, the former star with the New Jersey Nets, was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated on Tuesday morning when the sport utility vehicle he was driving struck a tree in Manhattan, the police said.

headline: Environmental Refugees Unable to Return Home
text: Mahe Noor left her village in southern Bangladesh after Cyclone Sidr flattened her family’s home and small market in 2007. Jobless and homeless, she and her husband, Nizam Hawladar, moved to this crowded megalopolis, hoping that they might soon return home.

headline: Felder to Leave Council and Join Liu
text: City Councilman Simcha Felder, a close ally of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg who supported his campaign to revise term limits, plans to resign from the Council to work for the new comptroller, John C. Liu, according to a City Hall official with with direct knowledge of the situation.

headline: ‘A Private Screening’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Has everybody here seen “Avatar?” Great movie, wasn’t it? Even President Obama took his family to see it at a private screening in Hawaii. After the movie, Obama was like, “So that’s what it’s like when something lives up to its hype.”

headline: Longhorns Have a Fan on the Tide
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — Alabama quarterback Greg McElroy didn’t move to Texas until he was 10.

headline: ‘The 3-D Version’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” on NBC: President Obama took his daughters to see the 3-D version of “Avatar.” There was an awkward moment when one of Obama’s daughters leaned over to him and whispered, “Now, that’s how you spend half a billion dollars.”

headline: ‘Holidays in Hawaii’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Everyone’s back from vacation today. In Washington, President Obama returned to the Oval Office after spending the holidays in Hawaii. And Joe Biden returned after spending the holidays on his home planet.

headline: Venture Reported for a 3-D TV Channel
text: On the Media Decoder blog, Brian Stelter of The Times reports that Discovery, Imax and Sony are forming a joint venture for a 3-D television channel. The venture is expected to be announced on Tuesday, timed to the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, where 3-D television is expected to be a hot topic. The project, described by two people with knowledge of the deal, has a start date of 2011.

headline: ‘We Don’t Need It’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: The global warming conference has been canceled. Right. We don’t need it. You see, because it’s so damn cold.

headline: ‘Some Hero Passengers’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Good to see everybody. You know, it is good to be back. We were off for Christmas, and apparently so was the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Decoding the ‘Lost’ Supper
text: With less than a month to go until the Feb. 2 premiere of the final season of “Lost,” ABC gave the show’s promotional machine a first fateful crank on Monday evening, releasing two images designed to whet the appetites of longtime “Lost” fans.

headline: On Our Radar…
text: 1) A spat between Russia and Belarus threatens Europe’s oil supply.

headline: O.K., I Guess We’re Not Retiring the Business Card (Yet)
text: Thanks for all of the great feedback to my November post on whether it’s time to retire the business card. I’d like to share a few of the responses:

headline: Slowing Pace of Home Sales Raises Fears of New Retreat
text: The number of houses placed under contract fell sharply in November in the first drop in nearly a year, figures released Tuesday show. It was the clearest sign yet that predictions of another downturn in real estate may become a reality.

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The ‘Best Values’ in Public Universities, as Handicapped by Kiplinger’s
text: Update | 9:14 a.m. Click here to read a comment from Jane B. Clark, the author of the Kiplinger “Best Values” article. In response to several comments submitted to The Choice, she provides some details of how the magazine’s survey is fashioned.

headline: No Surprise: Cadillac CTS-V Coupe Set for Detroit
text: With the Detroit auto show just around the corner, General Motors released photos of the forthcoming Cadillac CTS-V Coupe, a supercharged version of the luxury coupe introduced a few weeks ago at the Los Angeles auto show.

headline: The Producers Toss Some Wild Cards Into the Mix
text: The Producers Guild of America, which like the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences jacked up the number of best picture nominees to 10 this year, announced its picks Tuesday morning and the tea leaves are immediately being read across Hollywood. Its choices, which usually go mainstream, included the big studio releases “Avatar,” “Up in the Air,” “Up,” and “Invictus,” and the smaller fare including “An Education,” “The Hurt Locker,” “Inglourious Basterds” and “Precious.” “Star Trek” and “District 9″ — two movies that picked up good reviews and good returns at the box office but are considered long shots for Oscar nominations — also made the cut.

headline: Inside Out | Girly, Not Gooey
text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: Alexandra Raij Returns to El Quinto Pino
text: Alexandra Raij, who started the Chelsea tapas bars Tia Pol and El Quinto Pino with Heather Belz and Mani Dawes, then left to open the Basque restaurant Txikito with her husband, Eder Montero, will return to El Quinto Pino after the three women agreed to divide ownership of their restaurants.

headline: What’s in a Naming Right? Certainly Not Cash
text: What shall we call the new stadium that will house the Jets and the Giants starting next season?

headline: Fred McGriff and the Endorsement That Lives Forever
text: For years, Fred McGriff has been identified as “Major League Super Star.” It’s a fitting kind of catchall for those fabulous commercials McGriff does for Tom Emanski’s Defensive Drills video, a staple of ESPN for so many years.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Commandeers Film Piracy Record
text: As “Avatar” knocks down box office records with each day of its theatrical release, the film has hit another, less estimable milestone: It has become the fastest-pirated movie yet, according to one tracking firm’s figures. The Times of London reported that “Avatar” was illegally downloaded 500,000 times in its first two days of release and 980,000 times in its first week, according to the Web site TorrentFreak.com, which tracks usage of the file-sharing tool BitTorrent.

headline: Panther Fill-In
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this article from the Science Times, “A Puddy Tat, but Watch Out for That Bite.”  Use your own words, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words that were removed.

headline: Name This Stadium
text: In an article posted Tuesday, Richard Sandomir writes about the search for a sponsor at the Meadowlands’ new stadium:

headline: Avatar’s Virtual Appeal
text: The much-discussed irony of James Cameron’s “Avatar” (which has already grossed upwards of a billion dollars worldwide) is that it’s a celebration of primitivism, pantheism, and pre-modernity created with the most cutting-edge technological tools a modern capitalist society can muster. But Caleb Crain, in a provocative post, suggests that this isn’t an irony at all. The apparent contradiction inherent in a CGI-created blockbuster that celebrates back-to-nature tribalism can be resolved, he argues, once you realize that the audience inevitably experiences the movie’s primitive world as a “Matrix”-style simulation of nature, rather than the real thing — as an “escape” from technology, that is, that only technology can make possible:

headline: Spooning Up the Wrong Dose
text: Many people still use kitchen spoons to measure a dose of liquid medication. Now new research shows that the size of the spoon influences our ability to estimate the right dose — and most of the time, we get it wrong.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday: Midget Submarines and George Lucas
text: History buffs, especially those with an interest in warfare, will want to put PBS’s “Nova” series on their must-see list for Tuesday night (check local listings). The program goes beneath the waves at Pearl Harbor to investigate the possible role of Japan’s midget submarines in the attack of Dec. 7, 1941. It looks specifically at the battleship Arizona, which was sunk that day with a loss of 1,177 lives. “For decades, it has been thought that a bomb dropped by a Japanese aircraft sank the Arizona,” the program’s publicity says. “But the discovery of a group of Japanese midget subs in and around Pearl Harbor has raised questions about the battleship’s final hours.”

headline: Testing Infomercial Claims
text: It turns out the Snuggie may not be the perfect blanket after all.

headline: No Longer Majority Black, Harlem Is in Transition
text: For nearly a century, Harlem has been synonymous with black urban America. Given its magnetic and growing appeal to younger black professionals and its historic residential enclaves and cultural institutions, the neighborhood’s reputation as the capital of black America seems unlikely to change soon.

headline: Frisée Salad With Poached Egg
text: This is inspired by a classic French country salad. The traditional dish includes thick-cut bacon, but this version is great without the meat. You can serve it as a starter, but I like to make a meal of it.

headline: Woman Pleads Guilty to Stalking L.B.O. Billionaire
text: Thomas H. Lee, the billionaire and a pioneer of the private equity industry, can breathe a bit easier now that his longtime stalker has pleaded guilty, according to media reports.

headline: Briatore and Symonds Win Their Case Against F.I.A.
text: Flavio Briatore, the former Renault team director, has won his legal case in a French court against the Fédération Internationale de l’Automobile and his lifetime ban from all motor-racing activities has been overturned by the court. Briatore was also awarded a $21,500 compensation, although he had asked for $1.45 million. Pat Symonds, the former Renault team technical director, also had his five-year ban overthrown. The two were accused of having organized a deliberated crash by one of their drivers to influence the outcome of their other driver at the Singapore Grand Prix of 2008.

headline: Why Women Don’t Get Enough Sleep
text: Over at the Huffington Post, Arianna Huffington has joined with the Glamour editor Cindi Leive to make a New Year’s resolution. They vow to get more sleep this year, and they urge the rest of us to follow their lead.

headline: The Pregame Huddle: B.C.S. Title Game
text: There is little doubt who the top two teams in the nation are this season as Alabama and Texas prepare to play for the B.C.S. championship.

headline: Las Vegas Orders Cover-Up of Topless Mural Figures
text: This post includes links to some PG-13 images and video that may not be suitable for viewing at your workplace.

headline: Where Perfection Is Underrated
text: The hope in the air in Glendale, Ariz., was palpable, or maybe that was just pollen. But it seemed like everyone who hates the Bowl Championship Series (which means everyone, minus about 10 holdouts) desperately wanted the Fiesta Bowl to blow everyone’s doors off, to prove once and for all the B.C.S. is an evil cartel aligned against democracy and any college that pays its football coach less than $4 million a year. They wanted Boise State to score 77 points in spectacular fashion or Texas Christian to fill the universe with purple power.

headline: U.S. Reopens Its Embassy After Raids in Yemen
text: The United States reopened its embassy in Yemen on Tuesday, a day after Yemeni security forces killed two people suspected of being members of Al Qaeda and linked to the threats against several diplomatic outposts.

headline: Russian Parliament Weighs Stiffer Penalties for Protesters
text: MOSCOW  Among the draft laws that Russia’s Parliament will review when it reconvenes next week is a proposal that would increase significantly the punishment for protesters who block traffic or railway tracks, raising fines from 2,500 rubles, or $84, to 100,000 rubles, or $3,340, and increasing maximum prison sentences from 15 days to two years.

headline: For the Moment | What Does Design Mean?
text: Michele Caniato is the president of Culture and Commerce, a design management consultancy, and of Material Connexion, a materials consultancy and library; both companies are based in New York.

headline: Cycling on Camera, in New York and Beyond
text: There is something cinematic about riding a bicycle through New York traffic with its speed, lights and danger. For the rider, street scenes can open up in flashes between stopped cars, creating a kind of stuttered approximation of film. No wonder, then, that many riders, like Luke Stiles and Chris Thormann, have tried to capture these scenes with a camera.

headline: Senator Graham Censured Again
text: Updated, 7 p.m.  For the second time in the last few months, conservative Republicans in one of South Carolina’s counties have voted to censure Senator Lindsey Graham for his congressional votes.

headline: December a Mixed Month for Auto Sales
text: DETROIT  Automakers ended a miserable year with some less bad sales figures, though the Ford Motor Company was the only one of the three domestic companies to report higher numbers in December.

headline: Suspect in Deaths of 5 G.I.’s Is Freed, Iraqi Official Says
text: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi accused of being behind the killings in 2007 of five American soldiers has been released by the Iraqi government, according to an Iraqi official.

headline: Movies and Vices: Made for Each Other
text: As long as there have been movies, there have been scolds who condemn the movies for glamorizing vice. And the scolds have generally been right: one of the great pleasures of movie watching is that it allows us to witness and vicariously take part in all kinds of behavior we wouldn’t dream of (or would only dream of) undertaking in our daily lives.

headline: Obama Says Plot Could Have Been Disrupted
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that the government had sufficient information to uncover the terror plot to bring down a commercial jetliner on Christmas Day, but that intelligence officials had “failed to connect those dots.”

headline: Iceland Blocks Bank Compensation for Foreigners
text: The president of Iceland blocked a hard-fought $5 billion compensation deal with the British and Dutch governments on Tuesday, upending the precarious finances and politics of the island nation and further jeopardizing already frayed ties with Europe and international lenders.

headline: Bishop Yao Liang, 87, Imprisoned in China for Loyalty to the Vatican, Dies
text: BEIJING  Leon Yao Liang, a Roman Catholic bishop who spent 28 years in Chinese prisons during Mao’s rule for his refusal to renounce his allegiance to the Vatican, died on Dec. 30 in Xiwanzi, a town in north China’s Hebei Province.

headline: Indiana Chosen for Electric-Car Plant
text: Think, the Norwegian electric carmaker, said on Tuesday that it will open its first American assembly plant in Elkhart, Ind.

headline: Kirkus Reviews May Survive Yet
text: In December, the publishing industry was shocked by the news that the Nielsen company was shutting down Kirkus Reviews, the venerable journal of pre-publication book reviews used by many buyers as a hint at what might become bestsellers and a source of neglected gems.

headline: Kirkus Reviews May Survive Yet
text: In December the publishing industry was shocked by the news that the Nielsen company was shutting down Kirkus Reviews, the venerable journal of prepublication book reviews used by many buyers as a hint at what might become best sellers and a source of neglected gems.

headline: A.I.G. Sells Canadian Mortgage Insurance Unit
text: The Canadian mortgage insurance business of the American International Group will be sold to a private investor group headed by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, the group said Tuesday. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Apple’s App Store Tops 3 Billion Downloads
text: We hope Apple will stop counting soon, because this is getting repetitive. After announcing in September that more than two billion applications had been downloaded from its App Store for the iPhone and iPod Touch, Apple said on Tuesday that it had surpassed three billion downloads.

headline: Some Inspiration to Make 2010 a Success
text: We have never been big on those inspirational posters that uninspiring managers put up on the office walls. You know the ones. They show a picture of a kitten desperately grasping a tree branch with a caption like, “Hang in there, baby,” or a lone eagle flying above the countryside, with the words “Dare to soar.”

headline: Kenneth Noland, Color Field Artist, Is Dead at 85
text: Kenneth Noland, who painted some of the great emblems of the postwar American abstract style called Color Field painting, died Tuesday at his home in Port Clyde, Me. The cause was cancer, said his wife, Paige Rense, editor in chief of Architectural Digest. He was 85.

headline: Doughnut Plant to Open in Chelsea
text: I knew there was only one Doughnut Plant in New York, but did you know there were 27 in Asia? Now, that balance is about to be adjusted a bit.

headline: David P. Murbach, Finder of Rockefeller Center Trees, Dies at 57
text: David P. Murbach, a horticulturist who added an impresario’s flair to one of the biggest jobs in the world of trees and gardens, finding the holiday tree for Rockefeller Center, was found dead on Dec. 23 in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had an apartment. He was 57.

headline: 10 Ways to Cut Your Travel Costs This Year
text: LAST year was arguably the year of the travel deal, with resorts and airlines practically begging for bookings, and many travelers finding bargain airfares and hotel rooms as a result. But airlines have cut back capacity, meaning there will be fewer seats going unsold, and resorts may not be as quick to cut rates to attract guests, now that the economy looks as if it might be on a slight rebound. So now is the perfect time to review your booking strategy. Here are 10 simple steps you can take to help cut your travel costs in 2010.

text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Concern That Airport Scans May Be Pornographic
text: Updated | 6:56 p.m. According to a report in The Guardian, Britain may be forced to delay the introduction of full-body scans for all airline passengers because of concerns that the images produced may break national laws against the production of pornographic images of children.

headline: B.L.M. Expedites Review of Energy Projects
text: Thirty–one proposed renewable energy and power transmission projects have been put on the fast track for approval by the Bureau of Land Management, with the aim of getting them paid for with stimulus funding under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act.

headline: Correction: Correction to Year in Pictures
text: An article on Dec. 27 about the death of Edward M. Kennedy in August referred incorrectly to the assassination of his brother President John F. Kennedy, and a correction on Sunday erroneously corrected the length of his tenure in the Senate. The president was assassinated in 1963, the year after Edward Kennedy was elected to the Senate — not the same year. And as the article correctly reported, Senator Kennedy served 46 years — not 47, as the correction said. (The correction also erred in stating that the length of tenure was incorrect in Mr. Kennedy's obituary, in two other articles on Aug. 27 and Aug. 28 and in an editorial on Aug. 28. All four correctly reported the tenure as 46 years.)

headline: New Worlds Take On the Old
text: The Directors Guild of America will join its above-the-line buddies in the Producers Guild when its nominations are announced on Thursday, and for those looking for a leg up in Oscar pools, it’s worth paying attention. The D.G.A’s members are even better at predicting eventual Oscar winners than the producers, anointing the same filmmakers 55 out of 61 times. Last year’s winner, Danny Boyle, also went on to win the top Oscar for “Slumdog Millionaire,” since best director and best picture usually go hand-in-hand, a nifty little equation that is getting squeezed this year, when Kathryn Bigelow is earning accolades outsize to her film, “The Hurt Locker.”

headline: Home Fires: Getting the Word Out
text: My last memory of Iraq was of boarding a transport plane on the flight line at Balad Air Base in late January 2008. It had been raining and we were hoping to get out of the country before “MUDCON,” or mud conditions, turned every inch of desert not hiding below flight line or rocks into peanut butter.

headline: Mesa Air Group Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: The struggling regional airline operator Mesa Air Group said Tuesday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection in a Manhattan court in a bid to cut its oversize fleet.

headline: Playwright’s Prize Established in Honor of Horton Foote
text: The name and spirit of Horton Foote, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and screenwriter, will live on in a playwriting award that will be given out for the first time this fall. The Horton Foote Prize, whose creation was announced Tuesday and was endorsed by Mr. Foote before his death in March, will be awarded every other year to “an American playwright who has written an original work of exceptional quality,” its organizers said in news release. The competition will invite 65 resident theaters to submit a play by an author who has written at least three original full-length plays that have been produced by professional theaters; selection committees will choose a short list of finalists; and the winner will be determined by a group of four artistic directors Mr. Foote worked with closely: Andre Bishop (of Lincoln Center Theater); James Houghton (Signature Theater Company); Michael Wilson (Hartford Stage Company); and Andrew Leynse (Primary Stages). The $30,000 prize will be supplied by the Greg and Mari Marchbanks Family Foundation of Austin, Tex.; Ms. Marchbanks is also the founder and executive director of the prize committee.

headline: Resolving to Open a Restaurant by April 1
text: New Year’s resolutions are like business plans and leaky boats: make them, swear by them, commit to them and prepare to jettison them at any moment. Here are my restaurant resolutions for 2010, part one:

headline: The Courage to Break the China
text: In the Big City column on Saturday, I wrote about my grandmother’s Limoges china, which I used with abandon on New Year’s Eve after it had been neglected for decades. A saucer broke in the process, which at first made me cringe. Then I realized that breaking dishes was part of using dishes. (It helped when I discovered there were more saucers than cups, anyhow.)

headline: Google Introduces Nexus One, Its Rival to the iPhone
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Google stepped up its attack on the smartphone market on Tuesday, introducing a new touch-screen handset called Nexus One that is widely seen as a rival to Apple’s iPhone.

headline: ‘Countries of Interest’ — A Pakistani Perspective
text: I was 10 when my family left Pakistan. We packed our bags and made the move to Canada on July 4, 1991. It wasn’t by choice that we had taken the flight 26 hours earlier from Lahore to come to a country where we barely knew a single soul. Religious extremists in Pakistan had branded us “non-Muslim,” and our green Pakistani passports indicated our religious status. We are part of a small Muslim sect called Ahmadiyyat that falls outside the Sunni and Shiite majority in Pakistan and were therefore hunted by the authorities. We could not travel freely because to be identified as a “non-Muslim” in Pakistan could mean death.

headline: Citi Field Doesn’t Intimidate Bay and Won’t Deter Mets
text: The biggest mystery surrounding Jason Bay the free agent was whether he actually wanted to play for the Mets. After slipping into his No. 44 jersey, donning a blue cap and flashing a wide smile while shaking hands with Omar Minaya at an introductory news conference Tuesday, Bay insisted that he wanted the Mets as much as they wanted him.

headline: Think, an Electric Car, to Be Built in Indiana
text: Elkhart, Ind., has been dubbed the “R.V. Capital of the World” because of the concentration of recreational vehicle manufacturers there. That industry has been hard hit by the recession, however, and it is a sign of the times that one former R.V. factory will become the United States home of the Norwegian electric carmaker Think.

headline: These Quadruplets Weigh Enrolling as a Foursome at Hartwick College
text: If reading about the Crouch quadruplets of Danbury, Conn., who were admitted en masse to Yale last month, has piqued your interest in the college ambitions of other so-called “multiples,” I direct you to an article posted several days ago on the Web site of Newsday. (Note: Newsday requires visitors to register for its Web site.)

headline: Walter Mosley’s First Play to Open in Cincinnati
text: Walter Mosley, the crime novelist best known for his Easy Rawlins mysteries, has adapted his novel “The Tempest Tales” into his first-ever play, “The Fall of Heaven,” which will have its world premiere at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park from Jan. 23 to Feb. 20.

headline: Extended Period of Cold Raises Fears for Florida Crops
text: As a cold spell continued its rigid hold on much of the eastern United States on Tuesday, farmers in central and southern Florida were bracing for freezing temperatures overnight that could damage orange, strawberry and tomato crops.

headline: Pairings: Osso Buco Portobello
text: Deciding what to serve with brunello di Montalcino is no small challenge. In any vintage, the bold wines from this elite patch of the Tuscan countryside demand serious food. And grandstanding would not be out of place for the highly regarded 2004s.

headline: The Morning Skate: World Junior Clash, Kings Rule and Kovy’s Dance
text: The United States national junior team faces its Canadian counterpart tonight in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. for the I.I.H.F. World Under-20 Championship (NHL Network in the U.S. and TSN in Canada at 8 p.m. Eastern). It’s the first time these countries’ junior teams have squared off for the gold medal since the United States won gold in 2004 and for Team Canada, the game represents a chance to win a record sixth consecutive title.

headline: Parting the Clouds Over Brunello
text: BRUNELLO di Montalcino has had a couple of nightmarish years, plagued by a scandal that wouldn’t go away. But, to honor the new year and in the spirit of fresh starts, let’s for the moment set that aside to focus on what is in the glass. That would be red wine, made, by law, entirely of the sangiovese grape.

headline: Travel Deals: 30% Off Hotels in Chicago, New York and Washington, D.C.
text: Affinia Hotels, which operates a stylish but affordable collection of hotels, is offering up to 30 percent off rooms at properties in New York, Chicago and Washington, D.C., for stays through April 5.

headline: U.S.O.C. Picks Ex-Leader as Its New One
text: The United States Olympic Committee has hired Scott Blackmun, a Colorado Springs lawyer who previously served as acting chief executive of the organization, as its new leader, according to several people who are familiar with the decision.
