headline: Bulgarian Journalist Gunned Down in Sofia
text: LONDON  A prominent radio journalist and author of a book on Bulgaria’s gangsters was shot and killed Tuesday in the Bulgarian capital, Sofia, the first such murder since a new government was elected last July promising to clamp down on organized crime and corruption.

headline: Will New Security Measures Thwart Tourism?
text: The travel industry was already concerned that foreign visitors to the United States faced unfriendly, even hostile, screening from customs and security agents. Now, concern is rising that the latest change, announced Sunday in response to the Christmas Day bombing plot, will deter more visitors.

headline: Skadden, Arps Takes Lead as M.&A. Adviser
text: The New York law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom overtook Linklaters of Britain as the biggest legal adviser on global mergers and acquisitions in 2009, a year that saw a sharp drop in deals, a new study shows.

headline: N.C.A.A. Upholds Decision to Vacate as Many as 14 Bowden Wins
text: The N.C.A.A. did not let Bobby Bowden’s retirement party last very long before announcing Tuesday that it had upheld its decision to strip the Florida State football team of as many as 14 victories. The decision will leave Bowden as many as 19 behind Joe Paterno of Penn State for most victories among football coaches at major colleges.

headline: An Expensive Dip in the Sangiovese Pond
text: My column is on a wine panel tasting of the 2004 brunello di Montalcino. I tried to get past the scandal that has colored the coverage of brunello over the last two years, but it wasn’t easy. One can’t help mentioning it, and then it requires at least a minimal amount of explanation.

headline: Green Day Goes Broadway With ‘American Idiot’

With a book by Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong and Michael Mayer, who is also directing, “American Idiot” is scheduled to begin preview performances on March 24 and open on April 20, according to a statement from the producers on Tuesday.

headline: Terrorism Today: Investigating Al Qaeda’s Presence Around the World

headline: After a Delay, New Atlantic Terminal Pavilion Is Open

For years, that experience has been enhanced by the din and clutter of a construction site. Now, finally, the new Atlantic Terminal Pavilion has opened.

headline: Do Consumers Really Want 3-D TVs?
text: On our sibling blog, Bits, Nick Bilton reports that device manufacturers including Sony, Panasonic, Toshiba and LG are all announcing 3-D-enabled TV’s at C.E.S., and content companies plan to start making movies and TV shows for these 3-D experiences. headline: C-Span Seeks Live Coverage of Democratic Meetings

headline: Gillick on Morris: ‘He Just Found a Way to Win’
text: As we consider potential Hall of Famers this week, one background name comes to mind: Pat Gillick. As a general manager, Gillick built a two-time World Series winner in Toronto and oversaw playoff teams in Baltimore and Seattle. Then he helped the Phillies win the 2008 championship. Executives’ résumés don’t get much better than that.

headline: Orange Bowl: No. 10 Iowa (10-2) vs. No. 9 Georgia Tech (11-2)
text: Bless your hearts, Georgia Tech. You have disproved the belief that the option cannot work in major college football, and for that you have our thanks. In fact, Georgia Tech has done so well under the second-year coach Paul Johnson that the option may become the new craze in college football, supplanting the spread — which is on borrowed time — as the choice of high school coaches and undersized F.B.S. programs across the nation. However, if there is a flaw with the option offense, it is that given time, opponents can prepare for the multitude of looks it presents. Iowa, for instance, has spent the last month using glasses, water bottles and Gatorade to duplicate Georgia Tech’s multifaceted attack.

text: In Rhode Island, rare heritage livestock breeds like fainting goats are being protected by a process called cryopreservation.

headline: Pombo Loses an Ally in Comeback Bid
text: If Richard W. Pombo manages to make it back to Congress, it won’t be with the help of his longtime legislative ally Representative George Radanovich, the California Republican whose seat Mr. Pombo is seeking to fill.

headline: In London, River Views at the Right Price
text: LONDON  As an art student at Camberwell College of Arts in the 1990s, Rainer Cole, wanting to own property near the Thames but not having the means for the deposit, got creative. If he couldn’t live near the river, then why not on it?

headline: House Democrats Seek Changes in Senate Bill
text: House Democratic leaders said on Tuesday that they would insist on changes in the Senate’s health care legislation to make coverage more affordable for middle-class Americans and to tighten control over the insurance industry. But it remained unclear how much leverage the House would have in coming negotiations, given that Senate Democrats cannot spare a single vote without jeopardizing the bill’s chances of passing.

headline: Public Officials Attack City’s Heroin Pamphlet
text: If you’re going to do drugs, do it right, because even drug addicts deserve to have their lives protected.

headline: What You Get for ... $250,000
text: NATCHEZ, MISS.

headline: Republicans Join Call for Live Coverage of Health Talks
text: After C-Span released a letter earlier on Tuesday seeking to televise Congressional deliberations on merging the health care bills, Republicans have been seizing on the notion throughout the day as a way to criticize what will likely be less-than-public negotiations.

headline: Happy Days in 2009
text: The happiest day of 2009 was Easter, according to new survey findings. By contrast, the day filled with the most stress and worry was the day after the House passed the stimulus bill.

headline: Switch in Cohen Lawsuit Stuns Lawyer
text: The lawyer who initially represented Patricia Cohen, the ex-wife of Steven A. Cohen who is suing the hedge fund billionaire in a civil racketeering case, said he was blindsided by her decision to switch attorneys shortly after filing the case.

headline: In the Company of Misery
text: THE doctor’s receptionist phoned the other day, looking for my husband.

headline: That Old Black Magic, So Hard to Recapture
text: CHICAGO  Among the dozens of cartoons that Charles Addams drew of his devilishly subversive Addams family is one in which Gomez and Morticia; their daughter, Wednesday; son, Pugsley; and manservant, Lurch, are admiring the view from their new picture window. The view is of a cemetery crowded with tombstones.

headline: Playwright’s Prize Named for Horton Foote
text: The spirit of Horton Foote, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and screenwriter, will live on in a playwriting award that will be given for the first time this fall. The Horton Foote Prize, whose creation was announced Tuesday and was endorsed by Mr. Foote before his death last March, will be awarded every other year to “an American playwright who has written an original work of exceptional quality,” its organizers said in a news release. The competition will invite 65 resident theaters to submit a work by an author who has written at least three original full-length plays that have been produced by professional theaters; selection committees will choose a short list of finalists; and the winner will be determined by a group of four artistic directors Mr. Foote closely worked with: André Bishop (of Lincoln Center Theater), James Houghton (Signature Theater Company), Michael Wilson (Hartford Stage Company) and Andrew Leynse (Primary Stages). The $30,000 prize will be supplied by the Greg and Mari Marchbanks Family Foundation of Austin, Tex.; Ms. Marchbanks is also the founder and executive director of the prize committee.

headline: A Year for Christian Tourism
text: It’s shaping up to be an auspicious year for Christian tourism, thanks to two infrequent religious events in Europe.

headline: Private High School Coming to Greenwich Village
text: Greenwich Village will soon have a new private high school.

headline: Mortgage Modifications Affect Credit Scores
text: Do borrowers taking part in the Obama administration’s mortgage modification program deserve a black mark on their credit records?

headline: Biopharmaceutical Industry Is Banking on Boston
text: Companies battling for an edge in the biopharmaceutical industry have $2.3 billion in manufacturing plants in development in the Boston area to produce genetically engineered drugs.

headline: Apple Buys Quattro, an Ad Firm
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple encroached upon Google’s turf on Tuesday with its acquisition of Quattro Wireless, a mobile advertising company.

headline: A Mercedes Flagship That Sets the Standard
text: Mercedes-Benz USA is building a flagship dealership in a 333,000-square-foot retail space on 11th Avenue in Manhattan, which it expects to set the style standard for all other Mercedes dealers around the country.

headline: Must See: He Kept His Speed Graphic
text: Louis Mendes spent the holidays around Rockefeller Center, photographing the crowds and selling prints to his subjects. Nothing unusual about that. Unlike most photographers cashing in on Christmas spirit, however, he was using a vintage Speed Graphic camera — the type, he says, you normally see in the movies — with a Polaroid back. Writing about Mr. Mendes in “Polaroid Photographer,” David Gonzalez asked, “In an age when digital photography offers instant gratification and cameras come in most phones, who would have thought a decent living could be had taking pictures with a vanishing technology?” Mr. Mendes has taken portraits around New York for almost 40 years, and charges up to $20 for his one-of-a-kind images.

headline: App of the Week: Make a Resolution Easier
text: Improving your health, getting fit and losing weight never fail to top the list of New Year’s resolutions. All three are easy to do if you are willing to keep a food diary — which isn’t easy to do.

headline: Mosley’s First Play to Open in Cincinnati
text: Walter Mosley, below, the crime novelist best known for his Easy Rawlins mysteries, has adapted his novel “The Tempest Tales” into his first play, “The Fall of Heaven,” which will have its world premiere at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park from Jan. 23 to Feb. 20. The play centers on Tempest Landry, described in a playhouse statement as a streetwise young man from Harlem who is accidentally killed and finds himself in a dispute in heaven with St. Peter, who ultimately sends him back to earth in hopes that Tempest will recognize his mistakes in life. If he does not, heaven will collapse and Satan will reign supreme. Marion McClinton is directing the production; he is best known for his direction of plays by August Wilson, including the Broadway production of “King Hedley II,” for which he was nominated for a Tony Award. David Gallo, who won a Tony in 2006 for best scenic design for the musical “Drowsy Chaperone,” is designing the set. Leland Gantt will star as Tempest. Mr. Mosley is scheduled to hold a discussion of the play at the theater on Jan. 14.

headline: Green Day’s ‘American Idiot’ Heads to Broadway
text: The new musical “American Idiot,” based on the Grammy Award-winning album of the same name by the band Green Day, will move to the St. James Theater on Broadway this spring, in time to be eligible for the 2010 Tony Awards. With a book by Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong and Michael Mayer, who is also directing, “American Idiot” is scheduled to begin preview performances on March 24 and open on April 20, according to a statement from the producers on Tuesday. The musical, which centers on three young male friends whose lives take decidedly different turns, had a run last fall at Berkeley Repertory Theater, starring John Gallagher Jr., right, who won the Tony Award for best featured actor in a musical in 2007 for “Spring Awakening.” The Broadway cast was not announced in the statement on Tuesday. The lead producers are Tom Hulce and Ira Pittelman, who, with Mr. Mayer directing, also led the “Spring Awakening” team.

headline: Shumway Sells 8% Stake to Goldman Fund
text: The hedge fund manager Chris Shumway sold an 8 percent stake in his firm to a leveraged-buyout fund run by Goldman Sachs, according to a letter sent to investors on Tuesday.

headline: Football Rolls Over ‘Conveyor Belt’
text: A pair of reality shows, including one in which male contestants were delivered on a conveyor belt to prospective female mates, delivered decent ratings for ABC on Monday night. That network’s season premiere of “The Bachelor,” in which 25 women are vying for the affection of Jake Pavelka, a commercial pilot, drew an average of 9.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC finished the night in third as the “Conveyor Belt of Love” (yes, that is the title) garnered 6.5 million viewers for its debut. Fox won the night with its live broadcast of the Tostitos Fiesta Bowl. Final figures for that football game were not immediately available, but preliminary estimates were slightly higher than Fox’s 2009 broadcast of the Allstate Sugar Bowl, which averaged 13.4 million viewers. CBS ranked second for the night with reruns of its comedy lineup and “CSI: Miami” (10 million). NBC was fourth with a two-hour installment of “Heroes” (4.9 million) and “The Jay Leno Show” (4.8 million).

headline: ‘Avatar’ Commandeers Film Piracy Record
text: As “Avatar” knocks down box office records, the film has hit another, less estimable milestone: it has become the fastest-pirated movie, according to one tracking firm’s figures. The Times of London reported that “Avatar,” starring Zoë Saldana, right, was illegally downloaded 500,000 times in the first two days of its release and 980,000 times in the first week, citing figures from the Web site TorrentFreak.com, which tracks usage of the file-sharing tool BitTorrent. In the days leading up to the film’s release last month, its director, James Cameron, seemed confident that the 3-D effects would essentially make it immune to piracy, telling The Times of London, “You can pirate a 3-D movie, but you can’t pirate it in 3-D, so you can’t bottle that 3-D experience.” But the TorrentFreak.com numbers seem to tell a different story: “Avatar” was illegally downloaded far more often than its closest competitor, the “Twilight” sequel “New Moon,” which was downloaded 610,000 times in its first week of release. Still, 20th Century Fox, which released “Avatar,” seemed unconcerned that piracy would hurt box office grosses, which last weekend surpassed $1 billion in worldwide ticket sales. “Bootleg copies are unlikely to have much impact,” a studio spokesman told The Times of London. “Seeing the movie in 3-D in a cinema offers an experience that cannot be replicated.”

headline: Kirkus Reviews May Survive Yet
text: In December the publishing industry was shocked when the Nielsen company announced it was shutting down Kirkus Reviews, the venerable journal of prepublication book reviews used by many buyers as a hint at what might become best sellers and a source for finding neglected gems. On Tuesday it appeared that a white knight might be lurking in the wings. Eric Liebetrau, the journal’s managing editor, said in an e-mail message that Nielsen and Kirkus were “in the process of working out an arrangement with an acquiring company to continue the publication of the magazine.” He said he had no further details about the identity of the acquiring company, but said news was expected by the end of the month. “We will definitely publish a second issue in January,” Mr. Liebetrau wrote, “and then reassess the situation and hopefully continue publication in February and beyond.” Kirkus, a biweekly founded in 1933, published nearly 5,000 reviews a year.

headline: Lawmakers React to Paterson’s Proposal for Reform
text: In a conference call on Tuesday, aides to Gov. David A. Paterson on Tuesday briefed reporters on the governor’s proposal for ethics reforms that, if enacted, would be the most far-reaching such overhaul in state history.

headline: A New Prince, a Little Withholding, in a Puccini With a Modernist Touch
text: The tenor Salvatore Licitra took over the role of Calaf, a routed Tartar prince, in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Puccini’s “Turandot” on Monday night. When Mr. Licitra emerged in the late 1990s, he had the potential to be the next great Italian tenor. But over the years he has squandered his talents and sung with dismaying insecurity.

headline: Obama’s Speech
text: President Obama said that the failed terrorist attack could have been disrupted if intelligence officials had connected the dots, but they failed "to integrate and understand" the information. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: The Sviata Vecheria
text: A look at vushka, borscht and other dishes that Veselka serves as part of the traditional Ukrainian 12-dish holiday dinner.

headline: Google Shakes but Doesn’t Upend the Cellphone Market
text: Google sure does love shaking up the system.

headline: Montana Cowboys Lead, Coax and Cajole Their Charges Amid a Chorus of Bleats
text: The tagline for the wonderful documentary “Sweetgrass,” the first essential movie of this young year, is “the last ride of the American cowboy.” I suppose the word shepherd, with its pastoral evocations of maidens in pantaloons and lads with flutes, doesn’t have the necessary grit or mythic punch. But the quiet and cantankerous men in this movie, mostly in cowboy hats  one of which is charmingly ornamented with a sheep pin on the crown  are keeping and sometimes losing sheep as surely as Little Bo Peep did.

headline: Slow Start for Military Corps in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  The military’s effort to build a seasoned corps of expert officers for the Afghan war, one of the highest priorities of top commanders, is off to a slow start, with too few volunteers and a high-level warning to the armed services to steer better candidates into the program, according to some senior officers and participants.

headline: Google Will Sell ‘Superphone’ Direct
text: I have to think that a phone is not as exciting as you want it to be when the big news is the way in which you will sell it, even if you dub it part of a new class of “superphones.”

headline: Death of a Golden Boy Ripples Through a Family
text: Late in Caroline Link’s film “A Year Ago in Winter,” the bottled-up anguish of the Richters, a well-to-do family in Munich whose 19-year-old son and golden boy, Alexander (Cyril Sjostrom), shot himself to death, is conjured by a turbulent Peter Gabriel song, “Signal to Noise,” heard on the soundtrack.

headline: Senator Dorgan of North Dakota to Retire
text: Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, announced abruptly on Tuesday that he would not seek re-election this year – a clear sign of the difficulties Democrats will face in defending their large Congressional majorities in the upcoming mid-term elections.

headline: Thompson to Run for Mayor in 2013
text: The 2013 race for New York City mayor is on.

headline: Popular Drugs May Help Only Severe Depression
text: Some widely prescribed drugs for depression provide relief in extreme cases but are no more effective than placebo pills for most patients, according to a new analysis released Tuesday.

headline: Cleveland’s Incomplete Guide to Winning
text: Chase Stuart, a lawyer, Jets fan and statistical analyst, writes for the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog.

headline: The Struggles of Cairo’s ‘Garbage People,’ but No Whining
text: Following on the grimy heels of “Marina of the Zabbaleen” (released here in September) comes “Garbage Dreams,” a second documentary about a poor community of trash recyclers on the outskirts of Cairo. But in the hands of the director and photographer Mai Iskander, this new film digs deeper into the politics of a life that few would choose but many depend on.

headline: The Lap of Sonic Luxury
text: To all of the reasons to be presented at this year’s Consumer Electronics Show for one to stay planted on the living room couch for extended periods, add this one: the Logitech Speaker Lapdesk.

headline: Google’s Nexus One: A Roundup of Coverage
text: It’s official. As The Times’s Miguel Helft reported this morning, Google announced its first phone, the Nexus One. We just posted David Pogue’s review. Here’s a roundup of what the technology blogs are saying about the new phone.

headline: A Threesome: Husband, Wife, Shakespeare
text: TWO actors might work all their lives and never receive higher praise. In back-to-back productions of Shakespearean tragedy with Theater for a New Audience last season, Juliet Rylance’s brave, gracious portrayal of Desdemona was hailed in The New York Times as “exquisitely moving” and the dark, lean and hungry Hamlet of Christian Camargo as “virtually perfect.” At the time few knew they were newlyweds; their work was judged independently, on the merits.

headline: Oh, Just Answer the Question, Honey
text: LOS ANGELES  Children can exhibit a remarkable ability to obsess about the most detailed subjects: train timetables, species of dinosaurs, the names of 18 different dolls and their imaginary occupations. But should that ability be put to use on national television, with a whole lot of money riding on the memory of a preteen?

headline: Rajaratnam Expected to Face Additional Charges
text: Prosecutors have indicated that they plan to bring additional insider trading charges against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group, that could increase his potential prison time to a maximum of 15 years if he is convicted.

headline: Viola Davis Joins ‘Fences'; Lili Taylor Added to ‘Lips Together’
text: Viola Davis, recently seen suffering up a storm in the film adaptation of “Doubt” (a performance that earned her an Academy Award nomination among other plaudits) will not be getting a reprieve any time soon. The actress is set to join the cast of the coming Broadway revival of “Fences,” by August Wilson, in which she will play the put-upon spouse of Denzel Washington, its press representatives said on Tuesday. The revival of “Fences,” which won the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1987, is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on April 14 and open on April 26.

headline: TBS May Need to Get Creative in Replacing Caray
text: Five weeks since parting ways with Chip Caray as its No. 1 baseball announcer, TBS is still searching for his replacement.

headline: Death of a Friendship, Birth of a Play
text: IN 1947, while doing research for a screenplay in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn, Arthur Miller heard a story that reminded him of the plot of a Greek tragedy. An Italian-American longshoreman had turned in to authorities two illegal immigrants, relatives he had been sheltering in his home, in order to stop one of them from marrying his niece. Having violated an unwritten proscription against informing, he was disgraced and later disappeared  possibly, as rumor had it, murdered by one of the men he had betrayed.

headline: A City’s Specialty, Japanese in Name Only
text: Seattle

headline: ‘I.O.U.’
text: Introduction

headline: Laughing All the Way to the Bank
text: If you wanted to try to make sense of the global banking crisis, instead of merely weeping openly at your A.T.M. balance, 2009 was a very good year. Bookstores were filled with volumes that, with expert 20-20 hindsight, explained how capitalism went to hell. The blame was spread around: to politicians (for deregulating financial markets), to bankers (for gambling with exotic derivatives they barely understood) and to the rest of us (for living beyond our means, like insatiate zombie piglets).

headline: Should Players Be Responsible for Their Agents?
text: In the realm of N.B.A. discipline, some things are clear-cut. Throw a punch — get suspended. Rip the referees — get fined. The rules are as embedded in player psyches as the three-second violation.

headline: Sherlock Holmes, Amorphous Sleuth for Any Era
text: Arthur Conan Doyle grew so to hate his greatest creation, Sherlock Holmes, that in 1893 he tried to kill him off, plunging him over the Reichenbach Falls. He called it “justifiable homicide,” saying, “If I had not killed him, he would certainly have killed me.”

headline: Indian Official Gets Far on a Few Words
text: NEW DELHI  It seemed an innocent enough question, posed by an Indian on vacation recently in the palace-studded region of Rajasthan. Should the Indian government make it more difficult for tourists to visit the country’s glorious sights by tightening visa requirements in the name of preventing terrorism?

headline: Senator Dorgan of North Dakota Will Retire
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, announced abruptly on Tuesday that he would not seek re-election this year  a clear sign of the difficulties Democrats will face in defending their large Congressional majorities in the upcoming mid-term election.

headline: International Travelers: Share Your Security Experiences
text: In response to the Christmas Day bombing plot, additional screening has been announced for citizens of 14 nations, including Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and Nigeria, who are flying to the United States. Passengers holding passports from those nations, or taking flights that originated or passed through any of them, will be required to undergo full-body pat downs and will face extra scrutiny of their carry-on bags before they can board planes to the United States.

headline: Kenya: Efforts to Deport Cleric Fail
text: The authorities are having trouble deporting a radical Jamaican-born Muslim cleric because international airlines have refused to take him and Tanzania refused Kenya’s attempt to send him there, officials said Tuesday. The cleric, Abdullah el-Faisal, who officials say may have inspired the Nigerian man accused of trying to bomb an American airliner last month, had entered Kenya from Tanzania. “We have no intention of allowing him to enter into our country,” Tanzania’s Home Affairs minister, Lawrence Masha, said, saying no formal request had been made.

headline: Obama Cites Intelligence Failures
text: Jeff Zeleny of The Times discusses President Obama's speech that cited the intelligence community's lack of understanding and integration of information about the failed attack.

headline: Putting Lens on Lives in Suspended Animation in Gaza
text: GAZA  In the year since Israeli fighter jets and troops invaded this coastal Palestinian strip to stop rocket fire, time seems to have stood still. A blockade imposed by both Israel and Egypt to isolate the Hamas government bars the vast majority of goods and people from moving in or out. That means there is no reconstruction of destroyed buildings. Thousands remain homeless. Winter has arrived.

headline: Britain Tries to Ease Strain Over Bomb Suspect
text: LONDON  As President Obama and his national security team met at the White House to review the attempted Christmas Day bombing of an American trans-Atlantic airliner, the British government moved Tuesday to reduce strains between London and Washington over intelligence lapses in the case of Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, the suspect in the failed attack.

headline: Rare Breeds, Frozen in Time
text: NEWPORT, R.I.

headline: High and Low, With a French Twist
text: Paris

headline: Beltre to Play for Red Sox
text: The Boston Red Sox have agreed to terms on a one-year contract with third baseman Adrian Beltre, according to an official familiar with the deal. The official was granted anonymity because Beltre must still pass a physical to make the contract official. The deal guarantees Beltre $10 million.

headline: Harold Ford Jr. Weighs a Challenge to Gillibrand
text: Encouraged by a group of influential New York Democrats, Harold Ford Jr., the former congressman from Tennessee, is weighing a bid to unseat Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in this fall’s Democratic primary, according to three people who have spoken with him.

headline: Chinese Envoy Objects to More Penalties for Iran
text: UNITED NATIONS  Imposing tougher sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program is a poor idea while diplomatic negotiations remain possible, Zhang Yesui, the Chinese ambassador to the United Nations, said Tuesday.

headline: A Ukrainian Beacon in the East Village
text: ABOUT 40 years ago, Tom Birchard  a mild young New Jersey man of Pennsylvania Dutch and Midwestern antecedents  showed up at a fraternity party at Rutgers University, and was sucked unwittingly into the rest of his life.

headline: Flavors of Mexico, Made Fresh in Manhattan
text: Fresh tamales with chicken in red or green salsa, and vegetarian ones, with chilies, are the draw on Saturdays starting at 9:30 at Las Palomas, a tiny Mexican store. A newer attraction is goat barbacoa, fork-tender, mostly boned, and delicious reheated with a slather of salsa, also sold there.

headline: Reviving New York State’s Grain Belt
text: The Midwest is not the nation’s only grain belt. There once was another in upstate New York, and it is now being revived and expanded, not with commodity crops, but, to the delight of professional and amateur cooks and bakers, with specialty grains ground locally into flours and meals.

headline: Texas-Alabama: Rematch 45 Years in the Making
text: There is only one thing wrong with this national championship game, Pete Lammons says. It is not being held in the Orange Bowl.

headline: Ukrainian Christmas Borscht
text: Adapted from “The Veselka Cookbook,” by Tom Birchard with Natalie Danford (St. Martin’s Press, 2009)

headline: Promise to Trim Deficit Is Growing Harder to Keep
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is making final decisions on his budget for next year and is still promising to outline a path to substantially lower federal deficits. But on nearly every front, that goal has gotten harder since his first budget a year ago.

headline: A Mouthful of Rainbow
text: Melissa Bushell, left, who has been serving her bite-size cupcakes from the window of a SoHo coffee shop, has opened her own sleek little glass store. It features her tender half-dollar size cakes topped with bright flavorful icing. There are now nine flavors, expanded from seven; some, like cinnamon, mint chocolate chip and peanut butter cup, have fillings, too.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Markets Head Indoors

headline: Dos Toros Taqueria
text: IF the Dos Toros Taqueria just off Union Square brings to mind the sort of fresh, quick and cheap eating found at Mexican joints in the San Francisco Bay Area, that’s by design.

headline: Microsoft and H.P. to Reveal Slate PC Ahead of Apple
text: It could be one of Steve Ballmer’s riskiest trade-show moves in years.

headline: New Jersey Governor’s Brother: Asset and a Risk
text: If he weren’t the younger brother of New Jersey’s newly elected governor, Todd J. Christie might be seen as just another freewheeling, risk-taking, deep-pocketed Wall Street trader.

headline: A Once-Defiant U.A.W. Local Now Focuses on G.M.’s Success
text: LORDSTOWN, Ohio  For the better part of three decades, the car plant here was a seemingly endless source of trouble for General Motors.

headline: Christmas Sales Brought a Move Toward Stability
text: Despite a weak start to the holiday shopping season and snowstorms on historically big spending days, the nation’s retailers managed to have a better Christmas than in 2008, according to the latest data.

headline: David Murbach, Finder of Rockefeller Center Trees, Dies at 57
text: David P. Murbach, a horticulturist who added an impresario’s flair to one of the biggest jobs in the world of trees and gardens  finding the holiday tree for Rockefeller Center each year  was found dead on Dec. 23 in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had a home. He was 57.

headline: City Urged to Withdraw Flier on ‘Safer’ Heroin Use That Some See as How-To Guide
text: If you are going to do drugs, do it right, because even drug addicts deserve to have their lives protected.

headline: Voting System to Finally Join Electronic Age
text: The voting machine levers are officially history.

headline: Boldly, Boise State Moves the Question
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The fake punt known as Riddler will join Boise State’s historical repertory of trickery, alongside Statue Left and Circus from three years ago. Broncos Coach Chris Petersen’s daring call on fourth-and-9 from his own 33 in the Fiesta Bowl on Monday night was destined to be described as either fearless or insane.

headline: Randy Johnson Retires While Holliday Stays Put
text: There were two significant developments in baseball Tuesday, neither especially surprising: The 46-year-old left-hander Randy Johnson announced his retirement, and the free-agent left fielder Matt Holliday returned to the St. Louis Cardinals with a seven-year, $120 million contract.

headline: Casa Lever
text: HERE now is a new Italian restaurant of the Manhattan old school, built for socialites and those who finance them, staffed by handsome, rakish men with huge wristwatches. It’s the sort of place where in the movie, based on a novel as yet unwritten by Dana Vachon, you might cast Anne Hathaway as the lead and Diane Keaton as her mom. You’re welcome, too. For all this, Casa Lever is a deeply likable restaurant. It’s very New York.

headline: Planet Earth Is Blue
text: My review this week is of Casa Lever in that Midtown space oddity of a room that used to be Lever House, in Midtown. It’s a terrific place — two stars! — staffed by a crew of whip-smart Italians. It’s well worth visiting if you’re ever in the mood for Manhattan scenemaking amid a crowd of women who look like Anne Hathaway and men who look like the interior designer and wine merchant Marco Pasanella.

headline: Fed Missed This Bubble. Will It See a New One?
text: If only we’d had more power, we could have kept the financial crisis from getting so bad.

headline: U.S. Plans New Charge in Galleon Insider Case
text: Federal prosecutors said Tuesday that they planned to bring additional insider trading charges against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group, a move that could increase his possible prison time to more than 15 years if convicted.

headline: Gregg Allman on Leaving the Beacon: ‘One Monkey Don’t Stop No Show’
text: No rock ’n’ roll tradition lasts forever. Bob Dylan plugged in his guitar. Kiss (temporarily) washed off its face paint. And now the Allman Brothers Band is leaving the Beacon Theater.

headline: The Beacon Is Booked, So Allmans Will Move
text: No rock ’n’ roll tradition lasts forever. Bob Dylan plugged in his guitar. Kiss (temporarily) washed off its face paint. And now the Allman Brothers Band is leaving the Beacon Theater.

headline: Iran Shielding Its Nuclear Efforts in Maze of Tunnels
text: Last September, when Iran’s uranium enrichment plant buried inside a mountain near the holy city of Qum was revealed, the episode cast light on a wider pattern: Over the past decade, Iran has quietly hidden an increasingly large part of its atomic complex in networks of tunnels and bunkers across the country.

headline: U.S. Saw a Path to Qaeda Chiefs Before Bombing
text: WASHINGTON  Before detonating a suicide bomb in Afghanistan last week, a Jordanian militant was considered by American spy agencies to be the most promising informant in years about the whereabouts of Al Qaeda’s top leaders, including Ayman al-Zawahri, the terrorist group’s second-ranking operative.

headline: Under the Radar
text: Expect challenging, exciting and “sometimes just plain cockamamie new works” at the sixth annual “Under the Radar” festival which begins tonight at the Public Theater. This year’s festival, produced by Mark Russell, includes well-established figures like Richard Maxwell and the highly regarded Philadelphia troupe Pig Iron, Charles Isherwood writes. Also check out works from newer contributors, including “Silver Stars,” a song cycle derived from the experiences of gay men from Dublin to New York, as well as “The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle,” a multimedia adaptation of the Haruki Murakami novel directed by Stephen Earnhart, and “John Cassavetes’ Husbands,” a theatrical adaptation of the 1970 film about middle-age malaise.

headline: Elaine Stritch at the Carlyle
text: “With every new generation, popular art changes,” Stephen Sondheim said in a recent interview. “Already there’s a generation that thinks the Beatles are old-fashioned, which I find screamingly funny.” There’s little doubt of Sondheim’s staying power today and the same can be said for another artist of his generation  Elaine Stritch. Ms. Stritch, who is almost 85, is presenting “At Home at the Carlyle: Elaine Stritch Singin’ Sondheim ... One Song at a Time” an all-Sondheim program with six musicians at the Café Carlyle beginning this week. Her approach to Sondheim “is a dramatic no-holds-barred wrestling match between the singer and the song, in which there is little doubt about the outcome,” writes Stephen Holden. “Because Ms. Stritch is a ferociously age-defiant theatrical force, “Singin’ ” doesn’t fully evoke the savage, canny dramatic eviscerations one can expect in a show that may well be legendary after its run concludes on Jan. 30.”

headline: Take a Trip to California
text: There’s nothing like a little taste of the West Coast to warm a cold New Yorker. “If the Dos Toros Taqueria just off Union Square brings to mind the sort of fresh, quick and cheap eating found at Mexican joints in the San Francisco Bay Area, that’s by design,” writes Oliver Strand. “It was opened by brothers Leo and Oliver Kremer, two natives of Berkeley, Calif., who worshiped Gordo Taqueria, a local favorite founded in 1977. Dos Toros is something of an homage.” There are only three items on the menu: a taco, burrito and quesadilla, with a variety of possible preparations. Hint: say yes to the guacamole. Go for the “simple and succulent food, stripped-down cooking served in Spartan conditions. Just like at Gordo, Dos Toros has a short menu, high standards and such satisfying fare you don’t mind the hospital lighting.” Also look out for other Left Coast details: “the biodegradable corn-based utensils, the aggressive composting policy, the disarmingly nice staff.” It will make you feel like you’re in sunny California, at least until you walk back outside.

headline: Optimism Is Fresh Arrival in California Cul-de-Sac
text: MORENO VALLEY, Calif.  Phil Winkler pays a neighborhood kid to mow his lawn, that small-bore transaction of the American suburb, where adults are generally busy and teenagers offer a price that’s right. But for Mr. Winkler, the relinquishing of his mower was something remarkable.

headline: Television Begins a Push Into the 3rd Dimension
text: Ralph Kramden can finally buy a television.

headline: Jets’ Senior Citizen Weighs In on Sanchez
text: Defensive end Shaun Ellis is one Jet — the only one — who has been there and done that. Drafted by the Jets in 2000, Ellis is the longest-tenured player on the team. He has been through high and lows; he has also seen hotshot quarterbacks come and go.

headline: City Ignoring Law on Class Sizes, Suit Says
text: Despite receiving hundreds of millions of dollars to reduce class sizes, the city’s Department of Education has ignored state law and allowed classrooms to grow in the last couple of years, the city teachers’ union and other groups said in a lawsuit filed Tuesday.

headline: A Clothing Clearance Where More Than Just the Prices Have Been Slashed
text: In the bitter cold on Monday night, a man and woman picked apart a pyramid of clear trash bags, the discards of the HM clothing store that reigns in blazing plate-glass glory on 34th Street, just east of Sixth Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: Reprieve Eases Medical Crisis for Illegal Immigrants
text: ATLANTA — After a largely sleepless night, Cruz Constancia got up Tuesday morning wondering whether this would be the day that she finally stopped receiving dialysis without charge.

headline: Asian Computer Makers Move Into Riskier Ventures
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  For years, the process remained relatively static: PC makers like Hewlett-Packard and Apple, with well-staffed research labs and design departments, would dream up their next product and then hire a Chinese or Taiwanese fabricator to manufacture the largest number of units at the lowest possible cost.

headline: Sourcing of Article Awkward for Paper
text: Facing criticism for publishing the work of a start-up news organization, The Washington Post said Tuesday that it should have disclosed more about the group’s financier and his connections, and the paper’s ombudsman said he was looking into the relationship.

headline: A Tale of Two Flagella
text: They are the best of beings; they are the worst of beings. They are animals; they are plants. They are saviors; they are killers. They are predators; they are parasites. They are, in short, dinoflagellates — a large, diverse and eccentric group of (usually) single-celled organisms that are as celebrated as they are feared. And I hereby nominate them for Life-form of the Month: January.

headline: Shanahan Gets Job, but Market Is Slow
text: In Washington, the Redskins completed negotiations with Mike Shanahan on Tuesday night and a news conference is expected Wednesday to introduce Shanahan as the new coach. In Cleveland, Mike Holmgren started to talk to Eric Mangini about whether Mangini should remain the coach.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Asks Review of the Handling of His Case
text: Lawyers for Bradley Birkenfeld, the former UBS private banker who is headed to jail for helping wealthy Americans evade taxes through secret offshore accounts, asked the Justice Department on Tuesday to investigate whether prosecutors had mishandled his case.

headline: Bay Wanted to Be Wanted, and the Mets Obliged
text: As Jason Bay slipped into his No. 44 jersey, put on a blue cap and pumped the right hand of General Manager Omar Minaya at the opening to his introductory news conference Tuesday at Citi Field, the smile never left his face. Clearly, Bay seemed happy about being a Met. But he had yet to say so.

headline: In Packing Up, Morgenthau Unearths Treasures
text: Transferring control of the Manhattan district attorney’s office from Robert M. Morgenthau to Cyrus R. Vance Jr. has necessitated various housekeeping measures  replacing veteran prosecutors with new ones, hanging new pictures on the walls and putting new policies into effect.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Hidden Treasures From Morgenthau's Office
text: The district attorney’s treasures, including a letter from Eleanor Roosevelt and a medallion of Thomas E. Dewey’s.

headline: New Year but No Relief for Strapped States
text: SACRAMENTO  It is one of the bleakest new years that states have seen in over a decade.

headline: Iceland’s Leader Vetoes Bill to Repay 2 Lenders
text: The president of Iceland blocked a $5 billion compensation deal with the British and Dutch governments on Tuesday, upending the precarious finances and politics of the island nation and further jeopardizing already frayed ties with Europe and international lenders.

headline: Kraft Bolsters Its Hostile Bid for Cadbury by Raising New Cash
text: Kraft Foods took a big step on Tuesday to shore up its $16 billion hostile bid for Cadbury, the British confectioner, by selling one of its most profitable units to Nestlé.

headline: Court Backs War Powers Over Rights of Detainees
text: A federal appeals court panel on Tuesday strongly backed the powers of the government to hold Guantánamo detainees and other noncitizens suspected of committing terrorist acts.

headline: A Blockbuster That Proved Worthy of the Hall of Fame
text: Before he left the 1990 winter meetings in Chicago, Pat Gillick called his wife, Doris, to tell her he would be home in a few hours. Gillick, then the general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, also told her he had just traded Fred McGriff and Tony Fernandez to the San Diego Padres for Roberto Alomar and Joe Carter.

headline: Like King Solomon
text: Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more;Or close the wall up with our English dead …Follow your spirit, and upon this chargeCry ‘God for Harry, England, and Saint George!’

headline: House Democrats to Pursue Health Bill Changes
text: WASHINGTON  House Democratic leaders said Tuesday that they would insist on changes to the Senate health care legislation to make coverage more affordable for middle-class Americans and to tighten control over the insurance industry.

headline: Nurturing Sanchez Leads Jets to Rely on Him
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Mark Sanchez’s rookie season has included a series of upgrades, some more noticeable than others. The latest sat at the foot of his locker Tuesday, propped just so in front of a black loose-leaf notebook.

headline: Lawyer Says Third White House ‘Crasher’ Was Invited
text: WASHINGTON  The mystery man starring in a new movie in town  State Dinner Crashers: The Sequel  has come forward.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 935 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Corrections
text: A capsule summary in some copies on Monday for an article about the attitudes toward improving society on the part Teach for America graduates misstated the surname of a teacher shown in an accompanying picture. The error was repeated in a picture caption with the article. The teacher is David Donaldson, not Johnson.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Dec. 26 about hardships faced by construction workers in Fitchburg, Mass., as they settled into winter misstated the name of a national construction industry organization. It is the Associated General Contractors of America, not the Association of General Contractors of America.

headline: Smith Bagley, Executive and Democratic Fund-Raiser, Dies at 74
text: Smith W. Bagley, a business executive, philanthropist and major contributor to national Democratic candidates, died Saturday in Bethesda, Md. He was 74 and had homes in Washington, in Nantucket, Mass., and on St. Simons Island, Ga.

headline: Corrections
text: The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Indianapolis football fans who were disgruntled that the Colts rested key players while their perfect record was still intact, referred incorrectly to the start of the current professional football team in Cincinnati, which, like Indianapolis, watched as other cities were given franchises through the years. Cincinnati got the Bengals in 1968, not “in the 1970s.” (The Colts moved to Indianapolis from Baltimore in 1984.)

headline: Corrections
Corrections
text: A dance review on Dec. 26 about Soledad Barrio and Noche Flamenca, at the Lucille Lortel Theater, misstated a word in a line sung by Manuel Gago. He sang: “Ay! Que pena!,” not: “Ay! Che pena!”

headline: 2 Policemen Are Wounded as 3rd Officer Fires at Pit Bull
text: Two plainclothes police officers chasing a suspect as part of a drug investigation in the Bronx were injured Tuesday night when a third officer fired at a pit bull that had charged at them and a bullet ricocheted, a Police Department spokesman said.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about e-books, incorrectly described the publishing history of William Styron’s “Lie Down in Darkness.” It was first published in 1951 by Bobbs-Merrill, not Random House.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: As Clout Grows, Working Families Party Faces a Question: Has It Reached Too Far?
text: Bill de Blasio, New York City’s new public advocate, is a lifelong Democrat and a likely future mayoral contender. But ask him to name the most innovative political force in the state, and he points to the Working Families Party.

headline: Embattled Florida G.O.P. Chairman to Quit
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Under fire from Republicans upset with everything from his fund-raising efforts to his support for Gov. Charlie Crist in an increasingly bitter United States Senate primary, the chairman of Florida’s Republican Party announced his resignation on Tuesday.

headline: Immigration’s New Year
text: The quest for overhauling immigration received two very welcome lifts on New Year’s Day.

headline: Microsoft and H.P. to Reveal Slate PC Ahead of Apple
text: On our sister blog, Bits, Ashlee Vance offers a preview of what Microsoft’s chief executive, Steve Ballmer, will unveil during his Wednesday evening keynote at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

headline: PGA Tour's Focus on the Future Obscured by Present Problem: Woods
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii  When he arrived for his first news conference of 2010 on Tuesday, PGA Tour Commissioner Tim Finchem displayed a mood that pretty much matched the laid-back elegance of the Kapalua Resort. Wearing a white golf shirt, plaid slacks and a relaxed demeanor, Finchem talked in glowing terms about the new title sponsor, SBS, which has signed on for the next 10 years, and how Kapalua is a golf course the tour is very fond of and how the tournament is a great way to start the year.

headline: Juvenile Injustice
text: Gladys Carrión, New York’s reform-minded commissioner of the Office of Children and Family Services, has been calling on the state to close many of its remote, prison-style juvenile facilities and shift resources and children to therapeutic programs located in their communities. Her efforts have met fierce and predictably self-interested resistance from the unions representing workers in juvenile prisons and their allies in Albany.

headline: In From the Cold
text: Ten years after NATO went to war with Slobodan Milosevic over Kosovo, a democratically transformed Serbia has applied to join the European Union. That process is likely to take five years or more, but this is an apt moment to celebrate the turnaround in Serbian policies and attitudes under President Boris Tadic.

headline: The Peak of Something
text: On Monday, Dubai celebrated the completion of what is now, and is likely to remain for some time, the tallest building on the planet and its last-second name change. What was supposed to be called Burj Dubai (burj means tower in Arabic) rises to 2,717 feet above a series of rounded, bronzed setbacks. It took five years to complete and cost $1.5 billion. At the opening, it was renamed Burj Khalifa, in honor of Sheik Khalifa bin Zayed al-Nahyan, the emir of Abu Dhabi, which gave Dubai a $10 billion loan a few weeks ago to help head off the country’s financial collapse.

headline: Y2K and Warming: Alarm or Realism?
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Father Knows Best
text: Surely, the most important, interesting  and, yes, heroic  figure in the whole Christmas Day Northwest airliner affair was the would-be bomber’s father, the Nigerian banker Alhaji Umaru Mutallab.

headline: How 12/25 Was Like 9/11
text: IN the days since the attempted Christmas Day airplane bombing, many officials, including the White House’s counterterrorism director, John Brennan, have insisted that the Detroit incident was “not like 9/11.” In many respects, we agree. But the government’s handling of the intelligence leading up to the attack was eerily reminiscent of one of the most shocking  and relatively underreported  revelations to come out of the 9/11 commission’s hearings.

headline: Another Iranian Revolution? Not Likely
text: THE Islamic Republic of Iran is not about to implode. Nevertheless, the misguided idea that it may do so is becoming enshrined as conventional wisdom in Washington.

headline: U.S. Job Site Bans Bias Over Gender Identity
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has inserted language into the federal jobs Web site explicitly banning employment discrimination based on gender identity.

headline: Randy Johnson: An Appreciation
text: The first time I met Randy Johnson, I was 14 years old and he was playing for the Montreal Expos. I had a field pass for a game at Veterans Stadium in April 1989. I asked him to autograph his baseball card, and he said he’d be right back. He never returned.

headline: Donal Donnelly, Actor Who Nurtured Irish Roles, Dies at 78
text: Donal Donnelly, an Irish actor who embodied a variety of Irish characters on the American stage and in American movies, notably in the plays of Brian Friel and in John Huston’s adaptation of James Joyce’s short story “The Dead,” died Monday in Chicago, where he had been living for the past two years. He was 78.

headline: Phys Ed: Can You Be Overweight and Still Be Healthy?
text: The idea that people can be overweight and yet still quite healthy began gaining scientific and popular credence some years ago, fueled by the publication of a number of studies showing that men and women who were a few pounds overweight but physically active had less risk of developing cardiac disease than people who were of normal weight but sedentary.

headline: Access in the City? Wi-Fi in New York
text: New Year’s resolutions are made for many reasons — not least of which is so that they can immediately be broken. Last week I resolved first and foremost to put aside my iPhone (and laptop and other electronic devices) and experience destinations more directly. So what do I do this week? Offer tips on how to find free Wi-Fi in New York City, so you’ll never be without a digital tether.

headline: Showcase: Landscapes Under Foot
text: “To find new things, take the path you took yesterday.” — John Burroughs, naturalist and essayist

headline: Kenneth Noland, Abstract Painter of Brilliantly Colored Shapes, Dies at 85
text: Kenneth Noland, whose brilliantly colored concentric circles, chevrons and stripes were among the most recognized and admired signatures of the postwar style of abstraction known as Color Field painting, died Tuesday at his home in Port Clyde, Me. He was 85.

headline: Do Chipmunks Outrank Na’vi?
text: “Avatar’s” $1 billion in ticket sales may garner all the headlines for News Corporation’s 20th Century Fox, which released the sci-fi spectacle. But the studio’s other holiday film, “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel,” may be more valuable to shareholders in Rupert Murdoch’s media group over the long run.

headline: Senator Dodd Will Not Seek Re-election, Democrats Say
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the United States Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, Democrats familiar with his plans said Wednesday.

headline: Correction
text: The Critic’s Notebook last Wednesday about the best dishes in New York City restaurants in 2009 referred imprecisely to the Web site of Craft, the restaurant that formerly employed Karen DeMasco, who created one of the selected dishes, the maple budino dessert at Locanda Verde. Although Craft’s site still includes her biography, which can be found through a search engine, it no longer prominently features her.

headline: News Quiz | January 6, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Colorado Governor Won’t Seek Second Term
text: DENVER  Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. of Colorado, a first-term Democrat, and spokesman for a band of upstart Democratic governors in historically Republican strongholds in the West, will not seek a second term in office this fall, a Colorado Democrat with knowledge of the governor’s plans said Tuesday.

headline: Asia Gains Edge Backing Tech Start-Ups
text: For years, the process remained relatively static: PC makers like Hewlett-Packard and Apple, with well-staffed research labs and design departments, would dream up their next product and then hire a Chinese or Taiwanese fabricator to manufacture the largest number of units at the lowest possible cost.

headline: If Fed Missed This Bubble, Will It See a New One?
text: If only we’d had more power, we could have kept the financial crisis from getting so bad.

headline: Apple Buys Quattro, an Ad Firm
text: Apple encroached upon Google‘s turf on Tuesday with its acquisition of Quattro Wireless, a mobile advertising company.

headline: Decision Sets Stage for Pitched Battle
text: Senator Christopher J. Dodd’s plan to retire from Congress sets the stage for a contentious battle for a seat that Democrats have held for 46 years, with the party hoping to hold out against determined Republican opposition.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Asks Review of Handling of Case
text: Lawyers for Bradley Birkenfeld, the former UBS private banker who is headed to jail for helping wealthy Americans evade taxes through secret offshore accounts, asked the Justice Department on Tuesday to investigate whether prosecutors had mishandled his case, Lynnley Browning writes in The New York Times.

headline: Dodd Will Not Seek Re-election, Democrats Say
text: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the United States Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, Democrats familiar with his plans said Wednesday.

headline: When Have You Been Fooled by a Hoax or Practical Joke?
text: A fake e-mail message sent to the 4,900 students at Brooklyn Technical High School on Sunday night convinced most students —if only for an hour—that school was canceled the next day. When have you ever been the victim (or perpetrator) of a hoax or practical joke, large or small?

headline: North Korea Started Uranium Program in 1990s, South Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea apparently began pursuing a uranium enrichment program in 1996 at the latest, the South Korean foreign minister said Wednesday, bolstering fears that the North’s second route to building a nuclear bomb could be well on its way..

headline: U.S. Plans New Charge in Galleon Insider Case
text: Federal prosecutors said Tuesday that they planned to bring additional insider trading charges against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group, a move that could increase his possible prison time to more than 15 years if convicted, Zachery Kouwe reported in The New York Times.

headline: Wall St. Ends Mixed on Sliding Home Sales
text: Major stock indexes ended mixed Tuesday, a day after the Dow Jones industrials soared more than 150 points on upbeat manufacturing reports in the United States and China. Uncertainty over crucial reports this week on employment and the service industry also kept buyers at bay, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Attack in Kashmir Kills 3 Pakistani Soldiers
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least four soldiers were killed and 11 were wounded in what the authorities said could have been a suicide attack in the Pakistan-controlled part of the disputed Kashmir region on Wednesday, according to Pakistani officials and news outlets.

headline: Drip Pricing
text: A technique of online pricing where the total cost is revealed only at the end of the purchasing process, after a series of (compulsory/hidden) charges have been added.

headline: Schloss Said to Take N.Y. Investment Post
text: Lawrence Schloss, the chairman and chief executive of private equity firm Diamond Castle, has agreed to become the next chief investment officer for New York City, the Web site peHUB reported.

headline: Prudential Buys Singapore Bank’s Insurance Unit
text: United Overseas Bank, Singapore’s number three banking group, said Wednesday it would sell its Singapore life insurance unit to Prudential P.L.C. of Britain for 428 million Singapore dollars ($307 million), confirming an earlier report.

headline: Intuity Medical Gets $64 Million Injection
text: Intuity Medical, which makes blood glucose monitors, has received $64 million in a fourth round of funding, VentureBeat reported, citing a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: GMAC Predicts Further Loss of $5 Billion
text: GMAC Financial Services said on Tuesday that it expected to post a combined fourth-quarter loss of about $5 billion, largely on charges related to its bid to write down or sell risky mortgage assets, Reuters reported.

headline: DataSphere Obtains $10.4 Million in Funding
text: DataSphere, a start-up that helps media companies set up hyperlocal and niche news sites, has landed $10.8 million in fresh funding.

headline: Calpers’s New Board Members May Restore Image
text: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the biggest United States public pension fund, said on Tuesday that unofficial election results showed that Kurato Shimada and Joseph Jelincic had won member-at-large seats on its board.

headline: I.P.O. Market Remained Dreary in 2009

headline: Yemen Says It’s Arrested 3 Qaeda Militants
text: SANA, Yemen  Yemen announced Wednesday that it had arrested three militants from a cell of Al Qaeda suspected of making threats to Western targets here.

headline: Milestones: Christopher J. Dodd
text: An interactive timeline of Senator Chris Dodd's life and political career.

headline: Reed Elsevier Said to Eye Sale of Magazines
text: Reed Elsevier, the publishing and events group, is in advanced talks to sell some of its loss-making trade magazines and will close other titles during the first half of 2010, Reuters reported, citing an internal memo.

headline: Beazer Homes to Offer New Stock and Debt
text: Beazer Homes USA said Tuesday it would begin offerings of new common stock and convertible subordinated debt. The home builder’s shares tumbled in extended trading, The Associated Press reported.

headline: City of London Rents to Rebound, Report Says
text: Rents on the best commercial real estate in the City of London are set to increase 10.5 percent this year, as tenants move upmarket and supply diminishes, according to a report by King Sturge, a real estate consultant.

headline: Buyout Shops Chase Siemens Unit
text: Siemens has shortlisted a strategic buyer and five private equity firms as potential buyers of its hearing aid unit, potentially worth more than 2 billion euros ($2.9 billion), Reuters reported, citing several people familiar with the matter.

headline: Investors Cheer Departure of Biogen Chief
text: Investors welcomed the upcoming departure of Biogen Idec‘s chief executive, James Mullen, sending the company’s shares higher in early trading on Tuesday, Reuters reported.

headline: Kraft Gets 1.52 Percent Acceptance for Cadbury Bid
text: Kraft Foods said it had so far received a 1.52 percent acceptance from Cadbury shareholders for its hostile bid, but most shareholders are expected to wait to see if Kraft raises its bid before making their decisions, Reuters reported.

headline: Broadcom’s Samueli Resumes Role
text: Broadcom‘s co-founder, Henry Samueli, has resumed his role as chief technical officer for the chip maker after a federal judge dismissed a criminal charge against him, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Goldman Converts Preferred Shares in Sumitomo
text: Goldman Sachs Group agreed to convert its 100 billion yen ($1.09 billion) of preferred shares in Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: U.S. Exchanges Tout Speed After Tokyo Upgrade
text: A day after the Tokyo Stock Exchange introduced its new high-speed trading system, meant to capture the new need-for-speed in financial markets, United States exchanges were quick to tout how swift their systems are, Reuters reported.

headline: Swaying to the Beats of Africa in Prague
text: MC Jah Koko, the owner of Confessions, a Prague bar, is also a Nigerian-born reggae singer who gamely offers to dance with arriving patrons, his swaying invariably reciprocated.

headline: Citi’s John Havens Earned $9 Million in 2009
text: John Havens, head of Citigroup‘s securities business, earned about $9 million in total compensation in 2009, apparently making him the highest-paid executive at the bank.

headline: Global Financial Rules Overhaul Seen in 2010
text: Global financial regulation has changed little since the 2008 banking crisis, but that won’t be the case much longer, according to Reuters.

headline: U.K. Bonus Tax Has Mixed Results, Report Says
text: It seems that the U.K. government’s bank bonus tax has had mixed results.

headline: JAL Falls on Report That Agencies Eye Bankruptcy
text: Shares of Japan Airlines fell nearly 7 percent on Wednesday after a newspaper said the carrier’s main creditor and the finance ministry support bankruptcy as a way to restructure the heavily indebted airline.

headline: Anti-Whaling Vessel Damaged in a Collision at Sea
text: HONG KONG  An anti-whaling group’s high-speed boat and a Japanese whaler reported colliding at sea on Wednesday, with each blaming the other.

headline: The Yanquis Went Home
text: Today’s idea: Say adiós to the Monroe Doctrine, under which Washington long called the shots in its own backyard. “For the first time in centuries, the United States doesn’t seem to care much what happens in Latin America.”

headline: Ex-Perot Employee Returning $8.6 Million
text: A former employee of a Perot Systems affiliate who had been charged with insider trading has agreed to return about $8.6 million in illicit profits, federal regulators said Tuesday.

headline: Dal Five Ways
text: I wouldn’t say I live on dal, but it’s become a staple for me — along with about 200 other bean-based dishes — and I love its high flavor and speed of preparation. Read more in this week’s Minimalist column.

headline: AQR’s Mutual Fund Assets Said to Hit $1 Billion
text: When AQR Capital Management launched its first hedge-fund-style mutual fund in January 2009, the hedge fund was looking for ways to reach out to new investors, even as the industry faced withdrawals.

headline: Sampler: Turtle Protections and Lawn-Size Restrictions
text: Autism Clusters Probably Not Linked to Environment | The 10 places in California where there appears to be an uptick in the number of children with autism may be linked to parents’ ability to get help for their children rather than a specific environmental risk, according to a new study by the University of California, Davis, that was published in The Journal of Autism Research. Among the 10 clusters are the Sunnyvale-Santa Clara area, the San Carlos-Belmont area in San Mateo County and Sacramento. “I don’t think you have to worry about something in the neighborhood harming children,” said Irva Hertz-Picciotto, the project’s lead investigator. [The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: Was AOL-Time Warner Really the Worst Deal?
text: Gerald Levin, the former Time Warner chief who helped orchestrate the disastrous merger with AOL, said he had “presided over the worst deal of the century.” But The Telegraph says that Mr. Levin shouldn’t be too quick to grab for that tarnished crown.

headline: Dodd to Retire, but What About Financial Reform?

Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the United States Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, The New York Times’s Adam Nagourney reported Wednesday, citing Democrats familiar with his plans.

text: Ken Block, the American rally car driver whose power slides are familiar to millions through some very popular YouTube videos, has signed a deal with Ford to compete in rally racing’s big leagues, the World Rally Championship.

headline: Japan Replaces Ailing Finance Minister
text: TOKYO  Dealing another blow to the fledgling government, the Japanese finance minister resigned Wednesday, leaving Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama to appoint a successor with little fiscal experience to grapple with financing an ambitious campaign agenda, a growing public debt and a fading economic recovery.

text: At the Fremont, Calif., offices of Redwood Systems, a high-tech start-up, the super-efficient light emitting diode fixtures, or LEDs, that dot the ceiling dim imperceptibly as more natural light comes through the windows.
