text: 2010 Election Dispatches The departures of two Democratic Senators, Christopher Dodd of Connecticut and Byron Dorgan of North Dakota, puts the party’s precarious hold on the Senate more plainly than ever at risk.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, Jan. 6
text: Highlights from media coverage in Wednesday’s New York Times:

headline: Cadbury Shares Slide Toward Kraft Offer
text: Update | 9:52 a.m. Shares in Kraft dropped 2 percent to $28.18 in early morning trading on Wednesday, once again opening up the spread between its bid and Cadbury’s share price.

headline: The Morning Feed
text: More Tangles for Web of ‘Spider-Man:’ Is the name of Spider-Man now as poisonous to a project as a black widow’s bite? With plans for a Broadway musical about Marvel Comics’ best-known (and most lucrative) superhero in flux, The Hollywood Reporter says that a fourth “Spider-Man” film, planned for 2011, could be delayed by a creative dispute between the director Sam Raimi and the Sony movie studio. Mr. Raimi, who directed the first three “Spider-Man” movies, wants to pit the wall-crawler against the villainous Vulture, while the studio wants to emphasize a romantic subplot between Spidey and the Black Cat.

headline: We Are All Gadget Nerds Now
text: Over the holiday, Decoder was in Lower Manhattan at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Annex and found himself staring at Bo Diddley‘s guitar. Even, or especially, locked behind glass in an inert state, it is a thing of majestic, mysterious beauty.

headline: Will Exchanges Spur Lawsuits? Maybe Not
text: Could a health care overhaul lead to a raft of consumer lawsuits against insurers over medical claims denials?

headline: Connecticut’s Attorney General Will Seek Dodd’s Senate Seat
text: Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut’s Democratic attorney general, said Wednesday that he would run for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Christopher J. Dodd, who plans to announce his retirement later in the day.

headline: Trouble Tempers Working Families Party’s Triumph
text: Unabashedly left-leaning, the Working Families Party is the latest in a line of little-known but powerful third parties in New York. The party, whose leaders come from unions and liberal corners of the Democratic Party, rarely runs its own candidates. Leaders recruit and cross-endorse Democrats and put savvy field operatives to work in primaries and general elections.

headline: Slovak Air Security Test Goes Very Wrong
text: In what no doubt seemed like a good idea at the time, Slovak officials decided to test security at two airports in Slovakia on Saturday by concealing plastic explosives in eight suitcases and waiting to see what happened next. Read the full post.

headline: Senators Said Near Pact to Strip Fed of Some Powers
text: With skepticism over the Federal Reserve‘s role growing by the day, key senators are near an agreement to strip the banking regulator of much of its authority, Reuters reported Wednesday, citing two anonymous sources.

headline: Heavy Snow Causes Travel Disruptions in England
text: Unusually heavy snowfall stranded hundreds of motorists, disrupted trains and shut down schools and airports across Britain on Wednesday as the country suffered through its longest cold snap in nearly 30 years.

headline: Senior Labour Insiders Want Secret Ballot on Brown
text: LONDON  Months before a national election, two senior leaders in Britain’s governing Labour Party issued an unusual appeal on Wednesday for a secret ballot on the leadership of Prime Minister Gordon Brown, adding to a catalog of woes ranging from recession at home to criticism of his handling of the war in Afghanistan.

headline: Tennis Channel Takes Its Feud With Comcast to the F.C.C.
text: The Tennis Channel filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission late Tuesday accusing the cable giant Comcast of keeping it on a digital sports tier while making the Golf Channel and Versus, channels that Comcast owns, more widely available.

headline: SXSW Opening-Night Film Is Announced
text: The SXSW Film Conference and Festival in Austin has chosen an opening-night film likely to excite many of the fanboys it often attracts: the fanboy-themed action film “Kick-Ass.” Based on a comic by Mark Millar and John S. Romita, Jr., the film tells the story of a comic book enthusiast who becomes a superhero. Aaron Johnson stars and Matthew Vaughn (“Stardust,” “Layer Cake”) directs. The film will release nationwide on April 16 from Lionsgate.

headline: Sherlock Goes Daffy
text: In an analysis of Sherlock Holmes in Wednesday’s New York Times, Charles McGrath writes that Arthur Conan Doyle‘s celebrated detective “has appeared in countless movies, stage plays and television series, and has inspired a shelf full of literary sequels and knockoffs, as well as some cartoon versions. He has even been played by Daffy Duck.”

headline: Old Age, New Gizmos
text: When the vast Consumer Electronics Show, underway this week in Las Vegas, adds an exhibition called Silvers Summit, devoted to new products for the aging and their caregivers, brace yourselves. American tech companies, taking notice of the unmistakable demographic trends, have launched a surge.

headline: New Life for Solar-Updraft Technology?
text: The solar updraft tower, which uses the greenhouse effect and thermal convection to drive wind turbines and produce electricity, has been hailed as a novel — and promising — approach to renewable energy generation.

headline: Wednesday Reading
text: Consumer-focused stories appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The Way We Ate: The Ichthyophagous Club
text: For more than a century and a half, The New York Times has been recording the pleasures and prejudices of the American palate. “The Way We Ate” is a weekly tasting menu of vintage food writing from The Times’s archives.

headline: Starting Over at a Lexington Manufacturing Plant
text: It was almost 30 years ago that I led a management buyout of what was then a failing International Harvester factory in Springfield, Mo. As it is now, the economy then was in the tank and capital was next to impossible to come by. I was convinced that our only hope was to open the books and teach every employee how to think like an owner. As I explained in my first post, things have worked out pretty well for the company we created, SRC Holdings.

headline: Citing Tough Race, Dodd Steps Aside
text: EAST HADDAM, Conn.  Christopher J. Dodd has been in politics 36 years, including an ill-starred presidential run in 2008 and a record three decades as a United States senator from Connecticut. He can, then, count votes with anyone in Congress. But with his popularity at a nadir, he was not sure he could count enough votes in his home state to assure his election to a sixth term.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Devils and Hawks Stake Claims for Supremacy
text: Ten matches on Tuesday night as the N.H.L. embarks on the second half of the regular season in what will be a January jammed with games. Given that we’re so far along into the season, we’d expect to see a few elite teams establish themselves — and that’s exactly what we’re seeing. On this night it’s the Devils and Blackhawks, rising to the top alongside the Sharks. If they keep this up, pretty soon they’re going to be on another plane altogether. Home teams listed first:

headline: China Admits New Tainted-Milk Case Is Older
text: SHANGHAI  On Dec. 31, Chinese regulators announced that they had arrested three executives and shut down a dairy company here for selling products contaminated with an industrial chemical called melamine.

headline: At C.E.S., Cars Take Center Stage
text: Once thought of merely as the repository for thumping subwoofers and multi-disc CD changers, cars and trucks will be a major focus for high-tech gear at the annual Consumer Electronics Show opening this week in Las Vegas.

headline: ‘Up’ Shoots for Academy Upset
text: The Bagger has been enjoying breaking out the sports terminology during this awards season, finding out who’s in the pole position or who’s pulled off a hat trick. The wild card/dark horse/Cinderella at the dance this week may be “Up,” which was nominated for best picture by the Producers Guild of America on Tuesday. Pixar’s hit, about Carl, a 78-year-old widowed grump – played by Ed Asner – who turns his house into a floating bucket list quest, bringing a precociously annoying boy (Jordan Nagai) along for the ride, was hailed by many critics as an adult-worthy animated tale. The first five minutes of the film, which wordlessly captures Carl’s entire life with his wife, from meet-cute to wedding day to funeral, with images that rifle through cinematic classics, was especially sophisticated. Manohla Dargis called it “filmmaking at its purest.” Also, it makes everyone cry.

headline: City Opera Cedes Dates to City Ballet in Lincoln Center Deal
text: Starting this year the New York City Ballet will be taking over full use of the Lincoln Center theater that it shares with New York City Opera for four weeks in September and October  severely curtailing the opera company’s fall season  as part of an agreement that will give the opera some relief from its forthcoming building payments.

headline: A Different Kind of Showdown for Bob Barker
text: Though the real-life Bob Barker is better known for his affability and gentleness toward people with no conception of what things cost, a ship named for Mr. Barker, the longtime “Price Is Right” host, had its first confrontation with whalers on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. The Bob Barker, a 1,200-ton vessel operated by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, the activist group featured on the Animal Planet series “Whale Wars,” was among the ships that tried to stop a Japanese whaling mission in waters near Antarctica. Mr. Barker, 86, donated the money for his namesake ship after meeting the Sea Shepherd founder Paul Watson through a fellow animal advocate. “He said he thought he could put the Japanese whaling fleet out of business if he had $5 million,” Mr. Barker told The A.P. “I said, ‘I think you do have the skills to do that, and I have $5 million, so let’s get it on.'” Sea Shepherd describes itself as an anti-poaching organization, and says it enforces the United Nations World Charter for Nature by intervening in whaling missions.

headline: ‘We Are All Gadget Nerds Now’
text: It’s finally happened! We have arrived. When I say “we,” I mean nerds. We completely bypassed “cool” and went straight to mainstream. According to David Carr of The Times, writing on the Media Decoder blog, “We Are All Gadget Nerds Now.” He writes:

headline: Council Speaker Tries to Move Out of Mayor’s Shadow
text: A few weeks before Election Day, Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the New York City Council, met with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at a diner in Manhattan.

headline: Down is up
text: From Marketwatch:

headline: Content in the Service of the Gadget
text: The intersection of culture and technology has always been a rich, mashed-up place, but today’s burgeoning army of electronic devices, rather than just serving as a platform for stories, seems to be creating them, David Carr writes on the Media Decoder blog. On the eve of the Consumer Electronics Show, he says, it’s worth pointing out that content, which we’ve been told is king, seems increasingly to be serving as software used to animate various devices.

headline: Marijuana Trade School Finds a Bigger Home
text: The former home of a charter school at 1600 Broadway in Oakland is the new headquarters for Oaksterdam University, an Oakland-born trade school that teaches adults about the business of all things cannabis.

headline: ‘You Would Never Guess’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Did you hear about the guy that blew up his underpants? People are mad about that. I think it’s funny. I don’t know. Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab. You would never guess he’d be mixed up in something like this. Not Abdulmutallab.

headline: Graphic Content | Looking a Great Campaign in the Face
text: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chairman of the M.F.A. Design Department at the School of Visual Arts and a blogger and author.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday: Friends Forever?
text: Pinch yourselves, it’s really happening: Lisa Kudrow and Courteney Cox of “Friends” will be reunited on Wednesday on Ms. Cox’s “Cougar Town” (ABC, 9:30 p.m.). Ms. Kudrow has been just great as a therapist on the improvised Internet series “Web Therapy” (lstudio.com), but here she’s showing her medical versatility: she’s a dermatologist. And apparently this dermatologist knows how to cut, with a remark, at least. The episode is called “Rhino Skin.”

headline: ‘Updating the Oval Office’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: President Obama spent the day talking to officials about airline security. One of the things they are doing is adding dozens of names to the no-fly list. Uh, hello, have you tried flying out of Newark? We’re all on the no-fly list.

headline: Do You Overestimate Your Child’s Activity?
text: Compared to adults, children seem to be moving constantly. So it’s no surprise that most parents who are quizzed about their child’s physical activity level describe their children as fairly active.

headline: ‘Ideal Next-Door Neighbor’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” on NBC: A new poll asked Americans who their ideal next-door neighbor would be. The No. 1 answer was the Obama family, mainly because the Obamas are the kind of neighbors who would lend you a cup of sugar or a trillion dollars.

headline: A New Look at an Old Quarrel Over ‘Waterfront’
text: Some quarrels never seem to fade away, and the anti-Communist battles of the 1940s and 1950s are being fought long after most of the original antagonists are dead.

headline: ‘Exploding Underpants’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With david Letterman” on CBS: Cold. Am I right? You know, Rush Limbaugh was ill. And he had to go to the hospital. He had chest pains but he’s completely recovered. He’ll be back on his job on Wednesday, which is great because the country really can use some hot air now.

headline: Bernanke and the bubble
text: Following up on a point I made in Atlanta (along with many others), David Leonhardt takes Ben Bernanke to task for failing to concede that the Fed, himself included, missed the bubble.

headline: Iraq in the Future Perfect Tense
text: Simple word choices can tell a lot about a place. In American public conversation, Iraq is slipping into the future perfect tense — away from what is happening now, to what will have happened in the future.

headline: ‘The Situation in Yemen’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: The weather here in California is very nice. But it’s freezing all across the United States. In fact, in D.C., the weather is so bad — this is true — they actually hired convicted criminals to shovel snow at the U.S. Capitol. Isn’t that amazing? So it’s nice to see members of Congress doing something useful for a change.

headline: Off to the 2010 Races
text: A slow start to the 2010 elections? Not in this political environment.

headline: New Features, and Fees, for Checking Accounts
text: As banks look for new revenue sources, they are rolling out new types of credit cards and checking accounts with new fees attached.

headline: College Football Q.& A. With Pete Thamel
text: Pete Thamel, who covers college sports for The Times, answered reader questions on Wednesday (in the comment section below) about the Bowl Championship Series final, between Texas and Alabama, and other topics.

headline: Ivanhoe Mines Hires Citi to Advise on Strategic Options
text: Ivanhoe Mines may sell shares or debt, sell off a subsidiary or look at other options as it continues to develop its huge gold and copper mine in Mongolia, the company said Wednesday.

headline: In Protest, Chinese Films Pulled From Palm Springs Festival
text: Updated | 3:44 p.m. Two Chinese movies have been pulled from the Palm Springs International Film Festival to protest another film about the Dalai Lama and Tibet, Agence France-Presse reported. The Chinese movies “Nanjing! Nanjing!” (also known as “City of Life and Death”), about the Japanese occupation of Nanjing in 1937, and “Quick Quick Slow,” were withdrawn, according to China’s state-run Beijing Times, because the Palm Springs festival plans to screen a movie called “The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibet’s Struggle for Freedom.” That film, a documentary by Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, follows the Dalai Lama for a year, and its description in the festival’s program said that it chronicled “the 2008 protests in Tibet, the long march in India, the Beijing Olympics and the breakdown of talks with China.” A representative for “Nanjing! Nanjing!” said that the films were pulled on the order of China’s ministry of foreign affairs, its film bureau and the consulate general of China in Los Angeles.

headline: Answers From a Bicycle Mechanic
text: Following is the first set of responses from Eric Schofield, the manager at Bicycle Habitat on Lafayette Street in Manhattan, who is responding to readers’ questions about bicycle maintenance and repair.We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

text: A husband who follows in the wake of his successful wife.

headline: Three Views of Violent Clash Over Whaling
text: UPDATE 1/10: There is now a third video viewpoint on the collision between the Sea Shepherd anti-whaling speed boat Ady Gil and the Shonan Maru No. 2, which is described as a security boat in the Japanese whaling fleet. Sea Shepherd contends that this vantage point clearly shows that the Japanese ship was intent on closing with and ramming the protesters. [UPDATE, 2/6: Another collision at sea, this time between a Japanese harpoon vessel and the Bob Barker.]

headline: New Director of Cooper-Hewitt Is Named
text: Bill Moggridge, a founder of the design firm IDEO who is widely credited with designing the first laptop computer in 1980, has been named director of the Smithsonian’s Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York.

headline: The Alcon Independent Directors’ Dilemma
text: Novartis‘s bid to acquire Alcon is an odd duck of a deal.

headline: Drone Strikes Reported in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  American missiles, presumably fired by drones, struck twice Wednesday in North Waziristan, the Pakistani tribal region that is a stronghold of the Taliban and Al Qaeda.

headline: Travel Deals: All-Inclusive Stays Starting at $58
text: Occidental Hotels and Resorts — which operates all-inclusive resorts in Aruba, Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic and Mexico — is offering up to 57 percent off on stays through April 30, with rates starting at $58 a person.

headline: Democrats Face Shifting and Perilous Political Environment
text: President Obama awoke on Wednesday to a dispiriting reality: Less than a year after taking office on the strength of a historic Democratic sweep, his party is facing a shifting and perilous political environment that could have big implications for this year’s midterm elections and his own agenda.

headline: Courtney Love to Continue the Hole Story
text: Whether or not, as a timely movie title predicted, 2010 proves to be the year we make contact with intelligent alien life, it has already brought us something equally as improbable: the promise of Hole’s first shows in 11 years. The Guardian reported that Hole, the vintage-1990s grunge-rock band led by Courtney Love, announced on its Facebook page that it would play three European shows next month, starting with a performance on Feb. 17 at the Shepherds Bush Empire in London. The concert dates are also listed on a Web site for “Nobody’s Daughter,” an album that was once planned as a solo project for Ms. Love but was rebranded as a Hole album last year (and is still without a label or a release date). The Guardian said that the new lineup of Hole would include Ms. Love, the guitarist Micko Larkin, the bassist Shawn Dailey and the drummer Stu Fischer. It was unclear if Ms. Love’s former bandmates Eric Erlandson (who has previously declared “there is no Hole without me”) and Melissa Auf der Maur (who has said of Ms. Love, “She’s a nutbag and I really do care about her”) would be involved.

headline: 3-D’s Quest to Move Beyond Gimmicks
text: THE first Academy Awards banquet, held on May 16, 1929, and honoring films released between Aug. 1, 1927, and July 31, 1928, included a special award to Warner Brothers “for producing ‘The Jazz Singer,’ the pioneering outstanding talking picture, which has revolutionized the industry.”

headline: Texas and Alabama, Still on the Calendar
text: If you’re feeling a bit queasy today, consider it a case of season creep. Sports are throwing off our equilibrium by oozing into the wrong time of year. We should have been able to flip the college football switch on Jan. 1, but no, we still have Mack Brown and Nick Saban yammering at news conferences and they are not talking about their coming spring practices. Baseball’s handing-out-fat-contracts season no longer has any end and it feels bizarre talking about Hall of Fame inductions while we’re still sweeping up the Christmas tree needles. And Redskins-as-circus season, that’s a 365-day affair, not just when it gets a new ringleader.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Meets ‘Up in the Air’ in the Desert
text: By now, it should come as no surprise that “The Hurt Locker,” the film about bombs over, in and around Baghdad, has been named the year’s best by Metacritic, the online review aggregator. Kathryn Bigelow’s gutsy feature has won kudos from nearly every critical group, from New York to Los Angeles to the digital realm, which as we all know, long ago stopped being the domain of pajama-clad mouth-breathers and is now the domain of everyone. Though in the march toward The 10 — and the lock step to The One — awards from peer groups are more predictive, professional accolades are helpful, to be sure, if only because they encourage people to actually see the movie. “The Hurt Locker,” which was released in the summer, has made just over $16 million globally, or about what “Avatar” took home in an afternoon.

headline: Merrill Executive Ford Weighs Challenge to Gillibrand
text: Amid all of the Washington news Wednesday morning, we forgot to flag this bit of news: a Merrill Lynch executive is weighing a bid to unseat Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in this fall’s Democratic primary, The New York Times’s Michael Barbaro reported, citing three people close to the executive.

headline: Flutist to L.A. Philharmonic: I’ll Take Chicago
text: Symphony orchestra musicians, in public, at least, rarely cast aspersions on other orchestras. But the principal flutist of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra had some less than complimentary things to say about the Los Angeles Philharmonic, according to a newspaper report. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave and was performing with the Philharmonic temporarily — a fairly common occurrence when first-chair players are considering a move. Mr. Dufour has decided to stay at his Midwestern job, The Chicago Sun-Times reported on Tuesday, quoting him as saying that the Los Angeles Philharmonic has “no tradition there — no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble. Maybe they will have that someday in the future.”

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1.) Kiplinger’s list of public colleges with the best value.

headline: Spectacular Dempsey Goal Raises Eyebrows, and His Reputation
text: Clint Dempsey gave England and the world a look at his skill when he scored a stunning goal in Fulham’s 3-2 loss at Stoke City in the English Premier League on Tuesday. It was the Cottagers’ second straight loss following a run of six matches without a loss that had pushed the club to the middle of the pack.

headline: The First Senator From the Tea Party?
text: Charlie Crist’s perma-tanned face bears none of the strain you would expect from the archetype of the embattled Republican. Politicians are supposed to keep up appearances, but Crist is especially convincing, one of the more earnest politicians you will see, whether or not he means it.

text: The head of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School has decided to leave in June, disappointing many parents, students and staff members who had expected the popular school leader to stay longer.

headline: Peacefully Adrift as the Mississippi River Just Rolls Along
text: THE same drifting log had caught up with our kayaks again. It was sometime during our third day on the Mississippi River, or was it the fourth day, or the second or fifth? I’d lost myself again in a silent reverie, allowing my kayak to spin lazily along the great river’s western shoreline, like a bright yellow leaf with some kind of exotic beetle in a life vest perched in the middle of it.

headline: Alabama Quarterback Found Answers in Season of Self-Doubt
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  The whispers follow Greg McElroy around. He hears them as he walks across campus, eats at restaurants and even when he takes out-of-state trips.

text: In a flurry of deal making bolstered by government subsidies for renewable energy, venture capitalists invested $5.6 billion in green technology companies worldwide in 2009, according to a preliminary report released Wednesday by the Cleantech Group and Deloitte.

headline: Choptank It Shall Be
text: First Bobby Werhane and Joshua Morgan were going to call their Bleecker Street seafood restaurant Cherrystones. But that did not fly (or swim). Then it was Rockfish. Now, when it opens next week, in the space on Bleecker Street that was Bar Q, it will be called Choptank.

headline: Suicide Bomber Strikes at Police Officers in Caucasus
text: MOSCOW  A suicide car bomber killed six police officers in the capital of the Russian region of Dagestan on Wednesday. It was the deadliest such attack in months in a region where assassinations of police officers is a defining characteristic of the local militant Islamist movement.

headline: What Ails the Mona Lisa?
text: It’s not only famous authors whose life-threatening maladies can be diagnosed centuries after their deaths, but a medical expert at the University of Palermo in Italy says that he has also found evidence of medical afflictions in the subjects of some of the world’s most famous paintings, including the Mona Lisa, The Times of London reported. Vito Franco, a professor of pathological anatomy at the university, told The Times that he had spent two years examining people depicted in art masterpieces for evidence of disease and illness. Among his diagnoses, Dr. Franco said that Mona Lisa may have had high cholesterol, possibly evinced by a buildup of fatty acids under her skin, as well as a benign tumor in her right eye. He also said that the 5-year-old Infanta Margarita depicted in Velázquez’s painting “Las Meninas” might have had McCune-Albright syndrome, a genetic disease that affects bones, and the Virgin Mary in Piero della Francesca’s “Madonna del Parto” has a goiter on her neck.

headline: There’s an Android in My iPhone
text: Here’s one of the more curious gadgets you’re not going to see on the show floor of the Consumer Electronics Show. It’s an iPhone knock-off that may just be better than the iPhone.

headline: Senator Dodd Will Not Seek Re-election
text: Democratic Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut announced his decision not to seek re-election for a sixth term. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Can Parenting Be Truly Equal?
text: In the comments about my sleep post yesterday, Stella wrote: “I think women need to be more firm in their expectations of their husbands … There’s no reason that women should tolerate anything less than a 50-50 partnership, children or not.”

headline: Netbook Trio Uses New Intel Chip
text: This Wednesday is press day at the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, when manufacturers line up, one after another, to announce their new products. But press conferences are crowded, the information can be hard to absorb (especially by late afternoon) and lots of details can get lost.

headline: Heavy Snow Causes Disruptions in Britain
text: London, a city known for its low tolerance for snow, was buffeted by an unusually thick snowfall on Wednesday, the heaviest in more than 20 years. The snow and ice shut down railroad services, airports and schools across southern England and brought travel nearly to a halt on major highways.

headline: A Matter of Time: Conducting Experiments on Perception and Estimations of Time
text: Overview | How good are you at estimating time? Why does time seem to “fly when you’re having fun”? How do our brains perceive or track the passing of time? In this lesson, students estimate time spent on two short activities, one fun and one tedious, and then analyze and discuss their results and experiences. They then devise and conduct their own time-related investigations.

headline: Willie Mitchell, Soul Music Producer, Dies at 81
text: Willie Mitchell, who shaped the elegant yet gritty sound of Al Green, Ann Peebles and other stars of soul music as the house producer at Hi Records in the 1960s and ’70s, died Tuesday in Memphis, where he lived. He was 81.

headline: Gunfire at Gaza Protest Near Egypt
text: JERUSALEM  An anti-Egypt rally in southern Gaza turned deadly on Wednesday when demonstrators rushed the border fence and stoned Egyptian troops on the other side, leading to an exchange of gunfire and the death of an Egyptian soldier. Nine Egyptian soldiers and a dozen Palestinians were wounded from stones and gunfire, witnesses and medics said.

headline: Cohen Remains the Wild Card in Women’s Skating
text: Nearly four years have gone by since Sasha Cohen, the 2006 Olympic silver medalist, competed in an official figure skating competition. But with the 2010 Vancouver Games about month away, she appears set to break that drought.

headline: Passenger Jets Still Carry Unscreened Cargo
text: While a lot of attention has been paid in recent days to the need to find better ways to screen passengers and their luggage, as aviation security officials try to keep terrorists — or Slovak security officials — from smuggling explosives onto passenger jets, it remains an uncomfortable fact that entirely unscreened packages are still routinely loaded into the cargo holds of those same airplanes.

headline: How to Sell Your Business
text: You only sell your business once.

headline: Iranian Panel Calls Official in Charge of Prison ‘the Main Culprit’ in Detainee Deaths
text: A parliamentary panel in Iran on Wednesday implicated a senior official and ally of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in the deaths of at least three detainees arrested in June during antigovernment demonstrations, the Alef Web site reported.

headline: As Levy Mulls Bid for Governor, Hispanic Lawmakers Protest
text: ALBANY – His candidacy is not even official, and his announcement that he is considering running for governor is barely three days old.

text: NBC's Janet Samlien reports on the cold weather plaguing much of the nation. (Video: NBC)
