text: Sprint has the HTC Hero. Verizon has the Droid. T-Mobile has the Nexus One, among others.

headline: Two Democrats Will Not Seek Re-election
text: Senators Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota, both Democrats, will not be seeking re-election in November.

headline: Travel Planning Sites Team Up
text: Two prominent Web sites for travel planning have formed a canny partnership.

headline: Interior Chief Vows Scrutiny of Oil and Gas Leases
text: WASHINGTON  The interior secretary, Ken Salazar, said Wednesday that his department would conduct more rigorous reviews of oil and gas leasing on public lands, declaring that the agency would no longer be a “candy store” for the petroleum industry, as he said it had been during the Bush administration.

headline: Following Long Wait, Dawson Enters Hall Alone
text: Andre Dawson studied the voting from last year’s Hall of Fame election, and two figures stood out: 67 percent and 63 percent. The first was his percentage of votes, and the second was Bert Blyleven’s. Dawson predicted that this time, they would clear the 75 percent threshold needed for election.

headline: More Ballet, Less Opera at the State Theater: Win-Win?
text: The New York City Ballet has always wanted a fall repertory season at the theater it shares with New York City Opera at Lincoln Center. Now, the ballet’s wish is coming true, because of the economic needs of the opera. This September, the ballet will perform for four weeks in advance of its usual “Nutcracker” run, which starts in late November. The opera, in turn, will get $9 million in relief from its building payments, part of the $100 million gift given by the oil magnate David H. Koch toward the renovation of the theater, which was named after him and was completed in November. Read more about the arrangement.

headline: How Many Monkeys Do It Take to Stop the Show?
text: Here at ArtsBeat and its surrounding territories, we got a good laugh from Gregg Allman’s evocative explanation for why he wasn’t completely bummed about moving the Allman Brothers Band‘s annual residency to the United Palace from the Beacon Theater: “One monkey don’t stop no show,” he said.

headline: A New Video About Video
text: One of the overarching themes of C.E.S. this year (as it was, in fact, last year) is the ways in which TV programming is migrating to the Internet and how the Internet is migrating to television sets. In a new video, Bits blogger Nick Bilton takes a look at how we’re going to be watching television in the very near future.

headline: Essay: The Least of These My Brethren
text: In the winter of 1983, I interviewed and photographed dozens of Americans who had migrated to Florida from the Northeast and Midwest. They left because national unemployment was hovering around 10 percent, while in Florida it was 7.8 percent — and much warmer.

headline: Some at Fed See a Need to Do More for Housing
text: Despite extensive government intervention in the housing market, some policy makers at the Federal Reserve are worried that even more might need to be done.

headline: ‘Avatar’ and the Suspense-Free Shortlist
text: None too shockingly, “Avatar” is still in the running for best visual effects Oscar, as became clear on Wednesday when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences whittled down the original list of 15 movies to seven. The likely vanquished competitors are “District 9,” “Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince,” “Star Trek,” “Terminator Salvation,” “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen” and “2012.”

headline: OLED TV: Still Waiting in the Wings
text: With all the buzz at the Consumer Electronics Show focused on 3D television—with companies like Sony, Samsung and Panasonic announcing plans to sell 3D TVs to consumers this year—news about another potential video breakthough, a full-size OLED TV, is so far a no-show at C.E.S. 2010. So far.

headline: A Mixed Forecast for Financial Stocks
text: Investing in financial stocks will be “boring” this year compared with the charged atmosphere of 2009, analysts at FBR Capital Markets said in a report to clients on Wednesday. But they warned that residential loan losses and the weak economy would continue to clip the earning power of banks.

headline: Treat Me, but No Tricks Please
text: I RECEIVED an e-mail message recently from an angry doctor. He’d torn his hamstring running on a beach and spent eight weeks  a total of 20 hours  in physical therapy. Then his insurer said the physical therapy was not covered.

headline: Resolved
text: Here it is 2010 and Paper Cuts is waking up slowly, still waiting for that second cup of coffee to hit. Soon we’ll be back into the swing of things, with playlists and stray questions and bookish observations, but in the meantime we’ve been surfing through various reading resolutions for the New Year, and we wonder if you’d care to suggest any of your own. Forget “Moby-Dick,” though — we finally finished that one last year.

headline: AT&T Wants to Smarten Up Its Dumb Phones
text: As I reported on Monday, companies and entrepreneurs are bringing the app frenzy to feature phones — the simpler, less sophisticated cousins to shiny smartphones like the iPhone and Motorola Droid.

headline: Discovery to Show Pyramids, Great Wall in 3-D
text: One of Discovery Communications’ first 3-D productions, “ATLAS 4D,” will feature three-dimensional views of the Pyramids and the Great Wall of China. The program will be produced in 3-D and will be “used for several purposes,” a Discovery spokeswoman said Wednesday.

headline: Unauthorized Times Square Obama Ad Draws Attention
text: A New York garment company known for publicity stunts is getting one noticed by the Obama administration.

headline: Fed Minutes Show Division on Emergency Steps
text: Members of the Federal Reserve continued to grapple with uncertainties facing the economy at their most recent meeting, with some members suggesting that the central bank might have to expand measures to help the mortgage markets if the recovery stumbles, The New York Times’s Jack Healy reports.

headline: Debating Social Democracy
text: Responding to Jim Manzi (and myself) on the subject of Europe’s falling share of global G.D.P., Jon Chait points out that the gap between America’s economic performance and Europe’s over the last 30 years narrows dramatically if you look at G.D.P per capita, rather than just at overall economic growth. In other words, much of the widening gap between the U.S. and European shares of global G.D.P. can be chalked up to America’s population growth since the 1970s, rather than increasing per person wealth.

headline: Queens Principal Accused of Seeking Sex From Students
text: A high school principal in Ozone Park, Queens, inappropriately touched or solicited sex from at least four male students at the High School for Construction Trades, Engineering and Architecture, where he had served as principal since 2006, according a report by Richard Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the city’s Department of Education.

headline: Top Scams Targeted Recession Victims
text: On Wednesday, the Council of Better Business Bureaus released a list of what it considered the top scams of the 2009.

headline: Justice Said to Weigh Opposing Ticketmaster-Live Nation Deal
text: The Justice Department has a team of litigators prepared to oppose the merger of ticketing giant Ticketmaster and concert promoter Live Nation and could decide to take the deal to court, Reuters reported Wednesday, citing anonymous antitrust sources.

headline: Morgan Stanley Wins Lawsuit Against Discover
text: Morgan Stanley won a legal battle with its former subsidiary, Discover Financial Services, over nearly $800 million that Morgan Stanley says it was owed by the credit card company.

headline: Sondheim’s Wisdom, With Wistful Fragility
text: One reason any singing actor with a modicum of talent can’t go wrong interpreting the songs of Stephen Sondheim is that they make whoever sings them sound like a genius and a sage. In a fusion of sensibilities, the composer’s complicated thoughts become the singer’s, so that the performer’s best possible self  a more intuitive, smarter self (Mr. Sondheim doesn’t do stupid)  comes to the fore.

headline: Opposites Onstage, Opening a Season
text: In the current vogue of ballet programs arranged by theme (All Tchaikovsky! Love stories! Leotard ballets!) it’s easy to pine for the old days, when works with seemingly little in common lent a certain hot-and-cold balance to a night at Lincoln Center. On Tuesday evening the New York City Ballet opened its winter repertory season with such a disparate double-header: Peter Martins’s “Naïve and Sentimental Music,” followed by George Balanchine’s “Who Cares?” from 1970.

headline: City Says 9/11 Trials Will Cost $200 Million a Year
text: The Bloomberg administration has placed the price for security operations for the trials of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and other terrorism suspects connected to the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, at more than $200 million a year, which would make it by far the costliest security operation for a single event in the city in recent memory.

headline: Paterson Says Legislators Put State in Danger
text: ALBANY  In a strikingly blunt State of the State address, Gov. David A. Paterson chastised the lawmakers seated before him on Wednesday, saying they had spent the state into near-ruin and stood by as a plague of political corruption destroyed New Yorkers’ trust in their government.

headline: ‘Orphans’ Home Cycle’ Aims for Broadway for the Fall Season
text: A consortium of theater producers plans to transfer the Off Broadway production of Horton Foote’s “Orphans’ Home Cycle” to Broadway in the fall, rather than rush the show to Broadway this spring as had been discussed in recent weeks, two theater executives involved in the decision said on Wednesday.

headline: Spam E-Mail Appeals to Young, Overweight
text: Chances are you’ve seen those e-mail “spam” ads that tout the latest herbal remedy that promises dramatic weight loss. If you’re like most people, you just delete them.

headline: J. W. von Brunn, Accused Museum Gunman, Dies at 89
text: James W. von Brunn, who was accused of fatally shooting a security guard at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington in June, died on Wednesday at a hospital in North Carolina, near the federal prison where he was being held. He was 89.

headline: Officers Released From Hospital After Pit Bull Attack
text: When police officers in New York have reason to fire their weapons at dogs, they often hit their mark.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Jan. 6
text: “Could you just stand over there, for scale?” Most of us have — at one time or another — made such a request of a friend or family member, or been asked by a photographer to jump into the frame and serve as a human yardstick. It may not be personally flattering, but it’s certainly an effective device, as two pictures in today’s show, Slide 8 and Slide 10, quite dazzlingly reveal.

headline: Schwarzenegger: California Needs a ‘Sweetheart Deal,’ Too
text: Update | 5:42 p.m.  Congressional Democratic leaders, including the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, who represents San Francisco, are taking issue with Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger’s criticism of the major health care legislation.

headline: Writers Groups Oppose Google Settlement
text: A trio of writers groups has sent an open letter to members of Congress who are also authors, objecting to the Google book settlement that seeks to create a vast digital library of mostly out-of-print books.

headline: At C.E.S., Cars Take Center Stage
text: Over on Wheels, John R. Quain writes about the car-tech showcasing at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Among the highlights: Internet-connected cars, advanced navigation systems and a “Safe Driver TechZone.” Sales of in-car technologies are “expected to top $9.3 billion for 2009.”

headline: Florida Lawyer to Plead Guilty in Ponzi Scheme
text: Bernard L. Madoff may have company soon. A disbarred South Florida lawyer agreed in federal court on Wednesday to plead guilty later this month to charges accusing him of running Ponzi scheme that cheated thousands of investors out of $1.2 billion. The lawyer, Scott Rothstein, could be sentenced to life in prison.

headline: Desert bubbles
text: Some commenters on my Bernanke-bubble post wondered how the story I told back in 2005 can account for Phoenix and Las Vegas.

headline: Dispatch | Barcelona
text: The best way to beat a case of recession whiplash just might be a trip to Barcelona. Not only is Catalonia’s largest city a contagiously happy, optimistic sort of place, but it also just keeps getting better and better. Why? Recession or not — Spain’s economy is in bad shape, too — the locals honestly believe their city will be more beautiful, ecological, socially harmonious and culturally vibrant in the future, and they’re probably right.

headline: Adu Joins Greek Club Aris
text: Freddy Adu is going Greek. The United States midfielder/forward ended speculation about his immediate future Wednesday when he agreed to join Aris on an 18-month loan. Adu is contracted to Benfica, in Portugal, and he had fueled speculation  in his Twitter feed that  he could join Jozy Altidore at Hull City in England.

headline: Namath Has His Own Memories of ’65
text: No doubt about it, Joe Namath said Wednesday, he crossed the goal line with the ball on that fateful New Year’s Day of 1965.

headline: Colorado Governor Will Not Run Again
text: DENVER  Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. of Colorado, a Democrat who was elected in 2006 and hailed as a leader of what his party called a new strategy in the Rocky Mountain West, a region long dominated by Republicans, said on Wednesday that he would not seek a second term.

headline: Justice Department to Review Comcast-NBC Deal
text: The Justice Department said Wednesday that it would review Comcast‘s proposed acquisition of NBC Universal‘s broadcast network, cable channels and movie studios.

headline: Putting the “i” in Apple
text: In among all the speculation about the tablet that seems to be forthcoming from Apple and whether it will be a boon or a gallows for MSM, the name is getting a pretty good work-out. Some have noted that Apple seems to have its leopard paws on iSlate, but reader Patrick J. Shields is underwhelmed and suggested iTab had a nice ring to it. Maybe it’s time to help Apple and see if we can come up with a name. A few suggestions:

headline: U.S.O.C. Introduces Blackmun as New Chief
text: The United States Olympic Committee formally announced the selection of Scott Blackmun as its chief executive at a news conference Wednesday in Colorado Springs.

headline: Honda and Toyota Go Small at New Delhi Auto Expo
text: The 2010 auto show season has officially started, though not in the a place you might expect — India.

headline: N.B.A. Suspends Gilbert Arenas
text: As Gilbert Arenas prepared to play the Philadelphia 76ers on Tuesday night, he entered a circle of his Washington Wizards teammates, cocked his fingers into a gun and playfully shot them.

headline: Lou Reed and Friends to Play Benefit for Tuli Kupferberg
text: Lou Reed, John Zorn, Sonic Youth and others will play a benefit concert for Tuli Kupferberg (left), the Beat poet and original member of the Fugs, at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn on Jan. 22. Mr. Kupferberg, 86, has had two strokes over the last year, which have left him blind — although he still manages to regularly post video jokes to YouTube — and the tickets for the concert, which is being produced by Hal Willner, will help pay his medical expenses. Among the others performers are the singer John Kruth; Ed Sanders, Mr. Kupferberg’s fellow Fug; and Peter Stampfel of the Holy Modal Rounders (who also played on early Fugs albums). Tickets are $75 to $125 and are available at stannswarehouse.org or (718) 254.8779.

headline: An Oceanfront Home in Mexico
text: This 20-year-old house in a gated community in Rosarito is on the market for $895,000.

headline: What’s the Outlook for Democrats?
text: Updated, Jan. 7, 12:15 p.m. |  John Aldrich of Duke University joins the discussion. He says the Democrats will lose Congressional seats as turnout shrinks in 2010.

headline: Galleon Insider Inquiry Is Extended Again
text: Eight people charged in the wide-ranging insider trading investigation involving the Galleon Group have agreed with prosecutors on Wednesday to extend the inquiry for at least 21 days for a possible resolution of their criminal cases.

headline: Mobile Phones Eliminate Single-Serving Devices
text: As chips and sensors become smaller and more advanced, mobile phones are beginning to swallow and adopt any number of new functions. As a result, they are quickly replacing other single-serving devices, including GPS units and cameras.

headline: End of Road Nears for BBDO and Chrysler
text: As the long-running contract between the Chrysler Group and BBDO Worldwide nears its expiration at the end of January, the automaker is completing its line-up of replacement agencies.

headline: A Houseboat on the Thames
text: What started off as student quarters has turned into a permanent home.

headline: Preview: 'Brace for Impact'
text: The TLC program looks back at the crash landing in the Hudson River of US Airways Flight 1549.

headline: At Preview of Tavern Auction, Plenty of Oohs and Ahhs
text: They kicked the tires. Grandly. For the first time, dozens of potential bidders for 25,000 orphaned treasures from Tavern on the Green were admitted to the shuttered and bankrupt landmark restaurant in Central Park on Wednesday. They previewed next week’s three-day auction of 1,000 lots of items that have been valued at $100 to $1.2 million.

headline: The Pilot Navigates Fame
text: Watch Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III on a red carpet, and at any given moment three or four hands are on him. There are taps on his arms, hands outstretched and palms on his back from fans. People want to reach him, touch him, thank him, take the measure of a media legend.

headline: Properties for $250,000
text: Homes for sale in Mississippi, Arizona and Atlanta.

headline: Correction: The Week Ahead: Jan. 3 — Jan. 9
text: An article last Sunday misspelled the last name of the director of "The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle." He is Stephen Earnhart, not Earnheart.

headline: Kaleidoscopic Adventures, Creating a Range of Dramas Big and Small
text: No sooner does Twyla Tharp’s “Opus 111” begin than her architectural command of stage space becomes handsomely evident. She created this work in 2008 for Pacific Northwest Ballet, and, as the company performed the piece at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, other pleasures are soon part of the experience: the individuality and maturity of the 12 dancers; the attractive costumes by Mark Zappone; the Brahms String Quintet No. 2 in G that’s the accompaniment (and from which it takes its title). But the ways in which Ms. Tharp dramatizes space are constantly striking here. You can easily imagine how much better it would look on the larger stage of the company’s home theater, the Marion Oliver McCaw Hall, in Seattle; but the limited Joyce space cannot wreck it.

headline: Vudu Expands Its Service to More TV Makers
text: For the last two years I’ve been following Vudu, the Santa Clara, Calif., based start-up entirely focused on bringing a large on-demand catalog of movies from the Web into the living room. The company started out in the tough business of selling its own set-top box, then gradually began integrating its well-reviewed service into televisions and Blu-ray players.

headline: Hillary Clinton on Development Issues
text: Sec. Clinton gave an excellent speech on development today. She has a longtime interest in poverty issues, and President Obama’s mother was a pioneer in microfinance, yet so far the Obama administration hasn’t been particularly engaged in global poverty issues. It took forever, after all, to get an administrator for USAID, the aid agency. In contrast, President Bush never seemed very interested in global poverty, but he left a quite impressive legacy there — with Pepfar, the AIDS effort; the President’s Malaria Initiative; and his Millennium Challenge Corporation directing aid to countries with good governance.

headline: All Clear at the Fed
text: Harry Truman once asked for a one-armed economist, so he would not hear, “On the one hand . . . ” What would he have thought of a committee filled with economists?

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Cars zip through Mauritania’s desert in the 11-day Africa Eco Race, which ends in Dakar, Senegal.

headline: New Year, Same Ratings
text: New episodes of “NCIS” and “NCIS: Los Angeles” helped lift CBS above its rivals on Tuesday night, even against the FedEx Orange Bowl on Fox and the season premiere of “The Biggest Loser” on NBC. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 21.3 million viewers tuned in to “NCIS,” and 18 million viewers watched its spinoff, “NCIS: Los Angeles.” Fox was likely to place second with its live football broadcast, for which final ratings were not immediately available, but NBC appeared to be in a close race with Fox. NBC earned an average of 11.7 million viewers for “The Biggest Loser: Couples,” nearly matching the series’ highest rated debut a year ago (11.9 million).

headline: Flutist to Los Angeles: I’ll Take Chicago
text: Symphony orchestra musicians, in public at least, rarely cast aspersions on other orchestras. But the principal flutist of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra had some less than complimentary things to say about the Los Angeles Philharmonic, according to a newspaper report. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave and was performing with the Philharmonic temporarily  a fairly common occurrence when first-chair players are considering a move. Mr. Dufour has decided to stay at his Midwestern job, The Chicago Sun-Times reported on Tuesday, quoting him as saying that the Los Angeles Philharmonic has “no tradition there  no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble.” He added, “Maybe they will have that someday in the future.” Los Angeles has fine musicians, he said. “But we have achieved a very strong common purpose and set of aims in Chicago that they do not have or do not yet have there.” Deborah F. Rutter, the Chicago orchestra’s president, called Mr. Dufour’s decision “great news.” A spokesman for the Philharmonic, Sophie Jefferies, said: “We’re very sorry to see him go and wish him all the best. He is an amazing player.”

headline: Chinese Films Pulled From Festival in Protest
text: Two Chinese movies have been pulled from the Palm Springs International Film Festival in California to protest another film about the Dalai Lama and Tibet, Agence France-Presse reported. The Chinese movies “Nanjing! Nanjing!” (also known as “City of Life and Death”), about the Japanese occupation of Nanjing in 1937, and “Quick Quick Slow Slow,” a short film, were withdrawn, according to China’s state-run Beijing Times, because the festival plans to screen a movie called “The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibet’s Struggle for Freedom.” That film, a documentary by Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, follows the Dalai Lama for a year, and its description in the festival’s program said that it chronicled “the 2008 protests in Tibet, the long march in India, the Beijing Olympics and the breakdown of talks with China.” The Beijing Times called the movie a “Tibetan independence” film. A representative for “Nanjing! Nanjing!” said that the films were pulled on the order of China’s ministry of foreign affairs, its film bureau and the consulate general of China in Los Angeles.

headline: ‘Fences’ and ‘lips’ Add Cast Members
text: Viola Davis, below, recently seen suffering up a storm in the film adaptation of “Doubt” (a performance that earned her an Academy Award nomination, among other plaudits), will not be getting a reprieve any time soon. She will join the cast of the coming Broadway revival of “Fences,” by August Wilson, in which she will play the put-upon spouse of Denzel Washington, the show’s press representatives said on Tuesday. The revival of “Fences,” which won the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1987, is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on April 14 and open on April 26. ... Press representatives for the Roundabout Theater Company’s coming production of Terrence McNally’s “Lips Together, Teeth Apart,” said that Lili Taylor (of “Six Feet Under” and “I Shot Andy Warhol”) had joined the cast, which also includes Patton Oswalt (“Big Fan”) and Megan Mullally (“Will and Grace”). The production, directed by Joe Mantello, begins previews at the American Airlines Theater on April 9 and opens April 29.

headline: Courtney Love and Hole to Play European Shows
text: Whether or not, as a timely movie title predicted, 2010 proves to be the year we make contact with intelligent alien life, it has already brought us something equally improbable: the promise of Hole’s first shows in 11 years. The Guardian reported that Hole, the vintage-1990s grunge-rock band led by Courtney Love, above, said on its Facebook page that it would play three European shows next month, starting with a performance on Feb. 17 at the Shepherds Bush Empire in London. The concert dates, including ones in Milan and Amsterdam, are also listed on nobodysdaughter.com, a Web site for “Nobody’s Daughter,” an album that was once planned as a solo project for Ms. Love but was rebranded as a Hole album last year. (It is still without a label or a release date.) The Guardian said that Hole’s lineup would include Ms. Love, the guitarist Micko Larkin, the bassist Shawn Dailey and the drummer Stu Fischer. It was unclear if Ms. Love’s former bandmates Eric Erlandson and Melissa Auf der Maur would be involved.

headline: Bob Barker, Whale Pal
text: Though Bob Barker, below, is known for his affability and gentleness toward people with no conception of what things cost, a ship named for Mr. Barker, the former “Price Is Right” host, had its first confrontation with whalers on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. The Bob Barker, a 1,200-ton vessel operated by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, the group featured on the Animal Planet series “Whale Wars,” was among the ships that tried to stop a Japanese whaling mission in waters near Antarctica. Mr. Barker, 86, donated the money for his namesake ship after meeting the Sea Shepherd founder Paul Watson through a fellow animal advocate. “He said he thought he could put the Japanese whaling fleet out of business if he had $5 million,” Mr. Barker told The A.P. “I said, ‘I think you do have the skills to do that, and I have $5 million, so let’s get it on.’ ”

headline: Broadway Move Delayed for ‘Orphans’
text: A consortium of producers plans to transfer the Off Broadway production of “The Orphans’ Home Cycle” by Horton Foote to Broadway in the fall, rather than rush the show to Broadway this spring as had been discussed in recent weeks, two theater executives involved in the decision said on Wednesday. The producers had an opportunity to move into the Neil Simon Theater this spring for a limited run, but decided they needed more time to prepare the transfer, said the executives, James Houghton and Michael Wilson, who are the respective artistic directors of the Signature Theater Company and Hartford Stage. The play, a co-production now running at Signature through March, was the last work by Foote before he died last year, and is based on the lives of his parents and relatives in Texas in the early 1900s; the intention is to transfer the full cast, including Bill Heck and Maggie Lacey, above. Daryl Roth, a lead member of the consortium planning the Broadway transfer, said that the producers wanted more time to lock in group ticket sales, scale the production from the 160-seat Signature space to a larger theater, and develop a marketing plan for “Orphans,” which is a three-part play that runs nine hours and lacks star actors.

headline: Inspecting the Goods at Tavern on the Green’s Auction
text: On City Room, Glenn Collins joins the tire-kicking crowds at Tavern on the Green at the preview of the items to be put up for sale at next week’s auction. Among the 1,000 lots of items are candelabras, samovars, weather vanes, sculptures, murals, prints, lighting fixtures, silver and china place settings.

headline: Trying to Grow Up While Collecting Saliva and Fidgeting Off Chairs
text: With the attitude-laden title of “Once and for All We’re Gonna Tell You Who We Are So Shut Up and Listen,” a theatrical piece that has its New York premiere on Thursday, a little history is in order.

headline: Albums by Swift and Boyle Top 2009 Charts, as Sales Continue Plunge
text: The music industry rounded out a difficult decade with a difficult year.

headline: Young Pianist Thrust Into Elite Group
text: Odd, the pianist Kirill Gerstein thought. A music critic from Houston was coming to interview him in Jacksonville, Fla. Mr. Gerstein’s manager had arranged the meeting, at the Omni Hotel’s J bar, to coincide with a run of concerts last November. Might as well meet the writer, the pianist thought.

headline: Susan Boyle Still Tops the Weekly Chart
text: Susan Boyle  prevailed in the final week of music sales for 2009, holding at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a sixth week. Her “I Dreamed a Dream” (Syco Music/Columbia) sold 137,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Its 3.1 million sales gave Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) a run for its money as the best-selling album of the year, but in the end Ms. Swift prevailed. “Fearless” holds at No. 5 on the latest weekly chart with 60,000 sales, but her total for the year was 3.2 million. ( An article about album sales for the year is here.)

headline: Alabama’s McClain Sick, but Improving
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — After missing media day Wednesday with a stomach virus, Alabama linebacker Rolando McClain is improving and expected to play in Thursday’s Bowl Championship Series title game against Texas.

headline: U.S. Players in Training for Training Camp
text: It is good to be an elite soccer player in Southern California. The weather — 70 degrees and sunny on Wednesday — is great. The commute to the United States national team training camp, which convened this week at Home Depot Center in Carson, is pretty easy. And there are always other players around for pickup games and FIFA 10 tournaments on PlayStation.

headline: Tastes of Mariachi and Alabama
text: Usher

headline: Righting the Body’s Clock Through Chemicals
text: While Cephalon’s drug Nuvigil seeks to keep people awake when the body’s internal clock calls for sleep, experts say there are ways to make that clock adjust faster to a new time zone, thereby speeding resolution of jet lag.

headline: A Drug’s Second Act: Battling Jet Lag
text: It seemed like the offer of a lifetime  earn $2,500 by flying to France aboard a private luxury jet.

headline: The Obamas and Their Outerwear
text: A New York clothing company has gotten some extra unauthorized mileage out of President Obama’s coat choice for his visit to the Great Wall of China.

headline: Rebound Expected After Drop in Law Firm Mergers
text: The number of law firm mergers in the United States fell 24 percent in 2009 from the prior year, but that downturn is expected to be reversed this year as law firms look to join forces to increase profits and gain access to new markets, according to Altman Weil, a legal management consulting firm.

headline: Boulez’s Gentler Roar
text: LUCERNE, Switzerland

headline: I’ll Have a Low-Fat Muffin With My Frappuccino
text: A Stanford University study has found that customers at New York City Starbucks restaurants bought items with 6 percent fewer calories after the city began requiring chain fast food restaurants to post calorie counts in April 2008.

headline: Breaking Up in a Digital Fishbowl
text: THERE is a scene in the movie “He’s Just Not That Into You” in which Mary, played by Drew Barrymore, laments the numerous technological ways she is being rebuffed by a potential beau. E-mail. Text messages. MySpace. “It’s exhausting,” she complains.

headline: Cadbury Stock Price Draws Closer to Kraft’s Bid
text: Shares in Cadbury fell again on Wednesday, edging closer to the level of Kraft‘s $16 billion hostile takeover offer.

headline: Spoon: Still Independent, Still Cool
text: BOSTON

headline: A Pillow-Talk Portrait of a Hollywood Survivor
text: In writing his exhaustingly detailed biography of Warren Beatty, Peter Biskind relied on strange rules of decorum. He decided that Mr. Beatty’s relationship with his wife, Annette Bening, “was off limits, because I didn’t want to be in the position of writing anything that might embarrass them or their four children.” He chose to respect the privacy of the Beatty household. Less sacrosanct: Mr. Beatty’s pants.

headline: GMAC Bowl: Central Michigan (11-2) vs. Troy (9-3)
text: Perhaps no other bowl this season will send more people scrambling for a roster. You might know of Dan LeFevour, the Central Michigan quarterback, but are you familiar with Troy’s Jerrel Jernigan? How about Frank Zombo? Nick Lewis? Cameron Sheffield? Do you know which of the last four names was made up by me and plays for neither team?

headline: The Light Alston Touch: 40 Years of Casual Grace
text: London

headline: No Award for You, Mr. Hornby
text: All day Wednesday, the Twitterverse has been buzzing – if that’s the sound retweeting makes; the Bagger thinks of it as more of a low hum — with the news that Nick Hornby, the novelist, screenwriter and music lover, was deemed ineligible for a Writers Guild of America nomination for his script for “An Education.” Not that Mr. Hornby needs to sweat his reputation – dude has more accolades in more media than the RZA — but he is in good company: Quentin Tarantino’s “Inglourious Basterds,” Tom Ford and David Scearce’s “A Single Man” and Joe Penhall’s “The Road,” are also ineligible, reports Indiewire, because they are not guild-affiliated.

headline: Steady Drip of Leaks Corrodes the Core of the Iranian Regime
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Beatings, arrests, show trials and even killings have failed to discourage Iranians from taking to the streets in protest. But those same tactics may be taking a toll on the government itself, eating away at its legitimacy even among its core of insiders, Iran experts are saying. The evidence? Leaks.

headline: Restructuring of Simmons Is Approved
text: The Simmons Bedding Company says a bankruptcy judge has approved its plan to be taken over by a group that owns its rival Serta. Simmons plans to emerge from bankruptcy around Jan. 20, Reuters reports.

headline: Southern Schools Mark Two Majorities
text: ATLANTA  The South has become the first region in the country where more than half of public school students are poor and more than half are members of minorities, according to a new report.

headline: Moods Conducive to Dying and Dancing
text: Up on the screen above the Glasslands Gallery stage on Tuesday night, a car was being swallowed whole by flames. Beneath it the Chicago-born band Salem was suggesting what it might sound like to die.

headline: Out of the Blue, Prestige and Riches
text: EVERY diamond is a story as old as the earth and will outlast us all. Diamonds are, indeed, forever, but they are not forever in view.

headline: UBS Client Sentenced to 5 Years’ Probation
text: A New Jersey client of the international banking giant UBS has been sentenced to five years’ probation after pleading guilty to concealing more than $6 million in assets in Swiss bank accounts, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Picks Director, First Designer in Job
text: Bill Moggridge, a founder of the design firm IDEO who is widely credited with designing the look of the first commercial laptop, has been named director of the Smithsonian Institution’s Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York.

headline: H & M Says It Will Stop Destroying Unworn Clothing
text: The clothing retailer H & M promised on Wednesday that it would stop the practice of destroying new, unworn clothing that it could not sell at its store in Herald Square, and would instead donate the garments to charities.

headline: A Presidential Pat on the Back for Teachers
text: President Obama honored more than 100 math and science teachers at the White House on Wednesday. But the awards, he joked, came with a catch.

headline: 8,870 Pairs at the Table and Charity on the Agenda
text: ECatsBridge in England, under the guidance of Anna Gudge and Mark Newton, ran its eighth Children in Need simultaneous pairs last month. There were 490 heats over five nights in Botswana, Croatia, Cyprus, England and Spain, with 8,870 pairs competing. Nearly $95,000 was raised for the charity.

headline: With Dawson in Hall, Red Sox’ Evans Looks a Lot Better
text: You’ve got to be happy for the new Hall of Famer, Andre Dawson, a class act and a phenomenally talented player. On his conference call, he actually apologized to writers for taking so much time to come to his locker after games. He was in the trainers’ room, of course, getting treatment on his ravaged knees.

headline: A ‘Yooper’ in the Abortion Fight
text: Representative Bart Stupak, who is used to bearing the freezing temperatures of Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, is now enduring hatred from fellow Democrats over his anti-abortion amendment.

headline: Cheap Mobile Calls, Even Overseas
text: Recently, my parents returned from Italy with a few bottles of Chianti and $750 in AT&T calling charges. Buon giorno!

headline: Viewing Facebook via Roku
text: Viewing Facebook

headline: Men on Television: A Look at ‘West Wing’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Decade in Dance: Complexity and Emotion
text: To the Editor:

headline: Celebrities Onstage: The Cost of Stars
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: Men With a Message: Help Wanted
text: An article last Sunday about the depiction of men on television over the past decade misidentified the cable channel that runs the show in which Mary McCormack stars. The show, “In Plain Sight,” is on USA, not on TNT.

headline: AT&T to Sell Smartphones Using the Android System
text: LAS VEGAS  AT&T said on Wednesday that it planned to sell smartphones running the Android mobile operating system by the second half of the year, including Dell’s first smartphone.

headline: Jets, at 50-1, Are Right Where They Want to Be
text: Those who followed the Jets’  playoff projections in the last few weeks of the regular season know how steep their odds were to get this far.

headline: Coat Maker Transforms Obama Photo Into Ad
text: A garment company in New York known for publicity stunts has seized the attention of the Obama administration.

headline: A Faster Route From Camera to Web
text: When the first Eye-Fi SD cards came out, they were impressive (wirelessly uploading photos from your camera to your PC and online photo sites) but deadly slow. The new $150 Eye-Fi Pro card adds some welcome improvements.

headline: Tributes to a Father of Modern Harlem
text: They filed one after another into Riverside Church, mayors and governors and renowned preachers and musicians, all come to pay their respects to that most unusual product of our nation’s history, a man who became father to modern Harlem and godfather to generations of black politicians.

headline: Another Compact Camera Offers Changeable Lenses
text: Samsung has announced its first camera with interchangeable lenses, the NX10, which is being shown at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week.

headline: Smartphones and Tablets Could Doom Netbooks
text: Stuck between the still-evolving smartphone and the emerging tablet computer, the netbook computer would seem to be doomed.

headline: App of the Week: Recording Your Daily Bread
text: Improving your health, getting fit and losing weight never fail to top the list of New Year’s resolutions. All three would be easier if only you could keep a food diary.

headline: Prettier With Every Sip?
text: THE notion that beauty comes from within is taken seriously in certain Asian countries. In Singapore, at the restaurant Imperial Herbal, diners with skin conditions consult with an herbalist, who concocts treatments that are mixed into the dishes. Nescafé has found an avid market there for coffee with collagen, a protein found in connective tissues, on the theory that ingesting it will improve skin. In Japan, collagen is added to yogurt drinks, dried fruits and other foods.

headline: Scent Trails Start at the Top
text: HAIR scent may be the new fragrance frontier. In recent months, several new products with exotic fragrances are challenging popular hair-care scents like coconut, citrus and rosemary.

headline: On the Trail of a Diamond
text: Visitors to the Smithsonian who will soon have the rare opportunity to share in the Wittelsbach’s tale will also be venturing into the midst of a controversy about the gem.

headline: Using Beauty to Do Good
text: THE theme of “About Face,” the 240-page coffee table book that features 20 dramatic makeovers and goes on sale this month ($25), is that beauty should be used for “purpose instead of for vanity’s sake,” said its author, Scott Barnes, in a recent interview.

headline: Look Out for the SEC
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — Get ready for more talk of SEC domination if Alabama wins Thursday night’s Bowl Championship Series title game against Texas.

headline: Fighting Trend, China Is Luring Scientists Home
text: BEIJING  Scientists in the United States were not overly surprised in 2008 when the prestigious Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Maryland awarded a $10 million research grant to a Princeton University molecular biologist, Shi Yigong.

headline: Cleveland Orchestra Talks Break Down
text: Talks between the players and management of the Cleveland Orchestra broke down on Wednesday, and the musicians threatened to go on strike on Jan. 18. That is the day before the orchestra is to leave for a residency in Miami. “That tour is in question,” Jeffrey Rathbun, the orchestra’s assistant principal oboist and the musicians’ chief negotiator, said in a statement.

headline: ‘Carpetbaggers’ and New York’s Economy
text: Former Representative Harold Ford Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, is thinking of running for the Senate. From New York.

headline: Antitrust Case Has Implications Far Beyond N.F.L.
text: Is the National Football League a single entity, or a collection of 32 teams that compete against one another every week?

headline: Defense Ranks No. 1, but Jets Miss Jenkins
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A large man, even by N.F.L. standards, moved alone through the Jets’ practice complex Wednesday, wearing a T-shirt, gym shorts and running shoes instead of a green jersey, pads and a helmet.

headline: Saban Is Seeking His Statue of Liberation
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

headline: Security for Terrorism Trials Estimated at $200 Million a Year
text: Providing security for the trials of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and other terrorism suspects connected with the Sept. 11 attacks will cost more than $200 million a year, according to the Bloomberg administration, making it one of the most expensive security operations ever taken on by the city.

headline: Jets as Favorites? In Ryan’s World
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When asked Wednesday how it felt to be labeled as the biggest long shot of the 12 playoff teams, Jets Coach Rex Ryan replied: “I wasn’t aware of that. To me, we should be the favorites.”

headline: Brady and Patriots Ready for Life Without Welker
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Tom Brady won the N.F.L.’s Comeback Player of the Year award Wednesday a few hours before Wes Welker went on injured reserve. The intersection of their injuries may determine how far the Patriots go in the playoffs.

headline: Cone Leaves YES Network
text: David Cone, who joined the YES Network as a Yankees analyst in 2008, is not coming back.

headline: Schwarzenegger Seeks Shift From Prisons to Schools
text: SACRAMENTO  With his state strapped and his legacy looming, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger proposed on Wednesday to greatly reduce the amount of money California spends on its prisons and to funnel that sum to the state’s higher education system instead.

headline: An Early Assessment of the 2010 Senate Races
text: A glum atmosphere for Democrats, highlighted by the retirement of two senators, could jeopardize the party’s chances to retain the majority needed to block a filibuster.

headline: Clothing Retailer Says It Will No Longer Destroy Unworn Garments
text: The clothing retailer H & M promised on Wednesday to stop destroying new, unworn clothing that it cannot sell at its store in Herald Square, and would instead donate the garments to charities.

headline: Scripps Reports ‘Progress’ in Food Network Fight
text: For almost a week now, about three million Cablevision households in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been affected by a high-profile argument between the cable provider and Scripps Networks over how much they should pay for the Food Network and HGTV.

headline: Chief Says G.M. Is on Road to Profits
text: DETROIT  The new chief executive of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., sought to assure the public on Wednesday that the automaker was on track to be profitable in the wake of its bankruptcy last summer.

headline: American Needle: From Green Celluloid Visors to Caps of All Kinds
text: American Needle has become famous in sports law circles thanks to the Supreme Court, which will hear the company’s petition against the N.F.L. next week. But in the sports apparel business, American Needle has been a big player for decades.

headline: A Third Child for Orszag
text: Peter R. Orszag, President Obama’s budget director who recently announced his engagement, on Wednesday released a statement confirming that his previous girlfriend had a baby in November.

headline: Clark Clinches Vancouver Spot; Pearce Shows Improvement
text: Kelly Clark, the 2002 Olympic gold medalist in the halfpipe, became the first snowboarder to snare a spot on the 2010 United States halfpipe team by winning the United States Snowboarding Grand Prix at Mammoth Mountain, Calif. It is the third consecutive Olympic berth for Clark, who finished fourth at the 2006 Winter Games in Torino, Italy.

headline: Travel Planning Sites Team Up
text: On the In Transit blog, Dan Saltzstein reports that two prominent Web sites for travel planning have formed a canny partnership. Yapta, a site that allows users to track airfares and hotel prices, said that Tripit members can now receive automatic alerts on airline refunds or credits based on itineraries they create.

headline: Smackdown for the Senate Takes a Twist
text: Linda E. McMahon would recognize the scene.

headline: Tour Resumes Without Its Usual Sure Thing
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii  During most of the past decade, the opening of another successful year for the PGA Tour has been as close to a sure thing as a 2-foot putt.

headline: Diet Drug Maker Glaxo to Pay for a Film on Eating
text: LOS ANGELES  GlaxoSmithKline is getting into the movie business, pursuing an unusual and most likely controversial strategy to increase interest in a weight-loss drug.

headline: SEC Should Come Out on Top, Again
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  A week of posturing, lecturing and pontificating will end Thursday night with the Bowl Championship Series title game, and a college football season whose hallmark was conventional results should end in predictable fashion.

headline: Nigerian Indicted in Terrorist Plot
text: WASHINGTON  The indictment of a Nigerian man on Wednesday for the attempt to blow up a plane bound for Detroit on Christmas Day has rekindled a debate over whether such terrorism suspects should be treated as criminals or as enemy detainees.

headline: DirecTV Outlines 3-D Programming Push
text: DirecTV announced Wednesday that it would debut several 3-D channel services later this year.

headline: Danes Study Immigrants After Cartoonist Attack
text: COPENHAGEN  As part of the prolonged national headache caused by a Danish newspaper’s decision to publish 12 caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad in 2005, last weekend’s attack on one of the cartoonists responsible had a certain awful inevitability about it.

headline: Suit Says 2 Chinese Firms Stole Web-Blocking Code
text: BEIJING  A software company in California has sued two Chinese technology firms, charging that they stole its computer code to make an Internet-monitoring program that China’s government sought to install on every computer in the country last year before backing down.

headline: Where Is the Next War Zone?
text: In the wake of the Christmas Day attempt to blow up a Detroit-bound Northwest Airlines flight by a young Nigerian man, Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, Yemen is now in America’s focus.

headline: New Routine for Airports: Contradictions, Delays
text: CHICAGO  As he arrived at O’Hare International airport here on Wednesday, Dennis Weyrauch, a passenger, described two hours of waiting and scrutiny at the airport in Amsterdam before his plane took off: as happened to all passengers on his flight, his carry-on bag was searched methodically by hand, the insides of bottles in his toilet kit studied and his body patted down.

headline: In a Clash Over Cable, Consumers Lose
text: Chris Birckhead came home Tuesday night hoping that his TiVo had recorded “Chopped,” his favorite show on the Food Network. Instead, it had recorded a looped commercial from Cablevision, his cable provider, saying the network’s owner, Scripps, had taken his show away.

headline: Taking It to the Street
text: After its debut in August, the Asphalt Orchestra, a brain-child of Bang on a Can, was described by Anthony Tommasini as “part parade spectacle, part halftime show and part cutting-edge contemporary-music concert.” If you missed hearing this radical 12-member band the first time, then you’re in luck tonight, because they are performing a free show at the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center beginning at 8:30 p.m. Listen out for an eclectic mix of songs by Björk, Zappa, Mingus and others.

headline: Back to School
text: The question of what makes a good teacher has been a subject of hot debate in recent weeks. For evidence look no further than the divided reaction to a study Teach for America released about its participants and Amanda Ripley’s article in this month’s issue of The Atlantic. Tonight Cabinet, the art magazine based in Brooklyn, is presenting a more creative take on the issue with “Darcy Lange: The Art of Teaching.” The program will include a viewing and a discussion of a current exhibition of video work by Mr. Lange. In the 1970s, this New Zealand artist took his camera into schools in Britain to record daily events in the classroom. After the screening, a discussion about pedagogy and art will be led by panelists including Kelly Baum of the Princeton University Art Museum, Simon Critchley, a philosophy professor at the New School and Jeff Dolven, an English professor at Princeton. Drinks will be served.

headline: The Living Room as Art
text: For those of you who found the London apartment in “An Education” swoon-inducing or the Los Angeles bungalow in “A Single Man” as enticing as the very chic clothes, then head to Greenwich House’s newest exhibition, “Studio Pottery and Mid Century Style,” at 6 p.m. tonight. The show features a meticulous recreation of an American living room around 1960. The exhibition will include ceramics from the late 1950s and early to mid-1960s by Peter Voulkos, Gertrude and Otto Natzler as well as furniture by Florence Knoll, Eero Saarinen, Eames and others, not to mention textiles and lighting. To kick off the event, guests are invited to dress up in their own “Mad Men”-inspired frocks and nibble on period food and drink while they take in the stylish scene.

headline: At Dover, More Comfort for Mourning Families
text: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del. — So many families of the nation’s war dead came here in the last year to witness what the military calls the “dignified transfer” of the remains of their loved ones that sometimes, as on a night this past June, the small waiting area grew crowded and tense.

headline: Suicide Bombing Puts a Rare Face on C.I.A.’s Work
text: WASHINGTON  In the fall of 2001, as an anguished nation came to grips with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a slender, soft-spoken economics major named Elizabeth Hanson set out to write her senior thesis at Colby College in Maine. Her question was a timely one: How do the world’s three major faith traditions apply economic principles?

headline: Forum on Football Brain Injuries Set for Houston
text: After one hearing that prompted the N.F.L. to reshape several policies toward concussion management and another on Monday, the House Judiciary Committee announced Wednesday afternoon that a third discussion on football brain injuries would be held Feb. 1 in Houston.

headline: Jordanian Bomber’s Path Remains a Mystery to His Family
text: AMMAN, Jordan  The telephone rang at 7 a.m. on New Year’s Eve, and then the heavily accented voice of a stranger  possibly an Afghan  told the man who answered what had happened to one of his sons who disappeared a year ago.

headline: Changing of the Guard for Emily’s List
text: The founder and president of Emily’s List, a powerful fundraising network dedicated to electing Democratic women who support abortion rights, is handing the reins to a rising political star.

headline: Editors’ Note: In Light and Heat, Gadgets Claim to Fight Acne
text: The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about electronic home-treatment devices that supposedly alleviate acne, included a qualified endorsement of such products by Dr. Neil Sadick, a Manhattan dermatologist. Dr. Sadick has been an adviser to Radiancy, the maker of No!No! Skin products for acne removal, which were mentioned in the article. Although Dr. Sadick was not commenting directly on the No!No! device, the article should have either mentioned his connections to the company or omitted his comments.

headline: Democrats Wary as Two Senators Decide to Retire
text: WASHINGTON  The sudden decision by two senior Democratic senators to retire shook the party’s leaders on Wednesday and signaled that President Obama is facing a perilous political environment that could hold major implications for this year’s midterm elections and his own agenda.

headline: A Matter of Toughness
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — There has been plenty of questioning about the toughness of Texas in advance of Thursday’s Bowl Championship Series title game.

headline: Health Care’s Biggest Hypocrite — Or Hero
text: For Democrats who see their political prospects this year as a tossup between catastrophic and merely horrible, there is hope on the horizon from a most unlikely source. No, not Rush Limbaugh, who recently praised his medical experience in the government-mandated, heavily unionized health care system of Hawaii. Mahalo to him.

headline: U.N. Envoy to Afghanistan Warns of Peril of Emphasizing Security Over Social Issues
text: UNITED NATIONS  Kai Eide, the departing United Nations envoy to Afghanistan, warned the Security Council on Wednesday that an emphasis on security matters over social issues would doom international efforts to stabilize the country.

headline: F.D.A. Plans Safety Check of 3 Drugs for Anemia
text: The Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday that it would review of the safety of the widely used anemia drugs sold by Amgen and Johnson & Johnson after another clinical trial suggested that high doses of one of the drugs might cause strokes.

headline: U.S. Juniors Top Canada
text: John Carlson scored his second goal of the game 4 minutes 21 seconds into overtime as the United States beat Canada, 6-5, in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, to capture its second gold medal at the World Junior Hockey Championship. The loss was Canada’s first in the tournament since losing to the Americans in 2004 in Finland.

headline: Connecticut Attorney General Says He’ll Seek Senate Seat, and Is Quickly Embraced
text: Richard Blumenthal, the popular Connecticut attorney general, announced on Wednesday that he would seek the United States Senate seat being vacated by Christopher J. Dodd, suddenly altering the dynamic of an already volatile race.

headline: Deadly Explosion Arouses New Afghan Anger at U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  American forces inspecting an engineering project in eastern Afghanistan paused to toss candies to a clutch of curious Afghan children on Wednesday when a large explosion tore through the crowd.

headline: Abortion Foe Defies Party on Health Care Bill
text: MENOMINEE, Mich.  Representative Bart Stupak often endures things others find unbearable. He crisscrosses a Congressional district so vast that some constituents live eight hours apart and so cold that the beer at his beloved football games sometimes freezes. Years ago, as a state trooper, he blew out his knee chasing a suspect, and he has since had so many operations that he now returns to work the same day, toting crutches and ice.

headline: A Public Company Defends Staying Silent About a Legal Snarl
text: For years, Fidelity National Financial, the nation’s largest title insurance company, did not tell investors about dozens of lawsuits accusing two units and several employees of playing a role in an elaborate mortgage fraud scheme in San Diego.

headline: Heebie-Jeebies
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s time to discuss the Gödel Incompleteness Theorem, or at least the crossword equivalent. What do you do when you exhaust your skill and memory and still end up with a blank square or two, the emptiness mocking you, the sense of accomplishment, of completion, denied? Can you love a puzzle you can’t complete?

headline: From Bare to Refined
text: An American in Afghanistan looked forward to returning home and moving into his new apartment in New York, which the designer Richard Mishaan transformed on a budget of $10,000.

headline: Tsutomu Yamaguchi, Survivor of 2 Atomic Blasts, Dies at 93
text: Tsutomu Yamaguchi, the only official survivor of both atomic blasts to hit Japan in World War II, died Monday in Nagasaki, Japan. He was 93.

headline: Pearce’s Condition Upgraded
text: The snowboarder Kevin Pearce was upgraded from critical to serious condition and had his breathing tube removed as he slowly began to regain consciousness. Pearce, a 22-year-old widely expected to earn a spot on the United States Olympic halfpipe team, sustained a severe brain injury when he fell while training last Thursday. In a statement, Dr. Holly Ledyard of the University of Utah Hospital in Salt Lake City said that Pearce, who remained in intensive care, was beginning to follow commands. “While we’re pleased that he’s improving faster than anticipated, he still has a long recovery ahead of him,” she said.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Bamboozled by Obama?
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The American Prospect and Dayo Olopade of The Root debate whether liberals should be disappointed by President Obama's first year.

headline: Mayor Agrees to Step Down in Baltimore in Theft Case
text: Mayor Sheila Dixon of Baltimore, who was convicted of embezzlement last month, said Wednesday that she would resign from office in early February as part of a deal negotiated with prosecutors.

headline: Senate Subpoenaed for Records on Espada
text: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo subpoenaed the New York Senate on Wednesday for a broad range of e-mail messages and other records concerning Senator Pedro Espada Jr., the Bronx Democrat who led a monthlong coup that brought state government to a standstill this summer, Mr. Espada said.

headline: New York to Create Global Insurance Exchange to Cover Complex Risks
text: In a bid to create jobs and bolster New York’s position as a financial center, Gov. David A. Paterson announced plans on Wednesday to create an international insurance exchange, modeled after Lloyd’s of London.

headline: Do Try This at Home
text: If your first thought on seeing one-of-a-kind lamps is “Interesting, but is it so amateurishly wired it will conflagrate, setting my home afire, destroying all my belongings, including my irreplaceable collection of back issues of the New York Times Home section?” then your fears will be assuaged by the knowledge that a creator of these particular lamps, Tom Blake, right, is a licensed New York City electrician who has worked on the Chrysler and Empire State Buildings.

headline: Hawks Find Their Touch, and Nets Pay
text: CLEVELAND  DeShawn Stevenson, one of numerous Washington Wizards who laughed at Gilbert Arenas when he cocked his fingers into a gun and playfully shot them as they stood in a circle before a game against the 76ers on Tuesday night, said that neither he nor his teammates should have reacted the way they did.

headline: Courts Seek More Lawyers to Help the Poor
text: The recession has swelled the number of people showing up in New York State courts who cannot afford lawyers to 2.1 million annually, often turning eviction, foreclosure, debt collection and other civil cases into lopsided battles that raise questions about the fairness of the legal system.

headline: Avery Comes Alive Against the Stars, His Ex-Team
text: People say a lot of things about Sean Avery, but no one can say he lacks a sense of the moment.

headline: The Next Steps for Arenas and the League
text: Agent Zero is finding out the hard way that he’s not Agent 007. When Gilbert Arenas followed up his unloaded guns in the locker room with some pretend gun play before Tuesday’s game, a result was an indefinite suspension.

headline: Recalling I.D., a Beacon in Design
text: IT was by and large a jovial crowd that filled the back rooms of the Half King bar in Chelsea on Tuesday night, as a crush of former staff members, contributors and friends of I.D. magazine, the 56-year-old design bible that folded last month, gathered, ostensibly to mourn its passing. Though the evening was billed as a wake — its invitation was composed, appropriately, in a font called Requiem — the gestalt was more like a class reunion, a gaggle of bright former students who all seemed to like one another very much.

headline: Is Punditry a Prelude to a Race in New York?
text: Robert F. Kennedy possessed the biggest brand name in American politics. Hillary Rodham Clinton boasted eight years in the White House.

headline: Cone Says No to Yes
text: David Cone, who joined the YES Network as a Yankees analyst in 2008, is not coming back. He said his contract had expired and he wanted to spend more time with his family. “If I do return to broadcasting, YES would be my first choice,” Cone said.

headline: Asian Antiques That Outgrew Santa Fe
text: Shibui, the Asian antiques gallery, recently moved to Brooklyn from Santa Fe, N.M. In his new store in Dumbo, above, Dane Owen, Shibui’s owner, is selling Japanese Tansu chests from the 18th and 19th centuries, as well as vintage textiles, ceramics, glass and folk art — all of which he transported, with his staff, from Santa Fe.

headline: Ex-Official in Yonkers Faces Charges of Corruption
text: WHITE PLAINS  A former Yonkers city councilwoman was indicted Wednesday on federal charges of accepting nearly $167,000 in cash and gifts in exchange for dropping her opposition to two contentious developments, including a $630 million project that is the city’s largest private undertaking.

headline: A Program Helps Sharpen the Business Acumen of Those on the Rise
text: BOSTON  Taza Chocolate, whose stone-ground organic chocolate bars are made in a factory near here, in Somerville, Mass., was growing. The next step, according to its co-founder, Alex Whitmore, was to hire a marketing manager, preferably someone with many years of experience.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a third uninvited guest to President Obama’s first state dinner described incorrectly the vehicle that transported the guest, Carlos Allen, to the White House. It was a private van carrying guests to the event under Secret Service escort; it was not a State Department van.

headline: Men Who Jump the Picket Fence
text: THE house was an ordinary house: It bore him no malice. Alan Berks knows that now. But back in the spring of 2005, when Mr. Berks, a playwright, and his wife bought the three-bedroom home for $214,000, it often seemed that it was trying to ruin his life.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Dec. 18 about the New York City Housing Authority’s decision to stop issuing new federal rent subsidy vouchers to low-income New Yorkers because of budget cuts and increasing demand misstated the agency’s annual voucher allotment. It is 99,000, not 91,000.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Winter Clearance for New and Old
text: Buck House, on the Upper East Side, is discounting its antique and vintage furnishings by 30 percent until Jan. 31 (two 1920s Austrian benches, originally $4,800, are $3,360); 1318 Madison Avenue (93rd Street), (212) 828-3123 or buckhouse.biz.

headline: Treasures of the Tavern
text: Potential bidders are previewing a three-day auction of thousands of items from Tavern on the Green, the landmark restaurant in Central Park.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the opening of the world’s tallest building, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, misstated the position of Sheik Khalifa bin Zayed al-Nahyan, for whom the tower is named. He is president of the United Arab Emirates, not of Abu Dhabi. (He is emir of Abu Dhabi.) The error also appeared in a picture caption accompanying the article and was repeated in an editorial on Wednesday. The editorial also misstated the beneficiary of a $10 billion loan from Abu Dhabi. It was the emirate of Dubai, not the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Obama Urges Excise Tax on High-Cost Insurance
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama told House Democratic leaders at a meeting on Wednesday that they should include a tax on high-priced insurance policies favored by the Senate in the final version of far-reaching health care legislation, aides said.

headline: The Buzz on Twitter: Short and (Maybe) Sweet
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Bridge, Naturally
text: THE renovation problem that faced Nili Malach and Robert Poynter of San Francisco is not uncommon among those in an architecturally mixed marriage. Ms. Malach, a lawyer, is a modernist; her husband, who owns an advertising firm, is a traditionalist.

headline: Infomercial Products Take One on the Chin
text: IT may come as no surprise that in the February issue of Consumer Reports, where the product-testing magazine rates 15 infomercial products like the Snuggie (“The blanket with sleeves!”) and the ShamWow (“You’ll say wow every time!”), nearly all are found to be lacking.

headline: Corrections
text: A “Looking Ahead” report on Friday about the Under the Radar theater festival in Manhattan, which began on Wednesday and runs through Jan. 17, misstated the title of a work by Andrew Dawson, a British director and performer. It is “Space Panorama”  not “Invisible Atom,” another work in the festival.

headline: Fireplace Without the Smoke?
text: The Lighthouse, a portable indoor-outdoor fireplace, is the newest model from Planika, a Polish company. According to the manufacturer, it doesn’t produce smoke or odor — and doesn’t require ventilation. What makes it burn so cleanly, Planika says, is Fanola, a liquid bioethanol fuel made from potatoes that the company developed and sells with its fireplaces.

headline: Law School Admissions Lag Among Minorities
text: While law schools added about 3,000 seats for first-year students from 1993 to 2008, both the percentage and the number of black and Mexican-American law students declined in that period, according to a study by a Columbia Law School professor.

headline: Less Than Two Weeks
text: After weeks of maneuvering and delay, the New Jersey State Senate will finally vote on Thursday on whether to legalize same-sex marriage. The Senate needs to approve the bill, and the General Assembly needs to follow  quickly. Gov. Jon Corzine has pledged to sign the legislation into law; his soon-to-be-successor, Gov.-elect Christopher Christie, has vowed to veto it. The transfer of power takes place in less than two weeks on Jan. 19.

headline: The Rocky Road Home
text: FOR more than 25 years, Michael Logozzo, a native of Brooklyn, lived overseas, working various jobs — as a chef in Venice and in Rome, as a magazine editor in Paris and as a television host and fund-raiser in Warsaw. In 2003, he moved into a guarded compound in Kabul, Afghanistan, overseeing the acquisition of property for Roshan, a telecommunications company, and helping run a charitable program to feed Afghan children.

headline: Art Bartlett, Founder of Century 21 Real Estate, Dies at 76
text: Art Bartlett, a founder of Century 21, the real estate franchising giant whose brand name eventually appeared on “For Sale” signs on lawns throughout the country and even abroad, died on Dec. 31 at his home in Coronado, Calif. He was 76. The cause was complications of Alzheimer’s disease, his daughter, Stacy Bartlett Renshaw, said.

headline: Tough Cancer Is Gone, but Not the Bills
text: When Susan Rabinowitz learned she had lymphoma in May, the cancer was so advanced that her oncologist kept back his initial assessment until she was out of danger.

headline: Hospitals Could Stop Infections by Tackling Bacteria Patients Bring In, Studies Find
text: Hundreds of thousands of patients each year suffer from infections after surgery, and experts say more than half of those infections stem from bacteria the patients themselves are carrying in their nose or on their skin. Otherwise harmless bacteria can enter the body through surgical incisions and cause infections that can require expensive treatment, slow recovery or even cause death.

headline: A Kennedy Endorsement in Massachusetts
text: Victoria Reggie Kennedy, the widow of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, will endorse Martha Coakley, the Democratic candidate for his seat, on Thursday, according to the Coakley campaign.

headline: Polanski Urges Judge to Sentence Him in Absentia
text: LOS ANGELES  The Oscar-winning director Roman Polanski asked a Los Angeles Superior Court judge on Wednesday to proceed with his sentencing in a 1977 sex case even though he remains under house arrest in Switzerland.

headline: Doctor Indicted in Attack on Medical Board Chairman
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  A doctor who had been repeatedly penalized by the Arkansas Medical Board was charged in federal court here on Wednesday with planting a bomb that critically injured the board chairman as he left his home for a meeting of the panel last February.

headline: Despite Risks, Internet Creeps Onto Car Dashboards
text: LAS VEGAS  To the dismay of safety advocates already worried about driver distraction, automakers and high-tech companies have found a new place to put sophisticated Internet-connected computers: the front seat.

headline: Behind the Scenes in Costa Rica
text: I actually hadn’t intended to write today’s column; it was a bit of an accident. Originally when I booked my Central America trip I thought I would travel through Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, and my plan in Costa Rica was to write something narrowly about its success in health care. But then I chose to spend a bit more time in Honduras and Nicaragua, and everybody seemed to be out of Costa Rica for holiday travel. Since my return flight was from Costa Rica, I went anyway but figured I probably wouldn’t be able to write. (And, frankly, my daughter had come along for the trip in part because of the promise of going to Costa Rica; I didn’t want to be the one to tell her that she would get the Honduran slums and impoverished Nicaraguan villages, but no Costa Rican beach or jungle….)Then a Times researcher, Hilary Howard, sent me the Happy Planet Index report, which I read while driving around the country. The report got me thinking about Costa Rica and happiness. So I poked around, perused the data, and the column took shape. Originally, I thought I would frame the column more in terms of Latin and Caribbean countries doing unusually well in happiness surveys; I was fascinated by the idea that this reflected a cultural emphasis on building social capital as opposed to financial capital. But although it’s an interesting theory, I never found much evidence for it, and so I focused on Costa Rica and the gains it made in education after abolishing its army.

headline: Mary Daly, a Leader in Feminist Theology, Dies at 81
text: Mary Daly, a prominent feminist theologian who made worldwide headlines a decade ago after she retired from Boston College rather than admit men to some of her classes, died on Sunday in Gardner, Mass. She was 81 and had lived for many years in Newton Centre, Mass.

headline: Corrections
text: The 36 Hours column on Dec. 27, about San Miguel de Allende, misspelled the surname of a playwright and filmmaker and referred incorrectly to his house near Parque Juárez. He is Michael Cristofer, not Cristopher, and he owns the house in that neighborhood, he does not rent it.

headline: Strawberries on Ice
text: A cold snap has brought freezing temperatures that are threatening Florida's $375-million-a-year strawberry industry.

headline: Showcase: New Faces in an Old Gallery
text: It is a season for homecomings at Casa Aboy in San Juan. Thirty years after up-and-coming photographers exhibited their works at this gallery, they have returned — this time as masters.

headline: Many Ex-Detainees Said to Be Engaged in Terror
text: WASHINGTON  Administration officials said Wednesday that a classified Pentagon report concludes that of some 560 detainees transferred abroad from the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, about one in five has engaged in, or is suspected of engaging in, terrorism or militant activity.

headline: Resuming the Advertising Battle
text: After a brief hiatus, the television advertising wars over health care have resumed.

headline: Correction
text: An essay in the special “Lives They Lived” issue on Dec. 27 about the actor Karl Malden and the film writer Budd Schulberg misstated Malden’s position at the time he urged the motion-picture academy to give Elia Kazan an honorary Oscar. Malden was a member of the board and a former president of the academy; he was not the incumbent president.

headline: Correction
text: An essay in the special “Lives They Lived” issue on Dec. 27 about the actress Betsy Blair misstated the source of a song she sang over and over at the end of her life. “Love Is Here to Stay” is from the 1938 movie “The Goldwyn Follies,” not from a Broadway show.

headline: Flu Shot Study
text: Flu shots do not protect arthritis patients who are being treated with the intravenous drug rituximab, according to a new study by Dutch researchers. Because people with rheumatoid arthritis have depressed immune systems, flu vaccinations are recommended for them. But the study found that in patients vaccinated close to the time they get rituximab, the drug does not promote the formation of antibodies to protect against the flu. Researchers recommended giving the shots well before the rituximab treatment. The study began long before swine flu emerged, but the effects on that vaccine are expected to be similar. Rituximab is sold under the names Rituxan and MabThera.

headline: Massachusetts: Immigrant Arrests
text: Federal immigration agents stopped 58 immigrants in Foxborough, southwest of Boston, in an operation they said was to capture fugitives with criminal records. Of the immigrants, who were traveling in four vans, nine were arrested as criminal suspects and 49 were released but ordered to report to Immigration and Customs Enforcement for questioning, a spokesman for the agency said. Most of the immigrants were janitorial workers, many from Guatemala, who were on their way to clean the parking lot of Gillette Stadium, a lawyer for the Guatemalan Consulate said.

headline: Hedge Funds Tell Part of Results
text: Only foolhardy parents would allow their children to provide only the grades on their report cards that they were happy with. Yet hedge funds are given this luxury in reporting their performance to compilers of sectorwide performance indexes. A result is that while a single fund’s track record is clear enough, hedge fund index returns still flatter the average fund in the industry. Investors would be smart to call for a cleanup.

headline: France: Task Force on Genocide Planned
text: Justice Minister Michèle Alliot-Marie and Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner said France planned to create a permanent judicial task force to try cases of genocide and crimes against humanity. The task force, part of a bill to be put before Parliament this year, would examine cases in which there is a “French perpetrator, a French victim, or suspects who took refuge in France,” a Justice Ministry spokesman said. About 15 cases against Rwandans living in France and suspected of involvement in the 1994 Rwanda genocide are being investigated.

headline: Cuba: Official Says American Was a Spy
text: A Cuban official said Wednesday that an American contractor detained last month in Havana for distributing communications equipment to community groups worked for “the American secret services.” The official, Ricardo Alarcón, president of the Cuban National Assembly, offered no evidence for his claim, which was disputed by Development Alternatives Inc., a company based outside Washington. It said it employed the American for a pro-democracy contract provided by the United States Agency for International Development.

headline: Kelly Clark Makes Olympics Again

It is the third consecutive Olympic berth for Clark, who finished fourth at the 2006 Winter Games in Turin, Italy.

The wetlands at the Mai Po Marshes Reserve in the extreme northwest corner of the territory are the best place to catch a glimpse of the phenomenon — more than 60,000 birds winter at the reserve, coming from northern China, Korea, Russia and Mongolia.

headline: Sampler: Oakland Police Mistakes and Sully Navigates the Lingering Spotlight
text: Governor Proposes New Budget Priorities | In his final annual address to state lawmakers in Sacramento, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger proposed a constitutional amendment that would ensure no less than 10 percent of the state’s general fund be allotted for higher education and no more than 7 percent for the state prison system. Education leaders hailed the proposal, while some questioned the governor’s plan to cut prison costs by privatizing prison services. It has been five years since the state provided more money to public universities than prisons, and the plan faces obstacles. If it fails in Sacramento, watch for it to become part of a ballot initiative. [The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times]

headline: Yemen Says Bomb Suspect Met With Qaeda Figures
