headline: The Shrinking American Car Fleet
text: The auto fleet in the United States shrank by an estimated 2 percent in 2009, as 14 million cars were scrapped and only 10 million new cars were sold, according to a new report by the Earth Policy Institute, an environmental research organization in Washington.

headline: Travel Deals: Air Canada World Wide Sale
text: Air Canada is having a New Year’s Sale, with flights throughout Canada, the United States, Europe, Asia and elsewhere, starting at 50 Canadian dollars one way.

headline: At Mayor’s Breakfast, ‘Interfaith’ Means Atheists, Too
text: Six newcomers to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s annual interfaith breakfast stood out in the crowd of more than 400 religious leaders draped in vestments varying from turban to cassock. But the coterie did not draw attention because of unusual garb; this group included the first nonbelievers invited to the breakfast in the eight years that Mr. Bloomberg has held it.

headline: Gone Fishin’!

headline: Jets as Favorites? In Ryan’s World

headline: Reform of New York’s Courts Stalls
text: The most ambitious efforts in decades to reform New York State’s vast network of small-town courts  where sessions can be held in a garage, and where more than 1,450 judges who are not lawyers conduct trials  have stalled in Albany. Even a seemingly modest compromise, one that would allow a defendant to request that the judge be a lawyer, seems doomed, its sponsor says.

headline: Carbon Market Grew as Prices Fell in 2009
text: In spite of the global economic slowdown, the market for trading carbon dioxide jumped by 68 percent last year compared with the previous year, but the value of the market remained roughly unchanged after carbon prices fell.

headline: Thursday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: What to Watch: Game On
text: The collegiate national championship is decided Thursday night in the Rose Bowl, with ABC’s coverage beginning at 8 p.m. It’s Texas versus Alabama, and if you didn’t already know that, you’ll probably be looking for something else to watch. It’ll be a difficult search.

headline: ‘Becoming an Uncle’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Congratulations to President Obama on becoming an uncle. His brother-in-law, Craig Robinson, and his wife just had a son in Oregon. Or so they claim. Lou Dobbs is demanding to see the birth certificate.

headline: Attack Leaves 10 Dead in Southeast Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber attacking a pro-government militia commander detonated his bomb-laden vest in a southeastern provincial capital, Gardez, on Thursday, and witnesses said he killed 10 people and wounded 27, most of them civilians. Also on Thursday, the governor of a neighboring province survived a bomb attack.

headline: ‘More Than 80 Teachers’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” on NBC: Today, President Obama honored more than 80 teachers for excellence in math and science. Then he begged them to leave China and come teach here in the United States.

headline: ‘A Cruel Parent’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Anybody make New Year’s resolutions? I have to find something to do. I’m going to crash a White House state dinner.

headline: The 31 Places to Go in 2010
text: 1. Sri Lanka For a quarter century, Sri Lanka seems to have been plagued by misfortune, including a brutal civil war between the Sinhalese-dominated government and a separatist Tamil group. But the conflict finally ended last May, ushering in a more peaceful era for this teardrop-shaped island off India’s coast, rich in natural beauty and cultural splendors.

headline: ‘Quite a Matchup’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Today, Senator Chris Dodd unveiled his plan to reduce corruption in the Senate. He’s retiring.

headline: Maggie on Sex and Crazy Love, Part 1
text: Updated | 10:21 a.m.

headline: Kenya Deports Muslim Cleric Said to Be Linked to Terrorists
text: A Jamaican-born Muslim cleric whose online sermons drew the attention of a Nigerian man accused of trying to bring down an American airliner was deported Thursday from Kenya, where he had been arrested, according to news reports. He was sent to Gambia, where he was expected to stay briefly before returning to Jamaica.

headline: Small British Company Bets on Tidal Power
text: A British company with a device that creates energy from tidal movement announced late last month that it had received $5.6 million in financing that it hopes will help it reach larger commercial production within two years.

headline: British Oscars Double Down on ‘An Education’
text: “An Education” leads the “long list” of nominees released Thursday morning for the Orange British Academy Film Awards, better known as the BAFTAs, or the stiff upper lip version of the Oscars. Lone Scherfig’s film about a British schoolgirl, played by Carey Mulligan with an adorable pixie-worthy haircut, and her dashing older lover, played by Peter Sarsgaard with a gleam in his eye, earned 17 spots, including best picture, best director and six acting nods, which account for basically its entire cast.

headline: Scent Notes | 1872 for Men by Clive Christian
text: According to Guinness World Records, the world’s most expensive perfume is the designer Clive Christian’s limited edition No. 1, at $250,000 for a 50-milliliter bottle. That’s fine, but all that really matters is whether his scents are any good. Set aside No. 1 Imperial Majesty ($215,000 for 500 milliliters) and Monogram ($14,500 for 30 milliliters), and we’re left with three Clive Christian masculines, all of which are slightly offbeat and rather good.X For Men, created by the talented avant-garde perfumer Geza Schoen under Christian’s direction and launched in 2001, has one of the strangest drydowns I’ve ever experienced. It starts out as a delightful retro, channeling the aftershave used decades ago in Italian barbershops – delicious, aromatic pine with bark of burnished cinnamon. About five hours later, after that burns off, the scent that remains is neutral human breath, warm and strange – and incredibly, almost upsettingly intimate. The barber is inches away, squinting as he trims your sideburns. If you find that he’s a bit too close, simply reapply after a few hours and the ’50s-era pine will return and endure.

headline: Hurry Up and Wait for Title Game
text: For everything unlikable about professional sports  and frankly, we can sum much of that up with one picture of Gilbert Arenas as idiotic gunslinger  they do generally get the playoffs thing right, as in, they hold them immediately after a regular season. Forget for a minute that college football does not have an actual playoff, but perhaps even more ridiculously, their faux championship falls roughly three epochs after Texas or Alabama last played a game. The players should be wearing nametags to avoid embarrassing moments in the locker room like: “Uh, yeah, Joe, right? You’re our starting strong safety?”

headline: Struggling Pound Livens Up the London Housing Market
text: LONDON — A three-bedroom, 2,300-square-foot apartment recently went on the market in London’s fashionable Eaton Square and an Italian buyer immediately snapped it up for £5.65 million — a surprisingly quick sale in what has been a flat market.

headline: New Analysis of China's Real Estate Market Shows 'Dramatic' Growth
text: HONG KONG — No wonder the Chinese government is trying to extend its winter chill to the residential market. Average home prices in Shanghai leapt 68 percent last year, according to new research, while Beijing shot up 66 percent and Shenzhen, 51 percent.

headline: Chinese Looking in America, but Not Buying
text: When Angel Calzadilla, a Florida real estate agent, received an e-mail a few weeks ago from a man who said he was a Chinese executive and wanted to buy a house, he suspected a scam.

headline: Swiss Say Decision on Polanski Extradition Expected Soon
text: The justice ministry of Switzerland said Thursday it would probably decide this month or next whether it will grant a request by the United States to extradite Roman Polanski, Agence France-Presse reported. The ministry’s spokesman, Folco Galli, told Agence France-Presse: “We are preparing our decision. It could be January, it could also be in February. I am not going to be more precise.” Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was apprehended in Switzerland in September. He spent several months in a jail near Zurich before posting $4.5 million bail in December, and is now under house arrest in his chalet in Gstaad. On Wednesday, a written request from Mr. Polanski to be sentenced in absentia was presented to a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge. The judge, Peter P. Espinoza, has scheduled a hearing on Jan. 22 to consider the request.

headline: Buick Regal GS Concept Tipped as the Next Gran Sport
text: Over the Internet, General Motors is gradually revealing the cars it plans to unveil at the Detroit auto show. Earlier this week, it was the Cadillac CTS-V Coupe. On Thursday, G.M. revealed the Buick Regal GS.

headline: Gunman Kills 3 Co-Workers in St. Louis Factory and Then Himself
text: A factory worker who was suing his employer opened fire Thursday morning at an electrical equipment plant in North St. Louis, killing three co-workers before apparently taking his own life, St. Louis fire and police officials said. Five other people were injured.

headline: Letterman’s Finishing Game
text: After getting his turn in the tabloids for having an affair, David Letterman seems pretty much back to his old self in spite of the perils that some observers predicted. But even as others have moved on, Mr. Letterman, ever the rueful observer of self, has not forgotten.

headline: Red Bulls Hire Swedish Coach Hans Backe
text: The Red Bulls are taking on a definite Nordic personality.

headline: LSD, VBS, TFFF etc.
text: Novel fashion-world initialisms.

headline: Cheap Mobile Calls, Even Overseas
text: Internet services can reduce the cost of international cellphone calls to just pennies a minute. Read the full story.

headline: New York’s Next Idea Comes From Students in India
text: The next big idea for a business that could help solve New York City’s energy problems may have been devised by three students from India who had never visited the city before this week.

headline: Schwab Lowers Price for Online Trades
text: The online trading price wars continue.

headline: Plastic Logic Creates the ‘Paperless Briefcase’
text: After a year of slowly dribbling out news about its plans, Plastic Logic has finally unveiled the Que proReader, another rival to the Amazon Kindle and Barnes & Noble Nook in the growing market for electronic reading devices.

headline: Why Does Anyone Have Children?
text: A reader, Bailey, has a question. It’s a request for advice, but only in the broadest sense. Mostly it’s a philosophical inquiry, a “why”, rather than a “how,” of parenting. She’s 24, working in finance and reading Motherlode in anticipation of a day when she herself is a mom. All her reading makes her wonder, though, WHY people have children.  She writes:

headline: Answers From a Bicycle Mechanic, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Eric Schofield, the manager at Bicycle Habitat on Lafayette Street in Manhattan, who is responding to readers’ questions about bicycle maintenance and repair.

headline: E.P.A. Seeks Stricter Rules to Curb Smog
text: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday proposed a stricter standard for smog-causing pollutants that would bring substantial health benefits to millions of Americans while imposing large costs on industry and local governments.

headline: My First Olympic Journey Has Been an Emotional One
text: Erika Lawler, a 22-year-old forward from Fitchburg, Mass., who is a three-year veteran on the U.S. women’s national team, was named to her first Olympic team when it was announced in late December. She writes about the experience of heading to her first Games.

headline: All the Food That’s Fit….
text: Here at Diner’s Journal, where we are hyper-perceptive about all things food, we noticed that take-out orders are pouring into the lobby at an unprecedented rate. The reason? Our beloved New York Times cafeteria is closed today because several staffers reported that vague but scary ailment, gastro-intestinal distress.

headline: Reader Responses to Review of Google’s Nexus One
text: I think I may have accidentally unearthed a whole new untapped population online: the Android Army.

headline: New Year’s Resolutions
text: Gail Collins: David, Happy New Year. I don’t know how you feel about New Year’s resolutions. I tend to make 20 or 30 of them and the only ones that achieve fruition are things like “buy a better coat.”

headline: From Cartel to Corporation: Drug Trade Economics
text: Two prosperous business executives sat across a desk from each other a few months back in Ciudad Juarez, a violence-wracked Mexican town not far from El Paso, engaging in an intense negotiation. The man proposed a price of 4,000 pesos. The woman insisted she could not afford that much. How about 2,500?

headline: More M.&A. Seen in Asset Management Industry
text: The global asset management business witnessed a record-setting flurry of big deals last year, and more deals are expected this year, although probably not quite as large as those in 2009, analysts at the investment bank Jefferies & Company said Thursday.

headline: Conservatives Dilute ‘Purity’ Test for Candidates
text: Facing strong opposition from moderate Republican leaders, a group of conservative Republicans is proposing a watered-down alternative to a resolution that would have required party candidates to agree to at least eight of 10 positions in order to win support from the Republican National Committee.

headline: 36 Hours in New York City
text: URBAN renewal. The phrase conjures up government-backed megaprojects from the ’70s, but it’s organic to New York, where someone is always getting off the bus, train or plane. In the last year, the city has opened a hot new park, Lincoln Center celebrated its 50th anniversary with a major face-lift that includes a new fountain with 353 custom-made, computer-controlled nozzles, and the center of cool shifted innumerable times (but it’s probably still somewhere in Brooklyn).

headline: On CNN, a New Show for Ali Velshi
text: CNN is remodeling its afternoon schedule, assigning two hours of anchoring to its chief business correspondent, Ali Velshi.

headline: More on the Magic of RICO
text: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Obama to Meet With Clinton — Bill, That Is
text: Update | 1:46 p.m.  Health care is among the topics up for discussion when President Obama welcomes Bill Clinton to the Oval Office on this afternoon.

headline: U.S.S.F. Announces Deal on New D2 Scheme
text: Update | 5:00 p.m.  The United States Soccer Federation has put out a smoldering fire that had the potential to detract from a banner year of soccer when it announced on Wednesday an agreement for the operation of a new Division 2 league, one tier below Major League Soccer.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Gabourey Sidibe, Actress
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Literature After Taboo
text: In a long essay in last Sunday’s Book Review, Katie Roiphe defends the Great Male Novelists of yore — the Roths and Updikes, Mailers and Bellows — against their more stringent feminist critics, while contrasting them favorably with their less overtly chauvinist, narcissistic, and sex obsessed male heirs (think Jonathan Franzen or Jonathan Safran Foer or the late David Foster Wallace). “It has become popular to denounce those authors,” Roiphe writes of the GMNs, “and more particularly to deride the sex scenes in their novels.” But their “abiding interest in the sexual connection,” she argues, contrasts favorably with the style of their successors:

headline: Festival Replaces Films Pulled in Protest
text: The Palm Springs International Film Festival confirmed that two Chinese movies scheduled for the festival had been pulled from its lineup, and that those movies would be replaced with other films.

headline: A Chat With Google’s Green Energy Czar
text: Google is a search engine, an advertising company and now a cellphone maker. But a green energy company? That too, said Bill Weihl, Google’s so-called green energy czar, in an interview with Jeffrey Marlow of The Times on the Green Inc. blog. He said:

headline: Leftover Campaign Cash Is Ruled Eligible for Matching Funds
text: The 2009 mayoral election may still be fresh in everyone’s minds, but when it comes to money, the 2013 campaign has already begun.

headline: Kodak Unveils a Waterproof Camcorder
text: Kodak is all about sharing, and the company put photo sharing center stage at its Consumer Electronics Show announcement of four EasyShare shooters as well as a svelte touchscreen camera and a very cool and affordable update of its Zi8 pocket camcorder.

headline: A Writerly Nook of Brooklyn
text: Books have been born all over Brooklyn’s Fort Greene. Richard Wright labored over “Native Son” here while sitting on a hill in Fort Greene Park; a bench there now bears his name. He lived nearby, as did Marianne Moore, and several contemporary writers have roots in the neighborhood, including Colson Whitehead, Jhumpa Lahiri and Nelson George. For a tour of this literary hub (or to take the free workshops the New York Writers Coalition holds here to help people find their inner author), hop the subway to DeKalb Avenue or a nearby station. Bring pen and paper, in case the muse strikes.

headline: The Morning Skate: A Local Winter Classic? An Unsavory Night
text: We’re contending with some serious computer issues this week and working off a laptop that moves as fast as some of the aging guys in our regular Tuesday night skate (this writer included), but this is hockey and you have to play hurt. So here we go.

headline: Next-Gen USB 3.0 Arrives at C.E.S.
text: The next, speedier generation of the USB interconnect technology — version 3.0 — took a step closer to consumers this week with the introduction of Western Digital’s MyBook 3.0.

headline: NBC Denies Rumor of ‘Leno’ Cancellation
text: NBC executives denied a rumor that appeared on a Web site Thursday that the network had made a decision to cancel its “Jay Leno Show” — but at the same time the network acknowledged that low ratings for the show had become a serious problem for NBC’s affiliated stations.

headline: But Crashing Airport Security Was So Cute in ‘Love Actually’
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: A Day of Heroism and Horror
text: A GRUESOME fire and collapse before horrified crowds, people leaping out of windows, others dropping back inside into the flames, their bodies mangled into fragments or reduced to dust in the rubble — that was the Windsor Hotel fire of 1899.

headline: Walk Away From Your Mortgage!
text: John Courson, president and C.E.O. of the Mortgage Bankers Association, recently told The Wall Street Journal that homeowners who default on their mortgages should think about the “message” they will send to “their family and their kids and their friends.” Courson was implying that homeowners — record numbers of whom continue to default — have a responsibility to make good. He wasn’t referring to the people who have no choice, who can’t afford their payments. He was speaking about the rising number of folks who are voluntarily choosing not to pay.

headline: Reality Series Takes Football Recruit on Surreal Ride
text: It sounds like a fairy tale.

headline: NBC Denies Rumor of ‘Leno’ Cancellation
text: Update: NBC May Be Considering Reinstating Leno on ‘Tonight Show’

headline: Directors Give ‘Basterds’ Some Oscar Hope
text: Tea leaves alert: The Directors Guild of America, an uncanny prognosticator of eventual best picture Oscar winners, released its list of nominees on Thursday, one filled with the usual suspects and one big surprise. Kathryn Bigelow (“The Hurt Locker”), James Cameron (“Avatar”), Lee Daniels (“Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire”) and Jason Reitman (“Up in the Air”) received nominations as expected, but Quentin Tarantino and “Inglourious Basterds” have elbowed their way into the party.

headline: 6 Cited in Honduran Leader’s Ouster
text: MEXICO CITY  Six military officers involved in the ouster of Manuel Zelaya from the Honduran presidency last year were charged this week with abuse of power, but the charges are expected to be dropped as part of a deal to ease tensions in the country, officials said.

headline: Salazar Won’t Leave Cabinet for Gov.’s Race
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said today that he would not leave the Cabinet to run for governor of Colorado, and he urged John Hickenlooper, the mayor of Denver, to enter the race as a Democratic candidate.

headline: Scientists Reject Mountaintop Mining Methods
text: A dozen scientists call for no new permits for mountaintop coal mining until practices change.

headline: Olympus Brings HD Video to Rugged Camera Model
text: Olympus unwrapped at the Consumer Electronics Show an affordable rugged camera that can capture high-definition video, as well as new budget and higher-end pocket shooters that all sport new creative tricks.

headline: Apple Patent Application Could Presage Thinner Devices
text: An Apple patent application surfaced on Thursday that points to a new type of multitouch screen technology.

headline: Jayson Williams Is Arraigned
text: More than an hour and a half after cutting across four lanes of oncoming traffic on Avenue C and crashing into a tree, Jayson Williams, the former New Jersey Nets basketball player, told a police officer, “I’m sorry for causing trouble,” according to a Criminal Court complaint and statements made by a prosecutor in court on Thursday.

headline: Top Service Problem at I.R.S.: Not Picking Up the Phone
text: The most serious problem with the Internal Revenue Service for taxpayers: getting someone at the agency to answer phone calls.

headline: Samsung Adds Two Dual-LCD Cameras
text: Samsung added two new models to its DualView line of cameras with enhancements that make it easier to shoot video using the front LCD. Other than that, there’s not much new under the hood, and a lack of pricing makes it difficult to judge their value.

headline: In ‘Other’ Words: Writing Gently Humorous Essays About Stereotypes
text: Overview | How do stereotypes inform our ideas about others? How can we go beyond these misconceptions for a truer look at an “other”? In this lesson, students read a gently humorous essay examining British stereotypes about Americans, consider stereotypes and misconceptions of people in various groups and write lighthearted personal essays.

headline: Guilty Plea in Galleon Insider Trading Case
text: Update | 5:00 p.m. Anil Kumar, a former director at McKinsey & Company accused of leaking information to Raj Rajaratnam in the Galleon Group insider trading case, pleaded guilty on Thursday afternoon and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in the widening investigation.

headline: Iran Accuses Five of Warring Against God
text: At least five protesters arrested in Iran last week during antigovernment demonstrations will be tried on charges of warring against God, which carries an automatic death sentence if they are found guilty, Iran’s judiciary said Thursday.

headline: A Drug’s Second Act: Battling Jet Lag
text: A new drug, Nuvigil from Cephalon, could become the first medicine specifically approved by the Food and Drug Administration to combat jet lag.

headline: BMW Roundel: Not Born From Planes
text: For decades, the spin on BMW’s signature roundel — the automaker’s logo, which looks like a propeller blade set against a blue sky — was that it represented a propeller blade set against a blue sky. The design was supposedly a tribute to the roots of Bayerische Motoren Werke (or Bavarian Motor Works in English) in the early 20th century, when the company built aircraft engines.

headline: Are Doctors Ready for Virtual Visits?
text: For over a decade now, health care experts have been promoting telemedicine, or the use of satellite technology, video conferencing and data transfer through phones and the Internet, to connect doctors to patients in far-flung locales. But are doctors ready for this form of technology?

headline: Boston.com: Charles Pierce on Gilbert Arenas
text: “I am extremely disappointed in my friends over at the National Rifle Association. David Stern has severely restricted the Second Amendment rights of one Gilbert Arenas,” writes Charles P. Pierce on Boston.com. Read the rest of his thoughts on “the arms race in the Wizards locker room.”

headline: What Counts Toward the Cadillac Tax
text: President Obama apparently has embraced the so-called Cadillac tax, an excise tax on high-priced health insurance plans, urging its inclusion in the final health care legislation to be hammered out between Democratic leaders in the House and Senate.

headline: J. Paul Getty Museum Director to Step Down
text: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles announced Thursday that Michael Brand, who took over as its director at the end of 2005, would be stepping down. The museum did not explain why Mr. Brand was leaving or whether he was moving to another institution.

headline: Stern Talks of Lange’s Absence
text: With considerable reluctance, Howard Stern discussed on air the absence of Artie Lange, the comedian and frequent contributor to “The Howard Stern Show” who has been on an indefinite hiatus from the program since December. On Thursday morning’s broadcast of his Sirius XM show, Mr. Stern said at first that he felt uneasy and “weird” discussing a report about Mr. Lange that appeared Thursday in the Page Six column of The New York Post. “Artie’s demons run deeper than I ever knew,” Mr. Stern said, praising Mr. Lange’s contributions to the show before saying, “Artie’s alive, by the way — it was a suicide attempt.” Mr. Lange, who also appeared on the television series “Mad TV” and in films like “Dirty Work,” has discussed his illegal drug use in his standup comedy and a book, “Too Fat to Fish.” After several of his standup shows were canceled, including a performance scheduled for New Year’s Eve, his representatives said earlier this month that he had been hospitalized. A representative for Mr. Stern did not reply to a request for further comment.

headline: Jason Reitman Plays Video Journalist
text: Any journalist who has been shuffled down a hotel room corridor to a press junket can relate to Jason Reitman‘s clever video, “Lost in the Air,” about his adventures on the media tour for his film “Up in the Air.” In fact, many of those journalists may find themselves in this very video.

headline: The Doctor Will See You Now…On Video
text: New technologies allow doctors and patients to interact at far-flung locales.In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about the promise and the disappointment of telemedicine, which is the use of video conferencing, the Internet and other technology to connect physicians, health workers and patients around the world.

headline: Saying Goodbye to Bryant Park Christmas Tree, Decades After Climbing It
text: A tree only survives so long severed from its roots. The sad reminders of this are now plentiful in the city. Sweet-smelling needles adorn the floors of countless living rooms. Brittle, rust-colored skeletons of wood decorate curbside trash piles. At some city parks this weekend the dead or dying Christmas trees will be ground into mulch.

headline: Seeing Things | Johnston Marklee and Walead Beshty
text: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.

headline: Iranian TV Sees Conspiracy in Neda Video
text: Updated | 6:04 p.m. On Tuesday, Iran’s state-run Press TV aired a report on a new documentary made for Iranian television seeking to prove that the graphic, widely-seen amateur video of a female protester named Neda Agha-Soltan bleeding to death on a Tehran street last June was fake.

headline: Landscaping as a Seductive First Step
text: ON a quiet inlet of the Queens waterfront, where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed putting up athletes for the 2012 Olympics, land is being cleared for a series of parks that will be the front lawn for a large midpriced housing development.

headline: Listings and More, Just a Touch Away
text: THERE are over 100,000 iPhone apps available on iTunes. Some help you find a restaurant, others let you find Waldo. There is also a growing selection of real estate apps that will help you look for a home, but not all of them are designed for the New York City market.

headline: Contrarian Investor Sees Economic Crash in China
text: SHANGHAI  James S. Chanos built one of the largest fortunes on Wall Street by foreseeing the collapse of Enron and other highflying companies whose stories were too good to be true.

headline: The Way We Ate: Postscript
text: Last week, we published the story of Angelo Sferrazza, the talented boy chef from Manhattan who won an audience with Mussolini and a tentative job offer from the Waldorf-Astoria. Some readers wanted to know if he ended up at the hotel, or perhaps at some other kitchen.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: 1) Two economists at the Brookings Institution give President Obama a grade of “B” for his fiscal and tax policy over the last year. The content of their assessment seems a little more critical than the overall grade, though.

headline: New Housing, After a Court Order
text: VOICING compliance with a federal court order, the administration of Rob Astorino, the new county executive, pledged last week that Westchester would shift direction and create affordable housing in predominantly white towns and villages rather than in localities with high concentrations of blacks and Hispanics.

headline: What Cute Little Germs
text: A senior co-worker brings his sick children to work, rather than leave them at home with a sitter or his wife, or taking the day off. Recently, he brought them in with plastic caps on their heads. You guessed it: head lice! I don’t want to be infected, but I also don’t want to alienate my colleague, who will probably be my supervisor someday. We don’t have a human resources department, and the principals of our firm don’t seem to care. What should I do?

headline: Rethinking Vacation Homes
text: IN the heart of the winter, many homeowners may be romanticizing about a vacation home in warmer climes.

headline: An Embattled Zardari Hits Back
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Increasingly described as “embattled,” “beleaguered” and “isolated,” President Asif Ali Zardari is fighting back. His latest speeches have been defiant and hard-hitting. He smells a conspiracy to force him to resign and warns his enemies of a tough fight. Predictions of his imminent departure from the presidential palace regularly make the rounds here, although they seem to be inevitable in a society rife with rumors and speculations.

headline: Ex-Bear C.F.O. Said to Advise on Deal for Pali Capital
text: Samuel Molinaro, the chief financial officer of Bear Stearns at the time of the investment bank’s collapse in 2008, is apparently back in the finance game.

headline: A Place With a Certain Something
text: IT wasn’t just that Sally Ardrey’s home of 21 years stood along the path of the new Second Avenue subway line. Her building was on the main corner of Second Avenue and 72nd Street, the location of a future subway station.

headline: Sony’s Green Laptop (Literally)
text: At the Consumer Electronics Show, Stan Glasgow, the head of Sony Electronics in the United States, alluded to the arrival, in a not-too-distant future, of a laptop capable of rendering three-dimensional video. As it was, though, he settled for four new Vaio notebooks, each with its own personality. Here’s a brief look at each of them:

headline: The Tenor Sax Leads the Fusion
text: The tenor saxophonist Chris Potter puts enormous force into his sound, and an even greater measure of control. His tone, all over the extended range of the horn, is dry and dark, often brusque: he doesn’t purr or warble, and he treats vibrato as a special indulgence, like a dusting of shaved truffles. He’s fond of thwarted symmetry and surprising digressions. He knows how to build pressure in a solo, and he does this with such extraordinary technical command that his exertions can feel both heroic and routine.

headline: The Nano Is Coming … to Detroit
text: The Tata Nano, also known as the $2,500 car, has been a subject of curiosity and concern for auto industry executives since it was unveiled last year.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Jan. 7
text: Spencer Platt of Getty Images, newly arrived in Afghanistan (Slide 2), is the product of what turns out to have been one of the more impressive breeding grounds for contemporary photojournalists in America: Staples High School in Westport, Conn. He graduated in 1989. Two other notable alumni are Tyler Hicks, a staff photographer at The Times, and Lynsey Addario, based in Istanbul, whose work appears in The Times and National Geographic. (The high school, it should be noted, did not sign a promotional deal with a certain big-box office supply empire. It is named for its founder, Horace Staples.)

headline: What Were the Most Popular Times Articles in 2009?
text: What do you think the top five most-viewed articles on NYTimes.com in 2009 were about? President Obama’s inauguration? The plane that landed in the Hudson? “Balloon Boy”? Michael Jackson’s death?

headline: Delay of Game at the White House?
text: President Obama was scheduled to speak at 1 p.m. about the government’s report detailing the missteps and intelligence failures with the Christmas Day terrorism plot on a flight from Amsterdam to Detroit.

headline: The Wizards Without Arenas
text: Jon Nichols writes at basketball-statistics.com and is a graduate student at Harvard, where he is pursuing a master’s degree in information technology.

headline: Bike Lanes and Other Things Bike to Proliferate in Bay Area Cities
text: With combined state, federal and stimulus funding, and a little help from the courts, 2010 just might be the year of the bike in the Bay Area. Berkeley, Oakland and San Francisco plan on paving and/or striping at least 18.4 miles of new bike lanes and pedestrian pathways. Will bicyclists follow?

headline: Yours for Under $1 Million
text: TWO years ago, unemployment was around 5 percent, the average price paid for an apartment in Manhattan was nearing $1.7 million, and Eliot Spitzer had a good shot at becoming president.

headline: Peperonata
text: 8 gypsy peppers, or mixture of red, yellow and orange peppers, about 21/2 pounds total

headline: Bruschette With Ricotta and Peperonata
text: Extra-virgin olive oil

headline: New Year’s Toast
text: Putting your apartment up for sale these days is like going back to seventh grade. The combination of a major buyer’s market and the fun world of real estate blogs means a trip through the spanking machine of public mockery. You get to read all about what bad taste you have, how you’re not half as good as you think you are, why nobody’s going to like you, ever.

headline: ‘Enron’ Finds Its Jeffrey Skilling
text: The Tony Award-winning actor Norbert Leo Butz (“Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,” “Thou Shalt Not”) has been cast in the role of Jeffrey Skilling, the disgraced former president of Enron Corp., in the upcoming Broadway production of Lucy Prebble’s play “Enron.”

headline: Forbes Sells Building to N.Y.U.
text: Forbes Media is about to announce that it has reached an agreement to sell its building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan to New York University. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Forbes will continue to occupy the building under a five-year lease back arrangement.

headline: Saab Delays Board Meeting for Late Bidding
text: Saab Automobile, the Swedish automaker being wound down by General Motors, postponed a board meeting on Thursday as bidders including Spyker Cars of the Netherlands made last-ditch efforts to buy the company.

headline: Video Shows Newark Security Breach: A Kiss Before Flying
text: In an effort to identify the man who caused a security breach at Newark Liberty International Airport, video footage of the security gaffe was released on Thursday by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

headline: Lessons From the ‘Katrina Cottages’
text: LAST June, Nell Bard, a former social worker, was flipping through a Lowe’s catalog, comparing its plans for diminutive “Katrina cottages” with her own 780-square-foot converted summer cottage in the hamlet of Brookhaven.

headline: Twitter Land Likes Bama
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Four years ago when Vince Young and Texas de-railed the Southern California dynasty here, we didn’t have a college sports blog at The New York Times and Twitter was just a twinkle in some computer geek’s eye.

headline: Optimism About the New Year
text: SO is it over? The three-year period of unrelenting home price declines: has it stopped? And is it possible that sales prices will go the other way in 2010?

headline: Where People Stay, and ‘Play Musical Houses’
text: IF you’re contemplating buying a home in Douglas Manor, a peninsula on Little Neck Bay in northeast Queens, be advised: your neighbors may not think of your house as yours right away. On paper it belongs to you, but in their minds it may take years until you truly succeed its old owners.

headline: Nelson to Fight for All States
text: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has been under fire in recent days for winning some plum provisions for his home state in exchange for voting for his party’s big health care legislation. But in a statement on Thursday, Mr. Nelson said he would fight for all states to get the same benefits as Nebraska — a move that some Senate colleagues had predicted as inevitable.

headline: The Leader of the Cheers
text: GOWANUS HOUSES, a complex of 14 red-brick buildings that sits not far from its namesake canal in Brooklyn, opened on a June day in 1949, flush with the optimism that wreathed new housing developments for low-income New Yorkers. Among the 1,100-plus original families was a young couple named Leslie and Victoria Baskett Flowers.

headline: A Hatchback for High Rollers
text: LOOKING over the BMW 5 Series Gran Turismo is like waiting in an alley outside the hottest club in town. The view gets better inside.

headline: Free Agent Market: Best of the Rest
text: If the current list of remaining free agents had been available just a few years ago, we would be looking at one of the stronger classes in recent memory. But while age and injury have taken a toll on Vladimir Guerrero, Pedro Martinez, Miguel Tejada and Johnny Damon, they lead a long list of unsigned talent that can still help a team make a playoff push in 2010.

headline: John Oliver Would Like You to Watch His New Show (if That’s O.K. With You)
text: How exemplary a Briton is John Oliver? We can’t speak to his dietary habits or his oral hygiene, but we did learn in a recent telephone conversation with him that he simply cannot pay himself a compliment without immediately putting himself down. (Sometimes the putdowns aren’t even preceded by compliments.)

headline: ABC and Koppel in Talks for ‘This Week’
text: Ted Koppel may make a homecoming to ABC News.

headline: A Booming Economy in China
text: Signs of China's expanding prosperity are everywhere: construction cranes and bulldozers,  luxury-car showrooms, busy shops, long lines for ski lifts. But some fear the country's economy may be overheating, and headed for a collapse.

headline: Egyptian Christians Clash With Police
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Thousands of enraged Christians clashed with the police in Egypt on Thursday in response to a drive-by shooting the night before that left six Christians dead and nine wounded.

headline: Feel-Better Earbuds
text: Take two earbuds and call me in the morning.

headline: Time for a Repair Job and a Reality Check
text: “DETROIT” is shorthand for the American automobile industry in the way that Hollywood is a catch-all term for movies and television. Just as the studios don’t make many films in Hollywood anymore, automakers don’t build many cars in Detroit. Yet like its Tinseltown counterpart, the Motor City remains a beacon, even if the glow has dimmed.

headline: Talks Break Down at Cleveland Orchestra
text: Talks between the players and management of the Cleveland Orchestra broke down on Wednesday, and the musicians threatened to go on strike on Jan. 18. That is the day before the orchestra is to leave for a residency in Miami. “That tour is in question,” Jeffrey Rathbun, the orchestra’s assistant principal oboist and the musicians’ chief negotiator, said in a statement. The players’ contract expired at the end of August, but they have agreed to continue rehearsing and performing. Management, citing salary cuts among staff members and the music director, Franz Welser-Möst, above, offered a three-year contract calling for a 5 percent cut in the first year, a restoration of that amount in the second and a 2.5 percent increase in the third. “We need the union to recognize the shared sacrifice throughout the institution and respond in kind,” Gary Hanson, the orchestra’s executive director, said in a statement. The players offered a salary freeze for this year. A spokesman for the players, Howard C. Landau, said they had made concessions in the past, “which is why we keep slipping in the rankings” in relation to salaries at other orchestras. “We just can’t keep slipping any further,” he added. “There’s no way we can stay competitive. Our musicians are going to leave for greener pastures.”

headline: ‘People’s Choice’ Wins
text: “The People’s Choice Awards,” with Queen Latifah as host, attracted its largest audience in three years on Wednesday as 10.7 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour broadcast on CBS, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The 36th annual installment of the awards show helped lift CBS to No. 1 in the night’s ratings, as did CBS’s 8 p.m. special “I Get That a Lot” (8.5 million), in which celebrities pulled pranks. NBC ranked second on the night. Although its medical drama “Mercy” garnered a modest 7.3 million viewers at 8, “Law & Order: SVU” led the 9 p.m. hour with 10.8 million viewers. At 10 the “Jay Leno Show” drew 5.2 million viewers, edging past ABC’s “Ugly Betty” (5.1 million). ABC finished close behind NBC in third place with two episodes of “The Middle” at 8 (7.5 million) and 8:30 (8.2 million) followed by “Modern Family” at 9 (10.2 million) and “Cougar Town” at 9:30 (7.9 million). Fox was fourth with repeats of “Glee” at 8 and 9, both averaging 3.4 million viewers.

headline: Swiss Preparing Decision on Polanski
text: The justice ministry of Switzerland said Thursday that it may decide soon whether to grant a request by the United States to extradite Roman Polanski, Agence France-Presse reported. The ministry’s spokesman, Folco Galli, told Agence France-Presse: “We are preparing our decision. It could be January, it could also be in February. I am not going to be more precise.” Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was apprehended in Switzerland in September. He spent several months in a jail near Zurich before posting $4.5 million bail in December and is now under house arrest in his chalet in Gstaad. On Wednesday a written request from Mr. Polanski to be sentenced in absentia was presented to a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge. The judge, Peter P. Espinoza, has scheduled a hearing on Jan. 22 to consider it.

headline: Festival Replaces Films Pulled in Protest
text: The Palm Springs International Film Festival confirmed that two Chinese movies had been pulled from its lineup and would be replaced. The films, “City of Life and Death” (also called “Nanjing! Nanjing!”) and “Quick, Quick, Slow,” were withdrawn from the festival by China’s foreign affairs ministry and its film bureau in protest of another film, “The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibet’s Struggle for Freedom.” That film, a documentary, chronicles a year in the life of the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader. In a statement Darryl Macdonald, the director of the festival, said the films were withdrawn when the festival did not comply with a request from the Chinese to cancel screenings of “The Sun Behind the Clouds.” He added: “We cannot allow the concerns of one country or community to dictate what films we should or should not play, based on their own cultural or political perspective.” The festival said “City of Life and Death,” with Liu Ye, above, in a scene from the film, would be replaced with screenings of “For a Moment, Freedom,” an Austrian and French film about Middle Eastern refugees seeking European visas; and “Sticky Fingers,” a Canadian, French and Spanish comedy about inept gangsters. A replacement for “Quick, Quick, Slow” has not yet been announced.

headline: An Addition to ‘Enron’
text: The Tony Award-winning actor Norbert Leo Butz (below, in “Dirty Rotten Scoundrels”) has been cast in the role of Jeffrey Skilling, the disgraced former president of Enron Corporation, in the coming Broadway production of Lucy Prebble’s play “Enron.” Mr. Butz was last seen on Broadway as Bobby Gould in the 2008-9 revival of David Mamet’s “Speed-the-Plow.” “Enron,” which has been running to acclaim in London, was inspired by the financial collapse of the energy company whose name has become synonymous with corporate fraud. Many of the characters  like Mr. Skilling and Kenneth Lay  are based on former employees of Enron. (Mr. Lay was its chairman.) Directed by Rupert Goold, “Enron” is scheduled to begin previews at the Broadhurst Theater April 8 and open April 27.

headline: Boyle Remains No. 1
text: Susan Boyle prevailed in the final week of music sales for 2009, holding at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a sixth week. Her “I Dreamed a Dream” (Syco Music/Columbia) sold 137,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Its total year sales of 3.1 million gave Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) a run for its money as the best-selling album of the year; “Fearless” holds at No. 5 on the latest weekly chart with 60,000 sales, bringing its total for the year to 3.2 million. With no major new releases, Lady Gaga’s “The Fame” (Interscope) sold 82,000 last week to reach No. 2, Alicia Keys’s “Element of Freedom” (J) is third with 80,000, and Mary J. Blige’s “Stronger” (Geffen) is No. 4 with 62,000. Justin Bieber’s “My World” (Island) is No. 6 with 52,000 sales and the soundtrack to “Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel” (Rhino) is No. 7 with 51,000.

headline: On Health Care Bill, Nelson to Fight for All States
text: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has been under fire in recent days over his success in winning some plum provisions for his home state in exchange for his commitment to vote for the Democrats’ big health care legislation. But in a statement on Thursday, Mr. Nelson said he would fight for all states to get the same benefits as Nebraska — a move that some of his Senate colleagues had predicted as inevitable.

headline: Ex-Chief of C.I.A. Is Leaving Citi’s Board
text: John M. Deutch, a former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is stepping down from Citigroup’s board, the bank disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday. Mr. Deutch, 70, who has been a Citigroup director for 12 years, told the board on Monday that he would not stand for re-election at the bank’s next annual meeting, scheduled for April 20.

headline: Obama: ‘We Are at War’
text: President Obama on Thursday ordered a series of steps to improve the government’s ability to collect, share, analyze and act on intelligence of terrorist threats, saying the findings of a government review of the attempted airline bombing on Christmas Day revealed significant shortcomings in national security.

headline: In Focus | Diane Arbus and William Eggleston
text: New York’s Cheim & Read gallery opens its 2010 season on Thursday night with a blockbuster show featuring the work of two stars of the photography world: Diane Arbus and William Eggleston. “In the Absence of Others” shows rarely seen Arbus images of empty interiors and artificial landscapes. (The Moment was lucky to get one of her images, shown below.) She shoots the spaces with the same candid, documentary style she used in her images of people. In the Eggleston show, “21st Century,” viewers quickly fall in love with his color and composition and simultaneously feel a pang for the quietness of each image, whether it’s a doorway or a roll of printed fabric. From Cuba to Kentucky, California to Paris, Eggleston’s eye is unwavering, and his bold strokes of captured color light up the pigment print like fire. This is American photography at its best.

headline: Sudan Clashes Seen as Threat to Peace Treaty
text: At least 140 people were killed in clashes in recent days in a remote corner of southern Sudan, a United Nations official said Thursday, deepening worries that the American-backed peace deal ending decades of war there could collapse amid spasms of ethnically motivated violence.

headline: Reader Responses to Review of Google’s Nexus One
text: I think I may have accidentally unearthed a whole new untapped population online: the Android Army.

headline: In Winter Gardens, a Marriage of Botany and Stark Beauty
text: UNLIKE the tragic hero of Franz Schubert’s song cycle “Winter Journey” (“Tearless I must face the cold/Through the bitter weather”), multitudes of New Yorkers joyously headed for Central Park to experience in bright sunlight the season’s first pristine snowfall on a preholiday Sunday. And in late-afternoon dusk, under the glow of lamplight, the glistening field of white seemed etched by circuitous paths marked in the distance by streams of brightly clad walkers and the shadowy silhouettes of fences. “Invigorating crisp, clean air” was the motto of the day.

headline: Easy Rider, Part II: The Self-Balance Years
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — For my daughter Ali, who is 11, the highlight of the movie “Paul Blart: Mall Cop” last year was the way the title character patrolled his indoor beat: atop a Segway, one of those big-wheeled electric scooters that appear to be lifted from the old “Jetsons” cartoons.

headline: NBC May Be Considering Reinstating Leno on ‘Tonight Show’
text: NBC executives held discussions with both Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien Thursday about the future of the network’s late-night lineup. And while executives said that no final decision has been made, they did not deny that the network was considering moves that could include returning Mr. Leno to his old job as host of “The Tonight Show.”

headline: Whittakers at Pender Harbour
text: WHAT Small waterfront second-home community.

headline: TV on the Go — Once Again
text: Digital television gave, but it also took away. Digital TV brought us high-definition TV, and if you can get a signal, perfect reception. But one of the things that the switch to digital TV removed is the ability to watch TV while you’re on the move.

headline: At Ground Level, Taking Jazz’s Pulse
text: A lot of people at the Winter Jazzfest this weekend will be ticking off names on a mental checklist, or filing them away for later. This two-day festival, now in its sixth year, is expressly made for them: the prowlers and perusers, many seeking talent for hire. But tickets are also available to the public, at $25 a night or $30 for both, which gives the Winter Jazzfest another, more fascinating purpose. It is for the moment the only real mainstream jazz festival in New York, and its lineup amounts to a temperature reading of the scene at ground level, where it’s most vibrant and volatile.

headline: Tougher Smog Standards, but What About Tailpipes?
text: Environmental groups were full of praise on Thursday when the Environmental Protection Agency proposed the strictest standards to date for smog. Although automobile tailpipes have traditionally been a major source of the smog problem, the auto industry said that it had largely dealt with that issue. Ground-level ozone reductions, the carmakers said, were more likely to come from stationary sources like power plants.

headline: Batsheva From and Michael Altman
text: AS a prosecutor in the narcotics division of the Bronx district attorney’s office, Batsheva From relishes the challenge and drama of the courtroom. She spends many hours preparing a case, all too aware that improvisation may also be required to win over judge and jury.

headline: A Writerly Nook of Brooklyn
text: Books have been born all over Brooklyn’s Fort Greene. Richard Wright labored over “Native Son” here while sitting on a hill in Fort Greene Park; a bench there now bears his name. He lived nearby, as did Marianne Moore, and several contemporary writers have roots in the neighborhood, including Colson Whitehead, Jhumpa Lahiri and Nelson George. For a tour of this literary hub (or to take the free workshops the New York Writers Coalition holds here to help people find their inner author), hop the subway to DeKalb Avenue or a nearby station. Bring pen and paper, in case the muse strikes.

headline: Of Explosions and Catharsis
text: There were at least two surprises in the Directors Guild of America nominations announced on Thursday: the inclusion of Quentin Tarantino over, say, Clint Eastwood, whom the guild has favored in the past (though Mr. Tarantino was included for “Pulp Fiction”), and the nod for Lee Daniels, who becomes the first black director nominated by the guild and certainly the first openly gay black director. Perhaps this will ease Mr. Daniels’s, or his boyfriend’s, agita about awards season.

headline: He’s in Love; Excuse His French
text: In the sweet and slight and often charming coming-of-age tale “Youth in Revolt,” Michael Cera plays a teenager with rampaging hormones and, when the film opens at least, no obvious romantic prospects. On the face of it, this seems preposterous: Mr. Cera, who turns 22 in June, is a professional cutie-pie and very appealing to both the on screen characters (he usually gets the girl) and, to gauge from his popularity, the audience. After the movie I ran into a friend who was initially worried about this film because Mr. Cera always does the same thing, only to realize that what he does is exceptionally winning. Exactly.

headline: ‘Enron’ Finds Its Jeffrey Skilling
text: From Patrick Healy at ArtsBeat:

headline: Trial Pending, Suspect’s Cars Will Soon Be Freed
text: DENVER  The trial of Jeffrey L. Mowen, accused of defrauding investors in an $18 million Ponzi scheme in Utah and then trying to hire a hit man to kill four witnesses against him, is expected to be lurid at the least.

headline: Sony’s Memory Stick: Bowing to Reality
text: Deep within the speech by Stan Glasgow, president of the American arm of Sony Electronics, at the Consumer Electronics Show on Wednesday was this little tidbit: the company that pioneered the Memory Stick flash memory format would now accept the rival SD and SDHD memory card format in a number of its new camcorders and digital still cameras.

headline: Thinking vs. Feeling
text: That’s from a summary of a recent paper on the language used for marketing and persuasion. The paper is by Nicole D. Mayer, of the University of Illinois at Chicago, and Zakary L. Tormala, of the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

headline: House Democrats Push Back on Cadillac Tax
text: Several House Democrats on Thursday chafed at President Obama’s insistence that the final version of major health care legislation include a Senate proposal for a new tax on high-cost, employer-sponsored insurance policies.

headline: New Rules Proposed for Smog Pollutants
text: If adopted, the proposal will impose large costs on industry and local governments, but will also bring substantial health benefits to millions of Americans.

headline: A Safety Net That Tangles Investors
text: In the wake of a series of Ponzi schemes  the most notable being the Bernard Madoff fraud  the Securities and Exchange Commission voted last month to tighten the rules and make it much harder for money managers to misappropriate client funds.

headline: Coming to AT&T: Smartbooks, Toys and You Name It
text: Glenn Lurie, the president of emerging devices at AT&T, has what some people may consider a fantastic job.

headline: Inside the List
text: THINK PINK: Daniel H. Pink enters the extended hardcover nonfiction list at No. 16 with “Drive: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates Us.” Pink (inset) achieved full guru status with “A Whole New Mind” (2005), a paean to right-brain thinking that spent more than 29 weeks on the paper­back nonfiction list, thanks in part to a nod from Oprah Winfrey. (She distributed copies to Stanford’s graduating class after her 2008 commencement speech.) In “The Adventures of Johnny Bunko” (2008), billed as “America’s first business book in the Japanese comic format known as manga,” Pink reached out to the youth crowd with the story of a frustrated desk monkey who conjures up a tough-talking career counselor goddess by snapping open a pair of magic chopsticks.

headline: An Extrovert’s Brisk Dance Through Bach’s Arpeggios, in an East River Hall
text: “The Well-Tempered Clavier” was once the preserve of specialists, among both performers and listeners, but these days one or both of Bach’s collections of preludes and fugues in every key can be heard in live performance several times a year. The readings come in every flavor: on harpsichord, clavichord or piano; in accounts steeped in musicological detail or in freewheeling interpretations; and in grandly scaled traversals in halls as large as Carnegie or more intimate performances in chamber spaces.

headline: The Best French Toast
text: From diner breakfast to hotel brunch, challah seems to be the bread of choice for making French toast. This is a good idea in principle, but — like nearly all 21st-century bagels — most of the nation’s challah is the merest shadow of the beautiful eggy bread that Jews used to reserve for special occasions: a recurrent image in Isaac Bashevis Singer’s stories is the family so wealthy that it eats challah during the week rather than just on the sabbath.

headline: The Three Magi of the Meltdown
text: Just because hindsight is 20/20 doesn’t mean we shouldn’t occasionally avail ourselves of it. The upcoming second-year anniversary of the collapse of Bear Stearns provides just such an opportunity to look back with a degree of analytical wisdom not available at the time of the firm’s shocking demise in March 2008.

headline: Under the Radar: Five Questions About ‘John Cassavetes’ Husbands’
text: Translating the films of the director John Cassavetes for the stage is a novel concept, but not a new one. In 2008, Ivo van Hove’s tech-heavy staging of Cassavetes’s 1977 film, “Opening Night,” turned a stage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music into an ersatz film set.

headline: Getty Museum Director to Leave Post This Month
text: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles said on Thursday that Michael Brand, who took over as its director at the end of 2005, is stepping down at the end of the month.

headline: Contrarian Investor Predicts Crash in China
text: James S. Chanos built one of the largest fortunes on Wall Street by foreseeing the collapse of Enron and other highflying companies whose stories were too good to be true. Now Mr. Chanos, a wealthy hedge fund investor, is working to bust the myth of the biggest conglomerate of all: China Inc.

headline: More on desert bubbles
text: Ed Glaeser emails to say that, contrary to my suggestion, he doesn’t believe there were significant supply restrictions in Phoenix or Las Vegas. He directs me to a paper which says, if I understand it, that even in Flatland there may be sufficient short-run price inelasticity of supply to allow brief bubbles.

headline: Crankier Than Thou, but Open to New Love
text: Ben Singer (Matthew Broderick), the misanthropic protagonist of Josh Goldin’s film “Wonderful World,” voices many of the frustrations nagging at those who harbor suspicion that the world is going to hell. Ben is a divorced, semi-retired children’s musician and pothead who was once near the top of his field. His career went abruptly into decline when his record company encouraged him to make a solo album, then failed to promote it. Now he toils miserably as a proofreader at a law firm.

headline: To Sign or Not to Sign in Making Debit Purchases: Part 1
text: The New York Times article “How Visa, Using Card Fees, Dominates a Market” on Tuesday detailed the behind-the-scenes struggle between banks and retailers on whether to encourage customers to sign or punch in their PIN when making debit card purchases because of the higher fees that stores pay banks for signatures.

headline: CRE-ative destruction
text: For some reason I haven’t seen this: a comparison of commercial real estate prices from Moody’s/MIT with housing prices from Standard and Poor’s/Case-Shiller. Here it is:

headline: Eddie the Eagle Returns to Canada
text: Michael Edwards — the hopelessly unskilled and undertrained British ski jumper better known as Eddie the Eagle, who provided humorous relief at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary — returned to Canada on Thursday in preparation for the Vancouver Games. But Edwards, a drywaller by trade, did not come back as an athlete.

headline: Obama’s Remarks on the Terror Plot Review
text: Following is the text of President Obama’s remarks on Thursday in which he addresses the results of a government review of the attempted airline bombing on Christmas Day, as released by the White House:

headline: 3 Irish Women Bound by Blood and Behavior
text: “Little Gem,” a new play by Elaine Murphy that arrives at the Flea Theater trailing accolades from Dublin and Edinburgh, lives up to its title, although if it were trimmed, this jewel would definitely gleam more brightly. Intimately told and beautifully acted, Ms. Murphy’s play unfolds in alternating monologues, as three generations of Irish women greet life’s travails with strength, humor and the occasional vodka and Diet Coke or night of abandon on the salsa dance floor.

headline: Unscarred, Berlusconi Appears in Public
text: Less than four weeks after he was struck in the face following a rally in Milan, Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi appeared for the first time without bandages on Wednesday, during a shopping trip in France.

headline: Life as a Runway
text: Susan Sarandon talks about the crowd at Spin New York, a table tennis and social club in New York City, where the clientele is as studiedly understated as the sprawling gray and green interior.

headline: An Ancestor Takes Pride in a Taller Descendant
text: The Empire State Building has a message for the Burj Khalifa, the slightly-more-than-twice-as-tall tower that opened in Dubai on Monday: Welcome to the club.

headline: This is the way the Chicago School ends
text: Not with a bang, but with a cackle.

headline: Columbia’s Last 3-Point Specialist Is a Pro in Japan
text: Noruwa Agho has filled the net with 3-pointers for Columbia University at a higher rate than anyone else in Division I men’s basketball this season, hitting at 59 percent, as I wrote in Friday’s New York Times. But he is not the only Lions guard in recent years who had the touch from long range.

headline: A Fresh Makeover for Familiar Faces
text: Color changes everything. It has, anyway, in the East Gallery of the Frick Collection, where walls covered with brown velvet since the Johnson administration now glow a beautiful shade of coral.

headline: B.C.S. National Championship Game: No. 2 Texas (13-0) vs. No. 1 Alabama (13-0)
text: It’s funny just how quickly 126 days can pass, especially with college football’s propensity for scheduling games two, three, even four nights a week. Yet as we stand on the doorstep of the B.C.S. National Championship Game, that is how long it has been — a few days past four months — since Sept. 3, when South Carolina edged North Carolina State, 7-3, in the season’s first prime-time game. Perhaps it takes 126 days for the cream to rise to the top, as tonight’s title game pits the clear Nos. 1 and 2 in the F.B.S.: Texas, winners of the Big 12, and Alabama, the SEC champs.

headline: Fox Drops ‘Little Genius’ Premiere
text: The premiere of “Our Little Genius,” a new quiz show that was scheduled to be broadcast on Fox next week after “American Idol,” has been canceled, Fox announced Thursday, over what appears to be concerns that contestants were given information about the topics on which they would be quizzed.

headline: Coffee for Me, Worms for Her
text: Thomas S. Kaplan, the president of the board of directors of the 92nd Street Y, made a fortune in silver, platinum, oil, natural gas and gold. That is good news for the planet’s big cats and their habitats: their preservation is the mission of Panthera, a foundation that is a major philanthropic focus of his. Mr. Kaplan, 47, who is chairman of the Electrum Group, which mines gold, lives in Chelsea with his wife, Daphne Recanati Kaplan, and their son, Leonardo, 7, and daughter, Orianne, 9. ROBIN FINN

headline: Pearls, Fish and Devils Unbound at the Morgan
text: In the next two weeks the Morgan Library & Museum will hang framed 15th-century pages that staff members tore out of old books.

headline: Spirals of Self-Reflection, Made by Methods Mysterious
text: Acute  some might say neurotic  self-consciousness is one of modern art’s salient features. Before the art world went nuts in the 1960s, this meant focusing on the basic processes, materials and actions by which works were made, as in Abstract Expressionist painting, for example. Now cerebrally ambitious artists like to reflect on all the conditions impinging on art: on the gallery and museum system; on the ideological prejudices and blind spots of art history and criticism; on publications by which information and rumors about art are disseminated; and so on.

headline: In Los Angeles, an Urge to Purge
text: For two years the Los Angeles County Museum of Art has been quietly buying paintings and publicly selling them. Readers of Sotheby’s latest auction catalog may have noticed a group of old master paintings coming up for sale on Jan. 28. It isn’t the first time the museum has sold works from its permanent collection. Last year, in January and June, Sotheby’s auctioned paintings by Joshua Reynolds, Lucas Cranach the Elder, Pieter de Hooch and others, raising more than $6 million for the museum.

headline: Fox Drops ‘Our Little Genius’ Premiere
text: The premiere of “Our Little Genius,” a new quiz show that was scheduled to be broadcast on Fox next week following “American Idol,” has been canceled, Fox announced Thursday, over what appears to be concerns that contestants were given information about the topics on which they would be quizzed.

headline: ‘The Harvard Psychedelic Club’
text: Andy Weil and Ronnie Winston were friends and dorm mates in Claverly Hall. They were both incoming Harvard freshmen when they walked into Leary's office on Divinity Lane and volunteered to be research subjects in his psychedelic research project. Weil had grown up in a middle-class family. Winston was the son of Harry Winston, the wealthy diamond and jewelry manufacturer whose creations hung around the necks of trophy wives and Hollywood starlets from coast to coast. Neither of them would officially take part in the project, but they would both play an important, little-known role in the rise and fall of Richard Alpert and Timothy Leary.

headline: Tune In, Turn On, Turn Page
text: In the winter of 1960-61, when their lives began to overlap in Cambridge, Mass., Timothy Leary, Richard Alpert, Andrew Weil and Huston Smith resembled tweedy extras from “Mad Men.” These future psychedelic pioneers were still buttoned-down intellectuals and careerists, men who leaned more toward martinis than marijuana.

headline: Three Decades on, Reunited With a High School Sweetheart
text: BATH, N.H.

headline: An Interview With Rep. Steny Hoyer
text: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times interviews Representative Steny Hoyer, House majority leader and Democrat of Maryland.

headline: Batsheva From and Michael Altman Wed
text: The couple exchanged vows on Dec. 30, in front of Rabbi Hershel Billet and nearly 400 guests at the Great Neck Synagogue in Great Neck, N.Y.

headline: Film Excerpt: 'Nostalgia'
text: An excerpt from Omer Fast's 2009 film, now showing at the Whitney Museum.

headline: Should the Fine You Pay Be Based on How Rich You Are?
text: A Swiss court says yes.

headline: Brown Is Happy at Texas and as a Coach
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Ever since Texas named the defensive coordinator Will Muschamp its designated head coach-in-waiting last season, there has been speculation about when Longhorns Coach Mack Brown will retire.

headline: Ireland in February, With Romance in the Air, Manure on the Ground
text: A few weeks ago I resolved, in the spirit of the season, to adopt a more positive outlook in the new year. In particular I vowed to break the habit of seizing on every bad movie as a sign that civilization was collapsing. There is already so much doomsaying and apocalypse mongering going around. Why add to it?

headline: China Turns Drug Rehab Into a Punishing Ordeal
text: BEIJING  Fu Lixin, emotionally exhausted from caring for her sick mother, needed a little pick-me-up. A friend offered her a “special cigarette”  one laced with methamphetamine  and Ms. Fu happily inhaled.

headline: Eat, Pray, Marry
text: When exactly was it that “Eat, Pray, Love,” Elizabeth Gilbert’s 2006 memoir about her divorce and subsequent year of travel in Italy, India and Indonesia, crossed from mere best seller — published in more than 30 languages, feted by Oprah — to cultural phenomenon? The film adaptation is due out later this year, with Gilbert played by (but of course) Julia Roberts; some of the people Gilbert wrote about, including her ex-husband, are now working on books of their own; and Gilbert’s second appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” featured such admiring readers as a woman who had actually retraced much of Gilbert’s around-the-world journey. Perhaps most impressive of all, in a sign of what a widely understood reference point the book has become, it inspired a headline in The Onion: “Copy of ‘Eat, Pray, Love’ Left on ­Elliptical.”

headline: The Twisted Trail of the Khost Bomber
text: Stephen Farrell of The Times interviews the mother of Humam Khalil Abu-Mulal al-Balawi, the Jordanian suicide bomber  who killed 7 CIA officers in Khost, Afghanistan.

headline: Ah, Homer, It Seems Just Like Yesterday
text: “The Simpsons” has been on the air longer than “Gunsmoke,” but that’s not a reason to watch the show’s 20th-anniversary special on Fox this Sunday night. Tributes to even the best shows can smother them in pomposity. “The Simpsons 20th Anniversary Special: In 3-D! On Ice!” is worth a look because  as the self-mocking title suggests  it doesn’t make too big a deal of one of the most innovative, influential and irresistibly irreverent shows in the history of television.

headline: January Thaw for the Arts
text: These are the festivals mentioned in the article.

headline: Festivals to Enliven the Dead of Winter
text: ONCE upon a time, the first half of January was considered a slow, even dead, stretch for the performing arts in New York. Not anymore.

headline: Total Recall: A Journey From Vienna to Brooklyn and the Center of the Brain
text: It’s not often that you are invited to spend an hour or two in the presence of a Nobel Prize winner, and “In Search of Memory: The Neuroscientist Eric Kandel,” Petra Seeger’s new documentary, offers an especially gratifying opportunity. The film’s subject won the 2000 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his research into the workings of the brain. He is particularly interested in how, at the cellular level, the mind stores and sorts various stimuli and turns them into long- and short-term memory.

headline: Is It Reality or Fantasy? The Boundaries Are Blurred
text: Omer Fast, who has a powerful, discomforting solo show at the Whitney Museum of American Art, and another opening at Postmasters gallery in Chelsea on Saturday, was born in Jerusalem in 1972 and now lives in Berlin. But he studied art in New York City, and anyone who saw his graduate project in the 2000 Hunter College M.F.A. exhibition will remember it.

headline: New Jersey Senate Defeats Gay Marriage Bill
text: TRENTON  The State Senate on Thursday rejected a proposal that would have made New Jersey the sixth state in the nation to allow marriages involving same-sex couples. The vote was the latest in a succession of setbacks for advocates of gay marriage across the country.

headline: Theater Listings: Jan. 8 — 14
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Footage of Breach at Newark Is Released
text: In an effort to identify the man who caused a security breach at Newark Liberty International Airport, video footage of the episode was released on Thursday by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

headline: The Iron Horse Stalks a Sentimental Village
text: The railroad snakes ever closer in “Return to Cranford,” a sequel to “Cranford,” the five-hanky Victorian tearjerker and paean to preindustrial village life that collected eight Emmy nominations for PBS in 2008. Despite its tendency to maim and kill them, the fearsome machine is cautiously welcomed by the townspeople, some of whom recognize an economic lifeline when they see one.

headline: Excerpt: 'Human Target'
text: The new Fox action series, based on a comic book, stars Mark Valley as a resourceful private eye.

headline: Mika Brzezinski: Her Way
text: When did you first become aware of Mika Brzezinski, the co-host of MSNBC’s daily news discussion program “Morning Joe”? For the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, it was in the 1970s, when she spilled a plate of caviar on his lap. For me, it was a December morning in 2007, as I listened to the Carter-era statesman Zbigniew Brzezinski discussing Benazir Bhutto’s assassination. The anchorwoman addressed him as “Daddy.” Daddy? I looked up from my pancakes.

headline: Reliance Said to Sweeten Lyondell Bid
text: Reliance Industries of India has bolstered its offer to take a controlling stake in LyondellBasell Industries when the chemical maker exits bankruptcy, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing unidentified people familiar with the matter. But Lyondell seemed unlikely to accept the new terms and instead go ahead with a previous deal to turn itself over to its senior lenders.

headline: Futuristic World Where Vampires Rule
text: Among the many pleasures of “Daybreakers” is its reminder that vampire movies can function as more than just metaphors for teenage celibacy. Written and directed by Peter and Michael Spierig (the Australian twins who brought us the ebullient 2003 zombie caper “Undead”), this impressively styled thriller envisions a world where vampires rule, and humans run. Those who don’t are likely to find themselves transformed into Ready Meals and stored in a giant corporate larder: a futuristic Costco with only one product.

headline: Casting Identities in Light
text: IN the lexicon of automakers’ design studios, two abbreviations  D.R.G., for down the road graphic, and D.L.O., for the daylight opening area of the windows  crop up frequently. Together, they refer to the characteristic form of a car that makes it instantly recognizable, the profile that quickly tells a viewer whether the vehicle is a Fusion or a Forester, an Eclipse or an Elantra.

headline: Study Raises Cost Estimate for Electric Cars
text: DETROIT  As General Motors began assembling batteries for the coming Chevrolet Volt on Thursday, a new study cast doubt on the likelihood that electric cars will be widely popular in the near future.

headline: Apocalyptic Beliefs of American Evangelicals
text: Who knew that one of this year’s first horror movies would arrive not from Japan or the mind of Eli Roth but from three inquisitive nonfiction filmmakers? Turning their camera on the apocalyptic beliefs of American evangelicals (estimated in the film at more than 50 million), Kate Davis, Franco Sacchi and David Heilbroner illuminate a worldview marked by absolute certainty and chilling finality.

headline: Helen Gahagan Douglas, Hollywood Liberal
text: Sally Denton’s new biography of Helen Gahagan Douglas, the actress turned New Deal politician, starts on a lyrical note — “Her life would begin and end in sun-filled rooms” — and never really calms down. Despite its concision, a rare and usually admirable thing in biography, the book doesn’t achieve the tonal or interpretive modesty that might give Douglas her due without inflating claims for her significance and her victimization at the hands of Richard Nixon, who defeated her in their 1950 California Senate race. Douglas’s life was more richly and judiciously presented by Ingrid Winther Scobie less than 20 years ago, in a biography called “Center Stage.”

headline: Obama Details New Policies in Response to Terror Threat
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday ordered intelligence agencies to take a series of steps to streamline how terrorism threats are pursued and analyzed, saying the government had to respond aggressively to the failures that allowed a Nigerian man to ignite an explosive mixture on a commercial jetliner on Christmas Day.

headline: Blackhawks Flourish Under Tough Coach
text: If the Blackhawks were a Western movie, Joel Quenneville would be cast as a United States marshal, wise and worldly, so firmly in charge there’s no need to flaunt his power or ego. As a hockey team, the Hawks are thriving like a gold-rush boomtown under Quenneville’s sharp-eyed, self-assured leadership.

headline: Update: NBC Plan Would Move Leno Back to Late Nights
text: Pressed by affiliates and shrinking ratings, NBC has a plan in the works to radically alter its late-night television lineup, restoring Jay Leno to his old spot at 11:35 each weeknight, while pushing the man who replaced him, Conan O’Brien, to a starting time of 12:05 a.m.

headline: Former Blackwater Guards Charged With Murder
text: WASHINGTON  Two former Blackwater security guards were arrested Thursday on murder charges stemming from a shooting in Afghanistan last May that left two Afghans dead and a third wounded, the Justice Department said.

headline: Italy Puts Swiss Haven From Taxes Under Siege
text: LUGANO, Switzerland  Italy and Switzerland have been waging a quiet border war lately, and this picturesque town on the shores of an Alpine lake is caught in the cross-fire.

headline: A One-Man Version of ‘First Blood’
