text: Zachary Oberzan says he spent less than $96 to make “Flooding With Love for the Kid,” his one-man version of “First Blood,” but that’s disingenuous. Mr. Oberzan, who in addition to being the lone actor was also director, designer, cinematographer, editor and everything else for this odd project, apparently didn’t pay himself.

headline: Finding Happiness in Helping Those Who Have Less
text: Six years ago, Sheila Salmon, a retired educator and librarian, picked up The New York Times and read a Neediest Cases article about a retired bank executive who volunteered at a senior center.

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: Film Series

headline: Jobs Report Preview
text: The long-awaited December jobs report comes out Friday, and what it will say is anybody’s guess.

headline: Partners Near Default on Stuyvesant Town
text: The owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling sister complexes overlooking the East River in Manhattan, will miss a $16 million loan payment on Friday, which would put them in technical default on their mortgages, and the 20,000 residents in limbo.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Live Analysis: Alabama 37, Texas 21, Final
text: 12:15 p.m. | Use the comment section below to leave your thoughts on the game, even if all you have to say is, “Roll Tide Roll.” Congratulations to the Tide for its national championship and congratulations to Texas for another fine season. Stay with The Times and the Quad blog for more from Pasadena. And before we all get teary-eyed, remember that we’re only 239 days away from kickoff of the 2010 college football season.

headline: When Running for Office, Be Careful What You Wish For
text: The only thing missing in the most notable television ad in the Illinois governor’s race is Englebert Humperdink singing, “Release Me.”

headline: Holmgren and Browns Decide to Retain Mangini
text: Back in November, with his team reeling, his players grumbling, the fans booing, it was hard to imagine that Eric Mangini would make it until the end of the season. Instead, he will make it at least two. On Thursday, the Browns’ new president, Mike Holmgren, announced that Mangini would return for his second season, shocking many around the N.F.L. who assumed Holmgren would clean house.

headline: A Campaign Linking Clean Clothes With Stylish Living
text: PROCTER & GAMBLE is taking a nontraditional tack to help Tide, the best-selling detergent in America, fend off challenges from lower-priced rivals as strapped consumers continue to ponder practically every purchase.

headline: Democrats Anxious Over a Once-Safe Seat
text: BOSTON  Martha M. Coakley, the Democrat running for Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s seat in Massachusetts, had seemed so certain of winning the special election on Jan. 19 that she barely campaigned last month.

headline: Koppel Said to Be Talking With ABC About ‘This Week’
text: Ted Koppel, the former anchor of “Nightline,” may make a homecoming to ABC News.

headline: Princeton Players Are Divided by Heritage, United by Basketball
text: PRINCETON, N.J.  When asked about their political views, cultures and backgrounds and whether they create problems for them on or off the basketball court, Niveen Rasheed and Lauren Polansky laugh simultaneously.

headline: Google Applies to Become Power Marketer
text: Google is stepping up its forays into the energy world.

headline: Britain’s Central Bank Leaves Key Rate and Stimulus Unchanged
text: The Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate and economic support programs unchanged Thursday, opting to wait for stronger recovery signals before following other major central banks in starting to dismantle stimulus measures.

headline: Hospital Cuts Dialysis Care for the Poor in Miami
text: To chip away at an overwhelming budget deficit, Miami’s public hospital system stopped paying for kidney dialysis for the indigent this week, officials said, leaving some patients to rely on emergency rooms for their life-sustaining treatments.

headline: Lhasa de Sela, Singer Who Crossed Borders, Dies at 37
text: Lhasa de Sela, a Mexican-American singer and songwriter who became an international star after moving to Canada, died on Jan. 1 at her home in Montreal. She was 37.

headline: An Unusual Duo Tests Conventional Song Forms
text: Creative friction that playfully undercuts conventional song forms in a search of greater expressive latitude might describe the collaboration of Michael Winther, a theater singer of impeccable taste and polish, and the jazz pianist Dan Tepfer in their show, “Songs and Variations,” at the Metropolitan Room on Monday evening.

headline: Mad Family Day
text: Cutting, shredding, slashing and burning are usually processes associated with destruction. But on Saturday the Museum of Arts and Design will show children 5 and older how all that clipping and ripping can also play a role in creation.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Peers Hail Dawson, Hall of Famer and Expo Great
text: When Andre Dawson signed with the Chicago Cubs in 1987, submitting a blank-check contract during the height of collusion and working for less than half his salary from the year before, the Wrigley Field fans bowed to him from the bleachers.

headline: A Jazz Singer Saunters Through Old and New
text: Giacomo Gates approaches jazz singing with a showman’s poise and an aficionado’s zeal. Holding court on Wednesday night in the mezzanine lounge of the Kitano New York Hotel, he was solicitous but cool. He wanted to let his listeners in on a secret, bring them into his confidence. With his deep, cognac baritone and his vintage-hipster lexicon, he seemed an appreciative throwback, eager to share credit with his precursors while mindful of keeping a little for himself.

headline: Murky Trail for ‘Loner’ in Attack on C.I.A.
text: AMMAN, Jordan  Another blog posting appeared Thursday under the name of Abu Dujana al-Khorasani, eight days after the man who used that pseudonym blew himself up at a secret C.I.A. outpost in eastern Afghanistan. The headline: “When will my words drink my blood?”

headline: With Little Fanfare, the Los Angeles Kings Are in the Playoff Chase
text: LOS ANGELES  When Anze Kopitar arrived in Edmonton for a game this season, he was leading the N.H.L. in scoring. So after the doors to the visiting locker room swung open, he got the royal treatment. Kopitar, a center for the Los Angeles Kings, quickly found himself at the center of about 25 cameramen and reporters  for a morning skate.

headline: Repairs May Add to J.F.K.’s Delays
text: The average delay at Kennedy International Airport lasts more than an hour; one in every five flights left late last year; and its performance ranks in the bottom third of major American airports.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Thunkless in the Name of Progress
text: This is hard to prove, but the betting here is that many New Yorkers will miss the thunk.

headline: Further Slide Seen in Commercial Real Estate
text: There are 920 football fields of available office space in Manhattan. More than 180 major buildings totaling $12.5 billion in value  from Columbus Tower at 1775 Broadway to the office tower 400 Madison Avenue  are in trouble, meaning in many cases they face foreclosure or bankruptcy, or have had problems making mortgage payments. Rents for commercial office space fell faster over the past two years than in any such period in the last half century.

headline: Seeking Grants, Paterson Urges Education Changes
text: Gov. David A. Paterson on Thursday proposed a host of changes in state education law, including eliminating the cap on the number of charter schools, which he said would make the state more likely to receive $700 million in federal grant money.

headline: Charles Kleibacker, Fashion Designer, Dies at 88
text: Charles Kleibacker, a former fashion designer whose taste for intricately constructed gowns gave him the nickname Master of the Bias in the 1960s, died Sunday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 88.

headline: The Loose Cannon in the Locker Room for the N.B.A.
text: Los Angeles

headline: Fed Advice to A.I.G. Scrutinized
text: New revelations that the government stopped the American International Group from revealing information about its bailout had securities lawyers and policy makers buzzing on Thursday about whether the information had to be disclosed under federal securities law, and if so, what to do about the lack of compliance.

headline: Finding Tender Humanity Among Those Forest Fairies
text: There are stretches in the first act of George Balanchine’s “Midsummer Night’s Dream” when it grows hard to care for its bumbling human characters, all so blind to the woodland magic enveloping them in the darkness. Far better to root for the fairies, except that Shakespeare wrote a comedy, not a farce, and we must be made to feel for these frail mortals if the ballet is to touch on the play’s rich depths.

headline: Ex-Consultant Pleads Guilty in Galleon Insider Case
text: “Anil, you are a hero.”

headline: Mother and Son, Inverting and Exploring Standards
text: In a competitive musical climate in which most performers shout to grab attention, the cabaret singer Sandy Stewart embodies an oracular calm. Pondering standards in a quiet, confiding alto with a rolling, sensual vibrato, she turns lyrics into intimate overheard streams of consciousness. As she sang a program of standards accompanied on piano by her son, the brilliant jazz pianist Bill Charlap, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening, their concert offered a master class in subtle musical communication and interpretation.

headline: Integrity Concerns Force Fox to Postpone Child Quiz Show
text: LOS ANGELES  The premiere of “Our Little Genius,” a new quiz show featuring child contestants that was scheduled to be broadcast on Fox next week after “American Idol,” has been postponed and possibly canceled, Fox announced Thursday, over concerns about the integrity of the show.

headline: Sensible Rules to Regulate Risk
text: Sheila C. Bair looks to be leading the regulatory race to the top. The agency she oversees, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, recently unveiled a handful of clever ideas to contain risky bank behavior and protect the nation’s deposit insurance fund. Rival watchdogs fighting for turf will find it difficult to ignore the F.D.I.C.’s latest tactics.

headline: Home Fires: I Wanted to Be a Hero
text: Not too many weeks ago, I was honorably discharged from the Army. There was no fanfare, no hail and farewell party, no speeches. I finished out my eight-year enlistment with the Reserves quietly, simply having done my part, including a year-long combat tour in Iraq in 2003 and 2004.

headline: Art in Review
text: ‘THE PERPETUAL DIALOGUE’

headline: Still a Renegade After All These Years
text: It helps to think of time as cyclical, or at least non-Western and nonlinear, when encountering Joan Jonas’s “Mirage” at the Museum of Modern Art. The latest installation of a piece conceived in 1976, it suggests that Ms. Jonas’s art has a longer-than-usual lifespan because it’s constantly being reborn.

headline: Despite Aiding U.S., Iraqi Is Denied a Green Card
text: CHICAGO  Nada Alkhaddar spends her days at the Muslim Women Resource Center helping refugees and immigrants deal with government and commercial bureaucracies that can make life in the United States seem about as easy as computing the Alternative Minimum Tax.

headline: Cuba: American Not a Spy, U.S. Says
text: An unidentified American contractor arrested last month in Cuba for distributing communications equipment on the island was aiding a religious and cultural group and was not engaged in espionage activity, his employer, Development Alternatives Inc., said Thursday. A State Department spokesman, Philip J. Crowley, also denied Cuban claims that the man was a spy, Reuters reported.

headline: NBC Wants Leno Back in Old Slot
text: Faced with the failure of the biggest recent gamble in television, NBC is shuffling its late-night deck one more time.

headline: Kashmir: Gun Battle Kills 4
text: A 20-hour gun battle prompted by a deadly militant attack on a police outpost in Srinagar, in Indian-controlled Kashmir, ended Thursday after the police killed two militants, including a Pakistani citizen, Indian police officials said. A policeman and a civilian were killed, and 10 people were wounded. Kuldeep Khoda, the police chief of Jammu and Kashmir, said both militants belonged to Lashkar-e-Taiba, the terrorist group based in Pakistan that has been blamed for the 2008 attacks on Mumbai.

headline: Potential Ford Senate Bid Sets Off Scramble
text: The New York political world reacted swiftly and strongly to the possibility of Harold Ford Jr.’s candidacy for the United States Senate, with top Senate leaders trying to squash the bid and close advisers to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg meeting with Mr. Ford on Thursday to plot strategy for a campaign.

headline: Seeking Greener Pastures
text: PERRI CESARELLI gets up at 5:30 a.m., takes the dog out, eats breakfast, showers, dresses, then, at 7:05 walks the 12 minutes to the train station in Little Neck, N.Y., leaving herself a five-minute buffer before catching the 7:22 into Manhattan.

headline: F.B.I. Seizes Passport of Queens Man Scrutinized in Plot
text: F.B.I. agents on Thursday seized the passport of a Queens man who came under intense scrutiny last year during the investigation of an airport shuttle bus driver who was charged in a Qaeda bomb plot, law enforcement officials and the man’s lawyer said.

headline: Meet the Dude
text: Would the Dude be the Dude if not for Jeff Bridges? It’s a question academics in the burgeoning field of Lebowski studies should ponder and one you can pose to Mr. Bridges himself this Saturday at the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Mr. Bridges, whose performance in “Crazy Heart” is being touted this year for an Oscar, will be on hand to discuss his long career, including his portrayal of the Dude in “The Big Lebowski” (1998) and his breakout in “The Last Picture Show.” That 1971 Peter Bogdanovich movie will be screened following the discussion.

headline: Binge on Jazz
text: Winter Jazzfest, Nate Chinen writes, “is for the moment the only real mainstream jazz festival in New York, and its lineup amounts to a temperature reading of the scene at ground level, where it’s most vibrant and volatile.” At five Greenwich Village clubs this weekend you can hear how “the aesthetic center of the music has broadened and loosened, yielding to many different strategies of rhythm, harmony and texture.” Check out the new wave of hybrid acts like Vijay Iyer, who will appear with his trio and whose “Historicity” “was the consensus pick among critics for best jazz album of 2009” as well as Darcy James Argue’s Secret Society, “an ultramodern big band,” the violinist Jenny Scheinman, the Claudia Quintet and more.

headline: That’s Bull
text: It may come as a surprise, but P.B.R. doesn’t just stand for a brand of beer beloved by hipsters; it’s also the initials of the Professional Bull Riders. Fans of either, or both, should head this weekend to the 2010 bull-riding invitational at Madison Square Garden. Converging on the Garden floor Friday through Sunday: 700 tons of dirt, the top 45 bull riders in the country and 2,000-pound bulls. Grab your cowboy hat and boots; ironic stance is optional. Tickets start at $10.

headline: Arenas Image Is Pulled; Questions Are Raised
text: As professional sports leagues have moved deeper into the information media business  starting blogs, Web sites and television networks  they have taken on the look and feel of outlets run by fans and private news media outlets.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Gambling Concerns Prompt an N.B.A. Team to Act
text: Before the Washington Wizards had a gun problem, they had a gambling problem  a high-stakes card game that ended in acrimony, threats and ultimately a locker-room showdown that has thrust the franchise into chaos.

headline: Seeing Old Age as a Never-Ending Adventure
text: OCALA, Fla.  Ilse Telesmanich, 90, sprained her ankle hiking in South Africa last August. She tried to keep going on the three-week trip, she said, hobbled as she was.

headline: Weak Heart
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Friday and Saturday crosswords are not for the weak of heart, but if you’re not working through them yet, you’ll get there in time. They’re satisfying in a different way than the themed puzzles that appear Monday through Thursday. Like a good single-malt scotch, perhaps, it’s an acquired taste that you gradually grow into and then get to feel smug and sophisticated. With crosswords, there is little definitive evidence of a link to liver problems, but please solve responsibly.

headline: Deal Made to Monitor Brooklyn Hospital
text: New York City, the Justice Department and lawyers representing mentally ill patients at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, where a 49-year-old woman died in 2008 while waiting for treatment, said on Thursday that they had reached an agreement allowing the Department of Justice and the suit's plaintiffs to monitor conditions at the hospital.

headline: Timeline: 3-D Cinema
text: A look at some of the milestones in 3-D film over the years.

headline: Half of States See Dip in Under-18 Population
text: Maine, Michigan, North Dakota and Vermont had net losses of about one in 10 of their young people from 2000 to 2009, as the populations of Northeastern and Midwestern states continued to age faster than those in the Sun Belt, according to new Census Bureau data.

headline: Meters Bring Hardship, Washington Cabbies Say
text: WASHINGTON  A year and a half after meters were installed in taxis here, cabdrivers have seen their income drop 30 percent or more, representatives from the drivers’ associations said Thursday at a City Council hearing.

headline: Top 3-Point Shooter From Downtown Plays in Upper Manhattan
text: There was a garbage can playing the part of a defender along the right part of the 3-point stripe. Noruwa Agho crouched over, the basketball in his hands. He made a quick dart to his left and released a rainbow from beyond the arc that swished through the net.

headline: 2nd Chief Pleads Guilty in Surrogate Case
text: ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio  An Ohio police chief pleaded guilty Thursday to a reduced charge in a case in which another chief was convicted of stealing items from the home of a surrogate mother for the movie stars Matthew Broderick and Sarah Jessica Parker.

headline: Eight Years Later
text: President Obama was right to take responsibility for the near-catastrophic Christmas Day terrorist plot. The buck, as always, must stop with the president. And it was a relief to hear him candidly acknowledge widespread failures in the vast and vastly expensive intelligence and homeland security system and insist that his administration do better. It must.

headline: The Work of War, at a Fever Pitch
text: LOVE is a drug, and so too is war in Kathryn Bigelow’s visceral and morally urgent “Hurt Locker.” A story about men and battle and the murderous highs of violence, the film is set in the Iraq of 2004, the year that the torture photographs from Abu Ghraib were revealed to the world, the year that four American contractors were murdered in Falluja, the year that the American military death toll reached 1,000. Written by a journalist, Mark Boal, who based the story on his experiences covering Iraq, it centers on a crew of technicians who spend their dusty days and eerie nights in and around Baghdad disarming bombs.

headline: Inspired by Bird, Gallinari Boosts the Knicks
text: A few days ago Donnie Walsh handed Danilo Gallinari, the Knicks’ promising young forward, a DVD that could alter the trajectory of his career. Walsh, the Knicks’ president, gave Gallinari a collection of Larry Bird highlights, a captivating 30-minute compilation highlighting many of Bird’s best moves, passes, post-ups and rebounds.

headline: Executive’s New Studio Teams Up With Yahoo
text: The former NBC entertainment co-chairman Ben Silverman has lined up his first distributor, Yahoo, for his new studio, which he says will specialize in creating shows in concert with advertisers.

headline: Boy and Beasts, Human and Not
text: MOST of the action in “Where the Wild Things Are” takes place on an island of monsters, who roar their terrible roars and gnash their terrible teeth and, above all, try to work out their terrible emotional issues in the presence of a young boy named Max.

headline: Selig Says He Is Open to Considering a U.S.-Japan World Series
text: For decades, the Japanese have been clamoring for a real World Series that pits the best team in Major League Baseball against the best team in Japan.

headline: Mary Gardiner Jones, Consumer Advocate, Dies at 89
text: Mary Gardiner Jones, a prominent consumer advocate who as a member of the Federal Trade Commission in the 1960s and early ’70s helped expand its purview to ensure that the stuff of American life  from clothing to cereal to cigarettes  was safer, less expensive and more truthfully advertised, died on Dec. 23 at her home in Washington. She was 89.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a possible bid by Harold Ford Jr., a former congressman from Tennessee, for the Senate seat held by Kirsten E. Gillibrand misstated, in some editions, the amount of money Ms. Gillibrand had raised as of Oct. 1, the amount Mr. Ford raised during his run for a Senate seat in Tennessee in 2006, and the percentage of Mr. Ford’s total that came from New York. Ms. Gillibrand had raised $5.5 million as of Oct. 1, not $4 million; Mr. Ford raised $15 million in 2006, not $20 million; and a fifth, not a quarter, of that total came from New York. The article also referred incorrectly to the election of Hillary Rodham Clinton, who held the Senate seat before Ms. Gillibrand. Mrs. Clinton was elected 10 months after she moved to New York, not two years, and she moved to New York from Washington, not from Arkansas.

headline: The News Is Bad, the Bearers Stoic
text: It is a lazy summer day in a quiet New Jersey neighborhood decorated with yellow ribbons and American flags in Oren Moverman’s “The Messenger.” At an adjacent Army post Capt. Tony Stone (Woody Harrelson) and Sgt. Will Montgomery (Ben Foster) work as a team for the Army’s casualty notification service, bringing the news to families when a loved one has died in Iraq.

headline: Corrections
text: The Experience Necessary feature in some editions on Tuesday, about the master printer at Bowne & Company Stationers at the South Street Seaport Museum, misstated his surname in a passage in which he pointed out that his name is an anagram for Barrow Renter, and that he rents an apartment on Barrow Street. As the introduction to the article noted, he is Robert Warner, not Warren.

headline: President Is Said to Decide to Renominate Six Choices
text: President Obama will renominate Dawn Johnsen to lead the Justice Department’s powerful Office of Legal Counsel, along with his choices for five other jobs that the Senate did not act on last year, a White House official said Thursday.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Dec. 2 about Shaya Boymelgreen, a star of the New York real estate boom who has fallen on hard times, misstated part of the address of one of his apartment projects, in Brooklyn’s Dumbo neighborhood. It is at 42 Main Street, not 402. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message this week.

headline: Corrections
text: The Advertising column on Thursday, about Consumer Reports’ review of 15 infomercial products, erroneously attributed a distinction to the PedEgg, a foot callous remover that the magazine recommended. PedEgg was one of two items recommended  not “the only item that passed muster.” (The Magic Jack, a phone device using voice over Internet protocol, was the other.)

headline: After Super Bowl Catch, Tyree Is Just Hanging On
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Kelley Washington was at the Baltimore Ravens’ training facility the day the man with the Velcro helmet walked in. This could have been an awkward moment. After all, Washington was standing on the New England sideline two years ago, the night that man, David Tyree, wedged the football against his helmet to extend the Giants’ winning drive in Super Bowl XLII and ruin the Patriots’ bid for a perfect season.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about SeeClickFix.com, a Web site that lets residents communicate with local government officials, misstated its use in The Local blogs at NYTimes.com. Only the blogs that cover communities in New Jersey use SeeClickFix; The Local blogs in Brooklyn do not use it.

headline: Corrections
text: A Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about Nick Saban’s place in history alongside Alabama’s past football coaches, misstated, in some editions, the circumstances under which Coach Gene Stallings left the program after the 1996 season. He resigned; he was not fired.

headline: Arrest of a Pediatrician Followed Years of Complaints
text: The Delaware pediatrician who prosecutors say may have molested more than 100 patients showed a pattern of inappropriate touching that led to multiple complaints from patients and co-workers, according to court documents released this week.

headline: Corrections
text: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the 1965 Orange Bowl game, between Alabama and Texas, the same teams that played in the Bowl Championship Series title game on Thursday night, misstated the given name of a tackle who helped stop Alabama’s Joe Namath at the goal line on the game’s pivotal play. He is Diron Talbert, who played at Texas from 1964 to 1966  not Don, his brother, who played there from 1959 to 1961. The error was repeated on Thursday in a Sports of The Times column about Namath’s memories of the game.

headline: Arenas Suspension Has Limited Benefit to Wizards
text: The recent news surrounding Gilbert Arenas has generated a lot of questions.

headline: Corrections
text: A dance review on Thursday about Pacific Northwest Ballet, at the Joyce Theater, misidentified the work described as “too conscious of its effectiveness, too short of inner life” while at the same time “its skill of construction, all sharply timed to the Reich score, is something rare today.” That work is “3 Movements” by Benjamin Millepied  not “Opus 111” by Twyla Tharp, another work on the program.

headline: The Official Word to All, Get a Swine Flu Vaccination Now
text: Citing mistakes made in the 1957 flu pandemic, federal officials on Thursday urged hesitant Americans to get vaccinated now against swine flu to prevent any possibility of another wave of illness and deaths.

headline: Jets Are Riding an Arctic Blast to Cincinnati
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Behind the Jets’ locker room at their practice facility is a room filled with equipment, and behind that is a storage room that on Thursday was stacked with bags, boxes and crates that were about to be loaded on a leased 26-foot truck bound for Cincinnati.

headline: Corrections
text: An appraisal on Dec. 31 about David Levine, the caricaturist for The New York Review of Books who died on Dec. 29, may have left the incorrect impression that the Russian writer Aleksandr Pushkin, the subject of one of Mr. Levine’s drawings, was homosexual. The description of Pushkin as “a gay man” was a reference to his demeanor, not his sexual orientation.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: A Push for Cleaner Air
text: Between them, the Obama administration and the federal courts have reversed most of the Bush administration’s wrongheaded environmental regulations. But a few bad rules linger on the books, among them an inadequate health standard governing harmful ozone, which most people call smog.

headline: Spineless in California
text: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California was on the mark when he said this week that the state needed to change policies that spend more money on prisons than on the state’s once-vaunted higher education systems, which are being bled to death in budget cuts. But Mr. Schwarzenegger was way off the mark when he suggested that the answer was to privatize prison services or to pass yet another constitutional amendment, this time to limit prison spending.

headline: Avatars Don’t Smoke
text: Somewhere in the afterlife’s screening room, Will Hays, architect of Hollywood’s old Production Code, and the stern Catholic bishops of the Legion of Decency are probably sharing a chuckle, maybe over Scotch and cigarettes. Why? The recent fuss over “Avatar,” the James Cameron film in which the latest in cinematic technology meets the oldest argument in the movies: whether vice on screen encourages vice in real life.

headline: When Museums Sell Art to Raise Cash
text: To the Editor:

headline: For the Democrats, a Struggle to Hold Seats
text: To the Editor:

headline: As the Senate Turns
text: To the Editor:

headline: Term Limits on the New York State Legislature
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bubbles and the Banks
text: Health care reform is almost (knock on wood) a done deal. Next up: fixing the financial system. I’ll be writing a lot about financial reform in the weeks ahead. Let me begin by asking a basic question: What should reformers try to accomplish?

headline: The Messiah Complex
text: Readers intending to watch the movie “Avatar” should know that major events in the plot are revealed.

headline: The Not-So-Secrets of the Temple
text: Pittsburgh

headline: Give These Donors a Bone
text: EVERY year, more than 100,000 Americans discover that they have often life-threatening blood and bone-marrow diseases like leukemia. For many, the only hope is a transplant of blood-producing marrow cells.

headline: Montreal Expos, Forgotten by Many, Are Reuniting in Cooperstown
text: There is an episode of “Newhart,” the 1980s sitcom set at a lodge in Vermont, in which George the handyman considers which baseball team to root for. The Montreal Expos were somewhat local, but they would not do.

headline: New Standards for Rail Cars
text: Passenger trains must be manufactured to better withstand collisions under a federal rule to take effect in March that follows fatal accidents in New Jersey, Indiana and Maryland. Manufacturers like Bombardier Inc. must meet the new standards for trains sold to Amtrak and American commuter railroads. The rule requires stronger front-end frames on new passenger railcars and some locomotives to help prevent their collapsing or telescoping on impact.

headline: A Cultural Bounty
text: The first half of January has become a time for a bountiful array of theater, music and dance festivals in New York City.

headline: And on Your Left ... Never You Mind
text: WASHINGTON  Security rules imposed after the Christmas Day bombing attempt may diminish another one of the gee-whiz aspects of flying, the moments when the captain plays tour guide, pointing out landmarks to the passengers.

headline: Scathing Report on the Killing of 4 Officers
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In an often-blistering report of a shootout last March that left four police officers in nearby Oakland dead, an independent board there has found that commanding officers made a series of hasty and ill-advised decisions that may have contributed to the death toll.

headline: In Cuba’s Time Capsule, an Automotive Legacy
text: An article last Sunday about the Depósito del Automóvil, Cuba’s antique auto museum, referred incorrectly to a car in the collection. It is a replica of a Maserati racecar driven by Juan Manuel Fangio, the five-time world champion, in 1957, not 1960.

headline: A Special Visa Program Benefits Abused Illegal Immigrants
text: She was 14 when her mother smuggled her into Los Angeles. She met her future husband, a legal resident, two years later.

headline: A Foreclosure Crisis Rooted, the Family Says, in Predatory Lending
text: Giuseppa Bagnarol, 82, was in her final hours in August, dying at home surrounded by the large family she presided over as matriarch.

headline: Word of the Day | cerebration
text: cerebration •\ˌser-ə-ˈbra-shən\• noun

headline: Robert M. White Jr.
text: Mr. White, 45, is the founder and president of Real Capital Analytics, a Manhattan-based market research company that tracks commercial real estate sales and trends globally.

headline: Corrections
text: A caption last Friday with an article about Argonne National Laboratory’s shift from radioactivity to supercomputers referred incorrectly to the Experimental Boiling Water Reactor at the laboratory. The reactor was dismantled and its components removed almost 14 years ago; it is not scheduled to be dismantled.

headline: For Those Who Want to Play the Field
text: Included on my list of New Year’s resolutions was an old favorite: a commitment to drink less  particularly on weeknights, particularly wine.

headline: Alabama and Texas Battle for the National Title
text: A hard-hitting defense, an injured quarterback and an inconsistent freshman add up to a Crimson Tide championship.

headline: Sorting Out Legislation
text: The California State Legislature convened this week to begin dealing with a projected $19.9 billion budget deficit over the next 18 months, a situation Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger described as “our Katrina.” Beyond the budget, state legislators have other issues to contend with, including these three legislative proposals, all of which arise from local concerns or incidents.

headline: Way-Too-Early Top 10 for 2010
text: The celebration hasn’t even ended here at the Rose Bowl and we’re already thinking about next year. And we do realize that these rankings could change considering many teams have crucial players needing to decide their N.F.L. futures. So feel free to mock us, but here’s a way-too-early top 10 for 2010.

headline: Alabama Returns to the Top
text: PASADENA, Calif.  Texas and Alabama played a teeth-gnashing, bloody-knuckles game that fit the style of their forefathers, Alabama’s Bear Bryant and Texas’ Darrell Royal.

headline: Shivering Strawberries
text: WHO have been working all night to save their strawberry crops?

headline: A Texas Quarterback Story Line Takes a Decisive Plot Twist
text: PASADENA, Calif.  The Bowl Championship Series national title game Thursday night started with a story line of two Texas quarterbacks facing each other.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Wings Win on 51 Saves and a Last-Minute Goal
text: Ten games on Thursday, highlighted by a classic cliffhanger in Los Angeles, where the Red Wings won in a performance out of a move script. Home teams listed first:

headline: Under the Radar 2010
text: Images from some of the shows in the annual performing arts festival.

headline: News Quiz | January 8, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Arizona Concert Promoter Accused in Ponzi Scheme
text: A suburban Phoenix concert promoter has been accused of running a Ponzi scheme that bilked about 140 investors out of $25 million, federal authorities said Thursday.

headline: A Special Visa Program and Highlights from Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: Special Visa Benefits Abused Immigrants | Victims of domestic violence are often deeply reluctant to press charges, fearing retaliation or simply hoping their abusers will change. The risk of deportation only escalates the aversion to go to the police. One San Francisco woman endured such abuse, but now she legally lives in the country, thanks to what is known as a U visa — a humanitarian “island of niceness,” as one advocate called it, in a sea of restrictive United States immigration laws.

headline: A Star Returns and So Do the Cheers
text: All apparently is forgiven for Jon Scheyer, the local basketball star. One of the most decorated prep players in Illinois history from 2003 to 2006, Scheyer was often booed during his senior year at Glenbrook North High School after announcing he would attend Duke University instead of the University of Illinois.

headline: Lawyer Wants Oversight for Hiring
text: The lawyer responsible for federal oversight of hiring by the City of Chicago and Cook County now wants an independent monitor to patrol the personnel decisions of state government, too.

headline: How Has the ‘Digital Fishbowl’ Complicated Your Love Life?
text: Does Facebook make breaking up harder to do? Have you ever had an awkward moment in a relationship because of a text, e-mail or shared photo? A Style article this week looks at how services like these that connect us also make breaking up more difficult. Do you think that’s true? Tell us about your experiences.

headline: Big Bonuses at BofA, but Overall Pool Stays Level
text: Bank of America, the biggest lender in the United States, expects to pay record bonuses to some investment bankers while keeping the overall cost of incentive compensation below previous years, a company spokesman said, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Seeking Support in the Wrong Place
text: Gov. Patrick J. Quinn may impress some Hispanic voters by nominating Manuel Flores, above, the First Ward alderman, as chairman of the Illinois Commerce Commission. But the move did not go over well with Hispanic state legislators who have repelled challengers financed by the young, ambitious alderman.

headline: Talks With Ferrero Over Cadbury Said to Fade
text: Already seen as a long-shot bidder, Italian chocolate maker Ferrero‘s interest in Cadbury has cooled as the hurdles of getting financing and finding suitable partners before the deadline becomes increasingly daunting, sources familiar with the situation told Reuters.

headline: Putting World Into Series?
text: For decades, the Japanese have been clamoring for a real world series that pits the best team in Major League Baseball against the best team in Japan.

headline: The Agony of Colt McCoy
text: PASADENA, Calif. – Colt McCoy will end his time at Texas as the career leader for victories in college football by a quarterback, with 45. But any look at his career will always have a haunting, “What if?”

headline: SocGen Sues Gundlach for Breach of Duty at TCW
text: TCW Group, the Los Angeles-based unit of Société Générale, sued the former investment chief Jeffrey Gundlach and three former employees after more than half of its fixed-income professionals joined his new firm, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Ex-Consultant Pleads Guilty in Galleon Insider Case
text: “Anil, you are a hero.”

headline: Fed Advice to A.I.G. Scrutinized
text: New revelations that the government stopped the American International Group from revealing information about its bailout had securities lawyers and policy makers buzzing on Thursday about whether the information had to be disclosed under federal securities law, and if so, what to do about the lack of compliance, Mary Williams Walsh writes in The New York Times.

headline: Bernie Ecclestone to Buy Saab?
text: The car manufacturers may be drifting out of Formula One — or should I say flooding? — but Bernie Ecclestone, the chief executive of Formula One management, has not finished with car manufacturers yet. He’s making a bid to buy Saab in a joint deal with Genni Capital, which, by the way, is the company that bought into the Renault team.

headline: Judge Tells Perelman to Pay Barkin Firm
text: In yet another chapter in the bitter divorce of Ron Perelman and the actress Ellen Barkin, a New York judge has ordered the billionaire financier to pay more than $4 million to a film development company he co-founded with his ex-wife.

headline: Twitter Jail
text: Term used to describe the account suspension of overly loquacious Twitterers.

headline: P.E. Fund-Raising Down 68% in 2009
text: Last year was miserable for private equity fund-raising in the United States. Hitting its lowest point since 2003, private equity fund-raising fell 68 percent to $95.8 billion across 331 funds, down from $300 billion across 508 funds in 2008, according to Dow Jones LP Source. No category of funds escaped the slowdown, except for secondary funds — a major outlier that saw a more than 50 percent increase in fund-raising, VentureBeat writes.

headline: Even in Bad Year, Firms Register for I.P.O.s
text: Despite the grim numbers on venture-capital-backed initial public offerings this last year, PeHub, the forum for the private equity community, says that there are 28 companies registered to price their I.P.O.s in the United States.

headline: British Banks Said to Buy Back Talent
text: London’s investment banks are luring back traders and analysts they lost to brokerage firms during the credit crisis, compensating for lower bonuses by as much as doubling base salaries, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Former Homestore Chief to Admit Fraud Conspiracy
text: The former chairman and chief executive of Homestore.com on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to conspiring to commit securities fraud in a scheme to inflate the company’s revenue to win over Wall Street analysts.

headline: Geely Mulls How to Build Volvos in China
text: Now that Geely Automotive has won the bidding for Sweden’s Volvo carmaker, China’s No. 1 private automaker is making plans to set up a local production base, sources familiar with the company told Reuters.

headline: Sensible Rules to Regulate Risk?
text: Sheila C. Bair looks to be leading the regulatory race to the top, Breakingviews says. The agency she oversees, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, recently unveiled a handful of clever ideas to contain risky bank behavior and protect the nation’s deposit insurance fund. Rival watchdogs fighting for turf will find it difficult to ignore the F.D.I.C.’s latest tactics, the publication argues.

headline: Janus Taps Pimco Executive as New Chief
text: Janus Capital Group has picked a Pacific Investment Management veteran as its chief executive, ending a months-long search for a new leader at the Denver-based stocks mutual fund firm.

headline: Change in Japan a Tough Task for Finance Minister
text: TOKYO  It sounds like a script written for Hollywood: an idealistic reformer put in charge of cleaning up his nation’s most powerful center of entrenched bureaucratic influence.

headline: Myanmar Is Reported to Sentence 2 to Death
text: BANGKOK  A court in Myanmar has sentenced a retired military officer and a Foreign Ministry official to death for leaking details of a secret trip to North Korea by top government officials, according to news reports that cited lawyers in the country.

headline: Virgin Money Gets Its Bank at Last
text: Virgin Money finally found a way into retail banking, announcing Friday that it had reached an agreement to buy Church House Trust in a deal that values the regional bank at £12.3 million ($19.7 million).

headline: Further Slide Seen in N.Y. Commercial Real Estate
text: There are 920 football fields of available office space in Manhattan. More than 180 major buildings totaling $12.5 billion in value — from Columbus Tower at 1775 Broadway to the office tower 400 Madison Avenue — are in trouble, meaning in many cases they face foreclosure or bankruptcy, or have had problems making mortgage payments.

headline: For the Moment | The Future
text: Michele Caniato is the president of Culture and Commerce, a design management consultancy, and of Material Connexion, a materials consultancy and library; both companies are based in New York.

headline: Shares End Mostly Higher, Helped by Retail Data
text: Wall Street traders set aside worries about looming interest rate increases on Thursday and focused on stronger-than-expected holiday sales, helping cement modest gains for stocks.

headline: Saturday’s N.F.L. Wild-Card Matchups
text: Jets at BengalsSaturday, 4:30 p.m. (NBC)Line: Bengals by 2 1/2

headline: In Rome, Sinful Cantucci and Other Delights
text: In Tuscany, a small chocolatier rolls out pieces of dark chocolate by hand onto slabs of marble to protect its rich aroma from heat, then molds them into half-moon-shaped cookies and bakes them in a wood-fired oven. The chocolate cantucci — a sinful take on the traditional almond biscotti — are available in central Rome, where they can be sampled, along with other regional specialties, at Paciotti Salumeria (Via Marcantonio Bragadin, 51/53; www.paciottisalumeria.it; 39-06-3973-3646), a delicatessen near the Vatican. The cantucci, which are specially baked for the Paciotti family, have some claim to being the most delicious chocolate biscuits in Rome.

headline: Sunday’s N.F.L. Wild-Card Matchups
text: Ravens at PatriotsSunday, 1 p.m. (CBS)Line: Patriots by 3 1/2

headline: Italy Puts Swiss Tax Haven Under Siege
text: Italy and Switzerland have been waging a quiet border war lately, and the picturesque town of Lugano, Switzerland, on the shores of an Alpine lake, is caught in the cross-fire, The New York Times’s John Tagliabue writes.

headline: Executive’s New Studio Teams Up With Yahoo
text: The former NBC entertainment co-chairman Ben Silverman has lined up his first distributor, Yahoo, for his new studio, which he says will specialize in creating shows in concert with advertisers, The New York Times’s Brian Stelter reported.

headline: A Safety Net That Tangles Investors
text: In the wake of a series of Ponzi schemes — the most notable being the Bernard Madoff fraud — the Securities and Exchange Commission voted last month to tighten the rules and make it much harder for money managers to misappropriate client funds, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris writes in his latest High & Low Finance column.

headline: Partners Near Default on Stuyvesant Town
text: The owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling sister complexes overlooking the East River in Manhattan, will miss a $16 million loan payment on Friday, which would put them in technical default on their mortgages, and the 20,000 residents in limbo, The New York Times’s Charles V. Bagli reported.

headline: Take 5: Cultural Doings Around the Bay
text: Wondering what to do this weekend? We’ve got you covered.

headline: New Bids Emerge for G.M.’s Saab Unit
text: Saab‘s prospects for survival hung in the balance Friday as its owner, General Motors, weighed new offers for its Swedish unit, including one backed by the billionaire Formula One racing chief Bernie Ecclestone, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing reports.

headline: Goldman Sued by Pension Fund Over Bonus Plans
text: If Goldman Sachs was hoping that furor over its bonus payouts was subsiding, the bank might be disappointed by the latest development.

headline: Homer Simpson vs. Mickey Mouse
text: Today’s idea: Disney’s animated classics are primarily visual, but “The Simpsons” are meant to be heard, says an essay parsing the distinctions between two celebrated opposites of animation.

headline: Ammunition Explodes at a House in Pakistan, Killing 7
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A house in Karachi where militants appeared to have been storing ammunition for terrorist strikes was destroyed in a deadly explosion early Friday morning, police officials said.

headline: American Said to Lift JAL Offer to $1.4 Billion
text: In the battle for control of Japan Airlines, American Airlines has apparently raised the stakes.

headline: R.B.S. Sells Fund Operations to Aberdeen
text: Royal Bank of Scotland said Friday it had agreed to sell part of its asset management businesses to Aberdeen Asset Management in its latest effort to recovery from the financial crisis.

headline: The Making of the Military’s Standard Arms
text: In a pair of posts late last year (Part 1, Part 2), this blog covered several arguments surrounding the American military’s primary rifles, the M-16 and M-4, which are also widely used by police departments, counterterrorism units and other federal agencies. (Among those using M-4 rifles are the C.I.A., the State Department and the New York Police Department.)

headline: How the World Balances Health Care Risk
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Redstone Sells Russian Theaters to Daughter
text: National Amusements, the holding company controlled by Sumner Redsone, is selling its Russian theater chain to Mr. Redstone’s daughter and other investors in a further move to reduce its debt, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Behind the Warner Bros. and Netflix Accord
text: Earlier this week, Netflix cut a deal with Warner Bros. that will delay the availability of new Warner movies to Netflix subscribers by almost a month but expand the number of older Warner films available for digital streaming.

headline: Lawson Buys Healthvision for $160 Million Cash
text: Lawson Software, a maker of business software, said Friday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Healthvision Solutions for $160 million.

headline: Sampler: Bankruptcies Up, Parking Tickets Down, Deadheads Milling in Mill Valley
text: Stricter Air Standards Proposed | The Bay Area and other urban regions would be forced to do more to reduce pollution from cars and industries if health standards for smog proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday become final. For the Bay Area, this would mean more Spare the Air days and other measures. “We are going to have to work harder at cleaning the air,” said Lisa Fasano, a spokeswoman for the nine-county Bay Area Air Quality Management District. Failure to meet federal standards can result in loss of federal highway funds. [The Contra Costa Times, The New York Times]

headline: The Newark Airport Security Breach
text: Footage of the security breach at Newark Liberty Airport on January 3.

headline: After Months of Scrutiny in Zazi Terrorism Case, Two Arrests Came as a Surprise
text: For nearly four months, since the terrorism investigation focused on a Denver airport shuttle bus driver burst into public view and he was charged in what the authorities say was an Al Qaeda bomb plot, investigators have kept close tabs on two men from his old neighborhood in Flushing, Queens.

headline: A Family Property at Risk
text: Friday’s Barbary Coast column is about a Redwood City family on the verge of losing its homestead. The property looks like a slice of Positano in Silicon Valley, peppered with three homes on a steep countryside hill. Eight people live on the grounds.

headline: Churches Attacked in Malaysian ‘Allah’ Dispute
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Three Christian churches were attacked with firebombs Friday as tensions rose in a dispute over whether Christians could use the word “Allah” in this largely Muslim nation.

headline: Speed Read for Friday, Jan. 8
text: Highlights from media coverage in today’s New York Times:

headline: Reflections on China’s Oil Sands Bid
text: State-owned companies like PetroChina are probably going to be in the market for more energy deals in Canada due to that country’s high dollar, said the former Clinton administration trade official Patrick Mulloy, a member of the United States-China Economic and Security Review Commission.

headline: U.S. Job Losses in December Dim Hopes for Quick Upswing
text: The nation lost 85,000 jobs from the economy in December, the Labor Department reported Friday, as hopes for a vigorous recovery ran headlong into the prospect that paychecks could remain painfully scarce into next year.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: A Green Preview
text: The auto industry is still in austerity mode when it comes to car shows. The North American International Auto Show in Detroit begins press previews on Monday, and according to Jim Henry, reporter for CBS Interactive, “The list of 19 brands holding a press conference is shorter than the list of 26 that aren’t.”

headline: The Early Word: Unemployment at 10%
text: With the Obama administration signaling that it intends to shift focus toward jobs and the economy, the newest unemployment figures — released this Friday morning for December — show the rate holding steady at 10 percent.

headline: Lost Decade: Reason to Expect Better?
text: At the end of 1999, the Labor Department counted 110 million private sector jobs. The figure for the end of 2009, announced today and subject to numerous revisions before we get a final figure, was 108.4 million.

headline: Court Says Swiss Order on UBS Data Broke Law
text: Update | 10:36 a.m. A Swiss court said Friday that the country’s financial regulator had broken the law when it ordered UBS to hand over data on nearly 300 clients suspected of tax evasion to United States authorities last February.

headline: C.E.S. 2010: Explosion of E-Book Readers
text: Brad Stone on the proliferation of e-book readers at this year's Consumer Electronics Show.

headline: A Conversation With Elizabeth Gilbert
text: Elizabeth Gilbert, the author of “Eat, Pray, Love,” sits down with Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, to talk about what led her to write her latest book, "Committed."

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Friday morning.

headline: New York’s Big Buildings Command Small Prices
text: There are 920 football fields of available office space in Manhattan. More than 180 major buildings totaling $12.5 billion in value — from Columbus Tower at 1775 Broadway to the office tower 400 Madison Avenue — are in trouble, meaning in many cases they face foreclosure or bankruptcy, or have had problems making mortgage payments. Rents for commercial office space fell faster over the past two years than in any other such period in the last half-century.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Geoff Johns, Comic Book Writer
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Former SAC Analyst Linked to Insider Trading Case
text: Another former employee at Steven A. Cohen’s SAC Capital has reportedly been caught up in an insider trading probe.

headline: Formula One Boss in New Bid for Saab
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: Late-Night Hosts Joke About Latest Late-Night Chaos
text: Once again, the lives of the late-night comedians provided them with plenty of fodder for their topical monologues — and for once, the focus wasn’t on David Letterman. As news broke on Thursday that NBC was planning to remove Jay Leno from his 10 p.m. time slot and return him to an 11:35 p.m. show, at least a couple of the performers affected by this move couldn’t resist joking about it in their Thursday-night acts.

headline: O Tannen-boom
text: Video | A post-holiday recycling idea:

headline: A Double Dip?
text: The American economy lost 85,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in December, according to a government report released today. This was far worse than the median forecast — which had payrolls staying flat — put out Thursday.

headline: Shares Post Small Gains Despite Weak Jobs Report
text: A grimmer-than-expected report on employment rattled Wall Street on Friday, but a late rally in industrial and energy shares helped the major indexes end the first week of 2010 in positive territory.

headline: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Losses
text: The economy lost 85,000 jobs in December, worse than most forecasters had expected.

headline: Me, Campaign? Just Go to the Film

headline: The Labor Picture in December
text: The jobs report in December was far worse than expected.

headline: In Europe and U.S., Data Shows Murky Job Outlook
text: PARIS  The euro area has joined the United States in reaching a 10 percent unemployment rate as the American economy lost more jobs than expected in December, according to statistics released Friday.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
text: The first volume of Marvel’s “Dark Avengers” series, written by Brian Michael Bendis and illustrated by Mike Deodato, enters our paperback list at No. 6 this week. This new team emerged from “Secret Invasion,” an event mini-series that pitted Marvel’s heroes against a race of alien of shapeshifters up to no good. The final blow to the alien threat was delivered by Norman Osborn, the former Green Goblin, who became admired through out the world. Alas, his bad behavior was not behind him. He assembled a team of Avengers who looked familiar – Wolverine! Spider-Man! Ms. Marvel! – but are actually super-villains. This collection, “Assemble,” chronicles their story.

headline: Asked & Answered | Charlie Le Mindu
text: Wigs will never be the same after Charlie Le Mindu. Le Mindu, a 23-year-old designer known not just for his towering wigs but also for making clothes and accessories out of human hair, has set off a craze for avant-garde hair confections in London and around the world. Recently, Lady Gaga has been turning up in Le Mindu wigs. A native of Bordeaux, France, Le Mindu also has the distinction of being the only designer at London fashion week — or any fashion week, for that matter — to put on a show focused entirely on wigs. The Moment dropped by Le Mindu’s East London loft for a chat over tea.

headline: Bad, but Still Getting Better
text: This morning’s jobs report was certainly disappointing.

headline: Michael Pollan Offers 64 Ways to Eat Food
text: How did your great grandparents ever figure out what to eat? Long before nutrition scientists began studying food, long before marketers began advertising food and long before the author Michael Pollan started writing about food, people, somehow, managed to eat more healthfully than they do now.

headline: Friday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Being Clooney: Not as Easy as It Looks
text: THERE’S no mystery, none at all, about why George Clooney is a movie star. Guys who are extremely handsome, move well, can project intelligence and humor, appear to enjoy the company of women and possess soft, deep masculine voices have historically done pretty nicely for themselves on the silver screen.

headline: As More Go Hungry, The Neediest Cases Offers Help
text: A growing number of families in the United States are having trouble putting food on the table. According to federal data, in 2009, 49 million people lacked consistent access to adequate nutrition, an increase of 13 million from 2008. Short of cash, parents are forced to make difficult decisions. To make their money stretch farther, they may buy cheaper, less nutritious foods, cut back on meals or skip meals altogether so another member of the family can eat instead. More people are relying on food stamps, but they do not always cover a family's needs. This year, safety nets like food pantries and soup kitchens have had less resources and have faced increasing demand. Below, the seven agencies supported by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund discuss how the fund helped families not go hungry.

headline: Times to Turn Over Local Brooklyn Blog to CUNY J-School
text: The New York Times is turning over day-to-day control of a blog covering parts of Brooklyn to the City University of New York Graduate School of Journalism, in what could be a model for expanding hyper-local coverage to many communities at minimal cost.

headline: Maggie, Part 2: An Insider’s View of the Indie World
text: Maggie Gyllenhaal is not just a lauded actress and an enthusiastic Brooklynite, she is also something of an expert on how indie movies get sold and marketed, as the Bagger discovered over a recent lunch (at a family-run restaurant in Brooklyn, of course). In Ms. Gyllenhaal’s latest, “Crazy Heart,” the directorial debut of Scott Cooper, an actor, she plays the love interest of Jeff Bridges’s alcoholic country singer; it also stars Robert Duvall as his old friend and features music by T-Bone Burnett. Yet it very nearly fell to the straight-to-DVD ranks before being scooped up and thrust into the Oscar race late in the year. Now Mr. Bridges is being touted as the best actor front-runner, and, in the year of the 10, the film itself is a dark horse for best picture. (But don’t expect the movie’s good fortune to be reflected in the fortunes of its couple. “Jeff always makes this joke,” Ms. Gyllenhaal said, “like, oh they’re going to get together in the sequel, and it’s going to be called ‘Crazy Liver.’ ”) Here is Part 2 of our conversation; Part 1, now updated with more answers, is here.

headline: Eat Like the King

text: Joe Sexton, metropolitan editor of The New York Times, announced a major change for City Room on Friday morning.

headline: Modcloth Shows How to Win by Losing
text: Modcloth co-founders Susan Gregg Koger (chief creative officer) and Eric Koger (chief executive) started selling vintage clothing online as undergraduates at Carnegie Mellon University. In 2005, they were too junior to compete in their school’s high-tech business plan competition, the McGinnis Venture Competition (which is listed in our guide to business plan competitions). Instead, they pitched at Colorado State University’s Venture Adventure — and lost.

headline: Now Showing | Wieki Somers On Ice
text: Perfectly apropos of the frigid winter that seems to have settled over the United States and parts of Europe, “Frozen in Time,” by Studio Wieki Somers, opens Jan. 30 at Galerie Kreo in Paris. For this exhibition — which was inspired by a major ice storm in the Netherlands in 1987 — Somers, a Dutch designer, and Dylan van den Berg, her collaborator in the studio, took everyday objects — a stool, an architect’s lamp, a vase — and covered them in UV Topcoat, a liquid resin that hardens, or “freezes,” when exposed to sunlight, making the objects appear to be covered with a thick glaze of ice. For Somers, the subject was irresistible. “The half-transparent ice connected things in a matter-of-fact and extremely poetic way,” she explained in the news release for the exhibition. It also added another layer of meaning to familiar objects — an idea that permeates Somers’s work, like the Bathboat, a bathtub with the exterior of a rowboat, or the High Tea Pot, which is cast in porcelain from a pig’s skull. “Frozen in Time” runs until March 20.

headline: TV Calendar: New Shows in the New Year

headline: Meet the ‘Wheel of Fortune’ Player Who Didn’t Say ‘Self-Potato’

But Michael Newman, who recently accomplished the feat on an episode of “Wheel of Fortune,” feels a bit conflicted about his windfall: he’s the contestant who gave the correct response of “self-portrait” only after a rival player, Lolita McAuley, buzzed in first and gave the now-famous answer of “self-potato.”

headline: Crystalline Affliction
text: In myths and fairy tales, characters frequently shapeshift. Arachne becomes a spider. Midas’ daughter turns to gold. A frog winds up a prince. These stories speak to a persistent human concern: Our lives as we know them are temporary, subjected to merciless change. Merciless change is on full display in “The Girl With Glass Feet,” Ali Shaw’s fantastically imagined first novel. The story is as straightforward as the title suggests: Ida Maclaird, the book’s protagonist, has feet that are turning to glass.

headline: Love in the Time of Genocide
text: Kim Echlin’s novel “The Disappeared” contains many elements that might doom a lesser book: the deaths of multiple characters (among them the narrator’s baby); an unabashedly effusive love story; a mix of first- and second-person narration; and, as a setting, the bones and ashes of the Cambodian genocide, which claimed approximately 1.7 million lives between 1975 and 1979. Yet the book manages to be spellbinding.

headline: Return of the King
text: Maybe there’s no need to ask why a biographer of Jenny Uglow’s caliber and aesthetic interests — George Eliot, William Hogarth and Elizabeth Gaskell are just a few of her fortunate subjects — would take up the oft-told tale of Charles II’s restoration to the British throne. It’s a great story: The boy king, in exile after his father’s execution in a populist uprising, grows up to return as monarch, only to face epochal disasters like the plague and the Great Fire of London. Throw in the handsome king’s wandering eye (poor barren Queen Catherine had to put up with Charles’s bankrolling of one mistress after another, as well as the welcoming to court of his illegitimate children); an ABC of conniving ministers (Arlington, Buckingham, Clarendon); and a cluster of brilliant minds (Hobbes and Locke, Milton and Marvell, Newton, Dryden and the inveterate diarist Pepys), and it’s clear why chronicling this vital era became irresistible. But Uglow does more than narrate the dramatic events of the Restoration, a period known, not coincidentally, for its theater, which often parodied royal affairs.

headline: Houston, We Have a Problem
text: Many books have been published to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the 1969 landing of the first men on the moon. Wayne Biddle’s “Dark Side of the Moon” is not celebratory. As the title suggests, it is a deeply skeptical account of the early life and career of Wernher von Braun, who played a key role in the German rocket program before and during World War II. Von Braun was brought to America in 1945 and was later the leader in developing the Saturn V booster rocket that launched the Apollo 11 mission into space. A NASA Web site describes him as “without doubt, the greatest rocket scientist in history.”

headline: Home Tool
text: I had a revelation recently: a woman’s place is not in the home; it’s from the home! The good old home, with its dishes and dust, is, history has shown, not quite satisfying in itself. But maybe it’s a headquarters! In fact, turn your attention away from the kitchen and the bedrooms to the laptops, the cable, the e-readers, the smartphones, the high-speed triple-play tangle. Tricked out with telecommunications that could have serviced all of I.B.M. in 1950, the bourgeois home has become a woman’s base of operations. Try it: “Hi, boss. Today I’m staying home. Staying from home. I’m working from home.”

headline: Deconstructing Dubai: Considering Questions Posed By the New World’s Tallest Building
text: Overview | On January 4, Dubai officially became the home of the world’s tallest building. What does the Burj Khalifa represent and mean for Dubai? In this lesson, students consider the culture and landscape of Dubai and the significance of the Burj Khalifa. Then, depending on the activities you choose, they further investigate Dubai and its people, or research and critique buildings that are familiar to them, reflecting on their local or national significance.

headline: Nuclear Monopolist
text: Early in the morning of Aug. 29, 1949, a mushroom cloud soared up over the Kazakh deserts. The Soviets had detonated their first atomic bomb, a thrilling feat of engineering and physics. The man who had supervised the effort, the pitiless chief of the secret police, Lavrenti Beria, raced to telephone Stalin. But when the leader came on the line he declared that he already knew and hung up.

headline: Blood Ties
text: Twelve books into a series of mysteries set in England in the aftermath of World War I, the mother and son who team-write under the name of Charles Todd keep finding new ways to gauge the emotional effects of war on the living and the half-dead. The story behind THE RED DOOR (Morrow/­HarperCollins, $24.99) is so sad, the book should come with a warning sticker. It begins in Hobson, a village in Lancashire, on the day after the Armistice is signed — at the 11th hour on the 11th day of the 11th month of the year 1918 — when Florence Teller hits on a suitable gesture to welcome her husband home from the war, painting the gray front door of their house “a vibrant and glorious red.”

headline: The Americanization of Mental Illness
text: AMERICANS, particularly if they are of a certain leftward-leaning, college-educated type, worry about our country’s blunders into other cultures. In some circles, it is easy to make friends with a rousing rant about the McDonald’s near Tiananmen Square, the Nike factory in Malaysia or the latest blowback from our political or military interventions abroad. For all our self-recrimination, however, we may have yet to face one of the most remarkable effects of American-led globalization. We have for many years been busily engaged in a grand project of Americanizing the world’s understanding of mental health and illness. We may indeed be far along in homogenizing the way the world goes mad.

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this article posted online misstated the country where Vestas, a wind-turbine producer, is based. It is Denmark, not Spain. It also misstated the number of turbines to be built in a project off the British coast and the name of a group that estimated the pace of construction. The project is to total about 6,000 turbines, not 1,000, and the forecast came from Carbon Trust, a group financed by the British government. (Carbon Trust Investments is its venture-capital arm.)

headline: Paperback Row
text: LARK AND TERMITE,  by Jayne Anne Phillips (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) A young soldier dies in Korea in 1950 while his wife gives birth back home; nine years later, in West Virginia, their profoundly disabled yet “beautiful and calm” son is lovingly cared for by his half-sister. In this novel, a 2009 National Book Award finalist, Phillips tells their story from alternating points of view with rich language and deep sympathy. “This is the alchemy of great fiction,” Kathryn Harrison wrote in the Book Review. “The fantastic dream that’s created . . . is one the reader enters without ever looking back.”

headline: Chad Ochocinco, the N.F.L. Leader in Attention
text: Plenty of people see Cincinnati Bengals receiver Chad Ochocinco as a self-indulgent mocker of the N.F.L.’s rules and traditions. He offered a dollar bill to an official during one game this season and donned a sombrero and a poncho after a touchdown in another. Those stunts cost him $50,000 in fines from the league.

headline: With B.C.S. Done, Spring Must Be Near
text: The trickiest thing about college football’s supposed championship is how impossible it is to live up to its built-in expectations. After more than a month of blather and speculation, of head coach worship and quarterback coronations, of baying at multiple full moons, it makes the Super Bowl look like an instantly conceived pickup game by comparison. So when you hang with all that and still care on Jan. 7 and are handed a complete deflation five Texas snaps into the game, it really makes you want a refund. For something. Your microwave popcorn. Anything.

headline: Sci-Fi Films Oscar-Worthy? Discuss
text: One of the (stated) reasons that the Academy moved to 10 best picture nominees this year is to include more populist fare. (The unstated reasons, as Michael Cieply explores in a piece in this weekend’s special Oscar section, have more to do with boosting the telecast’s sagging TV ratings.) Movies like “Star Trek,” which made both box-office-watchers and critics happy, would seem tailor-made for the 10. And “Star Trek” did get one of the 10 slots on the Producers Guild of America ballots, alongside another sci-fi favorite, “District 9.” But, with a few exceptions, like “The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring,” the Academy has historically shown little love to films that explore the futuristic great beyond, the could-have-been past or the alternate-reality present. It’s not quite as strong as those fogies’ anti-comedy bias, but it’s there.

headline: Replacement Costs
text: When I checked into a hotel in California, I was starving, so I ate the $6 box of Oreos from the minibar. Later that day, I walked down the street to a convenience store, bought an identical box for $2.50 and replenished the minibar before the hotel had a chance to restock it. Was this proper? My view is “no harm, no foul.” In fact, my box was fresher: the Oreos I ate were going to expire three months before the box I replaced them with. DAVID LAT, NEW YORK

headline: Semantic Time Travel
text: At a glance, it’s obvious that the Historical Thesaurus of the Oxford English Dictionary, published in the fall to worldwide lexicographic acclaim, took a lot of work. The two thick blue volumes sort roughly 920,000 words into 797,120 meanings and organize those meanings into 236,400 numbered categories and subcategories. Like Peter Mark Roget’s famous thesaurus, first issued in 1852, the H.T.O.E.D. not only lists synonyms but also provides what its editors call a “modified folk taxonomy” of English’s meanings — carefully placing deity, for example, among the supernatural elements of the external world, while slotting worship among the manifestations of faith in the social world. It draws on the second edition of the Oxford English Dictionary, as well as a few Old English sources. The task of dicing up the O.E.D. and reassembling it into the H.T.O.E.D. took 44 years, and most of the intellectual labor was performed by humans, working with pencils and slips of paper. A 1978 fire would have proved disastrous if the slips had not been stored in metal drawers in metal filing cabinets.

headline: Youth Quake
text: In your new film, “Youth in Revolt,” you play the sort of charmingly reticent and tongue-tied character we know from your roles in “Juno,” “Superbad” and the television series “Arrested Development.” How does it feel to be the poster boy for awkward adolescence? I don’t value it particularly, but, I mean, it’s nice that people are going and seeing the movies.

headline: Going Cyborg
text: On my birthday a few years ago, I taught class, called the guy I was sleeping with and then became a cyborg. I didn’t know I was becoming a cyborg. I thought I was just getting a new leg. I’ve had 12 artificial legs in my life. The prosthetist said this leg would think 1,000 times per second about the ground. My parents said if I wanted the new leg, I better act fast. I was being released from their insurance. The guy I was sleeping with, Henry, said the new leg sounded hot, like something out of “Blade Runner.” But I had never seen “Blade Runner.”

headline: Prisoners of Parole
text: IN 2004, STEVEN ALM, a state trial judge in Hawaii, was frustrated with the cases on his docket. Nearly half of the people appearing before him were convicted offenders with drug problems who had been sentenced to probation rather than prison and then repeatedly violated the terms of that probation by missing appointments or testing positive for drugs. Whether out of neglect or leniency, probation officers would tend to overlook a probationer’s first 5 or 10 violations, giving the offender the impression that he could ignore the rules. But eventually, the officers would get fed up and recommend that Alm revoke probation and send the offender to jail to serve out his sentence. That struck Alm as too harsh, but the alternative — winking at probation violations — struck him as too soft. “I thought, This is crazy, this is a crazy way to change people’s behavior,” he told me recently.

headline: The Right Hand of the Fathers
text: I am writing to clarify the context of a quotation from me in David D. Kirkpatrick’s excellent article (Dec. 20, 2009) on Robert George. I did call Professor George a “Rambo Catholic” and an “ecclesiastical bully” in a post on the Mirror of Justice blog written in the context of the 2004 presidential elections. But not for criticizing pro-choice Catholics, as the article suggests. Instead, I found it objectionable that Professor George cast aspersions on the good faith of pro-life Catholics, like myself, who on occasion vote for pro-choice politicians to prevent other great harms to our nation, not to advance abortion rights.

headline: The Lives They Lived
text: When the Persian Gulf war started in 1990, I was working as a volunteer at a refugee shelter in Brownsville, Tex. With only a small stipend for personal expenses, I was unable to even think about going to an antiwar rally in Washington, scheduled for January 1991. That’s where Peg Mullen came in. News traveled around the community that the woman about whom “Friendly Fire” was written was chartering a bus for anyone who wanted to attend the rally. She filled that bus, at no cost to me and others who wanted to raise their voices in opposition. Before I read Sara Corbett’s essay, I had all but forgotten that moment and would not have been able to recall Mullen’s name. The endless bus trip, the solidarity, the cold and the crowd all come back to me now. It was a small act in a lifetime of actions. Thank you for reminding me of this grieving woman who, bolstered by anger and anguish, did more than her part to bring peace in our time. Holland, Mich.

headline: How I Earned My Wings Back

By the time he was perched on one knee and presenting an engagement ring, I feared it was too late to tell the love of my life that we had been brought together not by fate but as a result of my nationwide crusade to find a pilot.

headline: The B King Takes His Place on the a List
text: “WHAT took you so long?” was the question posed, semi-rhetorically, by Jonathan Demme to the assembled multitude at the Governors Dinner of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Nov. 14. Mr. Demme was on hand to present a special Oscar to his old mentor, the 83-year-old producer and director Roger Corman, whose prolific career in low-budget exploitation cinema was being recognized, at last, by the industry establishment that for most of his long working life he’d had precious little to do with. If you make even the most cursory check of the honoree’s filmography, the answer to Mr. Demme’s question might appear to be blindingly obvious: Directors whose résumés include titles like “Attack of the Crab Monsters,” “Teenage Caveman” and “The Saga of the Viking Women and Their Voyage to the Waters of the Great Sea Serpent” tend to have to wait a while for their Oscar.

headline: Comparing the House and Senate Health Care Bills
text: Now that the House and Senate are trying to reconcile their separate health care bills, it seems worthwhile to compare the two bills on the elements most important to small businesses. There are crucial differences between the two. In general, small companies — or at least the most self-interested among them — are likely to prefer the Senate bill, which is more lenient on employers and insurers alike. Employees and those most concerned about the integrity of the reforms — whether they’ll actually do what they’re supposed to do — are likely to gravitate toward the House version.

headline: They Really Like Me
text: ONLY three men (and, needless to say, no women) have won more than two Oscars for directing: Frank Capra, John Ford and William Wyler. A look at their winners  all have been issued on home video, though “The Best Years of Our Lives” is out of print  suggests how the taste of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has developed since its founding in 1927. The first Oscar ceremony, in 1929, when awards were given for films made in 1927 and 1928, was the first and last time the academy awarded two prizes for best direction, one for comedy (to Lewis Milestone for “Two Arabian Knights”) and one for drama (Frank Borzage for “7th Heaven”).
