(To see the report, go to The Oakland Tribune site.)

headline: Biden’s Mother Dies
text: Catherine Eugenia Finnegan Biden, the mother of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., died on Friday in Wilmington, Del. She was 92.

headline: C.E.S. Daily Diary: Day 2
text: If you liked the first batch of products shown in our previous video, get ready for more. Today’s segment includes new navigation tech, high-design laptops and the captain’s chair from the USS Enterprise.

headline: Conan O’Brien May Have Options at Fox
text: The future of NBC’s late-night plans may wind up in Conan O’Brien’s hands.

headline: Sri Lanka’s Fields of Tea
text: Sri Lanka has carved out a niche as a supplier of high-end teas.

headline: A Rebuttal to a Cool Climate Paper
text: Richard Lindzen, the meteorology professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology best known for his longstanding rejection of research pointing to dangerous climate disruption from human-generated greenhouse gases, has been bluntly challenged over a popular paper in Geophysical Research Letters last year that he co-wrote with post-doctoral researcher Yong-Sang Choi. The paper, assessing tropical sea surface temperatures in relation to flows of energy into and out of the atmosphere, asserted that the climate system was far less sensitive to human actions than the predominant view had it.

headline: White House Awards $2.3 Billion in Tax Credits for Clean Energy Developers
text: President Obama announced on Friday the award of $2.3 billion in tax credits for clean energy manufacturing — part of a broader push by his administration to stimulate job growth during the highest period of sustained unemployment in decades.

headline: The Role of a Lifetime
text: IN the age of the character-driven television series, there was a notable passing in 2009: “Monk,” the Emmy-winning USA show about an obsessive-compulsive crime-solver, went off the air in December after eight seasons. The series, with Tony Shalhoub as Adrian Monk, was one of the earliest examples of what has since become common fare: programs built around characters who are distinctive misfits. Some of the most obvious include “House” on Fox, with Hugh Laurie as an irascible doctor; “Psych” on USA, with James Roday solving crimes via fake psychic powers; “The Closer” on TNT, with Kyra Sedgwick as a deputy police chief tackling major crimes in Los Angeles.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Time for a Reality Check
text: Over the last couple of days, we have offered our design and green previews of the 2010 North American International Auto Show, which opens to the press bright and early Monday morning. The Times’s Micheline Maynard also talks about the Detroit auto show in WJR’s Greening of the Great Lakes podcast.

headline: Dissension Splinters African-American Critics Group
text: Updated | 6:36 p.m.  “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire” was the big winner at the African American Film Critics Association in December, picking up awards for best picture, best director, best screenplay and best supporting actress, for Mo’Nique. But the film’s star, Gabourey Sidibe, was snubbed as best actress in favor of Nicole Beharie from the lesser-known “American Violet.” Following the vote, Roger Friedman of The Hollywood Reporter’s Showbiz 411 blog reported that the tally had been manipulated by the group’s president, Gil Robertson IV, to engineer a win for Ms. Beharie. In return, Mr. Friedman suggested that Mr. Robertson was to receive payments from producers affiliated with “American Violet,” and wrote that the whole issue had sparked serious infighting among the group.

headline: The Damage of Card Rewards
text: For several years, I’ve wondered whether my aggressive pursuit of credit card rewards made me a selfish consumer.

headline: Would You Give Up Your Rewards Cards?
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I discuss a small crisis of conscience about credit cards that earn rewards.

headline: If Peter Orszag Is So Smart, What Will He Do Now?
text: Washington

headline: AOL Time Warner: Spin Off Plans
text: On the 10th anniversary of the merger of AOL and Time Warner, the top executives reflect on the biggest business deal in history.

headline: A Not-So-Sharp Sharp
text: Sharp, an LCD TV pioneer, has watched its American market share sink, outpaced by Samsung, Sony and even the upstart Vizio. But the company is making no excuses.

headline: AOL Time Warner: Accounting Scandal
text: On the 10th anniversary of the merger of AOL and Time Warner, the top executives reflect on the biggest business deal in history.

headline: AOL Time Warner: Life On Its Own
text: On the 10th anniversary of the merger of AOL and Time Warner, the top executives reflect on the biggest business deal in history.

headline: Race for Kennedy’s Seat Heats Up
text: Martha Coakley, the Democrat in the race for Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s seat in Massachusetts, still has significantly more money than Scott Brown, the Republican, according to financial reports filed Thursday.

headline: Weekend Links
text: The strange case of Metropolitan Andrei Sheptyts’kyi — righteous Gentile, Nazi collaborator, or both?

headline: In Suburban Schools, an Alternative to A.P.
text: JERICHO, N.Y.  In a St. John’s University English class the other day, 10 students tackled George Orwell’s “1984” like generations of collegians before them. But while there was plenty of higher-order thinking, the class  and the students  were technically still in high school.

headline: A Plea for Doris Day, and Other Oscar Treats
text: As you ease into your weekend, the Bagger would like to recommend some light reading. The Oscar preview issue of Arts & Leisure is now online, so you can breeze though the special brand of charisma that makes Clooney go, or the groundedness that keeps Mo’Nique staying put. Anybody not embroiled in C.E.S. coverage should check out the story on the long history of 3-D filmmaking, and its surprisingly uncertain future.

headline: Video of Sri Lankan Executions Appears Authentic, U.N. Says
text: On Thursday, Philip Alston, a human rights lawyer who is the United Nations Special Rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions, said that reports by three experts he had retained to examine video that appears to show the execution of prisoners in Sri Lanka “strongly suggest that the video is authentic.”

headline: Price of Tech M.&A. Is Expected to Rise
text: Technology executives believe it will become more costly to acquire rival companies this year than in 2009, according to a survey conducted by the 451 Group, a technology investment research firm.

headline: New Rules Ease Roth Conversions, but Benefits Vary
text: Don’t be surprised if your broker calls in the next few months and asks if you have thought about converting your traditional individual retirement account to a Roth I.R.A.

headline: The Reading Life:  Rediscovering a ‘Classic of American Cantankerousness’
text: Books and blogs about hunkering down – about consuming less stuff, cultivating frugality, growing your own, even dropping off the grid entirely – have multiplied since the financial crisis began. It’s a boom time for back-to-basics pundits.

headline: Sixth Graders Get an Early Crack at High School
text: On Friday morning, wind lashed snow down a frigid East 69th Street, where some of the only light in the near-dawn darkness came from a metal food cart.

headline: In Cahoots | Patti Smith and Steven Sebring
text: In 1995, the fashion photographer Steven Sebring met the legendary rocker Patti Smith while on a shoot for Spin Magazine. Fifteen years later, the pair has collaborated on a film, a book and an exhibition, the last of which opened this week at the Robert Miller Gallery.

headline: Tri-Tip Steak With Tomato Romesco
text: Mark Bittman fries and broils an unusual cut of steak and tops it with a sauce from Catalonia.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 8
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include the last night at Tavern on the Green, inauguration day, and a defeat for supporters of same-sex marriage in New Jersey.

headline: The New Age Cavemen and the City
text: LIKE many New York bachelors, John Durant tries to keep his apartment presentable — just in case he should ever bring home a future Mrs. Durant. He shares the fifth-floor walk-up with three of his buddies, but the place is tidy and he never forgets to water the plants.

headline: Global Tables | Stellar Sushi in Barcelona
text: Since Catalonia has no important historical connection with Japan, and Spain’s main Asian colonial fandango was with the Philippines, the recent rabid popularity of Japanese food in Barcelona may be a little puzzling at first.

headline: Subaru Makes Huge Leap in Brand Perception Survey
text: It is only the end of the first week of January, but for Subaru, 2010 is already shaping up to be a very happy new year.

headline: Correction: Blowing Smoke at a Ban
text: A picture last Sunday with an article about New York nightclub patrons who flout the city’s smoking ban was published in error. The photograph of two men was taken in 2007 and is not a recent example of the numerous bars where smoking is now tolerated. The man in sunglasses, who was not identified, is the artist Jeremy Blake, who died that year.

headline: A Baby in a Snowstorm
text: On this day of spun-sugar snow in the Northeast, this guest blog arrives from Heather Rowe. She became a Mom with her life partner, Britt, for the second time during a blizzard that hit their hometown of Takoma Park, Md., the weekend before Christmas.

headline: On the Street | Coated
text: Women on the streets of New York City are finding innovative and stylish ways of keeping warm this winter.

headline: Finally, All the Beer Is His
text: Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: AOl Time Warner: Levin Departs
text: On the 10th anniversary of the merger of AOL and Time Warner, the top executives reflect on the biggest business deal in history.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Whether it’s new a jet-setter playground or a cheap, off-the-beaten-path getaway, the world of travel is constantly changing. In this Sunday’s special issue, the editors of the Travel section pick 31 Places to Go in 2010 — from the newly opened beaches of Sri Lanka to a thriving art scene in Los Angeles to a budding gay scene in Nepal. Explore an interactive map of our picks, and then tell us where you want to go in the coming year.

headline: Obama’s Terrorism Response, a la ’24’
text: For those salivating for the return of TV’s “24” and Agent Jack Bauer, the Keep America Safe organization, led by high-profile figures like Liz Cheney, doesn’t want you to wait any longer. It borrows the sounds, digital terrorism countdowns and multi-screen views from the show, transferring them into the realm of real life, Obama-style.

headline: Planned Mural Will Not Be Installed at Ground Zero
text: A planned mural that was to cover part of the construction fence at ground zero has been moved off the site, the New York City Department of Transportation confirmed on Friday. The mural was designed by the architecture firm Sage and Coombe, which was selected in a competition announced last August by the transportation department and the Port Authority.

headline: Getting There: First, Journey by Keyboard
text: In New York, the shortest distance between two points is not a straight line, it’s an express line. Those bus and subway routes can feel as much a part of the city’s geography as the rivers that divide it and the bridges that span them. But the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s recent announcement that it plans to eliminate two subway lines and dozens of bus routes will force a lot of New Yorkers to redraw their mental maps, and rethink how they get from point A to point B.

headline: Tri-Tip: A Steak Worth the Hunt
text: MY mother broiled a mean steak, but it was never better than when she was able to coax a tri-tip out of the butcher. She faced two challenges when buying this cut. First, there are only two per cow, so it is not all that common. Second, it goes by so many (often incorrect) names  California cut, Newport steak, sirloin tip, sirloin butt, culotte, bottom sirloin, top sirloin and more  that it’s sometimes a bit of work just to make it clear what you want. I prefer the term tri-tip, which I believe to be not only correct but descriptive, because the steak is triangular and is the tip of the sirloin.

headline: Tri-Tip Steak With Tomato Romesco
text: 1 tri-tip steak, about 2 to 2 1/2 pounds, or other 2-inch-thick steak

headline: Origin of the Species, From an Alien View
text: WHERE did humankind come from?

headline: Carpetbagger: Ready, Aim, Action
text: Melena Ryzik learns the art of movie combat from Anthony Mackie, star of "The Hurt Locker."

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 8
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Recession Refuge: Uncle Sam’s Payroll
text: After swelling early in the recession, government payrolls have been falling for most of the past year. In December 2009 alone, 44,000 government jobs were lost on net.

headline: H.P. Working on ‘Half-Pint’ Android Tablet
text: Update | 7:33 p.m. Includes Hewlett-Packard’s response.

headline: MSNBC: New York Times Edition
text: John Harwood of the New York Times and CNBC, discusses monthly unemployment numbers, reports on charges in the Christmas day terror plot and speaks with Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland about the 2010 elections.

headline: Remembering Hardware
text: A developmentally disabled man with an extraordinary memory has spent 58 years working in a small Brooklyn hardware store.

headline: Video: Ready, Aim, Action!
text: Melena Ryzik learns the art of movie combat from Anthony Mackie, star of “The Hurt Locker.”

headline: H.P. Develops a Netbook Petri Dish
text: Take a step back, and you’ll find Hewlett-Packard doing something a bit extra with netbooks beyond just selling them. It’s using the tiny laptops as what I’ll call beta hardware.

headline: Risks: Loss of Bone Mass Linked to Contraceptive
text: Almost half of all women who use a popular injected contraceptive lose a significant amount of bone mass within two years, and researchers now say the greatest risk is to smokers, women who don’t consume enough calcium and those who have never gone through a pregnancy.

headline: Mental Health: Deficiencies in Treatment of Depression
text: Researchers reported last week that antidepressant drugs seemed to be effective mainly in people with severe depression, not those with milder forms. Now another study is reporting that only about half of all Americans with depression receive treatment of any kind.

headline: Get Ready for Wi-Di
text: Streaming content to living room televisions from computers remains a entertainment category that still mystifies most consumers, but a couple of sophisticated new “media player” devices have surfaced at the Consumer Electronics Show this week to make the challenge, well, less challenging.

headline: For Democrats: Blood in the Water, or Just Fresh Blood?
text: Chris Dodd? Done. Byron Dorgan? Ditto. Bill Ritter? Him too. John Cherry? Out. Martha Coakley? Sleeping uneasily. Other than the apparently sempiternal Robert Byrd, is every Democrat at risk of political extinction these days?

headline: A Sri Lankan Underdog Battles Global Tea Giants
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Merrill J. Fernando’s eyes lit up one recent morning when his son Dilhan handed him a box of Twinings Pure White Tea. He quickly ripped open a tea bag and spilled its contents onto a piece of paper.

headline: Obama Takes New Route to Opposing Parts of Laws
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is lowering the volume in a long-running argument between Congress and the executive branch over when, if ever, a president has the power to bypass federal statutes he has signed into law.

headline: And the Nominees Should Be...
text: The critics make their Oscar choices.

headline: By Landing Fleet, Small Port Sets Off a Storm of Envy
text: NEWPORT, Ore.  Fishing and timber are not what they once were, and the recession has slowed the rush for second homes. So it seemed the fate of this small port was clear: more struggle.

headline: Casting New Light on Russian Works
text: On paper, the two Russian works that Alan Gilbert conducted with the New York Philharmonic in an impressive concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall might seem unlikely choices to be included in programs for the orchestra’s important tour of Europe, which begins on Jan. 17.

headline: Bizarre Year for Estate Tax Calls for Extra Planning
text: Death and taxes, the joke goes, are the only certainties in life. But when it comes to the combination of the two, the estate tax, there is only uncertainty for 2010, The New York Times’s Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column.

headline: Plan to Close California’s Budget Deficit
text: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger took his first shot at closing California’s impending $20 billion budget gap on Friday, proposing large-scale pay cuts for state workers, the elimination of several social service programs and a plan to press the federal government for more money.

headline: Another Smooth Landing for a Hero
text: “Brace for Impact: The Chesley B. Sullenberger Story” provides yet another opportunity to ponder the miracle of US Airways Flight 1549. Not the fact that an Airbus A320 was ditched in a river, and all 155 people aboard survived; that, while unlikely, was within the bounds of plausibility.

headline: Space Alien Theorist Thrives in Old Age
text: Zecharia Sitchin, 89, has written a dozen books linking man's origins to space aliens. In his own life, he is able to live out his golden years independently with the help of Manhattan's conveniences.

headline: Times Names Features Editor
text: Trish Hall, a long-time writer and editor who has led a wide range of sections at The New York Times, was promoted on Friday to assistant managing editor for features.

headline: Across Divide in Iraq, a Sunni Courts Shiites
text: RAMADI, Iraq  In the unforgiving badlands of western Iraq’s Anbar Province, once a cradle of the insurgency and now a muddled landscape of corruption, simmering strife and spirited electoral campaigning, no one seems ready to pardon Hamid al-Hais.

headline: Missouri: New Details in Gunman’s Rampage
text: Investigators provided new details about the shooting that left three people dead and five injured at an ABB Inc. transformer repair plant in St. Louis on Thursday, saying that the gunman, Timothy Hendron, 51, carried four guns and fired more than 100 rounds. Mr. Hendron, an employee who was suing the company, fatally shot himself in the head. Investigators said another handgun was recovered outside the plant. Also killed were Carlton J. Carter, 57; Terry Mabry, 55; and Cory Wilson, 27. Investigators said Mr. Hendron’s motive remained unclear.

headline: Even Intel Has an App Store Now
text: If you’re a technology giant with even a modicum of ambition, pluck and bandwagon-jumping skills, then you have to have an app store nowadays.

headline: Thousands of Wind Turbines Coming to British Seas
text: LONDON  In an ambitious bid to revamp Britain’s energy strategy, Prime Minister Gordon Brown awarded contracts to major energy companies that are to erect wind farms along Britain’s coastline.

headline: Shifting From A.P. Toward Dual Enrollment
text: Connecticut high schools have traditionally emphasized AP courses, but that is changing as more schools add college-credit courses through partnerships with the University of Connecticut and other local colleges.

headline: St. John’s Expands Program for High Schools
text: St. John’s University, based in Queens, has been aggressively expanding its College Advantage Program on Long Island over the past three years. It has partnerships with 90 public and private schools, 37 in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

headline: Iona College Expands Link to High Schools
text: Iona College, a private Catholic institution in New Rochelle, has offered a dual-enrollment program called Link at Westchester and New York City high schools since the 1980s. But in the last two years, the program has expanded aggressively in Westchester, adding seven high schools for a total of 19 in the county.

headline: An Emphasis on A.P. Is Changing
text: New Jersey’s suburban high schools have traditionally emphasized AP courses, but that is changing as more schools add college-credit courses through partnerships with Bergen Community College, Fairleigh Dickinson University and other colleges in the state.

headline: Sony Has Some Fun With Product Names
text: Along with the Bloggie vidcam from Sony — you guys are kidding about the name, right? — and the Trik speaker dock designed for iPod, the colorful desktop Dash device proves that the Japanese innovator hasn’t lost its touch for jumping on (or creating) a trend.

headline: Going to College While You’re Still in High School
text: During my senior year at West Windsor-Plainsboro High School in New Jersey in 1985, I drove to Princeton University twice a week to take a multivariable calculus course. It was exciting, but also hard work, and it taught me that I did not love math enough to major in it. But back then, college courses were typically open only to students who had exhausted their high school’s courses in a particular subject, like math or a foreign language.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,363 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: The Week Ahead : Jan. 10 — 16
text: Classical

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Reports to Prison
text: Bradley Birkenfeld, an informant in a federal investigation of offshore tax evasion aided by UBS, reported to a federal prison in Pennsylvania on Friday to start a 40-month prison term that he denounced as unfair.

headline: Obama Tries to Turn Focus to Jobs, if Other Events Allow
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama keeps trying to turn attention to “jobs, jobs, jobs,” as his chief of staff has put it. But he is finding that it can be hard to focus on any one issue when so many demand attention, often unexpectedly. And as the lackluster employment report on Friday suggested, showing concern is not the same as showing results.

headline: Cancer Risks Debated for Type of X-Ray Scan
text: WASHINGTON  The plan for broad use of X-ray body scanners to detect bombs or weapons under airline passengers’ clothes has rekindled a debate about the safety of delivering small doses of radiation to millions of people  a process some experts say is certain to result in a few additional cancer deaths.

headline: Catherine E. F. Biden, Mother of the Vice President, Is Dead at 92
text: WASHINGTON  Catherine Biden, the mother of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and a presence on the campaign trail with him in 2008, died Friday at the Biden home in Wilmington, Del. She was 92.

headline: Los Angeles Times Sets Early Press Time for First Section and Starts Late News Pages
text: For generations, newspapers have tried to cut the time between printing and delivery, giving readers the latest news  especially on big stories that often land on the front page. The Los Angeles Times is about to take a big step in the other direction.

headline: Federal Judge Rejects Suit by Baltimore Against Bank
text: A federal judge this week tossed out a lawsuit by Baltimore against Wells Fargo, ruling that the city could not prove that the bank’s lending practices had resulted in broad damage to poor neighborhoods.

headline: Panel Will Question Big Bank Leaders
text: WASHINGTON  Eight months after Congress established a commission to investigate the causes of the financial crisis, the panel is at last getting its work under way, despite concerns that its report, due on Dec. 15, will arrive too late to influence the debate over regulatory reform.

headline: Party Off! (for the Moment)
text: A formidable heavy-metal tour that would have featured the bands Slayer and Megadeth has been postponed so Tom Araya, below, the bassist and vocalist of Slayer, can undergo back surgery at the end of the month. In a statement, the band’s manager, Rick Sales, said, “Tom gave various medical treatments more than a fair shot, but they just haven’t handled the problem, so he’s biting the bullet and is scheduled for back surgery at the end of this month.” The American and Canadian Carnage Tour dates that were to begin on Jan. 18 are being rescheduled, and tickets already purchased for earlier shows would be honored at the rescheduled dates.

headline: Marvel Sues Family of Comics Artist
text: Marvel Entertainment sued the heirs of the comic book artist Jack Kirby on Friday to end the family’s recent efforts to regain long-term rights to some of Marvel’s most popular characters. The copyright dispute started in September, when heirs to Mr. Kirby, who was a principal creator of Marvel mainstays like the X-Men, sent the company 45 notices of copyright termination. The notices said that various rights transferred to Marvel would revert to the family starting in 2014. Marvel, now officially a division of the Walt Disney Company, said it believes the claims are baseless. Rather than battling the family behind the scenes  a potentially costly endeavor even if successful  Marvel decided to file a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan asking that the notices be declared invalid. John Turitzin, Marvel’s general counsel, said in a statement, “Everything about Kirby’s relationship with Marvel shows that his contributions were works made for hire.” Marc Toberoff, a lawyer representing the Kirby family, did not return calls seeking comment.

headline: She Sings in an Opera, but Don’t Call Her Fat
text: The adage says it ain’t over till the fat lady sings. But call the lady fat to her face and it may be over sooner than you expect. The Italian soprano Daniela Dessi has walked out of a coming production of Verdi’s “Traviata,” saying that its director, Franco Zeffirelli, disparaged her weight and her age, The Times of London reported. At a news conference for his production of “La Traviata” at the Teatro dell’Opera in Rome, Mr. Zeffirelli said of Ms. Dessi, who was to sing the role of the ill-fated Violetta: “A woman of a certain age and plumpness is not credible in the character.” Ms. Dessi, above, with the baritone Juan Pons, told the newspaper that the director had said “other, more offensive things” about her. She added: “I believe a lot in the physical appearance of the singer. I have always taken care of myself. We should be respected for our voices. To be too thin is not good.” Ms. Dessi’s husband, Fabio Armiliato, who was to sing the role of Violetta’s lover, Alfredo, has also withdrawn from the production. Mr. Zeffirelli, who has rarely been one to hold his tongue, did not back down from his remarks to Ms. Dessi. “I did say she was on the plump side for the part, and she is,” he told The Times of London. “She is not exactly the kind of woman who is likely to die of tuberculosis.”

headline: Top Ice Dancing Pair Finds Strength in Stability
text: CANTON, Mich.  The prescribed path to becoming a world-class ice dancer almost always includes moving far from home as a young teenager to train, have a coach conduct a national search for a good partner, and then hope the match endures.

headline: ‘Howard Stern Show’ to Keep Artie Lange
text: An executive for Sirius XM radio said Artie Lange, below, would remain a part of “The Howard Stern Show” and would be welcomed back to the program after he’s released from hospitalization. In remarks made Friday on “The Howard 100 News,” a news broadcast on Sirius XM that covers matters related to Mr. Stern’s show, Tim Sabean, the senior vice president of the Howard Stern channels said, “Artie is very much a part of these channels, and we look forward to Artie’s fast recovery and we wish him all the best.” Mr. Lange has been on an indefinite hiatus from the show since December. After several of his standup dates, including a performance scheduled for New Year’s Eve, were canceled, his representatives said that Mr. Lange had been hospitalized. The police told The Associated Press that Mr. Lange was hospitalized after he stabbed himself at his apartment in Hoboken, N.J. On his program Thursday, Mr. Stern said that the act was a suicide attempt, but has added that it was a private matter for Mr. Lange’s family to address.

headline: New York Philharmonic Posts Record Deficit
text: The New York Philharmonic has reported a record deficit for last season, $4.6 million, and projects a shortfall of about $4 million this season. Eric Latzky, the orchestra’s spokesman, said on Friday that the reason for last year’s red ink was a shortfall in annual fund-raising amid the recession; the orchestra fell shy of its $25 million goal by $3.75 million. “We are dealing with longer-term deficits now,” Mr. Latzky said. “There is no question that the economic environment has had a significant impact on the New York Philharmonic. We’re looking for solutions for that situation.” Mr. Latzky said some measures had already been taken, including staff salary freezes, scaled-back parks concerts and the use of fewer substitute players. “Our goal is to protect the artistic vision, absolutely, and to build” on that vision, he said. Last season’s budget of $64.5 million has risen to $68.9 million this season. As at any orchestra, the largest expense comes from musician salaries and benefits. The orchestra’s contract expires after next season. Mr. Latzky declined to comment on whether management would seek a reduction in compensation. A recent effort to cut salaries at the Cleveland Orchestra has prompted the players there to threaten to strike.

headline: Where Unsold Clothes Meet People in Need
text: Good ideas have legs. One day in 1985, Suzanne Davis asked a friend, Larry Phillips, the president of the Phillips-Van Heusen clothing line, if his company had any excess inventory that could be used by homeless men. A few days later, Mr. Phillips sent 100 boxes of windbreakers to a shelter on the Bowery.

headline: Unions Rally to Oppose a Tax on Health Insurance
text: When millions of blue-collar workers were leaning toward John McCain during the 2008 campaign, labor unions moved many of them into Barack Obama’s column by repeatedly hammering one theme: Mr. McCain wanted to tax their health benefits.

headline: Talking of Kierkegaard, in Words and Movement
text: In theory, a contemporary dance set to a BBC discussion of Kierkegaard sounds ominously didactic.

headline: Where a Close Look Goes Right Through
text: The pleasures and challenges of working with glass are explored in “See Through,” the current group exhibition at the Islip Art Museum, organized by Karen Shaw. But the show also invites wider contemplation of transparency.

headline: Alabama Wins, as Does ABC
text: The Alabama Crimson Tide’s victory in the title game of the Bowl Championship Series on Thursday helped catapult ABC to No. 1 in the night’s prime-time ratings. Final figures were not immediately available on Thursday, but Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates showed the football game dominating all other programming by a wide margin, exceeding even last year’s audience for Fox’s championship coverage, which drew 26.8 million viewers when final ratings were released. CBS ranked second on the night with repeats of “CSI” at 8 and 9 p.m., which averaged 9.4 and 10.4 million viewers each. At 10, CBS’s rerun of “The Mentalist” (11 million) easily outpaced “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC (4.6 million). NBC finished fourth for the night with comedy repeats from 8 to 10, while Fox was third with reruns of “Bones” at 8 (6 million) and “Fringe” at 9 (3.1 million).

headline: Leno Can Make Jokes; Network Can’t Laugh
text: In the billowing cloud of confusion over the latest shuffle in late-night programming on NBC  Jay Leno back on “The Tonight Show,” or no, maybe Conan O’Brien stays on, or possibly even both  one thing seems pretty clear. Network late-night talk shows are like a Ford Taurus. They are better made and sportier than most people recognize, but that is easily forgotten because there are so many other choices out there.

headline: NBC’s Shift in Schedule May Be Up to O’Brien
text: The future of NBC’s plan to shake up its late-night television lineup may depend on just how much Conan O’Brien doesn’t like what the network has done to him.

headline: Where Fiber Art Meets Hot Fudge Sundae
text: Until recently, the contemporary art world politely ignored the encroachment into artists’ studios of techniques more commonly associated with traditional practical and domestic arts. “Knitted, Knotted, Netted” at the Hunterdon Art Museum confronts this trend head on, presenting work by a dozen artists made using the methods of the title.

headline: A Deluge of Devices for Reading and Surfing
text: LAS VEGAS  You’ve heard of Amazon.com’s Kindle. And you probably know that Apple is likely to introduce a tablet computer this year. Soon you may also be hearing about the Alex, the Que proReader and the IdeaPad U1 Hybrid.

headline: Homeless in California, but Top Dogs in New York
text: A passenger in Seat 20E took a two-hour nap. A fellow traveler nearby named Malibu had trouble relaxing, and was given a mild sedative. A cross-country plane ride from San Francisco to New York City will do that to you  especially if you happen to be an eight-pound dog.

headline: Jamaican Delights
text: While it might not be practical to follow the sun to Jamaica, People’s Choice Restaurant offers the next best thing: authentic island cuisine.

headline: A Kosher Deli Survivor
text: It’s been a tough few years for Jewish delis in Westchester. The Mount Kisco Kosher Deli and Restaurant was forced from its longtime home (though it found a new spot in White Plains) and Bloom’s Kosher Delicatessen and Restaurant in Yorktown Heights closed.

headline: Late Night Shuffle
text: A look at nearly two decades of shifting schedules and fortunes in late night.

headline: An Industry Is Maturing
text: Long Island’s wine industry, which began when the Hargrave Vineyard (now Castello di Borghese) was founded in 1973, is settling into maturity. Its main challenges, as I see them, include earning out-of-state recognition and addressing pricing issues.

headline: C.E.S. Daily Journal: Day 2
text: Sam Grobart, The Times's personal technology editor, takes a look at new gadgets from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

headline: White House Aides Said to Chafe at Slow Pace of Afghan Surge
text: WASHINGTON  Senior White House advisers are frustrated by what they say is the Pentagon’s slow pace in deploying 30,000 additional troops to Afghanistan and its inability to live up to an initial promise to have all of the forces in the country by next summer, senior administration officials said Friday.

headline: China Tries a New Tack to Go Solar
text: HONG KONG  As it moves rapidly to become the world’s leader in nuclear power, wind energy and photovoltaic solar panels, China is taking tentative steps to master another alternative energy industry: using mirrors to capture sunlight, produce steam and generate electricity.

headline: Heavy Rains End Drought for Texas
text: HOUSTON  The worst drought to strike Texas in the last 50 years has broken, ending a year-and-a-half dry spell in which farmers and ranchers suffered devastating losses, climatologists and agronomists said this week.

headline: In Downturn, an Upside: Generosity
text: Recession got you down? Look on the bright side  it’s not a crisis, it’s a crisatunity!

headline: U.S. Has Few Resources to Face Threats in Yemen
text: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration confronts the latest terrorism threat in Yemen, its diplomatic and development efforts are being constrained by a shortage of resources, a lack of in-house expertise and a fraught history with a Yemeni leader deeply ambivalent about American help.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the nepotism practiced by the president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, misidentified the current leader of Islah, the largest opposition party, founded by Sheik Abdullah al-Ahmar, who died in 2007 and whose family represents an internal challenge to Mr. Saleh’s. Islah is run by Mohammed al-Yadomi, an interim leader  not by Hamid al-Ahmar, one of the sheik’s sons. (Mr. Ahmar is expected to formally replace Mr. Yadomi.)

headline: From Japan, a Lethal Leading Lady
text: Video games are undoubtedly Japan’s most successful and popular cultural export. Television, film, music and most other mass media are usually too closely bound to the particular sensibilities of their country of origin to appeal to a broad global audience, especially in the case of a relatively homogeneous country like Japan.

headline: Winter Breaks Budgets and Rules the Road
text: CHICAGO  There’s the gold standard of snow and ice removal on major roads in the Midwest  asphalt, plowed smooth and salted for easy driving.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about changes in the late-night schedule at NBC misstated part of the name of the show on CBS that competes with “The Tonight Show” on NBC. It is “Late Show With David Letterman,” not “Late Night With David Letterman.” (That was the name of his show on NBC.)

headline: Gambling Executive Sentenced to Prison
text: ST. LOUIS (Bloomberg News)  The former chief executive of an Internet gambling company, BetOnSports, was sentenced to 33 months in prison on Friday.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Prescriptions column on Friday about Senator Ben Nelson’s role in negotiations over the Senate health care bill referred incorrectly to his position on Medicaid costs. Mr. Nelson, a Nebraska Democrat, told Senate leaders he opposed an increase in his state’s Medicaid costs, and suggested that all states be allowed to opt out of a proposed Medicaid expansion. Senate leaders proposed that the federal government pick up Nebraska’s full share of the new Medicaid costs, and Mr. Nelson agreed. He did not demand that the federal government cover those costs.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Courts Roll Back Limits on Election Spending
text: WASHINGTON  Even before a landmark Supreme Court ruling on campaign finance law expected within days, a series of other court decisions is reshaping the political battlefield by freeing corporations, unions and other interest groups from many of the restrictions on their advertising about issues and candidates.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Giuliani’s Misstatement, but Stephanopoulos’s Red Face

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about the funeral of Percy E. Sutton, a father of modern Harlem and a mentor to generations of New York’s black politicians, referred erroneously to his father, using information from an official program and from several of the official eulogists. The father, Samuel J. Sutton, was not in fact a former slave; he was born free in Texas.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the government’s instructions to the American International Group not to disclose information about its bailout misidentified the state represented by Edolphus Towns, chairman of a House oversight committee that has been conducting an inquiry into A.I.G.’s bailout. It is New York, not Maryland.

headline: Why, I Oughta . . . and I Did
text: “I’ve never seen you lose your temper.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about the University of Connecticut football team’s victory in the PapaJohns.com Bowl last Saturday at the end of an emotional season described incorrectly the fight that led to the stabbing death of defensive back Jasper Howard on Oct. 18. It was on campus, outside a university-sponsored dance at the student union; it was not off campus.

headline: From Battlefield to Ivy League, on the G.I. Bill
text: Cameron Baker, an undergraduate at Columbia University, made a point of wearing a “Coalition Forces” T-shirt at the start of the fall semester. He was not bragging or making a collegiate attempt at ironic humor.

headline: China and Tibet Skirmish at a Film Festival
text: LOS ANGELES  In celebrity wattage and as a showcase for the art of cinema, the Palm Springs International Film Festival has not garnered the attention typically bestowed upon similar carnivals at Cannes, Sundance or even, say, Toronto. But the Palm Springs festival has now earned a different kind of laurel: a bona fide diplomatic incident.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Al Qaeda Dumb?
text: Peter Beinart, left, of The Daily Beast and Jonah Goldberg of National Review debate Al Qaeda's sophistication.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in the Escapes pages on Jan. 1 about visiting Boston in the winter, which described modern and historical sites, misstated the year of Paul Revere’s famous ride. It was 1775, not 1776. The article also referred incorrectly to the age of his house. While some rooms are decorated in an 18th-century manner and Revere bought the house in 1770, it was built in the 17th century. It is not an 18th-century house.

headline: Corrections
text: An essay on Page 15 this weekend about underwater mortgages misstates the parties who believe their homes will go up in value quickly. It is the homeowners  not the “mortgagees,” who issue mortgages.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: Editors’ Note
text: On July 12, the Op-Ed page published an article by Jonathan Gruber, a professor of economics at M.I.T., on health insurance and taxation. On Friday, Professor Gruber confirmed reports that he is a paid consultant to the Department of Health and Human Services, and that his contract was in effect when he published his article. The article did not disclose this relationship to readers.

headline: France: Imam Deported to Egypt
text: France has expelled to Egypt a radical imam who preached violence against the West, Interior Minister Brice Hortefeux announced. Ali Ibrahim el-Soudany, 36, who preached at several mosques in the troubled suburbs of Paris, was expelled Thursday to Egypt, his country of origin, after being identified by French intelligence as a “dangerous individual who for months preached struggle against the West, despising our society and inciting violence,” Mr. Hortefeux said in a statement posted Thursday on the ministry’s Web site.

headline: In Search of an Archive of Warhol’s Era
text: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  In the nearly 23 years since Andy Warhol’s death, a veritable Factory’s worth of people have claimed that they worked by his side during the glory years of the 1960s, when he was revolutionizing art with his silk-screens and surface-luster vision of life.

headline: Chávez Devalues Currency Amid Oil Fall
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez announced a sharp devaluation of Venezuela’s currency on Friday night, a move that reflects the financial stress faced by his government since the price of oil, the country’s top export commodity, fell from its peak as a result of the global financial crisis.

headline: Going to Lincoln Center to Find a Parade Ground
text: Lincoln Center is determined to make the most of its newest space, the David Rubenstein Atrium  the former Harmony Atrium, on Broadway between 62nd and 63rd Streets  so it has packed it with attractions of all kinds, including free wireless Internet, a discount ticket booth, an information desk and a cafe.

headline: Get Down
text: Destined, or the opposite?That is the question.

headline: Claim That Attack on Opposition Figure in Iran Was Staged
text: Updated | Sunday | 5:00 p.m. Since protests erupted following Iran’s disputed election in June, the country’s government and its supporters have repeatedly suggested that foreign media organizations orchestrated the demonstrations and even tried to blame a BBC reporter for the brutal killing of a female protester captured on widely-seen amateur video. As The Lede reported on Thursday, a newspaper close to the country’s powerful Revolutionary Guards said in June that Neda Agha-Soltan was shot by a “member of the rabble” hired by the BBC’s Jon Leyne.

headline: Jobs and Politics
text: If there’s a silver lining in the December jobs report, it is this: Nothing concentrates the minds of politicians like rising unemployment in an election year. Unless Congress and the White House push a robust job-creation agenda  starting now  worsening joblessness is a distinct possibility, even if the economy in general recovers in the coming months. That means the unemployment rate could still be high or even climbing when the midterm elections near. That may be the best hope for concerted federal action to put Americans back to work.

headline: Wizards are Trying to Repair Season and Image
text: WASHINGTON  There were no suspensions Friday, no official censures and no apologetic news releases. For the first time in a week, the Washington Wizards were left to focus, momentarily, on basketball. Normalcy, however, remains a distant goal.

headline: For Immigrants, New Travel Concerns
text: Eating spiced lamb at a bustling Yemeni restaurant in Downtown Brooklyn, Mahib Alkrizy said that since Sept. 11, 2001, his wife, a religious Muslim who covers her hair, has come to expect being patted down and stared at when she travels by plane.

headline: Love Story That Flits Across Time and Space
text: The latest romantic comedy from the Hindi-film powerhouse Yash Raj Films, “Pyaar Impossible” is, like most Yash Raj movies, a fairy tale. And like most of the company’s pictures, it is also well made (if formulaic), enriched by slick production values and set in glossy faraway places: It begins at something called Ankert University in a tropical-pastoral paradise called California, touches down briefly in Mumbai and then settles in Singapore.

headline: The Question: But Is It Art? Yes, and With an Overtrick
text: Is bridge an art or a science?

headline: An Old Synagogue Downsizes in a Desperate Bid to Keep Itself Alive
text: Jerry Banberger scarcely observed any of his tribe’s rituals, but after watching the twin towers collapse from the roof of his Queens loft, he felt a primal need to say Kaddish.

headline: Ex-Police Official Backs Car Into Pregnant Woman
text: Howard Safir, a New York City police commissioner during the Giuliani administration, backed his sport utility vehicle into a pregnant woman on the Upper East Side on Friday afternoon and then drove away, the police said.

headline: Boys Behaving Badly, Screen to Stage
text: Who’s afraid of John Cassavetes? Not Doris Mirescu, whose stage adaptation of his movie “Husbands,” part of the Under the Radar Festival at the Public Theater, shares his most radical impulse: to shake up conventional narrative.

headline: Jets’ Offense Is Fortified by Five Big Men
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  What may look like a lot of pushing and shoving at the line of scrimmage, Jets center Nick Mangold said, is really an exercise of exquisite timing and footwork. The Jets’ offensive line, an aggregate 1,555 pounds, might as well be the Rockettes.

headline: G.O.P. Aide Is Charged in Violent Family Fight
text: By all appearances, John Michael Farren and his wife, Mary Margaret Farren, had the life many can only dream about: a $4 million house in an affluent Connecticut suburb; two daughters; and high-powered legal careers, hers in the energy practice of Skadden, Arps, and his as a top aide in three Republican administrations along with a stint as general counsel of Xerox.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Invitation to Disaster
text: We didn’t pay attention to the housing bubble. We closed our eyes to warnings that the levees in New Orleans were inadequate. We gave short shrift to reports that bin Laden was determined to attack the U.S. And now we’re all but ignoring the fiscal train wreck that is coming from states with budget crises big enough to boggle the mind.

headline: The Wizard With a Bad Plan
text: In our search for comity and common ground this year, perhaps we can all agree that professional athletes should try to reduce the use of firearms to resolve personal disputes in 2010.

headline: G.O.P. Grief and Grieving
text: The attack on the Republican establishment by the tea party folks grabs the gaze like a really bad horror flick  some version of “Hee Haw” meets “28 Days Later.” It’s fascinating. But it also raises a serious question: Are these the desperate thrashings of a dying movement or the labor pains of a new one?

headline: Gen. Lew Allen, Who Lifted Veil on Security Agency, Is Dead at 84
text: Gen. Lew Allen Jr., who held influential positions in United States military and scientific spheres, including chief of staff of the Air Force, but who gained the widest attention as the first National Security Agency director to discuss the agency’s ultrasecret work publicly, died Monday in Potomac Falls, Va. He was 84.

headline: 5-on-3 Advantage? Pull the Goalie
text: Fans who will watch the Vancouver Olympics may see more than the premier international hockey competition. They may witness the North American unveiling of a radical strategy: a midgame, six-on-three power play.

headline: Still Mourning a Husband While Caring for a Mother
text: Maria Petrik spreads brittle sheets of paper across a delicate Romanian lace tablecloth. Each page is covered with handwritten translations of words that she and her husband, Gyorgy, taught themselves after arriving in Queens two decades ago.

headline: What’s Next at U.S.C.?
text: LOS ANGELES –- There have been some surreal moments covering U.S.C. practices and games over the years. There was the era of celebrities on the sideline at practices, the famous Bush Push game and all of the celebrity buzz and agents that came with the Reggie Bush and Matt Leinart era.

headline: Man Is Held in Security Breach at Newark
text: The man who is believed to have slipped into a secured area of Newark Liberty International Airport and to have caused a six-hour shutdown of a major terminal on Sunday has been arrested, Port Authority officials said on Friday night.

headline: Seahawks Fire Mora After One Season
text: The Seattle Seahawks jumped onto a slowly spinning coaching carousel Friday, firing Jim Mora after just one injury-riddled season. But the Seahawks’ next move might be an even bigger surprise. ESPN reported that the Seahawks were pursuing University of Southern California Coach Pete Carroll.

headline: Seahawks Beckon, and U.S.C. Cringes
text: LOS ANGELES  Classes are not in session at the University of Southern California, although anyone walking around the campus near downtown would have seen palm trees swaying gently in the breeze on a sun-splashed day sent straight from a recruiting manual.

headline: Correction
text: The headline with a report last Sunday about the marriage of Laura O’Steen misspelled the bridegroom’s surname. As the report noted, she married Jeffrey Boatright, not Boatwright.

headline: President Karzai Gets Another Try
text: Five months after Afghanistan’s tainted presidential election, it still does not have a fully functioning government in place. President Hamid Karzai nominated 24 members to his new cabinet, and last week Parliament rejected 17 of them.

headline: Wind Power
text: Ken Salazar, the interior secretary, has decided that nine years of wrangling over a proposed wind farm off the Massachusetts coast must come to an end  even if it requires his personal intervention. This is the best news this controversial, yet important, project has received in a long time.

headline: 88, Count ’Em
text: Congress is eagerly announcing assorted hearings into last month’s attempted airliner bombing near Detroit. So far, five different panels plan to grill security and intelligence officials, and more are expected to seek their time in the limelight.

He also possesses the prerequisite talent to justify the attention.

headline: A Wealth of Japanese Art
Green Bay, Once Owned by Favre, Now Belongs to Rodgers

headline: David Gerber, Award-Winning Television Producer, Dies at 86
text: David Gerber, an Emmy- and Peabody Award-winning television producer who brought forward-thinking series like “Police Story” and “Police Woman” to prime time in the 1970s and produced more than 50 television films and mini-series during a four-decade career, died on Jan. 2 in Los Angeles. He was 86 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: The Night the Lights Went Out in Newark

But they were all overshadowed, as it were, by the one game among them that wasn’t completed. Home teams listed first:

headline: Predictions Past: Rex Still Doesn’t Have Anything On Buddy
text: Rex Ryan’s “We Should Be the Favorites” statement earlier this week was back page news in New York and seemed fairly bold. But if you are old enough to remember the 1985 Chicago Bears, whose defense was coached by Buddy Ryan, Rex’s father, then Rex’s comment might be considered more on the tame side.

headline: Video Links Taliban in Pakistan to C.I.A. Attack
text: AMMAN, Jordan  Humam Khalil Abu Mulal al-Balawi, the Jordanian suicide bomber who killed eight people at a Central Intelligence Agency outpost in Afghanistan last month, was shown in a video on Saturday saying that the attack was carried out in revenge for the 2009 killing of the Pakistani Taliban leader Baitullah Mehsud.

headline: Quirky New Products From Sharper Image
text: Sharper Image, the store that was once known for quirky and cool gadgets, hopes to now be known as the company that sells quirky and cool gadgets to other stores. After it left the retail business, it resurrected itself last year as a supplier of electronic gear to others.

headline: Late-Night Comedy Deathmatch: Hosts Take Aim at Themselves, and Each Other
text: And so it came to pass, on the Second Day of the Great Late-Night Upheaval of 2010, that all three of the major NBC hosts (sorry, Carson Daly) at last weighed in on the turmoil in their opening monologues. And like another famous trio of stooges of yore, one was angry and aggressive; one was mild-mannered and conciliatory; and one was just plain weird.

headline: The health insurance excise tax
text: OK, clearly I have to weigh in on this. Should there be a limit to the tax deductibility of employer-provided health insurance, which is what the excise tax in the Senate bill is supposed to fix?

headline: A Postseason Without Pittsburgh: Revisiting the ‘Concussion’ Game

text: A bit of blogging meta: I love my commenters. I even love it when, for example, they take my statement “the upper hand is on the other foot” as a reflection of my muddled thinking, rather than of my disreputable taste for Hot Shots! Part Deux.

headline: 2008 Campaign, All Over Again in New Book
text: Updated | 1:03 p.m.  For a year now, the characters from the 2008 presidential race have been settling into their new lives. Barack Obama is in the Oval Office. Hillary Rodham Clinton is Secretary of State. John McCain is back in the Senate. And Sarah Palin is eyeing her future.

text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: While speaking about the war on terror yesterday, President Obama said, “There is of course, no fool-proof solution. We have to stay one step ahead of a nimble adversary.” Nimble adversary? Sounds like somebody saw “Sherlock Holmes” over the holiday.

text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Nobody’s coming to New York City any more. The only foreign visitors we’re getting are from Guantanamo.

headline: ‘We Almost Had Him’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Well, in an effort to calm people down after this latest security problem, the White House said it is working even harder to find Osama bin Laden. And here’s the frustrating part. Turns out we almost had him. Did you hear about this? Earlier this year, he snuck into a White House state dinner. Nobody recognized him.

headline: Obama Says Benefits From Health Care Overhaul Would Be Immediate
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Saturday that Americans would see immediate benefits from a landmark overhaul of the nation’s health insurance system and he urged Congress to swiftly reconcile differences over the legislation so it could be signed into law in the coming weeks.

headline: Correction: The New Katrina Flood
text: An article last Sunday about lawsuits filed against hospitals in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, using information from court documents, referred incorrectly in some editions to Cameron B. Barr, a former vice president of Pendleton Memorial Methodist Hospital, who had assessed the hospital’s vulnerability to flooding before Katrina. Cameron B. Barr is a man.

headline: Letters: Freelancers and Climate Change
text: Re “Times Standards, Staffers or Not” (Jan. 3): The clear intent of the freelancers’ contract seems to be, “You will not accept anything of value not provided by The New York Times.” What payers are covered as “current or potential news sources”? Is there any person or organization that is not at least a potential news source? Even a Stylite Monk sitting on top of a column for 30 years might serve as a source in a story about his motivations or experiences. The policy appears to me to be facially nonsense. A better idea? Have all writers disclose to The Times all investments over $500 and all receipts of value greater than $250, have the list available to me online and let me judge the extent, if any, that their coverage might be influenced. MARK TRENTACOSTECherry Hill, N.J., Jan. 3, 2010 ●It is surprising that The Times would rely solely upon 3M’s reimbursement of travel expenses for Mary Tripsas to condemn her for violating policy, when 3M might have contributed instead to her Harvard Business School research budget (or had its proxy do so) and thus avoided the perception of a conflict. My experience has shown me that it is impossible to avoid all potential conflicts and that some conflicts may actually be productive. I agree that The Times should take a firm stand on the most egregious conflicts, but rather than focus obsessively on avoiding all conflicts, it should also consider the quality of the work produced.I think that it would have been more valuable if you had provided some commentary on the column that Ms. Tripsas wrote on 3M to assess whether and how her writing might have been influenced by the arrangement. That places a higher burden on the public advocate, but one that is appropriate, in my view.STEVE PERCOCOEast Falmouth, Mass., Jan. 3, 2010 ●The policy described in your column, that your that contributors “must be free of even the smallest hint of undue influence,” goes beyond what I feel is necessary to ensure that the “readers have reason to trust our credibility.” Frankly, I am offended that The the Times’s editors would feel I am such a puritan and/or ignoramus as to assume that any junket given to a freelance reporter in an entirely separate matter would taint the reporter’s credibility and objectivity, or that of The Times. I certainly don’t discount the risk of such things happening. Rather, I think that The Times is taking the easy way out. I would respect The Times more if it would allow a limited amount of flexibility in such cases, and itself undertook to determine whether a freelancer’s other activities threatened the credibility of what appeared in The Times. I recognize that part of the problem in the cases you cite is the fact that the freelancers didn’t report their own conflicts, and that is a separate issue from the conflicts themselves. Nevertheless, I remain uneasy that you are unable to live with the mere existence of conflicts. It reminds me of the concept of “ritual uncleanliness” that notionally pollutes all who come in contact with it, which is unworthy of an intelligent and sophisticated society.I have no intention of canceling my subscription, nor of ceasing my regular visits to The Times’s Web site, just because you have gone so far in depriving yourselves, and your readers, of useful contributors as to arguably lower the potential range of your coverage. But a regular and loyal customer nevertheless considers that you have done just that, and would be happy if you eased off just a little. DON THOMASCalgary, Alberta, Jan. 3, 2010 ●Rather than outright disqualification, wouldn’t simple disclosure of the potential conflict — in or alongside the published column — do the job in many cases? That way the reader could decide what weight to give the potential conflict in evaluating the reliability of the information in the column and the worth of the columnist’s opinion. JIM LUTHERMendocino, Calif., Jan. 4, 2010 ●When someone is on the staff of The Times, The Times undoubtedly pays for their travel to important conferences in the field they cover. But if they freelance they must pay for these trips with their own money?Sounds to me like it’s unethical for The Times to hire freelancers, because it’s a cheapskate way of transferring legitimate business expenses from The Times to the worker. The Times should cover these expenses themselves if the paper feels it is a conflict of interest for someone else to cover them (which I agree, it is). Forcing freelancers to pay those expenses when employees get them covered is not fair.ISABEL WALCOTT DRAVESManhattan, Jan 4, 2010●●Scientists and JournalistsRe “Stolen E-Mail, Stoking the Climate Debate” (Dec. 5): With some real intensive investigative research, maybe this is a “three-alarm story.” One way or another, The Times needs to get this one right. If this is a fraud, The Times surely does not want to be the last to acknowledge it. We cannot afford to be wrong on climate warming. If the Associated Press can put 11 staff members on Sarah Palin’s new book, The Times must have the staff to follow through on climate warming — including giving the many highly respectable skeptics a sufficient platform for raising their issues, and sinking or swimming. MIKE BOURISMendocino, Calif., Dec. 6, 2009 ●Why is it that the media at large, and your column in particular, refers to supporters of the human-caused global warming theory as “scientists,” but uses the term “skeptics” (not scientists) for any scientist who rebuts that theory? Are not the physicist Fred Singer and the climatologist Timothy Ball scientists (as well as skeptics)?Should you not describe the two camps as “supporters and skeptics,” or simply scientists? By referring to one group as “scientists” and the other as “skeptics,” you are boosting the credentials of one at the expense of the other. RONALD BREMNER Glen Ridge, N.J., Dec. 6, 2009 ●You missed a major opportunity to explore the difference in reporting on politics and science — and the challenges faced by reporters when science becomes politicized. I’m sure you know that there is broad scientific consensus on the science behind climate change. The latest I.P.C.C. synthesis report is quite clear about the cause and threat. At what point is it O.K. for a credible news organization to stop publicizing discredited theories and individuals? Does there need to be any verifiable proof at all? Or is it O.K. to give a few contrarians equal billing? At what point (if at all) did The Times stop quoting tobacco-industry-funded spokespeople? If we could find a few “scientists” to insist the sun revolves around the earth would we create a man-bites-dog controversy — and give them equal billing? SAM BOYKINQueens, Dec. 7, 2009 ● A deliberate conspiracy to cover up information is hardly ever the problem with The New York Times or any other media outlet. The problem is bias, which is not deliberate, but often unconscious. I have little doubt that The Times will be as conscientious and professional as possible, but because your information is necessarily limited and uncertain, you will tend to favor the data and the interpretations that support your belief in anthropogenic global warming. That’s normal and natural. Bias is a powerful force operating on any journalist. This much has become clear as a result of Climategate: The myth, perpetrated by global warming alarmists, that we have serene, Olympian scientists on the one hand and ideologically driven skeptics on the other is now gone with the global wind. If we are honest and admit the inevitable presence of bias even in the aeries of science, then we must acknowledge that the skeptics have a vital role to play in the debate, especially since it is now clear that we cannot count on the global-warming advocates to check themselves. If nothing else, the skeptics can improve the science of global warming by finding problems for advocates in the science to solve. TUCKER LANDYFrankfort, Ky., Dec. 6, 2009

headline: Quotation of the Week
text: “Santa delivers the goods.”

headline: Prime Number
text: 177,000: The price in dollars that a giant tuna fetched in an auction last week at Tokyo’s Tsukiji market, the world’s largest wholesale fish market. The 513-pound fish, one of the disappearing bluefins, was the most expensive since 2001, when a 440-pound tuna sold for a record $220,000 at the same market. Japan is the world’s biggest consumer of seafood. The Japanese eat 80 percent of the Atlantic and Pacific bluefin caught. The two tuna species are the most sought after by sushi lovers. Not surprising, the big tuna, caught off the coast of northern Japan, was bought and shared by the owners of two Japanese sushi restaurants and one Hong Kong one, according to a market representative. Conservationists say all populations of bluefin tuna are being depleted by overfishing.

headline: The Mona Lisa Diet: High Cholesterol = Bucolic Smile
text: What’s behind the Mona Lisa’s calm, enigmatic expression? An Italian medical expert thinks he has the answer: high cholesterol.

headline: Neighbors Challenge Energy Aims in Bolivia
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia  President Evo Morales’s leftist government, which has asserted greater control over some of South America’s most coveted natural gas reserves, is facing a challenge as neighboring countries move to achieve energy security by cutting their dependence on Bolivian gas supplies.

headline: I Don’t, I Don’t, I Don’t, I Don’t, I Don’t, I Don’t . . .
text: Warren Beatty may have notched thousands of bedposts in his bachelor days, if a new biography is to be believed, but only once has it been with the benefit of matrimony. On the other hand, vows are apparently a necessity for an Israeli man who at age 50 has just been granted his 11th divorce. The BBC reports that the man, from Jerusalem, usually divorces after two years and immediately goes out bride hunting. Or perhaps bride reeling. "I send out a hook in all directions, and the fish come on their own," the man, who was not named, said. According to the rabbinical court that announced the divorce, 11 is a record for Jews in Israel. The court praised the man's adherence to religious procedure. Under Jewish law, a man seeking a divorce grants his wife a "get," which declares, "You are hereby permitted to all men."

headline: New Afghan Cabinet Picks Still Generate Resistance
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai made a second effort to fill his cabinet on Saturday, nominating 16 new ministers a week after Parliament had rejected most of his first choices.

headline: Ragged, Topless, Relieved and Cryptic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Now that registration is open for the 2010 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, you’re probably looking forward to meeting and hanging out with fellow enthusiasts. There’s a problem, though. What should you do if you encounter one of those inevitable gaps in conversation? How can you get past that awkward silence and establish your creds as a competitor to be reckoned with at the same time? Don’t worry. Wordplay is here to help. Just say, “Myself, I prefer cryptic crosswords, of course.” Now all you have to do is sit back and watch the ruckus.

Mrs. Johnson, who was also one of the first entrepreneurs to market cosmetics made particularly for black women, was 93.

headline: Herbert Spiegel, Doctor Who Popularized Hypnosis, Dies at 95
text: Dr. Herbert Spiegel treated pain, anxiety and addictions by putting people into a trance. Broadway actors sought his help to overcome stage fright, singers to quit smoking, politicians to overcome fear of flying. For years he had a regular table at Elaine’s, as well as his own place on the national stage.

headline: Peyton Manning Is Named League M.V.P. for Record Fourth Time
text: Was it the seven fourth-quarter comeback victories he led? Or his ability to win a game when his team had the ball for just 15 minutes against the Miami Dolphins? headline: Calderon’s Return a Welcome Sight for Raptors Fans
text: Jose Calderon, the Raptors’ point guard, returned from a long injury absence Wednesday. He must have been a welcome sight for Toronto fans, not just because he is back but because he looked more like the sensation who took over the team at the end of the 2007-8 season than the less efficient version he had become. He had eight assists and one turnover in 25 minutes off the bench.

headline: Bomb Goes Off Near Greek Parliament Building
text: ATHENS  An explosive device was detonated outside the Greek Parliament building in the heart of Athens just before 8 p.m. Saturday. The attack caused no injuries and little damage.

headline: Make Sure You Get It Rite

headline: What About George?
text: George Kramer sat hunched on his stool behind the counter of the small hardware store on Coney Island Avenue, gazing out the window at the passing traffic. He was bundled up in a heavy sweater, a maroon wool cap folded above his ears. Toward the back of the store, beyond Mr. Kramer’s field of vision, Isaac Abraham was rifling through a cabinet. Mr. Abraham, the store’s owner for many years, knows Mr. Kramer about as well as anybody, and he was about to give a demonstration.

headline: The Evolution of American Landscape Art
text: So great are the expectations surrounding exhibitions of works from the Metropolitan Museum of Art that it is hard not to be slightly disappointed with the small show of Hudson River paintings at the New Britain Museum of American Art. But in spite of its modest size  a mere seven paintings from the Metropolitan  the overall quality of the works is exceptional.

text: College athletics are dominated by a relatively small group of schools like Alabama and Texas, which played for the football national championship on Thursday. But as storied as those programs are, they cannot match the dominance of the best collegiate chess teams.

text: The wine country town of Sonoma has long been derided as “Slow-noma” by bored teenagers looking for something to do at night. Now the adults are trying to make that snail-paced life a virtue.

headline: When a Word’s Look Counted as Much as Its Meaning
text: Typography is ubiquitous. A world without letters, numerals and symbols designed by skillful font makers would consist of boring billboards, pages and street signs. Yet unlike other forms of applied design, typography remains an obscure and little-understood field. When buildings are constructed, they make news. A new font barely registers in the public consciousness.

But as House and Senate leaders work to forge a consensus bill for final approval, they should look for ways to lessen the Medicaid burden on hard-pressed state budgets  and ensure that relief is fairly apportioned.

headline: More Perils of Ground Meat
text: About eight years ago, a company called Beef Products Inc. had the novel idea of injecting its ground beef with ammonia to kill deadly E. coli and salmonella. The Agriculture Department pronounced the idea effective and exempted Beef Products Inc. from routine tests. The company’s beef began appearing regularly in grocery stores, fast food restaurants and school lunch programs. It turned out the beef was not safe.

headline: Are They Really?
text: What’s with the apologies? Goldman Sachs’s Lloyd Blankfein caught his fellow titans by surprise in November, admitting that “we participated in things that were clearly wrong and have reason to regret.” That came less than two weeks after he infuriated pretty much everyone else by declaring that Goldman was “doing God’s work.”

headline: The Other Plot to Wreck America
text: THERE may not be a person in America without a strong opinion about what coulda, shoulda been done to prevent the underwear bomber from boarding that Christmas flight to Detroit. In the years since 9/11, we’ve all become counterterrorists. But in the 16 months since that other calamity in downtown New York  the crash precipitated by the 9/15 failure of Lehman Brothers  most of us are still ignorant about what Warren Buffett called the “financial weapons of mass destruction” that wrecked our economy. Fluent as we are in Al Qaeda and body scanners, when it comes to synthetic C.D.O.’s and credit-default swaps, not so much.

headline: Who’s Sleeping Now?

headline: Religion and Women

headline: White Clinches Trip to Vancouver
text: The snowboarder Shaun White, a gold medalist at the 2006 Winter Games and one of the most recognized athletes working toward February’s Olympics in Vancouver, earned a spot on the American team by winning Saturday’s United States Snowboarding Grand Prix competition at Mammoth Mountain in California.

headline: Cold Patches in a Warm World
text: There’s been an unrelenting string of commentary on Dot Earth, and in some other news outlets, from people passionately pointing to the cold conditions around the Northern Hemisphere and crowing about the end of global warming. Following up on my post from last week on the Arctic Oscillation, Ken Chang has written a Week in Review story with a bit more detail on the unusual atmospheric patterns behind the big, but very constrained, chill, and the dominance of warm conditions — just not where a lot of Western media are situated. (As I wrote, it was raining in parts of Greenland about a week ago.) [UPDATE, 1/11: Richard Betts, the head of climate impacts at the Met Office, has written a commentary for the BBC amplifying on the confusion between weather (cold or hot) and climate. It’s well worth a read, as is this column by Andrew Freedman at the Capital Weather Gang.]

headline: Corrections
text: A chart last Sunday with the Keeping Score column listing baseball players who finished a decade in the top three in home runs and runs batted in gave incorrect information for the 1980s and the 2000s. Mike Schmidt’s R.B.I. total in the 1980s was 929, not 829. Besides Alex Rodriguez, Albert Pujols was also a top-three finisher in the two categories in the 2000s, with 366 homers and 1,112 R.B.I. And Manny Ramirez, with 348 home runs and 1,106 R.B.I., was erroneously included in the 2000s.

headline: Corrections
text: An essay on Page 15 this weekend about underwater mortgages misstates the parties who believe their homes will go up in value quickly. It is the homeowners  not the “mortgagees,” who issue mortgages.

headline: Landscape Controls in View, and Other Highlights of Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: The Hissing of Summer Lawns (or Lawn Owners) | When Joni Mitchell wrote her song about summer lawns it was the 1970s and the lawn was still the archetypical suburban landscape, even in dry northern California. But now that a 2006 state law restricting water use for landscaping is finally taking effect, local jurisdictions all over the state must figure out what to do about the issue by Jan. 31. Some are adopting the state’s model ordinance on landscaping and water conservation; others, like Palo Alto and Menlo Park, are trying to come up with their own. Some of these severely limit the extend of lawns in new or remodeled corporate or residential landscapes. Wary of these possibilities and other more draconian drought-driven restrictions, homeowners in high-end lawn-bedecked suburbs like Atherton and Hillsborough are putting in their own wells as insurance against municipal water cutbacks.Taking It Slow and Easy in Sonoma | An Italian group recently honored Sonoma as a “slow city,” providing the livability of a time gone by, with few if any chain stores, enough farmers’ markets and a pedestrian- and bicycle-friendly ambiance. But the corollary of being slow seems to be being white and old and rich, judging by the town’s demographics. Which raises some questions: What price is the town paying for its slow lifestyle? Does it mean that many people who work in Sonoma have to drive a long way to get there? Will it mean that the generation growing up in Sonoma will be unlikely to have the money to live there?

headline: Corrections
text: An answer to a math problem in the Pop Quiz last Sunday misidentified the system commonly used by credit and A.T.M. cards to identify an erroneous card number. It is not the Codabar. It is the Luhn.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about service learning misstated the surname of a co-author of the book “The Unheard Voices: Community Organizations and Service Learning.” She is Elizabeth A. Tryon, not Tyron.

headline: Documents Reveal Earlier Immigrant Deaths
text: Over the last two years, the news media and Congress have brought attention to many deaths in the immigration detention system that appear to have involved substandard medical care or abuse. But a trove of documents obtained over recent months by The New York Times and the American Civil Liberties Union sheds light on even more fatalities.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary last Sunday about the comedian Jean Carroll misstated her date of birth. It was Jan. 7, 1911, not Jan. 6. The obituary also erroneously attributed an accomplishment to her. It was another Jean Carroll who wrote for the radio soap opera “Our Gal Sunday” in the 1940s and 1950s.

headline: Failed Olympics Bid Leaves Neighborhood in Flux

headline: Evanston Considers Cuts to Its Public TV Station
