headline: A Lady, Not by Leonardo, Retains an Expensive Allure
text: Since the 1920s a debate over the attribution of “Portrait of a Woman Called ‘La Belle Ferronnière,’ ” has been the stuff of legal dramas and scientific analysis, aesthetic disputes and connoisseurship differences.

headline: Hopped-Up Modern Salsa From Havana
text: An audience packed with cheering Cubans greeted David Calzado and his Charanga Habanera at S.O.B.’s on Friday night, in a rare and welcome American appearance by one of Cuba’s top bands  signaling, perhaps, an Obama administration thaw in Cuban-American relations. Formed in 1988 and persisting through multiple personnel changes, Charanga Habanera has made hits in Cuba through the 1990s and 2000s, and its set raced through them in an exultant, nearly nonstop two-hour medley. In songs like “Soy Cubano, Soy Popular” (“I Am Cuban, I Am Popular”), the band sang of its own fame and success, and the crowd proved it by shouting along, verse and chorus.

headline: The Kids Are All Right (and Flaunting Their Hooks, Taste and Cred)
text: On Thursday night Nick Jonas of the Jonas Brothers made his New York debut as a solo act at the Beacon Theater for around 2,000 shrieking young girls (and a couple of boys) and their chaperones. On Saturday afternoon, in the basement of Cake Shop on the Lower East Side, the all-girl Brooklyn kid-punk outfit Care Bears on Fire hosted a showcase of teen bands for an audience of a couple hundred: plaid-wearing peers, small children, parents scarfing down sandwiches and salads.

headline: New Chief to Be Named for Los Angeles Museum
text: There is almost no such thing as a secret in the art world, so when the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles announces its new director at a news conference on Monday morning, the name everyone is expecting to hear is that of Jeffrey Deitch. Neither Mr. Deitch, right, nor officials at the museum returned calls asking for comment, but several experts with knowledge of the search said that Eli Broad, the arts patron who pledged $30 million to save the museum when it was on the brink of financial collapse in 2008, reached out to many unconventional art-world personalities, including Tobias Meyer, head of Sotheby’s contemporary art department worldwide and Sotheby’s principal auctioneer, as well as Samuel Keller, the art fair impresario who ran Art Basel and Art Basel Miami Beach until he became director of the Beyeler Foundation in Riehen, Switzerland, in 2006. While the Harvard-educated Mr. Deitch has vast experience working with artists, selling artworks and presenting shows, he has never had a job that involved fund-raising, which is a crucial part of a museum director’s portfolio. He has, however, worn many hats. In 1979 he helped start an art advisory service for wealthy clients at Citibank. He has also been a private art dealer, and in 1996 founded Deitch Projects, which now has two spaces in New York; in 1997 Sotheby’s bought 50 percent of Deitch Projects, a relationship that has since dissolved. Besides running his galleries Mr. Deitch worked at Sotheby’s managing its 20th-century Art Gallery Program for a few years. Among the artists he has represented are Jeff Koons; the Japanese photographer and performing artist Mariko Mori; Dash Snow; and the British team Tim Noble and Sue Webster.

headline: Ground Zero Mural Shifts to Another Wall
text: A planned mural that was to cover part of the construction fence at ground zero has been moved off the site, the New York City Department of Transportation confirmed on Friday. The mural was designed by the architecture firm Sage & Coombe, which was selected in a competition announced last August by the department and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. In the end, though, “We didn’t think ultimately that any of the submissions was extraordinary enough, given that it’s the World Trade Center fence,” said Stephen Sigmund, a spokesman for the authority. The mural was to have been installed last month on the Church Street fence between Liberty and Vesey Streets, and remain up for about a year. Instead it will be mounted sometime in the spring at Louise Nevelson Plaza on Maiden Lane at William Street. The design has not been made public, but the competition guidelines called for a mural incorporating “bold, colorful imagery reflecting the vibrancy of the thriving downtown commercial and residential neighborhood.” The principals of Sage & Coombe did not respond to messages seeking comment.

headline: End May Be in Sight for ‘Hannah Montana’
text: Is Hannah Montana getting ready to give up her microphone? The Disney Channel programming executive Adam Bonnett told MTV News that the fourth season of the series “Hannah Montana,” which stars Miley Cyrus, right, as a teenager who is secretly a pop star, would be its last. “You never know in this business ... but right now, we’re scheduled to wrap after shooting this new batch of episodes,” Mr. Bonnett said in a statement. Rumors of the show’s end have been circulating for a while, and the current season’s hourlong finale, “Is Miley Saying Goodbye?,” scheduled for March, does not look as if it will provide any definite answers. “It’s one of the things she’s been wrestling with for months,” Mr. Bonnett said, referring to the show’s lead character, “whether it’s time to make a decision to continue being Hannah Montana or just be a regular, ordinary girl.” But Ms. Cyrus seems to have already begun to move on, with breaks in production of Season 4 scheduled around the promotion of her new film, “The Last Song,” in April.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Keeps the Top Spot at Weekend Box Office
text: Aliens, action and animals held the top spots at the weekend’s box office. Fox’s “Avatar” remained in first place, with domestic ticket sales of $48.5 million, down from $68 million the week before, according to box office tracking services. That puts the domestic cumulative total for “Avatar” at $429 million. Both “Sherlock Holmes” (Warner Brothers) and “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel” (Fox) held their second- and third-place positions, with domestic sales taking a plunge in each film’s third week: about $16.6 million ($165.2 million total) for “Holmes” and $16.3 million (just shy of $178.2 million total) for the furry musicians. Vampires lured audiences to “Daybreakers” (Lionsgate), arrived in fourth place with $15 million in its first week, bumping Nancy Meyers’s middle-aged romance “It’s Complicated,” (Universal) to fifth with a little more than $11 million in its third week ($76.3 million total).

headline: A Gossip Girl Becomes a Comic Book Heroine
text: The “Gossip Girl” actress Blake Lively, above right, has been cast opposite Ryan Reynolds, above left,  in a future Warner Brothers film based on the DC Comics character Green Lantern. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Ms. Lively will play Carol Ferris, the Lantern’s love interest and daughter of the aerospace company owner who hires the fearless pilot (and secret intergalactic hero) Hal Jordan. The director Martin Campbell (“Casino Royale”) has yet to cast the villains, Dr. Hector Hammond and the alien Sinestro. Shooting is to begin in Louisiana in March, with an expected release date of June 17, 2011. In the comic books Carol Ferris helps run her father’s company but develops some super skills of her own and eventually battles Green Lantern as Star Sapphire.

headline: Obama Plays Down Military Role in Yemen
text: President Obama said he has “no intention of sending U.S. boots on the ground” to Yemen and Somalia amid mounting concern about terrorist cells in those countries.

headline: A Green Goblin Speaks
text: The Tony Award-winning actor Alan Cumming (“Cabaret”) said Saturday that the coming Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” in which he is set to star as the Green Goblin, would be significantly delayed and that producers had hit a financial iceberg last year. Previews were scheduled to begin next month, but speaking at a TimesTalk event, Mr. Cumming, above right, said: “No one’s going to be there that day. We’re just waiting.” He said the show had hit “an iceberg of financial ruin” last year when producers could not raise enough money for the show, which is expected to cost upwards of $50 million. He said the producers should have taken down posters in the theater district that suggest the show is opening soon; the musical’s Web site, spidermanonbroadway.com, still says that previews start Feb. 25. The lead producer, Michael Cohl, who took over in November, has said that the production would take place on Broadway sometime this year. Mr. Cumming said it was “a really weird, frustrating thing to be waiting,” but added that based on the music (by Bono and the Edge of U2), costumes and sets that he had seen so far, the musical would be “a new, very exciting experience” for Broadway audiences.

headline: A Nation of Hunkered-Down Homebodies
text: The nation’s mobility rate fell last year to its lowest level since World War II, according to the latest census data. Growth is slowing in Sun Belt states and Northeastern states are holding on to more people. The current recession and lack of jobs  are big factors, but the trend has been gaining force since the 1950s, when nearly one-fifth of all Americans moved every year.

headline: Reunited With a Lost Corvair
text: Craig Pursley's search for a car like the one he drove as a teenager led to a surprising discovery.

headline: Study Finds That Papers Lead in Providing New Information
text: There are more places to go for local news but less news to find there, and the great majority of actual reporting still comes from newspapers, according to a study of the Baltimore area that is scheduled to be released on Monday.

headline: Large Price Jumps Reported for Small but Vital Drugs
text: Prices for a small but growing number of brand-name drugs have risen more than twofold in recent years as drug makers seek to squeeze greater profits out of often small-selling but vital medicines, according to Congressional investigators.

headline: Airlines Refuse to Transport Radical Cleric
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The radical Jamaican cleric who was deported to Gambia last week has been returned to Kenya, Kenyan news media reported late on Sunday.

headline: Dominating Victory by the Ravens Shakes Up a Dynasty
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Their injured receiver, Wes Welker, watched from a luxury box, his crutches propped nearby providing a fitting reminder of how fragile the New England Patriots’ grip on success has become. Perhaps, if better days are ahead, the Patriots will look back on this season as a blip in their dynasty, the moments when a young team tasted bitter defeat and grew from it.

headline: Optimism Takes Charge at Consumer Electronics Show
text: The mood at last week’s Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas was decidedly more upbeat than at the previous year’s show. At that exhibition, the chatter on the floor was less about innovation and breakthrough technologies than about how to weather the economic storm that would impede the kind of discretionary spending much of the electronics industry relies on.

headline: In Leno Fiasco, a Window to the Midlife Crisis of NBC
text: The syndrome is a familiar one. Men of a certain age  and it is almost always men  wake up one day and find that they are no longer the center of the universe. Women fail to look their way, co-workers don’t scurry to fetch them coffee and bosses stop thinking of them as someone on the rise.

headline: 6 Years, 3 Teams, 2 Divisions. Finally, a Starring Role.
text: OAKDALE, N.Y.  Defense suddenly turned to offense, and Christie Marrone was off, a 5-foot-6 blur of gold, navy and white, dribbling furiously down the court with the basketball she had just stolen. She finally delivered a nifty no-look pass to complete the two-on-one break.

headline: Revelers See a Dimming in a Capital’s Night Life
text: PARIS  The neighbors do not like the Zero Zero bar, a graffiti-plastered dive on an otherwise sleepy stretch of Rue Amelot, in the 11th Arrondissement. It is not so much the look of the place, they say, or any particular distaste for its youthful clientele. It is the noise.

headline: Two Ideological Foes Unite to Overturn Proposition 8
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The last time David Boies and Theodore B. Olson battled in a courtroom, the presidency hung in the balance as they represented opposite sides arguing the fate of the 2000 election.

headline: From Print to Phone to Web. And a Sale?
text: Print may be a flat medium, but that has not stopped magazine publishers from trying to add dimension to their pages. For at least a decade, they have been experimenting with bar codes and icons that could take readers to Web sites, trying to add a bit of Internetlike interactivity to their pages.

headline: Photo Replay: Ravens Beat Patriots
text: The Ravens put the Patriots on their heels from the game's first play and never looked back in a convincing A.F.C. wild-card win.

headline: Citing Hazard, New York Says Hold the Salt
text: First New York City required restaurants to cut out trans fat. Then it made restaurant chains post calorie counts on their menus. Now it wants to protect people from another health scourge: salt.

headline: A Vague Sense of What Makes a Hall of Famer
text: The guidelines for baseball’s Hall of Fame voting are condensed to one line: “Voting shall be based upon the player’s record, playing ability, integrity, sportsmanship, character, and contribution to the team(s) on which the player played.”

headline: In a Series, Nickelodeon Will Focus on Math
text: Nickelodeon, whose preschool shows focus on teaching social skills as much as letters and numbers, will move squarely into the academic realm, with the introduction of “Team Umizoomi,” which it said is the only preschool series centered entirely on teaching math to children.

headline: NBC Confirms Its Late-Night Shake-Up
text: PASADENA, Calif.  NBC confirmed Sunday what the television world already knew  that the network would end Jay Leno’s prime-time show in one month and return him to 11:35 p.m., bumping “The Tonight Show” and its host, Conan O’Brien, to 12:05 a.m.

headline: Two Killed in Belt Parkway Crash
text: Two young women died when they were thrown from a car that crashed on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn early Sunday. The car’s driver, a 29-year-old man, was charged with vehicular manslaughter, driving while impaired by alcohol and other counts, the police said.

headline: In Sour Economy, Biggest Gambler at Foxwoods Is the Casino Itself
text: MASHANTUCKET, Conn.

headline: Brooklyn Boy, 15, Charged in Stabbing of 12-Year-Old
text: A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy was charged on Sunday with stabbing a younger friend after they argued in a park where they had gone to smoke marijuana, the police said.

headline: Behind the Lens, Continuing a Legacy
text: Spike Lee needed to have his photo taken for a publicity tour a few months before the release of his new movie, “Malcolm X,” in 1992.

headline: Goldman Sachs Considers Charity Requirement
text: As it prepares to pay out big bonuses to employees, Goldman Sachs is considering expanding a program that would require executives and top managers to give a certain percentage of their earnings to charity.

headline: Visualizing Parade, Ryan and Jets are Hoping for Real Thing
text: When Coach Rex Ryan gave his Jets their schedule for the postseason last week, it went right through to a Super Bowl parade in February. Nothing like planning ahead. He just wanted to paint a picture in the players’ minds, wanted them to visualize the tantalizing possibility of winning a championship, because he is an unabashed believer that they can make the confetti-filled picture come to life.

headline: In Colorado, Craving Reform of Health Care and Congress
text: DENVER — Donny Seyfer, the manager of an auto repair shop here, had high hopes when President Obama and Congress tackled health care as their top priority early last year.

headline: Argentine President and Central Bank in Standoff
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  A disputed plan by President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina to use billions of dollars in foreign currency reserves to repay debt has inflamed political tensions in that country, Latin America’s third-largest economy.

headline: For Jets, Success Far Beyond One Playoff Victory
text: From his New Jersey basement Sunday afternoon, linebacker Bart Scott multitasked, alternately answering questions about his current team, the Jets, and rooting for his former team, the Baltimore Ravens, in its playoff game against the New England Patriots.

headline: Cardinals Beat Packers in Overtime
text: A shootout between quarterbacks -- the highest-scoring playoff game in N.F.L. history -- ended with a score by the defense as the Arizona Cardinals defeated the Green Bay Packers, 51-45.

headline: As a Statement, This Beating Could Linger in New England
text: Foxborough, Mass.

headline: How the AOL-Time Warner Merger Went So Wrong
text: A decade ago, America Online merged with Time Warner in a deal valued at a stunning $350 billion. It was then, and is now, the largest merger in American business history.

headline: Race Riots Grip Italian Town, and Mafia Is Suspected
text: ROME  More than a thousand African workers were put aboard buses and trains in the southern Italian region of Calabria over the weekend and shipped out to immigrant detention centers, following some of the country’s worst riots in years.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about Kai Eide, the departing head of the United Nations mission in Afghanistan, misstated the background of Jean-Marie Guéhenno, the former head of peacekeeping operations for the United Nations, who is one Mr. Eide’s possible successors. He is a career diplomat from France, not a general.

headline: Train From Sarajevo to Belgrade Revived
text: The famous train line from Sarajevo to Belgrade was disrupted during the Balkan conflict in the 1990s.

headline: G.O.P. Attacks Reid Over Comments
text: WASHINGTON  Republicans on Sunday sought to portray racially insensitive remarks attributed to Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, in a new book as similar to comments made in 2002 by Trent Lott, the Republican leader who was forced to step down.

headline: U.S. Bankers Are Fed Up With British Regulations
text: LONDON  A tough new requirement by Britain’s securities regulator that top banking executives and earners must defer 60 percent of their total compensation for a three-year period is pushing some American banks with extensive London operations to say that they just won’t take it anymore.

headline: Cardinals’ Defense Ends Shootout With Packers
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  For more than 60 minutes in the desert Sunday, the two gunslinging quarterbacks dueled to a draw, Arizona’s Kurt Warner and Green Bay’s Aaron Rodgers combining for 801 yards through the air and 9 scoring passes.

headline: Corrections
text: The Amman Journal article on Dec. 29, about a famed Jordanian sandwich shop, Reem, misstated the number of traffic circles or junctions that form the spine of Amman, the capital. There are eight, not seven. And a reporting credit with the article misidentified the city from which Mona El-Naggar contributed reporting. It was Amman, not Cairo.

headline: On Trial’s Sidelines, Abortion Foes Are Divided
text: When the trial of the man accused of murdering a doctor who performed late-term abortions begins on Monday in Wichita, Kan., Troy Newman, the leader of Operation Rescue, an anti-abortion group with headquarters a few miles from the courthouse, says he will most likely be at his desk, as usual, and certainly nowhere near the courtroom.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about the predominance of poverty and minority students in schools in the South misstated the name of a test that measures reading scores among fourth-graders. It is the National Assessment of Educational Progress, not the National Assessment of Economic Progress.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Monday about a new fee levied on movie and television production companies filming in some municipally owned buildings in New York City misstated the title of a television show that has used such buildings and will be subject to the fee, according to a spokesman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services. It is “Gossip Girl,” not “Gossip Girls.”

headline: Train Line Across the Balkans Restitches a Region
text: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  The siege of Sarajevo had just begun the last time Vera Bagur, now 68, took the famous train line from Sarajevo to Belgrade. It was one of the few physical links that bound Muslims, Serbs and Croats.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Friday about the fashion designer and museum curator Charles Kleibacker misidentified the Paris atelier where, Mr. Kleibacker said, in the 1950s he realized he wanted to become a designer. It was Christian Dior’s  not that of Yves Saint Laurent, who did not start his own atelier until 1962.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Cowboys Are Cruising, but Road Gets Tougher
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Now that the Dallas Cowboys have won a playoff game for the first time in 13 seasons, they can pursue what may be a more difficult objective.

headline: Guantánamo Reunion, by Way of BBC
text: New to Facebook, Brandon Neely was searching the site for acquaintances in 2008 when he typed in the names of some of the detainees he had guarded during his tenure as a prison guard at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Lights Repaired, and Lightning Finishes Off Devils
text: NEWARK  The Tampa Bay Lightning finally got to go home Sunday night, and not a moment too soon. Minutes after beating the Devils, 4-2, Tampa Bay cleared out of the dressing room, with every bit of equipment jammed into black duffel bags and hustled onto a cart.

headline: A Withering Harvest in Florida
text: In Florida’s agricultural core, there swims another harvest that has suffered more than any other because of a long cold snap: tropical fish.

headline: Senator’s War Chest Grows, but So Does Primary Threat
text: As United States Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand’s allies have elbowed out her would-be Democratic challengers one by one, they emphasized what was perhaps her most formidable weapon: her fund-raising muscle.

headline: NBC Will Televise Major Triple Crown Prep Races
text: Churchill Downs and NBC Sports are expected to announce Monday an agreement to broadcast six major prep races leading to the Kentucky Derby as part of a plan to attract casual fans as well as horseplayers. The move comes as NBC positions itself to win back the three legs of the Triple Crown in 2011.

headline: Lawmakers’ Visits on the First Day of the Detroit Auto Show Seem to Set a Pattern
text: DETROIT  Before opening to the public, the Detroit auto show always begins with a week of preview days, first for the media and then for dealers and others who work in the auto industry.

headline: A Higher Price Tag Enters Negotiations
text: As White House and Congressional negotiators work toward an agreement on a final version of sweeping health care legislation, they seem likely to push the 10-year price tag closer to the $1.05 trillion cost of the House-passed bill while relying on new taxes proposed by the Senate, probably including a bigger increase in the Medicare payroll tax than currently proposed.

headline: Taking Aim at the Big Names in Animated Film
text: GREENWICH, Conn.  Slumbering in a drab-looking office building here, Blue Sky Studios, the animated-movie division of 20th Century Fox, has long been dismissed as much of a threat. Nobody could catch DreamWorks and Pixar, moviedom figured, especially not a quiet studio that got its start with an animated laxative commercial.

headline: A Smaller Player Mounts Must-See Events
text: LAS VEGAS  Ever wonder why electronics stores try so hard to sell audio and video cables made by Monster Cable?

headline: Accounts, People & Miscellany
text: Accounts

headline: Teaching Green, Beyond Recycling
text: Jose Chirino, a 10th grader in Brooklyn with shoulder-length hair and a thin mustache, says flatly that his high school was his last choice.

headline: Aflac Is Leaving Its Agency, and Taking the Duck
text: THE familiar duck is front and center as Aflac expands efforts that began last year to tell consumers more about how its insurance products work. But the relationship between Aflac and the agency that created the character in 1999 is ending.

headline: Washington’s Gun Past Affects Arenas’s Future
text: WASHINGTON  The office of Peter Nickles, the District of Columbia’s attorney general, is on Pennsylvania Avenue, not far from the White House or the Verizon Center.

headline: M.T.A. to Unveil a Makeover of Its Web Home
text: New York City’s mass transit network has become cleaner, faster and more reliable in the past decade. But its Web site remained stuck in the past.

headline: NBC Expects Winter Olympics to Lose Money for the Network
text: NBC expects to lose money on its broadcast of the Vancouver Olympics, the first loss on an Olympics broadcast package in the network’s history, an NBC executive said Sunday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Action, and Now Reaction
text: The founders built the House of Representatives to act. And throughout President Obama’s first year, the House has acted.

headline: Is David Lee an All-Star? (And Other Thoughts.)
text: Since the idea of the Knicks’ David Lee making 20-foot jumpers no longer seems ludicrous, maybe it’s time to reconsider another once-unthinkable notion: David Lee as an All-Star.

headline: Action, and Now Reaction
text: The founders built the House of Representatives to act. And throughout President Obama’s first year, the House has acted.

headline: N.F.C. Divisional Playoff Matchups
text: Arizona Cardinals at New Orleans SaintsSaturday, 4:30 p.m. EasternTV: Fox

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: When Flood of E-Mail Pitches Recedes
text: Two weeks before Christmas, online retailers blasted out promotional e-mail at a rate 60 percent higher than the yearly median. But in the seven days just before the holiday, the average number of messages fell, according to the online marketing firm Responsys, which tracked e-mail from 104 of the 150 largest online retailers. What gives?

headline: A.F.C. Divisional Playoff Matchups
text: Baltimore Ravens at Indianapolis Colts Saturday, 8:15 p.m. EasternTV: CBS

headline: Moving Beyond a Childhood Beset by Loss and Illness
text: In the dimly lighted apartment in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Lowanda Hamilton, 23, cares for her bedridden grandmother, Evelyn Dunbar. At times, helping her eat, changing her diapers and managing her mood can be overwhelming for Ms. Hamilton. But the two share an indestructible bond.

headline: Hope of Reprieve for Bond Investors
text: It’s the slowest train wreck of the financial crisis: Commercial real estate is still screeching roughly two years after lenders jammed on the brakes.

headline: Jersey City Officer Shoots Man
text: A man was wounded in a police-involved shooting in Jersey City on Sunday night, a spokesman for the city said.

headline: A Meager Existence on Food Stamps
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nygard Store Tries to Impose a Press Curb
text: For most companies, store grand openings are about free publicity. But the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation now finds itself the target of a copyright infringement lawsuit after recording the opening of a shop in Manhattan controlled by the designer Peter Nygard.

headline: Privatized War, and Its Price
text: A federal judge in Washington, Ricardo Urbina, has provided another compelling argument against the outsourcing of war to gunslingers from the private sector. In throwing out charges against Blackwater agents who killed 17 Iraqis in Baghdad’s Nisour Square in September 2007, Judge Urbina highlighted the government’s inability to hold mercenaries accountable for crimes they commit.

headline: The Right to Confront Witnesses
text: Just last June, the Supreme Court decided that when prosecutors rely on lab reports they must call the experts who prepared them to testify. It was an important ruling, based on a defendant’s right to be confronted with witnesses against him, but the court is about to revisit it. The justices should reaffirm that the Sixth Amendment requires prosecutors to call the lab analysts whose work they rely on.

headline: Promises and Facts on Charter Schools
text: Charter schools  which are run with public money but subject to fewer state regulations  have a lot of supporters in Washington. Education Secretary Arne Duncan wants states to close some chronically failing schools and turn them into charters. Congress is so enthusiastic that it has created a $50 million fund and given Mr. Duncan the authority to directly finance charter school operators who want to replicate or expand successful programs.

headline: Youngstown Yawns
text: Anyone who’s spent time in Youngstown, Ohio, is entitled to nagging affection for the gritty old steeltown that has long struggled with lost jobs and serial political corruption. Bruce Springsteen lyricized its fate: “I’m sinkin’ down here Darlin’ in Youngstown.” There’s a touch of fresh hope at word that a collective yawn is greeting the return of former Representative James Traficant, who is on the streets vowing a political comeback after a seven-year prison stretch.

headline: A Message to Uganda About a Bill Against Gays
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Demands of the Classroom
text: To the Editor:

headline: Learning From Europe
text: As health care reform nears the finish line, there is much wailing and rending of garments among conservatives. And I’m not just talking about the tea partiers. Even calmer conservatives have been issuing dire warnings that Obamacare will turn America into a European-style social democracy. And everyone knows that Europe has lost all its economic dynamism.

headline: Let’s Talk About Faith
text: Liberal democracy offers religious believers a bargain. Accept, as a price of citizenship, that you may never impose your convictions on your neighbor, or use state power to compel belief. In return, you will be free to practice your own faith as you see fit  and free, as well, to compete with other believers (and nonbelievers) in the marketplace of ideas.

headline: Stacking the Deck Against Proposition 8
text: Washington

headline: Mr. Smith Rewrites the Constitution
text: Chicago

headline: Using a Pfizer Grant, Courses Aim to Avoid Bias
text: Stanford University on Monday will announce plans to develop new continuing education programs for doctors that will be devoid of the drug industry influence that has often permeated such courses.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Bolts Win Resumption of Newark Power-Failure Game
text: Four games on Sunday, including Chicago’s second loss in a row after blowing a 5-1 lead in St. Paul the night before, and the completion of that Devils-Lightning game suspended in Newark on Friday night. Home teams listed first:

headline: Strong Finish by Ogilvy in Start to the PGA Season
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii  Geoff Ogilvy came to Maui this year with a different set of golf clubs and a new sponsor’s name on his cap. But the only significant changes in his performance at the SBS Championship at Kapalua Resort were in his margin of victory and the identity of the runner-up.

headline: Word of the Day | sonorous
text: sonorous •\sə-ˈnȯr-əs, ˈsä-nə-rəs\• adjective

headline: Heineken Buys Femsa Beer Unit in $7.6 Billion Deal
text: Update | 6:49 a.m. Heineken said Monday that it would buy the beer operations of Femsa, one of Mexico’s biggest brewers, in an all-share transaction that values the business at $7.6 billion. The move further consolidates the beer industry into a few global players, Michael J. de la Merced and Chris V. Nicholson write in The New York Times.

headline: Heineken Nears a Deal With Femsa
text: Heineken is close to buying the beer operations of Femsa, one of Mexico’s biggest brewers, for $7.5 billion to $8 billion, people briefed on the matter said Sunday. The move would further consolidate the beer industry into a few global players.

headline: News Quiz | January 11, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: A.S.P.C.A. Airlift
text: WHO arranged and paid for a “Chihuahua airlift” in which 15 homeless dogs from San Francisco were flown to New York City?

headline: North Korea Calls for Peace Treaty Talks With U.S.
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Monday proposed talks with the United States to reach a formal peace treaty that would replace the truce that halted the Korean War 57 years ago, indicating that it would not give up its nuclear weapons until Washington signed such an accord.

headline: Goldman Sachs Weighs Requirement for Charity
text: As it prepares to pay out big bonuses to employees, Goldman Sachs is considering expanding a program that would require executives and top managers to give a certain percentage of their earnings to charity, Louise Story writes in The New York Times.

headline: Video: Father of C.I.A. Bomber Speaks
text: AMMAN, Jordan–The father of the suicide bomber who blew himself up in Afghanistan, killing seven Central Intelligence Agency operatives and his Jordanian supervisor, spoke to The New York Times about his son’s attack and what drove him to it.

headline: How the AOL-Time Warner Deal Went Wrong
text: A decade ago, America Online merged with Time Warner in a deal valued at a stunning $350 billion. It was then, and is now, the largest merger in American business history.

headline: Forte in Talks to Buy Goldman’s Shanghai Property
text: Shanghai Forte Land, a Chinese property developer, is in talks to buy a high-end residential property in Shanghai from Goldman Sachs, in a deal worth more than $200 million, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the situation.

headline: U.S. Bankers Are Fed Up With British Regulations
text: A new requirement by Britain’s securities regulator that top banking executives and earners must defer 60 percent of their total compensation for a three-year period is pushing some American banks with extensive London operations to say that they just won’t take it anymore.

headline: Is President Obama a ‘Wimp’ or a ‘Warrior’?
text: That’s the question Helene Cooper asks in a Week in Review article about the “labels” that presidents and parties get. What is your perception of our president nearly a year after his inauguration? Do you think he needs to “toughen up,” do you think he’s a “warrior,” or do you think these kinds of caricatures are all just politics and punditry?

headline: China Banks Said to Lend $88 Billion in Week
text: Chinese banks made about 600 billion renminbi ($88 billion) in new loans in the first week of 2010, the Economic Information Daily reported on Monday.

headline: Art Clokey, Animator Who Created Gumby, Dies at 88
text: Art Clokey, the animator who half a century ago created Gumby, that most pliant of pop-cultural figures, died on Friday at his home in Los Osos, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Vagabond Opera
text: They may hail from Portland, Ore., but the six-piece Vagabond Opera has a far more worldly repertory. “Paris hot jazz, gut-bucket swing, tangos, Ukrainian folk-punk ballads and klezmer” are just a few of the styles the troupe, which was founded in 2002 by Eric Stern, a trained opera singer and composer, mixes together to infuse new life into an Old World art form. The group performs in 11 different languages and sings not only opera but also elements of Weimar cabaret and Arabic and Balkan forms. They promise a burlesque Hula-Hooping fire performer too. They’ll be at the Highline Ballroom on Monday as part of World Music Festival beginning at 7 p.m.

headline: Won’t You Take Me to Monkey Town?
text: If you haven’t been to Monkey Town in Williamsburg, now is the time to go. The dining and performance space is, sadly, closing its doors on Jan. 24 because of “landlord issues.” The multiroom site, which features “classic dishes from a country that doesn’t exist,” offers adventurous cuisine, including braised rabbit ravioli, smoked-cheese stuffed poblano and crispy shrimp tacos, along with even more out there live music, video art and performances. Monday will be a showcase for “Swim” a group that includes former and current members of Beirut, Rivers, Freetime, Steer and WOOL as well as the ritualistic sounds of Aaron Moore, a member of Volcano the Bear & Amolvacy.

headline: The Literary Life
text: Philip Gourevitch, the New Yorker writer and editor of the Paris Review, announced recently that he will be leaving his editor’s post soon. Catch him tonight at Barnes & Noble, where he will be appearing with the author Richard Price. Hobnob with the literary elite while they discuss Mr. Price’s acclaimed novel, “Lush Life” and also celebrate the publication of “The Paris Review Interviews, IV,” which includes conversations with Philip Roth, E. B. White, Ezra Pound, Haruki Murakami, Stephen Sondheim, William Styron and more.

headline: Blacks Leisure, a British Retailer, Considers Share Issue
text: Blacks Leisure, the British outdoor goods retailer, said it was considering an equity fund-raising of between £15 million and £20 million ($24 million to $32 million), as it posted better sales in the run-up to Christmas, Reuters reported.

headline: BofA’s Post-Merger Bonuses May Not Be Panacea
text: Bank of America‘s crew on Wall Street can breathe a sigh of relief, Reuters Breakingviews says. It looks like the bank is set to hand out 2007-like bonuses to all its investment bankers and traders.

headline: Hope of Reprieve for Bond Investors
text: It’s the slowest train wreck of the financial crisis: Commercial real estate is still screeching roughly two years after lenders jammed on the brakes, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: Are They Really Sorry?
text: What’s with the apologies, The New York Times’s editorial board wants to know. Goldman Sachs’s Lloyd Blankfein caught his fellow titans by surprise in November, admitting that “we participated in things that were clearly wrong and have reason to regret.” That came less than two weeks after he infuriated pretty much everyone else by declaring that Goldman was “doing God’s work.”

headline: Ecclestone and Genii Said to Seek Cash For Saab Bid
text: Formula One‘s billionaire promoter, Bernie Ecclestone, and investment company Genii Capital will soon have initial financing to show General Motors that they can finance a purchase of carmaker Saab, Dagens Industri reported.

headline: N.Y. Fed Says Geithner Not Involved in A.I.G. Issue
text: Timothy Geithner, the former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, wasn’t aware of efforts to limit American International Group‘s bailout disclosures because the regulator’s top lawyer didn’t think the issue merited his attention, the lawyer told lawmakers, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: In Britain, Tate Trustees Pull Out of Hedge Fund Investments
text: It seems that the Tate Gallery, the charitable organization that runs two of London’s best-known museums, is no longer feeling the love for hedge funds.

headline: Macquarie Said to Mull $4 Billion Electricity Network Bid
text: Macquarie, the Australian investment bank, has teamed up with the Canadian Pension Plan and the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority to bid for an electricity network in Britain, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Strategies, at Smaller Prices
text: The lure of hedge funds was always their mix of mystery, complexity and exclusivity. In this post-bear-market, post-Madoff world, though, the cachet belongs to investments that are clear, simple and easy to buy and sell, The New York Times’s Conrad de Aenlle writes.

headline: Virgin Said to Talk to Blackstone on Northern Rock
text: Virgin Money, controlled by the British entrepreneur Richard Branson, has approached the Blackstone Group to seek backing for a new bid for the state-owned British bank Northern Rock, The Telegraph reported.

headline: 3i Said to Eye $1.6 Billion Growth Capital Fund
text: 3i Group, the British private equity firm, is planning to raise a £1 billion ($1.6 billion) fund to buy minority stakes in small businesses, in a return to its investment roots, The Sunday Times reported.

headline: Future Capital Eyes Biofuels Plant
text: A partnership set up by the investment boutique Future Capital Partners plans to raise £236 million ($380.6 million) for a biofuel plant it will construct in Grimsby, in northern England.

headline: Dubai’s Arabtec May Be in for Big Losses
text: Arabtec Holding, based in Dubai, may need a $1.7 billion investment by Abu Dhabi’s Aabar Investments to cope with future losses, analysts said on Sunday, as the construction company’s shares fell 6.9 percent.

headline: You Are Not What Your Record Says You Are
text: The Fifth Down wrote a blog post on Nov. 25 suggesting that the Ravens were the sleeper team of 2009 and that the Jets had more than a pulse.

headline: ‘That’s the Ticket,’ Winfrey Magazine Declares
text: Golden tickets aren’t just for Willy Wonka anymore. Now Oprah Winfrey is getting into the act.

headline: London’s ICA Celebrates the Art of Confusion
text: London’s Institute of Contemporary Art is going esoteric this month with an exhibition called “For the blind man in the dark room looking for the black cat that isn’t there,” a collection of works from more than 20 artists that focuses on the lack of knowledge, unlearning and “productive confusion” as ways to understand the world.

headline: Citi’s Japan Head Said to Return to N.Y.
text: The head of Citigroup in Japan, Douglas Peterson, is returning to New York after overseeing the sale of assets in Japan to help the banking company repay the government for its bailout during the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Chinese Brokers Vie for Trading Program
text: Eleven Chinese brokerages including Citic Securities and Haitong Securities will vie to be included in a pilot program for margin trading and short selling following a nationwide test run in 2008, The China Securities Journal reported, citing an unidentified regulator.

headline: Greenberg Blames Goldman for A.I.G.’s Collapse
text: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive at the American International Group, apparently thinks he knows who’s responsible for the collapse of the insurance behemoth: Goldman Sachs.

headline: Japan Said to Distance JAL From Delta and American
text: A decision on whether Delta Air Lines and American Airlines will be allowed to invest in Japan Airlines will not be made until the struggling carrier has a new management in place, Reuters reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Moist, Crepuscular, Pullulate, Lugubrious
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the words that grate on their ears.

headline: Urban ‘Creative Class’ Dismissed
text: Today’s idea: Perhaps nurturing a “creative class” isn’t the key to reviving industrial cities after all. An urban guru has second thoughts about his once-hopeful prescription, and now some civic leaders who bought into it aren’t happy.

headline: ESolar Strikes Deal to Build China Plants
text: ESolar, an American solar power company whose investors include Google and Oak Investment Partners, said Saturday it would help build a series of solar thermal power plants in China, as the world’s biggest emitter of greenhouse gases tries to decrease its reliance on coal, imported gas and oil.

headline: Was Arizona-Green Bay One for the Ages or Just One for the Record Books?
text: If you ask the Cardinals, Sunday’s 51-45 shootout victory over Green Bay should be considered one of the greatest games in N.F.L. history.

headline: Rumors of an Allianz Bid Drive Up Swiss Life Shares
text: Allianz is preparing a bid for Swiss Life Holding, Switzerland’s biggest life insurer, according to a report from the French Web site Wansquare, which cited various Swiss banking sources.

headline: Russian Tycoons Said to Plan Big London Listings
text: It appears that Russian oligarchs still have a soft spot for the London Stock Exchange. Several Russian tycoons are preparing for multibillion dollar London listings, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Have Women Done It?
text: An economist writes about recent articles on women taking over the work force.

headline: Ask About Improv Everywhere
text: Editor’s note, April 2: a few weeks after this feature appeared, Charlie Todd of Improv Everywhere lied to City Room repeatedly as we questioned him on whether one of his stunts was an April Fool’s hoax (it was). While the unwritten laws of the Internet prevent us from taking these posts down, we can’t vouch for anything he says here.

headline: Under Fire Again, Geithner Said to Retain Support
text: Even as he faces renewed criticism for the handling of the American International Group‘s bailout, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner still has the support of President Obama and Democratic leaders in Congress, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Winter Offensive | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Ford’s Global Focus
text: DETROIT — Media previews are about to begin. But overnight Ford revealed photos and information of perhaps one of the most important cars that we’ll see at the show — the new Ford Focus.

headline: Shares Edge Higher as Investors Await Earnings
text: As companies began releasing fourth-quarter results on Monday, the question on Wall Street was not so much whether businesses turned a profit but how they did so.

headline: House Lawmakers Return to Focus on Jobs, Health Care
text: The second session of the 111th Congress opens this week as the House returns to begin what promises to be an intense and partisan year.

headline: Thiel’s Fund Said to Fall 25% in 2009
text: The markets were good to many investors last year. But Peter Thiel apparently wasn’t one of them.

headline: Sampler: Same-Sex Marriage Goes to Court and Pancho Villa’s Son Dies in Hayward
text: Same-Sex Marriage Heads to Court | The first federal trial over the issue of same sex marriage begins on Monday in San Francisco. It will address whether the 2008 ballot vote to ban same-sex marriage in the state was unconstitutional. The trial is unusual on several fronts: It will include testimony from two gay couples at the center of the case, video coverage will be available at some point on YouTube and the two lawyers representing the gay couples were courtroom adversaries who argued opposite sides in the battle over the fate of the 2000 presidential election. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The New York Times]

headline: Overmedication in the Nursing Home
text: The number jumped out at me as I was reading a newly published study on mental health treatment in nursing homes: 71 percent.

headline: Jive Software Grows Up
text: We last looked at Jive Software in April, when the Sequoia Capital portfolio company was learning how to survive during the Great Recession, spurred on by its stark slide show called “R.I.P. Good Times.”

headline: The New Lawyers
text: Because of the economic crisis, new lawyers who thought they were destined for the boardroom have found themselves spending a year defending the poor.

headline: The Early Word: Unions on Health Care
text: The fight over how to pay for a overhaul of the health care system breaks out into the open today as top labor leaders head to the White House to criticize a proposal to tax family health insurance policies — the so called “Cadillac” plans worth more than $23,000 — because they fear it would hit many generous union-sponsored health plans.

headline: Too big to fail fail?
text: I’m puzzled by what David Warsh says about me (not for the first time):

headline: Media Equation: NBC Listens to Its Elders
text: In today’s Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Ford Sweeps Car and Truck of the Year
text: DETROIT — The Ford Motor Company’s strong showing in 2009 was reaffirmed Monday with a sweep of the North American Car of the Year and North American Truck of the Year Awards.

headline: Reaching Consensus on the Klamath
text: The second half of an agreement that parties hope will govern water use and lead to the restoration of the Klamath River, a contentious stretch of water in southern Oregon and northern California, has been reached by some two dozen groups.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Jacquelyn Jablonski, Model
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Speed Read for Monday, Jan. 11
text: Highlights from media coverage in The New York Times today:

headline: Ninth Church Vandalized in Malaysia as Tensions Rise
text: BANGKOK  A ninth church was vandalized Monday in Malaysia in a series of arson attacks that have raised religious tensions surrounding a dispute over the use of the word “Allah” by Christians in this mostly Muslim nation.

headline: War’s Fury No Longer Pauses for Afghan Winter
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s high mountains and harsh weather once meant that winter was a respite from much of the war’s violence, but as the deaths of six Western soldiers in three separate attacks on Monday show, this winter is proving to be different.

headline: In Citi Unit, a Study in Why Size Matters
text: A Citigroup unit called Global Transaction Services, or G.T.S., which converts currencies, helps send payments to American military contractors and processes passport applications, is an example of why Congress will have a hard time breaking up institutions deemed too big to fail, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: Investor Alwaleed Says Citigroup ‘on Right Path’
text: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, the Saudi billionaire who is the head of Kingdom Holding and a shareholder in Citigroup said the giant American bank had put the worst behind it and was now on the right path, Reuters reported.

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Monday morning.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Cheerleading From Washington
text: DETROIT — Although he didn’t bring pompoms, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood made a kickoff speech at the North American International Auto Show that was largely an exercise in cheerleading.

headline: Another Claim of Prosecutorial Misconduct
text: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Less Salt, Please, the City Asks
text: First New York City required restaurants to cut out trans fat. Then it made restaurant chains post calorie counts on their menus. Now it wants to protect people from another health scourge: salt.

headline: Talk to The Times: Micheline Maynard, Aviation Correspondent
text: Micheline Maynard, the senior business correspondent for The New York Times who covers the airline industry and aviation, is answering questions from readers Jan. 11-15, 2010. Questions may be e-mailed to askthetimes@nytimes.com.

headline: Vain Glorious | The Body Shop Originals
text: With Vain Glorious, The Moment breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

headline: Jonathan Gruber
text: Oy. I sort of missed the controversy over Jon Gruber and his contract with HHS. For those who haven’t been following this, Gruber — who is one of the three or four top health care economists in the nation — turns out to have a large research grant from the Department of Health and Human Services, for modeling the consequences of various reform plans. This has led some people, mainly Marcy Wheeler at Firedoglake, to question Gruber’s objectivity.

headline: Supreme Court Blocks YouTube Coverage of Same-Sex Marriage Case
text: The United States Supreme Court decided on Monday (.pdf) to block videotaped coverage for the first few days of a federal trial in San Francisco that was supposed to be available on YouTube.

headline: What to Watch Monday: Lose the Suit?
text: “How I Met Your Mother” (CBS, 8 p.m.), in its 100th episode, teases us with the possibility that Barney (Neil Patrick Harris) might give up suits for love. More vexing for some fans was the thought that they had waited five seasons only to find out that Rachel Bilson, who guest stars, was the mother. The rational ones realize that once there’s a mother, there’s no more show.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: 2012 Ford Focus
text: Update | 12:14 p.m.

headline: Solar and Biomass Plants to Work in Tandem in China
text: China’s plans to build 2,000 megawatts of solar thermal power using technology from a California company, eSolar, will also include the construction of biomass power plants to generate electricity when the sun sets.

headline: Thrust Temporarily Into Public Service
text: Some law students respond to a higher calling to create justice and serve the common good.  Others respond to the call of the money gods, the pedigree and the cerebral challenge. But the economic crisis of 2009 has created an unusual laboratory where some graduating students who thought they were heading for the corner office were thrust into crowded courtrooms.

headline: Citi’s North American Retail Banking Head to Resign
text: The head of Citigroup‘s North American consumer banking business, Teresa A. Dial, has stepped down for personal reasons and will become a senior adviser, the bank said on Monday.

headline: The Worst in TV? It’s Time for the Bennies
text: The Oscars have their foil in the Golden Raspberry Awards, which have been saluting the worst that Hollywood has to offer since 1981. But what about the small screen’s most awful? The Emmys have no counterbalance at the moment.

headline: Why Did ‘Big Love’ Change Its Credits? God Only Knows
text: This post might contain spoilers if you consider an opening theme song a narrative element.

headline: Europe’s OK; the euro isn’t
text: One addendum to today’s column: Europe is OK, but the single currency is having exactly the same problems ugly Americans warned about before it was created.

headline: The Logic of Looking Busy
text: Last week, Nate Silver ran the numbers on the odds of experiencing airborne terror, and found that there has been “one terrorist incident per 11,569,297,667 miles flown” in the last ten years. This means, in turn, that your chances of being on “a given departure which is the subject of a terrorist incident have been 1 in 10,408,947.”

headline: Down in the Trenches
text: In a press kit for Josephus Thimister’s first haute couture collection in a decade, in Paris on Jan. 24, I came across an intriguing photograph taken for Vogue by Steven Meisel. A millennial portrait of youngish world-shakers, it included Thimister, Hedi Slimane, Veronique Branquinho, Roberto Menichetti, and Miguel Adrover. In a fairly short time, these designers were to move away from the frontline of fashion—Mr. Slimane to photography, Mr. Thimister to Charles Jourdan—while others in the portrait, notably Nicolas Ghesquiere and Hussein Chalayan, were to hold our attention and still others, like Olivier Theyskens, seemed to enter a stage of limbo, between jobs. A number of stars are not included in the portrait—no Alber Elbaz, who was then leaving Saint Laurent for Lanvin, no Phoebe Philo, who was at Chloé at the time, and no Christopher Bailey, who perhaps had not yet proven himself at Burberry. Maybe the only thing group portraits tell us is to beware of group portraits. This is a highly unstable business, as we’ve learned in the last few years.

headline: Resting Your Starters, Revisited: Does Belichick Deserve Criticism?
text: The Colts and Coach Jim Caldwell never heard the end of their decision to rest starters in the third quarter of the Indianapolis-Jets game in Week 16.

headline: The Desktop: It’s Alive!
text: Pity the poor desktop computer.

headline: Starting Over in Lexington: The Picnic Lesson
text: When I arrived in Lexington, Ky., to give a speech to the workers at a factory that SRC Holdings had just acquired, I truly felt as if I had gone back in time. I was giving a speech just as I had some 30 years ago to convince a bunch of people that their jobs depended on opening their books and running the place as if they owned it.

headline: Monday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Toyota Promises ‘Affordable’ Hydrogen Fuel-Cell Vehicle
text: DETROIT — Toyota announced here on Monday that it plans to begin public sales of an “affordable,” highly fuel-efficient hydrogen fuel-cell vehicle in the United States by 2015 – or sooner, if refueling infrastructure becomes available.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Toyota FT-CH
text: Update | 12:41 p.m. More on the Toyota FT-CH:

headline: Detroit Auto Show: 18 Degrees Outside, but This Mercedes Seems to Be Melting
text: DETROIT — At 7:45 Monday morning, Mercedes-Benz showed off the lines of its new design language in the form of a sculpture — a two-and-a-half ton silver resin model that appeared to be rising from or sinking into a fabric floor. The slick silver skin, Mercedes said, was supposed to suggest the work of snow or sand or water — or the Terminator films.

headline: Ex-Wrigley Chief Joins Greenhill
text: William D. Perez, the former chief executive of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company and Nike, will join Greenhill & Company as a senior adviser, the boutique investment bank said Monday.

headline: New York Ripe for Electric Cars, Study Says
text: New Yorkers, start your electric cars.

headline: Video: A Blind Photographer and ‘The Miracle Worker’
text: When the coming revival of William Gibson’s “Miracle Worker,” starring Alison Pill as Annie Sullivan and Abigail Breslin as Helen Keller, opens in March, a blind photographer will have helped bring it to Broadway.

headline: London Theater Journal: Silence Speaks Volumes
text: Theater people are said to live for applause, and London theatergoers, although slightly less enthusiastic than their New York counterparts, are usually happy to oblige at the drop of a curtain. So it was strange –- and oddly refreshing — to experience the loud silence that greeted the end of the first act of “Our Class,” which I saw over the weekend in one of its final performances at the National Theater, where it opened in September. I was reminded that sometimes the sound of no hands clapping is a greater tribute than the collective clamor of many.

headline: Was ‘Simpsons’ Episode Edited to Spare Seth MacFarlane’s Feelings?
text: Update | 2:35 p.m.  Someone get Chief Wiggum on the case! A special 20th anniversary episode of “The Simpsons” ended with a thank-you message from the show’s producers to viewers, but appeared to omit a joke at the expense of their Fox colleague and sometime-rival Seth MacFarlane.

headline: Obama Weighs Tax on Banks to Cut Deficit
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will try to recoup for taxpayers as much as $120 billion of the money spent to bail out the financial system, most likely through a tax on large banks, administration and Congressional officials said Monday.

headline: Reporting on a Scarcity of Reporting Without Reporting
text: There’s a study from the Project for Excellence in Journalism that uses a small data set from Baltimore to reach some conclusions we all could have guessed at: Much of the news blogging consists of annotating the reporting of others. This post will be no different.

headline: Making Art of a Troubled Past
text: The Bagger spent the weekend having a meta-media moment, which is only natural when one writes about oneself in the third person. (It’s also handy when you’re the director of an acclaimed post-modern film). We had the urge to live-Tweet our own TimesTalk interview with James McAvoy — luckily someone else did it for us — and, like everyone else, checked out our own ZIP code on this nifty interactive Netflix usage map. Whatever, it’s better than self-Googling.

headline: In a Game Like Cardinals-Packers, Why Not Onside Kicks?
text: When two teams are breaching defenses as effortlessly as the Cardinals and the Packers were Sunday, does it make sense to try more onside kicks?

headline: Venture Capitalists Eye the Doctor’s Office
text: In a recent story, I talked with venture capitalists about their technology predictions for 2010 in computers, green technology, the Web and business software. But I left out a big area that tech investors are excited about: health care.

headline: Thain Weighs In on Financial Reform
text: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch and an architect of its sale to Bank of America during the financial crisis, has lain low since he left the financial industry last year. (And with good reason, given the hail of criticism he has faced.)

headline: App to Find Taco Trucks
text: Gourmet food trucks are all the rage, now offering upscale mobile meals of everything from carnitas and crepes to schnitzel and cupcakes. While that might seem like good news to foodies everywhere, there is a problem. Where do you find these trucks?

headline: Detroit Auto Show: With Granite, GMC Goes Beyond Countertops
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 11: GMC Granite concept

headline: Playoffs Q. and A. With Mike Tanier
text: Mike Tanier, an analyst for footballoutsiders.com who writes the game previews each week for The Times, answered readers’ questions on Monday (in the comment section below) about the N.F.L. playoffs.

headline: A Block Where Chase Has the Corners Covered
text: There are blocks in New York that are packed with banks. A Citibank stares across the street at a Capital One here, a Wachovia is steps from an HSBC there.

headline: Obama Considers Bank Fee to Help Cut Deficit
text: President Obama is likely to propose a fee on financial institutions to help reduce the federal deficit when he releases his budget plans in February, although the details remain unresolved, according to administration officials.

headline: The Surgeon General’s Weight Struggle
text: Given that two of three Americans are overweight, does it matter that the new surgeon general, Dr. Regina M. Benjamin, also struggles with her weight?

headline: Under the Radar: Five Questions About ‘Space Panorama’
text: In the solo show “Space Panorama,” playing as part of the Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater, Andrew Dawson recreates the entire Apollo 11 moon landing with nothing more than his hands, a table and Shostakovich’s 10th Symphony.

headline: A Rogue Homeless Shelter
text: Dan de Vaul houses dozens of homeless men and women on his ranch in central California, but neighbors and the authorities take issue.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1. ) “Avatar”: Socialist propaganda, or a full-throated defense of property rights?

headline: Fonts: Al Gore’s New Number 1
text: Since words and fonts go together like peas and forks, co-vocabularists may be interested in this delightful tale from the type foundry Typotheque regarding Al Gore’s involvement in the design of his new book, “Our Choice”:

headline: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 2
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you’ll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Allah – the Word
text: It was 2006 when I sat with a friend, Hikmat Farha, at the foot of a snow-capped Mount Hermon. Our conversation was about politics, as it usually is in Lebanon, and to make a point, he cited Imam Ali, warrior, sage and seventh-century caliph whom Shiite Muslims consider the divinely sanctioned successor to the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: In Reid’s Comments, Hints of Obama’s Own Words
text: Senator Harry Reid’s comments about Barack Obama’s race – and its positive implications for his presidential run in 2008 – have been well aired by now.

headline: A Homemade Homeless Shelter
text: Dan de Vaul has taken in dozens of homeless people by building ramshackle, illegal housing on his ranch in San Luis Obispo, Calif.  Some see him as a good Samaritan, but others consider the ranch to be a dangerous eyesore.

headline: Blagojevich Retreats From Race Remarks About Obama
text: CHICAGO – Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, is not the only one apologizing for using racially charged language when it comes to President Obama. On Monday, Rod R. Blagojevich, the indicted, ousted former governor of Illinois turned reality television show contestant and Elvis impersonator, had his own apologies to offer.

headline: China Sees ‘Avatar’ (and Criticizes It, Too)
text: While the numerous arguments inspired by James Cameron‘s science-fiction film “Avatar” have hardly quieted down in its fourth week of release, another group of voices has been added to the debate. On Jan. 2, “Avatar” opened in China, inspiring bloggers there to race back to their computers and pick apart the messages they are finding in that 3-D blockbuster.

headline: Pity the Packers
text: For all but the most die-hard Cardinals fans  and frankly, there may be 12 whose tenure stretches longer than 18 months  it is hard not to feel bad for the Packers. They did, after all, save wild-card weekend from a series of blowouts and “Ode to the Patriots Dynasty” soliloquies with their frantic comeback in Arizona, only to endure the final crushing indignity of a 51-45 overtime loss.

headline: Cuomo Demands Bonus Data From 8 Big Banks
text: Update | 12:52 p.m. Andrew M. Cuomo, New York’s attorney general, took aim at Wall Street’s looming bonuses on Monday, sending letters to eight of the nation’s biggest banks demanding information on how they structured those payouts.

headline: N.C.A.A. Wants the Young Madder About March
text: With this issue, In Advertising returns from its year-end hiatus. And because next Monday is a holiday, look for next week’s issue on Tuesday, Jan. 19.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: VW New Compact Coupe Concept
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 11: Volkswagen New Compact Coupe concept

headline: In New York City, a Chilly Library Has Its Rewards
text: In the pantheon of New York City jobs, many people face rugged extremes. Ironworkers brave fierce winds high on beams. Subway track workers traverse dank tunnels. Firefighters climb through flames.

headline: Hoeven Plans Bid for N.D. Senate Seat
text: North Dakota Gov. John Hoeven, a widely popular Republican, will announce that he is running for Senate on Monday evening, according to a state Republican official, a decision that likely increases the G.O.P.‘s odds of capturing the seat.

headline: Warming Imperils Crops in India and China
text: China and India, which constitute about 37 percent of the world’s population, face a future of sharply lower crop yields as a consequence of climate change, leading scientists in both nations warned recently.

headline: Monday Puzzle: Moonlighting Triangles
text: With most of the country in a state of deep freeze, let’s thaw ourselves mentally by imagining warmer climes. So for our first puzzle of the new year, here’s a story about a pair of do-it-yourselfers, Penny and Roger, who have just finished tiling their poolside patio. Do you feel the warm sunshine on your back already? Good!

headline: Different Tweets for Different Folks
text: In the new social media order, everyone will broadcast everything about themselves all the time, and generation gaps will be created at lightning speed. Major awards shows are no exception: both Adam Shankman, a producer of the Oscars, and Ricky Gervais, the host of the Golden Globes, have taken to Twitter. But over the weekend, they revealed very differing takes. While Mr. Shankman, also a judge on “So You Think You Can Dance,” was busy promoting the Academy Award dance auditions, asking his followers what they thought the 10 best picture nominees would be, and, like everyone else, admitting an obsession with “Jersey Shore,” Mr. Gervais was more reserved.

headline: A Fight for the Homeless and Against Authority
text: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif.  Burly, bearded and gleefully obscene, Dan de Vaul does not look the part of the bleeding-heart homeless advocate, sporting as he does a feather-topped cowboy hat, a large collection of guns and a bushel of hoary wisecracks.

headline: Featured Recipe: Farfalle With Gorgonzola, Arugula and Cherry Tomatoes
text: There was a time when pasta dishes dressed with just cheese, cream or milk were popular, at least with me and my family, but today they seem stodgy and fat. Here’s a variation on a classic dish, pasta with Gorgonzola, that adds color, acidity and strong flavor without increasing the cooking time a single second. And it increases the shopping and prep times by only about five minutes.

headline: Attacking, and Defending, Hard-to-Open Packaging
text: The hard-to-open packaging on Barbie dolls and other gifts underneath the Christmas tree has left many consumers ripping. Yes, these plastic fortresses deter shoplifters and help reduce the wastefulness of bulky cardboard boxes, manufacturers say, but at what cost?

headline: Abu Dhabi Royal Acquitted in Torture Trial
text: Updated | 1:38 p.m. A court in Abu Dhabi ruled on Sunday that 45 minutes of video showing a member of the emirate’s ruling family torturing an Afghan grain merchant — by stuffing his face with sand, firing a machine gun close to his body, hitting him with a whip and an electric cattle prod, cutting his bare buttocks by striking him a nail embedded in a stick and driving over him — did not prove the prosecution’s case that the sheik was guilty of a crime.

headline: Prize Patrol: Judges Announced for Sundance Film Festival
text: Enter the judges. The Sundance Film Festival, which begins on Jan. 21 in Utah, announced on Monday the members of the five juries awarding prizes. The awards will be presented on Jan. 30 by David Hyde Pierce.

headline: YouTube Moment on Hold in Same-Sex Marriage Case in San Francisco
text: The video above appears to be of technical checks at the federal court in San Francisco in preparation for what was supposed to be Monday’s YouTube coverage of the same-sex marriage case that opens today. On Monday morning, the United States Supreme Court issued a brief statement barring the videotaped coverage, at least for few days, until it had time to review the issue more thoroughly. The order halted the decision to allow “real-time streaming” of the trial.

headline: Counting of Calories Isn’t Always Accurate
text: Anyone who counts calories by using the figures on menus in fast-food restaurants or on the packages of frozen meals may want to count again. When researchers tested the food served in 29 chain restaurants and 10 frozen meals sold in supermarkets, they found that their calorie content averaged considerably more than the stated values.

text: The private equity industry had one of its worst years for fund-raising in 2009, and the situation is not expected to get much better this year, Preqin, a private equity data provider, reported in a new study on the industry.

headline: From Toshiba: 3-D 24/7
text: When attending a trade show, one quickly learns not to judge the quality of a product based on what you see on the show floor. At car shows, every vehicle is scratch-free, looks stunning and smells great. And at the Consumer Electronics Show last week, every television produced the most gorgeous picture you have ever seen, with deep blacks and terrific resolution.

headline: Burgers Without the Beef
text: Every time I read an article like the one in last month’s New York Times about the safety of beef, I tell my son, yet again, that I don’t want him eating beef at school or anywhere else that we haven’t agreed upon. Liam loves burgers, but he’s seen the movie "Food, Inc.," so he doesn’t argue too much. And he’s very happy to eat burgers that aren’t made with beef. I think it’s not so much the meat as much as the pleasure of eating a browned patty in a bun, with ketchup, that he likes (and that I like too). So I wasn’t surprised the other morning when, thinking out loud, I asked “What shall I do for Recipes for Health this week?” Without missing a beat, he replied, “Burgers.”

headline: Chicago Flutist Apologizes to L.A. After Hitting Sour Notes
text: Update | 3:21 p.m. A flutist with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra who briefly took a temporary post with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, only to return to Chicago, apologized for his departure and denied a news report in which he appeared to be critical of the Philharmonic. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave from the Chicago orchestra when he joined the Philharmonic on a one-year trial basis starting in September. But earlier this month he told The Chicago Sun-Times that he had decided not to remain in Los Angeles, telling that newspaper that the Philharmonic has “no tradition there — no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble.”

headline: Eric Rohmer, New Wave Film Director, Has Died
text: Eric Rohmer, the French critic and filmmaker who was one of the founding figures of the internationally influential movement that became known as the French New Wave, and the director of more than 50 films for theaters and television, including the Oscar-nominated “My Night at Maud’s” (1969), died on Monday. He was 89.

headline: Violence in Angola Puts South Africa on the Defensive
text: In the aftermath of Friday’s chilling attack on Togo’s national team, that left three dead, before the start of the African Cup of Nations, South African officials tried to separate the events in Angola from ongoing concerns about security for the World Cup in June.

headline: Now Brewing | Starbucks Gets a Makeover
text: In the 1990s, Starbucks was opening one new store per day. Green mermaid logos popped up on retail facades everywhere, sometimes within feet of one another, making the sameness from store to store all the more noticeable. But it’s not the ’90s anymore, and when Starbucks stock began dropping in 2007, the Seattle-based company realized, among other things, that the cookie-cutter approach to store design had fallen out of fashion. Last year, Starbucks announced it would renovate its thousands of company-owned stores, in 52 countries, to be more sustainable and to look, well, less global and more local.

headline: Los Angeles Museum Chooses Deitch
text: We have a winner: as expected, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles said on Monday that it would name Jeffrey Deitch as its director. Mr. Deitch, the New York gallery owner, has also helped start an art advisory service for clients at Citibank, and founded his Deitch Projects in 1996. Mr. Deitch also managed Sotheby’s 20th-century Art Gallery Program, and in 1997 Sotheby’s bought 50 percent of Deitch Projects, a relationship that has since dissolved. Other contenders for the position were believed to include Tobias Meyer, the head of Sotheby’s contemporary art department worldwide and Sotheby’s principal auctioneer, and Samuel Keller, the art-fair impresario who ran Art Basel and Art Basel Miami Beach until he became director of the Beyeler Foundation in Riehen, Switzerland.

headline: ‘View From the Bridge’ Actor Is Down for the Count
text: Even bogus boxing can be hazardous on a Broadway stage. Santino Fontana, who plays the young suitor Rodolpho in the current Broadway production of “A View From the Bridge,” remains out of the show since sustaining a minor concussion from a boxing scene with Liev Schreiber’s character during a performance New Year’s weekend. Mr. Fontana left the show temporarily under doctor’s orders, according to a statement on Thursday from a publicist for the show, and he was scheduled to still be off for Monday night’s performance. It is not clear when he will return. The role of Rodolpho is being played by the understudy, Morgan Spector. Mr. Fontana sustained the concussion during a scene in which Rodolpho is drawn into sparring by Eddie Carbone (Mr. Schreiber), the jealous uncle of Rodolpho’s love interest, Catherine (Scarlett Johansson). No one from the production was available to comment on Monday about Mr. Fontana’s health or whether the boxing scene has been re-choreographed, the publicist said.

headline: ‘Avatar,’ ‘Hangover’ Crash Writers Guild Party
text: “Avatar” has been lauded for its technological wizardry and the all-encompassing movie experience it offers. As for the writing: not so much. But that hasn’t prevented the Writers Guild of America from nominating James Cameron, the movie’s writer and director, for best original screenplay. He’ll face off against Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber for “(500) Days of Summer”; John Lucas and Scott More for the “The Hangover”; Mark Boal for “The Hurt Locker”; and Joel and Ethan Coen for “A Serious Man.”

headline: Simon Cowell Confirms He’s Leaving ‘American Idol’
text: Simon Cowell, the music impresario and tough-talking “American Idol” judge you love to hate, will leave “American Idol,” the Fox reality competition, after the current season, he said on Monday. Mr. Cowell made the announcement during a Fox presentation at the Television Critics Association press tour in California. Though there had been speculation about Mr. Cowell’s status with the show for several weeks, he said that he had only formally reached an agreement with Fox “at half-past-10″ this morning to bring another reality series, “The X Factor,” to the network next year. Mr. Cowell said he would leave “American Idol” to focus on that show. Bill Carter is at the event and will have updates on Media Decoder.

headline: New Jersey Vote Backs Marijuana for Severely Ill
text: TRENTON  The New Jersey Legislature approved a measure on Monday that would make the state the 14th in the nation, but one of the few on the East Coast, to legalize the use of marijuana to help patients with chronic illnesses.

headline: James Roday and Michael Weston Join the Cast of ‘Extinction’

The production is scheduled to run at Off Broadway’s Cherry Lane Theater from Feb. 13 to March 14. Directed by Wayne Kasserman, the cast will also include Amanda Detmer and Stefanie E. Frame, who appeared with the two men in a run of the play in Los Angeles last fall.

headline: Union Chief Blasts Health Benefits Tax

headline: Hunting Fossil Viruses in Human DNA
text: The borna virus is at once obscure and grotesque. It can infect mammals and birds, but scientists know little about its effects on its victims. In some species it seems to be harmless, but it can drive horses into wild fits. The horses sometimes kill themselves by smashing in their skulls. In other cases, they starve themselves to death. Some scientists have even claimed that borna viruses alter human behavior, playing a role in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, although others say there is no solid evidence of a link.

headline: F.T.C.: Has Internet Gone Beyond Privacy Policies?
