headline: The Match Game
text: I don’t put a great deal of stock in overly precise efforts to pair food and wine. I understand the desire to get things right — who wants wine and food to blot each other out? — but obsessive efforts, special methods, pairing wheels, etc., hold very little interest for me. I just want to have a good meal, with good wine, and I want to enjoy them both, together. I don’t think selecting proper wines is a problem, once you get in the habit of drinking wine with your meals.

headline: When Is Grabbing the Face Mask Not a Face-Mask Penalty?
text: To some, the picture speaks 1,000 words and four of them are: the Packers were robbed. The image of Cardinals cornerback Michael Adams with his index finger hooked on Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers’s face mask was captured far and wide, sparking the question of whether it was a penalty and why it did not negate the fumble Adams caused. The question gets louder because the fumble Adams caused turned into the game-winning touchdown in overtime of the N.F.C. wild card playoff game when linebacker Karlos Dansby ran it into the end zone.

And yet, as the show “Big Love” entered its fourth season last night, Michele Gazzolo, an anthropologist and writer who lives in southwest Michigan, is once again taken by the idea of a life with “sister-wives” to share the daily parenting chores.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: For Honda, One More Try at a Sporty Hybrid
text: DETROIT — After showing two concept versions of its CR-Z, most recently at the Tokyo Motor Show last October, Honda finally introduced the real thing here.

headline: Now Showing | Andrea Branzi
text: If you happen to be in Paris this week, it’s your last chance to see “Grandi Legni,” an exhibition of work by the Italian architect and designer Andrea Branzi at the Azzedine Alaia Gallery. Organized by two well-known Milan galleries — Design Gallery Milano and Nilufar — the exhibition features large-scale, mixed-media works that are the latest in Branzi’s continuing investigation of the anthropological, “animist roots” of design. Branzi, who was part of the radical architecture studio Archizoom in the 1960s and was a co-founder of the Domus Academy, feels that in its quest for formal perfection, contemporary design has hit a self-referential brick wall. In these seemingly primitive, totemic pieces, he employs old wood beams (the “big woods” of the exhibition’s title), semiprecious stones, mosaic and a new printing technology from 3M to search for the soul of design between the ancient and the modern.

headline: Healthy Aging, With Nary a Supplement
text: The Great Recession, so I’m told, has been great for one segment of the economy  the makers of pills and potions that offer the promise of keeping people healthy. A middle-aged woman remarked as she perused the supplement shelves in my local health food store (I was buying bulgur): “I can’t afford to get sick. I lost my job and I have no health insurance.”

headline: Hedge Funds Had a Banner Year in 2009

Hedge Fund Research, which tracks a number of funds, said its index of fund returns gained 1.25 percent in December, bringing last year’s gains up to 20.04 percent.

headline: Pinot Noir With an Umlaut
text: TODAY’S word, people, is spätburgunder. Let’s say it slowly: SHPAYT-bur-GUHN-der. That’s German for pinot noir, and the time has come to say it out loud.

headline: To Treat Bed-Wetting, Healthy Doses of Patience
text: A couple of weeks ago, I saw a 5-year-old girl who was still wetting the bed every night. It’s a common complaint: at least 15 percent of healthy 5-year-olds are not reliably “dry” at night. And bed-wetting is quite common even in older children.

headline: Google Apologizes to Chinese Authors
text: BEIJING  Google has agreed to hand over a list of books by Chinese authors that it has scanned in recent years, company executives said on Monday, in an apparent effort to placate writers who say their works were digitized without their permission.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Audi’s Second Electric E-Tron
text: DETROIT — Audi introduced a second electric car prototype in Detroit today, and it’s a family affair. Like the two-seater sports car Audi showed off recently in Frankfurt and Los Angeles, the new concept is also named E-Tron. The automaker is not trying to be confusing, said Michael Dick, a member of Audi’s Management Board, interviewed in Detroit. Audi says that “E-Tron” will be the name for a family of electric cars — hopefully to gain the same kind of resonance as “quattro” and “TDI.”

headline: Amid Scandals, Northern Ireland’s Leader Takes a Leave
text: LONDON  After days of political turmoil in Northern Ireland over the personal and financial affairs of his wife, the province’s first minister, Peter Robinson, stepped down temporarily on Monday as a co-leader of the power-sharing government that has ruled the province since 2007.

headline: Unions Want Obama to Drop Tax on Benefits
text: Union leaders said Monday afternoon that they planned to tell President Obama in a meeting later in the day that it would be a costly political mistake to enact an excise tax on high-priced, employer-sponsored health benefits.

text: The truism that theater is a place for collective make-believe has never seemed more true than at “The Myopia,” David Greenspan’s madcap, mind-bending odyssey into the poetics of the stage.

headline: Aging Well, Without Pills and Potions
text: In this week’s Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about the general public’s willingness to spend money on supplements for better health. She writes:

headline: Clinton, Starting Trip, Acknowledges Possible Tensions With China
text: HONOLULU  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, embarking on her first diplomatic trip of 2010, will try to ease tensions with Japan, America’s most important Asian ally, over a stalled agreement to relocate a Marine base on the island of Okinawa.

headline: Ex-Lehman General Counsel Asked to Join A.I.G.
text: The former general counsel at Lehman Brothers, Thomas A. Russo, has been asked to play that role at the American International Group following the departure of the insurer’s top in-house lawyer, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Coal Is Linked to Cancer in China Province
text: Nonsmoking women in an area of China’s Yunnan province die of lung cancer at a rate 20 times that of their counterparts in other regions of the country  and higher than anywhere else in the world.

headline: 'Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf'
text: A. O. Scott takes a look at a very unusual relationship at the heart of Mike Nichols's 1966 film, adapted from Edward Albee's Broadway play.

headline: Onstage Boxing Packs a Wallop
text: Even bogus boxing can be hazardous on a Broadway stage. Santino Fontana, below, who plays the young suitor Rodolpho in the current Broadway production of “A View From the Bridge,” remains out of the show since sustaining a minor concussion from a boxing scene with Liev Schreiber’s character during a performance on New Year’s weekend. Mr. Fontana left the show temporarily under doctor’s orders, according to a statement on Thursday from a publicist for the show, and he was scheduled still to be off for Monday night’s performance. It is not clear when he will return. The role of Rodolpho is being played by the understudy, Morgan Spector. Mr. Fontana sustained the concussion during a scene in which Rodolpho is drawn into sparring by Eddie Carbone (Mr. Schreiber), the jealous uncle of Rodolpho’s love interest, Catherine (Scarlett Johansson). No one from the production was available to comment on Monday about Mr. Fontana’s health or whether the boxing scene has been rechoreographed, the publicist said.

headline: Chicago Flutist Denies Unkind Sentiments
text: A flutist with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra who briefly took a temporary post with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, only to return to Chicago, apologized for his departure and denied a news report in which he appeared to be critical of the Philharmonic. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave from the Chicago orchestra when he joined the Philharmonic on a one-year trial basis, starting in September. But this month he told The Chicago Sun-Times that he had decided not to remain in Los Angeles, telling that newspaper that the Philharmonic has “no tradition there  no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble.” In an e-mail message to the Philharmonic’s musicians reported by the Culture Monster blog of The Los Angeles Times (latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster), Mr. Dufour wrote that he had returned to Chicago to have shoulder surgery and apologized for “having left the season so abruptly.” He also wrote that he was “grossly misquoted” by The Chicago Sun-Times, and added, “I sincerely hope that none of you have read it, but if any of you have seen it, I beg you not to pay any attention to it.” Andrew Patner, who wrote the report for The Sun-Times, told Culture Monster that he stood behind his reporting.

headline: A Big Woo-Hoo for ‘Simpsons’
text: A Fox celebration of the 20th-anniversary episode of “The Simpsons,” above, attracted as many as 20 million viewers on Sunday, according to Nielsen’s early ratings estimates. Those preliminary audience figures may be somewhat inflated by Fox’s overtime coverage of the N.F.C. wildcard football game, which drew more than 30 million viewers to Fox for the start of prime time. But based on the estimates, Fox projected that its anniversary episode of “The Simpsons” earned the series’s highest ratings since an episode that followed the Super Bowl five years ago. Fox won the night over all, drawing 12.3 million viewers for a documentary special, “The Simpsons 20th Anniversary Special: In 3-D! On Ice!” ABC placed second, while CBS and NBC ranked third and fourth. NBC’s third-season premiere of “Chuck” averaged 7.4 million viewers.

headline: Denmark Leads the Way in Digital Care
text: COPENHAGEN  Jens Danstrup, a 77-year-old retired architect, used to bike all around town. But years of smoking have weakened his lungs, and these days he finds it difficult to walk down his front steps and hail a taxi for a doctor’s appointment.

headline: ‘Glee’ Sends Out Call for Reinforcements
text: For its second season, the Fox musical “Glee” is holding a nationwide search for three new singers. The casting calls will begin in February for professionals and amateurs, ages 16 to 26, the “Glee” executive producer Ryan Murphy announced at a press event on Monday. “Anybody and everybody now has a chance to be on a show about talented underdogs,” Mr. Murphy said. Meanwhile, Fox confirmed on Monday that “Glee” would be renewed for a second season. The show has tested its fans’ patience at times, first with a preview of the first episode in May, four months before its season premiere, and again with another four-month break this winter between the first and second halves of the season.

headline: Judges Announced for Sundance Festival
text: Enter the judges. The Sundance Film Festival, above, which begins on Jan. 21 in Utah, announced on Monday the members of the five juries awarding prizes. The awards will be presented on Jan. 30 by David Hyde Pierce. The United States dramatic competition will be evaluated by the author Russell Banks (“Cloudsplitter,” “The Sweet Hereafter”); Jason Kliot, producer of 20 films that have been screened at the festival, including “Welcome to the Dollhouse”; Karyn Kusama, director of “Aeon Flux” and “Jennifer’s Body,” the critically drubbed zombie cheerleader movie; the actress Parker Posey (“The House of Yes,” “Best in Show”); and Robert Yeoman, a cinematographer on films like “Bottle Rocket” and “Drugstore Cowboy.” Lined up for the United States documentary competition are the producer-director Greg Barker (“Sergio”); the producer-director Dayna Goldfine (“Ballets Russes”); Nancy Miller, a senior editor at Wired magazine; the filmmaker Morgan Spurlock (“Super Size Me”); and Ondi Timoner, the only filmmaker to win the Grand Jury prize at Sundance twice, for “Dig!” and “We Live in Public.”

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Auto Workers’ Union Holds Jobs Protest
text: DETROIT — Nearly 100 auto workers and labor activists demonstrated in snowy, blustery conditions near the North American International Auto Show here, calling for a federal jobs recovery bill, a national single-payer health system and a green industrial policy.

headline: Facing End-of-Life Talks, Doctors Choose to Wait
text: It’s a conversation that most people dread, doctors and patients alike. The cancer is terminal, time is short, and tough decisions loom  about accepting treatment or rejecting it, and choosing where and how to die.

headline: A Life’s Labors Lost, but So What?
text: IT’S not a good idea to ignore what your computer is trying to tell you when it starts to do that thing where every once in a while the screen freezes like an ice rink and the cursor gets stuck on it, like a stranded skater.

headline: New Film May Sway Brazil’s Vote on President
text: SANTO ANTÔNIO de JESUS, Brazil  In the opening scenes of a new Brazilian movie, a 7-year-old boy roams barefoot through the parched, cactus-filled dirt of the northeastern town of Caetés, collecting water from a creek where cows drink while his mother waits in the one-room house he shares with seven brothers and sisters.

headline: States of Suffering
text: The downturn continues to gnaw away at states’ budgets, a new report shows.

headline: Who Owns What at Tavern on the Green?
text: And so, a new front was opened Monday in the enduringly complex court struggle over the assets of the bankrupt Tavern on the Green — the Battle of the Wormy Chestnut Wood.

headline: What ‘Idol’ Will Lose When Simon Cowell Departs
text: It’s a little too easy, but it bears saying: in leaving “American Idol” to produce an American version of his own show “The X Factor,” Simon Cowell will be taking the “Idol” X factor along with him.

headline: Asked & Answered | Chris Benz
text: With his penchant for classic American sportswear, his gentlemanly manners and his coterie of well-bred friends — Elettra Wiedemann, the model/grad student is his muse — Chris Benz is a designer who evokes a courtlier time. He likes to sift through his grandmother’s attic for inspiration and he recently traded in an old photo booth for a digital camera, but as Benz acknowledges with a sigh, “it’s not the same.” Even the lipstick color he created for Lancôme, the hotly anticipated Chris and Tell, due out next month, is a “Mad Men”-era peach.

headline: Deciphering the Chatter of Monkeys and Chimps
text: Walking through the Tai forest of Ivory Coast, Klaus Zuberbühler could hear the calls of the Diana monkeys, but the babble held no meaning for him.

headline: Part 1: A Dose of Knotty Modernism. Part 2: Quaint Nostalgia.
text: As programming approaches go, the one that James Levine ventured in a concert by the Met Chamber Ensemble at Zankel Hall on Sunday evening was a doozy. The first half of the program offered vocal works by Milton Babbitt and Elliott Carter, formidable modernists for whom Mr. Levine has shown a durable affinity; the second, Richard Strauss’s “Bürger als Edelmann” Suite, quaint, nostalgic music written for a staging of Molière’s play “Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme.” Finding offers for midconcert ticket handoffs on Craigslist would have been no surprise.

headline: Coat Company Agrees to Pull Obama Billboard
text: Weatherproof Garment Company, which turned heads last week with a Times Square billboard showing President Obama in one of its coats, has agreed to take down the billboard after hearing from the White House.

headline: A Call to Rein In Cold or Hot Climate Hype
text: Richard Betts, the head of the climate impacts division at Britain’s Met Office, has contributed a very useful essay to the BBC’s always illuminating “Green Room” opinion column in which he urges climate scientists to help society avoid misinterpretations or exploitation of climate extremes — either hot or cold. I asked him a few follow-up questions and the answers follow, but first, here are a couple of excerpts from the column.

text: AOL announced in November that it planned to cut its work force by about one-third, cutting up to 2,500 positions. On Monday, AOL said that about 1,100 employees accepted a buyout offer, and that this week it would begin laying off an 1,200 more workers.

headline: Rhythms Bursting With Suspense
text: For the major events of any Noche Flamenca program, no choreographer is cited. Some are pure music anyway, but  as with many but not all other flamenco presentations  the major dance solos apparently have no author save their performers.

headline: In Florida, Fresh Talent Takes to the Stage, Along With a Veteran Team
text: MIAMI  At the end of three of the five ballets in Miami City Ballet’s new program in the Adrienne Arsht Center here, people leapt to their feet at each performance last weekend; after every work there were cheers from all parts of the large auditorium. Yet the ovations stayed brief. And I suspect that relatively few people in South Florida, many of whom are still discovering each of these ballets for the first time, realize just how remarkable this company is.

headline: One Ballplayer Heartened by McGwire’s Admission
text: People who know Mark McGwire tend to love him. For Shelley Duncan, the former Yankee who signed with Cleveland recently, his relationship with McGwire runs deep.

text: After days of relentless rumors, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles confirmed on Monday that it had chosen Jeffrey Deitch, a veteran commercial dealer and deal maker, to be its new director, a straddling of the gallery and museum worlds that has few precedents.

headline: 1987 Redux?
text: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has risen each day for the first six trading sessions of the year.

headline: A Song of Silicon Valley

headline: Mysterious, Low-Tech, Basement Barnum
text: If it were possible to pet a piece of experimental theater, that’s what you would want to do to “L’Effet de Serge,” a French poodle of a show that is ingratiating itself with downtown audiences as part of the Public Theater’s annual Under the Radar Festival. This mysterious little play reveals an unassuming, modest gentleman named Serge staging low-tech spectacles in his cluttered basement for an audience that could fit inside a bathroom.

headline: City Unveils Plan to Trim Food Industry’s Use of Salt
text: Depending on your point of view, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is either a crusader for healthy living or a public scold who likes to tell people what they should and (more often) should not eat.

headline: Bootstrapping ‘The Messenger’
text: Six and a half million dollars. That’s how much “The Messenger,” the story of two Army men tasked with delivering, as A. O. Scott put it, “the grimmest imaginable news” to military families, cost to make. A lot in the real world, to be sure, but not very much for moviedom, considering that the cast includes Woody Harrelson, Ben Foster, Samantha Morton and Steve Buscemi. To cut costs, many perks were eliminated: Mr. Harrelson and Mr. Foster shared a trailer, and the shoot was a bone-thin 28 days.

headline: In Mass. Senate Race, Candidates Sharpen Their Pitches
text: Update | 9:08 p.m. Martha Coakley, the Democrat running for Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s seat in Massachusetts, called a news conference Monday to attack her Republican rival’s stance on taxes, health care and same-sex marriage amid more signs of Democratic anxiety about the race.

headline: Citi’s Memo on Changes at Consumer Banking Unit

headline: Bank’s Losses May Spell Shake-Up in Germany
text: Even in an era of bad banking deals, the case of Munich-based Bayerische Landesbank stands out, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing reports from Frankfurt.

headline: In Some Metro Areas, Job Growth
text: Unemployment rates — that is, the percentage of workers who want jobs and can’t find them — were higher in November than a year earlier in all 372 of the nation’s metropolitan areas, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported last week. But in some metro areas, the number of nonfarm payroll jobs actually grew.

headline: Letter: Cutting Travel Costs
text: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column “10 Ways to Cut Your Travel Costs This Year” (Jan. 10), as I read this article, I thought to myself: We are still in a recession. People are spending carefully; discretionary funds are all but extinct. So, why would I go through all this trouble (10 steps) to find a cheap fare. The airlines and hotels want my money. They’ve made a fortune over the past 10 years during the boom; now they have to adjust and offer me deep discounts if they want my money. I will not be running myself ragged trying to get the best deal. Period.

headline: Letter: Traveling to Tucson
text: To the Editor: The article “36 Hours Tucson, Ariz.” (Jan. 3) gave lots of excellent suggestions about my city. I was surprised, though, that the author recommended flying to Phoenix and driving “scenic I-10” to Tucson. This is one of the most unattractive and crowded roads in Arizona, and it can be closed for hours by traffic accidents (once you leave Phoenix, there’s no alternate route). Anyone who wants to come to Tucson for just 36 hours  and spend four (or many more) hours on I-10  should instead take a flight to our convenient, uncrowded airport.

headline: Corrections
text: The 36 Hours column on Jan. 3 about Tucson, Ariz., misstated the cross street of the location of one cafe and misstated part of the name of a menu item at another cafe. The Epic Cafe is on the corner of University Boulevard, not University Avenue, and the sampler of three dishes chosen by the chef at Cafe Poca Cosa is called El Plato Poca Cosa, not La Plato Poca Cosa.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks at the 1966 Mike Nichols film “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf,” adapted from Edward Albee’s play. The film stars Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, a real-life married couple at the time, acting out their domestic drama on the screen as the characters George and Martha. About their performances, Mr. Scott says the two “probably do more acting per frame of film in this movie than you’ve ever seen in your life.” Please  share your thoughts on the performances in “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf.”

headline: Citigroup Replaces Head of Consumer Banking
text: Citigroup announced on Monday that it would replace the head of its consumer banking business  the most troubled part of its financial empire  as the company braces for fresh troubles with home mortgages and credit cards this year.

headline: A New Boss, and a Jolt of Real-World Expertise
text: When the going gets desperate, the desperate get creative. On Monday the beleaguered Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles named as its new director Jeffrey Deitch, a prominent New York art dealer. This comes less than a week after Bill Moggridge, a prominent industrial designer and businessman, became the first design practitioner to head the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in New York  an institution thought by many to lack vision.

headline: Landesbank Losses May Bring Change to German Banking
text: FRANKFURT  Even in an era of bad banking deals, the case of Bayerische Landesbank, a bank based in Munich, stands out.

headline: Stroller, Diapers, Paperwork
text: THE recent return to the United States of a 9-year-old boy who was at the center of an international abduction and custody dispute once again called attention to the issues that can complicate international travel with children, especially when one parent is staying behind.

headline: A Year After a Splashdown, Returning to the Hudson
text: In almost everyone’s mind, it ranked as one of those where-were-you-when moments: the moment on a waning January afternoon when an airplane landed in the Hudson River.

headline: Mood Music and the Times Movie Reviews API
text: Our series of posts about external uses of Times APIs continues. Today we’re showcasing MovieMusicNow.com, which uses the Times Movie Reviews API.

headline: A Backup Sees Plenty of Action Off the Field
text: Surely “Blue Mountain State,” which officially arrives Tuesday on Spike, is the show that will finally get young heterosexual men to rise up and demand programming that doesn’t presume they are sex-obsessed Neanderthals.

headline: Ben Brantley Takes Readers’ Questions on London Theater

headline: A Song of Silicon Valley
text: From Damon Darlin at Bits:

headline: A Tribute to Her Father, Heavy on Latin Percussion
text: Nattily attired in white tuxedos and black ties, the New Desi Arnaz Orchestra, a 15-member Latin swing band with strings, sent a mild percussive charge from the stage of the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening. It was the first of five performances of an engaging show written and hosted by Lucie Arnaz, in tribute to her father, the Cuban-born bandleader Desi Arnaz.

headline: Look Out, Pixar, Here Comes ‘Fantastic Mr. Fox’
text: LOS ANGELES  Figuring out which film will win the Academy Award for best animated feature is usually the easiest part of filling out a ballot for your Oscar pool. Go down the list of nominees  often only three, because so few make the cut  and find the one produced by Pixar. Circle it.

headline: Sony Switches Spider-Man Plans
text: Spider-Man and Tobey Maguire are parting ways. Mr. Maguire was set to reprise his leading role in “Spider-Man 4” in May 2011 with Sam Raimi, who directed the first three installments, returning to the helm. But following disagreements about the creative direction of the film (Hollywood translation: the script wasn’t so good and there were conflicting casting strategies), Mr. Raimi opted to move on, according to Deadline.com. Rather than move forward with a different director, Sony decided to push the button on a “Spider-Man” reboot that it has been simultaneously developing. In a press release Monday afternoon, Sony confirmed that the next “Spider-Man” movie will take Peter Parker back to high school. The new chapter, written by James Vanderbilt (“Zodiac”), will have a new cast and director and focus on “a teenager dealing with both contemporary human problems and amazing super-human crises,” Sony said. The target release date is now summer 2012. Together, the first three “Spider-Man” movies sold over $1 billion in tickets at North American theaters, according to Box Office Mojo.

headline: Scary Ad Fails to Stop Croatia From Going Red
text: On Sunday, Croatians gave Ivo Josipovic a landslide victory in the country’s presidential election despite an ad campaign by his main rival that sought to portray the avant-garde composer and law professor as a Dr. Evil-like figure scheming to return the nation to communism.

headline: Perella Hires Tokum’s Investment Team
text: Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank run by Joseph R. Perella, left, has hired Tokum Capital Management’s investment team.

headline: Side by Side, With the Guilty, After Courts Send Them Home
text: Almost 10 years in the making, “My Neighbor My Killer” examines the emotional and judicial convulsions of post-genocide Rwanda through the oral testimonies of a handful of traumatized survivors.

headline: Ads to Protest Smoking in ‘Avatar’
text: Those who oppose smoking in movies aimed at young people planned to step up their assault on the science-fiction epic “Avatar” on Tuesday with advertisements in Hollywood trade papers that accuse the film of providing the equivalent of $50 million in free tobacco advertising. The full-page ads were scheduled to run in both The Hollywood Reporter and Daily Variety. For every $100 million it earns at the box office, “Avatar” will “deliver an estimated 40 million tobacco impressions to theater audiences,” said the ads, referring to scenes involving a cigarette-smoking character played by Sigourney Weaver. That estimate of the film’s value to tobacco companies included anticipated home video sales. To date, “Avatar” has taken in more than $1.3 billion at the worldwide box office. In a statement last week, James Cameron, its director, took sharp issue with the notion that the movie advocates smoking simply because it portrays cigarette use. The new advertisements were paid for by Smoke Free Movies, a campaign supervised by Stanton A. Glantz, director of the Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education at the University of California, San Francisco, with backing from the American Legacy Foundation. The foundation was established with money from a 1998 settlement of legal claims between tobacco companies and 46 states.

headline: Mr. Deitch Goes to MOCA. How Will the Art World Change?
text: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles confirmed on Monday that it had chosen Jeffrey Deitch, a veteran commercial dealer and deal maker, to be its new director, “a straddling of the gallery and museum worlds that has few precedents,” as Carol Vogel and Randy Kennedy write in an article about the appointment.

headline: As China Rises, Fears Grow on Whether Boom Can Endure
text: BEIJING  As much of the world struggles to clamber out of a serious recession, a gradual flow of economic power from West to East has turned into a flood.

headline: Midtown Lunch’s Founder Leaves Town
text: Zach Brooks, the founder of Midtown Lunch, the great guide to cheap food in central Manhattan, confirmed that he’ll be moving to Los Angeles at the end of this month, as  Eater reported earlier. His wife, a lawyer, will be taking a job there. But by Thursday or Friday he’ll be adding Downtown and Philadelphia sections to the blog, which he said will be run, at least temporarily, by “a roster of contributors” after he leaves.

headline: Nomura Taps Lehman Banker as Americas Head
text: Nomura said Monday that it has named former Lehman Brothers banker Glenn H. Schiffman as its head of investment banking for the Americas, as the Japanese investment bank seeks to bolster its international presence.

headline: Astor’s Son to Stay Free During Appeal
text: Brooke Astor’s son may remain free while his lawyers appeal his conviction on charges of stealing from and defrauding his mother, an appeals court judge has ordered.

headline: 5 Convicted in Britain Over Protest at Parade
text: LONDON  A court found five British Muslim men guilty on Monday of harassment and using insulting language during a protest they had staged at a parade welcoming British troops home from Afghanistan. The men had shouted slogans describing the soldiers as “murderers,” “rapists” and “baby killers.”

headline: Frigid Temperatures in South Are Putting Pipes and Patience to the Test
text: Unusually cold temperatures caused more than 70 city water mains to break over the past week in Jackson, Miss., prompting Gov. Haley Barbour to declare a state of emergency and close state offices on Monday.

headline: Oh, Right, That Attack Under Bush
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken a lot of heat since Friday, and it isn’t fair. Of course he knows that George W. Bush was president when the hijacked planes hit the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Lawyers Challenge Ohio on Executions
text: Proper training of prison officials could have prevented a botched execution in Ohio last year that led the state to overhaul its method of execution, lawyers for several death row inmates have argued in court filings.

headline: Miep Gies, Protector of Anne Frank, Dies at 100
text: Miep Gies, the last survivor among Anne Frank’s protectors and the woman who preserved the diary that endures as a testament to the human spirit in the face of unfathomable evil, died Monday night, the Anne Frank Museum in Amsterdam said. She was 100.

headline: Working with the Taliban?
text: The Wall Street Journal has a fascinating article today by Yaroslav Trofimov about how the U.N. is working in rural Afghanistan to vaccinate kids against polio — and carrying letters from Mullah Omar to protect them from local militants and fundamentalists. The laissez-passers from Mullah Omar are the only way for health workers to reach the more violent parts of rural Afghanistan in safety. It’s obviously embarrassing to have to carry permission slips from the Taliban, but, hey, that’s just the only way to work in those areas.I think that’s a useful way to think about education in rural parts of Afghanistan as well. Some aid groups are already negotiating with the Taliban about putting schools in certain areas that the Taliban control. The biggest concern for the Taliban has been that boys and girls be separate and that the girls are taught by a woman. Their other big issue is that the school books can’t have a photo of President Karzai. With those conditions they have, sometimes, been willing to allow girls’ and boys’ education. That’s not going to work everywhere, and the Taliban will be more suspicious of schools than of vaccinations — but I think it’s worth trying in more areas. If NGO’s can get some Taliban approval to work in some areas, that would be a step forward.

headline: Humorist for Counterterrorism Czar
text: Updated | 11:33 p.m. Last week The Daily Show recycled this clip from an interview with New Yorker humorist Calvin Trillin in June of 2006, in which he uncannily predicted the threat to the nation that might one day be posed by an “underwear bomber.”

headline: E-Mail? Free. Internet? That’ll Cost You.
text: EVERYBODY wants to be connected, and most major airlines in the United States have made bets that in-flight Wi-Fi Internet service will be a profitable sideline, or at least a worthwhile brand enhancer.

headline: Changing Mind-Sets About School, and Hygiene
text: Hoping for a career in television sports news, the Bronx-born Dane Martinez did an about-face after 9/11. After graduating from Syracuse University, he came home and taught under the Teach for America program. Now 29, he is the program manager of school leadership development for the city’s Department of Education.

headline: Heineken in Deal to Buy a Big Mexican Brewer
text: Heineken said Monday that it would buy the beer operations of Femsa, one of the biggest brewers in Mexico, in an all-share transaction that values the business at $7.6 billion. The move would further consolidate the beer industry into a few global players.

headline: Egypt Seeking Redemption at African Cup of Nations
text: Update | 1:00 p.m. On Tuesday, Egypt scored three unanswered goals to defeat Nigeria, 3-1, in each team’s opening match in the African Cup of Nations, which was played in Benguela.

headline: Emerging Running Backs on Wild-Card Weekend
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Georgia: Leaders of a Mutiny Receive Prison Sentences
text: The leaders of a brief, botched military rebellion against President Mikheil Saakashvili were sentenced Monday to lengthy prison terms, after a judge concluded that their aim had been to topple the government. The May 2009 mutiny was over after a few hours, when most of the 500-man tank battalion surrendered. Mr. Saakashvili initially suggested that Russia had planned the rebellion in order to force him from office. The three military men accused of masterminding the uprising were sentenced to 29, 28 and 19 years in prison.

headline: Future Kenya Port Could Mar Pristine Land
text: LAMU, Kenya  The evening call to prayer here is like a summons, for everyone on the island. As the sun dives toward the ocean, the Muslim residents stream into the mosques, little boys wearing impossibly bright white skullcaps, their mothers in diaphanous, black head-to-toe gowns. The last of the bikini-clad tourists pick themselves up from the beach, dust off the powdery sand and head back to the hotel for a drink.

headline: Fox Woos O’Brien, but Pact Is a Hurdle
text: PASADENA, Calif.  The dance between the Fox network and NBC’s disaffected late-night host, Conan O’Brien, got livelier Monday when Kevin Reilly, the president of Fox Entertainment, spelled out in some detail how interested Fox would be in starting a late-night show starring Mr. O’Brien  provided he found a way to extricate himself from his NBC contract.

headline: With New Member, Supreme Court Takes New Look at Crime Lab Ruling
text: WASHINGTON  Just six months after a narrowly divided Supreme Court announced that crime lab reports may not be used against criminal defendants at trial unless the analysts responsible for them testify, the court heard arguments on Monday about how the new system is working and whether it needs to be refined or rejected.

headline: Jobless, Homeless, and Now Known With a Sad Distinction
text: Every year, a handful of homeless people freeze to death in New York City, and in 2010, it appears, that grimmest of lists started early.

headline: Joint Effort in Europe Seeks Assets in Distress
text: The fund manager CRG Capital has announced a joint project with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to start a fund to buy distressed assets in Central and Eastern Europe.

headline: Should You Pay to Read This?
text: Would you be better off paying for online newspapers like this one? Should you feel guilty about downloading free music? Is the Web’s “information-wants-to-free” culture hurting writers, musicians and the rest of the “digital peasants,” as Jaron Lanier calls us, now providing unpaid content to be exploited by the “lords of the clouds” like Google?

headline: Closer Look at Accident of Ex-Official
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office is investigating an accident last week in which Howard Safir, the former New York City police commissioner, backed his sport utility vehicle into a pregnant woman on the Upper East Side and then drove away, a spokeswoman for the office said Monday.

headline: White House Opposes Challenge to Gillibrand
text: WASHINGTON  The White House made it clear on Monday that it opposed the prospect of Harold E. Ford Jr.’s running for the United States Senate in New York, even as Mr. Ford, the former Tennessee congressman, showed no signs of being deterred.

headline: McDonald’s Names U.S. Chief as Its No. 2 Executive
text: McDonald’s, the fast-food company, said on Monday that it had promoted Don Thompson, the head of its United States division, to become its No. 2 executive.

headline: Al Qaeda’s Shadowland
text: Washington

headline: Justices to Review Plan for Webcasts of a Trial
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court indicated Monday that it might soon have something significant to say about whether and when video coverage of federal trials is appropriate.

headline: President Signals Flexibility on Health Plan Tax
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama told union leaders at a private White House meeting on Monday that he remained committed to taxing high-cost insurance policies as a way to drive down health costs. But he also signaled that he was willing to amend the proposal to “make this work for working families,” a senior administration official said.

headline: The Tel Aviv Cluster
text: Jews are a famously accomplished group. They make up 0.2 percent of the world population, but 54 percent of the world chess champions, 27 percent of the Nobel physics laureates and 31 percent of the medicine laureates.

headline: Cardinals’ Timing Is Off on Final Field-Goal Try
text: TEMPE, Ariz.  If not for Arizona receiver Larry Fitzgerald’s brain cramp, there would have been no outrage Monday about how his teammate Michael Adams grabbed the face mask of Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers on what turned out to be the Cardinals’ winning play in overtime of their National Football Conference wild-card thriller on Sunday.

headline: As School Exit Tests Prove Tough, States Ease Standards
text: A law adopting statewide high school exams for graduation took effect in Pennsylvania on Saturday, with the goal of ensuring that students leaving high school are prepared for college and the workplace. But critics say the requirement has been so watered down that it is unlikely to have major impact.

headline: A Lofty Perch, Sure, but Reasons to Retool
text: THERE is a joke about the enthusiastic disk jockey on a top-40 radio station who liked to introduce the hottest hit record as “No. 1, and climbing higher every week.” The reason the joke is still being told in an era of downloaded music is that it has always been difficult to drum up interest in an entertainment property that is already successful.

headline: At a Mighty 104, Gone While Still Going Strong
text: Joe Rollino once lifted 475 pounds. He used neither his arms nor his legs but, reportedly, his teeth. With just one finger he raised up 635 pounds; with his back he moved 3,200. He bit down on quarters to bend them with his thumb.

headline: A Serious Proposal
text: The president of the American Federation of Teachers says she will urge her members to accept a form of teacher evaluation that takes student achievement into account and that the union has commissioned an independent effort to streamline disciplinary processes and make it easier to fire teachers who are guilty of misconduct.

headline: Russian Dissident’s Passion Endures Despite Tests
text: MOSCOW  You almost feel sorry for the police officer tasked with detaining Lyudmila M. Alexeyeva as she led an unsanctioned protest on New Year’s Eve. It is not just that at 82 years of age she appears as fragile as a porcelain teacup, or that she was dressed as a Snow Maiden, complete with sparkly hat and adorable fur muff.

headline: A Future That Doesn’t Guzzle
text: DETROIT  About 98 percent of the vehicles sold in the United States last year were powered by conventional gasoline engines, and hybrids occupied just a tiny niche.

headline: Here Comes Doveman
text: When he’s not working with indie-bands like Grizzly Bear, Antony and the Johnsons and the National, the pianist and composer Thomas Bartlett performs as Doveman. “His solo work is hushed, reverent and mesmerizing,” writes Amanda Petrusich. Listen for piano-driven ballads off his 2009 album, “The Conformist,” at Mercury Lounge Tuesday night, though the engagement also promises “friends.” Doors open at 7 p.m., with Samamidon and the Poison Tree.

headline: Under the Whale
text: Since 2006, PopRally has been a meeting ground for artists and their hipster hangers-on. The events series at the Museum of Modern Art and PS 1 showcases a cross-section of film, music and art. On Tuesday night, the video and performance artist Jen DeNike and the choreographer Melissa Barak combine forces to present a dance installation titled “Scrying” in the museum’s atrium under the huge whale skeleton by Gabriel Orozco. Go to listen to the experimental rock group Soft Circle and then watch the short ballet.

headline: Kamali Wear
text: “Her disco days are decades behind her,” Ruth La Ferla wrote of the fashion designer Norma Kamali last year. “And, despite an archive that includes studded skirts and bondage-wrapped playwear, she does not harbor a fondness for latex and lace.” Look instead for her updated spin on Grecian draped jerseys and sexy fleece activewear, perfect for cold weather dressing, at her store on West 56th Street this week. Until Friday, selected items are 20 to 70 percent off.

headline: DePaul’s Wainwright Is Third Coach to Be Fired
text: Looks like Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim was right.

headline: Come Rain or Come Shine
text: And now for my personal 2010 weather forecast.

headline: The True Answer and the Right Answer
text: At the beginning of the new year I resolved to leave off writing “old grouch” columns, columns that chronicle my inability to negotiate modern life. But resolutions rarely stand in the face of provocation, and so here I go again.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The How-To of an Admission in the Steroid Era
text: The strategy that Mark McGwire used Monday to lay out his admission to using steroids demonstrated that lessons were learned from other baseball stars who preceded him in making mea culpa about their drug use.

headline: Terror Suspect’s Lawyer Asks for Dismissal of Case
text: A federal judge in Manhattan was asked on Monday to dismiss an indictment against a terror suspect whose lawyer argued that his nearly five-year detention in secret C.I.A. prisons and later at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, was “perhaps the most egregious violation in the history of speedy-trial jurisprudence.”

headline: It Isn’t Working for Anyone Else
text: China’s economic strategy over the past two decades has been remarkably successful. By opening its doors to foreign investment and manipulating currency markets to keep the renminbi from rising against the dollar, it hitched itself to consumers in the industrial world and achieved spectacular growth.

headline: What the Financial Crisis Commission Should Ask
text: Questions anyone?

headline: U.N. Adopts Bland Home for Gutting of Quarters
text: UNITED NATIONS  Even before Secretary General Ban Ki-moon cut the blue ribbon on Monday to inaugurate the boxy, white, three-story building that will be his temporary headquarters for the coming three years or so, United Nations staff members started debating whether it more closely resembled a Wal-Mart or a maximum-security prison.

headline: Robbed, Then Scared; Armed, Then Arrested
text: The night the robbers shoved their way in, Jason Baez lay on the living room floor, terrified. He worried for his children, asleep in their bedroom; for his wife, prostrate next to him; and for himself as two men brandished guns and a third accomplice, a woman, lashed Mr. Baez and his wife with duct tape and electrical cord.

headline: 14 Across: Gumbo Vegetable
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Crossword puzzles are good for the brain. They are daily mental workouts that can build new neural connections and keep old ones strong. A puzzle like today’s — one that’s just plain fun — is also good for the gut. It’s like a dose of anti-stress tonic.

headline: Extremist Hutu Officials Blamed in ’94 Rwanda Assassination
text: Extremist Hutus in Rwanda’s government in 1994 were responsible for shooting down a plane carrying the Rwandan president, who was also a Hutu, in a premeditated attack that set off a spiral of violence that led to genocide, according to a report released Monday by the current Rwandan government.

headline: Bloggingheads: Can Drugs End Depression?
text: John Horgan, left, of the Stevens Center for Science Writings and George Johnson, author of "The Ten Most Beautiful Experiments," debate the effect of medication on depression.

headline: Deaths in Fires Last Year Were the Fewest on Record, Bloomberg Says
text: Fewer New Yorkers died in fires in 2009 than in any other year since 1915, when the city began keeping count, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Monday. The figures align with an overall pattern of declining fire deaths over the last two decades.

headline: Reds Win Bidding for a Potential Ace From Cuba
text: The winning bidder for Aroldis Chapman, a hard-throwing Cuban pitcher, is a midmarket team with nine losing seasons in a row. The Cincinnati Reds, of all teams, took a financial risk Monday for the potential reward of an ace starting pitcher.

headline: Cowell Says He Will Leave ‘Idol’
text: PASADENA, Calif.  Simon Cowell, the acerbic British music producer whose caustic commentary as a judge on “American Idol” has guided the program to the top of the television ratings, announced on Monday that he would leave the program after this season to begin producing and judging a new talent competition, “The X Factor,” for the Fox network in the fall of 2011.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the effects of early winter storms on already strained state and local budgets misstated, in some copies, the current number of state troopers in Iowa, where officials say they do not have enough patrol officers to handle all accidents. It is 379, not 37 (down from 455 about 10 years ago).

headline: Canesta's TV Remote Demonstration
text: In this demonstration, gestures are used to control the television and lighting on a Hitachi TV that is equipped with a digital camera that integrated Canesta's 3D-chip.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about the indictment of a former Yonkers city councilwoman and two other people on federal corruption charges misidentified the position once held by Zehy Jereis, one of those indicted. He is the former chairman of the Yonkers Republican Committee and a former board member of the Westchester County Republican Party; he was not the “former leader” of the Westchester party.

headline: Canesta's Avatar Demonstration
text: In this demonstration, James Spare, the chief executive of Canesta, explains how the company's chip technology would give 3-D vision to electronic devices.  Here, they demonstrate how a camera can see three-dimensional movement and translate that to controlling an avatar character on a computer.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the New Jersey Senate’s defeat of a bill that would have allowed same-sex marriages misstated, in some editions, the length of time between 1915, the year that New Jersey voters rejected a referendum that would have allowed women the right to vote, and the year that the 19th Amendment was ratified, granting women the vote nationwide. The amendment was ratified five years later, in 1920, not three years later.

headline: Corrections
text: The City Room column in some editions on Dec. 31, about a State Senate proposal for referendums asking voters whether New York should be split into two states, misstated, in some copies, the year that the Constitution was ratified. It was 1788, not 1787.

headline: Selig Says Steroid Era Is Basically Over
text: Over Bud Selig’s 17-year tenure as the head of Major League Baseball, he has made peace with the players union, internationalized the game, introduced interleague play and overseen a solid growth in team revenue.

headline: Low Profile for Chrysler After a Year of Change
text: DETROIT  Chrysler always had a showman’s flair for grabbing attention at this city’s annual auto show. Its stunt highlight reel includes driving a Jeep through the front window of the convention center and dropping a pickup truck from its ceiling.

headline: Now, Electronics That Obey Hand Gestures
text: LAS VEGAS  The technology industry is going retro  moving away from remote controls, mice and joysticks to something that arrives without batteries, wires or a user manual.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Friday about the F.B.I.’s seizure of a passport belonging to Adis Medunjanin, a Queens man who came under scrutiny during the investigation of what officials have said was a bomb plot by Al Qaeda, misspelled, in some copies, the surname of Mr. Medunjanin’s lawyer. He is Robert Gottlieb, not Gottleib. (Mr. Medunjanin was arrested on Friday on terrorism charges.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Friday about an expected mortgage default by the owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, sister apartment complexes in Manhattan, misspelled, in some copies, the given name of a longtime tenant at Peter Cooper who said apartment turnover had increased under the current landlords. She is Soni Fink, not Sonni.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Dec. 22 about criticism of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg by the outgoing and incoming city comptrollers after the Bloomberg administration acknowledged having more than 2,500 unregistered bank accounts misstated the year in which the city received $181 million from unregistered accounts controlled by the office of Robert M. Morgenthau, then the Manhattan district attorney. It was 2009, not 2008.

headline: Garment Company Removes Ad Showing Obama in Coat
text: The Weatherproof Garment Company, which turned heads last week with a controversial Times Square billboard showing President Obama in one of its coats, has agreed to take down the billboard after talking with the White House.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Saturday about an accident in which Howard Safir, the city’s former police commissioner, backed his car into a pregnant pedestrian in Manhattan included an erroneous address in some copies from the police for the scene of the accident. It took place in front of 1418 Third Avenue, not 1421 Third.

headline: The Cowboys Are Confident, but Wary
text: IRVING, Tex.  Dallas linebacker Bobby Carpenter recovered two fumbles in the Cowboys’ playoff victory over the Philadelphia Eagles, and seemed to be an appropriate spokesman for a dynamic defense that had helped spark a four-game winning streak heading into Sunday’s National Football Conference divisional game against the Minnesota Vikings at the Metrodome.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the first substantive hearing of a commission established by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis referred incorrectly to a similar investigation in 1932 that sought to learn the causes of the Wall Street crash of 1929. That inquiry was a series of hearings conducted by the Senate Banking Committee; it was not established as a commission. (The investigation has become known as the Pecora hearings, after Ferdinand Pecora, the chief staff investigator.) The error has appeared in other articles written since Congress last year began considering creating a commission to investigate the recent crisis, including articles on March 12, May 6 and July 16 last year and an Op-Ed Page column on Oct. 18.

headline: Corrections
text: The Advertising column on Monday, about a new campaign for Aflac, misidentified the agency behind the new advertising campaign. It is the Zimmerman Agency of Tallahassee, Fla., part of the Omnicom Group  not a Tallahassee office of Zimmerman Advertising, another Omnicom agency.

headline: First-Round Pick Has Last Seat on the Bench
text: OKLAHOMA CITY  An undrafted rookie earned minutes in Coach Mike D’Antoni’s rotation ahead of Jordan Hill, whom the Knicks selected with the eighth overall selection in last summer’s N.B.A. draft.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Catherine Biden, the mother of Vice President Joseph R. Biden, misstated Mr. Biden’s age during his first campaign for the United States Senate. He was 29, not 30. (By the time Mr. Biden was sworn in as a senator in January 1973, he had turned 30, the minimum age required for the office.)

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Bank Is in Talks to Settle State Claims Over Merrill
text: A year after its controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, Bank of America is discussing settling a troublesome state inquiry into the star-crossed deal and the billions of dollars in bonuses that Merrill hurriedly paid its employees.

headline: Looking at Ways to Treat Depression
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Favorite Hollywood Theme: The White Savior
text: To the Editor:

headline: Terror in Sudan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vonn Motivated by Weight Comment
text: Lindsey Vonn said in a conference call with reporters Monday that a recent article in an Austrian newspaper discussing the size advantage she has against her rivals helped motivate her last weekend when she won three consecutive races.

headline: Singing in Conference Play
text: Patrick Behan is a 6-foot-8 senior on the Bucknell basketball team. He is also an English major and an aspiring sportswriter. As he did last season, he will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

headline: Williams Pleads Guilty in ’02 Driver Shooting
text: SOMERVILLE, N.J.  Jayson Williams pleaded guilty to aggravated assault on Monday in the fatal shooting of his limousine driver, bringing toward a close a legal case that began nearly eight years ago.

headline: Judicial Security
text: A disgruntled litigant opened fire in a Las Vegas courthouse last week, killing a security officer and wounding a deputy marshal. The same day, the Justice Department released an audit that found that threats against judges and prosecutors have more than doubled since 2003 and warned that their security had critical deficiencies. Both events sound a much-needed alarm.

headline: No More ‘Candy Store’
text: Ken Salazar promised as the interior secretary to strike a better balance between the need for oil and gas development and the need to protect public lands in the Rocky Mountain West. In the Bush years, it was all about the drilling. The administration aggressively leased out millions of acres of public land and issued more than 50,000 drilling permits, in many cases risking wildlife habitat and ignoring legally mandated environmental reviews.

headline: A Real Election, Please
text: Muscling out campaign competition is undemocratic. Yet Democratic Party insiders in Washington have spent the last year trying to scare off potential challengers to Kirsten Gillibrand, the junior senator from New York. The last thing voters of New York State need is a coronation instead of a choice.

headline: Should Toronto Pursue Trading Bosh?
text: On Sunday, The New York Post reported that the Lakers were looking to acquire the Raptors’ Chris Bosh before the Feb. 18 trade deadline. Even though the report was couched in as much tentative language as possible, the Los Angels news media ran with the idea Sunday night. As the Lakers pounced on the Milwaukee Bucks, talk of Bosh filled the press lounge and postgame interviews.

headline: Risks Still High for Junk Bonds
text: Investors flocking to junk bonds need to think twice after allowing risk premiums on high-yield investments to get dangerously low. It’s good that fewer companies are failing. But high debt prices don’t leave room for 2010’s biggest financial market risk: the potential fallout when central banks withdraw from markets.

headline: Knicks See What ‘Improved’ Looks Like
text: OKLAHOMA CITY  The Knicks heard rumblings of the Oklahoma City Thunder’s improvement, but did not have a firsthand account, having not played the club in nearly a year. They can now offer testimony to the Thunder’s advancement.

headline: Challenge Lures Carroll to Seattle
text: LOS ANGELES  When Pete Carroll stood in front of his team for the last time, the man who had given U.S.C. its direction over the last decade was not sure where to go. He knew he was headed to Seattle, where the Seahawks hired him Monday to become their next coach, but he was not quite sure what to say.

headline: Showcase: Drained by Rising Waters
text: In all the coverage of the enormous Three Gorges hydroelectric project on the Yangtze River, and the creation of a vast reservoir that has displaced hundreds of thousands of people around his birthplace in Chongqing, the photographer Muge Huang Rong felt the lack of something very important. And personal.

headline: New Group Will Fight Cellphone Use by Drivers
text: Safety advocates credit Mothers Against Drunk Driving with helping to change attitudes about getting behind the wheel while intoxicated.

headline: Yo Jude: Photo Privacy Settings
text: J.D. Biersdorfer and Sam Grobart on how to manage photo privacy settings online.

headline: Focusing on the Future
text: Jerry Garrett surveys a subdued 2010 Detroit Auto Show.

headline: Jamie Langenbrunner of Devils Will Captain the U.S. Hockey Team
text: Jamie Langenbrunner, the stoic Devils right wing from Minnesota’s Iron Range with the powder-dry wit, was named Monday as the captain of the relatively young United States team for the Winter Olympics in Vancouver.

headline: Word of the Day | specious
text: specious •\ˈspe-shəs\• adjective

headline: Corrections
text: An editorial on Sunday mischaracterized the safety record of ground meat produced by Beef Products Inc. The editorial said incorrectly that two 27,000-pound batches of processed beef had been recalled. The contamination of the meat was discovered by the company in its plant before the beef was shipped. No meat produced by Beef Products Inc. has been linked to any illnesses or outbreaks.

headline: Giants: From Champion to Onion
text: It took only two years for the Giants to go from Super Bowl winners to the subjects of satire.

headline: Consuela Lee, Jazz Pianist and Educator, Dies at 83
text: Consuela Lee, a jazz pianist who fought to establish an arts school for children in rural Alabama on the grounds of a moribund academy founded by her grandfather, died Dec. 26 in Atlanta, where she had lived since 2007. She was 83.

headline: Bank Is in Talks to Settle State Claims Over Merrill
text: A year after its controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, Bank of America is discussing settling a troublesome state inquiry into the star-crossed deal and the billions of dollars in bonuses that Merrill hurriedly paid its employees.

headline: News Quiz | January 12, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Shirley Rich, Grand Dame of Casting, Dies at 87
text: Shirley Rich, widely regarded as a star among New York casting directors, who for half a century scoured the country for little-known actors  little-known actors with names like Judd Hirsch, Sean Penn and Tom Cruise  to flesh out a spate of Broadway plays and Hollywood films, died on Dec. 28 in Greenwich, Conn. She was 87 and lived in Rye, N.Y.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: For Burrows, Eight Goals in Three Games and Controversy
text: Four games in the N.H.L. on Monday, but the big story is in Vancouver, where the red-hot Alexandre Burrows scored two more goals. But he was also called on two questionable penalties, which he said afterward were the product of a referee’s personal animus against him. His contention was supported by Canucks goalie Roberto Luongo and coach Alain Vigneault. Home teams listed first:

headline: Coming Clean
text: WHO is Mark McGwire?

headline: Fed Said to Have Earned $45 Billion in 2009
text: The U.S. Federal Reserve made record profits in 2009 and will return $45 billion to the U.S. Treasury, after its efforts to prop up the economy created a windfall for the government, The Washington Post reported.

headline: JAL Awash With Sell Orders on Possible Delisting
text: Shares of Japan Airlines were flooded with sell orders on Tuesday on growing expectations that the carrier is headed for bankruptcy and delisting from the Tokyo exchange.

headline: Fed Fights in Court to Keep Bailout Details Secret
text: The Federal Reserve asked a U.S. appeals court to block a ruling that for the first time would force the central bank to reveal the identities of financial firms that might have collapsed without the largest government bailout in U.S. history, Bloomberg New reported.

headline: Joint Effort in Europe Seeks Assets in Distress
text: The fund manager CRG Capital has announced a joint project with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to start a fund to buy distressed assets in Central and Eastern Europe, Matthew Saltmarsh reports in The New York Times.

headline: Should Harry Reid Resign?
text: A new book about the 2008 presidential campaign quotes the U.S. Senate majority leader, Democrat Harry Reid of Nevada, as saying that “the country was ready to embrace a black presidential candidate, especially one such as Obama — a ‘light-skinned’ African American ‘with no Negro dialect, unless he wanted to have one.’ ” Some have called for Mr. Reid to resign. Should he?

headline: Shares Edge Higher as Investors Await Earnings
text: As companies began releasing fourth-quarter results on Monday, the question on Wall Street was not so much whether businesses turned a profit but how they did so.

headline: For Heineken, Femsa Deal Is a Beer Balancing Act
text: The Dutch brewer Heineken has managed a delicate balancing act in clinching the auction for the beer business of Femsa of Mexico, Breakingviews says. Despite outbidding SABMiller, the deal is in line with prices paid for growing Latin American markets. Meanwhile, Heineken’s all-share offer keeps debt under control while leaving its founding family in charge, the publication remarks.

headline: Losses in Manhattan Plague Singapore Fund
text: A butterfly flaps its wings in Manhattan, and Singapore sees a change in the weather. The Government of Singapore Investment Corp., manager of more than $100 billion of the city-state’s foreign reserves, reported losses from its investment in the borough’s largest residential enclave.

headline: Ex-Citi Executive Cut a Controversial Figure
text: Citigroup announced on Monday that it would replace the head of its consumer banking business — the most troubled part of its financial empire — as the company braces for fresh troubles with home mortgages and credit cards this year.

headline: Twitgrief
text: Condensed expressions of grief posted on Twitter.

headline: Blast Kills Physics Professor in Tehran
text: PARIS  A remote-controlled bomb attached to a motorcycle killed an Iranian physics professor outside his home in north Tehran on Tuesday, state media reported. The reports blamed the United States and Israel for the attack.

headline: Death of Accused Financier Ruled a Suicide
text: The death of the California financier Danny Pang was a suicide, Orange County sheriff”s officials and coroner’s investigators said Monday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: S. Korea and U.S. Dismiss N. Korea’s Peace Talks Proposal
text: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea and the United States said Tuesday that they would discuss a peace treaty with North Korea only after the North returned to six-nation disarmament talks and began dismantling its nuclear weapons program.

headline: What the Financial Crisis Commission Should Ask
text: On the eve of the first hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, which will query the chiefs of the biggest U.S. banks on the causes of the financial crisis, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin has some questions of his own.

headline: A New Tax on Banks and Bankers?
text: The Obama administration is considering a new fee on financial institutions to help recoup the cost of the banking system bailout.

headline: Ex-TCW Manager Fires Back After Lawsuit
text: The star bond fund manager Jeffrey Gundlach fired back at his former employer, Trust Company of the West, on Monday, saying the firm had smeared him in a lawsuit it filed last week.

headline: BofA’s Curl to Lose Risk Post, Report Says
text: Gregory Curl, who lost out to Brian T. Moynihan for the top job at Bank of America, may now find himself demoted.

headline: Ford Still Open to Talks on Sale of Volvo Cars
text: Ford Motor remains opens to talks with potential bidders for its Volvo cars unit despite a commercial agreement on a sale with China’s Zhejiang Geely, a Swedish business daily reported on Tuesday.

headline: Deadly Protest in Afghanistan Highlights Tensions
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A volatile town in southern Afghanistan erupted Tuesday as rumors spread that American servicemen had desecrated a Koran and defiled local women in a nearby village. Taliban provocateurs on the scene whipped up a crowd and goaded it to violence, local officials said.

headline: The Cubicle: Endangered Species
text: Today’s idea: The Great Recession is eliminating not just jobs but work stations as companies reduce their physical space, an article says: “Dilberts worldwide are losing their cubicles.”

headline: China’s Shanda Games Snaps Up Mochi Media
text: Shanda Games of China has agreed to buy Mochi Media, an American online game company backed by venture firms Accel Partners and Shasta Ventures, for $80 million in cash and stock.

headline: Persian Art Sparkles at Istanbul Palace
text: If you’ve always been interested in Persian history but a trip to Iran is not in the cards right now, a visit to Istanbul might be a good backup choice. Through Feb. 5, the museum at the city’s Topkapi Palace — former home of the Ottoman sultans — is hosting “Ten Thousand Years of Iran’s Civilization and Two Thousand Years of Joint Heritage,” an exhibition featuring some 150 objects from the National Museum of Iran, as well as pieces from Turkish museums.

headline: For Chrysler, a 2011 I.P.O.?
text: Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of both Fiat and Chrysler, said that the American carmaker might be ready for an initial public offering as soon as next year, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Alfa Romeo Not for Sale, Fiat Chief Says

headline: To Curb Loans, China Tells Banks to Increase Reserves

headline: Sampler: Marriage Trial Goes Personal and Oakland Airport Is Most Punctual
text: Personal Lives on the Stand | In the first day of the same-sex marriage trial in federal court in San Francisco, Theodore B. Olson asked his client, “What does it mean to be a lesbian?” Two gay couples testified about their lives and their reactions to the 2008 passage of Proposition 8, the state ballot initiative that changed the state’s constitution so that gays and lesbians could not marry. Video coverage of the nonjury trial, which addresses the constitutionality of the gay-marriage ban, is not available on YouTube, as had been planned. Hours before the trial began, the United States Supreme halted, for a few days, the plan to show the court proceedings on YouTube until the justices could review the issue of cameras in the court room. [The New York Times]

headline: Gone While Still Going Strong at 104
text: Joe Rollino once lifted 475 pounds. He used neither his arms nor his legs but, reportedly, his teeth. With just one finger, he raised 635 pounds; with his back, he moved 3,200. He bit down on quarters to bend them with his thumb.

headline: And the Powder Puff Goes To …
text: As usual, science-fiction and fantasy films dominated the shortlist of the seven films announced by the motion picture academy as finalists for the best makeup Oscar, though two period dramas sneaked in, The Associated Press reports. The finalists are “Star Trek,” “District 9,” “Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian,” “The Road” and “The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus,” as well as “The Young Victoria” and the Italian political drama “Il Divo.” Three nominees will be announced along with the other Oscar nominations on Feb. 2.

headline: My Internal Debate: Am I Playing the Recession Right?
text: When I prepared last year’s budget, the sales projections were based on a month or two of crisis-affected data. There was no way to know for sure whether the economy was going to get worse, stabilize, or start to improve. My approach was to cut some expenses, cut back on hours, add some furlough days, and reduce staff — all based on very little other than the knowledge that sales were evaporating and the hope that things would get better.

headline: Investors Sell as Japan Airlines Nears a Bankruptcy Filing

At the same time, two rival airlines, American and Delta, battled for a stake in JAL, which could still be a strong regional player once restructuring takes place.

headline: Letterman Offers His ‘Free Genius TV Advice’ to NBC
text: David Letterman seems to be happiest when he is at his most cynical, and recent days have given him plenty to be happy about. On Monday night, NBC’s late-night quagmire was once again the popular topic among the late-night hosts: Jay Leno continued to joke about his move to the start of NBC’s after-hours schedule as if he were getting fired; and Conan O’Brien continued to seethe (among his options, he said, was to “leave television altogether and work in a classier business with better people, like hard-core porn.”)

headline: A Stolen Kiss Looks Familiar, Though Time Has Gone By
text: There is something oddly compelling, even transfixing, about the time-lapse security video of Haisong Jiang, 28, sneaking into an off-limits area at Newark Liberty Airport to steal a kiss and a few moments with his departing girlfriend. It happened Sunday night, Jan. 3. Here is an intimate moment colliding with the post-9/11 world. All the bittersweet emotions of a long-distance relationship are captured in that embrace.

headline: Feeling Like Myself Again After Cancer
text: It has been nearly two years now since I learned I had prostate cancer, and 11 months since my last treatment. The surgical scar on my gut is fading, the radiation and hormones have leached from my body — and my soul — and my post-treatment depression is gradually lifting.

headline: ‘God Responded’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Listen to this. In his weekly radio and Internet address, President Obama said “we are on the verge” of guaranteeing Americans health insurance “whether they lose their job, change jobs, move or get sick,” which means Jay, Conan and I are going to be just fine. So don’t worry.

headline: ‘Harry Reid Under Fire’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” on NBC: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid is under fire for discussing whether or not President Obama has a “Negro dialect.” Reid is also in trouble for saying Joe Lieberman “talks all Moses-y.”

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: With Defense Test, China Shows Displeasure of U.S.
text: BEIJING  China said late Monday that it had successfully tested the nation’s first land-based missile defense system, announcing the news in a brief dispatch by Xinhua, the official news agency. “The test is defensive in nature and is not targeted at any country,” the item said.

headline: London Theater Journal: Dead Man Talking
text: LONDON — Funny how a dead body in the room can change the way you hear a conversation. That was always a large part of the frisson-generating appeal of “Rope,” Patrick Hamilton’s 1929 drama in which a cocktail buffet is served on a chest that hides a fresh corpse. And it is a perspective exploited to a stylish, poison-tipped hilt in Roger Michell’s highly satisfying revival at the Almeida Theater, which I caught on an appropriately dark and stormy Monday night.

headline: ‘An Over-Emotional Woman’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: It’s a great day for Sarah Palin. She was hired as a commentator for Fox News. She signed a multiyear contract, which means she’ll probably quit after a year.

headline: ‘The Mayor Misspoke’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: I’m tired of being cold. And I’m upset with that Al Gore, too. Always shooting his mouth off.

headline: Britain Moves to Ban Islamic Group
text: LONDON  Britain said Tuesday it was outlawing a radical Islamic group that had incited outrage by planning a protest march through the streets of a town made famous for its somber ceremonies honoring British soldiers killed in Afghanistan.

headline: What Are the Mets’ Plans for Fernando Martinez?
text: It was just three years ago that the Mets, fresh off a division title and with dreams of a dynasty, envisioned opening Citi Field with an outfield of Carlos Beltran and two prized prospects, Carlos Gomez and Fernando Martinez. As I’m sure you noticed, that never happened.

headline: ‘Viewers Might Get Confused’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: As you may know, our show has been canceled. NBC has some pilots to fill up the 10 p.m. time slot. They’re talking about bringing back “All in the Family,” with Harry Reid as Archie Bunker.

headline: The Holy See Wishes It Hadn’t Seen ‘Avatar’
text: Among the things the Vatican approves of: piety, penitence, “The Simpsons.” Among the things it does not endorse: sinfulness and “Avatar.” Both the Vatican newspaper and radio station have criticized that James Cameron film, calling it emotionally unengaging and saying that the film tries to replace divinity with nature, The Associated Press reported. The newspaper, L’Osservatore Romano, wrote that “Avatar” “gets bogged down by a spiritualism linked to the worship of nature,” according to The A.P. Vatican Radio said the movie “cleverly winks at all those pseudo-doctrines that turn ecology into the religion of the millennium,” adding: “Nature is no longer a creation to defend, but a divinity to worship.” The newspaper wrote that for all of the “stupefying, enchanting technology” in the movie, it offers “few genuine emotions.” But both news media outlets agreed, as the newspaper wrote, that the true accomplishment of “Avatar” was its “extraordinary visual impact.” The film is to be released in Italy on Friday.

headline: ‘Iranian Cyber Army’ Strikes Chinese Site
text: Less than a month after a group calling itself the “Iranian Cyber Army” attacked Twitter, users of China’s most popular search engine, Baidu, were redirected on Tuesday morning to a Web page displaying a message claiming that the same group had blocked access to that site as well.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Designer Night Party
text: DETROIT — The snow swam in the huge searchlights parked in front of the Bankle Building on Woodward Avenue, site of the  Designers Night 2010 party. It was held, by tradition, in the loft space of Camilo Pardo, a former Ford designer who started the event several years ago. The space is full of Mr. Pardo’s paintings, on canvas and on old car hoods, as well as his collection of cars, including a racer and an original Mini.
