headline: Balancing Suburban Landscapes and Water Conservation
text: The chart above catches the eye, telling any observer who knows the geography of the Peninsula and South Bay that some of the wealthiest areas in the region — places like Los Altos Hills (1), Hillsborough (2) and Woodside and Portola Valley (3) — consume far more water per capita than neighboring communities. It accompanied an article in Sunday’s Bay Area report about new moves to cut outdoor water use.

headline: Goldman Acknowledges Conflicts With Clients
text: A senior Goldman Sachs executive sent an e-mail message to clients on Tuesday disclosing that the firm’s Fundamental Strategies Group might have shared investment ideas with the firm’s proprietary trading group or some clients before sharing them with others.

headline: Readers Respond to McGwire’s Admission
text: Readers had a range of reactions to Mark McGwire’s admission on Monday that he used steroids in his career, including in his record-breaking season in 1998. Comments reflected anger at McGwire as well as disillusionment with Major League Baseball and the use of performance-enhancing drugs among players. Have a comment? Join the conversation in the comment section below.

headline: Encores! Announces Casting For ‘Fanny’
text: Encores! has found its Fanny — and its Cesar and its Marius, too. Elena Shaddow, George Hearn and James Snyder will play those characters in New York City Center’s coming Encores! production of “Fanny,” the musical based on Marcel Pagnol’s trilogy of “Marius,” “Fanny” and “César,” its press representatives said on Tuesday. Ms. Shaddow (whose Broadway credits include “The Woman in White” and “Fiddler on the Roof”) will play Fanny, the French woman whose illegitimate pregnancy sets off a story of romance and reconciliation. Mr. Snyder (Broadway’s “Cry-Baby”) will play Fanny’s lover, Marius, and Mr. Hearn (a Tony winner for “Sunset Boulevard” and “La Cage aux Folles”) will play his father, Cesar. The cast also includes Rondi Reed (a Tony winner for “August: Osage County”) as Honorine, Fred Applegate (“The Producers”) as Panisse, David Patrick Kelly as the Admiral and Michael McCormick as Escartifique. “Fanny,” which is directed by Marc Bruni, choreographed by Lorin Latarro and with music directed by Rob Berman, will run at City Center from Feb. 4 through 7.

headline: French Family Values
text: The debate over European economic performance has gone in two directions. One is the usual response of people when they get something very wrong: they start quibbling over minor details (which dataset was Manzi actually using? what about immigration?) to throw up dust clouds. The key thing to remember is that we had a flat assertion that social democracy leads to stagnant economies; that assertion is just wrong.

headline: Readers Climb Aboard the Doris Day Bandwagon
text: It turns out that many Times readers are hoping this year that whatever will be, will be an honorary Oscar for Doris Day. A post related to Douglas McGrath’s article in Sunday’s New York Times on why Ms. Day is worthy of a special Oscar has inspired more than 100 comments from readers, most of which are supportive of the idea of Ms. Day finally getting an award that has eluded her throughout her career.

headline: Top Terror Prosecutor Settles Into a Familiar Role
text: When a federal prosecutor asked a Virginia jury in 2006 to impose the death penalty on Zacarias Moussaoui, the so-called 20th hijacker on Sept. 11, he cited the agonizing calls from victims in the burning World Trade Center towers and on planes, and quoted the defendant’s own words as he rejoiced in their pain. “I wish there would be more pain,” Mr. Moussaoui had said.

headline: Weiner Wants Scofflaw Diplomats to Pay Up

Still, many foreign diplomats simply park where they please, and they have collectively ignored $18 million worth of the bright orange rectangles stuffed under their windshield wipers.

headline: Hard to Get, but Great to Find
text: My column this week is on the rise of German spätburgunder, better known to the rest of the world as pinot noir. Many people find it surprising that Germany makes red wines at all. In fact, the popularity of red wine in Germany has probably never been higher, and over the last few decades more and more pinot noir has been planted.

text: Google is moving closer to offering something like a Web-based disk drive where users can store any file and access it from anywhere.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: On Electric Avenue, Coffee Carts and Three-Wheelers
text: DETROIT — Electric Avenue extends for several blocks at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. The Dow Chemical-sponsored boulevard is colorful, encompassing both Korean-made plug-in coffee carts and three-wheeled E.V.’s. The concept seems to be to give some prime-time space (in this case 37,000 square feet) on the show’s main floor to small carmakers usually relegated to the basement.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 2: History Lessons
text: Update 7:06 p.m. Pacific Time | Speaking to reporters after Professor Cott had left the stand, defense lawyers lashed out at her performance, calling it a “disaster” and part of a strategy that backfired on the plaintiffs.

headline: Iraq Says Raid Uncovered a Plot to Bomb Ministries
text: BAGHDAD  A wide-ranging plot to bomb government ministries and other public places, to be followed by a wave of political assassinations, was uncovered by Iraqi officials, who responded Tuesday by bringing much of Baghdad to a virtual standstill while security forces conducted raids that netted large quantities of explosives, officials said.

headline: Race Assumes Central Role in New Orleans Vote
text: NEW ORLEANS  Less than a month before the primary, the race for mayor here is a struggle over who will bring down the soaring murder rate, who will attract badly needed new businesses and who will guide the city in its still dauntingly long road to recovery. But it is also about something else.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Musical Will Refund Tickets

headline: Confirming a Diagnosis of Celiac Disease
text: Dr. Sheila Crowe, a professor in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology in the department of medicine at the University of Virginia, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about celiac disease, an often overlooked digestive disorder that causes damage to the small intestine when gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye, is eaten. In a previous post, Dr. Crowe explained how celiac disease can present not just with digestive complaints, but also anemia and other conditions. Here, Dr. Crowe responds to readers wondering what tests should be requested to confirm a diagnosis of celiac disease.

headline: M.T.A. Cutbacks Spawn Protest in Bay Ridge

headline: Her Most Desperate Hour: Carrie Fisher Discusses ‘The Star Wars Holiday Special’

Not surprisingly, George Lucas and the rest of the cast of “Star Wars” would prefer to toss the special into the Sarlacc Pit. Or to the Rancor monster. Or into the Death Star’s reactor shaft. You get the picture.

headline: Disney’s Top Production Exec Leaves the Studio
text: The top production executive at Walt Disney Studios, Oren Aviv, has resigned under pressure in the latest of a string of management overhauls at the struggling company, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Skepticism Follows McGwire’s Tears
text: While the sporting world paused on Monday to absorb the “You don’t say!” news that Mark McGwire took steroids (tomorrow: Earth revolves around Sun), McGwire accomplished something remarkable: he made us pause while slapping our foreheads in mock surprise and made us cock our heads sideways like confused dogs for his seriously parsed “confession.” Yes, he used steroids but only occasionally (days that ended in Y) and only for (ahem) health benefits. They had nothing to do with his ability to hit home runs into orbit or his Volkswagen-size forearms.

headline: Is Refusing Bed Rest a Crime?
text: Arguments are under way today in the First District Court of Appeals in Tallahassee, Fla., in the case of Samantha Burton, who was confined to her bed by a judge earlier this year because she was at risk for a miscarriage.

headline: Appeal Request by Dan Rather Is Turned Down
text: Dan Rather’s request for an appeal in his lawsuit against CBS Corporation was turned down on Tuesday, marking an apparent end to the high-profile breach of contract case.

headline: Artists Miffed Over Rothschild Foundation’s Missing Grant Money
text: The Judith Rothschild Foundation has been one of those small grant-making organizations that can make a big difference to art.

headline: Redemptions Hit Hedge Funds in December
text: Investor allocations to hedge funds reversed in December for the first time since May, according to a preliminary analysis of the numbers by the data and research firm HedgeFund.net, raising concerns that investors are finding other places to put their money to work.

headline: The Different Fraud Protections for Signatures and PINs
text: Last week’s New York Times article “How Visa, Using Card Fees, Dominates a Market” detailed the behind-the-scenes struggle between banks and retailers to encourage customers to sign when making debit card purchases or to punch in their PIN because of the higher fees that stores pay banks for signatures.

headline: Pu-Pu? Yahoo!
text: Come summer you can take off your overalls, put on a Hawaiian shirt and check out the surf on Park Avenue South. Michael Stillman and Craig Koketsu, of Park Avenue Winter/Spring/Summer/Autumn and Quality Meats, will be opening Hurricane Club, a “decisively inauthentic” Polynesian spot.

headline: From the People Who Brought You ‘Pride and Prejudice and Zombies': ‘Android Karenina’
text: Literary hybrids of Jane Austen novels and zombie stories? That’s so last year. Quirk Books, which released the best-selling novels “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies” and “Sense and Sensibility and Sea Monsters,” has seen the future of the mashup novel, and it is Leo Tolstoy and robots. The publisher said on Tuesday in a news release that its next entry in its Quirk Classics series will be “Android Karenina,” an “enhanced edition” of the Tolstoy novel “set in a dystopian world of robots, cyborgs, and interstellar space travel.”

headline: Looking for an Escape From the Frigid City Streets
text: The snow may be gone from the city’s streets but the component-eating road salt and a bitter cold lingers, leaving many cyclists dreaming of warm breezes. But where to go to escape the chill? Should road warriors head inside for a long ride toward the wall on the trainer? Take up a winter sport like cross-country skiing (a favorite of Greg Lemond) or just hibernate on the couch with a bunch of cycling films for inspiration?

headline: Detroit Auto Show: CT&T C Square

headline: Hollywood, With Its Expensive Health Plans, Worries About Reform
text: As President Obama signaled his willingness to compromise at least a bit on a proposal that would levy a substantial excise tax on the most expensive health plans, called Cadillac plans, Hollywood is still waiting to exhale.

headline: Giving Pixar an Oscar Scare
text: As the Bagger’s Los Angeles buddy Brooks Barnes reports on Tuesday, the race for the best animated film Oscar is unexpectedly lively this year. The presumptive winner, a Pixar film – in this case, the hit “Up,” about a grumpy old man and his lofty bucket list quest – is getting sudden competition from “Fantastic Mr. Fox,” Wes Anderson’s painstakingly made stop-motion adaptation of the Roald Dahl novel. Critics and industry veterans alike were impressed by Mr. Anderson’s facility with a medium new to him, Mr. Barnes writes:

headline: Comcast Extends Deal With Harbert
text: Comcast has locked up another programming executive.

headline: Richard Beckman Leaves Condé Nast to Head e5 Global Media
text: Richard Beckman, a top executive at Condé Nast, resigned Tuesday to head e5 Global Media, the newly formed company that now owns the Hollywood Reporter, Billboard, AdWeek and other trade publications.

headline: More Bad Job Market News
text: The pace of layoffs appears to be falling. But recent trends suggest that things will continue to be tough for those already out of work.

headline: Arbitron Chief Out After Faulty Testimony to Congress
text: The chief executive of the radio-ratings giant Arbitron, Michael Skarzynski, abruptly resigned on Monday night, after it was discovered that he gave inaccurate testimony to a Congressional committee.

headline: Making the Documentary Cut
text: After coming out with its best director nominations last Thursday for best feature, the Directors Guild of America on Tuesday announced the nominees for best directing achievement in documentaries. (A category so sexy the Golden Globe doesn’t even include it in its nominations.)

headline: Poll: Obama’s Ratings on Health Care, Economy Drop Lower
text: Fewer Americans now approve of the way that President Barack Obama is handling the economy and health care, pushing his overall job rating below the crucial 50 percent mark, according to the latest CBS News poll.

text: THE BASICS

headline: Port Shut Down Over Explosives Leak
text: An early morning accident at the port in Morehead City spilled as many as five gallons of a highly explosive chemical, prompting officials to close the port and issue a voluntary evacuation for the surrounding area.

headline: Big Blue’s Smarter Marketing Playbook
text: I.B.M. trotted out its “smarter planet” campaign more than a year ago, starting with a speech by Samuel J. Palmisano, I.B.M.’s chief executive, at the Council on Foreign Relations. At the time, the campaign seemed an ambitious, though potentially risky, move. The vision of transportation, health care, cities, retailing, finance and other fields made more intelligent with digital technology — and yes, supplied largely by I.B.M. — could have easily fizzled and been portrayed as big-think puffery, out of step with an economy in a tailspin.

headline: Biden’s Mother Eulogized
text: WILMINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. called his mother, Catherine Eugenia Finnegan Biden, “a quintessential combination of both optimism and pragmatism” who instilled in her four children the ideal that everyone was equal.

headline: BlogTalk: Floating a Ford Candidacy in N.Y.
text: The chatter about Harold Ford Jr.‘s possible challenge to Senator Kirsten Gillibrand continues to swell today, building upon the White House’s decision on Monday to swat away the notion and Mr. Ford’s own Op-ed promoting the idea in The New York Post.

headline: Canadian Broadcasters Hope to Break Even on Games
text: Earlier this week, NBC said that its broadcast of the Winter Games in Vancouver next month will likely be the network’s first Olympic money loser. Now it appears that the host broadcaster isn’t doing much better.

headline: F.D.I.C. Seeks to Link Insurance Fees to Bank Pay
text: Federal banking regulators moved on Tuesday to seek public input on a plan to link the insurance premiums levied on banks to the degree of risk-taking encouraged by their executive pay policies.

headline: The Republican Situation
text: I agree with everything Ramesh Ponnuru says in his Time piece on why the G.O.P. shouldn’t get overconfident about midterm success. What’s more, I think that all of his warnings will still hold true even if Republicans do “make big gains at all levels,” as Ponnuru puts it, and head into next year with a larger minority in the Senate, control of more statehouses, and maybe even a slim majority in the House (hey, it’s possible). This warning, especially:

headline: Under the Radar: Five Questions About ‘Chekhov Lizardbrain’
text: Dan Rothenberg doesn’t hesitate when asked to explain what the show “Chekhov Lizardbrain,” which he directed for Philadelphia’s Pig Iron Theater as part of the Under the Radar Festival, is all about.

headline: Massachusetts Ad Wars in Senate Race
text: Martha Coakley has released the first negative television ad of the Massachusetts Senate race, reinforcing the perception that Democrats are worried about holding onto Edward M. Kennedy’s seat.

headline: We Have Ways to Make You Pay
text: There have been shame lists. There have been statistics, and corresponding threats of firings.

text: Q.

headline: Management Shake-Up Continues at Disney
text: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company continues to slash and burn through the management ranks of its struggling motion picture studio as it works to return the division to profitability.

headline: Happy ‘Date = ZIP Code Day,’ Flatbush
text: Jan. 12 is a very special day in Brooklyn, at least for fans of the Gregorian calendar. In Brooklyn, all ZIP codes begin with 112, so today’s date, written numerically, is identical to a ZIP code somewhere in the borough.

headline: Woodson Beats Out Jets’ Revis for Defensive Award
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. –- Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis lost the N.F.L.’s defensive player of the year award on Tuesday. It went to Charles Woodson of the Packers, the first cornerback to win the award since Deion Sanders in 1994.

headline: Coaches Come and Go, Except JoePa
text: Wow. Things sure do happen fast in academia. No sooner did Pete Carroll split from Southern California than Lane Kiffin walked away from Tennessee on Tuesday night.

headline: Conan O’Brien Says He Won’t Host ‘Tonight Show’ After Leno
text: In a statement to “People of Earth,” Conan O’Brien says NBC has not given him “some time and, just as important, some degree of ratings support from the prime-time schedule” to succeed as the “Tonight” host.

headline: The Life of the (Tea) Party: Comparing Social Protest Movements
text: Overview | What drives the current Tea Party movement and its protests? How does it compare with historical social movements? In this lesson, students explore the Tea Party movement, compare it to other social movements in American history and consider their impact.

headline: Lawmaker Seeks Culprit in A.I.G. Bailout
text: Representative Darrell Issa, the California Republican who is investigating the bailout of the American International Group, said Tuesday that the government must hold someone responsible for how the Federal Reserve Bank of New York dealt with A.I.G.

headline: American Idol Preview: 9 Questions on Season 9
text: American Idol begins its ninth season Tuesday at 8 p.m. on Fox. To kick things off, Jon Caramanica will ask nine questions each week about each episode. Share your thoughts and ask your own questions  in the comments area below. But first, a preview:

headline: Spanish Solar Firm’s Model: Build and Sell
text: The OPDE Group, a Spanish developer of solar energy, has received $145 million in financing from a group of Spanish banks, as it expands into other European countries and California.

headline: A Potentially Awkward Moment for Gillibrand and Ford
text: It may be slightly awkward for a couple of prominent guests at the Rev. Al Sharpton’s annual celebration of Dr. Martin Luther King in Harlem on Monday.

headline: A Glimpse of a Modern Pioneer
text: The 92nd Street Y commemorated the centenary of Erick Hawkins, a modern-dance pioneer, over the weekend with a three-day symposium featuring discussions, classes and performances, including a rare appearance by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company on Saturday night at the Y’s intimate Buttenweiser Hall. Who knew that such a group still existed, even in a small configuration of five members? Since Hawkins’s death in 1994, the company has gradually receded from the public eye.

headline: Finding a Way to Pay for Green Makeovers
text: Last year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed four laws and two programs that would have required the owners of New York’s largest buildings to pay for improvements to make their properties more energy-efficient.

headline: Protest in Nigeria Over Absent Leader
text: ABUJA, Nigeria  Hundreds of angry Nigerians marched down this capital’s broad avenues on Tuesday to protest the long absence of their president, who has been away for nearly two months getting medical treatment in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Judge Denies Rajaratnam’s Request to Reduce Bail
text: A federal judge on Tuesday afternoon denied Raj Rajaratnam‘s request to reduce his $100 million bail, siding with prosecutors who argued that the billionaire hedge fund manager of the Galleon Group should not get a break on his bail terms.

headline: Go for Broke | Akris’s Ai Bag
text: Long a staple of ladies who lunch (in Geneva), the Swiss fashion house Akris is expanding its line to include handbags. The horsey Ai Bag coincides with the acquisition of Comtesse, an 80-year-old German firm specializing in the manufacture of woven horse hair. Akris is no stranger to the material: it has been used to structure its coats, and there is even woven horsehair covering the walls of its London boutique. Pony up the hefty $3,990 at Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Akris boutiques.

headline: New Tours in 2010
text: With vacationers still wary about spending money in 2010, tour operators are offering travel packages that scale back on amenities like tour guides, while rebranding them as more flexible and independent-minded.

headline: A Wife’s Betrayal, a Husband’s Internal Seething
text: In 1993 the Metropolitan Opera presented its first production of Verdi’s neglected opera “Stiffelio” as a vehicle for Plácido Domingo. Without that star tenor in the demanding title role, and without James Levine conducting, the Met would not have taken a risk on the work, which had a dismal reception at its 1850 premiere in Trieste, Italy.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Jan. 12
text: Hands held over an oudoor fire for warmth. It is certainly an effective photojournalistic device for conveying — wordlessly — the idea that unusually cold weather is burdening a place that is unaccustomed to it and unequipped for it: India, in this case, from which several hands-over-the-fire pictures have been transmitted in recent weeks. (Today’s photo is Slide 10.) But is this a case of visual shorthand so effective it threatens to become cliché? A glance at the pictures below reveals subtle variety. Each picture tells a slightly different story. And that never gets tiresome.

headline: Frigid Londoners Line Up for Two Blasts of Heat
text: LONDON  With this city all a-shiver from a crippling cold snap  “the big freeze,” as the tabloids call it  it only made sense to visit two of the hottest women in town. So on Saturday I made my way through desultory snow flurries to the West End to see the young movie star Keira Knightley playing a young movie star, and then across the Thames to the Menier Chocolate Factory in Southwark, where the seasoned song-and-dance gal Tamzin Outhwaite was portraying a seasoned dance hall hostess.

headline: Obama to Appear at Democratic, G.O.P. Retreats
text: WILMINGTON — President Obama will appear at separate retreats for both House Republicans and House Democrats within the coming week, White House officials said on Tuesday.

headline: 15 Hall of Fame Finalists: Pick Your Five
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down

headline: PBS to Announce New Public Affairs Show
text: PBS will air a one-hour public affairs program called “Need to Know,” to be produced by New York’s WNET.org, on Friday nights beginning May 7, the organizations plan to announce Wednesday.

headline: Magazines Lost — Gulp — 58,340 Ad Pages in ’09
text: 6:50 p.m. Updated with corrected Meredith & Hachette figures, and more context for the Condé Nast figures.

headline: To Get to Paul Castellano Way, Make a Right on Plaxico Terrace
text: It may sound like an echo of the David Bowie song that goes, “We can be heroes — just for one day.” Seventh Avenue is being renamed “Project Runway Avenue” — just for one day.

headline: Ringo Starr Plans to Be Touring When He Hits (Drumroll Please) 70
text: Ringo Starr released his 16th studio album, “Y Not” (Hip-O Records) Tuesday, and since he was in town for a run of television appearances to promote the disc, he spent part of the afternoon holding a news conference on the set of “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” on which he will be the only guest Tuesday night. Backed by Ben Harper and the Relentless 7, Mr. Starr performed excerpts from a few songs on the new disc, as well as “I Wanna Be Your Man,” one his Beatles staples.

headline: Hello Creepy: A Spooky Side to Japan’s Cute Culture
text: There is a surprisingly fine line between nightmarish and cute. Jeremy Wade toes and then smears it in “There Is No End to More,” a solo for Jared Gradinger that returned for a one-night engagement at Japan Society on Monday.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Nelly’s Custom Ford Mustang
text: Lawyers for the rapper Nelly will be busy defending speeding tickets if his predictions come true. Nelly and Jim Farley, vice president of marketing for Ford, showed off Nelly’s custom Mustang GT, which will appear on the cover of his coming album on Tuesday at the 2010 North American International Auto Show.

headline: House Panel Subpoenas New York Fed on A.I.G.
text: The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee is demanding that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York turn over its records about the bailout of the American International Group, particularly those involving billions of dollars in payments made to A.I.G.’s trading partners.

headline: Dropping a Clue or Two About ‘Lost’
text: Pasadena, Calif.

headline: The Morning Skate: Replay Suspicions, Burrows’s Accusations and Dallas Does Rocky
text: The Philadelphia Daily News blogged last night and The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today that the N.H.L. is investigating whether the Fox Sports Pittsburgh television crew, the Penguins’ local rights-holder, intentionally or accidentally withheld evidence from video replay officials last Thursday of a play that was under review.

headline: New York City Ballet News
text: Some of New York City Ballet’s top dancers will take their final bows this spring season. The company has announced that dates have been set for the farewell performances of long-time principal dancers Yvonne Borree, Albert Evans, Darci Kistler and Philip Neal as well as the principal conductor Maurice Kaplow.

headline: New York’s Roman Empire
text: Dishes from Maialino, Testaccio and Numero 28 Pizzeria Romana, which are among the Roman restaurants that have opened in the last year.

headline: Popular Blood Therapy May Not Work
text: The treatment has become so popular that patients with orthopedic injuries are demanding it, willing to pay $1,000 or more out of their own pocket. Its appeal only soared higher when professional athletes like Tiger Woods and the football players Troy Polamalu and Hines Ward reported that it cured them.

headline: Award Show Politics, With Sass
text: Sandra Bullock – Sandy to your mom – was a surprise double-Golden Globe nominee, for her comedic work in “The Proposal” and for the heavy stuff in “The Blind Side,” and she has a good chance in that category at least.

headline: Why the Best Deposit Rates Are Decreasing
text: The best Internet bank rates on money market, certificate of deposit and savings accounts are decreasing, thanks to new Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation rate calculation rules for undercapitalized banks. Those are traditionally the banks that offer the most generous rates to attract depositors.

headline: Mystery at the Philharmonic: Who Was That Clarinetist?
text: If the New York Philharmonic had performed Rachmaninoff’s Second Symphony last season, the principal clarinetist would probably have been bathed in accolades for his solo stint in the Adagio, one of the most famous clarinet passages in the orchestral literature. For that clarinetist would have been Stanley Drucker, who retired in September after 60 years in the orchestra.

headline: A Good Stir-Fry Hides a Lot of Faults
text: A post with two headlines:

headline: Investigating Wall Street Compensation
text: Louise Story of The Times discusses the backlash over big bonuses on Wall Street.

headline: Mexico Holds Drug Suspect Accused of Grisly Tactics
text: MEXICO CITY  When it comes to gore, Mexico’s drug traffickers seem to compete among themselves for the title of most depraved. One will chop off the heads of victims. Another will string dead rivals from bridges or burn their genitals. Recently, hit men removed the face from a dead man and sewed it onto a soccer ball.

headline: Students Say Professor Was Government Critic
text: As my colleagues Alan Cowell and Nazila Fathi report, on Tuesday Iranian state television broadcast images shot in the aftermath of an explosion that killed a physics professor outside his home in north Tehran.

headline: ‘Baby Einstein’ Founder Goes to Court
text: A co-founder of the company that created the “Baby Einstein” videos has asked a judge to order the University of Washington to release records relating to two studies that linked television viewing by young children to attention problems and delayed language development.

headline: That Old R&B Tag Team of Love and Lust
text: “I need three chairs!” Mario shouted as he selected a girl from the crowd to bring onto the Gramercy Theater stage on Friday night. Stools materialized. The too-gentle R&B singer sat his choice down, his guitar player on her other side, and serenaded her with “I Choose You.” He was tentative. He was sweet. He kept a respectful distance.

headline: Article Search API Enhancements
text: The Times Article Search API already had a rich set of data attributes, but we couldn’t resist adding a few more. One of our general TimesOpen goals is to ensure that all our APIs interoperate as much as possible. The new fields are part of that effort, and they also offer new ways to search Times content.

headline: Case Study | Stocking the Bar
text: Case Study is a bimonthly posting on all things alcoholic by Toby Cecchini, T’s spirits columnist.

headline: Detroit’s Electric Avenue: The Street of Dreams?
text: DETROIT — Which would be a stranger sight: Humphrey Bogart, Marilyn Monroe and James Dean sharing a late snack at an all-night diner, or the filmmaker Chris Paine; Bob Lutz, the General Motors vice chairman; and Elon Musk, chief executive of Tesla Motors, taking a stroll down Electric Avenue at the Detroit auto show?

headline: Céline: Color & Play
text: The presentation of Céline’s early fall collection at Milk Studios had a let’s-get-down-to-business quality: a plain white space, clothes hanging from rails, models briskly going through a few changes. Have some coffee? Thank you, I will…

headline: CBS Comedies Deliver
text: “Two and a Half Men” and “The Big Bang Theory” delivered Monday’s top ratings by a wide margin. Those CBS comedies drew 17.3 million viewers at 9 for “Men” and 15.8 million at 9:30 for “Theory,” according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS won the night over all, including the 8 p.m. hour in which the 100th episode of “How I Met Your Mother” delivered a season-high 9.8 million viewers. Fox and ABC finished in a virtual tie for second place. Fox broadcast “House” at 8 (12.2 million) and a special episode of “Fringe” at 9 (7.8 million), while ABC’s two-hour installment of “The Bachelor” averaged 10.5 million viewers from 8 to 10. CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (13.6 million) easily led the 10 p.m. hour ahead of both “Castle” on ABC (9.5 million) and “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC (4.8 million). NBC was fourth for the night. On HBO on Sunday, the fourth season premiere of “Big Love” attracted 1.7 million viewers, a considerable improvement over the first episode of the show’s third season last year, which drew 1.2 million.

headline: Sony Switches ‘Spider-Man’ Plans
text: Spider-Man and Tobey Maguire are parting ways. Mr. Maguire was set to reprise his leading role in “Spider-Man 4” in May 2011 with Sam Raimi, right, who directed the first three installments, returning to the helm. But after disagreements about the creative direction of the film Mr. Raimi opted to depart, according to Deadline.com. Rather than go forward with a different director, Sony decided on a “Spider-Man” reboot that it had been simultaneously developing. In a press release on Monday, Sony confirmed that the next “Spider-Man” movie would take Peter Parker back to high school. The new chapter, written by James Vanderbilt (“Zodiac”), will have a new cast and director, and focus on “a teenager dealing with both contemporary human problems and amazing superhuman crises,” Sony said. The target release date is now summer 2012. Together, the first three “Spider-Man” movies sold over $1 billion in tickets at North American theaters, according to Box Office Mojo.

headline: PBS Sets New Shows
text: PBS will broadcast a one-hour public affairs program called “Need to Know,” to be produced by New York’s WNET.org, on Friday nights beginning May 7, the organizations plan to announce on Wednesday. The new show, to originate from WNET’s soon-to-be-opened studio at Lincoln Center, will blend field reports, features and interviews on topics including the economy, the environment, health, security and culture, and will make extensive use of public input generated online. No anchor or reporters have been announced. “Need to Know” will replace the public affairs programs “Bill Moyers Journal” and “Now,” which end in April. As part of the remake of PBS’s news and public affairs lineup, John Wilson, who oversees TV programming, said that PBS also planned to open a Web portal in May that would aggregate all of its news and public affairs content, as well as journalism from local public stations.

headline: Five Sites Agree to Stop Flushing Pharmaceutical Waste
text: New York State’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has reached a settlement under which five hospitals and nursing homes agreed to stop flushing pharmaceutical waste that could potentially contaminate New York City’s water supply.

headline: While ‘Spider-Man’ Musical Offers Refunds
text: After weeks of complaints from ticket holders, the producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” announced on Tuesday that they would refund tickets through Ticketmaster for preview performances that had been scheduled to start on Feb. 25 but are now, as expected, canceled. The producers did not provide new dates for previews or an opening night, saying only that a revised schedule would be announced shortly and that they still planned to open the show in 2010. With music by U2’s Bono and the Edge and direction by Julie Taymor (“The Lion King”), “Spider-Man” has been marred by delays after an earlier group of producers was unable to raise the money to produce the show. The production is now expected to cost about $50 million, making it the most expensive in Broadway history.

headline: Rather’s Appeal Request Rejected by Court
text: Dan Rather’s request for an appeal in his lawsuit against CBS was turned down on Tuesday, marking an apparent end to the breach-of-contract case. Mr. Rather, below, the former anchor of “CBS Evening News,” had appealed to the New York Court of Appeals, the state’s highest court, after the appellate division of the New York State Supreme Court ruled unanimously in September to dismiss the $70 million lawsuit he brought against the network in 2007. CBS executives say the legal proceedings are now over. In a statement Mr. Rather said he was “disappointed.” He had been seeking damages in a claim that his contract had been breached by CBS management and his reputation had been unfairly tarnished by the network’s handling of an investigation into his report on President George W. Bush’s National Guard record.

headline: U.S. Selects 18 Cities and 21 Stadiums as Potential World Cup Hosts
text: Chicago is the home of the United States Soccer Federation, but apparently not its kind of town when it comes to potential sites for the 2018 or the 2022 World Cup. And add San Francisco and the rest of Northern California to that list.

headline: Vancouver’s Winter Games May Lack Some Winter
text: Vancouver may be hosting the upcoming Winter Olympic, but Canada’s Pacific coast city often does not get the a typically Canadian winter.

headline: Wistful Baroque Moods Echo Through Time
text: There is often a pervasive sense of melancholy in the music of the early Baroque, a gentle wistfulness that underlies both somber and spirited scores, like the selections by Dario Castello and Tarquinio Merula performed in Paul Hall at the Juilliard School on Monday evening. Members of Juilliard’s new historical-performance program offered works by these two infrequently performed Italian composers to inaugurate the school’s ninth annual ChamberFest, a six-day series of chamber music performances by 20 student ensembles, which received intensive coaching by faculty members during the winter break. They were joined by guests from the Royal Academy of Music in London.

headline: On Our Radar …
text: A roundup of electric vehicle news from our friends at the Wheels blog, who are keeping tabs on the Detroit auto show this week:

headline: In Packers’ Loss, Rule Says No Call Was the Right Call
text: To some, the picture speaks 1,000 words and four of them are: the Packers were robbed. The image of Cardinals cornerback Michael Adams’s index finger hooked on Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers’s face mask was seen far and wide, sparking the question of whether it was a penalty, which would have negated the fumble Adams caused.

headline: Career Advice From Conan O’Brien
text: In light of recent events, now seems like a good time to pull out some of my favorite advice on risk-taking, courtesy of Conan O’Brien (from his 2000 Harvard commencement speech):

headline: Paterson’s Son Is Questioned by Police
text: Updated, 6:50 p.m.| Alex Paterson, the 15-year-old son of Gov. David A. Paterson, was questioned on Tuesday in New York after police officers found him and his friends playing dice on the Upper West Side.

headline: Aerial Skier Dismisses Conformity, and Gravity
text: DENVER  Each December, the family that launches together builds a rocket for the holidays.

headline: Voices of Gay Irishmen, Set to Song
text: Seeing “Silver Stars” is like taking a very short trip in a time machine. The show, a song cycle stitched together from the stories of older gay Irishmen, sounds like something you might have heard in New York a generation ago, when the act of coming out was by itself enough to hang a theater piece on.

headline: On the Web, a Wave of Support for Conan O’Brien
text: The Internet has voted, and it’s supporting Conan O’Brien in his struggle against NBC.

headline: House Hunting in ... Scotland
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM DUPLEX IN EDINBURGH

headline: For All Its Success, Will ‘Avatar’ Change the Industry?
text: LOS ANGELES  Just five months after Warner Brothers released its talking-picture sensation “The Jazz Singer” in October 1927, the studio was back in theaters with another talkie, the crime drama “Tenderloin.”

headline: Up-and-Coming Musicians, With a Prominent Backer
text: Orange Mountain Music, Philip Glass’s record label, was founded in 2001 as an outlet for Mr. Glass’s archival and out-of-print recordings. But the label quickly began releasing Mr. Glass’s new works as well, and before long it was releasing discs by musicians in Mr. Glass’s ensemble and young composers who had caught his ear.

headline: Now Toting | Heritage Man-Bags
text: “I hate seeing guys who have a good look going and then crack it open with a Manhattan Portage bag,” says the accessories designer Basil Racuk. “It drives me crazy.” We feel your pain, Basil. Though Jack Spade has made some progress in addressing this all-too common problem, the line’s ubiquity (in our non-scientific survey, every second man on the F train was carrying one) has compromised its appeal. Two solutions to the man-purse dilemma: Racuk’s eponymous collection of made-to-order satchels, and the Madly, a line of men’s bags just introduced by Melanie Dizon and Jake Quellman.Racuk, who’s based in Northern California, goes for a rustic-yet-refined look — think Berkeley professor crossed with Milanese aesthete — and works with customers on every aspect of a bag’s design. “A good accessory is an exclamation point,” he says. “You want to get it just right.” His designs are distinguished by their trend-proof but not boring classicism — you can order his minimally structured briefcase in bright red if you like.

headline: Muzak Wins Approval to Exit Chapter 11
text: The music may not have stopped when Muzak filed for bankruptcy last year, but the company synonymous with the songs piped into elevators and retail stores is playing a happier tune on Tuesday.

headline: Bank of America Shuffles Its Top Management
text: Bank of America shuffled its top management on Wednesday afternoon, replacing its chief risk officer and starting a search for a new chief financial officer, as Brian T. Moynihan, the new chief executive, moved to put his team in place.

headline: ‘Big Government’ Health Care
text: The federal government released its latest estimates of health spending last week, and they allow for some telling comparisons. In 2008, the country spent $2.3 trillion on medical care, or 16.2 percent of gross domestic product and $7,681 per person.

headline: The Object of Clooney’s Affection and Waltz as a Country Boy
text: After George Clooney‘s wanton kowtowing to the critic Rex Reed at the New York Film Critics Circle Awards on Monday night, the Baguette caught up with Mr. Reed, a longtime writer for The New York Observer, when the party was winding down.

headline: Vintage Clothing, Red-Carpet Ready
text: Los Angeles

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: SACO, ME.

headline: The Breslin Bar and Dining Room
Google Threatens Pullout from China After Cyberattacks on Dissidents
text: In a calm and understated blog post, Google said Tuesday that it had recently come under an unusual cyberattack from China. The Web giant said the attack was very different from previous ones because it was aimed at Chinese dissidents’ Gmail accounts.

headline: Powermat Reconsidered
text: In an article I wrote in October, I essentially trashed the magnetic induction charging products from a company called Powermat. With its expensive charging plate and cellphone adapters, users can charge several devices at once without using any cables.

headline: Remembering a Splashdown, Many Flights Later
text: Sheikh Ali remembers standing in the Charlotte-Douglas International Airport, waiting for Matt Kane, a co-worker who had been scheduled to land on a flight from New York. And the flight was late.

headline: The Spark That Ignited Rwanda’s Inferno
text: As followers of the Rwandan government’s Twitter feed will already know, a new report on the 1994 assassination of President Juvénal Habyarimana — an event Hutu extremists used as an excuse to begin the massacre of up to one million Tutsi and moderate Hutu that year — was released this week accompanied by a five minute video summarizing an investigative commission’s findings.

headline: Gaming Goes Lite
text: Gaming computers aren’t generally known for their subtle physical characteristics. In fact, more than a few gaming friends would like to see desktop boxes that look more like Dracula’s head.

headline: Bar Pleiades and Ardesia Wine Bar
text: Is pedigree destiny? Two sleek new bars from illustrious food families provide clues: Ardesia, descended from Le Bernardin; and Bar Pleiades, from the fecund Daniel Boulud.

headline: Going to the Mat With Mind and Body
text: Bertolt Brecht’s punishing, poetic “In the Jungle of Cities” follows a deadly philosophical battle between two men, Garga and Szlink, and its devastating effects on Garga’s world, set in a mythical Chicago. In the Polish company Teatr Nowy’s adaptation, “Versus,” at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar Festival, audiences face another epic struggle: between the highly physical action on the stage and Dorothea Sobstel’s fast-moving, at times wretchedly clunky translation running on a screen overhead.

headline: Eating Isn’t Rescuing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lassoing Hawaii’s Marine Trash
text: When my 8-year-old son first heard about the Texas-size trash patch accumulating in the Pacific Ocean, he asked me a basic question: “Why doesn’t somebody go pick it up?”

headline: A Mere Bag of Shells
text: To the Editor:

headline: On CBS, Letterman Jokes About NBC
text: “Things are getting interesting in late-night television,” David Letterman said at the start of his monologue today. (An understatement much?)

headline: A Grisly Tale in the Guise of Therapy
text: If you’ve been eager to spend a truly unpleasant hour in a theater, “Jerk” at Performance Space 122 is ready to accommodate you. The piece, part of both the Under the Radar Festival and Coil 2010, comes with high expectations, but by its end you may add a few other “uns” to your assessment as well, like unrewarding and unenlightening.

headline: Rohmer the Classicist, Calmly Dissecting Desire
text: Among the films Eric Rohmer directed in the ninth and last decade of his life were “The Lady and the Duke,” set in the embattled aristocracy of 18th-century France, and “The Romance of Astrea and Celadon,” based on a 17th-century French literary pastoral. These were not Mr. Rohmer’s only forays into the past  in the mid-’70s he made “Perceval” and “The Marquise of O ...”  but period dress was hardly this filmmaker’s habitual get-up.

headline: Fierce Quake Devastates Haitian Capital
text: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  A fierce earthquake struck Haiti late Tuesday afternoon, causing a crowded hospital to collapse, leveling countless shantytown dwellings and bringing even more suffering to a nation that was already the hemisphere’s poorest and most disaster-prone.

headline: Even R.B.S. Chief’s Mother Disapproves of His Pay
text: Anyone in charge of the Royal Bank of Scotland at this point in time is bound to take some flak for the British firm’s bailout by taxpayers. As it turns out, not even the chief executive’s parents are completely thrilled with his job, according to The Telegraph of London.

headline: Saudi and Yemeni Forces Fight Rebels on 2 Fronts
text: CAIRO  Saudi Arabia’s assistant defense minister, Prince Khaled bin Sultan, said Tuesday that Saudi forces had killed hundreds of Yemeni rebels who had occupied a border village, as fighting between the rebels and Yemen’s military also intensified nearby in the Yemen city of Sadah.

headline: In New York Restaurants, the Rise of Rome
text: YEARS ago, New Yorkers in search of culinary enlightenment did not come back from Italy raving about Roman food. Rome was where your plane landed on the way to that dream trip to Tuscany.

headline: Transformed Fort Lauderdale to Host Super Bowl
text: The game will be over in one evening — but for Fort Lauderdale hotels, the after-party could last years.

headline: In the Soviet Union, When Food Was Scarce, Hope Could Still Be Nourished
text: The title of Elena Gorokhova’s new memoir, “A Mountain of Crumbs,” about growing up in the Soviet Union in the 1960s and ’70s, comes from a game her grandmother invented to hide that she had almost no food to put on the table. She’d break up a slice of black bread and a cube of sugar on a plate and say to the crying child: “Look at how much you’ve got. A whole mountain of crumbs.”

headline: ‘A Mountain of Crumbs’
text: Chapter 1. Ivanovo

headline: For Israelis Now, Echoes of Strife Then
text: Personal reminiscence and Israeli history are woven into a dense, occasionally impenetrable cinematic poem in Amos Gitai’s film “Carmel,” whose title refers to the mountains near Haifa, Mr. Gitai’s native city. The film begins with a prologue in which Mr. Gitai, pictured in stills, is shown strolling alone on a beach to the strains of a Mahler symphony. Then it abruptly plunges back in time to a crude re-enactment of the Roman siege of Jerusalem in the first century A.D., when the future emperor Titus and his army destroyed the city and its temple.

headline: Google, Citing Attack, Threatens to Exit China
text: This article was reported by Andrew Jacobs, Miguel Helft and John Markoff and written by Mr. Jacobs.

headline: Lanvin: Leopard Ladies
text: Amid the sparkly vagabond bits at the Lanvin early fall presentation was an appealing sturdiness, registered in several wool suits, including a slouchy pants number in gray wool, and a very cool olive-drab trench coat.

headline: A Fallen Star of French Cuisine, Restored to Its Silver Platter
text: IT was a roasted drumstick that got me thinking about chicken breasts.

headline: A Deal With Bank of America Is in Their Prayers
text: Bank of America is facing the power of prayer over foreclosures.

headline: Gently Cooked Chicken Breasts With Garlic-Chili-Ginger Sauce
text: Adapted from Zak Pelaccio

headline: A Top Condé Nast Executive Is Leaving
text: A top Condé Nast executive, Richard D. Beckman, will leave to become chief executive of e5 Global Media, a new company that owns The Hollywood Reporter, Billboard and Adweek, the two companies said Tuesday.

headline: Blair Aide Unapologetic Over Britain’s Role in Prelude to Iraq War
text: LONDON  A close aide to former Prime Minister Tony Blair made a defiantly unrepentant appearance on Tuesday before the panel investigating Britain’s involvement in the Iraq war, saying Britain should “be really proud of the role that we played in changing Iraq from what it was to what it is now becoming.”

headline: Acer Notebooks Recalled for Overheating
text: In the laptop computer arena, having the hot hand is not an advantage.

headline: Real Estate Comeback? The Phone’s Ready
text: Is the real estate market making a comeback? I have no idea, but if it is, your phone is ready. Two new real estate apps are being released this week.

headline: Is LPD the Next LCD?
text: While covering the development of digital, high-definition television since its inception, I’ve been approached by any number of startups that promised The Next Big Thing in displays: rear-projection sets that would cost a small fraction of current technology; a technique to dramatically increase screen contrast and remove all reflective room light that was so promising it was financed by one of the biggest television manufacturers in the world; SED technology demonstrated by Toshiba that put the picture quality of the best plasma TVs to shame. In short, flat panel displays so enticing that makers of other technologies would immediately throw in the towel.

headline: Clinton Tries to Defuse Asian Tension
text: HONOLULU  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton kicked off her travels this year, as she did last year, by flying across the Pacific rather than the Atlantic. But this time, her itinerary is more urgent. With tensions rising between the United States and both Japan and China, Asia has emerged as a diplomatic hornet’s nest, even beyond the perennial threat of North Korea.

headline: The Breslin Bar and Dining Room
text: A SNACK to start, scrumpets: shredded lamb, breaded and fried, served with sweet mint vinaigrette. Also a soft-boiled Scotch egg, the orb caked in sausage meat, then breaded and fried.

headline: For Some, ‘Kosher’ Equals Pure
text: THIS year, for the first time, glatt kosher food will be sold at the Super Bowl.

headline: Dutch Carmaker Still Pushing to Buy Saab
text: DETROIT  The head of the Dutch carmaker trying to buy Saab said Tuesday that the company had the money to make a deal and that one was still possible even though General Motors had started to shutdown the Swedish carmaker.

headline: Deitch at MOCA: The Dealer on Taking Over the Museum
text: In a press conference on Tuesday to introduce Jeffrey Deitch as the new director of the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, board members and Eli Broad, a founding trustee, praised Mr. Deitch, the New York art dealer, as their unanimous choice after a months-long, global search for new leadership.

headline: Ecuador: Foreign Minister Resigns
text: Foreign Minister Fander Falconí resigned after President Rafael Correa criticized his handling of negotiations in connection with a forest-protection project. Ecuador has been seeking aid from rich industrialized nations, in exchange for limiting carbon emissions by preventing oil exploration in the forested area. Mr. Correa had recently said that donor countries in Europe had acted “shamefully” by seeking to impose some conditions in relation to projects funded by their aid. The talks have been focused on protecting tropical forest in the Yasuní region of northeastern Ecuador.

headline: Chicago Out in Cold in World Cup Bid
text: Chicago is the home of the United States Soccer Federation, but apparently not its kind of town when it comes to potential sites for the 2018 or the 2022 World Cup. San Francisco and the rest of Northern California are also on that list.

headline: Corzine, in Farewell, Admits Failure to Relieve Tax Burden
text: TRENTON  In a farewell address tinged with more wistfulness than Wall Street bravado, Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey acknowledged on Tuesday his inability to solve the state’s mounting fiscal problems and said he hoped that he would be remembered for his commitment to the state’s children.

headline: People of Earth Respond to Conan
text: Conan O’Brien’s statement about why he will not host “The Tonight Show” if NBC moves it to 12:05 a.m. sparked a lively and largely pro-Conan response online.

headline: Witness Is Revealed in Galleon Case
text: It is one of the biggest mysteries on Wall Street: Who is Tipper X, the secret witness at the center of the biggest insider-trading case in a generation?

headline: Kimchi Pancake
text: WHEN Hae Wha Pak and her partners opened Kunjip, a Korean restaurant in Midtown, nine years ago, she and Haksoon Kim, the executive chef, decided to reinvent the traditional savory pancake. The pancake is usually made with wheat flour and filled with scallions and spicy pickled cabbage (kimchi).

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: A Terra Cotta Dish for Earthy Baking
text: Winter sets the appetite for hearty casseroles of beans, grains, sausages and other meats. The cuisines of Italy, India, Mexico and other countries have plenty of dishes to choose from.

headline: The Grape Once Again Proves Its Versatility
text: Balsamic is not the only mellow Italian vinegar with a pedigree. Centuries ago, the Este family of Ferrara produced sopraffino. Unlike classic balsamic, it is made from red grapes (not white), which are not cooked but instead concentrated by natural evaporation during aging, similar to Spanish sherry vinegar.

headline: The Season for Maine Shrimp Is Extended
text: Tiny, sweet Maine shrimp have a short season, a mere six weeks in winter. But the current harvest is so robust, the state Department of Marine Resources has extended it to May 29.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: A Chance of Meatballs

headline: Somali Man Is Charged in 2 More Ship Hijackings
text: A Somali man who was brought to New York last year and accused of piracy in the hijacking of an American-flagged cargo ship off Somalia was charged on Tuesday with leading the earlier takeover of two other ships, in which hostages were taken.

headline: Feet Don’t Fail Us Now
text: My review this week is of The Breslin, a restaurant on the ground floor of the Ace Hotel, on 29th Street of Broadway in Manhattan. The Breslin is the brainchild of Ken Friedman, the scary smart music-head restaurateur behind the Spotted Pig and the late John Dory, and the chef April Bloomfield. Ms. Bloomfield cooks as hearty cuisine at The Breslin as she has at her other restaurants: pig’s feet and bellies, lots of fat and lots of flavor. This makes for nice dinners but difficult sleeping, even for those who consume moderately. (Check out the slide show above for a look at her food.)

headline: Secret Witness Emerges in Galleon Case
text: It is one of the biggest mysteries on Wall Street: Who is Tipper X, the secret witness at the center of the biggest insider-trading case in a generation?

headline: Sidelined From Work, but Always on the Hunt
text: As a nurse case manager, Karen Rashford worked as a liaison between sick foster children and the health care system they were not equipped to navigate by themselves.

headline: The Saudis’ View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Officer Offered Clemency for Sex, Woman Testifies
text: They seemed like routine police questions at first, the 26-year-old dog groomer said.

headline: In Reversal, Jaguar Habitat Will Be Protected
text: After more than a decade of resistance, the Fish and Wildlife Service said Tuesday that it would reverse previous decisions and protect the habitat of the jaguar.

headline: Green Civil War: Projects vs. Preservation
text: Environmentalists are more openly at odds over two goals: the preservation of wide open spaces vs. the use of public lands for renewable energy projects.

headline: Monserrate Will Face Sanction Votes
text: ALBANY  A special New York State Senate committee weighing the fate of Senator Hiram Monserrate is set to recommend that the Senate vote on two resolutions to sanction him, including one that would force him from office, people with knowledge of the committee’s plans said Tuesday.

headline: A Higher Authority
text: Yvonne Vizzier Thaxton, one of the sources in my article about the popularity of kosher food among non-Jews, was having coffee one Sunday after Catholic mass with some of her friends in Starkville, Miss.

headline: Boy, 4, Chooses Long Locks and Is Suspended From Class
text: HOUSTON  A suburban Dallas school district has suspended a 4-year-old from his prekindergarten class because he wears his hair too long and does not want his parents to cut it.

headline: It’s Football in January, but Minus the Weather
text: It is that part of the N.F.L. calendar when meteorology collides with muscle and momentum, and the results are condensed to shorthand  the Ice Bowl, the Fog Bowl, the Tuck Rule Game, the Freezer Bowl, the holy-cheese-it-is-cold-here-in-Green-Bay game two years ago. (That conference championship game with the Giants, played below zero, begs for a snappier moniker.)

headline: A New Wave of Asian Automakers
text: On display at the 2010 Detroit Auto Show are Asian automakers who are hoping to break into the North American market by introducing electric cars or buying existing automakers.

headline: Super Bowl Sales as Economic Indicator
text: THE Federal Reserve Board may want to scrutinize another statistic to gauge the health of the economy: demand for ads during Super Bowls.

headline: Magazines Lost a Fourth of Ad Pages in ’09
text: Just how bad was 2009 for magazines?

headline: Arbitron’s Chief Resigns After a False Statement
text: A single imprecise sentence uttered during hours of Congressional testimony prompted the resignation of the chief executive of Arbitron, Michael Skarzynski, on Monday.

headline: Mixed Signals on Airport Scanners
text: WASHINGTON  The Transportation Security Administration has promised not to store or transmit nude images of airline passengers made by whole-body scanners, but when it asked manufacturers to submit bids for such machines, it required that the scanners have exactly those capabilities, according to agency documents obtained in a lawsuit.

headline: Lack of Medicare Chief Is a Strike Against Reform
text: Almost a year after taking office, President Obama has not yet nominated anybody to run Medicare.

headline: Consuela Lee, 83, Pianist and Educator, Dies
text: Consuela Lee, a jazz pianist who fought to establish an arts school for children in rural Alabama on the grounds of a moribund academy founded by her grandfather, died Dec. 26 in Atlanta, where she had lived since 2007. She was 83.

headline: As McGwire Moves on, Public Will, Too
text: A hitting coach is probably the least visible person in uniform. He does most of his work in private, in the batting cage under the stands or in the clubhouse video room, long before and sometimes after the games. He appears on the field only during batting practice, studying hitters from the edge of the dirt circle behind the plate.

headline: Closing Pipeline to Needy, City Shreds Clothes
text: New York City officials destroyed tons of new, unworn clothing and footwear last year that had been seized in raids on counterfeit label operations, abandoning a practice of giving knockoff garments to groups that help the needy.

headline: Clothing Bank for Those in Need
text: A clothing bank in New York allows those who are down on their luck to don much-needed new clothes. (NBC video)

headline: Sanchez Stockpiles Points in the Confidence Game
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When Mark Sanchez looks at the N.F.L. playoffs, he sees the quarterbacks he once idolized, guys like Brett Favre and Peyton Manning, Kurt Warner and Drew Brees.

headline: As the Clock Runs, Warner Weighs if It’s Time to Go
text: TEMPE, Ariz.  Twelve hours after shepherding the Arizona Cardinals into the National Football Conference divisional playoffs, Kurt Warner was rounding up five of his seven children for school. As others crowned him the king of the postseason after his near-perfect performance against the Green Bay Packers, Warner spent Monday reveling in the commonplace activities of fatherhood.

headline: Colts Look for Balance of Rested Versus Rusty
text: INDIANAPOLIS  For two weeks, the Indianapolis Colts have let the Rest Debate rage around them. But quietly, they were working harder than usual.

headline: McGwire Portrayed as in Fear in 2005
text: Concerns that Mark McGwire would become ensnared in a federal drug investigation and possibly also become the target of state or local prosecutors led to his decision to dodge questions about his use of steroids at a Congressional hearing in 2005, according to several people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Jewish Film Festival Begins
text: It’s hard to sift through all 32 offerings of features and shorts from 13 countries that are part of the 19th annual Jewish Film Festival, which begins tonight. World War II dramas, the story of a Rothschild baroness in postwar New York, and a crime story co-directed by a Palestinian and an Israeli are all on the bill. Two of the stronger films, according to Stephen Holden, “depart from the beaten path of historical documentaries and feature films, many of which focus on the Holocaust.” One of them is Haim Tabakman’s fateful drama “Eyes Wide Open,” set in contemporary Jerusalem. The film observes the unforgiving response within an ultra-Orthodox enclave to a gay relationship involving one of its own. The other is Adam Elliot’s claymation feature, “Mary and Max,” which follows the pen-pal relationship of Mary Dinkle (the voice of Toni Collette), a lonely 8-year-old girl living outside Melbourne, Australia, and Max Horovitz (Philip Seymour Hoffman), an obese 44-year-old Jewish New Yorker with Asperger’s syndrome. Go to see those and discover other surprising cinematic gems. The films will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater and the Jewish Museum.

headline: A Wonderful, Magical Animal
text: “Nowhere in New York right now is the fetish for pork fat and dairy flavor more on display,” Sam Sifton writes, then at the Breslin where “April Bloomfield, the chef and an owner, is exhausting gall bladders daily.” If the thought of shredded lamb, breaded and fried; or a soft-boiled Scotch egg, the orb caked in sausage meat, then breaded and fried; or deep-fried stuffed pig’s foot, “the size of a toddler’s leg,” makes your mouth water, then this is your spot. The vaguely British barroom, off the lobby of the Ace Hotel, attracts a “bedlam of gastrotourists and scenemakers.” But a visit should not be taken lightly, with an offering of “10 colors of fat,” “excess can become wretched, and fast.” Thankfully, at least for your body’s sake, the restaurant doesn’t take reservations.

headline: Battle of the Internet Stars
text: If the phrases “David After Dentist,” “Lady Gaga Medley” and “Keyboard Cat” make you crack up immediately, or at least giggle, then the YouTube Wars Part I competition is the place to be tonight. Bring you’re knowledge of viral videos to the performance space Littlefield in Brooklyn, where contestants can go head to head in a bracket-style tournament. For each round, the two competitors will face-off by playing their two favorite YouTube videos to wow the crowd. Whoever gets the best reaction moves on to the next round. Come armed with a playlist worthy of a belly laugh or at least a hearty guffaw. Organizers recommend choosing your start point wisely; video clips are limited to one minute. There will be prizes and drink specials, too.

headline: Jan. 12-13: Updates on Haiti’s Earthquake
text: Some Haitians and visitors to the country have turned to the Web to share information about the earthquake that struck about 10 miles southwest of the capital of Port-au-Prince on Tuesday evening at a magnitude of 7.0. The Lede is continuing to track online sources on Thursday to supplement reporting by our colleagues. Readers who are in Haiti or are in touch with people there are encouraged to use the comment thread below to share firsthand accounts with us, or to point to them on other Web sites.

headline: Thought Experiment #2
text: QUESTION: What is the difference among these three photographs?

headline: Sarah Palin Makes Her Debut on Fox
text: Making her debut as a Fox News analyst Tuesday night, Sarah Palin immediately picked up the network’s mantra, promising that she would provide “fair and balanced commentary.”

headline: Senate Hopeful in New State Airs Evolving Views
text: In his first extensive interview since he began weighing a run for United States Senate from New York, Harold E. Ford Jr. distanced himself from his previous opposition to same-sex marriage, his description of himself as “pro-life” and his push to permit local police officers to enforce federal immigration law, and said he would be a fiercer advocate for New York than Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand.

headline: Hey Google, Anybody Home?
text: Google’s celebrated algorithms may power the Web’s most popular search engine, but they have not yet been programmed to answer a call when a customer has a problem.

headline: Why Does Health Care Cost So Much?
text: People like to live too much.

headline: Baseball to Monitor Marlins’ Spending
text: The Florida Marlins on Tuesday committed to spend any proceeds from Major League Baseball’s revenue-sharing plan on player development and salaries.

headline: Manslaughter Defense Remains Open Issue in Doctor’s Killing
text: WICHITA, Kan.  It remained uncertain on Tuesday whether an abortion opponent accused of murdering a nationally known abortion provider would be permitted to argue that the shooting fell short of first-degree murder because he was trying to save lives.

headline: Interview With Harold Ford Jr.
text: Following are edited excerpts from Monday’s interview with Harold E. Ford Jr., conducted by Michael Barbaro, a political reporter for The New York Times, at New York University’s campus in Manhattan:

headline: Contractor Jailed in Cuba Was Aiding Religious Groups, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON  The United States contractor detained in Cuba last month and accused of being a spy is a 60-year-old social worker from the Washington suburbs who had gone to Cuba to provide communications equipment to Jewish nonprofit organizations, according to American officials.

headline: O’Brien Rejects NBC Shift: He’s Set to Say Good Night
text: NBC may control its airwaves, but apparently it does not control Conan O’Brien.

headline: 58 Down: Folkie Guthrie
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Three famous women have been planted in today’s grid, with FLOWER GIRLS hinting at their floral/female connection. IRIS MURDOCH blooms first, followed by DAISY MILLER and finally ROSE KENNEDY.

headline: Reid Faces Battles in Washington and at Home
text: HARRY REID WAS HOARSE and hacking, drawn and more stooped than usual on a Sunday morning 12 days before Christmas. It was not yet noon, and Reid was in his second-floor corner office in an empty United States Capitol. He had arrived to bad news. Joseph Lieberman, the independent Connecticut senator, had announced on CBS’s “Face the Nation” that he would not support the Senate health care plan, which meant that Reid did not have the 60 votes he needed. Lieberman’s announcement, which torpedoed a compromise that Reid helped to midwife, caught the Senate majority leader by surprise. Reid had spoken with Lieberman two days earlier, and one of Lieberman’s top aides participated in the Saturday-afternoon conference call that Reid orchestrates for Democratic senators who will be appearing on the Sunday talk shows. “He double-crossed me,” Reid said stiffly, associates later recounted. “Let’s not do what he wants. Let the bill just go down.”

headline: Haiti’s Agony
text: A potent earthquake centered just 10 miles from a city of close to 2 million people, most of whom are deeply impoverished, is a recipe for utter calamity, and initial reports out of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and nearby communities indicate that is what has unfolded in that unlucky country. It appears that at least one hospital and a school — two of the keystone structures in any community — are among the buildings that collapsed, along with dozens of shanties built on steep slopes.

headline: A Year of Terror Plots, Through a Second Prism
text: WASHINGTON  As terrorist plots against the United States have piled up in recent months, politicians and the news media have sounded the alarm with a riveting message for Americans: Be afraid. Al Qaeda is on the march again, targeting the country from within and without, and your hapless government cannot protect you.

headline: Wall St. Pay Is a Focus of Many in Washington
text: Everyone in Washington is taking a swing at Wall Street pay.

headline: The Biggest Loser
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Is China the Next Enron?
text: Taipei, Taiwan

headline: Report Links Vehicle Exhaust to Health Problems
text: Exhaust from cars and trucks exacerbates asthma in children and may cause new cases as well as other respiratory illnesses and heart problems resulting in deaths, an independent institute that focuses on vehicle-related air pollution has concluded.

headline: U.S.C. Hires Kiffin as Coach
text: In a bold move that shows that Southern California is unafraid of raising the ire of the N.C.A.A., the Trojans hired Lane Kiffin, the controversial Tennessee coach, on Tuesday to replace Pete Carroll, who was hired as the Seattle Seahawks’ coach.

headline: For Bankers, Saying ‘Sorry’ Has Its Perils
text: As America recovers from the worst financial crisis since the Depression, some of the nation’s chief executives are offering that rarest of statements  an apology.

headline: Knicks Get Their Look at Iverson
text: PHILADELPHIA — More than a month after briefly entertaining the thought of signing Allen Iverson, the Knicks are set to face him here Wednesday night — provided Iverson plays through knee tendinitis that has kept him in and out of Philadelphia’s lineup.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the growing popularity of early-bird dinner specials among younger diners in Florida misidentified, in some copies, the location of the restaurant shown. It is in Miami Beach, not North Miami.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a dance installation, “Scrying,” created for the Museum of Modern Art’s PopRally event series, misspelled the surname of a dancer shown rehearsing. She is Grace McLoughlin, not McLaughlin.

headline: Union Chief Seeks to Overhaul Teacher Evaluation Process
text: WASHINGTON  Facing criticism that her union makes it too hard to get rid of bad teachers, Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers, on Tuesday announced a union-backed effort to develop a new model for how public school teachers should be evaluated, promoted and removed.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about the musical “The Addams Family,” now playing in Chicago and scheduled to come to Broadway in March, misidentified, in some copies, the maker of the film “A Nightmare on Elm Street” in citing examples of movies and television shows influenced by Charles Addams. It was made by Wes Craven, not Tim Burton.

headline: Corrections
text: A dance review on Tuesday about Miami City Ballet misspelled a dancer’s surname. He is Michael Sean Breeden, not Breedon.

headline: Corrections
text: A television review on Friday about “Return to Cranford,” on PBS, misidentified, at one point, the period in which the story is set. As the review noted elsewhere, it is set in 1844  the mid-19th century, not “the mid-18th century.”

headline: Tax Them Both
text: The White House is talking about levying a tax or fee on large banks to recover the $120 billion it spent to bail out the financial system. That is a good place to start, but it shouldn’t stop there. President Obama and Congress should also impose a windfall tax on the huge bonuses that bailed-out bankers plan to pay themselves over the next few weeks.

headline: Football and Antitrust
text: On the surface, American Needle Inc. v. National Football League seems to be about hats, shirts and other items with team logos on them. But if the United States Supreme Court issues a broad ruling in favor of the N.F.L., it could help define how far joint ventures can go in stifling competition.

headline: Looking Past the Facade of Italian City After Riots
text: ROSARNO, Italy  The official figures show there are 1,600 agricultural workers in this town, all but 36 of them Italians. The reality, exposed by the raw and violent riots here last week, was far different: Some 1,200 foreigners, most of them Africans, earned about $30 a day under the table picking oranges and clementines. Now that the town is largely cleared of foreign labor, the fruit remains on the trees.

headline: Compassion in New Jersey
text: It was a rare piece of good news for those suffering from such diseases as cancer, AIDS, Lou Gehrig’s disease and muscular dystrophy. The New Jersey Legislature on Monday legalized medically prescribed marijuana, and Gov. Jon Corzine has promised to sign the bill before leaving office next week.

headline: Miep Gies
text: “I am not a hero,” insisted Miep Gies. “I was just an ordinary housewife and secretary.” It was Mrs. Geis’s habit to deflect accolades for defying Nazi occupiers of Amsterdam by helping to hide Anne Frank, her family and three other doomed Jews in a secret annex to the business office of Anne’s father, Otto Frank.
