headline: How to Stop America’s Scientific Brain Drain
text: To the Editor:

headline: She Hid Anne Frank
text: To the Editor:

headline: Poverty in New York City
text: To the Editor:

headline: Questions for the Big Bankers
text: Today, the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, which Congress established last year to investigate the causes of the financial crisis, is scheduled to question the heads of four big banks  Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian Moynihan of Bank of America. The Op-Ed editors asked eight financial experts to pose questions they would like to hear the bankers answer.

headline: Google Would Abandon a Lucrative Market
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google threatened on Tuesday to pull out of China after it learned of immense security attacks and attempts to gain access to the Gmail accounts of Chinese dissidents and human rights activists.

headline: Talks to Begin on Creating a Bipartisan Budget Panel
text: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will begin talks this week with leading lawmakers about creating a bipartisan budget commission, an idea that has long languished in Congress but could become central to the Obama administration’s promise to reduce annual deficits.

headline: Kvelling Over a Matriarch of the Yiddish Theater
text: Out came the rugelach. Out came the bagels and lox. Out came the chicken salad. And out came the stories  in Yiddish, of course  about Mina Bern, the great Yiddish actress who died on Sunday, leaving a void in what is left of Yiddish theater in New York.

headline: Mina Bern, Versatile Yiddish Actress, Dies at 98
text: Mina Bern, a plucky and versatile actress and singer who was one of the last links to the scrappy world of Yiddish theater in New York, died Sunday in Manhattan. She was 98 and lived on the Lower East Side.

headline: Goalies Show Top Form as Devils Edge Rangers
text: It was a game worthy of the nine Olympians on the ice and the two behind the benches, a rugged but cleanly played contest of unrelenting high speed and numerous chances. In the end, however, it was the goaltending that was the most Olympian of all.

headline: Insurers Helped Pay for TV Attack Ads
text: Five big health insurance companies funneled millions of dollars to the United States Chamber of Commerce for television commercials attacking Congressional efforts to overhaul the health care system, the National Journal reported Tuesday.

headline: Illinois Tries United Front Against Fish and Lawsuit
text: CHICAGO  Federal and state officials from Illinois on Tuesday defended their efforts to ward off Asian carp, a voracious, nonnative fish that could threaten the ecosystem of the Great Lakes, even as they reported new evidence that the fish may be near Lake Michigan.

headline: Knox Burger, Agent and Book Editor, Dies at 87
text: As a magazine editor in the 1950s, Knox Burger published Kurt Vonnegut’s first short story. As a book editor in the 1960s, he asked John D. MacDonald to create a mystery series around a character who eventually turned out to be the detective Travis McGee. And as a literary agent in the 1970s, he took on a novel about a Russian detective by a largely unknown writer  “Gorky Park,” by Martin Cruz Smith  which in 1980 he sold to Random House for $1 million.

headline: Paterson’s 15-Year-Old Son Is Questioned but Not Charged After Dice Game, Officials Say
text: Alex Paterson, the 15-year-old son of Gov. David A. Paterson, was questioned by the police on Tuesday after officers found him and four friends playing dice on the Upper West Side, people with direct knowledge of the case said.

headline: Former Seagate C.E.O. Bill Watkins Joins an LED Start-Up
text: Seagate Technology, the big hard drive company, surprised people last January when the board abruptly fired its outspoken and candid chief executive, Bill Watkins. A year later, Mr. Watkins, as outspoken as ever, has resurfaced as the chief executive of an LED start-up called Bridgelux.

headline: Frantic Hunt for News on Haiti’s Quake
text: As news of the devastation wrought by a powerful earthquake trickled out of Haiti on Tuesday evening, Ricot Dupuy, a station manager at Radio Soleil d’Haiti in Brooklyn, sat alone in his radio booth fielding a flurry of phone calls from local listeners.

headline: Corrections
text: A recipe with The Minimalist column last Wednesday for French lentils with cashews misstated the amount of dried French green (Le Puy) lentils. It calls for one cup, not a half cup. A corrected recipe can be found at nytimes.com/dining.

headline:
At Goldman, E-Mail Message
Lays Bare Conflicts in Trading
text: For years, Wall Street whispered that Goldman Sachs profited handsomely by trading ahead of  or even against  its own clients.

headline: Down by the Banks of the River Charles: The ‘American Idol’ Premiere
text: Let the long period of national mourning begin: the ninth season of “American Idol” began tonight, and it was two hours of dead-man-walking. With the future stability of the show in doubt, Tuesday’s premiere episode, focusing on the Boston auditions, was a reminder of its strengths and weaknesses. Soak in Simon Cowell‘s evident distaste for Kara Dioguardi; ponder the physics of Victoria Beckham‘s head tilt; let the shock of a contestant saying Randy Jackson’s his favorite judge sting anew. Soon, this will all be just a memory.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Authority, Not Legality, of Civil Confinements
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday about the controversial practice of keeping sex offenders locked up after they have completed their criminal sentences  but from an unusual angle.

headline: Longhorns Look to Stay Unbeaten
text: Kentucky remained unbeaten with its 89-77 victory at Florida on Tuesday. Top-ranked Texas, the other undefeated team in Division I, plays at Iowa State on Wednesday. Texas had never been No. 1.

headline: Nobel Winner to Step Down as Chief at Sloan-Kettering
text: Dr. Harold E. Varmus, the Nobel Prize-winning president and chief executive of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, said Tuesday that he would be stepping down after 10 years as the head of the renowned Upper East Side medical institution.

headline: Lottery Numbers
California Panel Considers Money From Climate Rules
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Offering an early glimpse of how California might manage a central element of its ambitious greenhouse-gas law, a state committee has recommended that residents receive cash or tax breaks resulting from auctions of emission allowances to industries and other polluters.

headline: Deals to Restrain Generic Drugs Face a Ban
text: A group of House lawmakers and the head of the Federal Trade Commission want Congress to include a provision in the health care legislation that they say could save American consumers several billion dollars a year on prescription drugs.

headline: An Olympic Plot Line at the Garden
text: At Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, the Devils’ cast included the United States captain, Jamie Langenbrunner, who is also their captain, and Zach Parise, an American alternate captain.

headline: Obama to Propose Bank Tax to Recoup Bailout Losses
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has decided to seek a tax on big banks to recoup up to $120 billion that the government expects to lose from bailing out the financial system, automakers and some troubled homeowners.

headline: Labor Campaigns Against Tax on Health Plans
text: WASHINGTON  Having failed to persuade President Obama to scrap a proposed tax on high-cost health insurance policies, labor leaders took their case Tuesday to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, and they said they received a more favorable response.

headline: Fed Is Again Accused of Blocking Release of A.I.G. Bailout Information
text: For the second time in a week, the Federal Reserve was accused by a member of Congress on Tuesday of blocking the public release of information about the bailout of the American International Group.

headline: Google Refuses to Kowtow
text: I’m quite amazed that Google is showing the guts to announce that it will no longer censor within China (google.cn) and is prepared to pull out of China altogether. Wow! Finally, a company shows some principles and backbone in this area, after Microsoft Bing censored Chinese-language content worldwide (they claim it was a bug) and Yahoo helped the Chinese government sent dissidents to prison.There are no perfect solutions for dealing with a repressive government, and I made my own share of compromises when I lived for five years in China. I’m a big believer in engagement as a whole, when foreign engagement amounts to a watchdog and boosts civil society. But instead so many foreign companies have acted as lapdogs and facilitated censorship and surveillance, while refusing to speak up for the values they claim to be committed to.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,364 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 938 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Mixed Signals Complicate European Bank’s Task
text: FRANKFURT  With signals about European growth mixed and some weaker members of the European Union still in debt crisis, the European Central Bank is in a tough position as it seeks to pull back on measures that helped the euro zone through the recession.

headline: GLAAD Award Nominees Include ‘Glee,’ ‘True Blood,’ ‘Mad Men’ and ‘Precious’
text: The television shows “True Blood,” “Glee” and “Mad Men,” and the films “I Love You, Man” and “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ By Sapphire,” are among the nominees for the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation’s annual GLAAD Media Awards, the group announced. The winners of the awards, which are for “recognizing and honoring media for outstanding images” of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, the alliance said in a news release, will be chosen from 116 nominees in 24 English-language categories and 36 nominees in eight Spanish-language categories. “Precious” and “I Love You, Man” were among the five movies nominated in the outstanding film – wide release category; “True Blood” and “Mad Men” were nominated for outstanding drama series, alongside “Brothers & Sisters,” “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Skins”; and “Glee” was nominated for outstanding comedy series, as were “Modern Family,” “United States of Tara,” “Beautiful People” and “Greek.” The actress Cynthia Nixon will receive the group’s Vito Russo Award at a ceremony in New York, and the cast of the Broadway revival of “Hair” will receive a special recognition for its “commitment to raising visibility for marriage equality,” GLAAD said.

headline: Facebook Joins With McAfee to Clean Spam From Site
text: It looks like Facebook has finally gotten fed up with all the viruses and spam that is plaguing the social network and ensnaring and embarrassing its 350 million members.

headline: Simon and Garfunkel to Play Jazzfest
text: For a month, fans and potential customers of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival have been eyeing a big “artist TBA” on the schedule New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. That TBA has now been announced by the festival: the surprise act for the first of Jazzfest’s two weekends, on April 24, will be the reunited Simon and Garfunkel. It’s not the first time that Paul Simon has played Jazzfest, but it will be Art Garfunkel’s first time there, and this is to be Simon and Garfunkel’s only American appearance in 2010. Simon and Garfunkel fans have been awaiting news of unions shows in the United States since Mr. Garfunkel joined Mr. Simon onstage at the Beacon Theater in New York last February. The festival, now in its 41st year, will also feature, among many others, Lionel Richie, My Morning Jacket, Dr. John, Darius Rucker and Drake in its first weekend (April 23 to 25), and Pearl Jam, Aretha Franklin, Van Morrison, B.B. King, the Neville Brothers and Widespread Panic in its second (April 29 to May 2).

headline: North Carolina: Chemical Spill Closes Port
text: An early morning accident at the port in Morehead City spilled as much as five gallons of the highly explosive chemical pentaerythritol tetranitrate, or PETN, prompting officials to close the port and evacuate the surrounding area. Emergency officials made progress containing the spill, and by evening the evacuation was lifted. The accident occurred when a forklift operator punctured a container, putting holes in nine 110-pound drums containing PETN, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

headline: Showcase: Pounded Pavement
text: In a typical trip along the sidewalks of Manhattan, a pedestrian peering ahead can quickly take in a variety of expressions. Faces in the crowd inevitably reflect concentration and consternation, amusement and bewilderment, determination and aggravation. But glance down at any point along the way, and you may be surprised to see yet another face returning your gaze, like this one, with its faintly reptilian grin.

headline: Rail to the Trails
text: New York City skiers and snowboarders can rarely claim advantages over their brethren out West. Our nearby mountains are small compared with the Rockies and the Tetons. Instead of powder we have ice. And despite the bitter cold, our season is frustratingly short. But we do have one thing Coloradoans don’t — a subway to the ski area.

headline: Why Do So Many Winter Olympians Have Asthma?
text: Every four years, exercise-induced asthma draws special attention among scientists and the media, in lock step with the Winter Olympics. That’s because when the world’s premier cold-weather sports athletes convene in Vancouver for the 2010 Winter Olympics next month, they will share, as a group, not only exceptional fitness but also a disproportionate tendency to wheeze.

headline: Nintendo Wii to Add Netflix Service for Streaming Video
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Owners of the Nintendo Wii can finally stop waving their video game controllers in the air and sink back onto the couch.

headline: ‘Early Show’ Anchor Will Change Roles at CBS
text: The news anchor Russ Mitchell will exit “The Early Show” at the end of the week, leaving a gap in the lineup for the perennially third-place CBS morning show.

headline: A Compelling Matchup at the Palestra
text: No. 19 Temple (13-3) at Penn (1-10)Expect the corners of the Palestra to be packed Wednesday night for a game that will rekindle Philadelphia’s Big 5 glory.

headline: Chinese Maker Hopes to Offer Electric Car for U.S. by Year-End
text: DETROIT  After a disastrous year for the auto industry, carmakers are working hard to exude optimism and confidence at this year’s auto show.

headline: New Twist in Lawsuit Against Billionaire
text: A lawsuit filed by the ex-wife of one Wall Street’s richest hedge fund managers showed signs on Tuesday of becoming more complicated by the day.

headline: Battle For Ailing Japan Airlines Continues
text: Investors rushed to sell their shares in Japan Airlines on Tuesday and Wednesday ahead of a bankruptcy filing that could come as early as next week. At the same time, two rival airlines, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines, battled for a stake in JAL, which could still be a strong regional player once restructuring takes place, The New York Times’s Hiroko Tabuchi reported.

headline: Web Tool Tracks the Flu
text: Google’s Flu Trends, a surveillance tool for the United States that tracks flu-related search queries, will measure flu activity in 121 cities. Official flu trend data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, based on how many people with flu symptoms visit doctors, takes a week or more to collect, but the Google data will be updated daily. Google designed the tool in consultation with C.D.C. epidemiologists. Its successful flu shot finder is used by flu.gov and cdc.gov/h1n1flu, the government’s chief influenza Web sites.

headline: Haiti Lies in Ruins; Grim Search for Untold Dead
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Survivors strained desperately on Wednesday against the chunks of concrete that buried this city along with thousands of its residents, rich and poor, from shantytowns to the presidential palace, in the devastating earthquake that struck late Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Citigroup Bonus May Trump Goldman’s
text: This bonus season, would you rather be a banker at Goldman Sachs or Citigroup? Goldman has famously set aside more money to reward employees for their efforts last year. But the biggest bonuses will come mostly in stock, and Goldman’s shares have surged from the lows of the crisis. Give other banks’ shares a chance to catch up and bankers paid in the laggards’ equity could wind up richer on 2009’s spoils.

headline: Reaction in Knoxville to Kiffin’s Departure
text: Not everyone is excited about Lane Kiffin’s decision to leave Tennessee after 14 months and succeed Pete Carroll at U.S.C. Certainly the Volunteer faithful in Knoxville were feeling a little betrayed. This is from the Associated Press story:

headline: To Curb Loans, China Tells Banks to Increase Reserves
text: Chinese regulators ordered state-owned banks on Tuesday to set aside a larger share of their deposits as a reserve against failed loans, another in a string of indicators that Beijing is concerned about speculation in the nation’s fast-growing economy.

headline: Anxious Haitians in U.S. Search for Information
text: As news of the devastation wrought by a powerful earthquake trickled out of Haiti on Tuesday evening, Ricot Dupuy, a disc jockey at Radio Soleil d’Haiti in Brooklyn, sat alone in his radio booth fielding a flurry of phone calls from local listeners.

headline: Administration Says Stimulus Has Worked
text: WASHINGTONThe Obama administration, in its latest progress report on the $787 billion stimulus program, said both the overall economy and employment continued to be in better shape at the end of 2009 than they would have been without the government’s help.

headline: Anne Frank’s Protector
text: WHO was Miep Gies?

headline: News Quiz | January 13, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Haiti Disaster Relief: How to Contribute
text: For readers interested in contributing to help victims of the earthquake in Haiti, here is a list of contact information and links for some agencies that plan to provide relief.

headline: Haiti Disaster Relief: How to Contribute
text: For readers interested in contributing to help victims of the earthquake in Haiti, here is a list of contact information and links for some agencies that plan to provide relief.

headline: Deals to Restrain Generic Drugs Face a Ban
text: A group of House lawmakers and the head of the Federal Trade Commission want Congress to include a provision in the health care legislation that they say could save American consumers several billion dollars a year on prescription drugs.

headline: Gates Foundation Seeks to Spur Savings By the Poor
text: From Steve Lohr at Bits:

headline: Google’s Threat Echoed Everywhere, Except China
text: BEIJING  Google’s declaration that it would stop cooperating with Chinese Internet censorship and consider shutting down its operations in China ricocheted around the world on Wednesday. But in China itself, the news was heavily censored.

headline: Connecting to People Affected by the Quake
text: Updated Below | The powerful earthquake that struck Haiti on Tuesday knocked out telephones and electricity in the capital, Port-au-Prince, adding to the fears of many Haitian expatriates and family members who could not contact the people they knew in the country.

headline: Connecting to People Affected by the Quake
text: Updated Below | The powerful earthquake that struck Haiti on Tuesday knocked out telephones and electricity in the capital, Port-au-Prince, adding to the fears of many Haitian expatriates and family members who could not contact the people they knew in the country.

headline: Wall Street Pay Is a Focus of Many in Washington
text: Everyone in Washington is taking a swing at Wall Street pay.

headline: Chicago Out in Cold in World Cup Bid
text: Chicago is the home of the United States Soccer Federation, but apparently not its kind of town when it comes to potential sites for the 2018 or the 2022 World Cup. San Francisco and the rest of Northern California are also on that list.

headline: France Confident It Can Tax and Retain Bankers
text: The French government does not fear that taxing bank bonuses will lead traders and financial operations to flee Paris, according to Finance Minister Christine Lagarde, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

headline: Goldman E-Mail Lays Bare Trading Conflicts
text: For years, Wall Street whispered that Goldman Sachs profited handsomely by trading ahead of — or even against — its own clients. On Tuesday, a Goldman executive made an unusual admission that, in some cases, the rumors were true, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in The New York Times.

headline: Gates Foundation Seeks to Spur Savings by the Poor
text: For decades, the microfinance industry has really been about microcredit — making tiny loans to shoestring entrepreneurs in poor countries. Taking deposits and creating savings accounts for the poor has gotten short shrift.

headline: ’09 Deadliest Year for Afghans, U.N. Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Last year was the most lethal for Afghan civilians since the American-led war began here in late 2001, with the Taliban and other insurgent groups causing the vast majority of noncombatant deaths, according to a United Nations survey released Wednesday.

headline: TV: What’s Going On?
text: Comings and goings in television have been in the news a lot this week. Simon Cowell will leave “American Idol,” Sarah Palin will join “Fox News” and there’s a shake-up in late-night comedy at NBC. Have you followed this news? Do you watch any of these television franchises? Do you care?

headline: Beverly Hills Blocks Outside Students
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  In a contentious meeting ringed by police officers, the Beverly Hills school board voted Tuesday night to dismiss 206 students enrolled in its schools on out-of-district permits.

headline: How Citigroup Bonus Could Trump Goldman’s
text: This bonus season, would you rather be a banker at Goldman Sachs or Citigroup? Goldman has famously set aside more money to reward employees for their efforts last year.

headline: Elevation’s Latest Hire Is Another Apple Alum
text: Elevation Partners said Tuesday that Avadis Tevanian, a former Apple executive, has joined the private equity firm as a managing director, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Wall Street Drops as Banks Take a Hit
text: Stocks slid in a broad sell-off on Tuesday as investors pummeled financials on concerns about a potential government tax on banks, while Alcoa’s disappointing earnings tempered optimism about the economic recovery, Reuters reported.

headline: Obama to Announce TARP Fee on Banks
text: President Obama will announce plans on Thursday to raise up to $120 billion from major American financial firms to cover expected losses from a taxpayer-funded bank bailout, a senior administration official told Reuters.

headline: Foodoirs & Chicken Lit
text: Memoirs and novels centered around food.(Food+[mem]oir; Chick[en] lit[erature])

headline: Top Condé Nast Executive Leaves for e5 Global
text: A top Condé Nast executive, Richard D. Beckman, will leave to become chief executive of e5 Global Media, a new private equity-backed company that owns The Hollywood Reporter, Billboard and Adweek, the two companies said Tuesday.

headline: VMware Gently Nudges Microsoft with a Zimbra
text: VMware has once again put Microsoft on notice.

headline: Fed Again Accused of Blocking Release of A.I.G. Information
text: For the second time in a week, the Federal Reserve was accused by a member of Congress of blocking the public release of information about the bailout of the American International Group.

headline: Cablevision Board Approves Madison Square Garden Split
text: Cablevision Systems said Tuesday its board has approved the spinoff of its Madison Square Garden Group.

headline: Yahoo Sells Zimbra to VMware
text: Yahoo is selling the e-mail service Zimbra to VMware as part of an effort to focus on the Internet services that generate most of its revenue, The Associated Press reported.

headline: BYD Hopes to Offer Electric Car in U.S. This Year
text: After a disastrous year for the auto industry, carmakers are working hard to exude optimism and confidence at this year’s auto show.

headline: K.K.R. Scores Soccer Deal
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, seeking to diversify beyond traditional buyouts, has reportedly scored an underwriting gig, winning its first capital markets mandate in Europe as a co-manager on Manchester United‘s £500 million bond issue, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Judge Denies New Trial for Ex-Qwest Chief
text: A federal judge in Denver has denied a request by Joseph Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, for a new trial on insider trading charges.

headline: BlackRock Chief Sees Stronger Emerging Markets
text: The president of BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager, said on Tuesday that emerging markets are a bright spot for investment and warned that United States real estate prices will probably fall further.

headline: Ex-Seagate C.E.O. Joins LED Start-Up
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: K.K.R. Financial Prices $150 Million Offering
text: K.K.R. Financial Holdings on Tuesday said it priced its offering of $150 million in convertible senior notes due in 2017 in an underwritten registered public offering.

headline: A Tax on Banks and Their Bonuses?
text: The White House is talking about levying a tax or fee on large banks to recover the $120 billion it spent to bail out the financial system. That is a good place to start, but it shouldn’t stop there, The New York Times’s editorial board says.

headline: Court Is Told Mayor Aided in Massacre of Filipinos
text: MANILA  A witness to the massacre of 57 people in the southern Philippines testified Wednesday that the principal suspect in the case, a town mayor, had shot several of the victims himself and that the mayor’s father, the patriarch of a powerful political clan once allied with President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, had personally directed his son to carry out several of the killings.

headline: Ferrero Said to Drop Out of Cadbury Bidding
text: Ferrero of Italy has decided not to bid for Cadbury, further strengthening the case of Kraft Foods in its $17 billion takeover bid for the British chocolatier.

headline: Banking Chiefs in the Hot Seat, Again
text: As America recovers from the worst financial crisis since the Depression, some of the nation’s chief executives are offering that rarest of statements — an apology.

headline: Gundlach’s DoubleLine Registers 3 New Funds
text: DoubleLine Capital, the money management firm started last month by star bond fund manager Jeffrey Gundlach, plans to open three new mutual funds for the general public, Reuters said, citing a registration statement filed on Tuesday.

headline: Société Générale Issues Profit Warning After Write-Down
text: Société Générale  said Wednesday that it would write off another €1.4 billion in soured U.S. mortgage assets in the last quarter of 2009, but would still manage “a slight profit” for the period, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

headline: Almost Perfect: A Closer Look at Kurt Warner’s Gem
text: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

headline: A Festival of Mimes, No Berets Allowed
text: Since the late ’70s, London’s International Mime Festival has eschewed the genre cliché of beret-clad performers pretending to be stuck in a box. Instead, the annual festival, which runs at various sites through Jan. 31, is a forum for what Joseph Seelig, a co-founder, calls unconventional “visual theater.”

headline: Wall St. Must Pay ‘Mad Scientists’ Well, Lobbyist Says
text: Some Wall Street executives in line for fat bonuses are akin to “mad scientists” whose brilliance justifies the size of their pay packages, the head of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce said on Tuesday.

headline: App of the Week: Lock Up Your Android
text: 4:51 p.m. | Updated Noting the $19.90 annual subscription fee that comes with WaveSecure app, now owned by McAfee.

headline: Say ‘Formaggio’ | The Modeling Missonis
text: A family that models together stays together. Just ask the Missonis, who appear as walking advertisements for their namesake label in a new spring 2010 campaign. Photographed by Juergen Teller, the ads were shot at the family home in Sumirago, Italy, near the company’s headquarters and feature three generations of Missonis mugging for the camera. Not that it was hard to coax any of them to say “formaggio.” “For us home and factory have always been very close,” explains the label’s designer Angela Missoni. “It just felt like the right moment to propose something real.” And an even better time to cut back on modeling fees.

headline: Farewell, Faded British Beauty
text: Today’s idea: Britain in the 21st century has left behind decaying gentility and succumbed to the sterile minimalism of the international rich, an essay laments.

headline: Fed Paid Treasury Record $46.1 Billion in 2009
text: The Federal Reserve paid a record $46.1 billion to the U.S. Treasury last year as aggressive bond purchases and lending to fight the financial crisis swelled its net income by 46.8 percent.

headline: UBS’s New Code of Ethics for Employees
text: UBS released a new ethics guidebook for its employees Tuesday, taking a stand on financial crimes, especially tax evasion, as it seeks to get itself back on course after a year of legal troubles.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Bank of America (Again) on Merrill
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Bank of America for a second time over its takeover of Merrill Lynch, accusing the bank of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill before shareholders voted on the merger.

headline: More Questions for the Finance Chiefs
text: Today, the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, which Congress established last year to investigate the causes of the financial crisis, is scheduled to question the heads of four big banks — Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian Moynihan of Bank of America.

headline: Japan Airlines to Get New Chief
text: Kazuo Inamori, the honorary chairman of the electronics components maker Kyocera, said Wednesday thta he had agreed to become the new chief executive of troubled Japan Airlines.

headline: British Banks Said to Bite the Bullet on Bonus Tax
text: Banks in Britain will pay the one-time, 50 percent tax on bonuses levied by the Treasury rather than reduce compensation, accountants and lawyers who advise financial institutions told Bloomberg News, though bankers who face increased income taxes on those payouts may not be so accommodating.

headline: Was There a Commercial Real Estate Bubble?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Percents And Sensibility
text: Brad DeLong makes a very good point:

headline: Yemen Says It Has Killed Possible Chief of Qaeda Cell
text: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni security forces killed a man suspected of leading a cell of Al Qaeda and captured four other militants on Wednesday morning, hours after two soldiers were killed by Qaeda members in a neighboring district, Yemeni officials said.

headline: Sampler: Oakland Crime Summit, Campbell a Likely Senate Candidate
text: A Call for Outrage | Tammerlin Drummond, a columnist for The Oakland Tribune, calls for a crime summit in the city after the shooting death of Alvaro Ayala, 28, who died Sunday during a robbery outside his East Oakland house. Oakland residents seem to have become numb to the 100 or so annual homicide deaths. “Huge numbers of people are being injured and killed in this city,” said the police chief, Anthony Batts, who supports the idea of a crime summit. “Yet I don’t hear anybody yelling about it.” [The Oakland Tribune]

headline: Word of the Day | droll
text: droll •\ˈdrol\• adjective

headline: Thain Said to Hold Talks With CIT Over Top Job
text: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch who left Bank of America just months after the two companies merged, may be in talks for a new gig.
Olivia Judson is away this week.

headline: Hilco Consumer Capital Chief May Leave, Report Says
text: James Salter, the chief executive of Hilco Consumer Capital, may leave the Toronto-based private-equity shop to hang his own investment shingle, The New York Post reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline: The Early Word: Economic Inquiry Begins
text: Wall Street executives at the helms of bailed out banks are on the hot seat this morning for the first hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission.

headline: S.E.C. to Unveil New Investigative Units, Report Says
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is set to name chiefs for five new specialized investigative units, as the agency seeks to strengthen its enforcement program, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Q&A: Hong Kong’s Air-Pollution Problem
text: The air pollution in Hong Kong reached “life threatening” levels on average one in every eight days in 2009, The South China Morning Post reported in an article that was picked up widely by other news media last week.

headline: Obama, Congressional Leaders Resume Push on Health Care
text: President Obama and Senator Harry Reid hold their first face-to-face meeting on Wednesday since the controversy erupted over comments that Mr. Reid once made about Mr. Obama’s race and dialect. But that topic is not on the Oval Office agenda. Health care is.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, Jan. 13
text: Highlights from today’s media coverage in The New York Times:

headline: Today, We’re All Haitians
text: After 9/11, the French newspaper Le Monde declared: We Are All Americans. And after yesterday’s earthquake: Today, we are all Haitians. No country seems to have had worse luck with misrule, environmental mismanagement, natural disasters and poor governance than Haiti. And now the earthquake.Poverty always hugely magnifies natural disasters. I saw this first in the terrible 1991 cyclone in Bangladesh that killed more than 100,000 people. The poorest people lived in marginal areas, such as flood plains, and in flimsy huts that were immediately washed away. So they were killed. Those who were better off lived on firmer land in sturdier homes, and after the disaster they were able to afford clean water and medical care for their children. Frequently what kills people in these disasters isn’t just nature but its interconnection with poverty, and in Haiti it’s imperative to arrange not only the earthquake response — digging people out of rubble — but also a public health response by controlling disease and assuring access to clean water for survivors.

headline: Lehman’s Liquidator, Marsal, Looks to Buys Its Loans

I think. But then he also said he wants to make “The Tonight Show” the best it can be, which means he didn’t quit. I think. I don’t know. I have no idea. I’m sure the lawyers will figure that out. Actually, I can think of a much better solution than the lawyers. Here’s what I think we should do here — government bailout money. It worked with Wall Street. Why doesn’t Congress give NBC money to make more late night shows? That would solve everything.

headline: Enchanted Afternoon, Raucous Evening
text: REMEMBER double features? I barely do. They had mostly gone the way of VistaVision and drive-ins by the time I became a movie-mad youth. On a few occasions I created my own, sneaking in to see “Grease” one more time after paying for another movie. (Apologies, AMC Theaters; the check’s in the mail.) Luxuriating in a two-movie afternoon was the closest thing to decadence a 13-year-old can achieve. Or at least should.

headline: Is the Military Getting Soft?
text: Rank doesn’t matter, nor does it count if your father was a general or a sergeant major: Anyone who reports to his or her unit on Day One in poor physical condition has lost the respect of fellow soldiers.One company commander in my previous unit enjoyed testing his new lieutenants with a five-mile run at a blistering pace the day they arrived, followed by pull-ups, push-ups and a gamut of other calisthenics.

headline: The Kiffin Chronicles
text: We interrupt the melee on the University of Tennessee campus to request a moment of silence to mourn the passing of any last semblance of sanity in college sports. Because as peeved as the Volunteers crowd is  and yes, they are burning-mattresses peeved at Lane Kiffin for jumping ship for Southern California  the Trojans crowd may consider being even more ticked off. Because their university seems to be celebrating its wallow in serious N.C.A.A. mire (paging Reggie Bush) by holding its nose and swan-diving into the sewage.

headline: Genetic Testing for Celiac Disease
text: Dr. Sheila Crowe, a professor in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology in the department of medicine at the University of Virginia, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about celiac disease, an often overlooked digestive disorder that causes damage to the small intestine when gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye, is eaten. In previous posts, Dr. Crowe exploredthe varied symptoms of celiac disease and confirming a diagnosis of celiac disease. Here, Dr. Crowe responds to readers asking about the disease running in families, genetic tests that may help confirm a diagnosis, food allergies and thins that set off the ailment.

headline: Why Merchant Names Go Missing From Debit Card Statements

text: For many high school seniors and their families, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is attempting to streamline this year.

headline: Answers About Improv Everywhere
text: Editor’s note, April 2: a few weeks after this feature appeared, Charlie Todd of Improv Everywhere lied to City Room repeatedly as we questioned him on whether one of his stunts was an April Fool’s hoax (it was). While the unwritten laws of the Internet prevent us from taking these posts down, we can’t vouch for anything he says here.

headline: ‘Final’ Album in Johnny Cash Series Is Coming
text: The seemingly bottomless supply of songs that Johnny Cash recorded with the producer Rick Rubin before Cash’s death in 2003 has yielded enough material for one more album. As you’d expect from the musician who called himself the Man in Black, this latest album, “American VI: Ain’t No Grave,” is a mix of the mournful and the morbid: in a news release, publicists for Cash said it would include covers of Sheryl Crow‘s “Redemption Day,” Kris Kristofferson‘s “For the Good Times” and Tom Paxton’s “Can Help But Wonder Where I’m Bound” as well as “Aloha Oe,” and an original song called “I Corinthians: 15:55.” Lost Highway Records, which is releasing the album on Feb. 26 (which would have been Cash’s 78th birthday), called it the “final installment” in Cash’s “American Recordings” series, whose first self-titled release was in 1994. (As with other departed artists, this may not necessarily be Mr. Cash’s last posthumous release.) In a statement, Mr. Rubin said the songs on “American VI” were recorded in the months after Cash’s wife, June Carter Cash, died. “Johnny said that recording was his main reason for being alive,” Mr. Rubin added. “I think it was the only thing that kept him going.”

headline: City as Stage, Audience as Family
text: THE restaurant Veselka, in the East Village, has featured Ukrainian borscht on its menu, individual banana cream pies on its daily specials board, and, in 2008, at the fourth table from the entrance, “Etiquette,” a performance piece in which the ticket holders were also the actors. Presented by the Foundry Theater and its artistic producer, Melanie Joseph, the work called for two people at a time to play the parts of a young woman and an elderly philosopher, with the dialogue fed to them through headphones.

headline: Juggling Full-Time Work and Kids
text: The comments got all philosophical last week when I asked everyone their reasons for having children. Let’s get all practical today and discuss how you make your lives work once the children arrive.

headline: Skating Tries to Demystify Its Scoring System
text: It’s a modern mystery, stumping experts and amateurs alike, since the fall of 2005: What the heck is the International Skating Union’s judging system, and how does a skating fan make sense of it?

headline: Haitians in New York Eager to Help, but Struggle With How
text: They know how to make the calls. They know what to collect and send. In a city of insular immigrant communities, none has had more experience helping with disasters back home and knowing how to make crucial life-or-death connections than the Haitian communities in Brooklyn and in Cambria Heights, Queens.

headline: Artist’s Prize-Winning Work Is Destroyed. (It’s What He Wanted.)
text: Art is long and life is brief, but sometimes art is brief, too. A wall painting by Richard Wright that won him the Turner Prize in December has been erased by workers at the Tate Britain museum — as Mr. Wright intended, The Guardian reported. The painting, a gold-leaf fresco of an abstract design, was sanded and painted over by the museum’s art handlers last week, after an exhibition on the Turner Prize, the prestigious British art award, was closed. Mr. Wright, 49, who lives in Glasgow, was named the prize winner over the heavily favored installation artist Roger Hiorns. In an Arts Beat post, Roberta Smith described Mr. Wright as “a cross between Sol LeWitt and Fabergé” who creates elaborate works that are meant to exist temporarily. The Guardian said Mr. Wright was not in attendance at this work’s deletion.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Beauty: You’re a Prize
text: Welcome to awards season, when everything unreal and unimportant in showbiz is celebrated, digested and parsed with bloated, brainlessly baroque observations of no import whatsoever. The Samurai Shopper, as usual, is throwing her hat into the fluttering mists of fatuity to honor her own superstars: those beauty products that may or may not grace the faces of telegenic Golden Globers, Grammy-grabbers and the unfortunately named S.A.G. nominees. I’ll deploy the same sentimental, indulgent, politically circumspect judgment in awarding my prizes as the Hollywood corps does with theirs.

headline: Ke$ha Ends Susan Boyle’s ‘Dream’
text: Susan Boyle’s six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart has finally been ended, by a singer who couldn’t be more different. Ke$ha, a 22-year-old American whose song “TiK ToK” is an unabashed celebration of the liquor-fueled party life, opened at No. 1 with “Animal” (Kemosabe/RCA), which was released last week and sold 152,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Ms. Boyle’s “I Dreamed a Dream” (Syco Music/Columbia) fell to No. 2 with 93,000 sales, bringing its seven-week total to just under 3.2 million.

text: French international news channel France 24 interviews Haitian radio DJ, Carel Pedre about the earthquake in Haiti.

headline: Fabio Trabocchi Leaves the Four Seasons
text: Fabio Trabocchi has left the Four Seasons, The Feed reports, with a publicist citing “philosophical differences.”

headline: Under the Radar: Five Questions About ‘Ads’
text: The trademarks of a Richard Maxwell show are there: the silent pauses, the inflection-less monologues, the minimal set. All that’s missing are the actors.

headline: Espada May Have Violated Laws, Cuomo’s Office Says
text: Pedro Espada Jr., the State Senate majority leader, may have violated several laws by using a network of health clinics he controlled as a source of income for his personal and political use, according to court papers filed on Wednesday by the state attorney general’s office.

headline: Haiti’s Economy
text: Update | 1:29 p.m.

headline: Bankers Face Tough Questions at Crisis Hearing
text: The heads of Wall Street’s largest banks faced skeptical questions on Wednesday about executive pay and the failures of regulation from the bipartisan commission established to examine the causes of the biggest downturn since the Depression, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington. Tensions flared as commission members retraced the events leading to the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008 and pressed bankers on whether they or their employees had behaved unethically.

headline: Paterson Offers New Details on Son’s Brush With Police
text: Gov. David A. Paterson offered new details about the incident that led the police to detain his 15-year-old son on Tuesday afternoon, saying that a simple game of dice apparently caused a misunderstanding, and that there is no evidence that his son committed any crime or attempted to use a lost debit card found in his possession.

headline: Iraqis on Iraq – Falluja and Tikrit
text: As international attention increasingly shifts from Iraq to Afghanistan — we asked Iraqi journalists working for The New York Times to give a personal view of daily life in the areas where they live. Here, we offer views from Falluja and Tikrit as our colleagues Mohammed Hussein and Timothy Williams report on the escalation of violence in recent weeks and a suicide bombing in Anbar Province Wednesday morning. The names of the Iraqi journalists are withheld because of the continuing threat to their lives.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: GMC Granite, Audi A8 Win Design Awards
text: The GMC Granite won the EyesOn Design Award for Best Concept Vehicle at the North American International Auto Show on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Comedic Overachiever Adds Two Books to Résumé
text: Steve Martin has spun his wheel of talents again, and this time it has stopped at “author”: Grand Central Publishing said in an e-mail message that it had acquired two new books from Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian, bluegrass musician, New Yorker contributor and coming Academy Awards show co-host — one intended for young readers and one for the rest of us. The book for young readers is called “Late for School,” and is based on a song that also appears on Mr. Martin’s album “The Crow: New Songs for the 5-String Banjo”; it will include illustrations by C.F. Payne and a CD of the song (as well as a singalong version) and is to be released in September. The second book, called “Woman, One,” is a novel that “examines the glamour and the subterfuge of the fine art world” in New York, the e-mail message said. (Yes, Mr. Martin is an art collector, too.) The book, Mr. Martin’s first novel since “The Pleasure of My Company,” is planned for a November release. Both books were acquired by Deb Futter, the editor-in-chief of Grand Central Publishing, an imprint of Hachette Book Group.

headline: Forgiving Mark McGwire
text: As Joe Posnanski notes, nobody seems much inclined to do it. And you can understand why. McGwire’s extended mea culpa comes years after it became clear that he took steroids, years after he stammered his way through a Congressional hearing, years after a public expression of contrition would have counted as brave and morally impressive. He’s been beaten to the admission-and-apology punch by everyone from Alex Rodriguez to Jason Grimsley. And he still doesn’t want to acknowledge, for understandable reasons, that the steroids made all his home runs possible, even though saying that they kept him healthy so that he could hit home runs is basically the same thing anyway.

headline: Israel and Turkey Patch Up Latest Rift, Over Diplomatic Slight
text: JERUSALEM  Israel’s deputy foreign minister issued a formal apology to the Turkish ambassador on Wednesday after ostentatiously humiliating him earlier in the week and aggravating strains in a complex and increasingly troubled relationship between Israel and Turkey, its closest Muslim ally.

headline: A Landmark, but No Longer a Refuge for the Homeless
text: The West Park Presbyterian Church at Amsterdam Avenue and 86th Street is well known in the city for two reasons: its place as one of New York’s finest examples of Romanesque Revival religious architecture, and its role for more than 15 years as a haven for homeless people who camp in the building’s doorways at night.

headline: Hollywood Stagehands Union Comes Out Against Tax on Generous Health Plans
text: The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, whose 110,000 members work throughout the entertainment industry, is the latest Hollywood union to declare its formal opposition to a proposed excise tax on high-value health plans. In a letter sent to members of Congress on Wednesday, Matthew Loeb, the president of the alliance, said its general executive board had unanimously agreed to oppose “any tax on hard-fought benefits and to immediately notify you of this action.”

text: Michelle Obama said on Wednesday that Senator Harry Reid “had no need to apologize’’ for his racial comments about her husband. And Mrs. Obama dismissed the fracas over three uninvited guests who crashed her first state dinner as “a footnote’’ in an otherwise lovely affair.

text: Indianapolis Colts receiver Reggie Wayne and Baltimore Ravens safety Ed Reed go way back — all the way to their days as roommates at the University of Miami. They will face each other Saturday in a American Football Conference divisional round game. Aside from the fact that Reed could single-handedly doom your offense, he is apparently not the most reliable roommate either.

headline: James Hotel to Open in SoHo
text: The real estate market in the New York City may still be in the dumps, but that hasn’t slowed the opening of hotels.

headline: Cold Still Hurting Florida’s Farmers
text: MIAMI  Deep Freeze 2010? Ice Week? No one in Florida knows quite what to call the lengthy cold snap that finally eased on Wednesday, but there is little doubt that its economic and social impact will be memorable and significant.

headline: Mayor’s Critics Sue to Protest Outside His Home
text: A group that opposes charter schools and school closings filed a lawsuit against the city on Tuesday for “unconstitutionally and without any legal basis” denying its request to protest on the sidewalk outside the Upper East Side town house of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Protecting Data, Ahead of the Curve
text: Network-attached storage, or NAS, may be one of the best-kept secrets in personal technology.

headline: Concerns Over Britain’s Wind Plans
text: On Friday, the British government announced it had awarded licenses for several offshore wind projects with the potential to generate 32 gigawatts of power — or enough electricity to power nearly all the homes in Britain.

headline: Haiti Earthquake: Impact on the U.N.
text: U.N. Bureau Chief Neil MacFarquhar reports on impact of the devastating earthquake in Haiti on United Nations facilities and personnel there.

text: Updated | 4:06 p.m.  to note Jonathan Gruber’s government affiliation.

headline: Hummer Production to End
text: General Motors announced on Wednesday that it will stop production of the Hummer next week, according to The Associated Press.

headline: A Novel Take on Assisted Living
text: I can’t say with assurance that Leslie Larson’s “Breaking Out of Bedlam” is the first novel set in an assisted living facility, so I’ll just say it’s the first one I’ve read, and that it’s a kick.

headline: Ben Brantley Answers Readers’ Questions About London Theater
text: Readers are submitting questions for Ben Brantley, The Times’s chief theater critic, who is in London to see several shows.

text: Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard took the early lead in the “unfortunately timed press conferences” sweepstakes for 2010.

headline: After a Hole Emerged, Greene Hit His Stride
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Even now, two very good years later, Shonn Greene remembers what it was like to work in the warehouse at a furniture store nearly 1,000 miles from home for $8 an hour. It was not exactly hard work, but it was not a lot of fun, either.

headline: Well, Maybe Not Doomsday for the M.T.A.
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Less Fitness in the U.S. Military
text: Over on the “At War” blog, Tim Hsia writes about concerns that an ever-fatter American population has resulted in less-fit recruits to the military.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1.) Cool map, from the Modern Language association using census data, showing what languages are spoken where in the United States. It says there are more people in the United States who speak Yiddish than speak Thai, which I somehow find hard to believe.

headline: Obesity Rates Hit Plateau in U.S., Data Suggest
text: Americans, at least as a group, may have reached their peak of obesity, according to data the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released Wednesday.

headline: All About London Theater
text: Over on the ArtsBeat blog, readers are submitting questions for Ben Brantley, The Times’s chief theater critic, who is in London to see several shows. First up: what to see in the West End, experimental theater companies and actors to watch.

headline: Cedar Fair’s Management Entry Ticket
text: The Cedar Fair preliminary proxy filed this week is notable for disclosing that the company’s top executives will be staying for Apollo Management’s ride.

headline: Was There a Commercial Real Estate Bubble?
text: From Casey B. Mulligan at Economix:

headline: America vs. Europe
text: David Brooks: Gail, can I draw you into the America versus Europe debate? This is the old argument over which model of capitalism is better, the Anglo-American model or the continental one. It was recently rekindled by two bloggers extraordinaire — Jim Manzi and Jonathan Chait — and then joined by our colleague Paul Krugman.

headline: U.S. Regions Show Gains and Softness, Fed Reports
text: Little by little, regional economies in the United States are gaining strength, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday, though several pillars  housing, real estate and the jobs market  remain weak.

headline: In Spain, a Delicacy Rooted in Earth and Tradition
text: AS we sauntered up the steep, narrow cobblestone streets of Cáceres in western Spain, it wasn’t hard to imagine life there in the Middle Ages. Night was falling, and before us were Gothic churches, Roman arches and Moorish towers, glowing in the soft light of lanterns. It was an arresting sight, but our thoughts soon veered elsewhere  to food and the sumptuous meal we were anticipating.

headline: Studying the Studies: Evaluating Science and Health News Reports
text: Overview | How are scientific and medical study results reported to the public? How can and should people interpret these reports with an eye to reliability and seek additional information to put the news into scientific context? In this lesson, students reflect on what they look for in science and health news. Then, using any day’s Science Times and other resources, they evaluate news reports for validity and develop strategies for reading such reports and for developing research and experiment protocols.

headline: App Comparison | New iPhone Travel Guides
text: Another day, another iPhone app. While the deluge never seems to stop, there are a few recent apps that cover a somehow previously underaddressed need: travel guides.The new Wallpaper guide essentially brings a version of its existing guide books from page to screen, with 10 different cities at $3.99 a pop. For the most part the guides are smartly organized — there’s a 24-hour guide (good for business travelers or if the city is just one stop of many), a section of essential info (which includes the somewhat inessential average price of a bottle of Champagne), an insiders’ guide compiled by an actual resident and a panoramic photo of the city skyline with architectural highlights labeled and explained. The app also detects where you are in relation to every place in the guide and offers a link to Google maps for directions. Only the listings of restaurants, bars and nightclubs are lacking. They’re all consolidated into one section called Urban Life, which does have appealing suggestions but also gives short shrift to cities with thousands of places to eat, drink and be merry. The Berlin app is currently available as a free download on the iTunes store for any on-the-fencers out there.

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this column contained a factual error. The comments made by the Fox News analyst Brit Hume on Tiger Woods's faith were unprompted; he was not asked what advice he would give to Mr. Woods.

headline: Road Test: Space Heaters
text: The Times tested 10 portable models to see how well they performed.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 2: Devastation
text: Haitian authorities and humanitarian aid organizations are struggling to respond amid devastation wreaked by a 7.0 magnitude earthquake that struck near Port-au-Prince, Haiti, late on Tuesday.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 2: A Brooklynite Reacts
text: Donall St. Fleur, the owner of a Haitian pharmacy in Brooklyn, discusses the earthquake back home.

headline: Scene Two From the Bankers’ Lineup
text: Shortly after 11 a.m., Phil Angelides, the financial inquiry commission chairman, called a five-minute break and the CEO’s bolted for a back exit en masse, again except for Mr. Mack, who stayed behind at the witness table and entertained questions from a scrum of reporters.

headline: Can You Guess Your Home’s Walk Score?
text: This weekend, in a story that even we here at Bucks neglected to post in our Best of Times roundup of the best consumer reporting in The Times, the paper ran a story about the Walk Score, which a site of the same name generates.

headline: Celebrating Haydn, Even After His Anniversary Has Passed
text: One useful thing commemorations of composers’ births and deaths should do is remind us that some of the music performed on these occasions, and neglected otherwise, is worth keeping at hand between anniversaries as well. Last year one of the honorees was Haydn, and among the repertory looked at anew was his piano music. Though hardly strangers to the recital stage, Haydn’s keyboard works are treated like poor relations compared to Beethoven’s and Mozart’s. They should not be: these are rich scores, packed with ideas and technical challenges and brimming over with character.

headline: Solar Eclipse in India
text: An exceptionally long eclipse of the Sun will be visible from India this Friday, January 15th, and Jay Pasachoff is there ready to file a Lab report and mark a personal milestone: his 50th solar eclipse. Dr. Pasachoff, a professor of astronomy at Williams College, has been fascinated with eclipses since he was 11. He’s chairman of the working group on solar eclipses of the International Astronomical Union and the co-author, with Leon Golub, of “The Solar Corona.”

headline: ‘Billy Elliot’ Recoups Original $18 Million Investment
text: The Broadway producers of “Billy Elliot: The Musical” announced on Wednesday afternoon that they had recouped their original $18 million investment in 14 months of performances, with premium ticket prices helping earn back that capitalization at a faster clip than they initially had expected.

headline: Male Chromosome May Evolve Fastest
text: A new look at the human Y chromosome has overturned longstanding ideas about its evolutionary history. Far from being in a state of decay, the Y chromosome is the fastest-changing part of the human genome and is constantly renewing itself.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Revelers parade through the street of Vevcani, Macedonia, for a Carnival celebration, while a child decked out in pink (see Photo 2) looks on.

headline: Famous Readers
text: Here’s something cool: The blog Whose Voice Is That? has compiled a partial list of the celebrities who read audio books at Audible.com. Highlights include Sean Penn reading Bob Dylan’s “Chronicles: Volume 1” (in the category “Narrator as Cool as the Author”) and Paul Newman reading “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer” (“A Classic Reads a Classic”).

headline: Cabaret Garnishes a Chamber Concert
text: Like many other charitable organizations, the America-Israel Cultural Foundation has suffered financial difficulties precipitated by the recession and the collapse of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme. William A. Schwartz, the foundation’s president, shook a noisemaker after mentioning Mr. Madoff’s name during a speech at the organization’s 70th-anniversary gala concert on Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall.

headline: From the Mailbag
text: From the mailbag. Christine D. writes:

headline: The Morning Skate: Improving N.H.L. Video Review’s Integrity
text: Two recent incidents have called various aspects of N.H.L. officiating into question.

headline: Tennessee Begins Search for a Coach
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — It seemed like a normal campus here Wednesday. Students walked to class. Other students hunted for scarce parking spaces. It all seemed back in order.

headline: Moynihan Letters to Be Published
text: Letters, journals and other correspondence written by Daniel Patrick Moynihan over the course of his half-century career in public service will be published in a coming book.

headline: In Need of Some Financial Razzle Dazzle
text: Whither the Weinsteins? The fortunes of Harvey and Bob have been much discussed recently, and heading into the Golden Globes this weekend, where their films “Inglourious Basterds” and “Nine” picked up the most nominations cumulatively, doesn’t mean they get to rest on their substantial laurels. At Deadline Hollywood, Nikki Finke explores the financing of “Nine,” the star-laden musical which has largely been considered a clunker by audiences and critics, like A.O. Scott.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Jan. 13
text: Haiti, of course, leads the report. Elsewhere on Lens is the story of how Tequila Minsky, a New York freelancer, managed get some of the first photographs in Port-au-Prince on Tuesday: “There for the Quake.”

headline: African Bank Jumps Into Carbon Offsets
text: An African bank is hoping that a multimillion-dollar investment in a carbon offset project will help rejuvenate forests and wildlife in rural Kenya.

headline: Deaths at Hands of Militants Rise in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The number of Pakistani civilians killed in militant attacks rose by a third in 2009 over the previous year, according to a new research report, a toll that exceeded even the number of civilian deaths in Afghanistan.

headline: Small by Choice, Whether Clients Like It or Not
text: Nick Lessins and Lydia Esparza pride themselves on meeting high standards for quality, but not necessarily for catering to the demands of their customers. They are co-owners of Great Lake, a small Chicago pizza shop that has seen the mixed blessing of great reviews.

headline: Tricky at Every Turn, the Quad Can Make or Break a Routine
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  The single hardest move in single’s figure skating, the quadruple jump, is like an onside kick in football: highly risky, but highly rewarding  if it unfolds as planned.

headline: App of the Week: Standing Guard Over a Lost Phone
text: Thoughts of cellphone security often dwell on the danger that hackers pose, but the far more likely threat comes from a phone that is simply lost or stolen. That leaves your personal information, photos and whatever else (you didn’t store passwords on your phone, did you?) open to snooping.

headline: Rugged, Speedy, Aquatic, Cold-Tolerant. And Not a Seal.
text: Olympus unwrapped its Stylus Tough-3000 camera at the Consumer Electronics Show last week. The Tough-3000 is the first of the company’s rugged line to offer HD video capture (720p) and is also the most affordable Tough model at $230. The Stylus Tough-3000 can withstand a five-foot drop, is submersible to 10 feet and works in temperatures as low as 14 degrees. These are basically the same specs as the existing $280 Stylus Tough-6000.

headline: U.S. World Cup Bids Independent of 2010 Performance
text: Of all the things hinging on the United States national team’s performance in South Africa (pride, glory, the future of the game in America), the country’s bid to host either the 2018 or 2022 World Cup is not one of them.

headline: K2: A Trek to Danger’s Doorstep
text: ONE day last June, I roped up to a porter and we leaped over crevasses until we reached the side of K2, the second-tallest mountain on earth and one of its deadliest. We scrambled up a few hundred yards to the Gilkey Memorial, a rocky, sandy promontory at K2 Base Camp that commemorates climbers who have died on K2’s dangerous slopes.

headline: Wes Anderson Acceptance Speech
text: An animated version of Wes Anderson's acceptance speech for his award from the National Board of Review for "Fantastic Mr. Fox."

headline: Amtrak Introduces Blue, if Not Corinthian, Leather
text: The popularity of Amtrak’s Acela Express with the business elite of the Northeast Corridor might as well have earned the train a nickname: Boardroom on Rails.

headline: Why Would a Business Say No to Growth?
text: Nick Lessins and Lydia Esparza are the married owners of a Chicago pizza shop, Great Lake, that has received rave reviews, and they made the unconventional business decision not to capitalize on them. In his interview with the owners, Kermit Pattison asked why they choose to have their customers wait for hours rather than hiring more employees and expanding (a decision that has helped spur comparisons to the “Soup Nazi” on “Seinfeld”):

headline: Quitting Work for Kids
text: Earlier today we spoke about how to structure a return to work. Now let’s talk about how to structure a departure.

headline: Devastation, Seen From a Ship
text: The commander of the first American ship to reach earthquake-stricken Port-au-Prince, Haiti, described a scene of extraordinary devastation, with collapsed buildings reaching from the port into the hills above.

headline: Moynihan Letters to Be Published
text: At our sib-blog, ArtsBeat, Dave Itzkoff reports that letters and papers of the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan will be published later this year.

headline: Red Bulls Introduce New Coach
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The New York Red Bulls sporting director said that the team’s new coach was No. 1 on an extremely short list.

headline: Bankers in Their Own Words
text: The first public hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission featured the testimony of four top bank executives.

headline: Judge to the LeRoys: It’s All Yours, Almost
text: From Glenn Collins at Diner’s Journal:

headline: Can There Be an Awards Show Without Clooney?
text: Bagger poll: Are award shows more or less interesting if you’re not watching them in person? On the red carpet for the National Board of Review gala on Tuesday night, J. J. Abrams, the director of the surprisingly potential Oscar bait “Star Trek,” told the Bagger he prefers to watch the Oscars in bed (remote in hand, presumably). “The dream is staying home and being comfy,” he said. But he admitted he would probably brave the monkey suit, valet parking and hobnobbing this year, though he added, “I truly don’t think that ‘Star Trek’ has a shot of being nominated.” Additional Bagger poll: Is it more appealing when Hollywood types forthrightly lobby for attention, or do folks prefer it when they are all demure and self-effacing?

headline: Senators Call for Repeal of Insurers’ Antitrust Exemption
text: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and 18 other senators on Wednesday sent a letter to President Obama and Democratic Congressional leaders urging them to repeal the limited exemption for insurers from federal antitrust laws as part of the final version of major health care legislation.

headline: Avon’s Little Sister Is Calling
text: KRISTIAUNA MANGUM, 22, a senior at Ohio State University in Columbus, said she always had a flair for makeup, but never considered it a professional calling. Then she heard about a pilot college program offered by Avon’s little sister brand, Mark, two years ago. “My mother was an Avon Lady, so I thought, huh, maybe becoming a Mark Girl could really be the way to go,” she said.

headline: Simon and Garfunkel to Play Jazzfest
text: For a month, fans of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival have been eyeing a big “artist TBA” on the schedule. That TBA has now been announced: the surprise act for the first of Jazzfest’s two weekends, on April 24, will be the reunited duo of Simon and Garfunkel, above. It’s not the first time that Paul Simon has played Jazzfest, but it will be Art Garfunkel’s, and this is likely to be Simon and Garfunkel’s only American appearance in 2010. Simon and Garfunkel fans have been awaiting news of shows in the United States since Mr. Garfunkel joined Mr. Simon onstage at the Beacon Theater in New York last February. The festival, in its 41st year, will also feature, among many others, Lionel Richie, My Morning Jacket, Dr. John, Darius Rucker and Drake in its first weekend (April 23 to 25), and Pearl Jam, Aretha Franklin, Van Morrison, B. B. King, the Neville Brothers and Widespread Panic in its second (April 29 to May 2).

headline: Above Paris, and Bourgeois Cares
text: PARIS — If there is a flat surface in Jacques Gourvénec’s apartment in the 15th Arrondissement here, it probably has a painting sitting on it. The floor, the bookshelves, the windowsills and even the stairs are all used to display Mr. Gourvénec’s paintings  more than 500 of them. (The other 2,500 are stored in his offices in the Bastille neighborhood.)

headline: Jay Reatard Has Died
text: Update | 8:48 p.m. Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., the Memphis musician better known by his punk-rock stage name Jay Reatard, has died, his record label Goner Records said on Wednesday. In a statement posted at goner-records.com, the label said: “It is with great sadness that we report the passing of our good friend Jay Reatard. Jay died in his sleep last night. We will pass along information about funeral arrangements when they are made public.”

headline: Podesta and Pickens Stump for Natural Gas
text: T. Boone Pickens, the billionaire Texas financier, and John Podesta, President Bill Clinton’s White House chief of staff, are not exactly political soul mates.

headline: No More Free Rides From G.M. for Woods
text: It has been called the most expensive car crash in history. The pro golfer Tiger Woods has so far lost millions of dollars from sponsors who dropped or limited their use of his likeness in their marketing after news of his affairs. Now, he no longer has access to free cars from General Motors.

headline: Haiti and the Politics of Disaster
text: As Hurricane Katrina and the Iranian election protests showed, disaster and strife tend to bring out the best of the blogosphere. So it’s little surprise that the earthquake in Haiti has seen a bipartisan show of concern and support for aid efforts. That said, there’s always room for debate.

headline: I.R.S. Commissioner Doesn’t Do His Own Taxes
text: If you’re part of the 60 percent of Americans who hire tax preparers to do their income taxes, you’re in good company.

headline: The City From the Street
text: On an auspicious day in 1935, the Swiss emigré photographer Rudy Burckhardt and his friend, the poet and dance critic Edwin Denby, moved into a New York apartment next door to Willem de Kooning. “I remember walking at night in Chelsea with de Kooning during the Depression,” Denby recalled, “and his pointing out to me on the pavement the dispersed compositions — spots and cracks and bits of wrappers and reflections of neon light.”

headline: A Theater and a Jukebox in a Lightweight Package
text: The latest device that AT&T has picked up to sell through partners is the Mobinnova Beam.

headline: Boldly Going Where Bose Has Gone Before
text: Bowers & Wilkins  formerly called B&W, but that clashed with BMW  is the highly regarded British sonic innovator and maker of loudspeakers. Think of the company as the British Bose.

headline: Pastor Pleads Guilty to Swindling Immigrants in Queens
text: The Ecuadorean pastor in his storefront church in Corona, Queens,  promised the impossible: expedited green cards for illegal immigrants in exchange for several thousand dollars apiece, with few questions asked. And more than 100 people in the New York region, many of them Ecuadorean and desperate to remain in the country legally, took him up on his offer, handing a total of about $940,000.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Radio Iran Host of Fraud
text: The tight-knit Iranian-American Jewish community in Southern California is coming to terms with what could be its own mini-Madoff scandal.

headline: Tell Us How You Really Feel, Maureen
text: Maureen Dowd, the New York Times columnist who generally saves her biggest bullets for targets inside the Beltway, made an exception on Wednesday, going after what has been a long-running question for many:

headline: In Fiji, Dancing With Sharks
text: THERE’S a moment when the sheer awe of being arm’s length from a procession of hungry sharks — so close that you lock eyes with each one as it blitzes by your head — gives way to a sudden burst of clarity, and all your thoughts coalesce into a single edifying idea: “Maybe I should duck.”

headline: 36 Hours in Whistler, British Columbia
text: THERE are good reasons that much of the Winter Olympics is taking place in Whistler next month. Sure, North America’s biggest ski resort looms overhead. But this steep mountain valley is home to something else that makes it particularly welcoming to Olympic athletes: a global citizenry. Walk down the main promenade and see everyone from rich urban castaways and old-school hippies to French-babbling Québécois and weathered dropouts shouldering skis the size of ironing boards. It makes Whistler feel worldly and cosmopolitan, even when gold medals aren’t being handed out.

headline: Flawed Building Likely a Big Element
text: Engineers and architects who have worked in or visited Haiti say that substandard design, inadequate materials and shoddy construction practices likely contributed to the collapse of many buildings in the earthquake that struck Tuesday.

headline: Who’s That Man? A Mystery Clarinetist Takes a Bow at Philharmonic
text: When a pinch hitter comes out of the dugout, an announcer intones his name over the public-address system. When an understudy fills in for a Broadway actor, inserts in the program say who it is. A waiter even tells you what’s on special.

headline: Justices Skeptical of N.F.L.’s Court Claim
text: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for the National Football League and an apparel company staked out aggressive positions at a Supreme Court argument Wednesday over whether the league should be treated as a single entity or a collection of 32 independent companies for purposes of the antitrust laws.

headline: Report Reveals Role of Immigrants in City
text: Every chemical engineer in New York City was born in a foreign country. Two-fifths of the city’s accountants and auditors and more than one-fourth of its chief executives are immigrants. In the three neighborhoods with the highest concentrations of immigrants, Ecuadoreans outnumber residents from any other country.

headline: Direct Approach Works for Avon
text: IN the 1880s, David McConnell, a door-to-door book salesman in upstate New York, thought that he might have better luck if he presented potential customers with a gift of perfume. By 1886, McConnell had formed the California Perfume Company, and within 20 years, 10,000 representatives were selling 117 products in 600 styles. In 1939, the company changed its name to Avon Products.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes Curbs on High-Speed Trading
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a new rule on Wednesday that would bar brokers from allowing big clients to trade directly on their platforms with the exchanges, a practice known as unfiltered or naked sponsored access. The practice has been criticized by some market analysts, as it allows traders, especially high-frequency traders, to trade almost instantly at varying market centers without any associated checks on risk.

headline: Detroit Auto Show: Chrysler’s Electric Star, the Gem
text: It’s not easy to find Chrysler’s world-beater plug-in electric vehicle at the Detroit auto show. You have to work your way past the Ferraris, Fiat 500s, Dodges, Chryslers and Jeeps. There, tucked in a corner, you’ll find Chrysler’s green transportation star: the Gem. Chrysler has sold more than 40,000 Gems since 1999 and reportedly owns about 70 percent of the neighborhood electric vehicle market.

headline: Voice Mail You Can Read: It Saves Time (at the Risk of Meaning)
text: Visual voice mail is great if you want to know who sent a message before you go through the trouble of dialing your voice mail service to hear it.

headline: Obama’s First Veto Stands
text: President Obama’s first veto easily withstood a House attempt to override it on Wednesday.

headline: Views on Financial Regulation
text: Clips as four heads of Wall Street's largest banks faced skeptical questions about regulation from the bipartisan commission.

headline: Parting Glance: Dennis Stock, 1928-2010
text: Dennis Stock, whose photographs may have done almost as much to create James Dean’s public persona as the actor’s own performances, died Monday in Florida. He was 81.

headline: Remembering the Jets’ Great Escape in 2005
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. –- Before they beat the Cincinnati Bengals last Saturday, it had been five years since the Jets last won a playoff game. The previous win came in San Diego, at Qualcomm Stadium, the same place the Jets head this Sunday to face the Chargers in a divisional playoff contest.

headline: Alone (or Almost) With Michelangelo in Vatican City
text: IT was just after 8 p.m., by now dark outside the walls of Vatican City, and a small group of us were following a guide through the maze that is the Vatican Museums. We had wandered for 40 minutes through galleries crammed with 15th- and 16th-century Italian paintings, courtyards displaying Greek and Roman sculpture, and seemingly endless hallways lined with ancient maps and musty tapestries, before passing through a small doorway I had not noticed on my previous visits here. I glanced up and realized we had arrived in the Sistine Chapel.

headline: Art Crops Up in Sarajevo’s Shuttered Shops
text: ON a recent fall evening in Sarajevo, a crowd of art enthusiasts sipped drinks as one of Bosnia’s most respected artists and curators, Jusuf Hadzifejzovic, began his remarks at the opening of a new exhibition. Suddenly, the lights went out  but he continued his speech in darkness, unfazed. Minutes later, a cleaning woman calmly pushed her cart laden with mops and detergents through the center of the audience. The speeches went on.

headline: Electric Power at the Detroit Auto Show
text: Hybrid-powered and electric vehicles were among the most compelling new cars on display at the North American International Auto Show.

headline: Designs on a Boston Hot Spot
