text: BACK in 2006, the inhabitants of Fort Point said to be home to New England’s largest concentration of visual artists, met the news of plans for luxury condos with predictable resistance. Goldman Properties, a national real estate development firm, intended to turn the onetime industrial hub on Boston’s Inner Harbor into the city’s newest hot spot  Boston’s SoHo or South Beach. But much to the relief of the many artists, schemes to convert the stout 19th-century masonry buildings that define the neighborhood’s architecture haven’t come to fruition, thanks to the economic downturn.

headline: Restaurant Review: Mellilotos in Athens
text: This family-run, weekday-only restaurant specializing in organic dishes opened last July in the lobby of a commercial building just off Syntagma Square. But you’ll forget about the narrow restaurant’s meager décor when you take your first bite of the salmon baked in paper and topped with finely chopped fennel, leek, dill and celery root, in a delicate reduction sauce made from spinach and a tree resin called mastika (12 euros, or about $17 at $1.40 to the euro).

headline: His Last Job
text: In recent years, it has appeared that the surest route to a senior government job was to run Goldman Sachs.

headline: Heating Your Space
text: The Process

headline: Whiplash in the Greenhouse
text: There are a variety of debates under way over the merits or perils of focusing on particular climate (and sea level) findings, or a particular season’s conditions, in discussing human-driven global warming.

headline: Praising Virtuosos, Both Here and Gone
text: Accepting his 2010 N.E.A. Jazz Masters Award at the Rose Theater on Tuesday night, the pianist and composer Muhal Richard Abrams was appreciative but brisk. He thanked “the past masters,” implying both his fellow honorees and jazz’s broader pantheon. Then he issued one statement of conviction: “This music, jazz music, has a discipline that comes from practice, that’s very good for life in itself.” Within moments he was at the piano, infusing the evening’s first musical performance with a luminous severity.

headline: The Dumpster Beautified
text: Despite the plummeting mercury late Friday afternoon, a small crowd had gathered on the Bowery, near the New Museum, where three young women were gamely wallpapering a Dumpster in an elegant blue-and-white floral. A second Dumpster, covered in a green William Morris pattern and stuffed with a Christmas tree, had been finished elsewhere and rolled to the curb next to it.

headline: Video: Views on Regulation
text: The scope of the government’s involvement in the financial markets is likely to be a hotly debated topic as the Senate is expected to take up legislation on overhauling financial regulation in the next few months. The topic weighed heavily on Wednesday as four executives of the nation’s largest banks testified before the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, and there were some hints of their views on the subject. They had to walk a fine line between accepting responsibility for past mistakes and pushing back against regulatory reforms they consider too drastic.

headline: Furnishings, Marked Down
text: Home Decorators Outlet is offering up to 70 percent off area rugs through Jan. 31 (an eight-foot-round Flokati rug in olive green, originally $349, is $175); (877) 537-8539 or homedecoratorsoutlet.com.

headline: Detailed Reflections, Verbal and Visual
text: The soapbox is fully present, in the form of a couple of nondescript wooden blocks, but the speakers are more like specters in “Ads,” a boundary-pushing curio from the theatrical auteur Richard Maxwell at Performance Space 122, a co-presentation of the Coil festival and the Under the Radar smorgasbord of forward-looking theater.

headline: In Quake Aftermath, U.S. Suspends Deportations to Haiti
text: Responding to the devastation from the Haiti earthquake, Obama administration officials on Wednesday temporarily suspended deportations of illegal immigrants from that country.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 3: Legacy of Disaster
text: Even before the recent earthquake Haiti's environment teetered on the brink of disaster.  Brent and Craig Renaud report on the country's deforestation problems.

headline: High Design in D.C.
text: Is there a market for experimental design in Washington? Craig Appelbaum thinks so. On Jan. 16, Mr. Appelbaum, a lawyer who moonlights as an art dealer, will open Industry Gallery, specializing in the more adventurous reaches of 21st-century design, including new works by Nacho Carbonell, who was named Designer of the Future last month at Design Miami/ Basel, and Tejo Remy, an early member of the Dutch design collective Droog. The first exhibition will show 20 chairs hammered out of stainless steel and aluminum (including  “Rendez-vous,”  right) by Shlomo Harush, an artist and designer who splits his time between Milan and Brooklyn.

headline: A Duplex in Edinburgh
text: This 2,273-square-foot apartment is on the top two floors of a three-story home built around 1870.

headline: A Better Life, Starting at $6.99
text: IF you are overweight with a sinus problem and wrinkled clothing, and you wish your children would spend more time with you, and you are so worried about identity theft that you can’t sleep at night so you want to go to the kitchen and cook up some chicken, but you are afraid salmonella will get on the paper towels, it’s a darn shame you didn’t make it to the International Home and Housewares Show 2010 sneak preview at the Hilton Hotel in Manhattan last week, where they had all the tools to turn your sorry life around.

headline: SpaghettiOs Creator Dies at 83
text: Every once in a while, maybe even when Mom was watching Julia Child, you probably tucked in to a bowl of Franco-American SpaghettiOs. Wednesday afternoon brought the news that their creator, Donald Goerke, died. He also helped introduce Chunky Soup for Campbell’s.

headline: Golden Globes Seek 10% Ratings Rise
text: LOS ANGELES  For months, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, NBC and Dick Clark Productions have puzzled over a perennial question: How do we prop up the sagging ratings for the Golden Globes?

headline: ‘The Unnamed’
text: The Feet, Mechanical

headline: Compelled to Wander, Nowhere to Go
text: Tim Farnsworth, the unaccountably restless main character in Joshua Ferris’s second novel (after his charming but weightless “Then We Came to the End”), can’t stop walking. Nobody knows why, and “The Unnamed” takes its title from Tim’s peculiar condition. Is it medical? Is it spiritual? Or is it metaphorical in ways that suggest Mr. Ferris’s readers had better beware?

headline: What a Block That Was
text: My mother called, reminding me that the name of her First Avenue butcher — where she used to buy tri-tip under a variety of names — was Wertheimer’s, long since closed. (It could’ve been Wortheimer’s, forgive me.)

headline: Revisiting Satanic Deal With Strings
text: Sunday afternoon at La MaMa I was rooting for the devil. Or, rather, I was rooting for his puppet facsimile, Mr. Scratch, who was engaged in a spirited rhetorical debate with a Daniel Webster puppet during the climax of “The Devil You Know,” an Under the Radar Festival offering from Ping Chong & Company and Phantom Limb.

headline: The No Lock People
text: IT’S the lore and lure of bucolic small-town living: The community is so safe, people don’t even lock their doors. But Joyce Weisshappel, a 63-year-old vice president with the Corcoran Group, a real estate company, does not live in a small town; she lives in Manhattan, in a luxury apartment building. And she doesn’t think she has ever locked her door in the 30 years she has lived there — she doesn’t even know where the keys are.

headline: Where’s the Opera Chief? Look Onstage, or in the Pit
text: Plácido Domingo, conductor, steps into the pit of the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening for a performance of Verdi’s “Stiffelio.” Four days later Plácido Domingo, singer, steps onto the Met stage to open a run of Verdi’s “Simon Boccanegra.”

headline: The Triumph of the Size 12s
text: WHEN he met Crystal Renn for the first time last September over lunch at the Royalton in Manhattan, Stephen Gan, the influential creative director of fashion magazines like Harper’s Bazaar and Visionaire, had the same reaction as virtually everyone who comes face to face with the industry’s reigning plus-size model.

headline: The Capitol Hill Twitterverse
text: It may have been sort of a counterintuitive thought at one time, but it’s become pretty well-established that Republicans on Capitol Hill have embraced Twitter more than Democrats.

headline: Don’t Forget to Look Out the Windows
text: At Robert, the new restaurant on the ninth floor of the Museum of Arts and Design, the focal point is not necessarily the view of Central Park. Consider the orange acrylic LED lighting by Johanna Grawunder, a designer based in San Francisco and Milan. The rest of the design flowed from there, Ms. Grawunder said, including the palette of orange, purple and vermilion, and the choice of seating. (Vladimir Kagan’s 1956 Floating Back sofa was altered to keep the legs from jutting out enough to trip the waiters.)

headline: You Should Have Seen First Avenue in Those Days
text: On Bitten, Mark Bittman recalls the culinary glories a Jewish boy from Stuyvesant Town could find between 19th and 20th Streets back in the day.

headline: When the Gym Isn’t Enough
text: OVER the course of a year, Alex Feintuch, a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of South Carolina, spent more than $1,000 on fitness supplements.

headline: One on One: Anil Dash of Expert Labs
text: In this installment of One on One, I sit down with Anil Dash, formerly of Six Apart, which created the popular blogging software Movable Type. Mr. Dash is now the director of Expert Labs, a Government 2.0 initiative that aims to connect United States government projects with citizens who want to become more involved in the political discussion.

headline: Behind the Scenes: There for the Quake
text: On Tuesday morning, Tequila Minsky enjoyed a reputation in Lower Manhattan as an enterprising freelance photographer.

headline: And One-Eyed Offspring Makes Three
text: Parenthood never looked weirder or more terrifying than it does in “Smudge,” a new play by Rachel Axler at the Julia Miles Theater. Here are some of the things that Colby, a new mother, calls the thing she gave birth to: it, creature, hot dog, freak, smudge, a bunch of entrails in casing.

headline: Designer, Salesman, Mannequin
text: TUCKED among the racks of heavy wool navy pinstripe suits of Dries Van Noten, the usual assortment of Gucci and Prada togs for the directional male and some Chanel tweed jackets for men that should, in reality, bear a label that says Karl Lagerfeld Vanity Project, a new label appeared last fall at the Jeffrey New York store in the meatpacking district. It was an unfamiliar name: Devon Scott.

headline: Like a College Visit, Minus Kegs
text: JACKIE McMAKIN and her husband, David, are not the least bit apprehensive about moving next month from their home of 33 years in McLean, Va., to a retirement community in Shelburne, Vt. “We can’t wait,” said Ms. McMakin, who is 75 and a retired vocational counselor. “It suits our style perfectly — casual and sporty — the L. L. Bean of retirement communities.”

headline: ‘Idol’ Creator Plans to Start New Business
text: LOS ANGELES  The offstage turmoil around “American Idol” continues to grow as Simon Fuller, chief executive of 19 Entertainment and the creator of “American Idol,” is expected to announce soon that he is starting a new company to pursue film and other entertainment projects separately from 19 Entertainment and its publicly traded parent, CKX.

headline: Properties for $500,000
text: Homes for sale in Maine, North Carolina and Texas.

headline: In Leno vs. O’Brien, Fans Show Allegiance Online
text: Irritated by the proposed shakeup to NBC’s late-night schedule, Mike Mitchell, an artist in Los Angeles, sketched a heroic image of Conan O’Brien on Monday night, shaded the hair orange, and, recalling one of that talk show host’s nicknames, added the words “I’m with CoCo.”

headline: Obama and Democratic Leaders in Marathon Negotiations
text: President Obama and Congressional Democratic leaders have spent much of Wednesday holed up at the White House in a marathon negotiating session aimed at resolving differences between the House and Senate on sweeping health legislation that could cover more than 30 million uninsured Americans.

headline: Resetting a Mac’s Password
text: Q. I have a Mac and want to install system updates, but it keeps asking me for a password. I don’t remember it, so what can I do?

headline: Letters
text: On Physical Therapy

headline: Tavern on the Green Sells Out
text: Everything must go. The champagne flutes, the banana-split dishes, the 1950s Wurlitzer jukebox, the vintage street sign with its weathered prancing deer, the Tiffany glass, the entryway chandelier and even the doorman’s green frock coat with its fading gold braid and battered buttons.

headline: Now Branding | The Next Big Small (Edible) Thing
text: Tuesday night, upstairs at the bistro Ici, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a handful of hopefuls pushed snacks upon invitation-only guests and waited for the passing of judgment. One of them would take home the “I’m a Winner” trophy and, more important, win the consulting expertise of the Rooster Design Group. It was the culmination of the company’s first “The Next Big Small Brand Contest for Culinary Genius.” Rooster’s founders, Fernando Music and Fran Gaitanaros, had canvassed the 140 local applicants and winnowed the field down to the final five. They got all kinds. “We had some real head-scratchers,” Music mused. “Insects as nutritional supplements, positioned as a food that was borderline vegetarian. The insect ingredient would either be ground or mixed into the food product whole to make it more accessible and digestible. We also had a team with a perfectly nice product, good flavor profile, but one of the presenters was drunk … that was pretty dark.”

headline: Celebrating the Freshest 100-Year-Old Knish
text: The lowly knish, that humblest of pies, has turned 100, or at least the place that sells them has. No one knows for sure, of course, when or where the knish was actually invented. Nor does anyone know the precise date a knish became a knish. But in 1910, Yonah Schimmel’s opened a knishery on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

headline: Want It or Not, TV Goes 3-D
text: At the end of each season of “The Amazing Race,” the host always says something like: “Five continents, 14 countries, 21 days, 25,000 miles. You are the official winners of ‘The Amazing Race!’ ”

headline: Playwrights’ Nurturing Is the Focus of a Study
text: CHICAGO  When the playwright Tracy Letts handed over his “August: Osage County” for production in 2007, the board of the Steppenwolf Theater Company here agreed to forgo a balanced budget to finance this 13-character drama and its three-floor set. The bet paid off. The play earned rave reviews, moved to Broadway, won a Pulitzer Prize and a Tony Award, and recouped its investment.

headline: House Panel Demands Geithner’s A.I.G. Records
text: What was Timothy F. Geithner thinking when the American International Group was bailed out? The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee wants to know.

headline: Artwork Destroyed as Artist Planned
text: Art is long and life is brief, but sometimes art is brief too. A wall painting by Richard Wright that won him the Turner Prize in December has been erased by workers at the Tate Britain museum  as Mr. Wright, above, intended, The Guardian reported. The painting, a gold-leaf fresco of an abstract design, was sanded and painted over by the museum’s art handlers last week, after an exhibition on the Turner Prize, the prestigious British art award, was closed. Mr. Wright, 49, who lives in Glasgow, was named the prizewinner over the heavily favored installation artist Roger Hiorns. On the Arts Beats blog on nytimes.com, Roberta Smith described Mr. Wright as “a cross between Sol LeWitt and Fabergé” who creates elaborate works that are meant to exist temporarily. The Guardian said Mr. Wright was not in attendance at this work’s deletion.

headline: Comedic Overachiever Adds to Résumé
text: Steve Martin has spun his wheel of talents again, and this time it has stopped at “author.” Grand Central Publishing said in an e-mail message that it had acquired two new books from Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian, bluegrass musician, New Yorker contributor and coming Academy Awards show co-host: one intended for young readers and one for the rest of us. The book for young readers, “Late for School,” is based on a song that also appears on Mr. Martin’s album “The Crow: New Songs for the 5-String Banjo.” It will include illustrations by C. F. Payne and a CD of the song (as well as a singalong version) and is to be released in September. The second book, “Woman, One,” is a novel that “examines the glamour and the subterfuge of the fine art world” in New York, the e-mail message said. (Yes, Mr. Martin is an art collector too.) The book, Mr. Martin’s first novel since “The Pleasure of My Company,” is planned for a November release.

headline: Ke$ha Ends Susan Boyle’s ‘Dream’
text: Susan Boyle’s six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart has finally been ended, by a singer who couldn’t be more different. Ke$ha, below, a 22-year-old American whose song “TiK ToK” is an unabashed celebration of the liquor-fueled party life, opened at No. 1 with “Animal” (Kemosabe/RCA), which was released last week and sold 152,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Ms. Boyle’s “I Dreamed a Dream” (Syco Music/Columbia) fell to No. 2 with 93,000 sales, bringing its seven-week total to just under 3.2 million. Ke$ha, whose real name is Kesha Sebert, also has a very different audience from Ms. Boyle’s. “I Dreamed a Dream,” which retailers said attracted older customers, has been notable for having a very high proportion of its sales in CDs instead of digital downloads: at least 97 percent have been CDs, far above the industry average. But Ke$ha attracted younger and more computer-savvy fans. Seventy-six percent of the sales of “Animal” were digital, which Billboard said was the most for a No. 1 album. Also on this week’s chart, Lady Gaga’s “Fame” (Interscope) fell one spot to No. 3 with 66,000 sales; Alicia Keys’s “Element of Freedom” (J) is No. 4 with 62,000; and Mary J. Blige’s “Stronger With Each Tear” (Geffen) is No. 5 with 47,000.

headline: Judge Cites Discrimination in N.Y. Fire Dept.
text: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that New York City intentionally discriminated against black applicants to the Fire Department by continuing to use an exam that it had been told put them at a disadvantage.

headline: ‘Idol’ Returns to Winning Ways
text: The season premiere of Fox’s “American Idol” commanded almost 30 million viewers on Tuesday, proving that the series, which began in 2002, remains the undisputed ratings leader even if its popularity has waned in recent years. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 29.8 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour debut of the reality series’s ninth season, its first without Paula Abdul as a judge. Although the premiere audience was down compared to the 30.4 million who watched the first episode last season  not to mention the 33.4 million who watched the start of the seventh and 37.4 million who watched the start of the sixth  Fox easily dominated Tuesday’s ratings. The first runner-up, CBS, still drew relatively large audiences for its crime shows “NCIS” at 8 p.m. (20.7 million) and “NCIS: Los Angeles” at 9 (15.5 million). CBS also won the 10 p.m. hour following “Idol” with “The Good Wife” (13.8 million), which outperformed “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC (6.2 million) and “The Forgotten” on ABC (4.4 million). NBC ranked third on the night, averaging 8.1 million for “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10, while ABC finished a distant fourth.

headline: Injured ‘View From the Bridge’ Actor Departs Show
text: The actor Santino Fontana, who had been playing the key role of Rodolpho in the new Broadway revival of “A View From the Bridge,” said in a statement on Wednesday that he was leaving the show in order to make a full recovery from an onstage injury over New Year’s weekend that led to a concussion.

headline: GLAAD Award Nominees
text: The television shows “True Blood,” “Glee” and “Mad Men,” and films “I Love You, Man” and “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” are among the nominees for the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation’s annual GLAAD Media Awards, the group announced on Wednesday. The awards recognize and honor “media for outstanding images” of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. The alliance said the winners would be chosen from 116 nominees in 24 English-language categories and 36 nominees in eight Spanish-language categories. “Precious” and “I Love You, Man” were among the five nominees in the outstanding film (wide release) category; “True Blood” and “Mad Men” were nominated for outstanding drama series, along with “Brothers & Sisters,” “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Skins”; “Glee” (cast members pictured above) was nominated for outstanding comedy series, as were “Modern Family,” “United States of Tara,” “Beautiful People” and “Greek.”

headline: Vatican Pans ‘Avatar’
text: Among the things the Vatican approves of: piety, penitence, “The Simpsons.” Among the things it does not endorse: sinfulness and “Avatar.” Both the Vatican newspaper and radio station have criticized that James Cameron film, calling it emotionally unengaging and saying that it tries to replace divinity with nature, The Associated Press reported. The newspaper, L’Osservatore Romano, wrote that “Avatar,” which stars Sam Worthington, right, “gets bogged down by a spiritualism linked to the worship of nature,” according to The A.P. Vatican Radio said the movie “cleverly winks at all those pseudo-doctrines that turn ecology into the religion of the millennium,” adding, “Nature is no longer a creation to defend, but a divinity to worship.” L’Osservatore wrote that for all of the “stupefying, enchanting technology” in the movie, it offers “few genuine emotions.” But both outlets agreed, as L’Osservatore wrote, that the true accomplishment of “Avatar” was its “extraordinary visual impact.” The film is to be released in Italy on Friday.

headline: $2 Million in Donations for Haiti, via Text Message
text: Update | 12:48 a.m.  The organizers of the mobile donations said on Twitter Thursday night that over $2 million had been raised.

headline: Leaps and Bounds (and Boundlessness) in Step-Packed Choreography
text: After the British choreographer Richard Alston’s “Shuffle It Right” (2008)  the work with which his company opened its week on Tuesday night at the Joyce  my American companion said, “I want to see it immediately again.” Though I had seen it before in London, I felt the same way.

headline: After 4 Trials, Government Ends Its Case Against Gotti
text: After four trials, five years of effort and untold amounts of money dedicated to putting John A. Gotti in prison, the federal government has given up.

headline: Coast Guard Flyover of Haiti
text: Aerial video by Petty Officer 2nd Class Sondra-Kay Kneen of Port-au-Prince Haiti after a 7.0 magnitude earthquake.

headline: Ending Year on High Note, Then Starting on Another
text: The best way to end a bridge year is by winning an event on New Year’s Eve. The best way to start a bridge year is by winning an event on New Year’s Day. Judith Bianco, Win Allegaert and Justin Lall of New York and Hemant Lall of Dallas (Justin’s father) did both of those things at the regional in Myrtle Beach, S.C.

headline: Clinton and Gates Returning to D.C. Because of Haiti
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton is cutting short her first diplomatic trip of the year and returning to Washington to oversee the United States’ response to the Haiti earthquake.

headline: Why Blankfein’s Job Prospects Are Limited
text: From Floyd Norris at Notions on High and Low Finance:

headline: Google Upgrades Security on Gmail
text: Gmail users around the world are getting an important security upgrade.

headline: Ed Beach, Host of ‘Just Jazz’ Radio Show, Dies at 86
text: Ed Beach, the host of a popular jazz radio show in the 1960s and ’70s, who attracted listeners in New York and elsewhere with his sonorous voice, eclectic taste, vast erudition and pleasurably irascible temperament, died on Dec. 25 in Eugene, Ore. He was 86 and lived in Eugene.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Revisit 1994 Contract
text: Republicans really do think it could be 1994 all over again.

headline: Tavern on the Green Sells Out
text: From Glenn Collins at Diner’s Journal:

headline: Eh
text: Some readers were puzzled by my somewhat cryptic remarks about Canada in my optimal currency area post. What did I mean by saying that Canada is closer to the United States than it is to itself? Why is Canada a counterexample to Europeans who insist that a single currency is essential?

headline: Islamists Press Jordan to Stop Aiding U.S. Forces in Afghanistan
text: AMMAN, Jordan  Jordan, one of the United States’ closest allies in the Arab world, came under pressure on Wednesday from Islamists to stop cooperating with American forces in Afghanistan.

headline: U.S. Companies Join Race on Iraqi Oil Bonanza
text: BAGHDAD  A wave of American companies have been arriving in Iraq in recent months to pursue what is expected to be a multibillion-dollar bonanza of projects to revive the country’s stagnant petroleum industry, as Iraq seeks to establish itself as a rival to Saudi Arabia as the world’s top oil producer.

headline: I’m Czar Of The World!
text: Or at least want to be, says Eugene Fama.

headline: After China Attacks, Google Makes Gmail More Secure
text: Google is upgrading Gmail to a higher level of security by default.

headline: Administration Loosens Purse Strings for Transit Projects
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will make it easier for cities and states to spend federal money on public transit projects, and particularly on the light-rail systems that have become popular in recent years, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood said Wednesday.

headline: Follow-Up: Roger Ailes on Matthew Freud
text: In a recent front-page profile of Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News, David Carr and Tim Arango quoted Matthew Freud, the son-in-law of Rupert Murdoch, saying this about Mr. Ailes: “I am by no means alone within the family or the company in being ashamed and sickened by Roger Ailes’s horrendous and sustained disregard of the journalistic standards that News Corporation, its founder and every other global media business aspires to.”

headline: Daschle Handicaps the Final Health Bill
text: At an investor conference, Tom Daschle offers predictions about the final health care legislation.

headline: Decision Promised Soon on Cape Cod Wind Farm
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration moved a step closer on Wednesday to ending the nearly decade-long conflict over a major wind power installation off Cape Cod, Mass.

headline: Headphones That Vibrate — and Ones That Don’t
text: Twist and shout.

headline: Sweat Lodge Deaths Not Criminal, Guru’s Lawyer Says
text: LOS ANGELES  A lawyer for the New Age guru who led a sweat lodge ceremony in Arizona that left three people dead said Wednesday that the deaths were a “tragedy” and an “accident,” but should not be considered a crime.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 941 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans Wednesday:

headline: Binghamton President Announces Retirement
text: Lois DeFleur announced her resignation Wednesday as president of Binghamton University. DeFleur said in an e-mail message to the faculty that she was leaving in July because of her mother’s fragile health and her plans to be married.

headline: Morphine May Help Traumatic Stress
text: Doctors have long hoped to discover a “morning-after pill” to blunt the often disabling emotional fallout from traumatic experiences. Now it appears that they have had one on hand all along: morphine.

headline: Piercing the Sky Amid a Deflating Economy
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  In the first three days after Dubai opened the tallest building in the world, about 10,600 people paid a total of more than $280,000 to ride an elevator to the observation deck on the 124th floor. Outside, day after day, revelers jockeyed for position to be photographed standing before the shimmering tower that reaches 2,717 feet straight up into the steely blue sky.

headline: At 6-6, Rockets’ Chuck Hayes Is the Mite in the Middle
text: HOUSTON  In a position full of giants, the Houston Rockets’ Chuck Hayes stands out because he stands below them.

headline: After a Year of Learning, the First Lady Seeks Out a Legacy
text: WASHINGTON  She has settled her daughters in school  and watched “the wonder in their eyes” as they met the pope and the queen of England. She has polished her image and driven her poll numbers sky high, with carefully timed interviews and magazine cover shots. She has spotlighted military families, mentored young girls and begun a national conversation on healthy eating by planting the first White House garden since Eleanor Roosevelt’s day.

headline: Lieberman Disputes Reid’s Account of Health Bill Wrangling
text: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the independent Democrat from Connecticut, is taking issue with Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, for feeling double-crossed by Mr. Lieberman during critical negotiations over the health care bill.

headline: Essay: No End of Trouble. Ever.
text: As she prepared to depart for Haiti on assignment for The Times, Maggie Steber wrote this reflection on the country’s recent history. Her portfolio shows moments of joy as well as desperation and grief. Aperture published her book, “Dancing on Fire: Photographs from Haiti” in 1992. She has won top awards from World Press Photo and Pictures of the Year International. Her work appears regularly in National Geographic.

headline: Report on Lawyer’s Death Eases a Political Crisis in Guatemala
text: MEXICO CITY  The story is as convoluted as a film noir plot. A prominent lawyer is murdered after he accuses the president of plotting to kill him. But an international investigation finds that the murder was actually planned by the victim himself and carried out in a way that appeared intended to inflict maximum damage on the government.

headline: France: Bill Would Outlaw Harassment by Partners
text: The government has proposed a law that would make psychological abuse within couples a punishable offense. The law, applicable to both sexes, would cover repeated verbal abuse, threats of violence, insults and other forms of harassment. Critics have said such a law would be very difficult to enforce, but the draft has the backing of two main parties and Prime Minister François Fillon.

headline: Italy: Pope Meets With Woman Who Lunged at Him
text: Pope Benedict XVI on Wednesday met with and forgave the mentally unstable woman who knocked him to the ground at Christmas Eve Mass, the Vatican said in a statement. In a brief private meeting with Benedict on Wednesday, the woman, Susanna Maiolo, a Swiss and Italian citizen, expressed “her displeasure” at the events, while the pope “wanted to show his forgiveness, and his cordial interest and wishes for her health,” the Vatican said. Ms. Maiolo, left, has been held at a psychiatric center outside Rome and has not been charged with a crime.

headline: Government Ends Case Against Gotti
text: After four trials, five years of effort and untold amounts of money dedicated to putting John A. Gotti in prison, the federal government has given up.

headline: Iran: New Law Allows President to Cut Subsidies
text: The Guardian Council, the constitutional watchdog body in Iran, approved a controversial law that gives the green light to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad to cut government subsidies on energy and food, the IRNA news agency reported Wednesday. Analysts and opponents in Parliament had warned that the measure would lead to a sharp increase in prices.

headline: Russia Offers a Hand With Toilet Clog in Space
text: Russia has offered its astronauts’ help in unclogging a high-tech toilet on the International Space Station that is reportedly backed up because of excess calcium in astronauts’ urine. Aleksandr Vorobyov, a spokesman for Roscosmos, the Russian space agency, said a Russian crew member had helped repair a toilet in the American sector of the space station six months ago, so “they have some experience in this line of work.” The comments came in response to an article in the British newspaper The Daily Telegraph, which quoted the station’s flight director, David Korth, as saying, “We’ve learned a lot more about urine than we ever needed or wanted to know.” The problematic toilet was designed to purify urine into drinkable water.

headline: Agony Sets In as Medics Focus on the Survivors
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — “I just want my wife’s corpse,” said Lionnel Dervil, pleading in vain to bury his wife in his home province.

headline: U.S. Mobilizes to Send Assistance to Haiti
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, facing the first large-scale humanitarian crisis of his presidency, moved quickly to send help to Haiti, pledging Wednesday that the Haitians and their devastated island nation would have the “unwavering support” of the United States.

headline: Chinese Executives Held in Construction Site Deaths
text: Three Chinese executives in India have been arrested for possible connections to a chimney collapse at a construction site in Chhattisgarh State in September that killed 41 workers, according to a report on Wednesday in China Daily, an official newspaper. The executives are a project manager and two civil engineers working for a construction company based in Shandong Province, China. It had been given a contract to build a thermal power plant in India and had subcontracted the building of the chimney tower. The arrests come at a time when Indian officials are especially anxious over the influx of Chinese laborers.

headline: Obama and Lawmakers Seek Accord on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON  With a growing sense of urgency, President Obama and top Congressional Democrats held a marathon negotiating session on Wednesday in an effort to thrash out agreements on sweeping health care legislation that could provide insurance coverage to more than 30 million Americans.

headline: Waiting for Word From Haiti
text: It was only a month ago that Seth Stammler of the Red Bulls was driving through Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and thinking about the fragility of life.

headline: S.E.C. Reorganizes in Wake of Madoff Fraud
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission named six people on Wednesday to lead new investigative units as the agency reorganizes its enforcement efforts.

headline: Lawmakers Offer Ethics Plan, but Paterson Says It Falls Short
text: New York’s legislative leaders proposed their own ethics overhaul on Wednesday in an effort to restore public confidence in the wake of recent scandals that have exposed political corruption at the highest levels of power in Albany.

headline: Justice Dept. Fights Bias in Lending
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department is beginning a major campaign against banks and mortgage brokers suspected of discriminating against minority applicants in lending, opening a new front in the Obama administration’s response to the foreclosure crisis.

headline: Pirates-Hoyas and Plenty of Wild West Action
text: Seton Hall (10-5, 1-3) at No. 11 Georgetown (12-2, 3-1)The Pirates love to force a fast game that lets them find Jeremy Hazell (23.3 points) in transition. Herb Pope (12.9 points, 11.5 rebounds) is solid inside, but the Pirates need consistent play from their guards. The senior Eugene Harvey, who played only seven minutes in a loss to Connecticut, lost his starting spot to Keon Lawrence. Lawrence and Jordan Theodore, the third point guard, are still trying to establish themselves.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 2: Praying for News
text: Haitians living in the United States do not know if their loved ones are dead or alive, but are desperate to help.

headline: Country Without a Net
text: THOSE who know a little of Haiti’s history might have watched the news last night and thought, as I did for a moment: “An earthquake? What next? Poor Haiti is cursed.”

headline: Haiti’s Angry God
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

headline: U.N. Workers Struggle as Co-Workers Are Unaccounted For
text: UNITED NATIONS  Throughout the day, both at the United Nations headquarters and in Haiti itself, staff members struggled on Wednesday to concentrate on organizing a immense relief effort and not to focus on their friends and colleagues still buried under the rubble.

headline: Baidu’s Gain from Departure Could Be China’s Loss
text: SHANGHAI  If Google pulls out of China because of concerns over government controls, this country could be left with just one major Internet search engine: Baidu.com.

headline: In Queens, Haitian Voices
text: New Yorkers of Haitian descent in Cambria Heights, Queens, shared their concerns and hopes in the wake of the earthquake.

headline: Earthquake Hits Haiti
text: A powerful earthquake struck Haiti, causing widespread damage and panic in the impoverished country.

headline: Kiffin’s Departure Leaves Resentment and Uncertainty
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  The charred remains of a Lane Kiffin orange T-shirt lay in the gutter outside the Tennessee football complex. The crowd that had gathered here Tuesday night to taunt the former Volunteers coach was long gone by Wednesday.

headline: Are You a Gadget?
text: What does information want? Not so long ago Jaron Lanier would have answered a hot fudge sundae  and to be free, of course. Never mind the sundae, that was just us, but in the 1990s, John Tierney writes, Mr. Lanier “was one of the digital pioneers hailing the wonderful possibilities that would be realized once the Internet allowed musicians, artists, scientists and engineers around the world to instantly share their work.” Now, however, he has changed his answer. His new book, “You Are Not a Gadget,” “is a manifesto against ‘hive thinking’ and ‘digital Maoism,’ by which he means the glorification of open-source software, free information and collective work at the expense of individual creativity.” Whether you side with his current camp or not, head to the 92nd St. Y tonight where Mr. Lanier will discuss the book and the wild terrains of the Internets.

headline: The Hardest-Working Man in Publishing
text: Dave Eggers makes other writers feel lazy. When he’s not spinning out “great narrative nonfiction” in the form of “Zeitoun,” his chronicle of a man and his family brought down by Hurricane Katrina, he’s writing scripts, see “Where the Wild Things Are” and “Away We Go,” in between overseeing a one-time only, Sunday-edition-size newspaper: “McSweeney’s No. 33: The San Francisco Panorama” with full-color comics from Chris Ware, Dan Clowes and Art Spiegelman. Tell him to slow down at The Strand today where he’ll be appearing at 12. p.m.

headline: Mr. Sunshine
text: Julian Casablancas was once the “savior of debauched New York City rock ’n’ roll.” But those heady days when he and the Strokes were the leaders of the downtown guitar scene are long gone and, at the dawn of this decade, Mr. Casablancas is instead busy being a family man, eating healthy and relaxing in the Los Angeles sun. Tonight you can see the changed man in action when he performs at Terminal 5. He’ll be playing songs off his solo debut record, “Phrazes for the Young,” an “oddly hopeful” record.

headline: Proposals Clash on States’ Role in Health Plans
text: Should someone in Idaho or Nevada have significantly different health care coverage from someone in Massachusetts?

headline: Société Générale to Write Off More Debt
text: PARIS  The French bank Société Générale said Wednesday that it would write off another 1.4 billion euros in troubled American mortgage assets in the fourth quarter of 2009, but that it would still manage “a slight profit.”

headline: Meet Mikey, 8: U.S. Has Him on Watch List
text: The Transportation Security Administration, under scrutiny after last month’s bombing attempt, has on its Web site a “mythbuster” that tries to reassure the public.

headline: Democrats Fight to Hold Crucial Seat: Kennedy’s
text: BOSTON  Martha Coakley stepped briskly through a community center here Tuesday, issuing clipped greetings and appealing for votes in a race she was once thought to have sewn up. Always a bit stiff, she laughed politely when one man shouted his support, murmuring, “We all need to make some noise right now.”

headline: Wall St. Ethos Under Scrutiny at Hearing
text: The 10 members of the panel, brows furrowed and some furiously taking notes, squared off against the Wall Street chiefs in Washington over the billions in bonuses, and who was really to blame for bringing the financial system to its knees.

headline: In Miami, the Lack of Word Fuels Concern
text: MIAMI — Yvose Casimir slumped forward in a pew at the Notre Dame D’Haiti Roman Catholic church, her head resting on the next pew, deep in fervent and desperate prayer, while a lay leader intoned a prayer in Creole. There was not much more she could do, she said. She had been on the telephone with her sister in Port-au-Prince when the earthquake struck.

headline: A Cardinal Redeems Himself in a Big Way
text: TEMPE, Ariz.  In his Louisiana home, Rickey Bustle yelled at his television as if his voice might carry all the way to Arizona. One of Bustle’s former Louisiana-Lafayette players, Cardinals cornerback Michael Adams, was getting embarrassed by Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers on Sunday in a National Football Conference wild-card playoff game.

headline: Arnold’s Last Yodel
text: SACRAMENTO, Ca. — He was never as empty-headed as his enemies imagined, nor the cartoon character he sometimes portrayed. A Reagan Republican who married into the royalty of America’s Democratic dynasty, Arnold Schwarzenegger had everything going for him – no ties to party leaders, interest groups or the past.

headline: Surgery for Beltran Means He’s Likely Out Until May
text: The 2010 spring training is only a month away, but for the Mets it still seems like their injury-ravaged 2009. The team announced Wednesday night that center fielder Carlos Beltran, who missed 10 weeks last season with an ailing right knee, had arthroscopic surgery, making him unlikely to play in April.

headline: On Future Performance
text: Composing is what I love to do most. It is what best combines my various skills and interests — imagination, reflection, organization and the desire to communicate my thoughts and emotions to anyone who will listen. I also love solitude: I do my creative work in an 18th-century barn on our farm near Boston, where I can pursue my ideas without the need to explain or translate until all is ripe and ready. So it may seem like a paradox that another large chunk of my life is spent in one of the world’s most futuristic, collaborative and intensive centers of technological invention — the The Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab. But the attractions and complexities of merging these worlds are central to how and why I work, and grow from seeds planted when I was very young.My mom is a Juilliard-trained pianist and a remarkable pedagogue and my dad is one of the pioneers of computer graphics, but it actually took me a while to start combining these fields. I grew up as a cellist, first playing solo Bach, then chamber music (I never particularly enjoyed playing in orchestras), and then, by high school, original composed or improvised music using a wired (or is that “weird”?) transformed rock cello that I created by placing large headphones around the cello for amplification, then sending the sound through tape recorder loops and analog transformation processes.

headline: Art Rust Jr., Pioneer in Sports Talk Radio, Dies at 82
text: Art Rust Jr., a pioneering figure in New York radio sports talk shows and a sports historian whose books focused on the interplay of race and athletics, died Tuesday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: To Lead Schools, Christie Picks Voucher Advocate
text: TRENTON  The man once described by teachers’ union leaders as “the antithesis of everything we hold sacred about public education” was chosen to serve as state education commissioner by Governor-elect Christopher J. Christie on Wednesday.

headline: O’Brien Keeps Tapping His Saga for Jokes
text: Conan O’Brien kept up his drumbeat of jokes about his tense situation with his network Wednesday night — and even made a pointed reference to losing out on his show because Jay Leno wanted it, too.

headline: In Rebuke of China, Focus Falls on Cybersecurity
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Even before Google threatened to pull out of China in response to an attack on its computer systems, the company was notifying activists whose e-mail accounts might have been compromised by hackers.

headline: Long Island Shantytown Is Destroyed
text: Officials declared make-shift homes unsafe and ordered them leveled.

headline: 15 Across: Nazione di Napoli
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Tight. That’s the operative word in describing today’s theme. The approach is straightforward enough, that of adding letters to a phrase in order to form a new phrase. However, the degree of difficulty has been upped considerably by using only movie titles. Then comes the really inspired part.

headline: Aide to Leave Mayor’s Staff for a Job at His Charity
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s communications director will soon leave City Hall for a position at the mayor’s philanthropic foundation, becoming the first senior administration official to leave in Mr. Bloomberg’s third term.

headline: Google Is Not Alone in Discontent, but Its Threat to Leave Stands Out
text: HONG KONG — Google is far from alone among Western companies in its growing unhappiness with Chinese government policies, although it is highly unusual in threatening to pull out of the country entirely in protest.

headline: A Mini-Madoff Who Worked the Pews
text: CLIFTON, N.J.

headline: Makeshift Homes Are Leveled in Suffolk County
text: HUNTINGTON STATION, N.Y.  It would be easy to miss the narrow trail into the patch of woods that runs along Fifth Street here. Chunks of ice and snow muddy the path; gnarled, bare tree branches leave a passageway only a foot or two wide. Venturing a little farther, one begins to see the remnants of a home crudely made in an inhospitable area: discarded mattresses, rusty pans, artificial flowers, stuffed animals, a picture of Jesus.

headline: Gillibrand Responds to Ford’s Challenge, Calling Him Out of Touch With New York
text: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, after days of ignoring the political threat posed by Harold E. Ford Jr., on Wednesday forcefully took him on, suggesting that his views “may be right for Tennessee,” but are out of step with the voters of New York.

headline: Corrections
text: A graphic in some editions on Friday with the continuation of an article about the slumping commercial real estate market in New York, using information from real estate experts, referred imprecisely to 400 Madison Avenue. Although it has been identified as a property with financial problems, the owners are up to date on their loan payments.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Jan. 3 with an article about people whose only income is food stamps misstated, in one instance, data on the number of such people in Florida. There are more than 400,000, one in five of Florida’s food stamp recipients  not six million. (That is the number of such people nationwide.)

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column last Thursday about a new study on the interaction between the seasonal flu vaccine and the arthritis drug rituximab misstated a finding. The study found that in arthritis patients who receive the vaccine close to the time they take rituximab, the immune system apparently fails to make antibodies to the flu virus  not to arthritis.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Goal soccer roundup on Tuesday about safety concerns for this year’s World Cup in South Africa in the aftermath of an attack on Togo’s national team in Angola on Friday misstated the number of players that Arsenal sent to play for Ivory Coast in the African Cup of Nations there. It was one player (Emmanuel Eboué), not two.

headline: U.S.C. Welcomes Kiffin, and Deals With Questions
text: LOS ANGELES  When Lane Kiffin left Tennessee, students burned mattresses and threw debris at cars. He received a much more welcoming reception Wednesday when he was introduced as the new coach of Southern California.

headline: Corrections
text: The Books of The Times Review on Friday, about “The Harvard Psychedelic Club: How Timothy Leary, Ram Dass, Huston Smith and Andrew Weil Killed the Fifties and Ushered In a New Age for America,” by Don Lattin, referred incorrectly to the death of Diane Linkletter, daughter of the television and radio personality Art Linkletter. While Mr. Linkletter said his daughter was on LSD when she jumped from a window to her death in 1969 and blamed Mr. Leary, an autopsy found no evidence of the drug in her body. The review also referred imprecisely to the Harvard careers of Mr. Leary and Richard Alpert (later known as Ram Dass). While they taught psychology at Harvard, they were in the department of social relations  not the psychology department, which later absorbed the department of social relations.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the effect some of the technologies used to make the film “Avatar” might have on future movies, including “The Adventures of Tintin: Secret of the Unicorn,” erroneously included a studio among those releasing that film. It will be released by Paramount Pictures and Sony Pictures, but not in conjunction with DreamWorks. (Steven Spielberg of DreamWorks is the director.)

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: A theater review on Tuesday about “L’Effet de Serge,” at 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, misidentified the star. He is Gaëtan Vourc’h  not Philippe Quesne, who is the director and co-creator of the work with Mr. Vourc’h.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: Knicks Edge the 76ers on Lee’s Late Basket
text: PHILADELPHIA  David Lee’s shot bounced and bounced again, apparently not satisfied until it met every part of the rim.

headline: Forget Wind. Pickens Turns Focus to Gas.
text: DALLAS  Arabic script is about to appear on television sets across the country, with the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens helpfully reading an English translation.

headline: Help With Her Shyness, Then in Building Her Life
text: Elsa Sanchez greeted a recent visitor with a dimpled smile, a firm handshake and an air of maturity that belies her 18 years. She explained that she learned to project this confidence only a short time ago, at her high school.

headline: Donald Goerke, Creator of SpaghettiOs, Dies at 83
text: Donald Goerke, a Campbell Soup Company executive whose nonlinear approach to pasta resulted in SpaghettiOs, died Sunday at his home in Delran, N.J. He was 83.

headline: Texas Shuts Door on Millions in Education Grants
text: Texas will not compete for up to $700 million in federal education money, Gov. Rick Perry said on Wednesday, calling the Obama administration’s main school improvement grant program an unacceptable intrusion on states’ control over education.

headline: Anxious Moments Before Hearing the Words ‘I’m O.K.’
text: The call came just after noon on Wednesday, 19 hours after the earthquake hit Haiti. The Rev. Dr. Frank L. Fowler III, the pastor of Trinity United Methodist Church in Hackettstown, N.J., was checking in  from the airport in Port-au-Prince, on a borrowed satellite phone.

headline: Sample of Nestlé Cookie Dough Has E. Coli Bacteria
text: Nestlé USA said Wednesday that two samples of its Toll House refrigerated cookie dough made at a Virginia factory tested positive for E. coli bacteria this week despite rigorous safety measures put in place after a recall of the product last summer.

headline: Growth in Germany Neared Zero at End of ’09
text: FRANKFURT  Growth in Germany was near zero at the end of 2009, the government said Wednesday, as the nation struggled to climb out of its worst recession since World War II.

headline: Red Storm Ruins Stephenson’s Homecoming
text: The P.A. announcer at Madison Square Garden introduced the final starter for the Cincinnati Bearcats: “At guard, a 6-5 freshman from Brooklyn, New York, No. 33, Lance Stephenson.” And the boos flowed out of the stands.

headline: A Census Campaign That Speaks in Many Tongues
text: A campaign to encourage participation in the 2010 census reflects many of the major changes since the last census in the population that is to be counted.

headline: New Official Named With Portfolio to Unite Agencies and Improve Food Safety
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, moving to address the nation’s fractured food safety system, on Wednesday appointed Michael R. Taylor, a veteran food expert, as deputy commissioner for foods at the Food and Drug Administration. The newly created position is the first to oversee all the agency’s many food and nutrition programs.

headline: Some in Canada Say Strike Shows Risk of Foreign Control
text: SUDBURY, Ontario  Last July, the 3,300 unionized workers who normally work deep below this city in the vast nickel mines owned by Vale Inco did something unusual: they went on strike even though they had already been laid off temporarily.

headline: Few Burns for Four Bankers on the Hot Seat
text: WASHINGTON  The four bankers of the apocalypse strode into the Congressional hearing room and formed a crooked line. They raised their hands haltingly, looking at one another as if to see whether the other guys were going to do it, too. It was one of the more indecisive swearings-in you will ever see on Capitol Hill.

headline: Ruling Blocks Broadcasting of a Trial on Same-Sex Marriage
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday effectively eliminated the possibility that any part of the trial of a constitutional challenge to a ban on same-sex marriage now under way in San Francisco would be broadcast before it concludes.

headline: Year of the Tiger, Not Easily Tamed
text: A month before China ushers in the year of the tiger, its central bank has begun to address the effects of its roaring liquidity boom. It is encouraging that the authorities in Beijing are alert to the threat of an overheating financial system. But with so many countervailing forces, the liquidity tiger will not be tamed so easily.

headline: Ohio: Police Chief Sentenced in Break-In
text: The police chief of Bridgeport will spend 50 days in home confinement for his role in last year’s break-in of the home of a surrogate mother carrying twins for the movie stars Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick. The chief, Chad M. Dojack, pleaded guilty last week to a reduced charge of dereliction of duty for not reporting the crime. A chief in a neighboring town, Barry P. Carpenter, 40, was sentenced to 32 months in prison for going into the surrogate’s home and taking items. Mr. Dojack, 29, said he only failed to report the crime once he realized what had happened. Mr. Carpenter has resigned. Whether Mr. Dojack remains chief will be determined by the town’s mayor, who is the grandfather of Mr. Dojack’s wife.

headline: U.S.C.’s Orgeron Says He’s Following Recruiting Rules
text: After Lane Kiffin’s introductory news conference Wednesday night, Ed Orgeron, less than 24 hours after returning as Southern California’s defensive line coach and recruiting coordinator, found himself backed into a corner by a group of reporters.

headline: Bloggingheads:  The Curse of Power
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Byron York of The Washington Examiner debate partisanship and health care reform.

headline: Haiti
text: Once again, the world weeps with Haiti. The earthquake that struck on Tuesday did damage on a scale that scarcely could have been imagined had we all not seen the photos and videos and read the survivors’ agonizing accounts  of the sudden crumbling of mountainside slums, schools, hospitals, even the Parliament building and presidential palace.

headline: Google in China
text: Google has taken a bold stand by saying that it would stop cooperating with China’s online censorship and may pull out of the country entirely. Google had many reasons to reconsider its presence, but the discovery that it was a victim of a cyberattack aimed at Chinese human rights activists added a powerful one. There are limits to the price an American company should be willing to pay for access to 300 million Web users.

headline: Discrimination on Trial, but Not on TV
text: The trial that started on Monday in San Francisco over the constitutionality of California’s voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage could have been a moment for the entire nation to witness a calm, deliberative debate on a vitally important issue in the era of instant communications. Instead, the United States Supreme Court made it a sad example of the quashing of public discourse by blocking the televising of the nonjury trial.

headline: More Than a Scandal in Belfast
text: The struggle for power sharing  and lasting peace  in Northern Ireland has been long and bloody. Political leaders now must make sure that a sordid crisis does not threaten the agreement or the province’s future.

headline: World’s News Media Enter Port-au-Prince
text: The world’s news media scrambled to enter Port-au-Prince, Haiti on Wednesday, hours after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake decimated the capital city.

headline: The 10 Percent Rules
text: If Massachusetts was the Department of Homeland Security, the special election to fill Ted Kennedy’s senate seat would have the Democrats about four-fifths of the way up the terror alert code.

headline: Google Takes a Stand
text: It has been dispiriting to see America’s banks apparently stand for nothing more lofty than plunder. It has been demoralizing to see President Obama hiding from the Dalai Lama rather than offend China’s rulers.

headline: Word of the Day | dupe
text: dupe •\ˈdüp also ˈdyüp\• noun and verb

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Dec. 31, about the debate over the value of optimism, misspelled the surname of a woman who says the life of her terminally ill husband was prolonged a few weeks by a doctor’s encouragement. She is Ruth Rosoff, not Rossoff. The article also referred incorrectly to the price of LiveHappy, which is advertised as a “mobile happiness boosting program.” The $9.99 cost is one time only, not monthly.

headline: Braylon Edwards, Enigma
text: Steve Politi of The Star-Ledger with a nice get:

headline: Slim Aims to Unite 3 Telecom Firms
text: América Móvil, the telecommunications company controlled by Carlos Slim Helú, on Wednesday started a $21 billion offer for the Mexican telephone companies Telmex and Telmex Internacional, Reuters reported.

headline: News Quiz | January 14, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Helping Haiti
text: WHO were killed by the worst earthquake in Haiti in 200 years?

headline: Hershey Is Said to Be Still Working on Cadbury Bid
text: Hershey, the American chocolate maker, is still working on a bid for Cadbury that would top Kraft‘s $17 billion hostile takeover offer, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters on Wednesday.

headline: William J. Lederer, Co-Author of ‘The Ugly American,’ Dies at 97
text: William J. Lederer, a writer and career naval officer who, with Eugene Burdick, wrote “The Ugly American,” a novel that was among the first books to deal with American involvement in Southeast Asia and that barely veiled a blistering critique of the nation’s foreign policy there, died on Dec. 5 in Baltimore. He was 97.

headline: Pickens Focuses on National Security
text: Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens is turning up the volume and changing the pitch on his efforts to persuade Americans to embrace his energy plan.

headline: Few Burns for Four Bankers on the Hot Seat
text: The four bankers of the apocalypse strode into the Congressional hearing room and formed a crooked line. They raised their hands haltingly, looking at one another as if to see whether the other guys were going to do it, too. It was one of the more indecisive swearings-in you will ever see on Capitol Hill.

headline: Voices That Dominate Wall Street Take Meeker Tone
text: Summoned to Capitol Hill to explain their companies’ roles in the worst economic downturn since the Depression, leaders of four big Wall Street banks offered a largely clinical take on the financial crisis on Wednesday, pointing to lapses in risk management and government regulation but offering little sense of the turmoil’s human toll, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: How Are You Responding to the Disaster in Haiti?
text: People all over the world are reacting and responding to news of the disaster in Haiti – some by donating money and supplies, others by volunteering to go there to provide medical care and other aid. But the situation may be difficult to fathom. What kinds of information are helping you comprehend the devastation? And how are you responding to the news?

headline: China Backs Overseas Acquisitions by Airlines
text: China Southern Airlines led gains by air carriers in Hong Kong markets on Thursday, after an aviation regulator expressed support for consolidation and overseas acquisitions, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: MGM Said to Draw Interest From 12 Firms
text: Time Warner, Lions Gate Entertainment, as well as private equity firms, are among those weighing potential offers for the debt-ridden Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, though no bids have come in for the movie studio yet, Reuters reported, citing several sources familiar with the matter.

headline: Rusal I.P.O. Said to Be Fully Subscribed in Hong Kong
text: The initial public offering of Russia’s UC Rusal was fully subscribed by institutional investors on the third day of its bookbuilding process, people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Thursday, in a positive indication of demand for Hong Kong’s first-ever primary offering from a non-Asian company.

headline: Haiti Relief Effort Faces ‘Major Challenge’
text: A host of logistical problems snarled traffic at the Port-au-Prince airport on Thursday, forcing the airport to turn planes away, stranding relief workers for hours and threatening to delay the relief supplies that Haiti so desperately needs.

headline: Lotte Considers Acquiring Rival Korean Retail Chain
text: Lotte Group, which operates South Korea’s second-largest retailer Lotte Shopping, said it was considering buying GS Retail‘s department store and discount store operations in a deal that may be worth more than $1 billion.

headline: Open Space in Paris
text: This apartment, which has 14-foot ceilings, is on the top floor of a Beaux-Arts building in the 15th Arrondissement.

headline: Visible Technologies Raises $22 Million
text: Visible Technologies, a start-up that monitors digital and social media for brands, has landed $22 million in a fourth round of funding that VentureBeat says suggests renewed spending by big companies and brands.

headline: Get Satisfaction Gets $2.3 Million
text: Get Satisfaction, a start-up that hosts online customer service communities, has raised $2.3 million in a fresh round of financing, PaidContent reported.

headline: American Idol 9 on 9: The Atlanta Auditions
text: Tonight in Atlanta, it was “American Idol” at its finest: the gifted, the deluded, the earnest, the contrived. Kara still looked grim, but Simon smiled, and apparently no one told guest judge Mary J. Blige she’d have to sit through bad auditions as well as good ones. Tonight’s 9 questions:

headline: Geriaddicts
text: Elderly drug addicts.(Geriatric + addict.)

headline: RealNetworks Founder Steps Down as Chief
text: RealNetworks, the digital entertainment company, said on Wednesday that its founder, Rob Glaser, had stepped down as chief executive but would remain chairman.

headline: Justices Skeptical of N.F.L.’s Court Claim
text: Lawyers for the National Football League and an apparel company staked out aggressive positions at a Supreme Court argument Wednesday over whether the league should be treated as a single entity or a collection of 32 independent companies for purposes of the antitrust laws, The New York Times’s Adam Liptak reported.

headline: Should Kraft Hold the Line?
text: Kraft Foods should not budge — at least not much, Reuters Breakingviews says. Its reluctant British takeover target, Cadbury, has disclosed some impressive, if unsurprising, results and high expectations.

headline: Christmas Could Boost Matalan Sale Talks
text: A surge in Christmas sales at the British discount fashion retailer Matalan could reinvigorate a sale process that has run slowly since private equity houses first expressed an interest in the chain in October.

headline: Tensions Mount in Devastated Capital as Nations Step Up Aid Pledges to Haiti
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The distance between life and death narrowed in this flattened city on Thursday, with survival two days after the huge earthquake struck depending increasingly on the luck of being freed from under rubble, on treating the thousands of wounded and on speeding the halting flow of emergency food and water.

headline: Wall Street Closes Higher After Bankers Testify
text: The stock market closed higher on Wednesday, following the lead of financial shares as the heads of several big banks testified in Washington about the financial crisis.

headline: Tough Confirmation for E.U.’s Ex-Antitrust Chief
text: With her aggressive antitrust prosecutions, Neelie Kroes, the European Union’s former competition commissioner, should be one of the last officeholders on the Continent who needed to prove her pro-consumer credentials.

headline: Follow the Law, China Tells Internet Companies
text: BEIJING  Two days after Google announced that it would quit China unless the nation’s censors eased their grip, the Chinese government offered an indirect but unambiguous response: Companies that do business in China must follow the laws of the land.

headline: ‘Idol’ Creator Plans to Start New Business
text: The offstage turmoil around “American Idol” continues to grow as Simon Fuller, chief executive of 19 Entertainment and the creator of “American Idol,” is expected to announce soon that he is starting a new company to pursue film and other entertainment projects separately from 19 Entertainment and its publicly traded parent, CKX, The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Lose Staff to S.E.C., Survey Finds
text: Findings in a new report that United States hedge funds lost staff to endowments and sovereign wealth funds may not raise many eyebrows, but one of the employers found to be siphoning off hedge fund managers may come as a surprise: the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Forget Wind. Pickens Turns Focus to Gas.
text: Arabic script is about to appear on television sets across the country, with the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens helpfully reading an English translation, Clifford Strauss writes in The New York Times.

headline: Wilbur Ross Sees Slow U.S. Auto Sales Rebound
text: Wilbur Ross, the billionaire investor, said on Wednesday that the United States economy was nowhere near a full recovery and forecast 2010 as a year of moderate growth for American automotive industry sales.

headline: Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard Make a Really Big Deal
text: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

headline: Wynns Complete Divorce in Las Vegas
text: Steve Wynn, the billionaire chief executive of casino operator Wynn Resorts, is officially divorced for the second time from his wife, Elaine.

headline: Markets Nominee Seeks to Reassure Britain’s Finance Sector
text: The Frenchman nominated to oversee the European Union‘s internal market told his critics Wednesday that he would regulate to strengthen supervision of financial services but would not seek to undermine the City of London’s dominance of the sector in Europe, The New York Times’s Stephen Castle reported.

headline: VMware Gently Nudges Microsoft With a Zimbra
text: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

headline: JPMorgan May Report Profit Leap on Banking Fees
text: JPMorgan Chase, the first of the largest U.S. banks to report fourth-quarter results, may say profit more than tripled from the depths of the financial crisis in 2008 on a rebound in investment-banking fees.

headline: Britain’s Mandelson Warns Bidders Seeking Quick Profit
text: The U.K. business secretary, Peter Mandelson, has warned directors of predatory companies they should expect to run the “gantlet of criticism” if they ignored local and work force interests.

headline: Taxing Banks for the Bailout
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama laid down his proposal for a new tax on the nation’s largest financial institutions on Thursday, saying he wanted “to recover every single dime the American people are owed” for bailing out the economy.

headline: Barclays Gobbles Up LaBranche’s N.Y.S.E. Unit
text: Barclays, the British bank, has signed a deal to buy LaBranche & Company‘s New York Stock Exchange specialist business for $25 million (£15.3 million) in cash, underscoring the difficulties standalone market makers face in a shrinking industry.

headline: Argentina’s Talented Angel
text: The only things that might outpace the talent of Argentina’s forwards at the World Cup this summer are the expectations facing Diego Maradona’s team in South Africa.

headline: Reading English-Language Books in Paris
text: Generations of English-speaking literary expats in Paris have left a legacy of bookstores on both sides of the Seine. Many Anglophone readers swear by the much beloved Shakespeare and Company, or the Paris branch of the British chain W.H. Smith. But for those willing to hunt, there are several gems to discover: small, well-maintained stores crammed with new and used English-language titles — and plenty of character. Here is a selection; share your favorites below.

headline: Win Probabilities, and the Importance of Playoff Run Defense
text: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.)

headline: U.S. Approves Training to Expand Afghan Army
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Pentagon has authorized a substantial increase in the number of Afghan security forces it plans to train by next year, in time for President Obama’s deadline for United States combat forces to begin withdrawing from the country, military officials said Thursday.

headline: G.M. to Halt Hummer Production Pending Sale
text: General Motors will halt Hummer production next week at its Louisiana plant until sale of the brand to a Chinese company is completed, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Wall St. Ethos Under Scrutiny at Hearing
text: During the first day’s hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington on Wednesday, an essential truth about the Wall Street ethos was laid bare: if there’s a buyer — no matter how sophisticated — there’s always a seller, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

headline: Changing the Rules, Not the Tax Bill
text: Yes, a new tax on bank profits will raise money. But it will not prevent a major collapse in the future, two economists write.

headline: Obama Plan: A 10-Year Bank Tax to Recoup Bailout
text: Update | 12:28 p.m.  President Obama on Thursday proposed taxing about 50 big banks and major financial institutions for at least the next decade to “recover every single dime” from the bailout of Wall Street, The New York Times’s Jackie Calmes reports from Washington.

headline: BMW’s ActiveE Foreshadows the Megacity Car
text: DETROIT — BMW is approaching the electrification of the automobile through what it calls Project i. And although its cars — including the battery-powered Mini E and the Concept ActiveE, which is an electric version of the BMW 1 Series Coupe the company introduced in Detroit this week — have made a splash, Project i has generally flown under the radar. But, even in stealth mode (there isn’t even a Web site), the research initiative could be influential on BMW’s future products.

headline: Jan. 14: Updates on the Rescue Effort in Haiti
text: As we did on Tuesday and Wednesday, The Lede is continuing to follow news of the rescue effort in Haiti, where a 7.0 magnitude earthquake has caused death and destruction that has been difficult for Haitians and observers outside the country to assess, because of severe damage to the local communications infrastructure. To supplement the work of our colleagues — including Simon Romero’s reporting from Haiti — The Lede is tracking news coverage on the Web. We are also looking for personal accounts posted online and are asking readers to help draw our attention to any news and first-hand accounts they come across. Our Times Topics team has produced an overview of the week’s events so far.

headline: Sampler: No Video of Marriage Trial and Palo Alto’s Egg War Continues
text: Same-Sex Marriage Trial Not Coming to a Screen Near You | The Supreme Court said Wednesday that it would extend Monday’s temporary stay blocking distribution of video images of the federal trial in San Francisco over same-sex marriage. In a 5-to-4 ruling, the court said that the decision to allow video distribution was made in haste, and it blocked broadcasts to courthouses around the country. Its reasoning would apply to Internet broadcasts as well; YouTube distribution had originally been planned. The trial, which enters its fourth day, has had expert testimony over the history of marriage and the effect of laws banning same-sex marriage. [The New York Times]

headline: Uncertainty Grips Haitians in New York

In a city of insular immigrant populations, none have had more experience helping with disasters back home and knowing how to make crucial life-or-death connections than the Haitian populations in Brooklyn and in Cambria Heights, Queens.

headline: In a Surprise, Retail Sales Fell in December
text: Retail sales fell unexpectedly in December, the government said Thursday, despite earlier scattered signs that the 2009 holiday shopping season was stronger than expected.

headline: City Hospital Chief Calls for Coverage of Immigrants
text: The leader of New York City’s massive public hospital system warned this week that the health care bills in Congress would burden safety net hospitals by failing to provide coverage for uninsured immigrants while also reducing federal payments for indigent care.

headline: Design Underfoot | BCXSY’s Coat Rugs
text: Our favorite Israeli/Japanese, Netherlands-based design duo, Boaz Cohen and Sayaka Yamamoto of BCXSY, are at it again. The high-concept-centric designers, whose light-up swing lamp was on the cover the spring 2008 issue of T Design, came up with their latest project, Re-skinned, while wondering what happens to discarded leather and fur coats. They felt that throwing out the old coats was disrespectful to the animals whose skins made the garments. After some serious thrift-store digging, Cohen and Yamamoto found some likely candidates for their repurposing effort. In their experiments, they found that when the garments were disassembled and laid flat, their backs resembled traditional animal-skin rugs. Each rug is backed with felt and stamped with the BCXSY logo and a serial number for authenticity. At their introduction during Dutch design week in October, some of the rugs were snapped up by Rossana Orlandi for her renowned design store in Milan. And people have already approached Cohen and Yamamoto with their own coats, hoping to take them home again as rugs.

headline: Iraq Sentences 11 to Death in Ministry Bombings
text: BAGHDAD  A court in Baghdad sentenced 11 Iraqis to death on Thursday for planning and carrying out two devastating attacks last summer.

headline: Good News and Bad News on Food Safety and Health
text: The Food and Drug Administration has appointed the first official to oversee all the agency’s food safety programs. The official, Michael R. Taylor, is deputy commissioner for foods. Legislation expected to pass this spring would give even more power to his office to regulate food safety.

headline: Technology Helps Lead Shares Higher as Retailers Slip
text: Stocks advanced for a second day as technology shares climbed before Intel reported earnings. In addition, business inventories increased more than forecast, overshadowing an unexpected drop in retail sales.

headline: Obama Will Tap Bush and Clinton for Haiti Efforts
text: Updated: President Obama is asking his two immediate predecessors – George W. Bush and Bill Clinton – to come together to lead the nation’s humanitarian and relief efforts to Haiti in the wake of the earthquake that has ravaged the Caribbean island. The partnership is expected to be announced by the White House in the coming days, after officials have a better handle on the full scope of the devastation. Mr. Obama called Mr. Bush on Wednesday, aides to both men said, and Mr. Bush agreed to do whatever he could to help.

In his opening monologue, Mr. O’Brien offered this inspirational message: “I just want to say to the kids out there watching: You can do anything you want in life. Unless Jay Leno wants to do it, too.”
