headline: Labor Movement Starting an Online College
text: My colleague, Steve Greenhouse, who covers organized labor, reports that the labor movement is creating its own online college. The organizations behind the effort are the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the National Labor College, and the Princeton Review.

headline: Haitian Earthquake Spurs Stars to Action
text: The mobile communications company that is working with the pop musician Wyclef Jean to raise money for disaster relief in Haiti said on Thursday that it had raised more than $750,000 in donations since its campaign began on Tuesday. In a news release, Give on the Go, the fund-raising division of the Miami company Red Fish Media, said its goal was to raise more than $1 million per day. The campaign allows the users of mobile devices to make an instant donation of $5 to Mr. Jean’s Yéle Haiti foundation, a relief charity, by texting “Yele” to 501501. (The charge appears later on the user’s telephone bill.) In a statement, Matt McKenna, president of Red Fish Media, said “100 percent of the donations” are given directly to the charity. The campaign began at 6 p.m. on Tuesday, and Mr. Jean has tirelessly promoted it on his Twitter account, soon after a 7.0 magnitude earthquake struck Haiti about 10 miles southwest of Port-au-Prince.

headline: Do You Have the ‘Right Stuff’ to Be a Doctor?
text: Not long ago, a friend confessed that her son, who spends much of his free time volunteering at a children’s hospital and who is applying to medical school, has been particularly anxious about his future. “His test scores are just O.K.,” my friend said, the despair in her voice nearly palpable. “I know he’d be a great doctor, but who he is doesn’t seem to matter to medical schools as much as how he does on tests.”

headline: Russians See More Than Expected in ‘Avatar’
text: For those of you keeping score at home, the list of people, groups and nations that do not like “Avatar” include social and political conservatives; anticolonialists; antismoking advocates; the Vatican and China. To that list of detractors you can now add Russian filmgoers, who say the James Cameron movie too closely resembles a literary science-fiction series by the authors Arkady and Boris Strugatsky. The Guardian has reported that the Russian newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda ran an article on Monday comparing “Avatar” to the Strugatskys’ “Noon Universe” books: both take place in the 22nd century on Pandora, and the alien species in “Avatar” is called the Na’vi, while “Noon Universe” chronicles a race called the Nave. In the newspaper Novaya Gazeta, Dmitry Bykov wrote that some elements of “Avatar” were “unequivocally reminiscent” of the “Noon Universe” novels, and told The Guardian that “the film is harmful for western civilization.” But The Guardian reported that the surviving Strugatsky brother, Boris, had not yet seen “Avatar,” and that he played down any reports that he was accusing Mr. Cameron of plagiarism.

headline: A Parent’s Haitian Nightmare
text: Before I had children, my recurring nightmares were about missing a final exam or driving in a blinding snowstorm with faulty wipers. In the years since my sons were born, my worst nights are spent dreaming that they are trapped and hurt, and that I can’t reach them. I had that dream last night. Then my alarm radio woke me to the sound of an infant girl wailing in pain in Port-au-Prince, her father helpless in the face of her split scalp and broken legs.

headline: Should ‘American Idol’ Abolish Its Age Limits?
text: Now that we’ve all had a good laugh at with Larry Platt, the creator and performer of “Pants on the Ground,” we’d like to get serious for a moment. Unless the “American Idol” producers are feeling especially charitable, or certain Web sites keep promoting Mr. Platt relentlessly, we most likely have seen the sexagenarian superstar on the show for the last time. As commenters like Zaglossus and David have pointed out, Mr. Platt is technically not permitted to compete on “American Idol,” which allows performers only between the ages of 16 and 28 to participate. At 63, Mr. Platt’s eligibility ran out in 1975.

headline: Black Schools Restored as Landmarks
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Until 1923, the only school in the largely black farm settlement of Pine Grove was the one hand-built by parents, a drafty wooden structure in the churchyard. Anyone who could read and write could serve as teacher. With no desks and paper scarce, teachers used painted wood for a blackboard, and an open fireplace provided flashes of warmth to the lucky students who sat close.

headline: 2009: Heavenly Necci

headline: 1987: Heavenly Hots
text: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by Joanna Pruess. The recipe came from Bridge Creek Restaurant in Berkeley, Calif. A few tips: Don’t cook the pancakes all the way through. You want the center to be a pocket of cream. The pancakes are so fragile that it may take a few tries to flip them. I used the thinnest, most flexible spatula I own, wedged it halfway under the pancake, letting the other half hang, then turned my wrist and gently laid it down on the other side. I recommend this over more aggressive flipping, which will tear the pancakes.

headline: Recipe Redux: Heavenly Hots, 1987
text: Sometimes the name of a dish is irresistible. Ratatouille. Financiers. Mooncakes. Oysters Rockefeller. Fallen soufflé. Anything confited. And my recent favorite, pudding chômeur, which translates to “unemployed-person pudding.” (Biscuit dough baked in maple syrup and cream, it’s a delight that Canadians have been keeping to themselves.)

headline: The Bratwursts and Strudels of Yore
text: Few places in New York City would boast about serving sour meat and foamy beer. But in Yorkville, the Upper East Side’s easternmost stretch, some establishments proudly serve sauerbraten, a pickled pot roast, while others cultivate pouring sudsy booze. This German fare is a holdover from what was once a thriving ethnic enclave in the 19th century (there was even a German-language movie theater on 86th Street between Second and Third Avenues). The Second Avenue subway will not be finished until 2015 or later, so you’ll have to walk from the 86th Street stop of the Lexington Avenue line to Second Avenue to visit some of the last few outposts of German Manhattan.

headline: Senator Grassley Joins the Cost Conversation

It is far outpacing regular inflation and threatening to bust not only the federal budget but the finances of individuals and families as well.

headline: And the Winner is … T!

headline: After a Death, Embracing Life’s Diversity
text: CORINNE BAILEY RAE’S fans were worried about her. Onstage at the Hiro Ballroom in New York in December, dressed in a slinky Alexander McQueen jumpsuit, this English singer-songwriter was so thin, her baby-blue guitar weighed heavily on her petite frame. Standing 5 feet 2 inches with a wild halo of curly hair, she looked a decade younger than her 30 years. By the time she began to play “The Sea,” a powerful meditation on grief, it was enough to make the crowd feel protective.

When Mr. Miroshnichenko’s “Lady With the Little Dog” opens on Wednesday night at the David H. Koch Theater, it will be his second work and first premiere for City Ballet.

headline: Postcard From London: Sucking Blood
text: The adolescent craving to turn into a vampire did not, it seems, originate with the “Twilight” books. This is made evident by the National Theater’s icy revival of Ferdinand Bruckner’s “Pains of Youth,” a 1923 play in which some lively young things of Vienna want nothing so much as to be dead. One of them speaks of the ecstasy of being made love to by a man who sucks at her skin as if he wants her blood. This is the same man, a hypnotically handsome chap with bad feet and a rotting liver, who diagnoses his friends’ futures as a matter of either “bourgeois existence or suicide: there are no other choices.”

headline: The Bay Area Reaches Out to Help Haiti
text: Although the Bay Area has only a small Haitian community (numbering about 3,000 by some counts, according to The Mercury News), the reaction felt by many here has transcended national and regional ties. People want to help.

headline: Tight Ends Pose a Bigger Receiving Headache for Defenses
text: INDIANAPOLIS  When Mike Ditka played for the Chicago Bears in the 1960s, he took great pride in blocking for running back Gale Sayers. Tight ends then were used mostly like another tackle. Their primary job was to wall off the edge of the defense for the most important offensive weapon of the time: the runners. But the Bears’ coach, George Halas, had other ideas. He sometimes put space between Ditka and the offensive line, making Ditka one of the first tight ends to split out a bit and become a receiving threat. As a rookie in 1961, Ditka was the team’s leading receiver, catching 56 passes for 1,076 yards. In 1964, he caught 75 passes.

headline: Other Voices, Other Selves
text: “To write critically in English,” Zadie Smith asserts in the opening essay of “Changing My Mind,” “is to aspire to neutrality, to the high style of, say, Lionel Trilling or Edmund Wilson.” Praising Zora Neale Hurston, Smith complains that the mandarin critical mode elevates the experiences of white people to the norm while making “black women talking about a black book” look sectarian. Smith’s own way of escaping this narrow assumption is to declare boldly, “Fact is, I am a black woman.” A writer like Hurston, Smith adds, makes “ ‘black woman-ness’ appear a real, tangible quality, an essence I can almost believe I share, however improbably, with millions of complex individuals.” Hurston also allows Smith “to say things I wouldn’t normally — things like “She is my sister and I love her.”

headline: Sam Shepard: The Highwayman
text: For Sam Shepard, the prizewinning playwright and short-story writer (and sometime Hollywood actor) whose work might be characterized as Grass-Roots Gothic, infused as it is with a sense of folksy madness and populist brutality, the American landscape is a sprawling cemetery, a field of bad dreams spread out between two oceans. Its markers, commemorating acts of violence that seem to repeat themselves through the generations in a cruel infinity loop, consist of dark highways stretching to the horizon. Under them lies a dense matrix of remains. The bones of Plains Indians, Confederate soldiers, hard-luck homesteaders and hellbound drunks mix in a democratic necropolis capped by thousands of miles of oily blacktop. These routes, which for some writers promise liberation — an escape into unbounded freedom and possibility — are, for Shepard, roads of no return. Laid out north and south and east and west, they all lead in the same direction: down.

headline: He’s Back
text: As a boy in Chippawa, Ontario, James Cameron once sent some mice over the edge of Niagara Falls in a small submersible made from old mayonnaise jars, an Erector Set and a paint bucket. Another time, he made a hot-air balloon out of a dry-cleaning bag and some candles, floating it down the street until someone reported it as a U.F.O. and called the Fire Department. Together with the young Steven Spielberg’s experiments in civic alarum-raising — locking himself in the bathroom until the Phoenix Fire Department was summoned — Cameron’s excursions suggest two interlocking propositions: (1) If you want to know who is going to grow up to be a box-office titan, check out the rec­ords of your local Fire Department. And (2) nobody should be surprised if Balloon Boy turns into the proud auteur behind “Terminator Resurrection: This Time With Feeling.”

headline: Election Confidential
text: In July 2006 Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, abruptly summoned Barack Obama, then a freshman senator, for a meeting. Obama, who had a cordial but not warm relationship with Reid, immediately headed for his office, remarking to his press secretary Robert Gibbs, “I wonder what we screwed up.” Upon Obama’s arrival, Reid didn’t mince words: “You’re not going to go anyplace here,” he said. “I know that you don’t like it, doing what you’re doing.” After the lecture, when Obama had returned, Gibbs asked if anything was amiss. Not at all, Obama replied. “Harry wants me to run for president.”

headline: The Face of Suffering
text: What is a nonfascist literature? Is this a question we ask ourselves, as writers or as readers, and is it answerable? To put it another way, what is a noncollusive literature? Is there a poem that isn’t in negotiation, to some degree, with kings, presidents, generals and the people who hold other people’s heads under water just shy of drowning them? The easy answers are yes and no. In America, where we still jones for innocence and ruin, the intertwining of power and art hasn’t generally been a preoccupation of our literature — what a photograph of a meadow might have to do with Guantánamo, whether a play about marriage is connected to the doings of the secretary of state. Joan Didion’s work might trace the meridians of power through private and public lives, but she is a rare breed. Oddly, despite this being one of the largest participatory democracies in the world, as a culture we are reluctant to engage with, much less obsess over, the demonstrable fact that we’re born implicated, that our actions and the sufferings of others are inextricably linked.

headline: Help for Haiti

headline: Funeral Arrangements Announced for Teddy Pendergrass

headline: Blue Skies
text: America could use a truly Whiggish book right about now. More than a year into the Great Recession, it has become much harder to believe in the idea of inexorable progress. The moment is ripe for a counterintuitive, optimistic perspective that shows, despite appearances to the contrary, that the world is getting better and better every day, in every way. Gregg Easterbrook tries hard to satiate our inner optimist with “Sonic Boom.”

headline: The Bass Art of ‘Nukular’ Versification
text: Remember “nucular,” the pronunciation of “nuclear” that George W. Bush inserted into the national conversation? headline: A Saxophone Is Her Only Constant
text: Some young jazz musicians find their style and move in lock, stock and barrel, making little refinements over the years but basically keeping their place. Ingrid Laubrock, a German saxophonist who started her career in London and has spent the last 15 years playing there, sounds happily unsettled. On tenor and soprano, she’s omnivorous and pointed, slouching and precise, humorous and austere.

headline: Blow, Winds! Deconstruct Thy Text!
text: Certainly the playwright Young Jean Lee does not lack for chutzpah. Last season this talented writer made a heady splash on the downtown scene with “The Shipment,” a play about black identity politics that was audacious  coming as it did from a Korean-American  but also smart and entertaining. Now Ms. Lee has written and directed a cheeky, freaky modernist gloss on “King Lear,” which many consider to be Shakespeare’s greatest play, if not the greatest play written in the English language, if not the greatest play bar none.
