headline: Education Chief Criticizes N.B.A. and the N.C.A.A.
text: ATLANTA  Education Secretary Arne Duncan entered some of the most contentious debates in college sports on Thursday when, in a speech at the N.C.A.A. convention, he called for stricter consequences for college teams that do not graduate their athletes and said the N.B.A.’s age-minimum policy sets up young athletes for failure.

headline: A Rebel in Cyberspace, Fighting Collectivism
text: In 2006, the artist and computer scientist Jaron Lanier published an incisive, groundbreaking and highly controversial essay about “digital Maoism”  about the downside of online collectivism, and the enshrinement by Web 2.0 enthusiasts of the “wisdom of the crowd.” In that manifesto Mr. Lanier argued that design (or ratification) by committee often does not result in the best product, and that the new collectivist ethos  embodied by everything from Wikipedia to “American Idol” to Google searches  diminishes the importance and uniqueness of the individual voice, and that the “hive mind” can easily lead to mob rule.

headline: Celebrating the Tension Between Art and Science
text: The guitarist David Gilmore has a pronounced fondness for metric convolution, jigsaw complexity and a near-mystical spirit of intrigue. So it makes sense that “Numerology” is the name he has chosen for his new suite, created with a grant from Chamber Music America and presented at the Jazz Standard this week. With its whiffs of occult practice and brow-furrowed calculation, that title could apply to Mr. Gilmore’s entire body of work.

headline: Art in Review
text: ‘PRIMARY ATMOSPHERES’

headline: Password Unprotected
text: A good friend broke up last year with her longtime boyfriend. While they were dating, she learned the password to his e-mail account and occasionally checked his messages. Now she reads his entire in-box. As a result, she can’t get over him. I know she won’t stop until he changes his password. Is there any way to discreetly tell him to do so?

headline: Exotic Tastes of the Big Island
text: Hilo, Hawaii — CHERIMOYA, calamansi, rainbow papaya. Puna ricotta, poha berries, lilikoi. Lava salsa, dinosaur kale, Hamakua mushrooms. This is the exotic-food litany on the lips of pilgrims who go to the Hilo Farmers Market, held twice a week on the lush eastern side of the Big Island.

headline: Social Realism in a Poetic Lens
text: IN Andrea Arnold’s new film, “Fish Tank,” an unsmiling 15-year-old named Mia (Katie Jarvis), who lives in a housing project in Essex, in England, becomes close to the boyfriend of her uncaring mother. The man, an Irish charmer named Connor, played by Michael Fassbender, gives her money and lends her his video camera so that she can tape herself dancing to hip-hop. It soon becomes apparent that the relationship between Mia and Connor is becoming dangerously intimate.

headline: Breathtaking Panoramas
text: THE Big Island’s Kona-Kohala Coast in Hawaii, a stretch of about 35 miles of northwest shoreline, isn’t free of resorts and private communities, but there are far fewer than one might expect. In part this is the result of pressure at both local and state levels to stop the overbuilding that characterized development in places like Honolulu and the island of Maui. The developments here promote their open spaces and low-density building plans as thoughtful efforts to respect the land, noting that these efforts add value to their real estate by limiting inventory and offering breathtaking views.

headline: Tea Party Ticket Troubles
text: The planning for headliner guests like Sarah Palin and for media coverage at the Tea Party Nation convention in Nashville next month seems to be in a state of flux these days.

headline: Bernanke Defends Fed’s Oversight Role
text: Facing renewed calls from Washington to limit its authority, the Federal Reserve on Thursday defended its role as one of Wall Street’s chief watchdogs and said being able to monitor the health of banks was crucial to setting sound monetary policy.

headline: How Do You Get to the Big Apple Circus? Practice, Practice
text: The Big Apple Circus continues through Monday in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center; (888) 541-3750, bigapplecircus.org.

headline: Prosecutor in Galleon Case Plans to Set Up His Own Firm
text: Joshua I. Klein, an important prosecutor in the widening insider-trading case involving the Galleon Group and its founder, Raj Rajaratnam, is planning to resign to set up his own criminal defense firm, people close to the case said on Thursday.

headline: The Fine Print Behind Google’s Nexus One
text: David Pogue says that Google is imposing an early termination fee for people who cancel service with the phone — in addition to any early termination fee that the carrier would impose.

headline: A Space Opera in a Proper Galaxy
text: IN 2001 Gotham Chamber Opera opened its doors at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side of Manhattan with what was billed as the American stage premiere of the teenage Mozart’s moral allegory “Il Sogno di Scipione,” set in the Temple of Heaven. Now, after nine years spent establishing a repertory of rarities from Monteverdi to Piazzolla, the company is preparing its next space adventure. The vehicle this time is Haydn’s comedy “Il Mondo Della Luna” (“The World on the Moon”), to be presented, with unassailable if quixotic logic, in the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History beginning on Tuesday evening.

headline: M.P.G. Standards Loom, So Designers Look Afar
text: DETROIT

headline: In This World, It Pays to Be a Loner
text: A road warrior of a different sort, the title character played by Denzel Washington in “The Book of Eli” spends much of the story traveling by foot across an eerie landscape, a long and quick knife at the ready. The brown, dusty environs look familiar and not, dotted with abandoned cars and the occasional corpse. When Eli pauses, the camera settles near his feet, and the sky opens above him like a sheltering hand. With his green jacket and unsmiling mouth, he looks like a veteran of an unknown war, a soldier of misfortune  though, given the fog of religiosity that hangs over the movie, he might be an avenging angel.

headline: Gaining a Minute in the Race Against Time
text: We can all relax: we’re a minute further from doomsday than previously thought, according to a group of engineers, scientists, scholars and security specialists tracking prospects that humans might do themselves in.

headline: Ex-U.N. Weapons Inspector Is Charged in Child-Sex Sting
text: A former chief United Nations weapons inspector in Iraq has been charged in Pennsylvania with engaging in online sexual exchanges with a minor.

headline: Another Terrorist Plot, Another Very Long Day
text: A lot of secret agents have popped up on television since Jack Bauer first saved the day in 2001. None of them is nearly as intense, of course.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Paul Kahan, Chef
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Earthquake in Haiti Spurs Stars to Action
text: The mobile communications company that is working with the musician Wyclef Jean (above, arriving in Port-au-Prince on Wednesday) to raise money for disaster relief in Haiti said on Thursday that it had raised more than $750,000 in donations since its campaign began on Tuesday. In a news release, Give on the Go, the fund-raising division of the Miami company Red Fish Media, said its goal was to raise more than $1 million daily. The campaign allows users of mobile devices to make an instant donation of $5 to Mr. Jean’s Yéle Haiti foundation, a relief charity, by texting “Yele” to 501501. (The charge appears on the user’s phone bill.) In a statement, Matt McKenna, president of Red Fish, said “100 percent of the donations” go to the charity. Mr. Jean has tirelessly promoted the campaign on his Twitter account. Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt are among the other notable names who are contributing to relief efforts. In a statement on Wednesday, they said their Jolie-Pitt Foundation would give $1 million to the emergency medical operations of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières, which is responding to the devastation in Haiti.

headline: Injured Actor Departs ‘View From the Bridge’
text: The actor Santino Fontana, below, who had been playing the key role of Rodolpho in previews of the Broadway revival of “A View From the Bridge,” said he was leaving the show to make a full recovery from an onstage injury that resulted in a concussion. His understudy, Morgan Spector, who has been standing in since Jan. 7, will take over the role. Rodolpho is an Italian immigrant who has entered the United States illegally and draws the ire of Eddie Carbone (played by Liev Schrieber) for courting his niece (Scarlett Johansson). While Mr. Fontana initially was believed to have been injured in a boxing scene between Rodolpho and Eddie, people involved with the production now say that he suffered the injury in another scene over New Year’s weekend. In the statement, Mr. Fontana said, “Knowing that I would not be fully recovered and able to return until after opening, I’ve chosen to withdraw with great respect to my fellow actors and to my own health.” Gregory Mosher, the director, said in the statement: “Santino is a wonderful actor; we’ll miss him, and we are tremendously grateful for his selflessness in this difficult situation. But I have every confidence in Morgan.” “View” is to open Jan. 24.

headline: Moynihan Letters to Be Published
text: Letters, journals and other correspondence written by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, below left, over the course of his half-century career in public service will be published this year. On Wednesday, PublicAffairs said it would release a book culled from more than 10,000 pages of letters written by Mr. Moynihan, the former senator from New York, during his time on Capitol Hill and in the administrations of Presidents Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and Ford. In an e-mail message, PublicAffairs said the letters in the book, which does not yet have a title, would cover the 1950s to Mr. Moynihan’s death in 2003, and would reveal his thoughts on matters including the civil rights movement, the Vietnam War, health care, urban planning and the United Nations. Among the noteworthy recipients of Mr. Moynihan’s correspondence were Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Indira Gandhi, Chaim Herzog, William F. Buckley Jr. and Alexander Solzhenitsyn. The book is to be edited by Steven R. Weisman, a former staff member of The New York Times, who is now the editorial director and public policy fellow at the Peter G. Peterson Institute for International Economics in Washington.

headline: For Russians, ‘Avatar’ Seems a Little Familiar
text: For those of you keeping score at home, the list of people, groups and nations that do not like “Avatar” include social and political conservatives, anticolonialists, antismoking advocates, the Vatican and China. To that list you can now add Russian filmgoers, who say the James Cameron movie too closely resembles a literary science-fiction series by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky. The Guardian reported that the Russian newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda ran an article on Monday comparing “Avatar” to the Strugatskys’ “Noon Universe” books: both take place in the 22nd century on Pandora, and the alien species in “Avatar” is called the Na’vi, while “Noon Universe” chronicles a race called the Nave. In the newspaper Novaya Gazeta, Dmitry Bykov wrote that some elements of “Avatar” were “unequivocally reminiscent” of the “Noon Universe” novels, and told The Guardian that “the film is harmful for western civilization.” But The Guardian reported that the surviving Strugatsky brother, Boris, had not yet seen “Avatar,” and that he played down any reports that he was accusing Mr. Cameron of plagiarism.

headline: Win (and Loss) for ‘Idol’
text: Night two of “American Idol” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings by a wide margin on Wednesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the reality show drew an average of 26.3 million viewers, down from the 29.9 million who watched the season premiere on Tuesday. It was followed on Fox by a repeat of the 450th episode of “The Simpsons” (8.1 million). CBS ranked second, drawing low ratings for its comedies “The New Adventures of Old Christine” (6.3 million) and “Gary Unmarried” (5.8 million), but better results for its crime shows “Criminal Minds” (14 million) and “CSI: NY” (14.1 million). NBC was third with “Mercy” (6 million), “Law & Order: SVU” (7.7 million) and “The Jay Leno Show” (5.4 million). ABC’s lineup of comedies finished the night in fourth place.

headline: Voicing Opinion on Next Vols Coach
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — An on-line poll conducted by The Knoxville News-Sentinel asked fans to declare who they would want as the next head coach and it had the usual suspect as the leader: the Texas defensive coordinator Will Muschamp. He had 8,200 votes.

headline: Method Walking
text: Ben Foster likes to take walks — long, meandering ones. They’re how he clears his head and gets into character. Preparing for his role as a still-jumpy Army sergeant charged with delivering news of casualties in “The Messenger,” he marched around New York, where he’s only just moved after many years in California. “I’d walk for hours and hours for about two months every night,” he said, “looking at windows and cars, these abandoned cars, and allowing those cars and windows to become threats. So someone’s in that window and shoots you, you have to be prepared. It’s a constant readiness.”

headline: Union Bolsters Its Roster in M.L.S. Draft
text: There have been 45 55 were 64 players selected in the Major League Soccer SuperDraft — so far over four rounds. (What exactly is so super about it?) The first overall pick by the Philadelphia Union, the league’s newest club, was Danny Mwanga, an 18-year-old forward who scored 14 goals as a sophomore at Oregon State last season.

headline: The Destruction in Port-au-Prince
text: View satellite photos that show Port-au-Prince before and after the Jan. 12 earthquake.

headline: Defensive Coordinator Is First Casualty in New England Fallout
text: The fallout from the New England Patriots’ one-and-done postseason has begun: Dean Pees will not return as defensive coordinator after four years on the job.

headline: Republicans and Health Insurance
text: In her column today, Gail Collins goes into what she calls a rant.

headline: Finally, Some Electricity in the Air
text: DETROIT

headline: Iconic Checker Cab Company Shuts Down
text: It has been more than a decade since the last old Checker cab disappeared from the city’s taxi ranks and nearly three decades since the last new cab rolled off the production line.

headline: A Reckless Teenager, Seeking Solitude Yet Craving Connection
text: Mia, the 15-year-old protagonist of “Fish Tank,” Andrea Arnold’s tough and brilliant second feature, moves with such speed and fury that she seems to be trying to flee not only from her bleak surroundings but also from the movie itself. The narrow, nearly square frame boxes Mia in, and Ms. Arnold’s on-the-run hand-held tracking shots increase the sense of panicky claustrophobia. Living in a cramped apartment in a British housing project that stands like a cluster of megaliths in the middle of nowhere, Mia is at once trapped and adrift, unable to contain or to express the feelings seething beneath the blank, sullen mien she usually presents to the world.

headline: From a Troubled Past, Into the Line of Fire
text: “Human Target,” beginning on Sunday night on Fox, has an unusually small set of regular characters. Through the first two episodes there are just three: Chance and Winston (Mark Valley and Chi McBride), partners in an unconventional security firm, and Guerrero (Jackie Earle Haley), the shady figure they employ to hack into corporate and government computer systems.

headline: Names Fall Away in Vols’ Coaching Search
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — The news is being monitored from Kingsport to Memphis. Who is going to be the next Tennessee football coach to replace Lane Kiffin?

headline: Can ‘Idol’ Still Churn Out Stars? Time Will Tell
text: With a rush of publicity over the departure of Simon Cowell, “American Idol” returned this week for a ninth season, promising once again to introduce the next batch of fresh-faced pop stars.

headline: On Vacation and Looking for Wi-Fi
text: FOR several years, our extended family — 19 of us — has taken a holiday vacation in the tropics. Typically we go to an all-inclusive resort.

headline: Roundup of Reaction to Obama’s Bank Tax
text: Over at Economix, Catherine Rampell has a roundup of some of the reaction so far to President Obama‘s bank tax proposal. Here is a sampling:

headline: Teddy Pendergrass, R&B Soul Singer, Dies at 59
text: Teddy Pendergrass, the Philadelphia soul singer whose husky, potent baritone was one definition of R&B seduction in the 1970s but whose career was transformed in 1982 when he was severely paralyzed in an auto accident, died on Wednesday night in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 59.

headline: Florida’s Deep Freeze
text: A two-week cold spell was the longest in decades.

headline: Obama Seeks to Reassure House Democrats
text: Like most political junkies, President Obama said he keeps an eye on the blogs and the cable shows. So, he assured anxious House Democrats on Thursday, he fully understands what they have been going through in the tumultuous health care debate.

headline: McAfee Says Microsoft Flaw Was a Factor in Cyberattacks
text: Update | 1/15/10 11:57 a.m.  Clarifying that versions 6, 7, and 8 of Internet Explorer have the security flaw.

headline: Gran Turismo 5 Delayed Yet Again
text: For those video gamers who have waited patiently (or not so patiently) for nearly five years for the next installment of the esteemed racing simulation series Gran Turismo for Sony PlayStation, what’s another (fill in a number from one to 10 — then add “months” or “years”)?

headline: Waiting for Flexible Displays and Flexible Devices
text: Reports appeared online Friday of a new 19-inch flexible display that LG hopes to start integrating into new devices.

headline: For These 3, the Audacity of Nope
text: Here we are on yet another holiday weekend dedicated to celebrating the life and work of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., examining racial progress already made, and reflecting on how much remains to be done.

headline: On Stage: Aziz Ansari
text: An excerpt from the the comic's special, "Intimate Moments for a Sensual Moments," which premiered on Comedy Central in January.

headline: Senators Urge ‘Fail-Safe’ Provision in Case Savings Don’t Appear
text: Five Democratic senators urged the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, on Thursday to include a “fail-safe mechanism” in the final version of major health care legislation in order to guarantee the hundreds of billions of dollars in projected government savings that are intended to help pay for the bill.

headline: If California Owes You, It Would Like to Pay You
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Somewhere high in the snowy, mountainous wilds of Alpine County, Calif., there is a Californian with a piece of paper worth $1,305.

headline: Watch Out for That Disembodied Head, Girls
text: Delirious, deranged, gonzo or just gone, baby, gone  no single adjective or even a pileup does justice to “House,” a 1977 Japanese haunted-house freakout. Directed by Nobuhiko Obayashi, this energetic exemplar of pulp surrealism began surfacing in the United States last year, playing at events like the New York Asian Film Festival. Now, in advance of the Criterion DVD, which will be released later this year, it is receiving its first, must-see-now domestic theatrical run at the IFC Center in New York. A midnight movie in lysergic spirit and vibe, this was a film made for late-night screening and screaming.

headline: What’s That? 50 Degrees Isn’t Winter? Tell That to the People Shivering Here
text: NEW DELHI  Behind the counter of J & J Trading Company, an appliance wholesaler in a warren of electrical shops in Old Delhi, Rajinder Singh has no patience for customer service. A man eyeing the Turbo Hot Air asks for a test. Could the small metal heater be plugged in? Buy it first, Mr. Singh demands.

headline: Seven Years for a Lawyer
text: Remember Refco? That was a big scandal awhile back. In 2005, we learned that the owner of Refco, the commodities firm, had successfully hidden huge losses for years. The investors who bought the company’s public offering were the big losers.

headline: Big Brother and the Salt Shaker
text: The Bloomberg administration has announced an initiative to cut salt in packaged and restaurant foods by 25 percent over the next five years. Public health experts say these changes would reduce the incidence of high blood pressure and help prevent some strokes and heart attacks.

headline: Wall Street Gives Millions to Haiti Relief Efforts
text: As Haitians continue to reel from the massive earthquake that reduced much of its capital to rubble and killed an estimated tens of thousands of people, Wall Street firms are among those pledging millions of dollars to relief efforts.

headline: Time-Traveling With the Muses in Boston
text: BOSTON  You love art. When and where did that start? In school? At home? In books? For me it began when I was a kid in the 1950s and ’60s, before and during my teens. The primal scene was divided between two Boston museums where I spent a lot of time. I visited both again last week to check memory against reality and got a surprise: sometimes they match up.

headline: Toppled in Ukraine but Nearing a Comeback
text: DNEPRODZERZHINSK, Ukraine  Viktor F. Yanukovich was swept aside five years ago in the Orange Revolution, derided as a barrel-chested party boss and Kremlin stooge whose career was over as Ukraine embraced the West.

headline: Moving Through 'Fish Tank'
text: Katie Jarvis is featured in this dance scene from "Fish Tank," written and directed by Andrea Arnold

headline: Oscar Mayer Counts on the Joy, Not the Jingles
text: OSCAR MAYER, which has two of the most famous advertising jingles, is pushing them to the side as it introduces its biggest campaign to date.

headline: Google Move Gives Hope to Lawmakers
text: A quartet of House Republicans commended Google on Thursday for threatening to pull out of China earlier this week, saying the company’s actions could help spark the passage of legislation that aims to loosen the ties between American technology firms and countries that restrict human rights.

headline: Newspapers, Wire Services Add Staff in Haiti
text: With very few of their journalists based in Haiti and the country’s main airport closed to most flights after a major earthquake on Tuesday, most Western news organizations were caught out of place by the disaster. They resorted to chartering flights, asking for space on relief flights and even hitching rides with individual motorists. In most cases, they did not reach the devastated areas until the next day.

headline: Antitrust Questions for Monsanto
text: The Monsanto Company, the world’s largest seed producer, said on Thursday that the Justice Department had formally requested information on its herbicide-tolerant soybean seed business as part of an investigation into anticompetitive practices.

headline: For TV Networks, Haiti Story Brings Huge Mobilization
text: The Fox News correspondent Steve Harrigan is a veteran of the world’s worst calamities, but on television Thursday afternoon, as he stood beside one of the piles of rubble that pockmark Port-au-Prince, Haiti, he broke down.

headline: Reader Comments
text: Starting with this post, On the Runway is using a new commenting system. Readers of other Times blogs may be familiar with the new regime already, as it has quietly annexed many of our brethren. It’s also the same interface used for commenting on news articles.

headline: One Day at a Time
text: Mr. Pfeiffer discusses his morning routine and his role as White House blogger.

headline: Shiseido to Buy Bare Escentuals for $1.7 Billion
text: Shiseido said late Thursday that it has agreed to buy Bare Escentuals for $1.7 billion in cash, landing the Japanese cosmetics giant one of the biggest players in the world of mineral makeup.

headline: Fighting Illiteracy in Chicago, With Enthusiasm
text: Twice a month, Ava Zeligson stands in front of 55 strangers and, with her infectious enthusiasm, explains why each of them can make a difference in the battle against Chicago’s deeply entrenched illiteracy rate.

headline: Russian Attitudes Thaw on Rights Court
text: MOSCOW  The Russian Parliament is expected Friday to reverse its longstanding opposition to reforms in the European Court of Human Rights, as part of a new push to smooth over differences with the country’s European partners.

headline: Jordan: Israeli Vehicle Attacked
text: An Israeli Embassy vehicle was the target of a roadside bomb in Jordan on Thursday, but the explosion caused no injuries, the Israeli Foreign Ministry said. Several Israeli diplomats were heading in a convoy from Amman toward the border with Israel, Israel’s Army Radio reported. Jordan’s public information minister, Nabil Sharif, told Agence France-Presse that the bomb went off near the town of Naur, on the road between Amman and the Jordan Valley. He said an investigation was under way. The Israeli ambassador was not riding in the convoy at the time.

headline: Canada: Bomb Plot Leader Apologizes
text: A co-leader of a group that planned to bomb several targets in Ontario repeatedly apologized to Canadians and in particular to fellow Muslims at a sentencing hearing on Thursday. The man, Zakaria Amara, 24, said that his “naïve and gullible” interpretation of Islam led him to help form the group known as the Toronto 18. Mr. Amara, who pleaded guilty in October to terrorism and bombing charges, said that he was glad that he was arrested before causing any harm and that he had been changed by the time he had spent in prison. Prosecutors are seeking a life sentence for Mr. Amara.

headline: Directing the Message
text: He intends to maintain pattern of treating Fox News Channel differently.

headline: Iran: ‘Zionists’ Blamed for a Killing
text: The killing of a physicist this week appeared to have been carried out by Zionists, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said Thursday in his first public comments on the bomb attack. The “method of bombing” indicates “that Zionists did it and that they hate us and don’t want us to progress,” Mr. Ahmadinejad said, according to the news agency ISNA. The physicist, Masoud Ali Mohammadi, was buried Thursday amid heavy security. The government had blamed the United States and Israel for the killing on Tuesday. Two former presidents, Mohammad Khatami and Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, issued statements calling the assassination an act of terrorism but did not blame Israel or the United States. Mr. Rafsanjani called the assassination a sign of “a new era of intrigue.”

headline: Local Theaters Are Pulling Strings
text: The humble puppet, often crafted from rags, paper or even wire, is having its moment in Chicago theater. Once relegated to puppet-specific stages, the use of marionettes alongside actors in mainstream productions is “exploding,” said Roell Schmidt, the director of Links Hall performance space.

headline: Learning from the Past
text: No flight suits or ‘Mission Accomplished’ banners, Mr. Pfeiffer says.

headline: Shiseido Buys Manufacturer of Cosmetics
text: Shiseido, a Japanese cosmetics company, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Bare Escentuals, one of the biggest players in the world of mineral makeup, for $1.7 billion.

headline: A Spouse Down The Hall
text: The advantages - and disadvantages - of sharing a West Wing workplace with his wife.

headline: A Composer Embracing the 12-Tone Technique
text: Continuum, the new-music group that specializes in thematic programming and composer portraits, devoted its Wednesday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall to Ursula Mamlok, a German-born American composer who turns 87 on Feb. 1. Ms. Mamlok remains an eloquent advocate of the 12-tone technique, though in a modified form that pulls her music toward an almost neo-Romantic warmth.

headline: Arne Duncan Challenges the N.C.A.A.
text: Education Secretary Arne Duncan has been around the schoolyards and gyms in Chicago, has seen players who could have made more of themselves, in basketball and in life.

headline: Judge Orders F.D.A. to Stop Blocking Imports of E-Cigarettes From China
text: A federal judge on Thursday ordered the Food and Drug Administration to stop blocking the importation of electronic cigarettes from China and indicated that the devices should be regulated as tobacco products rather than drug or medical devices.

headline: Bank Chief Says Greece Gets No Special Treatment
text: FRANKFURT  Greece should not expect any special favors from the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, the bank’s president, said Thursday. But as Greek leaders presented a plan to drastically lower the country’s debt, Mr. Trichet called speculation that it might have to leave the European monetary union “absurd.”

headline: Filling Shopping Carts, and a Community Need
text: Not long ago it would have seemed inconceivable to Laura Martinez, a councilwoman here, that anyone would come to East Palo Alto to shop for food. Even Ms. Martinez and her family usually left town to do that.

headline: Four-Legged Survivors of Hurricane Katrina
text: One from the heart, the documentary “Mine” relates yet one more wrenching, infuriating story about Hurricane Katrina and the devastation wreaked both by the storm and by human error and indifference. While many victims in the movie will look familiar  whether waving from their New Orleans rooftops after the levees broke in 2005 or talking about their ruined lives and homes afterward  the majority of the victims here have usually been seen only in the background, forlornly howling and wagging their tails.

headline: Some Card Fees Waived for Haiti Aid
text: After being criticized for siphoning off up to 3 percent of charitable donations for transaction fees, the nation’s largest payment networks — Visa, MasterCard, American Express and Discover — announced that they would waive fees for some contributions aimed at aiding Haiti in the wake of a devastating earthquake. So more of the money you donate will find its way to the organizations providing relief.

headline: Foster Care Faltering and Other Issues From Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: Inadequate Foster Care Support Hits Bay Area Children Hard | In a familiar tale for cash-strapped California, the foster care system has been coming apart as because of inadequate state financing for at least 20 years, officials at the county level said. In the past two months, a succession of court decisions in favor of care providers lifted hopes that the judicial rulings might finally turn things around, but the lawsuits have simultaneously shed light on a system that has been cut to the bone. Jill Duerr Berrick, a professor in the School of Social Welfare at the University of California, Berkeley, said, “The supply and demand problem is so pressing that a child services agency is not always capable of finding the type of care that a child needs.” The Excell Center outside Turlock is one place that makes the finances work, but at the price of putting San Francisco children 110 miles from their roots.

headline: Bankers Without a Clue
text: The official Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission  the group that aims to hold a modern version of the Pecora hearings of the 1930s, whose investigations set the stage for New Deal bank regulation  began taking testimony on Wednesday. In its first panel, the commission grilled four major financial-industry honchos. What did we learn?

headline: The Story Behind the Obama Bank Tax
text: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Financial Difficulties Strain California’s Foster Care System
text: In the summer of 2008, a 13-year-old boy from San Francisco emerged from a government van and scanned his new surroundings. Five handsome houses, a small school and an old gymnasium stood on 11 rural acres in the Central Valley that bordered an almond orchard.

headline: Intel’s Bet on Innovation Pays Off in Faster Chips
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  At about this time last year, Intel’s board decided to invest $7 billion in new chip plants in Oregon, Arizona and New Mexico.

headline: Museums and Lawmakers Mull Sales of Art
text: It was once considered unthinkable: the notion of a museum selling off parts of its collection to pay the bills. But the recession has forced some institutions to do that  or at least consider it  and members of the New York State Legislature have been trying to draft a bill that would regulate such deaccessioning of artworks and artifacts.

headline: International Espionage? Kids Are Much Harder
text: The blooper reel that plays alongside the end credits of a Jackie Chan movie  a good-humored flurry of blown stunts and botched lines  is always amusing. In some cases, though, it’s more fun than what has come before, and in “The Spy Next Door” the outtakes are not all that great but still better than anything else in the movie.

headline: Catholics Gather Courtside to Put Their Faith on Display
text: There was no neutral zone for mere spectators. On one side were thousands decked in green, representing the Fighting Irish of Sacred Heart Cathedral Preparatory. Across the basketball court were an equal number in red and blue for the Wildcats of St. Ignatius College Preparatory.

headline: Obama to House Democrats: Buck Up
text: Like most political junkies, President Obama said he keeps an eye on the blogs and the cable shows. So, he assured anxious House Democrats on Thursday, he fully understands what they have been going through in the tumultuous health care debate.

headline: U.S. Official Says Talks on Emissions Show Promise
text: Todd Stern, the chief American climate change negotiator, said Thursday that the flawed and incomplete agreement reached last month in Copenhagen could provide significant benefits if countries followed through on its provisions.

headline: King Birthday Events
text: Big plans for the long weekend, or has Martin Luther King’s Birthday become more about cleaning the closet or clearing the Netflix queue than about honoring the civil rights leader? How about this: clean and clear on Saturday and Sunday, but leave Monday for Dr. King.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: In Power Push, Movement Sees Base in G.O.P.
text: HOLLAND, Pa.  The Tea Party movement ignited a year ago, fueled by anti-establishment anger. Now, Tea Party activists are trying to take over the establishment, ground up.

headline: Yemen: Clerics Oppose U.S. Troops
text: Several dozen Yemeni clerics, including the influential hard-line figure Abdel Majid al-Zindani, above, issued a statement on Thursday saying they would call for jihad, or holy war, if the United States sent troops to fight Al Qaeda in Yemen. President Obama has said he does not plan to send troops to Yemen, although the United States does provide training, intelligence and military hardware to help Yemen fight militants.

headline: Iraqi Commission Bars Nearly 500 Candidates
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s independent electoral commission on Thursday barred about 500 candidates from running in parliamentary elections in March, among them an influential Sunni Muslim politician, in a decision that could stoke sectarian tensions here and deprive the vote of crucial legitimacy in the eyes of part of the electorate.

headline: Expecting the Big One
text: THOUGH it can offer scant comfort to the victims of the earthquake in Haiti, seismology is making some slight progress in its search for the holy grail of being able to predict dreadful events like that on Tuesday. New studies into ultra-slow-motion events deep underground called nonvolcanic tremors are showing vague but promising signs that the same kind of subterranean danger signals that allow us today to forecast when a volcano is about to erupt may one day offer some warning of the hitherto unpredictable nucleation  the explosive beginning  of an earthquake.

headline: Accord Reached on Insurance Tax for Costly Plans
text: WASHINGTON  The White House, Congressional leaders and labor unions said Thursday that they had reached agreement on a proposal to tax high-cost health insurance policies, resolving one of the major differences between the House and the Senate over far-reaching health legislation.

headline: A Councilman’s Aide Extends a Lifeline All the Way to Haiti
text: For two hours on Thursday morning, Carline Keil tried to help Alex Alexis get a passport. His wife and three children lived in Haiti, and he had heard nothing since the quake struck two days before. There was nothing left to do but go there.

headline: Wizards’ Arenas Is Charged With Felony
text: Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards has been charged with felony gun possession in connection with his recent dispute with a teammate.

headline: Demonstrators Press for Haitian Advocate’s Release
text: Against the backdrop of the earthquake in Haiti, dozens of protesters gathered outside a Greenwich Village detention center on Thursday to demand the release of Jean Montrevil, a Haitian immigrant rights advocate and a community leader in New York who has been detained since December while awaiting deportation.

headline: Bonfire of the Bureaucrats
text: When the Berlin Wall unexpectedly fell 20 years ago, a German friend of mine made a sage observation: The Communists opened the wall for the same reason they had raised it 28 years earlier — to keep East Germans from fleeing west. The fact is that the “Ossies” had been streaming out of East Germany throughout that fall of 1989 through cracks in the Iron Curtain opened by Mikhail Gorbachev’s pere­stroika. Unable any longer to halt this hemorrhage by force, the desperate German leaders gambled that if they let their people visit the West from time to time, they might not wish to flee East Germany at every opportunity. The Politburo official assigned to announce the new rules on Nov. 9, 1989, botched it, giving the impression that the wall had been thrown open. East Berliners rushed to the crossings, a bewildered officer opened the gate, and the rest is — literally — history.

headline: For Google, a Threat to China With Little Revenue at Stake
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has said principle drove its threat to back out of China unless the government there allowed it to run its search engine without censorship.

headline: Stark Claustrophobia in the Family Cross-Fire
text: Per Kirkeby’s striking visual designs for Peter Martins’s “Romeo + Juliet” are neither pretty nor opulent, two things that sadly seem to have become prerequisites for big narrative ballets.

headline: A Call for a Monserrate Expulsion Vote, but He Says He Won’t Go Quietly
text: The political fate of State Senator Hiram Monserrate, a Queens Democrat convicted of assault in a dispute that left his companion with a gash on her face, grew uncertain on Thursday as a special committee recommended that the Senate vote soon on a motion to expel him.

headline: A Passion for Candy
text: Although we have always craved sweets, until the Industrial Revolution many of us made do with candy manufactured by bees, that most industrious of species. Factories and assembly lines made modern candy at once possible and necessary, even though candy contains few nutrients and is bad for our teeth. Now that we’re all fat and the earth is melting, we’re supposed to be off candy for good. Ordinary candy is just for Halloween; high-end candy, nestled in luxury boxes, is marketed as a sex substitute. But Alice Tatnall Ziplinsky, the narrator of Katharine Weber’s new novel, “True Confections,” knows better. Candy makes people happy.

headline: In Miami, Eager Helpers Meet Difficulties
text: MIAMI  The Rev. Reginald Jean-Mary had no time on Thursday to think about his mother, two sisters and a brother still missing somewhere in the ruins of the Haitian capital. He was busy trying to find a shipping container, consoling dozens of parishioners who lost loved ones in the earthquake-ravaged nation and organizing a team of nurses and doctors to send there.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Children Who Changed the World
text: In the winter and early spring of 1965, Alabama schoolchildren and teen­agers by the hundreds played a significant role in one of the civil rights movement’s pivotal victories: the march on Montgomery that crystallized Congressional support for voters’ rights legislation. In chronicling this episode primarily from the young participants’ perspective, Elizabeth Partridge takes the past off its pedestal and shows how ordinary people, children among them, can sometimes tip the balance and help determine the outcome of events.

headline: ‘Aunt Leaf’'
text: ‘AUNT LEAF’

headline: Seize the Time
text: Mothers. Can’t live with them. Can’t live without them. Yet 11-year-old Delphine and her younger sisters Vonetta and Fern have done just fine without theirs. Cecile, a poet, walked out on them just after Fern was born. Now, in the summer of 1968, their father, with the reluctant agreement of their grandmother, has decided that the three girls need to leave their Brooklyn home to spend a few weeks with their mother in Oakland, Calif., to get to know her.

headline: Dance Away the Heartache
text: A few recent movie performances suggest that a crop of young, first-time actors might be giving professionals a run for their money. There was Gabourey Sidibe’s turn in “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” and now there is Katie Jarvis. The teenager  discovered while having a fight with her boyfriend on the street in England  plays Mia, the 15-year old protagonist in “Fish Tank,” “Andrea Arnold’s tough and brilliant second feature,” A. O. Scott writes. In the movie, Mia “moves with such speed and fury that she seems to be trying to flee not only from her bleak surroundings but also from the movie itself.” The film offers a harsh brand of realism, “a world made familiar by the films of Ken Loach, Mike Leigh and other socially conscious anatomists of British misery.” Mia lives with her mother and sister in “a cramped apartment in a British housing project that stands like a cluster of megaliths in the middle of nowhere.” It also stars Michael Fassbender, recently of “Inglourious Basterds,” but it is the performance by Ms. Jarvis that makes this movie “a diamond-hard reflection on the peril and progress of a fragile soul in a bad situation.”

headline: Break Into the Vault
text: While you’re wandering around Brooklyn this Saturday searching for the perfect brunch spot, duck inside One Hanson Place where the Brooklyn Flea Market has recently set up shop. Below the historic space, which was once home to the Williamsburg Savings Bank and is now a historic landmark, hides a of food court worthy of the borough’s most sophisticated palates. The collection of carefully curated street-food includes Asian hot dogs dressed with kimchi, lobster rolls from Red Hook, fried fish tacos, hot Neapolitan-style pizza and more and can all be savored inside what was once the bank’s vault. It’s a cool setting and what’s above isn’t so bad either. Vintage clothing and furniture, records and costume jewelry, photographs and other random goods are arranged inside the largest building in Brooklyn, which dates to 1927. Admire the marble and mosaics under the vaulted ceilings while you eat and shop. It’s certainly better than waiting an hour for runny eggs.

headline: A Goonie Sings
text: Martha Plimpton is an actress who has demonstrated her versatility. The native New Yorker and “Goonies” alumnus has appeared in musicals like “Pal Joey” and serious dramas like “Cymbeline” and “The Coast of Utopia,” as well as a slew of feature films. On Saturday she’ll be at Lincoln Center performing a one-night-only concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center as part of its American Songbook series. Expect a night of songs and stories from Ms. Plimpton’s childhood growing up in the ’70s amid show-biz types in Manhattan. There are two shows, one at 8:30 p.m. and another at 10:30 p.m.

headline: Arguments at Court
text: Perry v. Schwarzenegger, the case challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, unfolded this week in a federal courtroom in San Francisco. The opening statements from dueling legal teams, expert opinions from academics and deeply personal testimonies from four gay plaintiffs were heard by Judge Vaughn R. Walker, but they were not seen by a YouTube audience, after the Supreme Court barred broadcasting the proceedings.

headline: Paterson Has More Than $3 Million in War Chest
text: Gov. David A. Paterson’s campaign reported on Thursday evening that he had more than $3 million on hand, a sharp drop in his available cash from the amount he had in the middle of last year and a development that was likely to increase doubts among Democrats about his political viability.

headline: Jersey Girls
text: New Jersey is a teenage state: it looks awkward in places, has questionable ethics from time to time and plays perennial underdog to New York. Perhaps this is why it’s home to so much good young adult literature, to which we can add Beth Ann Bauman’s novel, “Rosie and Skate.” Set on the Jersey Shore after the tourists have gone home, the novel uses the empty storefronts and windy beaches of autumn to explore loss, confusion and love as two sisters struggle with their alcoholic father and try out adult roles they are not quite ready for.

headline: Children’s Bookshelf
text: HERE COMES JACK FROST  Written and illustrated by Kazuno Kohara.  Roaring Brook. $12.99.(Ages 3 to 6)

headline: Morgue Becomes Mountain of Anguish
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  With chilling regularity, a pickup truck from the Haitian police or a taxi driver with a station wagon pulled up to deliver more bodies to the morgue. Flies buzzed on many of the bodies. Civil servants unloaded the cargo, their expressions hidden by white surgical masks.

headline: Ex-Anchor Jailed in Assault of Wife
text: SUFFERN, N.Y.  Dominic Carter, a former political anchor for NY1 accused of beating his wife, was led away in handcuffs on Thursday as he immediately began a 30-day sentence in the Rockland County Jail.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Beneath the Lion’s Gaze’
text: A review on Jan. 3 misstated, at one point, part of the title of the novel by Maaza Mengiste, set during and after the reign of the Ethiopian emperor Haile Selassie. As noted in the review, it is “Beneath the Lion’s Gaze,” not “Under the Lion’s Gaze.”

headline: Planned U.S. Tax Might Hurt Europe’s Banks Less
text: Europe’s Edge

headline: Indie Rock From Florida, but, Please, No Surfing
text: The Drums and Surfer Blood are bands so deep into the hype-cycle wormhole that they have to spend time denying misperceptions that they themselves have perpetuated. So what they want you to know is this: They’re not really interested in surfing.

headline: For the Jets’ Weatherford, Metallica Is Off the Playlist
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The heart rate of Steve Weatherford, the Jets’ punter who loves heavy metal rock and has a huge “Carpe Diem” tattoo on his left biceps, has returned to normal, but Jay Feely, the Jets’ place-kicker, is still joking that he is taking no chances.

headline: After Google’s Stand on China, U.S. Treads Lightly
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Last month, when Google engineers at their sprawling campus in Silicon Valley began to suspect that Chinese intruders were breaking into private Gmail accounts, the company began a secret counteroffensive.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘The Bauhaus Group’
text: A review on Dec. 27 about “The Bauhaus Group,” by Nicholas Fox Weber, misstated the early financial circumstances of Mies van der Rohe, the Bauhaus’s last director. Though his father, a middle-class stone­mason, suffered a financial reverse when Mies was a child, Mies was not “born in poverty.”

headline: Obama Pledges Aid to Haiti
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday promised $100 million along with more American troops for the relief effort in Haiti, vowing that the United States would stand with the impoverished nation as it grappled with the devastation of its capital city.

headline: House Music All Night: Stage as a Dance Club
text: Dixon Place isn’t a dance club, but the choreographer Niles Ford tried his best to turn it into one on Wednesday night in his energetic homage to nightlife, “In Search of the Invisible People.” Described in press materials as a “danceumentary,” the work, a collaboration with the choreographer Nathan Trice, explores house music and the thriving dance scene of the 1970s and ’80s.

headline: Burst of Mobile Giving Adds Millions in Relief Funds
text: Old-fashioned television telethons can stretch on for hours. But the latest charity appeal is short enough for Twitter: “Text HAITI to 90999 to donate $10 to @RedCross relief.”

headline: Report Says 9 Million Books Pirated Online
text: A study by a company that helps track pirated digital books estimates that there were 9 million illegal downloads of copyrighted books in the final months of last year. Attributor, which works for publishers including Hachette Book Group and John Wiley & Sons, scanned 25 Web sites that offer readers downloadable content, looking for 913 titles across categories ranging from business and investing to fiction. It found, for example, that illegal copies of “Freakonomics,” by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner, were downloaded 1,082 times and “Angels & Demons,” by Dan Brown, 7,951 times. The study did not track any titles published by the company’s clients, which would exclude the oft-pirated “Twilight” series published by Hachette. Rich Pearson, general manager of Attributor, said although not every pirated copy represented a lost sale, the potential loss to the publishing industry could be as high as $3 billion. Some analysts doubted that piracy was as big a problem for the book industry as the study suggested. Mike Shatzkin, chief executive of Idea Logical Company, a book industry consultant, said many people who might illegally download an e-book would never have bought it in the first place.

headline: Media Struggle to Convey a Disaster
text: The Fox News correspondent Steve Harrigan is a veteran of the world’s worst calamities, but on television on Thursday afternoon, as he stood beside one of the piles of rubble that pockmark Port-au-Prince, Haiti, he broke down.

headline: She’s Got Castanets, So Let Carmen Dance
text: In his overture to “Carmen,” Bizet introduces a recurring motif that listeners have invariably associated with fate and with the fatal liaison of Carmen and Don José. The composer meant it to be played with the curtain lowered. Then, as the stage action proceeds, he develops it powerfully, bringing it back often, in hauntingly different versions: like a flash of lightning, like a slow but tremendous warning, like an irresistible undertow.

headline: Pentagon Steps Up Talks on Ending ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is stepping up internal discussions on how gay men and lesbians might be able to serve openly in the armed services, military officials said on Thursday, in anticipation of fulfilling President Obama’s campaign pledge to repeal the “don’t ask, don’t tell” law.

headline: The Underlying Tragedy
text: On Oct. 17, 1989, a major earthquake with a magnitude of 7.0 struck the Bay Area in Northern California. Sixty-three people were killed. This week, a major earthquake, also measuring a magnitude of 7.0, struck near Port-au-Prince, Haiti. The Red Cross estimates that between 45,000 and 50,000 people have died.

headline: Into the Closet
text: Has anyone noticed that now that lesbians and gay men have left the closet to assert their equal rights as citizens, their adversaries seem to be running for a closet of their own?

headline: Clooney to Organize a Telethon for Haiti
text: Reached by telephone on Thursday evening, Stan Rosenfield, longtime publicist for George Clooney, confirmed that Mr. Clooney was scrambling to organize a Jan. 22 telethon to benefit victims of the Haiti earthquake.

headline: Executive Leaps to Leno’s Defense
text: PASADENA, Calif.  The verbal battle in the late-night wars got louder Thursday as a top NBC executive struck back against on-air attacks on the network’s once and future “Tonight Show” host Jay Leno.

headline: Could This Be the End of the Celebrity Mobster?
text: Predicting the demise of the Mafia is like predicting the demise of the “Rocky” franchise: Every time you think you have finally heard the last of it, it rears its ugly head.

headline: Immigrants in Detention to Be Sent Out of State
text: Immigration and Customs Enforcement will close a controversial detention center in Greenwich Village next month and transfer the center’s roughly 300 detainees to a county jail in New Jersey, federal officials announced on Thursday.

headline: 3rd-Party Candidate Named Kennedy Could Tip Senate Race in Massachusetts
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  In most elections, a politician calling himself the Tea Party candidate would cheer Democrats, raising hopes that he would siphon votes from Republicans by attracting some of the disaffected anti-Washington, anti-Obama electorate.

headline: Labor Panel Is Stalled by Dispute on Nominee
text: A dispute involving Senator John McCain has left the National Labor Relations Board unable to decide its most important cases.

headline: Vikings’ Allen at Top of His Game and Seeking His Next Adventure
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  For a guy who can bring down an elk with a spear and a buffalo with a crossbow  check out his YouTube videos  Minnesota Vikings defensive end Jared Allen’s aim with a Nerf basketball can be shaky. That is the story Vikings linebacker Ben Leber tells, anyway.

headline: Possibility of Plots Prompts More Checks for Explosives at Airports
text: WASHINGTON  The Department of Homeland Security moved Thursday to increase random checks for explosives at American airports after officials cited a heightened concern over possible terror plots against the aviation system.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 3: Death in the Streets
text: Marc Lacey reports on the scenes of life, death and rescue on Port-au-Prince's streets.

headline: Immigrant-Services Groups and Their Founder Are Frauds, Suit Says
text: Over the past 25 years, Edward Juarez-Pagliocco built a reputation as a national expert on immigrant affairs. His work earned him keys to cities in Florida and New Jersey, he had a radio show on WPAT-FM (93.1) in New York, and he wrote an immigration column for El Diario La Prensa, the Spanish-language daily.

headline: 52 Across: Set Sail
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — As a rule, the maximum number of answers and black squares in a Times themeless puzzle is 72 and 32 respectively (it’s 78 and 38 for Monday-to-Thursday puzzles). However, constructors sometimes aim much lower. The record for fewest answers is 52; the record for fewest black squares is 18. Given a choice between the two, my solving preference is for the few-black-squares variety, since the mix of letters and words can still be fairly interesting, whereas a puzzle with few answers will always have a very high common-letter count.

headline: A Blind Mother of Two Who Makes Her Own Way
text: Rahkiya Rawlins, legally blind since birth, has found ways of navigating the world.

headline: Declaration of Indies: Just Sell It Yourself!
text: LAST November inside a conference room at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, a film consultant named Peter Broderick was doing his best to foment a revolution. Mr. Broderick, who helps filmmakers find their way into the marketplace, was spreading the word on an Internet-era approach to releasing movies that he believes empowers filmmakers without impoverishing them economically or emotionally. Mr. Broderick divides distribution into the Old World and New, infusing his PowerPoint presentation with insurgent rhetoric. He has written a “declaration of independence” for filmmakers that  as he did that afternoon  he reads while wearing a tricorn hat.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a lowering of standards for high school exit exams in many states misstated, in some copies, the annual increase in the number of dropouts for which recent studies blame the exams. It ranges from 35,000 to 70,000 nationwide  not per state.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about Google’s threat to withdraw from China misstated the given name of the White House’s choice for Internet security adviser. He is Howard A. Schmidt, not Robert. The article also misspelled, in some editions, the name of the spiritual leader of the Gelug sect of Tibetan Buddhism, whose computers are suspected of having been attacked by the Chinese government. He is the Dalai Lama, not the Dali Lama.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the end of the worst drought in Texas in 50 years reversed the descriptions of La Niña and El Niño as well as their effect on the drought there. La Niña is the phenomenon that occurs when surface water temperatures along the equator in the Pacific Ocean are below normal, and it was what helped create the drought the past two winters. El Niño is a weather pattern that occurs because of the warming of the Pacific waters, and it was responsible for bringing rain to Texas this winter.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about a portrait, once believed by some scholars to be the work of Leonardo da Vinci, that is to be auctioned by Sotheby’s on Jan. 28, misidentified, at one point, the century in which it was thought to have been painted. It was the 15th century, not the 14th.

headline: Conan O’Brien’s Barbs Keep Coming
text: Conan O’Brien kept up the patter of jokes related to his late-night contretemps Thursday night:

headline: Catherine Deneuve, No Time for Chic
text: PARIS

headline: Editors’ Note
text: Several articles in the past year about the government’s plans to overhaul the health care system quoted Jonathan Gruber, identifying him as a professor of economics at M.I.T. On Friday, Professor Gruber confirmed reports that he is also a paid consultant on health care issues for the Department of Health and Human Services. Had editors been aware of his government work, the articles would have disclosed this relationship to readers.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about a play by the journalist and author John Conroy inspired by his reporting about accusations that some members of the Chicago Police Department tortured suspects in the 1970s and ’80s misstated, in some editions, the given name of the playwright who wrote “Copenhagen” in citing other morality plays. He is Michael Frayn, not Peter.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Monday about Art Clokey, the animator who created Gumby, using information from his production company, misstated the year he made the animated film “Gumbasia.” It was 1953, not 1955. The obituary also misidentified the materials used to make the title characters of the animated series “Davey and Goliath,” which Mr. Clokey produced with his wife, Ruth. The characters were puppets made of foam and other materials; they were not made of clay.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: Making Darwin the Legend a Man Again
text: PALE, winded, a blanket draped across his twitching knees, a sick, despondent man confides his woes to the minister who has stopped by. Stretching a sympathetic arm around the man’s shoulders, the minister murmurs, “God moves in mysterious ways.”

headline: From an Owner to the Quietest Sports Emperor
text: MORA, Mo.  This is not so much a hometown as a home road cut into the corn and bean fields two hours southeast of Kansas City. It is an isolated place  unincorporated, population 25  yet it has produced one of the country’s richest men, the owner of an aspiring global sports empire.

headline: Blacks Try to Retain Power as Board Race Splits Community
text: No matter how deep the snow, icy the sidewalks or wicked the wind, nothing was going to keep 76-year-old Mary L. Johnson away from Wallace’s Catfish Corner on Friday night.

headline: Former Bills Coach Picked to Revive Giants’ Defense
text: Perry Fewell will replace the dismissed Bill Sheridan as defensive coordinator of the Giants, the team announced Thursday night. Fewell, 47, was the interim coach of the Buffalo Bills for the last seven games after the firing of Dick Jauron.

headline: Cuomo’s War Chest Is Five Times as Big as Paterson’s
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has not formally announced his candidacy for governor, but he is already running ahead in the fund-raising race.

headline: Lottery Numbers
France, Grudgingly, Imagines Google as a Partner on Digital Media Projects
text: PARIS  As France slowly brings its cultural past and present into digital form, it is realizing that the job will require support from a company often viewed with deep suspicion here: Google.

headline: Chicago Withdraws From World Cup Bid
text: Less than three months after failing in a bid to host the 2016 Summer Olympics, civic leaders took Chicago out of the competition to host World Cup soccer games in 2018 or 2022.

headline: New Jersey Man Sentenced to 18 Years for Real Estate Fraud
text: Wayne D. Puff, who ran a huge Ponzi scheme fueled by the free-flowing money of the subprime mortgage era, was sentenced on Thursday to 18 years in federal prison and ordered to pay more than $100 million in restitution to his victims.

headline: Whose Bonuses Are They?
text: Maybe bankers do know a little bit about shame  or at least about public opinion polls.

headline: A Street-Level Campaign Intends to Take on Bigotry
text: It seems inconceivable that Chicago, aptly tagged “Beirut by the Lake” during the race-driven Council Wars of the mid-1980s, might serve as a national model of multicultural cooperation. This is why a passionate, pragmatic and well-financed coalition merits our attention.

headline: Help Haitians Help Haiti
text: Editor's Note, Jan. 15, 2010: In a  statement today, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano announced that Haitians in the United States as of Jan. 12, the day of the earthquake, could apply for temporary protected status.

headline: Sentenced to Abuse
text: The Justice Department needs to act swiftly and decisively to protect young people who are being battered and raped in juvenile corrections facilities all across the country. A shocking new study by the Justice Department’s Bureau of Justice Statistics surveyed more than 9,000 young people in custody and found that 12 percent reported being sexually abused one or more times, mainly by staff members.

headline: Albany’s Club
text: Pretty much everyone knows by now that the New York State Legislature is corrupt and dysfunctional. But it doesn’t end there. It seems every week that New Yorkers learn about another state legislator who has brought shame to the state  or worse. (Let’s not forget the felony convictions only last month of Joseph Bruno, the former Republican leader.)

headline: A Lifeline to Haiti: The Offers Pour In
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Latest Gadgets to Distract Drivers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Promoting Clean Energy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Civilization on a Fault Line
text: Madison, Wis.

headline: After Almost Quitting, Weir Executes a Career Pirouette
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  If his mother had not talked some sense into him last spring, Johnny Weir would not be at the United States figure skating national championships right now.

headline: Lawsuit Challenges Marketing of Stents
text: A former medical device executive claimed in a potential whistle-blower lawsuit that was unsealed this week that the makers of stents approved to treat digestive tract cancers had illegally marketed them for years to treat blocked blood vessels in other parts of the body.

headline: Biologic Drugs May Get Less Protection
text: President Obama is pushing for a last-minute change in the final health care bill that would shorten the time that expensive biotechnology drugs would be shielded from generic competition, pharmaceutical industry officials said Thursday.

headline: Senators Slip Late Goal Past Lundqvist to Top the Punchless Rangers
text: There can be a big difference between 0-0 games, even if they both feature goaltenders named Brodeur.

headline: A Mother and Daughter Look Ahead
text: Legally blind since birth, Rahkiya Rawlins, 36, has raised two children by herself. She is taking computer classes at the Catholic Guild for the Blind, an agency supported by the Neediest Cases Fund.

headline: Cuba Allows American Flyovers From Haiti
text: The United States has struck an agreement with the Cuban government to send medical evacuation flights with victims from the Haiti earthquake through restricted Cuban airspace, an official said, reducing the flight time to Miami by 90 minutes.

headline: Cuba Allows American Flyovers From Haiti
text: Jeff Zeleny has the word in The Lede blog about the Cuban government letting American planes use Cuban airspace to ferry victims of the earthquake to the United States for treatment.

headline: M.T.A. to Test Eliminating Tollbooths, Relying on E-ZPass
text: The mere mention of the words “toll plaza” can annoy even the most jaded New York drivers.

headline: All Things Design
text: Images from "Design USA: Contemporary Innovation" at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum.

headline: The Stars of the Circus
text: The Big Apple Circus has returned to Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center with a new show, "Bello Is Back!"

headline: Art, Downtown
text: A show at the Grey Art Gallery reminds us what the arts communities in the East Village, SoHo and TriBeCa were like at the height of the AIDS epidemic.

headline: An Interview With Timothy F. Geithner
text: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times interviews Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner.

headline: Showcase: Dark Screens, Bright Memories
text: Twelve years ago, Carl Weese parked his truck off Route 8 in rural Connecticut and stood in a field. Something peculiar had caught his eye.

headline: The Scene on Arrival in Port-au-Prince
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Flying into Toussaint L’Ouverture International Airport on Thursday night, a patchwork of lights ringed the bay of Port-au-Prince, offering one of the few glimmers of hope in a city that had been pitch black the night before.

headline: Word of the Day | dilute
text: dilute •\di-ˈlüt, də-\• verb and adjective

headline: Cuba Agrees to U.S. Medevac Flights
text: WASHINGTON    The United States has struck an agreement with the Cuban government to send medical evacuation flights with victims from the Haiti earthquake through restricted Cuban airspace, an official said, reducing the flight time to Miami by 90 minutes.

headline: Is Making San Diego Throw the Jets’ Best Path to a Victory?
text: “This is one of the top pass offenses…. the No. 1 pass offense and we’re No. 1 against the pass. Something’s gotta give and I think our guys are looking forward to the test.” — The Jets’ defensive coordinator, Mike Pettine

headline: Dennis Stock, Photographer of Intimate Portraits, Dies at 81
text: Dennis Stock, a photographer whose intimate and evocative portraits captured the essence of jazz performance and helped shape James Dean’s moody public persona, died Monday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 81.

headline: Bernanke Defends Fed’s Oversight Role
text: Facing renewed calls from Washington to limit its authority, the Federal Reserve on Thursday defended its role as one of Wall Street’s chief watchdogs and said being able to monitor the health of banks was crucial to setting sound monetary policy.

headline: Where Would You Most Like to Go in the World?
text: The travel section’s recommendations for “31 Places to Go in 2010″ may be out of your reach right now, but this is an invitation to dream. Where would you most like to go in the world and why?

headline: Taxing Banks for the Bailout
text: President Obama laid down his proposal for a new tax on the nation’s largest financial institutions on Thursday, saying he wanted “to recover every single dime the American people are owed” for bailing out the economy, Jackie Calmes writes in The New York Times.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: Articles on Dec. 28, 29 and 30, about the apparent bombing attempt on a flight to Detroit, discussed the use of full-body scanners for airport security. They cited Michael Chertoff, the former secretary of homeland security, as supporting wider use of the scanners. Mr. Chertoff has confirmed in several recent interviews that a manufacturer of the devices is a client of his consulting company. That connection should have been noted in the articles.

headline: A Window Opens on Pay for Bosses
text: Is it possible that shareholders will finally get a reliable view of what the bosses are getting paid? And that it will come this spring?

headline: Pearson Says I.D.C. Conducting ‘Strategic Review’
text: Pearson, the British publisher of Penguin books and The Financial Times, said Friday that its majority-owned unit Interactive Data Corporation was reviewing strategic alternatives, suggesting that a sale of the publicly-traded provider of financial market data could be in the offing.

headline: Patience Wears Thin as Desperation Grows
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As tension rose here in the battered Haitian capital, relief workers scrambled on Friday to deliver desperately needed food, water and medical care, recover survivors still trapped in the rubble and collect thousands of decaying bodies from the streets.

headline: CDC Software Withdraws Offer to Buy Chordiant
text: CDC Software, a Chinese business software developer, said Thursday that it had withdrawn a recent offer to buy Chordiant Software and sold its 1.3 percent stake in the company.

headline: Citadel in Talks to Hire Aksia Co-Founder, Report Says

text: Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge-fund firm, said assets fell 4 percent in the final three months of 2009 as its largest fund posted its first annual loss, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: 18 Years in Prison for Running New Jersey Ponzi Scheme
text: Wayne D. Puff, who ran a huge Ponzi scheme fueled by the free-flowing money of the subprime mortgage era, was sentenced on Thursday to 18 years in federal prison and ordered to pay more than $100 million in restitution to his victims.

headline: From an Owner to the Quietest Sports Emperor

It is an isolated place — unincorporated, population 25 — yet it has produced one of the country’s richest men, the owner of an aspiring global sports empire, The New York Times’s Jeré Longman writes.

headline: Planned U.S. Tax Might Hurt Europe’s Banks Less

headline: E-Trade Acquires, and Shutters, Cake Financial

headline: Technology Helps Shares Higher as Retailers Slip
text: Stocks advanced for a second day as technology shares climbed before Intel reported earnings. In addition, business inventories increased more than forecast, overshadowing an unexpected drop in retail sales.

headline: N. Korea Threatens to Halt All Talks With Seoul
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea, denouncing South Korea for drawing up a contingency plan to deal with the potential collapse of the North’s government, warned Friday that it would cut off all dialogue with the South and exclude it from all negotiations concerning the security of the Korean Peninsula. North Korea will also wage a “pan-national holy war of retaliation to blow away” the South Korean government, said a statement from the North’s highest ruling agency, the National Defense Commission, which is headed by the national leader, Kim Jong-il.

O’Brien reported.

It’s been particularly vocal about the drawbacks of plug-in hybrids.

headline: Sampler: Oakland Child Care Receives a Boost and the Sea Lion Party Will Wait
text: The Economics of Same-Sex Marriage Ban | Legalizing same-sex marriage would be an economic boost to San Francisco, said Edmund A. Egan, the chief economist for the City and County of San Francisco, who testified on Thursday in federal court in San Francisco. On Friday, lawyers for those seeking to overturn California’s ban on same-sex marriage are expected to call William Tam, a proponent in the Proposition 8 campaign. That 2008 ballot initiative, approved by 52 percent of the voters, changed California’s constitution to define marriage as being between a man and a woman. Also, Linda Greenhouse, in the Opinionator, looks at the drama around the Supreme Court ruling on Wednesday to prohibit the broadcasting of trial coverage and the court’s consideration of an appeal by same-sex marriage opponents in Washington State who seek to bar the public disclosure of petition signers. [The New York Times, The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: The Time for Bonus-Whacking Has Passed

headline: One Singular Auteur, Through Another
text: STEVEN SODERBERGH’S modus operandi is that no film he makes is like anything he’s made before. The one exception has been the “Ocean” series, which from first (“Ocean’s Eleven”) to last (“Ocean’s Thirteen”) was designed to make money and did. But once Mr. Soderbergh could add that particular genre of moviemaking to his résumé  in Hollywood, the franchise is a genre  he put it aside and returned to being the consummate anti-auteurist auteur, bouncing from the guerrilla epic “Che” to the coolly soft-core “Girlfriend Experience” to the comic corporate exposé “The Informant!”

headline: Star-Spangled Glamour | Bruce Weber’s ‘All-American’
text: For over three decades, the photographer Bruce Weber has defined contemporary American glamour with his editorial and advertising imagery. Weber has also been a prolific producer of books, including “All-American,” an annual almanac of the esoterica that he encounters in his travels. But when he sat down last year to plan the next edition, the world appeared to have shifted on its axis, with many around him struggling to find their feet. “I wanted to put together a series of stories as eclectic and inspiring as you might hear at a late-night party,” Weber says, “because the morning after, you feel a reason to continue, even if you don’t know all the answers.” Fittingly, the ninth volume of “All-American” (Little Bear Press, $140) is a casserole of conceits, from poetry and photojournalism to profiles on the choreographer Carmen de Lavallade and the doomed beatnik pretty-boy artist Bill Morrow. As ever, nature is never far in Weber’s search for the sublime: a paean to Big Sur features the strapping landscapes and characters that have made the place as synonymous with muscular naturalism as Weber himself.

headline: When Hollywood Learned to Talk, Sing and Dance
text: AS the snowballing box-office success of “Avatar” suggests a paradigm shift in film, it’s rewarding to contemplate the last time the movies assumed a new dimension, that of sound.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Seller List: Casting About
text: A favorite pastime of comic book fans is picking actors they would like to see portray their favorite heroes in big screen films. These days, with so many super-epics being turned out by Hollywood, it seems like only a matter of time before every actor has his shot at a super-costume drama. This week fans learned that Peter Saarsgard would play Hector Hammond in the upcoming “Green Lantern” film. Mr. Hammond is a bald telepath with a giant head and the hots for the hero’s girlfriend, Carol Ferris, who it was recently announced will be played by Blake Lively.

headline: Movie Misquotations
text: Over the last century or so, movie quotations, like pop-music lyrics, have come to replace Biblical verses and Shakespearean couplets as our cultural lingua franca, our common store of wit and wisdom. Yet many of the most frequently cited motion-picture lines turn out to be misquotations. The speech from “Dirty Harry” in which Clint Eastwood says, “You’ve got to ask yourself one question: ‘Do I feel lucky?’ Well, do ya, punk?” is commonly shortened to “Do you feel lucky, punk?” Michael Douglas’s “Greed, for lack of a better word, is good” (“Wall Street”) is condensed to “Greed is good.” Expressions of James Cagney like “You dirty, yellow-bellied rat” (“Taxi!”) and “Dirty, double-crossing rat” (“Blonde Crazy”) are immortalized as the snappier “You dirty rat.”

headline: ‘Terminated’ Reactor Projects May Be Revived

headline: An Exhausted Lady Gaga Cancels Concert
text: Update | 12:24 p.m.  The relentless life of Lady Gaga, with its burdensome headpieces and nonstop costume changes and makeup jobs, has at last gotten to Lady Gaga. On Thursday night that chameleonlike pop singer (whose real name is Stefani Germanotta) canceled a show she planned to perform at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., citing exhaustion, Billboard reported. On her Twitter account, Lady Gaga wrote on Thursday night that she “was feeling dizzy and having trouble breathing” and that paramedics later came and diagnosed of exhaustion and dehydration. She said her show, which has many coordinated moving parts and mechanical elements, would be too dangerous to perform because, she wrote, she “had passed out earlier.” Billboard said the Indiana show would be rescheduled for Jan 26; Lady Gaga’s “Monster Ball” tour is scheduled to go to Atlantic City on Saturday and play four shows at Radio City Music Hall next week.

headline: Pentagon Report on Fort Hood Details Failures
text: WASHINGTON  A Pentagon review released Friday portrayed a systemic breakdown within the military that permitted an Army psychiatrist, now charged with killing 13 people, to advance through the ranks despite concerns from his superiors about his behavior.

headline: Postcard From London: Inside the Financial Inferno
text: LONDON — Oh, what a nightmare I had on Thursday. It had something do with an economic collapse, a closed room that had shed its doorknobs, a feathered man who climbed walls and a tidal wave of multicolored balls. The dream ended around 11:12 p.m. At least I think it did, because I checked the watch on my shivering arm. On the other hand, when I stepped outside to clear my head, I had the uneasy sense that the dream was still going on.

headline: Keepsakes, Domestic and Dark

headline: How Generous Are We to Haiti? 92 Cents Per American Per Year
text: I was delighted that the White House denounced as “utterly stupid” the Rev. Pat Robertson’s suggestion that Haiti had suffered its earthquake because it had made a “pact with the devil,” and as “really stupid” the comment by Rush Limbaugh that Americans already donate to Haiti through tax dollars — which many took to mean that he discouraged giving, a suggestion he has strongly denied. In any case, I think those comments may reflect a current that many people think even if they don’t articulate, something like this: Those Haitians have screwed up their country, and we already pour money into their economy. We have our troubles at home, we have our needs, so why should our hard-earned dollars go to support Haitians who don’t help themselves. We’ve already been generous, and it hasn’t worked.
