headline: Sex and Gore? That’s Ancient History
text: WHEN the Victorians were feeling gloomy about their prospects they used to compare themselves to the ancient Romans. They read Gibbon, Plutarch and Tacitus and looked for parallels: a society burdened by empire, corrupted by wealth, deficient in manly virtue. Lately we have been doing much the same, only instead of consulting the Latin texts we turn to screen epics like “Gladiator,” the HBO series “Rome,” and the 2007 Zack Snyder film “300,” which, strictly speaking, was about Spartans, not Romans, but let’s not be fussy. The cable channel Starz, as part of an effort to expand its slate of original programming, is extending this classical tradition with “Spartacus: Blood and Sand,” a 13-part series that starts Friday, and has already taken the unusual step of commissioning a second season before the first one even runs.

headline: Out and About | Via Tortona, Milan
text: When in 1983 the Italian Vogue art director Flavio Lucchini and the photographer Fabrizio Ferri opened photo studios in a sleepy, warehouse-filled neighborhood southwest of Milan’s center, their colleagues questioned the move. “It was a completely abandoned stretch of Via Tortona, and was considered extremely out of the way,” recalls Lucchini’s sister-in-law Giulia Borioli, a former director at the complex, called Superstudio 13. “People said we were crazy to think that the fashion industry would embrace this neighborhood.”

headline: More TV Time For Surprise Reality Stars
text: Just because you’re a reality-show contestant who is technically too old to compete on “American Idol” doesn’t mean you can’t continue to appear on television over and over again. Larry Platt, the 63-year-old Atlanta resident who became an unlikely celebrity after performing his original song “Pants on the Ground” on “Idol” Wednesday night, has been booked to appear as a guest on “The View” on Monday morning, USA Today reported. Meanwhile, 48-year-old Susan Boyle, who has nothing to show for her appearances on “Britain’s Got Talent” except for millions of sales of her debut album, will appear on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” on Tuesday, her press representatives said on Friday.

headline: A Big Audience for Conan O’Brien’s ‘Tonight’
text: Even as negotiations for him to leave NBC moved toward a conclusion, Conan O’Brien continued a ratings surge Thursday night, posting huge advantages in early results among young-adult viewers for his “Tonight Show” on NBC.

headline: When Women Lose Their Hair
text: Hereditary hair loss and thinning hair are common concerns in women, but many popular treatments don’t do any good, writes Lesley Alderman in today’s Patient Money.

headline: The Brill Building
text: To the Editor:

headline: Realms of Gold
text: Can you examine the moral life of someone without morals? Does someone without morals have a moral life? And is the amoral life worth living?

headline: Iraqis on Iraq – Basra and Mosul
text: With international attention shifting from Iraq to Afghanistan — we asked Iraqi journalists working for The New York Times to give a personal view of the areas where they live. Here, our correspondents describe life in Iraq’s second- and third-largest cities, which until recently were very dangerous places to live and work. The journalists’ names are withheld because of the continuing threat to their lives.

headline: Travel Deals: Flight Sale to Australia
text: Qantas Airways is offering up to 50 percent off flights between select cities in the United States and Australia.

headline: Preaching Power, Jets’ Callahan Finds Fresh Start
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets’ offensive linemen laugh at the way Bill Callahan approaches football. They find his methods endearing, unusual and effective.

headline: Send Photos of Missing Loved Ones
text: The New York Times is collecting photos of missing people submitted by friends, family members and colleagues. Readers who have information can make photo submissions or read comments from others seeking information.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs Come Knocking
text: After a week overflowing with news about steroid confessions, itinerant coaches and felony gun charges, the weekend’s N.F.L. playoff games will arrive not a moment too soon, although the league has announced that if you have not been obsessing about them all week, as it requires, its people may be paying you a visit. Just a warning.

headline: ‘Make Mine a Sully’
text: Sure, he’s been called a hero. And his act of cool-headed bravery one year ago was nothing short of a miracle. But one honor may have passed Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III like a jet floating down the river: a cocktail in his name.

headline: Tips for Safe and Efficient Haiti Donations
text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has urged Internet users to be cautious and do their research before giving money to help the relief effort in Haiti.

headline: NBC's Ann Curry Reports From Haiti
text: As aid pours into Haiti, tension is mounting among the rubble as the search for survivors continues.

headline: Guess Who Said It? Late-Night Edition
text: Hey, kids! Here’s a fun game to play. Guess who said the following in The New York Times, after recently becoming the host of a popular late-night television program, only to face rumors that he was about to be replaced with another host?

headline: Bill Clinton on Devastation in Haiti
text: Former President Bill Clinton encourages Americans to donate money to victims of the earthquake in Haiti.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Jan. 15
text: Haiti continues to demand the world’s attention, but there is no lack of trouble in Kenya, China and India. In one instance, however, the darkness over the land was benign (Slides 9 and 10).

headline: Ricky Gervais: Team Leno or Team Coco?
text: Ricky Gervais and the writers of the Golden Globes are likely giving the comedy gods extra thanks this week — they do that by the ritual sacrifice of a Judd Apatow script — because the Jay/Conan dust-up is no doubt giving them reams of easy topical material. From the hosts’ own jokes to Jimmy Kimmel’s prosthetic chin to his skewering of Leno directly on Thursday night to the Craigslist listing, it is as surefire comedy gold as making fun of George Clooney. Right? How long do you think it will take until Mr. Gervais, the show’s host, makes a reference to the brouhaha on Sunday night? First joke of the monologue? Or after the first commercial break? Will he throw NBC zingers throughout the broadcast, despite (or because of) the fact that the Globes are being broadcast live on NBC? Will he — please, oh gracious, benevolent Mr. Apatow — appear in a Leno fright wig himself? Leave your thoughts in the comments.

headline: Up Front: Pankaj Mishra
text: A novelist, literary critic, essayist, travel writer and international journalist, Pankaj Mishra is also, as a recent interviewer in The Believer magazine put it, a “maverick scholar.” (A label, he joked in a recent e-mail message, that makes him sound like John McCain.)

headline: Inside the List
text: AUTHOR’S HELPERS: Kathryn Stockett’s first novel, “The Help,” finally hits No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, after 41 weeks of trying. Anne Tyler’s 18th novel, “Noah’s Compass,” enters at No. 3. Stockett has built her success through word-of-mouth and lots of media interviews and public appearances. Tyler (inset), on the other hand, hasn’t done a book tour or given a face-to-face interview since 1977. In a recent e-mail Q. and A. with Writer’s Digest, she said she doesn’t think about the reader until she has a final draft of a book: “At that point, I seem to picture my readers as brand-new to me. They have the neuter, faceless quality of people in dreams. It comes as a shock later when a real-life reader writes to me and turns out to be a specific human being.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE GREAT GAMBLE: The Soviet War in Afghanistan,  by Gregory Feifer (Harper Perennial, $15.99.) “No one ever actually ordered the invasion of Afghanistan,” a Soviet general staff officer told Feifer; it just happened through inertia and confusion. In this readable history of the Soviet war, based heavily on interviews with veterans and spies conducted when he was NPR’s Moscow correspondent, Feifer describes the bravery, lack of focus and futility of that effort. What can the United States learn from the Russian experience? “Don’t shoot up wedding parties,” our reviewer, Nicholas Thompson, summarized. And “never underestimate fanatics who know the terrain.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: COMMITTED: A Skeptic Makes Peace With Marriage,  by Elizabeth Gilbert (Viking, $26.95.) Picking up pretty much where “Eat, Pray, Love” left off, Gilbert describes how her boyfriend’s unforeseen visa problems enticed her into a most dreaded institution.

headline: Naked and Conflicted
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dimon’s Complaint: Bank Tax Isn’t Spread Fairly
text: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, says he believes it isn’t fair that the big banks will be the only ones forced to pick up the TARP tab under the proposed bank tax, suggesting that other companies that benefited from the government assistance program should pay up as well.

headline: Leaving Millions to a School They Embraced as Family
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  They were friends and confidantes, surrogate mothers for generations of boys at the Lawrenceville School, an elite boarding school that was once known as a feeder for Princeton University.

headline: To Curb Emissions, Port of Los Angeles Tests Hydrogen-Electric Trucks
text: The Port of Los Angeles is buying eight heavy-duty hybrid trucks that are powered by a combination of hydrogen fuel cells and lithium batteries. The trucks come from Vision Industries of Santa Monica and are part of the port’s emissions-trimming Clean Truck Program.

headline: A Facebook Movement, Against Mom and Dad
text: They feel her pain. At the Spence School and Greenwich High and Fullerton Union High and Nyack High and Narragansett High, teenagers and near-teenagers, hundreds of them, are waving a virtual flag for Tess Chapin, a 15-year-old from Sunnyside, Queens, who has been grounded for five weeks. A few days after founding the Facebook group  “1000 to get tess ungrounded”  Tess had nearly reached her stated goal, with 806 members by Friday morning; after this column about her quest was posted on nytimes.com, she surpassed it.

headline: On Assignment: Prayers in the Dark
text: Damon Winter of The New York Times arrived in Port-au-Prince on Wednesday. He has been traveling through the city in a car shared with Ron Haviv of the VII photo agency and Timothy Fadek, both veteran conflict photographers. James Estrin spoke with Mr. Winter by cellphone at midnight Thursday. Excerpts of their conversation can be heard below.

headline: Complaint Box | Baby Barflies
text: As a 5-foot-4, dark-haired Jewish girl in her early 20s, I was never a minority in New York City until I moved to Park Slope, Brooklyn, where I seem to be one of the few childless residents.

headline: Correction: New Housing, After a Court Order
text: The “In the Region” article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday, about plans and timetables for new affordable housing in Westchester in light of a recent court mandate, misidentified the nonprofit group that is marketing Minerva Place, a 14-unit affordable development in White Plains. It is Community Housing Innovations  not the Housing Action Council, another builder of affordable housing in the area.

headline: Teacher Q | How Should Teachers Be Evaluated?
text: In a recent Atlantic Monthly article called “What Makes a Great Teacher?”, Amanda Ripley writes that “the most stunning finding to come out of education research in the past decade” is that “more than any other variable in education—more than schools or curriculum—teachers matter.”

headline: Correction: Landscaping as a Seductive First Step
text: A rendering with the “Postings” column last Sunday about Hunters Point South, a midpriced housing development slated to be built on the Queens waterfront, carried an incomplete credit. The rendering was by Arup/Thomas Balsley Associates/Weiss/Manfredi  not just Weiss/Manfredi.

headline: New Grants to Help New Yorkers Buy Foreclosed Homes
text: Home buyers may be given up to $50,000 toward buying a foreclosed home in New York, thanks to a federal fund that has been awarded to the city’s housing agency, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

headline: Correction: On the Market in the Region
text: The “On the Market” page last Sunday included an erroneous name on the contributors’ line. It was Elsa Brenner who provided a listing for a 1910 colonial in Upper Grand View in Rockland County. It was not Marcelle S. Fischler.

headline: Details of ‘Hope for Haiti’ Telethon Are Announced
text: Update | 1:16 p.m.  Eleven broadcast and cable networks will show a two-hour telethon next Friday night to benefit the victims of the Haitian earthquake, MTV Networks announced on Friday. The commercial-free telethon, called “Hope for Haiti,” will be shown starting at 8 p.m., Eastern time, on ABC, BET, CBS, CMT, CNN, CW, FOX, HBO, MTV, NBC and VH1, in addition to the MTV Networks International, CNN International and National Geographic channels, which will show it around the world.

headline: Correction: Greenwich, on a More Modest Scale
text: The “Living In” column on Dec. 27, about Chickahominy, Conn., misspelled the name of a local stone mason who emigrated from Sardinia in the 1902s and was responsible for building various structures in town. He was Sebastiano Bazzoni, not Bozzoni.

headline: Madison Avenue Makes Haste to Help Haiti
text: A public service campaign to support relief efforts after the Haitian earthquake is already under way in what the Advertising Council, which oversees pro bono initiatives from Madison Avenue, calls its fastest response to a disaster.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jonathan Dee
text: This week: Jonathan Dee talks about his new novel, “The Privileges”; Stacy D’Erasmo guides us though Javier Marías’s trilogy, “Your Face Tomorrow”; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 5: Children
text: Update 6:35 p.m. Pacific Time | From the personal to the stiffly academic to the personal again, the trial came full circle by the first week’s end as Danny Chu, a lawyer in the San Francisco City Attorney’s office, called Helen Zia to the witness stand.

headline: Reaching Out a Valuable Part of Being an Olympian
text: In 2008, the United States Olympic Committee created the Team for Tomorrow program, an effort to involve American Olympic athletes in humanitarian relief programs around the world. They have donated tents to the earthquake-ravaged region in China in 2008 as well as worked with Habitat for Humanity to build homes for people in need. The U.S.O.C. is planning assistance to the Haitian Olympic Committee following that country’s devastating earthquake.

headline: Aid Workers on How Not to Help Haiti
text: Stephanie Strom, who covers philanthropy for The Times, pointed me to a blunt and useful post written by Saundra Schimmelpfennig, a leading expert on the recovery efforts after the Asian tsunami of 2004. Ms. Schimmelpfennig has opened her blog to advice from aid workers on the right and wrong ways to donate and help in the coming days and weeks.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week: Jonathan Dee talks about his new novel, “The Privileges”; Stacy D’Erasmo guides us though Javier Marías’s trilogy, “Your Face Tomorrow”; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Matisse for the Masses (Sort Of)
text: T Magazine’s beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

headline: H-P Ships High-Speed USB Notebook
text: A 15-inch Hewlett-Packard Envy laptop is now available with a USB 3.0 connector, making it among the first computers to be sold with the higher-speed technology.

headline: Bill Clinton Urges House Democrats Onward
text: In a 45-minute speech followed by a 45-minute question-and-answer session, former President Bill Clinton exhorted House Democrats to approve major health care legislation, work closely with the White House and to head into their re-election battles in November with eyes wide open.

headline: The Reading Life:  Postcards From the Edge
text: Hotel fires. Car crashes. Circus parades. Barn raisings. Offbeat family scenes. The photo postcards reprinted in Luc Sante’s spooky and engrossing new book, “Folk Photography: The American Real-Photo Postcard 1905-1930” (Yeti Books/VerseChorus Press, $24.95), don’t provide your usual images of waterfalls or mountain vistas. They’re examples of “real-photo” postcards, generally made for personal or local use, not intended for tourists.

headline: Answers About Improv Everywhere, Part 3
text: Editor’s note, April 2: a few weeks after this feature appeared, Charlie Todd of Improv Everywhere lied to City Room repeatedly as we questioned him on whether one of his stunts was an April Fool’s hoax (it was). While the unwritten laws of the Internet prevent us from taking these posts down, we can’t vouch for anything he says here.

headline: When I Was Left to Speak for Both of Us
text: “This is India red, and that’s black galaxy,” said the saleswoman, Diane, walking along the aisle of samples. She pointed one row over. “And that’s Balmoral green.”

headline: Smart Water Meters Struggle for Foothold
text: With many states projecting that they’ll face water shortages in the coming years, smart water meters that provide real-time data on water use can help conserve dwindling supplies.

headline: Caring for Both Your Parents and Kids
text: We are the sandwich generation, taking care of aging parents and young children. It is estimated that 25 percent of adults with children under the age of 18 are also responsible for elder care.

headline: ‘She Hasn’t Seen It’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: There’s big news out of Washington today. President Obama announced a plan to recover federal bailout money from banks. I guess that explains why Biden was seen yesterday buying a gun and a ski mask.

headline: Golden Globe Crossover
text: One of the many things the Hollywood Foreign Press Association likes to brag about itself — alongside the fact that it has the best party of the season and more stars in one room than a Scientology, Kabbalah and Forum meeting combined — is that the Golden Globe awards are a reliable predictor of Oscar winners. That has been true in the past; since the Globes starting nominating 10 best films, five each in drama and comedy/musical, its choices had twice the chance to line up with the Academy’s five, and usually the crossover was in the drama category. But in the year of The 10, things are a little hairier, as Variety points out. “Not surprisingly, many believe the group’s drama nominees will cross over, while the comedies will face a tougher road,” writes Glenn Whipp.

headline: ‘A Possible Terrorist’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” on NBC: It’s been reported that an 8-year-old boy from New Jersey is on the government’s airport watch list because he has the same name as a possible terrorist. So, it’s been a really bad week for little Skippy bin Laden.

headline: For CF Industries, Forever Turns to Never
text: Even the Forever War has to end.

headline: ‘Already Making Friends’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Do you folks know what is going on with NBC and the trouble they’re having with Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien? I thought this was nice. President Obama invited Jay and Conan to the White House for a beer.

headline: ‘Really Cracking Down’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Sarah Palin has signed with Fox News to be a correspondent. Well, in a statement today, Fox said if Palin does a good job, they’ll sign her to a longtime contract. If she doesn’t work out, they’ll just blame Leno. That’s what they said.

headline: Immediately After Haiti's Earthquake
text: Erik Parker, an American journalist in Haiti, shot this video on his iPhone moments after the earthquake on Tuesday, as he tried to help people trapped in a badly damaged building.

headline: More Glamour at Acapulco

text: Damien Cave reports on the relief efforts in Port-au-Prince.

headline: The iPhone Wins a Touchscreen Test
text: In a test certain to stir debate, technology consulting firm Moto Development Group tested how accurately the touchscreens on four handsets performed and declared the iPhone as the winner.

headline: Ravens Lineman Can Create His Own Ending
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Practice had just ended, and the most famous offensive lineman in the N.F.L. was still feeling feisty. Spotting a Baltimore Ravens teammate rolling on an argyle dress sock, Michael Oher nodded his way and asked, “You’re not really going to put that on, are you?” A reporter wearing a sweatshirt adorned with lacrosse sticks moseyed toward Oher, who laughed and told him, “Man, you wouldn’t last a day in the hood.”

headline: Low Rates for Just a Few
text: MORTGAGE borrowers might be forgiven for sometimes feeling like victims of a bait-and-switch scheme.

headline: At Year’s End, Sales Picked Up Pace
text: COMING off one of the worst years ever for the housing market, Connecticut has reason to be hopeful that 2010 will be better — chiefly because it is hard to imagine the economy sliding precipitously enough for sales to fall still further.

headline: Hotel Points Can Help Haiti
text: At a loss with how to help earthquake victims in Haiti? In addition to mobile and more traditional forms of donating, hotels are letting members donate their points.

headline: The Burger Experience Without the Beef
text: Even the most devoted burger lover may be feeling a bit queasy about eating ground beef these days.

headline: School Bake Sales Are Back On, but Only for Haiti
text: The city has taken a number of steps to help Haiti, gathering donations from the public, offering to send rescue workers and city engineers and giving city employees the option to have contributions deducted from their paychecks.

headline: Leading Men | Dressing the Part
text: With the Golden Globes kicking off awards season in Hollywood on Sunday, I wanted to offer some red-carpet wardrobe suggestions for our leading men. While a traditional single-breasted tuxedo will always be a handsome look, these options from the coming spring-summer season (just hitting stores now) allow for a bit more individualism. Just make sure to avoid parody — no mandarin collars, please!

headline: Senior Qaeda Figures Killed in Attack, Yemen Says
text: SANA, Yemen  A Yemeni airstrike on Friday afternoon killed at least five senior members of Al Qaeda’s Arabian branch, Yemeni officials said, including the group’s military commander.

headline: ArtsBeat: George Clooney Spearheads a Telethon for Haiti
text: George Clooney has successfully spearheaded the creation of a telethon to aid the victims of the earthquake in Haiti. To be shown all over the dial – on ABC, CBS, NBC, FOX, CNN, BET, CW, HBO, MTV, VH1 and CM, in addition to the MTV Networks International, CNN International and National Geographic channel – the telethon will be broadcast next Friday night. Mr. Clooney will host from Los Angeles with Haitian-American musician Wyclef Jean in New York and the CNN anchor Anderson Cooper in Haiti. Read more…

headline: Wallpaper 2010 Design Awards
text: As completely absorbed as I was by the winner of Wallpaper’s domestic design award (a slow cooker by Margriet Foolen for Royal VKB), I ought to mention that the best new men’s collection award went to Raf Simons and the best new women’s to Rei Kawakubo. Last year’s fashion winners were Junya Watanabe for men and Stefano Pilati of YSL for women.

headline: Working Families, Not Working
text: With so many more women in the labor force today, many people who have been laid off in this recession have at least had a spouse’s income to fall back on.

headline: American Red Cross Haiti Spot
text: In a new spot for the American Red Cross, Michelle Obama urges viewers to support relief efforts in Haiti.

headline: Making Bigger Bucks Than Ever
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Clothes Encounters
text: Whatever your circadian rhythms, you can satisfy them at the Clean Rite Center, where washers and dryers rumble all day long.

headline: CIT Group to Name Interim Chief Next Week
text: The CIT Group, the commercial lender that emerged from bankruptcy last month, plans to name a temporary replacement for its chief executive, Jeffrey M. Peek, after he steps down.

headline: Lots for the Family to Love
text: A ROCKLAND County hamlet in Orangetown, several miles southwest of Nyack, Pearl River is not nearly as trendy as its neighbors. It doesn’t have Hudson River views or storied estates. Its downtown of unadorned storefronts is a plain Jane next to Nyack’s or Piermont’s.

headline: Obama to Campaign in Massachusetts on Sunday
text: Updated: President Obama will travel to Massachusetts on Sunday to campaign for the Democratic Senate candidate, Martha Coakley, the White House said, a sudden decision in response to growing concern that the party could lose its 60-vote majority in the Senate and a seat that for decades belonged to Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

headline: It’s Not the Hudson, but Landfill Will Do for Pilot
text: Updated, 3:26 p.m. | It might come to be called the Miracle at the Landfill.

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: No More News
text: “NOW on PBS” (Friday night, check local listings) gets personal: the public affairs and investigative news program, which has been canceled and will go off the air in April, looks at the troubles of the news business. The guests are Bob McChesney and John Nichols, authors of “The Death and Life of American Journalism: The Media Revolution That Will Begin the World Again,” who advocate government subsidies for noncommercial journalism. “Law & Order” (NBC, 8 p.m. Friday) tackles the subject of the shrinking news business from a different angle: Lupo (Jeremy Sisto) and Bernard (Anthony Anderson) investigate the murder of a journalist.

headline: 24 Hour Cycle
text: At the laundromat, irregular things happen. People square off over washers  mine; no, mine. They sit on the counters where you were planning to fold T-shirts. Women conveniently forget a negligee in a dryer so you’ll find it and marry them. Street people try to sell utterly unnecessary things. Pesky process servers visit bearing summonses. People stare without mercy.

headline: Port of Los Angeles Tests Hydrogen-Electric Trucks
text: From our colleagues at Green Inc.:

headline: Vale in Talks to Buy Fertilizer Assets in Brazil
text: Vale S.A. said Friday that it was in talks to buy Bunge Ltd.’s fertilizer operations in Brazil for as much as $3.8 billion as that country, the world’s biggest producer of coffee, sugar and orange juice, seeks to cut its dependency on crop-nutrient imports.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Poster Art in Europe, Soderbergh, ‘Spartacus’ and More
text: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Talk Is Cheap — And Irrelevant
text: So there appears to be a spreading piece of conventional wisdom saying that instead of trying to pass health care reform, Obama should have “focused on the economy”. I’m with Kevin Drum: I have no idea what this is supposed to mean.

headline: Ivy Asset’s Chief Resigns Amid Restructuring
text: Sean Simon, head of the fund of hedge funds Ivy Asset Management, has left the firm amid a broad restructuring of the fund of funds unit within its corporate parent, the Bank of New York Mellon Corporation.

headline: On Health Care, Readers Speak; The Agenda Responds
text: The Agenda is grateful to all the readers who shared their views about the House and Senate health care bills. It is striking to see, at least in the reaction to the second post, that the bills seem to be under even fire from the left and the right. Now, as Democrats in the Senate, House, and White House seem to be wrapping up their negotiations, we’d like to pick up on a couple of those points.

headline: Lysacek Not Taking It Easy at Nationals
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — Evan Lysacek, the two-time United States national figure skating champion, didn’t need the quadruple jump at last year’s world championships to win the world title.Without the quad, a challenging jump which requires a skater to turn four times in the air, Lysacek also won the Grand Prix final in December.

headline: U.S. Mortgage Plan Aided 7 Percent of Borrowers
text: Mortgage payments have been permanently lowered for more than 66,000 borrowers under the Obama administration’s $75 billion program to protect homeowners from foreclosure, according to new federal data released on Friday.

headline: A Gentle Lift, but a Heavy One
text: How do you move a 14,000-pound marble vase into the Park Avenue Armory at East 67th Street?

headline: Aziz Ansari Gets ‘Intimate’
text: For a guy who earned his reputation by joking about popular culture, Aziz Ansari has done a pretty good job of insinuating himself into it. From his standup routines about his way-out explorations of Facebook and Craigslist or his love of musicians like R. Kelly and the Wu-Tang Clan, Mr. Ansari, 26, has leaped into a film and television career: he appeared in the Judd Apatow movie “Funny People” as an annoyingly successful comedian named Randy (or, as the character prefers, Raaaaaaaandy!); and he’s a star of the NBC sitcom “Parks and Recreation,” on which he plays the suave yet lazy government worker Tom Haverford. To his own astonishment, he has also become a friend of Kanye West, and once hung out in the rapper’s apartment (where they listened to Mr. West’s music).

headline: Steep Job Losses Offer Hope for Fast Rebound
text: WILL labor markets in the United States remain weak for an extended period?

headline: What We’re Reading
text: On City Room, a tribute to Yonnah Schimmels’ knishery on its 100th birthday. “People ask, ‘Are your knishes fresh?’” said Ellen Anistratov, who owns the knishery with her father, Alex Wolfson. “I say, ‘They’re a hundred years old.” Also, Dale DeGroff has come up with a cocktail to celebrate Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III — The Sully — sort of a Manhattan with a float of Champagne.

headline: Making Art Out of an Encounter
text: I first encountered Tino Sehgal’s work under ideal conditions: total ignorance. Happening to be in Berlin in 2006 at the time of the city’s art biennial, I heard from an art-dealer friend that there was one exhibition not to miss. “I won’t tell you anything more,” he said, as he walked me to the site and bid me farewell. I trod up a creaking staircase in a building from the turn of the last century and entered a decayed ballroom, its ornate moldings and gilt mirrors testifying to a more glorious past. Lying on the floor, a man and a woman, fully dressed, were embracing languidly. There was no one else in the room. My presence went unacknowledged. In a state of mounting confusion and embarrassment, I stayed until I could stand it no longer, and then I retreated down the staircase. Out on the street, I sighed with relief, because I once again knew where I was.

headline: Part-Time Fulfillment
text: The past year brought about setbacks for many. For me, it signaled the end of my 25-year marriage, the loss of membership in the family medical plan and the necessity of re-entering the workplace at midlife after a long hiatus as a stay-at-home mom. The market crash gobbled up a big chunk of my modest retirement account, and the divorce litigation left me with a pile of bills.

headline: Vigor Quest
text: NEARLY EVERY SUNDAY morning — Easter and Mother’s Day included — John Bellizzi says goodbye to his wife, Francesca, grabs an equipment bag and slides into the front seat of his black BMW. He drives to a high-school soccer field about 10 miles from his home in the New York City suburb of Rye.

headline: The Coast of Dystopia
text: I didn’t move to California to become a “Californian.” I usually say that I came for a job; the truth is, I was young and in love and I followed a boy. That was 21 years ago, and much to my surprise, I’m still here. The relationship fizzled, but I was seduced by the romance of the state. I’d become a true believer in the California dream, right as it began to fall apart.

headline: The Reader
text: Your latest book, “The Professor,” comes out on Tuesday, and I’m not sure which is more surprising: the candid disclosures about your love life or the sparkling and witty prose, which you do not expect from a professor of literature at Stanford University. Why does academic writing tend to be so unreadable?  Paradoxically, academic writers are often inhibited when it comes to speaking directly, possibly because they were all little goody-goodies in junior high school, and they’re being massed together in university departments, and when you put all the smartest kids in the class together, there’s a tremendous anxiety about whether one can live up to the seriousness of the enterprise.

headline: The Reviewing Stand
text: Here’s a challenge for students of expository writing: review a popular product on Amazon and aim to get your review chosen by readers as “most helpful.”

headline: Smoke Screen
text: My son was dropped from our family’s employee-sponsored health insurance shortly after graduating from college in May. While filling out the application for a new policy, he asked me how to answer a question about his marijuana use in the past year. I said, “Honestly.” He checked a box indicating he smoked very occasionally and was denied coverage. Now he is uninsured while countless pot-smoking liars have coverage. My husband thinks I gave our son foolish advice. Do you agree? M.H., MONTCLAIR, N.J.

headline: Letters in Response to the 1.3.10 Issue
text: What’s a Bailed-Out Banker Worth?

headline: Rescuers Race Clock in Haiti
text: Rescue efforts continued, but hope of finding more survivors of the earthquake alive faded as aid workers struggled to deliver relief supplies.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1.) Can gay rights boost economic prosperity?

headline: Is the U.S. Doing Enough for Haiti?
text: With conditions in Haiti growing worse by the hour, the Obama administration has pledged $100 million and is sending 5,000 troops to help in relief efforts there. Should the U.S. be doing more? Does it have an obligation different from other nations? Should the U.S. take on a nation-building project in Haiti?

headline: Europe Sends Aid and Pledges Money for Haiti
text: PARIS  The effort to aid Haitian earthquake victims is presenting Europe with the first test of its newly created foreign policy structure and prompting France to call on other nations to speed the forgiveness of the nation’s international debt.

headline: Burgers, Loaded
text: All of the ketchup and mustard bottles at Corey’s Catsup and Mustard are labeled Heinz. The hamburgers, though, are housemade, ground from beef every day, formed into slightly irregular, seven-ounce patties and cooked to order.

headline: Turkish Medley, Amply Served
text: THE handful of Turkish restaurants in Connecticut seem to cluster in and around New Haven, so it was a surprise to see a billboard off Interstate 84 advertising Anatolia in Waterbury.

headline: Can Main Street Win Business Plan Competitions?
text: Business plan competitions tend to emphasize technology.

headline: A Pizza Tradition Put to a New Test
text: ONE of the shrines for pizza aficionados in Connecticut, Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana, has had the audacity to open its fifth outpost smack in the middle of Central Park Avenue in Yonkers, where Ricky’s Clam House once stood. “Central Av,” as it is affectionately called by people who are particular about the tenderness of their mozzarella, is the source spring for Italian-Americans in Westchester, and the folks at Frank Pepe  the original owner’s grandchildren, to be exact  have taken a calculated risk in putting their thin-crusted, coal-fired pies right under the noses of a distinctly discerning audience.

headline: ‘Dual Agency’ Under Scrutiny
text: “IT’S a buyer’s market — everybody knows that, right?” said Paul Howard, an agent for NJHomeBuyer.com in Cherry Hill. “So how come so many buyers get frustrated when the seller seems to be holding more cards?”

headline: Comfort and Spice
text: There’s a stretch of Shrewsbury Avenue in Red Bank that’s lined with small Mexican grocery stores. That’s where you’ll find La Chaparrita, where the shelves are stocked with staples like salsas and queso fresco. But customers are drawn as well by the fresh Mexican comfort food.

headline: Fossil Fuel Use in 2034? Not Much Different.
text: A quarter century from now the United States’ reliance on fossil fuels will have declined only marginally, according to a projection from Black & Veatch, the engineering and energy consulting firm.

headline: Wireless Companies Speed Up Texted Haiti Donations
text: Update | 3:45 p.m.  Adding information from Sprint.

headline: Making History in a Brooklyn Neighborhood
text: WHEN Habitat for Humanity New York City consulted an architecture firm on its new site in the Ocean Hill section of Brownsville, Brooklyn, it received a response that switched on a light bulb. The firm, Dattner Architects, said that Habitat could proceed with its plan to build 12 town houses on the trash-strewn vacant lot, but that the site was actually capable of supporting many more units in apartment form — 41, to be exact.

headline: Schumacher Completes GP2 Test, Ready to ‘Go for It’
text: Michael Schumacher is feeling strong after his first real test on his comeback road to Formula One.

headline: Wings for Super Sunday
text: On Super Bowl Sunday, Feb. 7, Peter Ambrosio, the owner of Taxi’s Grille in Huntington, expects to sell more than 500 dozen fried chicken wings. That’s roughly 1,000 pounds of takeout, just in time for the big game.

headline: The River Floes
text: The Hudson River has frozen over as far south as Manhattan only three times in recorded history, according to I.N. Phelps Stokes’s six-volume classic “Iconography of Manhattan Island.” It hasn’t happened since 1821. So this scene, captured by a reader, Harrison Hill, on Wednesday, looking south from the Chelsea waterfront to the skylines of Lower Manhattan and Jersey City, is about as close as we get these days. Still, it’s not too bad. Thank you, Mr. Hill.

headline: The Problem of Corporatism
text: Chris Hayes has a great essay in The Nation that distills the free-floating left-wing anxiety about the Obama-era marriage of Big Business and Big Government, and tries to figure out what progressives ought to do about it. One answer he rejects is the possibility of a left-right alliance against crony capitalism:

headline: An Oakland Police Sergeant’s View of the Drug Trade
text: For 10 years, Sgt. Bernard Ortiz specialized in drug enforcement, then in 2008 became a sergeant for an eight-man squad (problem-solving officers, in Oakland police department parlance) in the North Oakland area.

headline: If Senators Bought Group Insurance
text: In virtually every industrialized country outside the United States, the contribution people make toward their health insurance is divorced from their age and health status. While this arrangement — known as community rating — is taken for granted abroad, it is still astoundingly controversial here in the United States.

headline: Rich People Exercise More
text: Rich people are much more likely to exercise than their poorer brethren, according to new survey findings from Gallup.

headline: Arenas Pleads Guilty to Gun Charge
text: WASHINGTON — Wizards point guard Gilbert Arenas pleaded guilty Friday afternoon to a felony charge of carrying a pistol without a license. Sentencing will be on March 26.

headline: Schumacher Completes GP2 Test, Ready to ‘Go for It’
text: From our colleagues at Formula One:

headline: President of Stevens Institute Agrees to Step Down
text: The embattled president of Stevens Institute of Technology, Harold J. Raveché, will step down in July, the college said Friday. And under terms of a settlement ending a lawsuit by the State of New Jersey that questioned his $1.1 million salary, the institute has accepted extensive governance changes that will stiffen oversight of its financial management.

headline: A Brooklyn Apartment Sold Too Soon?
text: MY face betrayed me, disbelief slowly turning to distress as I stared silently at the Sunday real estate listings spread out on the kitchen table. It was a look my wife had seen too many times.

headline: Lights! Speakers! Sound (in the Ceiling)!
text: Sonos popularized the idea of wirelessly sending music stored on your PC to satellite speakers around the house. Now Klipsch, the speaker manufacturer, has come up with a variation: Wirelessly sending music to light bulbs around the house.

headline: Giuliani Stumps for Brown in Mass. Senate Race
text: BOSTON — In the shadow of the Old North Church where lanterns were held for Paul Revere, supporters of the Republican Senate candidate, Scott Brown, seized on the scene’s revolutionary history, saying: “The liberals are going.”

headline: Jonathan F. P. Rose
text: Mr. Rose, 58, is the founder and president of the Jonathan Rose Companies, which specializes in sustainable development. The company is involved in both nonprofit and for-profit projects and is one of the largest developers of affordable housing in New York City.

headline: The Spirit of Port-au-Prince, Now Broken
text: Kesler Pierre grew up in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, attending services at the Port-au-Prince Cathedral. He saw Pope Jean Paul II near the cathedral during his 1983 visit. “The cathedral is the tallest building in Port-au-Prince,” he said on Friday in Brooklyn. “You can’t get lost in the city, because anywhere you are, you can see it.”

headline: Hands On With HP’s Web-Connected Printer
text: HP made a splash last year with the introduction of its Photosmart Premium TouchSmart Web inkjet printer. The all-in-one device — it prints, copies, faxes, and scans — connects directly to the Web and wireless-enabled computers with built-in Wi-Fi. It is fronted by a very intuitive 4.3-inch touch-screen LCD for printer navigation and preview of photos.

headline: Potential Strike Looming, Cleveland Musicians Make Their Case to an Audience
text: Members of the Cleveland Orchestra were onstage Thursday night for a performance of Strauss’s “Don Juan,” a violin concerto by Thomas Adès and Brahms’s Second Symphony. It was their first night back with their music director, Franz Welser-Möst, since they had said a strike could take place as early as Monday. About 15 minutes before the concert’s 8 p.m. start time, they left the stage, and a colleague announced that they would be passing through the aisles with leaflets, which is exactly what they did.

headline: Democrats Forced to Yank Ad Over 9/11 Image
text: With the Massachusetts Senate race now in anybody’s guess territory, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee has gone up with another advertisement – but not without a little difficulty.

headline: Power, Power Everywhere
text: Filmmakers know that five minutes — even though it doesn’t sound lengthy — can be a long amount of screen time. And now users of YoGen’s new hand-cranked cellphone charger will discover that truism as well.

headline: Winter in America (in Florence)
text: The arctic weather in Europe may be the simple answer, or perhaps it’s something deeper, but for some reason everybody at the Pitti Immagine Uomo trade fair in Florence, Italy, which closed today, was dressed like a mountaineer. On the runways and on the Renaissance streets, the default look comprised hiking boots, heavy felted, checked-wool puffed coats and scarves as wide as king-size bedspreads.Fashion rarely follows function or logic, but the fallout from the crumbling financial markets may also be responsible for this back-to-nature escapism. The Japanese have been forecasting this nature-bound, anti-urban trend for a few seasons and avant-garde Tokyo brands and boutiques have gone crazy for original plaid, snow boots and hunting gear of every kind, in the process re-energizing staid American mountain classics like Timberland, Pendleton, Woolrich, Filson, L.L. Bean and Red Wing. Last season at Pitti, Undercover showed a mix of tech and country styles that may have influenced the general mood.

headline: Mural Spotting, the Oakland Mystery Game
text: Walk around Oakland and you see weathered murals on buildings and under freeway underpasses, overlooked remnants of a time when public art had a lot of support. Sometimes, I catch sight of a mural from a freeway, or even in the rear view mirror of my car as I drive in downtown Oakland.

headline: Nelson Requests Removal of Nebraska Aid From Final Bill
text: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, on Friday asked the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, to remove a special provision in the health care legislation that would have the federal government pay for all of Nebraska’s costs of a proposed expansion of Medicaid, the federal-state insurance program for low-income Americans.

headline: Australian Open Men’s Field Is Wide Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Tennis officials here are fond of calling the Australian Open, which opens Monday, the Grand Slam of Asia/Pacific.

headline: Being Orson Welles
text: “I’m curious to find out when you’ll be posting Christian’s interview,” Christian McKay’s newly hired publicist e-mailed the Bagger a few days after we did the interview, the subtext being: please, run the interview! O.K., we’ll bite. Mr. McKay drew uniformly great notices for his performance as Orson Welles in “Me and Orson Welles,” otherwise known as the indie vehicle in which Zac Efron didn’t have bangs. A. O. Scott wrote that Mr. McKay, “a British actor with a slender résumé and superhuman confidence,” played the part with “a brio and wit that puts most biopic mummery to shame.”

headline: Totally in His Element
text: SOME New Yorkers long to live in spanking new apartment buildings outfitted with sleekly designed lobbies and basement health clubs. To many other New Yorkers, nothing is as desirable as a prewar apartment, with its artfully arranged rooms and walls so thick that some latter-day residents have trouble getting wi-fi service.

headline: Citadel’s Head of Investment Banking Leaves
text: Todd Kaplan, the head of investment banking at Citadel Investment Group, the giant hedge fund firm run by Kenneth C. Griffin, has resigned less than a year after joining the firm.

headline: Chinese Gay Pageant Is Shut Down
text: BEIJING  The contestants were prepping backstage and the judges were settling in, but the first Mr. Gay China pageant was not meant to be. An hour before the show was set to begin on Friday night, eight police officers walked into the Lan Club and shut down the event, saying organizers lacked necessary permits.

headline: Correction
text: In a column last week, I quoted Jonathan R. Cole, who praised the University of Chicago in his book “The Great American University: Its Rise to Pre-eminence, Its Indispensable National Role, Why It Must be Protected.” I failed to mention that Mr. Cole’s publisher, PublicAffairs Books, was founded by Peter Osnos, the chairman of the Chicago News Cooperative advisory board. Mr. Osnos had no role in the origin or handling of the column.

headline: Protesters Win Right to March Outside Mayor’s House
text: A group of protesters who sued the city for the right to demonstrate outside of the Upper East Side town house of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have won their case and will be permitted to hold their march, a lawyer representing the group said Friday.

headline: For Financial Advice, Arriving at the Right Dosage
text: Most everyone needs financial advice. The big question is how much.

headline: One of the Virgin Islands Welcomes First Resort
text: Private islands in the Caribbean don’t come cheap. But the Scrub Island Resort, which is expected to open next month in the British Virgin Islands, promises all the privacy without the high price.

headline: The Exercise
text: Here are the instructions for

headline: Much Ado About a ‘Beach Boy’ ‘Cuda
text: The “personal” 1971 Plymouth Hemi ‘Cuda of the Beach Boy singer Al Jardine could be the subject of an increased amount of notice when it crosses the auction block next week at the Barrett-Jackson event in Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Prosecutors Near New Plea Deal in Galleon Case
text: Update | 5:56 p.m. Federal prosecutors on Friday said that they were near another plea agreement in the Galleon Group case, a disclosure made as the government asked for more time to file indictments against three of the original defendants in the matter.

headline: More on Jon Gruber
text: Today Glenn Greenwald accused me of being a hypocrite for defending Jonathan Gruber, the health care economist who has become a target of some progressive opponents of the health care plan. He writes:

headline: Obama on Aid to Haiti
text: President Obama pledges continued immediate and long-term support to Haiti. (NBC video)

headline: Do You Pay For Financial Advice?
text: This week’s Your Money column discusses how much financial advice we need and when we should start paying for it.

headline: Cutcliffe Will Stay at Duke
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — Duke’s David Cutcliffe was apparently one of the targets of Tennessee’s search for a new football coach because Cutcliffe issued a statement Friday morning saying he was going to remain in Durham, N.C.

headline: Testosterone to Fine-Tune an Aging Body
text: Can a regimen of exercise, vitamins, supplements and hormone shots slow down nature’s clock? That’s the question explored in The New York Times Magazine this week. The story begins with 51-year-old John Bellizzi of Rye, N.Y., a patient of Dr. Florence Comite, a Manhattan endocrinologist.

headline: Classic Ad: 1954 Motorama
text: O.K., so it’s not an ad, really. But given the mostly sober proceedings at this year’s Detroit auto show, a look back at the bygone era of automotive glitz and glamor may be in order. And nothing exemplified pizazz during Detroit’s glory years quite like the General Motors Motorama, seen here in a 1954 promotional film.

headline: Status of Sand Volleyball Upheld in N.C.A.A. Vote
text: Sand volleyball has secured its spot on the list of emerging sports for women after narrowly surviving a vote Friday by Division I institutions and athletic conferences at the N.C.A.A. Convention in Atlanta to strip the sport of its status.

headline: Iran Warns Protesters Era of ‘Mercy’ Is Over
text: SANA, Yemen  Iran’s national police chief issued a stark warning to the country’s opposition on Friday, saying that the era of “mercy” was over and that the authorities would begin cracking down more harshly not only on street protests but also on anyone who used cellphones and e-mail messages to publicize them.

headline: Baroque Dexterity Applied to Dark French Passions
text: Like most countertenors, the French singer Philippe Jaroussky has specialized in the Baroque repertory, recording a number of impressive discs, including music by Vivaldi.

headline: Should Tess Be Grounded?
text: What’s a fair punishment for a 15-year-old who drinks alcohol at a party and misses curfew by an hour?

headline: Schumer Seeks to Keep Immigration Detention Site in Manhattan Open
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer is urging federal officials not to close immigration detention operations at the Varick Federal Detention Facility in Manhattan, saying that their decision to transfer its roughly 300 detainees to a county jail in New Jersey “will represent a crushing blow to the due process rights of immigrants detained within the New York metropolitan area.”

headline: Dream On Dept. | The Other Golden Globes
text: The Golden Globes, which will be awarded on Sunday, certainly qualify as Must See TV. We can’t wait to watch the endless parade of stars get up to the podium and thank the people who made it all possible for them: the directors, the producers, the agents, the plastic surgeons. Of course, there will be the usual camera pans to a smiling Jack Nicholson and a smirking Warren Beatty, insidery jokes by Tina Fey about the late-night wars, acceptance speeches by Meryl Streep and hopefully, plenty of heckling from the bleachers from the likes of Janice Dickinson and Bai Ling. Here are some of our favorite moments you might not see on your flat screen.Best Acceptance SpeechQuentin Tarantino thanking his first grade spelling teacher for inspiring “Inglourious Basterds.”

headline: Taste. Smell. Ahhhh, Wisdom.
text: It starts with The Exercise. “Become aware of where you are right now. Be aware of any expectations or concerns that may be present in the mind or heart. Now, let them go.” Feel your feet on the ground, your clothes on your skin. “Taste. Smell. Watch the breath as it enters and leaves the body. Now be aware of hearing.” And so on.

headline: Chairman Has a Gripe With the M.T.A., and a Desire to Fix It
text: New York’s bus, subway and rail network is inefficient, bloated and falling behind the world’s great transit systems.

headline: Drug Industry Group Threatens to Withdraw Support
text: Update | 5:42 p.m.

headline: Of Mutual Influence: The City and the 16th President
text: THINK “Lincoln” and “New York” and what first comes to mind might be the tunnel, the performing arts center, a hospital in the Bronx or a high school in Brooklyn.

headline: The Gavel Falls on Tavern on the Green
text: Everybody was invited to a three-day auction at Tavern on the Green this week.

headline: A Suburban Treasure, Left to Die
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.

headline: The Movie’s Coming on. No Barking.
text: Andrea Arden, 41, trains dogs for Animal Planet’s canine rags-to-riches makeover series, “Underdog to Wonderdog,” and for 15 years has run her own dog education/behavior modification business from three locations in Manhattan, including Animal Haven, a shelter on Centre Street. Separated from her husband, she lives in Red Hook, Brooklyn, with two Dobermans, two Savannah cats and her scruffy white terrier mix, Nora.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: HOMAGE is a new indoor skate spot opened by Michelle Sauer, 34, and Jose Portes, 36, a skateboarding couple whose skate shop, also named Homage, is a few blocks away, at 151 Smith Street. The shop is a big skater hangout and the couple offers lessons, but since it can be tough to find practice space in the winter, they opened this garage-like park at 615 Degraw Street, which has a suitable concrete floor and several wooden skateboard ramps wedged into it. The 2,500-square-foot space accommodates about 20 skaters; for now, it is open only to members who pay $100. Ms. Sauer, a former designer at Zoo York, the skateboard company, and at Burton, the snowboard company, said she and Mr. Portes planned to offer day-rate admission soon. “It’s hard for New Yorkers to skate in the winter,” Mr. Portes said. “So we wanted to set up a training facility because we want to see more pro skaters coming out of New York.”

headline: New American Attitude Applied to Old Favorites
text: IN a rollicking economy, the moderate prices, attentive service and solid food of BT Bistro, which opened in May, would probably ensure nightly crowds. Its location on Route 1, at the Clarion Hotel Palmer Inn, is an asset. So is the loyal clientele of the long-lived Ferry House in downtown Princeton, also owned by Bobby Trigg, who is the proprietor here.

headline: Full Bottles to Light Pours: A Spot for Wine Lovers
text: ARRIQUE Kitchen and Wine Bar, which opened in Babylon Village in September, is a wine lover’s dream. Fifty of the 150 wines on the list are available as half-bottles; 30 are sold by the glass in either three-ounce or six-ounce pours. And the restaurant will open any bottle on the list and sell it by the glass to a customer who commits to buying two glasses.

headline: Chic in Review | Kate Moss Drops a Habit
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Audio: The Health-Tax Deal
text: Here are two questions — one economic, one political — about the deal between the White House and labor unions regarding the tax on health-cost health plans:

headline: Globe Trotting to Iceland, Japan and Appalachia
text: Oneida

headline: Famous Peacenik Joins the Army
text: The Bagger’s big-(clown) shoes-to-fill predecessor, David Carr, is buddies with Woody Harrelson, so much so that when we started talking to Mr. Harrelson at a lunch recently, he decided to text Mr. Carr mid-talk. (“I’m going to tell him I’m talking to the new him,” he said.) Not sucking up, but the new him thinks that Mr. Harrelson has a shot at some awards glory at the Golden Globes this weekend for his against-type performance in “The Messenger” as Capt. Tony Scott, a hard-driving, hard-living Army man charged with delivering news of fallen soldiers to their families. Mr. Harrelson, of course, is a famous peacenik, a hippie by his own admission, known equally for being pro-marijuana and antiwar.

headline: Paulson and Friedman Called to Testify About A.I.G.
text: The list of those called to testify for a House inquiry into the American International Group and its payouts to its counterparties just gained a few more high-wattage witnesses.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: K2, distant and mysterious, is perhaps the most feared and respected climbing peak in the world. Graham Bowley, who reports on business for The New York Times, journeys there to discover an icy world as perilous as it is beautiful.

headline: Outsider Images in the Soviet Twilight
text: American visitors to “Four Perspectives Through the Lens: Soviet Art Photography in the 1970s-1980s,” an exhibition at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, may be surprised to discover that photography was not officially considered art in the former Soviet Union. It was regarded as a documentary tool at the service of Communist Party propaganda.

headline: Correction: No More Que Será Será: Give Day Her Due
text: An article last Sunday about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences’ lack of recognition of Doris Day referred incorrectly to the academy’s recognition of Orson Welles. He did in fact win an Oscar in a specific category, for best screenplay (“Citizen Kane”) in 1941. It is not the case that, like Charlie Chaplin, he “inexplicably never won the prize in competition.” (Welles also received an honorary Oscar in 1970.)

headline: Correction: Being Clooney: Not as Easy as It Looks
text: An article last Sunday about George Clooney misstated the profession of the character he played in “Michael Clayton.” He was a lawyer and former prosecutor; he was not a former police officer.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 944 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

headline: Correction: Coming Out in Ireland: Stories Set to Song
text: An article on Dec. 27 about the play “Silver Stars” misstated the project on which Culture Ireland and the Irish Theater Institute collaborated for the Dublin Theater Festival, where the play had a run in September. They produced a showcase with the Dublin Theater Festival, they did not produce the entire festival.

headline: Women, in All Their Glory
text: The Nassau County Museum of Art has its own building, lovely grounds and a pretty good collection, but like many suburban arts institutions, it struggles to find money for programming. One result is an exhibition like “The Subject Is Women: Impressionism and Post-Impressionism,” drawn largely from the collection of Arthur Levine, a vice president of the museum’s board, and his wife, Arlene Levine.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 15
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: A String of Successes in New London Music
text: New London

headline: The Week Ahead: Jan. 17-23
text: Dance

headline: Santo Domingo to Bedford, and Latin to Classical
text: LEONARD SLATKIN is a big jazz fan. But he was unprepared for what unfolded when, after performing as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center one spring night in 1995, he decided to catch the pianist Michel Camilo’s show at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village.

headline: Writer to Speak at a Tea on King Day
text: FOR the past 11 years, the Westchester Library System has celebrated Martin Luther King’s Birthday by holding the African-American Writers and Readers Literary Tea at Abigail Kirsch’s Tappan Hill in Tarrytown. Co-sponsored by the Westchester chapter of the Links, a service organization, the tea also ushers in Black History Month, during which African-American literature, performances, films and other events will be presented at the county’s 38 member libraries.

headline: Haitians Illegally in U.S. Given Protected Status
text: The Obama administration extended a special immigration status on Friday to Haitians living illegally in the United States that protects them from deportation for 18 months and allows them to work here.

headline: On East 95th, Lodger Was Last of the Line
text: The landlord from his old building was on the phone.

headline: Reliving the ’60s, on Screen and Live
text: If life made sense, Simone Forti’s name would be writ large, along with the other Judson Dance Theater artists who shattered conventional notions of performance in the 1960s. As it is, even those who are deeply invested in this history too seldom get a chance to see Ms. Forti’s work from this period and hear her charming, astute contextualization for it.

headline: Blaufränkisch Reveals Itself
text: Just returned from a lunch with six Austrian producers of blaufränkisch, and some of their wines were revelatory.

headline: For Crew and Passengers of Flight 1549, Reunions and Reminiscences
text: Forty degrees 46 minutes 10.19 seconds north latitude, 74 degrees 16.69 seconds west longitude: Michael Leonard had been there before.

headline: A New Look for the First Lady
text: After the family vacation in Hawaii, where a smooth, practical knot seemed to work, Michelle Obama has emerged with a new hairstyle. It looks shorter, rounder, more managed. One might be tempted to call the style an updated version of the classic Washington helmet. Mrs. Obama has tried a number of styles, their common theme a polished look that keeps the hair off her face. The style she wore around the Inaugural was somewhat longer and sportier, with bangs to one side. She did a glamorous version of that look for different events in April and May. Late in 2009, the bangs seemed to vanish.

headline: Bill Clinton Rallies With Coakley
text: Updated: BOSTON — Former President Bill Clinton, along with a veritable Who’s-who of Massachusetts Democrats rallied hundreds of supporters at a Boston hotel Friday afternoon, urging them to get out the vote amid signs that the race for the late Sen. Edward M. Kennedy’s seat is too close to call.

headline: Winter Citrus Salad
text: Mark Bittman takes a bite out of scurvy with a salad of oranges and grapefruit with honey dressing.

headline: The Gavel Falls on Tavern on the Green
text: From Glenn Collins at Diner’s Journal:

headline: Quixotes of the Theater, Chasing Complete Works
text: Theatergoers had various reasons to attend the recent opening night of “The Two Noble Kinsmen” by a small New York company called the Guerrilla Shakespeare Project. Some were lured by the play’s tale of two Theban soldiers. Others were friends of the cast or crew, or were there for the free Trader Joe’s sauvignon blanc.

headline: Negotiators Break for the Weekend
text: White House and Congressional leaders working on a final version of far-reaching health care legislation have wrapped up their discussions — at least for the weekend — and officials will now wait for cost analysis on various proposals to bridge the final differences between the House and Senate version so of the bill.

headline: Allowing Citrus to Add Sunshine
text: GOOD citrus can almost make you glad it’s winter. When it’s in season  that’s now  it’s equal or superior to anything else you can buy in the plant kingdom. Any way you can devise to eat it, you’re taking advantage of something at its peak. If this year is different because of Florida’s bad weather, it only makes the good citrus that arrives more precious.

headline: Another House Democrat Bows Out
text: Representative Vic Snyder of Arkansas announced Friday evening that he would not run for re-election in November, becoming the 11th House Democrat to bow out in the tough political environment.

headline: How Long Have You Been at Your Job?
text: In China, it’s known as the “iron rice bowl.” In the United States, it’s the “career job”: the position you have for your entire working life, the job you never expect to lose or leave. But does it exist? Or rather, did it ever exist?

headline: Duck Confit, and Hold the Fat
text: I HAD always been under the impression that making duck confit at home was a major undertaking, something along the lines of poaching a whole foie gras or deboning a pig’s foot. It was on the list of things to cook in my lifetime, but not necessarily high on the page.

headline: Battling Fears on Building Restrictions
text: Forty towns and villages out of the 111 incorporated communities on Long Island have adopted landmarking measures of varying strength to protect their historically and architecturally significant buildings and sites. Of the 40, 10 have enacted landmark laws that allow local governments to designate properties without owner consent, according to Alexandra Parsons Wolfe, director of the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities.

headline: A Bid to Preserve an Old Power Station
text: The Glenwood Power Station in Yonkers, with its twin smokestacks and majestic brick structure, is a familiar sight to riders of the Metro-North Railroad. But the station, constructed between 1904 and 1906 as part of railroad electrification, is hard to describe. “It wasn’t really built with a particular style in mind,” said Erin Tobin, a regional director for the Preservation League of New York State. “It has Romanesque Revival elements.”

headline: Hartford, a ‘Shining Example’
text: About 100 of Connecticut’s 169 cities and towns have local historic districts or other neighborhood preservation protections, but Hartford is the only place where the ordinance is citywide. In Hartford, buildings listed on the state register of historic places come under the ordinance’s jurisdiction, and those structures can be demolished only if there is no feasible or prudent alternative. “It’s a shining example,” said Helen Higgins, executive director of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation. “And it’s been hugely successful.”

headline: With a Tax, Restoring a Historic Fort
text: Fort Mott, in Pennsville, N.J., served as the main coastal defense for Philadelphia harbor during the Spanish-American War. Today, the fort, now a state park, has crumbling infrastructure and damaged walls, but not for long. Thanks to a business tax collected under a 2006 state constitutional amendment, a $1.65 million restoration project can begin.

headline: A Recession, but Threats Persist
text: During the fiscal crisis of the 1970s, when big development projects in New York City were suspended, many New Yorkers decided to save their city by preserving it.

headline: More Ways to Help Haiti
text: Here’s an update on fund raising that restaurants and others in the food world are doing to help victims of the earthquake in Haiti.

headline: From Bay State to Red State?
text: Strike One: “The mission in Afghanistan was to go in because we believed that the Taliban was giving harbor to terrorists … They’re gone. They’re not there anymore.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 15
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include passage of a medical marijuana bill, grief over lives lost in the Haitian earthquake, and the destruction of a shanty town on Long Island.

headline: New Arrests in Japan Fund-Raising Scandal
text: TOKYO  Prosecutors arrested two former aides of a leading member of Japan’s ruling party on Friday, adding to a growing scandal over campaign finance that has dogged the new government.

headline: Haitians Treated in Miami Hospitals
text: 23 patients — Haitian and American — have been admitted to the hospitals of the Jackson health system in South Florida. As of Friday afternoon, five have been discharged, seven are in critical condition, and the rest are stable. Two of the patients are children, one a 7-year-old boy, hospital administrators said. The injuries ranged from broken bones to head trauma.

headline: No Longer Their Golden Ticket
text: THE first-year corporate lawyers of “The Deep End,” a series that has its premiere on ABC this week, inhabit an alternative legal universe, where advancement on the partner track seems measured by their perfect grooming and ability to model designer suits and trade flirtatious banter.

headline: A Good Decade to Have a Drink
text: BY now, most of the reviews of the decade-that-just-was have been filed, and a consensus has emerged: If not “the worst decade ever,” as Time magazine put it, the ’00s were awful.

headline: Can Google Beat China?
text: Updated, Jan. 16, 9:40 a.m. |  Ross Anderson of Cambridge University joins the discussion. He says the growing complexity and volume of Web traffic will only make government censorship harder.

headline: Elizabeth Edwards Teeters on Her Pedestal
text: YET another illusion has been shattered.

headline: Progress Report of a Millennium Village
text: The following is the first in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones aren’t, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Torn Between 2 Phones: Nexus One vs. iPhone
text: To switch or not to switch, that is the question. Google’s announcement of its Nexus One smartphone happened over a week ago and I’m still receiving lots of Tweets and e-mail from readers asking the same question: Should they give up their iPhone for the Nexus One?

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Beatles Video Game: Sales Not So Fab
text: Here’s some news the Beatles were never used to hearing: they aren’t selling very well. According to a new report released by a market research company that tracks the video game industry, the heavily promoted (and widely lauded) game the Beatles: Rock Band has not performed as well as other popular music games, and the genre as a whole appears to be declining. The report, released on Thursday by NPD Group, said that over all the gaming industry had its best month ever in December, with more than $5.5 billion in sales of software, consoles and other hardware, and that the popular first-person shooter Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 had become the fourth-best-selling game of all time. But for games that involve the use of plastic guitars instead of guns, the picture wasn’t as rosy. The Beatles: Rock Band, which allows players to tap buttons along to the music of the Fab Four, has sold 1.18 million copies in the United States and 1.7 million copies worldwide since its release in September. By comparison, the music game Rock Band 2 sold 1.7 million copies in its first four months of release in 2008, and Guitar Hero: World Tour sold 3.4 million copies in that time. Guitar Hero 5, a franchise sequel released in September, has sold 996,000 copies.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Modest Interest in Haiti Special
text: A prime-time special about the earthquake in Haiti was no match on Thursday for the usual fare of crime shows and medical dramas. According to Nielsen’s estimates, ABC’s hourlong special, “Earthquake Haiti: Race to Save a Country,” drew 5.4 million viewers, finishing well behind Fox’s “Bones” (10.7 million) and a CBS rerun of “The Mentalist” (9.6 million). CBS led the night over all with “CSI” (15.4 million) and a new episode of “The Mentalist” at 10 (15.3 million). ABC finished second, with “Grey’s Anatomy” (12.7 million) and “Private Practice” (11 million). Fox was third with “Fringe” (6.6 million), while NBC ranked fourth with back-to-back episodes of “30 Rock” (5 million each).

headline: Being Lady Gaga Can Wear You Out
text: The relentless life of Lady Gaga, below, filled with burdensome headpieces and nonstop costume changes and makeup jobs, has at last gotten to her. On Thursday night that chameleonlike pop singer (whose real name is Stefani Germanotta) canceled a show at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., citing exhaustion, Billboard reported. On her Twitter account Lady Gaga wrote on Thursday night that she “was feeling dizzy and having trouble breathing,” and that paramedics later came and diagnosed exhaustion and dehydration. She said her show, which has many coordinated moving parts and mechanical elements, would be too dangerous to perform because, she wrote, she “had passed out earlier.” Billboard said the Indiana show would be rescheduled for Jan 26; Lady Gaga’s “Monster Ball” tour is scheduled to go to Atlantic City on Saturday and play four shows at Radio City Music Hall next week. The Associated Press reported that Lady Gaga performed on Friday on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” showing no signs of illness.

headline: Cleveland Musicians Make Case to Audience
text: Members of the Cleveland Orchestra were onstage on Thursday night for performances of Strauss’s “Don Juan,” a violin concerto by Thomas Adès and Brahms’s Second Symphony. It was their first night back with their music director, Franz Welser-Möst, since Jan. 6, when they had said that a strike could take place as early as this Monday. About 15 minutes before the concert’s 8 p.m. start time, they left the stage, and a colleague announced that they would be passing through the aisles with leaflets, which is exactly what they did. (Above, the keyboardist Joela Jones.) The leaflets made the performers’ case in a contract dispute with management, which wants them to take a salary cut this season, as staff members and executives have done. The musicians are calling for a freeze in pay at last year’s levels. After the leaflets were distributed, the players made their way back to their chairs, tuned up and started “Don Juan.”

headline: ‘Angels in America’ to Be Revived
text: The first New York revival of “Angels in America,” Tony Kushner’s landmark play about politics, AIDS and love, will begin preview performances at the Signature Theater Company on Sept. 14 and open in late October, with tickets priced at $20, Signature’s leaders announced on Thursday afternoon. The two parts of “Angels in America,” titled “Millennium Approaches” and “Perestroika,” will alternate in repertory from the start of performances and will be directed by Michael Greif, above right with Mr. Kushner and a Tony Award nominee for the musicals “Next to Normal,” “Grey Gardens” and “Rent.” The casting process is currently under way. An Off Broadway nonprofit theater, Signature has long drawn critical praise for its productions devoted to a single playwright each season and for charging an unusually low price for tickets (largely because of a grant from Time Warner Inc.). Two more works by Mr. Kushner will be presented during Signature’s 2010-11 season, its 20th. How long the initial run of “Angels” will last is not clear: Signature leaders did not give a time frame for the production, and it is almost certain to be extended if demand is strong. Subscriptions to the Kushner season will go on sale this spring, and individual tickets this summer.

headline: Editor & Publisher Finds New Owner
text: Cue the punch lines: The owner of a publication called FishRap has resuscitated Editor & Publisher, the magazine devoted to covering the newspaper industry. But the new Editor & Publisher returned to life late on Thursday, two weeks after it shut down, without two of its stalwarts. The editor, Greg Mitchell, and Joe Strupp, perhaps its best-known reporter, were not retained by the new owner, Duncan McIntosh. Mark Fitzgerald, who has worked at the magazine for 26 years, was named the new editor. Nielsen Business Media announced last month that it would close Editor & Publisher at the end of 2009, prompting inquiries from several potential buyers. The sale to the Duncan McIntosh Company, for an undisclosed sum, was announced on Thursday. Mr. McIntosh said in an interview that he wanted to shift Editor & Publisher’s focus toward the business and technology of the industry, with less emphasis on what happens in newsrooms. His company, based in Irvine, Calif., publishes several magazines and Web sites about boating and fishing, including Boating World.

headline: On Eve of Pope’s Visit to Synagogue, Some Ask if It Will Help
text: ROME  When Pope John Paul II visited Rome’s main synagogue in 1986, the first time a pope had ever entered a Jewish house of worship, it was a historic step forward in Catholic-Jewish relations. When Pope Benedict XVI visits the same synagogue on Sunday, the question is whether it will begin to repair the tensions that have developed between the two religions under his papacy.

headline: Sun Eclipsed: Ring Round the Moon
