text: The Moon did its job Friday. The annular solar eclipse was observed on the southern tip of India by Jay Pasachoff, the Williams astronomer and eclipse expert. Here’s his dispatch to the Lab from Kanyakumari:

headline: Sisters in Cinema
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: In Capital, Health Crisis Overwhelms Rescue Effort
text: With uncounted thousands dead and many thousands more injured, the stricken city of Port-au-Prince is in a vast medical crisis.

headline: Recasting Serbia’s Image, Starting With a Fresh Face
text: BELGRADE, Serbia

headline: Envoys to Meet on Possible Sanctions Over Iran Nuclear Program
text: UNITED NATIONS  Senior diplomats from the five permanent members of the Security Council and from Germany are scheduled to meet in New York on Saturday to discuss imposing new sanctions on Iran, with the Western nations seeking tough measures while China appears to be stalling for time.

headline: Strike Killed Hijacking Suspect, Pakistan Officials Say
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A militant of Palestinian origin who had been on the F.B.I.’s most-wanted list was killed in an American airstrike, two Pakistani intelligence officials said Friday.

headline: On Doubling Out of the Blue
text: If you play duplicate, at the end of a session check your scorecard and see how often the opponents went down two or more undoubled. If it happens a few times, you are not doubling for penalty often enough.

headline: Political Turmoil Follows Barring of Hundreds From Iraq Ballot
text: BAGHDAD  A knot of young men stood Friday outside the Umm Al Qura Mosque, once a nest of insurgent fervor where a year of relative tranquillity has softened the jagged edges of nearby bullet holes. They were angry, frustrated and quick to punctuate their denunciations of a decision to bar scores of Sunni candidates from Iraqi elections in March with a single word: sharaiyya, Arabic for legitimacy.

headline: Changes Made by a Single Stroke
text: Julian Casablancas seemed genuinely surprised that he was still a rock star when he brought his band to Terminal 5 on Thursday night, starting a two-night stand. A decade ago Mr. Casablancas’s band, the Strokes, spearheaded a New York City rock resurgence with concise, guitar-driven songs about alienation, glamor and strained romance. After three Strokes albums, the latest in 2006, the band members turned to solo projects, and Mr. Casablancas released his own album, “Phrazes for the Young” (Cult/RCA), in November.

headline: Kenya: Decision to Deport Cleric Prompts Protests
text: Police officers in Nairobi on Friday clashed with rock-throwing mobs who were angry about the government’s decision to deport a radical Islamist cleric. The police fired tear gas and unleashed attack dogs on hundreds of demonstrators. Witnesses said at least three people were killed. Kenyan officials recently arrested the Jamaican-born cleric, Abdullah al-Faisal, who has served jail time in Britain for inciting hatred, and are trying to deport him.

headline: Japan: Navy Ends Mission in Support of Afghan War
text: The defense minister ordered Japan’s ships to return from the Indian Ocean on Friday, fulfilling a government pledge to end an eight-year refueling mission in support of the war in Afghanistan. Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama refused to renew the law authorizing the mission, ignoring requests from the Obama administration to continue it as a show of support. Military experts have said the Japanese withdrawal would not affect military operations in Afghanistan.

headline: New Ships Idle, Waiting for Cargo to Fill Them
text: From Loch Striven in Scotland to the Strait of Malacca in Southeast Asia, more than a tenth of the vessels that transport the world’s manufactured goods in containers are idle. For most, orders to sail will not come for some time.

headline: North Korea: Anger Over a Contingency Plan
text: North Korea denounced South Korea’s reported contingency plan for the potential collapse of the North’s government, warning Friday that it would cut off all dialogue with the South and exclude it from all negotiations concerning the security of the Korean Peninsula. South Korean newspapers reported this week that the South recently revised the contingency plan in the belief that uncertain health of the North’s leader, Kim Jong-il, and the North’s deepening economic woes have made the country more unstable. The government has not confirmed the reports.

headline: Russia: Lawmakers Ratify a European Court’s Reforms
text: Parliament ratified a protocol on reforming the European Court of Human Rights on Friday. Russia has long accused the court of bias. With the measure passed, the court can now begin clearing a heavy backlog of cases, one-third of which are against Russia.

headline: F.D.A. Concerned About Substance in Food Packaging
text: In a shift of position, the Food and Drug Administration is expressing concerns about possible health risks from bisphenol-A, or BPA, a widely used component of plastic bottles and food packaging that it declared safe in 2008.

headline: Recipe: Old-Fashioned
text: Adapted from the Quarter Bar, Brooklyn

headline: Jets Fans Crave Victory, but Despair Is Never Far
text: In most ways, it is hard to typify a Jets fan. There may have been a geographic alliance once, when the team practiced on Long Island and played at Shea Stadium; those lines blurred with the team’s move to New Jersey.

headline: Italy Presses Its Fight for a Statue at the Getty
text: PESARO, Italy  One summer day in 1964 a fishing trawler from Fano, a small seaside town a few miles south of this provincial capital on the Adriatic, unexpectedly dredged up a life-size bronze statue from the ocean’s depths. Most likely fashioned in ancient Greece and lost at sea after being looted by Romans, the sculpture is now a centerpiece of the Getty Villa, part of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles.

headline: Jeffrey R. Fenster Picked for Workers’ Compensation Board Post
text: Ever since a law was passed more than two years ago to overhaul New York’s troubled system for administering claims of hurt workers, the state’s Workers’ Compensation Board has vowed to introduce sweeping improvements. Among the longstanding criticisms of the board, which employs about 1,450 people throughout the state, has been its history of hiring senior administrators without relevant qualifications.

headline: Decline in Shipping Business Puts Squeeze on Ports
text: Until mid-2008, the main worries for most port operators were congestion and a lack of infrastructure to cope with demand.

headline: Jan. 15: Updates on Rescue and Recovery in Haiti
text: On Friday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of Tuesday’s earthquake by pointing to news and information on other Web sites. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online by writing to us in the comments thread below.

headline: Poetry for Times of Calamity and War
text: Before the New York Philharmonic’s concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, Alan Gilbert, speaking on behalf of the musicians, dedicated the program to the victims of the earthquake in Haiti. As it happened, the scheduled works were movingly appropriate.

headline: Crunch Time: Selling Tales of the Great Downturn
text: The new George Clooney film, “Up in the Air,” hit a nerve with its portrayal of an unmoored corporate executioner who makes his living by firing people. Now several writers and their publishers are hoping to catch the same wave with a cluster of forthcoming memoirs and novels that describe the fallout of losing a job, losing a house or losing an investment account.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about Google’s threat to leave China because of what the company called hacker assaults and efforts to limit free speech on the Web misidentified, in some copies, the organizational affiliation of Rebecca MacKinnon, an expert on the Chinese Internet. She is a fellow at the Open Society Institute, a New York-based democracy advocacy group; she is not with the Open Space Institute, a New York-based environmental group.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the earthquake that struck Haiti on Tuesday misspelled, at one point, the surname of a New York photographer who was in Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital, and described what she called a scene of “general mayhem.” As noted elsewhere in the article, she is Tequila Minsky, not Minksy.

headline: Hershey Moves Closer to Making Cadbury Bid
text: Hershey edged closer to a bid for Cadbury of Britain on Friday, people briefed on the matter told DealBook, just days before Kraft is set to disclose its final offer for the confectioner.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about a federal judge’s ruling that the Food and Drug Administration could no longer block imports of electronic cigarettes from China paraphrased incorrectly from a statement released by Matthew L. Myers, president of the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, about the decision. Mr. Myers said the ruling opened a loophole in the F.D.A.’s ability to regulate nontobacco products containing nicotine. He did not say it opened a loophole in the new federal law that gives the F.D.A. authority to regulate tobacco products.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Friday about the actor Santino Fontana, who has withdrawn from the Broadway revival of “A View From the Bridge” because of an injury suffered onstage, misidentified the director of the short-lived revival of “Brighton Beach Memoirs” in which Mr. Fontana appeared last fall. It was directed by David Cromer, not Gregory Mosher. (As the report noted, Mr. Mosher is the director of “A View From the Bridge.”)

headline: Michael Kaufman, Times Reporter Who Roamed World, Is Dead at 71
text: Michael T. Kaufman, a former foreign correspondent, reporter and columnist for The New York Times who chronicled despotic regimes in Europe and Africa, the fall of Communism and the changing American scene for four decades, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 71.

headline: Corrections
text: A Spare Times entry on Friday about a screening of an excerpt from the documentary “AbUSed  The Postville Raid” at Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village and a post-screening discussion misstated the suggested donation. It is $10, not $20.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Jan. 6 about the abstract artist Kenneth Noland omitted a former wife, Peggy Schiffer. (His wife, Paige Rense, survives him.)

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: MSNBC: New York Times Edition
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC provides updates on the humanitarian crisis in Haiti, reports on the tightening of the Massachusetts Senate race and speaks with Gretchen Morgenson about a proposed tax on big banks.

headline: A400M Is Supported, but Money Is at Issue
text: Military officials from the countries signed up to buy the Airbus A400M transport plane reaffirmed their commitment to the much-delayed project on Friday but failed to reveal any additional financing.

headline: Ruined Ports Hindering Delivery of Relief
text: MIAMI  The first cargo ship carrying aid for quake-damaged Haiti set sail for the northern port of Cap Haïtien Friday evening, but most shipping companies that usually supply the country with goods are still unable to reach the desperate islanders because the main pier in Port-au-Prince has splintered and fallen into the ocean.

headline: F.C.C. Orders Wireless Mike Modifications
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Broadway theaters, sports franchises and other public entertainment forums must change the radio frequency they use for their wireless microphones under an order issued Friday by the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: A Place Where Diversity Extends to Sexuality
text: Huddled with aides last week in a room upstairs from his future district office, which the incumbent he defeated in the Democratic primary had yet to clear out, City Councilman Daniel Dromm ironed out the final details of his inauguration party.

headline: O’Brien and NBC Are Close to a Deal for His Departure
text: NBC and representatives of the network’s disaffected “Tonight Show” host, Conan O’Brien, continued negotiations Friday to settle his contract, but no outcome was expected Friday, according to one participant in the talks.

headline: Lady BlahBlah
text: I have often accused Sarah Palin of having more fight than strategy in her. But I must concede that her decision to become a contributor to Fox News is a shrewd one. Touché, Barracuda.

headline: Reuniting on the Hudson, but Smiling This Time
text: Forty degrees 46 minutes 10.19 seconds north latitude, 74 degrees 16.69 seconds west latitude: Michael Leonard had been there before.

headline: Trusted Aides to Bloomberg Get Big Bonuses
text: Patricia E. Harris, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s most trusted aide at City Hall, earned $451,000, including a $400,000 bonus, for less than two months of work on his re-election campaign, according to newly released documents. The records showed that Mr. Bloomberg showered his top aides with six-figure bonuses despite a narrower-than-expected re-election victory in November.

headline: Dapper, Privileged and Unapologetic
text: In retrospect, it should have always been clear that the polarizing New York indie-rock band Vampire Weekend had a little bit of ska in its DNA. Later iterations of that genre, revived every decade or so, gave secondhand consumption a bad name, its manhandling of reggae signifiers the laziest and most regrettable sort of musical borrowing.

headline: New Meaning to the ‘Haitian’ in ‘Haitian-American’
text: Detective Claude Jean-Pierre has stumbled through the terrible hours and days after the earthquake in a daze every Haitian recognizes. He slept a few hours each night and could not concentrate on work. He called relatives and searched every corner of the Internet for information. He started a list of volunteers, of police officers in his Brooklyn precinct, to go to the nation and help.

headline: 99.5 FM, Where the Board Meetings Make the Broadcasts Seem Tame
text: Comrades, comrades.

headline: 11 Networks Plan a 2-Hour Telethon
text: Eleven broadcast and cable networks will show a two-hour telethon next Friday night to benefit the victims of the Haiti earthquake, MTV Networks announced on Friday.

headline: At Sotheby’s, Tracing the Lives Behind the Letters
text: What is more moving: the meaning of important words or the trace left by their formulation, the sense of a precious document or the lines of ink that convey it? Does it matter, for example, that until next Saturday at Sotheby’s it is possible to look at the 1862 message in which Abraham Lincoln wrote to his dilatory Civil War general, George B. McClellan, urging him to take action? Or that we can read letters in which Benedict Arnold seems to be making a few too many excuses for himself during the Revolutionary War?

headline: Narrow Senate Race Unnerves Democrats on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON  With their party’s candidate struggling in Massachusetts in a race for what should be the safest of Senate seats, Congressional Democrats are growing increasingly unnerved about the political consequences of the health care overhaul even as their leadership closes in on a final agreement.

headline: Scaling the Digital Wall in China
text: The Great Firewall of China is hardly impregnable.

headline: State Looks at Doubling Cap on Charter Schools
text: New York legislators are poised to at least double the number of charter schools allowed in the state in an attempt to win as much as $700 million in federal education grants.

headline: With Rent Increase, Dangerous Stress
text: Cleo Wilder rises every day at 4:30 a.m. and embarks on a brisk walk  a holdover, he said, from his two-year stint in the Army at the dawn of the Vietnam War.

headline: Obama to Campaign for Senate Candidate in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON  In a last-ditch effort to avert a debacle for the Democrats, the White House announced that President Obama would campaign here on Sunday for Martha Coakley, the Democratic Senate candidate, amid growing signs that the race for Edward M. Kennedy’s Senate seat has become too close to call.

headline: Pick for Top Digital Job in Europe Is Grilled
text: BERLIN  The nomination of Neelie Kroes, who was hard-nosed as Europe’s antitrust chief, to a new post as commissioner for the digital agenda was in doubt Friday after she was accused of being evasive during a testy appearance before a committee of the European Parliament.

headline: For the Trapped, Rescue Is but the First Hurdle
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Herby Amel’s father dug through the collapsed college building first, pulling out a body so he could reach his son, trapped 20 feet into the pile. But when a rescue team from Miami arrived early Friday morning, Herby’s left ankle remained pinned under a fallen beam.

headline: Government Struggles to Exhume Itself
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  It did not take very long for Edwin Paraison, a member of Haiti’s cabinet, to take stock of his losses and deliver a thorough assessment of what remained of his government ministry.

headline: Hershey Said to Be Closer to an Offer for Cadbury
text: Hershey edged closer to a bid for Cadbury of Britain on Friday, people briefed on the matter said. The move comes just days before Kraft is set to disclose its final offer for the confectioner.

headline: N.B.A. Rookie Closes Inner Circle After Deadly Shot Is Fired
text: PHILADELPHIA  When Sacramento Kings guard Tyreke Evans was 7 years old, he hit the winning basket to beat his friend Dwayne Davis’s team and remain unbeaten in a youth league. Davis was inconsolable, so Evans’s oldest brother, James, visited his locker room and invited him to a nearby Chuck E. Cheese restaurant with the family.

headline: Wizards’ Arenas Pleads Guilty to One Felony Gun Charge
text: WASHINGTON  Washington Wizards guard Gilbert Arenas pleaded guilty Friday to one count of carrying a pistol without a license in the District of Columbia.

headline: Broadcast Coverage: Compassion and Self-Congratulation
text: One moment looters brandishing machetes trot through streets of Port-au-Prince lined with corpses, and soon after, Robin Roberts, a host of “Good Morning America,” kneels over a sleeping child, tenderly stroking her back.

headline: Capmark Investments Files for Bankruptcy
text: Capmark Investments, a unit of the bankrupt commercial property lender Capmark Financial Group, filed for bankruptcy in a bid to sell its management contracts and interests in real estate equity funds. Capmark Investments listed assets and debt of at least $1 billion on a Chapter 11 petition on Friday in Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. Its parent filed for bankruptcy last year amid falling property values and a drop in lending. The unit manages equity real estate and mortgage-related investments in the public and private markets, and had more than $1.7 billion under management as of Dec. 31, according to its Web site. Capmark Investments reached a deal on Thursday to sell the contracts and general partnership interest in its real estate equity funds to an unspecified third party, it said. The unit said it would seek bankruptcy court approval of the sale.

headline: Agreement Expected in NBC’s Talks With O’Brien
text: NBC and representatives of the network’s disaffected “Tonight Show” host, Conan O’Brien, have continued negotiations to settle his contract, but no outcome was expected Friday, according to one participant in the talks.

headline: A Gangland Bus Tour, With Lunch and a Waiver
text: LOS ANGELES  The tour organizer received assurances, he says, from four gangs that they would not harass the bus when it passed through their turf. Paying customers must sign releases warning of potential danger. And after careful consideration, it was decided not to have residents shoot water guns at the bus and sell “I Got Shot in South Central” T-shirts.

headline: China, Where U.S. Internet Companies Often Fail
text: SHANGHAI  If Google pulls out of China because of frustration with government restrictions, it will not be the first time an American Internet giant has retreated from the country.

headline: Saints Aim for the Strong Finish They’ve Talked About
text: NEW ORLEANS  The front of the black T-shirt shows the fleur-de-lis in gold with the words “Our City, Our Home.” On the back are the words “Finish Strong.”

headline: 25 Down: Deer Stalkers
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Have you ever been stumped by a clue and asked someone for help, perhaps even by posting a comment here — and the moment you did, the answer came to you? I mention this because that’s what happened to me with an answer in today’s NW territory, where I was momentarily stumped. The minute I asked my wife, who was passing by, the light dawned.

headline: Tennessee Hires Louisiana Tech’s Dooley as Coach
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  It was only a 35-minute introductory news conference, but it was also 35 minutes of a do-over. A year of brashness under Lane Kiffin was replaced with a more mature tone from Derek Dooley, who was introduced as Tennessee’s coach here Friday night.

headline: In Health Talks, President Is Hands-Off No More
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has taken full control of the health care negotiations, casting himself for the first time in the role of mediator between the House and Senate during a 72-hour marathon of talks that have turned his White House into a de facto Congressional conference.

headline: One Shining Moment for Pendergrass
text: Teddy Pendergrass, who died Wednesday, was an R&B superstar, but he also had a place in the hearts of many college basketball fans. For several years in the 1990s, it was the voice of Pendergrass that fans heard when CBS played “One Shining Moment,” the song that accompanies the highlight reel that traditionally ends its coverage of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Men Who Once Bent Steel Are Now on Bended Knee
text: Tom Townsend pulled a quarter from his coat pocket. It was no ordinary quarter: He usually keeps it and another one just like it in a plastic case at home, and as he held the rusty-brown 1996 coin in his hand at a funeral home in Brooklyn on Thursday night, people gathered around and stared at it and touched it, tracing their fingers over its unnatural U-shaped curve.

headline: Officer Is Convicted of Abusing Power in Seeking Sex
text: A New York City police officer who is accused of sexually assaulting several women was convicted Friday of telling an 18-year-old that he would destroy a summons he was issuing her in exchange for oral sex.

headline: On the Street | Puffed
text: The inexpensive and lightweight puffy down coats that have been around for decades have taken sophisticated new shapes, often in licorice black and in fabrics that resemble ciré.

headline: Plan Would Allow SUNY and CUNY to Set Tuition
text: Gov. David A. Paterson proposed on Friday that the State University of New York and the City University of New York be allowed to set their own tuition rates, a plan that would end a longstanding policy under which tuition increases are determined by the State Legislature.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Gender Testing Hangs Before the Games as a Muddled and Vexing Mess
text: At closed meetings in Miami on Sunday and Monday, medical specialists and representatives of the International Olympic Committee will tackle one of the most vexing questions in sports: What test should be used to determine whether an athlete competes as a man or a woman? Or should there be any official testing at all?

headline: Excerpt: 'Spartacus: Blood and Sand'
text: The new Starz series updates the Spartacus legend.

headline: Creams Offering Lighter Skin May Bring Risks
text: For years, Allison Ross rubbed in skin-lightening creams with names like Hyprogel and Fair & White. She said she wanted to even out and brighten the tone of her face, neck and hands. Mrs. Ross, 45, who lives in Brooklyn, also said that she used the lightening creams “to be more accepted in society.”

headline: The Road West
text: When I drive from New York to California, as I did again last week, I always hope I’m going to get a kind of backyard view of the present-day United States. But what I discover is that I’m driving through the past. The road west is littered with the bones of old vehicles, taunting me in their rusted glory from just beyond the fence-line. Every echo of Route 66 is a reminder of a time when the highway was a trail of automotive woe, of engine failures and bad rubber, of drivers on bended knee in front of a jack.

headline: Broad Minds Encourage Broad Laughter
text: It’s often been said that stand-up comedy is the most subjective art form. What’s side-splitting to one person is seditious to the next. Yet while the evolving dynamics of the Bay Area entertainment scene have broadened traditional definitions of what constitutes comedy, some of the audience still takes a narrow view of what’s funny and what isn’t.

headline: Swine Flu Deaths Reach 11,000
text: About 11,000 Americans have died of swine flu as of last month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. The agency’s previous estimate  for deaths from April, when the virus was discovered, to mid-November  was about 10,000. Because the second wave peaked in late October, the number is unlikely to rise much unless there is a third wave later this winter. The estimate by the World Health Organization as of Jan. 3 was 12,799 deaths worldwide. The two numbers are not directly comparable because the W.H.O. counts only laboratory-confirmed deaths. Only a small fraction of all flu cases are tested by laboratories, especially in poor and middle-income countries, and many deaths that the flu causes are officially given other reasons, like pneumonia or heart failure.

headline: Minaya Dials Back Mets’ Ire on Beltran
text: A day after the Mets sent an assistant to do verbal battle on the team’s behalf, General Manager Omar Minaya was back in place Friday, trying to smooth over the strained relationship between the club and Carlos Beltran.

headline: Raptors’ Bosh Likes Garden, Not the Glare
text: The first time Chris Bosh performed at Madison Square Garden, he played against Carmelo Anthony and Amar’e Stoudemire as a high school senior in the McDonald’s All-American Game.

headline: Bloggingheads: In Defense of 'Negro'
text: John McWhorter, left, of the Manhattan Institute and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the Harry Reid controversy.

headline: The Fire and the Focus of the Ivy League
text: HANOVER, N.H.  Kathy Delaney-Smith, the coach of the Harvard women’s basketball team, learned that she had breast cancer in December 1999, but she did not go public with the news until a month later. After a victory over Dartmouth, she let the news slip in a postgame interview.

headline: Leno and O’Brien Continue War of Words, More Coolly
text: The war of words between NBC’s two late-night stars cooled a bit Friday night, but both Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien offered a few jokes about their status at NBC and in recent press reports.

headline: Pastors in Northwest Find Focus in ‘Green’
text: MILLWOOD, Wash.  State auditors told Millwood Community Presbyterian Church last summer to close its farmers’ market on the church parking lot or the lot could no longer be claimed as tax-exempt. Without hesitation, the church kept the market and paid the $700 in annual taxes.

headline: Cadillac Plans
text: The agreement between the White House, Congressional leaders and labor unions over taxing high-priced health insurance policies is a reasonable solution to an issue that was threatening to derail health care reform. The agreement treats unionized workers far more favorably than nonunion workers, the price for the support of important Democratic constituencies. But it would preserve the tax’s crucial role in slowing the rise in health care costs for decades to come.

headline: Major Hasan’s Smooth Ascension
text: Pentagon officials are taking a sobering look at the career of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who has been charged with murder in a shooting spree in November that left 13 people dead in Fort Hood, Tex. Investigators have found that Major Hasan moved smoothly up the ladder despite early signs of an erratic temperament and instances of questionable behavior, all obvious to his superiors.

headline: Catching Up
text: At the start of 2008, all was going according to Marcia Bladen’s plans. She was earning enough as an administrative assistant at Time Warner to support her young son and, at night, was working on a master’s degree in community health. In time, she was expecting to get a second master’s, in clinical psychology, and open a rehabilitation center. She was not expecting to lose her job.

headline: Lend Me Your Ears
text: This just in from the Christian Broadcasting Network: The Rev. Pat Robertson did not say that the earthquake in Haiti was the result of God’s wrath at the Haitians for making a pact with the devil to get out from under French colonial rule.

headline: Resolve Among the Ruins
text: In Haiti, the apocalypse wears the trappings of the norm. It’s a place where heartbreak never seems to end.

headline: My Nights With Eric
text: TO those of us who have seen all of Eric Rohmer’s films it is impossible not to remember when, where, with whom we saw each one. I even remember the second and third time I saw his films. “My Night at Maud’s,” “Claire’s Knee,” “Chloe in the Afternoon” are grafted onto my life. Something happened between me and these films at the Thalia, at the Brattle, at the old Cinémathèque, or at the old Olympia Theater on the Upper West Side. But I can no longer isolate what that something is. I don’t even care to know what was exclusively Eric Rohmer’s and what was mine, what he was ever so cautious to convey and what I most likely misunderstood completely. The mix, as sometimes happens, becomes the work of art.

headline: Hasib Sabbagh, Co-Founder of Middle East Builder, Is Dead at 90
text: Hasib Sabbagh, a founder of the Consolidated Contractors Company International, one of the largest construction companies in the Middle East, died on Jan. 12 in Cleveland. He was 90.

headline: Geothermal Drilling Safeguards Imposed
text: The United States Energy Department, concerned about earthquake risk, will impose new safeguards on geothermal energy projects that drill deep into the Earth’s crust.

headline: Raptors Remind Knicks What Boos Sound Like
text: In the Knicks’ recent surge, Madison Square Garden had been a security blanket. They won 8 of their last 10 home games before Friday’s encounter with Toronto.

headline: Correction
text: An article on Jan. 3 that evaluated President Obama’s policies in the context of progressivism misspelled the surname of a historical political figure with whom Obama was compared. He was Robert La Follette, not La Follete.

headline: Court to Rule on Right to Privacy for Referendum Petition Signers

headline: A Truncated Term for the Democrats’ 60th Vote
text: WASHINGTON  Paul G. Kirk Jr. cannot be sure who will be succeeding him as the junior senator from Massachusetts or exactly when the transition will occur. But he can be certain that his time as a stand-in for the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy is running out.

headline: Health issues in a Millennium Village
text: The following is the second in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones aren’t, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

headline: China at Odds With Future in Internet Fight
text: BEIJING  At the elite Tsinghua University here, some students were joking Friday that they had better download all the Internet information they wanted now in case Google left the country.

headline: Morgan Stanley Tries on a New Psyche
text: JAMES P. GORMAN, a 6-foot-2 Australian, recently took up boxing lessons, in keeping with some of the trappings of his Midtown Manhattan office. On one wall, opposite an inspirational poem by Rudyard Kipling (“The Thousandth Man”), hangs a photograph of Elvis Presley sparring with Muhammad Ali.

headline: Kashmir Suicide Bomber Strikes Pakistani Soldiers
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber detonated his explosives on the Pakistani side of the Kashmir region on Saturday in a rare attack on the Pakistani military there.

headline: Spurs Are Saving Duncan for the Playoffs
text: On Tuesday night, Tim Duncan poured in 25 points and added 13 rebounds, 4 blocks, 4 assists and 2 steals for San Antonio in a 105-85 victory over the visiting Los Angeles Lakers. It was just another solid game from one of the most consistent players in the league.

headline: Palatopharyngoplasty Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I’ve always thought that writing a puzzle is like solving a puzzle. The same problems are tackled, just from different directions. I mention this because Ms. Cox and Mr. Rathvon have added a challenge to the “puzzle they solved” in creating today’s acrostic. Take a look at the A-to-Y answers. Did you notice anything about them, something they have in common?

headline: Senate Candidates Storm the Bay State by Bus
text: BOSTON, Mass. — The candidates for the open United States Senate seat in Massachusetts are hopscotching the state via bus Saturday as the tight race to fill the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s seat heads into its final days.

headline: Bagram Detainees Named by U.S.

headline: Quake Ignores Class Divisions of a Poor Land
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Marie Garmell Neptune, cradling one of her children and holding the hand of another, had lost everything. But as she boarded an American military cargo plane for Miami on Saturday with just the clothes on her back, she was one of the lucky ones.

headline: Son Learns From His Father, but Puts Trust in Himself

headline: Crime Rises as Aid Awaits Distribution
text: While countries and relief agencies have showered aid on Haiti, little of it is reaching increasingly desperate Haitians. Across the city, there were reports of intensifying looting and violence.

headline: NBC’s Slide to Troubled Nightly Punch Line

headline: In Show of Support, Clinton Goes to Haiti
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Bearing soap, bottled water and other much-needed supplies, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton flew into this ruined capital on Saturday and told the Haitian people that the United States “will be here today, tomorrow and for the time ahead.”

headline: Twilight for Tomlinson, but Another Chance to Shine

headline: Buying Landmarks? Easy. Keeping Them? Maybe Not.

text: ANYONE wondering how consumer rights might be faring in the Washington debate over financial regulatory reform has a lot to consider theses days.

text: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was not an image the sport of tennis wanted broadcast to the world, a player screaming and writhing in pain on the court and unable to receive help of any kind.

text: The owner of a Bronx diner has been accused of hiring a man to set his establishment ablaze last month, causing a five-alarm fire that burned for five hours as it ripped through a commercial stretch of the Norwood neighborhood, the authorities said.

headline: Gaining a Toehold for the E-Bike
text: TECHNOLOGY has eliminated many of life’s milder physical demands, like getting off the couch to change the channel, or going to the store to buy a book.

headline: Chinese Site Criticizes Investor for Its Google Support
text: In an unusual move, the Alibaba Group of China on Saturday criticized Yahoo, one of its largest shareholders, for siding with Google after a cyber attack on that company.

headline: The Iranian Exile’s Eye

headline: A Clear Coating, With Green Applications
text: IMAGINE how great it would be if, after dinner, you could stack the greasy dishes, pots, pans and utensils in the sink and let plain old water rinse away the grime  with no help from detergents, and little or no scrubbing. Bye-bye, dishpan hands.

headline: Bernanke and the Beast
text: IS galloping inflation around the corner? Without doubt, the United States is exhibiting some of the classic precursors to out-of-control inflation. But a deeper look suggests that the story is not so simple.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 17
text: This Sunday’s lineup of officials focus the bulk of their conversations on the relief efforts in Haiti, and the health care negotiations on Capitol Hill take a distant second place.

headline: O’Brien Tops Letterman in Friday’s Ratings
text: Conan O’Brien scored a sweeping win in the ratings on Friday night, continuing what looks increasingly like a victory lap in finishing his run on the “Tonight” show.

headline: Taking Away Directors’ Rubber Stamps
text: IT sounds like good work if you can get it, and thousands of people in corporate America do. On average, they attend 8 to 12 meetings annually. Although they are supposed to have fiduciary obligations, they often appear simply to warm their assigned seats, and to raise their hands when their leader calls for a vote. For that, they can receive as much as $640,000 a year.

headline: Birds of a Feather Wear Bad Costumes Together
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  Memo to Evan Lysacek: Nobody ever won the Olympics dressed as a magpie.

headline: Political Loyalty (or Lack of It) in the Tell-All Era
text: Late in the new book “Game Change,” a chronicle of the 2008 presidential campaign that has much of Washington cringing and the rest of the country gasping, comes a scene that may not match others for pure titillation but has an eerie, pitiable resonance all its own.

headline: The Road to the Cure
text: AT 8 o’clock most nights, my four siblings and I would gather around the TV. My dad was director of advertising for CBS in the early 1960s, and it was our family pastime to pick apart the ads on the different channels.

headline: From the Archive: Haiti, Alive
text: “There is a saying in Creole, the language of the streets here, that translates, ‘Beyond the mountains, more mountains,”’ Richard J. Meislin, a New York Times foreign correspondent, wrote from Port-au-Prince in 1982. “It is both literally and figuratively the story of this country, where life is increasingly a daily contest between nearly insurmountable poverty and nearly unbreakable faith.”

headline: Concrete Solutions
text: It’s obvious that many of the buildings that collapsed during the Haitian earthquake were poorly designed or constructed. In Haiti, because there is virtually no lumber for building, structures have been made of concrete blocks, often with inadequately reinforced concrete frames. But to suggest that the country simply be rebuilt to a technically higher standard is to take a shortsighted approach.

headline: When Stress Flirts With Burnout
text: Q. You are a professional who is accustomed to stress, but all the uncertainty and anxiety in the workplace these days is putting you under more pressure than usual. You feel burned out  are you?

headline: Two Belgians Qualify for Australian Open
text: The Belgians Xavier Malisse and Yanina Wickmayer made emphatic statements today at the Australian Open qualifying tournament, winning their way into the main draw after a winter of controversy surrounding their bans from professional tennis.

headline: Haiti in Ink and Tears: A Literary Sampler
text: Today is a good day to remember that in Haiti, nobody ever really dies. The many thousands who've had the breath crushed out of their bodies in the earthquake, and the thousands more who will not physically survive the aftermath, will undergo instead a translation of state, according to the precepts of Haitian Vodou, some form of which is practiced by much of the population. Spirits of the Haitian dead — sa nou pa we yo, those we don’t see — do not depart as in other religions but remain extremely close to the living, invisible but tangible, inhabiting a parallel universe on the other side of any mirror, beneath the surface of all water, just behind the veil that divides us from our dreams.

headline: Eight Ways to Rebuild Haiti
text: When the immediate crisis passes, how can we ensure that Haiti becomes a functioning nation? Eight experts give their prescriptions.

headline: A Broadcaster Turned Replay Editor
text: The N.H.L.’s video-review system has functioned well for 18 seasons. That is, until a defect in the system was exposed in the aftermath of a Penguins-Flyers game played on Jan. 7.

headline: Charlie Cook responds
text: In comments, Charlie Cook responds to my post expressing puzzlement over what it would have meant, or what difference it would have made, if Obama had “focused on the economy” rather than turning to health care:

headline: Squatters’ Rights
text: There are about a billion squatters in the world today, and over time many have transformed their once-squalid communities into normal urban neighborhoods. In the awful aftermath of the tremor that turned hundreds of thousands of Haitians into refugees in their own hometown, a few sensible squatter principles may hold out hope for the devastated residents of Port-au-Prince:

headline: After ‘SportsCenter’ Moment, Le Moyne Returns to Division II Reality
text: SYRACUSE  On Nov. 3, Le Moyne College pulled off perhaps the most stunning upset of the college basketball season. The Dolphins defeated the crosstown power Syracuse University in an exhibition game at the Carrier Dome, starting an unparalleled run of publicity.

headline: Clouds Beginning to Lift for a Player From Benin
text: VILLANOVA, Pa.  Frank Tchuisi, a Villanova graduate assistant, received the phone call around midnight in San Juan, P.R.

headline: Blip
text: Calculated Risk beat me to this: the economists at Goldman Sachs are now predicting 5.8 percent growth in the fourth quarter. But they also say that the headline number will be highly misleading: two-thirds of the growth will be an inventory bounce, with final demand growing only 2 percent. In short, it will be a blip.

headline: Skip the Graft
text: America’s efforts to assist Haiti over the last 20 years were hobbled by bitter partisan division over Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country’s elected, deposed and then reinstalled president. Unfortunately, as the American debate over policy toward Haiti subsided with Mr. Aristide’s final ouster in 2004, so did American interest.

headline: A Presidential Triple Plea for Haiti Fund
text: WASHINGTON  Former Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton began a new venture on Saturday to raise money for the Haitian relief effort from corporations, foundations and ordinary Americans, as President Obama pledged to ramp up the American response to the devastating earthquake.

headline: Tebow to Appear in Super Bowl Ad for Focus on the Family
text: The former Florida quarterback Tim Tebow will appear with his mother in a 30-second Super Bowl ad for the Christian group Focus on the Family, which says the theme will be “Celebrate Family, Celebrate Life.”

headline: Forget Gum. Walking and Using Phone Is Risky.
text: SAN FRANCISCO  On the day of the collision last month, visibility was good. The sidewalk was not under repair. As she walked, Tiffany Briggs, 25, was talking to her grandmother on her cellphone, lost in conversation.

headline: Learn From Postwar Tokyo
text: The standard approach to residential redevelopment projects is to take ground zero as a starting point  even if it means creating it. This often translates into shifting people from substandard but incrementally developing environments into apartment blocks that cut them off from their social networks and livelihoods. These projects often become housing-centric and blind to the relationship between neighborhoods and economic development. They end up benefiting the construction industry much more than the population they are supposed to serve.

headline: Structure? The Flatter, the Better
text: This interview with Cristóbal Conde, president and C.E.O. of SunGard, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: A Recovery Built on Water
text: When Columbus landed on Hispaniola in 1492, he marveled at the island’s luxuriant, towering forests. Today, on the Haitian side of the island, only 2 percent of the forest cover remains. During storms, water rushes off barren hillsides, causing deadly mudslides, clogging streams with soil and sewage and disappearing before it can replenish Haiti’s diminishing groundwater reserves.

headline: For ‘Safe’ Investors, This May Be a Challenging Year
text: MONEY market funds are paying investors next to nothing.

headline: Easy Money
text: The United States has a vast bureaucracy to scrutinize how our government spends money abroad. While this kind of oversight is often necessary, there must be an exception made for crisis response in failed states. I base this on my experience after the Iraq invasion.

headline: Sluggers and Bankers in the Strikeout Era
text: It seems fitting that in the same week that the mandarins of American finance were yanked to Capitol Hill to explain their roles in the global financial crisis, the baseball slugger Mark McGwire finally came clean about how he managed to crush so many monstrous home runs.

headline: Final: Saints 45, Cardinals 14
text: Joe Lapointe was in New Orleans, and provided live analysis of Saturday’s game between the Cardinals and the Saints, along with Andy Benoit, the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Guantánamo to the Rescue
text: Coinciding with the one-year anniversary of President Obama’s unfulfilled pledge to close the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, the disaster in Haiti suggests a new mission for the United States naval base, one that might burnish America’s reputation in the world, if not redeem the base itself. Guantánamo is just 200 miles from Port-au-Prince, only 50 miles farther than Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic, where American officials are staging earthquake recovery operations. Even as the United States works to close the prison, it should use the base for humanitarian intervention.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 5: Tensions Rising
text: Tension and frustrations are mounting in Port-au-Prince as aid workers scramble to reach survivors in need of food, water and medical supplies.

headline: Keep the Economy Underground
text: The underground economy in places like Haiti is often viewed as a criminal sector, made up of thugs and warlords, that sets back economic growth. But this is a one-sided portrait. Informal trading may be critical for Haiti’s recovery. Citizens in developing countries tend to find creative ways to make ends meet. The sharing of tools and workspaces, collective ownership of property, revolving credit associations and barter systems make up the backbone of the economy.

headline: Pope Quiz: Is Every Pontiff a Saint?
text: When Pope Benedict XVI approved a decree last month that nudged nearer to sainthood his controversial wartime predecessor, Pius XII, he sparked another round of the sort of Jewish-Catholic disputations that have marked his papacy, and even cast doubt on whether his trip to Rome’s main synagogue, set for Sunday, would go on.

headline: Where Baby Orwell Lived
text: The Bihar provincial government in India announced recently that it intended to restore George Orwell’s birthplace, in the town of Motihari, and open it as a museum. Doesn’t hurt to be reminded that Orwell was a child of the Raj — as was Kipling, whose birthplace, in Mumbai, is already a museum — but it’s hard to imagine that the Orwell bungalow will become much of an attraction. Orwell spent a mere year there, his first, and Motihari, on the Nepalese border, is one of the remotest places in India.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: With World Watching, Rio Focuses on Security
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  The police will invade 40 of the most violent slums in this city before the 2014 soccer World Cup being held in Brazil, with the goal of establishing a permanent policing presence in communities now controlled by well-armed drug gangs, Rio State officials say.

headline: For Charities, Fewer and Smaller Gifts
text: As the outpouring of donations to Haiti has made clear, the charitable impulse is alive and well. But it was somewhat in abeyance in 2009, as the recession limited people’s ability to give and even caused some givers to become receivers.

headline: Admission Doesn’t Guarantee Entry
text: If one of Mark McGwire’s objectives for confessing his use of performance-enhancing drugs was to help his Hall of Fame candidacy, he may need to find another approach.

headline: A Helping Hand for Haiti
text: This weekend, President Obama asked us to spearhead private-sector fund-raising efforts in the aftermath of the magnitude 7.0 earthquake that ravaged Haiti. We are pleased to answer his call.

headline: Test for Chile’s Coalition in Presidential Election
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  Facing the prospect that Chile could swing to the right for the first time in two decades, Eduardo Frei took the stage in the working-class neighborhood of La Granja and pressed his leftist credentials one more time.

headline: Olympic Fever Never Went Away
text: Scott Blackmun has had a case of what he calls five-ring fever since 1992, when he received his first legal assignment for the United States Olympic Committee. Now he is getting ready to begin what he considers his dream job as chief executive of the U.S.O.C. Blackmun, 52, had been the acting chief executive of the organization in 2000 and 2001. Then he went on to work as the chief operating officer for the Anschutz Entertainment Group, overseeing the development of the company’s stadiums, theaters and arenas. He returns to the Olympic committee Jan. 26; the Vancouver Olympics begin Feb 12. And his three teenage children approve. KATIE THOMAS

headline: Weld Joins Brown in Mass. Senate Rally
text: PLYMOUTH — State Senator Scott Brown started his day at a raucous rally with former Gov. William F. Weld, in front of the Quincy, Mass., library.

headline: Iraqi Politicians Form New Secular Coalition
text: BAGHDAD  Prominent Iraqi politicians on Saturday announced the formation of what might emerge as the country’s most powerful secular coalition in parliamentary elections in March, a group that includes a vice president, a former prime minister and a leading Sunni lawmaker who was barred last week from taking part in the vote.

headline: Letters: Critical Thinking in Business School
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: Hedge Fund Strategies, at Smaller Prices
text: An article last Sunday in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, about hedge fund strategies in mutual funds referred incorrectly to the hedge fund partnerships of Broadmark Asset Management. While the firm converted one such partnership into the Broadmark/Forward Tactical Growth mutual fund, it still has others.

headline: J.F.K. Terminal Evacuated After Security Breach
text: A terminal at Kennedy International Airport was evacuated on Saturday afternoon after a passenger apparently used a restricted exit, a breach that delayed dozens of flights and threw the area into chaos as hundreds of people were rescreened, the authorities said.

headline: Tennessee Tries to Give Its Fans a Reason to Believe
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  When someone pulls up in a car to take him to the store or to the movies or to go bowling, Bobby Maze, a senior guard on Tennessee’s basketball team, does not immediately jump in. First, he has to ask the big question.

headline: Radio Show for Focus on the Family Founder
text: Dr. James Dobson, the founder of  Focus on the Family and an influential voice for Christian conservatives, is about to depart from the organization he created and is starting a radio program that will give him greater leeway to hold forth on politics.

headline: Washington Border Area Is Bracing for Games
text: BELLINGHAM, Wash.  For nearly six years a group of as many as 150 government officials from dozens of security agencies have been meeting in Washington State every 90 days to discuss how to prepare for the 2010 Winter Olympics. Unlike security agencies gathering in Vancouver, the site of the Games next month, this group’s focus has largely been on this side of the Canadian border.

headline: An Odd Couple Defends Couples That Some (Oddly) Find Odd
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: In Latino Gardens, Vegetables, Good Health and Savings Flourish
text: SAN JOSE  At dawn, Maria Lupercio Alarcon wakens to the heady scent of onions and cilantro from her family’s first garden, outside her bedroom window.

headline: Figures Look at Families in Recession
text: Assessing the recession’s impact on families, the Census Bureau said Friday that unemployment rates for couples with children under age 18 had doubled from 2007 to 2009.

headline: For Antiterror Chief, a Rough Week Ahead as Hearings Begin
text: WASHINGTON  Not long after President Obama was inaugurated, Michael E. Leiter, the man in charge of the agency that is supposed to “connect the dots” to prevent terrorist attacks, took a stroll on the National Mall with a friend. The friend, a New Jersey doctor named Arthur Gross, mused aloud about what a new president feels when he learns of all the threats against the United States.

headline: Forecasting a Winner? No, the Weather.
text: The forecast calls for a relatively cool Monday in Melbourne, with temperatures perhaps not making it out of the 60s. A breeze is expected, maybe even a little rain. Temperatures should trend upward from there over the next few days, but no drastic weather is on the near horizon.

headline: Subtleties
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s been a while since Cathy Allis (formerly Millhauser) has given us a Sunday puzzle, and it’s nice to have her back. She’s one of the funniest constructors around. Of the 50 puzzles in Will Shortz’s Favorite Sunday Crosswords book, four of them are hers.

headline: The Great Tea Party Rip-Off
text: Even given the low bar set by America’s bogus conversations about race, the short-lived Harry Reid fracas was a most peculiar nonevent. For all the hyperventilation in cable news land, this supposed racial brawl didn’t seem to generate any controversy whatsoever in what is known as the real world.

headline: Our Basic Human Pleasures: Food, Sex and Giving
text: Want to be happier in 2010? Then try this simple experiment, inspired by recent scholarship in psychology and neurology. Which person would you rather be:

headline: Lonely Trek to Radicalism for Terror Suspect
text: KADUNA, Nigeria  Well before Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab disappeared into the rugged mountains of Yemen with an ominous goodbye to his father  warning him that “this is the last time you are going to hear from me,” according to top Nigerian officials  the tensions between the two pious men had already begun to show.

headline: The Road to Radicalization
text: Behind Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab’s journey from student to terrorism suspect was a struggle between an investment in this life and a longing for the next.

headline: O’Brien Talks Down to Final Details
text: With negotiations to settle Conan O’Brien’s contract with NBC down to final details Saturday, attention shifted to others who will be affected by the breakup between the late-night star and the network.

headline: What’s Our Sputnik?
text: Taipei, Taiwan

headline: The Sources’ Stake in the News
text: WHEN The Times interviewed Michael Chertoff about airport security after the underwear bomber tried to blow up a passenger jet on Christmas Day, he said full-body scanners should be deployed at airports. Chertoff, the former secretary of homeland security, did not volunteer that he is a consultant to a company that makes such equipment, and though they spoke to him twice, reporters never asked if he had a financial stake in the matter.

headline: Walking the Walk on School Reform
text: The American Federation of Teachers, the second-largest teachers’ union, has been working hard to distance itself from its competitor, the National Education Association, which tends to resist sensible reforms.

headline: 3 Blackwater Guards Called Baghdad Shootings Unjustified
text: WASHINGTON  Three private security guards working for Blackwater Worldwide who witnessed a 2007 episode in Baghdad in which at least 17 Iraqi civilians were killed by other Blackwater guards told a federal grand jury that they believed the shootings were unjustified, according to newly unsealed court documents.

headline: What’s in a Name? A Mountain of Controversy
text: The San Francisco lawyer who turned a few acres of vineyards into one of the country’s leading wine companies has always been known for thinking big. But his latest idea  to rename a Sonoma County mountain  is going over as smoothly as a bottle of turned Pinot.

headline: A View That Took Millions of Years
text: When Doris Sloan, 79, is stuck in traffic on Highway 24 east of the Caldecott Tunnel, she takes the long view  the really long view. An adjunct professor of earth and planetary science at the University of California, Berkeley, Ms. Sloan, who lives in North Berkeley, wrote the field guide “Geology of the San Francisco Bay Region.” (Her words have been edited and condensed.)

headline: Edward Schillebeeckx, Catholic Theologian, Dies at 95
text: The Rev. Edward Schillebeeckx, a prominent member of a wave of Roman Catholic theologians who helped reshape Catholicism during the Second Vatican Council and whose writings were later investigated for heresy, died on Dec. 23 in Nijmegen, the Netherlands. He was 95.

headline: Newsom Is Eclipsed in Marriage Movement
text: Nearly six years after Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco ignited a political and social firestorm by allowing same-sex couples to wed in his city, the issue of gay marriage remains at center stage, in the Bay Area and across the country.

headline: New York’s Street of Schemes
text: Over the past year, the New York Mayor’s Office of Special Enforcement has closed at least 64 of the storefront businesses that line the sidewalks of Canal Street from West Broadway to Lafayette Street, an area known as the Counterfeit Triangle. On one recent night, 10 buildings and 31 stalls were shut down, and a daisy chain of undercover and uniformed police officers filled an 18-wheeler with garbage bags holding $1 million worth of knockoff merchandise.

headline: Thunder in the Dome as Saints Advance to N.F.C. Title Game
text: NEW ORLEANS  To motivate his Saints against the Arizona Cardinals on Saturday, New Orleans Coach Sean Payton gave them baseball bats marked with the words “bring the wood.”

headline: 6 Major Powers Move Closer to Considering More Iran Sanctions
text: UNITED NATIONS  Six major powers agreed Saturday that the Iranian response to proposals to altering its nuclear development program had been inadequate and that it warranted consideration of further measures by the United Nations Security Council.

headline: A Mountain’s Proposed Name Change and Other Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: What’s in a Name? | The lawyer, Jesse Jackson, 79, who owns the privately held Jackson Family Wines, wants to change the name of Black Mountain, a 3,128-foot-high peak a few miles east of Geyserville, to Alexander Mountain. Mr. Jackson’s company is also seeking to create a new wine named Alexander Mountain, which, if approved, would permit the company to put a special label on the premium wine it makes from grapes grown at the base of the mountain. Area residents are not sympathetic, and a movement has formed against the change.

headline: Dr. Thomas L. Petty, Researcher of Long-Term Oxygen Therapy, Is Dead at 76
text: When Dr. Thomas L. Petty started his research into severe chronic lung disease in the mid-1960s, oxygen therapy was generally administered in hospitals and typically for only a short time. Lung disease experts believed that providing oxygen to pulmonary patients for extended periods would cause a buildup of carbon dioxide in their bloodstreams, making them sicker.

headline: Waylaid by Illness, Now Standing on Her Own
text: For Beatriz Hodge, the difference between a life in Puerto Rico and a life in New York was a trip to the zoo.

headline: In Race for U.S. School Grants Is a Fear of Winning
text: As Illinois jockeys for position as a leader in education reform with a $500 million application for Race to the Top money, the state’s inability to pay current bills makes educators skeptical of Illinois’s capacity to take on such new initiatives.

headline: Looting Flares Where Authority Breaks Down
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Along the capital’s main commercial strip Saturday afternoon, dozens of armed men  some wielding machetes, others with sharpened pieces of wood  dodged from storefront to storefront, battering down doors and hauling away whatever they could carry: shoes, luggage, rolls of carpet.

headline: The Death of a Playground Legend
text: Jon Scheyer was heating up the United Center on a cold Chicago night in early January, with 31 points and 6 assists in a no-sweat win over Iowa State. Now a senior at Duke, the spindly 6-foot-5 guard displayed the same deft shooting stroke and high-motor floor play that made him one of the most decorated prep players in Illinois when he was at Glenbrook North High School.

headline: Corrections
text: The City Critic column in some editions last Sunday, about travel routes that will be affected the most by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s planned service cuts, misidentified the bus that the writer boarded in the Bronx, the beginning of one route, and misstated the route name of the bus she boarded in Queens that brought her to her destination, 26th Avenue. The Bronx bus is the Bx16, not the B16, and the Queens bus is the Q28; there is no B28 bus. The column also misstated the name of the Bronx cemetery that she passed on her travels. It is Woodlawn Cemetery, not Woodland.

headline: Zenyatta to Compete This Year, Owner Says
text: Zenyatta, a front-runner with Rachel Alexandra for 2009 Horse of the Year, will come out of retirement and race in 2010, one of the horse’s co-owners, Jerry Moss, told the Santa Anita publicity department Saturday.

headline: The Pulse: Forget the Scarf, but Think About the Frogs
text: As Chicagoans basked in last week’s relative warmth, they might have spared a thought for frogs. Above-freezing temperatures melt the city’s roadside snowbanks, sending an annual average of 270,000 tons of road salt into the state’s waterways and giving flora and fauna a super-sized serving of NaCl.

headline: The Pulse: Tillman Goes Free, but Others Still Wait
text: Michael Tillman, who has said he was a victim of police brutality, was freed from prison this week, but more than 20 black men who also say they were tortured into confessions by the Chicago police from 1973 to 1991 remain in prison, according to the People’s Law Office.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing in the New Jersey Calendar in some editions last Sunday about a screening of “Antichrist” on Jan. 22 to 24, presented as part of the New Jersey Film Festival at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, misidentified the venue and Web site for the event and misstated the phone number for event information. The screening will be held in Room 105 of Voorhees Hall, not in the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum; both are at 71 Hamilton Street. The phone number is (732) 932-8482, and the Web site is njfilmfest.com.

headline: Denney and Barrett Seize an Olympic Berth
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  Even before the music stopped during their long program at the United States nationals, Caydee Denney and Jeremy Barrett stood at center ice Saturday and fell into a long, hard embrace.

headline: Corrections
text: The Quick Bite feature in some editions last Sunday, about Epstein’s of Hartsdale, N.Y., misspelled the surname of a co-owner and misstated the deli’s phone number. The co-owner is Robert DeGroat, not DeGroaf, and the phone number is (914) 428-5320.

headline: J.F.K. Terminal Evacuated
text: A terminal at Kennedy International Airport was evacuated on Saturday afternoon after a man apparently used a restricted doorway, a breach that delayed dozens of flights and threw the airport into disarray as hundreds of people were rescreened, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections
text: A review in some editions last Sunday of Alice’s restaurant in Lake Hopatcong, N.J., with the chef David Drake, included an outdated reference to his namesake restaurant, David Drake, in Rahway, N.J. It closed on Jan. 6.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about Georgetown University’s 72-69 victory over the University of Connecticut in men’s basketball on Jan. 9 misidentified the Georgetown player who passed to Greg Monroe for the final basket of the game. It was Austin Freeman, not Chris Wright.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in some copies last Sunday with an obituary about Freya von Moltke, a member of an anti-Nazi resistance group during World War II, misidentified the man shown. He was Field Marshal Helmuth von Moltke the Elder, the great-great-uncle of Mrs. Moltke’s husband; he was not Count Helmuth James von Moltke, her husband and a leader of the resistance.

headline: The Show Must Not Go On
text: Political theater and public scolding are good ways to draw attention to important issues and bad behavior, and Phil Angelides, chairman of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, made use of both last week. As he swore in four of the nation’s top bankers, it was impossible not to think of that famous scene with executives from the tobacco industry. During the questioning, he rebuked Lloyd Blankfein, head of Goldman Sachs, for his firm’s practice of selling mortgage-related securities and at the same time betting they would fall in value.

headline: New York’s Antique Divorce Law
text: Barring marriage by same-sex couples is not the only way that New York State’s policies on marriage are stuck in the past and inflict needless pain.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Trial by Ferry
text: There is nothing wrong with holding the trial of the man who has described himself as the mastermind of 9/11, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, in federal court in New York. But there is something wrong with spending upward of $200 million per year on security for a multiyear trial and disrupting the lives of people who have homes and jobs in Lower Manhattan, where the trial is to be held. Fortunately, there is a relatively easy solution to this problem: Governors Island.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: On Los Angeles Bus Tour, an Insider View of Gang Life
text: LOS ANGELES  “If nobody moves, nobody is going to get hurt,” Alfred Lomas, tattoos scrawled along his arms and neck, announced from the front of the bus just before it departed. “Just move all your money to the front.”

headline: Calipari Will Host Telethon to Raise Money for Haiti
text: A friend called Kentucky Coach John Calipari on Friday morning and told Calipari that he cried himself to sleep the night before because of the images from the tragedy in Haiti.

headline: If It Feels Good, Do It — Give!
text: My Sunday column looks at something that has been written about for ages: that it is more blessed to give than to receive. Not always true, it seems, but often. And given the crisis in Haiti and so many other parts of the world (I’m just preparing for a trip to one of the worst-off parts of the globe, so the issue is on my mind), there is a nice potential for an arrangement whereby we all benefit from a little more engagement.

headline: Cornell Opens Defense of Ivy Title With Win Over Columbia
text: ITHACA, N.Y.  Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said earlier in the week that he would seed the Cornell basketball team from a No. 4 to a No. 6 seed in this year’s N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: A Mess of a Primary to Inherit a Bigger Mess
text: Todd H. Stroger  the Cook County board president whose 2006 election may have matched last year’s election of President Hamid Karzai in Afghanistan as spectacle  may now belatedly pay the piper called democracy. Perhaps he should breathe a sigh of relief.

headline: G.O.P. Sees Political Gain in Health Care
text: Even as Democrats nail down the final details of their health care bill, Republicans are devising ways to convert it into political capital.

headline: End of the Line for Warner?
text: Kurt Warner, the Arizona quarterback, said he did not know if Saturday’s 45-14 loss to New Orleans would be the last game in his career. He is 38 years old, has played 12 seasons and has had several concussions.

headline: N.F.C. Divisional Playoffs: Saints Beat Cardinals
text: The Saints crushed the Cardinals, 45-14, Saturday in an N.F.C. divisional playoff game.

headline: Players, and Fans, Turn Out for Haiti Relief Effort
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – More than 14,000 tennis fans swarmed onto the grounds of the Australian Open on Sunday afternoon here in an impromptu show of financial support for Haiti relief efforts — and the chance to see top players in an exhibition staged at the last-minute suggestion of Roger Federer.

headline: Live Analysis: Final, Colts 20, Ravens 3
text: Judy Battista was in Indianapolis and John Woods was in Manhattan providing live analysis of Saturday’s game between the Ravens and the Colts. Scroll down to track the progress of the game, as it happened. You also can follow Judy on Twitter.

headline: Well-Rested Manning Leads Colts Past Ravens
text: INDIANAPOLIS  The Indianapolis Colts probably will not hold up Saturday night’s game as a monument to avoiding rust during a playoff bye week, considering that Ed Reed improbably intercepted Peyton Manning twice on the same third-quarter drive. But after nearly a month at the center of the debate about whether teams should rest their starters in meaningless games  and whether their own history of shaky playoff performances suggested they made the wrong choice  the Colts provided the answer: this time, it worked for them.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 5: Hunger Frays Nerves
text: Survivors show frustration and restraint at a locked supermarket, four days after a powerful earthquake devastated Port-au-Prince.

headline: Mel Cuba Dies at 99; Saved 4 Drowning Orphans in Queens
text: The winds were whipping toward shore that summer day more than seven decades ago when 105 orphans from the Pride of Judea Home on Dumont Avenue in Brooklyn stepped off buses for what was supposed to be a gleeful romp at the beach in Rockaway, Queens.

headline: The Poster as Propaganda
text: All across Europe, populist parties are growing by capitalizing on a very old-fashioned brand of propaganda art.

headline: A Surprise Dinner Party for the First Lady
text: Michelle Obama turns 46 on Sunday, and the president took her out for a surprise birthday dinner Saturday night, according to a pool report.

headline: McGwire’s Admission May Not Affect Hall of Fame Chances
text: Mark McGwire’s admission last week that he used performance-enhancing drugs did not improve his Hall of Fame candidacy, according to an informal poll by The Times. David Waldstein surveyed 35 Hall of Fame voters, and none who had bypassed McGwire said the confession would make a difference:

headline: Vows: Rachel & Todd
text: Rachel Grand and Todd Spiegelman met on a blind date in 2005. They continued dating until they broke up when Rachel's ex-boyfriend showed up again. A year later, Rachel received an e-mail from Todd.

headline: Israeli’s Blunder Sets Up a Surprising Finish
text: The biggest team event in chess is the biennial Olympiad, which was first held in 1924. At the last one, in Dresden, Germany, in 2008, teams from 146 nations competed.

headline: A.F.C. Divisional Playoffs: Colts Beat Ravens
text: The Colts and a well-rested Peyton Manning beat the Baltimore Ravens, 20-3, in an A.F.C divisional round game.

headline: Information on Haiti Is Getting Siloed
text: From Chris Csikszentmihalyi, Director of the M.I.T. Center for Future Civic Media: an important note to techies who are concerned with the situation in Haiti.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Sedin and Burrows Overshadow Crosby
text: Twelve games on Saturday, including a scare in the matinee game at Denver, where the Devils’ all-time leading scorer and 2009 Czech player of the year Patrik Elias was caught with his head down and knocked insensate. Fortunately, Elias seemed to be all right later, but he will undergo further examination back in New Jersey. Also, in Vancouver, Sidney Crosby came to town for only the second time in his N.H.L. career, just a few weeks after Alex Ovechkin made only his second trip to Vancouver as an N.H.L.’er. Good thing that the Olympics will be held there. Home teams listed first:

headline: Haiti Earthquake Multimedia
text: Videos, photographs and interactive features documenting the desperation in Haiti in the weeks after a powerful earthquake devastated the country on Jan. 12.

headline: In Paris, a Night Devoted to Django
text: On Tuesday at 9 p.m., Paris will come alive with the sounds of Django.

headline: Part 1: Answers on Fafsa and Financial Aid
text: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is attempting to streamline this year.

headline: The Fuss Over Favre Was for a Day Like This
text: Those who followed the Fifth Down in the off-season (thanks, Mom) know we had our share of Brett Favre coverage.

headline: Sure, Flying Is Less Fun, but Also Less Pricey
text: Once glamorous, air travel has turned into a slog of security rules, long waits and cramped limbs.

headline: Jyoti Basu, Leader of Communists in India, Dies at 95
text: NEW DELHI  Jyoti Basu, a powerful leftist leader who dominated politics in the state of West Bengal for more than two decades and nearly became India’s first Communist prime minister, died in Calcutta on Sunday. He was 95.

headline: 24 and Counting for American Men
text: This streak has to come to an end, right? You know the one. It started early last decade and has now surpassed the 20 mark.

headline: Until Flo Ebbs, Progressive Will Capitalize on Her Popularity
text: It is always difficult to predict when an advertising character will catch on — or flop. Case in point, Flo, the chipper pitchwoman in a campaign for Progressive insurance who is portrayed by an actor and comedian named Stephanie Courtney.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Tries Some Late-Night Diplomacy
The Sunday Word: Bound for Boston
text: President Obama is traveling to Boston today in an effort to shore up Martha Coakley’s bid for the Massachusetts Senate seat.

headline: Jan. 17: Updates on Rescue and Recovery in Haiti

Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online by writing to us in the comments thread below.
