headline: Karzai Closing In on Taliban Reconciliation Plan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government will soon unveil a major new plan offering jobs, security, education and other social benefits to Taliban followers who defect, according to the spokesman for President Hamid Karzai.

headline: Brown, Coakley, And the Outrage Gap
text: Wow. A video clip has surfaced from 2008 in which Scott Brown, the Republican candidate for Senate in Massachusetts, clearly suggested that President Obama may have been born out of wedlock.

headline: Refugee Camp Swells With Injured (NBC)
text: NBC's Michelle Kosinski reports about a makeshift refugee camp in Haiti that for the most part is orderly and safe.

headline: Responders Race to Treat Victims (NBC)
text: NBC's Dr. Nancy Snyderman reports on medical efforts in Haiti.

headline: Gehry Withdraws From Museum of Tolerance Project in Jerusalem
text: Update | 3:35 p.m. The architect Frank Gehry has withdrawn from a project to design a Museum of Tolerance in Jerusalem, according to a report in Israel’s Haaretz newspaper last week. The building, which is being built by the Simon Wiesenthal Center, which opened the first Museum of Tolerance in Los Angles in 1993, has drawn criticism because it is being constructed on a site that was once part of a Muslim cemetery. However, other architects involved in the project say that Mr. Gehry’s resignation was not related to protests over the site, but to financial issues. According to the architecture firm, Kolker, Kolker, Epstein Architects, part of the initial planning team, Mr. Gehry resigned after rejecting a request by the center to reduce the scope of the plan, the cost of which has been estimated at $250 million. Plans for the project were first announced at a groundbreaking ceremony in 2004 which included the former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Mr. Gehry and Arnold Schwarzenegger in Jerusalem.

headline: Cast Announced for ‘Come Fly Away’
text: Audiences can now prepare for boarding: “Come Fly Away” has its crew. The new Broadway musical conceived, choreographed and directed by Twyla Tharp and based on the music of Frank Sinatra, has announced its cast. The show, about four couples who fall in and out of love at a nightclub, stars Matthew Dibble, Holley Farmer, Laura Mead, Charlie Neshyba-Hodges, Rika Okamoto, Karine Plantadit, Keith Roberts and John Selya, all of whom appeared in last fall’s production of the show, then called, “Come Fly With Me,” at Atlanta’s Alliance Theater and several of whom appeared in Ms. Tharp’s 2002 Broadway hit “Movin’ Out” (that one was based on the music of Billy Joel). The show, which has a cast of 15 dancers and an on-stage 19-piece big band, is to begin previews on March 1 and open on March 25 at the Marquis Theater..

headline: Chaim Potok Papers go to Penn
text: The University of Pennsylvania is now home to the papers of the Jewish American author and rabbi Chaim Potok, the university announced Friday. Potok, the author of “The Chosen,” “My Name is Asher Lev” and other works about the struggle between religious and secular Jewish life, died in 2002 at age 73. An alumnus of the university, he bequeathed his papers to Penn, where he also taught. The collection includes writings, correspondence, lectures, sermons, article clippings and fan mail, including a letter from the Nobel Laureate and Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel. The collection will be housed in the university’s rare book and manuscript library.

headline: ‘Hurt Locker’ Takes Home Top Award at Critics’ Choice
text: The awards season is off to a good start for Kathryn Bigelow. Her action-packed film, “The Hurt Locker,” about a bomb disposal unit in Baghdad, took home prizes for best picture and best director at the Critics’ Choice Awards on Friday, The Associated Press reported. “It’s wonderful to have this honor,” Ms. Bigelow said at the ceremony, “but the recognition should also go to the men and women who are in the field to this day.” James Cameron’s “Avatar” and Quentin Tarantino’s “Inglourious Basterds” won the most awards, with Mr. Tarantino’s cast taking the prize for best ensemble and Christoph Walz winning for best supporting actor. Mr. Tarantino also won for best original screenplay. “Avatar” was named best action movie and also won for cinematography, editing, art direction, sound and visual effects. Jeff Bridges’ turn as a hard-drinking country singer in “Crazy Heart” earned him the best actor award while Meryl Streep and Sandra Bullock tied for the best actress honor for their respective work in “Julie & Julia” and “The Blind Side” and Mo’Nique won the best supporting actress prize for her portrayal of an abusive mother in “Precious.” The winners are chosen by members of the Broadcast Film Critics Association.

headline: The Foundry Theater
text: A look at some of the company’s past productions.

headline: Spielberg to Produce Ground Zero Documentary
text: Steven Spielberg is turning his eye to Ground Zero. The Oscar-winning director will be the executive producer of a documentary with the Science Channel about the reconstruction of the former World Trade Center site in lower Manhattan, Variety reported last week. “Rebuilding Ground Zero” will be broadcast in six parts in 2011. Filmed in 3D and high definition, the series will examine the different groups working to build the project, from the Port Authority of New York & New Jersey to the engineers, politicians and constructions crews. The series will also make use of time-lapse photography and other methods to chronicle the construction of One World Trade Center. The idea was initially conceived of by the architect Danny Foster and the director Jonathan Hock.

headline: Final: Vikings 34, Cowboys 3
text: Pat Borzi is in Minneapolis and Paul Myerberg in New York providing live analysis of today’s game between the Vikings and Cowboys. Use your refresh button to stay current with the updates.

headline: Obama Takes to the Pulpit
text: President Obama told a black church in the nation’s capital today that the promise inherent in his election as the nation’s first African-American president has yet to be fully realized, acknowledging that partisan Washington politics continued to play a big role in governance.

headline: ‘Hurt Locker’ Takes Home Top Award at Critics’ Choice
text: Kathryn Bigelow and her film “The Hurt Locker” took home top prizes for best picture and best director at the Critics’ Choice Awards on Friday while James Cameron’s “Avatar” and Quentin Tarantino’s “Inglourious Basterds” also were big winners. ArtsBeat has more on the awards, which also delivered a tie for best actress to Meryl Streep and Sandra Bullock.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 6: Steps Toward Normalcy
text: Damien Cave reports from Port-au-Prince on signs that some order is returning to the city as aid reaches survivors, many of whom sought solace at churches.

headline: Hussein Aide Again Given a Sentence of Death
text: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi court sentenced a former aide to Saddam Hussein to death by hanging on Sunday for having ordered a poison gas attack on a Kurdish village in 1988.

headline: Hansen and Watts Agree: Cold Weather, Warm Climate
text: As the ice that formed on the Hudson River during the recent cold snap begins to break up (see my video snapshot below), it’s perhaps a good time to close the case on unusual cold spells in an unusually warm world.

headline: Another Injury Clouds U.S. Future
text: Update | 6:13 p.m.  Late Tuesday, Fulham officials said that, after an examination, it was determined that surgery would not be necessary on Clint Dempsey’s right knee. The club said that Dempsey sustained “moderate damage” to the posterior cruciate ligament, but should be available before the end of the English Premier League season in May and should be fit enough to play for the United States at the World Cup in South Africa in June.

headline: Senator Enzi Says Bill Will Raise Costs
text: Continuing the conversation about why health care in America is so expensive, Senator Michael B. Enzi, Republican of Wyoming, explains his pessimism about the Democrats’ legislation emerging from Washington.

text: Damon Winter has been in Port-au-Prince since Wednesday. James Estrin spoke with him at 12:30 p.m. Sunday by satellite phone. Viewers are cautioned that this slide show includes very disturbing images.

headline: ‘Avatar,’ Atop the Box Office, Nears $500 Million
text: James Cameron’s “Avatar,” neared the $500 million mark at the North American box office in just 32 days (it took Mr. Cameron’s “Titanic” 98 days to get there), as it earned the No. 1 spot for the fifth weekend in a row with $41.3 million in ticket sales.

headline: Australian Open Begins With Eye on Henin and Clijsters
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Like politics, all sports are local, and the passions of Australians have been on full display the past 72 hours. Virtually every television and car radio has been tuned to the cricket test between Australia and Pakistan under way in Hobart  between lunch and tea, of course. Horse racing has been off and running day and night, too, from one rugged coast to another.

headline: Working Mothers in Germany
text: Katrin Bennhold looks at the lives of four working mothers in Germany and the difficulties they face managing careers and child care.

headline: In Senate Race, Massachusetts Bucks a Political Stereotype
text: MARLBOROUGH, Mass.  Angela Grenham, 50, was raised a Massachusetts Democrat  “We had the crucifix and the J.F.K. sign,” she recalled  and voted for a Democrat for president as recently as 2000, when she supported Al Gore.

headline: Pakistan Says Drone Strike Kills 15
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Missiles fired from American aircraft killed as many as 15 people in western Pakistan on Sunday, Pakistani security officials said, part of an increased campaign by the United States to use drones to kill militants.

headline: Democrats’ Backup Health Plan: Ask House to Back Senate Bill
text: With the Massachusetts special election for United States Senate increasingly unpredictable, Democrats in Washington are contemplating an array of backup plans should a Republican upset on Tuesday deprive the Democrats of the crucial 60th vote that they need to pass far-reaching health care legislation.

text: Greg Bishop and William C. Rhoden are in San Diego and George Bretherton is in New York providing live analysis of today’s game between the Jets and the Chargers. Use your refresh button to stay current with the updates.

headline: Magic Tricks, Cupcakes and Footwear: Partying, Golden Globe-Style
text: “How’s the Queen doing these days?” Oliver Stone asked Helen Mirren at a party on Saturday afternoon. “The Queen’s retired,” Ms. Mirren replied. Mr. Stone hadn’t kept up to date with Ms. Mirren’s historical roles; she’s currently playing Sonya Tolstoy in “The Last Station,” she reminded him at a brunch for Film Independent’s Spirit Awards nominees, one of the many parties the Bagger has popped in on this Golden Globes weekend, and the only one with decent food.

headline: Obama Rallies Democrats in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON — President Obama swooped into Massachusetts on Sunday in an attempt to rescue the flailing candidacy of Martha Coakley, the Democratic Senate candidate in a special election on Tuesday that will determine whether the party will preserve its 60-vote majority in the United States Senate and keep alive its health care agenda.

headline: Behind Defense and Favre, Vikings Beat Cowboys
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Minnesota Vikings defensive end Ray Edwards, a serviceable but rarely spectacular pass rusher, fell to the Metrodome FieldTurf late in the third quarter Sunday, grabbing his right knee. When Edwards limped off a few moments later, the crowd cheered as if Edwards were one of the Purple People Eaters from the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: Marriage and Mores in Rain-Soaked Hanoi
text: “If you don’t expect too much, everything’s simple,” declares Duyen (Do Thi Hai Yen), a radiant young Vietnamese bride in Bui Thac Chuyen’s moody, enigmatic film, “Adrift.” In the opening scene Duyen, still in her wedding gown, waits patiently by the nuptial bed as her new husband, Hai (Duy Khoa Nguyen), drinks himself into oblivion at a party on the floor below. When he is dragged upstairs unconscious, it is not an encouraging sign.

headline: China Restores Text Messaging in Xinjiang
text: BEIJING  The Chinese government continued to ease a six-month-old blackout on communications in the northwest region of Xinjiang by restoring some text-messaging services on Sunday, the state news media said.

headline: Conan Deal Is Imminent, Key Details All Worked Out
text: An announcement of a deal in the protracted negotiations between NBC and Conan O’Brien could come as early as later tonight, representatives of both sides said Sunday.

headline: Advanced Aesthetics: Creators and How to Stage Them
text: LONDON  Straight lines have never been part of the geometry of Alan Bennett, a writer known for his endearingly corkscrew approach to matters erudite. But with his “Habit of Art,” an amiable dodge of a play that imagines a late-life meeting between the poet W. H. Auden and the composer Benjamin Britten, he never seems to stop circling his subject. And you start to wonder if it’s because he’s afraid of not getting it right.

headline: 2010 Ford Taurus SHO
text: Ford's high-performance Taurus offers more excitement than any family sedan in recent memory.

headline: Staying True to Novel’s Vigor
text: Inspired by reading Pushkin’s “Eugene Onegin,” the Indian writer Vikram Seth achieved an unlikely alchemy in his 1986 debut novel, “The Golden Gate,” detailing the intermingled intimacies of five contemporary San Franciscans in their 20s with stately rhymed sonnets. In creating an opera based on Mr. Seth’s novel, the composer Conrad Cummings has fashioned an equally improbable fusion: lithe melodic lines that flow and entwine in the manner of Monteverdi, peppered with musical references to Henry Mancini and the punk band Black Flag.

headline: Bohemian Soul Mates in Obscurity
text: Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe were both born in 1946, at a time when “the iceman” and “the last of the horse-drawn wagons” could still be seen on city streets. Ms. Smith points this out at the start of her tenderly evocative memoir, “Just Kids,” but there is even stronger evidence that this book dates back a long time.

text: The fall 2010 collection from Burberry Prorsum.

headline: Professor Is a Label That Leans to the Left
text: The overwhelmingly liberal tilt of university professors has been explained by everything from outright bias to higher I.Q. scores. Now new research suggests that critics may have been asking the wrong question. Instead of looking at why most professors are liberal, they should ask why so many liberals  and so few conservatives  want to be professors.

headline: Catchphrase
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Some solvers get frustrated when there are too many clues about sports or opera or 19th century French poetry or whatever their particular blind spot happens to be. Today’s crossword is much simpler for television watchers. TV used to be the closest we had to a broadly shared cultural experience. Say the secret word and win $100. These days, you may not even have any friends who watch the tube. Times have changed.

headline: Visitors From Vienna Bring Both the Pastoral and the Not-So-Pastoral
text: Programming symphonic concerts is too often done to formula, the lamest, nowadays, being overture, concerto, intermission, symphony. If anything more challenging can be slipped by the marketing department, it is tucked somewhere inside to avoid encouraging patrons to arrive late or leave early.

headline: Design in Detroit
text: The focus was on smaller cars, global production and interactivity at the 2010 North American International Auto Show.

headline: Local Stop: Yorkville
text: The neighborhood has changed since German and Hungarian immigrants dominated, but some local businesses retain a European imprint.

headline: It’s All in the Telling, a Step at a Time
text: How odd: Stories dominate this winter’s repertory from New York City Ballet. This company built its international reputation as the world’s foremost purveyor of plotless one-act dance works, with minimal costumes and without scenery. True, a number of narrative dramas have been integral to its popularity, notably George Balanchine’s 1949 production of “Firebird” and his 1954 one of “The Nutcracker.” Yet never has it presented so high a proportion of full-length narrative ballets as during the current November-to-February season: “The Nutcracker,” “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” “Romeo + Juliet,” “The Sleeping Beauty” and “Swan Lake,” each armed with a variety of costumes and décors.

headline: Matching Wits in Cyberspace
text: Every Wednesday morning at 11 Eastern time, two experts play online at bridgebase.com with juniors from around the world. Each junior plays two deals. On Dec. 30 I played against Benito Garozzo, who was the declarer in this deal.

headline: From Tin Pan Alley to Springsteen With a Cock-Eyed Realist
Figure Skater’s Campaign to Retake His Summit
text: One problem with “Be Good Johnny Weir,” a Sundance Channel documentary series about the efforts of Mr. Weir, the figure skater, to climb back to the top of the sport, is that it will be irrelevant by the time it has its premiere on Monday. The pivotal competition, the nationals, which the series will finally get to in March, was held over the weekend in Spokane, Wash. Anyone who cares enough about skating to watch this show will already know whether Mr. Weir did well enough to make the Olympic team, his goal.

headline: Cast Announced for ‘Come Fly Away’
text: Audiences can now prepare for boarding: “Come Fly Away” has its crew. The new Broadway musical conceived, choreographed and directed by Twyla Tharp and based on the music of Frank Sinatra, has announced its cast. The show, about four couples who fall in and out of love at a nightclub, stars Matthew Dibble, Holley Farmer, Laura Mead, Charlie Neshyba-Hodges, Rika Okamoto, Karine Plantadit, Keith Roberts and John Selya, all of whom appeared in last fall’s production of the show, then called “Come Fly With Me,” at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta and at least two of whom appeared in Ms. Tharp’s 2002 Broadway hit “Movin’ Out” (that one was based on songs by Billy Joel). The show is to begin previews on March 1 and open on March 25 at the Marquis Theater.

headline: ‘The Hurt Locker’ Wins 2 Critics’ Choice Awards
text: The awards season has begun well for Kathryn Bigelow. Her suspense-filled film “The Hurt Locker,” about a bomb disposal unit in Baghdad, took home prizes for best picture and best director at the Critics’ Choice Awards on Friday, The Associated Press reported. “It’s wonderful to have this honor,” Ms. Bigelow said at the ceremony, “but the recognition should also go to the men and women who are in the field to this day.” “Avatar” and Quentin Tarantino’s “Inglourious Basterds” won the most awards, with Mr. Tarantino’s cast taking the prize for best ensemble and Christoph Waltz winning for best supporting actor. Mr. Tarantino also won for best original screenplay. “Avatar” was named best action movie and also won for cinematography, editing, art direction, sound and visual effects. Jeff Bridges’s turn as a hard-drinking country singer in “Crazy Heart” earned him the best actor award, while Meryl Streep and Sandra Bullock tied for the best actress honor, Ms. Streep for her work in “Julie & Julia” and Ms. Bullock for “The Blind Side,” and Mo’Nique won the best supporting actress prize for her portrayal of an abusive mother in “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire.” The winners are chosen by members of the Broadcast Film Critics Association.

headline: Strong Turnouts for the Na’vi and a Gypsy
text: James Cameron’s “Avatar” neared the $500 million mark at the North American box office in just 32 days (it took Mr. Cameron’s “Titanic” 98 days to get there), as it earned the No. 1 spot for the fifth weekend in a row with $41.3 million in ticket sales. The cumulative domestic total for “Avatar,” from 20th Century Fox, is $491.8 million, according to box office analysts, making it the No. 3 movie on the all-time domestic box office charts (not adjusting for inflation). Worldwide the film has taken in $1.6 billion, second only to “Titanic,” at $1.8 billion. The Denzel Washington action-adventure “The Book of Eli” (Warner Brothers) was second with a solid $31.6 million. “The Lovely Bones” (Paramount and DreamWorks) was third with about $17 million, a disappointing total for an expensive film from a major director (Peter Jackson), based on a best seller. “The Lovely Bones” will need to perform spectacularly to avoid becoming a box office disaster. “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel” (Fox) was fourth with about $11.5 million (for a new total of $193 million). “Sherlock Holmes” (Warner) was fifth with about $9.8 million ($180 million total). Also notable was a strong turnout for the Metropolitan Opera’s high-definition presentation of “Carmen,” starring Elina Garanca, right. Shown on 700 screens on Saturday, it sold about $3 million in tickets, a record for the Met movie series.

headline: Papers of Chaim Potok to Go to Penn
text: The University of Pennsylvania is now home to the papers of the Jewish-American author and rabbi Chaim Potok, the university announced Friday. Potok, the author of “The Chosen,” “My Name Is Asher Lev” and other works about the struggle between religious and secular Jewish life, died in 2002 at age 73. An alumnus of the university, he bequeathed his papers to Penn, where he also taught.

headline: Frank Gehry Withdraws From Museum Project
text: The architect Frank Gehry, below, has withdrawn from a project designing a Museum of Tolerance in Jerusalem, according to a report in the Israeli newspaper Haaretz last week. The project, being built by the Simon Wiesenthal Center, which opened the first Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles in 1993, has drawn criticism because it is being constructed on a site that was once part of a Muslim cemetery. However, according to the architecture firm Kolker, Kolker, Epstein Architects, part of the initial planning team, Mr. Gehry resigned after rejecting a request by the center to reduce the scope of the plan, the cost of which has been estimated at $250 million.

headline: Candidate Bans Worsen Iraq’s Political Turmoil
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi officials have done little to clarify who, exactly, has been disqualified from running for Parliament in March because of ties to Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party. They did, however, make clear on Sunday that, contrary to Iraqi television news, the government’s own spokesman was not among those declared a Baathist and therefore unfit for office.

headline: For Many Start-Ups, a Spot on the Nasdaq Is No Longer the Goal
text: SEATTLE  Investors in technology start-ups have been trying to end the drought in initial public offerings of tech companies. But for entrepreneurs, has taking a company public lost its allure?

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 946 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

headline: Star Turns at Liberian’s War Crimes Trial
text: PARIS  Testimony in the case against the former warlord Charles G. Taylor sounded more like a Hollywood mystery than a war-crimes trial last week, with a cast of characters including Naomi Campbell and Mia Farrow and a plot involving plans to trade guns for a bag of diamonds.

headline: The Bagger and the King of Insults
text: On Saturday night, at parties given by Paramount and Lionsgate here in Los Angeles, the Bagger encountered those fabled creatures, those unicorns of the awards season, the members of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. For the most part, they lived up to their fanboy reputation, snapping photos with stars and acting giddy. The Paramount party, at the Chateau Marmont, attracted an even rarer breed — older Academy members, who don’t usually brave the paparazzi. Don Rickles was there.

headline: Israeli Defense Minister Visits Turkey to Mend Frayed Ties
text: ISTANBUL  Israel’s defense minister, Ehud Barak, traveled to Turkey on Sunday to try to smooth over recent tensions that have further frayed the traditionally strong ties between the two countries.

headline: Pope Tries to Soothe Tensions With Jews
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI, in a visit to Rome’s main synagogue, sought to soothe tensions between Catholics and Jews on Sunday, though he and Jewish leaders aired one main point of contention: whether the church did enough against the Holocaust.

headline: Rain on the Red Carpet
text: Update | 8:20 p.m. Umbrellas are the accessory of the evening outside the the Beverly Hilton Hotel as celebrities arrived for the 67th Golden Globe Awards. Fans gathered along the red carpet wrapped themselves in plastic ponchos and cheered as slightly soggy celebrities passed by.

headline: A New York Volunteer Effort Will Soon Spread to 10 Cities
text: Since April, they have spruced up a dozen city blocks, helped give 164,000 flu vaccinations and installed 178,000 compact fluorescent bulbs in public housing. They are volunteers, part of an ambitious New York effort to tap unpaid workers as a permanent, strategic element in solving city problems.

headline: Therapists Report Increase in Green Disputes

headline: Renault Pledges to Keep a French Factory Busy
text: PARIS  Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault, sought to defuse an employment conflict with the French government, telling President Nicolas Sarkozy over the weekend that the automaker would split production of its new Clio model between France and Turkey, and would produce its new electric vehicle entirely in a plant near Paris.

headline: As Shrinking Newsrooms Use Upstarts’ Content, Vetting Questions Arise
text: News comes from more and more outlets, about which readers know less and less.

headline: Home Fires: A Guide and an Ally
text: Greetings again from the Sunshine State.

headline: Hoping It Won’t Be Needed, Democrats Ponder a Backup Plan on Health Care Bill
text: WASHINGTON  With the Massachusetts special election for United States Senate increasingly unpredictable, Democrats in Washington are contemplating a fall-back plan to advance far-reaching health care legislation, even if a Republican victory on Tuesday deprives Senate Democrats of the crucial 60th vote they need to overcome filibusters.

headline: Companies Fight Endless War Against Computer Attacks
text: The recent computer attacks on the mighty Google left every corporate network in the world looking a little less safe.

headline: O’Brien Deal With NBC Said to Be Imminent
text: A settlement in the protracted negotiations between NBC and Conan O’Brien to end the talk show host’s seven-month stint at “The Tonight Show” was said to be imminent on Sunday night, with all of the basic elements of the deal hammered out and both sides eager to be finished with it.

headline: Presidential Election in Ukraine Goes to a Runoff
text: KIEV, Ukraine  Two of the chief combatants in the 2004 Orange Revolution, which brought to power a pro-Western government that has left the public increasingly disillusioned, battled in a presidential election on Sunday, but because neither received enough votes to win outright, they will face each other in a runoff.

headline: In War Against the Internet, China Is Just a Skirmish
text: PARIS  In the beginning, there was one Internet, born from American research and embraced by academics around the world. It was in English and homogeneous, operating according to Western standards of openness.

headline: It’s Not Jay or Conan. It’s Us.
text: The other night, my daughter and I watched Jay Leno, talking about him and his soon-to-be-canceled show. We took in Conan O’Brien as well, dissecting the inside jokes and the implications of his walking away from “The Tonight Show.” As they did their thing, we talked about their performing styles, demographic appeal and remarkable hair.

headline: Jets Advance to A.F.C. Title Game
text: SAN DIEGO  Minutes after the Jets cemented the most surprising upset of this N.F.L. season, before travel plans for the American Football Conference championship had been booked, linebacker Bart Scott stood defiant at his locker, mouth running, faster than ever.

headline: United States Attorney Plans Drug-Terrorism Unit
text: The United States attorney in Manhattan is merging the two units in his office that prosecute terrorism and international narcotics cases, saying that he wants to focus more on extremist Islamic groups whose members he believes are increasingly turning to the drug trade to finance their activities.

headline: Schumer, Citing ‘Failures,’ Wants Airport Breaches Investigated
text: For the second time in two weeks, a New York-area airport went into lockdown after a security breach by someone who did not appear to be a terrorist.

headline: Internet Politics From Both Sides Now
text: For a brief shining moment, late in the 2008 campaign, Democrats thought that they might own the Internet.

headline: New Yorker’s Ambitions Shock Few Back in Memphis
text: MEMPHIS  If you don’t believe that Harold E. Ford Jr. is liberal enough to run for the United States Senate as a Democrat from New York, just ask Bob Capkovic.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: A First Visit to Tennis’s ‘Happy Slam’
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — This is not only my maiden trip Down Under but my first experience in the rarefied air of Grand Slam tennis. Before Friday, all I knew of either were the “Mad Max” movies and memories of being stretched out on the family room floor as a kid watching Rod Laver, Margaret Court, John Newcombe and Evonne Goolagong.

headline: A Rescue at U.N. Headquarters, as Others Wait and Hope
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Sunday made his first visit to Haiti since the earthquake that flattened much of the capital last week and plunged the international agency’s already beleaguered mission here into crisis.

headline: What Didn’t Happen
text: Lately many people have been second-guessing the Obama administration’s political strategy. The conventional wisdom seems to be that President Obama tried to do too much  in particular, that he should have put health care on one side and focused on the economy.

headline: U.S. Mulls Role in Haiti After the Crisis
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s aggressive response to the deadly earthquake in Haiti has led to criticism from the far right that the United States is taking on too much, at a time when its foreign-policy plate is already full.

headline: Shockey Still a Brash and Emotional Presence
text: NEW ORLEANS  Jeremy Shockey was a member of a Super Bowl championship team in the 2007 season as a tight end for the Giants. But it was hard for him to enjoy it because his season ended in Week 15 when he broke his left leg.

headline: Embracing Mo’Nique
text: The Bagger was disregarding protocol at the Golden Globes and wandering around the hallways near the press room backstage when we encountered Mo’Nique, the newly minted best supporting actress winner for “Precious,” receiving a long, heartfelt hug from a woman. Seriously, this was like a three-minute embrace. Who was that?

headline: Amid Rubble, Seeking a Refuge in Faith
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Five days after Haiti’s devastating earthquake, an evangelical pastor in a frayed polo shirt, his church crushed but his spirit vibrant, sounded a siren to summon the newly homeless residents of a tent city to an urgent Sunday prayer service.

headline: In Hollywood, Grappling With Studios’ Lost Clout
text: LOS ANGELES  A proposed sale of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the most powerful and lucrative studio during the golden age of film, drew only meager offers last week, and now Hollywood must confront a troubling question: Are movie studios becoming a financial footnote?

headline: Review of Jet Bomb Plot Shows More Missed Clues
text: This article is by  Eric Lipton, Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti.

headline: Why ‘Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs’ Didn’t Win
text: “I think it’s a little bit of a challenge for people to award a film called ‘Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs.’ It’s just a little bit silly sounding … ‘and the award goes to, ‘Cloudy with a Chance of Dancing Horses in the Rain!’” — Phil Lord, a director of “Cloudy,” on why his film wouldn’t win, on the red carpet of the Golden Globes.

headline: Oscar Race Begins at Golden Globes
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  A rain-drenched Hollywood paused in its efforts to raise money for Haitian earthquake victims on Sunday long enough to focus on the Golden Globes, perhaps the most frivolous of the high-profile stops on the entertainment industry’s awards trail. The big winner: James Cameron’s “Avatar,” which came away with awards for best dramatic picture and best director.

headline: Rescues Beat Dimming Odds in Haiti but Fall Short of Need
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Despite dimming odds, rescue workers pulled more people alive from the rubble  including a 7-year-old girl who survived more than four days eating dried fruit rolls in the supermarket that collapsed around her  as water and emergency aid deliveries improved on Sunday, though not nearly enough to meet Haiti’s desperate need.

headline: Minnesota Vikings at New Orleans Saints
text: Minnesota Vikings

headline: While Offense Is Pondered, Colts’ Defense Takes Over
text: INDIANAPOLIS  In the Baltimore Ravens’ locker room, running back Ray Rice gave voice to the Indianapolis Colts’ peculiar image problem.

headline: Right-Wing Businessman Wins Chile’s Presidency
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  Sebastián Piñera, a billionaire businessman and former senator, broke the 20-year hold on power of a leftist coalition on Sunday, becoming the first right-wing president to be elected in Chile since the dictatorship ended in 1990.

headline: Democrats Push to Salvage a Flailing Candidacy
text: BOSTON  President Obama came to Massachusetts on Sunday in hopes of rescuing the flailing candidacy of Martha Coakley, the Democratic candidate in an election on Tuesday that will determine whether the party preserves a 60-vote majority in the Senate needed to keep alive health care legislation and the rest of the president’s agenda.

headline: Jets at Indianapolis Colts
text: Jets

headline: Premium Cable Thumps the Networks
text: Some thoughts on the Golden Globes, television division:

headline: Haitian New Yorkers Hold on to Their Hope
text: At SS. Joachim and Anne School on the eastern edge of Queens, a first grader has lost his father. A third grader is mourning an uncle. His father is still missing.

headline: Wise Teenager, Unpromising Parents
text: The CW network, with its interchangeable casts and its New Mexico-size audiences (current population: around 2 million), is often dismissed as the kid’s table of prime time. It’s not a bad place to sit, though: with “Gossip Girl,” “The Vampire Diaries” and “Supernatural” representing 30 percent of its nighttime schedule, CW has as high a percentage of purely enjoyable programming as any broadcast network.

headline: Still Stung by Failure, Cubs Fans Convene to Refresh Faith
text: CHICAGO  The baseball writer Roger Kahn once wrote, “You may glory in a team triumphant, but you fall in love with a team in defeat.” By that axiom, the Cubs and their fans have one of sports’ most ardent love affairs, one that remains passionate despite a 101-year World Series title drought.

headline: For 45,000 Americans in Haiti, the Quake Was ‘a Nightmare That’s Not Ending’
text: MIAMI  One was a 22-year-old volunteer from Washington State who was teaching youngsters with mental handicaps. Another was a Dallas woman who was fitting impoverished Haitians for eyeglasses. A third was a California landscape architect who had just arrived with three other men to work on a project to build playgrounds and athletic fields.

headline: Wall St. Weighs a Challenge to a Proposed Tax
text: Wall Street’s main lobbying arm has hired a top Supreme Court litigator to study a possible legal battle against a bank tax proposed by the Obama administration, on the theory that it would be unconstitutional, according to three industry officials briefed on the matter.

headline: On Call for Acceptance Speech Advice
text: “I hope she wins for our movie,” Nora Ephron told the Bagger at some awards show or other in the last few weeks, on the subject of Meryl Streep competing with herself in the best actress — comedy category at the Globes. Ms. Ephron got her wish, when Ms. Streep won for “Julie & Julia.”

headline: The Globes: Wet and Earnest
text: If you weren’t sort of half paying attention to the Jets-Chargers game as you finished off a nice Spanish red, you may have noticed that some of the red-carpet smiles were more forced than usual this year at the Golden Globe awards. Getting out of a limo while you haul a couple of pounds of damp couture silk behind you isn’t exactly a blast. Heidi Klum, poured into a soupy Cavalli, actually seemed annoyed by the number of steps she had to negotiate — and she had Seal, her manly husband.

headline: The Green Table
text: An effort in San Jose, Calif., is helping residents in city neighborhoods grow their own produce in their own backyards.

headline: At the Cubs Convention, Hope Springs Eternal
text: Where does hope spring eternal? At a Hilton in downtown Chicago, site of the 25th annual Cubs Convention.

headline: Dream for the Plaza Fades in a Not-So-Gilded Age
text: When an Israeli billionaire bought New York’s storied Plaza Hotel for $675 million, he envisioned turning the plucky grande dame with the globally recognized name into mainly a luxury condo tower that would cater to the world’s wealthiest buyers and offer stores to satisfy their every desire.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Jan. 7 about China’s efforts to lure back expatriate scholars and scientists referred incorrectly to the resumé of Wang Xiaodong, a Howard Hughes Medical Institute investigator and a director of Beijing’s National Institute of Biological Sciences. Mr. Wang remains a full-time professor at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas  he has not left. (He simultaneously serves as director of the Beijing institute.)

headline: The One Way Older Actresses Have It Easier
text: In the press room, Meryl Streep said she thought she had it easy compared with younger actresses. “When I was coming up, there was no such thing as the 24-7 news cycle, the blogosphere commenting on their weight endlessly,” she said. “That always happened but it happened in apartments and restaurants. You didn’t hear everybody’s opinion of you” all the time.

headline: In Recall, a Role Model Stumbles
text: The Harvard Business School teaches future executives the gold standard in brand crisis management. The model dictates that a company should communicate clearly with the public about a crisis, cooperate with government officials, swiftly begin its own investigation of a problem and, if necessary, quickly institute a product recall.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about logistical problems at Haiti’s Port-au-Prince airport that threatened to delay rescue workers and supplies from reaching earthquake victims misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the vice president of Haiti Shipping Lines, based in Miami, who commented on relief efforts at the port of Cap Haitien. He is Richard Dubin, not Dupin.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about a contentious vote by the Beverly Hills, Calif., school board to dismiss students enrolled on out-of-district permits, using a board member’s estimate, misstated the number of students affected by the vote. It is 206, not “roughly 400.”

headline: Alec Baldwin, Conspicuous by His Absence
text: Sunday night’s best opportunity for NBC-bashing fizzled: Alec Baldwin, who won a third Golden Globe award for his portrayal of a power-mad NBC executive on “30 Rock,” was absent. What was the “previously scheduled charity event” that kept him away from the stage? Inquiring minds will certainly have tracked it down by tomorrow. A quick look at alecbaldwin.com showed that the schedule of Mr. Baldwin’s public appearances there ended with Dec. 31.

headline: Law to Curb Lobbying Sends It Underground
text: WASHINGTON  Ellen Miller, co-founder of the Sunlight Foundation, has spent years arguing for rules to force more disclosure of how lobbyists and private interests shape public policy. Until recently, she herself registered as a lobbyist, too, publicly reporting her role in the group’s advocacy of even more reporting. Not anymore.

headline: For Jets, Things Fall Right When They’re Done Right
text: San Diego

headline: Chuck’s Warm-Up Routine
text: “I need to eat, I need to drink, and then I need to smoke.” — Zachary Levi, of NBC’s “Chuck,” filling his plate in the press dining room.

headline: He Doesn’t Miss Limelight, but Bush Is Back in It
text: WASHINGTON  For the first time in a year, he was roaming the halls of the West Wing, greeting ushers and Secret Service officers by name and being briefed in the Oval Office on the latest crisis. As former President George W. Bush strode into the Rose Garden with that same broad gait, his eyes searched for familiar faces.

headline: At Genzyme, a Long View
text: Genzyme, a $14 billion biotechnology company, is getting a much-needed shake-up. Relational Investors, an investor in the company, is doing it by, at least for the moment, backing its management.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: In Church Visit, Obama Addresses Race, Struggle and Hope
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama told a church congregation here on Sunday that the promise inherent in his election as the nation’s first African-American president had yet to be fully realized, and he acknowledged the role partisan politics continues to play in Washington.

headline: A.F.C. Divisional Playoffs: Jets Surprise Chargers
text: With two fourth-quarter touchdowns, the Jets surprised the Chargers and set up a return date with the Colts in Indianapolis for the A.F.C. title game.

headline: For Ailing Health System, a Diagnosis but No Cure
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly everyone agrees that there is something sick about the American health care system, especially when it comes to the seemingly out-of-control rise in costs.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Grabs Some Oscar Momentum
text: James Cameron’s Golden Globes victory for directing “Avatar” was a bit of a surprise, given that his ex-wife, Kathryn Bigelow, was a critical favorite, at least, for “The Hurt Locker.” And it bodes well for the film’s Oscar chances, if it can get past the Academy’s largest block of voters, actors, who have historically been against movies that hide their assets behind technology and green screens.

headline: Digging Into Massachusetts Campaign, Democrats Might Find Midterm Strategy
text: The Massachusetts Senate race offers the clearest demonstration yet of Republican strengths in 2010  and of how beleaguered Democrats will try to fight back.

headline: $2.22? Gosh, That Sounds Expensive
text: Researchers have known for 80 years about a symbolic connection between speech and size: back-of-the-mouth vowels like the “o” in “two” make people think of large sizes, whereas people associate front-of-the-mouth vowels like “ee” with diminutiveness. Marketers can use this effect to make consumers think a discount is bigger or smaller than it truly is, according to a study soon to be published in The Journal of Consumer Research by Keith Coulter of Clark University and Robin Coulter of the University of Connecticut.

headline: Under Fire, Democrats Turn to Economic Populism
text: The Massachusetts Senate race offers the clearest demonstration yet of Republican strengths in 2010 — and of how beleaguered Democrats will try to fight back.

headline: Nets Seem Unlikely Threat to 1972-73 Sixers’ Loss Record
text: By his own accounting, Fred Carter has two claims to fame. He invented the fist bump. And he was the best player on the worst team in N.B.A. history. He will not readily surrender the titles.

headline: Disaster Touches a Haitian Enclave, but Comfort Is Just as Close
text: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.

headline: With Momentum, Chargers Fall Hard
text: SAN DIEGO  The Chargers were rested and ready, they were playing the best football in the N.F.L., and they believed they had a coach who knew how to win in the playoffs.

headline: Life-Changing Moments Where Land Meets Water
text: In both the best and the worst times of his life, Alejandro Vasquez found himself near the beach.

headline: Spreading the Love
text: Last year’s Golden Globes television awards were incredibly concentrated: HBO 7, NBC 3, AMC 1. This year the Hollywood Foreign Press Association spread the love a little more: HBO still led, with four awards, but Showtime made a strong showing with three and AMC, CBS, Fox and NBC grabbed one each. Cable still dominated, though, by the same 8-3 ratio.

headline: And the Winner Is … ‘Avatar’
text: The 67th annual Golden Globe Awards are taking place Sunday night at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. Check here for an updated list of winners throughout the night and share your thoughts about the ceremony in the comments.

headline: Lottery Numbers
After Dubai
text: When it looked as if Dubai would go bust last month, making global financial markets swoon, its wealthy neighboring emirate stepped in and bailed it out with a $10 billion loan. Unfortunately Dubai isn’t the only one teetering on the brink. Greece is also in trouble; so is Ireland. Others could follow. Unless the world’s richest nations come to the rescue of weakened states, the global financial crisis might sprout another leg and stop the nascent recovery in its tracks.

headline: A Bagram Reckoning
text: We keep waiting  in vain  for the Obama administration to stop trying to block judicial scrutiny of some of the Bush administration’s most outrageous policies on the detention of prisoners.

headline: How Retirees Saved the Banks
text: If you’re a retiree who relies on interest income, you know that the tap is running dry. In fact, many investors in certificates of deposits, savings accounts and money market accounts are losing money once taxes and inflation are subtracted from today’s extremely low yields.

headline: Politicians Watch Criminals Pack More Heat
text: The nation’s police chiefs are finding an alarming increase in criminals’ use of assault weapons  the high-powered battlefield rifles that used to be banned, back when the federal government showed greater concern for public safety. The 10-year ban expired in 2004, despite the vows of presidential nominees from both parties to fight for renewal. Congress hasn’t mustered the guts to try, preferring to roll over for the gun lobby.

headline: Mayor Faults Bill Doubling Charter Schools
text: A proposed law that would double the number of charter schools permitted in the state, but place significant new requirements and restrictions on them, drew criticism on Sunday from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who, under the law, would lose the authority to grant charters.

headline: Fixture of Avenue A Faces the Threat of a Padlock
text: Opposite Tompkins Square Park, the usual sort of post-midnight gathering was taking place on a recent evening inside a cramped storefront with tile floors and a worn blue counter.

headline: Hangover Jokes, by an Amateur
text: “I’m not good at writing jokes, I’m not even that good at telling them,” Justin Bartha, who played the straight man in “The Hangover,” which won for best comedy, said on the red carpet of the Golden Globes. “I need people to write for me to be funny.”

headline: Coming Soon: More Sassy Leading Ladies?
text: Sandra Bullock‘s best actress victory for playing a take-charge Southerner in “The Blind Side” — and her nomination for “The Proposal” — is a triumph for a different kind of leading lady. Would we now see a slew of laurel-wreathed sassy, funny ladies?

headline: Abbott Defends Skating Title With a Flourish
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  As Jeremy Abbott’s long program came to a close Sunday, before his final spin was complete, the crowd at the United States Figure Skating Championships had leapt to its feet and was roaring.

headline: Rachel Alexandra vs. Zenyatta Is Now Up to Voters
text: A race for superiority that has yet to be decided on the racetrack has now come down to the ballot box. Zenyatta and Rachel Alexandra are among the most accomplished horses ever to race: neither lost in 2009 and both achieved historic feats, but Eclipse Award voters had to choose between the two. The outcome still very much in doubt, the 2009 Horse of the Year will be announced Monday night in ceremonies at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Instincts Take Over as Sanchez Finds Keller
text: SAN DIEGO  In the far corner of the Jets’ victorious locker room, Dustin Keller sat in front of his locker, leaned forward and considered his place in franchise history.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC DATA Reports include: housing starts and Producer Price Index for December (Wednesday); Conference Board index of leading economic indicators for December; the Philadelphia Fed’s manufacturing index for January(Thursday).

headline: In Melbourne, Sharapova’s Comeback Ends Quickly
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  They are the best tennis players in the world, yet they still get butterflies, and all Kim Clijsters, Andy Roddick, Justine Henin and Rafael Nadal had to do was watch Maria Sharapova slink out of Rod Laver Arena to know why.

headline: Color and Design
Pay Rises for Leaders of Colleges, Survey Says
text: Many of the nation’s public universities eliminated courses and raised tuition last year, but the salaries and benefits of their presidents continued to rise, though at a slower rate than in years past, a new study has found.

headline: Median Pay of Public University Presidents Rose to $436,000 Last Year
text: For those who may have wondered how the financial crunch at the nation’s public universities might be affecting the pay of the leaders of those institutions, The Chronicle of Higher Education provides some answers.

headline: Honoring Dr. King
text: There are many places around the city paying tribute to Martin Luther King Jr. today. One of the highlights is sure to be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the borough’s president, Marty Markowitz, and Medgar Evers College of the City University of New York will host a public celebration in his honor. The festivities begin at 10:30 a.m. with the actor Danny Glover appearing as the keynote speaker and the New Life Tabernacle Mass Choir and the Human Orchestra providing musical performances. Stick around after the event at the opera house for a free screening of the documentary “Soundtrack for a Revolution,” which Mr. Glover produced. The movie explores the history of the civil rights movement through freedom songs and includes performances by John Legend, Joss Stone, Wyclef Jean, the Roots, Richie Havens and others. It begins at 1 p.m.

headline: By One Estimate, Nets Won’t Break N.B.A. Futility Record
text: Ryan Parker, a senior at the College of Charleston majoring in math and statistics, runs the Web site BasketballGeek.com.

headline: The Multi-Tasker at the Met
text: Up or down? It’s hard to know where to look for Plácido Domingo this week at the Met. When he is not in the pit conducting Verdi’s opera “Stiffelio,” he is onstage singing. He’ll be easy to spot tonight when he performs Verdi’s “Simon Boccanegra.” “As a young man, Mr. Domingo was a baritone,” writes Anthony Tommasini. “He built his top range through hard work, note by note, to become a tenor, a project that turned out extremely well. He has sung some 124 roles so far. Now, for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera, he performs his newest role, for baritone, the title role of Verdi’s ‘Simon Boccanegra.’ For this back-to-the-future adventure, Mr. Domingo will have the support of James Levine in the pit, and a cast including the tenor Marcello Giordani and the soprano Adrianne Pieczonka. Though the plot of ‘Simon Boccanegra’ is nearly impenetrable, in its revised version, which is offered here, the opera is rich with first-class Verdi music.”

headline: N.F.C. Divisional Playoffs: Vikings Pound Cowboys
text: Behind a swarming defense and four touchdown passes from Brett Favre, the Vikings pound Tony Romo and the Cowboys to advance to the N.F.C. title game.

headline: Helping Haiti
text: It’s no surprise that New Yorkers have come out in droves to contribute to the Haiti relief effort, and this week offers even more opportunities to help. City Winery will host a series of benefit concerts over a few days, beginning on Jan. 20 with Patti Smith and Yo La Tengo among the artists slated to perform, and tomorrow night Le Poisson Rouge is lending a hand, or space rather, with a concert featuring Groove Collective, DJ Logic, Bernie Worrell and Dr. Lonnie Smith. Tonight, the designers Narciso Rodriguez and Cynthia Rowley, as well as Chiara Clemente, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, Mickey Boardman of Paper magazine and an array of other fashionable folks, will host a benefit at Thom Bar, beginning at 6 p.m. A $20 minimum donation will cover Skyy and Patron cocktails and music by the D.J. Belinda Becker, as well as snacks by Kittichai. All proceeds will go to benefit the American Red Cross/Haiti Relief and Development. If you’re looking for other ways to contribute, just go here.

headline: For Two Croats, Obstacles Are as Plentiful as Success
text: WENGEN, Switzerland  Five weeks after surgery on his right knee, Ivica Kostelic felt healthy enough to rip down two selective slalom runs and end up the winner here Sunday.

headline: N.F.C. Championship Glance: Vikings vs. Saints
text: Minnesota Vikings (second seed) at New Orleans Saints (first seed)

headline: George Leonard, Voice of ’60s Counterculture, Dies at 86
text: George Leonard, a former journalist who foresaw the countercultural tides of the 1960s, then dived into them when he helped define the human potential movement at its de facto headquarters, the Esalen Institute, died on Jan. 6 at his home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 86.

headline: The Blue People May Soon See Oscar Gold
text: James Cameron’s “Avatar” — now jokingly rendered as “I See Blue People” instead of “Dances With Smurfs” — triumphed at the Golden Globes in a night when the biggest surprises came, perhaps, from the weather. Rain soaked the red carpet, which at least made it one of the few occasions when having an umbrella handler was not considered mere celebrity hubris. (The other being if you’re Sophia Loren.)

headline: Haiti Quake Day 6: Success and Failure
text: Simon Romero reports from Port-au-Prince on how a devastated country is fighting for stability.

headline: St. Patrick Guard Dishes Out Assists and One-Liners
text: ELIZABETH, N.J.  Kevin Boyle Jr., whose wit is considerably quicker than his crossover, has been heckled on stages as large as Madison Square Garden and in front of national television cameras for suspected nepotism, but that was for basketball.

headline: A Gentleman Enforcer Turns His Focus to Haiti
text: To go with the 1,126 penalty minutes he has accumulated, Georges Laraque has scored 53 goals in his 12-year N.H.L. career. But none were bigger than the one he scored Thursday, the night the Montreal Canadiens opened a fund-raising drive dedicated to earthquake recovery in Haiti.

headline: Rangers Trounce Canadiens, 6-2
text: The Rangers’ scorers finally awoke at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night in a 6-2 victory, though it took a game against the Montreal Canadiens, who have the second-worst regulation record in the East, to rouse them from their offensive slumber.

headline: A.F.C. Championship Glance: Jets vs. Colts
text: Jets (fifth seed) at Indianapolis Colts (first seed)

headline: Golden Globe Winners
text: A look at the winners of the 2010 Golden Globe awards.

headline: Even in Hollywood, World’s Troubles Impinged
text: Ricky Gervais, true to form, went after NBC at the Golden Globes, mocking the network’s Conan-Jay imbroglio with the words, “Let’s get on with it before NBC replaces me with Jay Leno.” But the NBC-hazing actually started on the red carpet, with Julia Roberts telling Billy Bush during the pre-game show, “NBC  you guys are in the toilet right now!”

headline: Haiti Quake Day 6: Faith and Healing
text: The decimated Catholic Church in Port-au-Prince offers hope while others offer what medical help they can.

headline: Wall St. Weighs a Challenge to a Proposed Tax
text: Wall Street’s main lobbying arm has hired a top Supreme Court litigator to study a possible legal battle against a bank tax proposed by the Obama administration, on the theory that it would be unconstitutional, according to three industry officials briefed on the matter, Eric Dash writes in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | January 18, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: For Many Start-Ups, Nasdaq Not the Goal
text: Investors in technology start-ups have been trying to end the drought in initial public offerings of tech companies. But for entrepreneurs, has taking a company public lost its allure?

headline: Kabul Attack Shows Resilience of Afghan Militants
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A team of militants launched a spectacular assault at the heart of the Afghan government on Monday, with two men detonating suicide bombs and the rest fighting to the death only 50 yards from the gates of the presidential palace.

headline: The Difference Between Glitter and Gold for Johnny Weir
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  No American figure skater is more engaging than Johnny Weir or more acutely balanced on that thin edge between art and sport. He clearly wants to be a star. The question is, can he still be a champion?

headline: China XD Begins New Year of I.P.O.’s Modestly
text: China XD Electric, the country’s largest maker of electricity transmission and distribution equipment, set an unambitious pricing range in its I.P.O. to raise up to 10.27 billion renminbi ($1.5 billion), in the country’s first major offering this year, Reuters reported.

headline: Wickmayer Wins Opener After Mighty Struggle
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — A rising star of women’s tennis, Yanina Wickmayer of Belgium, fought the elements and a determined challenger, Alexandra Dulgheru of Romania, to win a three-set battle before a capacity crowd of about 6,000 spectators on the Margaret Court Arena. After a lengthy rain delay, Wickmayer prevailed, 1-6, 7-5, 10-8, to reach the second round. Had she lost, it would have represented a major setback, even though she was not seeded here because of an unresolved dispute over her availability for drug testing. The match was interrupted several times by a summer rain that stalled many of the tournment’s opening-day matches and eventually drove the two women off the court and into the locker room in midafternoon after more than three hours of play. Wickmayer is ranked 16th in the world and had defeated Dulgheru three times last year while climbing the ladder of women’s tennis in the shadow of her Begian compatriots, Justine Henin and Kim Clijsters. But Dulgheru, a 20-year-old from Bucharest, fought tenanciously before yielding.

headline: Hanwha Plans $2 Billion I.P.O. of Korea Insurance
text: Hanwha Group, the South Korean conglomerate, is planning to take its Korea Life Insurance unit public as early as in the current quarter, the parent group said Monday, in an I.P.O. worth an estimated $2 billion.

headline: Election Monitors See Few Problems in Ukraine Vote
text: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukraine, where an election five years ago descended into mass protests over vote-rigging, carried out the first round of its presidential balloting far more competently and fairly on Sunday, election monitors said Monday.

headline: From the Cruyff Turn to the Blanco Bunny Hop and More
text: It was the brightest flash of brilliant Orange. In a 1974 World Cup group match between the Netherlands and Sweden, Johan Cruyff picked the ball up on the edge of the box under pressure from a defender, feigned to cross, then pulled the ball back between his legs, leaving the Swedish fullback flailing like a drunken sea captain. And just like that, the Cruyff Turn was born.Since then, there have been other moves that have become synonymous with an individual player. At the World Cup in South Africa this year, we can hope to see some of the players performing their signature moves in action.

headline: Stepanek Upset in Men’s First Day
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Ten days ago, Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic was battling toe-to-toe with Andy Roddick of the United States in the finals of the Brisbane International tournament. Stepanek, the defending champion, lost an epic encounter, 7-6 (2), 7-6 (7) and drew Roddick’s praise as an indefatiguable opponent.

headline: Man Who Shot Pope in 1981 Is Freed
text: ISTANBUL  Almost three decades after he shot and wounded Pope John Paul II, Mehmet Ali Agca walked free from prison on Monday, heading to a luxury hotel and proclaiming himself to be “Christ eternal.”

headline: Workplace Lingo
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the language they use at work – words and phrases that are (all too) familiar to them, but of curiosity to outsiders.

headline: Under the Stars, Shisha Smoke and Tasty Bites
text: Mumbai’s rooftop shisha lounges can be hard to find, but are worth seeking out. Even if smoking flavored tobacco from a hookah isn’t your thing, these restaurants offer the rare chance to eat good north Indian food as it’s meant to be eaten — under the stars, sitting on cushions amid air tinged with mint and rose.

headline: Jets Open Thread: The Formula Against the Colts
text: Next week’s A.F.C. championship game in Indianapolis will be one of the biggest games in Jets history.

headline: Escaping the Capital as Help Is Arriving
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Wharf Jérémie on this city’s edge was all chaos and destruction on Monday, with upturned shipping containers lying in the sea and pigs foraging on piles of refuse. But for a thousand or more seeking a ride on rickety boats away from the ruined capital, the wharf was a means to something hopeful: escape.

headline: Germany Supports Tougher Iran Sanctions
text: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel said Monday that Germany would support much tougher sanctions against Iran in a bid to halt its nuclear ambitions.

headline: Why Do Pet Stories Trump Haitian Disaster?
text: Today’s idea: Why does a dog who understands Polish attract more readers on the BBC’s Web site than the Haitian disaster? Because pet stories “sit midway between a global civil society and a global horror show,” a blogger says. And that’s not such a bad thing.

headline: Rex Ryan’s Postgame Speech in Locker Room
text: Do you suppose the Jets enjoy playing for this man?

headline: Remembering the Little People: Accounting for Kids

headline: Ask John Burns: Islamic Radicalization
text: This week, John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, will answer readers’ questions about Islamic radicalization. Mr. Burns was part of a team of Times reporters who worked on a profile of Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab published on Sunday tracing how this privileged young man embraced a violent vision of religion and is now accused of trying to ignite a bomb in an airplane over Detroit. How does it happen? How much is it personal, how much religious, how much the broader culture? Post a question below, and Mr. Burns will answer your questions later in the week.

headline: Newbery and Caldecott Awards Announced
text: Rebecca Stead, author of “When You Reach Me,” a mystery and a novel of friendship set in New York City, won the John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to children’s literature on Monday. Ms. Stead was widely considered a favorite among librarians and bloggers who write about books for young people. The novel, which takes place in 1979 and chronicles an intimate neighborhood on the Upper West Side, tells the story of Miranda, a sixth-grader who must unravel clues about why her best friend, Sal, stopped talking to her. “When You Reach Me” has spent eight weeks on the New York Times Best Seller List for children’s chapter books. The award was conferred by the Association for Library Service to Children, a division of the American Library Association, at the library association’s midwinter conference in Boston. The association also awarded the Randolph Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished American picture book for children to “The Lion & The Mouse” by Jerry Pinkney. Mr. Pinkney’s book is a nearly wordless adaptation of Aesop’s fable about how the king of the animal kingdom is helped by one of its smallest creatures. For the first time this year, the Young Adult Library Services Association, also a division of the library association, awarded a prize for a nonfiction work to “Charles and Emma: The Darwins’ Leap of Faith” by Deborah Heiligman.

headline: Sharapova’s Expectations Collide With Reality
text: There was a Russian named Maria victorious on Day 1 of the Australian Open on Rod Laver Arena, but it wasn’t Maria Sharapova. The lesser-known Russian Maria Kirilenko took out Sharapova in a battle of Marias, shocking the 2008 champion in three dramatic sets.

headline: Screen Saver | The Film/Art Gallery
text: Matthew McCarthy, the owner of the Film/Art Gallery, began collecting film posters as a boy, but his private obsession turned public only a few years ago. And he has Audrey Hepburn to thank. As the story goes, he was visiting his linen-backer to restore some old Hepburn movie posters when the linen-backer asked if McCarthy knew Sean Hepburn Ferrer, the actress’s son. “He thought Sean might be interested in buying some of the posters,” says McCarthy. And indeed, Ferrer bought a bunch of them. “That was my first big sale.” The introduction turned into a job for McCarthy as an archivist for the Hepburn foundation, and it prompted him to start his Web-based gallery, offering up some of his 3,000 vintage movie posters for sale. Hollywood and design insiders have quickly caught onto McCarthy’s astonishing collection of rare and foreign posters, many of them far more avant-garde than the standard-issue Hollywood versions. (Check out the Czech edition of “Cool Hand Luke.”) Besides continually adding to his collection, McCarthy (whose partner, Tyler Cassity, owns Hollywood Forever cemetery, where he hosts extremely popular movie nights in the summer) is planning a bricks-and-mortar gallery space to hold screenings and poster exhibitions based on particular stars, directors and genres.

headline: Lady Gaga Puts Off More Shows
text: Fans of Lady Gaga were sufficiently baffled by the lyrics to her song “Bad Romance”; now they’re trying to understand how the singer was able to make a Friday appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” while canceling or postponing several concert dates.

headline: Answers From a Young Lawyer
text: On Monday, City Room published a video report about lawyers destined for the corporate track who were diverted into public service. The video featured Chris Reid, a Fordham Law School graduate who was originally recruited by Ropes & Gray to work in their patent litigation practice, then gave him the option of finding a public interest job in lieu of his first year. Mr. Reid ended up working with the Legal Aid Society in Brooklyn housing court, keeping families in their homes.

headline: Reagan, Taxes, Jobs
text: Apropos of a point I made in today’s column: there were two major tax changes in Reagan’s first term, which began in January 1981. ERTA, aka the Reagan tax cut, was signed in August 1981; TEFRA, which raised taxes, was signed in September 1982.

headline: How Wyclef Jean’s Haiti Charity Spent Its Money
text: The Smoking Gun reports that a charitable foundation established by Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-American musician, has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars over the years paying Mr. Jean himself, along with his business partner, for rent and various services. Mr. Jean’s video response is now on YouTube.

headline: Postmodern Warfare: Chávez Says PlayStation Will ‘Teach You to Kill’
text: Let’s see Microsoft try to use these blurbs in their next Xbox campaign: the Sony PlayStation video game console has been criticized by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, not because he finds Assassin’s Creed II oddly unengaging or is growing impatient for the release of Final Fantasy XIII, but because he believes that it is “poison” and will lead children down a capitalist “road to hell,” Agence France-Presse reported. On his weekly radio and television show, Mr. Chávez said, “Those games they call ‘PlayStation’ are poison. Some games teach you to kill.” He added that violent video games are sold by capitalist countries so they can “later sell weapons,” and they “promote the need for cigarettes, drugs and alcohol so they can sell them,” according to Agence France-Presse. In October, Venezuela passed a law making it illegal to sell violent video games, an offense punishable by up to five years in prison. Mr. Chávez has previously criticized Nintendo for promoting “selfishness, individualism and violence,” and that was before the company released New Super Mario Bros. Wii, which is, like, totally impossible.

In an interview on the ABC morning program “The View,” Mr. Platt revealed how he came up with the song that has made him a minicelebrity ever since he performed it Wednesday night on “American Idol.”

headline: The $250 Million Underdog Celebrates
text: The king of the world Sunday night was Tom Rothman, the co-chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, the studio behind “Avatar.” “We’ve had a very strong, diversified year,” he said while fetching a seltzer and a soda for his kids at the bar of Craft. (Fox’s other big recent hit was “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel.”) He told us – in a mantra we heard all night – that James Cameron‘s “Avatar” was the underdog film.

headline: Risottos for Winter
text: When I’m at a loss as to what to make for a dinner party, or what to do with a given vegetable, I invariably turn to risottos. They please everybody  kids and adults, vegetarians and meat-eaters, the gluten-sensitive and even vegans, if you forego the final addition of Parmesan.

headline: Regimens: Questioning Benefit of Diabetes Test Strips
text: People with Type 2 diabetes are often advised to use blood-glucose test strips to monitor their blood sugar levels, but a Canadian analysis has found that routine self-monitoring is not cost-effective for many patients: the strips can cost almost a dollar each, and they prevent comparatively few complications of diabetes.

headline: British File-Sharing Verdict: Not Guilty
text: A software engineer who was the first person in Britain to be prosecuted for illegal file-sharing has been found not guilty of conspiracy to defraud, BBC News reported. The engineer, Alan Ellis, ran the now-defunct file-sharing Web site OiNK.cd from an apartment in Middlesbrough, in northern England, from 2004 to 2007 until it was shut down in a police raid. Though the site did not require users to pay and instead asked for voluntary donations, prosecutors said that Mr. Ellis had $300,000 in a Paypal account and received $18,000 a month in donations. Mr. Ellis, 26, said in court that he had not intended to defraud the copyright holders of the songs downloaded through OiNK.cd, and that he had set up the Web site “to further my skills. To better my skills for employability.” The site, which did not host any songs itself, facilitated the illegal downloading of more than 21 million music files.

headline: The Claim: If You Have a Seafood Allergy, Avoid CT Scans
text: THE FACTS Seafood allergies represent the most common form of food allergies in adults, affecting about 2 percent to 3 percent of Americans. But myths about the condition abound.

headline: Narrowing an Eating Disorder
text: The year was 1988, and I was a college student on my junior year abroad, traveling aimlessly through the Middle East and Europe. My backpack was crammed with shorts and T-shirts, bathing suits and sarongs, my Walkman and Grateful Dead tapes. And oh, yes, a scale, buried deep beneath layers of socks. Having been a chubby adolescent  and having spent six summers at fat camp  I was terrified of gaining weight.

headline: Luminous 3-D Jungle Is a Biologist’s Dream
text: When watching a Hollywood movie that has robed itself in the themes and paraphernalia of science, a scientist expects to feel anything from annoyance to infuriation at facts misconstrued or processes misrepresented. What a scientist does not expect is to enter into a state of ecstatic wonderment, to have the urge to leap up and shout: “Yes! That’s exactly what it’s like!”

headline: The Platypus Is Cute but Far From Harmless
text: In “The Nutmeg of Consolation” by Patrick O’Brian, the 14th in his series of maritime novels, the good Dr. Stephen Maturin’s unabashed joy at finally seeing a platypus in Australia is almost immediately tempered by the incapacitating pain he experiences when he is stung by poisonous spurs on the animal’s rear legs.

headline: Genome Study Provides a Census of Early Humans
text: From the composition of just two human genomes, geneticists have computed the size of the human population 1.2 million years ago from which everyone in the world is descended.

headline: Why Sharapova Lost to Kirilenko
text: Maria Kirilenko did not jump for joy or toss her racket skyward after winning her match with Maria Sharapova on the first day at the Australian Open. She even tried to quiet her more boisterous supporters as she walked to the net to shake hands with her taller, more celebrated opponent. Kirilenko looked as though she was already focusing on her next match, and this victory was not at all a surprise to her.

headline: Now Reading | Can’t Burn This
text: Who says literature can’t be hot? The Fine Books Company of Rochester, Mich., is selling “The Complete Science Fiction Asbestos Collection,” a set of fireproofed, autographed first editions of Ray Bradbury’s “Fahrenheit 451″ and Stephen King’s “Firestarter.” The books are bound in a silvery, asbestos material, and going for the minor sum of $31,810. For those with money to burn, apparently.

headline: Three Dominant Home Teams, and the Jets
text: Until the Jets crashed the party Sunday night, the N.F.L. playoffs had taken on the look of the bulked-up bullies kicking sand in the faces of weaklings. The dominance of the top-seeded teams  translation: of the home teams  should not have surprised anybody, though. Since 1990, home teams have a winning percentage of 73.8 in the divisional round of the playoffs, meaning that three-quarters of the time the top seeds advance to the conference championship round, according to the Elias Sports Bureau. And this year, there was a greater distance between the very best teams and those in the chase.

headline: For 9/11 Team, Haiti Brings It All Back
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A pile of rubble is a pile of rubble, whether it is Lower Manhattan or central Port-au-Prince. As a New York rescue team combed the wreckage of last week’s earthquake in search of long-shot survivors on Monday, some said one particular past disaster  the collapsed World Trade Center towers  was not far back in their minds.

headline: Milan Fashion | Rooted Looks
text: MILAN — The buzzword for the men’s shows here so far has been “heritage” — which is to say that designers are going back to their roots in order to entice still-weary customers with items that reflect the value of their houses rather than flash-in-the-pan status symbols. Dolce & Gabbana led the way with one of its strongest presentations in seasons, using Giuseppe Tornatore’s new film, “Baarìa,” as the starting point for a Sicilian-inspired collection highlighting Italian tailoring and distressed work wear. The Sunday-best suits looked especially sharp when contrasted with worn-out tank tops, frayed jeans and long johns tucked into worker boots. Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are celebrating their 20th anniversary this year, and their attention is clearly in the right place.

headline: Starting Over in Lexington: A Clarification
text: I have to admit, I was taken by surprise by some of the responses to my last post about the company we bought in Lexington, Ky. It seems a few people out there thought it was harsh of me to answer the questions from the shop floor by telling them it was up to them to figure out how to make this work. Some of the commenters said, You can’t just abandon your employees.

headline: Living With a Formerly Fatal Blood Cancer
text: In December 2005, a series of mysterious symptoms  night sweats, easy bruising, swollen ankles and breathlessness upon exertion  prompted Barry to see his doctor. Only six months earlier, a physical exam had found nothing abnormal. But now Barry’s white blood cell count was through the roof.

headline: Healing Physically, Yet Still Not Whole
text: Still haunted and chastened by the Puritan work ethic, our culture doesn’t much believe in convalescing, in full recovery. No matter what happens in our lives  a grave illness, a wrenching divorce, a death in the family  the unspoken understanding is that we should want to rush back into the game. Like an old-time quarterback who has had one concussion too many, we are expected to stagger back onto the field no matter what.

headline: A Little Too Close to the Battle in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The man with the bulging shawl had only just exploded when the real battle got under way.
