headline: For Gates Aides, No Fatigues at Work
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has told his military aides not to wear combat fatigues to work at the Pentagon anymore, reversing a symbolic change of protocol ordered in the harrowing days after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Further Reflections on a Golden ‘I’
text: Update | 2:57 p.m.  A number of readers raised concerns that the photo of Christina Hendricks at the Golden Globe Awards had been deliberately altered. The photo was slightly distorted inadvertently due to an error during routine processing. The photograph has been replaced.

headline: Glassmaking Thrives Offshore, but Is Declining in U.S.
text: The majestic steel beams of a soaring office tower beginning to rise from the ruins of the World Trade Center are a tribute to American resilience, but also a marker in the decline of yet another industry. Not an inch of imported glass went into the two lost towers, built 40 years ago. The lower floors of the new one will soon be sheathed in Chinese glass.

headline: Enriched by Record Ransom, Somali Pirates Free Tanker
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somali pirates off the eastern coast of Africa released a Greek oil tanker and its 28-member crew on Monday after receiving what they said was a $5.5 million ransom, believed to be the largest sum paid to free a hijacked ship.

headline: Managing Disasters With Small Steps
text: A week ago, Elizabeth Sheehan, the founder of Containers to Clinics, a nonprofit organization in Dover, Mass., was preparing to deploy the group’s first medical clinic overseas. Made from two shipping containers, it was to be sent to the Dominican Republic, where it would begin to fulfill the group’s long-term goal of building health care infrastructure in developing countries through networks of small container clinics in rural areas.

headline: Texas Textbooks
text: Oh, boy. Paul Samuelson famously declared, “I don’t care who writes a nation’s laws — or crafts its advanced treatises — if I can write its economics textbooks.” But guess who’s going to be writing our textbooks?

headline: How Do You Feel About Bordeaux?
text: My column this week is on inexpensive Bordeaux, costing $10 to $20 a bottle. Inexpensive Bordeaux might sound like an oxymoron, but in fact it accounts for the overwhelming percentage of the wine produced in the region. We just don’t hear about it much.

headline: Taking a Menu Forward to the 20th Century
text: American orchestras and their audiences have for years debated whether they should mainly be museums for the canonical repertory or evolving institutions that conserve that repertory but also push into the future. That debate came late to the Vienna Philharmonic, at least as it projects itself internationally, through tours and recordings: its conservatorship of the great works, particularly those of the Viennese Classical era, has always been the unchallenged heart of its mission.

headline: The Morning Skate: A Rainy Night in the Garden
text: The Garden crowd arrived late, possibly delayed by the cold January rain or the warmth of watching the Jets’ N.F.L. playoff game on TV from San Diego. No matter. The Rangers arrived late, too.

headline: Destructive creativity
text: I don’t always agree with Naomi Klein, and I don’t always disagree with David Frum, but Klein wins this one hands down: Frum worries that financial regulation might crush “the creativity of the system,” Klein counters that “we could all do with them being a little less creative.”

headline: Scorecard | Dolce & Gabbana Wins!
text: Is it really fashion week again, already? Not to fear, as ever, Scorecard is here keeping tabs on all the critic talk so you don’t have to. The opening day of the Milan men’s-wear shows Saturday marked the big 2-0 for the Dolce & Gabbana duo and a centennial for Ermenegildo Zegna, so it’s no surprise that amid the birthday festivities designers were all about going back to their roots. Critics, meanwhile, were feeling this archive digging — so long as fashion flashbacks didn’t land squarely in the “Flashdance” era.

headline: Ankles Gain as Candidates for Joint Replacement

headline: A New Joint Gains as a Candidate for Replacement
text: The bodies of many older Americans are practically bionic: more than 770,000 hip and knee replacements are performed each year in the United States.

headline: Skepticism for Obama’s Fiscal Policy
text: In a November 2008 Op-Ed article for The New York Times, the Nobel Prize-winning economist Joseph E. Stiglitz wrote that a huge stimulus package  as much as $1 trillion over two years  was needed to turn the Great Recession into a robust recovery and that new regulations were needed to change the destructive behavior of Wall Street that had brought about the fiscal calamities in the first place.

headline: Which Super Bowl Matchup Do You Want to See?
text: It is never too early to speculate about Super Bowl matchups. That conversation starts long before the season even begins, sometimes as soon as the previous Super Bowl ends. But after divisional weekend, we are down to four teams to choose from, to dissect, to mix and match until the Super Bowl is set. Which matchup would you want to see? Which overdone story line would you dread hearing about for two weeks?

headline: Music, Impersonations and Insights From the Crowd
text: Brian Fallon, the frontman of the terrific New Jersey punk band the Gaslight Anthem, played a rare solo show at the Bowery Ballroom on Friday night, but he was not unaccompanied. His three band mates weren’t there, but in their stead he got soused singalongs and hecklers.

headline: Secret Ingredients of Business Travel: Hot Sauce and Cash
text: I’VE learned two things about business travel. Always carry hot sauce and have enough cash for some decent tips.

headline: Obama to Deliver State of the Union Address Jan. 27
text: .Update | 6:49 p.m. President Obama will deliver his first State of the Union address on Jan. 27.

headline: Pitti Uomo | Technical Concepts
text: FLORENCE, Italy — Here in at the fall/winter 2010 men’s collections at Pitti Uomo it was hard to miss the continuing influence of vintage Americana on the sportswear being shown. However, there’s a new technical edge infusing these traditional tweeds with elements of the worlds of mountaineering and climbing.A line simply called M based in Tokyo offered the perfect emblem of this rugged rough-and-ready sportswear, showing a photo of a shaggy model in a down vest embellished with Fair Isle-style detailing in the shadow of a snowy peak along with the slogan “Challenge Mount Fuji … because it’s there.” It offered the same graphic pattern in a heavy woolen short, an odd choice for a winter “pant” but one that consistently cropped up at the show. The trek-worthy gear also featured hooded plaid parkas with built-in backpacks.

headline: Obama Breaks Ground With a Tweet
text: President Obama on Monday pushed the button on his first-ever tweet — a message about his visit to the headquarters of the American Red Cross to thank workers for their efforts in responding to the devastating earthquake in Haiti.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Player’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks at “The Player,” Robert Altman‘s 1992 film, adapted by Michael Tolkin from his novel, about an ambitious Hollywood studio executive, played by Tim Robbins, who gets involved in a murder.

headline: Sound of Ivy League Rock, With a World of Sources
text: Everything is natty and knowing in Vampire Weekend’s songs. They are marvelous, quick-fingered mechanisms of hooks and syncopations, riffs and references, both musical and verbal. They mesh bubblegum, Vivaldi, reggae, Zimbabwean chimurenga, new wave, soca and more. They cite Richard Serra, Cape Cod, the Khyber Pass, Aranciata, Contra Costa, Darjeeling tea, mansard roofs and diplomatic license plates.

headline: Pelosi: Mass. Election Won’t Stop Health Bill
text: With Democrats increasingly anxious about the special election in Massachusetts on Tuesday and what it will mean for their big health care legislation, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, told reporters in California Monday that the legislation would move forward not matter what.

headline: With New Films, CBS Charts Tough Middle Course
text: LOS ANGELES  CBS Films, the venerable television company’s upstart movie studio, had a problem with its first film. The emotional peak of “Extraordinary Measures,” a medical drama set for release on Friday, was arriving too early.

headline: A Rainy Globes Gets Ratings Boost
text: The rain at Sunday’s Golden Globes may have wreaked havoc on the hair-dos, but it did not wilt ratings. About 17 million people watched NBC’s live telecast of the ceremony, according to Nielsen data, a fat 14 percent increase from the year before, when about 15 million watched. In the crucial advertising category of people age 18 to 49, the Globes perked up 10 percent — exactly what the network had predicted — going into the night.

headline: Kraft and Cadbury Near a $19 Billion Deal
text: Update | 3:18 a.m. Kraft confirmed Tuesday morning that it was finalizing the terms for a friendly takeover of Cadbury of Britain.

headline: Mass. Senate Rivals Cross Paths in Last Push
text: Back Story With The Times’s Michael CooperClick Below to Listen

headline: A Very New York Novel Wins Newbery Medal
text: With its complex structure, evocation of time travel and resonant 1970s New York setting, “When You Reach Me,” a novel of mystery and friendship, won the John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to children’s literature on Monday.

headline: The Slugger and the Punching Bag
text: PRINCETON, N.J.  The playwright Will Power places an unlikely pair of contenders in the theatrical ring in the new play “Fetch Clay, Make Man,” which is having its premiere at the McCarter Theater Center here. In one corner we find Muhammad Ali, the world-renowned prize fighter and semiprofessional poet born Cassius Clay. Opposite him is Stepin Fetchit, the actor who made it big in Hollywood by performing a cruel comic stereotype of servility and laziness.

headline: Now Scrutinizing | A Rounder Golden Globes
text: Maybe it’s just me, but I could have sworn that some of the ladies who showed up at the Golden Globes on Sunday had put on a little weight. It’s almost criminal to name names, because the very actresses whose body-mass indexes have been the subject of endless tabloid speculation are the very ones now sporting sexier curves. You could definitely see the difference if you concentrated solely on the upper arms. Instead of a Barbie-doll circumference, there was suddenly, amazingly, a womanly roundness to their frames. More Marilyn than Twiggy, that’s for sure.

headline: Raucous Life Unveiled, in an Appeal to the Timid
text: There has to be some mistake. The title of the solo show is “Wild Man,” but the actor on the bare stage looks like somebody’s eighth-grade math teacher.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 7: A Mass Exodus
text: Thousands of earthquake refugees are fleeing to the countryside or trying to get on planes to leave the country entirely.

headline: The Return of Northeastern Republicans?
text: While we await tomorrow’s outcome in Massachusetts, this early-January analysis from Steve Kornacki is worth pondering:

headline: Not Guilty Verdict in File-Sharing Case
text: A software engineer who was the first person in Britain to be prosecuted for illegal file sharing has been found not guilty of conspiracy to defraud, BBC News reported. The engineer, Alan Ellis, ran the file-sharing Web site OiNK.cd, which is now defunct, from an apartment in Middlesbrough, in northern England, from 2004 to 2007 until it was shut down in a police raid. Though the site did not require users to pay and instead asked for voluntary donations, prosecutors said that Mr. Ellis had $300,000 in a Paypal account and received $18,000 a month in donations. Mr. Ellis, 26, said in court that he had not intended to defraud the copyright holders of the songs downloaded through OiNK.cd, and that he had set up the Web site “to further my skills. To better my skills for employability.” The site, which did not host any songs itself, facilitated the illegal downloading of more than 21 million music files.

headline: President Chávez, the Nongameboy
text: Let’s see Microsoft try to use these blurbs in its next Xbox campaign: the Sony PlayStation video game console has been criticized by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, not because he finds Assassin’s Creed II oddly unengaging but because he believes that PlayStation is “poison” and will lead children down a capitalist “road to hell,” Agence France-Presse reported. On his weekly radio and television show, Mr. Chávez said: “Those games they call ‘PlayStation’ are poison. Some games teach you to kill.” He added that violent video games were sold by capitalist countries so that they could “later sell weapons,” and that they “promote the need for cigarettes, drugs and alcohol so they can sell them,” according to Agence France-Presse. In October Venezuela passed a law making it illegal to sell violent video games, an offense punishable by up to five years in prison. Mr. Chávez previously criticized Nintendo for promoting “selfishness, individualism and violence.”

headline: Haitian Charity Questions Anger Wyclef Jean
text: In a video message posted on YouTube, the musician Wyclef Jean, below, defended himself against reports that he benefited personally from his Haitian relief charity, saying, “Not only I denounce all of that, I’m disgusted by that.” Last week the Web site thesmokinggun.com posted a report that said that the Yéle Haiti Foundation, the charity that Mr. Jean has promoted since the Haitian earthquake, “has a lackluster history of accounting for its finances.” The Smoking Gun, citing Internal Revenue Service records, said that the foundation had paid Mr. Jean and a business partner for rent, production services and Mr. Jean’s appearance at a benefit concert, and filed taxes for the first time in August, despite having incorporated 12 years ago. A weary-looking Mr. Jean, who was born in Haiti and recently returned from a visit there, said in the video that he had “always been committed to the people” of that country. He is scheduled to be a host of “Hope for Haiti,” a benefit telethon that will be on many networks on Friday. In a news conference on Monday, Mr. Jean reiterated his defense of the foundation. “Have we made mistakes before?” he said. “Yes. Did I ever use Yéle money for personal benefits? Absolutely not.” He added that the foundation’s books were “open and transparent,” and were given “a clean bill of health by an external auditor every year since we started.”

headline: For the Heirs to Holmes, a Tangled Web
text: For a 123-year-old detective, Sherlock Holmes is a surprisingly reliable earner.

headline: ‘Pants on the Ground’: The Back Story
text: Petrarch had Laura; Dante had Beatrice; and Larry Platt saw some guy on the street and was inspired to write his hit song “Pants on the Ground,” he said on Monday. In an interview on the ABC morning show “The View,” Mr. Platt revealed how he came up with the song that has made him a mini-celebrity ever since he performed it on Wednesday night on “American Idol.” After singing “Pants on the Ground” (and performing a dance routine, calisthenics and a split that didn’t quite happen), Mr. Platt, 63, told the “View” hosts Sherri Shepherd and Elisabeth Hasselbeck that he had devised the song during a stroll. “I was walking one day,” said an out-of-breath Mr. Platt. “I see a guy with a baby bottle in his mouth, pacifier, with his pants on the ground. That’s what gave me an inspiration.” Mr. Platt, a longtime civil rights activist, was appearing on “The View” to celebrate Martin Luther King’s Birthday.

headline: Globes Draw for NBC; N.F.L. Works for CBS
text: About 17 million people watched NBC’s live telecast of the Golden Globe Awards, which were hosted by Ricky Gervais, above, on Sunday night. The number, from Nielsen data, is a 14 percent increase over the year before. In the advertising market of those aged 18 to 49, the Globes perked up 10 percent  exactly what the network had predicted. The Globes are trying to climb back from the devastating effect of a writers’ strike, which scuttled the show in 2008. About 20 million watched in 2007, while the show’s high-water, mark came in 2004 with about 27 million viewers. NBC said the audience was its largest in the time period, excluding sports, in six years. Opposite the Globes and the eighth-season debut of Fox’s “24,” CBS appeared to lead Sunday night’s ratings over all largely because of an overrun of its coverage of the National Football League playoff game between the New York Jets and the San Diego Chargers. CBS drew more than 30 million viewers for the final hour of the game, at 7, helping to raise audiences for the network’s lineup that followed, including “60 Minutes” at 8 (16.7 million), “Cold Case” at 9 (10.7 million) and a rerun of “NCIS” at 10 (9.6 million). NBC ranked second on the night, and Fox edged ABC for third.

headline: Lady Gaga Cancels Several Shows
text: Fans of Lady Gaga were sufficiently baffled by the lyrics to her song “Bad Romance”; now they’re trying to understand how she was able to make a Friday appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” while canceling or postponing several concert dates. On Thursday evening Lady Gaga canceled a show she was to perform at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., writing on her Twitter account that she “was feeling dizzy and having trouble breathing” before the show and that she was later given a diagnosis of exhaustion and dehydration by paramedics. On Friday she taped an appearance on Ms. Winfrey’s show, where she discussed her upbringing, her personal life and her fans (and told the host, “There’s Gandhi, and there’s Oprah”) and also performed her song “Monster.” But that was the only performance that Lady Gaga would give for the weekend. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that she canceled a show scheduled for Saturday at the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa in Atlantic City. The concert promoter Live Nation said on livenation.com that a Lady Gaga show scheduled for Sunday in Wallingford, Conn., was canceled, and the Mohegan Sun casino in Uncasville, Conn., said one planned for Monday was postponed. Lady Gaga is scheduled to begin a four-night stand at Radio City Music Hall in New York on Wednesday.

headline: Group Hug | Renegade Convention
text: MILAN — The idea of rebels is always a powerful one in men’s fashion, and it’s been making the rounds here this season. Bottega Veneta’s Tomas Maier brought flair and sophistication to his parade of Teddy Boys with tapered trousers, bright blazers, chunky creeper shoes and slick duck’s tail hair. Roberto Cavalli’s renegades sported woven leather pants, destroyed jeans and metal mesh tops; at John Varvatos, rockers layered knit coats under and over double-breasted suits and long cardigan jackets. And at Emporio Armani, the nonconformist vibe came via snowboarding and acid-hued paraphernalia; not to mention, of course, the group of 30 models who closed the show wearing nothing but skimpy flesh-toned underwear and the Reebok EA7 sneakers developed by Emporio Armani and Reebok. Who worked out the nonconformist look best? You tell us.

headline: From Deep in the Back Catalog, a Weber-Mahler Collaboration
text: Mahler, paradoxically, first attained recognition as a composer by completing “Die Drei Pintos,” a now obscure three-act comic opera by Carl Maria von Weber. The Bronx Opera presented that complete work this month in what was billed as its New York premiere.

headline: Gilbert, Sullivan and Some Not-So-Helpful Ghosts
text: Just why “Ruddigore,” the 10th of the 14 operettas created by the peerless team of Gilbert and Sullivan, has failed to catch on over the years is hard to figure out. Introduced in 1887 in the wake of “The Mikado,” a runaway hit, “Ruddigore” was initially deemed a lesser work. Though its fortunes changed after a series of revisions, it is rarely encountered today.

headline: Brazen Attack in Kabul
text: The Taliban coordinated a brazen rush-hour attack in downtown Kabul, sending a message to the government that they will bring the fight from the countryside to the city.

headline: A Flash of Vulnerability, Yet Keeping Her Chin Up
text: Across 15 years or so, Beth Orton’s music has come in various flavors, devised by different producers, sometimes lodged in fast-passing mini-movements.

headline: What if Conan Said, ‘Goodbye, NBC. Hello, Internet’?
text: David Carr’s media column this week looks at the state of affairs with late-night television. He argues that the ratings drama surrounding “The Tonight Show” has nothing to do with Conan O’Brien or Jay Leno, but is instead a demonstration of the changing tide of consumer habits from television time slots to the Web.

headline: Jerry Jones’s Decision: Keep Wade Phillips?
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: For Former World’s Fair Ice Rink, Fragments of an Afterlife
text: When the Queens Museum of Art’s expansion project is finished, sometime around 2012, the museum will have doubled in size, to 100,000 square feet. The existing building’s conjoined twin, the World’s Fair ice rink, has already been demolished, and eventually, the museum will be airy and filled with light.

headline: Will China Achieve Science Supremacy?
text: A recent Times article described how China is stepping up efforts to lure home the top Chinese scholars who live and work abroad. The nation is already second only to the United States in the volume of scientific papers published, and it has, as Thomas Friedman pointed out, more students in technical colleges and universities than any other country.

headline: Get-out-the-vote Pitches in Massachusetts
text: LITTLETON, Mass. — Volunteers and campaign workers staffed phone banks for each of the candidates in the Senate race here, as they concentrated on energizing voters to get to the polls on Tuesday.

headline: European Banks Take a Step Toward More Normal Lending
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank and Swiss National Bank said Monday that they would end a program aimed at supplying Swiss currency to banks, in a further sign that the region’s financial system is becoming more stable.

headline: After Hearing in Pakistan, 5 Americans Allege Torture
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  The five American Muslim men from the Washington, D.C., area arrested last month in Pakistan on suspicion of plotting terrorist acts said at a court appearance on Monday that they were being tortured in custody.

headline: Democrats May Seek to Push Health Bill Through House
text: WASHINGTON  The White House and Democratic Congressional leaders, scrambling for a backup plan to rescue their health care legislation if Republicans win the special election in Massachusetts on Tuesday, have begun laying the groundwork to ask House Democrats to approve the Senate version of the bill and send it directly to President Obama for his signature.

headline: Hackers Said to Breach Gmail Accounts in China
text: BEIJING  Google e-mail accounts of at least two foreign journalists in Beijing have been compromised, a journalists’ advocacy group in China said on Monday, adding that hackers changed Gmail program settings so that all messages would be forwarded to unfamiliar addresses.

headline: A Pacific Island Challenge to European Air Pollution
text: BRUSSELS  A Pacific island nation has challenged plans by the Czech Republic to refit a coal-fired power station, in an appeal that environmental advocates on Monday described as the first of its kind.

headline: Modern-Day Pilgrims Find Interfaith Bond in Ancient Syrian Monastery
text: DEIR MAR MOUSA, Syria  As darkness falls over the vast Syrian desert and the first winter stars emerge, a trail of modern-day pilgrims is slowly climbing the stone steps of this remote cliff-top monastery.

headline: Date for State of Union
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will deliver his first State of the Union address on Jan. 27.

headline: Glen W. Bell Jr., Founder of Taco Bell, Dies at 86
text: Glen W. Bell Jr., whose idea in 1951 to sell crispy-shell tacos from the window of his hamburger stand became the foundation of Taco Bell, the restaurant chain that turned Mexican fare into fast food for millions of Americans, died at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Edward H. Linde, Co-Founder of Boston Properties, Dies at 68
text: Edward H. Linde, a founder of one of the largest real estate investment trusts in the nation — and the behind-the-scenes partner of Mortimer B. Zuckerman — died on Sunday in Boston. He was 68 and lived in Weston, Mass.

headline: An Antitrust Complaint for Google in Germany
text: PARIS  Google said on Monday that it faced antitrust complaints in Germany from newspaper and magazine publishers who want the company to pay for using article snippets in its Web news service and search results.

headline: Leno Expects Resolution Tuesday
text: Jay Leno on his show Monday night addressed the issue between NBC, Mr. Leno and Conan O’Brien and said “we should have an answer tomorrow” about whether he is going to return to the 11:35 p.m. time slot.

headline: U.N. Panel’s Glacier Warning Is Criticized as Exaggerated
text: A much-publicized estimate from a United Nations panel about the rapid melting of Himalayan glaciers from climate change is coming under fire as a gross exaggeration.

headline: Gunmen Attack a Charity in a Sunni Neighborhood of Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  Gunmen killed four or five people at the office of an Iraqi humanitarian group in a Sunni neighborhood in Baghdad at midday on Monday, and left a bomb for police responders, in a rare attack on a nongovernmental organization here.

headline: Guatemala: No Damage in Quake
text: An earthquake centered just off the Pacific Coast rattled nerves and sent people into the streets Monday morning, but officials in Guatemala and El Salvador said there were no reports of damage or injuries. The epicenter of the magnitude 5.8 quake was 65 miles south southeast of Guatemala City, the United States Geological Survey said.

headline: For Travelers in Danger, Someone to Swoop In
text: “THERE is no place in the world where there are no business travelers,” said Patrick Deroose, the manager of the corporate assistance division of the worldwide crisis response company International SOS.

headline: Taliban Leaders Unlikely to Accept Offer, Gates Says
text: NEW DELHI  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that there could be a surge of Taliban followers willing to reintegrate with the Afghan government of President Hamid Karzai, but that for now an Afghan government reconciliation with the Taliban leadership was unlikely.

headline: Stephon Marbury’s Next Play: China
text: Stephon Marbury, whose N.B.A. career was distinguished as much by off-court distractions and feuds with coaches as by his playmaking ability, is taking his game far afield: he has joined the Shanxi Zhongyu Brave Dragons of the Chinese Basketball Association, according to the team’s United States-based consultant.

headline: At Yemen College, Scholarship and Jihadist Ideas
text: SANA, Yemen  The mosque at Al Eman University is larger than a football field, an immense warehouse with breeze-block walls, a tin roof and industrial lighting. On Fridays, more than 4,000 men come to pray, lining up along the marks on the figured green carpet, giving each enough room to prostrate himself toward Mecca.

headline: The Bipartisan Panel: Did It Really Work?
text: WASHINGTON  The White House has joined some senators in a claim that upends an old saw. If there is no will among politicians to resolve budget problems, they argue, there is nonetheless a way  through a bipartisan commission.

headline: The Rise and Fall of a Sunni in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  Saleh al-Mutlaq has never shied from controversy, sometimes relishing his plunge into the turbulence of Iraqi politics. But even Mr. Mutlaq, a disheveled former agronomist, seems taken aback at landing square center in a growing dispute that threatens to unleash turmoil ahead of Iraq’s parliamentary elections in March.

headline: Shades of Prejudice
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Swiss Banker Blows Whistle on Tax Evasion
text: From his home in the quiet village of Rorbas, outside Zurich, Rudolf M. Elmer is chipping away at the centuries-old traditions of Swiss banking secrecy.

headline: As Haitians Flee, the Dead Go Uncounted
text: TITANYEN, Haiti — A few miles north of the busted-down buildings in Port-au-Prince, up a hillside where cows graze, an empty hole awaits the dead. Rectangular, 20 feet deep and wide, 100 feet long, it is one of the newest mass graves, but there are many more.

headline: Marking King Day, From Oval Office to Soup Kitchen
text: WASHINGTON  The White House installed a rare signed copy of the Emancipation Proclamation in the Oval Office on Monday, just in time for President Obama to mark his first Martin Luther King’s Birthday in office.

headline: U.N. Likely to Send More Security
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council is expected to agree on Tuesday to send an additional 3,500 soldiers and police officers to Haiti, a move requested by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to protect the distribution of emergency supplies and to ensure public order if post-earthquake frustrations boil over.

headline: Bloggingheads: Coakley's Woes
text: Chris Hayes, left, of The Nation and Tim Carney of The Washington Examiner assess the embattled Martha Coakley.

headline: Kraft Is Said to Reach Deal for Cadbury
text: Kraft Foods has reached a tentative deal for a friendly takeover of Cadbury of Britain, agreeing in principle to pay about $19 billion in cash and stock for the confectioner, people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

headline: Guatemala Protests Arrest of 3 in Florida Over Passports
text: The Guatemalan government has issued a public protest after three Guatemalans were arrested this month by immigration agents at a FedEx office in Florida, when one of the immigrants went to pick up a package containing his newly issued Guatemalan passport.

headline: Aid Arrives but Few Are Lucky to Get It
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  When the aid helicopters descend on the Pétionville Club golf course, once a playground for the wealthy and now a sprawling city of makeshift tents, the residents hurry toward them. But to get there, they must climb a steep embankment to a landing zone on top of a hill where the 82nd Airborne Division distributes the food and water.

headline: Bohemian Soul Mates
text: “Just Kids,” writes Janet Maslin, captures a moment when Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe “were young, inseparable, perfectly bohemian and completely unknown.” The “tenderly evocative memoir” by Ms. Smith, the punk-rock queen, chronicles her early relationship with the photographer. Ms. Smith came across Mr. Mapplethorpe in a back bedroom of a Brooklyn apartment. He “resembled a hippie shepherd,” while she “had been contemptuously described as looking like ‘Dracula’s daughter,’ ” Ms. Maslin writes. They would go on to “become roommates, soul mates, friends, lovers and muses.” On Tuesday night, starting at 7 p.m., Ms. Smith will read about those bygone days at the Barnes & Noble at Union Square.

headline: In Season
text: In 2007 the independent film “Once,” featuring the Irish musician Glen Hansard and the Czech pianist and songwriter Marketa Irglova, charmed audiences at the Sundance Film Festival. The pair, known as the Swell Season, went on to win an Academy Award for their duet from the film, “Falling Slowly.” The festival returns again this weekend, and another movie and soundtrack will surely emerge as the surprise hit, but before then go see the duo at Radio City Music Hall, where they will be performing songs from their follow-up album, “Strict Joy,” on Tuesday night.

headline: The Next Stop on Our Tour ...
text: Continue traveling through the city’s past with a visit to “Downtown Pix: Mining the Fales Archives, 1961-1991.” The exhibition reminds us what the arts scene in the East Village, SoHo and TriBeCa was like at the height of the AIDS epidemic, writes Martha Schwendener, “before gentrification and before the downtown ethos and aesthetic were packaged into family viewing spectacles like ‘Rent’ or those by Blue Man Group.” The show at the Grey Art Gallery includes more than 300 photographs and offers a glimpse of the “downtown of experimental art, music, film, theater and dance  often mashed up and delivered simultaneously.”

headline: Tyco to Acquire Broadview Security for $1.9 Billion
text: Tyco International will acquire Broadview Security for $1.9 billion in a deal that brings together two big North American names in residential and commercial security, the two companies said Monday.

headline: Super Bowl III-Peat
text: Hollywood would call it a remake. When the Jets play the Colts in the American Football Conference championship game Sunday, the cast will be different but the dialogue and the story line aren’t that much different than before the Jets played the Colts in Super Bowl III.

headline: A Deluge of Donations via Text Messages
text: A push by celebrities, athletes and the first lady encouraging text-message donations for earthquake relief in Haiti has contributed to a fund-raising bonanza for the American Red Cross, which a little over a year ago turned to Congress for a bailout.

headline: Defiant Vow to Rebuild Amid Ruins and Bodies
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Alain Villard was stuck in traffic when the earthquake devastated both his T-shirt factory in the rough-and-tumble neighborhood of Carrefour and his elegant boutique hotel in the Pétionville suburb.

headline: Big, in Banks, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
text: Can a bank be too big?

headline: Homeless Haitians Told Not to Flee to U.S.
text: MIAMI  America has a message for the millions of Haitians left homeless and destitute by last week’s earthquake: Do not try to come to the United States.

headline: Must There Be a Bottom Line?
text: Tomorrow, Jan. 19, marks the official publication of Barbara Herrnstein Smith’s “Natural Reflections: Human Cognition at the Nexus of Science and Religion.” The title would seem to identify the book as an addition to the ever-growing body of studies that explore the relationships and tensions between religion and science, usually with the intent either of declaring one epistemologically or morally superior to the other, or of insisting (somewhat piously) that the two are compatible if we avoid extreme claims and counterclaims, or of triumphantly announcing that science is a form of faith, or of purporting to demonstrate that religion can be explained in naturalist terms as an expression of the instinct to survive and propagate.

headline: Riding Wave of Disaffection, Brown Pushes for an Upset
text: Scott Brown, the Republican candidate for Senate, has run an aggressive, surprising campaign in Massachusetts, injecting fear into the Democratic machine over what was expected to be an easy victory.

headline: American Airlines Raises Its Baggage Fees, Too
text: American Airlines raised fees for checked bags on Monday, as the full-fare airline joined its rivals in finding a way to further increase revenue.

headline: A Gun Charge, a Guilty Plea, a Contract at Risk
text: When Gilbert Arenas opted out of the final season of his contract two summers ago, the Washington Wizards made a decision that haunts them to this day. Even though Arenas had played in only 13 games and the Wizards had been eliminated in the first round of the playoffs for a third consecutive season, he was the face of the franchise. Retaining him became their priority.

headline: Massachusetts Senate Candidates Push to Finish Line
text: BOSTON  With the weight of the political universe on their shoulders, the two candidates running for the Senate seat long held by Edward M. Kennedy embarked on a frenzied last day of campaigning on Monday, while outside groups on both sides of the health care debate flooded the state with money, advertisements and ground troops to try to influence the outcome.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 7: U.N. Aid Efforts
text: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, requested that 3,500 more security officers be sent to Haiti to help ensure relief efforts can take place effectively.

headline: After Career as Their Advocate, Coakley May Face Voters’ Wrath
text: Even during a fierce campaign for Senate, Martha Coakley speaks with quiet fervor, a serious woman who has been arguing issues since she was a standout on her Western Massachusetts high school debate team.

headline: Zoe Wheeler Fulfills a Goal
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is a debut. That’s somewhat unusual. We average a few debuts a month. It’s a debut by a teenager. That’s rare. The teenage constructor is a young woman. That’s unique. I chat with Zoe Wheeler further down and it’s the most fun interview I’ve ever done for Wordplay. But first, the puzzle.

headline: Strike in Cleveland Points to Classical Music Woes
text: CLEVELAND  One of the first high-profile labor tussles of 2010 is brewing at the Cleveland Orchestra, and it points to troubled times for the nation’s elite classical musical ensembles amid the Great Recession.

headline: Robinson Leads Knicks, and That Scares D’Antoni
text: There are many stunning things Nate Robinson can do on a basketball court, but the idea that he is fast becoming the Knicks’ primary decision maker was enough to send a shudder through Coach Mike D’Antoni.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about policy advocates who are choosing not to declare themselves as lobbyists, gave outdated information for Tom Daschle, the former Democratic leader in the Senate, who advises colleagues and private clients on health care policy and who also consults informally with the White House and former Senate colleagues. He recently joined the law and lobbying firm DLA Piper. He is no longer with Alston & Bird.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Dec. 26 about a thwarted bombing attempt aboard a Northwest Airlines flight from Amsterdam to Detroit on Christmas Day, citing information provided by federal officials, misstated the given name of the bombing suspect who was taken into custody. He is Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, not Abdul Farouk Abdulmutallab. A picture caption on Wednesday repeated the error.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Sunday about Dr. James Dobson, an influential voice for Christian conservatives who is leaving Focus on the Family, which he founded 33 years ago, to start a radio program that will allow him more leeway to talk about politics, misstated Dr. Dobson’s professional credentials. He is a psychologist, not a psychiatrist.

headline: Corrections
text: An article yesterday about President Obama’s visit on Sunday to Massachusetts in support of the state’s Democratic senatorial candidate, Martha Coakley, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of the deputy director of Organizing for America, which is handling the get-out-the-vote effort for Ms. Coakley. He is Jeremy Bird, not Byrd.

headline: Looking Fit, Roddick Sets Sights Deep in Draw
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was championship point of a grueling struggle last August in Washington, and neither Andy Roddick nor Juan Martin del Potro would give up.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about Gilberto Sanchez, a Bronx man who posted a pirated copy of the movie “X-Men Origins: Wolverine” on a Web site before its release, described his contact with the “Late Show With David Letterman” incorrectly. It was Mr. Sanchez who contacted the show first; a representative called him back. CBS did not invite him to appear with the movie’s star, Hugh Jackman, on the show. The same error appeared in a subheading with the article.

headline: For Edwards, Jets Epitomize Commitment to Winning
text: SAN DIEGO

headline: Out of the Woods
text: It takes a strange frame of mind to believe that demolishing a wooded encampment of homeless immigrant men and evicting them onto the streets during one of the coldest weeks of winter can be an act of prudence and compassion. But that is how the town of Huntington, in Suffolk County on Long Island, describes it.

headline: Researchers Find Study of Medical Marijuana Discouraged
text: Despite the Obama administration’s tacit support of more liberal state medical marijuana laws, the federal government still discourages research into the medicinal uses of smoked marijuana. That may be one reason that  even though some patients swear by it  there is no good scientific evidence that legalizing marijuana’s use provides any benefits over current therapies.

headline: Denied a Chance for Honest Work
text: Among the leading causes of recidivism are employment policies in the private and public sectors that discriminate against former offenders and too often drive them back to jail. New York State first addressed this problem more than 30 years ago with laws protecting the employment rights of people with criminal convictions. But two investigations by Attorney General Andrew Cuomo suggest that some companies are finding ways around these laws.

headline: Ms. Murkowski’s Mischief
text: Senator Lisa Murkowski’s home state of Alaska is ever so slowly melting away, courtesy of a warming planet. Yet few elected officials seem more determined than she to throw sand in the Obama administration’s efforts to do something about climate change.

headline: One Star for Ethics Reform
text: New York legislators proposed an ethics reform package last week that would definitely improve the miserable status quo in Albany. But the plan is not the full-fledged housecleaning necessary for a place that has gone too long without the slightest dusting of reform.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the Golden Globe Awards, where the AMC show “Mad Men” was named best dramatic television series, misstated, in some editions, the number of consecutive years it has won that honor. This was the third consecutive year, not the second.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: At a King Day Celebration, a Preview of a Gillibrand-Ford Primary
text: He sat in the front row. She was one row behind.

headline: For Christie, an Inauguration on a Budget
text: He made his name by indicting New Jersey politicians.

headline: School Plan for U.S. Aid Gets No Vote in Albany
text: An eleventh-hour push by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. David A. Paterson to improve New York State’s chances to receive up to $700 million in federal education financing faltered on Monday after the State Legislature balked at the plan.

headline: Blacks in Retreat
text: It has been easy for people to forget in the decades since we lost the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that he was a passionate fighter for economic justice as well as civil rights. The two goals were as closely linked as the hydrogen and oxygen atoms in water.

headline: The Pragmatic Leviathan
text: When I was in college, I was assigned “Leviathan,” by Thomas Hobbes. On the cover was an image from the first edition of the book, published in 1651. It shows the British nation as a large man. The people make up the muscles and flesh. Then at the top, there is the king, who is the head and the mind.

headline: Reliving Horror in a Test for the Death Penalty
text: NEW HAVEN  More than two years later, the details still have the power to horrify.

headline: Power Line Accident Prompts Evacuation and Subway Halt
text: Workers installing a gas line into a Brooklyn building accidentally struck a power line that feeds the subway on Monday, sparking electrical explosions that blew manhole covers into the air, disrupted subway service and rattled nerves in a pocket of Brooklyn Heights.

headline: For Last Shot, the Biggest of Guns
text: TITLE “Every Vote Matters”

headline: ‘Emergency Brake’ Confuses Many on Subway
text: The emergency brake is a ubiquitous fixture of New York City subway cars, a cord that allows passengers to bring 400 tons of metal to a screeching halt.

headline: A Message From the Kitchen
text: TITLE “Rebuttal”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Rachel Alexandra Wins Horse of the Year
text: Unbeaten on the racetrack last year, Rachel Alexandra won again Monday night, defeating her rival Zenyatta to take horse racing’s top prize, the Eclipse Award for Horse of the Year.

headline: Problems Mount at a Bronx Building Bought in a Bubble
text: It was in the community room on the ground floor of 1520 Sedgwick Avenue in the West Bronx that a young D.J. and his turntables helped to invent hip-hop, the music that spawned a global culture.

headline: What Lessons Those Carrots Are Teaching
text: Remember New York City’s plan to reward students who excelled with cellphones? That plan fell by the wayside, not because so many people thought it was absurd  after all, cellphones are not allowed in New York City Schools  but because the project’s guru, the Harvard economist Roland Fryer, decided to apply his energies elsewhere not long after the project began.

headline: New Public Advocate Assails Bloomberg’s Performance on Homelessness
text: In his first policy announcement since taking office, Bill de Blasio, the city’s new public advocate, will challenge Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s record on homelessness and call on him to intensify his efforts to address the problem.

headline: The Stuff We Could Teach Jack Bauer
text: Not many New Yorkers dwell on this anymore, but the city has been on orange alert for years, suggesting that the terrorism risk is forever high. Somehow, we’ve managed to get by without help from Jack Bauer, the ne plus ultra of counterterrorism on Fox’s long-running “24.”

headline: Call From Haiti Heartens Struggling Father
text: It was just before 3 p.m. on Saturday when the call came from his daughter, telling them she was alive.

headline: Harold Faber, Longtime Reporter and Editor for The Times, Dies at 90
text: Harold Faber, a retired reporter and editor at The New York Times whose work for the paper ranged from war reporting in Korea, sustaining a grave injury while doing so, to covering the regions north of New York City, died Jan. 7 at his home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Following His Father Into the World of Fish
text: Leslie Barnes was not born in the Fulton Fish Market, but almost. As a sprat of 5, he accompanied his father on predawn forays to buy seafood for their restaurant, London Lennie’s on Woodhaven Boulevard in Rego Park, Queens, founded in 1959. Leonard, the father, a cockney sailor who parlayed four fish and chips stands in London into his stake in the colonies, is gone, so Leslie Barnes, 54, the father of four daughters, is the big fish now.

headline: The Uses and Misuses of the Filibuster
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Ails Housing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Political Change in Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Millions of Marrow Donors
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Fed and the Housing Bubble
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sponsor Found to Replace Buick for Torrey Pines Event
text: The PGA Tour announced Monday that it had reached agreement with the Farmers Insurance Group of Companies, a Southern California-based insurance giant, to become the title sponsor of next week’s San Diego Open.

headline: Amid Reports of a Deal, O’Brien Jokes of a Gag Order
text: Update | 11:41 p.m.  Amid reports that the deal to settle Conan O’Brien’s contract with NBC could include at least a temporary gag order on both him and NBC executives, the host, whose ratings have surged since his contretemps with the network, took the opportunity on Monday to play his situation for laughs — though he did not direct any of the jokes at Jay Leno, the man who will return as the “Tonight” show host in the deal expected to be finalized Tuesday.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 7: N.Y. to Haiti
text: New York City police, fire and paramedic teams are working around the clock in Haiti.

headline: U.S. Team Awaits Word on Dempsey’s Knee Injury
text: Barely two weeks after scoring a dazzling goal for his club team, Fulham, Clint Dempsey is playing a waiting game. His immediate future and the United States’ hopes at this summer’s World Cup in South Africa hinge on the words of doctors who are evaluating Dempsey’s right knee after he was injured Sunday in an English Premier League match at Blackburn Rovers.

headline: In Cadbury-Kraft, 2 Winning Sides
text: It would have been astonishing if Kraft Foods’ hostile bid for Cadbury had gone to the bitter end. Like most contested takeover battles, this one looks to be edging toward a last-minute rapprochement. Cadbury will most likely squeeze more out of Kraft without an auction  an impressive feat.

headline: Who’s Up for Facing the Colts? Ellis Raises a Broken Hand
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets defensive end Shaun Ellis declared Monday that he would not let a silly little inconvenience like a broken left hand prevent him from playing in the American Football Conference championship game Sunday against Indianapolis. He has waited way too long for this chance.

headline: More Men Marrying Wealthier Women
text: Beagy Zielinski is a German-born 28-year-old stylist who moved to New York to study fashion in 1995 and stayed. Just before Christmas, she broke up with her blue-collar boyfriend, who repaired Navy ships.

headline: Israel’s Winter Athletes Come to U.S. Seeking Ice and Medals
text: HACKENSACK, N.J.  It almost never snows in Israel, and there is only one regulation ice rink in the entire country, in Metulla, on the Lebanese border, where temperatures regularly reach 100 degrees. During the 2006 war with Hezbollah, the rink had to be closed for security reasons and the roof was damaged from shelling. Even now, the ice is not entirely reliable, and there are not enough hours in the day to accommodate everyone who wants to use it: speedskaters, figure skaters, and hockey nuts who drive three hours from Jerusalem for Thursday night games.

headline: Word of the Day | poseur
text: poseur •\po-ˈzər, ˈpo-zər\• noun

headline: Snowboarder Davis Has Fractured Vertebrae
text: Danny Davis, an Olympic snowboarding hopeful, broke a bone in his lower back during an accident on an all-terrain vehicle on Sunday, putting an end to his season and sending another jolt through the United States halfpipe community.

headline: Carl Smith, Country Music Hitmaker, Is Dead at 82
text: NASHVILLE  Carl Smith, the dapper singer who ranked among the most popular country hitmakers of the 1950s, died on Saturday at his home in Franklin, Tenn., just outside Nashville. He was 82.

headline: News Quiz | January 19, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Don’t Walk This Way
text: WHOM do you know who regularly uses a cellphone to talk or text while walking?

headline: Swiss Banker Blows Whistle on Tax Evasion
text: From his home in the quiet village of Rorbas, outside Zurich, Rudolf M. Elmer is chipping away at the centuries-old traditions of Swiss banking secrecy.

headline: Japan Airlines Files for Bankruptcy
text: Japan Airlines, the once-mighty flagship carrier and Asia’s biggest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday, setting the stage for a state-led bailout that could bring sweeping changes to this busy corner of the global aviation market, Hiroko Tabuchi writes in The New York Times.

headline: Cadbury-Kraft: A Win-Win Deal?
text: It would have been astonishing if Kraft Foods’ hostile bid for Cadbury had gone to the bitter end, Reuters Breakingviews says. Like most contested takeover battles, this one looks to be edging toward a last-minute rapprochement. Cadbury will most likely squeeze more out of Kraft without an auction — an impressive feat, the publication remarked before the two companies’ announcement Tuesday.

headline: Swiss Re Gets $1.27 Billion in Deal With Buffett
text: The Swiss Reinsurance Company said on Monday that it had transferred part of its American life insurance business to Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate controlled by Warren E. Buffett, for 1.3 billion Swiss francs ($1.27 billion) to free up capital and invest it more profitably.

headline: Another Snowboarder Injured
text: Danny Davis, an Olympic snowboarding hopeful, broke a bone in his lower back during an accident on an all-terrain vehicle Sunday, ending his season and sending another jolt through the United States halfpipe community. Davis, 21, is expected to recover, but not in time for next month’s Vancouver Olympics. Davis is one of the best friends of Kevin Pearce, who sustained a traumatic brain injury Dec. 31 while training in the halfpipe of Utah’s Park City Mountain Resort.

headline: If Big Funds Go Old-School, Profits May Follow
text: Giant private equity funds won’t be back for a while, Reuters Breakingviews says. New research shows many investors have lost interest in multibillion-dollar funds. That will make it tougher for big buyout shops like Blackstone and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to raise money in the amounts they have become accustomed to. Some may even have to relearn smaller-scale methods of investing.

headline: Edward H. Linde, Zuckerman’s Partner, Dies at 68
text: Edward H. Linde, a founder of one of the largest real estate investment trusts in the nation — and the behind-the-scenes partner of Mortimer B. Zuckerman — died on Sunday in Boston, The New York Times’s Dennis Hevesi reported. He was 68 and lived in Weston, Mass.

headline: Europe Markets Rise Amid Rumors on Deals
text: European stock markets rose Monday as speculation of a pickup in corporate deal making kept investors interested on a day Wall Street was closed for the Martin Luther King public holiday and Greece’s budgetary woes continued to weigh on the euro.

headline: European Banks Take a Step Toward More Normal Lending
text: The European Central Bank and Swiss National Bank said Monday that they would end a program aimed at supplying Swiss currency to banks, in a further sign that the region’s financial system is becoming more stable, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing reported.

headline: Agency Combines Clients’ Stocks for Mini-Mutual Fund
text: Forget about the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index or the Dow Jones industrial average. The latest gauge of Wall Street performance — at least on Madison Avenue — is the K.B.S.& P. Client Stock Index, The New York Times’s Stuart Elliott writes.

headline: Does Who You Think You Are Influence What You Want to Do?
text: Do you have fixed ideas of what “type” of person becomes a nurse? A professor? A farmer, soldier or artist? Two sociologists have been studying the typecasting of professions by factors like gender and political ideology. What do you want to do? Do you think you are influenced by “occupational typing”?

headline: Morgan Stanley Tries on a New Psyche
text: James P. Gorman, a 6-foot-2 Australian, recently took up boxing lessons, in keeping with some of the trappings of his Midtown Manhattan office. On one wall, opposite an inspirational poem by Rudyard Kipling (“The Thousandth Man”), hangs a photograph of Elvis Presley sparring with Muhammad Ali.

headline: Capmark Unit Files for Chapter 11, and Signs Deal
text: Capmark Investments, a unit of the bankrupt commercial property lender Capmark Financial Group, filed for bankruptcy in a bid to sell its management contracts and interests in real estate equity funds.

headline: After Skype Founders Return — an I.P.O.?
text: One night in 2007, employees at Skype Technologies decided to send a message to their corporate parent, eBay. They picked up the desk of Henry Gomez, an eBay senior executive and Skype’s president, and moved it to a far corner of the company’s London office, according to a former eBay manager.

headline: Carpetbagger: Inside the Golden Globes
text: Melena Ryzik takes a look behind the curtain at the 2010 Golden Globe Awards.

headline: Alibaba Criticizes Investor Yahoo for Google Support
text: In an unusual move, the Alibaba Group of China on Saturday criticized Yahoo, one of its largest shareholders, for siding with Google after a cyber attack on that company, The New York Times’s David Barboza and Miguel Helft report.

headline: Goldman and Morgan Stocks Closing the Gap
text: Goldman Sachs Group, whose record earnings in the first nine months of last year fueled public outrage, will probably hit a profit plateau in 2010, just as Morgan Stanley rebounds from its worst year ever, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: BlackRock Acquires Helix Financial
text: BlackRock, the giant money manager, said Tuesday that it had acquired Helix Financial Group, a company based in Charlotte, N.C., that advises commercial real estate lenders.

headline: Castle Harlan Buys Plastic Container Makers
text: The private equity firm Castle Harlan said on Monday that it was buying the plastic container maker Pretium Packaging and its rival, the PVC Container Corporation, in deals valued at a combined $200 million.

headline: Travelport Takes $2 Billion I.P.O. to London
text: Travelport, the New York-based travel service company, introduced a $2 billion initial public offering on Tuesday to cut debt, in a sign that large share sales may be picking up, Reuters reported.

headline: App Developer Shopkick Attracts $2.5 Million
text: Shopkick, which develops applications for mobile devices, has collected $2.5 million in a first round of venture capital, VentureBeat reported, citing a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Credit Suisse Seeks More Asian Hedge Fund Business
text: Credit Suisse will increase the headcount in its prime brokerage team in Asia by 15 percent to 20 percent in 2010 as it tries to win business from the increasing number of global hedge funds eager to set up a base in the region, a senior official at the Swiss bank said.

headline: Iceslave Bill
text: Mordant nickname for the proposed $5 billion “Icesave Bill” – legislation that would commit Iceland to compensating the UK and the Netherlands for the banking failures of 2008.

headline: Citi Hires Former Morgan Stanley Asia Chief
text: Citigroup said on Monday it appointed a Morgan Stanley executive, Alasdair Morrison, as an Asia senior adviser, a new role for the bank meant to support its expansion across the region.

headline: Some Dubai World Creditors Said to Seek Loan Sale
text: Some creditors to Dubai World, which is currently restructuring $22 billion of debt, are seeking to offload loans to reduce their exposure to the Gulf emirate’s conglomerate, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Guvera, a Music Site, Lands $20 Million
text: Guvera, an ad-supported music site, has landed $20 million in a fresh round of funding from AMMA Private Investment, an Australian consortium of private angel investors, Tech Crunch reported.

headline: Cadbury Board Accepts $19.5 Billion Kraft Offer
text: After four months of pursuit, Kraft Foods announced the details Tuesday for a friendly takeover of Cadbury, whose board unanimously recommended the deal to its shareholders.

headline: Berkshire Said to Consider Stock Split of B Shares
text: Admirers of Warren E. Buffett who find Berkshire Hathaway‘s shares a little too rich for their blood may be in luck.

headline: A.I.G. Said to Look at Other Ways to Repay Bonuses
text: American International Group is exploring several ways to repay $26 million of the $45 million in bonuses that executives at its financial products unit pledged to return last year, including a plan to cut 2010 bonuses but pay them out early, according to press reports.

headline: Group Readies Bid for Three Canwest Newspapers
text: A group of bidders said on Monday that it was preparing to make an offer for three daily newspapers owned by the Canwest Global Communications Corporation.

headline: N.Y. Pension Said to Seed Finisterre Fund
text: The New York State Common Retirement Fund, the third-largest pension plan in the country, has given Finisterre Capital a boost with a $250 million investment in the hedge fund’s new emerging markets fund, Bloomberg News said.

headline: Spyker Says It’s Still in Talks With G.M. Over Saab
text: Spyker Cars said on Monday it was still in talks to buy Swedish auto brand Saab from General Motors. Spyker, the Dutch luxury carmaker, gave no indication of when a deal might be clinched.

headline: Posco Says Buffett Wants to Buy More Shares
text: Posco of South Korea said Tuesday that Warren E. Buffett, whose investment vehicle owns 4.5 percent of Posco, the world’s No. 4 steelmaker, had indicated he wanted to buy more stock, Reuters reported.

headline: In Hollywood, Grappling With Studios’ Lost Clout
text: A proposed sale of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the most powerful and lucrative studio during the golden age of film, drew only meager offers last week, and now, Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes of The New York Times write, Hollywood must confront a troubling question: are movie studios becoming a financial footnote?

headline: A Famed Parisian Kitchen Is Reborn
text: The Paris restaurant that helped cultivate the careers of names like Robuchon and Ripert has a new owner. Jamin (32, rue de Longchamp, 16th Arrondissement; 33-1-45-53-00-07; www.restaurant-jamin.com; Metro: Trocadéro and Boissière), which had its heyday in the 1980s, is now being run by Alain Pras, who bought the restaurant space — as well as the name — last year, and reopened it in October.

headline: Ultimate Jets Fan
text: The ultimate Jets fan might be the guy who was tossed out of the Chargers game on Sunday and who gained minor celebrity as the video shuttled around the Internet.

headline: Goldman Said to Delay Release of Bonus Details
text: Goldman Sachs is likely to unveil details of multimillion dollar bonuses to staff next week, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on Tuesday, a delay as the dispute over payouts heats up.

headline: The Age of External Knowledge
text: Today’s idea: Filtering, not remembering, is the most important mental skill in the digital age, an essay says. But this discipline will prove no mean feat, since mental focus must take place amid the unlimited distractions of the Internet.

headline: BMW Sauber Signs Pedro de la Rosa
text: Interesting how BMW Sauber — and by the way, that’s what the team still officially calls itself, despite BMW selling out — has decided to hire Pedro de la Rosa as its second driver. The team made the announcement Tuesday, and in the news release we learn that he’ll be 39 years old on Feb. 24.

headline: Are Luxury Retailers Ready to Shop?
text: Are luxury retailers gearing up for a little deal-making now that their clientele are returning to the stores?

headline: Preventing Haiti’s Next Crisis
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Big, in Banks, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
text: Jamie Dimon, chief of JPMorgan Chase, may have strong arguments that banks should be able to grow as big as they want, but there is a swelling chorus of leaders in the United States and abroad who are more concerned about the risk that such huge banks present to the rest of the economy, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

headline: Now Screening | Gucci
text: The fall 2010 collection from Gucci.

headline: Enjoying Revis for Years to Come
text: It would be almost football sacrilege to compare Darrelle Revis to Lawrence Taylor. No reason to do that. Taylor is in a separate category as a player who changed the game.

headline: Part 2: Answers on Fafsa and Financial Aid
text: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is attempting to streamline this year.

headline: Senate Returns, With Eye on Massachusetts
text: Congressional attention is fixated on Massachusetts as the Senate convenes Tuesday for the second session of the 111th Congress.

headline: Williams Criticizes Size of U.S. Open Fine
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  There were no outbursts from Serena Williams here  at least on the court. She swiftly and, for the most part stoically, took apart her overmatched opponent, Urszula Radwanska, in straight sets. Afterwards, however, the women’s defending Australian Open champion pointedly questioned the fine given to her for threatening to shove a ball down a line judge’s throat last summer at the United States Open.

headline: Sampler: Butterflies, Wind Turbines and 911 Immunity
text: Californians Still Feel Things Are Worse | California’s famous optimism is endangered. For the third consecutive year, a majority of Californians feel worse off financially than they did a year ago, according to a Field Poll. Until last year, Californians went more than 40 years without letting more than one year pass during which they felt that their finances were worse than the previous year. “This is a new era; California is usually bigger and better,” said Mark DiCamillo, the Field Poll director. “It’s not just affecting a certain population but is affecting a broad base of people.” [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: ‘What Were the Odds of This?’
text: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

headline: Rich Nations Call for Haiti Debt Relief
text: PARIS  Broadening the relief effort, the Paris Club of international creditors issued an appeal Tuesday for nations owed money by Haiti to cancel the debts to help reconstruction after the devastating earthquake a week ago.

headline: Verizon and AT&T Cut Prices
text: For all of the analyst predictions that carriers will have to raise their data plan prices, at least voice plan prices are going in the other direction. Verizon and AT&T are lowering prices for their unlimited calling plans.

headline: How to Send Money to Other Charities Using Text
text: AT&T has done a great job getting out the word that its customers can make a donation to Haiti earthquake relief via text message. Text the word “Haiti” to the number 90999 and a $10 donation is charged to your AT&T bill.

headline: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Barkley, Kansas City, Mo., acquired the business assets of Blacktop Creative, Kansas City, for undisclosed financial terms. The agency will be combined with the design group at Barkley and be renamed Barkley Blacktop. It will have 40 employees.

headline: Dark Days for Jets’ Rivals in A.F.C. East
text: While savoring unexpected success, Jets fans would never take pleasure in the troubles of their division brethren. O.K., maybe they might:

headline: Citigroup Reports a $1.6 Billion Loss for 2009
text: Update | 8:24 a.m. Even as it untangles itself from the federal government, Citigroup has shown few signs of a quick recovery. On Tuesday, the banking giant announced its second consecutive yearly loss, Eric Dash of The New York Times reports.

headline: Pandit Is Running Out of Time to Clean Up Citigroup
text: It is make or break time for Vikram S. Pandit.

headline: Today in Business Travel
text: For Travelers in Danger, Someone to Swoop InAfter the earthquake in Haiti, a service called International SOS jumped right into its mission to assist its clients in the area and evacuate them.

headline: A Nuclear Critic Draws a Lesson from France’s Success
text: A new statistical analysis of an almost-secret topic — what it costs to build nuclear reactors in France — may have some lessons for a “nuclear renaissance” in the United States.

headline: Jan. 19: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
text: On Tuesday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of last week’s earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort. Updates from previous days: Mon. | Sun. | Sat. | Fri. | Thurs. | Weds. and Tues.

headline: Google Delays Release of Cellphones in China
text: BEIJING  Google said Tuesday that it and a Chinese cellphone service company had postponed the release this week of two mobile phones that would use Google’s Android software.

headline: Devastation in Haiti Stirs Memories of Ground Zero
text: A pile of rubble is a pile of rubble, whether it is Lower Manhattan or central Port-au-Prince. As a New York rescue team combed the wreckage of last week’s earthquake in Haiti in search of long-shot survivors on Monday, some said one particular past disaster — the collapsed World Trade Center towers — was not far back in their minds.

headline: The Early Word: Bay State Ballot
text: Massachusetts voters will head to the polls to elect a senator on Tuesday, the end of a campaign more fascinating than almost anyone could have predicted. Here’s a wrap of coverage that’s out there Tuesday morning.

headline: Politics From A to Z: Massachusetts
text: BOSTON – It’s decision day in Massachusetts, where a special election is taking place to fill the seat of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy. Neither Democrats nor Republicans would have predicted the contest between Martha M. Coakley and Scott P. Brown would have turned into such a remarkable race.

headline: Drug Companies and a Pivotal Senate Race Help Lead the Markets Higher
text: The possibility that the dynamics of the health care debate could shift helped spur Wall Street higher on Tuesday, overshadowing concerns about the strength of banks and the American consumer.

headline: Tentative Deal in Cleveland Orchestra Strike
text: The strike at the Cleveland Orchestra appears to be over. The players and management said on Tuesday morning that a tentative agreement had been reached after a marathon bargaining session that began at noon on Monday and ended shortly before 6:30 a.m. Tuesday. The agreement requires ratification by the musicians and the orchestra’s board, and that is expected today, giving the orchestra enough time to move forward with a scheduled trip to Miami for a series of concerts and educational events. It is due to leave on Thursday. No details were released, but the issues centered on pay: the players offered a freeze on salary this year and management asked for a 5 percent cut, to be restored next year, and a 2.5 percent raise the following year.

headline: Digital Photo Frames Join the Social Scene
text: Over the past six months or so, digital photo frames have gotten connected and gone social. In addition to displaying photos from a memory card, a new breed of frames can connect to Facebook, Twitter, online-photo-sharing sites, and even RSS feeds.

headline: Punishing Lawyers in Corporate Frauds
text: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Inside Out | The Layered Look
text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: King, Young Fight Back to Lift American Hopes; Querrey Falls
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – In an up-and-down day for Americans, Vania King of Long Beach, Calif., was up and fighting mad.

headline: China Curtails Run of ‘Avatar’ as It Fills Theaters
text: BEIJING  “Avatar,” the Hollywood blockbuster that has proved wildly popular with Chinese moviegoers, will be pulled in the next few days from the majority of Chinese theaters where it is showing, Chinese media outlets reported Tuesday.

headline: Awards Punditry Gone Awry
text: Now that Los Angeles has dried out, momentarily, and possibly sobered up, it’s time to take stock. The efforts that the Golden Globes producers made to get better ratings worked; the awards pundits were not so successful. Most, according to The Los Angeles Times’s Gold Derby blog, got it wrong, or at least only half right.

headline: Solar Power Advocates Hopeful for 2010
text: Between 500 and 600 megawatts of solar power will be built this year across the United States — about double the figure of last year — according to Larry Sherwood, who compiles and studies such data as a consultant to the Interstate Renewable Energy Council, a nonprofit industry group.

headline: Milan: Inflation Man
text: After looking at images of Thom Browne’s buoyant new collection for Moncler Gamme Bleu in the silty pre-dawn of New York, the thought came to me that if Moncler were to make a film of Mr. Browne’s padded ski wear, the company should hire Wes Anderson and a small aircraft. There’s such a funny, bumptious quality about the clothes—the padded grays, the felon stripes, the great big snow boots—that I imagine silly but hopeful men (Bill Murray, ideally) flinging themselves out of airplanes trailed by brightly colored chutes. Nicely done, Mr. Browne.

headline: The Democrats’ Latest Health Cliffhanger
text: It is just shy of four weeks since the Senate adopted its big health care bill. And, oh, what a difference a month can make.

headline: Europe Mulls Policy on Biodiversity
text: Despite disappointment at the outcome of the climate summit in Copenhagen, European Union regulators are seeking to keep up a reputation for environmental leadership by seeking to build a strong common position ahead of international negotiations — this time on global biodiversity rules.

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Melanie Oudin Continues to Struggle
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Melanie Oudin had just blown four match points and her opponent, Alla Kudryavtseva, was gaining strength. She smacked the racket in her hand, blew air through her lips and tried to beat back the tears.

headline: Can Immigrants Solve Our Health Care Problems?
text: Aaron Edlin is a law and economics professor at the University of California, Berkeley. Dana Goldman is a pharmacy and public policy professor and the director of the Leonard D. Schaeffer Center for Health Policy and Economics at the University of Southern California.

headline: Modernizing Government: An Entrepreneurial Perspective
text: Last Thursday, President Obama invited executives from 49 of the nation’s leading companies to the White House to talk about how to make the government run more smoothly. “It’s exciting to see the leaders of some of the most innovative, cutting-edge, tech-savvy companies in the world gathered in the city where I had to fight tooth and nail just to get a BlackBerry,” he said by way of welcome. “There may be a little bit of a cultural clash here, but that’s exactly why we want you here.”

headline: ‘Crying Children Are the Worst’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Last night, President Obama attended his daughter Malia’s school recital. Not to see her perform or anything. Just to see if any of the kids had a solution to health care. And they didn’t.

headline: ‘An Updated Photo of Osama’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” on NBC: The U.S. State Department has released an updated photo of Osama bin Laden that shows what he might look like after aging a decade. And guess what? Somebody got fat!

headline: A Building in Decline
text: A year after a private equity backed investor bought the Bronx apartment building, 1520 Sedgwick Avenue, tenants say housing code violations have piled up.

headline: ‘Blaming Old Computers’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: The White House issued a statement today. They’re blaming government inefficiencies — this is true — they’re blaming it on old computers. Apparently, all the computers keep crashing. And everyone knows the only crashing tolerated at the White House is during state dinners.

headline: Heat Over Panel’s View of Asian Ice, Disasters
text: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, for two decades the most important guide for the global community to the causes and consequences of the phenomenon, is facing a series of challenge over its practices, both from within and without.

headline: ‘Robotic Women’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: People are worried about NBC. Earlier today, President Obama announced that he’s sending in 30,000 troops. Out to Burbank.

headline: Cleveland Settles Orchestra Strike
text: The musicians of the Cleveland Orchestra and their management settled a strike on Tuesday that lasted little longer than a quick scherzo but made clear the tensions raised by difficult economic times across the orchestra world.

headline: ‘A Smaller, Less Powerful Version’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: The heaviest snowfall in over 60 years is being reported in Beijing, China. To give you an idea of how bad it is, the army is now having to use snowplows to run over dissidents.

headline: The Bittersweet History of Bike Clubs
text: Neither snow, nor sleet, nor bone-chilling cold can keep the members of New York’s assorted recreational bicycle clubs from the swift — or, often, leisurely — completion of their appointed rides around and out of the city. The New York Cycle Club, the Five Borough Bicycle Club and Fast and Fab, a lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender bike club, are some of those that lead outings and other events year round. And while none of these was around at the turn of the last century, each traces its lineage back to the ubiquitous clubs that dominated the earliest years of cycling.

headline: In Britain, Cadbury Takeover Raises Job Concerns
text: Britain did not take long to respond to the announcement Tuesday that Kraft had reached a friendly agreement to take over Cadbury for £11.9 billion ($19.4 billion).

headline: War@WSJ: New Book Pulls Back Blankets on Murdoch’s Capture of The Journal
text: Get ready for another media parlor game, this one pivoting around “War at The Wall Street Journal: Inside the Struggle to Control an American Business Empire.” The book, by the former Journal media writer Sarah Ellison, is a scrupulously fair, careful account written from a close distance about how Rupert Murdoch came to own the crown jewel of American business journalism.

headline: Video: Inside the Golden Globes
text: Melena Ryzik takes a look behind the curtain at the 2010 Golden Globes.

headline: U.S. Troops Patrol Haiti, Filling a Void
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  American military helicopters landed on Tuesday at Haiti’s wrecked National Palace, and troops began rolling through the capital’s battered streets, signs of the growing international relief operation here. But the troops’ presence underscored the rising complaints that the Haitian government had all but disappeared in the week since a huge earthquake struck.

headline: Was Serena Williams’s Punishment Fair?
text: Serena Williams, in first Grand Slam appearance since her outburst at last year’s United States Open, bristled when asked about the $92,000 fine she received for the outburst.
