Joe Drape writes that she “pointedly questioned the fine given to her for threatening to shove a ball down a line judge’s throat last summer at the U.S. Open.”

headline: Text Messages in China to Be Scanned for ‘Illegal Content’
text: BEIJING  Expanding what the Chinese government calls a campaign against pornography, cellular companies in Beijing and Shanghai have been told to suspend text services to cellphone users who are found to have sent messages with “illegal or unhealthy content,” state-run media reported on Tuesday.

headline: Behind Kraft’s Raise, a Glimmer of Bigger Savings
text: Update | 8:10 p.m. Cadbury finally agreed to sell itself to Kraft on Tuesday, after the American food giant raised its takeover offer to £11.9 billion ($19.5 billion)

headline: Middle-Class Angst and San Francisco’s Health Plan
text: In 2007, San Francisco began Healthy San Francisco (HSF), “a health access plan” (read: health services) for poor residents without insurance. Last winter, H.S.F. expanded to middle-class residents. Justine Sharrock, a writer who also happens to be the daughter of an anesthesiologist, signed up in 2009, when the upper limit on annual income was increased to $54,150 for a single person (and $110,250 for a family of four).

headline: Now Screening | Versace
text: The fall 2010 collection from Versace.

headline: Theater Talkback With Charles Isherwood
text: Charles Isherwood, theater critic for The New York Times, is taking readers’ questions about his recent articles and reviews, including an Arts & Leisure essay comparing “South Pacific” and “Rock of Ages” and his reviews of “Lear,” “The Myopia,” and “Little Gem.”

headline: Boehner Hires ‘Contract’ Architect to Promote G.O.P. Platform
text: With House Republicans planning to reprise the Contract With America that catapulted them into House control in 1994, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the party leader, is bringing back an architect of the original contract as his chief of staff.

headline: For Electric Bikes, Three Makes a Trend
text: It’s a cliché in certain corners of the news media that a reporter needs to note three examples to report a story about a trend. The rule of three is often cited more in derision than admiration, but it seems to hold a certain amount of water. (For example, here, here and here. See how that works?)

headline: Spelling Check
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: Spelling Check
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: What Editors Do: Steven Lovelady
text: When civilians visit newsrooms, they are always amazed to see row after row of desks occupied by people who don’t actually write stories. And the question arises: What do editors do?

headline: Paterson Seeks Huge Cuts and $1 Billion in Taxes and Fees
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson proposed on Tuesday what would be the largest cut to school aid in more than two decades and nearly $1 billion in new or increased taxes and fees as he unveiled his budget, a plan that is likely to be the first chapter in a prolonged battle with the Legislature.

headline: Facebook Fill-In
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this New York Region story by Susan Dominus headlined “A Facebook Movement, Against Mom and Dad.” Use your own words and phrases, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words/phrases that were removed.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Girl Talk, Musician
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: New Rule Would Bar Illegal Fishing Vessels From Ports
text: The United States is looking to shore up its abilities to bar vessels involved in illegal fishing from entering its ports.

headline: Japan Stalls as Leaders Are Jolted by Old Guard
text: TOKYO  It had all the trappings of a typical political scandal in a nation that has seen all too many of them: stacks of cash from construction companies, shady land deals and late-night arrests of grim-faced political aides widely seen as fall guys for their powerful bosses.

headline: Coachella Lineup Announced
text: Jay-Z, Muse and Gorillaz will headline the 11th annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival when that sprawling rock event gets under way on April 16 in Indio, Calif., planners announced on Tuesday, hoping to maintain the momentum from last year, when the festival drew its second-highest crowds despite the economic downturn.

headline: On Assignment: “Silence and Submission”
text: Ron Haviv, who arrived in Haiti last week on assignment for People Magazine, has produced images of conflict and humanitarian crises worldwide for more than two decades. He is a co-founder of the photo agency VII and has published “Blood and Honey: A Balkan War Journal” (2000) and “Afghanistan: The Road to Kabul” (2002). He has received awards from World Press Photo, Pictures of the Year International and the Overseas Press Club. He was interviewed Monday by James Estrin.

headline: Regimens: Tailor Medicine Levels to Size and Weight, Doctors Say
text: When pediatricians prescribe medicine for children, they take the child’s size and weight into account and adjust the dose accordingly. But with few exceptions, medical practitioners take a one-size-fits-all approach when prescribing drugs to adults, whether the patient is petite or extra large.

headline: Another Strike Vote Planned at British Airways
text: The Associated Press is reporting that the union representing the cabin crews at British Airways said Monday that it would hold a strike vote in a dispute over pay, job security and working conditions. The union, Unite, said it would continue to negotiate with the airline while the vote by 13,000 cabin crew members went ahead starting next week.

headline: The Evolving I.P.O. Market, Circa 2010
text: What a difference a year makes.

headline: TNR on WashPo: ‘Inside the Messy Collapse of a Great Newspaper.’
text: Gabriel Sherman writes a big heave in The New Republic suggesting that the next generation of leadership at The Washington Post has failed to address old problems and created a few new ones.

headline: AARP Will Double Your Haiti Donation
text: The AARP is offering a dollar-for-dollar match on donations to its foundation, up to $500,000 in total contributions.

headline: Generation XD
text: The youngest generation that has never known life without the Internet.[Generation X + D(igital)]

headline: Travel Deals: American Airlines Flight Sale
text: If you’re looking for a quick winter getaway, American Airlines is having two sales: one for flights within the United States and Canada, and another specifically for ski destinations. Both end this week.

headline: Now Screening | Alexander McQueen
text: The fall 2010 collection from Alexander McQueen.

headline: Philadelphia Sends Valentines, 12 Months a Year
text: Not so long ago, a certain brand of cream cheese was asking consumers, “Isn’t it silly not to use Philly?” Substitute “ visit” for “use,” and you have the message being delivered by the next phase of a popular tourism campaign.

headline: Obama’s Haitian Dilemma
text: All of Washington is fixated on the Brown-Coakley race, but Tyler Cowen raises the possibility that the Haitian earthquake may cast a much longer shadow over Obama’s administration than today’s Bay State special election. Eventually, CNN’s coverage will wind down, the outpouring of online contributions will diminish, and Haiti will join Afghanistan on the list of nearly-impossible foreign policy dilemmas — except that Obama didn’t inherit this one from his predecessor, and Haiti lacks a War-on-Terror angle to keep Americans invested in its fate.

headline: Votes of Confidence Curiously Follow N.F.L. Playoff Flops
text: Allow us to interrupt your N.F.L. divisional round playoff hangover, the period in which you are wondering why the Chargers felt the need to announce a contract extension for Coach Norv Turner in what feels like minutes after their latest playoff flop rather than just poking their fans with a sharp stick. Or perhaps you are stuck on Dallas owner Jerry Jones’s vote of confidence for the ever-popular Wade Phillips for crafting one more playoff win with the Cowboys than Bill Parcells.

headline: Q&A: ‘Crossing the Energy Divide’
text: According to Robert Ayres and Edward Ayres, brothers and co-authors of the recently published book, “Crossing the Energy Divide,” the American economy uses energy with only 13 percent efficiency.

headline: Yale Admissions Office Sets Its Pitch to Music (and Dance)
text: Many fans of Disney’s “High School Musical” franchise are now old enough to apply to college, so it was probably inevitable that an admissions office would try to reach them by turning an otherwise staid group information session into a peppy music video.

headline: Behavior: Too Much Sitting Shortens Lives, Study Suggests
text: A new study from Australia suggests that couch potatoes live shorter lives.

headline: Australians Have Reason to Cheer
text: Day 2 at the Australian Open brought a homegrown celebration to Melbourne Park as Lleyton Hewitt, making his record-equaling 14th straight appearance at the tournament, led a charge of host-country players into the second round.

headline: MetLife Nears a Deal for A.I.G.’s Alico Unit
text: Update | 1:12 p.m. MetLife has emerged as the lead bidder for the American International Group‘s Alico life insurance unit, people briefed on the matter told DealBook, as A.I.G. seeks to sell off the unit to help repay its $182 billion in government aid.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 6: Civil Unions
text: Update 5:46 p.m. Pacific Time | After the lunch recess, Charles J. Cooper continued working his way through a meticulously prepared black binder, to which he continually referred as he cross-examined Professor Lee Badgett on her research methods.

headline: Obama Seeks $1.3 Billion More for Schools Initiative
text: With the fate of his health care overhaul hanging in the balance, and all eyes in Washington on the outcome of the special election in Massachusetts, President Obama sought to change the subject on Tuesday morning, albeit briefly, to education.

headline: Against Emerson
text: William Major and Bryan Sinche, writing in The Chronicle of Higher Education, consider the vatic pronouncements of Ralph Waldo Emerson and conclude, “This is the prose of a crazy person.”

headline: Schools With Many Homeless Students May Close
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: G.O.P. Senate Victory Stuns Democrats
text: BOSTON  Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state senator, rode an old pickup truck and a growing sense of unease among independent voters to an extraordinary upset Tuesday night when he was elected to fill the Senate seat that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy in the overwhelmingly Democratic state of Massachusetts.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1.) An economist who sees no way to stall rising health care costs: Baumol’s cost disease.

headline: Featured Recipe: Squid With Chilies and Greens
text: In this recipe, essentially a stir-fry, the squid is held out till near the end of cooking so as not to overcook it. The pair of strong spices — jalapeños and garlic — are also cooked minimally, and the greens are seared just long enough to wilt. Yet with these powerful flavors the dish comes together around the sweet but distinctive mildness of the squid.

headline: For Verdi, Masquerading as a Baritone
text: In 1959, when he was 18, Plácido Domingo auditioned for the National Opera in Mexico City as a baritone. The jury was impressed but told Mr. Domingo that he was really a tenor. Two years later he sang his first lead tenor role, Alfredo in Verdi’s “Traviata” in Monterrey. And so began one of the great tenor careers in opera history.

headline: Babies at the Bar? A Deluge of Readers Weigh In
text: Parents in Park Slope, Brooklyn, can be a lightning rod for criticism, and this weekend’s Complaint Box about parents who bring their children to neighborhood bars attracted comments like a Bugaboo stroller at a baby shower.

headline: Le Monde Appoints First Woman as Top Editor
text: PARIS  Le Monde, widely considered France’s newspaper of record, appointed a woman as executive editor on Monday, a first in its 65-year history.

headline: Judge Upholds Indictment in Letterman Extortion Case
text: A Manhattan judge on Tuesday upheld the indictment of an Emmy Award-winning television producer accused of trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman.

headline: Food for Thought | Copenhagen’s Coolest Dinner Theater
text: I love food, but I never actually wept over a meal until dessert at a former beer warehouse in Copenhagen last summer. I was at Madeleines Madteater — a kind of interactive dinner performance staged every few months in the neighborhood of Islands Brygge — eating nougat semifreddo while tightly wrapped together with a group of Danes in a stretchy white shroud, behind which waitstaff crept, caressing my back and pressing ghostlike faces through the fabric. There were lyrical strings and a dramatic chiaroscuro and a dancer undulating on the serving dais, and it was all gemütlichkeit, and ritual, and the sadness of endings, and — yes, I know this makes no sense. You had to be there. That is the point. It’s art you experience with all five senses, the most satisfying performance in town. Madteater is precisely as its name translates: food theater.Unsurprisingly, Madeleines is named for Proust. The project, which started in 2006, is a collaboration between the chef Mette Sia Martinussen and the film production designer Nikolaj Danielsen, along with a board of directors that includes an anthropologist, a psychotherapist, a couple of artists and a neurology professor conducting research into the senses. But this is no gimmick; it’s still very much about the food. Martinussen has long occupied a prime spot in the Modern Scandinavian cooking scene. She co-owned the experimental restaurant Ester & Soja with Claus Meyer, the chef of Copenhagen’s beloved Noma. And in 2001 she and Danielsen opened a conceptual dining room called 1.th (“First Floor to the Right”), following it the next year with the experimental traveling restaurant MetteSias Sommerbus.

headline: Erich Segal, Scholar and Author, Is Dead at 72
text: Erich Segal, a classics scholar who taught at Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Oxford but who was best known for creating two of the most enduring pop stories of the 1960s — he wrote the novel “Love Story” and was a co-writer of the screenplay for the Beatles’ movie “Yellow Submarine” — died on Sunday in London. He was 72.

headline: Group Hug | Gucci, Versace, McQueen
text: MILAN — Yesterday’s shows here continued to echo the emphasis that designers have placed on projecting authenticity. Gucci’s Frida Giannini went back to the house’s classic signatures, with ‘70s-inflected suits and turtlenecks, updated loafers with a bumped sole and wool sweaters trimmed in suede. The idea was to make sure there was something special for every kind of guy — though the decadent otter blazer or Mongolian lamb evening jackets are definitely for the wild at heart.

headline: Fearing Hackers Who Leave No Trace
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The crown jewels of Google, Cisco Systems or any other technology company are the millions of lines of programming instructions, known as source code, that make its products run.

headline: Erich Segal, ‘Love Story’ Author, Dies at 72
text: Erich Segal, a Yale classics professor turned popular writer whose first novel, “Love Story,” became a staggering commercial success if not quite a critical one when it appeared in 1970, died on Sunday at his home in London. He was 72.

headline: Should a 96-Year-Old Proposition 8 Supporter Lose a Public Post?
text: Update | 2:39 p.m. Pacific Time  Mayor Ron Dellums will pull from Tuesday night’s City Council agenda the reappointment of Lorenzo Hoopes and three others to the board of the city-owned Paramount Theater. The mayor is expected to make a decision on Mr. Hoopes’s reappoinment in the next week, said Paul Rose, a spokesman with the mayor’s office. “The community asked us to reconsider and that’s what we’re going to do,” Mr. Rose said.

headline: Postcard From London: Pinter With a Broken Heart
text: LONDON — British book reviewers have gone all fluttery of late over “Must You Go?,” Lady Antonia Fraser’s perfumed love poem of a memoir about her late husband, Harold Pinter. This portrait of marriage, which begins, “I first saw Harold across a crowded room,” is said to reveal the softer sentiments of a man known for stark dramas of human inhumanity. But you needn’t buy Ms. Fraser’s book to uncover a streak of gentleness in Pinter’s makeup; that side of him is touchingly in evidence in the new production of “The Caretaker” that opened on Monday night at Trafalgar Studios, with Jonathan Pryce as the fetid old tramp Davies.

headline: Confucius Shoves ‘Avatar’ Aside
text: “Avatar” may be racking up awards and nominations — the latest come from the Visual Effects Society, whose members gave it nods in categories like, “Outstanding Animated Character in a Live Action Feature Motion Picture” — it is not so popular with Chinese authorities. Sharon LaFraniere reports that the film, the most commercially successful of in history there, will be pulled from 2-D theaters to make room for a biopic about Confucius that stars Chow-Yun Fat. (Which, by the way, the Bagger would also pay to see.)

headline: The Real Pigou
text: Every intro text in economics talks about market-based techniques for dealing with pollution, and refers to Pigouvian taxes — effluent charges — as the right way to go (cap and trade can be equivalent). And I’d always assumed that Pigou himself wrote about pollution.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 8: Haiti's First Lady
text: The Times's Marc Lacey spoke with Haiti's first lady, Elizabeth Préval, who said that the Haitian government was still in place despite many buildings having been destroyed.

headline: Kate McGarrigle, Singer and Songwriter, Has Died
text: Kate McGarrigle, a Canadian singer and songwriter who, with her sister Anna, had a repertory of intimate songs about love and family in good times and bad, died of liver cancer on Monday. She was 63 and died at her home in Montreal, her brother-in-law, Dane Lanken, told The Associated Press.

headline: Jean Tschumi Drawings Are Donated to MoMA
text: The architect Bernard Tschumi has donated 43 drawings by his father, the Swiss architect Jean Tschumi, to the Museum of Modern Art, the younger Mr. Tschumi is to announce on Wednesday.

headline: A Blog About Dad
text: Recent increases in lifespan have neatly coincided with the rise of the Internet, so it’s little wonder that caregivers have taken to sharing their observations, frustrations and occasional exultation online. Like support groups that meet in church basements or community centers, personal Web sites and blogs can provide validation, empathy, practical counsel and a safe place to vent.

headline: Plan B
text: It sounds as if House Democrats — or at least their leadership — are prepared to pass the Senate bill if, as expected, they lose today’s special election.

headline: Bernanke Wants an Audit of Fed’s Bailout of A.I.G.
text: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Ben S. Bernanke, asked federal auditors on Tuesday to review the central bank’s role in the much criticized rescue of the American International Group in 2008.

headline: Iraqis on Iraq – Diyala and Kirkuk
text: With international attention shifting from Iraq to Afghanistan, we asked Iraqi journalists working for The New York Times to give a personal view of the areas where they live. Their names are withheld because of the continuing threat to their lives.

headline: Dealer Sues Woman to Cancel ‘Good Deal’
text: Update | 1:11 p.m. A dispute about the price of a Chrysler Pacifica between Walser Chrysler, a Minnesota car dealer, and the buyer, Tammie Townsend, has been settled, Ms. Townsend’s attorney, David Knodell, said Monday.

headline: Robert B. Parker, Mystery Writer, Has Died at 77
text: Update | 4:25 p.m. Robert B. Parker, the best-selling mystery writer who created Spenser, a tough, glib, Boston private detective who was the hero of nearly 40 novels, died on Monday at home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 77.

headline: Essay: Prison Break
text: The main prison in Port-au-Prince emptied after the earthquake last week. Those inmates who weren’t killed were free to walk through the rubble, into the heart of the city. And an estimated 4,000 of them did just that.

headline: Vancouver Rolls Out Art for Olympics
text: Vancouver will celebrate the body in sport, as well as art, during the 2010 Winter Olympics next month.

headline: And Multiply That by Nine Lives Apiece …
text: With the regularity of exploding manholes, cases of cat-hoarding crop up in the news. On Monday, workers from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the city’s Animal Care and Control agency, summoned by a neighbor’s complaint, went to a one-bedroom apartment in East New York, Brooklyn, where two cats Kima Graham adopted five years ago had somehow managed to produce 33 more.

headline: Wives Who Bring Home the Bacon
text: As my colleague Sam Roberts writes, the Pew Research Center today released a report on wives who outrank their husbands in both income and education.

headline: Pre-Carnival Cruising | Rio Fashion Week
text: Jesus Luz might currently be Rio’s most famous export, but at last week’s Fashion Rio, it was clear that the Brazilian city has much more to offer than man candy. Infused with positive energy from the announcement of the 2016 Olympics, several designers sent out strong shows that demonstrated mastery of much more than the itsy-bitsy bikini.Rio is first and foremost a beach town, and many designers give laid-back style an haute bourgeois spin that appeals to the city´s social elite. Take Victor Dzenk, who sent out flowing Grecian gowns of laser-cut silk chiffon to the strains of a spotlighted harpist deluged by a rain of confetti. The collection was the last word in camp, but the front row’s ladies who lunch were eating it up.

headline: Police Say Davis Crashed Into a Driveway Gate
text: The all-terrain vehicle accident that knocked the snowboarder Danny Davis out of his likely place on the United States Olympics team occurred at 3:30 a.m. Sunday. According to a report from the Summit County, Utah, sheriff’s department, Davis was on a four-wheel vehicle that slammed into a closed gate at the end of a driveway. The report said that Davis was thrown from the vehicle and later found unconscious by friends, with injuries to his legs. Other news media reports said that Davis was not alone, but it was not clear who was driving.

headline: Update on Massachusetts Senate Race
text: Adam Nagourney, The Times's chief political correspondent, assesses the race between the Democrat Martha Coakley and the Republican Scott Brown for the state's seat previously held by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

headline: Bernanke Asks for Review of Fed’s A.I.G. Bailout
text: Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, on Tuesday asked the investigative arm of Congress to conduct a “full review” of the Fed’s publicly derided bailout of the insurance giant American International Group, The Associated Press reports.

text: Chase Stuart, a lawyer, Jets fan and statistical analyst, writes for the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog.

text: TOKYO  Japan Airlines, the once-mighty flagship carrier and Asia’s biggest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday, setting the stage for a state-led bailout that could bring sweeping changes to this corner of the global aviation market.

headline: Why You Can Get Written Confirmation From Comcast Now
text: Thanks to the efforts of Marc Pachtman, you can now more confidently ask for a written confirmation of agreements with Comcast cable customer service phone representatives.

headline: U.S. Ski Chief: We Still Aspire to Be ‘Best in the World’
text: For several years, the slogan of the United States ski team has been, “Best in the World.” At the 2006 Turin Olympics, this motivational motto was perceived by the international community as more of a battle cry and, rightly or wrongly, a rather haughty one at that. In a memorable scene following the 2006 Olympic men’s giant slalom, after Austria’s Benjamin Raich and Hermann Maier finished first and third, Maier mocked the American slogan.

headline: ‘Poe Toaster’ Is a No-Show
text: “There are some secrets which do not permit themselves to be told,” Edgar Allan Poe wrote in his 1845 short story “The Man of the Crowd.”

headline: A Hard-Earned Victory for Youzhny
text: Margaret Court Arena was not packed with spectators, but the vocal, fiercely partisan crowd witnessed a gutsy and resourceful performance by the Russian Mikhail Youzhny. Down by two sets to love against the immensely talented Frenchman Richard Gasquet, Youzhny clawed his way back into the first-round match, winning back to back tie-breakers, forcing a fifth set despite cramping in his left quadriceps.

headline: Teacher With Bible Divides Ohio Town
text: MOUNT VERNON, Ohio  Most people in this quiet all-American town describe themselves as devoutly Christian, but even here they are deeply divided over what should happen to John Freshwater.

headline: A Robber in the Village Looks Improbably Familiar
text: A mini-crime wave in the boutiques and specialty shops of Greenwich Village has a face, and it looks an awful lot like William S. Burroughs.

headline: Jury for the Future Generation Art Prize Announced
text: The Future Generation Art Prize, a new $100,000 award for artists under age 35 created by the Ukrainian billionaire and art collector Victor Pinchuk, has announced the members of the prize’s jury, and many of the names are well-traveled ones on the international art circuit: Daniel Birnbaum, the director of the Städelschule art academy in Frankfurt, Germany, and the director of the 2009 Venice Biennale; Robert Storr, the dean of the Yale University School of Art and the director of the Venice Biennale in 2007; Okwui Enwezor, the director of Documenta XI in 2002 and a highly sought-after curator and writer; and Ai Weiwei, probably China’s most famous living artist.

headline: White House Looks Again to Senator Snowe
text: The White House says it hasn’t given up on getting Senator Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine, to vote in favor of a health care overhaul.

headline: The Morning Skate: The Auger-Burrows Controversy Spreads
text: With so many big hockey stories out there, it’s hard not to feel a thousand miles behind in covering them, but we’ll try to play a bit of catch-up here. With luck, only one or two new ones will break today (oops), Mike Peca retired; oops, Chris Osgood gets the start tonight for the Wings; oops, Petr Sykora is on waivers, oops. Mario Lemieux discloses he retired as a player in 2006 due to an irregular heartbeat).

headline: White House Promotes Rescue Video
text: The Obama White House has been running an aggressive public relations campaign out of Haiti, to spotlight the efforts of American troops and local search and rescue teams.

headline: Update: O’Brien Talks Held Up Over Staff Severance
text: With most of the television industry anticipating a formal announcement Tuesday of the widely expected exit of Conan O’Brien from NBC’s late-night lineup and the restoration of Jay Leno as host of the “Tonight Show,” the negotiations continued to be held up on one issue, according to representatives on both sides of the talks.

headline: Pakistani Scientist Is Removed From Court as Trial Begins
text: A Pakistani neuroscientist who is accused of opening fire on American soldiers and F.B.I. agents while being detained in Afghanistan in July 2008 finally faced jurors in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday, after months of delays in her trial.

headline: Blogging the Massachusetts Senate Race
text: Democrats Already Regrouping | 11:41 p.m.  Along with the hand-wringing by Democrats tonight in Washington, we’re told that there also was a fair bit of dialing. On the telephone, that is, as party leaders placed calls to some of the most vulnerable Democrats in the House and Senate.

headline: Hoyer on Senate Bill: ‘Better Than Nothing’
text: The House majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, offered a backhanded endorsement of the Senate health care bill on Monday, saying it was “better than nothing.’’

headline: New Tenant Lifts a Manhattan Street
text: The sunken plaza at 182 East 86th Street had been abandoned for so long it had begun to spook neighbors.

headline: Lesson on Limits of Eminent Domain at Columbia
text: In 2005, the United States Supreme Court upheld the right of officials in New London, Conn., to force the sale of private homes in a waterfront neighborhood to make way for a development project intended to improve the city’s tax base. The decision caused an uproar around the country, spurring 43 states to pass legislation limiting, to one degree or another, the use of eminent domain.

headline: Feng Shui in Austria
text: A six-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath contemporary near Salzburg is on the market for 890,000 euros ($1.3 million).

headline: As Different as Night and Day
text: WHEN my two older daughters arrived home from college for winter break, they suddenly behaved in all the ways that I once believed would make me the happiest mother in the world.

headline: $64.2 Billion Payday Seen for Wall Street
text: New York’s financial sector will pay $64.2 billion in bonuses this year, up from an estimated $57 billion in 2009, though this year’s amount would still be about $19 billion less than the amount paid out in 2008, the state budget division forecast on Tuesday in its revenue outlook.

headline: Queens Man Is Accused in Plot to Kill Service Members
text: A federal prosecutor told a judge on Tuesday that a man who traveled to Pakistan in 2008 to attend a Qaeda training camp conspired to kill American service members in Afghanistan.

headline: Is Obama’s Liberalism The Problem?
text: The consensus on the left is a resounding no. According to Jonathan Chait, Matt Yglesias, E.J. Dionne, and many others, Obama’s political difficulties are explained by a lousy economy, rather than a public backlash against liberalism. Like Ronald Reagan, who suffered a similar first-term swoon, the president is a prisoner of circumstance: His program is suddenly unpopular not because it’s too liberal and ambitious, but because the unemployment rate is around 10 percent and holding. In this climate, any agenda would be unpopular, and Obama would having exactly the same problems if he’d governed as a cautious incrementalist rather than a would-be Lyndon Johnson.

headline: Mauresmo’s Quiet Mark on Tennis
text: Eleven years ago Amelie Mauresmo burst on to the international tennis scene by upsetting three seeded players en route to the final of the Australian Open, where Martina Hingis ended her run. After her upset of Lindsay Davenport, Mauresmo came out as an openly gay woman at her news conference after the match. Her athleticism and long flowing strokes, especially her one-handed backhand, took the tennis world by storm. Her future looked limitless.

headline: Q&A: Exploring the Kenai Peninsula
text: Q.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Jan. 19
text: Comings and goings in Port-au-Prince. Coming: the 82nd Airborne, arriving by helicopter on the grounds of the ruined Presidential Palace. Going: thousands of citizens who have been living for a week with little or no food, water, shelter, power and waste removal. The latest post on Lens about the situation in Haiti, Damon Winter’s “Essay: Prison Break,” takes viewers inside the main prison in Port-au-Prince; now absent any prisoners.

headline: Project Haiti: Holding a Teach-In
text: Overview | What are the effects of the earthquake in Haiti? What issues, problems and questions has the disaster caused and raised? How are students responding personally, and how can they help? In this lesson, students either participate in a personal response activity or engage in an in-depth teach-in project, researching topics related to the earthquake and presenting their findings to the community. They then develop proposals for a community service plan and choose one or more to implement.

headline: Scorecard | Prada Wins!
text: Scorecard here, your handily reductive afternoon recap of all that’s new in Milan men’s fashion. Day 2 on the catwalks was still all about heritage dressing. At Gianfranco Ferré, Tommaso Aquilano and Roberto Rimondi’s latest take on the house codes failed to square the circle. Meanwhile, Miuccia Prada proved that sometimes to move forward you need to look back to the ’70s — by way of your own witty ugly-chic aesthetic, that is.

headline: Ad Industry Increases Efforts for Haiti
text: The response to the Haitian earthquake in the advertising community continues to gain momentum.

headline: House Hunting in ... Austria

headline: Is All Fair in Love and Debt Collecting?
text: Ethics in business is generally black and white. Don’t lie. Do the right thing. Treat people fairly. If you have a good moral compass, it usually does not require much thought to run an ethical business. Or to be an ethical person. There are, however, occasions that make you stop and think. Here is one of them:

headline: Reading Apple’s Tea Leaves
text: Moments after Apple sent an invitation to journalists on Monday in advance of an event next week, the invitation itself came under the kind of intense scrutiny that was once seen only when a new photo emerged of the Kremlin’s leadership.

headline: Where Does a Mother’s Time Go?
text: Two articles published in the past few days explore how a mother spends her time. Neither one is relaxing reading.

headline: A Barter for a Lease in Lebanon
text: Kamal Mouzawak and Rabih Kayrouz bartered for their vacation home in Batroun, about 25 miles northeast of Beirut.

headline: Supreme Court Rules on Trial Conduct in Georgia
text: WASHINGTON  Unusual practices in Georgia trial courts, including off-color gifts to court personnel from jurors in a capital case, were the subjects of a pair of unsigned Supreme Court decisions on Tuesday.

headline: City Hall to Start Shuffling Top Deputies
text: Moving to fulfill a promise made in his inaugural address, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday ordered that a top deputy in each city agency spend three weeks in another agency in an attempt to improve management habits.

headline: Susan Boyle Shut Out of Brit Awards
text: The shortlist for the Brit Awards, Britain’s version of the Grammys, seems at least one name too short to many fans. Susan Boyle, whose rocket to fame began in April after her appearance on “Britain’s Got Talent” and whose first record just finished a six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart, selling more than 3 million copies, was nowhere to be seen among the nominations, which include ones for Lady Gaga, Lily Allen and the newcomer Pixie Lott. The winner will be announced on Feb. 16 at a ceremony in London.

headline: A Big Map That Shrank the World
text: WASHINGTON  When a map of overwhelming dimensions and detail is presented to the ruler of a land, the homage, surely, is a kind of deference. The map is partly meant to be an illustration of the ruler’s powers, the extent of his realm, the range of learning he commands.

headline: Renovating for Rent, a Lebanese Retreat
text: It seemed they fell in love with the wrong house. In early 2004, Kamal Mouzawak, the founder of Beirut’s twice-weekly farmers’ market Souk el Tayeb, and Rabih Kayrouz, a Lebanese fashion designer, were looking for a second home in the Lebanese countryside or perhaps the mountains, a place where they could escape their busy work lives and the bustle of Beirut. But it was a house in Batroun, a the seaside town about 25 miles northeast of Beirut, that swept them off their feet.

headline: Ford to Take Leave From Merrill to Campaign
text: Harold Ford Jr., the Merrill Lynch vice chairman who is weighing a challenge to Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, is taking a 30-day leave of absence from the Wall Street firm.

text: There’s more than a little “Death of a Salesman” in Sean Cullen’s “Safe Home,” but Mr. Cullen’s forlorn characters could never dream of a career as grand as sales.

headline: Tiny Steps Toward Basic Services
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Almost every wing of St.-François de Sales Hospital lies in ruins. But about 68 doctors and nurses have turned what is left into a triage center that performed at least 17 operations Tuesday.

headline: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 3
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you’ll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: The Youngest of the Capsouto Frères Dies
text: Albert Capsouto, the youngest of three brothers who in 1980 started Capsouto Frères, one of the first of the more high-end restaurants in TriBeCa, died today from a brain tumor that was discovered two months ago. He would have been 54 next Tuesday.

headline: The Balkan Burger
text: Pljeskavica, the wide, thin patties that can be made with a mixture of beef, pork, veal and lamb, has arrived in New York.

headline: David Sarkisyan, Champion of Moscow Architecture, Dies at 62
text: MOSCOW  David Sarkisyan, a former physiologist and film director who became famous as the director of the Shchusev State Museum of Architecture here and for his campaigns to preserve architectural monuments against rampant post-Soviet development, died on Jan. 7 in Munich, where he had been hospitalized. He was 62.

headline: Accentuating Helen Mirren
text: For the Bagger’s nonexistent money, one of the juiciest races this season is for best actress. Meryl Streep (“Julie & Julia”) and Sandra Bullock (“The Blind Side”) both won at the Golden Globes, which recognize comedy and drama in separate categories, and tied at the Critics’ Choice Awards; the two, along with Carey Mulligan (“An Education”), Gabourey Sidibe (“Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire”) and Helen Mirren (“The Last Station”), are nominated for a Screen Actors Guild award.

headline: App of the Week: Hop on a Suite of Free Voice Services
text: As iPhone users await an outcome in Apple’s decision to withhold Google Voice (and the subsequent F.C.C. inquiry), they don’t have to go entirely without the features of Google Voice. Many are available through an app called Ribbit Mobile.

headline: Security Ahead? Pack Patience
text: SINCE the Transportation Security Administration began tightening security in response to the Christmas Day bombing plot, travelers have faced increasingly rigorous screenings at airports. They’ve been forced to cope with extra bag checks, closer scrutiny of their identification, and full body pat-downs that include children as well as adults.

headline: T. Boone Pickens Tweaks His Energy Plan
text: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas billionaire, got his first car, a 1942 Ford, in 1946. But in an interview today at The New York Times, he made it plain that the national romance with the automobile was beyond his reckoning. “America is nuts about cars,” he said. “I don’t quite understand this thing about horsepower. Cars are not a big deal to me, but they are a big deal to a lot of people.”

headline: Voices From the Race
text: The New York Times asked Boston-area voters their thoughts on the special election.

headline: Evidence Found for Chinese Attack on Google
text: SAN FRANCISCO  An American computer security researcher has found what he says he believes is strong evidence of the digital fingerprints of Chinese authors in the software programs used in attacks against Google.

headline: Dynamo Twosome’s European Reception Is Mixed
text: Two Houston Dynamo midfielders looking for opportunities overseas received mixed news Tuesday. After Stuart Holden was told his services would not be needed at Bolton, fellow American Ricardo Clark was signed by Eintracht Frankfurt in the German Bundesliga.

headline: Brit Awards Nominees
text: The shortlist for the Brit Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Grammys, seems at least one name too short to many fans. Susan Boyle, above, who rocketed to fame last April after her appearance on “Britain’s Got Talent” and whose first record just finished a six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart, selling more than three million copies, was nowhere to be seen among the nominees, who include Lady GaGa, Lily Allen, Taylor Swift, Jay-Z, Bruce Springsteen and the newcomer Pixie Lott. The winners will be announced on Feb. 16 at a ceremony in London.

headline: Funny Night for CBS
text: CBS’s Monday night comedy lineup finished on top of the ratings race, as usual, as “Two and a Half Men” at 9 and “The Big Bang Theory” at 9:30 delivered the evening’s largest audiences. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 16.2 million viewers tuned into “Men” and 15 million watched “Big Bang.” In the 8 o’clock hour, CBS’s “How I Met Your Mother” and “Accidentally on Purpose” posted season highs with 10.5 million and 9.6 million viewers. Fox ranked second for the night with a two-hour installment of the new season of “24,” which averaged 11 million viewers from 8 to 10, edging past “The Bachelor” on ABC in the same time period (10.6 million). ABC finished in third place for the night, with 9.4 million at 10 for “Castle,” which trailed CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (13.2 million) in its time slot but outpaced “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC (4.6 million). NBC was a distant fourth, garnering 6.7 million for “Chuck” at 8 but just 3.9 million at 9 for “Heroes.”

headline: $100,000 Art Prize
text: The Future Generation Art Prize, a new $100,000 award for artists younger than 35, created by the Ukrainian billionaire and art collector Victor Pinchuk, has announced the members of the prize’s jury, and many of the names are well traveled on the international art circuit. They include Daniel Birnbaum, the director of the Städelschule Art Academy in Frankfurt and the director of the 2009 Venice Biennale; Robert Storr, the dean of the Yale University School of Art and the director of the Venice Biennale two years before that; Okwui Enwezor, the director of Documenta XI in 2002 and a highly sought-after curator and writer; and Ai Weiwei, probably China’s most famous living artist. The Victor Pinchuk Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded in 2006, also announced that it had begun to accept entries from artists, who can submit applications online at futuregenerationartprize.org through April 18. The prize will be awarded every two years, along with a more populist noncash side award, the People’s Choice Prize, to be determined by a public online vote, à la “American Idol.”

headline: Early Play at the Australian Open
text: The first round of the Australian Open was pretty true to form, reports Joe Drape from Melbourne. What can fans expect as the tournament progresses?

headline: Big Plans for Coachella
text: Jay-Z, Muse and Gorillaz will headline the 11th annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival when that sprawling rock event gets under way on April 16 in Indio, Calif., planners announced on Tuesday. They are hoping to maintain the momentum from last year, when the festival drew its second-highest crowds, despite the economic downturn. The big news from the show is that it will serve as a stop on what seems to be shaping up as a sizable reunion tour for the long-lamented lo-fi band Pavement, which broke up a decade ago. Along with bands of the moment like Vampire Weekend, Dirty Projectors, Girls and Grizzly Bear, this year’s lineup includes some venerable names like Gil Scott-Heron, Grace Jones, Devo and Sly and the Family Stone, along with a few oddball entries like the filmmaker John Waters (maybe he’ll do his rendition of “Mama, I’m a Big Girl Now” from “Hairspray”?) and D J Lance Rock, of the hipster children’s show “Yo Gabba Gabba” fame.

headline: Is Poe to Be Toasted Nevermore?
text: “There are some secrets which do not permit themselves to be told,” Edgar Allan Poe wrote in his 1845 short story “The Man of the Crowd.” And since 1949 one such secret has attended Poe’s final resting place in Baltimore at the Westminster Hall and Burying Ground, where a black-clad figure has shown up annually early on the morning of Jan. 19, the author’s birthday, to raise a Cognac toast to his grave and deposit three red roses, along with the remnants of the Cognac bottle. But the visitor  whose identity, or identities, has never been revealed, despite some claims to the contrary over the years  failed to show up this year for the first time, ending a strange crepuscular tradition and disappointing a crowd of more than 30 people who forfeited a good night’s sleep to witness the visitation. “I was very annoyed,” Jeff Jerome, curator of the Edgar Allan Poe House, told The Baltimore Sun. “I’ve been doing this since 1977, and there was no indication he wasn’t going to show up.” Some conjectured that the Poe Toaster, as the visitor has come to be known, might have just had the flu or car trouble. But Mr. Jerome spoke with a Poe-ian air of finality. Last year was the bicentennial of Poe’s birthday, he said. “And if it was going to end,” he said, “that would be the perfect time to end it.”

headline: MoMA to Receive Jean Tschumi Drawings
text: The architect Bernard Tschumi has donated 43 drawings by his father, the Swiss architect Jean Tschumi, to the Museum of Modern Art, the younger Mr. Tschumi is to announce on Wednesday. Jean Tschumi, who died in 1962 at 57, helped influence modern architecture and design in the mid-20th century and became an influential figure in architectural education and practice. The works on paper range from Mr. Tschumi’s early work while a student in Paris to his last project, the Nestlé headquarters in Vevey, Switzerland. With this gift MoMA becomes the only institution outside of Europe to house a collection of drawings by Mr. Tschumi; the majority of his drawings are in the Archives of Modern Construction at the Lausanne Polytechnique, whose architecture school Mr. Tschumi founded in 1942, and in Basel in the collection of the pharmaceutical giant Novartis, formerly Sandoz, for which Mr. Tschumi built headquarters and laboratories in Switzerland and France. (Mr. Tschumi’s desk for the company director, above.) His notable works include the headquarters building of the World Heath Organization in Geneva. “I think he was very ambitious and at the same time a little ironical about the pitfalls of fame,” Bernard Tschumi said in a telephone interview from Paris on Tuesday. “I think he would have been extremely pleased, but with a twinkle in his eye.”
Olivia Judson is away this week.

headline: Sex and the Digital City
text: Last week, reputable Web sites reported that semi-reputable Web sites had reported that Tiger Woods entered a Mississippi clinic for sex-addiction rehab. Meanwhile, South Carolina’s legislature rebuked Gov. Mark Sanford for bringing “disgrace and shame” to the state via his extramarital affair with an Argentine journalist. And NBC aired a “Law & Order” episode apparently based on the alleged attempt to blackmail David Letterman over his staff liaisons.

headline: Poet in Exile, Still Gripping His Memories
text: Late in “A Room and a Half,” a rich, heady fictionalized biography of the exiled Russian poet Joseph Brodsky, the middle-aged Brodsky ruefully reflects in a voice-over about how children are in a desperate hurry to leave the nest.

headline: Now Screening | Dsquared
text: The fall 2010 collection from Dsquared.

headline: Beekeeping in Koraro
text: The following is the third in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones aren’t, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

headline: Christian-Muslim Mayhem in Nigeria Kills Dozens
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Armed with guns, machetes, torches, and bows and arrows, Christian and Muslim antagonists in central Nigeria’s religiously volatile city of Jos have been fighting for three days in sporadic clashes that have left dozens dead, witnesses and local news accounts said Tuesday.

headline: Exec Rejoins Credit Suisse From Renaissance
text: Neil Harvey is leaving his position as deputy chief executive of the Renaissance Group to head up Credit Suisse’s effort to build its asset management business in Asia and other emerging markets. Mr. Harvey will be based in Hong Kong and report to Robert Shafir, chief executive of asset management, and Kai Nargolwala, chief executive of the Asia Pacific region.

headline: Grass Fed | Working for Peanuts
text: If three is a trend, then peanuts are hot! Look! They’re on the menu at brand-new Flatiron restaurant Rye House, boiled, right next to sweetbreads done Buffalo-style. Look! They’re on the short menu of the weeks-old Baohaus, which is neither German nor arty, but instead a subterranean Asian eatery on the Lower East Side that slings steamed Taiwanese buns and boils up peanuts with a little rice vinegar in the brine. And they’re on the menu at that high church of hipness, the Breslin, the spawn of the Spotted Pig in the Ace Hotel, where April Bloomfield has married them to pork fat.

headline: The Battle for a Senate Seat
text: Massachusetts voters came out in what became a surprisingly tight special election for the United States Senate.

headline: Tavern Is in a Deeper Hole Than Was Thought
text: Now that the dust has settled from the auction last week of $3.5 million in items from the bankrupt Tavern on the Green, one thing is clearer. Tavern owes a lot more money than was realized.

headline: Online, It’s the Mouse That Runs the Museum
text: One morning last fall Judson Box woke up early to tend the horses at his farm near Leesburg, Fla. Before he could sit down to breakfast, however, his wife waved him over to the color TV that doubles as their home computer, thanks to an old WebTV setup. As Mr. Box leaned in closer to the grainy 17-inch screen, he started to make out the image of a fireman running through a tunnel.

headline: Rubbernecking at the Capsule Trade Show
text: While T’s men’s editors survey the pompadours (see Bottega Veneta) and hot pink camouflage (Hello, Prada!) on the runways in Milan, I will be making my rounds at the trade shows taking place in New York this week. First up: Capsule. Street fashion, new washes of denim, bold and bright sneakers along with reinterpreted brogues, the latest take on American workwear, etc. are all on display under two roofs (the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street, and Angel Orensanz Center, 172 Norfolk Street).

headline: The Charge: Not So Much Cash 4 That Gold
text: The flashy ads have become a staple on late-night television, sometimes featuring figures like the late Ed McMahon or M.C. Hammer, trumpeting promises of quick dollars in exchange for bits of old gold jewelry.

headline: Properties for $350,000
text: A condo in Memphis, a adobe in Cerrillos, N.M., and a house in Gloucester, Mass.

headline: A Late Bloomer, Still Reveling in the Spotlight
text: “Pop Star on Ice,” David Barba and James Pellerito’s swoony documentary about the figure-skating champion Johnny Weir, is one part hagiography and two parts psychotherapy. Together they showcase a talent both formidable and erratic, its bright and shining peaks sliding inexplicably into valleys of disaster.

headline: Leave No Sin Untaxed
text: Gov. David A. Paterson got a bit freewheeling on Tuesday in his bid to close the state’s canyonesque budget gap, unveiling proposals to legalize ultimate fighting, let supermarkets sell wine and expand the hours of video slot-machine parlors.

headline: After Atom Bombs’ Shock, the Real Horrors Began Unfolding
text: When Tsutomu Yamaguchi died two weeks ago, at 93, he was eulogized as a star-crossed rarity: a man who lived through two atomic blasts, at Hiroshima and then at Nagasaki. He was a man with very good luck, or very bad luck. It’s hard to decide.

headline: Taking Office, Christie Sees State’s Last Hope for Turnaround
text: TRENTON  Saying he would not squander New Jersey’s “last, best hope” to reverse its decline, Christopher J. Christie took office on Tuesday as the state’s 55th governor, vowing to break through partisan gridlock to bring about lower taxes, economic resurgence and school choice.

headline: Guinea Junta Picks Opponent as Premier on Path to Civilian Control
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Guinea’s military leaders appointed a veteran opposition figure as prime minister on Monday, a critical step in the transition to elections and civilian government later in the year, officials and news agencies reported.

headline: R.B.C. Names New U.S. Investment Banking Head
text: Update | 7:38 p.m. The Royal Bank of Canada said on Tuesday that it has hired a new head of United States investment banking and other bankers as the firm seeks to bolster its American footprint.

headline: New York Fed Defends Move in A.I.G. Bailout
text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York defended itself on Tuesday against complaints that it had told the American International Group not to disclose critical bailout details in public filings, saying it had only suggested deleting a sentence about paying the insurer’s trading partners 100 cents on the dollar because “it was not in fact precisely accurate.”

headline: Snack Time Never Ends
text: OF the many horrors that lurk in the e-mail in-box of a working parent  dental reminders, Facebook invitations involving some weird farm, “thoughts” from the boss  nothing quite rivals the snack request.

headline: A Sign of Latin America’s Fading Polarization
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  The election of a billionaire from a right-wing party as Chile’s president on Sunday appears to be less a signal of a regional move to the right than that of a pragmatic convergence of left and right agendas.

headline: Medical Miracle Nears a Milepost
text: In the dozen years since brain surgery brought relief from debilitating epileptic seizures, Diane Van Deren has become one of the world’s top endurance runners. She regularly competes in long-distance tests of perseverance, 100 miles or more through wicked terrain and tortuous conditions. She won the 300-mile Yukon Arctic Ultra two years ago, pulling a sled through the depths of winter, and was the first woman to complete the 430-mile version last year.

headline: How About a Snack?
text: With three children and a high-powered job in Los Angeles, Sheri Kaiserman is not easily unnerved. But she often feels done in by the doughnuts of others.

headline: Taxing Wall Street Down to Size
text: WHILE supply-side catechism insists that lower taxes are a growth tonic, the theory also argues that if you want less of something, tax it more. The economy desperately needs less of our bloated, unproductive and increasingly parasitic banking system. In this respect, the White House appears to have gone over to the supply side with its proposed tax on big banks, as it scores populist points against the banksters, too.
