headline: In Europe, Steps to Cracking Down on Tax Evasion
text: European finance ministers said on Tuesday that they had made progress in plans to crack down on tax evasion. At the same time, the ministers delayed dealing with the most delicate issues related to exchanging details on individuals’ tax matters.

headline: Economics of Haiti Aid Efforts
text: A roundup of some of the more provocative pieces from around the econoblogosphere that have been inspired by the Haiti relief efforts:

headline: Yelp’s Divide Between Businesses and Reviewers
text: In the February issue of Inc. magazine, Max Chafkin writes about the sometimes bitter split between reviewers on Yelp and the businesses they critique.

headline: Polanski Lawyers Say Prosecutors Misled Swiss
text: LOS ANGELES — In their latest filing with the Los Angeles Superior Court, lawyers for Roman Polanski on Tuesday said officials with the district attorney’s office here had “intentionally misled the Swiss” government with a false record of Mr. Polanski’s long-running sex case as a way to secure his extradition from that country illegally.

headline: At Age 11, Balancing Olympic Ambition and Youth
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  At age 11, Polina Edmunds is young enough to carry a teddy bear for good luck, but old enough to be a veteran dreamer of an Olympic gold medal in figure skating.

headline: When Fingers Would Fumble, Chefs Turn to Tweezers
text: EVERY so often, a tool will leap across professional borders and become standard in restaurant kitchens. The blowtorch, we now know, caramelizes as well as it solders. Today, the woodworker’s Microplane rasp is far more likely to zest a lemon than shape a credenza.

headline: MXco
text: 1491 Second Avenue (78th Street), Upper East Side; (212) 249-6080.

headline: Xi’an Famous Foods
text: 88 East Broadway No. 106, (entrance on Forsyth Street), Chinatown; no phone; xianfoods.com.

headline: Benefits
text: THE food and wine industry is helping to raise money for victims of the earthquake in Haiti.

headline: The Balkan Burger Unites All Factions
text: AMERICANS might think themselves masters of the all-beef patty, and Germans may claim bragging rights for its point of origin. But there is no burger passion greater than the one for pljeskavica.

headline: Schatzie’s Meat Market Heads West
text: Tony Schatz, a k a Schatzie, above, a fifth-generation New York butcher who had a meat market on the Upper East Side for 30 years, has moved it to the Upper West Side. The East Side store closed Jan. 9. The new market almost looks as if it has been a neighborhood fixture for years, not days (vintage cash register, old-fashioned white tiles).

headline: Raising a Glass With the Monks
text: The architecture and history of monasteries and abbeys make them popular tourist sites. Equipped with “A Taste of Heaven: A Guide to Food and Drink Made by Monks and Nuns,” by Madeline Scherb, those tourists may head for the gift shops first, to stock up on the wines, spirits, beers, cheeses, condiments and sweets, often from centuries-old recipes, that are made at many monasteries.

headline: Bitters From Germany, to Kick Up Your Cocktails
text: The new-guard bartenders who have driven a cocktail frenzy in the last decade depend on bitters. These potent alcohol-based elixirs, usually made with herbs, citrus peels and other aromatics, are used by the droplet in well-made drinks.

headline: School Adds Weeding to Reading and Writing
text: THOSE who believe trends start on the West Coast and are perfected on the East Coast might add to their argument a garden planned for an elementary school in Brooklyn.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: A Grab for Keepsakes as the Gavel Falls
text: IT was an everything-must-go sale, and everything went.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Beer and Steak ...

headline: Roman Holiday
text: My review this week is of Maialino, which the restaurateur Danny Meyer recently opened on the ground floor of the Gramercy Park Hotel. The concept is that of a Roman trattoria.

headline: Maialino
text: MAIALINO is the restaurateur Danny Meyer’s latest venture, a Roman-style trattoria at the Gramercy Park Hotel. It is warm and familiar, comfortable, a trattoria in an imaginary Rome where everyone comes from Missouri and wants you above all else to have a nice time.

headline: F.H.A. to Raise Standards for Mortgage Insurance
text: The Federal Housing Administration, which is supporting the housing market by insuring thousands of new mortgages every day, is expected to announce on Wednesday that it is tightening standards.

headline: A.I.G. Unit May Be Sold to MetLife
text: MetLife, where Robert H. Benmosche made his mark as an insurance executive, has emerged as the lead bidder for a major subsidiary of the American International Group, where Mr. Benmosche is now chief executive.

headline: Russia Seeks to Cleanse Its Palate of U.S. Chicken
text: MOSCOW  At the mere mention of American chicken at a central Moscow market, the poultry vendors pounce.

headline: The Surgical Touch
text: At Alinea in Chicago, David Beran assembles the garnishes for a pork belly dish: black sea salt, cucumber, garlic chips, bananas with curry, lime, onion, coconut, cashews, pepper puree and a citrus marigold mix. (Video: Peter Thompson)

headline: Dolphins’ Home Receives Its 7th Name Since 1987
text: The home of the Miami Dolphins has a new name  Sun Life Stadium  in time for the Super Bowl.

headline: CIT Appoints Interim Chief Executive
text: The CIT Group, the small- to midmarket lender, said late Tuesday that it has appointed a director, Peter J. Tobin, as its interim chief executive as it looks for a permanent new leader.

headline: NBC Haunted by Its Knockout Bid for the Games
text: The Winter Olympics start in 23 days, and NBC expects to lose $200 million on them.

headline: Berra Calls ’em as He Sees ’em
text: LA QUINTA, Calif.  Yogi Berra, the host of the 2010 Bob Hope Classic, spent part of Tuesday squinting into television lights, smiling for cameras and shaking hands.

headline: Centrist, and Yet Not Unified
text: So what should happen with health reform now?

headline: Molina Rebuffs Mets to Re-Sign With Giants
text: The Mets spent much of the off-season trying to persuade Bengie Molina to become their starting catcher, and they were relatively confident they could entice him to accept a one-year deal with a vesting option for a second season.

headline: Decision Day at the Polls in Massachusetts
text: There was little ambivalence or hesitation at polling places around Massachusetts on Tuesday as voters selected a senator to succeed the late Edward M. Kennedy. After more than a week of nonstop television commercials, automated phone calls and even a campaign appearance by President Obama, voters were well aware that there was more at stake in this race than the fate of a single Senate seat.

headline: The Trials of Gavin Newsom
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Google Hopes to Retain Business Unit in China
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Few people say they think Google’s Chinese-language search engine will survive the company’s confrontation with China.

headline: Arrests for a Revealing Dance Pit Flesh Against Faith
text: BANDUNG, Indonesia  Known during colonial times as the “Paris of Java,” this easygoing city remains famous in Indonesia for its universities, cuisine, fashion and night life. Residents of Jakarta, the capital less than three hours away by car, come here for weekend getaways and trips to the countless factory outlets.

headline: After Attack, Afghans Question Motives or See Conspiracies
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Twenty-four hours after seven insurgents stormed a shopping center in downtown Kabul and immobilized the city, the shoemakers who ply their trade in front of the mall were back in business on Tuesday.

headline: The N.F.L. Is Squeezing Discounters Over Apparel
text: Howard Faber has been selling official N.F.L. jerseys, hats and sweatshirts online for more than a decade. His business includes about $200,000 worth of all brands of apparel in a warehouse near Detroit. As with many online stores, Faber’s modest profit targets allow him to offer steep discounts.

headline: Ex-Convicts From U.S. Said to Join Yemen Radicals
text: WASHINGTON  Some American former convicts who converted to Islam in prison have moved to Yemen and a few may have joined extremist groups there, according to a new Senate report.

headline: China to Scan Text Messages to Spot ‘Unhealthy Content’
text: BEIJING  As the Chinese government expands what it calls a campaign against pornography, cellular companies in Beijing and Shanghai have been told to suspend text services to cellphone users who are found to have sent messages with “illegal or unhealthy content,” state-run news media reported Tuesday.

headline: Mariners Join Trend by Signing Hernandez to Long Deal
text: Baseball teams yearn for young ace pitchers because they are very productive for so little cost. Players need six years of service to reach free agency, and because their early years are often their best, young stars can be extraordinary bargains.

headline: Insider Faces Sentencing in ’07 Case
text: A former hedge fund manager named Mark E. Lenowitz has been secretly cooperating with an expanding federal investigation of insider trading on Wall Street for more than two years, in hopes of reducing his jail time.

headline: 53 Haitian Orphans Are Airlifted to U.S.
text: MIAMI  A group of 53 Haitian orphans landed in Pittsburgh on Tuesday morning, the first wave to arrive after the United States loosened its policy on visa requirements to expedite Americans’ adoptions of parentless children living in the post-earthquake ruins.

headline: A Plea for the Stricken in Haiti
text: To the Editor:

headline: Senator Dodd’s Mortgage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Listening to Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Port in Kenya
text: To the Editor:

headline: Calhoun Takes Leave for Medical Reasons
text: University of Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun took an indefinite medical leave of absence Tuesday, with the institution citing “temporary medical issues.” The university declined to specify Calhoun’s medical issues or offer a timetable for his return.

headline: In Federer’s So-So Win, No Reply to Rivals’ Hope
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  He has been Roger the Great for so long that when Roger Federer turns in a merely mortal performance, as he did Tuesday in the first round of the Australian Open, people start to wonder: what’s wrong?

headline: Mara Cites a Lack of Progress in Talks
text: The Giants co-owner John Mara said Tuesday he was resigned to an uncapped season in 2010 and thought the union and owners might be moving further apart in talks toward a new labor agreement.

headline: Russia: Ukraine to Get Ambassador
text: President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia said on Tuesday that he would send an ambassador to neighboring Ukraine now that it appeared that the next Ukrainian president would try to begin mending relations with Moscow. Mr. Medvedev recalled Russia’s ambassador last year to protest what he said were the anti-Russian policies of the current Ukrainian president, Viktor A. Yushchenko. On Sunday, Mr. Yushchenko lost his bid for re-election. The next Ukrainian president will be decided in a runoff on Feb. 7 between the opposition leader, Viktor F. Yanukovich, and Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko. Both support improving ties to Russia.

headline: Huge Payoff for I.B.M. After a Shift
text: The corporate technology industry is scrambling for higher ground, moving up from hardware into services and mixing in some business software. The goal is steady revenue, higher profit and tighter bonds with customers  and the model is I.B.M., which reported its quarterly results on Tuesday, finishing off a record year of profits for the company.

headline: Virginia Gunman Kills 8 and Shoots at the Police
text: A gunman shot and killed eight people before firing on law enforcement officers and hitting a police helicopter on Tuesday in a thickly wooded area of south-central Virginia, a state police official said.

headline: Interviews Begin for Ex-Aides to Ensign
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has begun interviewing former aides to Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, as part of a criminal inquiry into accusations that he arranged lobbying work for a onetime senior aide in the fallout from an affair he had with the aide’s wife, people with knowledge of the case said Tuesday.

headline: Marines Land in Villages on Edge of Life and Death
text: LÉOGÂNE, Haiti  The Marine helicopters began landing just before noon on Tuesday in a cow pasture here in this heavily damaged farming town about nine miles south of Port-au-Prince, kicking up strong winds and drawing crowds of the curious and hopeful.

headline: PGA Announces New Fall Tournament
text: A day after its surprise announcement naming Farmers Insurance as the title sponsor for next week’s event in San Diego, the PGA Tour followed up on Tuesday with the announcement of a new fall tournament to complete the 2010 schedule. The McGladrey Classic, sponsored by the accounting, tax and consulting firm RSM McGladrey, will be played from Oct. 7 to 10 at the Seaside Course at Sea Island Resort in Georgia. The event, with $4 million in prize money, will also expand the roster of tour players involved in high-level tournament operations positions. Davis Love III, a Sea Island resident, is the tournament chairman.

headline: Microsoft Puts a Time Limit on Bing Data
text: Bowing to pressure in Europe, Microsoft said Tuesday that it would comply with regulators and discard all data collected on users of its Bing search engine after six months.

headline: Issues Stand Before Israel in Joining Elite Group
text: JERUSALEM  Israel, which has catapulted in the past two decades from a minor state-dominated economy to a market-driven technology hothouse, is in the final stages of accession to the exclusive club of advanced countries, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. But its secretive weapons trade, patent-bending drug industry and occupation of Arab lands are raising last-minute questions.

headline: Aspirants
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — ETTA James shows up frequently in crosswords. I’ve seen her live — she’s a fine blues singer — but her grid popularity has at least as much to do with that convenient letter combination as her innate talent or even her popularity. When constructors toss coins into fountains, they wish for another Etta or ENYA to make it big in any field of endeavor, just so they can have more variety in their clues.

headline: Zeus Approves of Norv Turner’s Onside Kick
text: Frank Frigo and Chuck Bower developed the Zeus computer program, which can simulate hundreds of thousands of N.F.L. outcomes in seconds. They examined Norv Turner’s controversial decision to try an onside kick late in Sunday’s loss to the Jets.

headline: Republican Wins in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON — Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state senator, rode an old pickup truck and a growing sense of unease among independent voters to an extraordinary upset Tuesday night when he was elected to fill the Senate seat that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy in the overwhelmingly Democratic state of Massachusetts.

headline: Just Another Massachusetts Miracle
text: Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state legislator, will be the next junior senator from Massachusetts, and the message for Democrats is: “it won’t much matter”? Well, at least in terms of health care reform, writes Paul Waldman at the American Prospect, who sees two paths ahead:

headline: Webb Urges a Halt to Senate Health Care Votes
text: Responding to the Republican victory in Massachusetts, Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, is calling on Senate leaders to suspend any votes on the Democrats’ health care legislation until the winner in the special Senate election, Scott Brown, is sworn into office.

headline: Is China an Enron? (Part 2)
text: Last week, I wrote a column suggesting that while some overheated Chinese markets, like real estate, may offer shorting opportunities, I’d be wary of the argument that China’s economy today is just one big short-inviting bubble, à la Dubai. Your honor, I’d like to now revise and amend my remarks.

headline: Obama Pressing for Protections Against Lenders
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday stepped into the middle of a fierce lobbying battle by reinforcing his support for an independent agency to protect consumers against lending abuses that contributed to the financial crisis. The president’s move also signaled a tougher line and a more direct role as Congress weighs an overhaul of banking regulation.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about Stan Kroenke, whose portfolio of teams has made him a powerful figure in sports, described incorrectly the hit that scored Enos Slaughter in the eighth inning of Game 7 of the 1946 World Series, helping the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Boston Red Sox. The batter, Harry Walker, was credited with a double on the play, which has come to be known as Slaughter’s “mad dash”; it was not a single.

headline: Budget Ballot Initiatives Debated in Colorado
text: DENVER  Overturning Colorado’s Taxpayer Bill of Rights, a strict constitutional budget-collar known by its acronym, Tabor, is not on either major party’s official to-do list for the 2010 election cycle.

headline: Republicans Seize on Massachusetts Upset
text: Senate Republicans moved quickly on Tuesday night to cast the election results in Massachusetts as a referendum on the Democrats’ health care legislation and to urge the Democrats to abandon the bill.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Jan. 8 about two bombings in Afghanistan, one in Paktia Province and the other in neighboring Khost Province, misstated the area of Pakistan with which Paktia shares a border. It borders on the Kurram Agency, not North Waziristan.

headline: Kraft to Acquire Cadbury in Deal Worth $19 Billion
text: After months of fiercely resisting any deal, Cadbury agreed on Tuesday to an improved takeover offer from Kraft Foods, worth about $19 billion.

headline: Top Deputies Trading Places at City Hall
text: Moving to fulfill a promise made in his inaugural address, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday ordered that a top deputy in each city agency spend three weeks in another agency in an attempt to improve management habits.

headline: Corrections
Corrections
text: The Movie Box Office listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday reversed the revenue totals for “The Blind Side” and “Leap Year.” “Leap Year” was in eighth place with a weekly take of $5.9 million and overall revenue of $17.5 million in its two weeks of release. “The Blind Side” was in ninth place with a weekly take of $5.6 million and overall revenue of $226.8 million in nine weeks of release.

headline: A Leaner Budget for Lean Times
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York presented a lean budget on Tuesday that is a necessarily austere response to the state’s financial crisis. It is certain to make almost everybody unhappy.

headline: Secrets of the Immigration Jails
text: Americans have long known that the government has been running secretive immigration prisons into which detainees have frequently disappeared, their grave illnesses and injuries untreated, their fates undisclosed until well after early and unnecessary deaths.

headline: Policing Indecency
text: A few years ago, Cher, the entertainer, and Nicole Richie, the television personality, uttered brief expletives on separate music awards shows on Fox. The Federal Communications Commission ruled that the comments were indecent. A federal appeals court in New York is now considering the case. The court should rule that the F.C.C.’s decision violates the First Amendment.

headline: The Coal Ash Case
text: Just more than a year ago, one billion gallons of toxic coal sludge broke loose from a containment pond belonging to the Tennessee Valley Authority, burying hundreds of acres of Roane County in eastern Tennessee and threatening local water supplies and air quality. The Environmental Protection Agency immediately promised new national standards governing the disposal of coal ash to replace a patchwork of uneven  and in many cases weak  state regulations.

headline: Corrections
Rangers Go From Punchless to Offensive Force
text: Less than a week removed from a 172-minute goalless drought, the Rangers are suddenly behaving like an offensive juggernaut, racking up an 8-2 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Queens Man Is Accused in Plot to Kill U.S. Soldiers
text: A Queens College graduate who traveled to Pakistan in 2008 to attend a Qaeda training camp conspired to kill American service members in Afghanistan, a federal prosecutor said in court on Tuesday.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about San Diego’s departure from the N.F.L. playoffs on Sunday after it won its final 11 regular-season games described a key play incorrectly in some editions. Late in the third quarter, Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers threw a pass over the head of Vincent Jackson that was intercepted by the Jets; it did not sail over the head of Antonio Gates.

headline: Corrections
text: Picture credits in the Escapes pages on Friday with an article about unusual crops that are being grown in Hawaii misstated the photographer’s given name. He is Marco Garcia, not Mario.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a gene linked to compulsive behavior in dogs misspelled the surname of the actor who played Adrian Monk, the obsessive-compulsive detective in the television series “Monk.” He is Tony Shalhoub, not Shaloub.

headline: Lawyers Use Humor to Plead Case
text: THE adage about encountering the scene of a car accident  you don’t want to look, but can’t look away  may also apply to commercials for lawyers who represent victims of those accidents.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Friday, about faults, incorrectly described the location of Sichuan Province, the site of a 2008 earthquake. It is in southwestern China, not eastern China.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Year Later, Voters Send a Different Message
text: BOSTON  Special elections come and go. And the party that wins the White House one year ordinarily loses seats in the next Congressional election that comes along.

headline: A Pocket of Work in an Area of Joblessness
text: The metal factory in East New York, Brooklyn, could be a picture on an old postcard, one that captures the faith in industry and soaring optimism of the 1950s, accidentally left behind in a neighborhood that now is New York City’s capital of unemployment.

headline: Judge Upholds an Indictment in Letterman Extortion Case
text: A Manhattan judge on Tuesday upheld the indictment of an Emmy Award-winning television producer accused of trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman.

headline: Advocacy Groups Clash Over Future of Health Bill
text: Liberal advocacy groups are insisting that Democrats must press forward with efforts to overhaul the nation’s health care system despite the election results in Massachusetts on Tuesday night, while conservative groups are arguing that Scott Brown’s victory is proof that the Democrats’ health care bill is flawed and should be scuttled.

headline: Glacial Pace in Jury Selection for a Capital Murder Trial
text: NEW HAVEN  The first day of jury selection in the Cheshire triple murder case offered a taste of the intense emotions the case has brought to Connecticut, but ended without any jurors chosen in the capital murder trial.

headline: City Agrees to Conduct a Study on the Risks of PCBs in Schools
text: New York City school officials have agreed to assess the environmental risks posed by PCBs in school buildings and to come up with a plan for cleanups and for reducing potential exposure, federal officials said Tuesday.

headline: Outburst From Defendant in Afghan Shooting Trial
text: A Pakistani neuroscientist facing trial on charges that she tried to kill military officers and F.B.I. agents in Afghanistan erupted in a Manhattan courtroom and accused a witness of lying on Tuesday, as testimony began in her federal trial.

headline: A Big Band in Sync With the City
text: It took a good three or four minutes for the musicians to sidle to their places, arms filled with instruments and charts. Five saxophones. Four trombones and four trumpets. An acoustic bass. Congas. Bongos. The minor percussion  maracas and the guiro. The piano. And then, front and center, the lead man, in a throne of cymbals and foot pedals and drums.

headline: Wrangling in Albany Pushes State’s Request for School Aid to the Wire
text: ALBANY  Handing in its homework at almost the last minute, New York submitted an application to compete for $4 billion in federal education grants Tuesday, but without a charter school plan considered important to the bid.

headline: A Robber in the Village Who Looks Improbably Familiar
text: A mini-crime wave among the boutiques and specialty shops of Greenwich Village has a face, and it looks an awful lot like William S. Burroughs’s.

headline: O’Brien Continues Ribbing NBC as Deal Stalls
text: With the announcement of his contract settlement apparently stalled for another day, Conan O’Brien had one more opportunity to unleash some barbs toward NBC in his monologue Tuesday night. He even managed to dump on the network in Spanish.

headline: Remaking His Life After Nearly Losing It in Colombia
text: The motorcycle pulled alongside Carlos Martin’s Renault during a drive in Cartagena, Colombia. It was Dec. 18, 2000. Mr. Martin did not notice the bike, or the two men riding it, until they opened fire.

headline: George Jellinek, WQXR Opera Host, Dies at 90
text: George Jellinek, a former music director of the New York radio station WQXR and the host of a weekly program on opera singers and singing that ran on the station for 36 years, died on Saturday. He was 90 and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

headline: Your Trip Is Ready for Its Close-Up
text: Last week, as I walked through B & H, the giant electronics store in Midtown Manhattan in search of a strap for my wife’s camera, I made a quick stop in the video department to check on the Sanyo Xacti VPC-HD1010, the camera I bought a little over a year ago to record my Frugal Traveler adventures, like my family trip to Italy and several days of eating at Portland’s street carts.

headline: Scott Brown’s Victory Speech
text: The following is the prepared text of state Senator Scott Brown's remarks after winning the United States Senate race in Massachusetts, as provided by his campaign.

headline: India: A U.S. Promise on Afghanistan
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates assured Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India on Tuesday that the United States would not precipitously leave Afghanistan. A senior American defense official, quoting Mr. Gates, said that the defense secretary told Mr. Singh that “we intend to be in the region for a very long time.” President Obama has promised to begin troop withdrawals by July 2011. Mr. Gates and Mr. Singh talked about expanded cooperation between the two countries on military technology and cybersecurity. They also discussed China, whose growing influence in the region has increasingly concerned India’s leaders. Mr. Gates is in India for a two-day visit.

headline: Obama to Create Panel to Study Deficit
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to create a bipartisan commission to make recommendations to Congress on ways to reduce the federal budget deficit under an agreement reached Tuesday night at the White House.

headline: New Rules Set for H.M.O.’s in California
text: LOS ANGELES  Patients in health maintenance organizations in California should see their waiting times for doctors’ appointments reduced and even their telephone calls to physicians answered promptly under sweeping new rules that, for the first time, establish time standards in medical services.

headline: Carp DNA Is Found in Lake Michigan
text: CHICAGO  Genetic material from the Asian carp, a voracious invasive species long feared to be nearing the Great Lakes, has been identified for the first time at a harbor within Lake Michigan, near the Illinois-Indiana border, ecologists and federal officials said Tuesday.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Rangers and Sharks in Landslide Victories
text: Eight games on Tuesday night. The Rangers’ second straight goal deluge was probably the biggest story in the first part of the evening, and the Sharks’ second straight goal deluge was probably the biggest story in the second part. But that Sharks triumph also gave them first place over all in the N.H.L.

headline: Patience Pays Off in Kraft’s Pursuit
text: Sometimes the wait can be worth it. Kraft Foods’ sweetened offer for Cadbury followed four months of drooling over the British chocolatier that must have seemed like four years for Irene Rosenfeld, Kraft’s chief executive. But the delay had its benefits. Though the company will have to raise more money to pay for the final deal, that’s become easier and cheaper since Kraft made its bid.

headline: ‘American Idol’ 9 on 9: The Chicago Auditions
text: 12,000 contestants, 13 golden tickets: The Chicago auditions made for a ponderously dull night on “American Idol.” Despite Simon Cowell’s avowed distaste for country music, this episode featured the inimitable Shania Twain as a guest judge. The underwhelming lineup was perhaps payback. The two days of torture probably had Shania hopping the next plane back to La Tour-de-Peilz in Switzerland.

headline: Phys Ed: Will Olympic Athletes Dope if They Know It Might Kill Them?
text: In November, a study appeared in The New England Journal of Medicine that should give pause to many athletic dopers and those who love them. The study examined the effects of Darbepoetin Alfa, one of a class of drugs commonly known as Epo that is used to stimulate the body’s production of red blood cells. In the experiment, more than 4,000 patients with diabetes, kidney disease and anemia were given either Epo or a placebo. The researchers were testing the impact of the drug when it was used as approved, at moderate doses in sick people. What they found, to their surprise, was that slightly more of the patients taking Epo suffered heart attacks than those in the placebo group, that nearly twice as many suffered a stroke and that the Epo group’s self-reported quality of life, their subjective sense of fatigue and illness, was barely better than with placebo.

headline: Showcase: Wearing Down
text: Weather, time and general wear and tear take their toll on every kind of material, and the street is as a good a place to notice this as anywhere else. The sole of a businessman’s shoe in Lower Manhattan shows scuffs and the start of a hole. A close look at the sidewalk around Gramercy Park reveals the same thing is happening to bluestone as it is tread upon by millions of feet, decade after decade.

headline: Democrats Won’t Rush to Pass Senate Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Scott Brown’s decisive Senate victory in Massachusetts imperiled the fate of the Democratic health care overhaul in Tuesday as House Democrats indicated they would not quickly approve a Senate-passed health care measure and send it to President Obama.

headline: If Your Kids Are Awake, They’re Probably Online
text: The average young American now spends practically every waking minute  except for the time in school  using a smart phone, computer, television or other electronic device, according to a new study from the Kaiser Family Foundation.

headline: Word of the Day | supine
text: supine •\ˈsü-ˌpin\• adjective

headline: Credit Suisse Cuts Bonuses to Pay for British Tax
text: Credit Suisse says it will reduce its global bonus pool by 5 percent to pay for a new British tax on bonuses, but will cut deeper into the bonuses for its top managers in Britain.

headline: You Saw What in ‘Avatar’? Pass Those Glasses!
text: If you thought that “Avatar” was just a high-tech movie about a big-hearted tough guy saving the beguiling natives of a distant moon, you might want to check the prescription on your 3-D glasses.

headline: House Democrats Back Off Plan to Pass Senate Bill
text: House Democratic leaders appear to be backing away from a plan to ask their rank-and-file to approve the Senate version of major health care legislation and send the measure directly to President Obama for his signature.

headline: When Not in Rome ...
text: “Was New York City a better place when there were sad old men sitting at the bar in the lobby of the Gramercy alongside stooped former artist’s models, with smoke curling up toward the ceiling on exhalations of gin breath and despair?” asks Sam Sifton. “Probably not. But the era is worth recalling as you sit at Maialino, drinking prosecco or coffee and looking south toward Gramercy Park as cabs inch past.” The latest venture from the restaurateur Danny Meyer is a Roman-style trattoria at the Gramercy Park Hotel, whose name is Italian for little pig. Pork is of course on the menu, but so is stracciatella, the Roman chicken soup with thick strands of egg; cold antipasti; and entrees including “a moist and flavorful plate of swordfish with mushrooms and fennel fronds, and another of crisp deviled chicken with black pepper and pickled chilies.” Enjoy them at a table or at the bar, “long, wide and walnut, maybe the most cordial surface the designer, David Rockwell, has ever put into a restaurant.” Or try the restaurant’s pièce de résistance, maialino al forno. “The skin, blasted to crisp in a hot oven, is dusted in rosemary, cracked fennel, salt and pepper: an apparently unambitious preparation that tastes just great.”

headline: Opera Under the Stars
text: It doesn’t have an orchestra pit, a stage or proper lighting, but that didn’t deter the Gotham Chamber Opera’s artistic director Neal Goren from staging Haydn’s comedy “Il Mondo Della Luna” at the Hayden Planetarium’s dome at the American Museum of Natural History. “Doing this opera at the planetarium is a perfect way to marry arts and science,” said Mr. Goren in a recent article. The opera, about a strict father tricked by his daughters into believing that he has been transported to the moon, uses digital video projections provided by NASA, lasers and other spacey technologies to fuse music and stargazing. It runs through Jan. 28.

headline: Never Say Goodbye
text: Remember spending hours strolling through the old Tower Records store in the East Village, scanning the aisles for the latest Lemon Heads album or a potential love interest? Those days are long gone  as, thankfully, is our penchant for ’90s alternative rock  but for a few weeks you can revisit the feeling at the store’s old location on Broadway and East 4th Street, where the nonprofit group No Longer Empty has opened a multimedia art installation called “Never Can Say Goodbye.” The exhibition, by Ted Riederer, re-creates the store with record bins, album covers, music posters and a performance stage as well as works by Meredyth Sparks, Siebren Versteeg, Ryan Brennan and other artists, which touch on the history of the store, the changes in the music industry brought on by the Internet and how technology has transformed the art form. The installation, which is free and will feature live performances, runs through Feb. 13.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 8: A Proper Burial
text: Rob Harris joins a widow and her family on a pilgrimage to bury a loved one who died in last week's earthquake.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Europe, a Call to Follow Suit With Bank Tax
text: Sweden’s finance minister, Anders Borg, has called on his counterparts in Europe to follow President Obama’s lead with a supertax on banks to recoup the costs of propping up the industry, Reuters reported.

headline: Robert B. Parker, the Prolific Writer Who Created Spenser, Is Dead at 77
text: Robert B. Parker, the best-selling mystery writer who created Spenser, a tough, glib Boston private detective who was the hero of nearly 40 novels, died Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 77.

headline: As U.S. G.D.P. Shrinks, Merger Rules Shift
text: American antitrust regulators have lowered the dollar value of mergers that must be reported to the government to $63.4 million from $65.2 million, the Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday.

headline: News Quiz | January 20, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Kate McGarrigle, Canadian Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 63
text: Kate McGarrigle, a Canadian singer who, with her sister Anna, captivated critics and fellow musicians with warm harmonies and a style that drew on both folk traditions and the personalized approach of 1970s singer-songwriters, died on Monday at her home in Montreal. She was 63.

headline: Swimming With the Big Fish
text: WHOM do you know who has been scuba diving?

headline: Corrections
text: A brief report in Food Stuff last Wednesday about the extension of the Maine shrimp season this year misstated the last day of the harvest. It is May 29, not May 1.

headline: Letterman on the Jets’ Powers of Belief
text: They say there’s a fine line between confidence  and comedy. At least I think that’s what they say.

headline: Corrections
text: The Minimalist column last Wednesday, about the tri-tip cut of steak, misstated how many tri-tips can come from one animal. It is two, not one.

headline: Corrections
text: A recipe with The Temporary Vegetarian last Wednesday for kimchi pancakes omitted the amount of cayenne that may be substituted for Korean red pepper powder. It is one-half tablespoon. A corrected recipe can be found at nytimes.com/dining.

headline: What Exactly Happened When Gundlach Left?
text: Jeffrey Gundlach, the prominent bond fund investor who refers to himself as “The Godfather,” was storming around his office on Sept. 3, 2009, red-faced and fuming. He was anxious about his future at TCW Group, the Los Angeles firm where he had worked for almost 25 years, Reuters writes.

headline: Obama Pressing for Protections Against Lenders
text: President Obama on Tuesday stepped into the middle of a fierce lobbying battle by reinforcing his support for an independent agency to protect consumers against lending abuses that contributed to the financial crisis. The president’s move also signaled a tougher line and a more direct role as Congress weighs an overhaul of banking regulation, The New York Times’s Jackie Calmes and Sewell Chan write.

headline: Patience Pays Off in Kraft’s Pursuit
text: Sometimes the wait can be worth it. Kraft Foods’ sweetened offer for Cadbury followed four months of drooling over the British chocolatier that must have seemed like four years for Irene Rosenfeld, Kraft’s chief executive.

headline: Insider Faces Sentencing in ’07 Case
text: Update | 8:33 a.m.  with postponement of sentencing.

headline: South Korea Warns North on a First Nuclear Strike
text: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea would launch a pre-emptive conventional strike against the North if there were clear indications of an impending nuclear attack, the South Korean defense minister said Wednesday in Seoul, even as both countries were holding talks about improvements at their jointly operated industrial park.

headline: French Banks’ Role in A.I.G. Payout Questioned
text: Undermining a report that French banks were behind the New York Federal Reserve Bank’s payouts on American International Group, Bloomberg News writes that French lenders took haircuts on a similar deal in the same period.

headline: China Orders Some Banks to Rein in Loans
text: China has told some banks to limit lending and will restrict overall credit growth in the nation to 7.5 trillion renminbi ($1.1 trillion) this year, said the banking regulator, Liu Mingkang.

headline: 8 Arrested in Firebombing of Malaysian Churches
text: BANGKOK  Eight men were arrested on Wednesday in Malaysia in connection with the firebombing of a Pentecostal church last month, one in a series of attacks that has targeted a dozen Christian churches, the police said.

headline: Gates Warns of Militant Threat in South Asia
text: NEW DELHI  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates warned on Wednesday that the interconnected extremist groups on the Afghanistan-Pakistan border were working to destabilize the entire region and that “a victory for one was a victory for all.”

headline: Ontario Teachers Pension Plan Buys Acorn Care
text: One of Canada’s largest pension administrators, the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, has agreed to buy a leading British provider of special needs education for an undisclosed sum, Reuters reported.

headline: Stock Buybacks Back in Vogue in 2010?
text: Share buybacks by American corporations could be back in style this year, as an improving economy makes companies more willing to loosen their purse strings to fund transactions that could reward investors with a higher share price.

headline: What Are the Most Amazing Things You’ve Ever Seen in the Natural World?
text: A biologist writing in the Science Times talks about how “Avatar,” for her, “recreated what is the heart of biology: the naked, heart-stopping wonder of really seeing the living world.” When have you observed something in nature —whether a beautiful place, fascinating animal, spectacular storm or anything else large or small — that inspired wonder in you?

headline: Gacaca Courts
text: Open-air community trials in Rwanda, used to prosecute those accused of participating in the country’s 1994 genocide.[Gacaca derives from the Kinyarwanda word for “grass” or “lawn”.]

headline: Air France-KLM Said to Eye Polish Airline
text: Air France-KLM, the French-Dutch air carrier, may be interested in taking over the troubled Polish airline LOT, the Polish newspaper Dziennik reported Wednesday without naming sources.

headline: Takeovers — Do They Usually Do Harm?
text: Most takeovers end up doing more harm than good, The Daily Telegraph said in an editorial, because of the cuts that are necessary after a deal saddled the combined company with debt.

headline: V.C.’s Prescribe $8 Million for Orbis
text: Orbis Education, a developer of nursing-education software, has received $8 million in additional funding. Lightspeed Venture Partners led the Series B round of financing for the start-up, which is based in Indianapolis.

headline: Atlas Brings Its European Ops Back to Boston
text: Atlas Venture, the technology-focused venture capital firm, is bringing its European operations back to Boston, in a move to re-focus its strategy.

headline: Asia, not JAL, Is the Prize in Delta-American Fight
text: Japan Airlines isn’t the real prize in the fight between Delta Air Lines and American Airlines to become partners with the troubled carrier, The Associated Pres writes. The American carriers are after JAL’s Asian routes and the premium passengers that come with them.

headline: Paulson Said to Compete With ‘Emerging Managers’
text: John Paulson, the veteran hedge fund manager, will be vying with his former protege and other up-and-coming rivals for for investor money at an industry event next month, The New York Post reported, citing a “private and confidential” document.

headline: Showcase: Same Time, Last Year
text: On Jan. 20, 2009, the best possible thing happened to Luke Sharrett, a photojournalism major from Western Kentucky University who was in Washington to witness the inauguration of President Obama.

headline: U.S. Said to Score Premium from Banks on Warrants
text: The Treasury Department persuaded some big banks to pay more than market estimates to repurchase warrants issued to the government in the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a draft Treasury report.

headline: JPMorgan Said to Be in Exclusive Talks for Sempra
text: JPMorgan Chase has entered exclusive talks to buy the RBS Sempra commodities joint venture owned by Royal Bank of Scotland and Sempra Energy of the United States, people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Wednesday.

text: World markets dropped Wednesday, led by a near 3 percent tumble in Shanghai’s stock benchmark, as investors fretted about new curbs on the lavish bank lending that has driven China’s economic revival.

headline: Barclays May Face $27 Billion Deficit, Analysts Say
text: Facing a potential capital shortfall of £17 billion ($27.7 billion), Barclays may be forced to raise new funds from shareholders in order to avoid selling its stake in the money management firm BlackRock or canceling its recently reinstated dividend, Credit Suisse said Tuesday.

text: MANILA  The Philippines election commission cleared the way Wednesday for Joseph Estrada, a former president, to run for the office a second time.

headline: Goldman and Morgan Pay May Overshadow Results
text: Longtime rivals Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs  find themselves on different ends of the pay debate, as the surviving Wall Street titans prepare to disclose their fourth-quarter results, Reuters writes.

headline: Analysts Expect 4th Quarter Loss for BofA
text: Bank of America likely will post another loss when it reports fourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday, as banks continue to grapple with their problems loans and a weak economy, Reuters reported.

headline: Comparing 2009 Jets With 2000 Ravens
text: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net.  He also contributes at classactsports.com.

headline: Hong Kong’s Amazing Race
text: Hong Kong doesn’t have much in the way of professional sports, but it takes its horse racing very seriously. The racing season runs from September through July (it’s too hot in the summer), so this is just about midseason. The next major meet, at the Sha Tin track, is the first leg of Hong Kong’s Triple Crown on Jan. 31.

headline: Deglobalization? Forget It
text: Today’s idea: Reports of globalization’s recession-choked demise have been greatly exaggerated, an article says. It is actually stepping up its game.

headline: Attack of the Minimum-Wage Increase
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Hedge Funds Said to Bag $4.6 Billion in December
text: Total global hedge-fund assets grew by a hefty $4.6 billion in December, as the industry enjoyed its eighth straight month of capital growth, according to data released by Eurekahedge.

headline: Bomber’s Attempt Takes Center Stage on Capitol Hill

text: State Street, one of the world’s biggest institutional investors, said on Wednesday that fourth-quarter net income nearly doubled, beating market expectations, as assets under management climbed and the company cut costs, Reuters reported.

text: Kraft Foods and Cadbury saw their credit ratings cut to the lowest investment grade on Wednesday after Kraft won the backing of Cadbury’s board for its $19.6 billion takeover bid, Reuters reported.

headline: Bank of America Posts Loss for 4th Quarter
text: Update | 7:25 a.m. Strapped consumers continue to rain on Wall Street’s victory parade, but the deluge may be easing.

headline: Sampler: School Gardens Are in the Spotlight; Gavin Newsom Is Not
text: Gavin Newsom’s Next Career Move | In an interview with Maureen Dowd, Gavin Newsom jokes that his next career could be as “the clerk of a wine store.” He reviewed his political career and how the issue of same-sex marriage both put him into the national limelight but might have made it difficult for him to be seen as more than a single-issue candidate while running for governor in the past year. Daniel Weintraub, The Times’ Bay Area columnist, also commented on the mayor’s receding profile in Sunday’s report. The limelight has shifted several blocks away to a federal courthouse where the constitutionality of a state ban on same-sex marriage is being discussed. “This is it. God bless. It was fun while it lasted,” Mayor Newsom said of his career. “Guys like me don’t necessarily progress very far, which is fine.” [The New York Times]

headline: Alcon Directors Challenge Novartis’s Takeover Bid
text: The independent directors of Alcon, the eye-care products maker, said on Wednesday that they are challenging Novartis‘s bid to acquire full control of the company, calling its offer “grossly inadequate.”

text: The Bank of New York Mellon said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit surged as asset and wealth management revenue offset lower interest income, The Associated Press reported.

text: A day after gliding to 15-month highs, Wall Street stocks had their steepest losses since mid-December on Wednesday as investors fretted over lackluster profits and a slowdown in global lending.

headline: Man Surrenders in Virginia Killings
text: Just days before Christopher B. Speight surrendered to the police in connection with the killings of eight people in Appomattox County, Va., on Tuesday, co-workers said they had noticed that he had seemed sullen and on edge when he showed up for his job as a security guard at a small grocery store.

headline: Jan. 20: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
text: On Wedensday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of last week’s earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort. For updates from previous days see: Jan. 19 | Jan. 18 | Jan. 17 | Jan. 16 | Jan. 15 | Jan. 14 | Jan. 12 and 13

headline: Wild Edibles Settles With Workers’ Group Pushing Boycott
text: After filing for bankruptcy last July largely because of a boycott, Wild Edibles, one of New York’s leading seafood purveyors, has reached a tentative $340,000 settlement with the workers’ group that persuaded more than 70 restaurants to boycott the company.

headline: Nightmare in Haiti: Untreated Illness and Injury
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A strong aftershock rattled Haiti once again on Wednesday, causing even more physical damage and further traumatizing the jittery population. But the authorities said the biggest dangers now facing survivors of last week’s major earthquake were untreated wounds and rising disease, not falling debris.

headline: The Early Word: The Brown Effect
text: The effects of the stunning victory by Scott Brown are still settling in here in Washington  and in Massachusetts, with the Republican’s win signifying an end to the Democratic supermajority in the Senate and having major implications for the midterm elections.

headline: Wind Power Unreliable? Build More Turbines
text: One of the drawbacks to wind turbines is that while they may provide a lot of energy at times, they can never be counted on to provide energy in a pinch, a characteristic called “capacity.”

headline: Better Late Than Never? A Welcome Gift for Conan O’Brien
text: There’s been so much bad blood among the late-night hosts recently that it’s about time somebody did something nice for one of them. We turn the floor over to Norm Macdonald, who on Tuesday night finally brought Conan O’Brien the gift basket he’d been meaning to give the “Tonight Show” host since the summer.

headline: Home Construction Down Sharply in December
text: Home construction slowed more than expected in December, the government said on Wednesday, as high unemployment made builders nervous about the demand for new homes. Still, there were signs that future construction might pick up, helped by the lure of a government tax credit.

headline: From Struggling, Squabbling Albany, Bad News for Schools
text: Gov. David A. Paterson proposed on Tuesday what would be the largest cut to school aid in more than two decades and nearly $1 billion in new or increased taxes and fees as he unveiled his budget, a plan that is likely to be the first chapter in a prolonged battle with the Legislature.

headline: In a Family Emergency, Nurse or Wife?
text: My husband, Arthur, fell the Sunday before Christmas. He was walking the dog and slipped on a patch of black ice about a block from our house. Luckily, someone with a cellphone walked by and called our home.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Quarter Is Weak, Unlike Its Pay Pool
text: By almost any measure, 2009 was a lean year for Morgan Stanley  except when it came to pay.

headline: Dreams of a Sundance Bidding War
text: The Bagger has not even packed away our Southern California finery, and now we have to get ready to swaddle ourselves in down for the Sundance Film Festival. (We know, you’re crying for us.)

headline: The Perfect Trail: A Few Clicks Away
text: Let’s say you have a business trip to Knoxville, Tenn. coming up and you’d like to do an easy hike — say about seven miles — in the Great Smoky Mountains, about 45 miles away. But you’ve never hiked south of the Mason-Dixon line. How does one find such a trail?

headline: Supported by Brown, Massachusetts Reform Was a Model for Democrats in Washington
text: Senator-elect Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said in his victory speech that he is anxious to get to Washington and start his new job. But Mr. Brown, who owes his victory to independent voters, will quickly find himself at the center of a partisan typhoon over the fate of the major health care legislation.

headline: Vietnam, Quelling Dissent, Gives 4 Democracy Advocates Jail Terms
text: BANGKOK  Four democracy advocates in Vietnam were convicted Wednesday in a closely watched trial of trying to overthrow the state, prosecuted as part of campaign against dissent that has led to dozens of arrests in recent months.

headline: Hands-On | The Gropius Touch
text: When was the last time you looked at a piece of paper? Eight and a half by 11, unmarked, unblemished copy paper. That was the first task for the 20 students (and one architecture and design curator) at the Museum of Modern Art’s Bauhaus Lab last week. The workshop was one of a series that are being held in conjunction with the exhibition “Bauhaus 1919-1933: Workshops for Modernity,” which closes on Jan. 25. “Shout out your first thoughts,” said Ati Gropius Johansen, the daughter of the pioneering Modernist architect and Bauhaus founding director Walter Gropius, who was teaching the Three-Dimensional Workshop. Five people immediately said, “White.”The students were arrayed around a flower-shaped table in the atrium of the museum’s education wing. Johansen had placed one sheet of paper in the center. “What else?” she asked. “It has four sides.” “It has 90-degree angles.” “It is flat.” This last response interested Johansen. She reclined gently on the table. “How is it lying? If this were a person, what would you find yourself doing to it?” Another student blurted out, “It is like a baby.” After 10 more minutes of discussion, Johansen sent the students off with the instruction to create the biggest change in the paper with the least action: one fold, one roll, one rip.

headline: Three Experts, Three Views on Collector Car Trends
text: PHOENIX – Car collectors from around the world are either here in Arizona’s Valley of the Sun (where it’s raining, with more precipitation forecast throughout the week), or they are tuned in via television, telephone or the Internet as some 3,000 vehicles of special interest and historic value are up for auction at a variety of venues.

headline: The Times to Charge for Frequent Access to Its Web Site
text: Taking a step that has tempted and terrified much of the newspaper industry, The New York Times announced on Wednesday that it would charge some frequent readers for access to its Web site  news that drew ample reaction from media analysts and consumers, ranging from enthusiastic to withering.

headline: Buffett Is No Fan of Kraft-Cadbury Deal
text: Earlier this month, Warren E. Buffett fired an unusual shot across Kraft‘s bow: a public statement warning the American food giant not to overpay in its pursuit of Cadbury, and a threat to reject the company’s plans to issue up to 370 million new shares as part of the deal.

headline: Gas Drilling Techniques Under Fire … Again
text: Federal government oversight of hydraulic fracturing – a drilling technique that boosts natural gas extraction by blasting water, sand and chemicals underground at high pressure – is sorely lacking, putting drinking water supplies at risk, an environmental policy group claimed in a report released Tuesday.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Victory Stuns Democrats
text: BOSTON  Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state senator, rode an old pickup truck and a growing sense of unease among independent voters to an extraordinary upset Tuesday night when he was elected to fill the Senate seat that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy in the overwhelmingly Democratic state of Massachusetts.

headline: Wednesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Brown: ‘People Are Angry’
text: In an interview with NBC‘s “Today” show Wednesday morning, Senator-elect Scott Brown was asked if his victory was a referendum on President Obama.

headline: Answers About New York City’s High Schools
text: This week, Clara Hemphill, whose book series New York City’s Best Schools is regarded as the bible for navigating school choices, responded to readers’ questions about the high school admissions process and the myriad choices in the city.

text: Richard Pérez-Peña writes:

headline: Fools On The Hill
text: So, will health care reform fail because a lazy candidate didn’t bother campaigning and didn’t know her Red Sox? (Yes, there were national factors at work, but Nate Silver makes it clear that a better candidate would have won easily). It’s up to the House, which can and should just pass the Senate bill.

headline: Massachusetts Upset
text: Teacher’s Note: In case you’re talking about this news in class today, we’re publishing tomorrow’s ‘6 Q’s’ early.

headline: Officials Regret Curbs on Adding to Terror Watch List
text: WASHINGTON  Restrictions put into place last year that limit how people are added to terrorist watch lists unintentionally compromised the nation’s ability to prevent attacks, the Obama administration’s top counterterrorism officials testified Wednesday.

headline: Time For The Re-Set Button
text: There’s a scenario, believe it or not, in which Scott Brown’s stunning win last night could actually end up forestalling a massive G.O.P. sweep next November. It involves Barack Obama swallowing his pride, behaving like a President who’s just been thumped, and making a very public show of internalizing the lessons of last night in Massachusetts. And it involves dismissing, immediately and with prejudice, the liberal fantasy that Rahm Emanuel should spend the next few weeks “knocking heads together” in the House, in the hopes of pushing the Senate bill through Congress.

headline: A Note on Financial Reform
text: Whatever happens on health care — if House Democrats have any sense, they’ll just pass the Senate bill, but that’s a big if — financial reform is next up. But that leaves us with a question: what strategy should the Democrats follow?

headline: Interviews for Joan, but Not for John
text: Men may be discriminated against in job applications in female-dominated fields, a new working paper from Australia finds.

headline: In Defense of ‘Pants on the Ground’
text: I think it was Samuel Johnson who said that when a man is tired of “Pants on the Ground,” he is tired of life.

headline: Jobs Not Created
text: This CBO report on job creation leaves me a bit angry — not at CBO, but at SAOs (senior administration officials). Here’s a chart showing CBO estimates of jobs per buck from various employment-creating policies.

headline: Forest Carbon Offsets in the Ozarks
text: CE2 Carbon Capital, an investor in carbon emissions reduction projects, and Dogwood Carbon Solutions, an agency that helps private landowners gain access to the carbon credits market, announced last week that they have joined forces to develop carbon offsets on 300,000 acres of forest land in the Ozark mountain region of Missouri and Arkansas.

text: I am not happy about plans to create an independent deficit-reduction commission. text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: I just read President Obama plans to deliver his State of the Union address next Wednesday, Jan. 27. Until then, he’s just at home going: “Please everything get better by Wednesday. Please everything get better by Wednesday.”

headline: ‘Appearing Before Homeland Security’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: You know up in Massachusetts, the big election, are you following what’s going on up there? Ted Kennedy’s Senate seat is now up for grabs. The election is pretty close. I was thinking, you know, my money is on Jay Leno.

headline: Understanding the A.I.G. Dispute
text: If you want to understand why Congress and the public remain focused and angry about the bailout of the American International Group, you must read the statement released Tuesday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The statement is a game defense of the New York Fed’s role in A.I.G.’s disclosure of the Fed’s purchase of credit default swaps at approximately par value for a total of $61.9 billion. In fact, you can feel the frustration of the New York Fed in the statement as it strives to show just how transparent it is trying to be.

headline: At Australian Open, Belgian Women May Face Off
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  They are working their way to each other, Kim Clijsters and Justine Henin, a pair of Belgian women who know each other well. Clijsters did not have to sweat much to keep their appointment in the quarterfinals. She dusted Tamarine Tanasugarn  6-3, 6-3  in the second round of the Australian Open here Wednesday.

headline: ‘The Shady Lady’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Well, all the major airlines have raised their fees to check in baggage. In fact, it’s getting so expensive now to bring bags on board, even people who aren’t terrorists are stuffing things into their underpants.

headline: Grammys Plan a 3-D Tribute to Michael Jackson
text: Michael Jackson‘s ability to provide audiences with technologically innovative, over-the-top spectacles has in no way been curtailed by his death. The coming Grammy Awards ceremony will include a special tribute to the King of Pop featuring a portion that will be broadcast in 3-D, the Recording Academy said on Wednesday.

headline: Obama’s Nominee for T.S.A. Withdraws
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s nominee to head the Transportation Security Administration, Erroll Southers, withdrew his name on Wednesday, saying that Republicans had politicized the appointment. The withdrawal was a setback for Mr. Obama’s efforts to allay concerns about airline security after several highly publicized breaches.

headline: It’s on the Web: Concacaf U-20 Women
text: Concacaf, the regional confederation that includes the United States, bolsters its embrace of technology when it begins its Web coverage Wednesday afternoon of the regional U-20 qualifying tournament for the 2010 FIFA Under-20 Women’s World Cup this summer in Germany (Bochum, Bielefeld, Augsburg and Dresden).

headline: Big Oil Pursues Toreador Resources
text: Several big energy conglomerates are in initial discussions to buy or partner with the Toreador Resources Corporation, an independent oil and natural gas company that operates primarily in France, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

text: Update: We’ve posted additional information on M.B.A. tuition deductions here.

headline: Calm Returns to Torn Nigerian City; Toll Unclear

headline: Group Hug | Dsquared, D&G, Giorgio Armani and Z Zegna
text: MILAN — The men’s shows here ended with four radically different points of view. At Dsquared, Bill Kaulitz, the lead singer of the band Tokio Hotel, led a gang of bloodied, bare-chested hockey players — leaving some wondering whether the N.H.L. should consider a uniform of patent leather shorts, destroyed jeans with dangling chains and silver mesh tees. For D&G, the sport of choice was skiing, which provided a nifty excuse to layer the chunky knits, oversize parkas and furry hats that have been so prevalent. Giorgio Armani, on the other hand, kept his loose, fluid tailoring clean, though he did accessorize every look with bookish glasses and berets. And Z Zegna closed the week with snazzy suits with exposed seams, the better to reveal the quality and precision of the house’s sartorial skills. Take a look at our slide show and tell us who you think capped off Milan best.

headline: The Coach in the Machine
text: Sometime recently when we weren’t paying attention  perhaps we were distracted by Peyton Manning’s presnap histrionics or by trying to keep an accurate count of Tiger Woods’s mistresses  sports were completely taken over by coaches. This is not a good thing.

headline: Dialing in a Plan: The Times Installs a Meter on Its Future

headline: A Reluctant Retailer Decides to Open Her Books

Ms. Chambers, who was 23 at the time, had taken a chance by opening a retail shop in Springfield, Mo., called Staxx. She believed in the revitalization of the downtown area of the city and she was one of the first businesses to strike out there – something that earned her quite a bit of press and recognition.

headline: Longevity at the Opera: The Domingo Phenomenon
text: Plácido Domingo, who holds the job of general director at both the Washington National Opera and the Los Angeles Opera, is at the Metropolitan Opera to conduct and sing. As Daniel J. Wakin reported recently, Mr. Domingo “says he took the general director jobs with the thought of pursuing a second career after retiring from the stage. But his remarkably healthy and still-lustrous voice kept him in the performing game. ‘I cannot betray the singer,’ he said. ‘I won’t sing one day more than I should, but also I won’t sing one day less than I can.’ ”

headline: Genuine Actress Flirts With Stardom
text: IF you were to choose one article of clothing to represent Laura Linney, it would have to be the little black dress. Simple, elegant, appropriate for any occasion. Add a white pilgrim’s bonnet and a long apron, and Ms. Linney is transformed into the nobly suffering Elizabeth Proctor in Arthur Miller’s “Crucible.” Dress it up with pearls, a slash of red lipstick and Manolos, and she is a high-strung Upper East Side wife in the 2007 film “The Nanny Diaries.” Include a scarf, a camera bag and a crutch, and she becomes Sarah Goodwin, the recuperating war photographer in Donald Margulies’s new play “Time Stands Still,” opening on Broadway Thursday at the Manhattan Theater Club’s Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Shocking! | The Proto-TMZ
text: There are excerpts in “Shocking True Story” (Pantheon), a new history of the infamous and influential celebrity-scandal rag Confidential, that should strike you as straight out of a James Ellroy novel: the built-up glitz and the hard-boiled sleaze, to start, as well as something about the language — full of implication and insinuation, and as tart and pulpy as a blood orange. The author, Henry E. Scott, writes in the book’s acknowledgments that he was reading Ellroy’s “L.A. Confidential” when he became inspired to write about the magazine — which for five years in the 1950s incited paranoia in Hollywood’s bedrooms and boardrooms with tightly sourced, stylized accounts of celebrity indiscretion. At the New York-based magazine’s height — which is to say just before its downfall at the hands of Tinseltown attorneys — it enjoyed a circulation of 9 million. Its pages laid the groundwork for the National Inquirer, E! and US Weekly; indeed, where once went Confidential, now goes TMZ.Not unlike an Ellroy novel, “Shocking True Story” sometimes delights in the macabre, particularly in the long passages it lifts from Confidential’s pages. One article, from the magazine’s November 1954 issue, could almost describe a Jacques-Louis David painting from 150 years earlier: “Police found her nude body in the bathroom of her San Francisco apartment. There was a grim touch of neatness, even comfort, in the way she had met death. After filling the tub with water, she had arranged a stack of pillows around the edge and drowned herself.” The woman’s name was Dr. Jean S. Tatlock, and she was a communist. She killed herself in 1944, some six months after an overnight rendezvous with her former boyfriend, Dr. Robert Oppenheimer. This wasn’t news by late 1954, but it did endear Confidential’s charismatic, power-peddling owner, Robert Harrison, to J. Edgar Hoover’s F.B.I. and the forces of McCarthyism, who at a public hearing earlier that year stripped Oppenheimer of his Atomic Energy Commission security clearance.

headline: Coasting Into Spring
text: Wednesday’s sweater weather notwithstanding, blizzards and ice may yet lie ahead, but take heart: the dead of winter is behind us. Statistically speaking, at least. Jan. 19 has the lowest average temperatures of the year in New York City — a low of 26 degrees and a high of 37, according to AccuWeather.com. The average high and low for Jan. 20 both leap upward by three-tenths of a degree.

headline: Vampire Weekend’s ‘Contra’ Is No. 1
text: Let’s hear it for blogs, cable-knit sweaters and Morningside Heights: Vampire Weekend, the band of Columbia University graduates that began its rise to indie-rock fame long before it had released any recordings, has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with its second album, “Contra” (XL). Issued last week, “Contra” sold 124,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, giving it an easy victory over Susan Boyle’s “I Dreamed a Dream” (Syco Music/Columbia), at No. 2 with 77,000 sales, and Ke$ha’s “Animal” (Kemosabe/RCA), which fell two spots to No. 3 with 67,000.

headline: Obsessions | Dave’s Killer Bread
text: When I hear the phrase “organic bread,” I think of a funky, hairy person in sandals toiling away proudly in a heated adobe hut someplace in, oh, say, Vermont. I usually don’t think of a methamphetamine addict — does he even eat? — let alone a convict serving hard prison time. Which is why I was surprised to discover that one of the best commercially available organic breads — in my opinion — is manufactured by a convicted felon and former meth addict from Oregon named Dave Dahl.

text: The Bay Area blog has been reporting three times daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiff’s team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

headline: James Patterson Inc.
text: Like most authors, James Patterson started out with one book, released in 1976, that he struggled to get published. It sold about 10,000 copies, a modest, if respectable, showing for a first novel. Last year, an estimated 14 million copies of his books in 38 different languages found their way onto beach blankets, airplanes and nightstands around the world. Patterson may lack the name recognition of a Stephen King, a John Grisham or a Dan Brown, but he outsells them all. Really, it’s not even close. (According to Nielsen BookScan, Grisham’s, King’s and Brown’s combined U.S. sales in recent years still don’t match Patterson’s.) This is partly because Patterson is so prolific: with the help of his stable of co-authors, he published nine original hardcover books in 2009 and will publish at least nine more in 2010.

headline: The Great Unalignment
text: This time last winter, Democratic Washington was crackling with confident talk of a progressive re-awakening in the land and an enduring Congressional majority. “Realignment” was the word of the moment, as in the kind of demographic and ideological shift that shaped the nation’s politics for some 60 years after the election of Franklin Roosevelt. Now Democrats are trying to figure out how they lost what was presumed to be the safest Senate seat in the country — it belonged to Ted Kennedy for 46 years — and how to avoid hemorrhaging others. A year after George W. Bush’s chopper swung away from the Capitol and disappeared from sight, voters seem to have put his presidency behind them; they’re no longer willing to blame Republicans alone for high unemployment and rising gas prices, for home foreclosures and tuition hikes. The crises that Bush bequeathed to Democrats have now officially become theirs, and the notion of a great liberal realignment seems as retro as Friendster. A string of Democratic lawmakers, largely from rural and contested states, the kind of places that were supposed to now be more hospitable to Democrats than they were before, recently decided to pursue other careers rather than risk being turned out by wrathful voters. Party leaders who had once hoped to expand their majorities in November are now showing signs of panic as they scramble to stave off the prospect of crippling losses.

headline: Britain Tightens Antiterror Measures on Air Travel

headline: A Renewed and Improved Henin
text: The luck of the draw was very unkind to Elena Dementieva, who fought for nearly three hours in her Australian Open loss to Justine Henin last night. The match could easily have been a Grand Slam semifinal, and the level of play by Henin, now starting what she calls her “second career” in tennis, astonished the capacity crowd at Rod Laver Arena. There was no sign that she’s playing in only her second tournament since announcing her comeback. In fact, a case can be made that Henin 2.0 is an improved version of the former world No. 1.

headline: Berkshire Holders Approve 50-to-1 Stock Split
text: Berkshire Hathaway said Wednesday that its shareholders had approved splitting the company’s class B shares 50-for-1 as part of the company’s $26.3 billion acquisition of Burlington Northern Santa Fe, the nation’s second-largest railroad.

headline: What Kind of Weather Makes News?
text: Growing up in Chicago, I knew that a “partly sunny” forecast meant gray skies. And a “partly cloudy” forecast meant gray skies. The kind of wind that could turn your umbrella inside out was to be expected (just point the top toward the wind and move along).

headline: Crunching the Numbers
text: As the Saturday deadline for turning in Oscar ballots looms, some voters are having a difficult time coming up with the 10 best picture nominees, reports Pete Hammond at The Los Angeles Times. “I can barely find five movies to nominate; I have no idea what to do for 10,” one member told him.

headline: City Near Deal for New Coney Island Operator
text: Updated, 3:06 p.m.| It looks like Coney Island will not go without a whirling, clanging amusement park and a crop of new rides for the first time in more than a century as many had feared. The city’s Economic Development Corporation is negotiating a lease with an amusement park operator, Zamperla USA, for six vacant acres in the heart of what has been the amusement district, between Surf Avenue and the ocean.

text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, cracking down on tax cheats, said on Wednesday that the federal government would no longer award contracts to companies that did not pay their taxes, and called on Congress to pass legislation allowing the Internal Revenue Service to share information about businesses that owe back taxes.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: 1) Clay Shirky argues that women are less likely to succeed in the workplace because they are “bad at behaving like self-promoting narcissists, antisocial obsessives, or pompous blowhards, even a little bit, even temporarily, even when it would be in their best interests to do so.”

headline: Where Giants Dance and Crash in Japan
text: AT the edge of the balcony, a tiny woman was screaming. The elderly couple in the next row were jumping up and down. Below us, all around the ring at the Kokugikan, Japan’s national sumo stadium in Tokyo, a roaring crowd hurled seat cushions into the air. My husband and I looked at each other in amazement. After two weeks of travel among the intently well-behaved, rigorously unflappable Japanese, were we about to have a peek behind that decorous facade?

headline: Obama: Seat Brown Before Moving Ahead on Health Care Bill
text: President Obama said today that Democratic leaders in Congress should not try to “jam” the health care bill through in the coming days, saying that lawmakers should wait to move forward on the legislation until Republican Senator-elect Scott Brown of Massachusetts is seated.

headline: Laura Chapman Hruska, Co-Founder of Soho Press, Dies at 74
text: Laura Chapman Hruska, a founder and the editor in chief of Soho Press, an independent book publisher that specializes in literary fiction and exotic crime stories, died on Jan. 9 at her home in Manhattan. She was 74.

headline: Scorecard | Gucci Wins!
text: We must be in the full swing of Milan fashion week because, as Scorecard knows, when it comes to Monday’s shows critics weren’t afraid to let the barbs fly — yet somehow they never all quite seemed to agree. With rocker-chic faves Gucci and Versace going head to head, who came out ahead? We’ll give the win to Frida Giannini for her unexpected play of going back to Gucci’s pre-Ford-era heritage (there’s that word again!), but tell us, do you agree?

headline: Conan Surges in the Ratings Among Young Viewers

headline: Defendant in Afghan Shooting Trial Vows No More Outbursts

text: There was no real reason for Kenny Lofton to retire after the 2007 season. He was 40 years old, but he was still good. He had just played a full season and hit .290 with a .367 on-base percentage for Texas and Cleveland, helping the Indians come within a game of the World Series.

headline: The Savory Take on Fruit Salad
text: The citrus salad that is the subject of this week’s Minimalist column began life as a dessert. But as I played around with it, I realized that I liked it more the sharper I made it, and that I had already done something similar in a dessert form. So — I went with the savory dish.
