headline: Video Games | Loeffler Randall’s Spring 2010 Look Book
text: Fashion’s forays in the digital realm have been as uneven as a pre-braces overbite, but that’s not to say there haven’t been some noteworthy developments filling in the gaps. The SoHo-based label Loeffler Randall recently unveiled a slick Web site featuring shots by the photographer Jamie Isaia, and now the collaborative duo has followed up with a spring 2010 look book. Rather than go for the usual commercial shots, the designer Jessie Randall gave Isaia “creative license to bring her vision” to the project. The multimedia artist ran with the free rein — with the realist painter William-Adolphe Bouguereau’s sense of motion and rosy tableaus in mind — by shooting the brand’s first video look book, making its debut above.

headline: Lost in Translation
text: Bulgarians have something to celebrate today, as the country’s entry into the Oscar pool for foreign-language film, “The World Is Big and Salvation Lurks Around the Corner,” has advanced to another round. Eight other films made the shortlist, and as usual, there were some high-profile omissions. Those that made it include selections from Israel (“Ajami”), Kazakhstan (“Kelin”), the Netherlands (“Winter in Wartime”) and Peru (“The Milk of Sorrow”). The two most-well known films on these shores are Michael Haneke’s “The White Ribbon,” the German entry, and “A Prophet,” (“Un prophète”) by Jacques Audiard from France. Both received rapturous reviews and the bulk of attention from other awards and critics groups.

text: MUNICH  After an unidentified man’s laptop set off alarms at Munich’s international airport Wednesday indicating the possible presence of explosives, the traveler simply picked up the computer, walked into the crowded departure terminal and disappeared, touching off the fourth airport security scare in a month.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks New Charges Against Rajaratnam
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission wants to expand its lawsuit in the widening Galleon Group insider-trading investigation by adding new charges against two defendants, Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund’s billionaire founder, and Anil Kumar, a former director of McKinsey & Company.

headline: Nature’s Call: Drawing Inspiration From ‘Avatar’ to Study and Create Organisms
text: Overview | Does seeing the unusual flora and fauna in the movie “Avatar” inspire a sense of wonder at the natural world? How might the film awaken interest in plant and animal life on Earth? In this lesson, students reflect on their experiences with nature, compare it to their impressions of the fictional Pandora and then use their observation and research skills skills to investigate awe-inspiring living things here on Earth. They then construct fantastical beings using features of the organisms they studied.

headline: ‘The Pitmen Painters’ Coming to Broadway
text: The acclaimed London production of “The Pitmen Painters,” about a group of British miners who become artists, will transfer to the Broadway house of the Manhattan Theater Club in September, the theater company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Aid Urged for Groups Fighting Internet Censors
text: Five United States senators are publicly urging Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to move faster to support organizations that are helping people in countries like Iran and China circumvent restrictions on Internet use.

headline: Snack Time Never Ends
text: In the article “Snack Time Never Ends,” Jennifer Steinhauer writes about how snacking seems both mandatory and constant for American children. She writes, “Apparently, we have collectively decided as a culture that it is impossible for children to take part in any activity without simultaneously shoving something into their pie holes.”

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A man walks through the Delaram district at sunset in southern Afghanistan’s Nimroz Province.

headline: The Doctor Can See You Now
text: PLASTIC surgeons used to dispense advice primarily in private, face-to-face consultations, during which they would address a patient’s concerns and weigh the merits of surgery.

headline: Should Surgeons Meet Patients Online?
text: IMAGINE the ease. It’s 2 a.m. and you can’t stop thinking about your saggy midsection. You log on to SurgeonHouseCall.com and create a free patient profile declaring your wish to get a tummy tuck. You fill out a brief medical history and include photographs of the problem area.

headline: An Improbable Drive That Changed the Postseason
text: A Fifth Down reader, Marc Straus of Atlanta, sends in this highlight from the 2009 season:

headline: G.O.P. Used Energy and Stealth to Win Seat
text: This article is by Adam Nagourney, Jeff Zeleny, Kate Zernike and Michael Cooper.

headline: Roddick Shows a New Patience on Court
text: Andy Roddick dispatched the young Brazilian lefty Thomaz Bellucci in three workmanlike sets in the Hisense Arena in their second-round match. The match statistics tell a convincing story, that Roddick overwhelmed and outclassed Bellucci, winning 78 percent of points on his first serve and an incredible 75 percent of points on his second serve. He hit 11 aces and served no double-faults.

headline: Seating Senator-elect Brown
text: BOSTON — Senator-elect Scott Brown plans to head to Washington Thursday, hoping to pave the way to be sworn in as soon as possible.

headline: Trying to Make the Decision to Expand
text: We just published a small-business case study written by Adriana Gardella that reviews the expansion plans of Thinking Caps Tutoring, which offers personalized coaching, tutoring, and SAT preparation to about 300 students in public and private middle and high schools annually. Below are the analyses of several business owners with related experience:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Jan. 20
text: Desperation and relief are the counterpoised themes from Haiti at the beginning of Wednesdsay’s show. Ruth Fremson’s composition is the perfect visual expression of the term “bottleneck.” But Chris Hondros of Getty Images has captured what may be one of the first moments of unalloyed delight since last Tuesday.

headline: From Life’s Assembly Line: Hits, Push-Button or Not
text: Tyne Daly isn’t the first performer to reflect on the alarming way time seems to accelerate as the years pass. But her whip-smart, sophisticated new cabaret act, “The Second Time Around,” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, explores the concept with wit and musical know-how along with an attitude of amused resignation. If modern life seems more and more like a science-fiction fantasy in which we are moving at what she calls “warp speed,” so be it; what other choice is there?

headline: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 4
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: YouTube Takes a Small Step Into the Film Rental Market
text: SAN FRANCISCO  YouTube made its long-awaited entry on Wednesday into the business of online movie rentals. But do not expect to be able to stream to your PC the latest Hollywood blockbuster or even a flick from a studio’s dusty catalog of classics.

headline: The Way We Ate: Too Old to Tiki?
text: In 1994, Ruth Reichl announced that New York had outgrown tiki bars. Her review of Gauguin, a French-Polynesian fusion palace that briefly occupied the basement of the Plaza Hotel, ended on the image of two exiting customers: a delighted child and her somber father. He was somber, perhaps, because he had had to foot the bill in a restaurant that paid rent to Donald Trump. More important, he was too old to believe in “silly drinks and fake palms.”

headline: A New Comment System for ‘By the Numbers’
text: Hello “By the Numbers” readers! This is Hilary, Charles’s assistant, with some tech news:

headline: Moon as Setting for Earthly Foibles
text: Haydn at the Hayden. The idea was terrific.

headline: Bloomberg Cheers for Jets, and Quinn Wants a Recount
text: Sure, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may have a little experience throwing out first pitches or tossing ticker-tape celebrations for triumphant championship teams. But maybe he should leave the cheerleading to Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker.

headline: Comment of the Week
text: As disturbing as the graphic is, it is exceptionally well conceived. The minarets, as pointed out, resemble missiles, and I would argue that the message conveyed isn’t that Sharia law is the next step, but that Switzerland will become a war zone. This is powerful propaganda and succeeds because of its fear-inspiring forms. Unfortunately tolerance, sweetness and reason tend to have far less dramatic images to promote them, and hence they lose in the battle for emotional resonance.

headline: Megyn Kelly Gets Her Own Afternoon Program on Fox News
text: Megyn Kelly’s profile has risen a bit higher at the Fox News Channel.

headline: Pushing Back: Jazz Notes Against the Current
text: The young pianist Aaron Diehl is putting his talent against the odds. What he’s up to with his trio, which played at Smalls on Tuesday night, isn’t new in the temporal sense or “new” in the art-movement sense, which is to say it isn’t confrontational or puzzling.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: After filing for bankruptcy last July largely because of a boycott, Wild Edibles, one of New York’s leading seafood sellers, has reached a tentative $340,000 settlement with the workers’ group that persuaded more than 30 restaurants to boycott the company.

headline: Shopping With Enrico Bonetti and Dominic Kozerski
text: The New York-based designers sought out birdhouses and feeders that would appeal to birds and people alike.

headline: Christie Channels His Inner Bruce
text: He was sworn in as the Boss of New Jersey state government Tuesday afternoon, so who could blame Christopher J. Christie  – a devout fan of Bruce Springsteen, the state’s rock star laureate – from celebrating the occasion by taking the stage a few hours later at his inaugural party and belting out a few Springsteen songs?

headline: Cheep Chic
text: BIRDHOUSES don’t usually get as much attention from designers as human houses do, but there’s no reason birds shouldn’t have some style at home.

headline: Children Speak for Same-Sex Marriage
text: LAST month, advocates and opponents of same-sex marriage packed the New Jersey State House in Trenton, supporters in blue, opponents in red. Near the end of the day, Kasey Nicholson-McFadden took the microphone. “It doesn’t bother me to tell kids my parents are gay,” he said in a clear voice. “It does bother me to say they aren’t married. It makes me feel that our family is less than their family.”

headline: Putting the Indie Back in Sundance
text: LOS ANGELES  Can Sundance’s new director redefine not just the festival but also the entire independent film industry?

headline: Polling on Health Care — Divided and Unchanged
text: Despite yesterday’s special election in Massachusetts and the ensuing assessments that the election was a referendum on health care reform, a spate of recent national polls signal that little has changed the public’s mind over the last six months. Americans have remained divided over the health care legislation, without significant shifts.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Deep End'
text: The ABC legal drama follows first-year attorneys and the bosses that torment them.

headline: Obama Weighs Paring Goals for Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama signaled on Wednesday that he might be willing to scale back his proposed health care overhaul to a version that could attract bipartisan support, as the White House and Congressional Democrats grappled with a political landscape transformed by the Republican victory in the Massachusetts Senate race.

headline: In Shift, U.S. Lifts Visa Curbs on Professor
text: LONDON  Six years after using the Patriot Act to revoke the visa of a prominent Muslim academic, the United States State Department reversed itself and said Wednesday that it would no longer bar the scholar from entering the United States.

headline: Mixing Bits From Columns A and B
text: When we complain that an artist is unoriginal, what do we mean? Some of the most original artists have not been among the greatest. Virgil, Shakespeare, Mozart, Balanchine were all heavily derivative.

headline: A 3-D Tribute Planned for Jackson at Grammys
text: Michael Jackson’s ability to provide audiences with technologically innovative, over-the-top spectacles has not been curtailed by his death. The coming Grammy Awards ceremony will include a special tribute to the King of Pop, featuring a portion that will be broadcast in 3-D, the Recording Academy said on Wednesday. It’s not quite the return of “Captain EO,” the 3-D movie starring Jackson that was shown at Disney theme parks in the 1980s. But the Grammy Awards, which will be shown Jan. 31 on CBS, will honor Mr. Jackson with a performance that will show a short 3-D film, set to his “Earth Song,” that was originally being prepared for the This Is It tour he was rehearsing at the time of his death in June. The academy said that special 3-D glasses for this portion of the broadcast will be given out at Target stores (and of course to the audience members watching the Grammys at the Staples Center in Los Angeles). Other performers who will also participate in the tribute include Celine Dion and Smokey Robinson, above, as well as Jennifer Hudson, Carrie Underwood and Usher.

headline: Vampire Weekend’s ‘Contra’ Is No. 1 Album
text: Let’s hear it for blogs, cable-knit sweaters and Morningside Heights: Vampire Weekend, above, the band of Columbia University graduates that began its rise to indie-rock fame long before it had released any recordings, has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with its second album, “Contra” (XL). Issued last week, “Contra” sold 124,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, giving it an easy victory over Susan Boyle’s “I Dreamed a Dream” (Syco Music/Columbia), at No. 2 with 77,000 sales, and Ke$ha’s “Animal” (Kemosabe/ RCA), which fell two spots to No. 3 with 67,000. Lady Gaga, who appeared on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” on Friday  and has also canceled several recent concerts because of exhaustion and dehydration  occupies two slots in this week’s Top 10: “The Fame” sold 64,000 to reach No. 4, and its companion mini-album, “The Fame Monster,” rose four spots to No. 6 with 36,000. (Both are released by Interscope.) With no other major new releases, the rest of the Top 10 is made up of familiar titles: Alicia Keys’s “Element of Freedom” (J) is No. 5, Mary J. Blige’s “Stronger With Each Tear” (Geffen) is No. 7, Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) is No. 8, the soundtrack to “Alvin and the Chipmunks: the Squeakquel” (Rhino) is No. 9, and the Black Eyed Peas’ “E.N.D.” (Interscope) is No. 10.

headline: Those Daring Young Lawyers in Gray Flannel
text: The law relies on precedent, and so do legal dramas.

headline: New York State Budget Would Cut Arts Funds
text: Cultural support in New York State would be cut $9.6 million under the 2010-11 budget proposed by Gov. David A. Paterson on Tuesday. A final version of the budget is due to be enacted by April 1. The governor’s proposal would cut funds to the New York State Council on the Arts by $6.5 million for its grant-making and by $600,000 for its administrative budget. In addition state support would be eliminated for the Egg performing arts center in Albany and begin to be phased out for the New York State Theater Institute in Troy. (There would also be a decrease of $400,000 from the 2009-10 budget because of the elimination of one-time funds for grants to arts and cultural organizations provided under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.) “I’m deeply disappointed and distressed,” said Norma P. Munn, the chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, referring to the proposed reduction in arts council funds. “That’s an extraordinary cut.”

headline: EBay’s Profit Rises Sharply, Aided by Sale of Skype
text: EBay earnings soared in the critical fourth quarter, fueled by growth in the PayPal business, the sale of Skype and success in luring more people to its shopping Web sites during the holiday season.

headline: In Europe, the Arts Ask for Alms
text: BERLIN  Last week the shadow culture secretary for Britain’s Conservative Party, Jeremy Hunt, promised to introduce “a U.S.-style culture of philanthropy” if the Tories come to power in the coming election. Speaking before the State of the Arts conference in London, Mr. Hunt foresaw a “golden age” of tax breaks to encourage private donations and help cut back on government spending.

headline: Health Care Bill May Be Scaled Back
text: With Democrats reeling from the Republican victory in the Massachusetts special Senate election, President Obama on Wednesday signaled that he might be willing to set aside his goal of achieving near-universal health coverage for all Americans in favor of a stripped-down measure with bipartisan support.

headline: Showcase: Suddenly Long Ago
text: Asked to capture “hope” and “change,” 132 photographers in 79 countries answered in many ways. One chose to depict a man minutes after he was released from prison in Italy; another pointed her camera to a newborn baby in a Palestinian hospital.

headline: As Usual, ‘Idol’ Rules
text: An audition stop in Chicago turned up few Hollywood-bound candidates but yielded a typically large audience for “American Idol” on Tuesday night. That Fox reality show drew 26.1 million viewers, giving the network an easy win for the night and lifting a repeat of its new action series “Human Target” (9.2 million). CBS ranked second with a lineup of all repeats, including “NCIS” (14.1 million), “NCIS: Los Angeles” (12.3 million) and “The Good Wife” at 10 (9.6 million). NBC finished third with “The Biggest Loser” (9.9 million) followed by “The Jay Leno Show” (6.3 million), while ABC ranked a distant fourth. On Nickelodeon on Monday, a new installment of “iCarly” delivered a series record 11.2 million viewers at 8 p.m., beating all programming on network television in its time slot.

headline: Icahn Wins in Bid for Las Vegas Resort
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has made the winning bid to buy the bankrupt and unfinished Fontainebleau Las Vegas resort. According to court papers filed in Miami, the bankruptcy examiner in charge of running a court-supervised auction of the Fontainebleau said the only qualified bid received for the Fontainebleau was from Icahn Nevada Gaming Acquisition L.L.C., Reuters reports

headline: ‘(500 Days)’ Director Swings to ‘spider-Man’
text: If the next “Spider-Man” movie features an adorable nonlinear plot device, a musical number set to an underappreciated Hall & Oates song or a terrible final line that exhausts all your good will toward the film, now you know why. On Wednesday, Sony Pictures Entertainment announced that it had signed Marc Webb, above, the director of the hit romantic comedy “(500) Days of Summer,” to direct a fourth installment in its “Spider-Man” franchise, The Hollywood Reporter said. Last week news emerged that Sam Raimi, the director of the first three hit films about Spider-Man, and his star, Tobey Maguire, who plays the Marvel Comics hero and his alter ego, Peter Parker, were leaving the franchise over creative differences. Sony had said that it wanted to return the film series to the teenage roots of the Peter Parker character. In announcing that it had hired Mr. Webb, the studio said in a statement that it wanted a director “who could capture the awe of being in Peter’s shoes so the audience could experience his sense of discovery while giving real heart to the emotion, anxiety and recklessness of that age.” The new “Spider-Man” film is being planned for a 2012 release, but no stars or screenwriters have been announced.

headline: Polanski Lawyers Say Prosecutors Misled Swiss
text: In their latest filing with the Los Angeles Superior Court, lawyers for Roman Polanski on Tuesday said officials with the district attorney’s office had “intentionally misled the Swiss” government with a false record of Mr. Polanski’s long-running sex case as a way to secure his extradition from that country. The claim is included in a brief for a planned Friday hearing on whether Mr. Polanski, who in 1978 fled the United States before sentencing on a conviction of having sex with a minor, should now be entitled to sentencing in absentia. “Politics seems to be interfering with the just administration of the law,” wrote Mr. Polanski’s lawyers, Chad S. Hummel and Bart Dalton, in response to a district attorney’s brief arguing that Mr. Polanski should have to appear before sentencing. This month the Los Angeles County district attorney, Steve Cooley, formed a committee to explore a run for California attorney general. Tuesday’s filing did not specifically mention that possible run for state office, but it said the district attorney’s insistence that Mr. Polanski return to the United States was a “nakedly political” approach to the case. Los Angeles prosecutors have long argued that Mr. Polanski’s fugitive status deprived him of any right to challenge his treatment in California.

headline: Food Production Made Palatable
text: Bobby Bognar seems willing to eat almost anything. But about once an episode on his new show, “Food Tech,” he encounters something even he is compelled to spit out.

headline: Cuomo Files Suit to Shut Down Fund-Raisers
text: The telephone solicitor for the local Police Benevolent Association was polite at first, but when Toby Morse explained that she had decided not to give money this year, his tone shifted. He read aloud her address and wondered how sturdy her locks were. Over the following weeks, she received dozens of phone calls at all times of the day to press her for donations, including one from a man pretending to be a police officer.

headline: I.B.M.’s National Security Play
text: On the surface, I.B.M.‘s acquisition of the National Interest Security Company, a consulting firm, doesn’t appear too noteworthy. No financial information was disclosed, and the news release is laden with technical jargon like “predictive intelligence” and “enterprise architecture.”

headline: Mining Frail Aspirations in Rural China
text: The first feature from the young Chinese director Zhang Chi, “The Shaft” (“Dixia de Tiankong”) feels as though it were made by a very old soul. Tight and tender, this small family drama is so visually expressive that listening is always subordinate to looking.

headline: Haiti Quake Day 9: Severe Aftershock
text: A strong aftershock struck near the Haitian capital on Wednesday morning.

headline: Michelle Obama Tackles Childhood Obesity
text: On Wednesday, Michelle Obama asked the nation’s mayors to enlist in what she hopes will be her foremost project: an ambitious, wide-ranging effort to reduce childhood obesity.

headline: Unions and Health Insurance
text: Last week, the Obama administration struck a deal with labor leaders to temporarily exempt union members from paying the excise tax on more generous health insurance plans. Why was this such a big deal?

headline: App of the Week: Mimicking the Features of Google Voice
text: As iPhone users await Apple’s reconsideration of its decision to withhold Google Voice (and the subsequent F.C.C. inquiry), they do not have to go entirely without the features of Google Voice. Many are available through an app called Ribbit Mobile.

headline: Wireless System Sends Bach or Bowie Into Your Light Bulbs
text: Klipsch, the speaker manufacturer, has come up with a twist on multiroom audio: wirelessly sending music to light bulbs around the house.

headline: Earbuds That Dance or Not, and Have Artificial Intelligence
text: Technocel, an electronic accessories company, introduced what it calls the Ear Vibe, “the first stereo headset that vibrates to the beat of your music” at the Consumer Electronics Show. The $30 earbud-style headphones begin to move a bit when they encounter low-frequency notes. It’s kind of a makeshift bass enhancement.

headline: An Architect Pays Respects to a Dowager
text: BOSTON  More than a few eyebrows will likely be raised on Thursday when the Italian architect Renzo Piano unveils his design for the expansion of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here.

headline: A Great but Costly Printer Is Now More Affordable
text: Hewlett-Packard made a splash last year with the introduction of its PhotoSmart Premium TouchSmart Web inkjet printer. The all-in-one device connects directly to the Web with built-in Wi-Fi. The TouchSmart Web also connects directly to the Internet to print photos, coupons, maps, event tickets and other images by using apps that are downloadable from H.P.’s App Studio.

headline: At 90, a Fresh Start for Morgenthau
text: So what does a recently retired 90-year-old do in a tough economy? Well, if you’re a legendary former prosecutor with a Rolodex as extensive as the Bible and a passion for legal briefs, you do like Robert M. Morgenthau: join a big-time law firm.

headline: Time to Cowboy Up
text: The polls had barely opened in Massachusetts on election day, a winter dawn that showed Democrats really were going to lose the seat of the lion Teddy Kennedy, when the stocks of big health care companies started to surge.

headline: Now at Starbucks: A Rebound
text: SEATTLE  Young people wearing hoodies and chunky glasses are sipping microbrew beers and espressos, nibbling on cheese and baguettes made at a local bakery and listening to a guitarist strum and sing.

headline: Chevy Volt Pricing: The War of the Asterisk
text: How much will the forthcoming Chevrolet Volt actually cost? Is it the low $30,000s? Or is it around $40,000? Call it the war of the asterisk. The growing confusion over the pricing of battery E.V.’s and plug-in hybrids has to do with a $7,500 federal tax credit for purchasers of cars with battery packs of 16 kilowatt-hours or more. With high prices made unavoidable by expensive batteries, carmakers are sorely tempted to simply lower the price by the amount of the credit, then add an asterisk and fine print reading, “Price includes a $7,500 federal tax credit.”

headline: An Obama Anniversary, Mostly Unheralded
text: Happy anniversary, Mr. President.

headline: After Dempsey: A Look at the U.S. Depth Chart
text: Clint Dempsey’s knee injury proved not to be as severe as initially thought. But the prospect that the U.S. and Fulham midfielder would miss the the rest of the Premier League season and the World Cup revealed serious anxiety over the Americans’ attacking options for South Africa.

headline: Foxwoods Owner Reaches New Debt Forbearance Pact
text: The Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, which owns the Foxwoods Resort Casino in Ledyard, Conn., has reached a new agreement in principal with its senior lenders over a debt forbearance, with the deadline now pushed back to April.

headline: Talk to The Times: Janet L. Robinson and Martin A. Nisenholtz
text: Senior executives of The New York Times Company will answer questions from readers on Thursday about the company’s decision to charge for frequent use of NYTimes.com, which will take effect in 2011. (For more details, read the company’s announcement and this article about it.)

headline: ‘Fish Tank’: Hand-Held Warning
text: To the Editor:

text: To the editor:
