text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this article referred incorrectly to the National Rifle Association rating of Scott Brown, the winner of the special Senate election in Massachusetts. He had an A rating from the group, not an F rating.

headline: Overweight on Air France
text: The touchy subject of how airlines should or should not treat obese passengers came up again today when Air France issued a new policy to refund heavier passengers the cost of a second seat, but instead found itself having to clarify the move.

headline: Several Shades of Jazz, Some Infused With Metal
text: Myra Melford’s Be Bread

headline: Salazar Seeks Import Ban on Invasive Snakes
text: Reptile retailers, brace yourselves: the federal government wants to ban the import of some large and seemingly popular snakes.

headline: Screen Language, Deciphered
text: Screen Language,

headline: When Facing Eviction or Foreclosure, The Neediest Cases Fund Offers Hope
text: A New Yorker seeking shelter and warmth underneath cardboard boxes and ratty blankets along the city's wind-whipped streets is a typical image of homelessness – and the image that springs to mind for many people when they fall into a financial crisis. Below, the seven agencies supported by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund explain how they are able to keep people in their homes or are able to provide more secure housing by pulling from the emergency reserve.

headline: Trying to Stop Four Spades, With a Hint and Without
text: The most successful players at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., held Jan. 12 to 18, were R. Jay Becker of New York and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.

headline: A View From Inside Coakley’s Camp
text: Martha Coakley’s campaign had originally planned on spending less money in the general election against Scott Brown than it had spent winning the Democratic primary, its chief strategist said in an interview today.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Women are front and center on this month’s list of new books, as authors and as characters. Tracy Chevalier (“Girl With a Pearl Earring”) tests whether fossil hunters are as appealing as Dutch painting, while Elizabeth Kostova has left vampire tales for the realm of art. Another female character is on the lam from her husband, a small man in many ways. But not to worry, Ozzy Osbourne is on hand to supply the testosterone.

headline: Five Questions for Victor Garber
text: Victor Garber is tired of people telling him how closely he resembles Garry Essendine, the womanizing, petulant, vain, showy-rich actor he plays in the Roundabout Theater Company’s Broadway revival of Noel Coward’s comedy “Present Laughter.”

headline: A Look That’s Bulletproof
text: JACK BAUER is in play again, and so is his hard-guy attire — sweaty T-shirt, leather jacket and that government agent’s staple: a bulletproof vest.

headline: Taliban Overhaul Image to Win Allies
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban have embarked on a sophisticated information war, using modern media tools as well as some old-fashioned ones, to soften their image and win favor with local Afghans as they try to counter the Americans’ new campaign to win Afghan hearts and minds.

headline: Fall 2010 Men’s Wear Collections
text: Photos from the Prada, Giorgio Armani, Dolce & Gabbana, Gucci, Verace and Ermenegildo Zegna shows.

headline: Climate Change Bill Is in Doubt
text: As Democrats on Capitol Hill and the White House contemplated the fallout of the special election results in Massachusetts on Tuesday, proponents of major climate change legislation said they would persist in their efforts to win passage of a bill this year, despite a hostile political environment.

headline: Trying to Paint the Deity by Numbers Against a Backdrop of Jewish Culture
text: In her latest novel Rebecca Newberger Goldstein envisions an intellectually sublime creature who is named Lucinda Mandelbaum, known as “the Goddess of Game Theory” and famed for something called the Mandelbaum Equilibrium, which is one of the non-Nash equilibria in zero-sum games. Lucinda is also a beauty and a triathalete, as long as we’re counting glamorous attributes. Ms. Goldstein would be on thin ice with an über-woman like Lucinda if she herself were not a paragon in her own right.

headline: Crunching the Numbers, Part 2
text: As we near Oscar nomination day on Feb. 2, the Bagger decided to get all Malcolm Gladwell and apply some behavioral economics to the campaign process. We spoke with Jehoshua Eliashberg, a Wharton professor of marketing and operations management who has studied the film business for 20 years. He’s also developed a sideline predicting a movie’s eventual box office based only on its script, with impressive accuracy.

headline: Fashion Takes a Lie-Down
text: AS the new spring fashion advertisements begin circulating in earnest this month, you may be tempted to ask when it became O.K. for models to lie down on the job.

headline: ‘36 Arguments for the Existence of God’
text: The Argument from the Improbable Self

headline: Robert B. Parker’s Gentle Knight
text: When Robert B. Parker died the other day — sitting at his desk, they say, working on a novel — his private eye alter ego died with him. And while we might pretend that Spenser is now among the immortal shades of other recently departed sleuths created by Ed McBain, Donald E. Westlake, and Tony Hillerman, the truth is that another hero has left town for good.

headline: Buffett Assails Bank Tax and Praises Blankfein
text: Once again, it’s been Warren E. Buffett Day on cable TV’s financial programs (and to some degree on DealBook as well).

headline: He Wasn’t The One We’ve Been Waiting For
text: Health care reform — which is crucial for millions of Americans — hangs in the balance. Progressives are desperately in need of leadership; more specifically, House Democrats need to be told to pass the Senate bill, which isn’t what they wanted but is vastly better than nothing. And what we get from the great progressive hope, the man who was offering hope and change, is this:

headline: Read My Hips: These Are Jeans That Fit
text: THE big issues and tough questions are what concern us here in Style Land. Let other people fret about the recession, health care and the future of Conan O’Brien’s pompadour. What troubles us is how the male consumer’s simplest decision somehow became the most difficult and fraught. Why, that is, are blue jeans, that most blameless and universal item of apparel, the one thing men always get wrong?

headline: A Best Friend, Yes. Best Runner, Maybe Not.
text: A MAN’S friend is not always his best choice of a running partner. The same can be said of man’s best friend.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 949 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: How Fast Is Your Web Connection?
text: When Andrew M. Odlyzko investigated why the Internet connection from his home in Minneapolis to his office just over two miles away was so sluggish, he found the answer: the data was taking a round trip to Denver.

headline: U.N. Official Says Climate Deal Is at Risk
text: WASHINGTON  Just a month after world leaders fashioned a tentative and nonbinding agreement at the climate change summit meeting in Copenhagen, the deal already appears at risk of coming undone, the top United Nations climate official warned on Wednesday.

headline: China Paints Google Issue as Not Political
text: This article was reported by Edward Wong, Jonathan Ansfield and Sharon LaFraniere, and written by Mr. Wong.

headline: Packets Full of Miracles
text: HOW wrong can you go for $2.25? That’s the price of a packet of 20 tomato seeds from Baker Creek Heirloom Seeds. The variety I’m considering is called Furry Yellow Hog, and the catalog copy suggests that it has citrus notes and a four o’clock shadow, two traits I have never associated with a tomato.

headline: The Cool Crowd
text: A look inside the a few of the homes of those who have chosen to forgo heat.

headline: How an Inflammatory Term, Baathist, Bars Candidates in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Seven years after the United States-led invasion, and three years after the leader it overthrew was executed, a question in Iraq remains unanswered: Who is a Baathist?

headline: Union Responds to Mara’s Comments
text: The N.F.L. players union fired back at team owners Wednesday, one day after the Giants co-owner John Mara said he was frustrated by the pace of labor negotiations and was resigned to a 2010 season without a salary cap, starting in March.

headline: Still Jumping Strongly, Plushenko Makes a Comeback
text: TALLINN, Estonia  It certainly looked like the old Yevgeny Plushenko: from the hair (bowl cut on top, long in the back) to the ballet dancer’s flexibility to, above all, the jumps.

headline: Accord Reached to Let Honduran President Depart
text: MEXICO CITY  The president-elect of Honduras agreed on Wednesday to grant safe passage to the Dominican Republic for ousted President Manuel Zelaya next week, in a deal designed to offer a graceful exit for the deposed leader.

headline: China to Slow Lending to Fight Inflation
text: HONG KONG  Chinese authorities signaled Wednesday that bank lending would slow significantly this year, the latest in a series of moves intended to forestall inflation and stave off bubbles in the stock and property markets.

headline: From Boston to D.C., Recapping the Day
text: It’s been a dizzying day of blog posts, online and print articles, graphics and video, related to the election results in Massachusetts that resulted in the victory for Scott Brown, the Republican. From the Bay State to Capitol Hill, the developments have been incoming at a rapid pace.

headline: Regret on Himalayan Glaciers Estimate
text: An international scientific panel overseen by the United Nations expressed “regret” on Wednesday for publishing an unsupported estimate of the speed at which Himalayan glaciers were melting. The estimate, included in a landmark 2007 report by the group, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said that the glaciers in the Himalayas could disappear by 2035. The figure was culled from a dated magazine interview with an Indian glacier scientist who now denies that he used that number. Although there is abundant evidence that glaciers are retreating, scientists differ on the speed of that trend and which glaciers will be affected.

headline: Guilty Plea in Sale of Products With Steroids
text: VMG Global, a sports nutrition company in California, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to selling products under the guise of dietary supplements that had been illegally spiked with steroids, according to court documents.

headline: I.O.C. Panel Calls for Treatment in Sex Ambiguity Cases
text: A panel of medical experts convened by the International Olympic Committee recommended Wednesday that the issue of athletes whose sex seems ambiguous be treated as a medical concern and not one of fairness in competition.

headline: White House: Obama Still Prefers a Major Overhaul
text: President Obama may have signaled some willingness to compromise on a scaled-back version of health care legislation, but the White House wants to be clear that the president’s first preference is to pass the sort of far-reaching legislation that lawmakers and the administration were negotiating before the Republican victory in Massachusetts upended everything.

headline: Finding High Design on Sale
text: Mariette Himes Gomez, the New York decorator, will have a sale at her store, the Shop, below, on antiques and on new furniture and accessories designed by Ms. Gomez, from Jan. 27 to 31 (a chrome and glass coffee table, originally $7,900, will be $5,300); 504 East 74th Street (York Avenue), (212) 288-4971, theshopnyny.com.

headline: Let the Good Times Roll
text: AvroKO, the design firm in NoLIta, has collaborated with Eben Freeman, a mixologist, to create a professional-grade version of that old entertaining workhorse, the bar cart. The look was inspired by vintage travel bar suitcases and airline galley carts from the 1950s and ’60s, said Adam Farmerie, one of the designers. Mr. Freeman provided ergonomic insight on what is required for a fluid drink-making process. The result? A high-end mini bar that “can be a stage for hosts to perform some fun cocktail theatrics,” said William Harris, another designer.

headline: Haitians and Hasidim Find Common Cause
text: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.

headline: Chilled by Choice
text: SERIOUS cold, Justen Ladda said, is when the sponge in the kitchen sink feels like wood or the toothpaste freezes or the refrigerator turns itself off, as it did one particularly frigid day last winter. Not that Mr. Ladda, a 56-year-old sculptor who has lived heat-free in his Lower East Side loft for three decades, is bothered by such extremes. “Winter comes and goes,” he’ll tell you blithely, adjusting his black wool scarf and watch cap. (Along with fingerless gloves, long underwear and felt slippers, they are part of Mr. Ladda’s at-home uniform when the mercury dips.)

headline: Cohen Is Back on Ice After a Long Absence
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  The moment Sasha Cohen stepped onto the ice Wednesday for practice at the United States Figure Skating Championships, the cameras started clicking.

headline: Local Stop: Tompkinsville
text: In Tompkinsville, Staten Island, it’s not just the streets that intersect. Cultures converge as well.

headline: Uninvited White House Guests Take the Fifth at Hearing
text: WASHINGTON  Michaele and Tareq Salahi, the couple accused of sneaking into President Obama’s first state dinner in November, declined to answer questions posed by lawmakers on Wednesday.

headline: Zardari Re-emerges, but Effect on Pakistan Is Unclear
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  For the first time in months, President Asif Ali Zardari is doing what presidents normally do  giving rousing speeches, traveling around the country and asserting himself publicly as the country’s chief official.

headline: If Your Password Is 123456, Just Make It HackMe
text: Back at the dawn of the Web, the most popular account password was “12345.”

headline: Clients Who Want It All, and Designers Who Love Them
text: BUNNY WILLIAMS and Bill Stubbs gave a talk to a room of designers as part of a lecture series at the Decoration & Design Building last week (sorry, like the swatches at Schumacher, which held the breakfast after, it was open to the trade only). And while the purported topic, according to Mr. Stubbs, a decorator based in Houston, was how to build a brand, the real subject was how to handle a difficult client.

headline: Foreign Languages Fade in Class — Except Chinese
text: WASHINGTON  Thousands of public schools stopped teaching foreign languages in the last decade, according to a government-financed survey  dismal news for a nation that needs more linguists to conduct its global business and diplomacy.

headline: Designers of an Ottoman
text: Mary Little and Peter Wheeler are known for their designs for contract furniture companies — their Pool collection for Brayton, for example, made quite a splash several years ago. But until now the two, who hail from Ireland and England, respectively, and work under the name Bius Studio, have not approached the consumer market, except through private commissions.

headline: Architect, or Whatever
text: AT the Ballard Farmers’ Market in Seattle on a recent weekend, passers-by could be forgiven for thinking John Morefield was running for political office. Smiling, waving and calling out hellos to everyone who walked by his stand, he was the picture of friendliness. All he needed was campaign buttons and fliers.

headline: Class, Please Take Your Seats
text: Furniture Masters is one of the design industry’s best-kept secrets. The 62-year-old family business has provided custom upholstery services to a veritable Who’s Who of designers for decades. Now the Long Island City company is opening its doors to those who want to learn the craft, offering a five-week workshop where students will be taught to upholster a club chair, provided by the company — from the preparation of springs and webbing and the cutting and sewing of a muslin pattern to covering the chair with fabric. The course will be taught by Rogelio Olguin, a master upholsterer with more than 25 years’ experience, and the finished chair is the student’s to keep. The class meets from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. on five consecutive Saturdays, beginning March 6; the cost is $1,800, which includes all materials except fabric. Information: furnish-d.com.

headline: The Massachusetts Election
text: If anyone should have seen it coming in Massachusetts, it is President Obama  the long-shot candidate who rode to electoral victory on a wave of popular impatience and an ability to identify and address voters’ core anxieties.

headline: Fisk Takes Aim at McGwire
text: Carlton Fisk gave voice Tuesday to something a lot of others Hall of Famers believe. No surprise, but they’re disgusted by the steroids era.

headline: For Jets’ Sanchez, It’s All About the Beard
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The maturation of Mark Sanchez is evident in his statistics, decisions and demeanor. The most obvious sign of growth, however, is on his face.

headline: Tight-Lipped Colts Contrast Sharply With Blustery Jets
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Gary Brackett started out toeing the Indianapolis Colts’ company line. A month after they opened the playoff door to the Jets by pulling their starters with a 5-point lead in a Week 16 game, the Colts are confronted in the American Football Conference championship game with the monster they helped create. It is an irresistible story line to everyone but the Colts. Now they are channeling their inner New England Patriots, carefully crafting a compliment-a-thon for their opponent and tiptoeing around the obvious: the Jets probably would not have gotten close to playing this month if Curtis Painter had not entered the sport’s lexicon.

headline: Obama Trying to Turn Around His Presidency
text: WASHINGTON  Chastened and bruised, President Obama on Wednesday began the daunting process of trying to turn around his presidency in a drastically altered political environment that will test his leadership, his instincts and his political dexterity as never before.

headline: U.S. Envisions a Continuing Civilian Presence in Afghanistan and Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration’s ambitious civilian push in Pakistan and Afghanistan will keep thousands of Americans in those countries for years  rebuilding Afghan agriculture, rooting out corruption and using the local media to counter anti-American sentiment.

headline: Tiling Minus the Trowel
text: Bondera TileMatSet is a new product that promises to simplify tiling by replacing mastic applied with a trowel with what amounts to double-stick tape. I’m not particularly handy, so I wanted to try it.

headline: Packing a Series of Pluses
text: Apparently, the people in positions of power at Palm weren’t completely pleased with the plethora of P’s in the appellations “Palm Pre” and “Palm Pixi,” the app phones Palm produced for Sprint. Palm has now expanded the parade of P’s with a pair of improved products: the Palm Pre Plus and Palm Pixi Plus.

headline: Pictures Tell the Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: Girls on Film
text: “Barbara” wears a fur coat, a Marilyn wig and a blank stare. “Deborah” leans against the rear window of a car, casually smoking and “Beth” just sets things on fire in a parking lot. Inspired by Alfred Hitchcock, David Lynch, Douglas Sirk and other masters of sexy darkness, the photographer Alex Prager specializes in cinematic images of women. Her latest portraits can be seen at Yancey Richardson Gallery, which is presenting “Week-End,” now through Feb. 20. The exhibition of new work by Ms. Prager is the third installment in her trilogy of staged female portraits set in the artist’s native city, Los Angeles. Ms. Prager examines female types with wigs, makeup, retro costumes and intriguing narratives lurking just outside the frame that make you want to look.

headline: Laughing It Up
text: Wyatt Cenac is one of our favorite “Daily Show” correspondents; his recent visit to Las Vegas in search of a free buffet lunch and an apology from Harry Reid was a prime example of his smart brand of funny. Tonight he hosts Some Folks, a brand new comedy and music show at the 92nd Street Y in TriBeCa. The program kicks off with appearances by the comedians Colin Quinn, the former “Weekend Update” anchor and host of “Tough Crowd,” and Morgan Murphy, currently a writer for “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon.” The soul singer-songwriter and guitarist Bridget Barkan will perform.

headline: What’s in Store?
text: It may not generate the level of buzz as the impending e-reader, or represent a major technological leap for that matter, but Apple’s foray into the role of presenter has certainly excited classical music fans. Earlier this month the Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes gave an “elegant” performance of Beethoven in the “glass cathedral of commerce” on 67th Street, according to Anthony Tommasini. Tonight two famous first cousins once removed, Ira and Philip Glass will be at the company’s SoHo outpost beginning at 7 p.m. for the latest installment in the free performance series, iTunes Live. Wendy Sutter and the new ensemble, the Glass Chamber Players, will perform too.

headline: Haiti’s Many Troubles Keep Bodies Uncounted
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Dr. Alix Lassegue, the physician who runs this city’s largest hospital, including its morgue, has been trying to figure out how many people died after the earth buckled so violently last week.

headline: Vows to Move Fast for Haitian Immigrants in U.S.
text: MIAMI  Clutching their passports and well-thumbed documents, hundreds of illegal Haitian immigrants crowded into a Roman Catholic church here on Wednesday to seek help in applying for a program that would allow them to stay and work legally in the United States for 18 months.

headline: The Gadget Trap
text: To the Editor:

headline: Restoring the Sheen to the Hope Classic
text: LA QUINTA, Calif.  The history of the Bob Hope Classic is not so much written as engraved, and time has rendered even larger the outsized characters who have peopled it. From the time Arnold Palmer shot 22-under-par to win the first event in 1960, the Hope has been on a 50-year run that, for the most part, has glittered like a clear night in the desert.

headline: Both Parties Seek Ways to Channel Populist Ire
text: WASHINGTON  The remarkable Republican victory in Massachusetts demonstrated convincingly that the deep populist anger fueling the Tea Party movement has migrated from the political fringe to the mainstream, forcing both parties to confront how to channel a growing mood of public resentment to their own ends.

headline: TV Coverage of Women’s Short Program
text: The women’s short program at the United States figure skating championships from Spokane will be seen live on Universal Sports, starting Thursday at 10:30 p.m., eastern, until 2:30 a.m. Friday. Sasha Cohen is expected to compete at about 1 a.m.

headline: Leonhard May Lose His Helmet, but Not His Head
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets safety Jim Leonhard has a bright pink shiner under his left eye to match the bright pink smudge on the right thumb that he broke earlier this season. He also got kicked in the back of the head last Sunday when his helmet popped off as he pounced on a loose ball.

headline: Conan O’Brien, With Ratings Rising, Keeps Punching
text: As his settlement with NBC stalled for yet another day and his ratings grow every night, Conan O’Brien kept firing jokes at NBC in his “Tonight Show” monologue Wednesday night.

headline: Quiet Start to Trial in Police Brutality Case
text: A decade ago, during jury selection in the case of the police officers accused of torturing Abner Louima, thousands of people marched across the Brooklyn Bridge to protest abuses by the police.

headline: Discipline Helped Carve Path to Senate
text: WASHINGTON  Scott Brown lives by what he calls “Army values,” instilled 30 years ago when he joined the Massachusetts National Guard. “The most regimented person I know,” his oldest daughter calls the Republican politician, who abhors disorder while sometimes inviting it with audacious pursuits  whether jumping into frigid lakes at 5 a.m. (for triathlon training) or into a seemingly quixotic Senate race.

headline: Green Mold in the Fridge
text: The Thursday puzzle is in a special format that cannot be reproduced in Across Lite. Click here to see the puzzle as it appears in print.

headline: Home Fires: In Balad, Smoke and Fire
text: Balad Air Base in northern Iraq was once nicknamed “Mortaritaville” by the soldiers and airmen who called it home. When I was there from 2007 to 2008, mortar attacks were so common and seemingly ineffective that the frequent interruptions were often a welcome break from the daily grind.

headline: Teaching Americans What Haiti Needs: Money
text: Don’t send shoes, send money. Don’t send baby formula, send money. Don’t send old coats, send money.

headline: Republicans Oppose Obama Deficit Panel
text: WASHINGTON  Top Republicans on Wednesday were hostile toward President Obama’s plan to create a bipartisan commission on cutting projected deficits, raising doubts about the prospects of a main piece of his budget strategy.

headline: F.B.I. Charges Arms Sellers With Foreign Bribes
text: Sometimes the proposition was delivered in a quiet corner of the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Miami. Sometimes the setting was the elegant Ritz-Carlton Hotel, a few blocks from the White House.

headline: What Would It Feel Like to Hold a 10-Inch Apple Tablet?
text: The imminent Apple tablet announcement is purportedly just days away. For weeks, reports have been flowing from screen manufacturers that an Apple tablet computer could offer a 10-inch screen.

headline: The Other Side of the Other Wizard
text: Gilbert Arenas has the fame and the lavish contract, the All-Star credentials and the clever nicknames. His puckish reputation is so well established that even a felony gun charge can be plausibly cast as a misguided practical joke.

headline: Back on Duty, but Under a Cloud After a Death
text: A woman, pregnant and clearly in distress inside an Au Bon Pain store in Brooklyn, needed medical help. Two city medical workers, waiting in line, refused to provide it; the woman eventually died.

headline: Big Benefits Are Seen From Eating Less Salt
text: In a report that may bolster public policy efforts to get Americans to reduce the amount of salt in their diets, scientists writing in The New England Journal of Medicine conclude that lowering the amount of salt people eat by even a small amount could reduce cases of heart disease, stroke and heart attacks as much as reductions in smoking, obesity and cholesterol levels.

headline: Legislature Approves Ethics Bills, but Few Cheer
text: ALBANY  With 59 largely unenthusiastic ayes, the State Senate on Wednesday approved a package of bills meant to combat political corruption and require elected officials to disclose more about their outside financial interests.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the election of Scott Brown, a Republican, to fill the Senate seat from Massachusetts that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy, a Democrat, misstated the amount of time Mr. Brown will fill the seat until it is up for election again. Depending on how soon he is sworn in, Mr. Brown will serve almost three full years  not two. (The next election will be in November 2012, and the winner will be sworn in for a six-year term in early January 2013.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the declining fortunes of the Plaza Hotel in New York misspelled the surname of a part owner of the Oak Room, one of the Plaza’s restaurants. He is Joey Allaham, not Alaham.

headline: Banks See a Leveling Off in Bad Consumer Loans
text: Since the financial crisis hit, banks have chipped away at the mountain of mortgages and credit card debt looming over struggling Americans. At last, those efforts appear to be paying off, at least for the banks.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a report by The Associated Press in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about the felling of New England’s oldest and largest elm tree, known as Herbie, misstated its location. It was in Yarmouth, Maine  not Yarmouth, Mass.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a reunion of the passengers and crew aboard the US Airways jet that crash-landed onto the Hudson River a year ago misstated the location of the crash and the event that occurred 90 seconds into the flight. The crash was at 40 degrees 46 minutes 10.19 seconds north latitude, and 74 degrees 16.69 seconds west longitude  not south latitude. It was the intake of geese by the plane’s engines that took place at the 90-second mark, not the crash itself.

headline: As Cuomo Stays Silent on a Candidacy, the Pressure on Him Grows
text: ALBANY  Is it Hamlet on the Hudson, Part 2?

headline: World Bank Sees Slowdown in Global Growth as Stimulus Wanes
text: WASHINGTON  The global economic recovery, already fragile in some regions, will probably slow later this year as the effects of stimulus spending by national governments wane, the World Bank said on Wednesday.

headline: Alastair Martin, 94, Court Tennis Star and Modern Tennis Executive, Dies
text: Alastair B. Martin, who won a host of national championships playing the venerable game of court tennis, then helped forge the modern era of the Grand Slam-style game, died Jan. 12 at his home in Katonah, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Saturday about the mood among New York Jets fans as their team prepared for the division playoff game against the San Diego Chargers misstated the time between playoff appearances. It was three years ago  a 37-16 loss to the New England Patriots  not five years ago. (A playoff game five years ago marked the Jets’ last victory in the playoffs, a 20-17 win against the Chargers.)

headline: F.B.I. Violated Rules in Obtaining Phone Records, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation improperly obtained calling records for more than 3,500 telephone accounts from 2003 to 2006 without following any legal procedures, according to a newly disclosed report by the Justice Department’s inspector general.

headline: Rare Session for Supreme Court
text: The Supreme Court will hold a special session on Thursday, presumably to issue decisions. Such special sessions are unusual, leading many to suspect that the court will release its long-awaited decision in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, a major campaign finance case. The court has already taken the rare step of hearing arguments in the case twice. For the second argument, the court asked the parties to offer their views on whether it should overrule a 1990 decision that upheld restrictions on corporate spending to support or oppose political candidates, and part of the 2003 decision that upheld the central provisions of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law.

headline: Republican Outlines Plan to Seek Gillibrand’s Senate Seat
text: ALBANY  Fresh off the upset victory of Scott Brown, the Republican contender in the Senate race in Massachusetts, Bruce A. Blakeman, a Republican lawyer from New York City, arrived here on Wednesday to discuss his plans to run against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, the Democratic incumbent, this fall.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a debate by the board of WBAI, New York City’s countercultural radio station, over whether to seat a new member, Lynne F. Stewart  the radical lawyer imprisoned for aiding terrorism  referred imprecisely to Danny Schechter, who said of WBAI: “I wouldn’t call it a collective. I’d call it a collection.” Although he has produced documentaries that were broadcast on WBAI, and has often appeared on air, he has never been on the staff of the station.

headline: Fed Chief in New York Defends Main Office
text: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned Wednesday against auditing the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate decisions and curbing its regulatory powers, as some in Congress have urged. It was his most detailed defense to date of the central bank’s conduct during the financial crisis.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Dec. 8 about Dubai World’s negotiations with its creditors misidentified one of its foreign bondholders. It is Aurelius Capital Management in New York, not a company in Vienna with the same name. The Vienna firm pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Tuesday.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Jail Protest by Immigrant Detainees Is Broken Up by Agents
text: Agents in riot gear from Immigration and Customs Enforcement tried to break up a hunger strike by detainees at the Varick Federal Detention Center in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday, three detainees at the center said Wednesday in telephone interviews.

headline: A Percolating Candidacy
text: Conservatives quietly mobilized behind a state senator, Scott Brown, to fill the Senate seat left empty by the death of Edward M. Kennedy.

headline: Ruling Backs Judge Who Rejected Post-5 P.M. Appeal
text: A Texas judge who refused to keep a courthouse open to receive a last-minute death penalty appeal did not engage in serious wrongdoing and should keep her job, according to a judge reviewing ethics complaints against her.

headline: Banks’ Derivatives Activity Falls Under I.R.S. Scrutiny
text: Federal authorities are scrutinizing certain financial derivatives that may enable Wall Street banks to avoid collecting billions of dollars in withholding taxes on stock dividends.

headline: Code Violations Found in Manhattan Schools
text: More than one third of Manhattan’s public school buildings have hazardous code violations, including many that have gone unresolved for years, threatening the safety of children and teachers, according to a report by the Manhattan borough president’s office.

headline: Obama Picks Loretta E. Lynch for Brooklyn U.S. Attorney
text: The White House announced on Wednesday that President Obama would nominate Loretta E. Lynch as United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, setting her up for a return to a post she held at the end of the Clinton administration.

headline: Obama to Propose Limits on Risks Taken by Banks
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday will publicly propose giving bank regulators the power to limit the size of the nation’s largest banks and the scope of their risk-taking activities, an administration official said late Wednesday.

headline: Apple Courts Publishers, While Kindle Adds Apps
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It’s a formidable high-tech face-off: Amazon.com versus Apple for the hearts and minds of book publishers, authors and readers.

headline: Amazon Cracks Open the Kindle
text: As Motoko Rich and I report in Wednesday’s New York Times, Amazon.com is finally opening up the Kindle to developers. This has the potential to turn a popular single-purpose device into a more interesting and versatile gadget, limited only by the imagination of third-party programmers — and by what they can do with its monochrome e-ink screen.

headline: Surviving the Camps but Struggling in Brooklyn
text: Ruth Usherenko keeps an improbably thick book on a table beside the couch in her living room. In it are roughly 58,000 names, all belonging to Jewish Berliners who perished during Hitler’s regime.

headline: Lottery Numbers
3 Weeks Into Retirement, Morgenthau Takes a Law Job
text: So what does a recently retired 90-year-old do in a tough economy? Well, if you are a legendary former prosecutor with a Rolodex as extensive as the Dead Sea Scrolls and a passion for legal briefs, you do as Robert M. Morgenthau did: join a big-time law firm.

headline: Heightened Concern Over BPA
text: The Food and Drug Administration has raised its level of concern over the safety of bisphenol-A, or BPA, an industrial chemical found in baby bottles and the linings of canned goods and other consumer products. That is a welcome shift in attitude by an agency that seemed bent, during the Bush administration, on minimizing the potential for harm. But it sheds little light, for now, on how dangerous the chemical might be in the small amounts that leach out and are imbibed by infants and older people  or how rigorously it should be regulated.

headline: Indian Tribes Await Their Due
text: After more than a century of obstruction and delays, still another deadline looms for a settlement that would compensate hundreds of thousands of American Indians for billions of dollars lost by a government that failed miserably to manage tribal lands that had been entrusted to it.

headline: A Tern Around the World
text: We are all used to miniaturization in our daily lives  the steady shrinking of the electronic tools we use, like telephones and video screens. But what happens when miniaturization reaches the natural world?

headline: The Messages in a Political Upset
text: To the Editor:

headline: She Dies, and We Still Cry
text: To the Editor:

headline: Growing Up Distracted
text: To the Editor:

headline: High-Tech Dashboards
text: To the Editor:

headline: Democratic Silver Linings
text: Poor Democrats, cheer up. There’s always a bright side.

headline: Some Frank Talk About Haiti
text: On my blog, a woman named Mona pointed to Haitian corruption and declared: “I won’t send money because I know what will happen to it.” Another reader attributed Haiti’s poverty to “the low I.Q. of the 9 million people there,” and added: “It is all very sad and cannot be fixed.”

headline: Aftershocks
text: Port-au-Prince, Haiti

headline: Torture’s Loopholes
text: TOMORROW will be one year since President Obama signed an executive order outlawing torture, yet our debate about interrogation methods continues. Though the president deserves praise for improving matters, the changes were not as drastic as most Americans think, and elements of our interrogation policy continue to be both inhumane and counterproductive.

headline: Snake Ban Proposed
text: Responding to concern over alien snakes in the Everglades, the Fish and Wildlife Service proposed to ban the import and interstate transport of Burmese pythons and eight other snake species. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar announced the move at Kennedy Airport in New York, the nation’s biggest entry point for wildlife imports. The proposal would add four species of python, four species of anaconda and the boa constrictor to a list of “injurious species” regulated by federal law, making their import and interstate transportation a misdemeanor.

headline: Schwab Prices Its Offering at $19 a Share
text: Charles Schwab, the largest American online brokerage, said on Wednesday it priced an offering of more than 26 million of its shares at $19 a share, Reuters reported.

headline: Path to the Senate
text: With his victory in Massachusetts, Scott P. Brown is the unlikely successor to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the possibly fatal agent of President Obama's health care bill and the protagonist in one of the great political upsets in recent memory.

headline: Why Bankers Tend to Hoard
text: The big gap between short- and long-term interest rates should mean fat lending profits for American banks. But some, like Wells Fargo, are wary of rising interest rates. Higher rates overall might encourage them to lend, but simultaneously could reduce their capacity to do so. It’s a tricky problem.

headline: Word of the Day |excerpt
text: excerpt •\ek-ˈsərpt, eg-ˈzərpt,\• noun and verb

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Another Brodeur Shutout, Another Sedin and Burrows Show
text: Only three games on Wednesday night, highlighted by the goaltending showdown in Newark. There Martin Brodeur of New Jersey and Team Canada, making his 27th straight start for the Devils, faced Tomas Vokoun of Florida and the Czech Republic. Home teams listed first:

headline: China on Path to Become Second-Largest Economy
text: BEIJING  China said on Thursday that its economy rose by 10.7 percent in fourth quarter compared with a year ago, as the country continued to surge forward even as many other nations are still trying to punch through the global recession. That was up from a revised growth rate of 9.1 percent in the third quarter.

headline: For Super Bowl XLIV Advertisers, Synergy Is the Name of the Game
text: FOR millions of football fans, the Super Bowl is the biggest social occasion of the year. That is becoming the case for Super Bowl advertisers, too, as they add a robust presence in social media like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube to their marketing lineups.

headline: Exodus to Countryside Reverses Long Trend
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Arckela Dorvil carefully lifted his teenage sister from the road, practically holding his breath, trying desperately not to aggravate her wounded right side. He climbed into the back of a truck called Love Divine.

headline: Marshall Nirenberg, Biologist Who Untangled Genetic Code, Dies at 82
text: Marshall W. Nirenberg, a biologist who deciphered the genetic code of life, earning a Nobel Prize for his achievement, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: News Quiz | January 21, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Q.&A. on NYTimes.com
text: Q. Will access to NYTimes.com be free for subscribers to the print newspaper?

headline: GenRe Settles With U.S. Over A.I.G. and Prudential
text: A unit of Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, General Re, has agreed to pay $92.2 million to settle accusations that it helped the American International Group and Prudential Financial manipulate financial statements, the federal government said Wednesday.

headline: Corrections
text: The Fitness column last Thursday, about nutritional supplements for exercisers, overstated Dr. Teri M. McCambridge’s role at the American Academy of Pediatrics. She is the chairwoman of its council on sports medicine and fitness, not the chairwoman of the entire academy. The article also referred incorrectly to nitric oxide; although caffeine is often added to supplements that contain it, it is not a caffeine-based stimulant. And a picture caption with the article misidentified the exerciser who begins his morning workout by taking N.O.-Xplode. As the article correctly reported, he is Michael Deutsch  not Alex Feintuch, who is shown in the picture.

headline: Corrections
text: The Letters column last Thursday misstated the surname of a reader who defended the value of physical therapy. She is Barbara Bell, not Ball.

headline: Sinosteel Said to Seek I.P.O. Approval by June
text: Sinosteel, the Chinese state-owned metals trader, plans to file for an initial public offering of Chinese A-shares before March and get the required approvals by June, Huang Tianwen, the president of Sinosteel, was quoted as saying on Thursday, Reuters reported.

headline: CrowdFlower Gets $5 Million for Crowdsourcing
text: From Brad Stone at Bits:

headline: Why Massachusetts Voted Brown
text: Carolyn Ryan of The New York Times analyzes the different campaign styles of Scott Brown and Martha Coakley and how they may have determined the outcome of the Senate race in Massachusetts.

headline: Why Bankers Tend to Hoard
text: The big gap between short- and long-term interest rates should mean fat lending profits for American banks. But some, like Wells Fargo, are wary of rising interest rates. Higher rates overall might encourage them to lend, but simultaneously could reduce their capacity to do so. It’s a tricky problem, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: Bloggingheads:  How Brown Won
text: Ezra Klein, left, of The Washington Post and David Weigel of The Washington Independent discuss Scott Brown's winning strategy.

headline: Obama to Propose New Limits for Banks
text: President Obama on Thursday will publicly propose giving bank regulators the power to limit the size of the nation’s largest banks and the scope of their risk-taking activities, an administration official said late Wednesday.

headline: Some Disappointing Earnings Send Markets Lower
text: A day after gliding to 15-month highs, Wall Street stocks had their steepest losses since mid-December on Wednesday as investors fretted over lackluster profits and a slowdown in global lending.

headline: American Posts a Loss as Revenue Falls 7.4%
text: American Airlines ended 2009 with a loss and could start 2010 with a thud if the carrier loses its Asian partner, Japan Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday.

headline: Annual Poll of Freshmen Shows Effect of Recession
text: The recession hit this year’s college freshmen hard, affecting how they chose a school as well as their ability to pay for it, according to an annual nationwide survey released Thursday.

headline: Banks See a Leveling Off in Bad Consumer Loans
text: Since the financial crisis hit, banks have chipped away at the mountain of mortgages and credit card debt looming over struggling Americans. At last, those efforts appear to be paying off, at least for the banks, Andrew Martin writes in The New York Times.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Quarter Is Weak, Unlike Pay Pool
text: By almost any measure, 2009 was a lean year for Morgan Stanley — except when it came to pay, Graham Bowley writes in The New York Times.

headline: Banks’ Derivatives Activity Falls Under I.R.S. Scrutiny
text: Federal authorities are scrutinizing certain financial derivatives that may enable Wall Street banks to avoid collecting billions of dollars in withholding taxes on stock dividends.

headline: Fed Chief in New York Defends Main Office
text: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned Wednesday against auditing the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate decisions and curbing its regulatory powers, as some in Congress have urged. It was his most detailed defense to date of the central bank’s conduct during the financial crisis.

headline: Questions for Cristine Cronin of NYCharities.org
text: For several years now, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has depended on nycharities.org to manage online donations. Cristine Cronin, the president and founder of NYCharities.org, answers a few questions about online giving and how it supports the Fund.

headline: Baghdatis Hobbles Through Upset at the Australian Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – An irrepressible Marcos Baghdatis of Cyprus had just clawed his way back from two sets down to a 5-1 fifth-set lead when his legs began to cramp – again and again.

headline: Blackstone Said to Apply For British Bank License
text: It seems the Blackstone Group, which counts leveraged buyouts, real-estate investment, hedge-fund management and financial advisory among its areas of expertise, is donning yet another hat: savings bank.

headline: From Uno to Undici: Pizza Chain Files for Bankruptcy
text: Burdened by debt from a 2005 private equity takeover, the Uno pizzeria chain’s parent company filed for Chapter 11 protection Wednesday, with plans to give its lenders a controlling equity stake in exchange for debt.

headline: ‘American Idol’ 9 on 9: The Orlando Auditions
text: On Thursday night, an “American Idol” first, I believe: an on-screen arrest of a contestant. But is “Idol” still worth being arrested over? Or having  your old arrests dragged out into the sunlight? I mean, let’s have some perspective: the guest judge Kristin Chenoweth couldn’t even be bothered to stick around for Day 2 of the auditions in Orlando, Fla., though all she missed was a teenage felon.

headline: Symetra Offering May Overshadow 5 Other I.P.O.’s
text: The 2010 U.S. market for initial public offerings opens this week with a company connected to famed investor Warren E. Buffett getting most of the attention.

headline: Lavish Worlds, and the Headwear to Match
text: When Lady Gaga finished her thumping, strobing, razzle-dazzle song-and-dance numbers at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night, she held her pose and kept the stage lights on, delighting her many camera-wielding fans. Her Monster Ball tour always provided something worth a snapshot: a sci-fi tableau, perhaps, or a skimpy, glittery costume. The more her image gets around, the better Lady Gaga does. “Take my picture!” she urged the audience, in her first of four sold-out shows at Radio City. “I want to be a star.”

headline: Is It Issues, Ideology or Independence?
text: The election of Republican Scott Brown to succeed Ted Kennedy in the Senate has prompted soul-searching among Democrats and celebration among Republicans. But what else might it be about? What drives Americans’ election decisions?

headline: Rosenfeld’s Gambit: Defying the Oracle
text: Irene Rosenfeld is clearly feeling lucky, Reuters Breakingviews says. Ms. Rosenfeld, the chief executive of Kraft Foods, raised her price to secure Cadbury’s agreement to a takeover. But in reducing the stock component, she also removed a chance of Warren E. Buffett voting against the deal, the publication notes.

headline: U.S. Offers Pakistan Drones to Urge Cooperation
text: ISLAMABAD  The United States will provide a dozen unarmed aerial spy drones to Pakistan for the first time as part of an effort to encourage Pakistan’s cooperation in fighting Islamic militants on the Afghanistan border, American defense officials said Thursday. But Pakistani military leaders, rebuffing American pressure, said they planned no new offensives for at least six months.

headline: Clean Filtration Gets $3.5 Million
text: Clean Filtration Technologies, maker of a self-cleaning filtration system for drinking and waste water, has pocketed $3.55 million of a targeted $7.2 million round of financing, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Illegal Flower Donation
text: Flowers left outside Google’s offices in Beijing as a protest against state censorship.

headline: Infinium Capital Buys Fox River
text: Infinium Capital Management, the high-frequency futures trader, said in a joint statement late Wednesday that it would take over Fox River, a high-volume trader and specialist in equity options.

headline: Loch Capital Hurt By Galleon Ties, Report Says
text: It seems that Loch Capital Management, a Boston-based hedge fund, may be the latest victim of the insider trading scandal surrounding the Galleon Group, Reuters reported.

headline: Greece Mulls Bond Issue to Resolve Deficit
text: Greece is confident it can meet its financing needs as it grapples with a ballooning budget deficit and may issue bonds in yen and dollars this year to do so, top Greek officials declared Thursday, saying that the country could issue the bonds this year.

headline: London Finance Jobs Market Picks Up, Survey Says
text: Hiring is set to rise in London’s financial sector this year, according a new jobs survey by the recruiting firm Morgan McKinley.

headline: It’s Not All About Tennis for the Williams Sisters
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Venus Williams caught the play “Jersey Boys” this week and was photographed holding a guitar with the cast doing her best Pete Townshend. She has played a little tennis here, too, but she really didn’t have much to say about her performance.

headline: At a Dutch Church, a Tale of Two Countries
text: The former church known as De Nieuwe Kerk has built a reputation over the last couple of decades with exhibitions tailored around specific countries, often thematically or historically linked back to the Netherlands. A show at the museum (Dam Square; 31-20-638-6909; nieuwekerk.nl), simply titled “Oman,” focuses on the history and culture of that Middle Eastern country.

headline: In Nottingham, There’s a New Sheriff in Town
text: If Manager Billy Davies takes his club to the Premier League, Forest fans will do more than make him the sheriff of Nottingham by proclamation — he will be the new earl of England’s East Midlands.

headline: Creditors to Sell Stake in Olympic Ski Sites
text: Creditors of Intrawest Holdings, which owns the Whistler ski resort where part of the Winter Olympics are set to take place next month, plan to put their stake in the company on the auction block in February.

headline: Investors Watch Health Care in Wake of G.O.P. Win
text: Investors and distressed market advisers on Wednesday said the surprise Republican senate win in Massachusetts may present opportunities in health care bonds, hospitals and medical companies, Reuters reported.

headline: Kraft Bond Investors Disagree With Buffett
text: Warren E. Buffett may have real doubts about Kraft Foods‘ $19.3 billion takeover of Cadbury, but debt investors apparently don’t.

headline: Oracle Wins E.U. Approval for Acquisition of Sun
text: The European Commission said Thursday that it had approved the proposed $7.4 billion takeover of Sun Microsystems by Oracle, the U.S. software giant, because it would not significantly affect competition in the European Union, Matthew Saltmarsh writes in The New York Times.

headline: Celebrity: How Sick Is That?
text: Today’s idea: Modern society is an enabler of morbidly self-obsessed celebrities, an essay says, because people use them much as they use hypochondriacs — as foils for their own mortal fears.

headline: China Said to Punish Banks for Overlending
text: China punished some banks, including Bank of China, for lending too much, after a surge in new loans this year increased inflationary pressures, sources said on Wednesday citing central bank figures, Reuters reported.

headline: Super Bowl III Telecast Replayed Saturday
text: Passing along two e-mail messages I received:

headline: Live Nation May Sell Concert Sites for Deal, Report Says
text: Live Nation is willing to sell some of its concert sites on favorable terms to a rival, Anschutz Entertainment Group, in exchange for dropping its opposition to Live Nation’s proposed merger with Ticketmaster, The New York Post reported.

headline: An Antitrust Investigation of the Banks?
text: Simon Johnson is a professor at M.I.T.’s Sloan School of Management and a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.

headline: Istithmar Chief Resigns, Amid Dubai Woes
text: Dubai World has shown the chief executive of Istithmar World the door, as the conglomerate struggles renegotiate its roughly $22 billion of debt load, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: The Ford Logo That Almost Was
text: There are many interesting auto logo stories, including Cadillac’s recent discarding of its heraldic ducks in favor of a new version of its shield and crest. And BMW recently cleared up the history of its logo, saying that it’s based on the Bavarian flag, not a spinning propeller.

headline: Sampler: BART Airport Extension in Trouble and a Reward for a Missing Goat
text: BART Scrambles for Federal Funds | The Federal Transit Agency has threatened to give away $70 million in economic stimulus funds slated for the extension of BART to Oakland International Airport unless BART prepares an adequate analysis the project’s impact on the poor and minorities in its path. BART officials hope to break ground on the 3.2-mile extension this summer. Critics have called the extension a “ski lift to the airport” for the elite. “I think this is a problem of process,” said James Fang, the president of BART’s board. “We are confident we can beat back this last obstacle to the project.” [The Oakland Tribune]

headline: The S.E.C.’s Whistle-Blower Problem
text: By now, it’s well known that the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s system of handling whistle-blowers is in dire need of fixing, as the fraud cases of Bernard L. Madoff and R. Allen Stanford have shown.

headline: John Edwards Admits Paternity
text: John Edwards, who twice sought the Democratic presidential nomination, admitted in a statement on Thursday that he is the father of Frances Quinn Hunter, the 2-year-old daughter of his former mistress, Rielle Hunter.

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, Jan. 21
text: Here are some highlights from Thursday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: View From Indianapolis: Jets Beat a ‘Freshman Team’
text: The folks in Indianapolis may be tired of hearing how the Jets held their own against the Colts’ first unit in December. Bob Kravitz, The Indianapolis Star:

headline: Goldman Reports $4.95 Billion 4th-Quarter Profit
text: Goldman Sachs said Thursday it earned $4.95 billion in the fourth quarter, rounding out a very strong year for the Wall Street bank in 2009, The New York Times’s Graham Bowley reports.

headline: Strong Year for Goldman, as It Trims Bonus Pool
text: No one was crowing about their big paychecks at Goldman Sachs headquarters in New York on Thursday. Despite a record 2009, the bank announced that it had set aside only $16.2 billion to reward its employees.

headline: A Face-Off in Coal Country
text: CHARLESTON, W. Va. — Although a forum unfolding here today is nominally concerned with the “Future of Energy,” a very specific practice of energy resource extraction — and one prevalent in Appalachia — will hang heavy in the air: mountaintop removal coal mining.

headline: Rex Ryan Uncut, Colts Week
text: First the Super Bowl, then Rex Ryan can take over “The Tonight Show.”

headline: The Early Word: Brown’s in Town
text: Senator-elect Scott Brown Massachusetts , is in Washington on Thursday.

headline: Two Medical Workers Speak Out
text: A woman, pregnant and clearly in distress inside an Au Bon Pain store in Brooklyn, needed medical help. Two city medical workers, waiting in line, refused to provide it; the woman eventually died.

headline: The Underpants Gnomes Theory of Reform
text: Watching some liberal members of the House explain why they won’t do what’s necessary, and pass the Senate bill, I was wondering what they imagine will happen. Then the answer came to me: it’s the Underpants Gnomes business plan. In its original form this was:

headline: Taking Sundance Back to Its Roots
text: The Bagger is making her way to Park City, Utah, on Thursday, just in time for what Brooks Barnes says may be “the most important Sundance in years.” The festival has a new director, John Cooper, whose self-imposed mandate is “less commercial, more independent.” Turning it to that direction, Mr. Barnes writes, may be a harbinger for independent cinema in general, which has seen its ranks shuffled now that many studios have shuttered or shrunk their boutique divisions.

headline: See India by Luxury Train
text: India’s first cross-country luxury train the Maharajas’ Express will make its maiden journey from Mumbai to Delhi on March 6, stringing together subcontinental highlights from the iconic Taj Mahal to remote habitats of tigers.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Lost Vote
text: Kraft has deliberately structured its final offer to acquire Cadbury so that it won’t need the approval of its shareholders. That act of shareholder disempowerment isn’t sitting well with Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Conan O’Brien’s New Sidekick: The Bugatti Veyron Mouse
text: Last night, Conan O’Brien introduced a new series of skits as he concludes his final week as host of “The Tonight Show.”

headline: Conan O’Brien and NBC to Part Ways
text: Say farewell to Conan O’Brien.

headline: Tsonga Keeps Dent on His Heels
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — In a strangely muted display of power versus stealth, 10th-seeded Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France shut down the net-rushing game of Taylor Dent of Bradenton, Fla., in straight sets on Thursday night, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3.

headline: Conan O’Brien Finally Signs Off
text: Bill Carter reports:

headline: Jets’ Win Probability vs. Colts: 28 Percent
text: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.)

headline: The Developing Consensus
text: Thursday morning brought the release of the nominees for Britain’s Oscars, the BAFTAs, and the list reflected the growing consensus of this awards season, with one homegrown exception. “Avatar,” “Up in the Air,” “The Hurt Locker” and “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire” all received nominations for best picture. The wild card was “An Education,” Lone Scherfig’s film about a teenage girl in the England of the early 1960s being wooed by a man twice her age.

headline: One Part of One Closing School Will Be Spared
text: Education officials said Wednesday that community pressure had persuaded them to change course on a small part of their decision to close 20 schools for poor performance next year, in the first such reversal since the closings were proposed.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Teddy Cruz, Architect
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Police Explain Diversion of Flight to Philadelphia
text: Updated, 3:06 p.m. | A Philadelphia police spokesman, Lt. Frank Vanore, offered the following account of the confusion that ensued on US Airways Flight 3079 after a 17-year-old Orthodox Jew put on tefillin, the prayer garment made from a pair of small leather boxes containing scripture and connected by leather straps, shortly after takeoff:

headline: Thursday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Talk to The Times: Answers About Charging Online
text: Senior executives of The New York Times Company are answering questions from readers about the company’s decision to charge for frequent use of NYTimes.com, which will take effect in 2011. (For more details, read the company’s announcement and this article about it.)

headline: Banksy Strikes at Sundance
text: On Wednesday the Web started to percolate with word that Banksy had hit Sundance. Yes, the graffiti art that popped up in Park City, Utah, over the last couple of days was courtesy of everyone’s favorite anonymous street artist. But here is what the movie bloggers failed to figure out: This time, the art was just a sideshow to a film directed by the reclusive Banksy, “Exit Through the Gift Shop,” a surprise addition to the Sundance Film Festival, which kicks off on Thursday.

headline: Obama’s Bank Proposal Helps Erase the Month’s Gains
text: Concerns over President Obama’s plan to limit the activities of banks helped drag shares down on Thursday, erasing all the gains the stock market made in the first three weeks of 2010.

headline: Jan. 21: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
text: On Thursday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of last week’s earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort. Previous Lede updates: Jan. 20 |Jan. 19 | Jan. 18 | Jan. 17 | Jan. 16 | Jan. 15 | Jan. 14 | Jan. 12 and 13

headline: You May Now Resume Hassling ‘the Hoff’
text: After a highly contentious departure from the airwaves, a beloved personality has revealed the project in which he’ll make his long-awaited return to television. No, not Conan O’Brien — David Hasselhoff. A&E said that it had ordered a new “real-life docu-series” (or as it is also known, a “reality show”) that will star Mr. Hasselhoff (or as he is also known, “the Hoff”) that will follow him as he raises two teenage daughters and attempts to help them find their places in the entertainment industry. Mr. Hasselhoff, the former “Knight Rider” and “Baywatch” star, said earlier this month that he was quitting his position as a judge of the NBC competition program “America’s Got Talent,” saying only that he was leaving to pursue his own series. The A&E show, which does not yet have a title, will take viewers on a shadowy flight with Mr. Hasselhoff and his daughters, Taylor-Ann, 19, a communications major at the University of Arizona, and Hayley, 17, a fashion model, who both aspire to be professional singers. Ten episodes have been ordered and are scheduled to be shown later this year.

headline: An Antitrust Investigation of the Banks?
text: From Simon Johnson at Economix:

headline: The Insider | Trevor Groth
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, Sundance Film Festival’s Trevor Groth shares his essentials. The Utah native, who got his start at Sundance as an intern in 1991, became the director of programming last May. For the 2010 edition, which begins today and runs through Jan. 31, Groth and his team will present a roster of films that reflects a move back to the fest’s indie roots while at the same time showcasing works by filmmakers at the cutting edge of technology. He recently collaborated on a book, “Take 100: The Future of Film: 100 New Directors,” which will be published in May by Phaidon Press.

headline: Mikey, You’re Not Alone
text: A week ago, I wrote about 8-year-old Michael Hicks, a Cub Scout who has the misfortune of sharing a name with someone on the government’s terrorist watch list. That means that Mikey must jump through a few hoops to get a boarding pass and a seat assignment. The last time he flew, Mikey was aggressively frisked, his mother, Najlah Feanny Hicks, told me.

headline: Grand Theft Auto’s New Weapon: The iPhone
text: If you have ever wanted to use your iPhone to murder someone, deal drugs or commit mayhem, your moment has arrived.

headline: Ambush at Bardale
text: Omar Hammammi's face is finally uncovered in a 31-minute long video, released by the Shabaab. The instant jihadist classic  is a veritable homage to Omar.

headline: Clinton Urges Global Response to Internet Attacks
text: WASHINGTON  Declaring that an attack on one nation’s computer networks “can be an attack on all,” Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton issued a warning on Thursday that the United States would defend itself from cyberattacks, though she left unclear the means of response.

headline: Banksy Strikes at Sundance
text: On Wednesday the Web started to percolate with word that Banksy had hit Sundance. Yes, the graffiti art that popped up in Park City, Utah, over the last couple of days was courtesy of everyone’s favorite anonymous street artist. But here is what the movie bloggers failed to figure out: This time, the art was just a sideshow to a film directed by the reclusive Banksy, “Exit Through the Gift Shop,” a surprise addition to the Sundance Film Festival, which kicks off on Thursday.

headline: The Advantages of Incrementalism
text: To my suggestion that possibly, just possibly, voters are reacting negatively to ambitious liberal governance as well as to the unemployment rate, Jon Chait ripostes:

headline: Billy Joel’s New Bobber’s a Beaut
text: Hell for Leather on Wednesday showed off pictures of a terrific custom-built motorcycle that was headed to Brooklyn. Based on a Kawasaki W650, the bike was built by Deus Ex Machina, an Australian shop, and features a hardtail, a sprung seat, custom tank and peashooter pipes, among other mods.

headline: Fibromyalgia, H.I.V. and Chronic Fatigue
text: Dr. Nancy Klimas answers readers questions on the link between fibromyalgia, H.I.V., cystitis and chronic fatigue syndrome.

headline: Justices, 5-4, Reject Corporate Spending Limit
text: WASHINGTON — Overruling two important precedents about the First Amendment rights of corporations, a bitterly divided Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that the government may not ban political spending by corporations in candidate elections.

headline: Rapidly Moving ’39 Steps’ to Move off Broadway
text: Update | 1:04 p.m.  The revelation was hardly as suspenseful as an Alfred Hitchcock movie, but the producers of “The 39 Steps” announced on Thursday that their stage comedy, adapted from that 1935 film, will reopen off Broadway at New World Stages on March 25.

headline: For College Freshmen, Ripple Effects From the Recession
text: They may not pay the tuition bills themselves, but college freshmen are clearly concerned about the recession, judging by an annual nationwide survey.

headline: Send Us Your Lady Gaga Photos
text: Updated Jon Pareles writes that during the first of her four sold-out shows at Radio City on Wednesday, Lady Gaga urged the audience: “Take my picture! I want to be a star.” Were you at the show? Did you heed her request? Send us your photos, tell us about the show and we’ll display some of the photos and your stories here.

headline: The Concierge | Hors d’Oeuvres Duty
text: Christine Muhlke, T Magazine’s food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.

headline: ‘A Lackluster Campaign’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: There was a huge Senate race in Massachusetts yesterday. Republican Scott Brown pulled off the upset. Now some Democrats are accusing their candidate, Martha Coakley, of running a lackluster campaign. They were especially confused by her campaign slogan, “I guess we can?”

headline: ‘Two Daughters Available’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” on NBC: There was a big Senate race in Massachusetts yesterday. The winner, Scott brown, made a victory speech where he mentioned his two daughters were available. At least this explains his campaign slogan, “Scott Brown, creepy for Massachusetts, creepy for America.”

headline: ‘Hair’s Gone Gray’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: It was a year ago today that the president moved into the White House. An since that time, his hair’s gone gray, he’s made some people mad at him, he’s let down quite a lot of his supporters, which makes him perfect for his new job, host of “The Tonight Show.”

headline: Answers About New York’s High Schools, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of answers from Clara Hemphill, whose book series New York City’s Best Schools is regarded as the bible for navigating school choices.We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

headline: Easy Curries
text: A couple of years ago, at Jean Georges, my wife, Jackie, and I were served rack of lamb coated with crisp mint-scented panko crumbs. The sauce was basically the liquid part of a Thai curry, and it was just such a gas: it seemed to be a whole separate issue from the lamb, but the two things generated the most delicious, fun synergy, both on the tongue and up in the sinuses (my note on the dish says simply, “Aroma”).

headline: ‘One of Those Names’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: The Republicans elected a new senator from the State of Massachusetts. His name is Scott Brown. That’s one of those names they give you in the witness relocation program.

headline: ‘A Number of Explanations’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: It’s hard to believe President Obama has now been in office for a year. And you know, it’s incredible. He took something that was in terrible, terrible shape, and he brought it back from the brink of disaster. The Republican Party.

headline: Aid Groups Focus on Haiti’s Homeless
text: JACMEL, Haiti  Haiti has approved plans for more than a dozen sprawling tent cities in and around Port-au-Prince, the first step in an epic relocation effort that could reshape the country as up to one million people displaced by the earthquake find new places to live.

headline: Return to Tomorrow: Old Sci-Fi Series From ‘Star Trek’ Creator May Get New Life
text: Ron Howard and Brian Grazer are perhaps better known for projects about science-fact (say, “Apollo 13″) than science-fiction (though their adaptation of “The Cat in the Hat” was pretty trippy in a “2001” kind of way). But for their next project, the producing pair are boldly going where few have gone before: into the archives of the creator of “Star Trek,” Gene Roddenberry.

headline: Offering Care for the Caregiver
text: The man was nearing 90, losing his sight and showing signs of early dementia. After examining his abdomen, I fumbled trying to help him get his shirt and pants back on. After an awkward few seconds, the patient’s middle-aged son sprang forward from his seat near the door and began working through the buttons, zipper and belt with a practiced deftness.

headline: For Knicks’ Lee, a Grandfather, Mentor and Pal
text: David Lee used to go to the zoo with his grandfather. A lot of youngsters go to the zoo with their grandparents. This was a little different.

headline: Who Takes Care of the Caregiver?
text: In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline W. Chen writes about an aging patient with early dementia. But it was the man’s middle-aged son who made the biggest impression. She writes:

headline: Vain Glorious | Blow Outs to Benefit Haiti
text: With Vain Glorious, T Magazine breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

headline: Political Fallout From the Supreme Court Ruling
text: Updated: Even before their Massachusetts victory this week, Republicans enjoyed a multitude of advantages in this year’s midterm elections. The Supreme Court has most likely just delivered one more: money.

headline: Campaign Helps Prompt N.B.A. to Let Shannon Dunk
text: In December, I wrote about the grassroots campaign to get Lakers guard Shannon Brown in the All-Star slam dunk contest. Those efforts, which included YouTube videos, a barrage of Twitter activity, and a nifty catchphrase (“Let Shannon Dunk!”) with an eponymous website, paid off. On Monday, the league announced Brown’s selection for the contest, along with defending champion Nate Robinson of the Knicks and Gerald Wallace of the Bobcats. The fourth participant will be determined by a “dunk-in” contest between DeMar DeRozan of the Raptors and Eric Gordon of the Clippers, to be held at halftime of the Rookie-Sophomore game.

headline: The Mighty Tumble in North Carolina
text: If you are feeling shaky today, it is understandable. Something is seriously out of whack. Apparently, a crease developed in the universe somewhere over North Carolina. The Duke and North Carolina men’s basketball teams lost a game on the same night. Hasn’t happened in 14 years. The jolt was so profound it even prompted John Edwards to stop lying about the child he fathered. We are awaiting confirmation that his hair also moved.

headline: The Art of Finishing Off an Opponent
text: Although we are just reaching the third round at the Australian Open, there has been no shortage of stirring five-set matches. Of the 96 matches played so far in the men’s draw, 17 have gone to five sets. Remarkably, six of those matches involved a player coming back from being down, two sets to love. While Mikhail Youzhny’s courageous win over Richard Gasquet, in which he overcame a 4-2 deficit in the final set while cramping, was noteworthy, some of these phenomenal comebacks have been lost in the noise and bustle of the first week.

headline: Loyalties of Those Killed in Afghan Raid Remain Unclear

headline: Robben W. Fleming, University President in Turbulent Times, Dies at 93

headline: Right-Wing Flame War!
text: Charles Johnson has been writing a blog for almost as long as the word “blog” has existed. A bearish, gentle-voiced, ponytailed man who for three decades enjoyed a successful career as a jazz guitarist accompanying the likes of Al Jarreau and Stanley Clarke, Johnson has always had a geek’s penchant for self-education, and in that spirit he cultivated a side interest, and ultimately an expertise, in writing computer code. His Web log, which he named “Little Green Footballs” (a private joke whose derivation he has always refused to divulge), was begun in February 2001 mostly as a way to share advice and information with fellow code jockeys — his approach was similar in outlook, if vastly larger in its reach, to the guiding spirit in the days of ham radio. His final post on Sept. 10, 2001, was titled “Placement of Web Page Elements.” It read, in its entirety: “Here’s a well-executed academic study of where users expect things to be on a typical Web page.” It linked to, well, exactly what it said. The post attracted one comment, which read, in its entirety, “Fantastic article.”

headline: The V Generation
text: Your new book, “I Am an Emotional Creature,” is a collection of 30-plus fictional monologues in which you assume the confiding, often plaintive, voices of teenage girls — from a Chinese factory worker to a sex slave in Africa to a schoolgirl in suburban America bemoaning her lack of purple Ugg boots. Why do you see yourself as a spokeswoman for teenage girls?  I don’t feel like I’m a spokesperson at all for girls. I just feel like, O.K., in the way that “The Vagina Monologues” was an attempt to communicate stories of women and their vaginas, this is an attempt to communicate the stories of girls on the planet right now.

headline: James E. Cheek, Forceful University President, Dies at 77

headline: ‘Rent’ Tour to Close
text: If there were only a song in “Rent” that noted the passage of time in excruciatingly precise detail, this might be the moment to cite it. On Thursday, press representatives for that musical said that its national tour will play its final performance on Feb. 7, making it the first time since it opened that “Rent” will not be performed on a Broadway or national stage. “Rent,” Jonathan Larson‘s rock-opera gloss on “La Bohème,” had its Off Broadway and Broadway openings in 1996 (after a workshop production in 1994), and went on to play 5,123 performances at the Nederlander Theater before closing in 2008. The national tour has played 373 performances in 39 cities, traveling 54,000 miles in the process. The final tour performances of “Rent” will take place Feb. 3 through 7 at the Community Center Theater in Sacramento, and will feature Adam Pascal, Anthony Rapp and Gwen Stewart, from the musical’s original cast.

headline: Speech Therapy
text: In 1966, William Labov, the father of sociolinguistics, discovered that many people with New York accents — the stock Noo Yawk kind — didn’t like the way they talked. It was kind of sad. Labov found widespread “linguistic self-hatred,” he reported. People from New York and New Jersey described their own speech as “distorted,” “sloppy” and “horrible.” No wonder those great old accents came to be regarded as a class giveaway, to be thrown over in the name of assimilation, refinement and the acquisition of Newscaster English.
