headline: News Quiz | January 22, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Man Is Stabbed to Death in His 46th St. Apartment
text: A 41-year-old man was found stabbed to death and covered in a pile of clothes in his Midtown apartment on Thursday, the police said.

headline: Billboards Spur Oracle President to Admit Affair
text: Updated, 9:33 a.m. | The mystery of a Times Square billboard showing romantic photographs of the president of Oracle, Charles E. Phillips, alongside the words “Charles & YaVaughnie” and “You are my soulmate forever!” has been solved. In a statement Thursday, Mr. Phillips admitted to an extramarital affair.

headline: Venture Capital Was Tight for Tech Start-Ups in ’09
text: Venture capitalists, whose money provides fuel to technology start-ups, last year invested the lowest amount in such companies since 1997, according to a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers and the National Venture Capital Association released on Friday.

headline: Gates Says Taliban Must Take Legitimate Afghan Role
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The United States recognizes that the Taliban are now part of the political fabric of Afghanistan, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said here on Friday, but the group must be prepared to play a legitimate role before it can reconcile with the Afghan government.

headline: Visiting Congo
text: I’m overnighting in Rwanda, heading overland to Congo right now. It’s one of the most important and neglected humanitarian stories in the world, and I hope I can shine a light on it. If you have some issues you’d like me to look into, let me know.

headline: With Tougher Stance, Obama Takes On Banks
text: The tougher approach to financial regulation that President Obama outlined on Thursday reflected a changed political climate, the rebound in big banks’ fortunes after their taxpayer bailout and a shift in power within the administration away from those who had been seen as most sympathetic to Wall Street.

headline: A Beat Poet’s Ode to a Macintosh, and Other Highlights From Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: A Mac Is a Mac Is a Mac | Gary Snyder, the Beat-era poet and writer on wilderness whose path has crossed that of the personal-computer movement for decades, has written a never-published poem contemplating his Macintosh computer. Never published before now, that is. It appears in our pages as techies everywhere await Steven P. Jobs’ announcement next Wednesday of Apple’s latest brainchild.

headline: Strong Year for Goldman, as It Trims Bonus Pool
text: No one was crowing about their big paychecks at Goldman Sachs headquarters in New York on Thursday. Despite a record 2009, the bank announced that it had set aside only $16.2 billion to reward its employees.

headline: Busch Criticizes McGwire
text: If Mark McGwire thought all would be forgiven after he admitted taking steroids, he appears to have miscalculated. In recent days, Carlton Fisk, Jack Clark and Yogi Berra have taken shots at McGwire, who retired in 2001 and this month became a hitting coach for the St. Louis Cardinals, his old team.

headline: Swedish Bank Fee Sets Example for America
text: When it comes to rescuing banks, the Swedes are earning a reputation as trendsetters. First they set a standard for recovering from disaster; now they want to export their idea for how to pay for it, Matthew Saltmarsh writes in The New York Times.

headline: Obama’s Bank Proposal Helps Erase the Month’s Gains
text: Concerns over President Obama’s plan to limit the activities of banks helped drag shares down on Thursday, erasing all the gains the stock market made in the first three weeks of 2010.

headline: Bidders Said to Line Up for Global Mart Assets
text: Standard Chartered‘s private equity unit, the Chinese conglomerate Fosun Group and three other bidders are vying to buy two Chinese retailers and other assets from the investment firm Global Mart, in a deal expected to fetch about 500 million yuan ($73 million), Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: If Health Care Bills Fail, a Quandary for Insurers
text: With the possible collapse of the Congressional health care effort, health insurers might seem to have reason to celebrate. The legislation threatened to remake much of their business, with the prospect of burdensome government regulation and less profit from selling coverage to individuals and small businesses.

headline: Rusal Said to Raise $2.2 Billion in I.P.O.
text: Rusal, the world’s largest aluminum producer, raised 17.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.2 billion) in the first initial public offering by a Russian company in Hong Kong, two people familiar with the sale told Bloomberg News.

headline: How Much Time Do You Spend ‘Consuming Media’ Every Day?
text: The answer for the average 8 to 18-year-old, according to an  article about a new study, is “practically every waking minute — except for the time in school.” Is this true about you? Are you using a phone, computer, television, mp3 player or other electronic device for the vast majority of your free time? If so, how do you think such heavy media use is affecting you?

headline: Hopes Rest on Cohen’s Return to Competition
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  Desperate to restore a pulse to a flatlining sport, U.S. Figure Skating and NBC built their promotions for the national championships around the resuscitation of Sasha Cohen.

headline: China Rebuffs Clinton on Internet Warning
text: BEIJING  The Chinese Foreign Ministry lashed out Friday against criticism of China in a speech on Internet censorship made by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, calling on the United States government “to respect the truth and to stop using the so-called Internet freedom question to level baseless accusations.”

headline: Nagasu Is in the Lead, but She Isn’t Ready to Exhale
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  The good Mirai Nagasu, the one that oozes talent and effervescence, skated at United States championships on Thursday. She cracked a saucy smile and used her eyes to flirt with the crowd. With an Olympic berth at stake and the pressure mounting, she looked like she was having fun.

headline: Exiting Bankruptcy, DeCode Lands in V.C. Hands
text: DeCode Genetics, the gene-hunting company in Iceland, said Thursday that it had emerged from bankruptcy and would continue its genetics research and its gene-based diagnostics as a private company. It will abandon its efforts to develop drugs from its discoveries.

headline: Wall Street a Bright Spot Amid Grim Jobless Figures
text: The unemployment rate in New York City jumped in December to 10.6 percent, its highest level in nearly 17 years, as hotels, museums and builders eliminated jobs and hiring remained weak in most other businesses, the State Labor Department said Thursday.

headline: Bank Plan Trips Financial Stocks in Europe
text: Financial stocks in Europe sagged Friday, following sharp losses in Asia, but broader stock indices held firm as investors balanced the conflicting prospect of tighter financial regulation with gradually improving growth rates.

headline: Good Times and Bad, Henin Kept Her Coach in View

headline: Clijsters Knocked Out of Australian Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Bye, bye, Kim Clijsters. The Australian Open faithful barely got to know the U.S. Open champ here Friday night. She was on the court for 52 minutes, and Nadia Petrova, the 19th-seeded Russian, embarrassed her pretty much every second in a thorough 6-0, 6-1 banishment.

headline: Why Wait for Obama? Agencies Move on Banks
text: U.S. banking supervisors are using existing authority to raise standards for capital, liquidity and risk management without waiting for the Obama administration and Congress to hammer out a new regulatory structure, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Outside Goldman, Bomb-Sniffers and Barricades
text: The public outrage over Wall Street’s rich bonus culture apparently had Goldman Sachs so rattled that the bank had police barricades and bomb-sniffing dogs outside of 85 Broad Street Thursday, as it prepared to release earnings, The New York Post reported.

headline: Speeding in America? Nah
text: Apparently, the maniac wildly careening through traffic is offset by the moron going 40 miles per hour in the left lane.

headline: G.E. Profit Drops 19%, but Beats Predictions
text: General Electric’s profit fell 19 percent in the fourth quarter, the company said on Friday, a better result than Wall Street had expected. But mounting commercial loan losses and dwindling demand for items like jet engines raised some concerns among analysts, even though the company said it was on track for growth this year.

headline: ‘Controlled Serendipity’ Liberates the Web
text: When I finish writing this blog post, I will Tweet it.

headline: F1 to Ban Double Diffusers
text: This time it will be clear: No more double diffusers. According to a report on Autosport.com, the technical working group – all the F1 team technical directors – have finally agreed to ban the so-called double diffusers that caused the big controversy at the start of last season, and for which some lingering bitterness remained until the end.

headline: Sampler: Carrying a Gun in the Open and More Rain Needed
text: Parents Object To Internet Tower | Parents expressed anger at a school meeting Wednesday about a proposal to put a 37-foot Internet antenna tower disguised as an evergreen tree near Walnut Heights Elementary School’s playground. If approved, the school district would receive $15,000 a year from Clearwire, which sells a WiMax broadband service. The antenna spreads radio waves wider than Wi-Fi radio waves, something that concerns some parents. “I don’t want my kids used as an experiment,” said John Johnson. [The Contra Costa Times]

headline: Jets-Colts Q. and A. With Greg Bishop
text: Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The Times, answered readers’ questions on Friday in the comment section below. The Jets are preparing to face the Colts in the American Football Conference championship on Sunday.

headline: This Time, N.F.L. Star Is Watching Isner Advance
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Last week, John Isner, a 6-9 American with a monster serve, won his first single’s title last week in Auckland, New Zealand. How monster?

headline: The Early Word: Supreme Court Speaks
text: With midterm elections on the horizon, the Supreme Court released a decision on Thursday that opens the door for substantial changes in how campaigns are financed.

headline: Energy Debate Yields Little Middle Ground
text: CHARLESTON, W. Va. — Speaking ahead of Thursday evening’s debate between a coal executive, Don L. Blankenship of Massey Energy, and an environmental lawyer, Robert Kennedy Jr., the University of Charleston’s president, Ed Welch, expressed hope that he might nudge the two men “beyond their talking points.”

headline: Writing in the Dahl House, Part 2
text: “Fantastic Mr. Fox,” Wes Anderson’s adaptation of the Roald Dahl children’s book, has garnered Mr. Anderson some of the most effusive praise of his already-lauded career, and made him a contender in the awards game. Though he is not exactly a veteran of the circuit, his debut, “Bottle Rocket,” did win an MTV award in 1996. (“It’s so badly made though,” Mr. Anderson said. “It’s meant to look like popcorn and the carton just started to peel apart. It’s not one that you can really keep forever on the mantelpiece.”) The Bagger spoke to Mr. Anderson and his co-writer, Noah Baumbach, in Los Angeles. This is Part 2 of the conversation; Part 1 can be found here.

headline: Top Paterson Strategist to Leave Campaign
text: A top campaign strategist for Gov. David A. Paterson said Friday morning that she was departing the campaign, dealing a blow for the governor’s flagging bid to be elected in his own right later this year.

headline: New York’s Jobless Rate Now Exceeds Nation’s
text: The unemployment rate in New York City jumped in December to 10.6 percent, its highest level in nearly 17 years, as hotels, museums and builders eliminated jobs and hiring remained weak in most other businesses, the state’s Department of Labor said Thursday.

headline: A Coffee Bar, Not a Cafe
text: This week I was in Bluebird Coffee Shop, (72 East First Street, 212-260-1879) the coffee bar that opened in the former Simon Sips space (and what had been the Tasting Room before that).

headline: Commercial Real Estate and NBC Weigh Down G.E.
text: General Electric‘s decision to shrink its commercial finance arm and eventually divest itself of NBC Universal couldn’t have come fast enough.

headline: Hershey Won’t Challenge Kraft for Cadbury
text: Hershey announced Friday that it would not bid for Cadbury, making official what analysts and investors had suspected since Kraft presented a $19 billion revised offer that had the blessing of the Cadbury board.

headline: Revised M.T.A. Plan Would Avert Some Service Cuts
text: Updated, 1:36 p.m. | A newly configured slate of transit service cuts was unveiled on Friday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, restoring overnight service to several crosstown bus routes through Central Park, and avoiding some previously announced cuts, like less-frequent trains at night.

headline: The Choice
text: So, House Democrats have a choice: do they pass the Senate bill, or do they go back to the drawing board and spend several months cobbling together a plan that’s worse in almost every dimension, generating thousands of stories about hapless Democrats — and almost surely find that Senate Republicans block the new plan, too.

headline: Jan. 22: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
text: On Friday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of last week’s earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any firsthand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort. Previous Lede updates: Jan. 21 | Jan. 20 |Jan. 19 | Jan. 18 | Jan. 17 | Jan. 16 | Jan. 15 | Jan. 14 | Jan. 12 and 13

headline: How Andy Roddick Won: Patience
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Andy Roddick looked refreshed. He had just turned back a determined challenger, Feliciano López of Spain, in four sets. It was his sixth consecutive victory over Lopez, to whom he has not lost.

headline: Every Waking Minute? Examining Personal Media Habits
text: Overview | What are the implications of a new study showing that kids use electronic devices virtually all the time? In this lesson, students take a close look at their own media use over time, identify any detrimental habits, then develop personal plans and put them into action. They then write and deliver persuasive speeches on the media and technology topic of their choice.

headline: Tourists Return to an Ancient Crossroads in Syria
text: TO shouts of “yella-yella”  move along!  the driver of a donkey lugging a wagon overstuffed with pistachios parted the throngs of shoppers in Aleppo’s medieval souk. It was the middle of Ramadan, just hours before the iftar, the evening meal when Muslims break their daily fast, and the market’s serpentine rows of squat stalls were filled with black-veiled women and keffiyeh-clad men, sniffing the handmade olive soaps and stocking up on spices.

headline: Friday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: What Did Geithner Say?
text: Various news reports that Tim Geithner is privately opposed to the new Obama bank plan — which isn’t that much of a surprise, but he should not be talking about it (if he is). What we do have is this PBS interview, in which he certainly isn’t doing much to back the concept. The correct answer to “In essence are you saying that big banks need to be broken up” is “Yes”; add some qualifiers if necessary — “we’re not talking about a sudden disruption, but about new rules of the game, but the eventual goal is smaller banks that aren’t engaged in inappropriate activities” or something like that.

headline: Memories of Sugar Hill
text: Stories of people who grew up in a part of Harlem in the 1930s and ’40s and found success all around them.

headline: In Sugar Hill, a Street Nurtured Black Talent When the World Wouldn’t
text: New York is a city of blocks, each with its own history, customs and characters. Yet from these small stages spring large talents. Anyone who doubts that need look no further than a stretch of Edgecombe Avenue perched on a bluff near 155th Street.

headline: Obama Heads to Ohio, Trying to Turn the Page Toward Job Recovery
text: Yesterday, President Obama went to war with Wall Street. Today, he courts Main Street.

headline: Dealing With the Financial Burden of Autism
text: WHEN Jeff Sell’s twin sons were found to have autism 13 years ago, he, like so many other parents in the same situation, found himself with a million questions: Will my children be able to function? What are the best treatments and where do I find them? How will this affect the rest of my family?

headline: Donations to Haiti May Be Deductible on 2009 Returns

headline: The Moviegoer | No Sex Please, They’re Married
text: “Creation,” which concerns Charles Darwin’s 20-year-long Hamlet moment over writing “Origin of Species,” is not what you commonly call a sexy story — even if 5-year-old viewers (both of them) will still say eeeewww: a barnacle is graphically dissected, a fox eats a rabbit (thus furthering the cause of movie foxes not named Megan; see “Antichrist”) and, in Darwin’s workshop, acid-washed birds are boiled down to their bones. For adults, however, the most disturbing event in this British production will be a rather Victorian sex scene between Darwin and his wife, Emma. Why? Because they’re played by the real-life couple Paul Bettany and Jennifer Connelly.Sure, we understand: the director, Jon Amiel, wanted to avail himself of the instant intimacy of a married twosome. But who wants to see that? Who wanted to see Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger getting it on in “The Getaway”? Who wanted to cross the minefield that was Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman in “Eyes Wide Shut”? Who wanted to see Ed Harris and Amy Madigan (as the painter Jackson Pollock and heiress Peggy Guggenheim) coupling like wildebeests in “Pollock”? O.K., that was pretty funny. But married people in bed? You might as well watch a Don Johnson-Melanie Griffith festival.

headline: In the World’s Tech Hub, an Expensive Old Ritual
text: Today’s Barbary Coast column is about a primitive form of communication. No, not something from an ancient civilization. It’s the system in place to identify the trains, tracks and departure times at the otherwise very modern Caltrain terminus at 4th and Townsend Streets in San Francisco.

headline: Three Steps to Making Smart Haiti Donations
text: As soon as they heard about the earthquake, Haitians in Brooklyn started making their way to Savoir Faire, the record store in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, to pool what little information anyone had. And they also brought supplies to send back home  clothing, canned fruit, ramen, cases of bottled water. By early last week, the donations had been stacked into huge piles, and a plan had come into view: the store would lead a delegation of 25 people to Haiti, to rescue the children stranded at the Life for the World orphanage in the town of Source Matelas. Doctors, nurses and anyone else who wanted to come would each carry two large suitcases stuffed with food and medical supplies.

headline: Weekend Competition: Erroneous Advice
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to be downright mean by proffering deliberately unhelpful advice for visitors from out of town.

headline: Complaint Box | The E-Snub
text: NOT too long ago, a magazine in Manhattan invited me, by e-mail, to interview for a job. After meeting with me, the managing editor and the director of human resources asked me to take home the standard editing test and return it ASAP. I dutifully obliged.

headline: Letter: Antarctica's Allure
text: To the editor: Great new, enticing picks in “The 31 Places to Go in 2010” (Jan. 10) to whet the appetite for unusual travel. However, as a many-time traveler to Antarctica since the early 1980s, the statements suggesting that tourist travel has been only recent belie the facts. While 2010 may be a good year to go, ships complying with new standards at a later date will continue to make this continent the ultimate destination for those who have a love of unsurpassed natural beauty.

headline: Corrections
text: The cover article on Jan. 10 about 31 Places to Go in 2010 misidentified the opposing sides in the civil war that plagued Sri Lanka for a quarter century. The war was between the Sinhalese-dominated government and a separatist Tamil group, not between the Sinhalese majority and the Tamil minority.

headline: Spice Girls Plan a Musical Based on Their Songs
text: Watch out, “Mamma Mia!” The Spice Girls are cooking up a musical with an original story based on their hit songs, Reuters reports. The working title is “Viva Forever,” after the 1998 British No. 1 single by the five-member British band. The “Viva Forever” creators are the band’s former manager Simon Fuller and Judy Craymer, who produced the worldwide hit musical “Mamma Mia!” which featured the songs of the Swedish band Abba, and later became a movie starring Meryl Streep. “Mamma Mia!” has made $2 billion in the past decade. The Spice Girls show could debut on the London stage in two or three years, Mr. Fuller and Ms. Craymer said. The Spice Girls — Melanie Chisholm (Sporty Spice or Mel C), Victoria Beckham (Posh Spice), Geri Halliwell (Ginger Spice); Emma Bunton (Baby Spice) and Melanie Brown (Scary Spice) became a cultural phenomenon after releasing their first single “Wannabe” in 1996. The group split up in 2000 but reunited for a tour in 2007.

text: SOMETIMES, all it takes for a neighborhood to be transformed is some renovated footpaths.

headline: Kitty Kelley Takes On Oprah Winfrey
text: Oprah Winfrey is the latest subject for Kitty Kelley, known for her often unflattering, dishy and best-selling celebrity biographies. Crown Publishers announced this week that Ms. Kelley‘s 544-page, unauthorized “Oprah: A Biography,” will be released on April 13, The Associated Press reported. The first printing will be at least 500,000 copies. Ms. Kelley has written books about Frank Sinatra, Nancy Reagan and the Bush family. She conducted 850 interviews for the book and spent the last three years combing through Ms. Winfrey’s life, Ms. Kelley said, according to the A.P. She was, Ms. Kelley said, “full of admiration for her accomplishments and fascinated by her complexity.”

headline: Anne Boleyn, Queen for a Day
text: The story of Anne Boleyn, second wife of Henry VIII, ended in May 1536, when the master executioner of Calais — sent for specially, and said to be an adept in his art — separated her clever head from her seductive body with one clean stroke of his sword. Historians are still puzzling over Anne’s downfall. Henry had fought for years to extricate himself from his first marriage and create a world where he and Anne could be husband and wife; to achieve it, he had split Christian Europe apart. How did he become so alienated from her that he wanted her dead? Had she really slept with her brother George? Who was the prime mover in alleging against her multiple acts of adultery, involving five men? Was it Henry himself, crediting some slander and lashing out in blind rage? Or his minister Thomas Cromwell, fighting for his own career? What part was played by the papist supporters of the Princess Mary, Henry’s child by his first marriage? Were all these parties, for different reasons, acting together? And at what point was Anne’s doom sealed? Did her fortunes begin to falter in January 1536, when the king’s first wife died and Anne miscarried a child? Or was she brought down over a few days, in an atmosphere of fulminating panic that infected the entire court?

headline: On Liberia’s Shore, Catching a New Wave
text: WE were less than 30 minutes from our destination of Robertsport, home to Liberia’s nascent surfing scene, and gliding along what one local had accurately described as “the best dirt road in the country,” when my driver, Andrew, and I got into a loud and boisterous fight.

headline: Swiss Ruling Jeopardizes Deal for UBS Clients’ Names
text: A Swiss court ruled Friday that Swiss authorities may not disclose the account details of a wealthy American who used UBS’s private bank to evade American taxes.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Lake Chalet Seafood Bar & Grill, in Oakland, Calif.
text: Every city needs a lake, and every lake needs a $22 million restaurant on its shores, where you can munch on tacos while a passing gondolier sings in Italian. Luckily, Oakland has figured this out, and residents can now unwind at the Lake Chalet there, where an inconsistent menu takes a back seat to the stunning surroundings.

headline: Katherine Hess, Andrew Secunda
text: Katherine Kimble Hess and Andrew Morgan Secunda were married Saturday evening at Twenty Four Fifth, an event space in Manhattan. Amichai Lau-Lavie, the spiritual leader of Storahtelling, a Jewish organization, officiated.

headline: Long March
text: The ad agency employees who form the collective narrative voice of Joshua Ferris’s masterly debut, “Then We Came to the End,” are on intimate terms with the concept of branding. As branders, they undoubtedly would have advised their creator, in planning his second novel, to hew closely to the recipe that made his first novel such a critical and popular success, that made it read sort of like a highbrow novelization of “The Office.” With his second novel Ferris makes it clear that he has absolutely no intention, for the moment at least, of repeating himself or creating an authorial brand. In fact, it’s difficult to believe that “The Unnamed” and “Then We Came to the End” come from the same laptop.

headline: Alison Shaffer, Samuel Ballen
text: Alison Jill Shaffer and Samuel David Ballen are to be married Sunday in an outdoor ceremony at the Seagate Beach Club in Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Steinhardt is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Storm Hits Russo & Steele Collector Car Auction
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The Russo & Steele classic car auction was interrupted Thursday night by strong winds accompanying a wild storm that damaged cars and ripped away huge sections of the event’s tents and deposited them in the traffic lanes of the adjacent 101 freeway.

headline: Mets Acquire Gary Matthews Jr. From Angels

headline: The Producer
text: Heroes without flaws appear only in bad comics and worse books and movies. The giants who seize our attention and embody achievement at its most inspiring are often nearly as troublesome as they are noble, with defects and virtues that can stem from the same deep drives. Joseph Papp, the Brooklyn-born impresario who changed the face of the American theater by founding the New York Shakespeare Festival and the Public Theater, is unquestionably a hero of the complicated kind. His story is revisited in rich, rewarding detail in a fat new book, “Free for All: Joe Papp, the Public, and the Greatest Theater Story Ever Told,” written by Kenneth Turan and — what’s this? — yes, Papp himself.

headline: Danny Boyle to Direct ‘Frankenstein’ on the London Stage
text: Now let’s see. How many versions of “Frankenstein” will this make? Danny Boyle, the director of the Oscar-winning “Slumdog Millionaire” is to direct a stage adaptation of “Frankenstein,” based on the novel by Mary Shelley, The Guardian reports. Nicholas Hytner, the director of the National Theater in London, said that the British director will make his debut at the theater later this year. Mr. Hytner said that Mr. Boyle, who began his career at London’s Royal Court and the Royal Shakespeare Company, was returning to his first love after film “distracted” him for a while. (Mr. Boyle also directed “Trainspotting.”) “Danny first talked about this eight years ago and it has taken him eight years,” Mr. Hytner said of Mr. Boyle’s decision to direct the playwright Nick Dear’s new adaptation of “Frankenstein.” It will be a “large-scale and theatrically and visually ambitious stage production,” Mr. Hytner said

headline: Anne Bracken, Patrick Gavin
text: Anne Margaret Grace Bracken and Patrick William Gavin were married Saturday evening in Washington. The Rev. Susan Moss, an Episcopal priest and an aunt of the bride, officiated at the National Museum of Women in the Arts.

headline: Travel Deals: 40% Off in Turks and Caicos
text: The Seven Stars Resort in Turks and Caicos is offering 40 percent off as part of a winter special. With the discount, rooms start at $390 a night through March 31. A three-night minimum stay is required.

headline: A Home for Hidden Treasures in London
text: WHEN it first opened in 1852, the stated mission of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London was to inspire designers, manufacturers and artists of the day. Now, with a brand-new set of galleries, the museum is hoping to inspire visitors by luring them back through the centuries.

headline: Now Screening | Dries Van Noten
text: The fall 2010 collection from Dries Van Noten.

headline: One Thing After Another
text: Not long ago, I walked in on a group of medical residents inserting a central line catheter into a patient in the intensive care unit. They were gowned and gloved, working quietly over the patient’s neck, exposed through a small hole in a sterile blue drape, where a thick needle was entering under the collarbone. I ­noticed they had neglected to drape the ­abdomen and legs, but at this point it didn’t seem wise to interrupt the procedure, so I let it go. They had also apparently forgotten to don face shields and caps. I let that go, too. Like them, I wanted to get the ­procedure over with as quickly as possible ­before something bad happened.

headline: The Mobs Turn Their Ire to Athletes
text: Memo to star athletes, former athletes, coaches: This is not the time to tick people off.

headline: Room Service
text: You have to be a little crazy to read as much into “Psycho” as David Thomson does in “The Moment of ‘Psycho’: How Alfred Hitchcock Taught America to Love Murder.” Not that crazy people can’t be charming and erudite, just as Anthony Perkins’s Norman Bates is in that movie. But read this book in long stretches — sit, as it were, with Thomson in a room and listen to him expound — and you may start having that “I gotta get out of here” feeling.

headline: Troy Story
text: Neither the early life of Priam, the elderly king of Troy, nor his miserable and bloody fate are direct concerns of the “Iliad.” The Homeric epic opens in medias res, already in the 10th year of the Trojan War, and it draws toward its suspenseful close with one of the most brilliant and counterintuitive epi­sodes in all of ancient literature, Priam’s stupendously dangerous journey to the heart of the Greek camp to ransom the corpse of his son Hector from the Trojans’ implacable enemy, Achilles.

headline: Group Hug | Day 1 at the Paris Men’s Shows
text: The Paris shows were off to a good start with Louis Vuitton, where the men’s studio director, Paul Helbers, got things going with a Vienna-inspired parade of somber flecked coats and jackets, convertible boots with zippers and beautiful bags with abstract hand-painting by the artist Christian Schoeller. Helbers said that he had looked at artists like Egon Schiele and Gustav Klimt for inspiration; he also commissioned a soundtrack featuring a Kafka reading, and even changed the show-space configuration: instead of a normal runway, models walked in a mazelike setup to allow for greater proximity to the audience. It was a smart move. From the leather anoraks and blazers to the new clog-inspired short boots and the contrasting fabric insets on jackets and coats, this was a collection that needed to be seen up close.

headline: Kimberly Essency, Antonino Pillari
text: Kimberly Brooke Essency, the daughter of Barbara L. Essency and C. Keith Essency of Austin, Tex., was married in Manhattan Saturday to Antonino Pillari, a son of Maria Pillari and Francesco Pillari of Astoria, Queens. The Rev. Anthony Schueller performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

headline: Capitalist Chameleon
text: What is the nature of capitalism? For Joseph Schumpeter, the Austrian-born economist whose writings have acquired a special relevance in the past year or two, this most modern of economic systems “incessantly revolutionizes the economic structure from within, incessantly destroying the old one, incessantly creating a new one.” Capitalism, Schumpeter proclaimed, cannot stand still; it is a system driven by waves of entrepreneurial innovation, or what he memorably described as a “perennial gale of creative destruction.”

headline: Adjustments Likely in Hudson River Cleanup
text: Judging from some draft evaluations prepared by the Environmental Protection Agency and General Electric, the plan for dredging the Hudson River for PCBs faces some likely adjustments.

headline: The Buying Begins at Sundance
text: This is an auspicious beginning: hours before the opening film at the Sundance Film Festival, the first deal has already been made. Variety reports that “Waiting for Superman,” a documentary about the crisis in public education, was picked up by Paramount for its (much-streamlined) boutique Paramount Vantage division. The film comes from Davis Guggenheim and Lesley Chilcott, the director-producer team behind “An Inconvenient Truth,” which made an Oscar-winning moneymaker out of another unsexy topic — the environment.

headline: The Shopping Cure
text: The Egyptian Islamist theoretician Sayyid Qutb believed the West — in particular the United States — posed an existential threat to Islam. He feared that globalization, spearheaded by the American colossus, might eventually destroy Islam by tempting pious Muslims with freewheeling capitalism, the separation of religion from government and the unleashing of decadent “animalistic desires.” Qutb, in word and in deed, took up the sword against Gamal Abdel Nasser’s secular government. Nasser hanged him in 1966, but Qutb’s ideas transformed the world by inspiring Osama bin Laden’s Qaeda theology.

headline: Carolina Bolado and Nathan Hale

headline: The Year That Was
text: Europe’s geopolitical map, just 20 years after the breach of the Berlin Wall, looks like a foregone conclusion today — the natural upshot of Communism’s demise and the spread of liberal democracy. The Central Europeans are snugly in the European Union; NATO presides over a largely peaceful continent; and though spats between the West and an authoritarian Russia occasionally flare, this is surely understandable given all the givens.

headline: First Tweet From Space
text: On Friday Timothy Creamer, an Astronaut on board the International Space Station (I.S.S.), sent the first live tweet from space. It was one small tweet for man, one giant tweet for mankind.

headline: Fresh Powder Meets Fine Dining at Cortina d’Ampezzo
text: CONSIDERING the elegant bottle of sangiovese he was about to pour, the waiter’s ragged stocking cap and well-worn black sweater might have been casual to the point of gauche. The diners weren’t exactly in black tie either, with many dressed in stretchy sportswear and poofy coveralls. But the dishes were without flaw: an unusual beet ravioli, startlingly rich and sweet, and a creamy bowl of polenta that was cheesy and velvety.

headline: When N.F.L. Ruled Airwaves With Blackouts
text: In the dark days of silly, anti-fan blackouts, Jets fans had to travel at least 75 miles outside the New York City market to watch their team beat the Oakland Raiders in the 1968 American Football League championship game.

headline: This Article Is Not Yet Rated
text: ALONG with buckets of money  more than $1.6 billion so far, worldwide  and a couple of Golden Globes, James Cameron’s “Avatar” has collected a smattering of controversy. Some of the hue and cry has involved matters of political allegory and theological implication, as pundits have divined that this globally popular blockbuster may represent a veiled ideological attack on America, capitalism, humanity, monotheism or all of the above. But the fiercest attack on “Avatar” has focused on what may seem, compared to such lofty matters, like a minor detail. Of all the corny lines and ready-made catchphrases in Mr. Cameron’s script, perhaps none has turned out to be so provocative as one uttered by Grace Augustine, the scientist played by Sigourney Weaver: “Where’s my damn cigarette?”

headline: Another View: Putting Clients First by Going Private
text: William W. Sprague, chief executive of the privately held investment bank Madison Williams and a former Kidder Peabody and Smith Barney banker, says a return to a private partnership culture may be the best medicine for unrepentant Wall Street professionals.

headline: It’s Not Supposed to Work Like This
text: LIKE a lot of boomers, Allan Goldstein, 60, has mixed feelings about the online world he inhabits. As a college teacher — he’s the assistant director of the writing program at the Polytechnic Institute of New York University — he works with young people and feels pressure to keep current. He uses an electronic blackboard system to post his syllabus, class assignments and grades online, but he doesn’t trust it. “There are glitches,” he said. “The school’s system has crashed a few times. They want us to use it, but I back everything up on paper.”

headline: Florida by Subway
text: KATHERINE WAI CHAN and Jimmy Louie, who started dating as college students in Ohio in the late 1990s, began their life together in distinctly unprepossessing quarters.

headline: 2010: The Year of the Renter?
text: SCORES of stalled construction projects can be found scattered around New York City, but one category of building that doesn’t seem to have been sidetracked by the recession is the luxury apartment rental.

headline: Graphic Best-Seller Lists:  A Series Inspired by Christopher Robin, but Not for Kids
text: Tom Taylor has a problem. He is the inspiration for Tommy Taylor, a world-renowned boy-wizard character concocted by his father, an author. The pressure of being linked to such a beloved icon is crushing. There’s also an added complication: Tommy’s fictional world is seeping into the real one. And that’s just the beginning of “The Unwritten,” a new series written by Mike Carey and illustrated by Peter Gross, whose first collected edition lands at No. 8 on our softcover list this week.

text: Representative Barney Frank said Friday that the House Financial Services Committee, which he leads, would push to replace Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, seized by regulators almost 17 months ago, with a different model for mortgage financing.

headline: A Different ‘Howl’ for a Revamped Sundance
text: The revamped Sundance Film Festival – slogan: “Reborn. Rebellion. Rebirth. Rebel. Renewed. Rebooted” — got under way on Thursday night, and some changes were already evident. At the opening news conference, Robert Redford, the founder and guiding light, dissed a regular attendee: “Paris Hilton doesn’t have anything to do with anything,” he said, as Roger Ebert reported.

headline: Chair of Goldman Hedge Group Said to Retire
text: The chairman of Goldman Sachs‘s quantitative hedge fund group, whose funds run off of complex computer trading algorithms, plans to step down at the end of the month, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: David C. Walentas
text: Mr. Walentas, 71, is the founder and principal of the Two Trees Management Company, which has developed and managed more than four million square feet of commercial and residential real estate, mostly in New York City. Mr. Walentas is also credited with establishing the Dumbo neighborhood in Brooklyn.

headline: ‘Corporations Are Not People’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: The Supreme Court today ruled in a five votes to four decision that corporations can now spend as much as they want on political campaigns. In other words, if Exxon or Dow wants to support a candidate, they can give him or her as much money as they want. I can’t see that having any negative repercussions, can you?

headline: ‘Great American Speeches’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Well, today officially marks the beginning of President Obama’s second year in office. He has three years left, but NBC offered him $45 million to leave altogether. So, we’ll see what happens.

headline: Free Checking Could Go the Way of Free Toasters
text: Free checking began as a privilege. Once it spread, customers felt entitled. Eventually, it became a commodity, as most banks felt they needed to offer it. Soon, people took it for granted.

headline: ‘A Separation Agreement’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” on NBC: NBC and I have finally reached a separation agreement. I’d like to apologize to the guests that were scheduled for next week. President Barack Obama, the pope, the queen of England, and our good friend, Elvis Presley, was stopping by.

headline: Mapping Future Growth
text: IF every acre of unprotected open space on Long Island were developed with single-family homes, the landscape could hold another 90,000 homes. On the other hand, if erected as town houses, garden apartments and apartment buildings, the same 90,000 units could be built in downtown areas, utilizing about half of the 8,300 acres — or 13 square miles — of available parking lots, vacant land or open space on the Island.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Atul Gawande
text: This week: Atul Gawande discusses his new book, “The Checklist Manifesto”; Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The New York Times, remembers the great Joseph Papp; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: At Bonus Time, Less Appetite for Toys
text: WITH all eyes on banks and their bonus pools, there is the question of what happens to the bonus money the bankers receive this year. Will they return to flashy spending or invest it more conservatively?

headline: ‘Which Is More Hard to Believe?’

headline: New Guidelines Could Make Co-op Renovations Tougher
text: IF they had a theme song, the new co-op renovation guidelines from the New York City Bar Association might be set to the rock anthem “We’re Not Gonna Take It.”

headline: A Guide to the New Good Faith Estimate
text: Anyone who has shopped for a mortgage knows how confusing the process can be — loans come with different sets of fees, interest rates and closing costs, all of which must be untangled before you can figure out who’s offering the best deal. But comparison shopping may get a little easier.

headline: ‘The Delicate Balance of Power’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Well, in political news, the big upset. A Republican was elected to the U.S. Senate in Massachusetts, filling a seat once held by Ted Kennedy. So, this could tip the delicate balance of power in the U.S. Senate from the completely incompetent back to the morally corrupt.

headline: A Second Act for Trump Condo
text: JERSEY CITY

headline: In Ohio, Obama Vows to Keep Fighting on Health Care
text: ELYRIA, Ohio – Conceding his health care overhaul had run into “a little bit of a buzz saw,’’ President Obama vowed on Friday to keep fighting for legislation that will “hold the insurance industry accountable” and “to bring more stability and security to folks who are in our health care system.’’

headline: Luxury Retirement Community Planned in Westchester
text: ROUND-THE-CLOCK NURSING? You’ve got it. Alzheimer’s support? Ditto. Cocktail lounge and valet parking? But of course.

headline: Obstacles to Recovery in Haiti May Prove Daunting Beyond Other Disasters
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The relief effort in Haiti could end up being the most difficult, faith-testing recovery from a modern disaster, perhaps even exceeding that from the 2004 Asian tsunami, according to United Nation officials and aid groups with experience in large-scale catastrophes.

headline: São Paulo Fashion Week | Hits Below the Equator
text: São Paulo fashion week is still coming into its own, but it certainly gives good show. From a slew of supermodels to unmarked after-parties, the cool quotient held its own against the more traditional fashion capitals. This season’s model check saw Lara Stone walking for Forum Tufi Duek, Brazil’s prodigal son Jesus Luz doing an awkward catwalk turn for Ellus, Alessandra Ambrosio filling in for Gisele at Colcci, Isabeli Fontana opening for Alexandre Herchcovitch and Chanel Iman at Rosa Cha.

headline: Choking Game No Mystery to Children, Oregon Study Finds
text: One in three eighth graders in Oregon has heard of the dangerous “choking game,” and more than 1 in 20 have taken part, according to one of the first statewide surveillance efforts to gauge the popularity of this risky pastime.

headline: Comment by China Adds to Mystery of Missing Lawyer
text: BEIJING  The Chinese government made its first official comments on Thursday about a prominent human rights advocate who disappeared nearly a year ago, but its remarks left his fate shrouded in mystery.

headline: Swiss Court Rules UBS Cannot Release Client’s Data
text: A client of the Swiss banking giant UBS has won an appeal to prevent her account information from being handed over to authorities in Washington as part of a tax evasion investigation, Reuters reported.

headline: A New Take on Refinancing
text: SEARCHING for home mortgage rates online often means submitting information to a Web site, then withstanding a flurry of calls and e-mail messages from brokers and lenders trying to sell a loan.

headline: Risottos for a Midwinter Night’s Meal
text: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman turns to risottos, the creamy Italian rice and grain dishes that offer warmth and comfort on these cold winter nights.

headline: Attracted to Walkable New York
text: IT was Manhattan’s street life that appealed most to John Southern and Polly Crongeyer, residents of Pensacola, Fla. Last year the couple, who are both retired, “were thinking about redesigning our lifestyle a little bit,” Mr. Southern said.

headline: Fireman Ed Sits Out a Big One
text: All the earth — or at least those living in a frenzied parallel universe known as Jets fandom — might view the 6-foot-1, 235-pound retired New York City fireman as a talisman for regaining lost Super Bowl glory, a raging, one-man booster club for a once-storied football franchise on the verge of toppling doubt.

headline: Veterans Like Sharper Found a Fit With the Saints
text: NEW ORLEANS  The deal was struck during a business meal late last winter at Emeril’s.

headline: Oil Estimates in Venezuela Doubled
text: Venezuela has long been known to hold some of the world’s biggest deposits of oil sands — thick bituminous resources that require substantial investments and refining methods to develop.

headline: How Players Recover After a Match
text: With both the temperatures and the intensity ratcheting up as we round the bend into the second week at the Australian Open, recovery after a match starts to have a bigger effect on performance. Both Justine Henin and Kim Clijsters looked a step slow and not in top form in their second-round matches. And on the men’s side, Markos Baghdatis and Mikhail Youzhny each endured painful cramps at the end of their recent five-set wins.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1.) America’s best companies to work for, according to Fortune Magazine.

headline: Dark Times for Harley-Davidson’s Bottom Line
text: Harley-Davidson reported its 2009 earnings on Friday, and they were bad – worse than Wall Street analysts had been expecting. In fact, 2009 was the worst year for the Milwaukee-based motorcycle maker since 1993.

text: In today’s Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad focuses on the financial impact autism has on families. She writes:

headline: Would You Pay for a Checking Account?
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I explain why the free checking account may be an endangered species.

headline: A Static View in a Changing Neighborhood
text: THE view from the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, a five-block walkway that has overlooked New York Harbor from its perch at neighborhood’s edge since 1950, is almost the same as it was 60 years ago. The Lower Manhattan skyline rises up, seeming close enough to touch, against a backdrop of clouds; tugboats push barges to and fro; cars and trucks race underneath on the cantilevered Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

headline: Teacher Q | What’s Working Well in Your Classroom This Year?
text: In many schools the semester is winding down, so we thought this week we’d ask a question that might help you reflect on the last five months and inspire you for the next five.

headline: “Howl”: Allen Ginsberg and His Times Are Brought To Life
text: There was a “mad night” in 1955 when Allen Ginsberg read his poem “Howl” for the first time at the Six Gallery, a former auto-body shop on Fillmore street in San Francisco.

headline: Geithnerdaemmerung?
text: One surprise consequences of the debacle in Massachusetts is that Democrats are suddenly turning on the architects of the financial rescue. Bernanke’s reappointment doesn’t look so certain; Geithner and Summers are apparently on the outs.

headline: Going Really Indie, With His Own Cash
text: INSIDE the Bay Ridge Manor catering hall in Brooklyn recently, preparations were under way for yet another rites-of-passage weekend: bar mitzvahs, weddings, sweet 16s. But in an upstairs office resembling a military headquarters a different kind of promise was being fulfilled: “ ‘White Irish Drinkers’!,” a young woman said, answering the phone. No, it wasn’t an A.A. meeting. It was a movie.

headline: Davis Undergoes Second Surgery
text: The injured snowboarder Danny Davis had surgery for the second time since his all-terrain vehicle crash, this one on Thursday to repair a broken pelvic bone, his agent said in a statement.

headline: Footage of Subway Robberies
text: A video clip of a robbery on December 25, 2009 and footage of the suspect leaving the subway.

headline: Watching 'Serpico' With Serpico
text: Forty years after getting shot in a drug bust and testifying against police corruption, retired Detective Frank Serpico is still trying to heal.

text: Ms. Rivers calls her 5,000-square-foot home a "Connecticut country manor."

headline: Get Ready for a New Tax
text: Income taxes alone won’t be enough to fill the nation’s budget hole, according to a new study.

headline: Urban Bush Women, Moving Through a Defiant Past
text: Anniversaries are opportunities for pomp, circumstance and celebration. There was some of that on Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop, when the Urban Bush Women, led by its founder, Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, kicked off its 25th-anniversary season with “Zollar: Uncensored.” Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s artistic director, Judith Jamison, gave a postshow toast; audience members were pulled up onstage for an impromptu dance party.

headline: ‘Ransom’
text: The sea has many voices. The voice this man is listening for is the voice of his mother. He lifts his head, turns his face to the chill air that moves in across the gulf, and tastes its sharp salt on his lip. The sea surface bellies and glistens, a lustrous silver-blue-a membrane stretched to a fine transparency where once, for nine changes of the moon, he had hung curled in a dream of pre-existence and was rocked and comforted. He hunkers down now on the shelving pebbles at its edge, bunches his cloak between his thighs. Chin down, shoulders hunched, attentive.

headline: Debt Burden Now Rests More on U.S. Shoulders
text: THE United States government borrowed more money than ever before in 2009, but its largest lender  China  sharply reduced the amount it was willing to lend.

headline: Jackson Estate Opposes Allowance for Singer’s Father
text: Attorneys for Michael Jackson’s estate have filed papers opposing an effort by Joe Jackson, the singer’s father, to receive a monthly allowance, The Associated Press reported. Attorneys for the estate administrators, John Branca and John McClain, filed papers to deny Mr. Jackson’s request for more than $15,000 a month from his son’s estate. The attorneys noted that the singer did not name his father as a beneficiary in his will and trust and that Joe Jackson failed to show that his son supported him while he was alive. When he filed for the monthly stipend in November, Mr. Jackson said he needed his son’s financial help to survive.

headline: Part 5: Answers on the Fafsa and Financial Aid
text: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is trying to streamline this year.

headline: Loretta Lynn and Norah Jones to Play Lilith Fair
text: Loretta Lynn has been added to the 2010 lineup of the Lilith Fair, the music tour of female performers. Ms. Lynn, Cat Power, Kate Nash, Norah Jones and Lissie were among the artists announced by the festival producers this week. The festival also added San Diego, Phoenix and Austin to the tour. “I have never done shows with just other girl singers,” Ms. Lynn said in a statement. “When I first started out, they said girl singers couldn’t sell records or concert tickets. We’ve come a long way since then and we’re gonna have a big time out there!”

headline: Betting on Bernanke
text: From Catherine Rampell at Economix:

headline: Sundance in a Nutshell
text: The buzzy shorts premieres on Sundance’s opening night Thursday included “I’m Here,” a feature about robot love by Spike Jonze – financed by Absolut – and a documentary by Rory Kennedy, “The Fence,” about the inadequate structure separating the United States-Mexico border.

text: As the church filled up, a woman repeated the Hail Mary in French, over and over.

headline: Yearning for Glass-Steagall on Capitol Hill
text: President Obama’s plan to rein in big banks and their ability to make risky bets may seem to hark back to the days when commercial banking and investment banking were separated by the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act. But the so-called Volcker Rule, as Mr. Obama’s proposal is known, does not go as far as Glass-Steagall in that it would allow commercial banks to retain some investment banking activities, like underwriting securities and trading on behalf of clients.

headline: Woman and Two Girls Fatally Stabbed in Brooklyn
text: A 24-year-old man in Brooklyn fatally stabbed his female companion and her two young daughters, then phoned his father in the Bronx to tell what he had done, the authorities said.

headline: Weekend Links
text: David Frum proposes an alternative path to campaign-finance reform.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Atul Gawande
text: This week: Atul Gawande discusses his new book, “The Checklist Manifesto”; Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The New York Times, remembers Joseph Papp; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Ski Resorts Exaggerate Snow, Economists Say
text: Ever wonder why that foot of fresh powder that a ski resort brags about feels more like five inches when you actually get there? Well, a pair of Dartmouth economists may have found the answer.

headline: Gay Identity Refracted in Multiple Voices
text: WHAT did gay liberation do for gay cinema? To begin to tackle this question, one has to survey the shadowy history of on-screen homosexuality, consider the elusive notion of a gay sensibility and  as with all minority-group debates  weigh the conflicting ideological positions on difference and assimilation. But while there may be no easy answer, the coincidental appearance this week of two gay-theme events in New York repertory houses provides a window into the evolution of gay cinema, both in the shadow of liberation politics and far beyond it.

headline: Cavaliers Winning and Hurting
text: The Cavaliers could revel after their victory Thursday night as they completed a regular-season sweep over the Los Angeles Lakers, but their point guard corps is running thin.

headline: Koglin Hams in Grand Central Is Closing
text: For almost 10 years Koglin German Royal Hams has sold a staggering variety of hams, cured meats, sausages (25 different kinds of bratwurst) and imported goodies from marzipan to mustard at its stand at the Grand Central Market in Grand Central Terminal. But next Friday, the stand will shutter for good and Armin Koglin, the owner, will move to the Philippines.

headline: Equilibrium in Groove, and a Touch of Hip-Hop
text: It’s standard practice in jazz circles to refer to Fly as a different sort of saxophone trio. That’s a fair characterization, inasmuch as the band  Mark Turner on tenor and soprano saxophones, Larry Grenadier on bass, and Jeff Ballard on drums  upholds a keenly colloquial rapport, rejecting the post-bop heroic ideal. But the inspired stubbornness of that stance almost demands some kind of further distinction. Why not call it a bass trio, or a drum trio? Why not eliminate the frame of reference altogether?

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Smoking in Movies, Laura Linney, Melvin Van Peebles and More
text: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Helped to Heal by a Stranger’s Truth
text: I DRESSED as if preparing for a first date. I picked out a blue cotton sweater with an appliqué bird perched on the right shoulder. Pearl earrings, lip gloss, a touch of mascara. Jeans to balance out the makeup and the appliqué bird. I wanted to look as if I’d tried, but not too hard.

headline: Word Is Out: 30 Years Later
text: With the re-release of the documentary "Word Is Out," Mariposa Film Group looks back at the making of the film.

headline: Solow Gets a Delay
text: Jamie Solow has at least one more week of freedom.

headline: A Father’s Quest to Cure His Children
text: The new movie “Extraordinary Measures,’’ opening around the country this weekend, focuses on a father’s quest to find a treatment for Pompe disease, a rare and often fatal disorder that disables the heart and muscles. While the movie takes some liberties on the real life events and people it depicts, it’s based on the true story of entrepreneur John Crowley, as chronicled in the book “The Cure” by Wall Street Journal reporter Geeta Anand.

headline: ‘A Prophet’ Takes the Lead in French Oscar Race
text: Jacques Audiard’s ”Un Prophète” (“A Prophet”), which won the Grand Jury Prize at last year’s Cannes Film Festival, received 13 nominations on Friday for the César award, the French version of the Oscars, including ones for best film, best director and best actor for Tahar Rahim.

headline: Vikings Receiver Willing to Do Whatever It Takes
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Behind the end zones at the University of South Carolina, red tip hedges grow against the stands at Williams-Brice Stadium, perilously close to the field of play. Whenever a Gamecocks receiver pulls up short of the hedges while pursuing a pass, Coach Steve Spurrier evokes the name of Sidney Rice, the one player who never did.

headline: Historical Society to Open a Children’s Museum
text: When thinking of ways to spend a rainy Saturday afternoon, studying history is not high on the list for most families. Now, in a bid to make history more vivid, alluring and accessible for the Wii generation, an interactive “museum within a museum,” focusing on the lives of young New Yorkers, will open in November 2011 on the lower level of the New-York Historical Society, museum officials said.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 9: Research
text: The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiff’s team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

headline: Scorecard | Louis Vuitton Wins!
text: Bievenue à Paris! After the first day of men’s-wear shows, critics have already dropped that favored “heritage” buzzword. As Scorecard can tell you, concept reigns here in the City of Light, so better make sure your theme explores dualistic tension and depth. (Bonus points awarded for making references to Austrian symbolism, modernist lit, and/or the postmodern, preferably all at once.)

headline: Stover Avoids the Kicking Blues
text: Field-goal kicking wasn’t so great during the regular season — kickers converted just 81.3 percent, way off from last year’s 84.5 percent, the highest in N.F.L. history. But it has been a disaster in the postseason, where kickers have made just 57.8 percent of their attempts, including Shayne Graham and Nate Kaeding, who are a combined 0-5 against the Jets.

headline: Progressive Radio Hosts Say Air America Closing Won’t Affect Them
text: The hosts of several progressive talk shows hastened to remind fans on Friday that although the brand-name network Air America had abruptly folded, their shows were still on the air.

headline: Insight Into Obama's Financial Plan
text: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times spoke with Representative Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland and chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, on President Obama's approach to financial reform.

headline: Called Far and Wide to Touch Minds
text: Cornel West, 56, has many roles: Princeton professor, philosopher, fiery orator, civil rights activist, classical violinist and actor (in two “Matrix” movies). On weekends, Dr. West travels the country delivering lectures, being, in his own words, “a bluesman in the life of the mind, a jazzman in the world of ideas, forever on the move.”

headline: Brooklyn Hts. Montessori to Close Its Little Room
text: Brooklyn Heights Montessori School will close the Little Room, a well-known preschool for children with special needs, in August after failing to secure a new sponsor for the program during a yearlong search.

headline: The Broads Give More for Their Namesake Museum in Michigan
text: Museums in Los Angeles aren’t the only ones receiving gifts from Eli Broad. Mr. Broad, the billionaire philanthropist and Michigan State alumnus, and his wife Edythe Broad, have donated an additional $2 million to the construction of an art museum that bears their names on the Michigan State campus in East Lansing. The gift, announced by university officials earlier this week, brings the total gift from the couple to $28 million: $7 million earmarked for acquisitions, exhibitions and operations and $21 million for construction of the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum, designed by Zaha Hadid, the Pritzker-award winning architect.

headline: Pair of Military Vehicles Are the Heroes at Barrett-Jackson
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. – As I walked past row after row of vehicles during the collector car auctions here this week, I was struck by a display that drew a large crowd. Some people were walking away with tears in their eyes.

headline: As Colts Rested, Jets Awoke
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Jan. 22
text: Time and again, it comes down to this: individual faces seem to convey the impact of mass trauma far more resonantly than broader views of destruction and devastation. Several such faces already stand out in the coverage of the earthquake in Haiti. And today, Ruth Fremson added to that poignant gallery with her portrait of Jean Marseille (Slide 4), waiting at the University Hospital of Haiti to be transferred to a hospital ship because his injuries are so significant. Mr. Marseille’s gaze at the camera — his gravity unimpeached by the strip of tape across his forhead with the word, “Ship” — cannot be ignored and will not soon be forgotten.

headline: In Rossellini’s War Movies, the Naturalism Survives
text: IN the immediate aftermath of World War II, Roberto Rossellini made three films that helped to lay the foundations of modern cinema: “Rome Open City” (1945), “Paisan” (1946) and “Germany Year Zero” (1948). It’s almost impossible to underestimate the importance of these movies, both for the impact that their startling realism had on the audiences and filmmakers of the time and for the influence they continue to exert on directors.

headline: Poll: Americans Support Aspects of Health Care Legislation
text: In the latest poll from the Kaiser Family Foundation, Americans are evenly divided over the “health reform proposals being discussed in Congress,” a finding echoed in other recent national polls.

headline: Chief of Hollywood Trade Group to Step Down
text: LOS ANGELES  Dan Glickman, the chairman and chief executive of the Motion Picture Association of America, said on Friday that he was resigning his post at the Hollywood trade association as of April 1, to become president of Refugees International.

headline: Miserable in Michigan
text: Sixteen states and the District of Columbia had double-digit unemployment rates in December, according to a new government report, with Michigan’s jobless percentage still in the top spot.

headline: No News Is Good News at the New York Motorcycle Show
text: Expectations weren’t exactly high going into the 2010 New York Cycle World International Motorcycle Show. After a year of plummeting American sales, manufacturers were not in a position to showcase flashy new products or fancy exhibits. Most of the presentations at the media preview on Friday focused on products that had been revealed elsewhere. It was a distinct change from the 2009 show, when the industry had a previous-year sales boost to crow about and there were new models and concept bikes on display.

text: Perhaps no one has more at stake at the Sundance Film Festival this year than Diane Weyermann. Then again, few people have as much skin in the game.

headline: Leno to Appear on ‘Oprah Winfrey’ on Thursday
text: Conan O’Brien may be going under the radar for a while after signing off on “The Tonight Show” on Friday night, but the man making his way back into the host chair on that show, Jay Leno, will be highly visible in the coming months.

headline: Boat Carrying 124 Refugees Lands on Corsica
text: PARIS  A boatload of 124 refugees, many of them apparently Kurds from Syria, was discovered Friday morning on a beach in southern Corsica, the local police said. It was the first time that illegal immigrants were able to land on the island, a part of France, and they were put there sometime Thursday night or even before, presumably by smugglers, the police said.

text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: The Lowdown on the Pour Over
text: Cappuccinos at  Bluebird Coffee Shop didn’t do the trick for Oliver (Shaky) Strand. He needed more.

text: In his latest “chairman’s letter,” Howard S. Marks of Oaktree Capital Management explains why he is worried about the prospects for economic recovery.

text: Care to buy a plane?

headline: Glass-Steagall vs. the Volcker Rule
text: For the second time in less than 80 years, the nation’s commercial banks are being told to stick to their knitting. Their knitting is taking deposits, handling checking accounts, lending money and managing the nation’s payment system. Twice now, they have ventured beyond these standard activities, gotten into trouble and almost brought down the financial system.

headline: One Man Embodying 3 of His Artistic Mentors
text: There have been many superlative dancers who have been far from their own best choreographers. (Rudolf Nureyev surely tops the list.)

headline: John Burns Q. and A. on Islamic Radicalization
text: This week, John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, has been reviewing and responding to readers’ comments and questions on Islamic radicalization. On Thursday, Mr. Burns posted this essay on the topic; below are a few comments from At War readers that we thought were worth highlighting and Mr. Burns’s response.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Frozen pizzas and chili bowls? Not at Cortina d’Ampezzo, a fashionable ski resort in the Dolomites of northern Italy, which is prized for its fine dining as much as its fresh snow. Evan Rail skis his way from mountain hut to mountain hut, sampling the region’s Tryrolean goulash, house-made spaghetti and steaming polenta.

headline: Chic in Review | That’s Sir Marc Jacobs to You
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: More Colleges Report Increases in Applications
text: Freshman applications to Princeton are up 19 percent this year, Bloomberg.com reports.

headline: Jamaica High May Close, but Memories Will Live On
text: INSIDE the high-ceilinged vestibule of the Georgian Revival showplace that is Jamaica High School, a red sign reads, “Eighty percent of success is just showing up.” Alas, the school’s average attendance rate this year is 79 percent.

headline: With Help From Friends, Fruit Vendor Is Free
text: Around 3 in the morning on Thursday, Trisha Alam awoke to a shocking but joyous sight. Her father, Nurul Alam, a Bangladeshi fruit vendor who worked on the Upper East Side and whose plight The New York Times chronicled last month, had returned to their home in Parkchester in the Bronx after around three months’ detention at the Hudson County Correctional Center in Kearney, N.J.

headline: The Dangers of YouTube
text: With the news that Sundance and the nearby, concurrent festival Slamdance will share content with online and non-traditional platforms like YouTube and Microsoft’s Xbox 360, Variety examines whether these short-term deals could hurt filmmakers looking for distribution. With every angle needed to make a profit, “the availability of a movie for rent before a film is sold could dissuade some dealmakers from offering a more lucrative deal, considering one of their distribution platforms has already been eliminated from the mix,” Marc Graser writes.

headline: Serving the Community, Satisfying the Palate
text: JULIE CARRIÓN, the director of catering and culinary services at the Kitchen @ Billings Forge, is having a tart-crust crisis.

headline: Where Alsace Meets Belgium
text: MOULES ET FRITES has been packed ever since it opened in Syosset in mid-November. It’s owned by the Reststar Hospitality Group, which counts Bistro Cassis in Huntington, Bistro Citron in Roslyn and Brasserie Cassis in Plainview among its many holdings.

headline: Wine Appreciation, Made Easier
text: KELLY TOBIN, a 35-year-old stockbroker from Hoboken, learned that the old rule of white wine with fish and red with meat no longer applies.

headline: Cameras Swarm Rajaratnam at Restaurant
text: In a rare moment away from the courthouse, Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group‘s founder and accused mastermind of a multimillion-dollar insider trading ring, was caught on camera by Bloomberg News leaving Tao restaurant in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: Biden to Meet Iraq Leaders Amid Candidate Dispute
text: BAGHDAD  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived Friday in a visit that underlined an enduring reality of Iraq under the Obama administration: As the United States prepares to withdraw, an Iraqi political system tailored to crisis and brinkmanship has repeatedly necessitated United States intervention to propel the political process forward.

headline: Bonus Tops $8 Million for Chief at Morgan
text: A few days after Morgan Stanley reported its first loss in its 74-year history, the bank announced on Friday that its chief executive, James P. Gorman, would receive $8.11 million in deferred stock as part of his bonus for 2009.

headline: Carole Stimpfle, Gregg Savarese
text: Carole Anne Stimpfle, a daughter of Eileen Stimpfle and John B. Stimpfle of Northvale, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Gregg Adam Savarese, the son of Louis A. Savarese, of Randolph, N.J., and the late Ilene W. Savarese. Msgr. Frank Del Prete performed the ceremony at SS. Peter and Paul Church in Hoboken, N.J., with Rabbi Ari Fridkis taking part.

text: Update | 6:00 p.m.

headline: Bonus for Morgan Stanley Chief Tops $8 Million
text: A few days after Morgan Stanley reported its first loss in its 74-year history, the bank announced late Friday afternoon that its chief executive, James P. Gorman, would receive $8.11 million in deferred stock as part of his bonus for 2009, The New York Times’s Graham Bowley reports.

headline: State of Shock
text: People on Wall Street are in a state of shock today. It shows in the stock market, which is down 5 percent in three days.

headline: Capsized
text: The State of Maine, it’s often said, is a state of mind, a state sometimes inscrutable to relative newcomers like my husband, Marty, and me. So we were not surprised to be the only boaters heading out from the dock near Damariscotta on a gorgeous Saturday morning last November. We launched onto calm seas, so confident of the weather that we didn’t bother to check the forecast or pack our safety gear — the extra paddles, whistles, radio and flares. But half a mile from shore, we learned why no one else was out. The wind blew up, as did the chop. Our boats got skittish. Marty’s Red Sox cap blew off, and I begged him not to circle back for it. He assured me that we had seen much worse, that we would be fine. It was the response I had come to expect from him.

headline: Tastes of Japan, in Many Flavors
text: JAPANESE restaurants have become so popular that even small towns may have several to choose from. Ardsley is especially endowed, with three within a half mile, each with a distinct style.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 22
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a metals factory in Brooklyn, prayers for earthquake survivors in Haiti, and a new job for Robert M. Morgenthau.

headline: For Lady Gaga, Every Concert Is a Drama
text: In her stunningly gruesome extravaganza at Radio City Music Hall, Lady Gaga scowls more than she smiles, muses about dying and appears on vast video screens vomiting, being slapped and generally being abused. “Fame is killing me,” she says. Death becomes her.

headline: The Keypad Solution
text: There is a long and noble history of trying to change the English language’s notoriously illogical system of spelling. The fact that through, rough, dough, plough, hiccough and trough all end with -ough, yet none of them sound the same as any of the others, is the sort of thing that has been vexing poets and learners of English for quite some time. Proponents of “fixing” this wayward orthography have included some of the most prominent names in American history. Benjamin Franklin suggested changing the alphabet, and Andrew Carnegie provided money for people to study the problem. President Theodore Roosevelt issued an edict in 1906 that gave the Government Printing Office a list of 300 words with new spellings: problem cases like artisan, kissed and woe were to be changed to artizan, kist and wo. Roosevelt was largely ignored by the G.P.O., and the matter was soon dropped. Although this issue has been extensively studied and argued over by these and other eminent thinkers, there has been an almost complete lack of success in effecting any substantial progress.

headline: Just Walk Away
text: Roger Lowenstein triggers a provocative idea. If enough underwater homeowners threaten to walk away from their mortgages at the same time, the banks would have no choice but to renegotiate terms, potentially lowering everyone’s principal. What we need is a community organizer. Isn’t that what President Obama used to do?

headline: Russian Oligarch’s Long Road to a Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: MOSCOW  Oleg V. Deripaska, the Russian oligarch, was so deeply in debt at the onset of the financial crisis that Russian and Western banks could have bankrupted his company, the sprawling aluminum giant Rusal, within months.

headline: The Reading Life: Parsing the Poetry Best-Seller List
text: The words “poetry” and “best seller” don’t appear often in the same sentence. But if you want to get a handle on what verse Americans are reading right now, here’s the place to go – the Poetry Foundation’s contemporary poetry best-seller list.Scanning the most recent Poetry Foundation list, for the week ending Jan. 3, 2010, one thing is pretty clear: it’s Mary Oliver’s world, we only live in it. Ms. Oliver, who writes earnest poems about nature, has no fewer than five books in the Top 10. (She’s been knocked out of the No. 1 position this time, however, by Wendell Berry’s book “Leavings.”)

headline: Obama, With Defiant Tone, Vows to Push Agenda
text: ELYRIA, Ohio  President Obama, striking a no-retreat, no-surrender posture in the wake of his party’s humiliating defeat in the Massachusetts Senate race this week, vowed Friday to press on with his expansive domestic agenda  including a health care overhaul and tough new restrictions on banks  even if it meant he had to “take my lumps” from political critics.

headline: On This Road, Watch Your Step
text: THE killer road beckons benignly in the winter sunshine. The name remains the same, Hempstead Turnpike, but any charm it once had is gone, along with its tolls.

headline: Third and Atlantic Avenues Have Most Fatalities
text: From 2006 to 2008, the deadliest roads for pedestrians in the city were Third Avenue in Manhattan and Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, which each had nine fatalities, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: In Westchester, Areas ‘Not Conducive to Walking’
text: There were 27 pedestrian fatalities in Westchester County from 2006 to 2008, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. They were not concentrated in any one area, and no road had more than three deaths.

headline: U.S. 1 and U.S. 5 Have Most Deaths in the State
text: From 2006 to 2008, 94 pedestrians were killed in Connecticut. Fourteen of those deaths were along U.S. 1 and U.S. 5, which traverse the state, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Burlington County Road Has State’s Most Deaths
text: In New Jersey, 451 pedestrians were struck and killed by vehicles from 2006 to 2008. With nine fatalities during those three years, U.S. 130 (Burlington Pike), in Burlington County, an 83-mile stretch whose southern portion is in Philadelphia’s suburbs, had more pedestrian deaths than any other road in the state.

headline: Other Deadly Stretches on Long Island
