text: Hempstead Turnpike’s sibling to the southeast, the stretch of Sunrise Highway (Route 27) in Suffolk County, ranked second in the region in pedestrian fatalities from 2006 to 2008, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. There were 11 deaths on the road during that period.

headline: Sony Adds GPS and SD Card Support
text: Sony unwrapped two new Cyber-shot cameras that pack cool features like built-in GPS, automatic high dynamic range (HDR) image capture, and a new wireless file transfer technology. They also can record full HD 1080p video in the AVCHD format, a first for Sony.

headline: Confusion in the Haitian Countryside
text: Outside Port-au-Prince, major obstacles still stand in the way of getting food, water and shelter to those affected by the earthquake.

headline: Samsung Compact Camera Adds GPS
text: It’s officially a trend, and a great one at that. Point-and-shoot cameras are gaining built-in GPS capabilities that are very useful to peripatetic photographers who want to geo-tag their images.

headline: An Age When Love Needs a Safety Net
text: Sometimes, love is not all you need. In fact, it can be downright dangerous. Love abounds in the family depicted in Darci Picoult’s new play, “Lil’s 90th”; but the Eldridges are in big, big trouble anyway.

headline: Polanski Denied Sentencing in Absentia
text: LOS ANGELES  A state court judge here rejected the director Roman Polanski’s request to be sentenced while he remains under arrest in Switzerland, setting the stage for a renewed legal battle over his extradition to face sentencing on a 32-year-old sex charge.

headline: On Stage, Feeling More at Home Away
text: To find an audience outside Connecticut, Brian Dolzani has written alternative rock songs with themes that most anybody can relate to  like the romance of “Summer” and the everyday ennui of “Water.” But he doesn’t necessarily relish playing them for the home-state crowd.

headline: A Helmet for Obama
text: The House Judiciary Committee has devoted two hearings to the subject of football head injuries. The Senate will soon consider a bill to raise awareness of the seriousness of sports concussions. As the issue climbs the political ladder, it’s fair to wonder if President Obama will chime in on the subject.

headline: Letting Postcards Tell Niagara Falls’ Story
text: Once a favorite of newlyweds, Niagara Falls has thrived for decades as a general tourist destination and, more recently, as the setting for several casinos. In the spring and summer months, the New York Power Authority even turns up the water flow to please the crowds.

headline: Seedorf Responds: 10 Answers From Milan’s No. 10
text: Clarence Seedorf, the A.C. Milan midfielder, participates in a monthly exchange with New York Times readers. On Friday, two days before his team will take on Inter Milan in the season’s second derby at the San Siro, he answered questions about Milan, how club’s can better manage their business affairs and the World Cup. Previous discussions can be found here.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 22
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: In Unions, Government Workers Surpass Private-Sector Workers
text: Many people, when they hear the phrase “union worker,” probably imagine someone who works on an assembly line. But such blue-collar jobs are probably no longer representative of the typical union man or woman.

headline: From a Dutch Painter, Works With Much to Say
text: As the Hudson Valley has celebrated the 400th anniversary of its discovery by Henry Hudson in a Dutch expedition, art exhibitions focusing on contemporary Dutch culture have been especially rich. “Fendry Ekel  The Witness,” a show of a dozen works in its final week at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art, is among them.

headline: The Quilt as Canvas
text: MORRIS TOWNSHIP

headline: In Suburban Houses, Roots of Modernism
text: Levittown, the mass-produced suburb built in Nassau County after World War II, is often the first thing that comes to mind when the subject is Long Island architecture. Fair enough; it was the archetype for such communities throughout the country. But what is less well known is that Long Island provided fertile ground for early Modernism in American architecture. Many of the most prominent Modern architects designed homes here, including Frank Lloyd Wright, Philip Johnson and Marcel Breuer. A remarkable exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art seeks to document their achievements.

headline: Filmmaker Seeks to Temper the Message of ‘An Inconvenient Truth’
text: LOS ANGELES  At the Sundance Film Festival four years ago, the global-warming debate took center stage with the premiere of an alarming work, the director Davis Guggenheim’s documentary “An Inconvenient Truth.”

headline: Oakland Prospect Retires to Join Priesthood
text: Grant Desme hit 31 home runs and stole 40 bases in Class A last season, and as an encore, he was named most valuable player of the Arizona Fall League. The Oakland Athletics had plans to invite Desme, a 23-year-old outfielder, to spring training next month.

headline: Paris Men’s: Small Epiphanies
text: The high points of the day were Rick Owens and Comme des Garcons. Many times an Owens’ show feels like a journey of self-realization: the American who brought his dark, singular aesthetic to Paris and seemingly discovered it there. His latest collection flowed like a skillful narrative. The opening looks were tailored, monochromatic and spare, with cropped pants and a shoulder line that looked as straight and strong as an industrial beam.

headline: Projecting a New Laptop
text: In addition to touch screens and tablets — all the rage this month — throw in the miniature projector as part of the new wave of features destined for the laptop.

headline: Décor: Far East Chic. Diners: Pure Manhattan.
text: A brief bankerish stroll from the New York Stock Exchange, this seven-month-old Asian-accented French restaurant, at 40 Broad Street, seems to have been created for purposes of wealth redistribution  that is to say, to separate its upscale clients from their disposable income by way of a $69 three-course dinner and a highly curated, high-altitude wine list. The décor is Far East chic (silk walls, ornamental calligraphy brushes), but the diners are pure Manhattan: equities traders, corporate lawyers and, last week, an Iranian-born wine connoisseur who turned up with her cousin and Connecticut-bred companion.

headline: A Big-Picture Look at Google, Microsoft, Apple and Yahoo
text: On Wednesday, I wrote about a battle looming between Apple and Google as discussions take place over the possibility of Apple making Microsoft‘s Bing the default search engine on the iPhone.

headline: A Celebrated Scout Camp on Staten Island Is in Jeopardy
text: IN the wooded heart of Staten Island lies a rugged spread of land, crowned by a rustic lake, that has provided camping grounds for Boy Scouts and Cub Scouts from the New York area for 60 years.

headline: Bush Senior: Hutchison for Governor
text: Former President George H.W. Bush officially endorsed Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, in her gubernatorial primary against sitting Gov. Rick Perry.

headline: Cartoons, Tennis and Traffic Lights
text: Training for the Open

headline: Diner Serves Apocalypse, Easy on the Destruction
text: In “Legion” the world ends not with a bang but with a short stack. Recycling motifs from “The Birds,” “Near Dark,” the “Terminator” films and other apocalyptic fantasies, the film convenes a collection of strangers  upper-middle-class white family with issues, black father with handgun, etc.  at a diner in the Mojave Desert, where they are caught in the crossfire of a celestial battle.

headline: Coakley Looks Back
text: Shortly after her loss in Massachusetts, Martha M. Coakley has delivered her own post-mortem on how her campaign to succeed the late Edward M. Kennedy in the Senate went awry.

headline: Jean-Georges's Fried Rice
text: Mark Bittman recreates the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten's fried rice, topped with crisp ginger and a fried egg.

headline: A Little Get-Together for Stage and Television
text: Salon-style concerts, a staple of the 18th and 19th centuries, are happily making a comeback in both the private and the public spheres. The star violinist Joshua Bell, a regular at the world’s major concert halls, has even refurbished his home in New York to accommodate impromptu jam sessions with classical, jazz and rock musicians.

headline: Structural Integrity and People, Too
text: DURING one three-week period recently Iwan Baan touched down in Amsterdam, Mexico City, Miami, New York, Milan, Rome, Tokyo, Medellín and Basel, where he photographed buildings designed by some of the world’s top architects, including Herzog & de Meuron, Rem Koolhaas and Toyo Ito. Along with Steven Holl, Thom Mayne and the Japanese firm Sanaa, they have helped turn Mr. Baan, 34, into almost certainly the most peripatetic architectural photographer in the world as well as one of the most widely published.

headline: C.I.A. Deaths Prompt Surge in U.S. Drone Strikes
text: WASHINGTON  Since the suicide bombing that took the lives of seven Americans in Afghanistan on Dec. 30, the Central Intelligence Agency has struck back against militants in Pakistan with the most intensive series of missile strikes from drone aircraft since the covert program began.

headline: Fried Rice, Dressed Simply
text: HAVING written cookbooks with the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten (along with being his friend) for more than 15 years, I’ve seen him develop a fair number of stunning recipes. My favorites have always been the simple ones, those that came from his Alsatian background or his years working and traveling in Asia. And I was never more impressed than when he created his version of fried rice, topped with crisp ginger and a fried egg.

headline: She Works. They’re Happy.
text: EVER since Betty Friedan urged women to leave the house and pursue careers, people have argued over whether women’s marriages and romantic prospects would suffer for it. Was a financially successful woman a threat to her husband or a relief?

headline: Bounce and Pounce in a Zany Evening, Channeling Singers
text: Sometimes it’s best to start with a song and add a few steps. David Zambrano has done that and more in “Soul Project,” an enthralling evening of visceral solos set to soul music.

headline: Discussing That Word That Prompts Either a Fist Pump or a Scowl
text: For most followers of MTV’s reality series “Jersey Shore,” the big news on Thursday was the on-screen breakup of the summer sweethearts Ronnie Magro and Sammi Giancola during the cast’s late-night reunion show.

headline: A Little Deception, and a Whole Lot of Points
text: You are sitting West. Against two diamonds doubled, you lead the heart ace: deuce, seven (normal count), six. What will you do next?

headline: U.S. Delays Setting Up More Anti-Taliban Militias
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  An ambitious plan to increase the number of anti-Taliban militias in villages across the country has been put on hold until worries about creating warlords can be assuaged, an American officer in Kabul said Friday.

headline: Haiti Adds Resonance to Sundance Documentaries
text: PARK CITY, Utah  Unscrupulous charities, Sally Struthers and those ubiquitous “dollar a day” commercials on cable networks have made sponsoring a child in Africa a joke to many people. It was certainly that for Jennifer Arnold, the director of a documentary on child sponsorship that had its premiere on Friday at the Sundance Film Festival here.

headline: Bahai on Trial in Iran Worries Brother From Afar
text: CLINTON, Md.  For as long as  Bahaism has existed, the forebears of Rezvan Tavakkoli have abided by it. And over the generations, since the faith’s origin 166 years ago, Mr. Tavakkoli’s people have paid the price of their devotion.

headline: The Well-Wired East End
text: The rise of blogs and social media like Twitter and Facebook offers consumers the chance to keep closer tabs on Long Island wines.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 952 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Study Points to Disease as Main Killer in Darfur
text: With violence in Darfur in an extended lull, a new study assessing dozens of mortality estimates for the six years of fighting there has concluded that about 300,000 people died, but that disease, rather than violence, killed at least 80 percent of them.

headline: Heavy on the Healthy
text: Nevaèh Cuisine is an appropriate name for this ambitious specialty take-out and catering shop (Nevaèh is heaven spelled backward).

headline: A Fight Song by Prince for His Hometown Team
text: Prince, above, whose hits have included “Little Red Corvette” and “Purple Rain,” is continuing on the color spectrum with a tribute to the Minnesota Vikings called “Purple and Gold.” The rock star, originally from Minnesota, wrote the tune to cheer on the Vikings, who will play the New Orleans Saints on Sunday in the National Football Conference championship game, with the winner going to the Super Bowl. “Purple and Gold” had its debut this week on the 9 p.m. newscast of the Fox affiliate KMSP-TV in Minneapolis. Prince said he was inspired to pick up his pen after watching in person as the Vikings beat the Dallas Cowboys, 34-3, last weekend, after not seeing the team play in years until this season. The hymnlike song (with Prince’s own brand of spelling) says in part: “as we approach the throne we won’t bow down/this time we won’t b denied/raise every voice and let it be known/in the name of the purple and gold/we come in the name of the purple and gold/all of the odds r in r favor/ no prediction 2 bold.” The Vikings wide receiver Bernard Berrian used his Twitter page to thank Prince. “He is definitely one of my favorites,” Mr. Berrian said.

headline: Put Your Money Where Your Politics Are
text: McCain-Feingold, that Quixotic attempt to turn money and politics into oil and water, was lanced by the Supreme Court on Thursday in a 5-4 decision based on the idea, espoused by Justice Anthony Kennedy, that “If the First Amendment has any force, it prohibits Congress from fining or jailing citizens, or associations of citizens, for simply engaging in political speech.” To some extent, most of us would agree on the “citizens” point — it’s that “associations” bit that’s the fly in the ointment for many.

headline: Danny Boyle Wants His Own ‘Frankenstein’
text: Now let’s see. How many versions of “Frankenstein” will this make? Danny Boyle, the director of the Oscar-winning “Slumdog Millionaire” is to direct a stage adaptation of “Frankenstein,” based on the novel by Mary Shelley, The Guardian reported. Nicholas Hytner, the director of the National Theater in London, said that Mr. Boyle would make his debut at the theater later this year. Mr. Hytner said that Mr. Boyle, who began his career at London’s Royal Court and the Royal Shakespeare Company, was returning to his first love after film “distracted” him for a while. (He also directed “Trainspotting.”) “Danny first talked about this eight years ago and it has taken him eight years,” Mr. Hytner said of Mr. Boyle’s decision to direct the playwright Nick Dear’s new adaptation of “Frankenstein.” (Boris Karloff, above, starred in the 1931 film adaptation.) It will be a “large-scale and theatrically and visually ambitious stage production,” Mr. Hytner said.

headline: Annoying a Politician and Ending Up in Cuffs
text: One evening last August, as Edward Kerry Sullivan stood outside his apartment building on Staten Island, a car pulled up and a man got out. By Mr. Sullivan’s recollection, the conversation went like this:

headline: Spice Girls Want Their Own Musical
text: Watch out, “Mamma Mia!” The Spice Girls are cooking up a musical with an original story based on their hit songs, Reuters reported. The working title is “Viva Forever,” after the 1998 British No. 1 single by the five-member British pop group. The “Viva Forever” creators are the band’s former manager Simon Fuller and Judy Craymer, who produced the worldwide hit musical “Mamma Mia!”, which featured the songs of the Swedish band Abba, and later became a movie starring Meryl Streep. “Mamma Mia!” has made $2 billion in the last decade. The Spice Girls show could have its debut on the London stage in two or three years, Mr. Fuller and Ms. Craymer said. The Spice Girls  Melanie Chisholm (Sporty Spice or Mel C), Victoria Beckham (Posh Spice), Geri Halliwell (Ginger Spice), Emma Bunton (Baby Spice) and Melanie Brown (Scary Spice)  became a cultural phenomenon after releasing their first single, “Wannabe,” in 1996. The group split up in 2000, but reunited for a tour in 2007.

headline: Lawyers Oppose Jackson’s Father’s Plea
text: Lawyers for Michael Jackson’s estate have filed papers opposing an effort by Joe Jackson, the singer’s father, to receive a monthly allowance, The Associated Press reported. The lawyers, John Branca and John McClain, filed papers asking a judge to deny Mr. Jackson’s request for more than $15,000 a month from his son’s estate. They noted that the singer did not name his father as a beneficiary in his will and trust and that Joe Jackson failed to show that his son supported him while he was alive. When Mr. Jackson filed for the monthly stipend in November, he said he needed the financial help to survive.

headline: Shopping With Erin Rooney Doland
text: The editor of the blog Unclutterer.com searched for items that can make order out of chaos.

headline: More Funds for Art Museum at Michigan State
text: Eli Broad, the billionaire philanthropist and Michigan State alumnus, and his wife, Edythe Broad, have donated an additional $2 million to the construction of an art museum designed by Zaha Hadid on the Michigan State campus. The gift, announced by university officials, brings the total gift from the couple to $28 million: $7 million earmarked for acquisitions, exhibitions and operations and $21 million for the construction of the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum on the East Lansing campus. “This new museum, designed by one of the world’s leading architects, will become a contemporary art destination, and it extends our mission of allowing art to be seen by the broadest public,” Mr. Broad said in a statement. The university hopes to raise about $7 million more to complete the museum. Groundbreaking is scheduled for March 16.

headline: From Kitty Kelley, an Oprah Tell-All
text: Oprah Winfrey, right, is the latest subject for Kitty Kelley, known for her often unflattering, dishy and best-selling celebrity biographies. Crown Publishers announced this week that Ms. Kelley‘s 544-page unauthorized “Oprah: A Biography,” will be released on April 13, The Associated Press reported. The first printing will be at least 500,000 copies. Ms. Kelley has written books about Frank Sinatra, Nancy Reagan and the Bush family. She conducted 850 interviews for the book, the publisher said, and Ms. Kelley said she spent the last three years combing through Ms. Winfrey’s life, according to The A.P. Ms. Kelley said she was “full of admiration for her accomplishments and fascinated by her complexity.”

headline: Ready to Spend, but Not to Boast
text: LAST year, investment bankers and their spouses kept their wallets shut during bonus season, first, out of panic, and later, fearing mobs with torches would descend upon their gated estates.

headline: CBS Crime Dramas Take Control
text: “The Mentalist” attracted the most viewers on Thursday night, as 14.5 million tuned in to the CBS crime show at 10, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS also delivered the most viewers for the night over all, earning the second-largest audience as well at 9 with “CSI” (14.2 million). In the 8 p.m. hour, CBS broadcast back-to-back reruns of its sitcom “The Big Bang Theory” (7.2 million), which outperformed its time-slot competitors, the premiere of ABC’s new legal drama “The Deep End” (7.1 million) and new episodes of NBC’s comedies “Community” (4.7 million) and “Parks and Recreation” (4.3 million). Fox’s “Bones” led the 8 p.m. hour (11.9 million), but Fox ranked third for the night, garnering a more modest 6.9 million viewers at 9 for “Fringe.” ABC finished in second place, thanks to “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 (12.6 million) and “Private Practice” at 10 (9.7 million). NBC ranked a distant fourth with new episodes of “The Office” at 9 (7.6 million) and “30 Rock” at 9:30 (5.6 million), followed by “The Jay Leno Show” at 10 (4.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Ending the Reign of Chaos
text: GETTING organized has long been a popular New Year’s resolution — right up there with losing weight and quitting smoking. But unless you live alone, it can seem almost impossible, since it requires the participation of everyone in the household.

headline: 18th-Century Extroverts and Introverts at Zankel Hall
text: Europa Galante, the superb period-instrument ensemble led by the violinist Fabio Biondi, explored two distinct sides of the 18th-century orchestral repertory at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening. The first half of the program was devoted to the extroverted music of Telemann. After intermission Mr. Biondi and company set their sights on Italy by way of four strikingly different composers: Sammartini, Nardini, Corelli and Locatelli.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: 'Oh My God! It's Harrod Blank!'
text: An excerpt from "Oh My God! It's Harrod Blank!," a film by David Silberberg.

headline: 'Corner Store'
text: An excerpt from "Corner Store," a film by Katherine Bruens.

headline: For Tapestry, One More Renaissance
text: WHEN Chris and Suzanne Sharp conceived of their Banners of Persuasion tapestry project, the premise was fairly straightforward. “In the Renaissance people would commission an artist to do a tapestry for them,” Mr. Sharp said in a phone interview, “and then they’d commission a workshop to produce the design. We thought it would be interesting to return to the same format and that synergy between the commissioning person and the artist and the workshop.”

headline: In Paris, Jackets Are a Good Fit
text: Paris

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Storm-Damaged Auction Site Remains Closed
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The site of the Russo & Steele classic car auction here remained cordoned off Friday evening by Scottsdale fire officials, who said the storm-damaged area was too dangerous to allow auction officials and concerned car owners back in.

headline: Man Accused of Killing Companion and Her Two Daughters
text: A 24-year-old man fatally stabbed his companion and her two young daughters in their Brooklyn home, wrapped them in garbage bags, and waited at least a day before calling his father in the Bronx to tell what he had done, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Imagining Spenser in the World of Tennis
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The American detective writer Robert B. Parker never wrote a full-fledged murder mystery about tennis. It’s a pity.

headline: Defending Their Dealerships
text: Mark Calisi says he believes he lost his Chrysler-Jeep dealership on Long Island because he irritated a company executive.

headline: At Bonus Time, Less Appetite for Toys
text: With all eyes on banks and their bonus pools, there is the question of what happens to the bonus money the bankers receive this year. Will they return to flashy spending or invest it more conservatively? Paul Sullivan examines this question in his Wealth Matters column in The New York Times and finds a number of people are leaning toward caution.

headline: Celebrities Sell Books in Britain (Talent Optional)
text: LONDON  The crowd at the annual Crime Thriller Awards here some months back was happily basking in mutual congratulation when the writer Lynda La Plante introduced an unexpected note of discord. Onstage to receive an honor, Ms. La Plante took the opportunity to denounce the British publishing industry, accusing it of spending too much time and money on inane memoirs by television celebrities.

headline: Ready for Anything
text: Photos from the men’s presentations in Paris, where behind the drama are clothes meant to be worn.

headline: Britain: Terrorist Threat Level Raised
text: Britain’s intelligence services raised the threat level of a terrorist attack from “substantial” to “severe” on Friday. The rating, the fourth highest of five levels, means an attack is considered to be highly likely. Home Secretary Alan Johnson said there was no intelligence to suggest that an attack was imminent. “All I would say to the public is we need to be vigilant,” he said.

headline: Ivory Coast: Court Rules on Payment in Toxic-Waste Dumping Scandal
text: An appeals court ruled Friday that compensation to some 30,000 victims of a toxic-waste dumping scandal should be turned over to a self-appointed community representative. The money, about $45 million, was to settle claims from the 2006 dumping of oil-based sludge around Abidjan by the commodities trading firm Trafigura. More than 100,000 people sought treatment and 15 died. Lawyers for the victims said that Claude Gouhourou’s claim to represent the victims was false, that the ruling jeopardized the payments and that they would appeal.

headline: France: Prince to Fix Up Historic House
text: The Qatari prince who owns the 17th-century Hôtel Lambert signed an agreement on Friday with a group of preservationists who had opposed his plans to renovate the mansion, the Ministry of Culture said. The accord will allow Prince Abdullah bin Khalifa al-Thani to proceed with the renovation, which had been suspended in September, the ministry said. The Paris historical association had argued that the prince’s plan to modernize the building on the Île St.-Louis was a threat to France’s cultural heritage.

headline: Depth of School Cuts Depends on Who Gets Them
text: ALBANY  When Gov. David A. Paterson proposed this week cutting more than $1 billion in school aid to help address the state’s financial crisis, the critics quickly pounced. Mr. Paterson’s cuts would cripple New York’s schools, they charged, hurt children and undermine the state’s economic recovery.

headline: Israel: U.N. Is Paid for Damage in Gaza
text: Israel paid the United Nations $10.5 million in compensation for damage to United Nations facilities in the Gaza Strip during the three-week Israeli assault on the territory last winter, said Martin Nesirky, the spokesman for the secretary general. Israel did not accept legal responsibility for the seven events covered by the agreement with the United Nations, the spokesman said. “The money will not itself repair the buildings and facilities damaged,” said Mr. Nesirky, noting that cement and other building materials cannot get through Israel’s blockade of the territory.

headline: A Serene Advocate for Chile’s Disappeared
text: SANTIAGO, Chile

headline: The Happy Warrior
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

headline: Haiti’s Icon of Power, Now Palace for Ghosts
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The only sound inside Haiti’s National Palace comes from the crunch underneath one’s soles. Its ornate reception rooms are strewn with rubble. The stench of decaying bodies, a week and a half after the earthquake, still wafts in the air.

headline: Google Founders to Sell, But Are Not Losing Control
text: Update | 1/23/10 12:19 a.m.  Correcting the amount of money that the founders would get if they follow through on the sales.

headline: On the Street | Critters
text: A dash of whimsy for the post-holiday blues, knitted animal-face hats have made their way from the skating rink and the ski slope to the city streets.

headline: Leno to Speak at the White House Correspondents’ Dinner
text: Right in the middle of one of the most contentious periods in his long career, Jay Leno was announced Friday as the choice to be the keynote speaker for the White House Correspondents’ dinner in May.

headline: A Young Life Unbowed by Illness and Separation
text: At 8 years old, Essence Griffin knows how it feels to be given up by her mother. She knows how it feels for her grandmother to get so sick that she spends months  which might as well be years in the short life of a child  in the hospital, and how it feels to call 911 eight times because her grandmother is sick and the ambulance is not coming.

headline: Arizona Intentionally Snared Last Jaguar, Inquiry Finds
text: Contrary to their denials, employees of the Arizona Game and Fish Department intentionally snared the last known jaguar in the Southwest last year, a report by the federal government says.

headline: A House of Worship for Grape and Grain
text: IT’S hard to imagine a more diverse array of restaurants and bars than financial district fixtures like Ulysses, Bayard’s, Adrienne’s and Harry’s. Yet the proprietor of those establishments, Peter Poulakakos, has managed to innovate again with his newest venture, Vintry Wine & Whiskey, nestled in the heart of Stone Street in lower Manhattan.

headline: Justices Turn Minor Movie Case Into a Blockbuster
text: WASHINGTON  So much for judicial minimalism.

headline: Most U.S. Union Members Are Working for the Government, New Data Shows
text: For the first time in American history, a majority of union members are government workers rather than private-sector employees, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced on Friday.

headline: Bryant Has a Blend of Stardom and Grit
text: Nearly two years ago, Kobe Bryant swiped at a basketball. In the process, he bent his right pinkie finger, tearing the ligaments. Surgery was expected.

headline: Guerrilla Comic Invades Los Angeles
text: FOR someone like Marc Wootton even the simplest query  “How did your new Showtime series come about?”  can be an excuse for theatrical digression.

headline: In Abortion Murder Trial, No Motive Mentioned
text: WICHITA  Jurors in the trial of an abortion opponent accused of murdering Dr. George R. Tiller, one of the nation’s only late-term abortion providers, never heard the word “abortion” on Friday as a prosecutor here laid out her case in an opening statement.

headline: A Bittersweet Aftertaste for Jets Fans on Long Island
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Cesar Garcia sat at a corner table in the Coliseum Deli the other day, his back to the athletic field across Hempstead Turnpike where not long ago the New York Jets ran practice sprints four days a week, burning calories by the millions before hauling themselves  and some of the greatest appetites ever known to the deli world  into his joint.

headline: Simulators Prepare Soldiers for Explosions of War
text: FORT EUSTIS, Va.  A Humvee bumps along a dirt road fringed by mountains, their snowy peaks glinting in the sun. Rifle shots crackle from a rocky bluff, signaling a Taliban ambush. Suddenly an explosion rocks the vehicle, tossing it from side to side before it bounces to an uneasy stop, smoke billowing into the cab.

headline: A Weekend to Deal With Ifs, Ands and Buts
text: People on Wall Street are in a state of shock today. It shows in the stock market, which is down 5 percent in three days.

headline: Plea Rejected in Case of Hepatitis Infections
text: DENVER  Suggesting that 20 years in prison was not enough punishment for the crime, a federal judge on Friday rejected a plea agreement for a former hospital technician and drug user who admitted that she exposed hundreds of patients in her care to hepatitis C.

headline: Isner’s Big Serve Presents Tough Task
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  John Isner is a big server in every sense of the word. He is 6 feet 9 inches tall, and he routinely rockets a tennis ball at 138 miles an hour. In his three years on the professional tour, Isner has been regarded somewhere between an oddity and the next great American player.

headline: A Chinese Tale: Faith, Tradition, Confucius and Same-Sex Marriage
text: In Friday’s paper, I took a look at the quietly flourishing communities of evangelical Chinese Christians in Northern California.

headline: Republicans Strain to Ride Tea Party Tiger
text: As they look to make gains in statehouses and Congress this year, Republicans are trying to harness the Tea Party energy that helped make an unknown named Scott Brown the senator-elect from Massachusetts.

headline: They Passed Through Jamaica High
text: In the wake of the decision to close Jamaica High School in Queens, a look back at some notable students.

headline: Haiti’s Aftershocks Felt at a School in New York
text: To make sense of the earthquake, the eighth-grade science class analyzed plate tectonics, used computer animation to simulate tremors of different magnitudes, and browsed satellite images to zero in on their family villages in Haiti. Down the hall, a kindergarten teacher took a lower-tech approach: piling Legos on two cardboard squares and bumping them together until the toy buildings crashed down.

headline: Haitian Mother Didn’t Give Up on Son, Who Eventually Was Pulled From Ruins
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  When a three-story building in one of the city’s poorest neighborhoods collapsed last week, a 21-year-old tailor who lived there was counted among the estimated tens of thousands of Haitians killed by the earthquake.

headline: Emergency Air Cargo Shipments to Haiti Face High Prices That May Last Awhile
text: Amid the many problems facing relief efforts in Haiti are sharp increases in air cargo costs for emergency supplies that may endure longer than usual.

headline: 24 States’ Laws Open to Attack After Campaign Finance Ruling
text: In Wisconsin, conservative and pro-business groups said Friday that they were considering a lawsuit to block a proposed law that would ban corporate spending during political campaigns.

headline: A Rift at the Fed Over the Bailout of A.I.G.
text: New documents submitted to Congressional investigators examining the 2008 rescue of the American International Group show that officials at the Federal Reserve were deeply divided over the structure of the bailout and its long-term implications.

headline: China Rebuffs Clinton on Internet Warning
text: WASHINGTON  Tensions between China and the United States over Internet policy deepened Friday, with the Chinese government accusing Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton of jeopardizing relations between the two countries with her criticism of Chinese censorship.

headline: Trailer: 'On the Boards'
text: OntheBoards.tv is the first online, pay-per-view series dedicated to presenting progressive contemporary performances from around the world.

headline: Player’s Barbs Crack Colts’ Code of Silence
text: INDIANAPOLIS  The Colts have carefully avoided even the appearance of disparaging the Jets this week. They went so far as to say they understood Rex Ryan’s bravado when he said he would be shocked if the Jets did not win the American Football Conference championship game.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Sports Briefing column on Friday about criticism of the former St. Louis Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire after he admitted taking steroids described incorrectly the background of Adolphus A. Busch IV, who issued a statement chastising McGwire’s behavior. Although Mr. Busch is a member of the family that once owned the team, it is his nephew, August A. Busch IV  not Mr. Busch  who was a chief executive of Anheuser-Busch and who was involved in a car crash that killed a passenger.

headline: Corrections
text: A jazz entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Pete McCann Quartet, at the Brooklyn Lyceum, misstated the performance date. It is Wednesday night, not Tuesday night.

headline: Awesome, and Then Some
text: (Warning: Good friends have refused to believe a word of what I’m about to relate. Your credulity is about to be strained.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Page 32 this weekend about the writer James Patterson refers incorrectly to his share of the publishing market. Since 2006, Mr. Patterson has written one out of every 17 hardcover novels  not hardcover books  bought in the United States.

headline: Corrections
text: SPORTS

headline: With Kindle, the Best Sellers Don’t Need to Sell
text: Here’s a riddle: How do you make your book a best seller on the Kindle?

headline: In Arizona, a Stream of Illegal Immigrants From China
text: TUCSON  The unforgiving terrain of the Sonoran Desert, south of here, whose searing summers and frigid winters claim hundreds of lives each year, has long been a favored avenue of entry for illegal immigrants from Mexico and other Latin American countries. But in the last year, the authorities say, smugglers have increasingly capitalized on a much more lucrative business  trafficking Chinese citizens into the United States.

headline: Thousands Fleeing Disaster Receive a Welcome to America
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  With visions of destruction still in their heads, planeloads of Haitians and Haitian-Americans received an all-American post-disaster welcome Friday in the brightly lighted gymnasium at the Homestead Air Reserve Base south of Miami: customs inspections, peanut butter crackers and phone calls, with dollops of that indispensable condiment, hand sanitizer.

headline: No Tears for Nagasu as She Takes Lead After Short Program
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  When Mirai Nagasu saw her score pop onto the leader board at the United States Figure Skating Championships on Thursday, she looked straight into the television camera and did a little dance.

headline: Banks May Get Help to Escape Risk Limits
text: Only a year after the government stepped in to aid Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley by granting them access to the federal safety net, policy makers are developing an exit path that would allow them and others to escape limits on banks being proposed by the Obama administration.

headline: The Week Ahead: Jan. 24- 30
text: Art

headline: Heated Words at the Polanski Hearing
text: LOS ANGELES — From the beginning, it was clear that Friday’s hearing in the Roman Polanski case, in which Judge Peter Espinoza refused to grant Mr. Polanski’s request to be sentenced in absentia, was going to be a rough one. The judge started 20 minutes late, leaving an especially large gaggle of news people and hangers-on shuffling around the halls. On taking the bench, he announced that he had already given lawyers a tentative ruling, but was willing to hear a few last words before finalizing it.

headline: Heart Patients Warned Against Using Meridia, an Anti-Obesity Drug
text: European and American drug regulators had two starkly different reactions this week to data on an obesity drug. The raw data from the study indicated that people with certain health problems who took the prescription diet drug Meridia had more heart attacks, strokes and other cardiovascular problems than people getting a placebo.

headline: No Progress in Talks for Financing of European Military Plane
text: BERLIN  Military officials from the European countries with orders to buy the Airbus A400M military transport plane tried and failed again Friday to resolve differences over how to share billions of euros in cost overruns.

headline: Artists on Tapestries
text: Fred Tomaselli, Gavin Turk and Shazia Sikander discuss how their original work was translated into tapestry form for the show, "Banners of Persuasion," now at the James Cohan gallery.

headline: Mets Acquire Gary Matthews Jr., an Itinerant Outfielder
text: Gary Matthews Jr. has been a Met before. At the start of the 2002 season, he pinch-hit for Al Leiter and pinch-ran for Mo Vaughn. Then he was traded to Baltimore, the fifth stop in a seven-team, 11-year major league career.

headline: Lenin’s Body
text: When I was young I us’d to waitOn the boss and hand him his plate;And Pass down the bottle when he got dry,And brush away the blue tail fly.

headline: Paris Accessories: Cold Play
text: Here’s a closer look at one of the adorable hats (by Stephen Jones) at Comme des Garcons, and a glove at Rick Owens that seems a blend of mitten and sweater sleeve. The accessories have obvious limitations—no side view from the hat, no fingers with the gloves—but, hey, what’s not to like?

headline: Asian Hotel Brands Make the Journey to Europe
text: SINGAPORE  International hotel brands are stepping up their investments in the Asia-Pacific region because of its outsized growth prospects. So it would seem almost counterintuitive for luxury hospitality brands based in Asia to be opening hotels in Europe, where growth is slowing.

headline: Advantage, Arizona, in Bid to Keep the Cubs
text: The Chicago Cubs moved a step closer toward getting a new spring training facility in Mesa, Ariz., hurting hopes in Naples, Fla., of luring the team east.

headline: Oakland Prospect Retires to Join the Priesthood
text: Grant Desme hit 31 home runs and stole 40 bases in Class A last season, and as an encore, he was named most valuable player of the Arizona Fall League. The Oakland Athletics had plans to invite Desme, a 23-year-old outfielder, to spring training next month.

headline: A Brooklyn Bar and Haven Teeters on the Edge of Extinction
text: The Starlite Lounge in Brooklyn is one of those institutions that have been around for so long, neighbors no longer stop to notice how incongruous their presence really is.

headline: Born the Same Year; Similarities End There
text: CHOPIN and Schumann, whose bicentenaries the classical music world celebrates this year, have long been linked as pioneers of Romanticism, in part because of the shared year of their births. Yet they were quite different creative artists who had little personal contact and moved mostly in separate circles.

headline: Building Bridges From Purcell to George Crumb
text: In the program note for her recital of songs by Henry Purcell and George Crumb at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, the soprano Christine Schäfer wrote that “for me there’s no such thing as ‘early’ music or ‘new’ music.” In her view, knowing each side of the repertory makes you hear the other differently.

headline: O’Brien’s Last Good Night
text: Conan O’Brien closed out his career at the “Tonight” show — and NBC — with a last monologue centering on his tumultuous last week on the show and a last commentary that expressed his gratitude for the opportunities NBC gave him and for the staff and friends and fans who supported him.

headline: U.S. Soccer Player Is National Hero (in Honduras)
text: CARSON, Calif.  With the United States trailing by a goal in the waning seconds, Jonathan Bornstein looked at his fellow defender Steve Cherundolo as the team prepared to take a corner kick.

headline: Bloggingheads: Citizens United
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Heather Gerken of Yale Law School discuss the Supreme Court's campaign finance ruling.

headline: Revised M.T.A. Plan Would Spare Some Routes and Cut Others
text: A newly configured slate of proposed transit changes, unveiled Friday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, would resurrect a subway line and restore service to many of New York City’s bus routes, including crosstown lines in Manhattan, that had been singled out for elimination.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Plot Suspect Implicated Himself, Officials Say
text: A Queens College graduate who has been charged with receiving Qaeda training and of plotting to kill American soldiers abroad gave investigators “very detailed information” about “terrorist-related activities” involving himself and others, prosecutors said in a letter filed in court on Friday.

headline: A Chemistry Forged Over Cigars and Defense
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets’ ministry of defense was a package deal, a threesome of defensive coaches, more Sack Pack than Rat Pack. The franchise hired Rex Ryan as coach, and Ryan insisted on hiring Mike Pettine as defensive coordinator and Dennis Thurman as the defensive backs coach.

headline: Celebrities Go Low-Key, and Sometimes Nameless, in the Haiti Telethon
text: George Clooney is the un-Jerry Lewis of celebrity telethons. The star-studded fund-raiser on Friday that he organized for victims of the Haiti earthquake was a study in carefully muted star power. More than 100 of the most famous actors and music stars in the world went on stage pretending to be nobody.

headline: Pakistan Hesitates, Again
text: For years, Pakistan’s leaders denied that extremists  in Pakistan and neighboring Afghanistan  posed a mortal threat to their country. After the Pakistani Taliban got within 60 miles of Islamabad last April they decided that they had no choice but to fight back. They were right. Unfortunately, their understanding of self-interest seems to stop at a border that the Taliban certainly does not respect.

headline: Here’s How to Help
text: President Obama promised this week to reconnect to the concerns and needs of Americans who are suffering from the recession. One important way to do that is to help hard-pressed families hang on to their homes.

headline: A Good Fight
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton picked the right battle this week, calling for an end to Internet censorship and naming governments that suppress the free flow of information  including China, Iran, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Vietnam, Tunisia and Uzbekistan.

headline: Storm Week
text: On the radar maps, the storms that swept across California this past week looked like a series of Rorschach tests in primary colors. They swirled down out of the Pacific only to fracture and disintegrate when they hit land. No matter what measurements you used  snowpack depth at Bishop Pass, swell height data from the coastal buoys or the drip rate off the porch roof  everyone was watching the storms, hoping for a blossoming desert or simply to get over the mountains before the Grapevine closed with snow.

headline: Corporate Spending in Our Elections
text: To the Editor:

headline: Teaching the Chinese Language in American Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Chemical BPA: Views of the Industry and Others
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Lady and the Arlen
text: This is not the hour of the good loser in Democratic circles.

headline: They Still Don’t Get It
text: How loud do the alarms have to get? There is an economic emergency in the country with millions upon millions of Americans riddled with fear and anxiety as they struggle with long-term joblessness, home foreclosures, personal bankruptcies and dwindling opportunities for themselves and their children.

headline: Mobs Rule
text: Welcome to the mob: an angry, wounded electorate, riled by recession, careening across the political spectrum, still craving change, nursing a bloodlust.

headline: Bringing Democracy to New York
text: IN Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s State of the City speech on Wednesday, he spoke of the City Council as if it were an equal partner in government. Indeed, the mayor’s surprisingly close re-election, the unusual defeat of a handful of council members and some spirited races in the general election in a city where winning the Democratic primary is tantamount to victory, might lead one to expect the 51-member body to be imbued with new democratic vigor. However, the council members inaugurated this month have joined a body whose governance structure is hardly more democratic than a high school student council’s  where the principal calls the shots.

headline: Northeastern Salvages Season Before It’s Too Late
text: BOSTON  More than half of the scholarship players on the Northeastern University basketball team hail from outside the United States, with birthplaces like British Columbia, Sudan and Cape Verde.

headline: Correction
text: A biographical note for the author of an article on Jan. 10 about the influence of American ideas on the treatment of mental illness abroad misidentified the publisher of his new book. Ethan Watters’s ‘‘Crazy Like Us: The Globalization of the American Psyche’’ was just published by Free Press, not Basic Books. The article also gave an outdated name for a patient advocacy organization that has supported a biomedical view of mental illness. It is the National Alliance on Mental Illness, no longer the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill.

headline: Halfpipe Team Is Taking Shape
text: PARK CITY, Utah  The snowboarders Hannah Teter and Scott Lago probably secured spots on the United States Olympic halfpipe team Friday night, and Shaun White had “the run of my life” in winning the United States Snowboarding Grand Prix.

headline: Mets Acquire Matthews From Angels
text: Gary Matthews Jr. has been a Met before. At the start of the 2002 season, he pinch-hit for Al Leiter and pinch-ran for Mo Vaughn. Then he was traded to Baltimore, the fifth stop in a seven-team, 11-year major league career.

headline: Irwin Dambrot Dies at 81; Caught in Gambling Scandal
text: Irwin Dambrot, who helped lead City College to the 1950 N.I.T. and N.C.A.A. basketball championships, only to be engulfed in a national point-shaving scandal that tarnished an unprecedented feat and rocked the college game, died on Thursday. He was 81 and lived in Mendham, N.J.

headline: Bryant Rises to the Occasion at the Garden
text: Powerful forces, both athletic and political, filled Madison Square Garden on Friday night, making the Knicks bystanders in their own building.

headline: The Cycle of Mel
text: A look at the justice-fighting roles of Mel Gibson.

headline: In Song, Trying to Convey the Scope of a Tragedy
text: Some songs are written with meaning in mind. Others have meaning thrust on them. Still others are chameleonlike, taking on the mood of the room.

headline: Dennehy’s Vivid Performances Fit Chicago Stage
text: When Brian Dennehy steps onto the stage at the Goodman Theatre and launches into his bravura portrayal of Erie Smith, the washed-up hustler at the heart of Eugene O’Neill’s “Hughie,” you sense that you are watching a man who is very much at home.

headline: Serena Williams Cruises Into Fourth Round
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Serena Williams, a four-time Australian Open winner, continued her assault on a fifth title Saturday, steamrolling past Carla Suárez Navarro of Spain, 6-0, 6-3.

headline: After the Massachusetts Massacre
text: It was not a referendum on Barack Obama, who in every poll remains one of the most popular politicians in America. It was not a rejection of universal health care, which Massachusetts mandated (with Scott Brown’s State Senate vote) in 2006. It was not a harbinger of a resurgent G.O.P., whose numbers remain in the toilet. Brown had the good sense not to identify himself as a Republican in either his campaign advertising or his victory speech.

headline: The Naked and the Dead
text: I wondered how the Governator of California felt about the crumbling Kennedy legacy in Massachusetts and the rocketing Scott Brown, who has promised to scuttle the health care bill.

headline: Classic Ad: America’s First Su-BAH-ru
text: In this Sunday’s Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen finds much to praise in the newly redesigned Legacy and Outback from Subaru (emphasis, in this case, on the first syllable). It seems the company has come a long way in four decades.

headline: Federer and Williams Sisters Bring Their Everyday Game
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Perhaps because the Australian Open heralds the arrival of a new season with new challenges for the world’s top tennis players, one line of questioning is persistent: “How’s your form? How’s your fitness? Are you playing well enough to win?”

headline: Prince vs. Favre in ‘Viking Idol’
text: Well, someone has to do this.

headline: Favre Story Underplayed?
text: Is it possible that the Brett Favre story — overplayed to the point of nausea in the off-season — has now become a little underplayed?

headline: Now Screening | Jean Paul Gaultier
text: The fall 2010 collection from Jean Paul Gaultier.

headline: Part 6: Answers on the Fafsa and Financial Aid
text: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is trying to streamline this year.

headline: 1968 A.F.L. Title Game: One Jets Fan’s Story
text: In the comments section a few days ago, Jon Silverberg of Brooklyn shared a story about having to travel out of New York to watch the A.F.L. title game in 1968.

headline: January’s Poli-Book Best-Seller List
text: “Game Change,” a book about the 2008 presidential campaign that has a tell-all, confessional feel to it, debuts at No. 2, near the top of our first Caucus list of political best-sellers in 2010.

headline: The Changing Economics of Marriage
text: Today, more women than ever are earning as much or more at work than their husbands. How are the changing economics of marriage affecting husbands and wives?

headline: Now Screening | Rick Owens
text: The fall 2010 collection from Rick Owens.

headline: Saturday Word: Obama and the Court Ruling
text: The Obama administration has begun working with Congress to craft a “forceful, bipartisan” response to the Supreme Court’s decision that the government may not ban political spending by corporations in elections, President Obama said in his weekly address.

headline: Shaun White Wins, With a McTwist
text: PARK CITY, Utah — The snowboarder Shaun White has upped the ante again, winning Friday night’s Grand Prix here, with what he called the hardest trick he has ever done: a Double McTwist 1260.

headline: Preview: U.S. vs. Honduras
text: The United States men’s national team faces Honduras at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif., on Saturday night (live at 9 p.m. Eastern on Fox Soccer Channel and Telefutura) in an international friendly. It is the first game of the year for both teams as they prepare for the World Cup in South Africa.

headline: Jose Maria Lopez at USF1
text: Further confirmation that the USF1 team project is really happening: Jose Maria Lopez’s manager told Reuters that the driver would be joining the team and the announcement will be made on Monday.

headline: The Millennium Cities Initiative
text: The following is the fourth in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones aren’t, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

headline: ‘Vulnerable to Mudslides’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: It’s been raining here in Los Angeles all week. People are evacuating their homes in areas that are vulnerable to mudslides. Is it me or has this state had nothing but disasters since Arnold Schwarzenegger took over as governor?

headline: ‘Imagine What Would Happen’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Yesterday, President Obama met with a group of mayors at the White House. He told them that he was glad not to be running a city during this recession. It’s part of Obama’s new campaign slogan, “Sucks to be you.”

headline: Intimations of Sanity
text: Politico reports that Harry Reid and Nancy Pelosi are working on a strategy that just might save health care: get the House to pass the Senate bill, while the Senate uses reconciliation — a process that avoids the need for a 60-vote supermajority — to address some of the concerns of House Democrats.

headline: The Bernanke Conundrum
text: A funny thing happened on the way to the Bernanke confirmation: the vote in Massachusetts turned an easy coronation into a tough fight. And this isn’t one of those cases where everyone who knows something is on one side. Look at two of my favorite econobloggers: the very judicious Calculated Risk says “We can do better”, while Brad DeLong says, “Don’t block Ben.”

headline: Agassi Inspired Thoughts on Drivers and Other Athletes
text: I’m reading and thoroughly enjoying Andre Agassi’s autobiography, “Open.” At the moment I’m only 67 pages into it, but I’m really struck most by one thing: Although I read a couple of reviews of this book, my recollection of the reviews was that the big deal with this Agassi story was that he admits to taking drugs during his tennis career. For me, that’s a thoroughly uninteresting point compared to the extraordinary story of how his father worked him as a child and gave him no choice in life as to what he would do. He would be world champion, No. 1, tennis player. No choice, any disagreement about that and you’re punished, kid. And coupled with this treatment by the father – which even more miraculously actually succeeded – Andre talks about how much he hated tennis as a child, and in the first chapter of the book while fighting through his last United States Open, his hate for the game then too!

headline: A Challenge Awaits Serena Williams
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — As overpowering as Serena Williams has been in search of her fifth Australian Open title, she has a dangerous fourth-round match against one of the Australia’s native daughters, Samantha Stosur.

headline: Now Screening | Kris Van Assche
text: The fall 2010 collection from Kris Van Assche.

headline: Blockbuster Ratings for O’Brien’s Final ‘Tonight’
text: Updated | 1:28 p.m. Conan O’Brien’s farewell fared spectacularly on Friday night, pulling in what is expected to be the biggest audience in late night since his own first night as host of the “Tonight” show in June.

headline: Tennessee Woman Accused in Trail of Death
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Few people here know that the ashes of David Leath, still in the cardboard box from the crematorium, are kept on a shelf above the clean towels in the Suburban Barber Shop where he cut hair at the middle chair for almost 40 years.

headline: Foot on Bomb, Marine Defies a Taliban Trap
text: SHOSHARAK, Afghanistan  If luck is the battlefield’s final arbiter  the wild card that can trump fitness, training, teamwork, equipment, character and skill  then Lance Cpl. Ryan T. Mathison experienced its purest and most welcome form.

headline: Going Too Far
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I’m particularly fond of Eric Berlin’s “Going Too Far” puzzles, although I found this one trickier than usual.

headline: Two U.S. Soldiers Are Among 17 Afghan Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 17 people died in four separate episodes in Afghanistan on Saturday, while a police chief was kidnapped and a provincial governor narrowly escaped assassination.

headline: In Brash Coach, Jets Knew They Had a Winner
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets’ improbable run to the verge of their first Super Bowl appearance in 41 years started last January in a hotel conference room near the Baltimore-Washington airport.

headline: Super Bowl Champion Jets Ignited a Sporting Revival in the Big Town
text: Do the Jets really understand what they could set in motion Sunday against the Colts?

headline: Biden Says U.S. Will Appeal Blackwater Case Dismissal
text: BAGHDAD  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. promised Iraqi leaders on Saturday that the United States would appeal the dismissal of manslaughter charges against five Blackwater Worldwide security contractors involved in a deadly shooting here that has inflamed anti-American tensions.

headline: Jean Simmons Dies at 80; Actress Whose Talent Exceeded the Parts She Played
text: Jean Simmons, the English actress who made the covers of Time and Life magazines by the time she was 20 and became a major midcentury star alongside strong leading men like Laurence Olivier, Richard Burton and Marlon Brando, often playing their demure helpmates, died on Friday at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 80.

headline: Gates Sees Fallout From Troubled Ties With Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Nobody else in the Obama administration has been mired in Pakistan for as long as Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates. So on a trip here this past week to try to soothe the country’s growing rancor toward the United States, he served as a punching bag tested over a quarter-century.

headline: Israel Poised to Challenge a U.N. Report on Gaza
text: TEL AVIV  The Israeli military is completing a rebuttal to a United Nations report accusing it of grave violations of international and humanitarian law in its Gaza invasion a year ago. Its central aim is to dispel the report’s harsh conclusion  that the death of noncombatants and destruction of civilian infrastructure were part of an official plan to terrorize the Palestinian population.

headline: Obama Moves to Centralize Control Over Party Strategy
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is reconstituting the team that helped him win the White House to counter Republican challenges in the midterm elections and recalibrate after political setbacks that have narrowed his legislative ambitions.

headline: The Jets’ Field-Goal Block Unit Believes It Can Influence Any Kick
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Eight minutes into the most recent game between the Jets and Indianapolis  long before the Colts pulled their starters and started a controversy  a 30-year-old reserve Jets linebacker named Bryan Thomas blocked an extra point.

headline: Obama Team Reunites
text: In an Oval Office meeting on Tuesday, just hours before Republicans scored their first electoral victory of the year in the Massachusetts Senate race, President Obama asked David Plouffe to oversee the Democratic Party’s midterm election efforts. Read Jeff Zeleny and Peter Baker’s report in Sunday’s newspaper today.

headline: British Man Held for Fraud in Iraq Bomb Detectors
text: BAGHDAD  The director of a British company that supplies bomb detectors to Iraq has been arrested on fraud charges, and the export of the devices has been banned, British government officials confirmed Saturday.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Halak Gives Hope to Habs and Slovakia
text: Three games on Friday night, led off by another Olympic preview — Canada goalie Martin Brodeur vs. Slovakia goalie Jaroslav Halak. Home teams listed first:

headline: Thriving Saints Helped New Orleans Revive After Hurricane Katrina
text: NEW ORLEANS  One week after the Super Bowl, citizens of this enchanting and peculiar city will place a crown upon the head of Saints quarterback Drew Brees. They will dress him in a tunic, put him on a float and parade him through the streets before cheering throngs.

headline: In Search of Fatter Wallets at Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah

headline: Halfpipe Squads Take Shape
text: PARK CITY, Utah  The snowboarders Shaun White and Kelly Clark finished the United States Olympic qualifying season Saturday by winning for the fourth time in five events, emphatically sending them to the Winter Games in Vancouver as the halfpipe riders to beat.

headline: For Richer or for ... Not Quite as Rich
text: EVERY era needs an emblematic tycoon, and for the age of the Great Recession, you couldn’t do better than Peter M. Brant.

headline: The Apple Guessing Game
text: “There is no such uncertainty as a sure thing,” wrote the Scottish poet Robert (“Auld Lang Syne”) Burns.

headline: Web Is Bringing Skaters’ Lives Uneasily Close to Fans’ Obsessions
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  When Brian Orser received an e-mail message last fall from an admirer of his star figure skater, Kim Yu-na of South Korea, he wrote it off as another piece of fan mail.

headline: Correction: Photo Caption
text: A picture credit last Sunday with a collection of excerpts from literary writings about Haiti misspelled the surname of the photographer. The picture, of a girl dancing on a barren landscape, was taken by Maggie Steber, not Stebber.

headline: Why Is a Utility Paying Customers?
text: BOISE, Idaho

headline: Sardonic at Heart? Download This to Make Your Point
text: This is what we really need. For those who want to make sure their sarcasm is recognized for what it is, Sarcasm Inc., a Michigan company, has developed the “SarcMark” to identify sarcastic comments in e-mail and text messages.

headline: Resetting the Moral Compass
text: IT was great to see President Obama renew his focus on financial reform last week, even if it looked like an attempt to distract voters from his party’s stunning loss of the Senate election in Massachusetts. Even so, by promoting the ideas of Paul Volcker  the esteemed former Federal Reserve chairman  the White House is finally elevating the discourse on how best to rein in risky behavior at banks and protect beleaguered taxpayers from future bailouts of Wall Street.

headline: With a No-Show, Poe’s Mystery Fan Stirs Speculation
text: Does this mean nevermore? For the first time since 1949, a black-clad figure known as the Poe Toaster failed to show up at Edgar Allan Poe’s gravesite in Baltimore to celebrate the anniversary of the writer’s birth 201 years ago. The visitor, whose identity has remained a mystery, would raise a Cognac toast and leave behind three red roses, along with the remnants of the Cognac bottle. About 30 Poe fans stood in the cold for hours early on Jan. 19 as they waited for the mysterious visitor, The Baltimore Sun reported. Some speculated the toaster might have just had the flu or car trouble — or that he had died. “So many people have said: ‘I hope it’s not over. It was such a nice tradition,’ ” Jeff Jerome, curator of the Edgar Allan Poe House, told the newspaper. “But maybe it has just run its course. It wasn’t going to last forever.”

headline: Knicks Succeed by Selling an Intangible: Hope
text: As short-term investments go, a Knicks season-ticket plan might seem rather ill fated. Fans last summer were asked to send thousands of dollars to a 32-win team that had added no significant talent and was trudging toward the second year of a wait-now, rebuild-later plan.

headline: Quotations of the Week
text: “I need a better word than unprecedented or amazing to describe what’s happened with the text-message program.”—Roger Lowe, a Red Cross spokesman, on a campaign that has brought in $22 million in pledges since the earthquake in Haiti.

headline: Watch Where You Click (and Have a Great Day)
text: IN this episode, the Haggler again asks whether the Internet is a net plus or net minus for consumers. It’s certainly excellent for consuming, which is to say that e-commerce has been a spectacular boon for people who like to shop but hate to bathe and leave the house.

headline: What My Mentors Have Taught Me
text: A FEW years ago, I changed jobs, moving from the beverage industry to the biopharmaceutical industry. I didn’t know how to get ahead in the new environment, however, so I turned to a mentoring program. I’d recommend finding a mentor for help with your career. If you’re open to what you hear and have realistic expectations, I can’t think of a downside.

headline: Banks May Get Help to Escape Risk Limits
text: Only a year after the government stepped in to aid Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley by granting them access to the federal safety net, policy makers are developing an exit path that would allow them and others to escape limits on banks being proposed by the Obama administration, The New York Times’s Louise Story and Eric Dash report.

headline: Fatal Radiation
text: Scott Jerome-Parks received a fatal radiation overdose during treatment with a relatively new type of linear accelerator.

headline: The Joy of a Family Shop
text: MY dad was an engineer in the military when I was growing up. We moved about every three years and returned to California when he retired, just before I started high school.

headline: Prime Number
text: 1/2: Lowering the amount of salt people consume by half a teaspoon a day could reduce cases of heart disease, stroke and heart attacks as much as reductions in smoking, obesity and cholesterol levels, a study in The New England Journal of Medicine reported. The study, by scientists at the University of California, San Francisco; Stanford University Medical Center; and Columbia University Medical Center, comes as health authorities around the country are considering policies that would pressure food companies to reduce salt in processed foods.

headline: Why Can’t the I.R.S. Help Fill in the Blanks?
text: IN the digital age, filing income tax returns should be a snap. The important data from employers and financial institutions have already been sent to the government’s computers. Yet taxpayers are still required to perform the anachronistic chore of preparing a return from scratch. And, in many cases, they pay a software company for the privilege.

headline: Three Faces of Market Danger
text: AFTER one of the most volatile periods for stocks in decades, it’s only natural for investors to wonder how risky the markets will be in 2010.

headline: Making Sense of the New Political Anger
text: Like so many good narratives, political stories often unfold along simple lines but invite multiple, at times conflicting, interpretations.

headline: Underwater, but Will They Leave the Pool?
text: MUCH has been said about the high rate of home foreclosures, but the most interesting question may be this: Why is the mortgage default rate so low?

headline: Earl Wild, Pianist, Dies at 94
text: Earl Wild, an American pianist and composer who was renowned for his performances of the virtuoso showpieces of the grand Romantic tradition but whose enormous repertory included everything from Baroque works and Mozart concertos to contemporary scores, died Saturday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 94.

headline: High Heels? They Just Don’t Fit
text: This interview with Bobbi Brown, founder of Bobbi Brown Cosmetics, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Jean Simmons and Earl Wild Are Dead
text: Two captivating performers whose careers flourished throughout the middle of last century, the British actress Jean Simmons and the American pianist and composer Earl Wild, died this weekend.

headline: Archbishop Killed in Quake Is Buried
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Hundreds of Haitians  some still bandaged, many in tears  gathered in the parking lot of the destroyed cathedral here Saturday for the funeral of the archbishop of Port-au-Prince.

headline: What Could You Live Without?
text: It all began with a stop at a red light.

headline: Building Safer Schools in Poor, Shaky Places
text: [March 6 | Update The Times has an article on the enormous social impact from the loss of hundreds of schools in Haiti. Also relevant is my recent post and story on Istanbul’s efforts to strengthen schools and other public buildings before its next big quake.]

headline: More (Steve) Jobs, Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
text: The most striking feature of Barack Obama’s campaign for the presidency was the amazing, young, Internet-enabled, grass-roots movement he mobilized to get elected. The most striking feature of Obama’s presidency a year later is how thoroughly that movement has disappeared.

headline: Well, It Wasn’t a Bad Year for Everyone
text: The last year will be remembered as a bad one for business. Losses, layoffs, pay cuts, furloughs, closings  the numbers and the news were largely negative. And yet, over all, some industries managed to avoid the negative vibrations. A sampling of sales figures in major industry categories makes this clear.

headline: Cultural Riches Turn to Rubble in Haiti Quake
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Long before its ground started heaving, Haiti was already a byword for a broken place. Its leaders were considered kleptocrats; its people were jaw-droppingly poor. But there was still a pride that burst forth from the people here, linked both to the country’s heroic history and to the vibrant culture that united them and enabled them to endure.

headline: Does Corporate Money Lead to Political Corruption?
text: WASHINGTON — “There are two things that are important in politics,” Mark Hanna, the great Republican kingmaker of the late 19th century, once said. “The first thing is money, and I can’t remember what the second one is.”

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Face to Face With Tragedy
text: It was hard to look at some of the pictures of suffering and death caused by the earthquake in Haiti  and impossible to turn away.

headline: Correction: Buying Landmarks? Easy. Keeping Them? Maybe Not.
text: An article last Sunday about Tishman Speyer Properties misidentified the adviser hired by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to negotiate a loan restructuring with Tishman Speyer over office buildings in Chicago. It is BlackRock, not the Blackstone Group. The article also misstated the size of a deal in which Tishman Speyer acquired Archstone Smith. It was $22.2 billion, not million.

headline: Figure Skaters of Asian Descent Have Risen to Prominence
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  Before finishing second at the United States Figure Skating Championships, Mirai Nagasu said with a teenager’s irrepressibility, “I’m here to show myself and others I’m the future of the U.S.A.”

headline: Correction: Sure, Flying Is Less Fun, but Also Less Pricey
text: A picture caption with the Backdrop feature last Sunday about the history of air travel misidentified an Eastern Airlines plane photographed in the 1930s. It was a DC-2, not a DC-3.

headline: A Brushback for Loner Tale
text: And you thought “Howl” got a soft reception. In what feels like Sundance’s first full-blown critical wipeout, “Hesher” got pushed face down in the slush by the trade magazine critics and prominent movie bloggers after its premiere on Friday.

headline: The Taliban Don’t Seem Ready to Talk
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The last time somebody tried to make a deal with the Taliban to end the war in Afghanistan, he didn’t get far.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 24
text: This week, the networks are serving up earfuls of post-Massachusetts election politics and examinations of the future of the midterm elections and the health care legislation.

headline: The Book Club With Just One Member
text: Early in the novel “When You Reach Me,” which last week won the John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to children’s literature, the narrator, Miranda, falls into an uncomfortable conversation with a schoolmate about her favorite book,  “A Wrinkle in Time”  by Madeleine L’Engle.

headline: Father Time in Pads
text: Most of the country might have learned last Sunday why 40-year-old Brett Favre, after shoulder surgery, after his seasonal flirtation with retirement, has continued to play. But the Hall of Famer George Blanda did not need to see pinpoint passes, sandlot improvisation or butt-slapping joie de Favre to get it. He has known all along.

headline: In 1970, a 43-Year-Old Became the Raiders’ Comeback Kid
text: George Blanda, then 43, came off the bench for the Oakland Raiders to throw touchdown passes and kick field goals that won or tied five consecutive games during the 1970 season. This is the way that remarkable stretch played out:
