headline: China to Seek ‘Stability’ in Tibet via Development
text: BEIJING  China’s top leaders laid out a strategy last week for bringing “leapfrog development and lasting stability” to the Tibetan regions, the state news agency reported late Friday.

headline: A Bar Mitzvah/Graduation/Wedding, All in One
text: The Bagger got the gamut of the Sundance experience on Friday – well, except for the whole skiing part. But there was the requisite media hype; the press room for “Howl” included folks from Vanity Fair and IFC and yes, the Bagger herself, all talking about a movie that seemingly fizzled out of the gate.

headline: In Japan, U.S. Losing Diplomatic Ground to China
text: TOKYO  When Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates visited Japan’s new leaders in October, not long after their historic election, he pressed so hard and so publicly for a military base agreement that the Japanese news media labeled him a bully.

headline: Remembering Two Storytellers From the N.H.L.
text: The hockey world lost two of its most respected communicators last week. John Halligan, a hockey historian best known as the Rangers’ longtime public-relations director, was 68. Paul Quarrington, an award-winning Canadian novelist, essayist, screenwriter and musician, was 56.

headline: Imagining a Stronger Haiti Past the Pain
text: Until Jan. 12, Haiti was a “fragile state” desperate for help to develop a working economy and effective institutions. Now it is something much worse — a charnel house with tens of thousands of corpses in a capital city laid waste. Relief has superseded development, and languid policy debate has given way to a vast and accelerating mobilization.

headline: Jersey Native Has Failed to Turn Rutgers Around
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Gilvydas Biruta, a 6-foot-8 Lithuanian with exceptional leaping ability, landed in the United States two years ago with little knowledge of college basketball. After enrolling at St. Benedict’s Prep, a national power in Newark, he attended games at local colleges. When his friend Greg Echenique, a former St. Benedict’s player, started at Rutgers in November 2008, Biruta went to see him play.

headline: TV Refugees From Moscow
text: KIEV, Ukraine — In the final weeks of Ukraine’s presidential campaign, all the candidates have wanted to appear on Savik Shuster’s political talk show. Denied an invitation, one even threatened to carry out a swashbuckling raid on Mr. Shuster’s television studio in Kiev to force a very impromptu live debate with a rival.

headline: In Northern Michigan, an Olympic Training Hot Spot Has Emerged
text: GAYLORD, Mich.  When word spread through the woods of northern Michigan that world-class snowboarders had gathered in this little town to train for the coming Winter X Games and the Vancouver Olympics, locals jokingly asked if they had become horribly lost on their way to a real ski resort in Colorado or British Columbia.

headline: Radiation Offers New Cures, and Ways to Do Harm
text: As Scott Jerome-Parks lay dying, he clung to this wish: that his fatal radiation overdose  which left him deaf, struggling to see, unable to swallow, burned, with his teeth falling out, with ulcers in his mouth and throat, nauseated, in severe pain and finally unable to breathe  be studied and talked about publicly so that others might not have to live his nightmare.

headline: Things Aren’t So Simple Anymore for Shaun White
text: Shaun White had won the snowboarding event the day before with a dazzling run of flips and spins above the 22-foot walls of the halfpipe in Copper Mountain, Colo. But this was the next day, a quiet Sunday in December, in an ordinary house on a dead-end dirt road above the ski town of Breckenridge.

headline: In 1975, 2 Women Crossed a Barrier
text: When the day finally came that she would break down a huge professional barrier, Robin Herman did not have much time to prepare. Herman, then a 23-year-old reporter for The New York Times, had been trying for a year to persuade N.H.L. teams to allow her and other female reporters access to athletes in the postgame locker room when, unexpectedly, the two coaches at the 1975 N.H.L. All-Star Game in Montreal said, yes, women would be given the same access as men.

headline: Massachusetts: Political Kingmaker, Political Heartbreaker
text: WASHINGTON — Long before Scott Brown hopped in his pickup truck and did the electoral equivalent of doughnuts on the White House lawn, President Obama’s political destiny, for better or worse, was tied more closely to Massachusetts than to any state but Illinois.

headline: In Stosur, a Tough Test in Round 4
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  As overpowering as Serena Williams has been in search of her fifth Australian Open title, she has a dangerous fourth-round match against Australia’s Samantha Stosur.

headline: Abraham Sutzkever, 96, Jewish Poet and Partisan, Dies
text: Abraham Sutzkever, one of the great Yiddish poets of his generation who evoked the nightmare of the Holocaust with images of a wagonload of worn shoes and the haunting silence of a sky of white stars, died Wednesday in Tel Aviv. He was 96.

headline: Swimmers See Games Around the Corner
text: LONG BEACH, Calif.  Here it is, the dead of winter, and it is hard to turn on the television  particularly NBC  without catching a glimpse of Michael Phelps swimming through the streets in a sandwich commercial, or parting water in a pool for an Olympics promo.

headline: In Some Ways, Jets Look Like a Champion
text: Jay P. Granat, a psychotherapist, and Carlton J. Chin, a financial analyst, are the authors of “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method.”

headline: Feeling Like Old Times in Boston
text: BOSTON — Reggie Lewis isn’t walking through that door. Jim Calhoun isn’t walking through that door, either. None of the luminaries from Northeastern’s basketball history are going to rise from Matthews Arena, the century-old hockey arena where the Huskies play.

headline: Tax Increase for the Rich Is at Issue in Oregon
text: CENTRAL POINT, Ore.  Few places have felt the twin challenges presented by Oregon’s broken state budget and its knotted tax system the way this old farm town has.

headline: Abridged Edition
text: Click here to see what the print version of this grid looks like.

headline: In a Kennedy Hometown, Warm Feelings Don’t Necessarily Mean Votes
text: HYANNIS, Mass.  The residents of this cozy village on the southern shore of Cape Cod recollect with pride the sight of his unmistakable hefty, white-topped frame as they exchanged greetings on the street, waited together in line at the local ice cream shop, shared a church pew or returned his dogs  those dogs!  after they found their way into some neighboring yard.

headline: The Case for a Climate Bill
text: The conventional wisdom is that the chances of Congress passing a bill that puts both a cap and a price on greenhouse gases are somewhere between terrible and nil. President Obama can start to prove the conventional wisdom wrong by making a full-throated case for a climate bill in his State of the Union speech this week.

headline: Settlement in Dispute That Riveted the Chess World
text: A legal dispute that had riveted the chess world and hobbled the United States Chess Federation, the game’s governing body, has been settled  mostly.

headline: Governor Paterson’s Turn on Ethics
text: After New York’s Legislature passed an ethics package last week, Senator Liz Krueger, a Democrat from Manhattan who voted for the bill, told her colleagues, “We need to not pat ourselves on the back that much because we have further to go.”

headline: A Thrill Ride Down an Icy Chute
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Speeds topped out at about 35 miles per hour on the Utah Olympic Park luge, skeleton and bobsled course. That is about one-third as fast as Olympian lugers. It was fast enough.During reporting for an coming story, two of us from The New York Times were invited by USA Luge to steer a sled down the track used for the 2002 Winter Games. While it provided useful perspective for the story (it will run in February, if the suspense is just too much), it also offered a glimpse of what it takes to slide feet-first down an icy, banked chute.

headline: Juniors Watch: Strong Fields, With Few Americans
text: The Australian Open junior championships begin Sunday, with the girls and boys fields featuring four of the top five in the International Tennis Federation’s junior rankings.

headline: Watching It All, Walking the Beat
text: Oscar Padilla, 38, the San Francisco-born son of Salvadoran immigrants, joined the San Francisco Police Department 11 years ago. For the last eight years, he has worked at the Ingleside Station in the city’s south-central area. Last year, he volunteered for a foot patrol beat on Mission Street. He is on duty on Sundays. (His words have been edited and condensed.) SUSAN SWARD

headline: Making a Healthy Lunch, and Making It a Cause
text: Between them, Kristin Richmond and Kirsten Tobey have worked on Wall Street, traveled the world and taught school from East Africa to Ecuador. Now they make lunch for a living.

headline: National Book Critics Circle Finalists Are Announced
text: The National Book Critics Circle announced the finalists for its 2009 book awards on Saturday night at Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. The organization consists of some 600 book reviewers and was founded in 1974. The awards will be given out on Thursday, March 11, at the New School in New York. Now for the nominees:

headline: Obama Turns Up Heat Over Ruling on Campaign Spending
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama took aim at the Supreme Court on Saturday, saying the justices had “handed a huge victory to the special interests and their lobbyists” with last week’s 5-to-4 decision to lift restrictions on campaign spending by corporations and unions.

headline: Students Face a Class Struggle at State Colleges
text: At 2:29 p.m. on Jan. 12, Juan Macias, 19, a sophomore at San Francisco State University, sat in a cafe near the engineering firm where he works part time as an office assistant, staring at a laptop computer screen.

headline: Q. and A. With Thomas Jones
text: In his 10th N.F.L. season, at an age when most running backs have started, or finished, a sharp decline, Thomas Jones posted career numbers with the Jets. This follows his usual unusual pattern. Drafted seventh over all by Arizona in 2000, Jones has played for four teams and reached the Super Bowl with Chicago in the 2006 season. Yet he was voted to his first Pro Bowl last season and he gained a career-high 1,402 rushing yards this season. But there is more to the 31-year-old Jones. He is the Jets’ unquestioned leader and pregame speaker. He runs a music production company, Outta Pocket Entertainment. And he enjoys watching old television sitcoms.

headline: Serena and Sam: Two Who Know How to Serve
text: It’s not as rare as a solar eclipse, but it’s getting there. O.K., that’s an exaggeration. But what should unfold in the fourth-round match between Serena Williams and Samantha Stosur is something you don’t see often nowadays: a match between two women who haven’t been afflicted with the yips when they step up to the baseline to serve.

headline: Villanova’s Reynolds Is Happy to Be Back
text: Although Notre Dame’s Luke Harangody was picked as the preseason Big East player of the year, Villanova’s Scottie Reynolds is certainly making a case during the regular season.

headline: More Than 150,000 Have Been Buried, Haiti Says
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Haiti’s government provided a preliminary assessment of the earthquake’s body count on Saturday, putting it at more than 150,000, and declared that the search for survivors trapped in the rubble would soon be coming to an end.

headline: My So-Called Wife
text: Pasadena, Calif.

headline: Nonfiction Filmmakers Still Tell Rich Stories
text: The Bay Area has long been known as a center for documentary filmmaking. Many local documentarians have won or been nominated for Academy Awards, including Sam Green (“The Weather Underground”) and Robert Epstein (“The Times of Harvey Milk”). The area is home to the Independent Television Service, a major financer of documentary films, as well as some of the most respected film schools in the country.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s trip to Haiti on Saturday misspelled the surname of a Haitian doctor with who lives in the United States and who traveled with Mrs. Clinton. He is Herby Derenoncourt, not Derononcourt.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about the presidential election in Chile misstated the year when Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator of Chile, was arrested in Britain on a Spanish warrant that alleged he had committed crimes against humanity. It was 1998, not 1988.

headline: Students’ Class Struggles and Other Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Pages
text: Class Struggles | Because of state budget cuts, California’s state university system, which enrolls 433,000 students, is overwhelmed. Educational opportunities cost more and are harder to grasp and even harder to hold onto than ever before, with truncated offerings, furloughed professors and overcrowded classrooms.

headline: Are the Huskies on the Rebound?
text: Is UConn gearing up for a second-half run?

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about St. Paul’s School in Garden City, N.Y., a historic building that the village is considering tearing down, referred incorrectly to a vote on its fate. Forty-five percent  not a majority  of residents voted for demolition, with the remainder voting to either mothball the building or convert it into apartments.

headline: Deadly Truck Explosion Closes the L.I.E. 10 Hours
text: A fuel tanker flipped on the Long Island Expressway on Saturday morning, resulting in an explosion that killed the driver, melted the roadway and caused major delays for travelers in both directions.

headline: Man Arrested in Vermont in Fatal Stabbing of Event Planner
text: A suspect in the fatal stabbing this week of a security industry event planner has been captured in Vermont after New York City detectives tracked him there, partly by tracing his use of the victim’s credit cards, the authorities said.

headline: 3 Are Stabbed, One Fatally, Outside Times Square Club
text: Three men were stabbed, one fatally, in a swirl of violence outside a popular nightclub in Times Square early Saturday morning, the authorities said.

headline: Bankers’ Sense of Entitlement
text: We suspect most Americans would be baffled to realize that bankers see themselves as victims of the Obama administration’s financial policies. But there you go.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about landmarking measures on Long Island misstated the ethnic origins of Rafael Guastavino, the architect of a house, now for sale, on an unprotected site in Bay Shore. He was Spanish, not Italian.

headline: Hidden Danger
text: Radiation accidents like those that injured Scott Jerome-Parks and Alexandra Jn-Charles don't have to be made public under New York state law, leaving many unaware of treatment risks.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Page 32 this weekend about the writer James Patterson refers incorrectly to his share of the publishing market. Since 2006, Mr. Patterson has written one out of every 17 hardcover novels  not hardcover books  bought in the United States.

headline: The Legacy of Baker Street
text: Eventually, time will have its way with Sherlock Holmes, and he will pass fully into the public domain. In America, that bow to posterity will come sometime in 2023. Until then, Holmes is privately owned, and the subject of an uncongenial dispute among the descendants of Arthur Conan Doyle over who controls the rights to his venerable detective, whose last adventure appeared in print in 1927. The details of the squabble over the estate are less important than the lesson to be drawn from it.

headline: Pair’s Win Shows Depth of U.S. Dancing Lineup
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  Even before they were 10 years old, Meryl Davis and Charlie White had dreamed of this.

headline: White House Is Confident Bernanke Will Be Confirmed
text: WASHINGTON  After a full-scale mobilization, White House officials expressed confidence on Saturday that they had contained a populist uprising among Democratic senators that had threatened President Obama’s nomination of Ben S. Bernanke to a second term as the Federal Reserve chairman.

headline: Bob Noorda Is Dead at 82; Designer Took Modernism Underground
text: Bob Noorda, an internationally known graphic designer who helped introduce a Modernist look to advertising posters, corporate logos and, in the 1960s, the entire New York City subway system, died on Jan. 11 in Milan, his adopted city. He was 82.

headline: Jack T. Litman, Lawyer for ‘Preppy Killer’ and Others, Is Dead at 66
text: Jack T. Litman, a lawyer known for his cerebral, cool and aggressive defense of notorious murder defendants and his uncanny ability to persuade juries to sympathize with crimes of passion over four decades, died at a Manhattan hospital on Saturday morning. He was 66.

headline: Two Lives on the Road to Independence, One Step at a Time
text: In daily articles from November to January, the Neediest Cases charitable campaign provides a window into the lives of the people it serves. Sometimes the money provided by the fund can offer minor but vital assistance; sometimes it can do little more than lessen the pain of a daily struggle.

headline: UConn’s Second-Half Blitz Topples Texas
text: STORRS, Conn.  Texas guard Avery Bradley arrived for a 6 a.m. workout last summer, expecting to see only his teammates. But there, among the still-groggy group, was the would-be senior forward Kevin Durant, who had left the program two years earlier to become the second overall pick in the 2007 N.B.A. draft.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about renaming a mountain in Sonoma County referred incorrectly to plans by a winemaker to change the name of Black Mountain, an area outside of Geyserville, to Alexander Mountain. The winemaker, Jesse Jackson, wants to use the name for a new wine appellation  not for a new wine. (An Alexander Mountain wine already exists.)

headline: Giving Away Half a House
text: My Sunday column is about the Salwen family of Atlanta, and how they sold their house and used half the money to fund poverty-fighting projects in Ghana. To me, the most striking thing about their story and book was how the project empowered not only the Ghanaians but also the Salwens. And I see that all the time: Somebody reluctantly takes on some good cause, thinking that it’s the right thing to do even if they’re way too busy, and then the cause turns out not to be a sacrifice but the best thing they’ve done.

headline: The Power of Storytelling: A Look at Three Bay Area Documentaries
text: The Bay Area has long been known as a center for documentary filmmaking. In her latest column, Chloe Veltman says that while the success of locally produced documentaries can be attributed to education, funding and community, it ultimately comes down to storytelling.

headline: More Than Academics at Morton Alternative
text: A gritty industrial patch of a blue-collar Chicago suburb seems an unlikely setting for the pioneering curriculum at Morton Alternative High School. The program, which combines intensive psychotherapy with conventional studies to help gang members and emotionally troubled teenagers finish school, has reported promising results and has attracted the notice of educators nationwide.

headline: Looking Sharp, Hewitt Now Turns His Focus Toward Federer
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  There is not a more visceral competitor in all of tennis than Australia’s Lleyton Hewitt. He roars “come on” after hard-fought points, aims Popeye-styled muscle-flexes to the crowd and snarls and stamps as he scrambles about the court. No matter if you love or hate him, you hear him and feel him.

headline: The Pulse: Emanuel’s Influence Expands to Puppet World
text: How many strings can Rahm Emanuel pull at once? This is not a trick question.

headline: The Fiscal Fear Factor Is Increasing by the Day
text: In the genteel environs of the Commercial Club of Chicago, a bastion of the business establishment since 1877, the luncheon declaration was a jarring call to arms.

headline: The Pulse: Proposed Bill Would Shield People Reporting Overdoses
text: As a former heroin user, Kathleen Kane-Willis said she remembered being afraid when she called 911 to report a drug overdose because she thought she might be arrested. Now a drug policy researcher at Roosevelt University, Ms. Kane-Willis is pushing to resurrect legislation that would help shield callers from prosecution when they seek medical attention for themselves or someone else who has overdosed.

headline: The Pulse: Prix Fixe Dinners at Chicago Restaurants
text: These are fine times for penny-pinching gourmands. The Chicago Convention and Tourism Bureau’s Chicago Restaurant Week, which features three-course lunches for $22 and dinners for $32 at over 160 of the city’s leading restaurants, runs from Feb. 19 to 28.

headline: Movie and Book Explore Link Between Board and Bedroom
text: Can chess be erotic? Yes, according to the movie “Joueuse,” which was released last month in France and Germany.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Honduras
text: It was the first game of the year for two teams off to South Africa for the World Cup. Bob Bradley’s U.S. team can be generously called experimental — the majority of the European-based American players were not available Saturday because it was not an official FIFA international game day.

headline: White and Clark Riders to Beat in Vancouver
text: PARK CITY, Utah — The snowboarders Shaun White and Kelly Clark finished the United States Olympic qualifying season Saturday by winning for the fourth time in five events, emphatically sending them to the Winter Games in Vancouver as the halfpipe riders to beat.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Correction
text: Because of an editing error, the “In the Region” article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday, about the state of the housing market in Connecticut, referred incorrectly to 14 sales in New Canaan in 2008. That was the number for the fourth quarter, not “all of 2008.”

headline: In New Hampshire, an Angry Tide Swells
text: MILFORD, N.H.  George Brown, 50, the owner of Arthur’s barber shop on the Oval in this picturesque New England town, said he “breathed a sigh of relief” whenScott Brown was elected to the Senate last week in neighboring Massachusetts.

headline: Murray Rolls; Nadal Awaits in Quarterfinal
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  John Isner’s big serve was not big enough to dispatch Andy Murray from the Australian Open. Murray, the scrambling Scotsman, employed crosscourt forehands and drop shots in their match Sunday to run Isner, the 6-foot-9 American, out of his comfort zone.

text: SPOKANE, Wash.  On a night when figure skating fans had waited for the performance of Sasha Cohen, the skating star of old who was trying to make her third Olympic team, they ended up seeing two younger skaters sparkle even brighter.

headline: Afghanistan to Delay Parliament Vote

headline: N.F.C. Title Game: Welcome to Thunder Dome
text: No city wants this like New Orleans. It’s all we talk about. Think about. Dream about. Sunday will be a beautiful day in the city of New Orleans. I will wake up… find the second line parade that heads straight to the Superdome.. and enjoy the dreamlike atmosphere. It’ll be a great game!— From a reader named New Orleanian in the comments section

headline: Car Owners Survey Storm Damage at Auction Site
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The storm-damaged site of the Russo & Steele classic car auction reopened Saturday to concerned car owners and auction officials.

headline: Vows: Dana & Zachary
text: Dana Kaplan and Zachary Davidson met on a blind date. They soon discovered that they were both practical jokers and fell in love. They were joking throughout the relationship, including the proposal.

headline: Gamboa Retains Belt; Lopez Wins a Title
text: In the first of two featherweight title fights at Madison Square Garden, Yuriorkis Gamboa (17-0, 15 knockouts) kept his W.B.A. title, stopping Rogers Mtagwa at 2 minutes 35 seconds of the second round. Juan Manuel Lopez (28-0, 25 knockouts) won the World Boxing Organization featherweight title by knocking out Steven Luevano with a right hook 44 seconds into the seventh round. Also at the Garden, John Duddy (28-1) knocked out Juan Astorga (14-4-1) just 1:55 into their middleweight fight.

headline: Brooklyn’s Foreman to Face Cotto at Garden
text: Yuri Foreman, the 154-pound World Boxing Association champion, will make his first title defense against Miguel Cotto on June 12 at Madison Square Garden, the promoter Bob Arum said. It will be Cotto’s first fight since his loss to Manny Pacquiao. Foreman (28-0, 8 knockouts) is from Brooklyn and has a large New York City following, as does the Puerto Rican Cotto (34-2, 27 knockouts).

headline: Afghanistan Postpones Parliamentary Election by 4 Months
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Independent Election Commission said Sunday that it would delay Afghanistan’s parliamentary election by four months, from May until September, citing a lack of money, logistical challenges and the continuing violence in the country.

headline: Murray Defeats Isner in Straight Sets

headline: Cabaret Culture Stays Sexy in Berlin
text: Berlin will always be synonymous with the artistic diversity and decadence of the Weimar Republic. But aside from the occasional revivals of “The Three Penny Opera,” cabaret culture in the city is largely a thing of the past. Perhaps the most insistent exception is the Kleine Nachtrevue (“Little Night Revue”), an erotic nightclub in the Schöneberg district that balances the risqué with the classy.

headline: Skating’s Scoring Has Little Love for Artistry
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  As Mirai Nagasu completed her stirring free skate Saturday night, the crowd at Spokane Arena leapt to its feet in raucous applause. A hail of toy animals rained onto the ice. Clearly, most in attendance thought that Nagasu had won the United States Figure Skating Championships.

headline: Henin, Back on the Court, Is as Fierce as Ever
text: MELBOURNE, Australia -– Her legs are sore, and she’s had the three most taxing matches of any woman –- or for that matter man – here at Melbourne Park. But even after nearly two years away from competitive tennis, Justine Henin hasn’t lost an ounce of ferocity or mental toughness. In only her second tournament back, she had a date in the quarterfinals after a three-set victory over 20-year-old fellow Belgian Yanina Wickmayer, 7-6, 1-6, 6-3.

headline: Roddick Finally Turns Back Gonzalez
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Andy Roddick was down 2 sets to 1 to Fernando Gonzalez, and he had blown four set points before finally taking the match to a fifth set. As he sat in his chair to catch his breath between sets, he growled, mostly to himself, “I’m not going anywhere.”

headline: McCain Nudges Obama Toward His Party’s Health Plans
text: In the wake of a political setback for national health care legislation, Senator John McCain, the losing candidate in the last presidential election, advised his victorious 2008 adversary on Sunday that the way to get meaningful changes passed is to “start from the beginning” by meeting with Republicans.

headline: Robert A. Mosbacher, 82, Ex-Commerce Chief, Dies
text: Robert A. Mosbacher, a native New Yorker whose swashbuckling career as a wildcatter in the oil fields of Texas and Louisiana paralleled and often intersected with that of President George H. W. Bush, whom he served as a fund-raiser, confidant, political adviser and secretary of commerce from 1989 to 1992, died at a Houston hospital on Sunday. He was 82 and lived in Houston.

headline: As Haiti’s Focus Turns to Shelter, Families Press Search for Missing
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As officials focused Sunday on the Herculean task of this nation’s physical recovery  clearing the wreckage and setting up housing for the hundreds of thousands left homeless by an earthquake  desperate relatives of those still missing pleaded with the authorities not to give up the search.

headline: A View From Brooklyn of Tragedy Most Classic
text: What’s extraordinary about Gregory Mosher’s beautifully observed production of “A View From the Bridge” is how ordinary most of it feels. Very little in this revival of Arthur Miller’s kitchen-sink drama with knives, which opened Sunday night at the Cort Theater, calls loudly for our consideration. Voices are often kept to a just audible murmur, and the Hollywood sheen of the show’s big-name stars, Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson, has been dimmed to a matte finish.

text: Last year, investment bankers and their spouses kept their wallets shut during bonus season, first, out of panic, and later, fearing mobs with torches would descend upon their gated estates.

text: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Sunday that several Jewish settlement blocs in the West Bank would always remain part of Israel, a comment that upset the Palestinians even as the Obama administration’s Middle East envoy was trying to coax them back into peace talks.

headline: Know Your Feds
text: I’m hearing a lot from people who want Paul Volcker as Fed chair. (Consider the joke about exemplifying too big to fail as having been made). There really is nobody with his stature (literally, as it happens) and moral authority. And he’s a powerful advocate of financial reform.

headline: Exclusive!!! Gossip Has a History!
text: “No one speaks of the good we’ve done,” the magazine mogul Robert Harrison complained. Perhaps he was referring to Confidential magazine’s occasional public-service article about the dangers of cigarette smoking or air travel. But in 1957 readers could be pardoned for overlooking Mr. Harrison’s good deeds; he was much better known for the innuendo mongering that had turned Confidential into America’s most dangerous publication and created its legacy. Ask John Edwards whether the magazine’s tactics are still operative today.

headline: Navigating Between Abandon and Control
text: New York is internationally celebrated for ballet and modern dance. But I find it remarkable that of the five live performances I watched last week  which included ballet and modern dance, ranging from 1950s works to premieres  by far the freshest dancing, and much of the most enthralling choreography, came from a group from Maryland specializing in the Kuchipudi style of India.

headline: Championing the Music of Neglected Traditionalists
text: The battles within contemporary music during the middle decades of the 20th century are long forgotten. Young composers today couldn’t care less that way back when, the new-music scene was divided into warring camps, with the complex modernists on one side and those who maintained at least loose connections to tonal procedures on the other.

headline: U.N. Seeks to Drop Some Taliban From Terror List
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The leader of the United Nations mission here called on Afghan officials to seek the removal of at least some senior Taliban leaders from the United Nations’ list of terrorists, as a first step toward opening direct negotiations with the insurgent group.

headline: Connecting Purcell With George Crumb
text: In the program note for her recital of songs by Henry Purcell and George Crumb at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, the soprano Christine Schäfer wrote that “for me there’s no such thing as ‘early’ music or ‘new’ music.” In her view, knowing each side of the repertory makes you hear the other differently.

headline: At Festival in India, Books Are the Buzz
text: JAIPUR, India  A crowd, some members sitting on the floor, listened attentively last week as the author Amit Chaudhuri described the influence of writers from Ireland and the American South on his work.

headline: Liberal Radio, Even Without Air America
text: In a week of bad news for liberal causes, the announcement that Air America, the left-wing talk-radio network, was abruptly closing was greeted this way by Markos Moulitsas, founder of the Daily Kos political blog, when he asked on Twitter, “Air America was still really on the air?”

headline: Pie, Then Confession: Madoff Case as Legal Thriller
text: “Damages” is “Law & Order” as rendered by Marcel Duchamp. The series rips a scandal from the headlines, then fragments it so artfully that it takes an entire season to see the whole picture.

headline: G.O.P. Seeks to Widen Field of Play in Fall Elections
text: WASHINGTON  Republicans are luring new candidates into House and Senate races, and the number of seats up for grabs in November appears to be growing, setting up a midterm election likely to be harder fought than anyone anticipated before the party’s big victory in Massachusetts last week.

headline: Freezing Motion in a Festival of Dance Films
text: Our television screens keep taking us to scenes of devastation in Haiti. So it is uncanny to realize that the choreographer Ralph Lemon, in planning his “i get lost” Platform series, had already (in December or earlier) booked for Tuesday a screening of the (silent) unedited films taken in Haiti by Maya Deren between 1947 and 1954. Here is another Haiti: in particular, the Haiti of Vodoun rites and their scenes of religious possession.

headline: Homeless Need Tents in Haiti
text: Haitian and international officials issued an urgent call for help putting roofs over the heads of the estimated hundreds of thousands of people left without shelter by the quake.

text: The research project began in 1970.

headline: Very British, Somewhat Borat and a Lot of Nerve
text: The British comedian Marc Wootton employs much the same techniques as Sacha Baron Cohen but steers in the direction of situation comedy rather than anarchic farce. While he doesn’t often inspire the helpless laughter that “Borat” or “Da Ali G Show” provoke, his quieter, more slowly building situations can have their own devastating payoffs.

headline: N.F.C. Championship Final: Saints 31, Vikings 28 (Overtime)
text: Thayer Evans and Joe Lapointe were in New Orleans providing live analysis of the N.F.C. championship game Sunday between the Vikings and the Saints.

headline: ‘Hope for Haiti’ Takes in $57 Million
text: The George Clooney-led telethon “Hope for Haiti Now: A Global Benefit for Earthquake Relief,” raised more than $57 million in 24 hours, according to a statement from the producers. That preliminary total did not include donations from corporations or large private donations. A recording of the event, which featured performances by Madonna, Bruce Springsteen and Stevie Wonder, among others, was the No. 1 iTunes album in 18 countries on Saturday. ... Another musical benefit for Haiti is in the works, this one led by the pianist Lang Lang, a Unicef Goodwill Ambassador, and the conductor Christoph Eschenbach. They announced plans for a concert at Carnegie Hall on March 21 to benefit Unicef and its effort to help children who survived the earthquake. The Schleswig-Holstein Festival Orchestra, made up of musicians under the age of 27, will provide accompaniment.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Rules for a Sixth Weekend
text: The cerulean-skinned warriors of “Avatar” (20th Century Fox) were No. 1 at the North American box office for an astonishing sixth weekend in a row, selling about $36 million in tickets for a new domestic total of $552.8 million. Fueled by particularly strong sales at higher-priced 3-D and Imax locations, “Avatar” now ranks as No. 2 on the all-time domestic box-office charts, behind only “Titanic.” (The rankings do not account for inflation.) Sony’s inexpensive “Legion,” a supernatural thriller, was second this weekend with about $18.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which tracks ticket sales. “The Book of Eli” (Alcon Entertainment via Warner Brothers) was third with about $17 million (and a new total of $62 million). Terrible reviews may have hurt “The Tooth Fairy,” a Fox comedy starring Dwayne Johnson. It opened in fourth place with about $14.5 million. “The Lovely Bones” (Paramount) was fifth with about $8.8 million ($31.6 million total). As expected, the fledgling CBS Films had a tough time with its “Extraordinary Measures,” a modestly budgeted medical drama starring Harrison Ford and Brendan Fraser that opened in seventh place with about $7 million.

headline: Woman Collides With a Picasso
text: On Friday afternoon a woman taking an adult education class at the Metropolitan Museum of Art accidentally lost her balance and fell into “The Actor,” right, a rare Rose Period Picasso, tearing the canvas about six inches along its lower right-hand corner. Immediately after the accident the painting was taken to the Met’s conservation studio so experts could assess the damage, museum officials said. A statement released by the Met on Sunday afternoon said, “The damage did not occur in the focal point of the composition and the curatorial and conservation staffs fully expect that the repair  which will take place in the coming weeks  will be unobtrusive.” The canvas  about 6 ½ feet by 4 feet  was hanging on the wall of a second-floor gallery with other early Picassos. The museum declined to identify the woman, but said she was not injured. Picasso created the painting, which depicts an itinerant acrobat theatrically posed, during the winter of 1904-5. Museum officials said they expected the repair to be completed in time for “Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art,” an exhibition of some 250 works from its collection opening on April 27.

headline: Penn and Pattinson May Join the Circus
text: Sean Penn, below, and Robert Pattinson, bottom, may be joining Reese Witherspoon in a Fox 2000 film adaptation of Sara Gruen’s best-selling novel “Water for Elephants,” Variety reported. Francis Lawrence (“I Am Legend”) will direct that Depression-era story, to be adapted by Richard LaGravenese (“The Fisher King”), in which a veterinary student drops out of school and takes a job with a traveling circus. Ms. Witherspoon plays the equestrian Marlena, who is married to an animal trainer, most likely to be played by Mr. Penn, according to Variety, though contracts have not been finalized for Mr. Penn or Mr. Pattinson. Production is expected to begin in June.

headline: In the Wings
text: SoHo Rep in TriBeCa has announced a second extension of “Lear,” the playwright Young Jean Lee’s riff on mortality and family using the Shakespeare tragedy as a jumping-off point. It will now run through Feb. 14. ... The Living Theater in Lower Manhattan has announced an extension of its production of “Red Noir,” written by the poet Anne Waldman and adapted and directed by Judith Malina. Performances will run through Feb. 27, with a “pay what you can” policy on Wednesdays and Thursdays. ... The 52nd Street Project, a children’s theater company and arts education resource center in Midtown, will cut the ribbon on its new home and theater on Tenth Avenue on Feb. 8. The comedian Lewis Black and the actresses Edie Falco and Mary Testa, among others, will take part in the festivities, which are to include an open house with activities, music and food from the neighborhood. The new building, in the Archstone Clinton development, includes a 150-seat theater, rehearsal rooms, offices, a lounge and tutoring space.

headline: Familiar Wins at SAG Awards
text: The Screen Actors Guild Awards were in large part a rerun of the Golden Globes, with Jeff Bridges, Sandra Bullock, Mo’Nique and Christoph Waltz claiming the top film honors at the ceremony in Los Angeles on Saturday night, according to the guild’s Web site, sag.org. They joined Kevin Bacon, Alec Baldwin, Drew Barrymore, Michael C. Hall and Julianna Margulies, who reprised their Globes wins in the television categories. The one departure of the evening was the award for actress in a comedy series, which went to Tina Fey for NBC’s “30 Rock,” beating out Toni Collette who won the Golden Globe, as well as last year’s Emmy, for her performance in Showtime’s “United States of Tara.” Ensemble awards went to the casts of “Glee” and “Mad Men” for television and “Inglourious Basterds” for film. The guild’s highest honor, the Life Achievement Award, was presented to Betty White.

headline: Colts Put End to Jets’ Surprising Run
text: INDIANAPOLIS  The Jets trudged toward their locker room in silence as confetti swirled behind them on the field. The N.F.L.’s most talkative team had finally been muted, muzzled by quarterback Peyton Manning and the explosive hometown Colts in the American Football Conference championship game.

headline: National Book Critics Announce Finalists
text: Some familiar names and past winners were mixed in with newcomers on the list of the National Book Critics Circle Award finalists announced Saturday at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. The awards, given annually by the critics’ group, will be handed out on March 11. The fiction finalists included Hilary Mantel’s “Wolf Hall,” which won the Man Booker Prize last year, and two National Book Award finalists, Bonnie Jo Campbell’s “American Salvage” and Jayne Anne Phillips’s “Lark and Termite.” The other finalists in the fiction category were Michelle Huneven for “Blame” and Marlon James for “The Book of Night Women.” Finalists were also announced for autobiography, biography, criticism, nonfiction and poetry. Notable names among those nominees included Mary Karr, Edmund White, Tracy Kidder and Louise Glück. The Ivan Sandrof Lifetime Achievement Award will be given to Joyce Carol Oates.

headline: Oscar Clues From the SAG Awards
text: On Saturday night, as the Screen Actors Guild awards were being doled out in Los Angeles, the Bagger was still Sundancing it up, going to screenings that involved seeing Kristen Stewart nearly naked and partying with the dudes from “Cyrus,” Jonah Hill and John C. Reilly. So we hope to be forgiven for skipping the SAGs, which followed much the same rhythm as the Golden Globes. Jeff Bridges, Christoph Waltz, Mo’Nique and Sandra Bullock all picked up statuettes, making them near-locks for the Oscar nominations, to be announced next week. Ms. Bullock in particular is riding a wave of awards-show buzz that would’ve surprised red carpet-watchers a year ago. The Bagger hasn’t heard much talk about industry types loving “The Blind Side,” the film Ms. Bullock won for, but its performance at the box office ($234 million and counting) surely has won hearts and minds.

headline: More on N.Y. Fed’s Actions on A.I.G. Details
text: As a House oversight committee prepares for a Wednesday hearing over the government’s handling of the American International Group‘s bailout — an event that will feature testimony from Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner — more documents are emerging about efforts to keep details of that rescue confidential.

headline: Democrats, Get Down to Business
text: SCOTT BROWN’S victory last week in the Massachusetts Senate race, following the Republican gubernatorial triumphs in New Jersey and Virginia, marked the third time in three months that the Democratic Party has lost the support and trust of independent voters.

headline: Mavericks Deal the Knicks Their Worst Home Defeat
text: By the time the fourth quarter was ticking away, the Knicks-Dallas Mavericks game looked a bit like one of those old Harlem Globetrotters-Washington Generals games, with unconscious outside shots, uncanny inside flings, thunderous dunks and little resistance to the spectacular or the routine.

headline: Names of the Dead

headline: Alpha Wives: The Trend and the Truth
text: Why are more American men marrying women who make more money than they do? Maybe it is the simple fact that more higher-earning women are available. And social norms have changed, with the benefits of such unions supposedly winning out over the perceived blow to the male ego.

headline: Bill Gates, Sundance Celebrity

headline: ‘Buried’ Finds a Savior
text: Update | 10:45 a.m. Amid the cold and crowds of Park City, distributors are showing interest in several movies, including the Ryan-Reynolds-Trapped-In-A-Coffin film “Buried” and the Ben-Affleck-Trapped-In-An-Unemployment-Office movie “The Company Men.” On Sunday, the producers of “Buried” chose Lionsgate, according to Variety, representing the first major acquisition of the festival. The price tag: about $3.5 million.

headline: Op-Ed: Advanced Pressure
text: The filmmaker Vicki Abeles features the stories of students and teachers of Advanced Placement classes and the pressures they face in our achievement-obsessed culture.

headline: Corporate Antagonism Goes Public
text: When Time Warner Cable was tussling over fees with the News Corporation, it did something that would have been unthinkable in the backrooms where deals were once struck: it hired a political consultant to mount a public campaign against its own client.

headline: Court Ruling Invites a Boom in Political Ads
text: Among those closely watching the Supreme Court ruling last week that loosened restrictions on corporate campaign spending were local television stations, which now hope for a windfall.

headline: For Transgender People, Name Is a Message
text: Katherine used to be Miguel. Olin had a girl’s name. And in October, Robert Ira Schnur, 70, became Roberta Iris Schnur, a Manhattan retiree with magenta lipstick and, she noted the other day, chipped silver nail polish.

headline: Wal-Mart Tells Employees It Will Cut 11,200 Jobs
text: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation’s largest retailer, is cutting about 11,200 jobs at its Sam’s Club warehouses, the company told its employees in a memo on Sunday.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Jaguars Don’t Live Here Anymore
text: EARLIER this month, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced it would designate “critical habitat” for the endangered jaguar in the United States and take the first steps toward mandating a jaguar recovery plan. This is a policy reversal and, on the surface, it may appear to be a victory for the conservation community and for jaguars, the largest wild cats in the Western Hemisphere.

headline: Campaign Trail | Annie Leibovitz for Louis Vuitton
text: When we think of the face of Louis Vuitton, glamazons like Madonna and Lara Stone spring to mind — not the photographer Annie Leibovitz. But the newest installment of the label’s “core values” campaign features a shot of Leibovitz with her longtime friend Mikhail Baryshnikov.

headline: Christmas Bombing Try Is Hailed by bin Laden
text: WASHINGTON  Osama bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda, spoke publicly for the first time about the botched Christmas Day airliner bombing, praising the attempt  but not explicitly taking responsibility for it  in an audiotape broadcast Sunday that was aimed personally at President Obama.

headline: A Playland for Apps in a Tablet World
text: Apple’s move to open up the iPhone to outside programmers in 2008 started a software-writing frenzy. Giant companies and bedroom tinkerers alike rushed to get their applications into the App Store and onto the phone’s 3.5-inch touch screen.

headline: General Puts Up a Fight in Sri Lanka’s Election
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  When President Mahinda Rajapaksa announced late last year that he would move the presidential election up by two years and seek a fresh mandate from Sri Lanka’s war-weary electorate, he seemed like a shoo-in.

headline: O’Brien Undone by His Media-Hopping Fans
text: Conan O’Brien made a triumphant exit from NBC Friday night, accompanied by one of the most impressive outpourings of support by younger viewers that any late-night host had ever seen  and Mr. O’Brien was effusive in his thanks for their backing.

headline: Still Preparing, Cuomo Courts Black Support
text: ALBANY  As New York’s political world waits for Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo to make official his run for governor, Mr. Cuomo has been quietly but methodically working to defuse an issue that helped unravel his last quest for the job.

headline: Independent Group to Look at Ways to Reduce Debt
text: WASHINGTON  Just as President Obama and Congressional Democrats are trying to create a bipartisan commission on reducing the debt, some well-known former elected officials and veterans of past administrations are announcing their own task force on Monday, underscoring the mounting concern over the nation’s fiscal future.

headline: The Bernanke Conundrum
text: A Republican won in Massachusetts  and suddenly it’s not clear whether the Senate will confirm Ben Bernanke for a second term as Federal Reserve chairman. That’s not as strange as it sounds: Washington has suddenly noticed public rage over economic policies that bailed out big banks but failed to create jobs. And Mr. Bernanke has become a symbol of those policies.

headline: Insurer Steps Up Fight to Control Health Care Cost
text: A front in the national health care battle has opened in New York City, where a major hospital chain and one of the nation’s largest insurance companies are locked in a struggle over control of treatment and costs that could have broad ramifications for millions of people with private health insurance.

headline: Ex-Opera Performer Still Singing, and Volunteering
text: Inside Rayford Dudley’s sunny 45th-floor apartment in the Manhattan Plaza, the view is breathtaking. Mr. Dudley, a retired opera singer, is one of the original residents of the place, a 1970s-era Mitchell-Lama complex on 43rd Street and Ninth Avenue.

headline: Web Filters Cause Name Change for a Magazine
text: OTTAWA  In 1920 when the Hudson’s Bay Company began publishing a magazine for its 250th anniversary, The Beaver: A Journal of Progress probably seemed to be a good title. The company, which controlled much of the landmass that is now Western and Northern Canada, owed much of its early fortune to the trade in beaver pelts.

headline: Transfer Wes Johnson Finds Paradise at Syracuse
text: SYRACUSE  There is a simple reason Syracuse’s Jim Boeheim has taken just five transfers in his 34 seasons as head coach.

headline: In Haiti, Many Amputees Have No Place to Go
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In a tent serving as an acute-care ward on the grounds of this city’s biggest hospital, Jocelin François was sitting up in bed when a nurse went by, barking at him in French. Mr. François, whose left leg was amputated nearly to his knee after the earthquake on Jan. 12, threw out his arms and fell back on the mattress.

headline: Hungry for New Content, Google Tries to Grow Its Own in Africa

headline: Looking Ahead

headline: Pakistan’s Rebuff Over New Offensives Rankles U.S.
text: WASHINGTON  The Pakistani Army’s announcement last week that it planned no new offensive against militants for as long as a year has deeply frustrated senior American military officers, and chipped away at one of the cornerstones of President Obama’s strategy to reverse the Taliban’s gains in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: In Drug War, Tribe Feels Invaded by Both Sides
text: SELLS, Ariz.  An eerie hush settles in at sundown on the Tohono O’odham Nation, which straddles 75 miles of border with Mexico.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Jan. 13 about a report from a special state committee expected to recommend that the New York Senate vote on two resolutions sanctioning Senator Hiram Monserrate, who was convicted of misdemeanor assault on his companion, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the Senate Democratic leader, John Sampson, who said Mr. Sampson would not comment on the report. The spokesman is Austin Shafran, not Shafrin.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Jan. 10 about Freya von Moltke, a member of an anti-Nazi resistance group during World War II, misstated the name of the university from which she earned a doctorate in law in 1935. At the time, it was the University of Berlin, not Humboldt University. (It became Humboldt in 1949.)

headline: Rivalries as Keen as on the Field
text: THERE is nothing like the big matchups at the Super Bowl as powerhouse players go head to head. headline: A Quest to End Spending Rules for Campaigns
text: WASHINGTON  James Bopp Jr. likes to begin speeches by reading the First Amendment. He calls opponents, including President Obama, “socialists.” He runs a national law practice out of a small office in Terre Haute, Ind., because he prefers the city’s conservative culture.

headline: Sanchez’s Graduation Day Leaves Him Wanting More
text: INDIANAPOLIS  His eyes weary, his body bruised, his lips pursed, Mark Sanchez walked through the Jets’ locker room Sunday night carrying a red toiletry kit. He was on his way to cleanse himself of a disappointing loss, a 30-17 defeat to the Indianapolis Colts in the American Football Conference championship game, but he had another task in mind, too. When he returned, the beard he had spent the previous five weeks cultivating was gone.

headline: An Unofficial Candidate, on the Trail
text: BUFFALO  Harold E. Ford Jr. does not so much enter a restaurant as attack it. His eyes dart around the room as he figures out where to start. He systematically introduces himself to everyone: the waiters, the busboys, and then, the diners.

headline: Defending Police Officers Who Are in Legal Trouble

He did the same a few years later, after graduating from law school, selling Frank Hogan, then the Manhattan district attorney, on the story of his working-class Irish upbringing and noting the many times that Mr. Hogan had been discussed at the Patten family dinner table.

headline: New Rule Allows Use of Partial DNA Matches

text: A day after being released from federal custody in Pennsylvania, a Haitian immigrant whose detention in December touched off protests told supporters at a Manhattan church on Sunday that he was so close to being deported this month that friends were waiting for him at the airport in Port-au-Prince.

headline: Newsday Employees Reject Contract With Pay Cuts
text: Following the lead of their national union president, employees at Newsday on Sunday overwhelmingly rejected a contract with pay cuts and other concessions. The vote by members of Local 406 of the Graphic Communications Conference of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was 473 to 10 against the proposed pact.

headline: Citibank in 2011, Hypothetically
text: Suppose it is 2011 and the so-called Volcker Act has recently become law, sharply curtailing banks’ riskier activities, like hedge funds and proprietary trading, and separating those activities from consumer businesses and retail deposits. Citigroup’s recently arrived chief executive, Bob Steel, formerly of Wachovia, is dismantling the group to comply with the law. A memo to the bank’s staff announces that Tim Geithner has been hired as head of the bank’s strategy and investor relations. Oddly, this imaginary situation is not such a stretch.

headline: Producers Scramble the Oscar Race
text: At the Hollywood Palladium on Sunday, the Producers Guild of America gave its top movie honors to the producers of “The Hurt Locker” — turning the Oscar race into a mad scramble. Just a day earlier, the Screen Actors Guild gave its highest movie honor to the acting ensemble behind “Inglourious Basterds.” A week earlier, the Golden Globe for best dramatic motion picture went to “Avatar.”

headline: Did Officials Bungle the End Game for Vikings?

headline: Obama to Offer Aid for Families in State of the Union Address
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will propose in his State of the Union address a package of modest initiatives intended to help middle-class families, including tax credits for child care, caps on some student loan payments and a requirement that companies let workers save automatically for retirement, senior administration officials said Sunday.

headline: Saints and Vikings Fans Share an East Village Bar
text: Of all the gritty Manhattan taverns that exiled disciples of the New Orleans Saints would choose to make their own, why did they have to pick the very same East Village watering hole where displaced Minnesota Vikings fans had already staked a claim?

headline: In Clicks on Ads, the Sound of Fraud
text: In 2009, when an online ad was clicked by a computer in Vietnam, the odds were nearly even that the click was fraudulent. Web sites practice so-called click fraud by running Internet ads, soliciting clicks, receiving payments from advertisers for the clicks, and then kicking some money back to the clickers. Much of the clicking is done by botnets, enormous networks of personal computers that are harnessed and controlled using viruses.

headline: Nadal, Defending Champion, Shrugs Off the Whispers
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Rafael Nadal has been reminded daily that he has not beaten a top-10 player in his last 11 such matchups, a fallow period stretching back to May. Juan Martín del Potro, Novak Djokovic and Nikolay Davydenko have all had his number.

headline: Analysis: How Roddick Escaped Gonzalez
text: Fernando Gonzalez was feeling it. Winners were flying off his racket, and his serving was pinpoint precise and tough to read. Ahead by two sets to one and serving to force a fourth-set tie-breaker against Andy Roddick, Gonzalez looked poised to upset the higher-ranked American. Having lost the coach Larry Stefanki, who jilted Gonzalez to work with Roddick, a sweet victory was within reach.

headline: N.F.C. Championship: Saints Outlast Vikings
text: New Orleans took advantage of Minnesota's mistakes and won in overtime.

headline: Inevitably, Manning Solves Ryan’s Complex Defense

headline: Surviving Twice, Saints Reach Super Bowl
text: NEW ORLEANS  The owner of the Saints, Tom Benson, danced back and forth, from one foot to the other, a little soft-shoe shuffle as he left the artificial turf of the Superdome.

headline: Showcase: Long Soviet Shadows
text: Jenish’s home in Kyrgyzstan is underground, near pipes that deliver hot water to the city overhead. The photographer William Daniels portrayed him tossing back a glass of vodka, as starkly lit as a figure by Caravaggio. The realities faced by a day laborer could not be plainer than in this picture (Slide 5). And its grim atmosphere sets the mood for Mr. Daniels’s depiction of contemporary Kyrgyzstan, a destitute former Soviet republic in central Asia.

headline: Super Bowl at First Glance
text: For the first time since 1993, the two No. 1 seeds advanced to the Super Bowl. The Saints and the Colts each started 13-0, and it’s fitting that the season’s most dominant teams made it to Miami, where Indianapolis won the Super Bowl three seasons ago. The Colts’ defense suddenly looks like the 1985 Bears’ compared with the defense New Orleans played against Minnesota. Expect still more offense in the Super Bowl, with the two best quarterbacks this season, Peyton Manning and Drew Brees, taking center stage. But the Saints had better tighten up their protection of Brees, or Colts end Dwight Freeney will run wild.

headline: Sites to Refuel Electric Cars Gain a Big Dose of Funds
text: Better Place, the closely watched start-up that hopes to create vast networks of charge spots to power electric cars, is set to receive a vote of confidence on Monday, in the form of $350 million in new venture capital.

headline: U.S. Women Lack Established Star in Figure Skating
text: SPOKANE, Wash.  Minutes after being named to the United States Olympic team late Saturday, more than two hours after the United States Figure Skating Championships had ended, the teenagers Rachael Flatt and Mirai Nagasu bubbled over with joy.

headline: The U.S. Women’s Hockey Team Is Not as Battle-Tested as It Intended
text: MINNEAPOLIS  In putting together a schedule leading to the Olympics, the United States women’s hockey team hoped to intersperse a dozen or so games against Minnesota boys’ high school teams within its usual lineup of international and collegiate opponents. USA Hockey officials and Coach Mark Johnson thought that boys’ prep teams best replicated the speed of Team Canada, its rival for Olympic gold. And the state’s rich prep hockey tradition offered a bounty of potential opponents within easy drive of the team’s home base in Blaine.

headline: Stuyvesant Town Returned to Creditors
text: The owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the iconic middle-class housing complexes overlooking the East River in Manhattan, have decided to turn over the properties to creditors, officials said Monday morning.

Kristof asks readers this question in his latest column, telling the story of an Atlanta family who, wanting to “do something” about inequity in the world, sold their luxurious family home and donated half the proceeds to charity. What would you be willing to give up to help others? Why?

text: OSLO  A man was wounded when several shots were fired early Monday morning into the Oslo residence of Mullah Krekar, a Kurdish cleric who helped found the militant Islamist group Ansar al-Islam in Iraqi Kurdistan in 2001 while he held refugee status in Norway.

Minow, the former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, were asked by several foundations to explore how nonprofits like schools, libraries and museums could tap into emerging digital technologies.

headline: An Animated Discussion
text: The cartoonist Garry Trudeau will help us try to get a handle on the ongoing wars in Afghanistan and Iraq tonight at the  92nd Street Y. The "Doonesbury" creator will be part of a round-table discussion with David Stanford, who with Mr. Trudeau, publishes Trudeau's Sandbox, a blog by Iraq soldiers and veterans, as well as the photographer David Levinthal. The discussion, which will be moderated by Time magazine editor and writer Roger Rosenblatt, will examine the conflicts as they are seen through cartoons, blogs, photography and traditional journalism.

headline: Can I Interest You in a Sarcophagus?
text: "If you are in the market for a 14,000-pound, 6-foot-tall urn carved from a block of pink Tennessee marble and encircled by a neo-Classical frieze of Indians hunting buffalo and engaging in intertribal warfare, hurry over to the 56th-annual Winter Antiques Show," writes Ken Johnson, "before someone else snaps it up." The object is on view at Gerald Peters, one of 75 art and antiques dealers gathered to "dazzling effect" under the "capacious roof" of the drill hall at the Park Avenue Armory on view daily through Jan. 31. Go to marvel at items like a complete Egyptian sarcophagus, Tiffany lamps, Cubist flappers, and others displayed in booths that are constructed to resemble tony antique shops and even a room in an 18th-century Bostonian home. The show covers a "practically encyclopedic range of art, decorative objects, furniture, tribal arts and crafts," with "dealers in ancient art, medieval suits of armor, Art Nouveau, American folk art and Modernist design." The cutoff for the newest material is 1969. The oldest objects date back thousands of years.

headline: Dance Culture
text: The choreographer Mark Morris is well acquainted with dance forms from other cultures. Tonight you can start to catch up with him by paying a visit to India by way of the Dance on Camera Festival. The annual festival, with films from around the world through Feb. 2, opens tonight at the Mark Morris Dance Center in Brooklyn. On the bill is the premiere of "Nrityagram: For the Love of Dance," a documentary by Nan Melville about a gurukul, or dance village, near Bangalore where students live and dance in close proximity with their master guru. Before the documentary will be a screening of "Bahudha," part of a series of duets using the Kathak style of Indian classical dance. The colorful short shows two dancers performing before projected images of themselves. Stick around after the film when Mr. Morris and Ms. Melville will participate in a Q. and A.

headline: For Obama Economic Aides, a Tough Week Looms
text: From John Harwood at The Caucus:

headline: Citibank in 2011, Hypothetically
text: Suppose it is 2011 and the so-called Volcker Act has recently become law, sharply curtailing banks’ riskier activities, like hedge funds and proprietary trading, and separating those activities from consumer businesses and retail deposits.

headline: Robert A. Mosbacher, 82, Ex-Commerce Chief, Dies
text: Robert A. Mosbacher, a native New Yorker whose career as a wildcatter in the oil fields of Texas and Louisiana paralleled and often intersected with that of President George H. W. Bush, whom he served as a fund-raiser, confidant, political adviser and secretary of commerce from 1989 to 1992, died at a Houston hospital on Sunday. He was 82 and lived in Houston.

headline: More Tainted Dairy Products Are Found in Chinese Stores
text: BEIJING  Health officials in southern China have swept frozen confections and other dairy products from stores after discovering they contained melamine, the industrial compound at the center of a tainted-food scandal that rocked China’s dairy industry in 2008, news reports said Monday.

headline: Better Place to Refuel With $350 Million
text: Better Place, the closely watched start-up that hopes to create vast networks of charge spots to power electric cars, is set to receive a vote of confidence on Monday, in the form of $350 million in new venture capital.

headline: Longest Super Bowl Droughts
text: Tales of woe by Jets fans can be overdone. Since the 1998 season, the team has been to two A.F.C. title games and to the playoffs six times over all. But in one respect, the gloom is justified.

headline: Two Achieve a First for China in the Quarterfinals
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Folks here had hoped Australia Day, a commemoration of a historic settlement, might come one day early and be celebrated with a couple of major upsets in a sport this country cherishes. So what if Roger Federer and Serena Williams are the world’s most fabulous tennis players? Lleyton Hewitt, the native son, is a two-time Grand Slam winner and former No. 1; Samantha Stosur, another top Australian, is ranked No. 13 and climbing.

headline: KDDI Pays $4 Billion for Liberty’s Stake in Japanese Cable Company
text: Liberty Global, the United States-based communications company controlled by John Malone, said Monday that it would sell its stake in Jupiter Telecommunications of Japan to KDDI Corporation, a Japanese wireless operator, for $4 billion.

headline: In Negotiations, Corporate Antagonism Goes Public

headline: Garcon Takes Haiti Onto the Field

Yesterday, Garcon had 11 catches for 151 yards and a touchdown against the Jets. He lifted the Colts, then he carried the flag for Haiti.

headline: Passion and Death Meet at Madrid Exhibition
text: Through Sunday, visitors to Madrid can ogle the dreamy soccer star David Beckham between the sheets in a 2004 Sam Taylor-Wood video — just one of the pieces included in the exhibition “Lagrimas de Eros” (“Tears of Eros”), on view jointly at the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza (Paseo del Prado 8; 34-91-369-0151; www.museothyssen.org) and the Fundación Caja Madrid (Plaza San Martin 1; 34-90-224-6810; www.fundacioncajamadrid.org). Across a survey of 119 works spanning centuries, the exhibition looks at the links between eroticism and the death instinct.

headline: Ferrero Officially Bows Out on Cadbury

This is one weird moment, really seeing Schumacher involved in a team car launch and wearing the team colors — if silver is a color, and I’m color blind anyway, so who knows. The car is said to have green on it too?!

headline: A True Story, Except When It’s Not
text: Bansky, of course, was nowhere to be found at the Sundance premiere of his new movie, “Exit Through the Gift Shop.” Or rather, the anonymous British street artist may have been in the capacity crowd on Sunday night, but who would’ve known? Morgan Spurlock, perhaps, who’s a fan and a collector — and a connoisseur of the stunt documentary. “Exit Through the Gift Shop” was a late addition to the Sundance schedule but caused a stir when Banksy graffiti pieces began popping up in Park City; people have been brushing aside the snow to photograph them all week long.

headline: Whitacre Said to Become G.M.’s Permanent Chief
text: Update | 12:57 p.m.  General Motors on Monday said it was ending its search for a chief executive, instead electing to have its chairman and interim chief, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., take the job permanently. Mr. Whitacre, 68, did not say how long he anticipated continuing to run the automaker, except that it would be “an adequate amount of time to get done what we need to get done.”

headline: The Food Program in a Koraro School
text: The following is the fifth in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones aren’t, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

headline: Biden’s Son Will Not Run for Delaware’s Open Senate Seat

text: Think “custom car” and you’re usually thinking about artists like Ed “Big Daddy” Roth or Von Dutch. The name Fornasetti does not come to mind. The bidding starts at $9,000 — significantly less than, say, a vintage Fornasetti room divider.

headline: Travel Deals: Discounted Theater Tickets in New York and London

headline: Some National Universities Look Locally for Students
text: Until the past few decades, universities like Harvard, Yale and Stanford relied heavily in their admissions process on a feeder network of headmasters, guidance counselors and principals at nearby prep schools and high schools, to say nothing of their alumni. But for a number of reasons — not least the desire to diversify their classes — these institutions and others began combing the nation in earnest in the 1960s and 1970s to assemble their freshman classes.

headline: ‘Jersey Shore’ Party Becomes a Dangerous Situation
text: The MTV reality series “Jersey Shore” isn’t broadcasting any more new episodes, and yet it still finds ways to trouble its home state. On Friday night, a party at a New Jersey nightclub where the “Jersey Shore” cast members were scheduled to appear drew an unexpectedly large crowd, resulting in fights among clubgoers hoping to catch a glimpse of Snooki or the Situation, and forcing the police to temporarily close down the street. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that the 501 Lounge in Montclair, N.J., hosted a “Jersey Shore” event on Friday night that drew an estimated 2,000 fans to the 800-person capacity club. “They had crowds much larger than they could control,” David Sabagh, the police chief of Montclair, told The Star-Ledger. “They had 600 upstairs, 200 to 300 downstairs and 400 outside.” He added: “There were fights inside and fights outside.” Mr. Sabagh said four people were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and drunken driving. On Thursday night, the season finale of “Jersey Shore” was watched by 4.8 million people.

headline: Of Fate and Fumbles

Ignore all the pontificating about how Obama needed to focus differently, seek bipartisanship with people who have no interest in making a deal, etc.. The primary factor in Obama’s troubles is, simply, the continuing weakness of the job market.

headline: Agreement on Effort to Help Haiti Rebuild
