headline: ‘Avatar’ Makes Its Mark on China’s Geography
text: China, it can be safely said, has a complicated relationship with “Avatar.” Last week it was reported that the 2-D version of the science-fiction epic, directed by James Cameron, was being pulled from many Chinese theaters; now a mountain there is being renamed for a peak seen in the film. In a ceremony on Monday, the Southern Sky Column in Zhangjiajie City, in China’s Hunan province, was formally renamed the Avatar Hallelujah Mountain, Reuters reported, citing the local government’s official Web site. The name change seemed to be an effort to stir up the interest of Chinese tourists, who have helped “Avatar” sell more than $100 million in tickets, breaking box office records in the country. Travel companies have already begun offering tours that emphasize the region’s resemblance to Pandora, the lush alien moon depicted in the film. On its site, the municipal government wrote: “Pandora is far but Zhangjiajie is near. Welcome to Zhangjiajie to see ‘Avatar’s’ Hallelujah Mountains and discover the real world of Pandora.”

headline: After 34 Years, a Plainspoken Justice Gets Louder
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Private Equity Deals Leveled Out Last Quarter
text: The number and value of private-equity deals in Europe leveled off in the fourth quarter, after showing constant growth throughout last year, according to a new report released by Candover.

headline: Obama’s Speech on Helping the Middle Class
text: Following is a text of President Obama's and Vice President Joseph R. Biden, Jr.'s remarks on Monday when they addressed an Obama administration task force aimed at helping the middle class, as released by the White House:

headline: Ant Colony
text: On Saturday, the Invisible Dog, a burgeoning new art center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, opened its doors for large installation by the French conceptual artist Xavier Roux. An enormous ant built of steel and nylon balloons, with a porkpie hat suspended above its head, “The Ant” refers to the childrens’ poem by the Surrealist artist Robert Desnos. The poem’s refrain is well known in France: “An 18-meter ant/With a hat on its head/That doesn’t exist, that doesn’t exist!” The rhyming whimsy, however, conceals a dark history: Desnos was a resistance fighter, and the 18-meter ant refers to the 18-meter train cars used by the Nazis for transport.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 10: Domino Effect
text: The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs’ team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

headline: More Senators Take Sides on Bernanke Reconfirmation
text: Update | 4:20 p.m.  Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat from California, also said Monday that she supported Ben S. Bernanke’s reconfirmation as Federal Reserve chairman.

headline: UBS Names Executives to Run Fixed-Income Unit
text: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

headline: The Pacifica Geological Drama: Man, With Equipment vs. Nature, With Power
text: At the Chit-Chat Cafe in Pacifica, tables were rearranged Sunday so that cafe patrons could watch boulders being unloaded from trucks. People drove to this coastal town 15 miles south of San Francisco for the big show, the effort to shore up the cliff supporting three apartment buildings, according to an article by Carolyn Jones in The San Francisco Chronicle.

headline: Saving Lives on the U.S.N.S. Comfort
text: The U.S. Navy struggles to get earthquake victims to the Comfort, a hospital ship, so they can be treated.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: 1) United Van Lines recently released its annual migration report, based on where its customers moved to. For the second year in a row, the District of Columbia was the top destination for moving Americans. On the other end of the spectrum, Michigan had the highest percent of outbound moves, for the fourth consecutive year.

headline: The Media Equation: Applecadabra!
text: In Monday’s Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

headline: Paterson’s Budget Could Cripple City, Bloomberg Says
text: ALBANY — With New York City’s fiscal health in the balance, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg traveled to Albany on Monday to ask the Legislature’s help in stopping some of Gov. David A. Paterson‘s proposed budget cuts, saying they were unfair, could cripple the city and would force him to layoff thousands of police officers and firefighters.

headline: Meeting an Unmet Need
text: A Times photographer on the patients she met at a free medical clinic in Los Angeles.

headline: In ‘Game Change,’ Wall St. Makes a Few Cameos
text: You need only watch the cable talk shows or read the political press to realize that “Game Change,” the fly-on-the-wall political tome from John Heileman and Mark Halperin, is the book of the moment. It’s hard not to talk to a politico and not hear gossip about the back story of the 2008 presidential race, from ill-worded remarks from Senator Harry Reid to the slow implosion of Senator John McCain‘s presidential campaign.

headline: Monday Puzzle: Stashing Llamas
text: After an adventure finding buried treasure last week, we return to the mountains in this week’s puzzle. We’ve had a mountain puzzle about the one-L lama (who’s a priest). Here’s one about the two-L llama (who’s a beast).

headline: Delhi to Ditch Coal for Natural Gas
text: The city of Delhi, India, has announced that it will shut down all of its coal-fired power plants and switch to natural gas, according to an article in The Hindustan Times.

headline: Bill Gates, Party Animal
text: As Brooks Barnes noted on Sunday, one of the unlikeliest must-see celebrities at Sundance has been Bill Gates. Mr. Gates was in town promoting a documentary, “Waiting for Superman,” about the educational system, which Paramount Vantage bought even before the festival started. As Mr. Barnes also notes, “Viacom, Paramount’s corporate parent, recently agreed to team with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to promote education improvement; as part of the agreement, the foundation pays third parties that create such content for Viacom.”

headline: O’Brien Not Laughing All the Way to NBC’s Bank
text: Just to be totally clear — and regardless of what any bandleaders for any other NBC late-night shows might say — a publicist for Conan O’Brien said on Monday that none of the skits and stunts that Mr. O’Brien ran during his final week at the host of “The Tonight Show” broke NBC’s budget or cost more than what was normally spent on the show.

headline: The Morning Skate: Isles See Green, Laraque Sees Red and No One Sees Canucks
text: In breaking news Monday morning, the Quebec Major Junior League has suspended the Devils draft choice Patrice Cormier for the remainder of the season. Playing for Rouyn-Noranda Huskies on Jan. 17, Cormier elbowed Quebec Remparts Mikael Tam in the head, sending Tam sprawling to the ice and convulsing (video). Here are stories on the suspension from CBC.ca and TSN.ca.

headline: New Hotel Brand Wants to Become a Grand Elysian
text: To prove that successful brands can be born in hard times, marketing historians point to examples like Fortune magazine and Snickers candy bars, both brought out in 1930; Diet Coke, introduced in 1982; and the iPod, which came out in October 2001.

headline: Hedge Funds Sue Porsche for Billion Lost on VW
text: A group of hedge funds filed a lawsuit on Monday against Porsche SE and two former executives, accusing the German sports car company of lying and illegally manipulating shares of Volkswagen A.G., thus costing the funds more than $1 billion in trading losses.

headline: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Paris Couture: Dior’s Many Icons
text: Most of the day-to-day, minute-by-minute events in the fashion world are so random and implausible that nothing really surprises. Outside the Dior haute couture show, held in the house, where the pale gray walls are lined with portraits of the famous and (mostly) departed, a throng of photographers and onlookers waited behind steel barricades. It was a chilly gray day. I was greeted like a country mouse by the security man at the entrance. He pulled at the corner of my invitation to see if there was a seat assignment, and then waved me in. On the stairs to the salons, I saw more camera people and then roses galore. The displays were abundant and colorful enough, surrounded by puddles of fabric, to be camp. I said hello to one or two people from the house and then found my seat.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: American Family Insurance, Madison, Wis., selected the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP, to handle its creative account, which had been handled by Element 79 Partners, Chicago, part of the Omnicom Group. Spending was estimated at $30 million to $35 million.

headline: That Figures: Understanding Numbers in News Reports
text: Overview | What can understanding the magnitude of numbers tell us about what is happening in the world around us? Why is it important to comprehend numbers in the news? In this lesson, students develop the skill of understanding numbers in news stories by examining a story that interests them, developing a meaningful context and visually representing the numbers.

headline: Generations of Admirers Play Their Respects
text: Tuli Kupferberg, a leader of the Fugs, was 41 when that Lower East Side band started in 1964. He had a Depression-era New York catarrhal croak, and cheerful paranoia. He wasn’t cute, and was a chanter, not a singer. Two other band members, Ed Sanders and Ken Weaver, carried the melodies. Mr. Kupferberg was both ultracynical and ultraidealistic. Aside from all the other liberation going on in a Fugs record  sexual, poetic, drug-related, political  there was the amazing fact of this rabbinical monotone finding its use in a rock band.

headline: An All-Brahms Program, Careful and Calculated, but Not Cautious
text: Among the most memorable recitals at the Boston Early Music Festival last spring was a Beethoven program by the cellist Pieter Wispelwey and the fortepianist Kristian Bezuidenhout, in which Mr. Wispelwey played on a period cello and made the familiar sonatas and variations sound zesty and fresh. He did much the same for Brahms in a Sunday afternoon recital at Alice Tully Hall, this time using a modern cello, with Paolo Giacometti as his pianist.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Reject Obama’s Latest Tax-Break Plans
text: The senior Republican on the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, Representative Dave Camp of Michigan, issued a statement today rejecting President Obama’s plans to help middle class Americans with additional tax breaks for retirement savings, education and child care, which are expected to be outlined in Wednesday evening’s State of the Union speech.

headline: Music in Review
text: LE POèME HARMONIQUE

headline: Berkeley to Vote on Letter to Iran on 3 Hikers’ Behalf
text: It has been 179 days since three graduates of the University of California, Berkeley, were arrested and charged with illegally crossing the Iranian border during a hiking trip last summer. Friends and family of Shane Bauer, Sarah Shourd and Joshua Fattal, as well as the Kurdish government, say the border crossing was unintentional, a case of unfamiliar terrain. But the Iranian government has accused the three hikers of espionage, and said they will be tried.

headline: Blueberries Pack a Nutritional Wallop
text: Blueberries are the king of fruits when it comes to micronutrients. They may not have the vitamin C of oranges and grapefruit, or the potassium found in bananas. But blueberries do have an abundance of phytonutrients, whose strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, some scientists believe, may help protect against heart disease, colon cancer and other maladies.

headline: Iran Opposition Leaders Drop Demand for New Election
text: CAIRO  Two of Iran’s opposition leaders, Mohammed Khatami and Mehdi Karroubi, appear to have dropped their demand for a new presidential election, saying that while they still believe the vote in June was fraudulent, they accept Mahmoud Ahmadinejad as the head of state, according to Iranian news services.

headline: Chief of Jaguar Land Rover Leaves
text: Just as Ed Whitacre removes the interim tag from his chief executive position at General Motors, Tata Motors announces that David Smith, the top man at Jaguar Land Rover, is stepping down.

headline: An Ill Father, a Life-or-Death Decision
text: I am utterly spent by the time my father lands in the emergency room, shortly after 1 a.m. on a cold January night.

headline: Abusing Not Only Children, but Also Science
text: Given the vested interests lurking all over the current medical landscape, it is no wonder that the scientific method is so often mauled a little in transit. Cases of data ignored or manipulated to serve an agenda are like muggings in a bad neighborhood: you hear about them all the time, but in fact relatively few are ever openly examined.

headline: Another Awards Show Looks Across the Ocean
text: Are irreverent British comedians the new hosts with the most? Seems so. After Ricky Gervais took the posh out of the Golden Globes, Eddie Izzard — known his cross-dressing and, increasingly, for his mainstream actor gigs — will do the same for the Spirit Awards, the producers announced on Monday.

headline: China to Move Against Local Lobbyists
text: BEIJING  Addressing a facet of political life all too familiar to Americans, China’s government is reported to have ordered the closure of thousands of “regional liaison offices”  in essence, lobbying firms  that local governments and companies operate in Beijing to curry favor with high officials.

headline: Seeking a Place at Airports
text: Virgin America has managed to survive skyrocketing oil prices and an economic crisis since it started in mid-2007 and even hopes to achieve an operating profit this year.

headline: Slime Mold Proves to Be a Brainy Blob
text: Let’s hear it for slime molds.

headline: Patient Safety: Conversation to Curriculum
text: Two summers ago, as bright-eyed third-year medical students, we rushed into clinics and operating rooms, eager to apply our textbook knowledge at last to the daily practice of working with patients.

headline: Cheap Seats: Off Broadway Twofers
text: For the second year, On the House, a program of NYC & Co., the city’s tourist board, is offering a two-for-one ticket deal for 25 Off Broadway shows.

headline: 2 More Senators Support Bernanke
text: From Sewell Chan at Economix:

headline: Trial of Woman Accused of Killing Real Estate Agent Begins
text: A lawyer for the woman accused of killing Linda Stein, a former real estate agent and punk-rock manager whose clients included the Ramones, conceded on Monday that his client was guilty, but not of murder.

headline: Cheap Seats: Day-of-Show Discounts at Lincoln Center
text: Starting Wednesday at noon, Lincoln Center will offer discounted day-of-show tickets at its box office.

headline: The Details of Obama’s Middle-Class Plan
text: In his State of the Union address on Wednesday, President Obama  is expected to propose a package of modest initiatives intended to help middle-class families squeezed between sending their children to college and caring for elderly parents. Here are some of the proposals that are expected, according to a news release and fact sheet the White House released Monday.

headline: Justice Dept. Clears Ticketmaster Deal
text: Ending a yearlong investigation, the Justice Department on Monday announced its conditions for accepting a proposed merger between Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation, a deal that could significantly remake the live entertainment business by combining touring, management and ticketing into one company.

headline: Dietary Dilemma
text: Q. Since vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin, is the supplement I take with my low-fat breakfast being absorbed? I eat half a grapefruit, shredded wheat with banana, nonfat yogurt and nonfat milk.

headline: Don’t ‘Schmear’ Me, Ford Warns
text: ALBANY – It’s a smear campaign, New York-style.

headline: Group Hug | Fall Trends From Paris
text: The Paris men’s-wear shows just ended, and several key fall 2010 trends are already clear. I know — who’s thinking about next fall when we’re all freezing and pining for spring? Still, it’s always good to be prepared, and you can always check your closet to try and get a jump-start on what everyone will be doing next winter. For example, you could tuck your pants into boots — pretty much every designer has shown a version of long johns tucked into rugged explorer footwear. Or, see if you already have a floor-grazing coat, like the ones at Dior Homme, or a cape like John Galliano’s. Go through our slide show of the key looks from this past weekend, and let us know what trends you think will actually stick.

headline: Referees Are Gunning for Tall Guys, Study Asserts
text: The German defender Philipp Lahm, a diminutive 5 foot 7, is often described as skillful, heady and tenacious. A veritable frantic smurf on the back line for his national team (63 caps) and club team, Bayern Munich (more than 120 games since 2005), who often encounters taller and stronger opponents.

headline: Fresh Off a Massachusetts Victory, G.O.P. Aims at Illinois
text: CHICAGO  Republicans in Illinois hold no statewide offices, are minorities in both chambers of the State Legislature and struggle some years to recruit viable candidates even at the top of the ballot.

headline: U.S. Clears Ticketmaster Deal With Conditions
text: The Justice Department approved the merger of Live Nation and Ticketmaster Entertainment on Monday, but it imposed several conditions on the deal that Assistant Attorney General Christine Varney said would have the effect of lowering ticket prices.

headline: Tea Party Convention Loses Another Sponsor
text: Another participating organization has pulled out of the National Tea Party convention in Nashville next month, adding to the sense of unraveling around an event that was billed as the coming together of the grassroots movement that shot up across the country starting a year ago.

headline: Telling Time With Spices
text: A friend who wants to remain anonymous writes (and I love this):

headline: A Deadly Quake in a Seismic Hot Zone
text: To scientists who study seismic hazards in the Caribbean, there was no surprise in the magnitude 7 earthquake that devastated the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince, two weeks ago.

headline: In Labor, a Snack or a Sip?
text: Maternity wards have long forbidden women in labor to eat or drink. Even when labor goes on and on, the bill of fare is usually limited to ice chips.

headline: Parasites: ‘Tropical’ Diseases Are Common in Arctic Dwellers, a Survey Finds
text: The kind of worm and protozoan infections that are often called neglected “tropical” diseases are also common among aboriginal peoples living in the Arctic, according to a recent survey.

headline: Hedge Funds Sue Porsche Over VW Stock Deals
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: Man Testifies on Police Acts in Subway
text: In court, Michael Mineo told the story of his troubled young life, reciting the wrongs he had committed against others, and those he said had been visited upon him.

headline: Wide Fallout in Failed Deal for Stuyvesant Town
text: In the beginning, investors and lenders could not get enough of the record-breaking $5.4 billion deal to buy the largest apartment complexes in Manhattan: Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.

headline: Breaking Down Nadal vs. Murray
text: Uncle Toni is a master at lowering expectations for his nephew Raphael Nadal, the six-time Grand Slam winner and defending champion at the Australian Open. Despite winning seven of nine times against his quarterfinal opponent Andy Murray, Uncle Toni sounds suspiciously like a campaign manager trying to make his candidate the underdog.

headline: When House Prices Rise, Sales Fall
text: The December sales numbers for existing home sales show disappointing sales, and higher prices. That reverses previous trends.

headline: In the Mail: Fielding Messages for Serpico
text: In response to my profile on Sunday of Frank Serpico, I received roughly 100 e-mail messages from readers. There were, of course, dozens from fans of the film “Serpico” who appreciated an update, and from people in publishing looking to get in touch with Mr. Serpico. But there were some unusual ones in the bunch.

headline: A Mixed Report on American Health
text: There is some good news in the numbers released last month by the National Center for Health Statistics on the health of Americans in the first half of 2009. But there is ample bad news, too, and a third of us are not feeling very well: the percentage of people who reported having excellent or very good health declined to 66.6 percent in the 2009 period, from 69.1 percent in 1998.

headline: Critics' Picks: Network
text: A. O. Scott looks at Sidney Lumet's 1976 satire.

headline: Going Into Labor? It’s O.K. to Snack
text: For years, women enduring lengthy labors have been prohibited from eating or drinking, and typically they are only given ice chips to sustain them. But a new look at the research suggests the practice may be outdated. Today’s Science Times reports:

headline: Obama Couldn’t Make Jury Duty
text: Update | 4:39 p.m.  The circuit court in Cook County, Illinois, lists seven reasons why you may be excused from jury duty, such as being on active duty in the military, living in a nursing home and serving as the primary caretaker of another person. Maybe it needs to list an eighth: You’re running the country.

headline: Ticketmaster and Live Nation Win Approval To Merge
text: After months of scrutiny, the Justice Department announced on Monday that it had approved a merger of Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation, creating a giant new company that could reshape almost every aspect of the live entertainment business.

headline: No. 1 vs. No. 1: It’s Rarer Than You Think
text: The New Orleans Saints probably didn’t feel much like a No. 1 seed Monday, considering they barely escaped with a victory against a Vikings team that exposed plenty of weaknesses. Still, when the Saints and the Colts meet in Miami Gardens, Fla., in two weeks, the Super Bowl will feature the two most dominant regular-season teams, and the top seeds in each conference.

headline: Stirring Storytelling and Amorous Rapture
text: Ask any serious vocal enthusiast to provide a list of the finest singers currently working, and the chances are good that Bernarda Fink, an Argentine mezzo-soprano, will figure in. Here in New York, where Ms. Fink has appeared infrequently, her renown stems primarily from her performances on CD, including opera recordings conducted by René Jacobs and highly desirable recital discs on the Harmonia Mundi label.

headline: Shared (Not Divided) Parenting
text: It’s a continuing conversation within households, and here on Motherlode, about how to make parenting feel less lopsided and more equal. A couple who spends a lot of time talking about this subject — first as a goal in their own life, and then as authors of the book “Equally Shared Parenting: Rewriting the Rules for a New Generation of Parents” — are Marc and Amy Vachon. I wrote about their book here a few weeks ago, and in the comments, many of you questioned whether parenting should be equal if the resulted would be constant weighing, measuring, dissecting and bickering about how to divide their time.

headline: Exercise: In Women, Training for a Sharper Mind
text: Older women who did an hour or two of strength training exercises each week had improved cognitive function a year later, scoring higher on tests of the brain processes responsible for planning and executing tasks, a new study has found.

headline: A Better Brain After Weight Lifting
text: New research shows that older women who lift weights build more than muscle. Weight lifting also appears to lead to better brain health. In today’s Science Times, Roni Rabin writes:

headline: Princeton Raises Tuition and Fees 3.3%
text: Princeton is raising undergraduate tuition, room and board and some fees 3.3 percent, the university announced on Monday. In its press release, Princeton called it “one of the lowest percentage increases in undergraduate tuition and fees since 1966″ and said that the trustees had also endorsed a 9.6 percent increase in the financial aid budget.

headline: After Smoking and Fats, Focus Turns to Salt
text: In decades past, when companies wanted to test-market a product meant to enhance health and well-being, they often tried it first in California  where people were reputed to be the most health-conscious in the country. But now companies might be wise to consider field-testing their wares in New York City.

headline: Building Better Hydrogels With Mix of Clay and Water
text: If you’re like most people, you probably don’t think much about hydrogels. Even when you encounter them  those Jell-O cubes in the school cafeteria, say, or the Sea Foam Salad you had at Grandma’s  you probably don’t give them a second thought.

headline: Rangers’ Sale Ends Months of Wrangling
text: The sale of the Texas Rangers baseball team ends months of wrangling between the Hicks Sports Group, headed by the former private equity maven Thomas O. Hicks, and the team’s debt holders, made up of various investors including hedge funds and wealthy individuals.

headline: Answers About Salt and Health
text: In today’s Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores the science behind New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s efforts to curb sodium intake. She writes:

headline: Surrender That Submarine
text: Trevor Cook has been accused of securities fraud in civil cases filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. No court has ruled on the claims, but civil cases can lead only to fines and injunctions, not to prison terms.

headline: Play, Then Eat: Shift May Bring Gains at School
text: Can something as simple as the timing of recess make a difference in a child’s health and behavior?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Jan. 25
text: Two other catastrophes, both documented in dramatic photographs, displaced Haiti as the lead subject of Pictures of the Day for the first time since the earthquake. (This, of course, is exactly the concern of advocates for Haitian victims; that the story of their suffering will quickly fade from global consciousness.) In Baghdad, a coordinated bombing attack killed 36 people in and around the Ishtar Sheraton, the Babylon Hotel and the Hamra Hotel. Ayman Oghanna was among the photographers on the scene and produced one of the many unsettling pictures of the immediate aftermath (Slide 2). And in Beirut, an Ethiopian Airlines plane with at least 90 people aboard crashed into the Mediterranean shortly after takeoff.

headline: A Less-Than-Serious Suicide
text: To be or not to be, that is the punch line.

headline: Physicists’ Dreams and Worries in Era of the Big Collider
text: A few dozen scientists got together in Los Angeles for the weekend recently to talk about their craziest hopes and dreams for the universe.

headline: Black Babies, Boys Less Likely to Be Adopted
text: Both straight and gay adoptive parents are likely to exhibit racial and sex-based biases when applying to adopt a child, a new study finds.

headline: The Tyranny Of Markets
text: Gah. I hate, hate, hate it when people say that we have to do something, not on its merits, but because otherwise we would damage market confidence. Nobody really knows how the markets will react; the right thing, always, is to pursue policies that look right on the substance.

headline: When Impulse Control Goes Awry
text: The title of Robert Stone’s new collection of stories, “Fun With Problems,” is clearly meant to be read in an ironic sort of way. Mr. Stone’s characters do not have fun. They may get high, get drunk or get loaded, but they are almost always lost, disaffected and desperate. They may visit exotic parts of the world and go on all sorts of wild adventures, but in doing so, they are always courting danger or falling prey to bad faith, bad karma and bad vibes. Even scuba diving or bungee jumping becomes for them existential confrontation with mortality, raising primal questions about courage and angst, life and death, God or his absence.

headline: Now Booking | Caribbean Queens
text: Despite a still tricky, if rebounding, real-estate market, several luxury hotel brands are throwing caution to the tradewinds with splashy new Caribbean resorts. After a long delay, the Viceroy Anguilla finally made its debut last month, joining the sleepy little island’s outsize collection of high-end hotels. (The Moorish-inspired Cap Juluca still reigns supreme, while the much-touted developments of Temenos and Rendezvous Bay have stalled.) At this latest Viceroy, situated on Mead and Barnes Bays, Kelly Wearstler has created ultradecadent penthouses suites, cabana-lined infinity pools and multiple lounges, among them the Half Shell, carved out of the side of a cliff.In the Turks and Caicos, where construction seems to continue unabated on Grace Bay Beach (for better or worse), the new Veranda Resort, managed by the company that owns the chic Grace Bay Club, begins accepting guests Feb. 1. It might siphon off some of the jet set who’ve been holing up at the nearby Gansevoort Hotel, but probably just a little — the chainlet’s third outpost after New York and Miami has been going strong since last spring.

headline: ‘Match of Hate,’ Renewed
text: With the taste of World Cup defeat still lingering, Egypt will have a chance to face down its archrival Algeria — again — when the teams play in the African Cup of Nations semifinal Thursday in Benguela, Angola. The two North African teams played two fiercely contested matches late last year to determine the final spot in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. The meetings were marred by violence and controversy.

headline: Engineers Plot the Future of a Hobbled Mars Rover
text: PASADENA, Calif.  As they have on many days during the past six years, about 10 engineers at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory gathered in a conference room here last Tuesday to plan the schedule of the Mars rover Spirit.

headline: Keeping Options Open, Novelist Tows Museum on Road to Dream
text: SEBASTOPOL, Calif.  As the rakish, love-struck, sex-obsessed teen hero of the 1993 cult novel “Youth in Revolt,” Nick Twisp encounters all manner of obstacles, including dysfunctional parents, jealous rivals, the Berkeley police and, of course, acne.

headline: Ruling Could Mean Lower Rents for 300,000 Tenants
text: To most renters in New York City, it sounds like a modest, even enviable, rent increase: pay an additional $45 if your monthly rent happened to be less than $1,000 and you had been living in the same apartment for more than six years.

headline: The ‘Upfront’ Is Looking Up
text: One sign that the television networks were suffering as a result of the economy was decisions by several to cut back or eliminate their annual presentations of coming fall shows to advertisers during several days in May known as the “upfront” week.

headline: Obama Greets the Lakers
text: If you’re going to talk trash with the Los Angeles Lakers, it helps to be president. Harder for the other guy to talk back.

headline: For Citigroup’s Pandit, Soul Food or Sushi, Please
text: Some critics of finance may assume that all Wall Street executives enjoy are the finest and most expensive of meals. Nothing less than the power-lunch extravaganzas at the Four Seasons or San Pietro will do.

headline: Timing the Sale of Your Business
text: A recent report published by BizBuySell — one of the Internet’s largest marketplaces for buying or selling a small business — confirmed a hunch I’ve had for several months, namely that small business deals seemed to pick up during the latter part of 2009. While many business owners have put their exit plans on hold until the economy recovers, others are not only hanging on but enjoying growth and have a bright outlook for 2010.

headline: A New Way to Look for Diseases’ Genetic Roots
text: The hunt for the genetic roots of common diseases has hit a blank wall.

headline: Welcome! Now Go Home
text: MY husband likes a dinner party as much as the next person. Until 9 p.m.

headline: Dreams of a Teenage Loser
text: If you buy the old rumors that Disney animators sometimes slipped pornographic images into their artwork, then you can probably also readily imagine that writers of Disney teenage comedies like “Jonas” and “Wizards of Waverly Place” sit around after hours, knock back a few and concoct raunchy versions of their standard scripts.

headline: Laptop Sales Help Apple Top Forecasts
text: Apple said Monday that it earned $3.38 billion in its most recent quarter, handily beating Wall Street’s optimistic expectations with record sales of Macs and iPhones.

headline: Cutting a Deal With the Taliban
text: In separate interviews published on Monday, both Gen. Stanley McChrystal, the top American commander in Afghanistan, and his boss, Gen. David Petraeus, suggested that peace talks with the Taliban may be on the horizon.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Joseph Altuzarra, Designer
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Mixing Extroverts and Introverts of the 18th Century
text: Europa Galante, the superb period-instrument ensemble led by the violinist Fabio Biondi, explored two distinct sides of the 18th-century orchestral repertory at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening. The first half of the program was devoted to the extroverted music of Telemann. After intermission Mr. Biondi and company set their sights on Italy by way of four strikingly different composers: Giovanni Battista Sammartini, Pietro Nardini, Arcangelo Corelli and Pietro Antonio Locatelli.

headline: A Tale of E-Silence Ignites a War of Words
text: After interviewing for job at a New York magazine and completing the requisite editing test, Neal Hirshfeld waited and waited for a response from human resources. When Mr. Hirshfeld’s patience expired, he decided to have his revenge by accepting an offer that he never received, calling the company’s human resources department to tell them that he would report to duty on Monday morning. When he let the human resources director in on the joke, he didn’t let her down easy.

headline: Opposites in Style, Equals in Stature
text: Great musical theater does not always take place in the precincts around Times Square, as I was forcefully reminded last week. In a span of three days I caught two of the most memorable musical theater performances I’ve seen so far this season. Neither was part of a Broadway show.

headline: Corporate Backing for Research? Get Over It
text: I find myself in the unfamiliar position of defending Al Gore and his fellow Nobel laureate, Rajendra K. Pachauri.

headline: Solid Renderings of Strauss and Other Stalwarts
text: In “Grossmächtige Prinzessin” from Strauss’s “Ariadne auf Naxos,” Zerbinetta takes a “Sex and the City” approach to heartbreak, coquettishly insinuating that the despairing Ariadne needs a rebound fling. On Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, the stellar soprano Diana Damrau flirted her way through the treacherous vocal terrain of Zerbinetta’s showpiece aria, vividly accompanied by James Levine and the Met Orchestra.

headline: Brains Behind ‘Beetlejuice’ to Head Cannes Jury
text: The filmmaker who turned Michael Keaton into an undead bio-exorcist and Johnny Depp into an emotionally stunted chocolatier has just taken another step toward legitimacy. On Tuesday the Cannes Film Festival is to announce that it has named Tim Burton, director of “Beetlejuice” and “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” (and many more phantasmagoric blockbusters), to serve as the jury president for its coming festival. In a statement the Cannes festival president, Gilles Jacob, called Mr. Burton “a magician of visual delights who turns the screen into a faerie wonder.” He adding, “We hope his sweet madness and gothic humor will pervade the Croisette” in Cannes. Mr. Burton, whose work is currently featured in a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, said in a statement, “After spending my early life watching triple features and 48-hour horror movie marathons, I’m finally ready for this.” The 63rd Cannes Film Festival is to run from May 12 to 23, and film selections are expected to be announced in mid-April.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Makes Mark On China’s Geography
text: China, it can be safely said, has a complicated relationship with “Avatar.” Last week it was reported that the 2-D version of this science-fiction epic, directed by James Cameron, was being pulled from many Chinese theaters. Now a mountain there is being renamed for a peak seen in the film. In a ceremony on Monday the Southern Sky Column in Zhangjiajie City, in Hunan province, was formally renamed the Avatar Hallelujah Mountains, Reuters reported, citing the local government’s Web site (www.zjj.gov.cn/website/). The name change seemed to be an effort to stir the interest of Chinese tourists, who have helped “Avatar” sell more than $100 million in tickets, breaking box-office records in the country. Travel companies have already begun offering tours that emphasize the region’s resemblance to Pandora, the lush alien moon depicted in “Avatar.” On its site, the municipal government wrote: “Pandora is far but Zhangjiajie is near. Welcome to Zhangjiajie to see ‘Avatar’s’ Hallelujah Mountains and discover the real world of Pandora.”

headline: ‘Buried’ Finds Savior
text: On Sunday at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, Lionsgate paid an estimated $3.5 million for “Buried,” a Spanish thriller starring Ryan Reynolds as a civil contractor in Iraq who awakens to find himself buried alive in a wooden coffin. His captors have given him nothing but a lighter and a cellphone, which he must use to meet their ransom demand before he suffocates. Tagline: “170,000 square miles of desert. 90 minutes of oxygen.” “Buried,” sold by United Talent Agency, was a hot item for buyers going into the festival for several reasons. Genre films typically don’t have much downside  they are cheap to make and comparatively easy to market. And if that marketing is executed properly they can become phenomena with young audiences. (See: “Paranormal Activity.”) Although he has yet to show he can anchor a movie, Mr. Reynolds is a budding heavyweight. Warner Brothers recently hired him to play the lead in “Green Lantern,” a megapicture planned for summer 2011.

headline: Economists’ Reactions to Bernanke Renomination
text: Economists left, right and center have weighed in on Ben S. Bernanke’s nomination to serve a second term as Federal Reserve chairman. Here are a few of their reactions:“I’m with Abraham Lincoln: don’t swap horses in the middle of the stream.” — James Hamilton, University of California, San Diego

headline: O’Brien Not Laughing All the Way to NBC’s Bank
text: Just to be totally clear, a publicist for Conan O’Brien, above, said on Monday that none of the skits and stunts that Mr. O’Brien ran during his final week as the host of “The Tonight Show” broke NBC’s budget or cost more than what was normally spent on the show. In a telephone interview, Leslee Dart, Mr. O’Brien’s publicist, said the comedy sketches “all fell within the show’s normal prop and music budget guidelines.” For example, for a skit in which Mr. O’Brien appeared to bring the Kentucky Derby-winning horse Mine That Bird onstage while showing Super Bowl footage on a television screen, Ms. Dart said, “the horse was a standard rental and the Super Bowl footage wasn’t from the N.F.L.” For a segment in which Mr. O’Brien showed off an expensive Bugatti Veyron automobile while playing the Rolling Stones song “Satisfaction,” Ms. Dart said, “The Bugatti was loaned to the show for free, and the music clearances were no different than the show gets for other pop tunes all the time.” ?uestlove, the bandleader on NBC’s “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” had written on Twitter that it cost “The Tonight Show” $500,000 to play the Beatles song “Lovely Rita” when Tom Hanks appeared on the show on Friday. But a representative for Sony/ATV Music Publishing, which handles the Beatles catalog, said that it cost the show only a “nominal fee.”

headline: ‘Jersey Shore’ Party a Dangerous Situation
text: The MTV reality series “Jersey Shore” isn’t broadcasting any more new episodes, but it still finds ways to trouble its home state. On Friday night a party at a nightclub in Montclair, N.J., where the “Jersey Shore” cast members were scheduled to appear, drew an unexpectedly large crowd, resulting in fights among clubgoers hoping to catch a glimpse of Snooki or the Situation and forcing the police to close the adjacent street temporarily. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that the event at the nightclub, the 501 Lounge, drew an estimated 2,000 fans to the 800-person-capacity club. “They had crowds much larger than they could control,” David P. Sabagh, the Montclair police chief , told The Star-Ledger. “They had 600 upstairs, 200 to 300 downstairs and 400 outside.” He added, “There were fights inside and fights outside.” Chief Sabagh said that four people had been arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and drunken driving. On Thursday night the season finale of “Jersey Shore” was watched by 4.8 million people.

headline: Football Conquers All
text: Fox’s National Football League playoff coverage dominated Sunday night prime-time ratings as more than 50 million viewers tuned in to watch the National Football Conference championship game, according to Nielsen’s preliminary estimates. Although final ratings for the live broadcast were not available on Monday, overnight numbers for the New Orleans Saints’ overtime victory over the Minnesota Vikings showed an impressive 27.6 rating for Fox, or more than a quarter of American households. By comparison, CBS and ABC, which finished in a virtual tie for second place, struggled to top 8 million viewers for a single program. ABC averaged 7.8 million viewers for “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” from 8 to 10, while a rerun of “Desperate Housewives” at 10 drew 4.2 million. CBS earned 7 million at 7 for a special “60 Minutes” tribute to that newsmagazine’s former executive producer Don Hewitt. CBS broadcast crime show repeats from 8 to 11, including “CSI: NY” (5.4 million), “Cold Case” (6.1 million) and “CSI: Miami” (7.2 million). NBC ranked fourth for the night with “Dateline” from 7 to 9 (4 million), followed by coverage of the United States Figure Skating Championships (3.6 million).

headline: Hybrid Boards Rethink the Curve
text: ALTHOUGH snowboarders have a reputation for trying ever-more-dazzling tricks, snowboard technology has changed only incrementally until recently. For decades, almost all boards had a camber, or curve: if you looked at the board from the side, it was convex, rising to an arc in the middle and then pointing up again at the tips.

headline: Made in Americana | Red, White, Blue … and Black
text: In the collaboration-crazed world of men’s wear, the hookup of Steven Alan and Michael Williams was only a matter of time. And geography. Every morning, Williams — who, as the man behind the blog A Continuous Lean, is pretty much the charismatic leader of the cult of Americana — makes the trek from his apartment in the Financial District to his office in SoHo. The designer and retailer Alan, meanwhile, commutes in the opposite direction to his office in TriBeCa. “I would walk north and he would walk south,” Williams says. “The more that I saw him, the more we talked.” The result of those discussions, two shirts ($168 each) that arrive today at Williams’s newish A.C.L. & co. online shop, is both predictable and a little surprising.

headline: Robot Love
text: Spike Jonze, objectively speaking one of the coolest dudes around, is mild-mannered and polite almost to the point of awkwardness. (We mean that in a nice way.) Mr. Jonze created a stir when he was at Sundance for a few days showing a 30-minute short, “I’m Here,” which he made with money from Absolut. It’s a robot love story with more human than computer-generated effects: square-headed Sheldon (Andrew Garfield) falls for sleek Francesca (Sienna Guillory), who’s quirky and fun but prone to losing body parts.

headline: Lawmakers Take Aim at Tanning Beds
text: Beneath Brittany Lietz Cicala’s porcelain skin and flowing blond hair are blemishes from nearly three dozen surgeries to remove cancerous moles, including an eight-inch scar across her back. The 2006 Miss Maryland title-holder, Ms. Cicala, 24, blamed an obsession with tanning beds for triggering the cancer.

headline: Does 401(k) Advice Help Boost Returns?
text: Investors who receive employer-provided help investing in their 401(k)s have better returns than those who go it alone, according to a recent study. That provides some support for the Obama administration’s expected proposal, which would make unbiased investment advice available to workers who participate in these types of plans.

headline: Twitter Could Become the Unemployed’s Best Friend
text: Update | 5:06 p.m.  Adding clearer quote from Mr. Barton at end.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Network’
text: This week, A. O. Scott gets “mad as hell” with Sidney Lumet‘s 1976 film “Network,” a satirical look at the inner workings of the corporate media. While the television landscape has changed in myriad and fundamental ways since “Network” was released, Mr. Scott argues that “the film’s essential insights about the nature of mass communication in modern society are as fresh as ever.” Please share your thoughts about the film — its relevance and resonance — with a comment below.

headline: Scorecard | Rick Owens Wins!
text: Did Scorecard speak too soon? It seems house codes (i.e., heritage) were a point for discussion in the analysis of Friday’s shows, where Rick Owens scored major points for his luxe take on his own futoro-goth thing. Meanwhile, back at the Gothic cathedral of Givenchy, general consensus among the fashion cardinals was that Riccardo Tisci’s novitiates weren’t quite Catholic.

text: To the Editor:

text: In a way, this is a tale of two cities.

text: To the Editor:

headline: To a Tapestry’s Warp and Weft, Add Vision and Craft
text: It is always instructive when artists translate their work from one form into another, especially if the end result is the mad, magical, labor-intensive domain of tapestry. While astoundingly flexible and able to represent the finest details, the warp and weft of the loom have a regularizing effect. Their physical consistency creates a level playing field but also deadens some designs while enhancing others. So we learn new things about an artist’s sensibility and how well it travels.

headline: Turning Trash Piles Into a Bird-Watcher’s Paradise
text: “Do you see what I see?” Seth Wollney asked.

headline: Explanation Offered for Error in U.N. Climate Report
text: BRUSSELS — Faulty communication allowed an unsubstantiated estimate ofthe melting rate of Himalayan glaciers to make it into the landmark 2007 report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a senior scientist and panel official said Monday.

headline: Questions Over Fixing Torn Picasso
text: Since 1952 “The Actor,” a rare Rose Period Picasso, has hung prominently at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, along with other examples of early paintings by this Spanish master. But on Monday it could be found in a new, temporary home, the Met’s conservation laboratory, where experts there are trying to determine the best course of action for this 105-year-old painting’s brand-new feature: an irregular, six-inch tear running vertically along the lower right-hand corner.

headline: Trailer for 'The Park'
text: The trailer for "The Park," a sumptuous new original series from T.

headline: A Walk in ‘The Park’
text: “The Park,” a sumptuous new original series from T — yep, we have those, see our T Takes — debuts next Monday. Directed by Poppy de Villeneuve and set within the majestic bounds of Central Park, the five-episode series stars Macaulay Culkin, Q’orianka Kilcher, and the vaunted stage actress Mary Beth Peil, who plays Chris Noth’s mother on “The Good Wife.”

headline: Too Much Power
text: My former Times colleague Susan Antilla has a fun column today on the scare tactics being used by the Chamber of Commerce and others to defeat the president’s proposal for a Consumer Financial Protection Agency.

headline: Who’s Conflicted Now?
text: Have we gone too far in worrying about “conflicts of interest,” as I argue in my Findings column?

headline: A Factory Sputters Back to Life in Haiti
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In a city still overwhelmed by rubble and desperate for food and money, a small miracle of commerce took place on Monday: a garment factory reopened.

headline: Judge Allows S.E.C. to Add Galleon Case Charges
text: A federal judge ruled Monday evening that the Securities and Exchange Commission could add new charges against Raj Rajaratnam and others involved in the broadening insider trading case surrounding the Galleon Group.

headline: Pentagon Asks Senate Panel to Wait on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: The Obama administration has asked the Senate Armed Services Committee to delay hearings on the fate of the military’s controversial “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, because the president expects to discuss it in Wednesday’s address to Congress, the committee chairman said today.

headline: Turning Trash Piles Into a Bird-Watcher’s Paradise
text: “Do you see what I see?” Seth Wollney asked.

headline: Obama Says He’d Rather Be a ‘Really Good One-Term President’
text: With his poll numbers in retreat and his agenda under fire, President Obama said in a television interview today that he would not sacrifice his ambitious goals simply to win a second term in the White House.

headline: Halloween With Omar
text: Omar Hammami celebrates Halloween in 1992 in Alabama.

headline: Economics Rap Battle
text: John Papola and Russ Roberts have finally released their much-anticipated (by me, anyway) music video of a rap battle between those two economic gangstas, John Maynard Keynes and Friedrich Hayek. Considering Professor Roberts blogs at a site called “Cafe Hayek,” you can sorta guess where his sympathies lie. But it’s a fun video no matter where you fall in this epic rivalry.

headline: The Ozone Hole Is Mending. Now for the ‘But.’
text: That the hole in Earth’s ozone layer is slowly mending is considered a big victory for environmental policy makers. But in a new report, scientists say there is a downside: its repair may contribute to global warming.

headline: Omar Plays in Snow
text: Omar Hammami rarely saw snow in Alabama.

headline: Bill Gates Defends Google, Then Pans It
text: Bill Gates dropped by The New York Times on Monday to discuss his full-time job as head of the Gates Foundation, the world’s largest philanthropy, especially its work in global health and development.

headline: Stitching the Narrative of a Revolution
text: BEIJING  It was the height of the Cultural Revolution, but in the heart of China’s capital, in range of the prying eyes of foreign embassies, young Beijingers had embraced the tenets of capitalism.

headline: A Leading Role for Women in Keeping the Home Fires Burning
text: BASED on the bond between men and their barbecue grills, you might think an affinity for flame would translate indoors to the fireplace. But in a recent campaign for its manufactured logs, Duraflame has made women the center of attention.

headline: Out of Tragedy, Questions About God
text: To the Editor:
