Trumpeters in gold-tasseled coats tipped their horns to the sky, heralding the arrival of teenage demigods. The star quarterback and his teammates came first in the parade, followed by the homecoming queen and her court. Behind them, on a float bearing leaders of the student government, a giddy mop-haired kid tossed candy to the crowd.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, Jan. 27       (Or as it’s now known, ‘Apple Tablet Day’)
text: Highlights from today’s media coverage:

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Coyotes’ Doan Ignites Inspiring Rally
text: Eight games on Tuesday night, highlighted by the Phoenix Coyotes, who continue to surprise during a season that most thought they’d be playing in Hamilton or barely surviving by scraping together pennies. Home teams listed first:

headline: NATO and Kazakhstan Reach Transit Pact for Afghanistan
text: MOSCOW  NATO and Kazakhstan completed an agreement Wednesday that will permit NATO allies to ship cargo through Kazakh territory to Afghanistan, providing an important alternative to vulnerable routes elsewhere.

headline: Electric Trucks Before Electric Cars?
text: WASHINGTON — The biggest thing at the Washington Auto Show – quite literally – is a 22,000-pound electric truck. Two, actually. They have been built by Smith Electric Vehicles, an established British brand. The American company, a licensee based in Kansas City, Mo., began deliveries in December.

headline: ‘Avatar,’ Painted With the Palette of ‘Pocahontas’
text: “Avatar” may now be the highest-grossing movie of all time (with assists from inflation and the higher costs of 3-D and Imax screenings) but that hasn’t stopped moviegoers from pondering the cinematic pedigree of that James Cameron blockbuster — particularly the many plot details that “Avatar” seems to share with the 1995 Disney film “Pocahontas.”

headline: Style Map | St. Bart’s
text: The social epicenter of the Caribbean, St. Bart’s is where Diddy, Gisele and mega-yacht captains come together to shop at Louis Vuitton, eat moules frites at La Marine and dance on the tables at Le Ti. This season the French island is heating up again: hotels have been redone (like the Carl Gustaf), new kitchens set up and shops stocked with fresh goods. Here’s where tastemakers on holiday get their style fix.

headline: What Readers Want to Hear Tonight
text: Updated: After the White House disclosed some of the tax-break initiatives aimed at the middle class that President Obama plans to outline in his address to Congress tonight, readers offered their views on what they hoped to hear from the president in his State of the Union address.

headline: Uncle Who Vouched for Terror Suspect Arrested
text: In the days after he emerged in September as a suspect in what federal prosecutors called a Qaeda terror plot, much about the life of Najibullah Zazi became the subject of intense interest.

headline: Fundamentalists and the Atheists Who Love Them
text: As a general rule, I try to avoid writing about both Pat Robertson and Richard Dawkins. (The attention only encourages them). But Dawkins’ “defense” of Robertson, against the “milquetoast” Christians who rushed to disavow the televangelist’s suggestion that the Haitian earthquake victims were being singled out for divine punishment, offers an interesting illustration of militant atheism’s symbiotic relationship with religious fundamentalism. Here’s the new atheist:

headline: Never Too Early to Start 2013 Campaign
text: The 2009 mayor’s race was so, well, last year. Bring on 2013!

headline: As Nations Meet, Clinton Urges Yemen to Prove Itself Worthy of Aid
text: LONDON  Senior officials from the United States and 19 other countries gathered here on Wednesday to declare themselves friends of Yemen. But Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton administered a dose of tough love, saying Yemen, an impoverished Arab nation, must earn increased foreign aid by rooting out corruption, settling internal strife and protecting the rights of girls and young women.

headline: Why the Payroll Tax Break Won’t Create Jobs
text: I just read a proposal from Senators Charles Schumer and Orrin Hatch in The New York Times that is meant to give private companies incentive to hire people who have been out of work for 60 days.

headline: Economists’ Hip-Hop Showdown

headline: Schumacher’s Optimism

headline: Tyranny of the Majorities
text: If we learned anything about Barack Obama during the now-distant campaign of 2008, it was that he was a man who valued stoicism and self-possession in himself and others. And so it was significant, in an understated way, to hear Obama’s press secretary describe him, on the day of the election in Massachusetts to fill Ted Kennedy’s former Senate seat, as “surprised and frustrated” by the collapse of the Democratic candidate, Martha Coakley, and then to hear Obama’s closest aides heaping scorn on her campaign. You could see how this latest defeat might have registered on Obama like a horse hoof to the abdomen, shaking him from his prized equanimity and plunging his White House into a spate of uncharacteristic self-doubt. On a personal level, Obama had to feel that he had somehow failed one of his mentors, allowing not only Kennedy’s seat to slip away but quite possibly his dream of national health care too. Politically, the Massachusetts election seems likely to presage worse days ahead, suggesting, as an unending parade of commentators have now pointed out, that Obama and his governing party could face a calamitous November.

headline: Drawing Fire, Geithner Backs Rescue of A.I.G.
text: WASHINGTON  Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, defended the bailout of the American International Group again on Wednesday to a group of representatives who would not buy his explanations.

headline: Storing Energy as Ice?

Were you offered a job by the president?  No. There was no natural position for me within the usual structure of government.

headline: Poet Chosen Over Toibin in Literary Prize Shocker
text: It was supposed to be the literary prize that Colm Toibin was going to win in a walk — the one for which his novel “Brooklyn” was named the “runaway favorite” by one British newspaper, for which one British bookmaker gave 6-to-4 odds in the author’s favor and another declared it dead even. Instead, Mr. Toibin has gone home a runner-up in the Costa book of the year competition, having lost to a poet. The Guardian reported that Christopher Reid was named the winner of the Costa award for his collection “A Scattering,” about his wife, Lucinda Gane, who died in 2005. Mr. Reid became only the fourth poet to win the prestigious British literary award &#8212 and its prize of about $48,000 — following Douglas Dunn, Ted Hughes and Seamus Heaney (who was the most recent poet to claim victory, in 1999). Josephine Hart, one of the prize’s 11 jurors, told The Guardian, “It is a devastating piece of work and all of us on the jury felt it was a book we would wish everybody to read.” In addition to “Brooklyn,” other finalists for the award included Patrick Ness’s children’s book “The Ask and the Answer”; Raphael Selbourne’s first novel, “Beauty”; and Graham Farmelo’s biography of the quantum physicist Paul Dirac, “The Strangest Man.”

headline: Open the Marriage, Close the Door

Our housekeeper might have seen me in bed with my boyfriend. Must I explain? When I travel for business, I sometimes take my boyfriend. Must I fill in a co-worker I see only occasionally? I don’t want to hide my affection for my boyfriend or make anyone uncomfortable. NAME WITHHELD, SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Is There an Ecological Unconscious?
text: About eight years ago, Glenn Albrecht began receiving frantic calls from residents of the Upper Hunter Valley, a 6,000-square-mile region in southeastern Australia. For generations the Upper Hunter was known as the “Tuscany of the South” — an oasis of alfalfa fields, dairy farms and lush English-style shires on a notoriously hot, parched continent. “The calls were like desperate pleas,” Albrecht, a philosopher and professor of sustainability at Murdoch University in Perth, recalled in June. “They said: ‘Can you help us? We’ve tried everyone else. Is there anything you can do about this?’ ”

headline: The Dog Who Hates Me
text: It was the movie “Hotel for Dogs” that sealed the deal. My kids had been asking for a dog for years, promising to take care of it, arguing how our family wouldn’t be complete until we had one. But after we rented that movie, in which humans can’t really find happiness without a canine pal, our kids became inconsolable in their dogless sorrow. Moaning, wailing — you’d have thought they severed an artery. Fine, we’ll get a dog. Yay, Dad!

headline: Carnegie Hall Announces Its 2010-11 Schedule
text: Carnegie Hall announced its plans for next season on Wednesday. The headlines: There will be a “Perspectives” series led by the singer-songwriter James Taylor and the violinist Christian Tetzlaff, along with a festival dedicated to Japan run by Seiji Ozawa. Valery Gergiev will conduct the Mariinsky Orchestra in most of the Mahler symphony cycle (the remainder of the symphonies will take place at Lincoln Center, with the London Symphony Orchestra).

headline: Should You Walk Away From Your Mortgage?
text: The New York Times has run a couple of articles, including this one, in recent weeks about whether it makes sense to walk away from a mortgage that is bigger than the house is now worth. In a recent paper cited in an article on Sunday, a University of Arizona law professor, Brent White, explained that the vast majority of underwater homeowners continued to make mortgage payments even if it might make more financial sense for them to strategically default and walk away.

headline: New York Pops Takes a Chance on Abba
text: The great 2010 Abba-thon continues: following the news that the best-selling Swedish pop quartet will be honored with its own museum in London, the New York Pops said on Thursday that it is planning an entire concert of Abba music to kick off its 2010-11 season. In a news release, the New York Pops said that it will open its coming season on Oct. 15 at Carnegie Hall with “The Music of Abba,” featuring Rajaton, the Finnish vocal ensemble, performing hits like “Dancing Queen,” “Mamma Mia” and “Take a Chance on Me.” Other events on the Pops schedule include an 80th birthday celebration for Stephen Sondheim on Nov. 19; a holiday concert with Brian Stokes Mitchell on Dec. 10 and 11; a performance of “El Ritmo de la Vida,” a new work of Latin music by Doc Severinsen, the former “Tonight Show” band leader, on Jan. 28, 2011; and a concert honoring the 50th anniversary of Judy Garland‘s Carnegie Hall debut, featuring Ashley Brown, Heather Headley and Karen Olivo, on March 11, 2011. The Pops performances will be conducted by its musical director, Steven Reineke.

headline: ‘Hope for Haiti Now’ Leads Album Sales
text: “Hope for Haiti Now,” the download-only album of performances from the Haiti benefit telethon on Friday night, is No. 1 on this week’s Billboard chart, outselling Susan Boyle, Lady Gaga and other hits by a wide margin despite being on sale for only part of the week. After going on sale through iTunes shortly before the show began on Friday, the album (released by MTV Networks, and for sale also through Amazon, Napster and Rhapsody) sold 171,000 copies in the United States through Sunday, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is the first digital-only release to reach No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, and proceeds will benefit relief organizations.

headline: The New Indie Film Arms Race
text: It was barely a week ago that the Bagger parachuted into Sundance, ready to gorge on movies and parties. Mission accomplished! Though only a few films have sold since then (most notably “Buried”), and a few more have drawn the kind of attention that suggests distribution is imminent, there has been another kind of contest at play: At nearly every post-screening Q.&A. and interview, filmmakers have mentioned how long (or short) their shoot was. It’s a badge of honor in the indie film world to get a movie in the can in 24 or 26 days, an indication of how economically (fiscally and timewise) you work. By that metric, “Howl,” the artsy feature about Allen Ginsberg, was a winner: it was shot in 14 days.

headline: Berlin Fashion Week | Party Like It’s 1929
text: Germany is still stuck in a financial slump, but judging from the nonstop revelry that took place at Mercedes-Benz Berlin Fashion Week, for the country’s tastemakers, life is a cabaret. Hugo Boss got the party started on Thursday at the Hamburger Bahnhof museum, with a post-show soiree following its Boss Black runway presentation. Guests, including celebrities like Hillary Swank and Matt Dillon, filed behind the stage and into a massive tent with an L.E.D.-lit dance floor and high-tech digital projections, not to mention four full bars, servers circling with magnums of Champagne and — get this — an open invitation to smoke. Try getting that kind of treatment in New York these days, where austerity is the new black. Compared to the party, which left many guests nursing massive hangovers at the next day’s shows, the collection was tame, working a high-end sexy secretary angle for women and a nerd-bird banker vibe for “Mad Men”-loving male clientele.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 12: The End (for Now)
text: The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs’ team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

headline: Passing the Baton at the Opera Orchestra of New York
text: Eve Queler, the founder and longtime music director of the Opera Orchestra of New York, who has seen the institution through recent financial struggles, is preparing to step down from her post. The orchestra said in a news release that it had appointed Alberto Veronesi, the Italian conductor, to serve as its full-time music director starting with its 2011-12 season. Ms. Queler, who established the orchestra in 1971 to present concerts by established opera performers and emerging talents — including Renée Fleming, Deborah Voigt and José Carreras — will share the baton with Mr. Veronesi for the orchestra’s 40th anniversary season in 2010-11. During that time he will serve as music director designate and conduct an opera-in-concert performance. The next season, Ms. Queler will become conductor laureate, and Mr. Veronesi will begin a five-year term. Mr. Veronesi is the music director of the Puccini Festival at Torre del Lago and the Orchestra Sinfonica Siciliana, as well as the artistic director of the Filarmonica del Teatro Comunale di Bologna. He will retain these positions during his time with the Opera Orchestra.

headline: The Sap Flows in Brooklyn. How Sweet it Is.

One three-story-high specimen in a backyard in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, yielded syrup old-fashioned and mellow. Read the full story by Ava Chin, the Urban Forager, on The Local.

headline: The Democrats’ Dark Valley
text: Anyone inclined to pin all the blame for last Tuesday’s Senate outcome on poor hapless Martha Coakley should check out the numbers John Judis has compiled here, which compare Senate polling data to Barack Obama’s approval ratings in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Missouri and Colorado. In each case, the trend is clear: As the president’s ratings drop, the Democratic Senate candidate’s number execute a nosedive as well, and the G.O.P. candidate pulls ahead. None of the plunges are as steep as the one that Coakley took, and none of these states are as solidly Democratic as Massachusetts. But I suspect that in the long run, she’ll look less and less like the worst Senate candidate since Alan Keyes, and more and more like the victim of a national climate that was beyond any individual Democrat’s control.

headline: ‘Passing Strange’ Collaborators Prepare a Concert

headline: What Obama Should Say Tonight

I know you’ve been keeping it in your desk drawer, under the explanation for why God allows evil to exist in the world and how consciousness emerges from the brain, and I was hoping if I asked real nice you might share it with me.

headline: Questions for Lula Washington, Who Helped ‘Avatar’ Move

Any small moment could be the one that launches or inspires them; together those moments will set the direction of their lives.
