headline: Venturing Out on a Handyman’s Errand
text: Let us say, for argument’s sake, that you are a New Yorker with a very large Chia Pet collection and a wife who has finally grown impatient with your habit. It is now time to organize them on a shelf — problem is, you don’t have a shelf. So you choose the manly option — build one — and head off not only to buy the tools you need but also to engage, along the way, in a variety of other roll-up-your-sleeves pursuits.

headline: Six Meaningless Claims on Food Labels
text: Although food labels are supposed to tell us exactly what’s in the food we’re buying, marketers have created a language all their own to make foods sound more healthful than they really are.

headline: Now Playing: A Trailer for ‘Wall Street’ Sequel
text: Update | 3:03 p.m. We’ve written about it before, but now you can watch get a glimpse of “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” the sequel to Oliver Stone‘s touchstone of the go-go 1980s. Watch the trailer here.

headline: Parts of Health Bill May Pass Separately, Pelosi Says
text: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, on Thursday said House Democrats were waiting for the Senate to signal how it might try to proceed on major health care legislation, but she reiterated the commitment of her caucus to adopt a bill this year.

headline: Unemployment Today vs. the Great Depression
text: The job market may be in its worst condition in decades, but the Great Depression was still much, much worse.

headline: The Morning Skate: Outcry Against Head Shots Grows
text: The issue of stopping head shots in hockey may have reached a critical mass as a result of Patrice Cormier’s elbow to the head of Mikael Tam in a Quebec Major Junior Hockey League game this month.

headline: Happy Days Aren’t Here Again
text: The mood at this year’s World Economic Forum may not be as gloomy as in 2009, but there’s hardly a feeling that the good times are here again.

headline: Molto Triennale | A New Design Museum
text: The scene Tuesday afternoon at the TriBeCa offices of the Italian television network RAI International was, perhaps not surprisingly, a little like RAI’s distinctive brand of programming: leisurely, charming, chatty, full of attractive personalities and, for English speakers anyway, slightly baffling. But not necessarily in a bad way. The event was billed as a send-off for “Roy Lichtenstein, Meditations on Art,” an exhibition of more than 100 works by the late Pop artist opening that day at the Triennale museum in Milan. But the 50 or so men and women milling around a red-carpeted 25th-floor meeting room sipping Pellegrino and speaking fluent Italish were there for what proved to be bigger news: the official announcement that the Triennale — the impressive 87-year-old design-focused institution — will open a New York satellite exhibition space, Triennale NYC, this spring.A live closed-circuit TV hookup with the Triennale in Milan — think giant projection-screen Skype — yielded a series of disconnections, pixelated greetings back and forth across the Atlantic (“saluti a tutti!”) and halting moments of unclear protocol, but the crowd took it all in with breezy bella figura. On the screen, there was the Triennale president Davide Rampello at the museum in Milan, and in the room an array of Italian-culture panjandrums, including the Italian Consul General Francesco Maria Talò, the RAI director Massimo Magliaro and Roberto “Bobo” Manzoni, a veteran Milanese businessman who has been guiding the Triennale’s effort to scope out potential new locations, à la the Guggenheim, around the world. Manzoni said that a visit to MoMA in December 2008 gave him the flash of inspiration that allowed him to “follow a dream”: to open Triennale NYC across West 53rd Street in what was the home of the Museum of Arts and Design (formerly the American Craft Museum) from 1986 until 2008, when it moved to new quarters in the remade 2 Columbus Circle.

headline: The Doctors Are Real, but Not the Patient
text: In the latest Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about the challenges doctors face in working as a team, and how even experienced doctors can fumble when they work together for the first time.

headline: A New Grasp of Complexities in Washington, and of Blame
text: Last month, Mary Haas, a 62-year-old retiree in Wisconsin, told pollsters that she disapproved of President Obama’s handling of the economy. While his State of the Union address did not change that opinion, Ms. Haas did say Thursday that she now appreciated his frustrations about dealing with Congress, particularly on health care.

headline: What to Watch: Henin vs. Williams
text: The fierce rivalry between Serena Williams and Justine Henin resumes on Saturday night in the Australian Open singles final. Although this is their 14th meeting,(Williams leads, 7 to 6) it will be their first meeting in a Grand Slam final. Williams is seeking her fifth Australian title and 12th major championship, while Henin looks to add her second Australian Open championship and her eighth Grand Slam title.

headline: Looking for the Perfect Artichoke
text: Here I am at the Giant Artichoke, a restaurant and farmstand in Castroville, California, near Monterey. It’s the self-proclaimed artichoke capital of the world. Indeed, the Salinas Valley is covered in artichokes and other mild-weather crops, including grapes.

headline: White House v. the Supreme Court
text: The White House is trying to back up President Obama’s side after a rare moment of dispute with Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. was captured on camera during last night’s State of the Union.

headline: Shave Every Day. Shower Every Two Months.
text: Patrols are a constant for the Marine infantry in Afghan outposts. The Marine Corps believes that little keeps a unit as safe, as effective or as informed as having a constant — and constantly changing — presence moving over the ground.

headline: The End of an Era?
text: Update | 3:39 p.m. As the indie Mecca of Sundance closes up shop for the year, industry watchers and movie fans are paying their respects to the onetime indie powerhouse Miramax, which shut its offices in New York and Los Angeles on Thursday.

headline: Venturing Out on a Handyman’s Errand
text: Let us say, for argument’s sake, that you are a New Yorker with a very large Chia Pet collection and a wife who has finally grown impatient with your habit. It is now time to organize them on a shelf — problem is, you don’t have a shelf. So you choose the manly option — build one — and head off not only to buy the tools you need but also to engage, along the way, in a variety of other roll-up-your-sleeves pursuits.

headline: How ‘The Catcher in the Rye’ Eluded One Editor
text: In an interview with George Plimpton in The Paris Review in 2000, Robert Giroux recalled how he won and lost the opportunity to publish “The Catcher in the Rye” while he was an editor at Harcourt, Brace & Co. Here is how Mr. Giroux, the Farrar, Straus and Giroux chairman who died in 2008, described his first meeting with J. D. Salinger:

headline: Farewell, J. D. Salinger
text: A lot of authors seem frozen in time, stuck forever at the age they were when they first entered the public’s consciousness. That was even truer of J. D. Salinger than most — because he stopped publishing after 1965, because he fiercely guarded his privacy, because he remained so closely identified with the perpetual adolescent Holden Caulfield and the arrested adolescent Seymour Glass — and so the news of Salinger’s death today was almost less shocking than the fact that he was 91 years old when he died.

headline: Accelerator Pedal Supplier in Toyota’s Recall Has Many Customers
text: The CTS Corporation, the Indiana-based automotive supplier that makes the gas-pedal assembly at the center of Toyota’s “stop sale” order and recall announcements this week, also produces assemblies for other manufacturers, including Honda and Ford.

headline: Senate Votes Along Party Lines to Raise Debt Limit
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted on Thursday to raise the nation’s debt limit to $14.3 trillion, a $1.9 trillion increase that would allow the government to keep borrowing to cover operations beyond the November election and into early next year.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Melanie Oudin
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Giant Steps: The Survival of a Great Jazz Pianist
text: Influential artists sometimes click in the public consciousness only after the rise of the movements they have influenced. A school of creative work emerges — seemingly spontaneously, its origins obscure at first. Then, with attention to the artists in that school comes recognition of their influences, their antecedents and their mentors. After Pollock, de Kooning and their peers in postwar American art established Abstract Expressionism, the precursory importance of prewar iconoclasts like Kandinsky became clear. After the Ramones, the Sex Pistols and the Clash blurted forth punk rock in the 1970s, a rude vision became apparent in the noise of ’60s garage bands like the Seeds.

headline: A Forecast for VMware’s Shopping Spree
text: VMware, a maker of business software, has been on an expansionary kick ever since it went public in 2007, acquiring companies to help it dominate the world of virtual computing. Recent purchases like SpringSource and Zimbra have enabled VMware expand its reach, but it may need to acquire even more companies to make the most of its recent purchases, according to a new report from the 451 Group, a technology investment research firm.

headline: Letter: Sri Lanka
text: To the Editor: Regarding "The 31 Places to Go in 2010" (Jan. 10): I am surprised you included Sri Lanka as one of the 31 places to visit. It appears your newspaper seems to have forgotten the innumerable human rights violations committed by successive Sri Lankan governments, the worst being by the present regime. Journalists have disappeared; people with independent views were abducted and whereabouts not known; massacre of the Tamils by the army in May 2009; no press freedom and no law and order.

headline: Letter: Vatican Tours
text: To the Editor: Adam Nagourney's article on private Vatican tours "Alone (or Almost) With Michelangelo in Vatican City" (Jan. 17) provided readers with the names of several companies offering after-hours tours of the Vatican Museums and the Sistine Chapel. Another option exists for those who prefer to see Italy as part of an escorted group. The tour operator Tauck now includes private Vatican visits on seven guided itineraries. The cost of the visit is built into each tour or cruise price.

headline: Join the Club! Supporting Independent Reading With Book Groups
text: Overview | What are the benefits and drawbacks of reading both independently and as part of a group, like a class, book club or online network? In this lesson, students consider the value of private and collective reading experiences and then form book clubs around titles they “pitch” to each other. They respond to the texts as they read and execute a final project. Ideas for concurrent and culminating activities are provided.

headline: Looking for ‘Lost’ Clues? Watch These Episodes
text: With 95 episodes of “Lost” already broadcast, it would be all but impossible to review the entire series before the premiere of the final season on Tuesday. But there are shortcuts. Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers of the series, provided a list of the episodes that they think are the most crucial for newcomers who want to prepare for the final season and for longtime viewers who want to refresh their memories about key plot points and characters. Total viewing time? About six hours. Episodes are available free on ABC.com and Hulu.com and for sale or rent on iTunes, Netflix and on DVD.

headline: The Dutiful and the Mind-Boggling
text: Andrew Young’s hero was an inspiring Southern orator and a paragon of Christian virtue. He was a pillar of his community. Then he was photographed in compromising circumstances, outed as an adulterer and beset by a scandal that destroyed his career. “They caught me, Andrew,” the Rev. Bob Young confessed to his heartbroken teenage son.

headline: ‘Hesher’ Finds a Partner
text: Here’s how the film festival pendulum works: “Hesher,” which stars the “(500) Days of Summer” Sundance sweetheart Joseph Gordon-Levitt as a non-sweetie, long-haired-loner-weirdo, got great buzz at the outset of the festival but withering reviews when it actually had its premiere. But the movie, from the first-time writer-director Spencer Susser, struck a chord with fanboys (“I feel like I just had my brain thrown in a blender, splattered with hot sauce and nails,” was one Twitter review). “I flat out loved HESHER,” wrote Quint at Ain’t It Cool News. “For tone and sheer ballsy entertainment this one is going to be hard to top during my Park City adventure.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Jan. 28
text: Jorge Silva of Reuters, who took the picture of the boy in Slide 5, crossed into Haiti from the Dominican Republic 36 hours after the earthquake. “Every day that passed we realized the dimension of the destruction was even greater,” he wrote. “Every time I explored what was behind a wall, in a garden or a plaza, inside a field hospital or in the ruins of a house, there would be more children who urgently needed food and medicine.” Mr. Silva’s work has appeared here once before, on Sept. 25. It was also a picture of a young boy. But this fellow was on the beach at Margarita Island, off the coast of Venezuela; a place and a time that now must seem very distant to Mr. Silva.

headline: Curse of Spree: Knicks’ Lee Left Off All-Star Roster
text: David Lee has failed to make the N.B.A. All-Star team, extending the Knicks’ drought to nine years and raising the question of whether mystical forces are at work. Call it the curse of Sprewell.

headline: Two Also-Rans of the Great Skyscraper Race
text: THE new Burj Khalifa in Dubai, at 160 stories and 2,717 feet high, makes the 102-story Empire State Building into a pipsqueak, and indeed the urge to build the tallest structure in the world is an infectious one. Within that aspirational tradition John A. Larkin bears the mantle of two attempts. He proposed the boxy 110-story “Larkin Tower” in 1926, and reprised it in 1952 with a plan for the “World Trade Building” — 132 stories, 2,000 feet high.

headline: After the Putti, the Baby Calamari
text: WHO doesn’t have childhood memories of field trips to the museum? After a morning of being guided through the paintings and sculptures of the great masters, everyone would head for the basement cafeteria, where you would stand in line, plastic trays in hand, waiting to be treated to a lunch of rubbery chicken and gooey tapioca pudding. Those days are gone, or at least numbered. Increasingly museums are moving away from the middle-school approach to feeding visitors, with its emphasis on a lowest-common-denominator menu, in favor of stylish restaurants that offer fine dining to go with the fine art.

headline: Despite Changes, Many Still Oppose Google Books Deal
text: UPDATE 8 P.M. January 28 Removing reference to Arlo Guthrie’s support for the settlement. He filed a brief in opposition.

text: The Times's Monica Davey discusses the trial of Scott Roeder, who is accused of killing George R. Tiller, a Kansas abortion doctor.

headline: Now Viewing | ‘Supermodels’ by Timothy Greenfield-Sanders
text: In the art and fashion worlds, many a project begins with a fabulous party. In the case of “Supermodels of the ’70s and ’80s,” the photographer Timothy Greenfield-Sanders’s new exhibition at Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea, it was a party thrown by the hairstylist Harry King. “The room was full of all these fabulous women,” the photographer says, “and it seemed an obvious opportunity.”

headline: Jobs and Youthful Optimism
text: Gallup just released its latest poll numbers on the percentage of Americans who say now is a good time to find a “quality job.” For the last few months, less than a tenth of Americans answered in the affirmative.

headline: Movie Misquotations
text: As Fred Shapiro rightly notes, the title of Woody Allen’s film “Play It Again, Sam” is not an accurate quotation from the motion picture “Casablanca.” But it is possible to read that title as something other than a “misquotation.” The hero of Allen’s film, Allan Felix, is obsessed with the figure of Humphrey Bogart — especially with his character, Rick, from “Casablanca” — and imagines himself re-enacting Rick’s heroic gesture at the climax of the film. “Play it again, Sam” is, whether intentionally or not, a doubly witty trope: suggesting both the action in the mind of Felix, replaying the role of Rick, and the action of Woody Allen himself, in creating a film that involves a parody of a theme from “Casablanca.” This very compression makes it easy to miss the implications of that title. If Woody Allen did not intend these implications, then he was lucky to hit on so brilliant a “misquotation.”

headline: Obama’s War Over Terror
text: Peter Baker’s reference to President Bush’s prediction that if a Democrat won the election, “he or she would be like Dwight Eisenhower to his Harry Truman,” shows Bush’s ignorance of history. Truman was ostracized and deemed politically ineffective because he went against public opinion and limited the Korean War with MacArthur’s firing. He in effect introduced us to the outside-the-box concept of “limited war,” which led to the concept of détente. What Bush did was make a pre-emptive attack on a tyrannical government for no known legitimate reason. Truman’s cause was justified by subsequent history, whereas Bush’s actions will have us scratching our heads 20 years hence. Bristol, Conn.

headline: Vigor Quest
text: I propose a type of research that was not cited in Tom Dunkel’s article — probably because it doesn’t exist: a comparison study. The research I suggest would entail a group of participants on the Cenegenics program and comparable participants who are strongly motivated to engage in a program of weight training and aerobic exercise, combined with a highly nutritious diet and widely accepted supplements like vitamin D and fish oil.

headline: CORRECTION
text: An article on Jan. 17 about the use of hormones to forestall the aging process misspelled the third word in the name of one of them. It is human chorionic gonadotropin, not gondatropin.

headline: 'Reconciliation' Top Priority for Karzai
text: France24 reports from the international conference on Afghanistan held in London.

headline: The Four Basic Elements of Dining (and Umami, too)
text: “If someone likes a restaurant, just enjoys being in that space, say no more, the game has been won.” That’s a chef talking, a highly acclaimed young New York City gastro-turk.

headline: Bernanke Confirmed for Second Term
text: In a victory for President Obama, Ben S. Bernanke has been confirmed for a second term as head of the Federal Reserve. The Senate voted 70-30 on Thursday to leave Mr. Bernanke at the helm of the central bank for another four years. The confirmation came minutes after senators voted, 77-23, to end a debate in which critics excoriated the central bank’s handling of the financial crisis.

headline: The Coast of Dystopia
text: Thank you for Peggy Orenstein’s truly sad but wonderfully written piece on the death of California’s educational dream. This state seems to have been working long and hard to destroy its schools, first with the irrational Proposition 13 capping property taxes and thus stripping the elementary and secondary schools of their most logical source of funding and now moving on to damage the centers of higher education with a perpetually deadlocked Legislature that can no longer manage to put Band-Aids on the wounds it keeps producing. They often say that trends begin in California and spread to the rest of the country. Let’s not forget, it was California that foisted Ronald Reagan on the country, propelling the ideology that now prevails: every man for himself.

headline: J.D. Salinger and ‘The Catcher in the Rye’
text: When J.D. Salinger died in 2010, Charles McGrath wrote his Times obituary. In it, he describes the initial reaction to “Catcher” and how reading it used to be a “rite of passage”:

headline: In TV Interviews, Giuliani Misstatements Go Unchallenged
text: For the second time in under a month, the former presidential candidate Rudy Giuliani is coming under criticism for his misstatements in television interviews.

headline: Tampering at Landrieu Office Called a ‘Stunt’
text: NEW ORLEANS  The lawyer for one of the four men arrested Monday on charges of interfering with the phones in Senator Mary L. Landrieu’s office in New Orleans said the episode was a prank based on what conservative activists have said was a problem getting through to the senator’s office during the health care debates.

headline: Less Water Vapor May Slow Warming Trends
text: A decrease in water vapor concentrations in parts of the middle atmosphere has contributed to a slowing of Earth’s warming, researchers are reporting. The finding, they said, offers part of the explanation for a string of years with relatively stable global surface temperatures.

headline: A Big Audience for State of the Union
text: President Obama’s first State of the Union address was one of the longest in recent years, and it was also one of the most watched.

headline: Now Showing | Elliott Erwitt for Puerto Rico
text: Fifty years ago, when the 26-year-old photographer Elliott Erwitt shot an advertising campaign for Puerto Rico, the island still held a sense of the exotic for American travelers. Nowadays, Old San Juan has a Marshall’s discount store on one of its main plazas, and the island struggles to differentiate itself from other spots in the Caribbean — that is, as a place to hole up in a pool-side cabana between trips to the beach and the breakfast buffet. Which is why Puerto Rico tourism officials have commissioned Erwitt to reprise his 1950s shoot with a new portfolio of images intended to recapture some of the island’s cultural allure (you can read about the campaign in Stuart Elliott’s advertising column). It’s yet more evidence — in addition to the recently revived grand-dame hotels and retro cocktails and velvety old-world passenger trains — that nostalgia is a powerful force in the travel world just now. Here’s a look at Erwitt’s photographs, then and now, the difference at times being poignantly hard to discern.

headline: Mona Lisa She Is Not, but Coveted Nonetheless
text: The portrait of a woman made famous because it is not by Leonardo da Vinci sold at Sotheby’s on Thursday for $1.5 million. That price, which included the auction house’s fees, was triple the high estimate of $500,000.

headline: Conan O’Brien’s Final Week Turned Out to Be His Biggest
text: In an indication of just how big a national event Conan O’Brien’s farewell turned out to be, the official national ratings released Thursday confirmed that the late-night star had his biggest week among young viewers in his seven-month run as host of “The Tonight Show.”

headline: ‘Avatar’ Mountains Come Back to Earth
text: If you’d like to plan a visit to the Hallelujah Mountains for your next vacation, your best bet is to see “Avatar” for the seventh time. A Chinese city is backing away from reports that it renamed one of its mountains for those floating peaks from the James Cameron film, amid complaints that the city was caving in to Western cultural influences. On Monday the government of Zhangjiajie City in the Hunan province said it had changed the name of the nearby Southern Sky Column to Avatar Hallelujah Mountains; the change was apparently an attempt to capitalize on the success of “Avatar,” which has earned more than $100 million in China. But according to Reuters the state-run Xinhua news agency reported that the decision was unpopular with city residents, who “accused officials of being money-oriented and blindly worshiping Western culture.” A local tourism official told Xinhua: “We only added a way to call the mountain. The previous name is not abolished.” China is historically wary of the effects of Western culture, and recently pulled the 2-D version of “Avatar” from many movie theaters.

headline: Art in Review
text: JOHN MCLAUGHLIN

headline: Smaller Season for Los Angeles Opera
text: As it predicted, the Los Angeles Opera has announced a downsized season of six productions for 2010-11  one or two fewer than usual  because of financial troubles. They are “Il Postino” by Daniel Catán, a world premiere; “Le Nozze di Figaro”; “Lohengrin”; “Rigoletto”; “Il Turco in Italia”; and “The Turn of the Screw.” The tenor Ben Heppner, above, will take the title role in “Lohengrin,” with Dolora Zajick singing her first Ortrud. George Gagnidze, who sang Scarpia in the Metropolitan Opera’s controversial production of “Tosca” this season, will star in “Rigoletto.” Plácido Domingo, the company’s general director, will appear as the poet Pablo Neruda in “Il Postino” and will conduct performances of “Le Nozze.”

headline: Skiers Buy Vacation Homes as Prices Fall
text: DENVER

headline: Don’t Jump in the Lake
text: WHO Mark Hulst, 48, a business owner

headline: A Window Into the Turbulence of 16th-Century Rome
text: Early in the 16th century Rome and Florence were locked in a heated rivalry. Florence had the Medicis, or what was left of them; Rome was in ruins  it had been sacked in 1527  but it had the papacy, and with it the promise of rebuilding. The best artists were frequently caught in between.

headline: Jaw-Breaking Boston Detective Unravels His Daughter’s Murder
text: The last time we saw Mel Gibson in a leading role, he was throwing cold water on alien invaders in M. Night Shyamalan’s “Signs.” Now after a hiatus spent burnishing his reputation as the world’s pre-eminent director of ultraviolent dead-language epics, he tries a return to movie-star form in “Edge of Darkness,” in which he plays a grieving dad trying to solve and avenge the death of his daughter.

headline: ‘American Idiot’ Gets Its Broadway Cast
text: The Broadway cast of the musical “American Idiot” will look largely familiar to anyone who saw the show in its Berkeley Repertory Theater incarnation, but newcomers can get an introduction to the performers at the Grammy Awards broadcast on Sunday night on CBS. John Gallagher Jr., Michael Esper, Mary Faber, Rebecca Naomi Jones, Tony Vincent and Christina Sajous will all reprise their roles in the Broadway transfer of the musical, which begins previews on March 24 at the St. James Theater and opens on April 20. They will be joined by Stark Sands, a Tony Award nominee for “Journey’s End.” The cast will perform the song “21 Guns” with the band Green Day on the Grammy Awards. The musical, adapted from the band’s best-selling album “American Idiot,” is directed by Michael Mayer and features orchestration by Tom Kitt and choreography by Steven Hoggett.

headline: Composers Who Made the Center Hold
text: The Focus! festival at the Juilliard School is examining the generation of composers who created a mainstream American style in the 25 years after World War II. Mainstream, here, means traditional: in a program note Joel Sachs, the festival’s director, broadly describes the composers he has in mind as those who “wrote pieces called ‘Symphony’ and still used Italian tempo markings.” They were not avant-gardists, experimentalists or innovators but musicians determined to uphold European formal traditions, though in an updated harmonic language and with an American accent.

headline: Bachmann and Blackburn Bail on Tea Party
text: Even before the Tea Party’s $549-a-head convention next week, some of the movement’s biggest champions are partied out.

headline: Jeff Daniels to Return to ‘God of Carnage’
text: The producers of “God of Carnage” have announced that Jeff Daniels, top right, who appeared in the original cast last year, would return to the Broadway run in March, but this time in the role first played by James Gandolfini. Lucy Liu, bottom right, who starred in “Charlie’s Angels” and other films, will join the fray as well. Along with Mr. Daniels and Ms. Liu, who will be making her Broadway debut, will be Janet McTeer (“Mary Stuart”), reprising the part she played in the London production of “Carnage,” and Dylan Baker. Hope Davis and Marcia Gay Harden, who won a Tony Award in June for her role in the play, were the original wives of the two husbands in the four-member cast. The current second cast, featuring Christine Lahti, Annie Potts, Jimmy Smits and Ken Stott, is performing through Feb. 28. Mr. Daniels was said to have had so much fun the first time around that he was eager to return to the show, a comedy about two couples who fight over an altercation between their sons. The third cast will take over the show on March 2; no exit date has been announced. Tickets are on sale through June. “God of Carnage,” by Yasmina Reza, also won Tonys last year for best play and best director for Matthew Warchus.

headline: Howard Zinn, Historian, Is Dead at 87
text: Howard Zinn, historian and shipyard worker, civil rights activist and World War II bombardier, and author of “A People’s History of the United States,” a best seller that inspired a generation of high school and college students to rethink American history, died Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87 and lived in Auburndale, Mass.

headline: Theater Listings: Jan. 29 — Feb. 4
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: ‘Because It’s There’ Is the Least of Their Reasons
text: As you watch Philipp Stölzl’s gripping survival drama, “North Face,” it is impossible not to put yourself in the boots of the mountaineers clinging to a sheer, icy rock face during a blizzard that threatens to send them into oblivion. The sight of the exhausted climbers fighting to stay alive after failing to reach the summit of the Eiger, a 13,000-foot peak in the Swiss Alps, is transfixing in the way that well-told life-and-death adventure tales inevitably are. It is the film’s more mundane elements  an awkward, under-nourished love story and half-baked politics  that are problematic.

headline: Lou Reed and Sting Do Oldies
text: Experiments in Dissonance: That wasn’t the title of the program of popular standards produced by Hal Willner for Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series at the Allen Room on Wednesday evening. But it would have been a more accurate description of the concert somewhat misleadingly called “Hal Willner’s I Gotta Right to Sing the Blues? Music and Readings from ‘A Fine Romance: Jewish Songwriters, American Songs.’ ” (Note the question mark in the title.)

headline: Taking a Walk Through J. D. Salinger’s New York
text: Hey, listen. You know those ducks in that lagoon right near Central Park South? That little lake? By any chance, do you happen to know where they go, the ducks, when it gets all frozen over?

headline: In the Packaging of Loans, a Bust With Precedent
text: Real estate securitization was one of the great innovations in finance in the last quarter-century. In an unprecedented way, it allowed vast sums of money to go into the real estate market from people who traditionally did not take part in it.

headline: Magic, Sparkle and Happily-Ever-Afters Galore
text: Storybook ballets are full of conventional magic: benevolent fairies and malevolent spells and princely kisses to rescue whichever princess happens to need rescuing.

headline: The Iniesta Generation
text: Soccer players are reputed to do it for 90 minutes and some fans of Barcelona, inspired by their favorite team, did it … and did it … and did it.

headline: Don’t Smirk, Sundance’s Roots Do Show
text: PARK CITY, Utah  The spin was hotter and the vibe somewhat warmer at the 26th annual Sundance Film Festival here, while the movies were much the same, with good and bad entries promising much and sometimes delivering. Each year the festival, which ends Sunday, takes over this ski town in northern Utah, flooding the snowy, icy streets with some 40,000 attendees. This year, though, it also has a new director in John Cooper, a low-key, long-time Sundancer who took over from another veteran, Geoffrey Gilmore.

headline: A Sugar Hill Town House
text: Paul Kogan and his wife, Deborah Copaken Kogan, live with their children in a century-old gray limestone town house in Sugar Hill in Harlem.

headline: What’s Really Fair in Love and War?
text: Sarah Goodwin, the complicated woman at the heart of “Time Stands Still,” seems to thrive on conflict, at least professionally. A photojournalist who covers wars and global strife, she keeps chaos at arm’s length by trapping it in the camera lens, exerting a fierce control over moments of horror by fixing them in time.

headline: Day 2, Non-Apple News
text: It’s Day 2 of Apple-mania, and technology writers everywhere are weighing in on the pros and cons of the iPad. But what else is happening online?

headline: Andrew Young’s Mind-Boggling Memoir
text: Janet Maslin calls “The Politician,” the much-anticipated memoir by Andrew Young, the one-time aide to former presidential candidate John Edwards, a “mind-boggling book about the sheer freakiness of Mr. Edwards’s hubris, ambition and dishonesty.”

headline: A Kinetic Innovator, Plumbing the Surreal
text: The camera has been recording dance and choreography, some of it custom-made for the screen, since the earliest cinematic days of Georges Méliès. Like Méliès, a great many modern directors connect dance to fantasy, dreams, magical tours, alternative states.

headline: Now Playing: The Three Bears
text: Once upon a time there were three little brown bears. They lived on Baranof Island in Alaska. One day, their mother wandered too close to people, and she was killed. The orphans were rescued by the Alaskan government and taken to a shelter called Fortress of the Bear. From there, the bears took a plane to New York. They arrived at the Bronx Zoo in time to play in the Christmastime snow you see above.

headline: A Global War on Terror
text: Of all the slights that have stoked the outrage of vocal supporters of Israel, the one that prompted a makeshift protest in downtown Manhattan on Thursday is undoubtedly the smallest.

headline: Ming-Yi Chuang and Alan Smith
text: MING-YI CHUANG was a bank examiner, not an actress, but she met her future husband while starring in a four-minute film about breaking up — with a kumquat.

headline: Huynh Closes One Door and Opens Another
text: Is Michael Huynh finding too much on his plate, or is he just changing plates?

headline: Restaurant Umami
text: On our small-business blog “You’re the Boss,” Bruce Buschel, who brought you “The 100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do”, has a round-table discussion about what matters most in a restaurant — food? ambience? service? price? the wine? How about umami.

headline: Treasury Streamlines Its Mortgage Program
text: Borrowers seeking to improve their mortgages through a government program will soon find the paperwork a little less cumbersome.

headline: News So New It Just Has to Start Early
text: It’s 5:57 p.m. Do you know why the 6 o’clock news is already on?

headline: Just Cut the Painting in Half
text: To help decorate our younger daughter’s new apartment, my husband and I offered any item in our basement. She took a painting. A few days later, she phoned to say that she had researched the artist, and his work averages $11,000 at auction.

headline: Battling an Image and Reality, Berlusconi Takes on the Mafia (Real and Fictional)
text: ROME  It seemed a spirited defense of his nation’s reputation: calling organized crime groups “a terrible pathology,” Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Thursday criticized movies and television shows that fictionalized the Mafia for giving Italy “a negative image abroad.”

headline: Goel Leaves Intel Amid Galleon Charges
text: Rajiv Goel, an Intel employee charged in connection with the huge Galleon Group insider trading case, has left the company, an Intel spokesman told DealBook on Thursday.

headline: Wednesday’s Ratings
text: While President Obama commanded the largest network television audiences in prime time on Wednesday for his first State of the Union address, Fox’s “American Idol” dominated the 8 p.m. hour with 24.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. No other network came close to matching Fox in the 8 p.m. time slot, although both CBS and ABC broadcast comedy reruns, and NBC offered a repeat of “Mercy” (4.2 million). Meanwhile a precise accounting of the president’s audience was not immediately available on Thursday, but preliminary overnight estimates show the speech probably attracted a smaller audience than the president’s first address to a joint session of Congress in February of last year. That speech drew 52.4 million viewers, while Wednesday’s speech, which began at 9 p.m. and lasted until 10:20, appeared to have garnered an audience more similar in size to President Obama’s prime-time address in December about the American strategy in Afghanistan, which drew 40.8 million viewers. Final ratings were expected to be released late in the day on Thursday.

headline: After Ratings Decline, ‘Ugly Betty’ Is Canceled
text: “Ugly Betty,” the ABC series that won a Golden Globe award for best comedy in its first season on the air in 2006-7 but whose audience has fallen by half over its four seasons, to about five million currently, will end its prime-time run this spring, the network and the show’s producers said. ABC said it will broadcast eight more original episodes, including a series finale. An adaptation of a popular Spanish-language soap opera, “Betty La Fea,” about an unattractive but cheerful secretary at a fashion magazine, “Ugly Betty” was imported to the United States by Reveille Productions and featured America Ferrera, left, as Betty, a role for which she won a Golden Globe and an Emmy for acting in her first season. The initial buzz around the show was strong even before the series premiere, but convoluted story lines alienated some viewers. This season ABC moved the series to Friday nights, where ratings fell dramatically, before shifting the program to 10 p.m. Wednesdays after the cancellation of “Eastwick.”

headline: Onetime ‘Idol’ Prospect Finds His Inner Rebel
text: Sometime in 2007 Jason Castro accidentally stumbled through a door that led to the auditions for “American Idol” and decided to just stick around. At least that’s how it seemed throughout that show’s seventh season, from his first appearance right up until he placed fourth. He had about one-tenth the intensity of the next-most-lethargic contestant, appeared anxious when it came to speaking and was only beginning to test the boundaries of his voice.

headline: Grammys’ Weight Is Now Measured in Face Time
text: THE award or the performance? The recognition or the spectacle? Those are perennial questions for the Grammy Awards, which will be bestowed for the 52nd time on Sunday at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, and broadcast live on CBS at 8 p.m. Eastern Time.

headline: Universal Orlando Conjures Up a Harry Potter Spot in the Super Bowl
text: Marketing professors say that a good use of commercial time bought during a Super Bowl is to promote a new product, service or attraction. The folks at the Universal Orlando Resort in Orlando, Fla., must be reading their textbooks.

text: FILM SERIES

headline: Artists Rights Act Applies in Dispute, Court Rules
text: A federal appeals court has decided that a lower court erred in 2007 when it ruled in favor of the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in a bitter dispute between the museum and the artist Christoph Büchel over an immense, unfinished installation.

headline: AT&T and Apple Allow Cheap VoIP Calls on 3G
text: In all of the hullabaloo over it the iPad, a long-awaited change to the iPhone got lost in the shuffle: Apple has taken the wraps off VoIP calls over the 3G network. That could mean a potentially huge savings on domestic and foreign calls.

headline: Shining a Light on a Forgotten Poet
text: Mary Webb, a British novelist, deprecated herself despite having published six books and dozens of poems set in her native Shropshire. Known in the 1920s for her evocative descriptions of the countryside and racy plots involving abortion, patricide and premarital sex, she nonetheless called herself “wholly un-gifted” and sometimes felt “whelmed in remorse & terror” over her perceived literary mistakes.

headline: He’s Older and a Cuckold, but He Has Tough Friends
text: “44 Inch Chest” can be described as six guys sitting around in barely furnished rooms, talking. Actually, one of the six says nothing at all: he sits quietly in the chair to which he’s tied, bruised and bloody and shaking and wondering if  or maybe just when  the other five will kill him.

headline: Wall St. Tries to Put a Price on Volcker Rule
text: President Obama is pushing hard for stricter financial regulation, promising in his first State of the Union address that he would not sign a bill that “does not meet the test of real reform.” This has left Wall Street wondering how much Mr. Obama’s regulatory proposal, known as the Volcker Rule, will cut into its profits.

headline: Europe on the Upper East Side
text: The Upper East Side gallery scene can often seem a bit staid, but it has its mercurial side. For one thing, the art in its contemporary galleries frequently pushes the envelope. For another, its many semiprivate dealers occasionally mount shows en masse, whether by plan or coincidence, that amount to collective mood swings. Sometimes Asian art is ascendant, or 19th- and early-20th-century American art. Right now the neighborhood has broken out in exhibitions of European drawings.

headline: Mumblecore Auteurs Get Ready for Their Close-Up
text: Let this be a lesson to budding filmmakers everywhere: if you make low-budget, scruffy comedies with a distinct point of view long enough, you will eventually attract … other people who like low-budget scruffy comedies with a distinct point of view. At least that’s what happened to the Duplass brothers, Jay and Mark, the Austin, Tex.-based auteurs of the mumblecore genre (“The Puffy Chair” and “Baghead”). They hit Sundance this year with their first mainstream film, “Cyrus,” developed for and distributed by Fox Searchlight. The feature, their first to crack 90 minutes (“only because our credits are like five minutes long,” Jay said) was largely improvised; it stars John C. Reilly and Marisa Tomei as a couple whose relationship is threatened by her adult son, Jonah Hill, in the title role. The Bagger liked it and so did many others at Sundance; it won unofficial best-of polls  and even had some watchers talking Oscars – pretty heady stuff for a couple of dudes who made their Sundance entrée with what they called their “$3 movie” and cast their parents in the follow-up. The Bagger spoke with them in the plasticized courtyard of a hotel in Park City.

headline: Poor Insurance Adjuster Has a Devil of a Problem
text: There is one joke in the first-time filmmaker Hue Rhodes’s pretentious indie road comedy, “Saint John of Las Vegas,” that plays off its inspiration, Dante’s “Inferno,” with witty ingenuity. The image of a sinner burning eternally in hell becomes a carnival performer, Smitty (John Cho), known as the Flame Lord, who after a technical malfunction finds himself trapped in his protective suit that bursts into flames every 20 seconds. Approached by John Alighieri (Steve Buscemi), a ratty-looking insurance-claims adjuster investigating a possible fraud, Smitty pleads for a cigarette.

headline: Coins and a Fountain That Make a Magic Mess
text: It goes without saying that we root for Beth (Kristen Bell) and Nick (Josh Duhamel), the appealing would-be couple at the center of “When in Rome,” to find bliss together. And it goes without saying that they will. This is a romantic comedy, after all, and no genre is more reliable in its outcome. But if that foreordained result  in this case an Italian wedding at the end to echo the one where Nick and Beth met cute at the beginning  is going to be satisfying, there need to be obstacles along the way. Nothing too serious or painful, of course, but an inkling of trouble sufficient to convince us that the happy ending has been properly earned.

headline: Wired Kids, Negligent Parents?
text: Young Americans from the ages of 8 to 18 spend more than seven and a half hours a day on average using a smart phone, computer, television or other electronic device. On top of that, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation  study released last week detailing these habits, many children are electronic multitaskers — surfing the Web, for example, while listening to music or watching TV.

headline: Loss Forecast at Motorola; Shares Drop
text: The stock of Motorola, the mobile phone maker, fell after the company forecast a surprise first-quarter loss, signaling that new handsets were failing to increase sales.

headline: Of Teen Angst and an Author’s Alienation
text: What really knocked readers out about “The Catcher in the Rye” was the wonderfully immediate voice that J. D. Salinger fashioned for Holden Caulfield  a voice that enabled him to channel an alienated 16-year-old’s thoughts and anxieties and frustrations, a voice that skeptically appraised the world and denounced its phonies and hypocrites and bores.

headline: Emanuel: Democrats Not Dropping Health Care
text: Some observers have wondered whether Democrats are quietly planning to abandon President Obama’s sweeping health care overhaul. But Mr. Obama’s chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, insists that is not the case.

headline: Tale of a Terrorist
text: A Palestinian terrorist and an Israeli outcast lock fates in “For My Father,” a wartime romance about people more at odds with their own cultures than with each other’s.

headline: Swedish Banks Diverge on Bonus Question
text: Sweden’s top banks are going their separate ways on the question of employee bonuses.

headline: A Race for Identity
text: “Do you feel black?” a counselor asks Avery Klein-Cloud in the documentary “Off and Running,” voicing the question that hovers subliminally over every scene. Avery, an African-American teenager, is clear. “I don’t know what that means,” she says, though the film has already suggested that the answer is no.

headline: Obama Plan Privatizes Astronaut Launchings
text: President Obama will end NASA’s return mission to the moon and turn to private companies to launch astronauts into space when he unveils his budget request to Congress next week, an administration official said Thursday.

headline: ‘The Catcher in the Rye’ in 1960: Permission Slip Required
text: I first read J.D. Salinger’s “Catcher in the Rye” in the summer of 1960, when I was 12. I heard about it from an older boy who was an unerring guide to books that were racy. So I went to my local library, in Brighton, Mass., asked for “Catcher,” and was told that I would need a note of permission from my parents. The librarian glared at me as she said this. My mother, who was not a big reader herself, wrote a note saying I should be allowed to read whatever I wanted, which now seems one of her greatest gifts to me. That little piece of paper got me into the other, grownup side of the library, where I found a lot of books that opened my eyes and, I suppose, led me eventually to become a writer myself. I have since read better books than “Catcher” but few that made a more lasting impression. I still recall reading the first paragraph and thinking to myself, “You can really do that?”

headline: Spain, Greece and Latvia Affirm Their Commitment to the Euro
text: DAVOS, Switzerland  Leaders from three of Europe’s most economically troubled countries said on Thursday that the financial crisis had only solidified their commitment to the euro, and they pledged to make budget cuts and other changes required for membership.

headline: Baggage Fee Not Taxable, I.R.S. Says
text: Airline baggage fees are not taxable, the Internal Revenue Service said, a victory for carriers trying to protect a growing revenue stream.

headline: While Confident Health Care Will Pass This Year, Democrats Still Search for a Plan
text: WASHINGTON  Democratic leaders in Congress voiced resolute optimism on Thursday that they would adopt major health care legislation this year, and they said that doing so was a crucial element of President Obama’s broader agenda to create jobs, revive the economy and reduce federal budget deficits.

headline: Preschools Add Brush-and-Spit to Day
text: HAVERHILL, Mass.  The twelve 4-year-olds sat in a corner, small hands clasping toothbrushes. Isaac and Aaron brandished them like swords, stabbing each other in the side. Jacky rubbed his into the carpet. Abigail squirmed, and Chayleece jumped up and down.

headline: Using Humor in a Campaign Supporting Disabled People
text: A NATIONAL effort to encourage businesses to employ workers with disabilities is not your father’s hire the handicapped campaign.

headline: Speed Thrills in Contest for Vonn’s Helmet
text: The American alpine racer Lindsey Vonn held a public contest to design the helmet she will wear at the Vancouver Games, and she announced Thursday that the winning entry belonged to Laddie Lee Whitworth, a 60-year-old retired machinist from Pocatello, Idaho.

headline: Women’s League Shutters Popular Los Angeles Team
text: Women’s Professional Soccer has decided to shut down the Los Angeles Sol, its most popular team, after failing to find a buyer for the club.

headline: Bright, a Halfpipe Medal Contender, Sustains Another Concussion
text: Torah Bright of Australia, a strong contender for a medal in snowboard halfpipe at the Olympics next month in Vancouver, pulled out of the Winter X Games on Thursday after sustaining her second concussion in three days.

headline: Vonn Plots Her Final Training for Vancouver
text: There is one remaining series of World Cup races before the Vancouver Games — this weekend in St. Moritz, Switzerland — and after that, Lindsey Vonn said Thursday, she will be resting and training.

headline: Has Ford Earned Its Share Price?
text: Is Ford’s auto business worth $52 billion? With the company’s stock trading at over $11 a share, that’s the value investors appear to be putting on it. Sure, the company is performing nicely compared to its Detroit rivals, Chrysler and General Motors. But to justify its valuation, Ford needs to prove its rebound has staying power.

headline: Amazon’s Holiday Sales Buoyed Profit
text: Amazon.com reported fourth-quarter profit and sales that beat analysts’ estimates as shoppers took advantage of holiday discounts and free shipping.

headline: How to Regain Control of an Accelerating Vehicle
text: As Toyota deals with a recall and a sales moratorium on eight of its American models, drivers may be wondering what action they should take if they find themselves in a car that accelerates out of control.

headline: Israel Signals Tougher Line on West Bank Protests
text: NILIN, West Bank  For more than a year, this village has been a focus of weekly protests against the Israeli security barrier, which cuts through its lands. Now, the village appears to be at the center of an intensifying Israeli arrest campaign.

headline: From Reeds to the River, a Village From Iraq’s Past
text: HALAICHIYA, Iraq  The phrase has a poetry that the land lacks. “Behind the sun,” its residents say in Arabic, and it means that this forlorn locale, at the headwaters of the channel that joins the Tigris and Euphrates, is flung as far as any other town in Iraq.

headline: Promises and Perks to Try to Lure Cubs From Arizona
text: With spring training approaching, the annual tussle between the Grapefruit and Cactus Leagues has returned, only with a twist.

headline: Mudslides Trap Tourists Near Peru Ruins
text: Five days after mudslides crippled roads and rail access near the Machu Picchu ruins in the mountains of southern Peru, more than 1,000 people had been evacuated by helicopter, but hundreds more remained stranded and faced food and water shortages.

headline: Brazil: High Blood Pressure Sidelines President
text: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, left, suffered an attack of high blood pressure and canceled his trip to Davos, Switzerland, for the Global Economic Forum, where he was to have accepted the Global Statesman award. Mr. da Silva, 64, fell ill Wednesday while on the presidential plane in Recife and was taken to a hospital, said Cleber Ferreira, the president’s private doctor. He said that the attack had been caused by stress and fatigue, adding that the president’s blood pressure was “absolutely normal” and that he did not have a hypertension problem.

headline: South Korea: North Fires Into Disputed Waters Again
text: For a second straight day, North Korea fired shells into waters near the disputed western sea border with South Korea, asserting its territorial claims in the most volatile section of the inter-Korean frontier. After lobbing dozens of shells on Wednesday, North Korean shore guns roared again Thursday in what the North called a routine military exercise, said a spokesman at the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the South Korean military. The border was drawn by the United Nations at the end of the Korean War but never accepted by the North.

headline: Bursting Pride in Super Bowl Team Replenishes a City
text: NEW ORLEANS  The threshold for excessive celebration here is high.

headline: Medicine for Musicians
text: The players of the Houston Symphony were not the only virtuosos from their city holding forth at Carnegie Hall on Thursday. While the orchestra rehearsed in the main auditorium for its evening concert, doctors from the Methodist Center for Performing Arts Medicine of the Methodist Hospital in Houston were participating in a daylong symposium on the management of medical problems among musicians specifically and performing artists more generally. Sponsored by the center in collaboration with the Center for the Performing Artist at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, the conference was timed to coincide with the orchestra’s big night.

headline: Battling for Health Coverage as Cancer Spreads
text: Rashidam Shakirova moved from Atlanta to New York in 2008 so she could earn more as a home health-care aide  $9 an hour instead of $7. But she now believes that her new job indirectly took a drastic toll on her health.

headline: Reelabilities Film Festival
text: Mainstream movies with disabled characters follow a well-worn path that begins with an obstacle  be it a hardened heart (“Rain Man”), the inability to read (“The Miracle Worker”) or merely life itself (“Forrest Gump”)  and ends with the barrier surmounted and audience members reaching for their Kleenex.
