text: AROUND TOWN

headline: An Author’s Prose
text: A sampler of J. D. Salinger’s prose.

headline: Latest Legal Battle Leaves America’s Cup Showdown in Doubt
text: They have been dueling without boats and without salt water in their faces for nearly three years. Instead of the customary helmsmen and bowmen, the combatants in the 33rd America’s Cup have been the lawyers and public-relations specialists pushing the opposing agendas of the team owners Larry Ellison of BMW Oracle Racing and Alinghi’s Ernesto Bertarelli, who said this week that he would forfeit the Cup if he lost his latest court battle.

headline: Experts Say a Rewrite of Nation’s Main Education Law Will Be Hard This Year
text: In his State of the Union address, President Obama held out the hope of overhauling the main law outlining the federal role in public schools, a sprawling 45-year-old statute that dates to the Johnson administration.

headline: Seeking Fans in 2 States, Despite a Record of 4-40
text: As they sauntered around the Brooklyn Hospital Center, the two pro basketball players seemed like the stars they once were, larger-than-life figures who drew the gaze and praise of nearly everyone they passed. Awed children shook their hands; adults awkwardly asked for autographs.

headline: Bank Tax Is Knotty Issue for New York’s Senators
text: President Obama’s proposal to impose new taxes on large banks is testing the ties New York’s United States senators have with Wall Street, a pillar of the state’s economy and a major source of their campaign dollars.

headline: Possible Teacher Layoffs Would Have Big Impact
text: For more than three decades, New York City schools have soldiered on through turmoil, politics, recessions, budget crises and a changing cast of mayors and chancellors. But since 1976, the system has never carried out significant layoffs of teachers.

headline: Firm Brings Gene Tests to Masses
text: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.  The new movie “Extraordinary Measures” is based on the true story of a father who starts a company to develop a treatment for the rare genetic disease threatening to kill two of his children before they turn 10.

headline: Real Estate Interests Help Cuomo Gain a Big Edge in Cash
text: As Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo readies his candidacy for governor, one industry is helping him amass a huge fund-raising advantage: real estate.

headline: Landlord Faces Lawsuit for Harassment
text: State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced Thursday that he intends to sue a major New York landlord that he says harassed hundreds of tenants in rent-regulated apartments in Queens and Manhattan in a systematic effort to force their departure to create vacancies for higher-paying tenants.

headline: Chinese Leader Offers a Glimpse of the Future
text: DAVOS, SWITZERLAND  China gave the world a glimpse of the next generation of Chinese leaders on Thursday when Li Keqiang, widely expected to be the next prime minister, vowed that his country would act swiftly to shift from an over-reliance on exports toward greater domestic consumption.

headline: Inmates’ Stock Is Rising in Albany District Fight
text: ALBANY  As state lawmakers prepare to redraw the boundaries of Congressional and state legislative districts, one segment of the population is quickly becoming a coveted constituency: prisoners.

headline: Health Bill Stalled, Obama Juggles an Altered Agenda
text: WASHINGTON  The White House on Thursday signaled the outlines of its strategy for breaking the partisan logjam holding up President Obama’s agenda, saying Democrats would move quickly to underline their commitment to fixing the broken economy and to build an election-year case against Republicans if they do not cooperate.

headline: Suspicious Backpack Leads to Courthouse Evacuation
text: To the woman who found a knapsack outside the federal courthouse in Brooklyn on Thursday, taking it to the courthouse’s lost and found office might have seemed like a simple act of courtesy.

headline: Like the Crisis of the ’70s, but Angrier
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his new budget plan on Thursday, ushering in what is sure to be a period of unity among New York’s many disparate groups. No doubt, they will all agree on a single course of action to get the city through its fiscal distress: Cut some other guy’s program, but don’t ask me to make a sacrifice.

headline: Supreme Court Gets a Rare Rebuke, in Front of a Nation
text: WASHINGTON  It is not unusual for presidents to disagree publicly with Supreme Court decisions. But they tend to do so at news conferences and in written statements, not to the justices’ faces.

headline: New Panel Will Study Disposal of Waste
text: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department plans to announce on Friday the formation of a “blue ribbon” commission to study the disposal of nuclear waste.

headline: Henin and Williams Know Life Beyond Tennis
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Serena Williams and Justine Henin have seen plenty of each other over the years  they have played 13 matches, with Williams holding a 7-6 edge. But when they take the court here in the women’s final of the Australian Open on Saturday night, they will do so with a newfound respect and appreciation of each other.

headline: In Disaster, Tensions Ease Between an Island’s Rivals
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Like almost anyone from Hispaniola, the island uncomfortably shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic, Paloma Rivera is acutely aware that the two nations distrust each other, complain about each other and cite grievances about each other going back well over a century.

headline: Intense Seeker of Powerful Elegance
text: IF a single word can be used to characterize the British artist and movie director Steve McQueen, it is probably “particular.” Curators often invoke it when describing the way he insists on presenting his enigmatic, carefully wrought films and videos: with every detail of the installation precisely specified, down not just to the dimensions of the screen and the viewing space, but also to the finish on the surrounding floors and walls.

headline: 19th-Century Concept, With a Few Upgrades
text: PAT METHENY, the jazz guitarist, has lately spent an inordinate amount of time thinking about robots. Actually, that’s putting it mildly: he has been downright obsessed with robots, and with getting them to do his bidding. “I haven’t slept more than four hours a night for six months now,” he said one day last fall at a makeshift rehearsal space in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, the former home of a Byzantine Catholic church.

headline: Pop Against the Grain, With Sounds of the ’70s
text: THEY grow up so fast now. It seems like only last summer that the Jonas Brothers  Nick, Joe and Kevin  were cementing their hold on the teenage hive mind.

headline: Are Those Love Songs? On a Yeasayer Album?
text: YEASAYER is braced for a backlash. “People could turn on us at any moment,” said a smiling Anand Wilder, 27. He’s one of the three songwriters, singers and multi-instrumentalists in the Brooklyn band Yeasayer, along with Chris Keating, 28, and Ira Wolf Tuton, 30.

headline: Untouched by War, in Iraq
text: The village of Halaichiya has the distinction of never having seen an American, much less a soldier.

headline: Administration Considers Moving Site of 9/11 Trial
text: WASHINGTON  Facing mounting pressure from New York politicians concerned about costs and security, the Obama administration on Thursday began considering moving the trial of the chief organizer of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks out of Manhattan, administration officials said.

headline: Republicans Compromise on Ideological Test
text: HONOLULU – A potentially divisive dispute over a Republican National Committee “purity resolution” that would require candidates to commit to a series of conservative positions – or face a cut-off of party funds – has apparently been averted.

headline: For Apple, iPad Said More Than Intended
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple has generated a lot of chatter with its new iPad tablet. But it may not be quite the conversation it wanted.

headline: Haiti Recovers Slowly
text: Haiti's devastated capital, Port-au-Prince, showed increasing signs of life as a motley assortment of enterprises reopened.

headline: The Next Time
text: Three years ago, after Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. led the Supreme Court to the brink of overturning a few precedents but then blinked, a frustrated Justice Antonin Scalia accused the chief justice of “faux judicial restraint.”

headline: Cloud Over the Capitol
text: Something stinks in the Capitol, literally. Senate Democrats had to move their weekly caucus lunch on Tuesday from the ornate Mansfield Room to a room in the new Congressional Visitor Center because the stench, mostly on the second floor of the Senate, was so bad. Accusations about the fish entrée in the Republican luncheon were quickly dismissed. So was a rumor that workers renovating Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s old hideaway office cut through a sewer line and never cleaned up. The smell persists, and the air is rife with theories of its source.

headline: Brooklyn Beats
text: Rain Machine is a side project of Kyp Malone from TV on the Radio, and it “leaves no question as to exactly where Mr. Malone’s main band gets its churn and melancholy,” writes Jon Caramanica. Mr. Malone will be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday, with Anti-Pop Consortium, for Sounds Like Brooklyn. The music festival, in its fourth year, features an eclectic mix from the neighborhood  one that seems to have a knack for churning out really great bands. Head to BAM tonight for a totally different pairing when Les Savy Fav headlines a show that also includes the Vivian Girls, “whose wistfully melodic no-fi dream-pop will probably be the haziest sound ever featured in the Academy’s Howard Gilman Opera House.” The festival continues next weekend, Feb. 4-6, with shows all around the borough, featuring Dred Scott Trio, The Sweet Divines, The Antlers, Rose Parade and more.

headline: Soup’s On
text: Roasted winter squash and carrot bisque from “21” Club or Jean-Claude’s lobster bisque from Chez Josephine: Could there be more perfect meals for a cold winter day? You can choose either one  or both  at the NYC Restaurant Week Truck, which will be parked on Broadway between 50th and 51st today. In honor of restaurant week, the city is offering soups from 24 of the city’s restaurants, including Le Cirque, Blue Water Grill, Tribeca Grill, Delmonico’s Steakhouse and many more. The soups cost $6 and come with bread from Tom Cat Bakery. Even better, $1 from every NYC Restaurant Week Truck purchase will go to The Haiti Relief Fund at the Mayor’s Fund to Advance New York City. The truck is on the move through Feb. 5, so check the Web site for times and locations.

headline: Coney Country
text: Despite many attempts to revive Coney Island, for most New Yorkers the former resort still conjures images that are more likely to resemble a Diane Arbus photograph than a charming Victorian postcard. But Save Coney Island, the volunteer nonprofit organization, hopes to change that. This Saturday, the group, which is working to restore Coney Island to an amusement destination, is hosting “Gone Country for Coney,” a Country Jamboree at Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo. The all-day benefit event, which begins at 3 p.m. and runs through 9:30 p.m., features performances by rock, country and blue-grass groups, including Citigrass, Piñataland, the 2009 fiddle champion Rob Hecht, Central Valley Wildfire and Animal Pharm. The program will also feature dance performances by the Prospect Cowgirls and plenty of BBQ and raffle prizes, not to mention an after-concert burlesque.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a new effort by the United States and other countries to help stabilize Yemen, which is threatened by poverty, insurgency and Al Qaeda militants, misstated the year that Edmund J. Hull, a former United States ambassador to Yemen, first traveled to that country’s more dangerous areas in an earlier American effort to foster aid projects. It was 2002, not 2003.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the devastation of Haiti’s National Palace in the Jan. 12 earthquake misspelled the surname of a structural engineer from California who was helping Haitian officials plan the safest route into crumpled parts of the building to retrieve sensitive documents. He is Kit Miyamoto, not Miramoto.

headline: Europe Weighs Possibility of Debt Default in Greece
text: European leaders are quietly considering whether to come to the aid of their troubled neighbor Greece amid fears that the nation might default on its debts and unleash another round of financial crisis.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the lost cachet of the karakul hat, the Afghanistan headgear made famous by President Hamid Karzai, misidentified, in some editions, the nationality of the fashion designer Tom Ford, who once called Mr. Karzai “the chicest man on the planet.” Mr. Ford is American, not British.

headline: A World Cup Dream Revives India’s Women’s Team
text: GOA, India  When the Indian women’s national team takes the field against Sri Lanka on Friday in the South Asian Games, it will be its first soccer match in two years.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Thursday with the TV Watch column, about President Obama’s State of the Union address, misidentified, in some editions, two people shown watching the speech at a Los Angeles cultural center. They are Chez Nwanyanwu and Juliet Lawrence, not Wajenda and Ivory Chambesi.

headline: Mets and Smoltz Still Talking
text: Discussions between the Mets and John Smoltz continue apace, and Mets front office officials had more internal discussions Thursday about adding the veteran right-hander.

headline: Trial of Three Officers Looks at Internal Inquiry
text: The focus of the police brutality trial unfolding in a Brooklyn courtroom shifted Thursday from the disputed events of Oct. 15, 2008, when prosecutors say that a 24-year-old body piercer was abused by an officer in a subway station, to aspects of the investigation that followed.

headline: Shudders Follow a Killing on Madison Avenue
text: The yellow crime-scene tape stretched from the elegant iron railing outside the century-old Florian Papp antique furniture shop, past the R. S. Durant jewelry store next door and down the sidewalk to the edge of the doorway of F. M. Allen, a luxury safari and sportswear shop. It stopped short of Pat Areias, a small, upscale belt and buckle shop where the display window was already decorated with red hearts for Valentine’s Day and a two-inch-wide alligator belt cost $720.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a listing in the New Jersey Calendar in some editions on Sunday about a performance by the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra this Sunday at the Mayo Center for the Performing Arts in Morristown misstated the phone number for tickets. It is (800) 255-3476.

headline: Neuroscientist Denies Trying to Kill Americans
text: For just over a week, a Pakistani neuroscientist being tried on charges of trying to kill American soldiers and F.B.I. agents in Afghanistan has been kicked out of the courtroom nearly every time she has spoken, her angry outbursts judged a disruption.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: A picture caption with an article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a competition to design a pedestrian bridge at Volkswagen’s new plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., reversed the identifications of two Auburn University students who helped develop the winning proposal. Dylan Cook was second from right and Tyler Maloney was at far right.

headline: 47 Across: It Merged With Tanganyika in 1964
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you drink coffee while solving your puzzle? Or maybe a Diet Coke to wash down some HOHOS? A bit of food or drink can come in handy for a puzzle like today’s. It keeps one busy while mulling and musing and meandering among the clues to find something of help.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of credits on Monday with a television review of “Damages,” on FX, omitted a production company and erroneously included another. Besides Sony Pictures Television and FX Productions, KZK Productions should have been credited, but not No Hands Productions.

headline: Jets’ Sanchez Considering Surgery on Knee
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  General Manager Mike Tannenbaum’s decision to trade up and choose Mark Sanchez at No. 5 in last April’s draft served as a launching point for the Jets’ rise to the American Football Conference title game. Now, after visiting with the orthopedic surgeon Dr. James Andrews, Sanchez is deciding whether to have an operation on his left knee, which he originally hurt in August 2008.

headline: Corrections
text: An art column on Jan. 15 about the Museum of Fine Arts and the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston referred incorrectly to the size of the Egyptian collection at the Museum of Fine Arts. The museum says it has the largest collection of Egyptian Old Kingdom art outside of Cairo, not the largest collection of all Egyptian art outside that city.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Thursday about the astrophysicist Andrew Lange, whose measurements of light left over from the Big Bang helped explain the shape and nature of the universe, misstated the given name of Dr. Lange’s father. It is Alfred, not Albert.

headline: Obama Sets Ambitious Export Goal
text: WASHINGTON  In promising Wednesday night to double the United States’ export growth over the next five years, President Obama set an ambitious goal for American trade policy that, he said, could create two million jobs.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Building Haiti’s Economy, One Mango at a Time
text: IN an astonishing outpouring of generosity, nearly half of American households have donated money to help Haiti recover from the recent earthquake. The United States government and other governments around the world, for their part, have sent thousands of relief workers and have pledged $1 billion so far. But Haitians need something more fundamental than relief from the present situation; they need jobs that they can count on for years ahead. For this, the private business sector is essential. Luckily, business leaders are meeting now in Davos, Switzerland, and Haiti is prominent on their agenda.

headline: Nokia Profit Rises on Smartphone Sales and Cost-Cutting
text: Nokia, the world’s largest maker of mobile phones, said on Thursday that its profit rose 60 percent in the fourth quarter as cost-cutting measures and an increasing share of the smartphone market helped offset a decline in revenue.

headline: At Florida Stop, Obama Announces Rail Investment
text: TAMPA, Fla.  President Obama sought to rekindle the fire of his presidential campaign on Thursday as he left behind his political challenges in Washington and began a series of trips around the nation to show that his administration is striving to rebuild the economy and accelerate sluggish job growth.

headline: Bloggingheads: Tea Partiers' Paranoia
text: Michelle Goldberg of The American Prospect and Matt Welch of Reason debate the mindset of the Tea Party movement.

headline: S.E.C. Settles Stockman Lawsuit
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had reached a tentative settlement of a civil lawsuit against David A. Stockman, a former budget director in the Reagan administration. The agency said in the suit that he and other executives of the bankrupt auto-parts maker Collins & Aikman of Southfield, Mich., had misled investors.

headline: In Sweden, Banks Differ on Paying Bonuses
text: Sweden’s top banks are going their separate ways on the question of employee bonuses.

headline: Walking in Holden's Footsteps
text: A tour of New York spots in “The Catcher in the Rye.”

headline: Raptors Pile On to Knicks’ Anguish
text: David Lee is playing like an All-Star but was denied the honor presumably because his team does not win enough. On Thursday, Lee played like an All-Star, while battling an actual All-Star, and the Knicks lost again, which seemed to prove the point.

headline: Vibrant Flavors, Served When the City Sleeps
text: Out by the cold expanse of Ocean Beach is not where you’d expect to find good food at 2 a.m.

headline: Many Successful Gay Marriages Share an Open Secret
text: When Rio and Ray married in 2008, the Bay Area women omitted two words from their wedding vows: fidelity and monogamy.

headline: North Korea: Second American in Custody
text: North Korea acknowledged that it had detained an American for illegally crossing into its territory from China, the second United States citizen to be held as the North’s dispute with Washington over its nuclear weapons program continues. The American entered North Korea on Monday and was under interrogation, the North’s state-run news agency, K.C.N.A., said. The other American being held is believed to be Robert Park, a Christian missionary from Arizona.

headline: In Santa Clara, Uneven Fight Over a New Stadium for the 49ers
text: As Santa Clara ponders whether to play ball with the San Francisco 49ers and the National Football League, the money, glamour and traditional political power line up on the pro-stadium side. The stop-the-stadium campaign will run on e-mail, shoe leather and indignation about rich owners and athletes.

headline: Ending ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: Toward the end of his State of the Union address Wednesday night, President Obama said something that untold numbers of Americans who suffer discrimination had wanted to hear for more than 16 years. He promised to work to repeal the law that bans gay members of the military from living their lives openly.

headline: They’re Right to Be Galled
text: In his budget proposal this week, Mayor Michael Bloomberg had chilling news for New York City’s 300,000 workers. With a $4.9 billion deficit projected for the coming year, he said, the city will have to renegotiate benefits and cut its work force. That was a hard but necessary truth, and Mr. Bloomberg must now steel himself for months of wrestling with the city’s powerful unions.

headline: Lilly and Evelyn
text: On Jan. 29, 2009, in the East Room of the White House, President Obama signed his first bill into law, the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act. It overturned a notorious 5-to-4 Supreme Court decision from 2007 that had denied Ms. Ledbetter restitution for years in which her employer, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, had paid her less than her male colleagues.

headline: J.D. Salinger
text: The last, long stage of J. D. Salinger’s life  the unpublishing of himself  is now over. It began, more or less, when he moved to Cornish, N.H., in 1953, two years after “The Catcher in the Rye” came out. And it ended with his death this week at the age of 91.

headline: Thoughts on the State of the Union
text: To the Editor:

headline: Disagreeing About Fields
text: The shortage of athletic fields in many Bay Area communities affects the number of children who can play Saturday soccer and has led to nasty turf wars.

headline: A View From Kabul: The Election and the Police
text: To the Editor:

headline: FedEx and the Immigrants: What Guatemala Says
text: To the Editor:

headline: Columbia and the Eminent Domain Lawsuit
text: To the Editor:

headline: March of the Peacocks
text: Last week, the Center for American Progress, a think tank with close ties to the Obama administration, published an acerbic essay about the difference between true deficit hawks and showy “deficit peacocks.” You can identify deficit peacocks, readers were told, by the way they pretend that our budget problems can be solved with gimmicks like a temporary freeze in nondefense discretionary spending.

headline: The Perot Option
text: There is a specter haunting America: the specter of a saner, updated version of Ross Perot. He is lurking out there, ready to ride the free-floating anger and distrust of Washington. He is out there now in one of his homes or private jets, getting madder by the day. He is large of ego, full of money and cranky in mien.

headline: Out of Auschwitz
text: Paris

headline: It’s Not Hockey, It’s Bandy
text: ROSEVILLE, Minn.  On a recent 10-degree night in this Twin Cities suburb, two men’s teams skated and stick-handled and zeroed in on goal.

headline: Assessor Candidate Benefits From Property Tax Lawyers
text: By day, Joseph Berrios is the longest-serving member of the three-man board that holds the power to cut the property tax bill for any parcel in Cook County. By night, Mr. Berrios is a master fund-raiser, bringing in about $3 million in political contributions over the last decade from the same lawyers who ask him and the board to give tax breaks to their clients.

headline: A Display of Old Masters
text: “Master Drawings New York,” an annual weeklong constellation of exhibitions, offers a wealth of extraordinary talents.

headline: At Leo High, a Gathering and a Mission
text: A breath-draining climb up three flights of stairs is required to reach the basketball court at Leo High School, but the reward is a trip back through time. Peach baskets would fit the décor of the tiny gym better than the glass backboards that hang there.

headline: Results of Study on Cellphone Use Surprise Researchers
text: Laws banning cellphone use while driving apparently haven’t reduced crashes, according to a study released on Friday that compared the number of total crashes before the ban with the number after. The study found virtually no difference in the numbers, a finding that had the researchers scratching their heads.

headline: Freestyle Skier Is Betting On Making 2014 Olympic Alpine Team
text: ASPEN, Colo.  Jon Olsson figures he will spend close to $500,000 in an attempt to win a $6,000 bet. But when it comes to the calculus of quashing skiing stereotypes, saving face, and breaking down barriers, Olsson, one of the world’s most accomplished freestyle skiers, still figures he will somehow come out ahead.

headline: Still Arguing His Case, Even After All These Years
text: Time stopped in drab Cook County Eviction Court last week as the lawyer George N. Leighton smoothly argued for the Illinois International Port District in a marathon dispute involving a 1965 lease and whether a slip for big ships on the Calumet River was properly dredged.

headline: Word of the Day | vantage
text: vantage •\ˈvan-tij\• noun

headline: Snow Stockpiles Are Said to Be Enough
text: OTTAWA  Emergency snow stockpiles at the resort hosting freestyle skiing and snowboarding for the Winter Olympics in Vancouver are more than ample to cover any further thaw, the organizing committee said Thursday.

headline: Attention Commuters: Stop to Enjoy the Tiles
text: The city’s latest effort to liven the drudgery of commuting as part of its Arts in Transit program was unveiled at the Belmont C.T.A. station on Thursday.

headline: The Pulse: Ultimo Will Close After Four Decades
text: Ultimo, a symbol of European haute couture in Chicago, is closing its doors on Saturday after 40 years.

headline: No Woods, but Plenty of Good Scores at Torrey Pines
text: SAN DIEGO  As a bright orange sun crept toward the western horizon on Thursday, the face of the cliffs of La Jolla took on a reddish hue, as though embarrassed by the sheer beauty that annually reflects off Torrey Pines Golf Course this time of year.

headline: Murder Suspect Caught on Camera
text: From an outdoor security camera, video of a man the police believe to be the killer of an employee at an Upper East Side jewelry store.

headline: Santa Clara’s Stadium Fight and Highlights From Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: Notes From the South Bay Scrimmage | As the San Francisco 49ers continue their courtship with the City of Santa Clara and the voters among its 117,000 residents, the council and the mayor who favor paying for a stadium to attract the football team are riding on a glossy publicity campaign, complete with the likeness of the soccer star Brandi Chastain. Meanwhile, the opponents are running on shoe leather. A local election, most likely on June 8, will determine whether the city puts up $114 million to help the 49ers leave Candlestick Park in San Francisco and play in Silicon Valley beginning in 2014.

headline: The Rules of the Road in Open Relationships
text: My column this week looks at the prevalence of open relationships in the gay community. A new study from San Francisco State University estimates that half of the gay male couples in the Bay Area have this arrangement.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Blackhawks Pip Sharks in Clash of Western Titans
text: Seven games on Thursday night, and the big one was the last one, Chicago at San Jose, for the league lead. A 60-minute win on this night would put the Hawks atop the N.H.L.; anything less would leave the Sharks on top. But first, the other games. Home teams listed first:

headline: In Packaging of Loans, a Bust With a Pedigree
text: Real estate securitization was one of the great innovations in finance in the last quarter-century. In an unprecedented way, it allowed vast sums of money to go into the real estate market from people who traditionally did not take part in it. But the people making the loans did not need to worry if they would be repaid, and in the end the entire edifice collapsed.

headline: Art-astrophes
text: WHO painted the painting shown here, which was damaged when a wrecking ball came through the wall of the house where it was hanging and “shot a perfect hole through the canvas”?

headline: News Quiz | January 29, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: New York Mellon Said to Eye PNC’s Global Unit
text: Bank of New York Mellon is in talks to buy PNC Financial Services Group‘s global investment-servicing unit for as much as $2.5 billion to add hedge-fund and mutual-fund clients, a person familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: BHP Buys Potash Producer in Canada
text: BHP Billiton, the global mining giant, said Thursday it had agreed to acquire Canadian potash explorer Athabasca Potash for 341 million Canadian dollars ($323 million) in cash, expanding its asset base in the potash-rich Canadian province of Saskatchewan.

headline: Barclays Seeks Dismissal of Lehman’s Lawsuit
text: When is a secret $5 billion windfall profit not a secret or a windfall?

headline: China Manufacturer Prices I.P.O. to Raise $1.7 Billion
text: China First Heavy Industries has set the price range for its Shanghai initial public offering at 5 to 5.80 renminbi, which could raise 11.6 billion renminbi ($1.7 billion) in China’s biggest I.P.O. this year, Reuters reported.

headline: From Finance to Fine Skis: A Banker’s Trajectory
text: Benedikt Germanier, while still a senior currency strategist at UBS, decided that he had become just another battery hen on a trading floor where money was everything that counted. So he ditched his bonus and banker life in the United States to make skis, Bloomberg News writes.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Books and Authors?
text: In his obituary of J.D. Salinger, Charles McGrath writes, “Reading ‘Catcher’ used to be an essential rite of passage, almost as important as getting your learner’s permit.” What are the books and authors that have been “essential” for you, whether you read them as a child or recently?

headline: U.S. U-20 Women Qualify
text: Goals by Kristie Mewis and Teresa Noyola gave the United States women’s under-20 national team a 2-1 win over Costa Rica in Guatemala City in a semifinal game of regional qualifying for the world championships this summer in Germany. The victory means the United States has qualified for the FIFA U-20 Women’s World Cup, regardless of the outcome of the Concacaf championship game.

headline: Delphi’s Asia Business Bought by Autoliv
text: Autoliv, the global seatbelt and airbag maker, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy the Asian auto safety business of United States auto parts maker Delphi for an undisclosed sum, Reuters reported.

headline: New Trial Sought for French Ex-Premier
text: PARIS  French prosecutors will appeal the judgment clearing former Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of complicity in an effort to tarnish his rival, the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, the Paris state prosecutor announced on Friday.

headline: SouthGobi Shares Take a Dive on First Day
text: SouthGobi Energy Resources, the Canadian-listed coal miner, saw its shares fall about 11 percent on their Hong Kong debut, hurt by the stock’s overly high valuation and poor timing, Reuters reported.

headline: Citing 9/11, Blair Defends Legacy at Iraq Inquiry
text: LONDON — Almost seven years after he ordered British troops to join the American-led invasion of Iraq, former Prime Minister Tony Blair mounted an unwavering defense of his actions on Friday, saying he would take the same steps again to counter what he depicted as a threat from Saddam Hussein that had assumed far greater dimensions after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Developed Market Funds Suffer Redemptions
text: Investor concerns about tightening lending conditions in China and deteriorating finances in Greece and Japan led them to pull cash out of developed market equity funds and invest in debt funds in the week ended Jan. 27, fund tracker EPFR Global said late on Thursday.

headline: Allianz Executive Dampens Swiss Life Rumors
text: Investors hoping that Swiss Life would be gobbled up by Allianz may be disappointed to hear that the German insurer isn’t on the hunt for any big deals.

headline: Judge Denies WaMu Request for Deal Documents
text: A Delaware bankruptcy judge on Thursday denied Washington Mutual‘s request to force government regulators and others to turn over documents related to the 2008 collapse of Washington Mutual Bank, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Worried Bankers Reach Out From the Sidelines
text: Chief executives of the world’s biggest banks, including Bank of America and Deutsche Bank, met with policymakers in Davos on Thursday afternoon, concerned that their interests and opinions about financial regulation are going unheard.

headline: Information Curtain
text: Hillary Clinton’s Churchillian description of Internet censorship.

headline: Lee A. Archer, Ace Tuskegee Airman and V.C., Dies
text: Retired Air Force Lt. Colonel Lee A. Archer, a Tuskegee Airman considered to be the only black ace pilot who also broke racial barriers as an executive at a major U.S. company and founder of a venture capital firm, died Wednesday in New York City. He was 90.

headline: Davos in the Media: Bank Reform and Resistance
text: There were three hot topics buzzing around the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday: banking reform, banking reform and more banking reform.

headline: Bank Tax Is Knotty Issue for New York Senators
text: President Obama’s proposal to impose new taxes on large banks is testing the ties that New York’s United States senators have with Wall Street, a pillar of the state’s economy and a major source of their campaign dollars, The New York Times’s Raymond Hernandez writes.

headline: Lackluster Economic News Pushes Market Lower
text: Wall Street was hit with a string of disappointments on Thursday: a weaker-than-expected unemployment picture, a tepid recovery in manufacturing and skepticism about technology companies, including concerns about Apple’s tablet device.

headline: S.E.C. Settles Stockman Lawsuit
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had reached a tentative settlement of a civil lawsuit against David A. Stockman, a former budget director in the Reagan administration and a private equity investor. Terms of the tentative settlement were not disclosed.

headline: Inexpensive Gene Tests for Parents-to-Be
text: The new movie “Extraordinary Measures” is based on the true story of a father who starts a company to develop a treatment for a rare genetic disease threatening to kill two of his children before they turn 10.

headline: Gates Foundation to Double Spending on Vaccines
text: Endorsing vaccines as the world’s most cost-effective public health measure, Bill and Melinda Gates said Friday that their foundation would more than double its spending on them over the next decade, to at least $10 billion.

headline: Favre and a Battering by Fate
text: Larry Canale is a columnist at Tuff Stuff’s Sports Collectors Monthly and editor in chief of the monthly newsletter Antiques Roadshow Insider (insert your own joke about Brett Favre being an antique).

headline: Global Leaders Struggle With Bank Regulation
text: The conversation among business and government leaders at the World Economic Forum no longer revolves around whether to regulate the banking industry more sharply, but rather how to do so.

headline: Speed Read For Friday, Jan. 29
text: Highlights from Friday’s media coverage in The New York Times:

headline: For Relaxation in Mumbai, Try a Massage
text: In this often overwhelming city, weary dwellers have a robust selection of affordable massage and reflexology outposts to choose from, depending on their privacy standards and the body part in need of a knead.

headline: Marx, God and Faith in the Markets
text: The Bible is revolutionary, declared a certain Mr. Marx.

headline: Biogen Confirms Icahn’s Bid for 3 Board Seats
text: Biogen Idec confirmed on Thursday it has received notice from Carl C. Icahn that he intends to nominate three people to its board as he seeks to expand his influence at one of the world’s biggest biotech companies.

headline: Chinese Leader Offers a Glimpse of the Future
text: China gave the world a glimpse of the next generation of Chinese leaders on Thursday when Li Keqiang, widely expected to be the next prime minister, vowed that his country would act swiftly to shift from an over-reliance on exports toward greater domestic consumption.

headline: An Evening on Cameron’s Pandora
text: James Cameron, director of “Avatar,” clearly struck a chord with some of the depressed bankers and gloomy businessmen in Davos when he told them at an exclusive evening session about his blockbuster film that his aim was “to put a global audience into a lucid dream state.”

headline: Champions Spar as McLaren Mercedes Launches MP4-25
text: Well now, that was fun. I did not go to England for the McLaren launch, but I felt like I was there – as did plenty of the readers of this blog, I’m sure. The McLaren launch just finished a few seconds ago, and the whole thing was visible online over a nearly perfect Internet connection. I thought I was watching television.

headline: ‘Long Tail’ Becomes Longer Tale
text: Today’s idea: Welcome to the “long tail” of manufacturing. “If the past 10 years have been about discovering post-institutional social models on the Web, then the next 10 years will be about applying them to the real world,” writes Chris Anderson.

headline: Looking for Women in Wall Street’s Top Ranks
text: When Sallie Krawcheck was hired six months ago as president of global wealth and investment management at Bank of America, she was besieged with e-mail messages from current and former Wall Street women celebrating her return to the fray.

headline: Federer, Making Quick Work of Tsonga, Will Face Murray in Final
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  So much for all the pretournament talk about how Roger Federer was distracted, aging and vulnerable at the Australian Open, and how 8 to 10 players were ready to knock him from his throne. After filleting Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France in straight sets, now there is only one: Andy Murray, the scrambling Scotsman.

headline: Cuomo to Sue Vantage Properties for Harassment
text: New York State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said he intended to sue a major landlord that he accuses of harassing hundreds of tenants in rent-regulated apartments in Queens and Manhattan in a systematic effort to force their departure to create vacancies for higher-paying tenants, The New York Times’s Charles V. Bagli reported.

headline: No Such Thing as ‘Simple’ Health Reform
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Former BofA Chief Gives Moynihan High Marks
text: Hugh McColl Jr., who built Bank of America into the behemoth it is today, apparently feels really good about the bank’s new chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan.

headline: Switzerland Tries to Lure British Financiers
text: It seems that Switzerland is making full-court press to persuade British-based investment bankers and hedge fund managers to pack their suitcases and head for a low-tax enclave.

headline: Burkle Said to Offer to Take Control of Barneys
text: Ronald Burkle has offered to invest at least $50 million in Barneys New York in order to take control of the luxury department store operator, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Seeing Through the Apple (and ‘Avatar’) Hyperbole
text: There are a few similarities between Wednesday’s Apple announcement and the blockbuster movie “Avatar.” They both cost many millions of dollars and took many years to produce. They both required vast amounts of technology to build, and of course they will both make hundreds of millions of dollars for their respective companies. But they will also share another category: too much hype before their launch, and a result that comes across as intriguing and entertaining, yet sadly anticlimactic.

headline: JPMorgan Said to Plan Global Corporate Bank Unit
text: JPMorgan Chase is launching a worldwide business aimed at selling loans and commercial banking services to multinational corporations, the Financial Times reported.

headline: After Stuyvesant Default — ‘TrumpTown’?
text: Will the sprawling Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village Manhattan apartment complex one day be known as “TrumpTown”?

headline: Sampler: Palo Alto to Plant Trees and San Jose to Consider Tree Maintenance Tax
text: BART to Avoid Fare Increases, for Now | On Thursday, BART directors said they would not raise fares or cut service to help close a $25.2 million shortfall in the current budget. Although the transportation agency said it would cut 74 positions, 55 of those are vacant, 12 employees can transfer to another job and the number to be laid off can be reduced further if there is more turnover. BART will also rely on $19.2 million in stimulus and other funds to help close the gap. Proposals, like imposing a surcharge of 10 or 25 cents for rides through the Transbay Tube, were bypassed for now. “We believe those charges would have a negative impact on our already soft ridership,” said Carter Mau, BART’s executive manager for planning and budgets. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: As Bonuses Shrink, Goldman Said to Offer Loans
text: After The Wall Street Journal reported that banks were doling out other financial perks to their employees to ease the toll taken by the slimmer bonuses, Gawker got busy investigating Goldman Sachs‘s lending practices.

headline: Black Named as JPMorgan Vice Chairman
text: Steven D. Black, the executive chairman of JPMorgan Chase‘s investment bank, was named a vice chairman of the firm on Thursday, as part of a plan to give more responsibility to the investment banking head, James E. Staley.

headline: So How’s Holden Caulfield Holding Up?
text: Right-thinking ArtsBeat readers can agree that J.D. Salinger was no phony. The Times’s chief book critic, Michiko Kakutani, writes in an appraisal that the author, who died Wednesday at 91, had “unerring radar for the feelings of teenage angst and vulnerability and anger,” and that “The Catcher in the Rye,” published in 1951, “remains one of the books that adolescents first fall in love with — a book that intimately articulates what it is to be young and sensitive and precociously existential.”

headline: Shares Fall for the Day, the Month and the Year
text: For those on Wall Street who believe in omens, crystal balls or just plain historical precedent, Friday was not a day to rejoice.

headline: Overcoming the Ugly Factor in Building-Integrated Solar Design
text: The idea of integrating solar power with building materials has been an attractive concept for decades, but one of the biggest challenges, according to Anna Dyson, director of the Center for Architecture Science and Ecology, or CASE, has been aesthetics.

headline: Live From Davos, Day 3: The Bankers Meet
text: Good morning from Davos, where the topic of the day isn’t anything that happened during the official panels of the World Economic Forum.

text: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, please send them one per comment:

headline: The Early Word: Business in Baltimore
text: Two days after calling for more cooperation between Democrats and Republicans, President Obama heads to Baltimore for a discussion with House Republicans at their retreat.

headline: U.S. Economy Grew at Vigorous Pace in Last Quarter
text: The United States economy grew at its fastest pace in more than six years at the end of 2009, even as businesses resisted hiring and continued to do more with less.

headline: Snake Charmer | Chrissie Morris, Cobbler
text: The London-based shoe wizard Chrissie Morris had a lot on her mind when she designed this multifunctional stiletto of rock python, stingray and suede. Inspired by the cagelike structure inside a Gothic church cupola, the shoe has a detachable suede ankle strap (not shown) so you can wear it — get this — three different ways. It’s not exactly cheap ($1,390 at kirnazabete.com), but this kind of ingenuity is oh so New Economy.

headline: Real Estate Is Top Giver to Cuomo Campaign
text: As Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo readies his candidacy for governor, one industry is helping him amass a huge fund-raising advantage: real estate.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Teaches Jay Leno the Meaning of ‘Sucker Punch’
text: The momentary disappearance of Conan O’Brien from the airwaves brought peace to the late-night landscape for, oh, about four days. On Thursday night, the surviving combatants were reapplying their war paint as the ABC host Jimmy Kimmel used his monologue to rebut Jay Leno, who said that Mr. Kimmel had “sucker-punched” him in an earlier interview on Mr. Leno’s show. And by rebut, we mean pound him mercilessly.

headline: Danica Patrick Announces 12-Race Nascar Schedule
text: Danica Patrick said Thursday that she planned to compete this year in at least 12 races on the Nascar Nationwide Series, the second highest level in the sport. Officials at the racetracks where she expects to compete promptly stomped on their marketing accelerators to sell tickets.

headline: Bin Laden Adds Climate Change to List of Grievances Against U.S.
text: Osama bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda, blamed the United States and developed countries for not halting climate change and said that the global economy should immediately abandon its reliance on the American dollar, according to an audiotape released Friday by the broadcaster Al Jazeera.

headline: The Blip Cometh
text: As expected, a big GDP number (pdf), signifying nothing much. It’s an inventory blip: topline growth at 5.7 percent, but only 2.2 of that is final demand.

headline: Sexing Up Ukrainian Politics
text: The annual lunch hosted by Ukrainian powerbroker and philanthropist Viktor Pinchuk in Davos has often been a bellwether for the tangled politics of the huge country of 46 million sandwiched between Russia and Europe.

headline: Private Equity Is Bullish on Clean Energy
text: With strong interest from corporations eyeing the clean energy sector, 2010 could turn out to be a good time for private equity and venture capital firms to pursue investments.

headline: Complaint Box | Ubiquitous Pets
text: This week’s Complaint Box features two views on dogs in public, from Barbara Rosenblatt and Erica Manfred.

headline: Massachusetts Sets Ambitious Energy Standards
text: Massachusetts state officials on Friday announced new energy efficiency standards for utilities that aim to be the most ambitious in the nation.

headline: Breakfast at Melbourne, More or Less
text: The women’s and men’s finals of the Australian Open will be shown live this weekend when many people in the United States will be asleep. But each match will then be shown on tape several times.

headline: 'The Planets'
text: An excerpt from the HD visual presentation, produced  by the filmmaker Duncan Copp, featuring Gustav Holst's score. Courtesy of the Houston Symphony.

headline: Migraines Force Sufferers to Do Their Homework
text: MIGRAINES may be right up there with root canals and childbirth as one of life’s more painful experiences. But unlike childbirth or dental surgery  the pain of which can be dulled with standard medications  migraines are notoriously tricky to treat.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
text: Are comic books the new lease on life for television series that have ended their runs? There certainly seem to be more adventures in store for characters created by Joss Whedon. He’s already been involved in the comic-book version of Season 8 of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” which is published by Dark Horse. (There are even plans to reunite her with – spoiler alert! – Angel). This week, another of Mr. Whedon’s television creations enters our softcover list at No. 3. “Serenity: Better Days” continues the journey of the space-faring crew from the 2002 television series “Firefly.” The show was canceled early in its first season, but its characters returned in the 2005 film “Serenity” and as a comic book, “Serenity: Those Left Behind.”

headline: Liberals and Incrementalism
text: This Mark Schmitt piece on the tug-of-war within liberalism dovetails with some of the themes I’ve been exploring lately. He writes:

headline: Another View: The Revenge of the Luddites?
text: Michael Pagano, a finance professor at Villanova, argues that the Volcker Rule resembles another attempt to turn back progress — namely, the Luddite movement of nearly 200 years ago.

headline: Bain Capital Invests $12 Million in Edgar Online
text: Bain Capital said Friday that it has invested $12 million in Edgar Online, a publicly traded data services company that helps businesses prepare regulatory filings in a new format that will be mandatory by 2012.

headline: The Spectacle of West Bank Protests
text:
With a stalled peace process, Israeli soldiers and Palestinian protesters clash violently each Friday. 
The skirmishes are a combination of desperate activism and staged theater.

headline: Vance Starts Greasing the Rusted Wheels of Change
text: He strolled into the mostly empty room on Wednesday, jolly as can be. He looked the part of a public figure, with his black suit, navy blue tie stamped with small ducks, and tortoiseshell glasses.

headline: Google vs. China: Considering Threats to Internet Freedom
text: Overview | What threats exist to Internet freedom, and how can people and democratic governments combat them? In this lesson, students imagine how they might communicate, and evade censors, if they were antigovernment activists. They then look more closely at the issues involved in the dispute between Google and China and develop ideas for how Google or the United States government should respond. Finally, they do independent research to learn more about the types of information that the Chinese government has sought to block online.

headline: Friday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Inside the List
text: I AM PATTI: “Just Kids,” the new memoir by Patti Smith, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 7 — not bad for a singer who had precisely one hit single, “Because the Night,” which reached No. 13 on the pop charts in 1978. It may also be a rare moment of punk poetic justice in a book market that tends to be friendlier to the likes of Tori Spelling and Kathy Griffin than to defiantly un-Botoxed middle-aged rockers. And then there’s poor Ozzy Osbourne, marooned at No. 26 on the extended list with “I Am Ozzy.” In an epilogue called “Patient Notes,” the now drug-free sexagenarian confesses he’d still like to have a No. 1 album in America but is realistic about what will be on his headstone: “I ain’t under any illusions. If I close my eyes, I can already see it: ‘Ozzy Osbourne, born, 1948. Died, whenever. He bit the head off a bat.’ ”

headline: Performers Plan More Charity Projects For Haiti
text: Entertainment personalities are continuing their efforts to raise awareness and money for the earthquake relief effort in Haiti. On Thursday, BET Networks said that it would hold a benefit concert and celebrity telethon for Haitian charity organizations, to be presented on several cable channels on the night of Feb. 5. The event, to be called “SOS Saving Ourselves – Help For Haiti,” will take place at the AmericanAirlines Arena in Miami and will be hosted by Queen Latifah;, Sean Combs, known as Diddy; and Pharrell Williams. It is to be shown from 8 to 10 p.m. Eastern time on BET, MTV, VH1 and the Centric channel, with proceeds going to charity organizations like Yéle Haiti, CARE, Project Medishare and Children’s Safe Drinking Water. A full lineup of artists for the concert has not been announced, but Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-born musician and founder of Yéle Haiti, is expected to perform at the event.

headline: Law Has Little Effect on Early Release for Inmates
text: COXSACKIE, N.Y.  With his swollen legs and a throaty rasp that whistles like a kettle through his broken teeth, Eddie Jones is an unlikely man to make history.

headline: Musical Planets, and Real Ones
text: Like an alien’s scarred cranium, an orange Mars rose slowly above the stage of Carnegie Hall. Later, Venus hung suspended, an alabaster orb in the darkness. Strips of Jupiter’s surface of swirling colors looked like canvases of abstract art. Moons made guest appearances.

headline: Tony Blair on Iraq: ‘No Regrets’
text: Update | 1:09 p.m.  No Regrets.

headline: Weekend Competition: Malapropisms
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit malapropisms – either those they have overheard or those of which they are guilty.

headline: How Times Have Changed (or Not) for Deals
text: The financial markets are returning to measurable health and consequently private equity firms are now doing deals more frequently, even those particularly hurt. Apollo Management, scarred by the Huntsman/Hexion acquisition, has a pending acquisition of Cedar Fair, and TPG, which posted a $1.35 billion loss after its investment in Washington Mutual, is acquiring IMS Health. About a week ago, Lone Star Funds agreed to acquire Lodgian in a deal valued at $270 million.

text: BALTIMORE — It’s the rumble in Baltimore as House Republicans take on President Obama today.

headline: McDonald’s Goes Local
text: Pete Confalone, an old friend and a faithful correspondent who lives in Miami, sends this hilarious clip from the Huffington Post. Italy has arranged with McDonald’s to use local produce and traditional flavors on a couple of burgers. This is along the lines of making a Mickey D’s burger with (sugary sweet) barbecue sauce to somehow regionalize it — but is it better (i.e., artichoke puree is good stuff) or worse (i.e. it puts a friendlier face on fast food)? More amusing than monstrous, I suppose, but your comments?

text: Phoenix

headline: Obama Offers a More Generous Tax Credit for Hiring
text: This morning, as President Obama visits a small business in Baltimore to unveil a temporary tax credit to encourage the hiring of new employees, The Agenda would like to fill you in on the details. The initiative, which would require Congress’s assent, is more generous than earlier versions that have floated around Washington, and it’s tailored more specifically for small businesses.

headline: Art of the Road Trip | Mark Dion’s Souvenirs
text: In the catalog for the artist Mark Dion’s project “Travels of William Bartram — Reconsidered,” now on view at the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery, Dion is quoted as saying, “I like things — not pictures or facsimiles of things.” This is a little like Michael Bloomberg saying he likes being mayor: inarguably true, and more than a bit of an understatement.

headline: Slurping Through Tokyo
text: Back in 1993, when I was a sophomore in college, I came across a movie that changed my life: “Tampopo,” the charming tale of a truck driver who comes to the aid of a young, beleaguered widow who’s struggling to raise a child—and run a ramen shop. The movie, directed by the late Juzo Itami, is all about food—about the intricacies of making ramen and eating ramen, about slurping noodles, about the ways that what we eat and how we eat make us who we are.

headline: Co-op Buyer Looks for a ‘Bridge’
text: Q.

headline: Packed With Guilty Pleasures
text: BETHLEHEM, N.H.

headline: The Night Belongs to Us
text: Apart from a certain shared apprehension of immortality — complacent in one case, but endearingly gingerly in the other — the skinny 28-year-old on the cover of Patti Smith’s seismic 1975 album, “Horses,” doesn’t look much at all like Picasso’s portrait of Gertrude Stein. But because the shutterbug was Robert Mapplethorpe, who was soon to become fairly legendary himself, that exquisite photograph of Smith on the brink of fame is as close as New York’s 1970s avant-garde ever came to a comparable twofer. The mythmaking bonus is that the latter-day duo were much more genuinely kindred spirits.

headline: Bad Choices
text: A Robert Stone character is often in a position to do harm or good, and his inclination is often to choose harm. This harm is as frequently to the protagonist himself as it is to others — the characters in Stone’s new collection, “Fun With Problems,” are, like many in contemporary fiction, dangerous mostly to themselves. But what distinguishes Stone’s men and women is that they realize it. They are conscious of their bad decisions, which prevents them from resembling that more ordinary fictional bungler, the still-waters-run-deep guy hatched by Hemingway and subsequently adopted by an unending stream of male American story writers.

headline: The Question of Quality
text: A LONGTIME Land Rover strength is its off-road ability, but a serious weakness is its reliability, according to two leading research organizations, Consumer Reports and J. D. Power & Associates.

headline: Pen and Brush Town House Sale Looks Likely
text: Pen and Brush, a nonprofit space in Greenwich Village for public exhibitions and performances and earlier a private club where women gathered for teas and dinner, has found a buyer for its historic town house on East 10th Street, its executive director, Janice Sands, confirmed on Friday.

headline: A Tenement Transformed Tells the Lives of Its Squatters
text: When Andrew Castrucci moved into a tenement on East 3rd Street in 1986, he arrived not with a real estate agent and a new set of keys but with two accomplices who stood watch as he used a 10-pound sledgehammer to smash through cinder blocks filling a rear door to the derelict building.

headline: Faithless Love
text: The photos lying on her lover’s desk depicted a young, naked, pregnant woman photographing herself, legs apart, in front of a mirror. In his notebook, also lying open (or was it closed?), beside the photos, was an entry about “Blandine” — not the pregnant woman, another one — where he wrote of his great desire for her. “She’s so beautiful!” Thus Catherine Millet’s hellacious ordeal began with not one but two women, naked, fertile, beautiful and, of course, younger. When she confronted her partner, Jacques Henric, on the phone with her discovery of the two women, he generously promised, when he returned from a trip, to “tell me all about the affairs he had had with five or six women.” Alas, the hollandaise has already thickened. And so Millet is catapulted down the rabbit hole of jealousy, from which there is little chance of return — and never to innocence.

headline: From Spyker to Saab, a Quest for Miracles
text: THE top executives at most car companies can rattle off the names of their models. Victor R. Muller can tell you the names of his customers.

headline: Shifting Gears
text: Are you the kind of person who instinctively hates the fact that foreign companies are investing billions of dollars in some of America’s most depressed regions, creating millions of well-paying jobs and acting as an engine of growth and prosperity? Me neither.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Shipments of California wine fell last year for the first time in 16 years, The Los Angeles Times reports. “Consumption of wine is up 2.1% nationally, but industry analyst Jon Fredrikson told the audience at the annual Unified Wine & Grape Symposium on Wednesday that the American public was snubbing tonier bottles from the Golden State and instead opting for cheaper bulk wine imports from overseas winemakers.” And in Australia, imports are up and the value of Australian wine sales are down.

headline: Travel Deals: Valentine’s Day Getaways
text: Several hotels and tour companies are offering sweetheart deals, some lasting the entire month of February.

headline: Prove It
text: Imagine, if you can, a novel that imbues pot roast, green beans and scalloped potatoes with Gnostic import — not just evoking the aroma of Sundays past, with their “old orderliness, aloof from all disruption,” as in Marilynne Robinson’s last novel, “Home,” but embodying specific doctrinal precepts and divine mysteries. Reason recoils. Yet, in the philosopher-novelist Rebecca Newberger Goldstein’s latest work of fiction, “36 Arguments for the Existence of God,” the rotund and orotund Jonas Elijah Klapper, the “Extreme Distinguished Professor of Faith, Literature and Values” at Frankfurter University (think of Brandeis), proposes the traditional Jewish Sabbath meal of cholent (bean and potato stew) and kugel (pudding) to his overawed grad student, Cass Seltzer, as a worthy dissertation topic. And he’s not kidding. “All of the dishes have kabbalist significance,” he tells Seltzer. “The tzaddikim, or righteous ones, proclaimed that there are profound matters enfolded in the kugel.”

headline: The Way We Learn
text: In the four rigorously reasonable essays in “The Marketplace of Ideas,” Louis Menand takes up four questions about American higher education: “Why is it so hard to institute a general education curriculum? Why did the humanities disciplines undergo a crisis of legitimation? Why has ‘interdisciplinarity’ become a magic word? And why do professors all tend to have the same politics?”

headline: It’s a Family Affair: Sly Stone Sues Manager
text: Sly Stone has filed a lawsuit against his longtime manager, Jerry Goldstein, saying that Mr. Goldstein defrauded him of “tens of millions of dollars” in royalties for more than 20 years, and that he registered a trademark for the name Sly and the Family Stone without permission. In the suit, filed on Thursday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Sly Stone (whose real name is Sylvester Stewart) and another former manager, Ken Roberts, request an accounting of royalties and unspecified financial damages that their lawyers estimate at $20 million to $30 million. (The musician previously told his side of the story in this 2008 profile in Vanity Fair.)

headline: Haitian Lawmakers Seek to Delay Elections
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Lawmakers in the lower house of Haiti’s Parliament plan to ask President René Préval to postpone upcoming elections and instead extend their terms of office by two years, United Nations officials said on Friday.

headline: Glory Days
text: By all rights, sidemen should be the ones with the best stories in rock ’n’ roll. Lead singers, burdened by the requisite narcissism and constant media presence, seem unlikely to open up and reveal much. The other band members are the ones with front-row seats for the madness and less public image to preserve.

headline: The Nifty 50 | Matt Bomer, Actor
text: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America’s up-and-coming talent.

headline: Tom, Dick and Carlin
text: Two new books center on the collision between comedy and the old establishment. “Last Words,” a posthumous autobiography from George Carlin, is a jazzy, inward-looking piece of work. Its strength lies in its documentation of how this great comedian made the trip from a happy-to-be-here entertainer of the 1960s to the salt-in-the-wound ­philosopher-comic of the 1970s and beyond. “Dangerously Funny: The Uncensored Story of ‘The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour,’ ” by the veteran television critic David Bianculli, is a straightforward chronicle that charts the rise and fall of a charming double act cut down in its prime by annoyed CBS executives.

headline: Smiley’s People
text: Twenty years ago, the subject of this vast and fascinating book did not, officially speaking, exist at all. The Security Service, better known as MI5, is the domestic arm of British intelligence. While its sister organization, MI6, supplies the British government with foreign intelligence, MI5 is responsible for counterintelligence, countersubversion, counterterrorism and security within the United Kingdom.

headline: With Recall Expanding, Toyota Gives an Apology
text: DETROIT — The president of Toyota issued his first apology Friday as his troubled automaker expanded its recall to include Europe and it rushed to complete its strategy to modify or replace millions of accelerator pedals.

headline: Honda Recalls 141,000 Fits in U.S. for Window Issue
text: Honda said it was recalling about 141,000 2007–8 Honda Fits in the United States because of a fire hazard involving the power-window switch.

headline: Finding the Right Migraine Treatment
text: While watching my daughter’s volleyball practice from the sidelines recently, I struck up a conversation with another mom who looked, quite frankly, awful. “Migraine,” she explained, wincing as she spoke.

headline: Race to the Top, but Not to the Web
text: After scores of states applied for a competitive education grant known as Race to the Top last week, the vast majority of states posted their applications online for all to see.

headline: Postcolonial Everyman
text: Chinua Achebe has a real knack for titles. With its simple assertion that “Things Fall Apart,” Achebe’s now classic 1958 novel took Yeats’s horrified imaginings of Christian Europe’s apocalyptic end and made them resonate within the space of precolonial black Africa. Now, some 50 years later, Achebe has given this volume of autobiographical essays its own Pandora’s box of a title. Deceptively disarming, “The Education of a British-­Protected Child” belies the complexity of what he calls the “strongly multiethnic, multilingual, multireligious, somewhat chaotic” situation he was born into as a colonial subject whose first passport described him as a “British Protected Person.” As the 16 essays in this collection reveal, the “education” Achebe and his fellow Nigerians received from their exploitative and racist self-proclaimed protectors “would not be a model of perfection.” Indeed.

headline: California Officials Would Not Regulate Electric Car Charging Firms
text: California officials have indicated they are not inclined to regulate electric car infrastructure companies that plan to sell electricity to drivers through networks of charging stations.

headline: Abortion Foe Found Guilty in Doctor’s Killing
text: WICHITA, Kan.  In the end, it took jurors 37 minutes on Friday to convict Scott Roeder, an abortion opponent, of first-degree murder in the death of George R. Tiller, one of the few doctors in the country to perform late-term abortions.

headline: Clinton Warns China on Iran Sanctions
text: PARIS  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned China on Friday that it would face economic insecurity and diplomatic isolation if it did not sign on to tough new sanctions against Iran for its nuclear program, seeking to raise the pressure on Beijing to fall in line with an American-led campaign.

headline: Canada’s Supreme Court Says Inmate’s Rights Were Violated at Guantánamo
text: OTTAWA  The Supreme Court of Canada ruled Friday that Canadian agents violated the rights of the only Canadian citizen held at the Guantánamo Bay detention center when they interrogated him there. But the ruling, the second concerning the man’s politically sensitive case, does not order the government to demand his return to Canada, as he has long requested.

headline: Après le Déluge
text: Paris may be known as the City of Light, but “the City of Water” would be just as apt. Since its origins as an island outpost in the middle of the Seine, the city owes some of its greatest advantages — its trading routes, military security and fertile farmland — to its riverside position. That placement has also, however, long made Paris vulnerable to flooding. The city’s Roman name, Lutetia, is said to derive from the Latin word for mud (lutum), and one of its oldest neighborhoods, the Marais, was originally just that: a marsh. In 814, an unnamed author remarked that “when God wants to punish the people of Paris by water, he sends such a flood and overflows the river Seine.” Divine retribution or not, the deluge is an age-old Parisian problem and accounts for its otherwise improbable-sounding motto: Fluctuat nec Mergitur (“She is tossed about by the waves but does not sink”).

headline: Cast Away
text: Who remembers the last survivors of Muslim Spain, whom Spaniards contemptuously called Moriscos (“little Moors”)? Impressive research on them has appeared in the last 30 years, yet until now, none of it has escaped beyond the walls of the academic ghetto. Matthew Carr’s well-balanced and comprehensive book brings the story of their tragic fate to a wider public.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Marines Invest in Local Afghan Projects
text: BOGRABAD, Afghanistan  Abdul Salam, an elder in this impoverished Afghan village, rose to meet the approaching Marines and Navy corpsman. Behind him, his mosque had a new concrete floor and two windows. Last month, before the Marines paid him to refurbish it, the mosque was windowless and had a dirt floor.

headline: The Rap on Happiness
text: Smart people often talk trash about happiness, and worse than trash about books on happiness, and they have been doing so for centuries — just as long as other people have been pursuing happiness and writing books about it. The fashion is to bemoan happiness studies and positive psychology as being the work not of the Devil (the Devil is kind of cool), but of morons. “No mockery in this world ever sounds to me so hollow as that of being told to cultivate happiness,” Charlotte Brontë wrote in 1853. “What does such advice mean? Happiness is not a potato, to be planted in mould and tilled with manure.”

headline: U.N. Mission Head in Afghanistan Met With Taliban Envoys
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Members of the Taliban leadership met with a United Nations official earlier this month to discuss the possibility of entering into face-to-face peace talks with the Afghan government, American and United Nations officials said Friday.

headline: Tax Tips for the Unemployed and Financially Distressed
text: If you’ve lost your job, or suffered a big drop in income, you may have a significantly different tax situation from previous years.

headline: Davos Diary on CNBC: Washington on Everyone’s Minds
text: We can’t stress this enough: Washington is the dominant topic at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this year. Between the panels and at the parties, political and business leaders from around the world keep asking whether or not the Obama administration can pull off its ambitious initiatives.

headline: Talking About a Revolution (for a Digital Age)
text: “IT is time to blow the whole thing up.” In September 1960, when those words were lobbed at the world by a New York-centric, off-Hollywood circle of malcontents called the New American Cinema Group, there was no mistaking their radical urgency. Given the cold war times  one of the first large ban-the-bomb rallies had been held in Madison Square Garden some months earlier  this call to annihilation might have seemed tasteless. But for this group, whose numbers included the film critic, later filmmaker Jonas Mekas and the not-yet-director Peter Bogdanovich, the time for a free American cinema, one rooted in personal vision and liberated from censorship and the distribution and exhibition strangleholds, was now.

headline: BlackRock Hires Former Goldman Banker
text: BlackRock said Friday that it had hired a former Goldman Sachs banker, Kendrick R. Wilson, to be a vice chairman and help support the firm’s client relations as the firm solidifies its position as one of the world’s largest asset managers. Mr. Wilson’s large Rolodex could help BlackRock’s win new clients as well as help it gain a louder voice in Washington.

headline: Bair Offers Guarded Praise for Trading Curb Limits
text: Sheila Bair, the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said on Friday that proposed proprietary trading limits are “very positive,” but said they would not have necessarily reined in risk-taking at the institutions that required huge bailouts.

headline: The Financial Side to Paternity Leave
text: Our colleagues over at the Motherlode blog note that the British government has just approved a paid paternity leave system that allows men to stay home for up to three months, under certain circumstances, to take care of a newly arrived child.

headline: Memories of Salinger, From Blog to Blog
text: The death of J. D. Salinger, whose life remained private in a way few celebrities could imagine possible for today (Tiger Woods en tête), left many blogging in the blanks of his life or else reliving those few moments, literary or otherwise, they spent with the man.

headline: Teacher Q | What Are Your Favorite and Least Favorite Books to Teach?
text: I taught “The Scarlet Letter” eight times in my classroom career, and got to the point where I could reel off whole passages by memory.

headline: Another Push for Wine Sales in Groceries
text: It’s a new year, and a new New York State budget proposal, but it’s the same old deficit. So once again, Gov. David A. Paterson has proposed allowing New York groceries to sell wine as a means of raising revenue through license fees.

headline: Results of Study on Cellphone Use Surprise Researchers
text: Over on our sister blog, Wheels, Cheryl Jensen writes that laws banning cellphone use while driving have not resulted in a reduction in car crashes. The study was conducted by the Highway Loss Data Institute.

headline: Why J. D. Salinger Never Wanted a ‘Catcher in the Rye’ Movie
text: It’s been the dream of many a producer — and perhaps the nightmare of many a faithful reader — that J. D. Salinger‘s novel “The Catcher in the Rye” might someday be translated to another medium. In a report for The Associated Press, Hillel Italie writes that Mr. Salinger considered a stage version of the novel in which he himself would play its teenage protagonist, Holden Caulfield. That (mercifully) never happened; nor did offers for film adaptations from Billy Wilder, Elia Kazan, Steven Spielberg and Harvey Weinstein, all of which the author summarily turned down.

headline: Q. & A. With Reggie Miller
text: Reggie Miller did not hit every big shot of his 18-year N.BA. career against the Knicks, but sometimes it felt that way. Miller, who is remembered as one of the great clutch performers of his generation, is the star of an ESPN documentary, “Winning Time: Reggie Miller vs. the New York Knicks.” The film, which will be broadcast on March 14, highlights the Knicks-Pacers rivalry and focuses on Miller’s legendary performance in the 1995 playoffs. In Game 1 of that series, Miller scored 8 points in 18.7 seconds to break the Knicks’ hearts and give Indiana a come-from-behind victory at Madison Square Garden. Whether it was feuding courtside with Spike Lee or butting heads with Knicks like John Starks, Miller was at the center of the rivalry.

headline: The Importance of Being Ernie
text: Cops love him. So do schoolchildren, and their parents, and nice old ladies, and waiters in Greek diners, and charity bigwigs, and late-night comedians.

headline: On Water Vapor and Warming

headline: Activist Offers Justification for Tampering in Senate Office

Landrieu’s New Orleans office, James O’Keefe III, the conservative advocate, said Friday that he was trying to determine whether Ms. Landrieu was avoiding constituent complaints.

headline: Blueberries Morning, Noon and Night
text: Frozen blueberries are one of the foods I wrote about in “The 11 Best Foods You Aren’t Eating.” These nutrient-rich fruits are available year-round and don’t spoil, and blueberries have been associated with better memory in animal studies.

headline: Leaving Nebraska for Iraq

headline: The University of California to Play the Waiting-List Game
text: For the first time in its history, the University of California is expected to institute waiting lists for incoming applicants, possibly starting this spring. More than 1,000 applicants may be affected.

headline: Oscars Try to Navigate Through Babel
text: THERE was a time when the Academy Award for best foreign-language film reflected the state of world cinema: Fellini films won back-to-back Oscars in the mid 1950s, as did Bergman films in the early ’60s. But the category has come to suggest a peculiar gulf between Academy opinion and the tastes of critics and audiences alike.

headline: Helping the Sax Find a Classical Home
text: THE saxophone, invented by the Belgian-born instrument maker Adolphe Sax around 1840, has seldom achieved prominence in the classical instrumentarium. Master orchestrators like Strauss, Ravel and Rachmaninoff have used it for coloristic purposes, and a number of composers have featured it as a solo instrument. But its chamber repertory is sorely limited, as Matt Levy found when, as a student at the University of Michigan 25 years ago, he started the Prism Quartet, a classical saxophone ensemble.
