text: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland  The skiing great Annemarie Moser-Pröll can rest easier after Saturday’s women’s downhill, in which Lindsey Vonn’s winning streak came to a decisive end.

headline: Vancouver’s Former Mayor Remains Face of the Games
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Millions watched four years ago as Vancouver’s mayor, Sam Sullivan, rolled onto the Olympic stage in Italy. Spasms shot through his legs. The blinding lights felt warm.

headline: Robert Joffe, Cravath Partner, Dies at 66
text: Robert D. Joffe, a leading New York lawyer and partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore who played a critical role in Time Inc.’s $14 billion merger with Warner Communications, died in Manhattan on Thursday. He was 66.

headline: Excess Reigns at Super Bowl and That’s No Ballyhoo
text: Before there was a Super Bowl, there was Super Bowl hype.

headline: Long-Suffering Saints Fans Could Use Some Good Times
text: If there is any justice in the world, les bons temps  the good times  will continue to roll right through next Sunday, straight through to Mardi Gras.

headline: Food Distribution Retooled; Americans Arrested
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  After two weeks of often chaotic food distribution, the United Nations announced plans on Saturday for a coupon-based system that aims to give rice to 10,000 Haitians a day at each of 16 locations around Port-au-Prince.

headline: Leaders in Davos Admit Drop in Trust
text: DAVOS, Switzerland  If there was one takeaway from the annual gathering of business and political leaders in Davos this year, it was this: trust in governments, corporations and above all banks has become as elusive as sure footing on the icy streets of this Alpine resort.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 31
text: With the White House newly focused on the economic recovery, particularly jobs, the Sunday talk shows follow suit, bringing along lots of talk about election-year politics.

headline: Willie Mays, at 78, Decides to Tell His Story
text: On the night of April 29, 1961, at dinner in Milwaukee, Willie Mays ate some bad barbecue. He was up all night, sick to his stomach, and so wobbly the next afternoon he told Alvin Dark, the manager of the San Francisco Giants, to erase his name from the lineup. Lew Burdette was scheduled to pitch for the Braves.

headline: Derby County Ends Nottingham Forest’s Streak
text: Derby County ended Nottingham Forest’s 19-game unbeaten streak in England’s League Championship with a 1-0 victory at Pride Park Stadium on Saturday.

headline: G.O.P. Hits Its Stride, but Faces Rifts Over Ideology
text: HONOLULU  Republican leaders burst into applause here the other day as their luncheon speaker, Gov. Linda Lingle of Hawaii, shared the latest analysis by a Washington Congressional handicapper: The way things are heading, she read, “you can count on the Democratic majority in the House being toast this fall.”

headline: Missile Strikes Kill 15 in Pakistani Tribal Region, Officials Say
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Three missiles believed to have been fired from American drones killed 15 militants in North Waziristan late Friday night, Pakistani security officials said Saturday. The target of the strike was a compound in the Mamad Khel area of North Waziristan, the officials said.

headline: 4 Afghan Soldiers Are Killed by a Mistaken Airstrike
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a confusing nighttime firefight, an American-Afghan force called in an airstrike on an Afghan Army checkpoint on Saturday, killing four Afghan soldiers and prompting a denunciation from the country’s Defense Ministry.

headline: All Those Little Stuyvesant Towns
text: WHEN money grew on trees during the late great credit boom, private equity firms plunged headlong into New York City real estate. Not only did these companies snag dazzling Manhattan office towers, they also paid up for thousands of mundane rental apartments across the five boroughs.

headline: Does Finance Need Better Air Traffic Control?
text: Iceland’s president, Olafur Ragnar Grimsson, said financial regulators can learn a lot from the airline industry.

headline: Redford on the New Sundance
text: As the 2010 Sundance Film Festival comes to an end this weekend, how is Robert Redford feeling about this year’s installment?

headline: Smart Dust? Not Quite, but We’re Getting There
text: In computing, the vision always precedes the reality by a decade or more. The pattern has held true from the personal computer to the Internet, as it takes time, brainpower and investment to conquer the scientific and economic obstacles to nudging a game-changing technology toward the mainstream.

headline: Officer Discovers Stolen Police S.U.V. at La Guardia Airport
text: A police officer with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey who spotted a city police sport-utility vehicle oddly parked at La Guardia Airport on Saturday discovered that it had been stolen that morning in the Bronx, the authorities said.

headline: Of Women, Sleep Deprivation and Financial Meltdown
text: At a Davos conference dominated by China, women — that other huge emerging market — rose to the fore on Saturday morning in a debate about “The Gender Agenda.”

headline: Europe Agonistes
text: Amid all the Davos musings about a G2 world dominated by the United States and China, Europe was a very muted presence.

headline: What Happened to Regulatory Reform?
text: NEARLY two years ago, as a presidential candidate, Barack Obama gave a stirring speech at Cooper Union in New York about the need to reform the country’s financial system. Joseph E. Stiglitz, the Nobel-winning economist, recalls it fondly in his powerful new book, “Freefall: America, Free Markets, and the Sinking of the World Economy” (Norton, $27.95).

headline: Recharging Your Cellphone, Mother Nature’s Way
text: A NEW solar cell that imitates Mother Nature’s way of converting sunlight to energy is making its debut in a variety of consumer products.

headline: For Moon, Many Stops Before N.B.A. Arrival
text: CLEVELAND  If an N.B.A. hopeful is toiling in basketball’s minor leagues, he had better make a name for himself quickly. N.B.A. scouts and general managers are not generally interested in a 26-year-old with a long résumé of teams, unless he has been a star somewhere in Europe.

headline: In Reality, Marcoux Becomes a Hot Prospect
text: On Jan. 9, Gov. David A. Paterson was the No. 1 trend on Google’s hot-searches list because of a skit that mocked him on “Saturday Night Live.” No. 9 was Cole Marcoux, a Dartmouth quarterback recruit who rode a wave of success from a reality series to a role in that afternoon’s U.S. Army All-American Bowl.

headline: Bush Is in Town, So He Stops By the White House
text: A day after meeting with House Republicans, President Obama sat down on Saturday with one of the party’s elders as he met at the White House with the first former President Bush.

headline: Stuck in Neutral? Reset the Mood
text: The United States and other advanced economies may be facing a long, slow period of disappointing growth.

headline: Islamic Republic Crushed the Dreams of Iran’s Top Tennis Players
text: Before a capacity crowd in December at the season-ending ATP Masters tournament, Mansour Bahrami worked his tennis magic once again. Playing one deft trick shot after another, he captivated the fans at Albert Hall in London with a comedic sense that was part Buster Keaton and part Meadowlark Lemon.

headline: States Taking the Lead Addressing Concussions
text: As dozens of state lawmakers consider legislation to improve awareness and treatment of concussions in youth sports, the movement is resembling a music style or weather pattern: what started in the Pacific Northwest is wafting across the United States.

headline: Prime Number
text: 41: The potential cost, in billions of dollars, of a 1,700-mile-long pipeline to carry natural gas from Alaska’s North Slope to Alberta, Canada, according to the corporations TransCanada and Exxon Mobil, which are working together on what would probably be the biggest civil engineering project in North America, and one of the most challenging. With production from the state’s Prudhoe Bay oil field declining, Alaskans have been hoping for years that natural gas would take over as the state’s financial mainstay. The companies are also considering a second option: a 800-mile-long pipeline to Valdez, Alaska, with a price tag estimated at upwards of $26 billion. Those projects are among several in the planning stages to tap vast supplies of natural gas in Alaska and Canada.

headline: China May Make Dog and Cat Meat a Delicacy No More
text: China's National People's Congress is expected to consider banning a centuries-old culinary tradition: the consumption of dog and cat meat.

headline: Fernandes and Pliskova Earn Junior Titles
text: Tiago Fernandes put Brazil on the list of countries with junior Grand Slam winners with a 7-5, 6-3 victory over the wild card Sean Berman on Saturday in the final of the Australian Open boys’ championship.

headline: Quotations of the Week
text: “In order to dance, you need a dance partner and there ain’t no partner out there.”—Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, on prospects for bipartisanship.

headline: Finding a Job by Starting a Business
text: Last year, more laid-off managers and executives grew tired of waiting for human resources departments to call them back. They took matters into their own hands by starting companies.

headline: First-Gen Tesla Roadster’s Days Are Apparently Numbered
text: Tesla Motors is declining to comment on the revelation — contained in its Securities and Exchange Commission filing for an initial public offering on Friday — that it will stop producing the first generation of its famous Roadster after 2011. But the company says the second generation could be available in 2013.

headline: Letters: Underwater, but Will They Leave the Pool?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: Massachusetts: Kingmaker, Heartbreaker
text: An article last Sunday about the role of Massachusetts in President Obama’s political life misstated the position he held at The Harvard Law Review. He was the publication’s first African-American president, not its first African-American editor.

headline: Correction: The Book Club With Just One Member
text: An article last Sunday about reading as both private and social pursuit misstated the given name of the best-selling author of “The Help.” She is Kathryn Stockett, not Elizabeth.

headline: Correction: Grist
text: A brief article last Sunday about the failure of a black-clad figure known as the Poe Toaster to show up at Edgar Allan Poe’s grave site in Baltimore to celebrate his Jan. 19 birthday misstated the number of years since Poe was born. It was 201 years ago, in 1809  not 101 years ago.

headline: Recruiting Market Is Up in Connecticut, Thanks to Penn State’s Interest
text: STAMFORD, Conn.  J. R. Ferguson, a defensive end from Florida, took part in a pillow fight at a football camp in August in Paisley, Fla. The battle pitted members of two teams against each other, and, by Ferguson’s count, his squad won. Impressed with the strength of his teammates Khairi Fortt and Silas Redd Jr., a pair of Connecticut prospects, Ferguson wondered about the odds of seeing two stars from such a small state.

headline: A Record Gust Gets Blown Away
text: An extreme-weather record has been shattered. Barrow Island, off the coast of Australia, last week claimed the new record for the fastest gust of wind ever recorded — during a cyclone, at 253 miles an hour — surpassing the old mark, 231 miles an hour, set in New Hampshire in 1934.

headline: In Politics, Scamps, Saboteurs and the Occasional Criminal
text: WASHINGTON — The arrests of four conservative activists in New Orleans last week on suspicion of tampering with the phones in Senator Mary L. Landrieu’s office recalls an obscure “Saturday Night Live” skit from the 1970s. It was called “Dangerous but Inept,” and it featured a fake talk show in which the guest (played by Laraine Newman) was Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme, the pistol-wielding klutz whose misadventure a few feet from President Gerald Ford landed her in jail for 34 years.

headline: In Haiti, a Puzzling Drought of Tears
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Amidst all the personal tragedy that has played out here in the two weeks since the earthquake, one thing has been in short supply: tears.

headline: Is It Really That Tough to Get Credit?
text: The Times just published an article about small businesses, desperate for credit, who turn to purchase-order financing to keep their operations running. The reporter, Andrew Martin, talked to business owners who pay interest rates as high as 40 percent on an annualized basis to borrow money from a purchase-order lender, Hartsko Financial Services, whose New York City offices are in Queens, right above an acupuncture clinic that used to be a massage parlor. Richard Eitelberg, Hartsko’s founder and president, says his business was up 80 percent in 2009.

headline: As New Jersey Tightens Its Belt, the Racing Industry Holds Its Breath
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Meadowlands Racetrack has had some of the highest-quality harness racing in the country and dozens of the sport’s most important races. But in recent years, the track has become a money-losing drain on the state of New Jersey, which now threatens its survival.

headline: Warning: Don’t Read the Warning
text: Hydrocordaplyex will rejuvenate your muscles and return your physical stamina to that of a much younger man. Four out of five doctors interviewed recommended Hydrocordaplyex for those who seek a more active, youthful lifestyle. Take Hydrocordaplyex and live the life you always envisioned for yourself.

headline: Mickelson Addresses Questions, and Shots
text: SAN DIEGO  Life at golf’s pinnacle is both heady and headache inducing, a reality Phil Mickelson has seen up close this week. Though the World Golf Rankings list Tiger Woods as the No. 1-ranked player by a comfortable margin, his hiatus has thrust Mickelson out of his former spot as golf’s No. 2 and into the role of leading man, the de facto No. 1.

headline: Snowboarder Looks to Make Fall a Footnote
text: ASPEN, Colo.  Her nickname was Lucky Lindsey until she fell at the 2006 Olympics just feet from the finish in the women’s snowboard cross final while leading the field by a wide margin.

headline: U.S. Seeks Options for Airlifting Haitian Patients
text: MIAMI  Three days after the United States military suspended medical evacuations of critically injured earthquake victims from Haiti, officials in Washington continued to search for ways to resume the flights on Saturday, including looking to states beyond Florida, which has taken in most of the patients.

headline: Obama Budget Freezes Much Domestic Spending
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will send a $3.8 trillion budget to Congress on Monday for the coming fiscal year that would increase financing for education and for civilian research programs by more than 6 percent and provide $25 billion for cash-starved states, even as he seeks to freeze much domestic spending for the rest of his term.

headline: For Disabled, Ice Time Can Be Best of Times
text: Joseph Bowser was an Army sergeant serving in Iraq in 2004 when a mortar explosion sent shrapnel through his lower right leg and foot. Doctors gave him a choice between keeping his leg, but with limited use and needing pain medication for the rest of his life, or having it amputated and replaced with a prosthesis.

headline: Steve Jobs and the Economics of Elitism
text: The more, the better. That’s the fashionable recipe for nurturing new ideas these days. It emphasizes a kind of Internet-era egalitarianism that celebrates the “wisdom of the crowd” and “open innovation.” Assemble all the contributions in the digital suggestion box, we’re told in books and academic research, and the result will be collective intelligence.

headline: A Survey of Youth Sports Finds Winning Isn’t the Only Thing
text: At a time when sports tutors seem as plentiful as piano teachers and high school games are routinely nationally televised, Peter Barston has learned something important about youth sports.

headline: The Muddled Selling of the President
text: WASHINGTON — On this much, President Obama’s friends and foes could agree: He eludes simple labels.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Toyota to Issue a Fix for Recalled Cars
text: DETROIT  Toyota Motor has come up with a remedy to fix the millions of cars it recalled because their accelerator pedals could become stuck, dealers and a federal official said Saturday.

headline: Iraq Mends a System to Treat Trauma
text: BASRA, Iraq  During quiet moments, Fadel Khadum Adel, a former soldier, often hears someone speaking his name into his right ear. The voice is a welcome one, usually that of his mother or father, but when he looks there is no one there.

headline: Mays Found Creative Ways to Avoid Ejection
text: Willie Mays decided, at last, to cooperate with a biographer because, he said, so many people had reminded him of things they had done together that he thought it worthwhile to let someone collect those stories. Many of those stories came out in a recent interview, too many than could fit in this article about the book, including this one about his relations with umpires.

headline: Kurt Warner, Man in Full
text: “We will rally around Kurt Warner, and we will play good football.” — Rams Coach Dick Vermeil, after his starter at quarterback, Trent Green, sustained a season-ending injury in the preseason in 1999.

headline: How to Reform Our Financial System
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA 10 days ago set out one important element in the needed structural reform of the financial system. No one can reasonably contest the need for such reform, in the United States and in other countries as well. We have after all a system that broke down in the most serious crisis in 75 years. The cost has been enormous in terms of unemployment and lost production. The repercussions have been international.

headline: Political Uncertainty Grips a Russian Republic
text: MAKHACHKALA, Russia — Last week here in the capital of the southern republic of Dagestan, the wind whipped uncollected garbage in every direction and tens of thousands of citizens lost heat, electricity and water.

headline: Uncle Sam Wants You ... to Have a Job
text: President Obama has a jobs problem. Fifteen million Americans want work. Few companies want to hire. The burden shifts to the government. What can it do?

headline: Camus Fired Up
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Inspired to Pick Up Where Others Left Off for Holocaust Survivors
text: Three years ago, Robert Ivker, a radiation oncologist, read an article about a caseworker dedicated to helping Holocaust survivors apply for reparations from the German government. The article, part of the Neediest Cases campaign, inspired him to start a fund to benefit New York-area Holocaust survivors, many of whom were destitute. His own efforts were described in a Neediest Cases article in 2008.

headline: Main Opposition Leaders in Iran Call for Rally
text: The two main opposition leaders in Iran called on their supporters on Saturday to take part in a demonstration on Feb. 11, the anniversary of the 1979 Islamic Revolution.

headline: A Look at America’s New Hope: The Afghan Tribes
text: For three decades now, Communism, civil war and Islamic fundamentalism have laid siege to Afghanistan’s tribes. In many ways, Afghanistan’s tribal structure is arguably the weakest it has been in the country’s history.

headline: Haiti Is Again a Canvas for Approaches to Aid
text: UNITED NATIONS  The fact that Haiti was mired in dysfunction well before the earthquake, despite having received more than $5 billion in aid over about two decades, is fueling a contentious debate on whether a grand reconstruction plan can finally fix the country or would be doomed to repeat previous failures.

headline: Modern Players Prove Bobby Fischer Was Wrong
text: Bobby Fischer once famously remarked that “chess is dead.” What he meant was that so much had been discovered about the game that creativity and innovation were waning.

headline: Safety Agency Is Investigating Gas Pedal Maker
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said that it had opened an investigation on Tuesday into the manufacturer of the accelerator pedals used on about 2.3 million recalled Toyotas.

headline: Congo’s Forgotten War
text: The war unfolding in eastern Congo has claimed perhaps 30 times as many lives as the Haiti earthquake, but this crisis generates little international response, reports Nicholas D. Kristof.

headline: A Determined Quest to Bring Adoptive Ties to Foster Teenagers
text: ST. LOUIS  After a day of knocking on doors chasing fleeting leads, Carlos Lopez and his partner finally heard welcome words: Yes, a resident confirmed, the man they were seeking lived in this house and would be home that evening.

headline: Orphaned, Raped and Ignored
text: KALEHE, Congo

headline: In Portland, Growing Vertical
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Urban gardening used to seem subversive. People planted tomatoes in public parks, strung their hops to rooftops to make homebrew and reclaimed empty lots as community farms, never mind the property owner.

headline: Keep an Eye on It
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — The title of today’s puzzle had me wondering from the get-go if an “add an I” theme might be in the offing. It was, and to amusing effect.

headline: Never Heard That Before
text: Davos, Switzerland

headline: In New York, Mix of Emotions Over 9/11 Trial Move
text: All the worrying about what a federal terrorism trial might mean to the city, or to New Yorkers themselves, is over.

headline: Secondhand Sources
text: “Game Change,” the gossipy reconstruction of the 2008 presidential election that opens today atop The New York Times nonfiction best-seller list, is filled with racy anecdotes about dysfunctional marriages and political back-stabbing. What it does not have are identifiable sources.

headline: One Year Down, a Presidency Yet to Go: Bush Faces the New World Order
text: As the candidate of hope and change, President Obama has doubtless spent some private time around his first anniversary in office wondering whether he shouldn’t have been more specific about the kind of change he’d hoped for. If a single year has so transformed his political fortunes, imagine what cannot be imagined in the next three ahead.

headline: It Happened in Our Backyard
text: We sympathized with the concerns about security and inconvenience raised by the Justice Department’s plan to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described 9/11 mastermind, at a federal courthouse in downtown Manhattan, a short walk from ground zero.

headline: On New, Spare Broadway, Less Scenery to Chew
text: For the big Broadway musical, surviving the recession often means that the sets are rarely stars anymore.

headline: One Year Down, a Presidency Yet to Go: For Nixon, All That Jazz
text: IN April 1969, three months after his inauguration, President Richard Nixon hosted a party at the White House to celebrate Duke Ellington’s 70th birthday and award the Duke the Medal of Freedom. Great American jazz figures were there. Musicians played Ellington songs arranged by Gerry Mulligan. Joe Williams and Mary Mayo sang. Ellington danced with Rose Mary Woods. After dinner, the president had a nightcap with the pianist Earl Hines.

headline: One Year Down, a Presidency Yet to Go: Ford’s Four Seconds
text: IN his first State of the Union speech, on Jan. 15, 1975, President Gerald R. Ford told Congress and the American people in his plain-spoken manner: “I must say to you that the State of the Union is not good.” And then he listed the particulars: The economy was suffering from stagflation  simultaneous high inflation and economic recession. Unemployment was rising toward 8 percent. There was an energy shortage and high oil prices because of an embargo on petroleum shipments by Arab nations. The federal budget deficit was approaching $50 billion and the national debt $500 billion  big money in those days. As we prepared the speech  the first draft wasn’t even completed until around 3:30 a.m. on the day of the address  Ford asked Roy Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, if he had any good economic news to include. Ash replied, “That’ll take about four seconds.”

headline: Security in an Insecure Land
text: Alix Sainvil, a Haitian-American United Nations police officer, worked to secure Cité Soleil. But the disaster may cause gang violence and instability to return this poor neighborhood.

headline: One Year Down, a Presidency Yet to Go: Carter’s Sunny Day
text: THINGS were tough as Jimmy Carter prepared for his 1978 State of the Union address, one year into his term. But they seemed, strangely, hopeful. The president’s big domestic initiative that year was a national energy policy. The gas-station lines and first-ever spike in fuel prices in the mid-1970s made this a genuine emergency. He hadn’t yet gotten the whole plan through, but the previous summer he had signed legislation creating the Department of Energy and begun imposing standards that, even after he was gone, kept improving the fuel efficiency of American cars, buildings and factories.

headline: Ronald Reagan, a Man With a Plan
text: Political platforms are usually written for election campaign purposes, then quickly scrapped after a presidential election. But the 1980 Republican platform bore a simple five-word title: “Family, Neighborhood, Work, Peace, Freedom,” and was planned and written with the purpose of creating an agenda for a Reagan administration on Day One, Jan. 20, 1981. My signal memory of Reagan’s first year in office is that we were actually able to stick to the plan that he insisted we put in place.

headline: One Year Down, a Presidency Yet to Go: Bill Clinton’s Narrow Victories
text: Barack Obama, reeling from the Democratic defeat in the Massachusetts Senate race, isn’t the first president to get an unwelcome anniversary gift a year after taking office. On Jan. 20, 1994, Attorney General Janet Reno announced that, at President Bill Clinton’s request, she had appointed Robert Fiske as special counsel to investigate the Whitewater case. What we didn’t know then was that seven months later, Mr. Fiske would be replaced by Ken Starr, whose investigation would ultimately lead to the president’s impeachment. But what those of us on the Clinton staff were learning fast after 12 tumultuous months on the job was how little control we had over our own unfolding drama. The cockiness of the campaign was giving way to a humility imposed by history.

headline: One Year Down, a Presidency Yet to Go: Bush’s Full Plate
text: THEY served pineapple upside-down cake for dessert that snowy evening at Camp David, the last weekend of President George W. Bush’s first year in office. I remember thinking it seemed fitting. “What a year,” President Bush said during dinner. “Sometimes it seems like seven,” replied Condoleezza Rice, his national security advisor. But no one else said much. The emotions had been too raw, too intense. The sudden horror of Sept. 11 had changed the course of the presidency, making America’s national security the president’s relentless focus. “Continued vigilance” were the watchwords, as we fully expected additional attacks.

headline: One Year Down, a Presidency Yet to Go
text: With the State of the Union address, President Obama marked the symbolic end to his first year in office. From the outside, it seemed like a pretty rough roller-coaster ride. But did other administrations have it any easier? The Op-Ed editors asked veterans of the previous seven administrations to reflect on their initial 12 months in office — and to provide some perspective for the current team in the White House.

headline: Globetrotters on Ice, All Tricks Included
text: The N.H.L. has gained huge attendance the last few seasons with its annual outdoor Winter Classic, played at places like Wrigley Field and Fenway Park. Never an organization to pass up a good idea, the Harlem Globetrotters decided to play a game outdoors as well. Not wanting to mess with success, they decided they too would play their game on ice.

headline: Pro or Con, Lobbying Thrived
text: President Obama has blamed many factors for the stalling of his health care overhaul, from the recent special election in Massachusetts that deprived Democrats of their supermajority in the Senate to his own failure to better explain the legislation to the American people.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about alumni recollections of Jamaica High School, which is scheduled to close, misstated the name of the educational institution led by Judith Shapiro, class of 1959. It is Barnard College, not Barnard University.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about the University of Connecticut’s 88-74 victory over Texas in men’s basketball on Saturday, Jan. 23, misstated, in some copies, the given name of the Huskies’ senior guard who scored 32 points. He is Jerome Dyson, not Eric. The article also quoted incorrectly from comments by George Blaney, UConn’s associate head coach. Blaney said, “Jerome moves in straight lines, no matter where he is on the court. ” He did not refer to the player as Eric.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, the Phys Ed column on Page 17 this weekend, about the ability of exercise to slow some aspects of aging, misidentifies the German city that is home to Saarland University Clinic, which has conducted studies on the life spans of human cells. It is Homburg, not Hamburg.

headline: Avoiding Errors in Radiation Therapy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tom Brookshier, Eagles Star and Broadcaster, Dies at 78
text: Tom Brookshier, a star defensive back who helped lead the Philadelphia Eagles to the 1960 National Football League championship and later teamed with Pat Summerall as CBS’s No. 1 professional football broadcasting duo, died Friday at a hospital in the Philadelphia suburb of Wynnewood, Pa. Brookshier, who lived in West Conshohocken, Pa., was 78.

headline: No Jobs, No Recovery
text: It may seem counterintuitive, but with the government reporting stronger-than-expected economic growth at the end of last year, now is the time to think about renewed recession  and to act to avoid it.

headline: Climate Change and the S.E.C.
text: There were predictable howls after the Securities and Exchange Commission told publicly held companies they should warn investors of any potential effects from climate change on their bottom lines. Representative Joe Barton, among the most reliable of the oil, gas and coal industries’ many friends in Congress, complained that the commission’s time would be better spent on “investor protection” rather than imposing new burdens on corporations and promoting the “social agendas” of environmental groups.

headline: Super Bowl Censorship
text: The commercials during the Super Bowl, a showcase for the best (or worst) in TV advertising, often generate buzz and sometimes outrage. This year, viewers will see one ad that has already triggered a heated debate about abortion and censorship.

headline: Interrogating Detainees: Senator Feinstein’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ethnic Stereotyping
text: To the Editor:

headline: Haiti, God and Suffering
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pedestrian Injuries and Deaths in Suburbia
text: To the Editor:

headline: The State of the Union Is Comatose
text: HANDS down, the State of the Union’s big moment was Barack Obama’s direct hit on the delicate sensibilities of the Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito. The president was right to blast the 5-to-4 decision giving corporate interests an even greater stranglehold over a government they already regard as a partially owned onshore subsidiary. How satisfying it was to watch him provoke Alito into a “You lie!” snit. Here was a fight we could believe in.

headline: Discontent and Anger Motivate Voters
text: Finishing his breakfast at Valois Restaurant in Hyde Park last week, Craig Woods, a 55-year-old pipe fitter from Lake County, had to be reminded that there is a primary election on Tuesday. He said he tried to forget unpleasant subjects  like politicians and the “promises they always break.”

headline: From Some Experts, Questions About Candidates in Tuesday’s Primary
text: The final Democratic debate in the primary for governor on WTTW-TV commenced at the same moment the Goodman Theatre premiered a double bill of one-act plays starring the estimable Brian Dennehy. Both events, staged as Tuesday’s primary draws near, proved to be about self-delusion.

headline: As Lender, Senate Candidate Impacted Bank Woes
text: Alexi Giannoulias would be nothing in Illinois politics if not for Broadway Bank. Now the near-failure of that family-owned bank is threatening to make him a political non-entity again.

headline: Rhode Island’s Coach Jim Baron Is a Rebuilder at Work, Again
text: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I.  Rhode Island Coach Jim Baron, the son of a mason, grew up in a Brooklyn tenement. One of eight kids, he willed his way out of the projects through hard work. Baron still has a gruff Brooklyn accent, and his old-school mustache and Burberry glasses show the dichotomy of his hard-nosed work ethic and his success as a college coach with more than 350 victories.

headline: Anonymous Sources Fuel Senate Controversy
text: Today’s public editor column is about how The Times handled “Game Change,” a tell-all book relying exclusively on anonymous sources. Another controversy over anonymous sources that involves The Times directly has been simmering for a while.

headline: TV Show Burnishes a Player’s Résumé
text: On Jan. 9, Gov. David A. Paterson was the No. 1 trend on Google’s hot-searches list because of a skit that mocked him on “Saturday Night Live.” No. 9 was Cole Marcoux, a Dartmouth quarterback recruit who rode a wave of success from a reality series to a role in that afternoon’s U.S. Army All-American Bowl.

headline: Voters Seem to Like Campbell’s Switch
text: Tom Campbell was not supposed to be in this position.

headline: A California Reckoning in a Case of Abuses Abroad
text: The three refugees from Somalia came to the Bay Area several years ago to escape the violence of their homeland, to put the terror behind them. But they were shocked to learn in 2002 that a former Somali official they believed responsible for brutality against their family was living freely in the United States.

headline: From the Inside Looking Out
text: When a 1,099-foot container ship like the Xin Fei Zhou makes its way toward the mouth of San Francisco Bay, it is met by a bar pilot like Bruce Horton. Mr. Horton, 48, has the job of boarding ships and navigating them under the Golden Gate Bridge and through the tricky currents and tides to the Port of Oakland, or the oil refineries along the Carquinez Strait or farther up the delta. MALIA WOLLAN

headline: Site for Terror Trial Isn’t Only Obstacle
text: For much of President Obama’s first year in office, his national security team worked to devise a secure plan to send dozens of Yemeni detainees held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba — the largest single group at the prison camp — home to Yemen, perhaps to a rehabilitation program.

headline: Corrections
text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Conservatory Theater Still Seeks Its Ovation
text: Like the thrill of settling into a plush seat as the curtain rises on a highly anticipated production, there’s the excitement over the announcement every March of the American Conservatory Theater’s coming season, with its promises of innovatively staged classic plays, bold new works by powerful writers and acclaimed productions imported from beyond the Bay Area.

headline: Corrections
text: The Evening Hours column last Sunday reversed the identities of two guests shown at the Winter Antiques Show party on Jan. 21. Alan Gerry was on the left and Ron Greenberg was on the right. The column also misspelled the given name of a guest at the Gotham Chamber Opera performance on Jan. 19. She is Domna Stanton, not Donna.

headline: Your Comments on my Congo Column
text: My Sunday column is the first of several from eastern Congo, site of the most lethal conflict since World War II — and perhaps the most under-covered. There are of course many problems in the world, many demands on our conscience. But the Congo war seems to me particularly important because of the death toll (already 5.4 million as of April 2007); the savagery or rape and mutilation directed at civilians; and the prospect that some pressure and heavy diplomacy could resolve it. Moreover, without that pressure and diplomacy, it will continue unabated for years to come. I do think that the news media have dropped the ball on this one, but that may reflect the new media realities in which television reporting in particular from abroad just falls off the map.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sundance Spreads the Love
text: Sundance spread its awards love across an eclectic mix of films, with the bleak drama “Winter’s Bone” and the war documentary “Restrepo” winning grand jury prizes in the American section and the comedy “HappyThankYouMorePlease” and the school-system documentary “Waiting for Superman” winning audience trophies.

headline: Vows: Ming-Yi & Alan
text: Ming-Yi Chuang and Alan McIntyre Smith met through a film production. Ming-Yi was randomly chosen from the audience to star in a movie to be directed by Alan. The couple hit it off and started dating.

headline: White Is Said to Be O.K.; Snowboard Cross Athlete Is Injured
text: A spokeswoman for Shaun White‘s snowboard sponsor, Burton, said White had experienced no ill effects from striking his head on the lip of the halfpipe Friday night during practice at the Winter X Games.

headline: Knicks Fall to Wizards as Playoff Spot Recedes Further
text: WASHINGTON  Where once the Knicks charted their progress through a steady rise in the standings, collecting precious percentage points at a time, they now count in reverse.

headline: Somali Refugees Seek Justice and Other Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: A Reckoning in Abuse Case | Since 1998, the Center for Justice and Accountability, a small San Francisco nonprofit, has been filing suit on behalf of human rights victims seeking to hold their tormentors accountable. A group of Somalis from the Bay Area filed suit against a former Somali prime minister living on the East Coast, and the case is currently before the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Highlights From the Australian Open
text: Key moments and victories from the 2010 Australian Open.

headline: Bleiler Again Tops Clark, Setting Up Potential Showdown
text: ASPEN, Colo. — Gretchen Bleiler defeated Kelly Clark for the second time this month, setting up a potential showdown in the halfpipe at the Winter Olympics in Vancouver in February.

headline: When the Banks Don't Lend
text: With banks timid about lending, small businesses have turned to unconventional lenders like Hartsko Financial Services, which provides high interest short-term loans to small and midsize companies.

headline: In Congo, a Struggle Against a Tide of Violence
text: The columnist Nicholas D. Kristof shares images of some of the people he has met in eastern Congo, where millions have died in a civil war that has been waged for a dozen years.

headline: Not All the Calls Went the Saints’ Way
text: On this blog and at other sites, officials have been criticized for  calls that hurt the Vikings in the N.F.C. title game. A few days later, an N.F.L. vice president in charge of officiating said that one of the hits on Brett Favre should have been a penalty.

headline: Letters in Response to the 1.17.10 Issue
text: Obama’s War Over Terror

headline: Aman Spa Goes Urban at London Hotel
text: The first Aman Spa outside of an Amanresort opened earlier this month at the Connaught hotel in London (Carlos Place, W1; 44-20-3147-7305/6; www.the-connaught.co.uk), part of the venerable 113-year-old hotel’s recent 33-room extension.

headline: Remembering Tom Brookshier
text: Recollections of Tom Brookshier, who died of cancer Friday at age 78. Brookshier was an excellent defensive back for the Eagles but gained greater renown as a broadcaster. He and Pat Summerall were CBS’s top N.F.L. broadcasting team for most of the 1970s. Before the era of cable and computer, many fans experienced the game through them.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Senators and Canucks Just Keep On Winning
text: Saturday was Hockey Day in Canada, and Stratford, Ontario, was the host community for that country’s annual celebration of the game. Here’s a small part of CBC’s presentation of the daylong event:

headline: With Australian Title, Federer Returns From Vulnerable to Invincible
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  How can you make breaking records look so easy? Ask Roger Federer. He did it Sunday night, winning his 16th Grand Slam title with a straight-sets victory over Andy Murray and re-establishing his grip on tennis supremacy.

headline: An Iraqi in America…
text: Mudhafar al-Husseini, an Iraqi journalist who used to work for The New York Times in Baghdad, has written an interesting blog post on how he and his family have had to make cultural adjustments now that they have moved to America on a refugee program. It appears on the Web site of the Committee to Protect Journalists.

headline: South Africa and FIFA Try to Ease Concerns About Power Problems
text: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa — Last month, as dozens of people out for the evening scrolled along the boardwalk, a popular area along the Indian Ocean with restaurants, specialty shops and bars here, the city was suddenly enveloped in darkness. Generators kicked in providing some power, but the shutdown brought most activity to a standstill for several hours.

headline: Directors Turn to ‘Hurt Locker’
text: Has the Oscar horse race developed a leader of the herd? On Saturday, the Directors Guild of America awarded its top prize to Kathryn Bigelow for helming “The Hurt Locker,” the Iraq war drama that also took the best-film honors from the Producers Guild a week before. So “Avatar” may no longer be the the film to beat this season.

headline: Watch the Grammy Awards With ArtsBeat
text: The award or the performance? The recognition or the spectacle? As Ben Sisario noted last week, those are perennial questions for the Grammy Awards, which will be handed out on Sunday at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, and broadcast live on CBS at 8 p.m. Eastern Time.

headline: Sunday Word: Budget Matters
text: The $3.8 trillion 2011 budget proposal that President Obama will hand over to Congress Monday includes a 6 percent funding increase for civilian research programs and $25 billion for cash-starved states.

headline: CNN Names Candy Crowley New Sunday Anchor
text: CNN has named Candy Crowley the new anchor of “State of the Union,” the cable news channel’s Sunday morning political talk program.

headline: Anastos Recap
text: Ernie Anastos through his years as a broadcaster.

headline: A Meaningful Moment for Vancouver’s Former Mayor
text: If you enjoyed my article in Sunday’s newspaper on Sam Sullivan, the former mayor of Vancouver who waved the Olympic flag in Turin, Italy, in 2006, then there is more to see. A group, explore.org, recently visited Sullivan and filmed a short documentary about what he’s doing now.

headline: Indie Evolution
text: From Jarmusch to Bujalski, images from American independent cinema.

headline: Moving Your Business to a Smaller Market
text: I recently ran across an article in The San Francisco Chronicle titled “Big City Blues” in which the author described his struggle over whether to leave the Bay Area and move his family to a more affordable city. While I found myself nodding my head in agreement, I had to laugh at the way he put the process in terms of ending a long-term relationship.

headline: U.S. to Resume Airlift of Injured Haitians
text: WASHINGTON  The White House said Sunday that it would resume a United States military airlift of Haitians seriously injured in the Jan. 12 earthquake, reversing a five-day suspension that doctors worried would strand patients with devastating burns, head and spinal cord trauma, amputations and other wounds.

headline: Bankers Put Focus on ‘Real Economy’
text: Jobs will be hard to find in both the developed and developing world as bankers, corporations and governments work to put the financial system and world economies on a firmer footing, key participants at the World Economic Forum said Sunday, The New York Times’s Alison Smale reports.

headline: Leaders in Davos Admit Drop in Trust
text: If there was one takeaway from the annual gathering of business and political leaders in Davos this year, it was this: trust in governments, corporations and above all banks has become as elusive as sure footing on the icy streets of this Alpine resort, The New York Times’s Alison Smale reports.

headline: Disney Looking to Sell What’s Left of Miramax
text: The Walt Disney Company has been quietly shopping what remains of its Miramax film unit and has secured seven to 10 interested bidders, according to a mergers and acquisitions expert with knowledge of the process.

headline: What They Said in Australia
text: By now you’ve seen, read or heard that Roger Federer has captured his 16th Grand Slam title in a 6-3, 6-4, 7-6 (11) dismantling of Andy Murray on Sunday. And a day earlier, Serena Williams won her fifth Australian Open championship in a three set thriller over Justine Henin, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2.

headline: 2010 Land Rover LR4
text: The new Land Rover is big and fast, and handles well both on-road and off.

headline: Among the Classics and Exotics, a Few for Everyman
text: Several inexpensive cars in very nice condition stood out from the silk purses in Arizona.

headline: Mel Gibson Can’t Topple ‘Avatar’
text: LOS ANGELES — And the blue money just keeps rolling in.

headline: An Awards Ceremony, Unbound
text: “Your movie is as beautiful as your legs,” Lee Daniels told Kathryn Bigelow, the evening’s big winner, while up on the podium Saturday night at the Directors Guild Awards. “You make me question my sexuality.” Mr. Daniels, the director of “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” also noted that he was wearing Spanx, to the delight of the women in the room.

headline: Pasadena Playhouse to Shut Down
text: The Pasadena Playhouse, the state theater of California, is scheduled to close its doors on Feb. 7, after the final performance of “Camelot,” because of deep debt. The entire staff of 37 was laid off on Thursday. “We firmly believe it would be irresponsible to continue to operate in the same financial patterns of the past,” Stephen Eich, the executive director of the playhouse, said in a statement, adding that the theater will explore bankruptcy as well as financial reorganization. The playhouse, which was founded in 1917 and has closed and filed for bankruptcy before because of financial troubles, has been the staging ground for many hits, including “Looped,” starring Valerie Harper as Tallulah Bankhead, which is scheduled to start previews at the Lyceum on Broadway this month.

headline: Mel Gibson Can’t Topple ‘Avatar’
text: LOS ANGELES  And the blue money just keeps rolling in.

headline: Behind Every Diva, Another Diva
text: Like “Upstairs, Downstairs,” Bravo brings a fine-grained focus to the servant class. Only instead of chronicling the inner lives of Edwardian butlers and parlor maids, Bravo follows the meltdowns of assistants in gyms, showrooms and fashion houses. These underlings show the same self-deluding loyalty, only with garish egos instead of practiced deference.

headline: ‘Red,’ About Rothko, Is Headed for Broadway via London
text: Broadway likes safe bets, which is why there has always been a steady stream of British plays making the journey from London to New York. Even American plays occasionally have to prove their box office worth in Britain before opening on Broadway. “Red,” a new drama by the playwright and screenwriter John Logan about the Abstract Expressionist painter Mark Rothko that received sterling reviews at the Donmar Warehouse in London, will start previews for a 15-week limited run at the Golden Theater in March, according to a publicist for the show. This two-character play, directed by Michael Grandage, stars Alfred Molina as Rothko and Eddie Redmayne as the painter’s ambitious assistant. The setting is 1958 New York, after Rothko has been hired to paint a series of murals for the Four Seasons restaurant in the new Seagram Building on Park Avenue.

headline: The Folks Who Live on Easy Road
text: In an interview about his new novel, “The Privileges,” Jonathan Dee recently told The Wall Street Journal that he had wanted to write about a marriage “where two people are so perfect for each other that it becomes problematic for the rest of society.” But “The Privileges” doesn’t set off the alarm bells that description implies. The man and woman around whom it revolves aren’t overtly problematic for anyone, not even for each other.

headline: The Wyckoff-Bennett House
text: A historic Brooklyn home, chock full of antiques, has been in the hands of only three families since colonial times.

headline: Karen Schmeer, Documentary Film Editor, Killed in Hit-and-Run Accident
text: Karen Schmeer, a film editor whose work includes “The Fog of War,” died Friday in Manhattan, after she was run down by a car when crossing a street, the police said. She was 39.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Leader Is Reported Dead
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani and American officials said Sunday that they were increasingly convinced that the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, Hakimullah Mehsud, Pakistan’s chief domestic enemy and the man behind the suicide attack on a C.I.A. base in Afghanistan in December, had died from wounds sustained in a drone strike.

headline: Jury Is Still Out on Pro Bowl Experiment
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. – The Pro Bowl will be played Sunday night, which will finally stop the flow of players dropping out of the game. At last count, ESPN, which will broadcast the game, said 30 players won’t be on the field because they are members of the two Super Bowl teams or because they are injured.

headline: Federer’s Victory Was All in the Planning
text: In Brad Gilbert’s book “Winning Ugly” he writes that Ivan Lendl liked to start his matches carefully, playing at about 65 percent of his shotmaking ability in order to get his rhythm, probe his opponent and figure out the conditions on court. Once he’d gotten a feel for things, he gradually opened his game up, going for his shots and thwarting whatever tactics his opponent was playing. The first set of the Australian Open men’s final on Sunday night was played this way for the first seven games, with Andy Murray and Roger Federer testing one another, trying to figure out the other’s early game plan.

headline: Taking It Squeegee
text: Video | From the Long March to less strenuous work:

headline: A Crime Writer’s Pages Come to Life in His Death
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria  In his first autobiographical thriller, “Secrets of the Mobsters,” the Bulgarian crime writer Bobi Tsankov, backed by a burly bodyguard and a driver, both armed with semiautomatic weapons hidden underneath their long coats, confronts a gangster boss called Stretko near a lake in the center of Sofia. “So what now?” the boss says, flashing a cocky grin. “Will your guards kill me?”

headline: Neil Young Wins First-Ever Grammy Award
text: Updated | 6:52 p.m.  Well, that only took, what, 50 years? After a career spanning nearly a half-century as a solo artist and a member of groups like Buffalo Springfield and Crosby Stills Nash and Young, Neil Young won his first Grammy Award in a pre-telecast ceremony in Los Angeles on Sunday afternoon. The award, for best art direction on a boxed or special limited edition package, was shared among Mr. Young and his art directors Gary Burden and Jenice Heo for the boxed set “Neil Young Archives Vol. 1 (1963-1972).” Upon his win, Mr. Young (who did not receive his first Grammy nomination until 1989, for the video for “This Note’s For You”) told the crowd: “Thanks a lot, everybody.” Mr. Young was also nominated for a Grammy in the best solo rock vocal category, but lost to Bruce Springsteen.

headline: Where Do New Yorkers Like to Slurp?
text: “Why don’t you link to Matt Gross’s article on Tokyo ramen shops and ask New Yorkers or Diner’s Journal readers for their favorite noodle shops?” a reader asks. O.K., we will. Where do you like eating ramen in New York?

headline: Coupon System Under Way in Haiti
text: United Nations workers initiated a new, more organized system of distributing food, issuing coupons that Haitians could redeem for bags of rice.

headline: U.S. Arms for Taiwan Send Beijing a Message
text: WASHINGTON  For the past year, China has adopted an increasingly muscular position toward the United States, berating American officials for the global economic crisis, stage-managing President Obama’s visit to China in November, refusing to back a tougher climate change agreement in Copenhagen and standing fast against American demands for tough new Security Council sanctions against Iran.

headline: Holding Ace-King but Picking a Different Lead
text: You are on lead against a trump contract with an ace-king holding in an unbid side suit. What would you lead?

headline: Beyoncé, Taylor Swift Win Big at Grammys
text: Beyoncé was the top winner at the 52nd annual Grammy Awards with six prizes, including song of the year for “Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It).” Taylor Swift won album of the year. Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live blogged the show as they watched the broadcast. What did you think of the ceremony? Share your thoughts and ask questions here.

headline: Four Men, a Counter and Soon, Revolution
text: GREENSBORO, N.C.  The sign still says “F. W. Woolworth Co.” in bright gold letters running across the building on South Elm Street, just as it did 50 years ago. And within that two-story structure, the same stainless steel dumbwaiters and commercial appliances line the mirrored walls. The lunch counter, which includes a bowling-alley-long tabletop that must dwarf any currently in use, is largely intact; the original chrome and vinyl chairs are still mounted in the floor. This site is an authentic, half-century-old relic, a remnant of the mundane, the insignificant, the quaint.

headline: Music in Review
text: AMERICAN COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA

headline: Amazon Relents in Fight Over E-Book Pricing
text: Amazon.com has surrendered, at least for now, in its mounting battle with book publishers over the price of electronic books.

headline: New CDs
text: LIL WAYNE “Rebirth” (Cash Money/Universal)

headline: Hot Dog!
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This is Scott Atkinson’s second New York Times crossword. I remember his wonderfully clever debut (Across Lite, blog) because the elaborate gimmick was hard to describe. I ended up writing a whole paragraph about it in XWord Info.

headline: Local Stop: Greenwich Village
text: Venturing out for the sake of the manly art of shelf-building and other roll-up-your-sleeves pursuits.

headline: Copland’s Folksy Melodies and the Timeless Theme of Youthful Yearning
text: Having devoted this year’s Focus! festival to the composers who sought to create a mainstream American style after World War II, the Juilliard School found an ideal finale in Aaron Copland’s second opera, “The Tender Land,” performed at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater on Saturday night. Of all the composers under examination, Copland has proved by far the most durable. And if “The Tender Land” is hardly his most successful work, it is as close as he came to doing for American opera what he did for homegrown ballet in works like “Appalachian Spring” and “Billy the Kid.”

headline: Meditations on What Happens When Two People Share a Space
text: How precisely the human body can move, and yet how varied and ambiguous its meanings. A shoulder tucked forward under a chin, a palm planed and tilted just so, a raised foot rotating in minute degrees from a planted heel: we see everything and understand so little.

headline: Pianist and Cellist Have an Encounter With Chopin and Schumann
text: A duo recital for piano and cello is not the most obvious way to celebrate the Schumann and Chopin bicentennials, since both composers treated the cello as a relatively minor player. But at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening the cellist Yo-Yo Ma joined the pianist Emanuel Ax in the first of three recitals Mr. Ax is devoting to the two composers. It’s an indication of the continuing popularity of these performers, who are frequent collaborators, and of the Romantic repertory that the hall was packed, with audience members crowded onto both sides of the stage.

headline: Ryan Apologizes for Obscene Gesture Aimed at Dolphins Fans
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Rex Ryan’s team didn’t make it to the Super Bowl, but the Jets’ coach has certainly made a splash in Miami anyway. While attending a mixed martial arts event in Miami on Saturday night, Ryan made an obscene gesture to a group of Dolphins fans, who promptly captured the moment with a camera phone. It is unclear whether the fans did or said anything to provoke the effusive Ryan, who is smiling in the photo, which was sent to several South Florida media outlets Sunday.

headline: Taking a Ride on Jazz’s Main Line
text: The trumpeter Jeremy Pelt has spent most of the last decade as a young exemplar, traveling the postbop continuum on his own steam, at his own pace. As a bandleader he has plunged headlong into funk and dipped a toe in chamber orchestration, but the larger theme of his output seeks a footing on the bedrock of jazz convention. He’s still finding good terrain to explore there, as he proved at Jazz Standard on Thursday night.

headline: Of Pasta and Memories: 3 Women in a Kitchen
text: Any of the disaffected characters in “Alone, OH” could have penned the Mad Libs-inspired letter found in the choreographer Michou Szabo’s program: “In the kitchen  we never knew having [blank] for dinner was anything other than your choice  not because we didn’t [blank].”

headline: Trying to Cure What Ailes Us
text: A shocking moment on This Week. You can see what I was talking about here.

headline: Foursquare Teams With Bravo TV
text: Bravo TV and Foursquare will announce a new partnership on Monday that will integrate Bravo TV shows with the game aspects of Foursquare, a social networking site that encourages people to interact in the real world. The partnership hopes to engage viewers long after they turn off the television, close their laptops and stop watching Bravo’s TV shows.

headline: In the Naked Museum: Talking, Thinking, Encountering
text: If you’ve ever wanted to see the interior of the Guggenheim Museum in its pristine state, now’s the time. For the solo show of the young European artist Tino Sehgal, the great spiraling rotunda, recently ablaze with Kandinskys, has been cleared out. There isn’t a painting in sight.

headline: Singer’s Interior Voice Comes to Play Outside
text: St. Vincent was well into a captivating concert at the Allen Room on Friday when someone onstage put the evening in perspective. That someone was Annie Clark, who is to St. Vincent what Bruce Wayne is to Batman: one and the same, but with better manners and a shyer, more secretive air. “This is just dreadfully pleasant,” said Ms. Clark, taking in the elegance of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series. Her choice of words felt true to the spirit of her finely detailed, carefully distressed, willfully unnerving songs.

headline: A Composer Finds Ideas All Over
text: No one would describe the busy theater composer Michael Friedman as a Broadway-hungry practitioner of commercial formulas headed for Disneyland, although he has the versatility and training to go there. A politically engaged satirist with the ear and curiosity of an investigative journalist would be closer to the mark.

headline: U.S. Bobsledder Has Clear Picture of His Goal
text: The images are mostly blurs, but that is because of the speeds Steve Holcomb travels and no longer the result of a deficiency. After having corrective eye surgery, Holcomb can now see it all, or as much as possible, while steering a bobsled down an icy chute at speeds that rival Joba Chamberlain’s fastball.
